"What tumor suppressor gene does the E6 protein from Human Papillomavirus (HPV) bind to and inhibit? p53"
"What tumor suppressor does the E7 protein from Human Papillomavirus (HPV) bind to and inhibit? p105-Rb::specific"
"A(n) sinonasal papilloma is a benign tumor of the squamous mucosa of the sinuses that is thought to be due to HPV infection"
"Laryngeal papillomas are benign papillary squamous proliferations commonly found on the true vocal cords. They are associated with HPV6 and HPV11"
"Koilocytes have characteristic perinuclear halos that are hallmarks of HPV infections"
"Levothyroxine is a recombinant form of T4 that serves as a thyroxine replacement. It has agonist action at thyroid hormone receptors"
"Condyloma Acuminatum is a type of Condyloma that is caused by HPV, typically types 6 and 11"
"Koilocytes are a histological feature of HPV infected cells and are a hallmark of HPV infection"
"What is the carcinoma risk associated with HPV6 and HPV11? Low"
"What types of HPV are the cause of HPV-related vulvar carcinoma? High Risk HPVs (16, 18, 31, 33)"
"Which type of Vulvar Carcinoma is typically seen in women of reproductive age? HPV-related"
"What is the most common cause of Vaginal Carcinoma? High-risk HPV subtypes (16, 18, 31, 33)::be specific"
"Which area of the cervix is especially targeted by HPV? Transformation zone"
"What is the cancer risk associated with HPV16? High"
"What is the cancer risk associated with HPV18? High"
"What is the cancer risk associated with HPV31? High"
"What is the cancer risk associated with HPV33? High"
"What is the cancer risk associated with HPV6? Low"
"What is the cancer risk associated with HPV11? Low"
"Which protein from high-risk HPV strains binds to p53? E6"
"E6 is a protein from high-risk HPV that binds to p53"
"E7 is a protein from high-risk HPV that binds to Rb"
"Which protein from high-risk HPV binds to Rb (specifically p105-Rb)? E7"
"Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia (CIN) is a dysplastic pre-cancerous cervical lesion often occuring after loss of p53 and Rb post-HPV infection"
"What are the most common types of low-risk HPV? HPV6; HPV11"
"What is the key risk factor for Cervical Carcinoma? High-risk HPV (16, 18, 31, 33)"
"What is the gold standard procedure for screening for Cervical Carcinoma? Pap Smear"
"What is the cancer risk associated with HPV42-44? Low"
"What urogenital disorder is associated with low-risk HPV subtypes? Condylomas/warts"
"Koilocytes are a histological feature of HPV infected cells and involve a nucleus with a 'raisin-like' shape"
"What strains of HPV cause Condylomata Acuminatum? HPV6; HPV11"
"What is the most common risk factor for Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Penis? High-risk HPV [16, 18, 31, 33] (66% of cases)"
"Besides high-risk HPV, what is the second most major risk factor for Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Penis? Lack of circumcision and poorly maintained foreskin"
"Verruca (Warts) are soft, flesh-coloured, cauliflower-like papules that appear on the skin due to HPV infection of keratinocytes"
"What is the cause of Verruca (Warts)? HPV 1-4 infection of Keratinocytes"
"Which cell cycle checkpoint is blocked by p53? G1 to S"
"Which cell cycle checkpoint is blocked by hypophosphorylated Rb? G1 to S"
"Hereditary Spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant hematological disorder that involves spheroid erythrocytes due to a spectrin or ankyrin defect"
"Patau Syndrome (Trisomy 13) is an autosomal trisomy that is associated with rocker-bottom feet and microphthalmia"
"Patau Syndrome (Trisomy 13) is an autosomal trisomy that is associated with cleft lip::face and cleft palate::face"
"DiGeorge Syndrome is a 22q11 deletion syndrome that presents with thymic aplasia, parathyroid aplasia and cardiac defects"
"Why doesn't Rickettsia spp. gram stain well? Obligate intracellular bacteria"
"Which stain is used to best visualize Chlamydia? Giemsa stain"
"Which stain is used to best visualize Borrelia? Giemsa"
"Which stain is best used to visualize Rickettsiae? Giemsa"
"Which stain is used to visualize Trypanosomes? Giemsa"
"Which stain is used to visualize Plasmodium? Giemsa"
"Which stain is used to visualize Cryptococcus neoformans? India ink"

"Eaton agar::Which special culture media/agar is used to isolate Mycoplasma pneumoniae, as it contains cholesterol necessary for growth"
"Sabouraud agar::Which special culture media/agar is used to isolate fungi"
"Rickettsia spp. and Chlamydia spp. are obligate intracellular, pleomorphic, gram-negative bacteria that cannot make their own ATP"
"Neisseria meningitidis is a species of Neisseria that is encapsulated"
"What is the urease expression of Staphylococcus epidermidis? Positive"
"What is the urease expression of Staphylococcus saprophyticus? Positive"
"What is the Novobiocin sensitivity of Staphylococcus saprophyticus? Resistant"
"What is the Novobiocin sensitivity of Staphylococcus epidermidis? Sensitive"
"Preformed enterotoxins::Which exotoxin from Staphylococcus aureus causes rapid::rapid or slow-onset food poisoning"
"Which Staphylococcus species is the 2nd most common cause of uncomplicated UTI in young women? Staphylococcus saprophyticus"
"Which bacteria is the most common cause of meningitis? Streptococcus pneumoniae"

"Which toxin from Clostridium tetani causes Tetanus? Tetanospasmin"

"Pott's Disease is a possible complication of extrapulmonary Tuberculosis that involves spread of infection to vertebral bodies"
"What color colonies do lactose-fermenting enteric bacteria yield on MacConkey agar? Pink"
"Which species of Neisseria ferments glucose and maltose? Neisseria meningitidis"
"IgA Protease is a protein secreted by Neisseria spp. that functions to cleave secreted host IgA at its hinge region"

"Neisseria meningitidis::Which species of Neisseria has a polysaccharide capsule, which inhibits phagocytosis"
"Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a species of Neisseria that has no vaccine due to rapid antigenic variation of pilus proteins"
"Which serotype of Neisseria meningitidis lacks a vaccine? Type B*"
"Neisseria meningitidis is transmitted via Respiratory and Oral secretions"
"Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome is a rare complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) that involves inflammation of the liver capsule and formation of \violin-string\\" adhesions\""
"Neonatal Conjunctivitis is an early (2-5 days) ocular infection seen in neonates due to Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection during childbirth"
"Septic Arthritis, most commonly of the knee is a musculoskeletal complication of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection"
"What is the etiology of meningococcemia? Neisseria meningitidis"
"What organism causes Relapsing Fever? Borrelia recurrentis"
"How is Relapsing Fever (Borrelia recurrentis) transmitted? Louse"
"Which pet animals are associated with Campylobacter infection? Puppies"
"What is the etiology of Endemic Typhus? Rickettsia typhi"
"What is the treatment for all disorders caused by Rickettsia spp.? Doxycycline"
"Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever is a zoonotic infection caused by Rickettsia rickettsii that presents with a rash that typically starts at the wrists and ankles and then spreads to the trunk, palms and soles"
"Q Fever is a Rickettsial-like disease that can be obtained via aerosolized spores released from tick feces or cattle placenta"
"Q Fever is a Rickettsial-like disorder caused by Coxiella burnetti that presents as pneumonia"
"Which serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis are associated with Neonatal Conjunctivitis? D-K"
"Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungal infection that is mostly seen in ketoacidotic diabetic and leukemic patients"
"Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungal infection that presents with rhinocerebral and frontal lobe abscesses"
"Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungal infection that presents with headache, facial pain, and a black necrotic eschar on the face"
"Mucor spp. is a species of opportunistic fungus that presents as nonseptate hyphae branching at wide angles"
"What is the treatment for Pneumocystis jirovecii? TMP-SMX or Pentamidine"
"Toxoplasmosis is a CNS protozoal infection that presents with brain abscesses in HIV patients; seen as ring-enhancing brain lesions on CT/MRI"
"Which subspecies of Trypanosoma brucei is from East Africa? Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense"
"Which subspecies of Trypanosoma brucei is from West Africa? Trypanosoma brucei gambiense"
"African Sleeping Sickness is a CNS protozoal infection caused by Trypanosoma brucei subspecies that is diagnosed by a blood smear"
"Trypanosoma cruzi::protozoa is the etiology of Chagas Disease"
"Chagas Disease is a visceral protozoal infection that presents with dilated cardiomyopathy, mega-colon and mega-esophagus"
"Where (geographically) does Chagas Disease predominantly occur? South America"
"How is Chagas Disease (Trypanosoma cruzi) transmitted? Reduviid bug (aka the \kissing bug\\") feces\""
"Chagas Disease is a visceral protozoal infection that is diagnosed by the visualization of Trypanosoma cruzi on a peripheral blood smear"
"What is the most common etiology of Mononucleosis? EBV"
"Mononucleosis is a complication of EBV infection that presents with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, pharyngitis and lymphadenopathy"
"Mononucleosis is a disease caused by EBV that is also commonly referred to as \kissing disease\\" as it is often seen in teens and young adults\""
"Where is EBV latent? B cells"
"Which receptor does EBV use to enter B cells? CD21 (C3d; CR2)"
"EBV is a Herpesvirus that can give rise to atypical lymphocytes (Downey Cells) on a peripheral blood smear"
"Which diagnostic test is used to detect EBV infection? Monospot Test"
"The Monospot Test is a diagnostic test that detects the heterophile antibodies seen in EBV infection via agglutination of sheep or horse RBCs"
"Which Herpesvirus is associated with Hodgkin's Lymphoma? EBV"
"Which Herpesvirus is associated with endemic Burkitt Lymphoma? EBV"
"Which Herpesvirus is associated with Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma? EBV"
"Which Herpesvirus causes Mononucleosis with a negative Monospot test? CMV"
"Which Herpesvirus is associated with causing retinitis in immunocompromised patients? CMV"
"Which Herpesvirus is associated with characteristic Owl's Eye inclusions in infected cells? CMV"
"CMV is a Herpesvirus that is latent in mononuclear cells"
"The Tzanck smear is a diagnostic test used to identify HSV or VZV through a smear of an opened skin vesicle"
"Which serological antigen from EBV is produced if the infection is active and productive? Viral Capsid Antigen (VCA)"
"Which serological antigen from EBV is seen in latent infection? Epstein-Barr Nuclear Antigen (EBNA)"
"Epstein-Barr Nuclear Antigen (EBNA) is a serological antigen from EBV that contributes to Hodgkin's or Burkitt's Lymphoma"
"Hairy Leukoplakia is a dermatological infection caused by EBV that commonly presents on the lateral tongue"
"CMV is a Herpesvirus that causes retinitis in HIV patients that presents with cotton-wool spots on funduscopy"
"Esophagitis and Colitis are GI complications that are often seen alongside CMV Retinitis in immunosuppressed patients"
"What CD4+ cell count is associated with CMV retinitis in HIV patients? < 50 cells/mm3"
"Primary B-cell CNS Lymphoma is a Lymphoma often associated with EBV that can present as focal/solitary lesions, thereby differentiating it from Toxoplasmosis"
"Squamous Cell Carcinoma is a cancer caused by HPV in HIV patients that often presents at the anus (in MSMs) or the cervix"
"CMV is a Herpesvirus that causes interstitial pneumonia in HIV patients"
"Where on the body is Staphylococcus epidermidis found? Skin"
"What food source is associated with Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning? Meats; Mayonnaise; Custard (meats and cream based food)"
"Staphylococcus aureus; Staphylococcus epidermidis::Which strains of bacteria (2) are associated with Osteomyelitis in patients that have received a prosthetic joint replacement"
"Streptococcus agalactiae, Escherichia coli, and Listeria monocytogenes are bacteria that all cause meningitis in neonates"
"How is CMV transmitted? Sexual contact; Organ transplant; Vertically through placenta"
"Rubella, Toxoplasma, and CMV are 3 ToRCHeS infections that are associated with a \blueberry muffin\\" rash\""
"Which HPV strains cause Condyloma Acuminata? HPV6; HPV11"
"Condyloma Acuminata is an STD caused by HPV6 or HPV11 that presents with anogenital warts and koilocytes::what cellular pathology"
"Neisseria gonorrhoeae STI that presents with urethritis, cervicitis, prostatitis and a white, creamy purulent discharge"
"What is the etiology of Syphilis? Treponema pallidum"
"Which 2 bacteria are the most common causes of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)? Chlamydia trachomatis (subacute; often undiagnosed); Neisseria gonorrhoeae (acute)"
"Which bacteria often causes subacute Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) and hence often goes undiagnosed? Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes D-K"
"Which bacteria often causes acute Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)? Neisseria gonorrhoeae"
"Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is a genitourinary disorder caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae that presents with purulent cervical discharge"
"Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative nosocomial bacterial infection that has respiratory therapy equipment as a risk factor"
"Which Herpesvirus is associated with infecting an organ transplant recipient? CMV"
"Pseudomembranous colitis is a GI complication of ampicillin use that results from overgrowth of Clostridioides difficile in the GI tract"
"Which 3rd generation Cephalosporin is used to treat meningitis and gonorrhea? Ceftriaxone"
"How do Cephalosporin antibiotics influence the nephrotoxicity of Aminoglycosides? Increase"
"Which bacterial ribosomal subunit is targeted by Chloramphenicol? 50S"
"Which bacterial ribosomal subunit is targeted by Linezolid? 50S"
"What is the primary clinical use of Tetracycline antibiotics? Borrelia burgdorferi Mycoplasma pneumoniae Intracellular bugs (Rickettsia, Chlamydiae)"
"Tetracyclines are a class of protein synthesis inhibiting antibiotics that are effective against intracellular organisms by virtue of their ability to accumulate intracellularly"
"What is the MOA of Chloramphenicol? Blocks peptidyltransferase at the 50S ribosomal subunit"
"Anemia and Aplastic Anemia::2 are dose-dependent/independent hematological complications of Chloramphenicol use"
"Gray Baby Syndrome is a complication of Chloramphenicol use in premature infants as they lack hepatic UDP-Glucuronyl Transferase"
"What is the mechanism of Chloramphenicol resistance? Plasmid-encoded acetyltransferases that inactivate the drug"
"Clindamycin is a protein synthesis inhibiting antibiotic that is known to treat anaerobic infections above the diaphragm (e.g. aspiration pneumonia, lung abscesses, oral infections)"
"Pseudomembranous colitis is a possible complication of Clindamycin use due to resultant Clostridioides difficile overgrowth"
"Fluoroquinolones are a class of antibiotics that can possibly cause leg cramps and myalgias along with cartilage damage"
"The treatment for Neisseria gonorrhoeae is Ceftriaxone + azithromycin or doxycycline for possible chlamydia infection"
"What is the treatment for Chagas Disease (Trypanosoma cruzi)? Nifurtimox, Benznidazole"
"Which viral enzyme monophosphorylates Acyclovir/Famciclovir/Valacyclovir, thereby activating it? Thymidine kinase"
"What is the mechanism of resistance to Acyclovir/Famciclovir/Valacyclovir? Mutated/Absent Thymidine Kinase"
"Foscarnet is an antiviral agent that acts as a viral DNA polymerase inhibitor by binding to the pyrophosphate-binding site of the enzyme"
"What is the treatment for CMV retinitis in immunocompromised patients when Ganciclovir fails? Foscarnet or Cidofovir"
"What is the treatment for Acyclovir-resistant HSV? Foscarnet or Cidofovir"
"What is the MOA of Cidofovir? Preferential direct inhibition of viral DNA polymerase"
"Fluoroquinolones are a class of antibiotics that are avoided in pregnancy as they cause cartilage damage"
"Chloramphenicol is an antibiotic that is avoided in pregnancy as it causes \Gray Baby\\" Syndrome\""
"Which complement deficiency is associated with increased risk for Neisseria infection? C5b-C9 (terminal complement deficiency - membrane attack complex)"
"Aplasia cutis is a possible teratogenic complication of methimazole if given in the first trimester"
"Agranulocytosis and Aplastic Anemia are rare hematological complications of propylthiouracil and methimazole use"
"What drug used to treat hyperthyroidism is associated with hepatotoxicity? Propylthiouracil"
"On which day after fertilization is the zygote formed? 1"
"On which days following fertilization is the morula formed? 3-4"
"On which days following fertilization is the blastocyst formed? 4-5"
"On which days following fertilization does implantation occur? 6-10"
"During which week of gestation is the bilaminar disc (of epiblast and hypoblast) formed? Week 2"
"During which week of gestation is the trilaminar disc formed? 3"
"During which week of gestation does gastrulation occur? 3"
"During which week of gestation does the primitive streak appear? 3"
"What is the embryonic origin of the spinal cord? Neural tube (neuroectoderm)"
"What is the embryonic origin of the Alveoli, epithelium of trachea / bronchi? Endoderm"
"Which antacid is associated with hyporeflexia, hypotension and cardiac arrest if overused? Magnesium hydroxide"
"Conditions that cause vomiting include infection, medication, vestibular dysfunction, and chemoradiation"
"The nucleus tractus solitarius, also known as the vomiting center (located in the medulla) receives main inputs from: 1. GI tract 2. Vestibular system 3. Area postrema (chemoreceptor trigger zone)"
"The nucleus tractus solitarius projects neurons to other medullary nuclei to coordinate the vomiting response"
"The GI tract directly communicates with the nucleus tractus solitarius via the vagus nerve (CN X)"
"GI irritation, due to infection, chemotherapy, or distension, causes mucosal serotonin release"
"Serotonin activates 5-HT3 receptors on the vagal afferents, which relay their impulse to the nucleus tractus solitarius"
"The vestibular system communicates directly with the nucleus tractus solitarius via the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII)"
"The vestibular system is responsible for vertigo and motion sickness (vestibular nausea)"
"The area postrema (chemoreceptor trigger zone) is located adjacent to the nucleus tractus solitarius in the 4th ventricle"
"The area postrema (chemoreceptor trigger zone) responds to emetogenic substances (e.g. chemotherapeutic agents)"
"Ondansetron antagonizes the 5-HT3 receptor on vagal afferents in the GI tract"
"Ondansetron is used to treat chemotherapy or post-operative induced nausea and vomiting"
"Ondansetron may cause constipation at the gut and headache/dizziness at the head as possible side effects"
"Ondansetron can prolong the QT interval and induce torsades"
"Ondansetron may cause serotonin syndrome, which presents with symptoms including rigidity, tremor, hyperthermia, and confusion"
"The vestibular system contains H1 histamine receptors, which are coupled to Gq"
"Diphenhydramine and meclizine (1st generation H1 receptor blockers) may cause significant sedation and have significant anti-muscarinic properties"
"The vestibular system contains M1 muscarinic receptors"
"Scopolamine is a(n) muscarinic (M1) antagonist that treats vestibular nausea (motion sickness)"
"Motion sickness (vestibular nausea) is treated with 1st generation anti-histamines (diphenhydramine, meclizine) and scopolamine"
"Metoclopramide antagonizes D2 receptors in the area postrema (treats chemotherapy induced vomiting)"
"Metoclopramide has upper GI prokinetic effects, making it useful for treatment of delayed gastric emptying due to post-surgical disorders and diabetic gastroparesis"
"Metoclopramide (D2 antagonist) is contraindicated in patients with small bowel obstruction"
"Metoclopramide can cause diarrhea as a result of its prokinetic effects"
"Side effects of metoclopramide include drowsiness and depression as a result of central D2 blockade"
"Side effects of metoclopramide include extrapyramidal effects such as dystonia, akathisia, and parkinsonian features as a result of central D2 blockade"
"Chronic use of metoclopramide may lead to tardive dyskinesia, especially in the elderly"
"Metoclopramide may cause neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which presents with symptoms including fever, rigidity, mental status changes, autonomic instability, and rhabdomyolysis"
"Metoclopramide may cause elevated prolactin levels, which can cause galactorrhea, impotence, gynecomastia, and menstrual disorders"
"Metoclopramide can cause QT prolongation and induce torsades"
"The area postrema (chemoreceptor trigger zone) contains neurokinin 1 (NK1) receptors which are activated by substance P"
"Aprepitant antagonizes NK1 receptors in the area postrema, which is used to treat chemotherapy-induced vomiting"
"Which anti-emetic(s) should be used to treat a patient with nausea/vomiting due to GI irritation? 5-HT3 receptor antagonists, such as ondansetron"
"Which anti-emetic(s) should be used to treat a patient with nausea/vomiting due to motion sickness? 1. H1 receptor blockers, such as diphenhydramine and meclizine 2. M1 receptor blockers, such as scopolamine "
"Which anti-emetic(s) should be used to treat a patient with nausea/vomiting due to emetogenic substances in the blood/CNS? 1. D2 receptor blockers, such as metoclopramide 2. NK1 receptor blockers, such as aprepitant "
"Histamine, from ECL cells, activates H2 receptors (coupled to Gs) on the basolateral membrane of parietal cells"
"Vagal stimulation is a potent direct activator of parietal cells (H+ secretion) via binding of the neurotransmitter ACh to M3 receptors"
"What drug class do cimetidine, ranitidine, famotidine, and nizatidine belong to? H2 receptor antagonists"
"By what mechanisms can H+ secretion still occur in a patient on H2 receptor blockers? Direct stimulation of parietal cells by vagal stimulation and gastrin stimulation"
"H2 receptor antagonists are especially effective at reducing nocturnal secretion of acid, however, they only have modest impact on meal-stimulated secretion of acid"
"H2 receptor antagonists (e.g. cimetidine) may be used to treat GERD and peptic ulcers, although PPIs are the first line treatment"
"The H2 receptor antagonist cimetidine is a potent inhibitor of cytochrome P-450 and therefore has multiple drug interactions"
"The H2 receptor antagonist cimetidine has many anti-androgenic effects (e.g. gynecomastia, impotence, elevated prolactin levels)"
"Both cimetidine and ranitidine decrease renal excretion of creatinine"
"Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) irreversibly::reversibly or irreversibly inhibit the H+/K+-ATPase pump, which is the final common pathway for H+ secretion"
"Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are effective at reducing both nocturnal and meal-stimulated secretion of acid and thus suppress H+ secretion to a greater extent than H2 receptor blockers"
"What is the first line treatment for a patient with Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome? Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs)"
"What is the first line treatment for a patient with H. pylori infection? Triple therapy with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) + clarithromycin + amoxicillin or metronidazole"
"One adverse effect of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) is increased risk for Clostridioides difficile infection (2-3x increased risk)"
"In addition to increased risk for C. difficile infection, patients on proton pump inhibitors are also at increased risk for pneumonia"
"Proton pump inhibitors decrease the absorption of divalent cations (Ca2+, Mg2+, and Fe2+), which require an acidic environment"
"Reduced calcium absorption as a result of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) increases risk of worsening osteoporosis (e.g. increased osteoporotic hip fractures)"
"Decreased magnesium absorption as a result of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) may cause hypomagnesemia"
"When proton pump inhibitors are unable to control gastric acid secretion, octreotide (a long acting somatostatin analog) may be of use in treating gastrinomas"
"The mechanism of action of laxatives is via a change in the consistency of feces"
"Osmotic laxatives are non-absorbable substances that draw water into the intestinal lumen, causing distention and peristalsis"
"Magnesium hydroxide and magnesium citrate are both examples of osmotic laxatives"
"Polyethylene glycol (PEG) is a non-absorbable sugar that acts as a(n) osmotic laxative"
"Lactulose is a non-absorbable sugar that acts as a(n) osmotic laxative"
"In addition to its use as an osmotic laxative, lactulose may be used in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy"
"What is the mechanism of action by which lactulose treats hepatic encephalopathy? Lactulose is metabolized into acidic metabolites, which convert NH3 to NH4+ (trapped in intestinal lumen and excreted)"
"Rifaximin is a poorly absorbed antibiotic that eradicates ammonia producing intestinal bacteria and thus treats hepatic encephalopathy"
"Two main side effects of osmotic laxatives include diarrhea and dehydration"
"Psyllium is a(n) bulk-forming laxative"
"Stool softeners are surfactant agents that faciliate the penetration of stool by water and lipids"
"Docusate is used medically as a(n) stool softener"
"Senna and Bisacodyl are cathartic (stimulant) agents that acts via stimulation of the enteric nervous system and increased colonic secretions"
"Chronic use of senna causes brown pigmentation of the colon, known as melanosis coli"
"Opioid agonists (e.g. diphenoxylate, loperamide) treat diarrhea by activating μ-opioid receptors in the GI tract"
"Loperamide is a(n) μ-opioid agonist that does not cross the BBB, therefore there is no analgesia and low potential for addiction"
"Opioid agonists (e.g. loperamide) increase colonic phasic segmentation contractions, causing increased colonic transit time"
"Diphenoxylate is a(n) μ-opioid agonist that does cross the BBB, therefore it is combined with atropine to prevent abuse"
"A patient is more likely to get addicted to which anti-diarrheal μ-opioid agonist? Diphenoxylate; it crosses the BBB"
"Anti-diarrheal agents are contraindicated in patients with bloody diarrhea or fever"
"What GI side effect may be caused by opioid agonists? Constipation"
"VIPoma and carcinoid tumor both cause secretory diarrhea"
"Octreotide (a somatostatin analog) may be used to treat the secretory diarrhea caused by VIPoma and carcinoid syndrome"
"Metoclopramide has drug interactions with digoxin and diabetic agents"
"Which two anti-emetics can cause torsades as a possible side effect? Ondansetron and metoclopramide"
"Interferons are immunomodulatory cytokines that are released from virus infected host cells"
"Upregulation of interferon synthesis in infected cells is accomplished by interleukins"
"Interferon alpha may be used in the treatment of hepatitis B and C infections"
"Interferon alpha may be used in the treatment of neoplasms, including hairy cell leukemia and malignant melanoma"
"Interferon alpha may be used to treat Kaposi sarcoma caused by HHV-8"
"Interferon alpha may be used to treat condyloma accuminata caused by HPV"
"Interferon alpha may be used to treat renal cell carcinoma"
"Which hepatitis drug causes flu-like symptoms as a possible side effect? Interferon alpha"
"Chronic therapy of interferon alpha may result in neurotoxicity, causing mood disorders (e.g. depression) and confusion"
"Which hepatitis drug has myelosuppression as a possible side effect? Interferon alpha"
"Which type of interferon is associated with drug-induced lupus? Interferon alpha"
"Interferon β may be used to treat multiple sclerosis"
"Interferon gamma may be used to treat chronic granulomatous disease (CGD)"
"What two factors determine if a patient with hepatitis C infection should be treated & what the treatment regimen should be? HCV genotype and the stage of liver disease (i.e. liver fibrosis)"
"All patients with virologic evidence of chronic HCV infection should be considered for treatment, except those with limited life expectancy"
"The goal of treatment of HCV is to achieve a(n) sustained virologic response (SVR), which is the inability to detect HCV RNA by PCR for 6 months after stopping treatment"
"What is the traditional standard treatment for hepatitis C? Once weekly pegylated-interferon alpha with daily oral ribavirin::specific"
"Ribavirin is a(n) guanosine nucleoside analog"
"Ribavirin must be phosphorylated three times::specific by intracellular enzymes to reach its activated nucleotide form"
"A major side effect of ribavirin is that it may cause dose-dependent hemolytic anemia (10-20% of patients)"
"Ribavirin is contraindicated in pregnant women due to its teratogenic effects"
"In addition to hepatitis C, what other virus is ribavirin classically used to treat? respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)"
"Sofosbuvir is a nucleotide analog that inhibits the HCV NS5B RNA-dependent RNA polymerase"
"Adverse effects associated with sofosbuvir include fatigue and nausea"
"Sofosbuvir and simeprevir are not used as monotherapies for HCV, but rather as part of a regimen including ribavirin +/- pegylated-interferon alpha"
"Simeprevir is a NS3/4A protease inhibitor that may be used for the treatment of hepatitis C genotype 1"
"Adverse effects of simeprevir include photosensitivity and rash"
"Simeprevir is a(n) inhibitor of cytochrome P450 and thus may have many drug interactions"
"Second generation NS3/NS4A protease inhibitors and NS5A inhibitors are under clinical investigation to develop HCV treatment regimens that do not require interferon/ribavirin administration"
"Which two NRTIs are used to treat hepatitis B? lamivudine and tenofovir"
"What is the traditional standard treatment for hepatitis B? Interferon alpha + lamivudine"
"Misoprostol is a synthetic analog of ProstoGlandin E1"
"Misoprostol promotes increased production and secretion of a gastric mucous barrier and decreased acid production"
"Misoprostol is a PGE1 analog that may be used to prevent NSAID-induced peptic ulcers"
"Misoprostol is contraindicated in women of childbearing potential due to its abortifacient effects"
"Misoprostol is not used very often due to its ability to cause diarrhea as a side effect"
"Peptide and Protein Hormone Synthesis: Translation of a preprohormone begins in the cytoplasm with a signal peptide at the N terminus"
"In the first step of hormone synthesis, preprohormone is synthesized in the cytosol, directed by specific mRNA"
"All steroid hormones are derivatives of cholesterol"
"Amine hormones are derivatives of the amino acid tyrosine"
"Amine hormones include thyroid hormones and catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine)"
"When regulating hormone secretion via negative feedback, some feature of hormone action, directly or indirectly, inhibits further secretion of the hormone"
"When regulating hormone secretion via positive feedback, some feature of hormone action causes more secretion of the hormone"
"Sensitivity is defined as the hormone concentration that produces 50% of the maximal response"
"If more hormone is required to produce 50% of the maximal response, then there has been a(n) decrease in sensitivity of the target tissue, and vice versa"
"The hormone sensitivity (responsiveness) of a target tissue may be changed in two ways: 1. Change the number of receptors 2. Change the affinity of receptors"
"Down-regulation is a mechanism in which a hormone decreases the number or affinity of its receptors in a target tissue"
"Up-regulation is a mechanism in which a hormone increases the number or affinity of its receptors in a target tissue"
"G proteins have three::# subunits"
"The alpha subunit of G proteins has intrinsic GTPase activity and may bind GDP (inactive) or GTP (active)"
"Guanine nucleotide releasing factors (GRFs) facilitate dissociation of GDP so that GTP can bind more rapidly, increasing the rate of G protein activation"
"GTPase activating proteins (GAPs) facilitate hydrolysis of GTP, decreasing the rate of G protein activation"
"In the first step of the adenylyl cyclase and phospholipase C mechanism of signaling, binding of hormone to its receptor causes release of GDP from its α subunit (αs, αi, or aq) and replacement by GTP"
"In the adenylyl cyclase mechanism of cellular signaling, the αs-GTP complex activates adenylyl cyclase, which then catalyzes the conversion of ATP to cAMP"
"In the adenylyl cyclase mechanism of cellular signaling, the second messenger cAMP activates protein kinase A, which then phosphorylates specific proteins to produce physiologic actions"
"After its use as a second messenger in the adenylyl cyclase signaling pathway, cAMP is degraded to 5'-AMP by phosphodiesterase"
"In the phospholipase C mechanism of cellular signaling, the αq-GTP complex activates phospholipase C, which then catalyzes the liberation of DAG and IP3 from PIP2"
"In the phospholipase C mechanism of cellular signaling, the IP3 generated from PIP2 causes release of Ca2+ from intracellular stores in the endoplasmic or sarcoplasmic reticulum"
"In the phospholipase C mechanism of cellular signaling, Ca2+ and diacylglycerol (DAG) activate protein kinase C, which phosphorylates specific proteins to produce physiologic actions"
"What hormone acts through a receptor guanylyl cyclase? Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)"
"Binding of atrial natriuretic peptide to its receptor guanylyl cyclase causes conversion of GTP to cGMP"
"Newly synthesized cGMP (from guanylyl cyclase activity) activates protein kinase G, which phosphorylates specific proteins responsible for physiologic actions"
"What hormone/chemical acts through a cytosolic guanylyl cyclase? Nitric Oxide"
"NO synthase cleaves the amino acid arginine into citrulline and nitric oxide"
"Once nitric oxide diffuses into muscle cells, it activates soluble (cytosolic) guanylyl cyclase, which converts GTP to cGMP"
"What is the difference between the binding sites of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and nitric oxide (NO) to guanylyl cyclase receptors? - ANP binds to a receptor guanylyl cyclase - NO binds to a cytoplasmic guanylyl cyclase"
"Which two amino acids do protein kinase A and protein kinase C phosphorylate to continue the signaling cascade? Serine & threonine"
"Receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity within the receptor molecule"
"Receptor-associated tyrosine kinases do not have intrinsic kinase activity, but rather associate non-covalently with proteins that do (e.g. JAK)"
"One type of receptor tyrosine kinase is a(n) monomer, which dimerizes and auto-phosphorylates upon binding of a hormone or ligand"
"One type of receptor tyrosine kinase is a(n) dimer, which auto-phosphorylates upon binding of a hormone or ligand"
"Receptor-associated tyrosine kinases are non-covalently associated with a tyrosine kinase, such as JAK"
"Targets of JAK (tyrosine kinase associated-receptor pathway) include STATs, which cause transcription of new mRNAs and new protein synthesis"
"What type of receptor do growth hormones use for their signaling pathways? Receptor associated tyrosine kinases"
"How do the receptors bound by steroid and thyroid hormones differ from the receptors bound by peptide hormones? Peptide hormones bind extracellular receptors"
"Relative to time, how do peptide hormones differ from steroid hormones?  - Steroid hormones act slowly (taking hours) - Peptide hormones act quickly (within minutes) "
"Steroid hormone-receptor dimers are transcription factors that bind to steroid-response elements (SREs) of DNA and initiate transcription"
"What is the end effect of steroid hormones? Synthesis of new proteins"
"The pituitary gland, which also is called the hypophysis, consists of an anterior and posterior lobe"
"The hypothalamus is connected to the pituitary gland by a thin stalk called the infundibulum"
"The connections between the hypothalamus and the posterior pituitary are neural only"
"The posterior pituitary is a collection of nerve axons whose cell bodies are located in hypothalamic nuclei"
"The anterior lobe of the pituitary gland is primarily composed of endocrine cells"
"The hypothalamus and anterior pituitary are linked directly by the hypothalamic-hypophysial portal system"
"Hypothalamic hormones stimulate or inhibit the release of anterior pituitary hormones"
"The β subunits of the anterior pituitary hormones TSH, FSH, and LH are different and are responsible for the unique biologic activity of each hormone"
"The ACTH family of hormones includes: 1. ACTH 2. Melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH) 3. Gamma and β-lipotropin 4. β-endorphin"
"Melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH) is found in POMC and its fragments, thus, increased levels of POMC and ACTH may lead to skin/mucosal pigmentation (e.g. Addison disease)"
"Growth hormone is synthesized in the somatotrophs::cell type of the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland"
"At puberty, there is an enormous secretory burst of growth hormone induced by estrogen (females) or testosterone (males)"
"What is the effect of sleep on growth hormone secretion? Increased"
"What is the effect of somatostatin on growth hormone secretion? Decreased"
"The insulin-like growth factor (IGF) receptor has tyrosine kinase activity, similar to the insulin receptor"
"How does growth hormone affect protein synthesis and lean body mass? Increased"
"What direct action does growth hormone have on production of insulin-like growth factor (IGF)? Increased"
"Growth hormone/IGF-1 alters cartilage metabolism to increase linear bone growth"
"Failure to grow, short stature, mild obesity, and delayed puberty is associated with what hormone deficiency? Growth hormone deficiency"
"The most important of the somatomedins is somatomedin C, also known as IGF-1"
"Prolactin is synthesized by lactotrophs, which represent approximately 15% of the tissue in the anterior pituitary"
"Prolactin secretion is tonically inhibited by dopamine"
"What is the effect of bromocriptine (a dopamine agonist) on prolactin secretion? Decreased"
"Prolactin stimulates milk production in the breast by inducing synthesis of milk components including casein and lactose"
"Prolactin stimulates breast development in a supportive role with estrogen"
"What effect does prolactin have on ovulation and spermatogenesis? Decreased / Inhibition"
"Hypothalamic destruction or hypothalamic-hypophysial tract disruption result in prolactin excess by causing loss of tonic inhibition::process by dopamine"
"How can prolactin excess be treated? Dopamine agonists (e.g. bromocriptine)"
"What two hormones are secreted by the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland? ADH and oxytocin"
"Both ADH and oxytocin are neuropeptides, synthesized in hypothalamic neurons and secreted from nerve terminals in the posterior pituitary"
"Oxytocin is packaged with neurophysin I"
"The cell bodies of ADH-secreting neurons originate primarily in the supraoptic nuclei of the hypothalamus"
"Hypovolemia or volume contraction is another potent stimulus for ADH secretion"
"What is the effect on ADH secretion if a patient has low volume AND low osmolarity? Volume trumps osmolarity and ADH is secreted"
"Through which secondary messenger(s) does the ADH-bound V2 receptor propagate its signal? cAMP"
"The receptor for ADH on vascular smooth muscle is a(n) V1 receptor"
"Through which secondary messenger(s) does the ADH-bound V1 receptor propagate its signal? IP3/Ca2+"
"What is the end result of ADH binding to V1 receptors on vascular smooth muscle? Contraction of vascular smooth muscle"
"Central diabetes insipidus is caused by failure of the posterior pituitary to secrete ADH"
"Which ADH disorder is characterized by low levels of circulating ADH and thus large volumes of dilute urine? central diabetes insipidus (nephrogenic has high ADH levels)"
"Central diabetes insipidus is treated with a(n) ADH analogue, such as dDAVP (desmopressin)"
"Which type of diabetes insipidus is characterized by an inability of the posterior pituitary to secrete ADH? Central diabetes insipidus"
"Which type of diabetes insipidus is characterized by elevated levels of ADH? Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus"
"Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is treated with thiazide diuretics"
"What endocrine pathology is treated with demeclocycline? SIADH"
"What is the major stimulus for oxytocin secretion? Suckling of the breast"
"What conditioned responses may stimulate oxytocin secretion? Sight, sound, or smell of an infant"
"Oxytocin is secreted in response to dilation of the cervix during labor or orgasm"
"Oxytocin causes contraction of myoepithelial cells in the breast, forcing milk stored in the mammary alveoli into the ducts for ejection"
"Oxytocin is a hormone that may be used to induce labor and reduce postpartum bleeding"
"Cretinism is a condition of severely stunted physical and mental growth due to untreated congenital deficiency of thyroid hormones"
"Thyroid hormones are synthesized by the follicular epithelial cells of the thyroid gland"
"In the first step of thyroid hormone synthesis, thyroglobulin is synthesized from tyrosine in the thyroid follicular cells"
"If there are low levels of iodine (I-), the activity of the Na+-I- cotransport increases, and vice versa"
"Thyroid peroxidase and deiodinase may be inhibited by propylthiouracil (PTU), which is used therapeutically for the treatment of hyperthyroidism"
"Thyroperoxidase is inhibited by Methimazole and PTU"
"High levels of I- inhibit organification of I2, and therefore inhibit synthesis of thyroid hormones (Wolff-Chaikoff effect)"
"After organification of I2, coupling between two molecules of DIT may combine to form thyroxine (T4)"
"After organification of I2, coupling between a molecule of MIT and a molecule of DIT may combine to form triiodothyronine (T3)"
"After iodinated thyroglobulin is synthesized, it is stored in the follicular lumen as colloid until the thyroid gland is stimulated to secrete thyroid hormones"
"What three steps does thyroid peroxidase catalyze during the synthesis of thyroid hormones?  1. Oxidation (I- to I2) 2. Organification (of I2 into MIT and DIT) 3. Coupling (of MIT and DIT into T3 and T4)"
"When the thyroid gland is stimulated, iodinated thyroglobulin is endocytosed into the follicular epithelial cells"
"After release from iodinated thyroglobulin, T4 and T3 enter the systemic circulation"
"After release from iodinated thyroglobulin, MIT and DIT are deiodinated by the enzyme thyroid deiodinase, reproducing I- and tyrosine"
"A patient with thyroid deiodinase deficiency would mimic which mineral deficiency? Iodine deficiency, due to inability recycle iodine"
"In the circulation, most of the T3 and T4 is bound to thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG)"
"The T3 resin uptake test may be used to indirectly assess circulating levels of TBG"
"What is the result of pregnancy on a T3 resin uptake test? Resin uptake is decreased"
"Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) secretion is decreased in response to free T3/T4"
"Through which secondary messenger(s) does TSH exert its actions on the thyroid gland? cAMP"
"One role of TSH on the thyroid gland is to increase both synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormones by the follicular cells"
"Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) has a trophic effect on the thyroid gland, thus, chronic elevation of TSH causes hypertrophy/hyperplasia of the thyroid gland"
"Which thyroid disorder is associated with high concentrations of Thyrotropin receptor antibodies (TRAb)? Graves disease"
"Thyroid hormone increases the processes of glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, proteolysis, and lipolysis, all of which may provide sources of ATP"
"What is the effect of thyroid hormone on the cardiovascular and respiratory systems? Increased activity"
"Thyroid hormone works synergistically with growth hormone and somatomedins to promote bone formation"
"Thyroid hormones stimulate bone maturation as a result of ossification and fusion of the growth plates"
"Hypothyroidism in the perinatal period causes irreversible mental retardation (cretinism)"
"In adulthood, which thyroid disorder is associated with listlessness, slowed speech, somnolence, impaired memory, and decreased mental capacity? hypothyroidism"
"A useful adjunct therapy for hyperthyroidism is a(n) β-adrenergic blocking agent, such as propranolol"
"Hyperthyroidism may be treated surgically via thyroidectomy or with the drug propylthiouracil (PTU), which inhibits both thyroid peroxidase and deiodinase"
"In which disorder (hyper- or hypothyroidism) may a patient present with a goiter? Both!"
"Hypothyroidism may be treated with thyroid hormone replacement therapy (e.g. levothyroxine, triiodothyronine)"
"The adrenal medulla is of neural crest origin"
"The zona glomerulosa secretes mineralocorticoids, such as aldosterone"
"The zona fasciculata secretes glucocorticoids, such as cortisol"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of adrenocortical hormones? Cholesterol desmolase"
"The major glucocorticoid produced in humans is cortisol (hydrocortisone)"
"The major mineralocorticoid produced in humans is aldosterone"
"Pregnenolone may be converted to progesterone via the enzyme 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase"
"11-deoxycorticosterone (DOC) may be converted to corticosterone via the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase"
"Corticosterone may be converted to aldosterone via the enzyme aldosterone synthase"
"The zona glomerulosa normally cannot produce glucocorticoids because it lacks the enzyme 17α-hydroxylase"
"Can mineralocorticoids still be produced if the mineralocorticoid pathway is blocked below the level of DOC (i.e. absence of 11β-hydroxylase or aldosterone synthase)? Yes, 11-deoxycorticosterone (DOC) and corticosterone both have mineralocorticoid activity"
"Can mineralocorticoids still be produced if the mineralocorticoid pathway is blocked above the level of DOC (i.e. absence of 21β-hydroxylase)? No"
"Pregnenolone may be converted to 17-hydroxypregnenolone via the enzyme 17α-hydroxylase"
"17-hydroxypregnenolone may be converted to 17-hydroxyprogesterone via the enzyme 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase"
"11-deoxycortisol may be converted to cortisol via the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase"
"Can glucocorticosteroids still be produced if there is absence of 17α-hydroxylase? Yes, the zona fasciculata can still produce corticosterone, which has glucocorticoid activity"
"Can glucocorticosteroids still be produced if there is absence of cholesterol desmolase, 21β-hydroxylase, 11β-hydroxylase, or 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase? No, a lack of any of these enzymes would block the synthesis of both corticosterone AND cortisol"
"Adrenal androgens, such as DHEA and androstenedione, have a(n) ketone group at C-17 and are excreted as 17-ketosteroids in the urine"
"Which enzyme is unique to the zona glomerulosa and thus the mineralocorticoid synthesis pathway? Aldosterone synthase"
"Which enzymes are unique to the zona fasciculata/reticularis and thus the glucocorticoid and androgen synthesis pathways? 17α-hydroxylase and 17,20-lyase::2"
"21-carbon steroids include both the mineralocorticoids and glucocorticoids (progesterone, deoxycorticosterone, aldosterone, and cortisol)"
"19-carbon steroids, such as DHEA and androstenedione, have androgenic activity and are precursors to estrogen"
"18-carbon steroids have estrogenic activity"
"Metyrapone is a drug that inhibits glucocorticoid biosynthesis via inhibition of the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase"
"Cortisol levels are highest just before awakening and lowest in the evening"
"Which zones of the adrenal cortex does ACTH act on to increase steroid hormone synthesis? All three zones :)"
"ACTH increases steroid hormone synthesis via stimulation of the enzyme cholesterol desmolase, thus increasing the conversion of cholesterol to pregnenolone"
"Long-term effects of ACTH include up-regulation of ACTH receptors, thus increasing the sensitivity of the adrenal cortex"
"Through which secondary messenger(s) does ACTH exert its actions on the adrenal cortex? cAMP"
"How does cortisol affect secretion of CRH from the hypothalamus? Inhibits secretion, both directly and indirectly"
"How does cortisol affect secretion of ACTH from the anterior pituitary? Inhibits secretion, directly"
"The dexamethasone suppression test is useful in patients with hypercortisolism::broad issue"
"What is the result of a dexamethasone suppression test if the cause of hypercortisolism is an adrenal cortical tumor? Neither low nor high dose dexamethasone suppresses cortisol secretion"
"What is the effect of somatostatin and opioids on ACTH secretion? Decreased"
"Aldosterone secretion (from the zona glomerulosa) is under tonic, but not exclusive, control by ACTH"
"The primary regulation of aldosterone secretion occurs through changes in ECF volume (via the renin-angiotensin II-aldosterone system) and changes in serum potassium levels"
"Decreases in ECF volume (e.g. hemorrhage or decreased Na+) cause a decrease in renal perfusion pressure, which in turn increases secretion of the enzyme renin"
"Renin is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I in the plasma"
"Angiotensin I is converted to angiotensin II by the enzyme angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)"
"Angiotensin II acts on the zona glomerulosa to stimulate aldosterone synthesis via increased activity of the enzyme aldosterone synthase"
"To what receptor does angiotensin II bind? AT1 receptor"
"Through which secondary messenger(s) does the angiotensin II-bound AT1 receptor propagate its signal? IP3/Ca2+"
"How does hyperkalemia influence aldosterone secretion? Increased aldosterone secretion"
"Glucocorticoids are a potent stimulator for gluconeogenesis, thus they are essential for survival during fasting"
"Glucocorticoids may have anti-inflammatory effects by inducing the synthesis of lipocortin, an inhibitor of phospholipase A2"
"Glucocorticoids may have anti-inflammatory effects via the inhibition of the release of histamine and serotonin from mast cells and platelets"
"What is the effect of glucocorticoids on blood neutrophil levels? Increased (neutrophilia) due to decreased WBC adhesion"
"Do glucocorticoids cause an increase or decrease in eosinophils? Decrease"
"How do glucocorticoids suppress the immune response? By inhibiting production of IL-2 and subsequent T-cell proliferation"
"Cortisol (glucocorticoids) up-regulates α1 receptors on arterioles, increasing their sensitivity to catecholamines (i.e. norepinephrine and epinephrine)"
"Glucocorticoids (e.g. cortisol) are essential in maintaining vascular responsiveness to catecholamines"
"Glucocorticoids decrease bone formation by decreasing osteoblast activity"
"What is the effect of glucocorticoids on fibroblast activity? Decreased"
"Cortisol results in a(n) increased glomerular filtration rate (GFR)"
"Cortisol results in decreased REM sleep and increased awake time"
"Exogenous corticosteroids can cause candidiasis and reactivation of TB as a result of IL-2 inhibition"
"At high concentrations, cortisol can bind to mineralocorticoid (aldosterone) receptors"
"Mineralocorticoids (aldosterone) cause increased renal K+ secretion via action on the principal cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct"
"Mineralocorticoids (aldosterone) cause increased renal H+ secretion via action on the α-intercalated cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct"
"In females, the adrenal androgens are responsible for the development of pubic and axillary hair and for libido"
"In adrenogenital syndrome, the overproduction of adrenal androgens will result in increased urinary levels of 17-ketosteroids"
"What classes of steroid hormones are decreased in Addison disease? All three (glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and androgens)"
"What is the level of ACTH in Addison disease? Why? Increased; low cortisol levels stimulate ACTH secretion by negative feedback"
"What effect does Addison disease have on blood sugar levels? Hypoglycemia"
"Addison disease may present with decreased pubic/axillary hair and libido in females due to decreased levels of androgens"
"What is the treatment of Addison disease (primary adrenocortical insufficiency)? Replacement of glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids"
"Secondary adrenocortical insufficiency occurs when there is insufficient CRH (uncommon) or insufficient ACTH"
"Does secondary adrenocortical insufficiency present with hyperpigmentation? Why? No, ACTH levels are low therefore there is no increased melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH)"
"Does secondary adrenocortical insufficiency present with any of the following symptoms: hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, or hypotension? No, aldosterone levels are normal"
"Cushing syndrome is the result of chronic excess glucocorticoids by: 1. Adrenal gland hyperplasia 2. Pharmacologic doses of glucocorticoids (most common) 3. ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease) 4. Ectopic ACTH production (e.g. small cell lung carcinoma)"
"What clinical features are seen in Cushing syndrome/disease that are a result of increased androgen levels: Virilization (in women)"
"Conn syndrome, or primary hyperaldosteronism, is caused by a(n) aldosterone-secreting tumor"
"Conn syndrome presents with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis due to increased aldosterone levels"
"Treatment of Conn syndrome consists of administration of a(n) aldosterone antagonist, such as spironolactone, followed by removal of the aldosterone-secreting tumor"
"What clinical features are seen in 21β-hydroxylase deficiency that are a result of increased androgen levels in females? Masculinization (clitoral enlargement, early appearance of pubic/axillary hair)"
"In 21β-hydroxylase deficiency, there is an increased level of urinary 17-ketosteroids"
"What is the treatment for 21β-hydroxylase deficiency? Replacement therapy of both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids"
"Aldosterone levels in 17α-hydroxylase deficiency are decreased due to mineralocorticoid excess (specifically DOC), which blocks RAAS."
"The alpha cells of the islets of Langerhans compose 20% of the islet and secrete glucagon"
"The synthesis of insulin is directed by a gene on chromosome 11"
"What may cause increased insulin levels and normal or decreased C-peptide levels? Exogenous insulin use"
"Once inside the pancreatic β-cell, glucose is phosphorylated by the enzyme glucokinase"
"In the pancreatic β cell, metabolism of glucose generates ATP, which may cause closure of select K+ channels with consequent membrane depolarization"
"Increased ATP:ADP ratio in the pancreatic β cell (as a result of glucose metabolism) causes ATP-sensitive K+ channels to close, causing membrane depolarization"
"Why is oral glucose a more powerful stimulant of insulin secretion than IV glucose? Oral glucose stimulates secretion of GIP and GLP-1"
"How do sulfonylurea drugs (e.g. tolbutamide, glyburde) cause an increased insulin secretion? By closing the ATP-dependent K+ channels, causing depolarization and subsequent insulin release"
"What effect does glucagon have on insulin secretion? Increased"
"What effect does somatostatin have on insulin secretion? Decreased"
"The β subunits of the insulin receptor have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity"
"After phosphorylating intracellular proteins, the insulin receptor is internalized (via endocytosis) and either degraded, stored, or recycled"
"What effect does insulin have on insulin receptors in target tissues? Causes down-regulation"
"The number of insulin receptors is increased in starvation and decreased in obesity"
"What are the three locations that insulin acts on? Liver, muscle, and adipose tissue"
"Insulin increases glucose transport to muscle and adipose tissue by directing the insertion of the GLUT4 transporter into the cell membranes"
"Insulin decreases blood glucose concentration by promoting synthesis and storage of glycogen in the muscle and liver, while simultaneously inhibiting glycogenolysis"
"Insulin decreases blood glucose concentration by decreasing gluconeogenesis via increased production of fructose-2,6-bisphosphate"
"Insulin inhibits ketoacid formation in the liver because decreased fatty acid degradation provides less acetyl CoA substrate for ketoacid formation"
"Insulin stimulates amino acid uptake into cells and increases protein synthesis in muscles"
"Insulin results in increased K+ uptake into cells"
"What is the effect of insulin on blood K+ and amino acid concentration? Decreased (due to increased uptake into cells)"
"Does glucose cross the placenta? What about insulin? Glucose does; insulin does not"
"What are the blood concentration levels of amino acids and fatty acids in a diabetes mellitus patient? Increased"
"What is the blood concentration of K+ in a patient with diabetes mellitus? Increased (hyperkalemia) due to decreased K+ uptake into cells"
"Glucagon causes decreased fatty acid synthesis and increased lipolysis, which shunts substrates towards gluconeogenesis"
"What is the effect of glucagon on blood fatty acid and ketoacid concentration? Increased, due to increased lipolysis"
"What is the effect of glucagon on urea production? Increased, secondary to increased gluconeogenesis"
"Which nutrients (glucose, amino acids, fatty acids) stimulate release of somatostatins? All three :)"
"What is the effect of insulin on somatostatin secretion? Decreased"
"What is the effect of somatostatin on insulin and glucagon secretion? Decreased"
"What percent of total Ca2+ in the blood is bound to plasma protein? 40%"
"What percent of total Ca2+ in the blood is ultrafilterable? 60%"
"What percent of total Ca2+ in the blood exists in an ionized form (i.e. as Ca2+)? 45-50%"
"What percent of total Ca2+ in the blood is complexed to anions (e.g. sulfate, citrate, phosphate)? 10-15%"
"What is the only form of biologically active Ca2+? Free, ionized Ca2+"
"Hyperreflexia, spontaneous twitching, muscle cramping, tingling, and numbness are signs of which calcium imbalance? Hypocalcemia"
"The Chvostek sign is twitching of the facial muscles elicited by tapping on the facial nerve; it is an indicator of hypocalcemia"
"The Trousseau sign is carpopedal spasm upon inflation of a blood pressure cuff; it is an indicator of hypocalcemia"
"Why does hypocalcemia cause symptoms such as tingling/numbness and twitching/cramping? Decreased extracellular Ca2+ decreases the threshold potential (makes it more negative)"
"Constipation, polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy, and hyporeflexia are signs of which calcium imbalance? Hypercalcemia"
"What is the effect of acidemia on free ionized Ca2+ concentration? Increased"
"What is the effect of alkalemia on free ionized Ca2+ concentration? Decreased"
"Which three organ systems are involved in Ca2+ homeostasis? Bone, kidney, and intestine"
"Which three hormones are involved in Ca2+ homeostasis? Parathyroid hormone, calcitonin, and vitamin D (1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol)"
"What demographic is associated with positive Ca2+ balance? Growing children"
"What demographic is associated with negative Ca2+ balance? Women during pregnancy or lactation"
"Parathyroid hormone is synthesized and secreted by the chief cells of the parathyroid glands"
"Parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion is regulated by plasma Ca2+ concentration"
"When plasma Ca2+ concentrations decrease, parathyroid hormone secretion is increased (and vice versa)"
"Secretion of PTH is controlled by extracellular (serum) Ca2+ binding to Ca2+-sensing receptors in the parathyroid cell membrane"
"Chronic hypocalcemia causes secondary hyperparathyroidism, which is characterized by increased synthesis and storage of PTH and hyperplasia of the parathyroid glands"
"Mild decreases in serum Mg2+ concentration cause increased PTH secretion"
"Severe decreases in serum Mg2+ concentration cause decreased PTH secretion"
"What is the effect of increased serum PO43- on PTH secretion? Increased"
"The actions of PTH are coordinated to produce an increase in serum Ca2+ and a decrease in serum phosphate (PO43-)"
"Through what secondary messenger(s) does PTH exert its actions on bone and kidney tissue? cAMP"
"In bone, PTH receptors are located on osteoblasts, but not on osteoclasts"
"Initially and transiently, PTH causes an increase in bone formation by a direct action on osteoblasts"
"In bone, the long-term effect of PTH is bone resorption via indirect action on osteoclasts"
"The action of PTH on osteoclasts is indirect and mediated by cytokines released from osteoblasts"
"Resorption of the organic matrix of bone is reflected in increased hydroxyproline excretion in the urine"
"The overall effect of PTH on bone is to promote bone resorption, which delivers both Ca2+ and phosphate to extracellular fluid"
"Will the effect of PTH on bone alone increase ionized Ca2+ concentration? No, the calcium released would complex with the released phosphate, hence the importance of the phosphaturic action of PTH on the kidney"
"PTH acts on the kidney to inhibit renal phosphate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule, which therefore increases phosphate excretion"
"The cAMP generated as a result of the action of PTH on the proximal tubule is excreted in the urine (urinary cAMP)"
"PTH acts on the kidney to increase renal calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule"
"How does PTH increase intestinal Ca2+ absorption? Indirectly, by stimulating production of 1,25-(OH)2D3 in the kidney"
"PTH Actions Summary Picture: no answer :)"
"Primary hyperparathyroidism is most commonly caused by a(n) parathyroid adenoma (which secretes excess PTH)"
"Primary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and increased circulating levels of PTH"
"Patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have increased Ca2+ excretion due to the high filtered load of calcium on the kidney"
"What is a possible complication of increased Ca2+ in the urine (e.g. due to primary hyperparathyroidism)? Calcium-oxalate kidney stones"
"Patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have increased urinary excretion of phosphate, calcium, and cAMP"
"Which parathyroid disorder is characterized by \stones"
"What is the treatment for a patient with primary hyperparathyroidism? Parathyroidectomy"
"In secondary hyperparathyroidism, PTH levels are elevated secondary to hypocalcemia (or hyperphosphatemia)"
"Hypoparathyroidism is most commonly a result of thyroid surgery, or less commonly may be autoimmune or congenital"
"Hypoparathyroidism is characterized by decreased serum calcium (hypocalcemia) and increased serum phosphate (hyperphosphatemia)"
"Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a, or Albright hereditary osteodystrophy, is due to a defective Gs protein in the kidney and bone, which causes end-organ resistance to PTH"
"Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a is characterized by hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia that is not correctable by administration of exogenous PTH"
"What is the difference in PTH levels in hypoparathyroidism versus pseudohypoparathyroidism? PTH levels are elevated in pseudohypoparathyroidism due to stimulation by hypocalcemia"
"Some malignant tumors secrete PTH-related peptide (PTH-rp), which is structurally homologous with the PTH secreted by the parathyroid glands"
"Humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy is due to increased PTH-rp secretion and presents similarly to hyperparathyroidism (e.g. hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia)"
"Humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy may be treated with zoledronate (a bisphosphonate) or pamidronate, which inhibits bone resorption"
"Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH) is caused by inactivating mutations of the Ca2+-sensing receptors that regulate PTH secretion"
"What is the inheritance of familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH)? Autosomal dominant"
"What is the effect of chronic renal failure on serum phosphate levels? Increased"
"In chronic renal failure, increased serum phosphate complexes Ca2+ and leads to decreased free, ionized Ca2+"
"In chronic renal failure, decreased production of the active form of vitamin D, (1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol) by the kidney contributes to decreased ionized Ca2+"
"The decreased ionized Ca2+ in chronic renal failure causes secondary hyperparathyroidism, which is characterized by increased levels of PTH"
"In CKD, the combination of elevated PTH and decreased 1,25-(OH)2D3 produces renal osteodystrophy, in which there is increased bone resorption and osteomalacia"
"The major stimulus for calcitonin secretion is hypercalcemia"
"The major function of calcitonin is to inhibit bone resorption, thus decreasing the plasma Ca2+ concentration"
"Calcitonin may be used to treat which calcium imbalance? Hypercalcemia"
"One external source of vitamin D (cholecalciferol) in the body is through ingestion/diet"
"Cholecalciferol is converted to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (25-OH-cholecalciferol) in the liver; this compound is chemically inactive"
"In the kidney, 25-hydroxycholecalciferol may be hydroxylated by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase to produce 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol; this compound is chemically active"
"In the kidney, 25-hydroxycholecalciferol may be hydroxylated to produce 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol; this compound is chemically inactive"
"The activity of the renal enzyme 1α-hydroxylase is increased with decreased serum Ca2+ concentration"
"The activity of the renal enzyme 1α-hydroxylase is increased with increased PTH levels"
"The activity of the renal enzyme 1α-hydroxylase is increased with decreased serum phosphate concentration"
"The role of vitamin D (cholecalciferol) is to increase both Ca2+ and phosphate plasma concentrations to promote bone mineralization"
"1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol increases intestinal absorption of Ca2+ through synthesis of calbindin D-28K"
"In addition to calcium, 1,25-(OH)2 D3 also increases the intestinal absorption of phosphate (PO43-)"
"Similar to its action on the intestines, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol increases the renal reabsorption of Ca2+ and phosphate"
"In bone, 1,25-(OH)2 D3 acts syngergistically with PTH to stimulate osteoclast activity and bone resorption"
"What effect does 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol have on its own production? Inhibits it (negative feedback)"
"In children, vitamin D deficiency causes rickets"
"In adults, vitamin D deficiency causes osteomalacia"
"Vitamin D resistance most commonly occurs due to chronic renal failure"
"Pituitary adenoma is a benign tumor of the anterior pituitary cells"
"Pituitary adenomas may be functional (hormone producing) or nonfunctional (silent)"
"Nonfunctional pituitary adenomas present with symptoms due to mass effect"
"Pituitary adenoma may present with bitemporal hemianopsia due to compression of the optic chiasm"
"Pituitary adenoma may present with hypopituitarism due to compression of normal pituitary tissue"
"A non-specific symptom of pituitary adenoma is headache (due to mass effect)"
"In males, prolactinoma presents as headache, decreased libido, and infertility"
"Prolactinoma may be treated with a(n) dopamine agonist, such as bromocriptine or cabergoline"
"Growth hormone cell adenoma presents as gigantism in children due to increased linear bone growth"
"Growth hormone cell adenoma presents as acromegaly in adults"
"Acromegaly is characterized by a large tongue with deep furrows and a deep voice"
"Acromegaly causes enlarged bones in the hands, feet, and jaw"
"Acromegaly may cause growth of visceral organs, leading to dysfunction"
"Acromegaly causes impaired glucose tolerance (i.e. insulin resistance), which may present as secondary diabetes mellitus"
"Acromegaly is associated with increased insulin resistance"
"What is the most common cause of death in patients with acromegaly? Heart failure"
"Growth hormone cell adenoma may be diagnosed by elevated serum levels of growth hormone and/or IGF-1"
"Growth hormone cell adenoma may be diagnosed by lack of GH suppression by oral glucose"
"One possible treatment for a growth hormone adenoma is a(n) somatostatin analog, such as octreotide"
"One possible treatment for a growth hormone adenoma is a(n) GH receptor antagonist, such as pegvisomant"
"TSH cell, LH-producing, and FSH-producing adenomas occur, but are rare::frequency"
"Symptoms of hypopituitarism arise when >75% of the pituitary parenchyma is lost"
"One possible cause of hypopituitarism in adults is pituitary adenoma (due to mass effect)"
"One possible cause of hypopituitarism in children is craniopharyngioma (due to mass effect)"
"One possible cause of hypopituitarism is a(n) pituitary apoplexy, which is a sudden hemorrhage of the pituitary gland, often in the presence of an existing adenoma"
"Hypopituitarism may be caused by Sheehan syndrome, which is a(n) pregnancy-related infarction of the pituitary gland"
"During pregnancy, the size of the pituitary gland doubles, but blood supply does not increase significantly"
"Pregnancy-related infarction of the pituitary gland (Sheehan syndrome) often occurs following postpartum bleeding"
"Symptoms of Sheehan syndrome include poor lactation, loss of pubic hair, and fatigue"
"External causes of hypopituitarism include brain injury and radiation"
"Hypopituitarism may be caused by empty sella syndrome, which may occur due to trauma or congenital defect of the sella"
"Empty sella syndrome occurs due to atrophy or compression, and ultimately destruction of the pituitary gland"
"Empty sella syndrome is characterized by absence of the pituitary gland on imaging"
"What demographic is more commonly affected by empty sella syndrome? Obese women"
"What is the treatment for hypopituitarism? Hormone replacement therapy"
"Central diabetes insipidus is characterized by polyuria and polydipsia with an inability to concentrate urine due to lack of ADH"
"Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is characterized by polyuria and polydipsia with an inability to concentrate urine due to lack of response to ADH"
"Etiologies of central diabetes insipidus include pituitary tumor, autoimmune, trauma, surgery, and ischemic encephalopathy"
"Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is often caused by ADH receptor mutations"
"Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus may be caused by drugs such as lithium and demeclocycline"
"Both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are characterized by urine specific gravity < 1.006"
"Both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are characterized by low urine osmolality"
"Both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are characterized by serum osmolality > 290 mOsm/kg"
"Both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are characterized by blood hyperosmotic volume contraction"
"Central diabetes insipidus is characterized by low levels of ADH"
"Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is characterized by normal or elevated levels of ADH"
"Treatment for central diabetes insipidus includes hydration and desmopressin, which is an ADH analog"
"Treatment for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus includes hydration and HCTZ, which is a thiazide diuretic"
"Diagnosis of diabetes insipidus is aided by the water deprivation test"
"In diabetes insipidus, the water deprivation test fails to increase urine osmolality"
"One possible cause of SIADH is small cell lung carcinoma, which provides a source of ectopic ADH"
"Disease of which organ system is most commonly associated with SIADH? Pulmonary"
"SIADH may be caused by drugs, such as (Can't Concentrate Serum Sodium) - Carbamazepine - Cyclophosphamide - SSRI"
"SIADH is characterized by increased retention of free water"
"SIADH is characterized by urine osmolality > serum osmolality"
"The very low serum Na+ concentration in SIADH can lead to cerebral edema and seizures"
"In SIADH, serum Na+ levels must be corrected slowly to prevent osmotic demyelination syndrome"
"Treatment of SIADH includes water restriction and demeclocycline, which is a tetracycline"
"A(n) thyroglossal duct cyst presents as a(n) anterior, midline::location neck mass that moves with swallowing or protrusion of the tongue"
"How does hyperthyroidism cause an increased basal metabolic rate? Via increased synthesis of Na+-K+ ATPase pumps"
"Which thyroid imbalance presents with decreased heat production (cold intolerance) and decreased sweating? Hypothyroidism"
"Which thyroid imbalance presents with increased heat production (heat intolerance) and increased sweating? Hyperthyroidism"
"Which thyroid imbalance presents with weight gain and decreased appetite? Hypothyroidism"
"Which thyroid imbalance presents with hyperdefecation / diarrhea? Hyperthyroidism"
"Which thyroid imbalance presents with decreased reflexes? Hypothyroidism"
"Which thyroid imbalance presents with tachycardia, palpitations, and arrhythmias? Hyperthyroidism"
"Which thyroid imbalance presents with bradycardia and dyspnea on exertion? Hypothyroidism"
"Does hyperthyroidism present with hypo- or hyper-cholesterolemia? Why? Hypocholesterolemia; due to increased LDL receptor expression"
"Does hypothyroidism present with hypo- or hyper-cholesterolemia? Why? Hypercholesterolemia; due to decreased LDL receptor expression"
"Does hyperthyroidism present with hypo- or hyper-glycemia? Why? Hyperglycemia; due to increased gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis"
"What type of hypersensitivity is Graves disease? Type II (antibody-mediated)"
"What type of goiter is associated with Graves disease? Diffuse goiter"
"Graves disease is associated with pretibial myxedema which occurs due to activation of dermal fibroblasts"
"Scalloped colloid is a characteristic histological finding associated with Graves disease"
"What are the \4 P's\\" used to treat thyroid storm? 1. Prednisolone (corticosteroid) 2. Potassium iodide (Lugol iodine) 3. Propylthiouracil 4. Propranolol (beta-blockers)\""
"Hypothyroidism in neonates and infants is known as cretinism"
"A pot-bellied, pale, puffy-faced child with protruding umbilicus, protuberant tongue, and poor brain development is characteristic of cretinism"
"Myxedema is the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans in the skin and soft tissue; it is most often associated with hypothyroidism"
"In hypothyroidism patients, myxedema commonly affects the larynx (causing deep voice) and tongue (causing enlargement)"
"Which thyroid imbalance is associated with warm, moist skin and fine hair? Hyperthyroidism"
"Initially, Hashimoto thyroiditis presents as hyperthyroidism due to thyrotoxicosis during follicular rupture"
"Histologically, Hashimoto thyroiditis is associated with chronic inflammation with well-developed germinal centers"
"Does subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain) present with a tender or nontender thyroid? **Very tender**"
"Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain) may initially present with hyperthyroidism, which typically is followed by a brief hypothyroid state"
"What histological findings are associated with Subacute thyroiditis (de Quervain)? Granulomatous inflammation"
"Riedel thyroiditis is characterized by replacement of thyroid by fibrous tissue with inflammatory infiltrate"
"Riedel thyroiditis is considered a manifestation of IgG4::esoterically specific :(-related systemic disease, which includes autoimmune pancreatitis, retroperitoneal fibrosis, and noninfectious aortitis"
"Thyroid nodules are more likely to be benign::benign or malignant than malignant::benign or malignant"
"If a thyroid nodule has decreased uptake of 131I, it is considered a(n) 'cold' nodule"
"How is a biopsy performed for a thyroid nodule? Fine needle aspiration (FNA)"
"What is the main distinguishing feature between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma of the thyroid? Follicular adenoma has a lack of capsular and vascular invasion"
"Exposure to ionizing radiation in childhood is a major risk factor for thyroid papillary carcinoma"
"What two gene mutations are associated with increased risk of thyroid papillary carcinoma? RET and BRAF"
"Thyroid papillary carcinoma may be lined by cells with clear, 'Orphan Annie eye' nuclei"
"In addition to 'Orphan Annie eye' nuclei, thyroid papillary carcinoma may have cells with intranuclear grooves and inclusions"
"Thyroid papillary carcinoma may have psammoma bodies on biopsy, which are characterized by concentric layers of calcification"
"Thyroid medullary carcinoma is a malignant proliferation of parafollicular \C\\" cells\""
"In thyroid medullary carcinoma::malignancy, calcitonin often deposits within the tumor as amyloid, which may be visualized with a(n) congo red stain"
"Detection of a RET oncogene mutation warrants prophylactic thyroidectomy"
"What two multiple endocrine neoplasias are associated with thyroid medullary carcinoma? MEN 2A and MEN 2B"
"What is the prognosis of thyroid anaplastic carcinoma? Poor"
"What type of thyroid carcinoma is illustrated in this histology slide? Anaplastic carcinoma"
"What is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism? Parathyroid adenoma (>80%)"
"What is the serum calcium level in primary hyperparathyroidism? Increased (due to increased PTH)"
"As a result of hypercalcemia, patients with primary hyperparathyroidism are at increased risk for calcium oxalate kidney stones"
"Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium in the tubules of the kidney due to primary hyperparathyroidism"
"Primary hyperparathyroidism may lead to CNS disturbances, such as depression and seizures"
"The increased level of calcium in primary hyperparathyroidism may lead to activation of pancreatic enzymes, causing acute pancreatitis"
"Is a patient with hyperparathyroidism more likely to present with constipation or diarrhea? Constipation"
"Primary hyperparathyroidism often presents with increased levels of urinary cAMP due to the activation of Gs proteins when PTH binds its receptor"
"Hyperparathyroidism often presents with increased levels of serum ALP due to increased osteoblast activity"
"What is the serum level of calcium in primary hyperparathyroidism? Increased (hypercalcemia)"
"What is the serum level of phosphate in primary hyperparathyroidism? Decreased (hypophosphatemia)"
"What is the serum level of calcium in secondary hyperparathyroidism? Decreased (hypocalcemia)"
"What is the most common cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism? Chronic renal failure"
"How does renal insufficiency cause secondary hyperparathyroidism? (sorry)  1. Renal insufficiency causes decreased phosphate excretion and thus increased serum phosphate levels 2. Increased serum phosphate may bind free, ionized calcium, thus decreasing serum calcium levels 3. Decreased free calcium stimulates PTH release from the parathyroid glands"
"Chronic renal disease can cause a secondary hyperparathyroidism syndrome known as Renal Osteodystrophy, which is characterized by bone lesions due to increased bone resorption (from elevated PTH)"
"Tertiary hyperparathyroidism is refractory (autonomous) hyperparathyroidism resulting from chronic renal disease"
"Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a or Albright hereditary osteodystrophy is characterized by shortened stature and shortened 4th and 5th digits"
"What is the inheritance of pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a (Albright hereditary osteodystrophy)? Autosomal dominant"
"Which endocrine disorder presents with the physical features of Albright hereditary dystrophy but without the end-organ PTH resistance? Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism"
"Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a occurs due to an inherited defect from the mother due to imprinting"
"Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism occurs when a defective Gs alpha-subunit is inherited from the father"
"Diagnosis of parathyroid disease summary: no answer :)"
"Type 1 diabetes mellitus is due to autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β cells by anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies"
"What type of hypersensitivity is type 1 DM? type IV HSR"
"What age group is most commonly affected by type 1 DM? < 30 years old"
"Is type 1 DM characterized by a strong or weak genetic predisposition (compared to type 2)? Relatively weak (50% concordance in identical twins)"
