"Is type 2 DM characterized by a strong or weak genetic predisposition (compared to type 1)? Relatively strong (90% concordance in twin studies)"
"Histology of type 2 diabetes mellitus demonstrates islets with amyloid deposits"
"What is the level of insulin in a patient with type 2 diabetes (elevated, decreased, normal)? Variable; increased early in disease, but may be decreased later in disease due to β cell exhaustion"
"What is the most common type of diabetes mellitus? Type 2"
"What demographic is most commonly associated with type 2 DM? Middle-aged, obese patients"
"Steroid diabetes may be seen in patients on glucocorticoid therapy"
"The diagnosis for diabetes mellitus may be made using HbA1c which reflects average blood glucose over 3 prior months"
"What is the diagnostic cutoff for HbA1c for a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus? ≥6.5%"
"Diabetic ketoacidosis often arises with stress (e.g. infection)"
"What are the two major ketone bodies produced in a type 1 diabetic patient? β-hydroxybutyrate and acetoacetate"
"Diabetic ketoacidosis is associated with a(n) fruity breath odor due to exhaled acetone"
"Diabetic ketoacidosis is associated with Kussmaul respirations, which is rapid/deep breathing to compensate for metabolic acidosis"
"What is the intracellular potassium level in a type 1 diabetic patient? Decreased::increased or decreased"
"What is the treatment for diabetic ketoacidosis? IV fluids, insulin, and K+ (to replete intracellular stores)"
"Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic non-ketotic syndrome often presents with glucose levels > 600 mg/dL and increased serum osmolarity (> 320 mOsm/kg)"
"Why doesn't hyperosmolar hyperglycemia non-ketotic syndrome present with ketoacidosis? Why? ketone production is inhibited by presence of insulin"
"One chronic complication of diabetes mellitus is non-enzymatic glycosylation of vascular basement membranes"
"Non-enzymatic glycosylation of medium and large-sized vessels leads to atherosclerosis in diabetic patients"
"Non-enzymatic glycosylation of small vessels can cause hyaline arteriolosclerosis of the kidney, which may lead to chronic renal failure"
"Non-enzymatic glycosylation of hemoglobin leads to HbA1c"
"In diabetes patients, osmotic damage may occur when glucose in tissue is converted to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase"
"In diabetes patients, peripheral neuropathy and autonomic neuropathy occurs as a result of osmotic damage to Schwann cells"
"In diabetes patients, blindness occurs as a result of osmotic damage to pericytes::cell type of retinal blood vessels, weakening the vessel wall and causing aneurysm formation"
"Glucose is converted to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase"
"What is the treatment for a glucagonoma? Octreotide (somatostatin analog) or surgery::2 options"
"A(n) insulinoma is a tumor of pancreatic β cells"
"The Whipple's triad help confirm symptomatic hypoglycemia - low blood glucose - symptoms of hypoglycemia - resolution of symptoms after normalization of glucose levels"
"About 10% of cases of insulinoma are associated with MEN 1 syndrome"
"A(n) somatostatinoma is a tumor of pancreatic delta cells"
"Somatostatinoma may present with diabetes due to inhibition of insulin"
"The secretin stimulation test may be used to aid in the diagnosis of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome"
"If a patient has Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, gastrin levels will remain elevated after administration of secretin (secretin stimulation test)"
"Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is caused by a(n) gastrinoma of the pancreas or duodenum"
"Carcinoid tumors often secrete serotonin (5-HT), which is dumped into the portal vein and processed by the liver via monoamine oxidase (MAO)"
"Elevated levels of 5-HIAA, a metabolite of serotonin, in the urine is indicative of a(n) carcinoid tumor"
"What is the most common malignancy in the small intestine? Carcinoid tumor (neuroendocrine cells)"
"Carcinoid syndrome may occur if the carcinoid tumor metastasizes to the liver"
"Carcinoid syndrome is characterized by bronchospasm (asthmatic wheezing), recurrent diarrhea, and flushing of the skin"
"Carcinoid syndrome may cause carcinoid heart disease, which is characterized by right-sided valvular fibrosis leading to tricuspid regurgitation and pulmonary valve stenosis"
"Why are left-sided valvular lesions not seen in a patient with carcinoid heart disease? blood passes through the lung, which contains MAO, thus converting 5-HT to 5-HIAA before reaching the left heart"
"VIPoma is a non-α, non-β, non-δ islet cell pancreatic tumor that secretes VIP (also known as WDHA syndrome)"
"The symptoms of VIPoma are Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, and Achlorhydria"
"Cushing syndrome simply refers to an increase in serum cortisol"
"Cushing disease refers specifically to a(n) ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma"
"What is the most common endogenous cause of Cushing syndrome? Cushing disease (i.e. an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma)"
"One clinical feature of Cushing syndrome is muscle weakness with thin extremities"
"Clinical features of Cushing syndrome include moon facies, buffalo hump, and truncal obesity due to increased fat storage, secondary to excess insulin"
"One clinical feature of Cushing syndrome is abdominal striae which is a result of impaired collagen synthesis, allowing blood vessels to rupture easily"
"One clinical feature of Cushing syndrome is hypertension, which is a result of an upregulation of alpha1-adrenergic receptors, causing increased sensitivity of blood vessels to catecholamines"
"One clinical feature of Cushing syndrome is osteoporosis, which is a result of decreased osteoblast activity"
"One positive screening test for Cushing syndrome is no cortisol suppression with overnight low-dose dexamethasone test (1mg)"
"What is the state of the adrenal glands in Cushing syndrome due to exogenous corticosteroids? bilateral atrophy"
"What is the state of the adrenal glands in Cushing syndrome due to primary adrenal adenoma, hyperplasia, or carcinoma? Atrophy of the uninvolved gland; hyperplasia of the involved gland::hyperplasia, atrophy; one, both"
"What is the state of the adrenal glands in Cushing syndrome due to ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma? Hyperplasia of both adrenal glands::hyperplasia, atrophy; one, both"
"What is the state of the adrenal glands in Cushing syndrome due to a paraneoplastic (ectopic) ACTH secretion? Hyperplasia of both adrenal glands::hyperplasia, atrophy; one, both"
"What is the differential diagnosis in a Cushing syndrome patient with suppressed ACTH? 1. Exogenous glucocorticoids 2. Adrenal adenoma (or carcinoma, hyperplasia)"
"What is the differential diagnosis in a Cushing syndrome patient with elevated ACTH? 1. Cushing disease (ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) 2. Ectopic ACTH secretion"
"If a patient with ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome has increased ACTH secretion following a CRH stimulation test, the most likely cause of their syndrome is Cushing disease"
"If a patient with ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome has no increase in ACTH secretion following a CRH stimulation test, the most likely cause of their syndrome is ectopic ACTH secretion"
"What two tests may be used to differentiate between Cushing disease and ectopic (paraneoplastic) ACTH secretion? 1. High-dose dexamethasone suppression test 2. CRH stimulation test"
"Hyperaldosteronism presents as hypertension::blood pressure with hypernatremia::Na+, hypokalemia::K+, and metabolic alkalosis::H+"
"Aldosterone increases Na+ and H2O reabsorption at the distal tubules and collecting duct"
"Congenital adrenal hyperplasia occurs due to loss of one of the four enzymes needed for cortisol synthesis"
"11β-hydroxylase deficiency presents with hypokalemia::K+ and hypertension::blood pressure"
"What clinical features are seen in 11β-hydroxylase deficiency that are a result of increased androgen levels: virilization (in women)"
"17α-hydroxylase deficiency presents with hypokalemia::K+ and hypertension::blood pressure"
"Adrenal insufficiency is the inability of the adrenal glands to generate enough glucocorticoids +/- mineralocorticoids"
"In primary adrenal insufficiency, the metyrapone stimulation test results are increased ACTH with decreased 11-deoxycortisol"
"In secondary/tertiary adrenal insufficiency, the metyrapone stimulation test results are decreased ACTH with decreased 11-deoxycortisol"
"Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome classically follows after DIC in young children with N. meningitidis infection"
"Adrenal atrophy or destruction due to disease is the cause of chronic::acute or chronic primary adrenal insufficiency, also known as Addison's disease."
"The most common cause of Addison disease in the West is autoimmune destruction"
"A common cause of Addison disease is metastatic carcinoma, especially from the lungs"
"One clinical feature of Addison disease is hypotension::BP"
"Does secondary adrenal insufficiency present with hyperkalemia? No, because aldosterone synthesis is preserved"
"Tertiary adrenal insufficiency is seen in patients with chronic exogenous steroid use, precipitated by abrupt withdrawal"
"The adrenal medulla is composed of chromaffin cells, which are derived from neural crest"
"The adrenal medulla is responsible for the secretion of the catecholamines norepinephrine and epinephrine"
"The classic finding on gross exam for a pheochromocytoma is a(n) brown tumor"
"In what time course pattern will patients with pheochromocytoma experience their symptoms? episodically, not continuously"
"The five episodic hyperadrenergic symptoms of a(n) pheochromocytoma are: 1. Pressure (increased BP) 2. Pain (headache) 3. Perspiration 4. Palpitations (tachycardia) 5. Pallor"
"Treatment for a pheochromocytoma is surgical excision"
"Prior to removal of a pheochromocytoma, irreversible α-antagonists, such as phenoxybenzamine are administered, followed by β-blockers"
"Up to 25% of cases of pheochromocytoma are associated with germline mutations, including NF-1, VHL, and RET (MEN2A/2B)"
"Pheochromocytoma is associated with the rule of 10s"
"One classic location for a pheochromocytoma outside of the adrenal medulla is in the bladder wall, which presents with episodic symptoms of a pheochromocytoma following urination"
"One classic location for a(n) pheochromocytoma outside of the adrenal medulla is the organ of Zuckerkandl at the inferior mesenteric artery root"
"Removal of a lingual thyroid may result in hypothyroidism if it is the only thyroid tissue present"
"What is the embryonic origin of parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid? Endoderm"
"What is the embryonic origin of the adrenal medulla? Neural crest::specific"
"Overall, the effects of insulin are anabolic::anabolic, catabolic"
"Which bidirectional insulin-independent transporter is found in the β-islet cells, liver, kidney, and small intestine? GLUT2"
"Which insulin-independent transporter is found in the brain and placenta only? GLUT3"
"Which insulin-independent transporter is found in the spermatocytes and the GI tract (fructose)? GLUT-5"
"Tissues that are not dependent on insulin for glucose uptake may be remembered using the mnemonic \BRICK LIPS\\": B: Brain R: RBCs I: Intestine C: Cornea K: Kidney L: Liver I: Islet (β) cells P: Placenta S: Spermatocytes\""
"Overall, the effects of glucagon are catabolic::anabolic, catabolic"
"What is the effect of chest wall trauma on prolactin secretion? Increased"
"What is the effect of ghrelin on appetite? Increased"
"In response to sleep deprivation, ghrelin secretion is increased"
"What is the effect of leptin on appetite? Decreased"
"In response to sleep deprivation, leptin secretion is decreased"
"What is the effect of endocannabinoids on appetite? Increased (\the munchies\\")\""
"Which steroid hormone enzyme deficiency presents with increased renin activity? 21-hydroxylase"
"Overall, the effect of cortisol is catabolic::anabolic, catabolic"
"After PTH binds to osteoblasts, RANK-L is secreted which binds to RANK on osteoclasts, increasing bone resorption"
"Overall, the effects of thyroid hormones are catabolic::anabolic, catabolic"
"The main functions of thyroid hormone can be remembered with the \7 B's\\"? 1. β1 effects"
"Which hormones use cGMP as their secondary messenger? ANP, BNP, NO::3"
"Which hormones use IP3 as their secondary messenger? GnRH Oxytocin ADH (V1) TRH Histamine (H1) Angiotensin II Gastrin"
"Which endocrine hormones use receptor-associated tyrosine kinases as their signaling pathway (2 +2 bonus)? Prolactin, Growth hormone"
"In women, decreased levels of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) causes hirsutism due to increased free testosterone"
"Adrenal insufficiency may present with sugar and/or salt cravings due to decreased levels of glucocorticoids +/- mineralocorticoids"
"What are the two main areas that experience hyperpigmentation due to Addison disease? Skin and mucous membranes"
"The cells of neuroendocrine tumors contain amine precursor uptake decarboxylase (APUD)"
"What is the most common tumor of the adrenal medulla in children? Neuroblastoma"
"The most common presentation for a(n) neuroblastoma is abdominal distention with a firm, irregular mass that can cross the midline"
"Neuroblastoma is characterized by the serum markers bombesin and neuron specific enolase"
"Which rosettes are seen in Neuroblastoma? Homer-Wright Rosettes"
"Neuroblastoma is characterized by increased levels of homovanillic acid (HVA) and vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) in the urine (catecholamine metabolites)"
"Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia presents with mild hypercalcemia and hypocalciuria with normal or increased PTH levels"
"What is the most common cause of hypoparathyroidism? Surgical excision"
"One complication of hyperparathyroidism is osteitis fibrosa cystica, which is characterized by bone pain and cystic bone spaces filled with brown fibrous tissue"
"What surgical approach is used in the removal of a pituitary adenoma? Transsphenoidal resection"
"Nelson syndrome is an enlargement of existing ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma after bilateral adrenalectomy for refractory Cushing disease"
"Nelson syndrome presents with symptoms of both mass effect and elevated ACTH, including hyperpigmentation, headaches, and bitemporal hemianopsia"
"Laron syndrome, also known as dwarfism, is due to defective growth hormone receptors, causing decreased linear growth"
"Laron syndrome, or dwarfism, is characterized by increased GH and decreased IGF-1"
"Clinical features of Laron syndrome include short height, small head circumference, facies with saddle nose and prominent forehead, small genitalia, and delayed skeletal maturation"
"Pituitary apoplexy presents with sudden onset severe headache with visual impairment (bitemporal hemianopsia, diplopia) and features of hypopituitarism"
"Carcinoid syndrome is associated with the \rule of 1/3s\\"\""
"What is the inheritance of all multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes? Autosomal dominant"
"MEN 1 is associated with pituitary tumors that secrete prolactin or GH"
"MEN 1 is associated with pancreatic endocrine tumors, such as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (gastrinoma), insulinomas, VIPomas, and glucagonomas (rare)"
"MEN 1 is associated with parathyroid adenomas"
"Which three organs or diseases are involved in MEN 2A? Parathyroid, thyroid (medullary carcinoma) and pheochromocytomas"
"MEN 2A is associated with parathyroid hyperplasia"
"MEN 2A and 2B are associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma::thyroid malignancy"
"MEN 2A and 2B are associated with pheochromocytoma::adrenal medulla"
"Which three organs or diseases are involved in MEN 2B? Thyroid (medullary carcinoma), pheochromocytomas, and mucosal neuromas"
"MEN 2B is associated with mucosal neuromas (oral/intestinal ganglioneuromatosis)"
"MEN 2B is associated with marfanoid habitus and mutations in the RET gene"
"MEN 2A is associated with mutations in the RET gene, which codes for receptor tyrosine kinase in cells of neural crest origin"
"Activation of which adrenergic receptor increases production of insulin? β2"
"What is the effect of insulin on Na+-K+-ATPase activity? Increased (thus causing increased K+ uptake into cells)"
"When insulin acts on liver tissue, it causes increased glycogenesis and decreased glycogenolysis"
"When insulin acts on muscle tissue, it causes increased glycogen storage and increased protein synthesis"
"Regular insulin is the only insulin that can be administered IV"
"Insulin Detemir and Glargine are characterized by long action and duration"
"Sulfonylureas (and meglitinides) bind the ATP-dependent K+ channels on pancreatic β cells, causing release of endogenous insulin"
"DPP-4 inhibitors increase levels of endogenously secreted GLP-1"
"The effects of cortisol may be remembered with the mnemonic \A BIG FIB\\": A: increased Appetite B: Blood pressure (increased"
"Metformin, a(n) biguanide, is the first line oral agent for the management of type 2 diabetes"
"Genetic sex is defined by the sex chromosomes, XY in males and XX in females"
"Gonadal sex is defined by the presence of testes in males and ovaries in females"
"Phenotypic sex is defined by characteristics of the internal genital tract and the external genitalia"
"At gestational weeks 6 to 7 in genetic males, the testes begin to develop"
"The male gonads consist of three cell types: germ cells, Sertoli cells, and Leydig cells"
"The germ cells of the male gonads produce spermatogonia"
"The Sertoli cells of the male gonads synthesize a glycoprotein called anti-müllerian hormone, which is critical for the development of male genitalia"
"The Leydig cells of the male gonads synthesize testosterone"
"The female gonads consist of three cell types: germ cells, granulosa cells, and theca cells"
"The germ cells of the female gonads produce oogonia"
"The theca cells of the female gonads synthesize the hormone progesterone"
"Testosterone stimulates the growth and differentiation of the wolffian ducts, which develop into the male internal genital tract"
"Anti-müllerian hormone (müllerian inhibitory factor) causes atrophy of the müllerian ducts, which would have developed into the female internal genital tract"
"In androgen insensitivity syndrome a person is genotypically XY but has female external genitalia with male internal genitalia"
"In childhood, hormone levels are lowest and FSH levels are greater than LH levels"
"In puberty and throughout the reproductive years, FSH levels are less than LH levels"
"In senescence, hormone levels are highest and FSH levels are greater than LH levels"
"The primary event that initiates puberty is the onset of pulsatile secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus"
"The pulsatile pattern of GnRH after puberty drives a parallel pulsatile secretion of both FSH and LH by the anterior pituitary"
"At puberty, GnRH up-regulates its own receptor in the anterior pituitary, thus increasing sensitivity"
"The onset of menstrual cycles in females is referred to as menarche"
"Eighty percent of the adult testis is composed of seminiferous tubules, which produce the sperm"
"Twenty percent of the adult testis is composed of connective tissue interspersed with Leydig cells, which synthesize and secrete testosterone"
"Germ cells (spermatogonia) maintain the germ pool and produce primary spermatocytes"
"Sertoli cells (males) secrete inhibin B::specific, which serves to inhibit FSH"
"Sertoli cells secrete androgen-binding protein which maintains local testosterone levels and  Inhibin B which inhibits FSH "
"Tight junctions between adjacent Sertoli cells form the blood-testis barrier, which isolate gametes from autoimmune attack"
"Sertoli cells function to support and nourish developing spermatogonia"
"Sertoli cells are the homolog of female granulosa cells"
"What is the effect of increased temperature on sperm production? Decreased"
"What is the effect of increased temperature on inhibin B secretion? Decreased"
"Which cell type of the seminiferous tubule regulates spermatogenesis? Sertoli cells"
"Leydig cells secrete testosterone in the presence of LH"
"What is the effect of increased temperature on testosterone production? No effect"
"Male Leydig cells are the homolog of female theca cells"
"What is the location of germ cells and Sertoli cells in relation to the seminiferous tubules? Form the lining"
"What is the location of Leydig cells in relation to the seminiferous tubules? Present in the interstitium"
"The first stage of spermatogenesis is DNA replication (interphase) of spermatogonia to generate the primary spermatocyte"
"After the primary spermatocyte has been formed, it undergoes meiosis I to become a(n) secondary spermatocyte"
"After the secondary spermatocyte has been formed, it undergoes meiosis II to become a(n) spermatid"
"After spermatids have been formed from secondary spermatocytes, they undergo spermiogenesis to form spermatozoa"
"What changes occur during the process of spermiogenesis? - Loss of cytoplasmic contents - Gain of a(n) acrosomal cap - Development of flagella"
"After which stage of spermatogenesis does the diploid sperm become haploid? Meiosis I (primary spermatocyte to secondary spermatocyte)"
"One full cycle of spermatogenesis takes 64 days"
"Where in the testis does spermatogenesis occur? Seminiferous tubules"
"What is the pathway of sperm during ejaculation? Seminiferous tubules Epididymis Vas deferens Ejaculatory ducts (receives vas deferens and seminal vesicle) (Nothing) Urethra Penis "
"The primary location for the maturation and storage of sperm is the epididymis"
"The seminal vesicles secretes a fluid rich in fructose, citrate, prostaglandins, and fibrinogen, which are nutritive for the ejaculated sperm"
"The prostate gland adds a slightly alkaline secretion to sperm ejaculate, which is rich in citrate, calcium, and enzymes"
"Ejaculated sperm cannot immediately fertilize an ovum, but rather must reside in the female reproductive tract for capacitation to occur"
"Leydig cells do not contain the steroid hormone enzymes 21β-hydroxylase or 11β-hydroxylase and, therefore, cannot synthesize glucocorticoids or mineralocorticoids"
"In the first step of testosterone synthesis, cholesterol is converted to pregnenolone via the enzyme cholesterol desmolase"
"Pregnenolone may be converted to 17-hydroxypregnenolone via the enzyme 17α-hydroxylase"
"17-hydroxypregnenolone may be converted to dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) via the enzyme 17,20-lyase"
"Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) may be converted to androstenedione via the enzyme 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase"
"In some tissues, such as the prostate, dihydrotestosterone is the active androgen, not testosterone"
"Testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone via the enzyme 5α-reductase"
"5α-reductase inhibitors, such as finasteride may be used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia because they block activation of testosterone (to DHT) in the prostate"
"Pulsatile secretion of GnRH stimulates the anterior pituitary to secrete FSH and LH"
"Anterior pituitary control of spermatogenesis and testosterone secretion are regulated via the hormones FSH and LH"
"The pituitary hormone FSH acts on the Sertoli cells to maintain spermatogenesis"
"The pituitary hormone LH acts on the Leydig cells to promote testosterone synthesis"
"Testosterone acts via an intratesticular paracrine mechanism to reinforce the spermatogenic effects of FSH in Sertoli cells"
"What is the effect of testosterone on GnRH secretion? Decreased"
"What is the effect of testosterone on LH secretion? Decreased"
"The Sertoli cells release a substance called inhibin B::specific which causes decreased secretion of FSH (negative feedback)"
"Which hormone directly inhibits the secretion of LH in males? Testosterone"
"Which androgen is responsible for closing of epiphyseal plates (cessation of pubertal growth)? Testosterone"
"Which androgen is responsible for libido? Testosterone"
"Which androgen is responsible for differentiation of the external male genitalia (penis and scrotum)? Dihydrotestosterone (DHT)"
"Which androgen is responsible for differentiation of the prostate? Dihydrotestosterone (DHT)"
"Which androgen is associated with prostate growth? Dihydrotestosterone (DHT)"
"Which androgen is associated with male hair patterns and balding? Dihydrotestosterone (DHT)"
"Which androgen is associated with sebaceous gland activity? Dihydrotestosterone (DHT)"
"Androgen insensitivity syndrome is caused by a deficiency of androgen receptors in target tissues of males"
"In 5α-reductase deficiency, a person is genotypically XY but has underdeveloped (ambiguous) male external genitalia with normal internal genitalia"
"In males, androgens are converted to estrogen by cytochrome P-450 aromatase"
"In males, androgens are converted to estrogen primarily in adipose tissue and the testis"
"In males, exogenous testosterone causes decreased intratesticular testosterone, leading to decreased testicular size and azoospermia"
"The function of the ovaries are oogenesis and secretion of the female sex steroid hormones progesterone and estrogen"
"The outer, and largest, layer of the ovary is the cortex, which contains all the oocytes enclosed in a follicle"
"The middle layer of the ovary is the medulla, which contains a mixture of cell types"
"The inner layer of the ovary is the hilum, through which blood vessels and lymphatics pass"
"The functional unit of the ovaries is the single ovarian follicle, which comprises one germ cell surrounded by endocrine cells"
"In the developing ovaries, primordial germ cells produce oogonia by mitotic divisions until gestational weeks 20 to 24"
"DNA replication (interphase) of oogonia generates the primary oocytes (arrested in prophase 1)"
"Which phase of the cell cycle are primary oocytes arrested in until ovulation? Prophase I (of meiosis I)"
"Beginning at ovulation, primary oocytes begin to complete meiosis I (diploid) to form secondary oocytes (haploid)"
"Which phase of the cell cycle are secondary oocytes arrested in until fertilization? Metaphase II (of meiosis II)"
"After fertilization, the secondary oocyte completes meiosis II to form a(n) ovum"
"Primary oocytes are arrested in prophase I of meiosis I for years until ovulation"
"Secondary oocytes are arrested in metaphase II of meiosis II until fertilization"
"The first stage (long) of ovarian follicle development involves development of a(n) primary follicle from a primordial follicle"
"The second stage (short) of ovarian follicle development involves the development of a(n) graafian follicle from a primary/secondary follicle"
"In the third stage (rapid) of ovarian follicle development, a single graafian follicle achieves dominance and ruptures, releasing its oocyte into the peritoneal cavity via the process of ovulation"
"If fertilization occurs, the residual elements of the ruptured ovarian follicle form the corpus luteum, which synthesizes and secretes steroid hormones"
"If fertilization does not occur, the residual elements of the ruptured ovarian follicle is replaced by a scar called the corpus albicans"
"In the ovaries, theca cells synthesize pregnenolone from cholesterol via the enzyme cholesterol desmolase"
"In the ovaries, cholesterol desmolase activity is stimulated by the hormone LH"
"In the ovaries, theca cells synthesize and secrete progesterone from pregnenolone via the enzyme 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase"
"In addition to progesterone, theca cells also synthesize androstenedione which diffuses to nearby granulosa cells"
"In the granulosa cells of the ovary, androstenedione is converted to testosterone via the enzyme 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase"
"In the granulosa cells of the ovary, testosterone is converted to 17β-estradiol::specific form via the enzyme aromatase"
"In the ovaries, aromatase activity is stimulated by the hormone FSH"
"Hypothalamic control of oogenesis and progesterone/estradiol secretion are regulated via the hormone GnRH"
"Ovarian granulosa cells may produce inhibin, which inhibits FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary"
"Ovarian granulosa cells may produce activin, which stimulates FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary"
"Which female sex steroid is responsible for the development of female genitalia (fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, vagina)? Estrogen"
"Which female sex steroid is responsible for the development of breasts? Estrogen"
"Which female sex steroid is responsible for growth of the ovarian follicle and endometrial proliferation? Estrogen"
"Which female sex steroid is responsible for female fat distribution? Estrogen"
"What is the effect of estrogen on LH, estrogen, and progesterone receptors? Up-regulation::up- or down-regulation"
"What is the effect of estrogen on prolactin secretion? Increased"
"What form of estrogen is produced in the ovary? 17β-estradiol"
"What form of estrogen is produced in the placenta? Estriol"
"What form of estrogen is produced in the adipose tissue? Estrone"
"Rank the forms of estrogen from most to least potent? 17β-estradiol > estrone > estriol"
"What is the effect of estrogen on levels of HDL? Increased"
"Which female sex steroid is responsible for the maintenance of pregnancy? Progesterone"
"Which female sex steroid is responsible for spiral artery development? Progesterone"
"Which female sex steroid is responsible for watery cervical mucus, which facilitates sperm entry into the uterus? Estrogen"
"Elevated levels of progesterone in a non-pregnant patient is an indication that ovulation has occurred"
"During pregnancy, there is a(n) 50-fold increase in estradiol and estrone"
"During pregnancy, there is a(n) 1000-fold increase in estriol, which is an indicator of fetal well-being"
"Variation in menstrual cycle length is attributed to the variability in duration of the follicular phase"
"By convention, day 0 of the menstrual cycle marks the onset of menses"
"The first phase of the menstrual cycle is the follicular (proliferative) phase, which lasts from days 0 to 14"
"During the follicular phase a graafian follicle develops into a(n) dominant follicle with atresia of neighboring follicles"
"The follicular phase of the menstrual cycle is dominated by the hormone 17β-estradiol (estrogen), causing endometrial proliferation"
"During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, progesterone levels are low"
"In the middle of the menstrual cycle ovulation occurs, which occurs 14 days prior to menses"
"Ovulation follows the LH surge, which occurs due to a burst of estradiol"
"In the middle of the menstrual cycle, estradiol stimulates FSH and LH secretion"
"At ovulation, cervical mucus increases in quantity and becomes more watery and penetrable by sperm"
"Estradiol levels decrease just after ovulation, but increase again during the luteal phase"
"Ovarian follicular growth is fastest during the 2nd week of the follicular phase"
"The second phase of the menstrual cycle is the luteal phase, which lasts from days 14 to 28, ending with the onset of menses"
"During the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle, the corpus luteum begins to develop"
"The corpus luteum synthesizes estradiol and progesterone"
"The luteal phase of the menstrual cycle is dominated by the hormone progesterone, causing increased secretory activity and vascularity of the endometrium"
"During the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle, basal body temperature increases due to the effect of progesterone on the hypothalamic temperature set-point"
"During the luteal phase of menstruation, cervical mucus becomes more thick (less watery) and less penetrable by sperm"
"If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses and estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly"
"What is the result of decreased progesterone on fertility? Decreased"
"What is the effect of progesterone on LH and FSH secretion? Decreased"
"Patients with abnormal menstrual bleeding present with variations of a(n) normal menstrual cycle and symptoms of anemia"
"Abnormal uterine bleeding is further subcategorized by PALM-COEIN; with Structural causes including: - Polyp - Adenomyosis - Leiomyoma - Malignancy / hyperplasia"
"Abnormal uterine bleeding is further subcategorized by PALM-COEIN; with Non-structural causes including: - Coagulopathy - Ovulatory dysfunction - Endometrial - Iatrogenic - Not yet classified"
"In cases of heavy menstrual bleeding, Abnormal uterine bleeding can be treated with hormone therapy or NSAIDS / tranexamic acid"
"In early pregnancy (first trimester), the source of steroid hormones is the corpus luteum"
"In mid-to-late pregnancy (second and third trimester), the source of steroid hormones is the placenta"
"Pregnancy is characterized by steadily increasing levels of estrogen and progesterone"
"Fertilization must occur within one day(s) of ovulation"
"The receptivity of the endometrium to the fertilized ovum is critically dependent on a(n) low estrogen/progesterone ratio"
"The function of hCG is to maintain the corpus luteum by acting like LH for the first 8-10 weeks of pregnancy"
"The dominant hormone produced during the first trimester of pregnancy is hCG"
"During the second and third trimesters, progesterone is produced by the placenta, using cholesterol from the mother"
"During the second and third trimesters, the fetal adrenal gland converts pregnenolone to DHEA-sulfate"
"During the second and third trimesters, the fetal liver converts DHEA-sulfate to 16-hydroxy DHEA-sulfate"
"During the second and third trimesters, 16-OH DHEA-sulfate is converted to estriol via the enzymes aromatase and sulfatase"
"As parturition nears, the estrogen/progesterone ratio increases, which makes the uterus more sensitive to contractile stimuli"
"Which hormone remains elevated following parturition? Prolactin"
"Why does lactation not occur during pregnancy, even though prolactin levels are increasing? Progesterone and estrogen downregulate prolactin receptors on the breast"
"As long as lactation continues, ovulation is suppressed, due to inhibitory effects of prolactin on GnRH, FSH, and LH"
"Oral contraceptives contain high doses of estrogen and progesterone (or progesterone alone) which prevent ovulation via inhibition of FSH and LH"
"In the male, the SRY gene on the Y chromosome produces testis-determining factor, which is necessary for testes development"
"Anti-müllerian hormone, from the Sertoli cells, is also referred to as müllerian inhibitory factor"
"If there is a lack of Sertoli cells or MIF during development of a genotypically XY fetus, there is both male and female internal genitalia and male external genitalia"
"The indifferent gonad (testis, ovary) begins development next to the fetal kidney, known as the mesonephros"
"Which embryologic structure develops into the fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper portion of the vagina (internal female genitalia)? Paramesonephric (müllerian) duct"
"Müllerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome, presents as primary amenorrhea in females with fully developed secondary sexual characteristics"
"Which embryologic structure develops into the seminal vesicles, epididymis, ejaculatory duct, and ductus deferens (male internal genitalia, except prostate)? Mesonephric (wolffian) duct"
"Septate uterus is a common anomaly of the uterus due to incomplete resorption of the septum"
"What is the treatment for septate uterus? Septoplasty"
"What is the effect of septate uterus on fertility? Decreased"
"Bicornuate uterus is an anomaly of the uterus due to incomplete lateral fusion of Müllerian ducts"
"Uterus didelphys is an anomaly of the uterus due to complete failure of lateral fusion of the müllerian ducts, leading to double uterus, vagina, and cervix"
"Is pregnancy possible in a patient with uterus didelphys? Yes"
"The male glans penis is homologous to the female glans clitoris, which both arise from the genital tubercle"
"The male corpus cavernosum and spongiosum are homologous to the female vestibular bulbs, which both arise from the genital tubercle"
"The male bulbourethral glands (of Cowper) are homologous to the female greater vestibular glands (of Bartholin), which both arise from the urogenital sinus"
"The male prostate gland is homologous to the female urethral and paraurethral glands (of Skene), which both arise from the urogenital sinus"
"The male ventral shaft of penis (penile urethra) is homologous to the female labia minora, which both arise from the urogenital folds"
"The male scrotum is homologous to the female labia majora, which both arise from the labioscrotal swelling"
"Hypospadias is the abnormal opening of the penile urethra on the ventral surface of the penis due to failure of urethral folds to fuse"
"Epispadias is the abnormal opening of the penile urethra on the dorsal surface of the penis due to faulty positioning of the genital tubercle"
"Which congenital penile abnormality (hypospadias or epispadias) is more common? Hypospadias"
"The congenital penile abnormality epispadias is associated with exstrophy of the bladder"
"The congenital penile abnormality hypospadias is associated with inguinal hernia and cryptorchidism"
"What is the male remnant of the processus vaginalis? Tunica vaginalis"
"What is the female remnant of the processus vaginalis? None (obliterated)"
"What is the male remnant of the gubernaculum? Scrotal ligament (anchors testes within scrotum)"
"What is the female remnant of the gubernaculum? Ovarian ligament + round ligament of uterus::2"
"What is the venous drainage of the left ovary/testis? Left gonadal vein -> left renal vein -> IVC"
"What is the venous drainage of the right ovary/testis? Right gonadal vein -> IVC"
"What complication arises more often in the left testis than the right due to its venous drainage? Varicocele"
"What lymph nodes do the ovaries/testes drain into? Para-aortic lymph nodes"
"What lymph nodes do the glans penis, clitoris, and penile urethra drain into? Deep inguinal nodes"
"What lymph nodes do the prostate, cervix, corpus cavernosum, inferior bladder, and proximal vagina drain into? Internal iliac nodes"
"What lymph nodes do the vulva, scrotum, distal anus, and distal vagina drain into? Superficial inguinal nodes"
"What lymph nodes do the body of the uterus, cervix, and superior bladder drain into? External iliac nodes"
"The parasympathetic nervous system is responsible for the male erection (tumescence) via the pelvic (S2-S4) nerve"
"Which substance is generated in response to PNS innervation via the pelvic nerve to mediate an erection? Nitric oxide (NO), which causes increased cGMP"
"The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for emission of semen via the Hypogastric nerve (T11-L2)::root nerve"
"Which substance is released by the SNS to inhibit an erection (detumesecence)? Norepinephrine"
"The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for sperm emission (testes to prostatic urethra) via the hypogastric nerve"
"The somatic nervous system is responsible for sperm expulsion via the pudendal nerve"
"PDE-5 inhibitors such as sildenafil (viagra) cause decreased cGMP breakdown, thus maintaining an erection"
"Mittelschmerz is transient mid-cycle ovulatory pain that may mimic appendicitis"
"The Apgar score is an assessment of newborn vital signs following labor via a 10-point scale evaluated at 1 minute and 5 minutes"
"Low birth weight is defined as less than 2500 grams (5.5 pounds)"
"Breast milk is the ideal nutrition for infants < 6 months old"
"Exclusively breastfed infants require vitamin D supplementation"
"Breastfeeding reduces maternal risk of breast and ovarian cancer"
"What is the effect of smoking on the onset of menopause (earlier, later)? Earlier onset"
"Very elevated levels of FSH is specific for menopause"
"Menopause is associated with increased levels of FSH, LH, and GnRH with decreased levels of estrogen"
"Menopause before age 40 suggests primary ovarian insufficiency"
"The symptoms/complications of menopause may be remembered with the mnemonic \HAVOCS\\": H: Hot flashes"
"The source of estrogen after menopause becomes peripheral conversion of androgens"
"Menopause is due to decreased estrogen production due to age-linked decline in the number of ovarian follicles"
"Estrogen/progesterone replacement therapy may be used to minimize the symptoms of menopause"
"Menopause is less symptomatic in obese women due to increased levels of estrogen"
"Menopause is usually preceded by 4-5 years of abnormal menstrual cycles"
"Menopause is diagnosed by amenorrhea for at least 12 months"
"The Tanner stages of sexual development are assigned independently to genitalia, pubic hair, and breast"
"In Tanner stage I, a person is pre-pubertal (childhood) with no pubic hair and a flat chest"
"In Tanner stage II, pubic hair appears (pubarche), breast buds form (thelarche), and testicular enlargement occurs"
"In Tanner stage III, the pubic hair coarsens, the penis size increases, and the breast enlarges"
"In Tanner stage IV, the penis width and glans increases and the breast enlarges with raised areola"
"In Tanner stage V (adulthood) the penis and testis enlarge to adult size and the areola flattens"
"The vulva anatomically includes the skin and mucosa of the female genitalia external to the hymen (labia majora, labia minora, mons pubis, and vestibule)"
"A(n) bartholin cyst is a cystic dilation of the bartholin gland"
"The bartholin gland is present on each side of the vaginal canal and produces mucus-like fluid that drains via ducts into the lower vestibule"
"Bartholin cysts arise due to inflammation and obstruction of the bartholin gland"
"What demographic is most commonly associated with Bartholin cysts? Women of reproductive age"
"A(n) bartholin cyst presents as a unilateral, painful cystic lesion at the lower vestibule adjacent to the vaginal canal"
"Condyloma is a warty neoplasm of genital skin, often caused by low-risk HPV strains, and is often large"
"What is the most common cause of condyloma accuminata? HPV (esp. types 6 and 11)"
"Condyloma acuminata is caused by HPV types 6 and 11"
"Condyloma latum is caused by secondary syphilis"
"Histologically, HPV-associated condylomas are characterized by koilocytes"
"The following image shows koilocytic change, which appears as a wrinkled nucleus and is characteristic of HPV infection"
"Condylomas rarely::frequency progress to carcinoma"
"Lichen sclerosus is characterized by thinning of the epidermis and fibrosis (sclerosis) of the dermis"
"Lichen sclerosus presents as leukoplakia with parchment-like (thin) vulvar skin"
"What demographic is most commonly associated with lichen sclerosus? Postmenopausal women::pre- or post-menopausal women"
"Does lichen sclerosus present with increased risk for squamous cell carcinoma? Yes, slightly increased risk"
"Does lichen simplex chronicus present with increased risk for squamous cell carcinoma? No"
"Lichen sclerosus and lichen simplex chronicus are both generally benign::malignant potential"
"Lichen simplex chronicus is hyperplasia of vulvar squamous epithelium"
"Lichen simplex chronicus presents as leukoplakia with thick, leathery vulvar skin"
"Lichen simplex chronicus is associated with chronic irritation/inflammation and scratching"
"Vulvar carcinoma arises from the squamous epithelium lining the vulva"
"Vulvar carcinoma presents as leukoplakia; a biopsy may be required to distinguish carcinoma from other causes (e.g. lichen sclerosus and lichen simplex chronicus)"
"Vulvar carcinoma may be caused by two pathways: HPV related or non-HPV related"
"HPV-related vulvar carcinoma is most commonly due to HPV types 16 and 18 (high risk)"
"What demographic is most commonly associated with HPV related vulvar carcinoma? Women of reproductive age (< 50 years old)::age"
"HPV-related vulvar carcinoma arises from vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), a dysplastic precursor lesion characterized by koilocytic change, disordered cellular maturation, nuclear atypia, and increased mitotic activity"
"Non-HPV related vulvar carcinoma arises, most often, from long-standing lichen sclerosus"
"What demographic is most commonly associated with non-HPV related vulvar carcinoma? Elderly women (average age >70 years)"
"Paget disease (of the vulva and nipple) is characterized by malignant epithelial cells in the epidermis"
"Paget disease (of the vulva and nipple) presents as erythematous, pruritic, ulcerated skin"
"Does extramammary paget disease of the vulva often present with underlying carcinoma? No"
"Does paget disease of the nipple often present with underlying carcinoma? Yes"
"Extramammary paget disease must be distinguished from melanoma, which rarely can occur on the vulva"
"Extramammary paget disease of the vulva may be distinguished from melanoma by the following immunohistological features: 1. PAS +::+/- 2. Keratin +::+/- 3. S100 -::+/-"
"Melanoma may be distinguished from extramammary paget disease of the vulva by the following immunohistological features: 1. PAS -::+/- 2. Keratin -::+/- 3. S100 +::+/-"
"The following image shows large cells in the epidermis with a clear halo, which are characteristic of Paget disease"
"Mucosa of the vagina is lined by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium"
"What embryological structure is the lower (distal) 2/3rd of the vaginal canal derived from? Urogenital sinus"
"The normal fetal epithelium of the lower 2/3rd of the vaginal canal is squamous epithelium"
"What embryological structure is the upper (proximal) 1/3rd of the vaginal canal derived from? Müllerian duct"
"During normal development, squamous epithelium from the lower 2/3 of the vagina grows upward to replace columnar epithelium lining the upper 1/3 of the vagina"
"Vaginal adenosis is the focal persistence of columnar epithelium in the upper 1/3rd of the vagina"
"Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, also known as sarcoma botryoides, presents with bleeding and a(n) grape-like mass protruding from the vagina or penis of a child"
"Vaginal carcinoma is usually related to which infectious disease? HPV (high-risk strains)"
"The ectocervix is lined by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium"
"The endocervix is lined by simple columnar epithelium"
"The transformation zone is the squamocolumnar junction between the ectocervix and the endocervix"
"HPV is a sexually transmitted DNA virus that infects the lower genital tract, especially the cervix at the transformation zone"
"Risk of CIN depends on HPV type, which is determined by DNA sequencing"
"What are the high-risk strains of HPV? 16, 18, 31, 33::4"
"What are the low-risk strains of HPV? 6, 11::2"
"High-risk HPV strains produce E7 protein, which increases destruction of Rb"
"What is the extent of epithelial involvement by immature dysplastic cells in CIN I? Less than 1/3"
"What is the extent of epithelial involvement by immature dysplastic cells in CIN II? less than 2/3"
"What is the extent of epithelial involvement by immature dysplastic cells in CIN III? slightly less than the entire thickness of the epithelium"
"What is the percent chance of reversal back to normal cervical epithelium in CIN I? 66% reversal"
"What is the percent chance of reversal back to normal cervical epithelium in CIN II? 33% reversal"
"What is the percent chance of reversal back to normal cervical epithelium in CIN III? Slim, but still possible"
"What is the percent chance of reversal back to normal cervical epithelium in carcinoma in situ? Not possible"
"Besides for multiple sexual partners, the other major risk factors for cervical carcinoma are: - deficiency of the immune system - infection by high-risk HPV - tobacco use - early onset of sexual activity - lack of barrier contraception"
"What demographic is most commonly associated with cervical carcinoma? Middle-aged women (average age is 40-50 years)::age"
"Which subtype of cervical carcinoma (adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma) is associated with HPV? Both :)"
"The most common type of cervical carcinoma is squamous cell carcinoma (80%)"
"Advanced cervical carcinoma tumors often invade through the anterior uterine wall into the bladder, blocking the ureters"
"Hydronephrosis with post-renal failure is a common cause of death in advanced cervical carcinoma in females"
"Pap smear screening begins at age 21 and are performed every three year(s)"
"One limitation of pap smears is inadequate sampling of transformation zone resulting in false negative screening"
"What is the most common cause of hematochezia in adults? Diverticulosis"
"Growth of endometrium is estrogen driven (proliferative phase)"
"Preparation of endometrium for implantation is progesterone driven (secretory phase)"
"Asherman syndrome is secondary amenorrhea due to loss and scarring of the basalis layer of the endometrium"
"Asherman syndrome is often the result of overaggressive dilation and curettage (D&C)"
"Acute endometritis is due to a bacterial infection of the endometrium"
"Chronic endometritis is due to chronic inflammation of endometrium"
"The histology image below has lymphocytes and plasma cells in the endometrium, which is indicative of chronic endometritis"
"Common causes of chronic endometritis include retained products of conception, chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (e.g. from long-standing chlamydia), IUD, and TB"
"What is the treatment for infectious endometritis? Gentamicin + clindamycin with or without ampicillin"
"Endometrial polyps and endometrial hyperplasia can arise as a side effect of the chemotherapeutic drug tamoxifen"
"Endometriosis is the abnormal placement of endometrial glands and stroma outside the endometrial lining/cavity"
"Endometriosis often presents with dysmenorrhea and cyclic pelvic pain; it may also cause infertility"
"What is the most supported theory for the etiology of endometriosis? Retrograde menstruation"
"One theory behind the etiology of endometriosis is metaplastic transformation of multipotent cells"
"One theory behind the etiology of endometriosis is transportation of endometrial tissue via the lymphatic system"
"What is the most common site that endometriosis spreads to? Ovary"
"What is the appearance of an ovarian endometrioma? Chocolate cyst (blood-filled)"
"When endometriosis spreads to soft tissue, it appears as \gun-powder lesions\\"\""
"Endometriosis spread to the Pouch of Douglas (posterior cul-de-sac) can present with dyschezia (pain with defecation) and painful intercourse"
"Endometriosis spread to the bladder wall presents with dysuria"
"Endometriosis spread to the bowel serosa presents with abdominal pain and adhesions"
"Endometriosis spread to the fallopian tube mucosa presents with increased risk of ectopic tubal pregnancy and infertility"
"The presence of endometrial tissue (endometriosis) in the uterine myometrium is known as adenomyosis"
"Continuous (not pulsatile) GnRH agonists may be used to treat adenomyosis (endometriosis in the myometrium)"
"There is an increased risk of carcinoma at the site of endometriosis, especially in the ovary"
"Endometrial hyperplasia is the hyperplasia of endometrial glands relative to the stroma"
"Endometrial hyperplasia is usually caused by unopposed estrogen"
"Endometrial hyperplasia typically presents as postmenopausal::pre- or post-menopausal uterine bleeding"
"Endometrial hyperplasia is classified histologically based on architectural growth pattern (simple or complex) and the presence or absence of cellular atypia"
"The most important predictor for endometrial hyperplasia progression to carcinoma is cellular atypia"
"Which architectural growth pattern of endometrial hyperplasia has higher risk of progression to carcinoma? Complex::simple or complex"
"Endometrial hyperplasia has increased risk for progression to endometrial carcinoma"
"What is the most common invasive (malignant) carcinoma of the female genital tract? Endometrial carcinoma"
"In the hyperplasia pathway (75%) of endometrial carcinoma, the carcinoma arises from endometrial hyperplasia"
"In the sporadic pathway (25%) of endometrial carcinoma, the carcinoma arises in an atrophic endometrium with no precursor lesion"
"Endometrial carcinoma is a malignant proliferation of endometrial glands"
"Endometrial carcinoma often presents as post-menopausal bleeding"
"Endometrial carcinoma arises via two distinct pathways: hyperplasia and sporadic"
"Endometrial carcinoma from the hyperplasia pathway has a(n) endometrioid histology"
"Endometrial carcinoma from the sporadic pathway has a(n) serous, papillary histology"
"The average age of presentation of endometrial carcinoma from the hyperplasia pathway is 60 years old"
"The average age of presentation for endometrial carcinoma from the sporadic pathway is 70 years old"
"What mutation is common in endometrial carcinoma from the sporadic pathway? p53 mutations"
"What is a possible histological finding of serous, papillary endometrial carcinoma (sporadic pathway)? Psammoma bodies (concentric spherules with dystrophic calcification)"
"Risk factors of endometrial carcinoma from the hyperplasia pathway are related to estrogen exposure"
"Which autosomal dominant syndrome is associated with increased risk for colon, ovarian, and endometrial carcinoma? Lynch syndrome (HNPCC)"
"What is the most common tumor in females? Leiomyoma (fibroid)"
"What demographic has increased incidence of leiomyoma (fibroid)? African Americans (peak occurrence 20-40 years old)"
"Leiomyoma (uterine fibroid) is a benign neoplastic proliferation of smooth muscle arising from myometrium"
"Leiomyoma (fibroid) is related to estrogen exposure"
"Leiomyomas (fibroids) increase with pregnancy (increased estrogen) and decrease with menopause (decreased estrogen)"
"Gross examination of leiomyoma (fibroid) shows multiple, well-defined, white, whorled masses that may distort the uterus and impinge on pelvic structures"
"The histology image shows a whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles with well-dermarcated borders, which is characteristic of leiomyoma (fibroid)"
"What is the most common symptom of leiomyoma (fibroids)? Nothing (asymptomatic)>Heavy menstrual bleeding (when symptomatic)"
"Severe bleeding from leiomyoma (fibroid) may lead to iron deficiency anemia"
"Leiomyosarcoma is a malignant proliferation of smooth muscle arising from the myometrium"
"What is the precursor lesion for leiomyosarcoma? None -- arises de novo; leiomyosarcomas do not arise from leiomyomas***"
"Gross exam of leiomyosarcoma often shows a uterus with a single lesion with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage"
"An ovarian follicle consists of an oocyte surrounded by granulosa and theca cells"
"Degeneration of ovarian follicles may result in follicular cysts"
"Polycystic ovarian syndrome (Stein-Leventhal syndrome)::fancy name is multiple follicular cysts in the ovary and anovulation due to hormone imbalance"
"Polycystic ovarian syndrome is characterized by high::high/low LH and low::high/low FSH"
"Polycystic ovarian syndrome often has a LH:FSH ratio >2"
"In polycystic ovarian syndrome, increased LH production causes excess androgen production (from theca cells), resulting in hirsutism"
"In polycystic ovarian syndrome, excess androgen (from theca cells) is converted to estrone::specific subtype in adipose tissue, which inhibits FSH secretion from anterior pituitary"
"What demographic is most commonly affected by polycystic ovarian syndrome (Stein-Leventhal syndrome)? Obese, young women"
"Polycystic ovarian syndrome is a condition characterized by at least 2/3 of the following criteria: - clinical signs of hyperandrogenism - irregular periods (typically oligomenorrhea)::menstrual finding - polycystic ovaries on ultrasound"
"Polycystic ovarian syndrome is associated with insulin resistance, which may cause type II diabetes mellitus 10-15 years later"
"Patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome have increased risk of endometrial carcinoma, secondary to unopposed effects of estrogen"
"Polycystic ovarian syndrome presents with enlarged, bilateral cystic ovaries"
"Follicular cyst is the most common ovarian mass in young women"
"A(n) follicular cyst is a distention of an unruptured graafian follicle"
"Ovarian tumors may arise from three different cell types: 1. surface epithelium 2. germ cells (e.g. oocyte) 3. sex cord stromal tissue (e.g. granulosa & theca cells)"
"Surface epithelial tumor is the most common class of ovarian tumor (70%)"
"The two most common subtypes of ovarian surface epithelial tumors are serous and mucinous; both usually cystic"
"Ovarian cystadenoma is a benign tumor composed of a single cyst with a simple, flat lining of epithelial cells"
"Ovarian cystadenomas (surface epithelial tumors) most commonly arise in women aged 30-40 years old"
"What is the most common benign ovarian tumor? Serous cystadenoma"
"Serous cystadenoma is a benign tumor lined with fallopian tube-like epithelium; often bilateral"
"Ovarian mucinous cystadenoma is a large, multiloculated benign tumor lined by mucus-secreting epithelium"
"Ovarian cystadenocarcinoma is a malignant tumor composed of complex cysts with a shaggy lining of epithelium and invasion into the connective tissue"
"Ovarian adenocarcinomas (surface epithelial tumor) most commonly arise in women aged 60-70 years old"
"Borderline tumors have features in between benign and malignant"
"Borderline tumors have better prognosis than clearly malignant tumors, but still carry metastatic potential"
"BRCA1 mutation carriers have increased risk for serous adenocarcinoma of the ovary and fallopian tube"
"What is the most common malignant ovarian neoplasm? Serous cystadenocarcinoma"
"Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma may present with pseudomyxoma peritonei, which is an intraperitoneal accumulation of mucinous material, usually from a GI, ovarian, appendiceal tumor"
"One type of a rare ovarian surface epithelial tumor is a(n) endometrioid tumor, which is composed of endometrial-like glands and is usually malignant"
"15% of ovarian endometrioid tumors are associated with an independent endometrial carcinoma"
"One type of a rare ovarian surface epithelial tumor is a(n) Brenner tumor, which is composed of bladder-like epithelium (urothelium)"
"Brenner tumors are solid, encapsulated tumors with a yellow-tan appearance; they have \Coffee bean\\" nuclei on H&E stain\""
"Ovarian surface epithelial tumors typically present late and therefore have poor prognosis"
"Ovarian surface epithelial tumors typically present with vague abdominal symptoms (e.g. pain, fullness) and signs of compression (e.g. urinary frequency)"
"Germ cell tumors are the second most common class of ovarian tumor (15%)"
"What demographic is most commonly affected by ovarian germ cell tumors? Women of reproductive age (15-30 years old)::age"
"Cystic teratoma is a cystic tumor composed of fetal tissue derived from two or three embryologic layers (e.g. hair, teeth, bone, skin, gut, thyroid, etc)"
"In addition to immature tissue, cystic teratomas may become malignant via somatic malignancy"
"Struma ovarii is a cystic teratoma composed primarily of thyroid tissue and thus may cause hyperthyroidism"
"What is the most common malignant germ cell tumor in females? Dysgerminoma"
"A(n) dysgerminoma is an ovarian germ cell tumor composed of large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei; described as \fried egg\\" cells\""
"Dysgerminoma is equivalent to its male testicular counterpart, termed a(n) seminoma"
"Dysgerminoma has a(n) good prognosis"
"What serum markers may be elevated in dysgerminoma? LDH and hCG::2"
"What demographic is most commonly associated with dysgerminoma? Adolescent females"
"What is the most common germ cell tumor in children (esp. male infants)? Endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumor"
"Endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumor is a malignant tumor that mimics the yolk sac"
"What serum marker is characteristically elevated in endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumor? Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)"
"Endodermal sinus tumors are characterized by what histological finding (50%)? Schiller-Duval bodies (glomeruloid-like structures)"
"Choriocarcinoma is a malignant germ cell tumor composed of mononuclear cytotrophoblasts and multinuclear syncytiotrophoblasts, but with absent villi"
"Choriocarcinoma is a small, hemorrhagic tumor with early, diffuse hematogenous spread, especially to the lungs"
"What serum marker is characteristically elevated in choriocarcinoma? hCG (produced by syncytiotrophoblasts)"
"Choriocarcinoma is associated with which type of ovarian cyst? Theca-lutein cyst"
"Embryonal carcinoma is a malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary or testis composed of large primitive cells"
"What is the most common malignant ovarian sex cord stromal tumor? Granulosa cell tumor"
"Granulosa cell tumor is an ovarian sex cord stromal tumor that often produces estrogen and inhibin"
"Granulosa cell tumor predominantly affects women in their 50s::age"
"Histologically, granulosa cell tumors are characterized by Call-Exner bodies, which are granulosa cells arranged in follicle / rosette-like collections around eosinophilic fluid, resembling primordial follicles"
"Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor is a rare ovarian sex cord-stromal cell tumor that may produce androgens, thus causing hirsutism/virilization in women"
"Fibromas are benign sex cord stromal tumors of fibroblasts (bundles of spindle-shaped cells)"
"Meigs syndrome is a triad of ovarian fibroma, ascites, and hydrothorax (pleural effusion)"
"Fibroma is an ovarian sex cord stromal tumor that may present with a \pulling\\" sensation in the groin\""
"Krukenberg tumor is metastatic mucinous tumor that involves both ovaries; most commonly due to metastatic gastric carcinoma (diffuse type)::specific"
"Primary mucinous tumors of the ovary (e.g. surface epithelial tumor) are usually unilateral::unilateral/bilateral, where as Krukenberg tumors are usually bilateral"
"Pseudomyxoma peritonei is massive amounts of mucus in the peritoneum"
"Which ovarian neoplasm is characterized histologically by Schiller-Duval bodies (glomeruloid-like structures)? Endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumor"
"Ectopic pregnancy is the implantation of a fertilized ovum at a site other than uterine wall"
"Ectopic pregnancy may present with a(n) lower than expected rise in the hormone hCG based on dates"
"Major complications of ectopic pregnancy are hematosalpinx (bleeding into the fallopian tube) and/or rupture"
"Spontaneous abortion is more common in patients in a(n) hypercoagulable state, such as those with antiphospholipid syndrome"
"What is most commonly the effect of teratogens during the first two weeks of gestation? Spontaneous abortion"
"What is most commonly the effect of teratogens during the weeks 3-8 of gestation? Organ malformation"
"What is most commonly the effect of teratogens after week 8 of gestation? Organ hypoplasia"
"Placenta previa is attachment of the placenta to the lower uterine segment over (or < 2 cm from) the internal cervical os"
"Placenta previa presents with painless third trimester bleeding"
"Risk factors for placenta previa include multiparity and prior C-section"
"Placental abruption may cause fetal distress and thus a(n) still birth"
"Placental abruption typically presents with abrupt, painful third trimester bleeding"
"Placenta accreta is the abnormal attachment of the placenta to the myometrium, without penetrating it"
"Gestational hypertension is a blood pressure >140/90 mmHg after the 20th week of gestation with no proteinuria, pre-existing hypertension, nor end-organ damage"
"Preeclampsia is pregnancy-induced hypertension with proteinuria or end-organ dysfunction after 20th week of gestation"
"Preeclampsia typically presents after the 20th week of gestation"
"Preeclampsia is caused by abnormal placental spiral arteries, causing endothelial dysfunction, vasoconstriction, and ischemia"
"There is an increased incidence of preeclampsia in patients with pre-existing hypertension, diabetes, chronic renal disease, and autoimmune disorders"
"Eclampsia is defined as preeclampsia with seizures"
"HELLP syndrome is a manifestation of severe preeclampsia that presents with hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets"
"What finding on blood smear is characteristic of HELLP syndrome? Schistocytes (due to thrombotic microangiopathy)"
"HELLP syndrome can lead to hepatic subcapsular hematomas, which may rupture leading to severe hypotension"
"Eclampsia and HELLP syndrome both warrant immediate delivery of the baby"
"Sudden Infant Death Syndrome is the death of a healthy infant (1 month to 1 year old) without obvious cause"
"Hydatidiform mole is an abnormal conception characterized by swollen and edematous chorionic villi with proliferation of trophoblasts only"
"Hydatidiform mole presents with uterine enlargement more than expected for the date of gestation"
"Hydatidiform mole presents with higher levels of hCG than expected for the date of gestation"
"In areas with no prenatal care, a hydatidiform mole presents in the 2nd trimester with passage of grape-like masses (large, edematous villi) through the vaginal canal"
"In areas with prenatal care, hydatidiform mole is diagnosed by routine ultrasound early in the first trimester"
"A hydatidiform mole may be detected via the absence of fetal heart sounds"
"Hydatidiform mole presents with a 'snow-storm' appearance on ultrasound"
"A(n) complete hydatidiform mole is characterized by 46 chromosomes"
"A(n) partial hydatidiform mole is characterized by 69 chromosomes"
"A(n) partial hydatidiform mole most commonly consists of 2 sperm with 1 egg"
"A(n) complete hydatidiform mole most commonly consists of 1 sperm that duplicates within a(n) enucleated egg (85%, karyotype 46, XX)"
"A(n) partial hydatidiform mole contains fetal tissue"
"A(n) complete hydatidiform mole does not contain fetal tissue"
"A(n) complete hydatidiform mole is more commonly associated with increased uterine size"
"A(n) complete hydatidiform mole is associated with very increased levels of hCG"
"A(n) partial hydatidiform mole is associated with mildly increased levels of hCG"
"A(n) complete hydatidiform mole is associated with increased risk of choriocarcinoma"
"A(n) partial hydatidiform mole is associated with very little increased risk of choriocarcinoma"
"In a(n) partial hydatidiform mole, only some villi are hydropic, and there is only partial trophoblastic proliferation around the vili"
"In a(n) complete hydatidiform mole, most villi are hydropic and there is circumferential trophoblastic proliferation around the villi"
"What is the treatment for a hydatidiform mole? Dilatation and curettage"
"After a hydatidiform mole, patients should monitor hCG levels to ensure adequate mole removal and to screen for development of choriocarcinoma"
"Early hypertension during pregnancy (before 20 weeks) is associated with a(n) hydatidiform mole"
"What type of ovarian cyst is associated with a hydatidiform mole? Theca-lutein cysts"
"Choriocarcinoma in females may arise as a complication of gestation or as a spontaneous germ cell tumor"
"Choriocarcinoma that arises as a(n) spontaneous germ cell tumor has a(n) poor response to chemotherapy"
"Choriocarcinoma that arises from gestation has a(n) very good response to chemotherapy"
"What chemotherapeutic drug is used in the treatment of a hydatidiform mole if hCG levels remain elevated after D&C? Methotrexate"
"Hypospadias is due to failure of urethral folds to close"
"Epispadias is due to abnormal positioning of the genital tubercle in men"
"Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is an STD characterized by necrotizing granulomatous inflammation of inguinal lymphatics and lymph nodes"
"Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1-L3)"
"Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) eventually heals with fibrosis; perianal involvement may result in rectal strictures"
"Penile squamous cell carcinoma is the malignant proliferation of squamous cells of penile skin"
"What infectious pathology is associated with penile squamous cell carcinoma? High-risk HPV (2/3 of cases)"
"Penile squamous cell carcinoma is associated with a lack of circumcision (foreskin can act as a nidus)"
"One precursor lesion of penile SCC is Bowen disease, which is the in situ carcinoma of the penile shaft or scrotum that presents as leukoplakia"
"One precursor lesion of penile SCC is Erythroplasia of Queyrat, which is the in situ carcinoma of the glans of the penis that presents as erythroplakia"
"One precursor lesion of penile SCC is Bowenoid papulosis, which is an in situ carcinoma of the penis that presents as reddish papules"
"Which precursor lesion to penile SCC is more commonly seen in younger patients (40s)? Bowenoid papulosis"
"Which precursor lesion to penile SCC does not progress to invasive carcinoma? Bowenoid papulosis"
"Which three continents are associated with increased prevalence of penile squamous cell carcinoma? Asia, Africa, South America"
"Peyronie disease is the abnormal curvature of the penis due to fibrous plaque within the tunica albuginea"
"Peyronie disease is associated with erectile dysfunction"
"Ischemic priapism is a painful sustained erection lasting >4 hours"
"What blood disorder is associated with ischemic priapism? Sickle cell anemia (sickled RBCs get trapped in vascular channels)"
"What is the effect of cryptorchidism on fertility? Decreased"
"Risk of cryptorchidism is increased if a baby is born prematurely"
"What is the effect of cryptorchidism on inhibin B levels? Decreased (due to decreased Sertoli cell activity)"
"What is the effect of cryptorchidism on FSH levels? Increased"
"What is the effect of bilateral cryptorchidism on testosterone levels? Decreased"
"Orchitis is an inflammation of the testicle"
"Common infectious causes of orchitis in young adults include Chlamydia trachomatis (D-K) and Neisseria gonorrhoeae"
"Common infectious causes of orchitis in older adults include E. coli and Pseudomonas"
"What is a possible viral cause of orchitis in teenage males? Mumps virus"
"Autoimmune orchitis involves the granulomatous inflammation of the seminiferous tubules of testicles"
"Testicular torsion occurs due to twisting of the spermatic cord over thin-walled veins of the scrotum"
"Testicular torsion causes hemorrhagic infarction of the testicle"
"Testicular torsion commonly presents in 12-18 year olds with sudden testicular pain, high-riding testis, and absent cremasteric reflex"
"Varicocele is caused by dilated veins in the pampiniform plexus due to increased venous pressure"
"Varicocele presents as scrotal swelling with a palpable \bag of worms\\" while standing\""
"Varicocele most commonly occurs on the left side of the body"
"Varicocele is associated with left-sided renal cell carcinoma"
"What is the effect of varicocele on fertility? Decreased"
"What imaging technique may be used to diagnose a varicocele? Ultrasound with Doppler"
"Hydrocele is due to accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis surrounding the testis"
"Acquired hydrocele (\noncommunicating\\") may be secondary to infection"
"Does a hydrocele transilluminate? Yes"
"Testicular tumors may arise from either germ cells or sex-cord stroma"
"Testicular tumors present as a firm, painless testicular mass that cannot be transilluminated"
"Are testicular tumors biopsied? Why or why not? No; increased risk of seeding the scrotum"
"What is the most common class of testicular tumor (>95%)? Germ cell tumors"
"What is the most common testicular tumor? Seminoma"
"What age group is associated with testicular germ cell tumors? Men 15-40 years of age"
"Testicular germ cell tumors that are seminomas (55%) are very responsive to radiotherapy, metastasize late, and have excellent prognosis"
"Testicular germ cell tumors that are non-seminomas (43%) have variable responses to radiotherapy and metastasize early"
"Seminoma is a malignant testicular tumor comprised of large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei, sometimes described as a \fried egg\\" appearance\""
"Seminoma is a testicular germ cell tumor that forms a homogenous mass with no hemorrhage or necrosis"
"In rare cases, seminomas may have elevated levels of the hormone hCG"
"Seminomas are associated with increased levels of placental ALP"
"Embryonal carcinoma is a testicular germ cell tumor that often has a(n) glandular/papillary morphology"
"Chemotherapy of an embryonal carcinoma may result in differentiation (e.g. may mature into a teratoma)"
"Embryonal carcinoma is a non-seminoma germ cell tumor and therefore has a relatively worse prognosis"
"Embryonal carcinoma may have increased levels of hCG and normal or elevated levels of AFP"
"Embryonal carcinoma is a testicular germ cell tumor that forms a hemorrhagic mass with necrosis"
"What is the most common testicular tumor in children (< 3 years old)? Yolk sac (endodermal sinus) tumor"
"Which testicular neoplasm is characterized histologically by Schiller-Duval bodies (glomeruloid-like structures)? Endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumor"
"Elevated levels of hCG (e.g. choriocarcinoma) may cause gynecomastia (males) or hyperthyroidism due to homology between hCG and TSH, FSH, and LH"
"Testicular germ cell tumors often present as a(n) mixed germ cell tumor; prognosis is based on the worst component"
"Testicular sex cord-stromal tumors are composed of Sertoli cells and/or Leydig cells and are usually benign::benign or malignant"
"Leydig cell tumors are testicular sex cord stromal tumors that produce estrogens or androgens, causing gynecomastia (men) or precocious puberty (boys)"
"Leydig cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor associated with characteristic Reinke crystals (eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion) on histology"
"Sertoli cell tumor is a testicular sex cord stromal tumor comprised of tubules, usually clinically silent"
"What is the most common cause of testicular cancer in older men (>60)? Lymphoma"
"What type of lymphoma is usually the cause of testicular cancer in older men? diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (aggressive)"
"The posterior aspect of prostate is palpable by digital rectal exam (DRE)"
"The glands and stroma of the prostate are maintained by androgens"
"The glands of the prostate secrete a(n) alkaline (pH), milky fluid that is added to sperm and seminal vesicle fluid to make semen"
"Common infectious causes of acute prostatitis in young adults include Chlamydia trachomatis (D-K) and Neisseria gonorrhoeae"
"Common infectious causes of acute prostatitis in older adults include E. coli and Pseudomonas"
"Acute prostatitis often presents with dysuria and fever/chills"
"A patient with acute prostatitis may have a tender, 'boggy' prostate on DRE"
"Prostatic secretions of a patient with acute prostatitis often contain WBCs with culture showing bacteria"
"Prostatic secretions of a patient with chronic prostatitis often contain WBCs with culture showing no bacteria"
"Chronic prostatitis presents as dysuria with pelvic or low back pain"
"Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is the age-related hyperplasia of prostatic stroma and glands"
"Does benign prostatic hyperplasia increase risk of cancer? No"
"Benign prostatic hyperplasia most commonly occurs in the periurethral zone (middle/lateral lobes) of the prostate"
"Benign prostatic hyperplasia may present with problems starting and stopping urination"
"Benign prostatic hyperplasia may present with impaired bladder emptying"
"Benign prostatic hyperplasia may present with nocturia (increased urination throughout the night)"
"Benign prostatic hyperplasia may present with hypertrophy of bladder wall smooth muscle with increased risk for diverticulum formation"
"Benign prostatic hyperplasia may present with microscopic hematuria"
"The PSA level in benign prostatic hyperplasia is often slightly elevated due to hyperplasia of prostatic glands"
"One possible complication of benign prostatic hyperplasia is hydronephrosis, due to backup of fluid into the kidney"
"Benign prostatic hyperplasia may be treated with a(n) non-selective α1 antagonist such as terazosin"
"Benign prostatic hyperplasia may be treated with a(n) selective α1A,D antagonist such as tamsulosin"
"Prostate adenocarcinoma is the malignant proliferation of prostatic glands"
"Which form of cancer is the 2nd most common cause of cancer death in men? Prostate cancer"
"What ethnicity is associated with increased risk for prostate adenocarcinoma? African Americans > Caucasians > Asians"
"A diet high in saturated fat may increase risk for prostate adenocarcinoma"
"Prostatic adenocarcinoma most commonly occurs in the posterior periphery of the prostate"
"Screening for prostatic adenocarcinoma begins at 50 with digital rectal exam and PSA"
"PSA > 10 ng/dl is worrisome at any age and may be indicative of prostatic adenocarcinoma"
"A decreased % of which form of PSA is suggestive of prostatic adenocarcinoma? Free-PSA (cancer makes bound-PSA)"
"A(n) prostatic biopsy is required to confirm the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma (cannot use PSA levels alone)"
"Prostatic adenocarcinoma is characterized by small glands that infiltrate normal tissue and nuclei that contain dark nucleoli"
"Prostatic adenocarcinoma may be graded using the Gleason grading system"
"The Gleason grading system (for prostatic adenocarcinoma) is based on architecture, not nuclear atypia"
"A higher score using the Gleason grading system (for prostatic adenocarcinoma) is associated with a(n) worse prognosis"
"Which two serum markers are often elevated in prostatic adenocarcinoma? PSA and PAP (prostatic acid phosphatase)"
"Which serum marker may be elevated due to metastasis of prostatic adenocarcinoma to bone? Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)"
"Prostatic adenocarcinoma often has osteoblastic::type metastases, which is indicated by lower back pain"
"If prostatic adenocarcinoma has not metastasized (i.e. local disease), it may be treated with prostatectomy"
"Prostatic adenocarcinoma may be treated with GnRH analogs (e.g. leuprolide) and/or androgen receptor inhibitors (e.g. flutamide)"
"Breast tissue is a modified sweat gland that is embryologically derived from skin"
"Breast tissue can develop anywhere along the milk line, which runs from the axilla to the vulva (e.g. supernumerary nipples)"
"The terminal duct-lobular unit (TDLU) is the functional unit of the breast; lobules make milk that drains via ducts to nipple"
"The lobules and ducts of breast tissue are lined by two::# layers of epithelium"
"The inner cell layer of breast tissue is the luminal (epithelial) cell layer"
"The luminal (epithelial) cell layer of breast tissue is responsible for milk production in the lobules"
"The outer cell layer of breast is the myoepithelial cell layer"
"The myoepithelial cell layer of breast tissue is responsible for propelling milk towards the nipple"
"During pregnancy, breast lobules undergo hyperplasia"
"After menopause, breast tissue undergoes atrophy"
"Lobules and small ducts of breast tissue are present in highest density in the upper outer quadrant"
"Galactorrhea refers to milk production outside of lactation"
"Is galactorrhea a symptom of breast cancer? No!"
"Acute (lactational) mastitis is due to a bacterial infection of breast, usually Staphylococcus aureus"
"Acute (lactational) mastitis is associated with breast feeding"
"Acute (lactational) mastitis presents as a warm, erythematous breast with purulent nipple discharge"
"Treatment for acute (lactational) mastitis is continued drainage (e.g. feeding) plus antibiotics (e.g. dicloxacillin)"
"Periductal mastitis is inflammation of subareolar ducts"
"Periductal mastitis is usually seen in smokers"
"Periductal mastitis occurs due to a relative vitamin A deficiency, which results in squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts"
"Periductal mastitis presents as a subareolar mass with nipple retraction due to pull from myofibroblasts during healing"
"Mammary duct ectasia is inflammation with dilation of the subareolar duct"
"Mammary duct ectasia presents with a periareolar green-brown nipple discharge (inflammatory debris)"
"Mammary duct ectasia is associated with chronic inflammation with plasma cells seen on biopsy"
"Mammary duct ectasia classically arises in multiparous (parity), post-menopausal women"
