"Fat necrosis of breast tissue is usually related to trauma, but a history of such is not always reported"
"Fat necrosis of breast tissue presents as a painless mass on physical exam"
"Fat necrosis of breast tissue presents as a(n) calcified oil cyst::specific on mammography"
"Biopsy of breast tissue with fat necrosis shows necrotic fat with associated calcifications and giant cells"
"Fibrocystic changes are the most common changes in pre-menopausal breast"
"Fibrocystic change presents as a 'lumpy' breast that may be painful"
"Fibrocystic change of the breast presents as cysts with a(n) blue-domed appearance on gross exam"
"Fibrocystic changes of the breast generally are benign::benign or malignant"
"Some fibrocystic-related changes carry increased risk for invasive carcinoma, which applies to both breast(s)"
"What is the relative risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma with fibrosis and cysts (fibrocystic changes)? No increased risk"
"What is the relative risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma with apocrine metaplasia (fibrocystic changes)? No increased risk**"
"Sclerosing adenosis is an increase in acini (ducts) and stromal fibrosis of breast tissue, which may be seen as calcifications on mammogram"
"What is the relative risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma with sclerosing adenosis (fibrocystic changes)? 1.5-2x increased risk"
"Epithelial/ductal hyperplasia is an increased number of cells in the terminal ductal or lobular epithelium of the breast"
"What is the relative risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma with epithelial hyperplasia (fibrocystic changes)? 1.5-2x increased risk"
"What is the relative risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma with atypical epithelial hyperplasia (fibrocystic changes)? 5x increased risk"
"Intraductal papilloma is a small papillary proliferation within lactiferous ducts, typically beneath the areola of the breast"
"Which type(s) of cells line the fibrovascular projections of an intraductal papilloma of the breast? Both epithelial (luminal) and myoepithelial cells"
"Intraductal papilloma of the breast typically presents as a(n) bloody nipple discharge in a(n) pre-menopausal woman"
"What is the most common cause of nipple discharge (serous or bloody)? Intraductal papilloma (often bloody)"
"Which type(s) of cells line the fibrovascular projections of a papillary carcinoma of the breast? Only epithelial cells; no myoepithelial cells"
"Papillary carcinoma of the breast typically presents as a(n) bloody nipple discharge in a(n) post-menopausal woman"
"Fibroadenoma is a benign small, well-defined mobile breast mass composed of fibrous tissue and glands"
"What is the most common benign neoplasm of breast? Fibroadenoma"
"Fibroadenoma is most common in women under 35 years old"
"Size and tenderness of a fibroadenoma of the breast increases with exposure to estrogen"
"Does fibroadenoma increase risk of breast cancer? No (benign)"
"Phyllodes tumor is a fibroadenoma-like tumor with overgrowth of the fibrous component, causing 'leaf-like' projections"
"Phyllodes tumor is most commonly seen in post-menopausal women"
"Can Phyllodes tumor increase risk of breast cancer? Yes, some may be malignant"
"Malignant breast tumors most commonly occur in post-menopausal women"
"What is the most common location for an invasive breast tumor? Upper-outer quadrant of the breast"
"Risk factors for developing breast cancer are generally associated with increased estrogen exposure"
"Increased risk of developing breast cancer is associated with a(n) older::younger/older age at first live birth"
"What is the effect of obesity on risk of developing breast cancer? Why? Increased, due to increased estrone production from adipose tissue"
"Increased risk for breast carcinoma is associated with early menarche and late menopause"
"Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is the malignant proliferation of cells in the ducts of the breast with no invasion of the basement membrane"
"Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is detected as microcalcifications on mammography"
"Mammographic calcifications can be associated with benign conditions such as sclerosing adenosis (fibrocystic change) and fat necrosis"
"Comedocarcinoma is a subtype of DCIS (breast) that is characterized by high-grade cells with dystrophic calcification in the center of ducts immediately surrounded by central necrosis"
"Paget's disease is ductal carcinoma in situ that extends up the ducts to the skin of the nipple"
"Paget's disease (of the nipple) presents as nipple ulceration and erythema"
"Paget's disease of the nipple is almost always associated with an underlying carcinoma (e.g. DCIS)"
"The following image shows malignant epithelial cells in the epidermis of the nipple, which is representative of Paget's disease"
"What is the most common type of breast cancer? Invasive ductal carcinoma (~75% of all breast cancers)"
"Invasive ductal carcinoma presents on physical exam with a firm, fibrous \rock-hard\\" mass with sharp margins\""
"Invasive ductal carcinoma classically forms duct-like structures"
"Invasive ductal carcinoma presents as mass detected by physical exam (> 2cm) or mammography (> 1cm)"
"Invasive ductal carcinoma may present, grossly, with classic \stellate\\" infiltration\""
"Advanced invasive ductal carcinoma tumors may result in dimpling of skin or retraction of the nipple"
"One subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast) is tubular carcinoma, which produces tubules in a desmoplastic stroma"
"Tubular carcinoma can be differentiated from normal breast tissue by lack of myoepithelial cells and presence of desmoplastic stroma"
"What is the prognosis of the tubular carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast)? Good"
"The following image represents the tubular carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma:"
"One subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast is mucinous carcinoma, which is characterized by malignant cells floating in 'pools of mucus'"
"What is the prognosis of the mucinous carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast)? Good"
"What demographic is most commonly associated with the mucinous carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast)? Elderly women (average 70)"
"The following image represents the mucinous carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma:"
"What is the prognosis of the medullary carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast)? Good"
"One subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast) is medullary carcinoma, which is characterized by large, high-grade malignant cells growing in sheets with lymphocytic infiltrate"
"There is an increased incidence of medullary carcinoma of the breast (a subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma) in patients with BRCA1 mutations"
"One subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast) is inflammatory carcinoma, which is characterized by an erythematous and swollen breast that does not resolve with antibiotics"
"Inflammatory carcinoma, a subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma, is characterized by cancer within dermal lymphatics"
"What is the prognosis of the inflammatory carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast)? Poor (50% survival at 5 years)"
"What other clinical pathology is inflammatory carcinoma of the breast often mistaken with? Acute mastitis"
"The following image represents the inflammatory carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast): hint: the circled area is lymphatics"
"The gross appearance of inflammatory breast cancer is often described as resembling a(n) orange peel (Peau d'orange) (due to invasion of lymphatic spaces)"
"Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is the malignant proliferation of cells in the lobules of the breast with no invasion of the basement membrane"
"Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is often discovered incidentally; does not produce mass or calcification"
"Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is a non-invasive breast cancer characterized by dyscohesive cells due to lack of E-cadherin protein"
"Lobular carcinoma in situ is treated with anti-estrogenic drugs (e.g. tamoxifen) to reduce risk of subsequent carcinoma"
"Which type of invasive breast carcinoma is characterized as often being bilateral with multiple lesions in the same location? Invasive lobular carcinoma"
"Invasive lobular carcinoma grows in a(n) single-file pattern due to lack of E-cadherin"
"The following image represents invasive lobular carcinoma (breast):"
"What is the most important factor in determining prognosis of breast cancer? Metastasis"
"What is the most useful factor in determining prognosis of breast cancer? Spread to axillary lymph nodes"
"How is axillary lymph node involvement assessed when looking for spread of breast cancer? Sentinel node biopsy"
"Presence or absence of which three receptors or genes are most important in predicting response to treatment of breast cancer? estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR) and Her2/neu amplification"
"Breast cancer that is ER+ and PR+ is most likely to respond to anti-estrogenic agents such as tamoxifen"
"Breast cancer that has Her2/neu amplification is associated with good response to trastuzumab (herceptin)"
"Breast Cancer Assessment: The following is an immunohistochemical stain for the estrogen receptor, which is located in nuclei"
"Breast Cancer Assessment: The following is an immunohistochemical stain for the HER-2 (c-erbB2) receptor, which is located on the cell membrane"
"'Triple-Negative' breast cancer is negative for ER, PR, and HER2/neu and has a(n) poor prognosis"
"What demographic is most commonly associated with triple negative breast cancer? African American women"
"What are the two single most important gene mutations associated with hereditary breast cancer? BRCA1 and BRCA2"
"Females with BRCA1 mutations have increased risk for which types of cancer? Breast, ovarian, and fallopian tube::3"
"BRCA2 mutation is associated with breast carcinoma in males"
"If a women undergoes prophylactic mastectomy, can she still develop breast cancer? Yes, there is a small chance due to small amounts of remaining breast tissue"
"Male breast cancer most commonly presents as a(n) subareolar mass in older males"
"What type of breast cancer is most common in males? invasive ductal carcinoma"
"At what week does the genitalia of a developing fetus begin to show male/female characteristics? Week 10"
"Craniopharyngioma is a benign tumor of Rathke's pouch that is filled with cholesterol crystals and calcifications"
"Dizygotic (“fraternal”) twins arise from 2 eggs that are separately fertilized by 2 different sperm"
"Dizygotic (“fraternal”) twins will have 2 separate amniotic sacs and 2 separate placentas (chorions)"
"Monozygotic (“identical”) twins arise from 1 fertilized egg (1 egg + 1 sperm) that splits in early pregnancy"
"If the developing embryo splits in the 2-cell stage (0-4 days), the twins will be di::mono/di-chorionic and di::mono/di-amniotic"
"If the developing embryo splits in the morula stage (4-8 days), the twins will be mono::mono/di-chorionic and di::mono/di-amniotic"
"If the developing embryo splits in the blastocyst stage (8-12 days), the twins will be mono::mono/di-chorionic and mono::mono/di-amniotic"
"If the developing embryo splits after the embryonic disc is formed (>13 days), the twins will be conjoined"
"The umbilical vein supplies oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus"
"The umbilical vein drains oxygenated blood into the fetal IVC via the liver or ductus venosus"
"The umbilical arteries return deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta"
"There is one umbilical vein(s) and two umbilical artery (arteries)"
"Presence of one umbilical artery is associated with congenital and chromosomal anomalies"
"Umbilical arteries and veins are derived from the allantois"
"During the 3rd week of development, the yolk sac forms the allantois, which extends into the urogenital sinus"
"The allantois becomes the urachus, which is a duct between the fetal bladder and the umbilicus"
"The vitelline duct is a duct that connects the embryonic yolk sac to the midgut lumen"
"During the 7th week of development, the obliteration of the vitelline duct (omphalo-mesenteric duct) occurs"
"If the vitelline duct COMPLETELY fails to close, a vitelline fistula (persistent vitelline duct) develops, which is characterized by meconium discharge from the umbilicus"
"If the vitelline duct only closes partially, a(n) Meckel diverticulum develops, with the patent portion attached to the ileum"
"The Infundibulopelvic Ligament connects the ovaries to the lateral pelvic wall"
"What vasculature is contained in the suspensory ligament of the ovary (infundibulopelvic ligament)? Ovarian vessels"
"The Cardinal ligament connects the cervix to the side wall of the pelvis and contains the uterine vessels"
"The uterine arteries are contained in the cardinal ligament, which themselves are formed via anterior division of the internal iliac arteries"
"The round ligament of the uterus connects the uterine horn (fundus) to the labia majora"
"What female structure is a derivative of the gubernaculum and travels through the inguinal canal? Round ligament of the uterus"
"The broad ligament connects the ovaries, uterus, and fallopian tubes to the pelvic side wall"
"What three folds make up the broad ligament in females? Mesosalpinx, mesometrium, and mesovarium"
"The ovarian ligament connects the medial pole of the ovary to the lateral uterus"
"What is the fibrous capsule that surrounds the seminiferous tubules in the testis? Tunica albuginea"
"The membranous segment of the urethra is prone to injury from pelvic fracture"
"Injury to the posterior membranous urethra (e.g. pelvic fracture) can cause urine to leak into the retropubic space"
"The bulbar and penile urethra are at risk of damage with perineal straddle injuries"
"Injury to the anterior penile urethra (e.g. perineal straddle injury) can cause urine to leak beneath the deep fascia of Buck"
"Polyhydramnios is the presence of too much amniotic fluid and may be associated with fetal malformations (e.g. esophageal or duodenal atresia due to inability to swallow)"
"Oligohydramnios is too little amniotic fluid, and may be associated with bilateral renal agenesis or posterior urethral valves (males)"
"What is the most common gynecologic cancer worldwide? Cervical (due to lack of screening or HPV vaccination)"
"Which gynecologic cancer (endometrial, cervical, ovarian) has the worst prognosis? Ovarian"
"Premature ovarian failure presents with symptoms of menopause after puberty but before age 40"
"What is the most common mechanism of chromosomal aneuploidy? Meiotic nondisjunction"
"Klinefelter syndrome is most commonly characterized by a(n) 47,XXY karyotype"
"Which sex chromosome disorder is associated with gynecomastia, female hair distribution, tall/long extremities and eunuchoid body shape in a male? Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY)"
"What is the level of testosterone in a patient with Klinefelter syndrome? Decreased (seminiferous tubule dysgenesis, abnormal Leydig cell function)"
"What is the level of estrogen in a patient with Klinefelter syndrome? Increased"
"Klinefelter syndrome is associated with testicular atrophy::size"
"Which sex chromosome disorder is associated with short stature, shield chest, and webbed neck in a female? Turner syndrome"
"What is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea? Turner's syndrome"
"What is the level of estrogen in a patient with Turner syndrome? Decreased (due to ovarian dysgenesis)"
"Turner syndrome is associated with preductal coarctation of the aorta, which may present as a femoral pulse less than brachial pulse"
"Double Y males are characterized by a(n) 47,XYY karyotype"
"How do double Y males (XYY) appear phenotypically? Normal, very tall"
"Ovotesticular disorder of sex development, also known as true hermaphroditism, is the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue"
"Placental aromatase deficiency is the inability to synthesize estrogens from androgens"
"Placental aromatase deficiency results in masculinization of female (46,XX) infants"
"Placental aromatase deficiency can present with maternal virilization during pregnancy"
"Androgen insensitivity syndrome is due to a defect in the androgen receptor, which results in a normal-appearing female that is genotypically XY"
"A testosterone-secreting tumor (or exogenous steroids) presents with increased testosterone and decreased LH"
"Primary hypogonadism presents with decreased testosterone/estrogen and increased LH"
"Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism presents with decreased testosterone/estrogen and decreased LH & FSH"
"Kallmann syndrome is characterized by a defective migration of GnRH cells and defective formation of the olfactory bulb"
"Kallmann syndrome presents as infertility in males and amenorrhea in females; anosmia may be present in both sexes"
"Turner syndrome is most commonly characterized by a(n) 45,XO karyotype"
"In 5-alpha-reductase deficiency, there are normal levels of testosterone and normal/increased levels of LH"
"Alendronate, pamidronate, zoledronate are all examples of bisphophonates, which are the first line treatment for osteoporosis"
"Bisphosphonates have a chemical structure similar to pyrophosphate"
"Bisphosphonates bind to hydroxyapatite in bone, inhibiting osteoclast activity"
"When bound to bisphosphonate, Osteoclasts are unable to adhere to the bony surface, thus decreasing their activity"
"Bisphosphonates decrease the development and recruitment of osteoclast precursors"
"In addition to decreasing osteoclast activity, bisphosphonates also may induce osteoclast apoptosis"
"Which two drugs are useful in the acute treatment of hypercalcemia of malignancy? Bisphosphonates and calcitonin"
"Bisphosphonates and calcitonin are useful in the management of Paget disease, which is characterized by uncontrolled osteoclast resorption with secondary disorganized bone formation"
"Oral bisphosphonates may cause upper GI side effects"
"What osteoporosis drug has side effects that include acid reflux, esophagitis, and esophageal ulcers? Bisphosphonates (oral)"
"One rare side effect of bisphosphonates and denosumab is osteonecrosis of the jaw (rare)"
"As a result of decreased osteoclast activity, bisphosphonates may cause hypo-calcemia"
"Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) are a class of drugs that are useful in the treatment and prevention of postmenopausal osteoporosis"
"Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that has estrogen agonist activity on bone"
"Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that has estrogen antagonist activity on breast and uterus"
"Chronic exposure of PTH stimulates osteoblasts to express RANKL, which binds to RANK on osteoclast surfaces to increase activity"
"Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody against RANKL, useful in the treatment of osteoporosis"
"Calcitonin promotes Ca2+ excretion by the kidney"
"One possible adverse metabolic effect of exogenous calcitonin is hypocalcemia"
"The site of action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH, vasopressin) is the collecting duct of the kidney"
"What G-protein receptor is the ADH-activated V1 receptor coupled to? Gq"
"ADH activation of the V1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle causes vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure"
"What G-protein receptor is the ADH-activated V2 receptor coupled to? Gs"
"The V2 receptor for ADH is located on the basolateral membrane of the collecting duct"
"ADH-activated V2 receptors cause translocation of aquaporin 2 channels to the renal apical membrane, causing increased reabsorption of free water"
"Extra-renal ADH-activated V2 receptors are located on the vascular endothelium"
"ADH activation of the V2 receptor on vascular endothelium causes release of von Willebrand factor (vWF) and factor VIII"
"What anti-psychotic drug is a common cause of drug-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus? Lithium"
"One class of drugs that may treat nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is thiazide diuretics, which enhances the uptake of NaCl and H2O in the proximal tubule"
"Amiloride is a K+ sparing diuretic that may be used to treat Lithium induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus"
"Amiloride is useful for the treatment of lithium-induced diabetes insipidus"
"NSAIDs, such as indomethacin, may be used to treat nephrogenic diabetes insipidus"
"Central diabetes insipidus may be treated with exogenous administration of ADH"
"Desmopressin (DDAVP), a long-acting synthetic analog of ADH, may be used to treat central diabetes insipidus"
"Desmopressin (DDAVP) has high specificity for the ADH-activated V2 receptor"
"In addition to central diabetes insipidus, desmopressin (DDAVP) may be used to treat von Willebrand disease, which is associated with increased bruisability and mucosal bleeding"
"In addition to central diabetes insipidus, desmopressin (DDAVP) may be used to treat hemophilia A, which is associated with hemarthrosis and prolonged bleeding after minor procedures"
"Desmopressin may be used to treat night enuresis (bed wetting)"
"What adverse effect may desmopressin (DDAVP) have on sodium levels? Hyponatremia"
"Exogenous ADH is useful in the management of esophageal variceal bleeding by reducing portal hypertension (via action on V1 receptors)"
"-Vaptans (tolvaptan, conivaptan) are the first line treatment for treatment of SIADH"
"What adverse effect may -vaptans (tolvaptan, conivaptan) have on sodium levels? Hypernatremia"
"What is a serious complication of vaptans (e.g. tolvaptan, conivaptan) that may occur if SIADH-induced hyponatremia is corrected too quickly? Central pontine myelinolysis (osmotic demyelination syndrome)"
"Which tetracycline may be used as a second line treatment in the treatment of SIADH? Demeclocycline"
"Which treatment for SIADH may end up causing nephrogenic diabetes insipidus? Demeclocycline"
"What adverse effects are associated with demeclocycline? Photosensitivity and abnormalities of bone/teeth (e.g. discolored teeth)::2"
"Which type of receptor is associated with growth hormone? Receptor associated tyrosine kinase"
"Through what hormone does growth hormone exert its growth promoting effects? Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1)"
"What hormone is responsible for long bone growth (pubertal growth spurt)? IGF-1"
"Growth hormone stimulates the liver to produce IGF-1"
"Growth hormone has anabolic::anabolic/catabolic effects in muscle"
"Growth hormone has catabolic::anabolic/catabolic effects in adipose tissue"
"Growth hormone may be administered exogenously for the treatment of GH deficiency"
"Growth hormone is a hormone that may be used to treat Prader-Willi syndrome, an autosomal dominant genetic disease associated with growth failure, obesity, and carbohydrate intolerance"
"Growth hormone is a hormone that may be used for treatment of Turner syndrome, which is characterized by an XO genotype"
"Mecasermin is a recombinant form of IGF-1 that may be used to treat growth failure due to severe IGF-1 deficiency"
"A metabolic adverse effect of mecasermin, a recombinant IGF-1, is hypoglycemia"
"Growth hormone secreting pituitary adenoma causes acromegaly (adults) or gigantism (children)"
"Octreotide (somatostatin analog) may be used to treat acromegaly and gigantism if symptoms persist after trans-sphenoidal resection"
"What hormone analog may be used to treat VIPoma and carcinoid syndrome? Octreotide (somatostatin analog)"
"What hormone analog may be used to treat insulinoma, glucagonoma, and gastrinoma? Octreotide (somatostatin analog)"
"Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, may be useful in the management of esophageal variceal bleeding by reducing portal blood flow and variceal pressure"
"Octreotide may cause GI side effects"
"Octreotide can cause steatorrhea due to decreased pancreatic secretions and gallbladder contractility"
"Cabergoline and bromocriptine are D2 receptor agonists, which may be used to treat acromegaly by inhibiting secretion of GH from the anterior pituitary"
"In addition to treatment of acromegaly, cabergoline and bromocriptine (D2 receptor agonists) may be useful in the treatment of hyper-prolactinemia (e.g. prolactinoma)"
"Pegvisomant is a(n) GH receptor antagonist, which may be used to treat acromegaly"
"Which hormone-secreting pancreatic tumor is associated with necrolytic migratory erythema? Glucagonoma"
"Dexamethasone, hydrocortisone, and prednisone are all examples of glucocorticoids"
"Once bound (activated), the glucocorticoid receptor enters the nucleus and binds to glucocorticoid response elements to regulate gene transcription"
"What is the effect of glucocorticoids on production of phospholipase A2? Decreased (inhibition)"
"Glucocorticoids prevent production of arachidonic acid by inhibiting phospholipase A2"
"Glucocorticoids inhibit production of inflammatory prostaglandins by cyclooxygenase"
"Glucocorticoids inhibit production of inflammatory leukotrienes by lipoxygenase"
"Glucocorticoids prevent activation of T cells and B cells by inhibiting production of proinflammatory cytokines (e.g. IL-2)"
"Glucocorticoids prevent production of neutrophil adhesion molecules, causing demargination and subsequent neutrophilia"
"What is the effect of glucocorticoids on blood neutrophil levels? Increased (neutrophilia)"
"What is the effect of glucocorticoids on blood lymphocyte levels? Decreased (especially T-helper cells)"
"What is the effect of glucocorticoids on blood peripheral eosinophil levels? Decreased (reduced)"
"Glucocorticoids are useful for treating inflammatory disorders (e.g. gout, rheumatoid arthritis, asthma, IBD)"
"Glucocorticoids are useful for immunosuppressive therapy (e.g. transplant rejection prevention, treatment of autoimmune disorders)"
"What is the effect of glucocorticoids on insulin resistance? Increases resistance"
"Glucocorticoids stimulate gluconeogenesis by the liver, which may cause hyperglycemia"
"Glucocorticoids increase hepatic glycogen storage"
"Abrupt withdrawal of glucocorticoids may cause tertiary adrenal insufficiency"
"Glucocorticoids have a(n) catabolic::anabolic/catabolic effect on peripheral skeletal muscle"
"Glucocorticoids have a(n) catabolic::anabolic/catabolic effect on peripheral fat tissue"
"Glucocorticoids inhibit the proliferation of fibroblasts thus impairing the process of wound healing"
"Glucocorticoids may cause osteoporosis due to inhibition of osteoblast activity *bonus: what supplements should be taken to prevent this?"
"High-dose glucocorticoids may cause glucocorticoid-induced psychosis (e.g. hypomania, confusion, hallucinations)"
"High dose Glucocorticoids may exert mineralocorticoid effects leading to increased potassium excretion"
"Glucocorticoid use may cause candidiasis and reactivation of latent infections, such as tuberculosis"
"What type of diabetes may be induced by glucocorticoid use? Steroid diabetes"
"Glucocorticoids may cause peptic ulcers::specific as an adverse GI effect"
"Which two hormones or hormone analogs may be used for the management of esophageal variceal bleeding? Desmopressin (ADH analog) and octreotide (somatostatin analog)"
"How does minute ventilation change during pregnancy? Increased"
"What is the purpose of decreased maternal PCO2 during pregnancy? Facilitate CO2 elimination from the fetus"
"Around which weeks of pregnancy do the levels of hCG peak? weeks 8-10"
"When grading a females obstetrical status using GTPAL, what does G represent? Gravidity (the total # of pregnancies)"
"When grading a female's obstetrical status using GTPAL, what does T represent? Term deliveries (the total # of deliveries after 37 weeks)"
"When grading a females obstetrical status using GTPAL, what does P represent? Pre-term deliveries (the total # of deliveries after 20 weeks, but before 37 weeks)"
"When grading a female's obstetrical status, what does A represent? Abortions (the total # of deliveries before 20 weeks)"
"When grading a females obstetrical status using GTPAL, what does L represent? Number of living children"
"The four components of a prenatal quad screen are: 1. AFP 2. hCG 3. Estriol 4. Inhibin A"
"Compared to normal, what changes detected by a neonatal quad screen would be indicative of trisomy 21? AFP: decreased Estriol: decreased hCG: increased** Inhibin A: increased**"
"Compared to normal, what changes detected by a neonatal quad screen would be indicative of trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome)? AFP: decreased Estriol: decreased hCG: decreased Inhibin A: normal or decreased"
"Which trisomy(trisomies) are characterized by increased levels of hCG? Trisomy 21 (down syndrome)"
"Which trisomy(trisomies) are characterized by decreased levels of hCG? Trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome), trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome)"
"What is the effect of multiple gestations (e.g. twins, triplets) on hCG levels? Increased"
"Amniocentesis may be done as early as 15 to 17 weeks"
"Chorionic villus sampling may be done as early as 10 to 13 weeks"
"What is the risk of fetal loss in amniocentesis? What about chorionic villus sampling? 0.5% in amniocentesis versus 1% in CVS"
"What is a possible adverse effect associated with performing chorionic villus sampling before 9 weeks? Limb defects"
"The inability to detect neural tube defects is a downside of chorionic villus sampling when compared to amniocentesis"
"What day of fetal development is characterized by chorion formation? Day 4 (thus twins that split after day 4 are monochorionic)"
"What day of fetal development is characterized by amnion formation? Day 8 (thus twins that split after day 8 are monoamniotic)"
"The presence of 1 yolk sac with 2 fetal poles is indicative of monoamniotic twins"
"The presence of cord entanglement is indicative of monoamniotic twins"
"What is a possible complication of monochorionic twins as a result of anastamosis? Twin-twin transfusion syndrome"
"In twin-twin transfusion syndrome, the donor is anemic, pale, and has restricted growth"
"In twin-twin transfusion syndrome, the recipient is polycythemic, overloaded, and at risk for heart failure"
"Which two phospholipids are abundant in surfactant? Lecithin (phosphatidylcholine) and sphingomyelin"
"The umbilical arteries return deoxygenated blood from the fetal internal iliac arteries to the placenta"
"A(n) patent urachus occurs due to total failure of the urachus to obliterate"
"A patent urachus presents as a straw colored urine discharge from the umbilicus with erythema around the area"
"A(n) urachal cyst is due to partial failure of the urachus to obliterate, resulting in a fluid-filled cyst"
"A(n) urachal cyst presents as a fluid-filled cavity lined with uroepithelium, between the umbilicus and bladder"
"A(n) vesicourachal diverticulum is a diverticulum due to a slight failure of the urachus to obliterate"
"A vesicourachal diverticulum presents as outpouching of the bladder"
"The medial umbilical folds are remnants of the obliterated umbilical arteries"
"The median umbilical ligament is a remnant of the obliterated urachus"
"The ligamentum teres hepatis (round ligament of the liver) is a remnant of the obliterated umbilical vein"
"Invasive mole is typically the malignant progression of a(n) complete hydatidiform mole"
"Invasive moles are diagnosed by histologic evidence of villi invading the myometrium on a hysterectomy specimen"
"Causes of hypertension (e.g. cocaine, smoking, and preeclampsia) all increase the risk for placental abruption"
"Placental abruption may be diagnosed using the Kleihauer-Betke test, which looks for fetal RBC in the maternal blood"
"Vasa previa is a complication of pregnancy that occurs when fetal vessels run over, or in close proximity to, the cervical os"
"What pregnancy complication is associated with painful third trimester bleeding? Placental abruption"
"Oligohydramnios is the presence of too little amniotic fluid and may be associated with placental insufficiency, bilateral renal agenesis, and posterior urethral valves (inability to excrete urine)"
"What is the treatment for preeclampsia or eclampsia to prevent seizures? IV magnesium sulfate"
"What level of proteinuria is required to make a diagnosis of preeclampsia? ≥ 300 mg/day"
"What is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage? Uterine atony"
"The main causes of post-partum hemorrhage may be remembered with the \4 T's\\": 1. Uterine aTony (most common) 2. Trauma (lacerations"
"What chemotherapeutic drug is used in the treatment of an ectopic pregnancy? Methotrexate"
"Klinefelter syndrome characterized by the presence of an inactivated X chromosome (Barr body)"
"Is Turner syndrome characterized by the presence of an inactivated X chromosome (Barr body)? No (45,XO)"
"Which two breast pathologies affect the stroma of the breast tissue? Fibroadenoma and phyllodes tumor"
"What type of breast cancer may present with signet ring cells? Lobular carcinoma (both in situ and invasive)"
"Gynecomastia is defined as breast enlargement in males due to increased estrogen compared with androgen activity"
"Physiologic gynecomastia may occur in newborn, pubertal, and elderly males"
"What drugs are commonly associated with gynecomastia? Spironolactone, Hormones, Cimetidine, and Ketoconazole::4"
"Gynecomastia is associated with increased levels of estrogen (e.g. cirrhosis::liver), decreased levels of androgens (ex Klinefelter syndrome), or testicular tumors (ex. Leydig cell tumor)"
"What type of ovarian neoplasm is often described as a yellow, friable (hemorrhagic) solid mass? Yolk sac (endodermal sinus) tumor"
"Which ovarian neoplasm is most commonly associated with an increased LDH? Dysgerminoma"
"Which ovarian neoplasm is most commonly associated with an increased AFP? Yolk sac (endodermal sinus) tumor"
"Theca-lutein cysts are often associated with choriocarcinoma and hydatidiform moles"
"What is the treatment of choice for a pregnant women with hyperthyroidism in the first trimester? Propylthiouracil (PTU)"
"Propylthiouracil (PTU) is used to treat hyperthyroidism by blocking both thyroid peroxidase and 5'-deiodinase"
"Methimazole is used to treat hyperthyroidism by blocking thyroid peroxidase only"
"What is a possible skin complication associated with propylthiouracil and methimazole? Rash"
"Levothyroxine is a T4 hormone analog used to treat hypothyroidism and myxedema"
"Triiodothyronine is a T3 hormone analog used to treat hypothyroidism and myxedema"
"What is a possible off-label use of the thyroid hormone replacement therapy (e.g. levothyroxine and triiodothyronine)? Weight loss supplement"
"Which pituitary hormone is useful for stimulating labor via the induction of uterine contractions? Oxytocin"
"Fludrocortisone is a synthetic analog of aldosterone with little glucocorticoid effects"
"What drug may be used to replace mineralocorticoids in primary adrenal insufficiency? Fludrocortisone (aldosterone analog)"
"What is a possible skin complication associated with fludrocortisone? Hyperpigmentation"
"Possible adverse effects of fludrocortisone, an aldosterone analog, include edema and exacerbation of heart failure"
"What drug acts by increasing sensitivity of Ca2+-sensing receptors in the parathyroid gland? Cinacalcet"
"Cinacalcet may be used in the treatment of primary or secondary hyperparathyroidism by increasing sensitivity to Ca2+-sensing receptors"
"What adverse effect is associated with cinacalcet? Hypocalcemia (due to decreased PTH)"
"What enzyme is responsible for metabolizing sorbitol into fructose? sorbitol dehydrogenase"
"What is an adverse effect common to all antacids? Hypokalemia"
"Which antacid is associated with constipation if overused? Aluminum hydroxide"
"Which antacid is associated with diarrhea if overused? Magnesium hydroxide"
"Which antacid is associated with proximal muscle weakness and seizures if overused? Aluminum hydroxide"
"Which antacid is associated with hypophosphatemia and osteodystrophy if overused? Aluminum hydroxide"
"Which antacid is associated with hypercalcemia (milk-alkali syndrome) and rebound acid increase? Calcium carbonate"
"Antacids can affect bioavailability of other drugs by altering gastric and urinary pH"
"What drugs are characterized by binding to an ulcer base and providing physical protection? Bismuth, sucralfate::2"
"Bismuth and sucralfate may be used to increase ulcer healing"
"In addition to increased ulcer healing, bismuth and sucralfate may be used to treat travelers diarrhea"
"Sulfasalazine is a combination of sulfapyridine (anti-bacterial) and 5-aminosalicylic acid (anti-inflammatory)"
"Sulfasalazine is a combination drug that may be used to treat ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease (colitis component)"
"Sulfasalazine is activated by colonic bacteria"
"One adverse effect of sulfasalazine is reversible oligospermia"
"What is the clinical use for orlistat? Weight loss"
"A major adverse effect of orlistat is steatorrhea, which may lead to decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins"
"Orlistat is an inhibitor of gastric and pancreatic lipase, thus leading to decreased breakdown and absorption of dietary fats"
"Ursodeoxycholic acid (ursodiol) is a non-toxic bile acid used in the treatment of early primary biliary cirrhosis"
"Ursodeoxycholic acid (ursodiol) may be used in the prevention or dissolution of gallstones"
"Ursodeoxycholic acid acts via increasing bile secretion and decreasing cholesterol secretion/reabsorption"
"What drug may be used to treat diabetic or post-surgical gastroparesis by increasing resting tone, contractility, and LES tone? Metoclopramide (D2 receptor antagonist)"
"Does metoclopramide, a D2 receptor antagonist, influence colon transport time? No"
"How do levels of AFP change in a fetus with neural tube defects? Increased"
"Which ulcerative colitis drug is associated with reversible oligospermia? Sulfasalazine"
"A(n) nucleosome (10 nm chromatin) is negatively charged DNA wrapped around the outside of positively charged proteins called histones"
"Histones are rich in the amino acids lysine and arginine"
"What class of histone is not found as a pair in a nucleosome? H1"
"What class of histone is found outside the nucleosome and functions to condense the nucleosome together? H1"
"What classes of histones are found as a pair in the nucleosome? H2A, H2B, H3, H4::4"
"What is the function of the H1 class of histones? Condense/link the nucleosomes together"
"A(n) nucleosome is made up of a strand of DNA wrapped nearly twice around two copies of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4"
"In mitosis::cell cycle phase, DNA condenses to form chromosomes"
"What cell cycle phase do DNA and histone synthesis occur? S phase"
"What form of chromatin is highly condensed? Heterochromatin"
"What form of chromatin is less condensed? Euchromatin"
"What form of chromatin appears darker on EM? Heterochromatin"
"What form of chromatin appears lighter on EM? Euchromatin"
"What form of chromatin is transcriptionally inactive and sterically inaccessible? Heterochromatin"
"What form of chromatin is transcriptionally active and sterically accessible? Euchromatin"
"What form of chromatin do Barr bodies exist as? Heterochromatin"
"Heterochromatin is the highest order of packaging of the chromosome"
"Without H1, the nucleosome exists as 10 nm chromatin"
"With H1, the nucleosome exists as 30 nm chromatin"
"What process is used by mismatch repair enzymes to distinguish between old and new DNA strands in prokaryotes? DNA methylation"
"DNA methylation at CpG islands represses transcription"
"What process is used to genomically \imprint\\" DNA during embryogenesis? DNA Methylation\""
"Histone methylation usually reversibly represses DNA transcription"
"Histone acetylation usually activates DNA transcription"
"What process takes DNA and makes more DNA? Replication"
"What process takes DNA and makes RNA? transcription"
"What process takes RNA and makes protein? translation"
"What process takes RNA and makes DNA? reverse transcription"
"DNA is much larger::size than RNA"
"Are RNA and protein typically fragmented before analysis? No"
"Is DNA typically fragmented before analysis? Yes"
"How many ring(s) do purines have? Two"
"How many ring(s) do pyrimidines have? One"
"Which bases are purines? Adenine and guanine"
"Which bases are pyrimidines? Cytosine, uracil, and thymine"
"Which purine is characterized by an amino group at the 12 o'clock position? Adenine"
"Which purine is characterized by no amino group at the 12 o'clock position? Guanine"
"Which pyrimidine is characterized by an amino group at the 12 o'clock position? Cytosine"
"Which pyrimidine is characterized by no amino group at the 12 o'clock position AND no methyl group(s)? Uracil"
"Which pyrimidine is characterized by the presence of methyl groups, but no amino group at the 12 o'clock position? Thymine"
"Deamination of cytosine makes uracil"
"What is the difference (structurally) between thymine and uracil? Thymine has a methyl group, uracil does not"
"Which pyrimidine is found in DNA only? Thymine"
"Which pyrimidine is found in RNA only? Uracil"
"A(n) nucleoSide is a base plus a sugar (ribose or deoxyribose)"
"A(n) nucleoTide is a base plus a sugar (ribose or deoxyribose) plus phosphate"
"What is the nucleoSide that is made with adenine? Adenosine"
"What is the nucleoSide that is made with guanine? Guanosine"
"What is the nucleoSide that is made with cytosine? Cytidine"
"What is the nucleoSide that is made with uracil? Uridine"
"What is the nucleoSide that is made with thymine? Thymidine"
"Which carbon lacks a hydroxyl group in DNA strands? 2' carbon"
"DNA & RNA are made of nucleotide monophosphates connected via a(n) phosphodiester bond"
"Generally, the 3' end of DNA or RNA is a(n) hydroxyl group"
"Bases of a DNA strand are complementary and held together by hydrogen bonds"
"How many hydrogen bonds exist between a G-C base pairing? Three"
"How many hydrogen bonds exist between an A-T base pairing? Two"
"What is the effect of increased G-C content on the melting temperature of a DNA strand? Increased melting temperature"
"What amino acids are necessary for purine synthesis? Glycine, Aspartate, Glutamine::3"
"One feature of the genetic code is that it is unambiguous: each codon specifies only 1 amino acid"
"One feature of the genetic code is that it is degenerate/redundant: most amino acids are coded by multiple codons"
"One feature of the genetic code is that it is commaless, nonoverlapping: it is read from a fixed starting point as a continuous sequence of bases"
"One feature of the genetic code is that it is universal: genetic code is conserved throughout evolution"
"How many possible combinations of 3 base codons are there? 64"
"Of the 64 possible codons, how many encode amino acids? 61 (3 are stop codons)"
"How many amino acids are made from the 64 possible codons? 20"
"Which sequence of bases is a start codon (methionine) in mRNA? AUG"
"What does AUG encode for in eukaryotes? Methionine (start codon)"
"What does AUG encode for in prokaryotes? N-formylmethionine, or fMet (start codon)"
"Which three sequences of bases are mRNA stop codons? UGA, UAA, UAG"
"The origin of replication is a particular consensus sequence of base pairs in a genome where DNA replication begins"
"AT-rich sequences are found in promoters and origins of replication"
"The replication fork is a Y-shaped region along the DNA template where leading and lagging strands are synthesized"
"Which enzyme is responsible for unwinding the DNA template at the replication fork? Helicase"
"Single-stranded binding proteins prevent DNA strands from reannealing during replication"
"Which enzyme is responsible for relaxing the DNA strand by creating single- or double-stranded breaks in the DNA helix to add/remove supercoils? Topoisomerase"
"What is another name for prokaryotic topoisomerase II? DNA gyrase"
"What class of drugs inhibits prokaryotic topoisomerase II and topoisomerase IV? Fluoroquinolones"
"What chemotherapeutic drugs (2) inhibit eukaryotic topoisomerase II? etoposide/teniposide"
"Which enzyme is responsible for making an RNA primer on which DNA polymerase III can initiate replication (prokaryotes)? Primase"
"Which enzyme is responsible for elongating the DNA strand? DNA polymerase (specifically, DNA polymerase III in prokaryotes)"
"DNA polymerase must see a(n) RNA primer to bind, which is complementary and antiparallel to the polymerase"
"DNA/RNA polymerase always read in the 3' to 5' direction"
"DNA/RNA polymerase always build in the 5' to 3' direction"
"DNA polymerase pauses and checks (\proof-reads\\") via 3' -> 5' exonuclease activity\""
"Is DNA synthesis high or low fidelity? High"
"Which enzymes are responsible for removing the RNA primer in eukaryotes? RNase H and FEN-1::2"
"Which enzyme catalyzes the formation of a phosphodiester bond between Okazaki fragments? DNA ligase"
"The enzyme which adds TTAGGG::sequence to 3' ends of chromosomes to avoid loss of genetic material with every duplication is known as Telomerase"
"Which replication enzyme is a RNA-dependent DNA polymerase, and thus a major example of reverse transcriptase activity, in humans? Telomerase"
"Telomerase is a rare example where reverse transcriptase::enzyme activity occurs endogenously in humans"
"What pathology is associated with increased telomerase activity? Cancer"
"What pathology is associated with decreased telomerase activity? Progeria (premature aging)"
"RNA polymerase doesn't have to see a RNA primer to bind"
"Does RNA polymerase have 3' exonuclease activity (proof-reading)? No"
"Is RNA synthesis high or low fidelity? Low (no proof-reading)"
"Which type of DNA mutation causes the least severe damage? Silent mutations"
"Which type of DNA mutation causes the most severe damage? frameshift mutations"
"A(n) transition is type of DNA mutation in which a purine is mutated to another purine (or pyrimidine to pyrimidine)"
"A(n) transversion is a type of DNA mutation in which a purine is mutated into a pyrimidine, and vice versa"
"What class of DNA mutations are characterized by a single nucleotide change? Point mutations"
"A(n) silent mutation occurs when a nucleotide substitution codes for the same amino acid"
"A(n) missense mutation occurs when a nucleotide substitution codes for a different amino acid"
"A(n) nonsense mutation occurs when a nucleotide substitution codes for a stop codon"
"A(n) frameshift mutation occurs when there is a deletion or insertion of a number of nucleotides not divisible by 3, resulting in misreading of all nucleotides downstream"
"A mutation at a(n) splice site results in a retained intron in the mRNA, leading to a protein with impaired or altered function"
"Lac Operon: In the presence of low glucose, there is increased adenylyl cyclase activity, leading to an increase in cAMP"
"Lac Operon: Increased cAMP (low glucose) leads to activation of catabolite activator protein (CAP), which resides upstream from the promoter, causing increased transcription"
"Lac Operon: In the presence of high lactose, the repressor protein is unbound from the operator site, leading to increased transcription"
"Lac Operon: What is the expression level of the Lac genes in the presence of low glucose and lactose available? Strong expression"
"Lac Operon: What is the expression level of the Lac genes in the presence of high glucose and lactose unavailable? No expression"
"Lac Operon: What is the expression level of the Lac genes in the presence of low glucose and lactose unavailable? No expression"
"Lac Operon: What is the expression level of the Lac genes in the presence of high glucose and lactose available? Low (basal) expression"
"What mutation is induced by UV radiation? Pyrimidine dimers (e.g. thymine dimers)"
"What form of DNA repair fixes mutations induced by UV radiation? Nucleotide excision repair"
"The enzyme that recognizes and excises pyrimidine dimer mutations is excision endonuclease"
"The enzymes that repair pyrimidine dimer mutations are DNA polymerase and DNA ligase"
"What phase of the cell cycle do nucleotide excision repairs occur? G1"
"Xeroderma Pigmentosum is an inherited pathology due to a defective Nucleotide Excision Repair pathway"
"DNA replication errors lead to mismatch base mutations"
"What form of DNA repair fixes mutations due to DNA replication errors? Mismatch repair"
"Recognition and facilitation of excision of mismatched nucleotides occur via enzymes found on two genes: MSH2 (MutS) or MLH1 (MutL)"
"The enzymes that repair mismatched base mutations are DNA polymerase and DNA ligase"
"What pathology is characterized by a deficiency of the enzymes used in mismatch base repair? Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer [HNPCC])"
"What phase of the cell cycle do mismatch base repairs predominantly occur? S"
"Deamination (e.g. cytosine to uracil) is a mutation that may occur spontaneously or due to heat or nitrates"
"What form of DNA repair fixes mutations due to spontaneous/toxic deamination? Base excision repair"
"In base excision repair, base-specific glycosylases remove the altered base and create a(n) AP (apurinic/apyrimidinic) site"
"Which base excision repair enzyme is responsible for removing nucleotides at the 5' end? AP-endonuclease"
"Which base excision repair enzyme is responsible for removing nucleotides at the 3' end? Lyase"
"Which base excision repair enzymes are responsible for filling and sealing the gap from the excised bases? DNA polymerase-β::specific (filling) and DNA ligase III::specific (sealing)"
"What phase of the cell cycle do base excision repairs occur? Throughout the cell cycle"
"Which forms of DNA repair repairs double-stranded breaks (due to ionizing radiation)? Nonhomologous end joining and homologous recombination"
"Mechanisms to repair dsDNA breaks are defective in Ataxia telangiectasia, Fanconi anemia, and SCID"
"The direction of protein synthesis is N-terminus to C-terminus"
"The triphosphate bond of DNA is the target of 3' hydroxyl attack (strand elongation)"
"Drugs that block DNA replication often have a modified 3' OH, preventing addition of the next nucleotide (\chain termination\\")\""
"Does reverse transcriptase require a primer? Yes! Because it is a DNA polymerase (RNA dependent DNA polymerase)"
"While DNA polymerase binds to a primer, RNA polymerase binds to a(n) promoter"
"The template strand is the dsDNA strand used for transcription; it is complementary and antiparallel to mRNA"
"The coding strand is the strand of dsDNA that is NOT used during transcription, but is identical to mRNA (substitute T/U)"
"Where is most of rRNA synthesized? Nucleolus"
"Where is most mRNA / tRNA synthesized? Euchromatin (nucleus)::chromatin"
"The dsDNA sequence reported in databases is the coding strand, unless specifically stated otherwise"
"Practice: If a DNA template sequence is TAGC, what is the mRNA sequence? GCUA"
"The untranslated region (UTR) of mRNA is the portion of mRNA which contains no protein information"
"Does prokaryotic mRNA have introns and exons? No"
"Does prokaryotic mRNA have post-transcriptional processing? No"
"Prokaryotic transcription terminates when there is a \stem-loop\\" sequence"
"Prokaryotic translation begins when a ribosome binds a(n) Shine-Dalgarno sequence"
"In eukaryotes, each gene has it's own promoter, to which RNA polymerase II may bind"
"The initial mRNA of eukaryotes contains introns and exons, which undergo splicing"
"Eukaryotic translation begins when a ribosome binds a(n) 7-methyl-G-cap"
"The promoter is the site where RNA polymerase II and general transcription factors bind to DNA upstream from a gene locus"
"The promoter is an AT-rich upstream sequence with TATA and CAAT boxes"
"A mutation in the promoter commonly results in a dramatic decrease in the level of gene transcription"
"Promoters serve as binding sites for general::general/specific transcription factors"
"Enhancers are stretches of DNA that increase gene expression by binding specific transcription factors"
"Silencers are sites where negative regulators (repressors) bind to DNA"
"Enhancers increase transcription via enhanced activity of the enzyme RNA polymerase II"
"Enhancers serve as binding sites for specific::specific/general transcription factors"
"Are enhancers/silencers close or far from the gene it regulates? May be close to, far from, or within the gene (in an intron)"
"Within an enhancer, there are domains known as response elements (RE), to which specific transcription factors bind"
"How can enhancers be far away from the gene it regulates? DNA will bend to bring enhancer to promoter"
"Steroid receptors are specific transcription factors that bind to steroid response elements to cause a steroid response"
"What class of protein receptor is common to all steroid hormones, thyroid hormones, and vitamins A/D? Zinc finger"
"cAMP response element binding (CREB) proteins are specific transcription factors that bind to cAMP response elements (CREs) to cause a response to cAMP"
"What class of protein receptor is common to cAMP response element binding (CREB) proteins? Leucine zipper"
"Homeodomain proteins are specific transcription factors that regulate gene expression during development"
"The genes that are responsible for the generation of homeodomain proteins are the homeobox (HOX) gene and PAX gene"
"What pathology is associated with a defective PAX gene? Klein Waardenburg Syndrome"
"What morning sickness drug (no longer used) inadvertently prevents binding of homeodomain proteins to enhancers, thus causing limb abnormalities? Thalidomide"
"Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) are specific transcription factors that bind to peroxisome proliferator response elements (PPREs) causing increased peroxisome expression"
"What class of drugs acts via activation of PPAR-gamma? Thiazolidinediones"
"What class of drugs acts via activation of PPAR-alpha? Fibrates"
"Nuclear factor kappa B (NF-kB) is a specific transcription factor that binds kB elements, which regulates expression of many genes in the immune system"
"The glucocorticoids class of drugs acts via suppression of NF-kB signaling"
"RNA polymerase I makes rRNA"
"RNA polymerase II makes mRNA"
"RNA polymerase III makes tRNA and 5S rRNA"
"Which RNA polymerase binds to DNA at a promoter site? RNA polymerase II"
"In eukaryotes, RNA polymerase II may be inhibited by α-amanitin"
"What drug is an inhibitor of prokaryotic RNA polymerase? Rifampin"
"What drug is an inhibitor of both prokaryotic AND eukaryotic RNA polymerase? Actinomycin D"
"How many different RNA polymerases do prokaryotes have? One (makes all 3 kinds of RNA)"
"The initial (primary) transcript transcribed from eukaryotic DNA is heterogenous nuclear RNA (hnRNA)"
"Capped, tailed, and spliced hnRNA is called mRNA"
"In what part of the cell is mRNA formed? Nucleus"
"In what part of the cell is mRNA translated? Cytosol"
"One co-transcriptional modification is the addition of a(n) 7-methylguanosine cap at the 5' end"
"One post-transcriptional modification is the addition of a(n) poly-A tail at the 3' end"
"One post-transcriptional modification is the splicing out of introns"
"Does Poly-A polymerase require a template (post-transcriptional processing)? No"
"What sequence of bases represents a polyadenylation signal? AAUAAA::6"
"mRNA quality control occurs at cytoplasmic processing bodies (P-bodies), which contain exonucleases, decapping enzymes, and microRNAs"
"mRNAs may be stored in P-bodies for future translation"
"In the first step of alternative splicing, the primary transcript (hnRNA) combines with small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPS) and other proteins to form the spliceosome"
"After the spliceosome has been formed in alternative splicing, a(n) lariat-shaped (looped) intermediate is generated"
"In the final step of alternative splicing, the lariat is released to precisely remove the intron and join two exons"
"Antibodies to spliceosomal snRNPs, also known as anti-Smith antibodies, are highly specific for SLE"
"Antibodies to U1 RNP are highly associated with mixed connective tissue disease"
"Every intron has a 5' donor GU site and a 3' acceptor AG site, which are brought together to form the Lariat-shaped loop"
"Which portion of eukaryotic hnRNA contains the actual genetic information coding for protein? Exons"
"Which portion of eukaryotic hnRNA contains intervening noncoding segments of DNA? Introns"
"Different exons are frequently combined by alternative splicing to produce a larger number of unique proteins"
"One hematological pathology that is due to abnormal splicing variants is β-thalassemia"
"rRNAs are the most abundant RNAs"
"microRNAs are small, noncoding RNA molecules that post-transcriptionally regulate protein expression"
"microRNA often leads to the silencing/inactivation of target mRNA, thus causing decreased translation into protein"
"Abnormal expression of miRNAs contributes to certain malignancies (e.g. by silencing an mRNA from a tumor suppressor gene)"
"tRNAs are the smallest RNAs and have a clover-leaf structure"
"At the base of a tRNA molecule is a(n) anti-codon loop, which base pairs with a codon of mRNA in a complementary, antiparallel fashion"
"At the 3' end of a tRNA molecule is a(n) 5'-CCA-3' sequence, which is the amino acid acceptor stem"
"The T-arm of tRNA contains the TΨC sequence (ribothymidine, pseudouridine, cytidine) necessary for tRNA-ribosome binding"
"What is the function of the T-arm of tRNA? tRNA-ribosome binding"
"The D-arm of tRNA contains dihydrouridine residues necessary for tRNA recognition by the correct aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase"
"What is the function of the D-arm of tRNA? Recognition of tRNA by the correct aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase"
"tRNA is joined with its specific amino acid via the enzyme aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase"
"Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase requires ATP and releases inorganic PPi"
"A(n) mischarged tRNA reads its usual codon but inserts the wrong amino acid"
"Accurate base pairing is usually required only in the first two nucleotide positions of a mRNA codon because codons differing in the 3rd \wobble\\" position may code for the same amino acid\""
"Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase and binding of charged tRNA to the codon are responsible for accuracy of amino acid selection"
"The bond formed between an α-carboxyl group and an α-amino group of adjacent amino acids is a(n) peptide bond"
"Peptide bond formation is facilitated by the ribozyme peptidyl transferase"
"What is the smaller ribosomal subunit used in prokaryotic translation? 30s"
"What is the larger ribosomal subunit used in prokaryotic translation? 50s"
"What is the total size of the ribosome used in prokaryotic translation? 70s"
"What is the smaller ribosomal subunit used in eukaryotic translation? 40s"
"What is the larger ribosomal subunit used in eukaryotic translation? 60s"
"What is the total size of the ribosome used in eukaryotic translation? 80s"
"Eukaryotic Initiation Factors help assemble the 40s ribosomal subunit with the initiator tRNA"
"Which nucleotide triphosphate is used in the charging of tRNA? ATP"
"Where in the cell does translation begin? Cytoplasm"
"The 40s ribosomal subunit initiates translation by binding to the 7-methylguanosine cap"
"The 30s ribosomal subunit initiates translation by binding to the shine-dalgarno sequence"
"Translation is initiated by GTP hydrolysis"
"At what site of the ribosome does tRNA bind to for translation initiation? P site"
"Which tRNA binds to the P site of the ribosome to initiate translation? Methionine-tRNA"
"tRNA binds to the A site on the ribosome for elongation"
"Which nucleotide triphosphate is used in the translocation of tRNA? GTP"
"In the first step of strand elongation, a(n) aminoacyl-tRNA binds to the A site"
"After aminoacyl-tRNA binds to the A site of the ribosome, peptidyl transferase, a ribozyme, catalyzes peptide bond formation (translation)"
"In the final step of translation elongation, translocation of the ribosome occurs, advancing the ribosome 3 nucleotides towards the 3' end of mRNA"
"Translocation of the ribosome during translation moves peptidyl tRNA from the A site to the P site"
"In addition to GTP, translocation of the ribosome during translation also requires eukaryotic elongation factor 2 (eEF-2)"
"The E site of the ribosome holds empty tRNA as it exits"
"In the final step of translation, a stop codon is recognized by release factor and the completed polypeptide is released from the ribosome"
"One example of a post-translational modification is trimming, which entails the removal of N- or C-terminal propeptides from a zymogen to generate mature protein"
"One class of post-translational modifications is covalent alterations, which include phosphorylation, glycosylation, hydroxylation, methylation, acetylation, and ubiquitination"
"A(n) chaperone protein, is an intracellular protein involved in facilitating and/or maintaining protein folding"
"What is the shortest phase of the cell cycle? M phase (mitosis + cytokinesis)"
"Which cell cycle phase is characterized by resting, non-dividing cells? G0"
"What cell type remains in G0 and can only regenerate from stem cells? Permanent::Stabile/Permanent/Labile"
"What type of cells are the following examples? Permanent::Labile, Stable, or Permanent?"
"What cell type enters G1 from G0 when stimulated? Stable (quiescent)"
"Hepatocytes, lymphocytes, PCT, and periosteal cells are examples of what cell type? Stable (Quiescent)::Labile, Stable, or Permanent?"
"What cell type never enters G0 and divides rapidly with a short G1? Labile"
"What cell type is affected most by chemotherapy? Labile (gut epithelium, skin, hair follicles, etc)"
"Which cell cycle phase is characterized by DNA synthesis and replication? S"
"Which cell cycle phase(s) are part of interphase? G1, S, G2"
"Which cell cycle phase(s) are NOT part of interphase? M"
"Transcription occurs throughout which cell cycle phases? Interphase (G1, S, G2)"
"Which tumor suppressor protein acts at the G1 check point? p53"
"What part of the cell is the site of synthesis of secretory proteins? Rough endoplasmic reticulum"
"Where in a cell does N-linked oligosaccharide addition take place? Rough endoplasmic reticulum"
"The RER in neurons, known as Nissl bodies, synthesize peptide neurotransmitters for secretion"
"What cellular structure are mucus-secreting goblet cells (small intestine) and antibody-secreting plasma cells rich in? Rough endoplasmic reticulum"
"Free ribosomes are unattached to any membrane and are the site of synthesis for cytosolic and organellar proteins"
"What part of the cell is the site of steroid synthesis and detoxification of drugs and poisons? Smooth endoplasmic reticulum"
"How can the smooth endoplasmic reticulum be distinguished from the rough ER? Smooth ER lacks surface ribosomes"
"When proteins are misfolded, multiple ubiquitins are added, which aids in trafficking to the proteasome"
"The proteasome is a barrel-shaped protein complex that degrades damaged or ubiquitin-tagged proteins"
"Defects in the ubiquitin-proteasome system have been implicated in some cases of Parkinson disease"
"Inside the proteasome, proteases cleave ubiqutinated proteins into peptide fragments"
"Which membrane-bound organelle is involved in the catabolism of very-long-chain fatty acids, branched-chain fatty acids, amino acids, and ethanol? Peroxisome"
"The golgi apparatus is the distribution center for proteins and lipids from the endoplasmic reticulum to the vesicles and plasma membrane"
"On the N terminal side of newly synthesized protein, a stretch of 10-15 hydrophobic amino acids forms the N-terminal signal sequence"
"The N-terminal signal sequence of a newly synthesized protein is bound by a(n) signal recognition particle (SRP), which attaches the complex to the ER membrane"
"Signal recognition particles (SRPs) are abundant, cytosolic ribonucleoproteins that traffic proteins from the ribosome to the RER"
"What would happen if there is absent or dysfunctional signal recognition particles (SRPs)? proteins accumulate in the cytosol"
"In the ER, co-translational N-glycosylation adds sugars onto the amino acid asparagine"
"In the Golgi apparatus, post-translational O-glycosylation adds sugars onto the amino acids serine and threonine"
"Which enzyme phosphorylates mannose in the Golgi apparatus, facilitating protein trafficking? Phosphotransferase"
"In the Golgi apparatus, mannose-6-phosphate is added to proteins for trafficking to lysosomes"
"Defective GlcNAc-1-phosphotransferase causes I-cell disease (inclusion cell disease/mucolipidosis type II)"
"Endosomes are sorting centers for material from outside the cell or from the Golgi, sending it to lysosomes for destruction or back to the membrane/Golgi for further use"
"Which inherited lysosomal storage disorder is characterized by coarse facial features, clouded corneas, and restricted joint movement with high serum levels of multiple lysosomal enzymes? I-cell disease"
"I-cell disease is characterized by high plasma levels of lysosomal enzymes"
"What differentiates I-cell disease from other inclusion body diseases? I-cell has a mixed accumulation of junk forming the inclusion bodies"
"Which vesicular trafficking protein is responsible for retrograde Golgi transport (cis-Golgi and ER) and intra-Golgi transport? COPI"
"Which vesicular trafficking protein is responsible for anterograde Golgi transport (ER to cis Golgi)? COPII"
"Which vesicular trafficking protein is responsible for transport between the trans-Golgi and lysosomes? Clathrin"
"Which vesicular trafficking protein is responsible for transport between the plasma membrane and endosomes (receptor-mediated endocytosis)? Clathrin"
"Cytoskeletal elements are a network of protein fibers within the cytoplasm that support cell structure, cell and organelle movement, and cell division"
"Which type of filament is predominantly involved in muscle contraction and cytokinesis? Microfilaments (e.g. actin, microvilli)"
"Which type of filament is predominantly involved in maintainence of cell structure? Intermediate filaments (e.g. desmin, cytokeratin)"
"Which type of filament is predominantly involved in movement and cell division? Microtubules (e.g. cilia, flagella)"
"What type of filament are actin and microvilli? Microfilament"
"What type of filament are cytokeratin and desmin? Intermediate filaments"
"What type of filament are cilia and flagella? Microtubule"
"Microtubules are a cylindrical outer structure composed of a helical array of polymerized heterodimers of α- and β-tubulin"
"Each α- and β-tubulin heterodimer of a microtubule has 2 GTP bound"
"Microtubules grow slowly::speed and collapse quickly::speed"
"Which type of filament is involved in slow axoplasmic transport in neurons? Microtubules"
"Which molecular motor protein is responsible for retrograde transport to the microtubule (+ to -)? Dynein"
"Which molecular motor protein is responsible for anterograde transport to the microtubule (- to +)? Kinesin"
"Drugs that act on microtubules may be remembered with the mnemonic \Microtubules Get Constructed Very Poorly\\": M: Mebendazole (antihelminthic) G: Griseofulvin (antifungal) C: Colchicine (antigout) V: Vincristine/Vinblastine (anticancer) P: Palcitaxel (anticancer)\""
"Cilia are organized in a(n) 9+2 arrangement of microtubule doublets"
"The base of a cilium below the cell membrane, called the basal body, consists of 9 microtubule triplets with no central microtubules"
"Axonemal dynein is a(n) ATPase that links peripheral 9 doublets and causes bending of cilium (movement)"
"Kartagener syndrome is a(n) autosomal recessive::inheritance disease characterized by immotile cilia due to a(n) dynein arm defect"
"Kartagener syndrome results in decreased male and female fertility"
"Which developmental pathology is characterized by bronchiectasis, recurrent sinusitis, and situs inversus? Kartagener syndrome"
"What do fungal plasma membranes contain that others lack? Ergosterol"
"For each ATP consumed, the sodium-potassium pump transfers 3 Na+ out of the cell (pump phosphorylated)"
"For each ATP consumed, the sodium-potassium pump transfers 2 K+ into the cell (pump dephosphorylated)"
"The Na+-K+ ATPase pump is located in the plasma membrane with the ATP site on the cytosolic side"
"Ouabain is a cardiac glycoside that inhibits the Na+-K+ ATPase pump by binding to the K+ site"
"What class of drugs directly inhibit the Na+-K+ ATPase pump? Cardiac glycosides (e.g. digoxin)"
"What is the most abundant protein in the human body? Collagen"
"The function of collagen is to organize and strengthen the extracellular matrix"
"What type of collagen is the most common (90%)? Type I"
"What type of collagen makes up bone, skin, and tendon? Type I"
"What type of collagen makes up cartilage? Type II"
"What type of collagen makes up skin and blood vessels? Type III"
"What type of collagen makes up reticulin fibers? Type III"
"What type of collagen makes up the basement membrane? Type IV"
"The vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome that is caused by a deficiency of type III collagen can lead to: - the formation and rupture of aneurysms - rupture of organs (ex. in women the uterus::specific organ during birth)"
"What type of collagen is decreased in osteogenesis imperfecta type I? Type I"
"What pathology is characterized by a defective type IV collagen? Alport syndrome"
"Type IV collagen is targeted by autoantibodies in Goodpasture syndrome"
"Collagen is a repeat of a tripeptide following the pattern Gly-X-Y, made by fibroblasts"
"One third of the collagen strand is made of the amino acid glycine"
"In the first step of collagen synthesis, translation of collagen alpha chains forms preprocollagen"
"Collagen Synthesis: After the collagen alpha chains are synthesized, specific residues of the amino acids proline and lysine are hydroxylated"
"Collagen Synthesis: Hydroxylation of selected prolines and lysines during collagen synthesis requires vitamin C"
"Collagen Synthesis: Following hydroxylation of proline and lysine, there is glycosylation of pro-α-chain hydroxylysine residues"
"Collagen Synthesis: After hydroxylation and glycosylation, hydrogen and disulfide bonds help form a(n) triple helix of collagen α chains (procollagen)"
"Collagen Synthesis: After the triple helix is formed, the procollagen is exocytosed into the extracellular space"
"Where in the cell does synthesis, hydroxylation, and glycosylation of preprocollagen occur? Rough endoplasmic reticulum"
"Collagen Synthesis: Once in the extracellular space, cleavage of disulfide-rich terminal regions of procollagen by procollagen peptidase forms the insoluble tropocollagen"
"Collagen Synthesis: Staggered tropocollagen molecules are reinforced by covalent lysine-hydroxylysine cross-linkages to make collagen fibrils"
"Formation of lysine-hydroxylysine cross-linkages (collagen synthesis) requires both copper and the enzyme lysyl oxidase"
"Where in the cell does the synthesis and formation of tropocollagen and collagen fibrils occur? Extracellular space"
"Which collagen synthesis pathologies are associated with problems with cross-linking? Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Menkes disease::2"
"Which collagen synthesis pathologies are associated with problems forming the triple helix? Osteogenesis imperfecta and Scurvy"
"What genetic bone disorder is also known as brittle bone disease? Osteogenesis imperfecta"
"Osteogenesis imperfecta is most commonly caused by gene defects in COL1A1 and COL1A2"
"What is the inheritance of osteogenesis imperfecta (most common)? Autosomal dominant"
"Osteogenesis imperfecta may be confused with child abuse"
"Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by multiple recurrent fractures with minimal trauma"
"Osteogenesis imperfecta may present with blue sclerae due to translucent connective tissue over choroidal veins"
"Osteogenesis imperfecta may present with hearing loss due to abnormal ossicles"
"Some forms of osteogenesis imperfecta have tooth abnormalities, including opalescent teeth that wear easily due to lack of dentin"
"The classical type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (joint and skin symptoms) is caused by a mutation in type V collagen"
"What type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is the most common type? Hypermobility type (joint instability)"
"Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is characterized by faulty collagen synthesis causing hyperextensible skin"
"Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is characterized by faulty collagen synthesis causing hypermobile joints"
"Ehlers-Danlos syndrome may present with easy bruising and a tendency to bleed"
"The classical and vascular forms of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are inherited in a(n) autosomal dominant manner"
"What is the inheritance of Menkes disease? X-linked recessive"
"Menkes disease is caused by impaired copper absorption and transport due to a defect in the ATP7A gene"
"What gene is defective in Menkes disease? ATP7A"
"The defective Menkes protein (Menkes disease) leads to decreased activity of the enzyme lysyl oxidase"
"Menkes disease results in brittle, \kinky\\" hair"
"Elastin is a stretchy protein within skin, lungs, large arteries, elastic ligaments, vocal cords, and ligamentum flava"
"Elastin is rich in non-hydroxylated proline, glycine, and lysine residues (amino acids)"
"Elastin is broken down by the enzyme elastase, which is normally inhibited by α1-antitrypsin"
"Elastin is tropoelastin with fibrillin scaffolding"
"What gives elastin its elastic \rubber-like\\" properties? Cross-linking\""
"Where in the cell does cross-linking of elastin take place? Extracellular space"
"Marfan syndrome is caused by a defect in fibrillin, a glycoprotein that forms a sheath around elastin"
"Emphysema may be caused by a(n) α1-antitrypsin deficiency, resulting in excess elastase activity in alveoli"
"Wrinkles of aging are due to decreased collagen and elastin production"
"Recombinant DNA is DNA spliced together from two sources (usually human gene + bacterial vector)"
"A(n) palindrome is a DNA sequence which reads the same backwards and forwards on opposite strands of DNA (usually 4 or 6 bp)"
"What class of enzymes cleaves nucleotides at the ends of a DNA strand? Exonucleases"
"What class of enzymes cleaves nucleotides in the middle of a DNA strand? Endonucleases"
"Cloning is the production of a recombinant DNA molecule that is self-perpetuating"
"The first step of cloning is to isolate the eukaryotic mRNA of interest"
"Cloning: Isolated mRNA is exposed to reverse transcriptase to produce cDNA (lacks introns)"
"Cloning: After cDNA is produced, cDNA fragments are inserted into bacterial plasmids, which contain antibiotic resistance genes"
"Cloning: After the recombinant plasmid has been produced, it is transformed into bacteria"
"DNA requires fragmentation for analysis, RNA and proteins do not (analyzed directly)"
"All RNA/DNA is negatively charged"
"Most proteins are negatively charged (except histones)"
"Gel electrophoresis separates fragments on the basis of size"
"When using blotting procedures, the probe determines what sequences are detected"
"A(n) Southern blot is used to analyze DNA"
"A(n) Northern blot is used to analyze RNA"
"Does a Southern blot require gel electrophoresis before analysis? Yes"
"Does a Northern blot require gel electrophoresis before analysis? Yes"
"A Northern blot is useful for studying gene expression"
"A(n) Western blot is used to analyze protein"
"What type of probe is used to bind protein when using a Western blot? Labeled antibody"
"What type of probe is used to bind DNA/RNA when using a Southern/Northern blot? Labeled single stranded DNA / RNA oligonucleotide"
"The Western blot *used to be* the confirmatory test for HIV after a positive ELISA"
"Does a Dot (slot) blot require gel electrophoresis before analysis? No!"
"A(n) Southwestern blot is used to identify DNA-binding proteins using labeled oligonucleotide probes"
"RFLP analysis analyzes DNA using variations in restriction enzyme sites between homologous DNA strands"
"Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is a powerful diagnostic tool used to amplify a desired fragment of DNA"
"In the first step of PCR, DNA is denatured by using heat to separate the strands"
"In the second step of PCR, DNA primers anneal to specific sequences on each DNA strand to be amplified"
"In the final step of PCR, heat-stable Taq DNA polymerase elongates the DNA sequence following each primer"
"How many primers are needed for polymerase chain reaction (PCR)? Two (one for the 3' end of each DNA strand)"
"What type of primer is used in a polymerase chain reaction (PCR)? DNA primer"
"Which end of the DNA strand does the DNA primer bind to during PCR? 3' end"
"PCR requires the addition of all four deoxynucleotide triphosphates (dNTPs) for DNA synthesis"
"Flow cytometry is a laboratory technique used to assess size, granularity, and protein expression of individual cells in a sample"
"What laboratory technique is useful in determining CD4 cell count in HIV patients? Flow cytometry"
"In flow cytometry, cells are tagged with antibodies specific to surface or intracellular proteins"
"In flow cytometry, antibodies are tagged with a unique fluorescent dye, which is detected and counted during analysis"
"Flow Cytometry Example: Cells in the left lower quadrant are CD3- and CD8-"
"Flow Cytometry Example: Cells in the left upper quadrant are CD3+ and CD8-"
"Flow Cytometry Example: Cells in the right lower quadrant are CD3- and CD8+"
"Flow Cytometry Example: Cells in the right upper quadrant are CD3+ and CD8+"
"Microarrays analyze thousands of nucleic acid sequences arranged in grids on glass or silicon"
"Microarrays are a laboratory technique used to profile gene expression levels of thousands of genes simultaneously to study certain diseases and treatments"
"Microarrays use a(n) labeled DNA/RNA probe, which is hybridized to the chip, and a scanner detects the relative amounts of complementary binding"
"What two types of variations in DNA are detected when using microarrays? (DNA markers)  - Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) - Copy number variations (CNVs)"
"Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)::not Coombs is an immunologic test used to detect the presence of either a specific antigen or antibody in a patient's blood sample"
"When using ELISA, detection involves the use of a(n) antibody linked to a(n) enzyme"
"Karyotyping is a process in which metaphase::phase chromosomes are stained, ordered, and numbered according to morphology, size, arm-length ratio, and banding pattern"
"What laboratory technique is used to diagnose chromosomal imbalances? Karyotyping"
"Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) uses a fluorescent DNA/RNA probe to bind to a specific gene of interest on chromosomes"
"Fluoresence in situ hybridization (FISH) is a laboratory technique used for specific localization of genes and direct visualization of chromosomal anomalies"
"A(n) microdeletion is detected with FISH as no fluorescence on a chromosome compared to fluorescence at the same locus on the second copy of that chromosome"
"A(n) translocation is detected with FISH as fluorescence outside the original chromosome"
"A(n) duplication is detected with FISH as an extra site of fluorescence on one chromosome relative to its homologous chromosome"
"Transgenic strategies in mice involve random insertion or targeted insertion/deletion within a mouse genome"
"A(n) knock-out transgenic mouse has had a gene removed"
"A(n) knock-in transgenic mouse has had a gene inserted"
"A(n) Cre-lox system can inducibly manipulate genes at specific developmental points (e.g. study a gene whose deletion causes embryonic deaths)"
"RNA interference uses dsRNA complementary to an mRNA of interest to \knock down\\" gene expression\""
"A(n) locus is the specific location of a gene on a chromosome"
"Alleles are different forms of a single gene"
"When looking at a pedigree, a square is indicative of a(n) male"
"When looking at a pedigree, a circle is indicative of a(n) female"
"When looking at a pedigree, a(n) shaded circle/square is indicative of a diseased individual"
"If a disease has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, it is usually doesn't skip generations"
"Autosomal dominant diseases are often due to defects in structural genes"
