"Autosomal dominant diseases are often pleiotropic and variably expressive"
"If a disease has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, it is usually does skip generations"
"Autosomal recessive diseases are often due to enzyme deficiences"
"There is an increased risk of autosomal recessive diseases in consanguineous families"
"If a disease has an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, it usually does skip generations"
"If a disease has an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, there is NO male-to-male transmission"
"X-linked recessive diseases are commonly more severe in males"
"If a male has an X-linked recessive disease, all of his daughters will be carriers"
"In females, one of two X-chromosomes is condensed and its genes turned off by cytosine methylation::specific action, forming heterochromatin (lyonization)"
"The formation of Barr bodies (X-chromosome inactivation) is also known as lyonization"
"If a disease has an X-linked dominant inheritance pattern, it usually doesn't skip generations"
"If a disease has an X-linked dominant inheritance pattern, there is NO male-to-male transmission"
"If a male has an X-linked dominant disease, all of his daughters will be affected"
"What is the mode of inheritance of hypophosphatemic rickets (vitamin D-resistant rickets)? X-linked dominant"
"Hypophosphatemic rickets is an inherited disorder resulting in increased phosphate wasting at the proximal tubule; results in rickets-like presentation"
"If a disease has a mitochondrial inheritance pattern, it can be inherited only from the mother"
"Mitochondrial diseases mostly affect neurons and muscles, which are both highly aerobic"
"Mitochondrial diseases often demonstrate variable expression in a population or within a family due to heteroplasmy"
"Muscle biopsies of patients with mitochondrial myopathies often show \ragged red\\" fibers\""
"Mitochondrial myopathies often present with myopathy, lactic acidosis, and CNS disease"
"Mitochondrial DNA encodes 22 tRNAs and 2 rRNAs"
"If a mother has a mitochondrial disease, all her children are affected"
"If a father has a mitochondrial disease, all his children are unaffected"
"Codominance describes an inheritance in which both alleles contribute to the phenotype of the heterozygote"
"Variable expressivity describes phenotypic variation among individuals with the same genotype"
"If some individuals who have the disease genotype do not display the disease phenotype, the disease is said to have incomplete penetrance"
"Pleiotropy describes the contribution of one gene to multiple phenotypic effects"
"Anticipation describes the increased severity or earlier onset of a disease in succeeding generations"
"What class of diseases is characterized by anticipation? Trinucleotide repeat diseases (e.g. Huntington disease)"
"If a patient inherits or develops a mutation in a(n) tumor suppressor gene, the complementary allele must be deleted/mutated before cancer develops"
"A(n) dominant negative mutation results in a heterozygote in which one allele produces a nonfunctional altered protein that also prevents the normal gene product from the normal allele from functioning"
"If mutations at different loci can produce a similar phenotype, a disease has locus heterogeneity"
"If different mutations at the same locus produce the same phenotype, a disease has allelic heterogeneity"
"Heteroplasmy is the presence of both normal and mutated mtDNA, resulting in variable expression of a mitochondrially inherited disease"
"Uniparental disomy is the inheritance of 2 copies of a chromosome from one parent and no copies from the other"
"Does a uniparental disomy result in euploidy or aneuploidy? Euploidy"
"If a uniparental disomy results in a(n) heterozygous offspring, there may have been a(n) meiosis I error"
"If a uniparental disomy results in a(n) homozygous offspring, there may have been a(n) meiosis II error"
"Genetic imprinting is the normal differential expression of an allele depending on parental origin (e.g. only one allele is active)"
"Both Prader-Willi and Angelman syndrome are due to a mutation or deletion of genes on chromosome 15"
"In Prader-Willi::Prader-Willi OR Angelman syndrome, the maternal gene is imprinted and the paternal gene is mutated/deleted"
"In Angelman syndrome, the paternal gene is imprinted and the maternal gene is mutated/deleted"
"25% of cases of Prader-Willi syndrome are due to maternal uniparental disomy"
"5% of cases of Angelman syndrome are due to paternal uniparental disomy"
"What pathology is characterized by insatiable appetite (hyperphagia), obesity, intellectual disability, and hypogonadism? Prader-Willi syndrome"
"What pathology is characterized by inappropriate laughter, seizures, ataxia, and severe intellectual disability? Angelman syndrome"
"What pathology is also known as \happy puppet\\" syndrome? Angelman syndrome\""
"In both Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome, the most common abnormality is a gene deletion"
"When using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics, p and q represent allelic frequencies"
"When using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics, p2, 2pq, and q2 represent genotypic frequencies"
"What equation is used to calculate allele frequency when using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics? p + q = 1"
"What equation is used to calculate genotypic frequency when using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics? p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1"
"When using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics, the frequency of an X-linked recessive disease in males is equal to q"
"When using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics, the frequency of an X-linked recessive disease in females is equal to q2"
"When using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics, the frequency of a carrier of a recessive disease is equal to 2pq"
"One assumption of Hardy-Weinberg population genetics is that there is no net migration"
"One assumption of Hardy-Weinberg population genetics is that there is completely random mating"
"One assumption of Hardy-Weinberg population genetics is that natural selection is not occurring"
"One assumption of Hardy-Weinberg population genetics is that no mutations have occurred at the locus"
"Sister chromatids are joined together at the end of S phase at the centromere"
"The short arm of the chromosome is known as the p arm, and the long is the q arm"
"Acrocentric chromosomes are characterized by very short p arms"
"What chromosomes are considered acrocentric chromosomes? 13, 14, 15, 21, 22::5"
"What is the most common mechanism of chromosomal aneuploidy? Meiotic nondisjunction"
"Mosaicism describes the presence of genetically distinct cell lines in the same individual"
"Somatic mosaicism occurs when a mutation arises from mitotic::[mitotic/meiotic]] errors after fertilization and propagates through multiple tissues or organs"
"Gonadal mosaicism occurs when the mutation is only in egg or sperm cells"
"McCune-Albright syndrome is lethal if the mutation occurs before fertilization (affecting all cells), but survivable in patients with mosaicism"
"McCune-Albright syndrome is due to a mutation affecting G-protein signaling"
"McCune-Albright syndrome is characterized by unilateral café-au-lait spots, precocious puberty, and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia"
"Crossover is chromosomal rearrangment between homologous chromosomes"
"Reciprocal translocation is chromosomal rearrangement between non-homologous chromosomes"
"What type of chromosome is most commonly involved in a robertsonian translocation? Acrocentric chromosomes"
"A(n) Robertsonian translocation occurs when the long arms of 2 acrocentric chromosomes fuse at the centromere and the 2 short arms are lost"
"How can a Robertsonian translocation cause chromosomal imbalance in offspring? A gamete with the mutated chromosome is passed on (e.g. gamete with t(14;21))"
"Do Robertsonian translocations usually cause pathology in the individual who acquired the mutation? No, it usually is a balanced translocation"
"Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by a congenital microdeletion of chromosome 5p (short arm)"
"What pathology is associated with microcephaly, intellectual disability, and a high-pitched cry? Cri-du-chat syndrome"
"Williams syndrome is caused by a congenital microdeletion of chromosome 7q (long arm)"
"What pathology is associated with \elfin\\" facies"
"An isochromosome is a chromosome with two copies of one arm and no copies of the other"
"What pathology may be caused by an isochromosome in the X chromosome? Turner's syndrome (46,X,i(Xq))"
"Linkage disequilibrium describes the tendency of alleles at two loci on the same chromosome to be inherited together greater or less often than expected by chance"
"Linkage disequlibrium is measured in a(n) population, not in a family"
"If alleles at two loci are inherited equally as expected by chance, the loci are said to be in linkage equilibrium"
"The closer the recombination frequency is to 0%, the closer alleles in a haplotype are to each other"
"If two linked genes have a recombination frequency of 15%, approximately how far apart are they? 15 centiMorgans (cM)"
"LOD scores are used to calculate the probability that two loci are linked (linkage disequilibrium)"
"An LOD score greater than 3 indicates linkage"
"An LOD score less than -2 indicates no linkage"
"Marfan syndrome is due to a(n) FBN1 gene mutation on chromosome 15"
"What protein is defective in Marfan syndrome? Fibrillin (scaffold for elastin)"
"What pathology is associated with long, tapering fingers and toes (arachnodactyly) and subluxation of lenses? Marfan syndrome"
"Marfan syndrome typically presents with subluxation of the lenses upward::direction and temporally::direction"
"Marfan syndrome is associated with a floppy mitral valve"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Marfan syndrome? Autosomal dominant"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Fragile X syndrome? X-linked dominant"
"What class of diseases is Fragile X syndrome a part of? Trinucleotide repeat expansion diseases"
"Fragile X syndrome is due to a trinucleotide repeat in the FMR1 gene"
"What pathology is associated with an enlarged jaw, testes, and ears? Fragile X syndrome"
"What sequence of nucleotides is repeated in Fragile X syndrome? CGG"
"What is the second most common cause of genetic intellectual disability? Fragile X syndrome (#1 is Down syndrome)"
"What class of diseases is Huntington disease a part of? Trinucleotide repeat expansion diseases"
"What class of diseases is Friedreich ataxia a part of? Trinucleotide repeat expansion diseases"
"What class of diseases is myotonic dystrophy a part of? Trinucleotide repeat expansion diseases"
"What sequence of nucleotides is repeated in Friedreich ataxia? GAA"
"What sequence of nucleotides is repeated in Huntington disease? CAG"
"What sequence of nucleotides is repeated in myotonic dystrophy? CTG"
"What is the most common cause (95%) of Down syndrome? Meiotic nondisjunction"
"4% of cases of Down syndrome are due to unbalanced Robertsonian translocation"
"1% of cases of Down syndrome are due to mosaicism"
"What is the most common cause of genetic intellectual disability? Down syndrome"
"Down syndrome may present with increased nuchal translucency on ultrasound"
"Down syndrome presents with decreased serum PAPP-A"
"Down syndrome presents with increased free β-hCG"
"Down syndrome presents with increased inhibin A"
"Down syndrome presents with decreased estriol"
"Down syndrome presents with decreased free α-fetoprotein (AFP)"
"What pathology is associated with intellectual disability, prominent epicanthal folds, and a single palmar crease? Down syndrome"
"What chromosomal abnormality is associated with Down syndrome? Trisomy 21"
"What chromosomal abnormality is associated with Edwards syndrome? Trisomy 18"
"What chromosomal abnormality is associated with Patau syndrome? Trisomy 13"
"The findings in Edwards Syndrome may be remembered with PRINCE Edward: - Prominent occiput - Rocker-bottom feet - Intellectual disability- Nondisjunction - Clenched fists with overlapping fingers - low-set Ears"
"Patients with Edwards syndrome and Patau syndrome often die within 1 year(s) of birth"
"Edward syndrome and Patau syndrome present with decreased serum PAPP-A"
"Edward syndrome and Patau syndrome present with decreased free β-hCG"
"Edward syndrome presents with decreased or normal inhibin A"
"Edward syndrome presents with decreased estriol"
"Edward syndrome presents with decreased free α-fetoprotein (AFP)"
"The findings in Patau Syndrome may be remembered with the 5'Ps - cleft Palate - holoProsencephaly::h--P--- - Polydactyly - aPlasia cutis - Polycystic Kidney disease"
"How does the cardiac output of the left heart compare to the right heart? Equal (in steady state)"
"The rate at which blood is pumped from either ventricle is called the cardiac output"
"The rate at which blood is returned to the atria is called the venous return"
"Oxygenated blood flows from the lungs to the left atrium via the pulmonary vein"
"Blood flows from the left atrium to the left ventricle through the mitral (bicuspid) valve"
"Blood flows from the left ventricle to the aorta through the aortic valve"
"Blood flows from the aorta to the systemic arteries and tissues"
"Blood flows from the tissues to the systemic veins and ultimately the vena cava before returning to the right atrium"
"Deoxygenated blood flows from the vena cava to the right atrium"
"Blood flows from the right atrium to the right ventricle through the tricuspid valve"
"Blood flows from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery through the pulmonic valve"
"Blood flows from the pulmonary artery to the lungs for oxygenation"
"Which type of blood vessel has extensive elastic tissue and smooth muscle? Artery"
"Arteries are under high pressure"
"The blood volume contained in the arteries is called the stressed volume"
"The smallest branches of arteries are known as arterioles"
"Arterioles are a type of blood vessel with the highest resistance in the cardiovascular system"
"Arteriolar resistance is regulated by the sympathetic nervous system"
"What type of receptor is found on the arterioles of skin, splanchnic, and renal circulation? α1-adrenergic receptors"
"What type of receptors are found on the arterioles of skeletal muscle? α1- and β2-adrenergic receptors::2"
"When activated, α1-adrenergic receptors cause contraction of vascular smooth muscle"
"When activated, β2-adrenergic receptors cause relaxation of vascular smooth muscle"
"Which type of blood vessel has the largest total cross-sectional and surface area? Capillaries"
"Which type of blood vessel is the site of exchange of nutrients, water, and gases? Capillaries"
"Capillaries are thin-walled blood vessels that consist of a single layer of endothelial cells surrounded by a basal lamina"
"Veins are under low pressure"
"The blood volume contained in the veins is called the unstressed volume"
"What type of adrenergic receptor do veins have? α1-adrenergic receptors"
"What type of blood vessel contains the largest percentage of blood in the cardiovascular system? Veins"
"What equation may be used to calculate the velocity of blood flow (v) given the flow rate (Q)? v = Q/A"
"Velocity of blood (v) is inversely proportional to the total cross-sectional area"
"What type of blood vessel has the lowest flow velocity? Capillaries"
"What equation may be used to calculate the blood flow (Q) given pressure and resistance? Q = ΔP/R"
"Blood flow (Q) is inversely proportional to the resistance of blood vessels"
"The magnitude of blood flow (Q) is directly proportional to the size of the pressure difference between blood vessels"
"The direction of blood flow is determined by the direction of the pressure gradient and is always from high to low pressure"
"The resistance of the entire systemic vasculature is called the total peripheral resistance (TPR)"
"In Poiseulle's equation, Resistance is directly proportional to the viscosity (η) of the blood"
"Resistance is directly proportional to the length of the blood vessel"
"Resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius of the blood vessel"
"What type of resistance is illustrated by the arrangement of blood vessels within a given organ? Series resistance"
"The equation Rtotal = R1 + R2 ... may be used to calculate the total resistance of a system arranged in series"
"Which type of blood vessel causes the greatest decrease in pressure in a vascular system arranged in series? Arterioles"
"When resistances are arranged in series, the total flow through each level of the system is the same"
"What type of resistance is illustrated by the arrangement of blood vessels in systemic circulation? Parallel resistance"
"The equation 1/Rtotal = 1/R1 + 1/R2 ... may be used to calculate the total resistance of a system arranged in parallel"
"When a blood vessel is added to a system in series, the total resistance increases"
"When a blood vessel is added to a system in parallel, the total resistance decreases"
"When vessels are arranged in parallel, the total resistance is less than the resistance of any of the individual arteries"
"When resistances are arranged in parallel, the pressure through each level of the system is the same"
"Ideally, blood flow in the cardiovascular system is laminar, or streamlined"
"If blood flow is laminar, the highest velocity occurs at the center of the blood vessel"
"Reynolds' number predicts whether blood flow will be laminar or turbulent"
"When Reynolds' number is increased, there is a greater tendency for turbulent blood flow"
"Turbulent flow in a blood vessel causes audible vibrations known as bruits or murmurs::2"
"A(n) increase in velocity of blood causes an increase in Reynolds' number"
"A(n) decrease in viscosity of blood causes an increase in Reynolds' number"
"What is the effect of blood vessel narrowing (e.g. thrombus) on Reynolds' number? Increased"
"Viscosity of blood depends mostly on hematocrit"
"What is the effect of anemia on blood viscosity? Decreased"
"What is the effect of polycythemia on blood viscosity? Increased"
"Shear is a consequence of adjacent layers of blood traveling at different velocities within a blood vessel"
"Shear is highest at the wall of a blood vessel"
"Shear is lowest at the center of a blood vessel"
"The capacitance (compliance) of a blood vessel describes the volume of blood the vessel can hold at a given pressure"
"The greater the amount of elastic tissue there is in a blood vessel (elastance), the lower the compliance is"
"What equation may be used to calculate the capacitance of a blood vessel? C = V / P"
"Which type of blood vessel has the greatest capacitance? Veins"
"What is the result of aging on the capacitance (compliance) of arteries? Decreased (more stiff, less distensible)"
"Systolic pressure is the highest arterial pressure during the cardiac cycle"
"The \blip\\" in the arterial pressure curve"
"Diastolic pressure is the lowest arterial pressure during the cardiac cycle"
"The pulse pressure is the difference between the systolic and diastolic pressures"
"Pulse pressure is directly proportional to stroke volume"
"Pulse pressure is inversely proportional to arterial compliance"
"What equation may be used to calculate mean arterial pressure given a patient's blood pressure? MAP = 2/3 diastolic pressure + 1/3 systolic pressure"
"Compared to the systemic vasculature, the pressures in the pulmonary vasculature are much lower"
"Compared to the systemic vasculature, the resistance in the pulmonary vasculature is much lower"
"Action potentials in the heart are usually initiated in the SA node, which serves as the pacemaker"
"Action potentials spread from the SA node to the AV node and right/left atria, simultaneously"
"Conduction velocity through the AV node is slower than in the other cardiac tissues"
"From the AV node, the myocardial action potential enters the Bundle of His"
"From the Bundle of His, the myocardial action potential enters the Purkinje fibers and ultimately the ventricles"
"The resting membrane potential of cardiac cells is determined primarily by potassium (K+) ions"
"In a cardiac cell, the conductance to K+ at rest is high::high/low"
"The Na+ and K+ concentration gradients across the cardiac cell are maintained by the Na+-K+-ATPase pump"
"Phase 0 of the myocardial action potential is characterized by rapid upstroke/depolarization"
"Phase 0 of the myocardial action potential is caused by opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels"
"Phase 1 of the myocardial action potential is characterized by initial repolarization"
"Phase 1 of the myocardial action potential is caused by inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels and opening of voltage-gated K+ channels"
"Phase 2 of the myocardial action potential is characterized by plateau"
"Phase 2 of the myocardial action potential (plateau) is caused by a balance of K+ efflux and Ca2+ influx through voltage-gated channels"
"The calcium channels that open during the plateau phase (myocardial action potential) are L-type channels"
"The influx of calcium during the plateau phase of a myocardial action potential triggers release of Ca2+ from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, causing myocyte contraction"
"Phase 3 of the myocardial action potential is characterized by rapid repolarization"
"Phase 3 of the myocardial action potential is caused by massive efflux of K+ and closure of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels"
"Phase 4 of the myocardial action potential is characterized by a return to resting membrane potential"
"What type of action potential occurs in the ventricles, atria, and Purkinje system? Myocardial action potentials (phase 0 through phase 4)"
"Phase 0 of the SA node action potential is characterized by upstroke"
"Phase 0 of the SA node action potential is caused by opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels"
"How does the rate of upstroke in a SA node action potential compare to that of a myocardial action potential? SA node is slower"
"What type of calcium channels exist in the SA node? L-type (primary) and T-type::2"
"What phases of the myocardial action potential are not present in an SA node action potential? Phase 1 & 2 (initial repolarization & plateau)"
"Phase 3 of the SA node action potential is characterized by repolarization"
"Phase 3 of the SA node action potential is caused by activation of K+ channels and inactivation of Ca2+ channels"
"Phase 4 of the SA node action potential is characterized by slow depolarization"
"The rate of phase 4 in the SA node action potential cycle determines heart rate"
"Which phase in the SA node accounts for its pacemaker activity and automaticity? Phase 4 (slow depolarization)"
"Phase 4 of the SA node action potential is caused by a slow, mixed Na+/K+ inward current via If (\funny\\") channels\""
"What three cell types are considered latent pacemakers? Cells of the AV node, bundle of His, and Purkinje fibers"
"Conduction velocity is the speed at which action potentials are propagated within the tissue"
"Where in the heart is conduction velocity the slowest? AV node"
"Where in the heart is conduction velocity the fastest? Purkinje fibers"
"Conduction velocity depends on the size (magnitude) of the inward current during the upstroke of an action potential"
"Excitability is the ability of cardiac cells to initiate action potentials in response to inward, depolarizing current"
"The absolute refractory period refers to the period in which no action potential can be initiated"
"In cardiac cells, the absolute refractory period begins with the upstroke and ends after the plateau"
"The effective refractory period refers to the period in which a(n) conductive action potential cannot be generated"
"The relative refractory period refers to the period in which a second action potential is possible, but requires a greater-than-normal stimulus"
"The effects of the autonomic nervous system on heart rate are called chronotropic effects"
"A negative chronotropic effect decreases heart rate"
"A positive chronotropic effect increases heart rate"
"What is the result of sympathetic stimulation on heart rate? Increased"
"What is the result of parasympathetic stimulation on heart rate? Decreased"
"Through what receptor does the sympathetic nervous system increase heart rate? β1 adrenergic receptor"
"Activation of β1 receptors in the SA node produces an increase in If channel activity, which increases the rate of phase 4 depolarization and thus heart rate"
"Through what receptor does the parasympathetic nervous system decrease heart rate? M2 muscarinic receptor::specific#"
"Activation of M2 receptors in the SA node produces a decrease in If channel activity, which decreases the rate of phase 4 depolarization and thus heart rate"
"The effects of the autonomic nervous system on conduction velocity are called dromotropic effects"
"A negative dromotropic effect decreases conduction velocity through the AV node"
"A positive dromotropic effect increases conduction velocity through the AV node"
"What is the result of sympathetic stimulation on conduction velocity? Increased"
"What is the result of parasympathetic stimulation on conduction velocity? Decreased"
"A(n) negative dromotropic effect increases the PR interval on an ECG"
"A(n) positive dromotropic effect decreases the PR interval on an ECG"
"The P wave on ECG represents atrial depolarization"
"Atrial repolarization is not seen on an ECG because it is masked by the QRS complex"
"The duration of the P wave correlates with the conduction velocity through the atria"
"The PR interval on ECG is the time from the initial depolarization of the atria to the initial depolarization of the ventricles"
"The PR interval on ECG depends on the conduction velocity through the AV node"
"The QRS complex on ECG represents ventricular depolarization"
"The T wave on ECG represents ventricular repolarization"
"T-wave inversion may indicate recent myocardial infarction (MI)"
"The QT interval on ECG represents the entire period of ventricular depolarization, contraction, and repolarization"
"The ST segment on ECG is an isoelectric period (horizontal line) when the ventricles are depolarized"
"The U wave on ECG is prominent in hypokalemia and bradycardia"
"The J point on ECG is the junction between the end of QRS complex and start of ST segment"
"Which pacemaker in the heart has the fastest rate? SA node (hence why it is dominant)"
"The left bundle branch of the bundle of His divides into anterior and posterior fascicles"
"The AV node is located in the posteroinferior part of the interatrial septum"
"Slowed conduction through the AV node normally causes a(n) 100-msec delay, allowing time for ventricular filling"
"Serotonin syndrome as a side effect of ondansetron is more common in patients with concommitant use of drugs that increase levels of serotonin"
"Vitamin D resistance occurs due to the absence of the renal enzyme 1α-hydroxylase, thus preventing activation of vitamin D"
"The sarcomere is the contractile unit of the myocardial cell"
"What part of a myocardial cell is responsible for carrying action potentials into the cell interior? T tubules"
"What part of a myocardial cell is the site of storage and release of Ca2+ for excitation-contraction coupling? Sarcoplasmic Reticulum (SR)"
"During the plateau of a myocardial action potential, Ca2+ enters the cell through dihydropyridine receptors (L-type Ca2+ channels)"
"Entry of Ca2+ into the myocardial cell during the myocardial action potential triggers further release of Ca2+ through ryanodine receptors (Ca2+ release channels)"
"In the myocardial cell, high intracellular Ca2+ binds to troponin C, causing tropomyosin to move out of the way, which allows actin and myosin interaction"
"The magnitude of the tension that develops during myocardial excitation-contraction coupling is proportional to levels of intracellular Ca2+"
"Relaxation of a myocardial cell occurs when: - Ca2+ is reaccumulated in the sarcoplasmic reticulum by the action of Ca2+ ATPase (SERCA) - Ca2+ is pumped out of the cell by the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger (NCX)"
"Gap junctions are low-resistance paths between cardiac cells that allow for rapid electrical spread of action potentials"
"Contractility, or inotropism, is the intrinsic ability of myocardial cells to develop force at a given muscle length"
"A positive inotropic effect increases heart contractility"
"A negative inotropic effect decreases heart contractility"
"Cardiac contractility correlates directly with intracellular Ca2+ concentration"
"Sympathetic stimulation increases phosphorylation/inhibition of phospholamban, which increases activity of Ca2+ ATPase aka SERCA"
"Parasympathetic stimulation decreases atrial::atrial or ventricular contractility via M2 receptors"
"What effect does increased heart rate have on cardiac contractility? Increased contractility (to an extent)"
"What effect does decreased heart rate have on cardiac contractility? Decreased contractility"
"Cardiac contractility increases with increased::increased or decreased catecholamines"
"Cardiac contractility increases with increased intracellular Ca2+"
"Cardiac contractility increases with decreased extracellular Na+"
"What is the effect of cardiac glycosides on contractility? Increased contractility"
"Cardiac glycosides exert their actions via direct inhibition of the Na+-K+ ATPase pump"
"What effect do cardiac glycosides have on intracellular Na+ concentration? Increased"
"Increased intracellular [Na+] in cardiac myocytes causes decreased activity of the Ca2+-Na+ exchanger"
"Decreased activity of the Ca2+-Na+ exchanger (e.g. due to cardiac glycosides) causes increased intracellular Ca2+ concentration"
"The velocity of shortening of cardiac muscle is maximal when afterload is zero"
"The velocity of shortening of cardiac muscle decreases as afterload increases"
"Stroke volume is defined as the volume of blood ejected by one ventricular contraction"
"Ejection fraction is defined as the fraction of the end-diastolic volume that is ejected in each stroke volume"
"The equation SV = EDV - ESV may be used to calculate stroke volume"
"The equation ejection fraction = SV/EDV may be used to calculate ejection fraction"
"Cardiac contractility can be estimated by the left ventricular ejection fraction"
"Ejection fraction is normally > 55%"
"What equation is used to calculate cardiac output given a patients stroke volume and heart rate? CO = SV x HR"
"The Frank-Starling relationship states that the force of contraction is proportional to the end-diastolic length of the cardiac muscle fiber"
"What is the effect of increased venous return on end-diastolic volume (EDV)? Increased EDV"
"Increases in contractility cause the Starling curve to shift upward"
"Decreases in contractility (e.g. heart failure) cause the Starling curve to shift downward"
"Exercise causes the Starling curve to shift upward"
"Isovolumetric contraction is the first phase of a cardiac cycle and represents the period between mitral valve closing and aortic valve opening"
"Ventricular (systolic) ejection is the second phase of a cardiac cycle and represents the period between aortic valve opening and closing"
"Isovolumetric relaxation is the third phase of a cardiac cycle and represents the period between aortic valve closing and mitral valve opening"
"Rapid ventricular filling is the fourth phase of a cardiac cycle and represents the period just after mitral valve opening"
"Reduced filling is the fifth phase of a cardiac cycle and represents the period just before mitral valve closing"
"The width of a pressure-volume loop is the stroke volume"
"Preload is approximated by ventricular end-diastolic volume (EDV)"
"What effect does increased venous return have on preload? Increased preload"
"Afterload is approximated by mean arterial pressure"
"What effect does increased aortic pressure have on afterload? Increased afterload"
"Increased preload::AL/PL/CT results in a(n) increased width on a pressure-volume loop curve"
"Increased afterload results in a(n) decreased width and increased height on a pressure-volume loop curve"
"Increased contractility results in a(n) increased width and increased height on a pressure-volume loop curve"
"What effect does increased preload have on stroke volume? Increased SV"
"What effect does increased afterload have on stroke volume? Decreased SV"
"What effect does increased afterload have on end-systolic volume? Increased ESV"
"What effect does increased contractility have on end-systolic volume? Decreased ESV"
"What effect does increased contractility have on stroke volume? Increased SV"
"What effect does increased preload have on ejection fraction? Increased EF"
"Which phase of the cardiac cycle is the period of highest O2 consumption? Isovolumetric contraction"
"According to the law of Laplace, cardiac wall stress = P*r / 2H"
"Cardiac O2 consumption is directly related to the amount of tension developed by the ventricles"
"What is the effect of increased afterload (increased aortic pressure) on cardiac O2 consumption? Increased O2 consumption"
"What is the effect of increased ventricular diameter on cardiac O2 consumption? Increased O2 consumption"
"What is the effect of increased contractility on cardiac O2 consumption? Increased O2 consumption"
"What is the effect of increased heart rate on cardiac O2 consumption? Increased O2 consumption"
"The reasons there is concentric left ventricular hypertrophy in response to systemic hypertension is that increased wall thickness decreases wall stress by offsetting increased wall tension"
"The left ventricle compensates for increased afterload by thickening (hypertrophy) in order to decrease wall tension"
"What effect does increased aortic pressure (afterload) have on cardiac wall stress? Increased wall stress"
"According to the Fick principle: Cardiac Output (CO) = O2 consumption / (arterial O2 content - venous O2 content)"
"The resistance of a vessel may be calculated using Poiseuille's equation, which states R = 8ηl/πr4"
"The likelihood of turbulent flow may be calculated using Reynolds' number, which states NR = ρdv/η"
"The SA node is located in the wall of the right atrium near the orifice of the superior vena cava"
"The heart sound S1 is due to mitral and tricuspid valve closure"
"The normal heart sound S1 is loudest at the mitral area"
"The heart sound S2 is due to aortic and pulmonic valve closure"
"The normal heart sound S2 is loudest at the left upper sternal border"
"Atrial systole is preceded by the P wave on ECG, which marks depolarization of the atria"
"The increase in atrial pressure caused by atrial systole appears on the venous pulse curve as the a wave"
"Is the fourth heart sound (S4) normally audible in adults? No"
"The heart sound S4 can be associated with ventricular noncompliance"
"The abnormal heart sounds S3 and S4 are best heard at the heart apex, with the patient in left lateral decubitus position"
"The abnormal heart sound S4 may be audible during atrial systole (late ventricular diastole)"
"How does ventricular volume change during atrial systole? Increase"
"What phase of the cardiac cycle begins during the QRS complex on ECG? Isovolumetric ventricular contraction::specific"
"The heart sound S1 may be audible during isovolumetric contraction"
"When the left ventricle contracts, the left ventricular pressure becomes greater than left atrial pressure and the mitral valve closes"
"The mitral valve closes slightly before the tricuspid valve, thus heart sound S1 may be split"
"During rapid ventricular ejection, the ventricular pressure becomes greater than aortic pressure and the aortic valve opens"
"How does aortic pressure change during rapid ventricular ejection? Increase"
"How does ventricular volume change during rapid ventricular ejection? Dramatic decrease"
"The end of rapid ventricular ejection corresponds with the onset of the T wave on ECG"
"During right ventricular contraction, the tricuspid valve bulges into the right atrium, which appears as the c wave on the venous pulse curve"
"The onset of reduced ventricular ejection corresponds with the onset of the T wave on ECG"
"How do aortic and ventricular pressure change during reduced ventricular ejection? Decrease"
"During atrial relaxation, the tricuspid valve returns to its downward position, which appears as the x descent on the venous pulse curve"
"The heart sound S2 may be audible during isovolumetric relaxation"
"How does ventricular pressure change during isovolumetric relaxation? Decrease"
"Increased right atrial pressure, due to filling against a closed tricuspid valve, appears as the v wave on the venous pulse curve"
"Isovolumetric relaxation corresponds to the end of the T wave on ECG"
"During isovolumetric relaxation, the ventricular pressure becomes less than aortic pressure and the aortic valve closes"
"Inspiration delays closure of the pulmonic valve which causes splitting of the S2 heart sound"
"During rapid ventricular filling, the left ventricular pressure becomes less than the left atrial pressure and the mitral valve opens"
"How does atrial pressure change during rapid ventricular filling? Decrease"
"The abnormal heart sound S3 may be audible during rapid ventricular filling (early diastole)"
"In what demographics may the heart sound S3 be normal? Children, young adults, pregnant women, athletes::4 options"
"The presence of the heart sound S3 in middle-aged or older adults indicates volume overload"
"Reduced ventricular filling, or diastasis, is the longest phase of the cardiac cycle"
"What phase of the cardiac cycle is most affected by changes in heart rate? Reduced ventricular filling (diastasis)"
"During rapid ventricular filling, the right atrium empties into the right ventricle, which appears as the y descent on the venous pulse curve"
"The cardiac function curve plots left ventricular cardiac output (LVCO) vs right atrial pressure (RAP)"
"The vascular function curve plots right atrial pressure vs venous return"
"The mean systemic pressure is the point at which the vascular function curve intersects the x-axis"
"The mean systemic pressure is equal to the right atrial pressure when the venous return is zero"
"What effect does increased blood volume have on mean systemic pressure? Increased"
"An increase in mean systemic pressure is reflected in a shift of the vascular function curve to the right"
"A decrease in mean systemic pressure is reflected in a shift of the vascular function curve to the left"
"What effect does increased venous tone (decreased compliance) have on mean systemic pressure? Increased"
"What two factors influence the value for mean systemic pressure? Blood volume, venous tone"
"The slope of the vascular function curve is determined primarily by total peripheral resistance (TPR)"
"A(n) positive inotropic agent causes the cardiac function curve to shift upwards"
"A(n) negative inotropic agent causes the cardiac function curve to shift downwards"
"The intersection of the cardiac and vascular function curves is the operating point of the heart"
"A positive inotropic agent causes the cardiac output to increase and right atrial pressure to decrease"
"A negative inotropic agent causes the cardiac output to decrease and right atrial pressure to increase"
"An increased blood volume (or venous tone) causes the cardiac output to increase and right atrial pressure to increase"
"A decreased blood volume (or venous tone) causes the cardiac output to decrease and right atrial pressure to decrease"
"An increased TPR causes the cardiac output to decrease and venous return to decrease"
"A decreased TPR causes the cardiac output to increase and venous return to increase"
"A(n) decrease in TPR causes a(n) clockwise rotation of the vascular function curve"
"A(n) increase in TPR causes a(n) counterclockwise rotation of the vascular function curve"
"A(n) decrease in TPR causes a(n) upward shift of the cardiac function curve"
"A(n) increase in TPR causes a(n) downward shift of the cardiac function curve"
"What equation is used to calculate mean arterial pressure using a patient's cardiac output? MAP = CO x TPR"
"Mean arterial pressure is maintained at a constant level of approximately 100 mmHg"
"The baroreceptor reflex is a fast, neurally mediated mechanism of regulating arterial pressure"
"What type of receptor acts as a pressure sensor? Baroreceptor"
"Baroreceptors are stretch mechanoreceptors located within the carotid sinus and the aortic arch"
"Which baroreceptors are responsive to both increases and decreases in arterial pressure? Carotid sinus receptors"
"Which baroreceptors are responsive to increases in arterial pressure only? Aortic arch receptors"
"Information from the carotid sinus baroreceptor is carried to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) via the glossopharyngeal nerve"
"Information from the aortic arch baroreceptors is carried to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) via the vagus nerve"
"What effect does decreased stretch (e.g. hemorrhage) have on the afferent firing rate of a baroreceptor? Decreased firing rate"
"In response to decreased afferent baroreceptor firing, there is increased efferent sympathetic firing (baroreceptor reflex)"
"In response to decreased afferent baroreceptor firing, there is decreased efferent parasympathetic firing (baroreceptor reflex)"
"How does decreased efferent parasympathetic firing (e.g. baroreceptor reflex) affect heart rate? Increased HR"
"How does increased efferent sympathetic firing (e.g. baroreceptor reflex) affect heart rate? Increased HR"
"How does increased efferent sympathetic firing (e.g. baroreceptor reflex) affect contractility? Increased contractility"
"How does increased efferent sympathetic firing (e.g. baroreceptor reflex) affect TPR? Increased TPR (via increased arteriolar vasoconstriction)"
"How does increased efferent sympathetic firing (e.g. baroreceptor reflex) affect venoconstriction? Increased venoconstriction"
"The integrity of the baroreceptor reflex can be tested with the Valsalva maneuver"
"What change in heart rate is expected during the valsalva maneuver if the patient's baroreceptor reflex is intact? Increased HR"
"The a wave on jugular venous pulse corresponds to atrial contraction"
"The c wave on jugular venous pulse corresponds to right ventricle contraction"
"The x descent on jugular venous pulse corresponds to atrial relaxation"
"The v wave on jugular venous pulse corresponds to right atrial filling"
"The y descent on jugular venous pulse corresponds to right atrial emptying into the right ventricle"
"The renin-angiotensin II-aldosterone system is a slow, hormonally mediated mechanism of regulating arterial pressure"
"The renin-angiotensin II-aldosterone system regulates mean arterial pressure primarily by adjusting blood volume"
"The renin-angiotensin II-aldosterone system is activated in response to a(n) decrease in mean arterial pressure"
"A decrease in renal perfusion pressure causes the juxtaglomerular cells of the afferent arterioles to secrete renin"
"Renin is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I in the plasma"
"Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) catalyzes the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II"
"In which organ does angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) catalyze conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II? Lungs (primarily)"
"Angiotensin II stimulates the synthesis and secretion of aldosterone by the adrenal cortex"
"Angiotensin II increases Na+-H+ exchange in the proximal convoluted tubule"
"Angiotensin II increases thirst via its action on the hypothalamus"
"Angiotensin II causes constriction of arterioles"
"Peripheral chemoreceptors are located in the carotid bodies and aortic bodies"
"Peripheral chemoreceptors are stimulated by decreased Po2 and pH"
"Peripheral chemoreceptors are stimulated by increased Paco2"
"Central chemoreceptors are stimulated by changes in pH and Pco2 of the brain"
"When the brain is ischemic, the Pco2 increases and pH decreases"
"In response to increased Pco2 in the brain, there is intense peripheral vasoconstriction"
"Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) is released from atrial myocytes in response to increased blood volume and atrial pressure"
"Through which secondary messenger does ANP exert its actions? cGMP"
"Atrial natriuretic peptide generally causes dilation of arterioles"
"What effect does atrial natriuretic peptide have on Na+ reabsorption at the renal collecting tubule? Decreased reabsorption"
"Atrial natriuretic peptide dilates afferent renal arterioles and constricts efferent renal arterioles, which increases excretion of Na+ and water, along with downregulating ENaC on the collecting tubules"
"Atrial baroreceptors respond to decreased blood volume by increasing release of vasopressin (ADH) from the posterior pituitary"
"Vasopressin (ADH) causes constriction of arterioles by activating V1 receptors"
"Vasopressin (ADH) causes water reabsorption by the renal distal tubule and collecting ducts by activating V2 receptors"
"At the junction of the arterioles and capillaries is a smooth muscle band called the pre-capillary sphincter"
"Lipid-soluble substances cross the membranes of capillary endothelial cells by simple diffusion"
"Small water-soluble substances cross the membranes of capillary endothelial cells by aqueous clefts (between endothelial cells)"
"Large water-soluble substances cross the membranes of capillary endothelial cells by pinocytosis"
"The effective osmotic pressure contributed by protein is called the oncotic pressure"
"The Starling equation is used to determine fluid flow (Jv) and states that Jv = Kf [(Pc - Pi) - σ(πc −πi)]"
"When Jv (fluid flow) is positive, there is net fluid movement out of the capillary (filtration)"
"When Jv (fluid flow) is negative, there is net fluid movement into the capillary (absorption)"
"When net fluid movement is out of the capillary into the interstitial fluid, it is called filtration"
"When net fluid movement is into the capillary from the interstitial fluid, it is called absorption"
"The magnitude of fluid movement is determined by the hydraulic conductance (Kf) of the capillary wall"
"What does Kf represent in regards to capillary fluid exchange? Permeability to fluid (water)"
"What does Pc represent in regards to capillary fluid exchange? Capillary hydrostatic pressure"
"Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc) pushes fluid out of the capillary"
"Capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc) is highest at the arteriolar end of the capillary and lowest at the venous end"
"What does Pi represent in regards to capillary fluid exchange? Interstitial hydrostatic pressure"
"Increased interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi) pushes fluid into the capillary"
"What does πc represent in regards to capillary fluid exchange? Capillary oncotic pressure"
"Increased capillary oncotic pressure (πc) pulls fluid into the capillary"
"What does πi represent in regards to capillary fluid exchange? Interstitial oncotic pressure"
"Increased interstitial oncotic pressure (πi) pulls fluid out of the capillary"
"The excess fluid filtered out of the capillaries is returned to the circulation via lymph"
"Capillary fluid transudation results in clinically apparent edema when the fluid outflow (net plasma filtration) has risen sufficiently to overwhelm the resorptive capacity of tissue lymphatics"
"Edema may be caused by increased capillary pressure (Pc)"
"Edema may be caused by decreased plasma proteins (πc)"
"Edema may be caused by increased capillary permeability (Kf)"
"Edema may be caused by increased interstitial proteins (πi)"
"What is the effect of capillary injury (e.g. toxins, burns) on capillary permeability, Kf? Increased Kf"
"Autoregulation is the maintenance of a constant blood flow to an organ in the face of changing arterial pressures"
"Active hyperemia is the concept that blood flow to an organ is proportional to its metabolic activity"
"Reactive hyperemia is an increase in blood flow in response to a prior period of decreased blood flow"
"The vasodilator metabolites produced by tissues as a result of increased metabolic activity may be remembered using the mnemonic \CHALK\\": C: CO2 H: H+ A: Adenosine L: Lactate K: K+\""
"Histamine causes arteriolar dilation and venous constriction"
"Bradykinin causes arteriolar dilation and venous constriction"
"Serotonin causes arteriolar constriction"
"The E-series prostaglandins are vaso-dilators"
"The F-series prostaglandins are vaso-constrictors"
"Thromboxane A2 is a vaso-constrictor"
"What is the major factor determining autoregulation of blood flow to the heart? Local metabolites"
"The most important local metabolic factors for coronary circulation are nitric oxide (NO) and adenosine (vasodilatory)"
"What is the major factor determining autoregulation of blood flow to the brain? Local metabolites (vasodilatory)"
"The most important local metabolic factors for cerebral circulation are CO2 and H+ (pH)"
"What is the major factor determining autoregulation of blood flow to the lungs? Hypoxia (causes vasoconstriction)"
"In the lungs, hypoxia causes vaso-constriction"
"In most organs, hypoxia leads to compensatory vaso-dilation"
"What are the major factors determining autoregulation of blood flow to the villanous kidney? Myogenic and tubuloglomerular feedback::2"
"What is the major factor determining autoregulation of blood flow to the resting skeletal muscle? Sympathetic innervation"
"Sympathetic stimulation of α1 receptors in skeletal muscle causes vaso-constriction"
"Sympathetic stimulation of β2 receptors in skeletal muscle causes vaso-dilation"
"What is the major factor determining autoregulation of blood flow to the exercising skeletal muscle? Local metabolites"
"What is the major factor determining autoregulation of blood flow to the skin? Sympathetic innervation"
"The primary function of autoregulation of blood flow to the skin is temperature regulation"
"Exposure to cold temperatures causes increased activation of thyroid hormone"
"Exposure to cold temperatures causes increased sympathetic nervous system activity"
"Exposure to cold temperatures activates centers in the posterior hypothalamus, which then activate α and γ motoneurons innervating skeletal muscle, causing shivering"
"Mechanisms for dissipating heat are coordinated in the anterior hypothalamus"
"Increased body temperature causes decreased sympathetic nervous system activity"
"Pyrogens induce fever via increased production of IL-1, which acts on the anterior hypothalamus to increase local production of prostaglandins"
"How does exercise affect total peripheral resistance? Decreased TPR"
"When a person moves from a supine to a standing position, blood pools in the veins of the lower extremities"
"Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) is a good approximation of left atrial pressure"
"In mitral stenosis, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) is greater than LV end diastolic pressure"
"How is pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) measured? Pulmonary artery catheter (Swan-Ganz catheter)"
"What is the approximate normal pressure in the right atrium? < 5 mmHg"
"What is the approximate normal pressure in the right ventricle (systolic and diastolic)? 25/5 mmHg"
"What is the approximate normal pressure in the left atrium? < 12 mmHg"
"What is the approximate normal pressure in the left ventricle (systolic and diastolic)? 130/10 mmHg"
"What is the approximate normal pressure in the pulmonary artery (systolic and diastolic)? 25/10 mmHg"
"What is the approximate normal pressure in the aorta (systolic and diastolic)? 130/90 mmHg"
"B-type (brain) natriuretic peptide (BNP) is released from ventricular myocytes in response to increased tension"
"A B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) blood test is used for diagnosing heart failure"
"Torsades de pointes is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with shifting sinusoidal waveforms on ECG"
"Torsades de pointes can progress to ventricular fibrillation (VF)"
"A long QT interval predisposes to torsades de pointes"
"Treatment for torsades de pointes includes magnesium sulfate"
"Deficiencies of which two cations are associated with torsades de pointes? K+ and Mg2+"
"Congenital long QT syndrome is an inherited disorder of myocardial repolarization, typically due to ion channel defects"
"Congenital long QT syndrome has increased risk of sudden cardiac death (SCD) due to torsades de pointes"
"Romano-Ward syndrome is a form of long QT syndrome that is purely cardiac (no deafness)"
"Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome is a form of long QT syndrome that involves sensorineural deafness"
"What is the inheritance of Romano-Ward syndrome (a form of long QT syndrome)? Autosomal dominant"
"What is the inheritance of Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome (a form of long QT syndrome)? Autosomal recessive"
"What is the inheritance of Brugada syndrome? Autosomal dominant"
"What demographic is most commonly affected by Brugada syndrome? Asian males"
"Brugada syndrome presents with an ECG pattern of pseudo-right bundle branch block and ST elevations in leads V1 - V3"
"Patients with Brugada syndrome are at increased risk of ventricular tachyarrhythmias and sudden cardiac death (SCD)"
"Patients with Brugada syndrome may prevent sudden cardiac death with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD)"
"Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is the most common type of ventricular pre-excitation syndrome"
"Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is due to an abnormally fast accessory conduction pathway from the atria to ventricle via the bundle of Kent, which bypasses the slower AV node"
"Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome presents with a characteristic delta wave on ECG"
"Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome presents with a(n) widened QRS complex and shortened PR interval on ECG"
"Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome may result in re-entry circuit, causing supraventricular tachycardia"
"During inspiration there is a(n) decrease in intrathoracic pressure, which increases venous return"
"Increased venous return during inspiration leads to increased RV filling and ejection time"
"Increased RV ejection time during inspiration causes delayed closure of the pulmonic valve (normal splitting)"
"Wide splitting is a delayed pulmonic sound, especially on inspiration, seen in conditions that delay right ventricle emptying"
"Fixed splitting is a delayed pulmonic sound, regardless of inspiration"
"What pathology is associated with fixed splitting? Atrial septal defect (ASD)"
"Paradoxical splitting is heard in conditions that delay aortic valve closure"
"In paradoxical splitting, the P2 sound occurs before a delayed A2 sound"
"Does aortic stenosis cause a systolic or diastolic murmur? Systolic murmur"
"What is the shape of a murmur due to aortic stenosis? Crescendo-decrescendo"
"Where is a murmur due to aortic stenosis the loudest? Heart base (aortic area)"
"A murmur due to aortic stenosis may radiate to the carotid arteries"
"Does mitral/tricuspid regurgitation cause a systolic or diastolic murmur? Holo-systolic murmur"
"A holosystolic high-pitched \blowing\\" murmur is indicative of what pathology? Mitral/tricuspid regurgitation\""
"Where is a murmur due to mitral regurgitation the loudest? Apex (mitral area)"
"A murmur due to mitral regurgitation may radiate to the axilla"
"Where is a murmur due to tricuspid regurgitation the loudest? Tricuspid area"
"A murmur due to tricuspid regurgitation may radiate to the right sternal border"
"Does mitral valve prolapse cause a systolic or diastolic murmur? Late systolic (with midsystolic click)"
"A murmur with a midsystolic click is indicative of what pathology? Mitral valve prolapse"
"What causes the midsystolic click in a murmur due to mitral valve prolapse? Sudden tensing of chordae tendinae"
"What is the shape of a murmur due to mitral valve prolapse? Late crescendo"
"Where is a murmur due to mitral valve prolapse the loudest? Apex (mitral area)"
"A murmur due to mitral valve prolapse is loudest just before which heart sound? S2"
"Does a ventricular septal defect cause a systolic or diastolic murmur? Holo-systolic"
"Where is a murmur due to ventricular septal defect the loudest? Tricuspid area"
"Does aortic regurgitation cause a systolic or diastolic murmur? Diastolic"
"What is the shape of a murmur due to aortic regurgitation? Early decrescendo"
"Does mitral stenosis cause a systolic or diastolic murmur? Diastolic"
"A delayed, rumbling late diastolic murmur is indicative of what pathology? Mitral stenosis"
"A murmur with an opening snap is most likely indicative of what pathology? Mitral stenosis"
"A continuous, machine-like murmur is indicative of what pathology? Patent ductus arteriosus"
"A murmur due to patent ductus arteriosus is loudest at which heart sound? S2"
"What is the likely cause of this murmur: aortic stenosis"
"What is the likely cause of this high-pitched, \blowing\\" murmur: mitral/tricuspid regurgitation\""
"What is the likely cause of this murmur: mitral valve prolapse"
"What is the likely cause of this harsh-sounding murmur: ventricular septal defect"
"What is the likely cause of this murmur: aortic regurgitation"
"What is the most likely cause of this murmur: mitral stenosis"
"What is the likely cause of this murmur? Patent ductus arteriosus"
"Vasculitis is defined as inflammation of the blood vessel wall"
"The innermost layer of the arterial wall is the intima, which consists of endothelial cells on a basement membrane"
"The middle layer of the arterial wall is the media, which consists of smooth muscle"
"The outer layer of the arterial wall is the adventitia, which consists of connective tissue surrounding blood vessel"
"Vasculitides often present with symptoms of organ ischemia due to thrombosis of inflamed vessels or luminal narrowing from fibrosis"
"Giant cell (temporal) arteritis is a form of large-vessel vasculitis"
"Giant cell (temporal) arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis that classically involves branches of the carotid artery"
"What demographic is classically affected by giant cell (temporal) arteritis? Elderly females (> 50)"
"Giant cell (temporal) arteritis may present with unilateral headache due to involvement of the temporal artery"
"Giant cell (temporal) arteritis may present with jaw claudication"
"Giant cell (temporal) arteritis may present with visual disturbances due to involvement of the ophthalmic artery"
"Giant cell (temporal) arteritis is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica, which is characterized by aching/stiffness of the shoulders and hips"
"How does the ESR change in a patient with giant cell (temporal) arteritis? Increased (often >100)"
"Biopsy of a patient with giant cell (temporal) arteritis reveals an inflamed vessel with giant cells and focal granulomatous inflammation"
"Biopsy of a patient with giant cell (temporal) arteritis reveals intimal fibrosis"
"The lesions of giant cell (temporal) arteritis are segmental, therefore diagnosis requires biopsy of a long segment of the vessel"
"What is the treatment for a patient with giant cell (temporal) arteritis? High-dose corticosteroids and tocilizumab"
"Without treatment, patients with giant cell (temporal) arteritis are at high risk for blindness"
"Takayasu arteritis is a form of large-vessel vasculitis"
"Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous thickening and narrowing of the aortic arch and proximal great vessels"
"What demographic is classically affected by Takayasu arteritis? Young Asian females (< 40)"
"Takayasu arteritis may present with visual and neurologic symptoms"
"Takayasu arteritis is associated with a(n) weak or absent pulse in the upper extremity"
"How does the ESR change in a patient with Takayasu arteritis? Increased"
"What is the treatment for a patient with Takayasu arteritis? Corticosteroids"
"Polyarteritis nodosa is a form of medium-vessel vasculitis"
"What demographic is classically affected by polyarteritis nodosa? Middle-aged men::age group"
"Polyarteritis nodosa is a necrotizing vasculitis that involves most organs, except the lungs"
"Polyarteritis nodosa may present with hypertension due to involvement of the renal artery"
"Polyarteritis nodosa may present with abdominal pain and melena due to involvement of the mesenteric artery"
"Polyarteritis nodosa may present with neurologic disturbances/dysfunction"
"Polyarteritis nodosa may present with skin lesions (e.g. cutaneous eruptions) in up to 1/3 of patients"
"Polyarteritis nodosa is a necrotizing vasculitis that is associated with positive serum HBsAg in 30% of patients"
"Early lesions of polyarteritis nodosa are characterized by transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis"
"Late lesions of polyarteritis nodosa are characterized by fibrosis, leading to vessel narrowing"
"The combination of dilatation (aneurysms) and narrowing (fibrosis) in polyarteritis nodosa gives blood vessels a(n) \string of pearls\\" appearance on imaging\""
"Polyarteritis nodosa is characterized by innumerable renal microaneurysms and spasms on arteriogram"
"What drugs may be used to treat a patient with polyarteritis nodosa? Corticosteroids, cyclophosphamide::2"
"Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) is a form of medium-vessel vasculitis"
"What demographic is classically affected by Kawasaki disease? Asian children < 4 years old"
"Which artery is commonly affected in Kawasaki disease? Coronary artery"
"Patients with Kawasaki disease may develop coronary artery thrombosis, which can lead to myocardial infarction"
"Patients with Kawasaki disease may develop coronary artery aneurysms, which can rupture; therefore, get a(n) echo::diagnostic test"
"The symptoms of Kawasaki disease may be remembered with the mnemonic \CRASH and burn\\": C: Conjunctivitis R: Rash (polymorphous -> desquamating) A: Adenopathy (cervical lymph nodes) S: Strawberry tongue (oral mucositis) H: Hand-foot erythema and edema & Burn: Fever\""
"Treatment for Kawasaki disease includes aspirin and IVIG"
"Buerger disease (thromboangiitis obliterans) is a form of segmenting medium-vessel vasculitis that extends into contiguous veins and nerves"
"What demographic is classically affected by Buerger disease? Heavy smokers, males < 40 years old"
"Buerger disease is a segmental thrombosing vasculitis that commonly involves the digits"
"Buerger disease often presents with intermittent claudication that may lead to gangrene and autoamputation of digits"
"Patients with Buerger disease often experience Raynaud's phenomenon"
"What is the treatment for Buerger disease? Smoking cessation"
"Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener) is a form of small-vessel vasculitis"
"Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener) is a form of necrotizing, granulomatous vasculitis that classically involves the nasopharynx, lungs, and kidneys"
"Granulomatosis with polyangiitis most commonly affects middle aged men and these patients commonly have a(n) saddle nose deformity"
"Granulomatosis with polyangiitis often presents with upper respiratory tract symptoms, such as sinusitis or nasopharyngeal ulceration"
"Granulomatosis with polyangiitis often presents with lower respiratory tract symptoms, such as hemoptysis, cough, and dyspnea"
"Granulomatosis with polyangiitis often presents with kidney-related symptoms, such as hematuria, red cell casts, and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN)"
"Which vasculitis is characterized by a triad of: (1) Focal necrotizing vasculitis (2) Necrotizing granulomas in the lung and upper airway (3) Necrotizing glomerulonephritis Granulomatosis with polyangiitis"
"What does a chest X-ray of a patient with Granulomatosis with polyangiitis show? Bilateral large nodular densities/infiltrates"
"What significant laboratory finding is associated with Wegener granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis)? Positive c-ANCA"
"What drugs may be used to treat Granulomatosis with polyangiitis? Cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids::2"
"Microscopic polyangiitis is a form of small-vessel vasculitis"
"Microscopic polyangiitis is a necrotizing vasculitis that commonly involves the lungs, kidneys, and skin"
"How does microscopic polyangiitis present differently from granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener)?  GPA: + nasopharyngeal involvement, + granulomas, c-ANCA MPA: - nasopharyngeal involvement, - granulomas, p-ANCA ::2 things + bonus: name the antibody"
"What significant laboratory finding is associated with microscopic polyangiitis? Positive p-ANCA"
"What drugs may be used to treat microscopic polyangiitis? Cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids::2"
"Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-strauss) is a form of small-vessel vasculitis"
"What type of white blood cell is elevated in Churg-Strauss syndrome? Eosinophils"
"Which serum immunoglobulin is elevated in Churg-Strauss syndrome? IgE"
"What vasculitis is a granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis with eosinophilia? Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)"
"What two organs are commonly affected by Churg-Strauss syndrome? Heart and lungs"
"What respiratory pathology is commonly associated with Churg-Strauss syndrome? Asthma"
"Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss), a small-vessel vasculitis, commonly presents with asymmetric multifocal neuropathy, typically manifesting with wrist drop and foot drop"
"What significant laboratory finding is associated with Churg Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)? Positive p-ANCA"
"Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a form of small-vessel vasculitis"
"What demographic is classically affected by Henoch-Schonlein purpura? Children::age group"
"Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a vasculitis that occurs secondary to IgA immune complex deposition"
"The classic clinical triad of Henoch-Schonlein purpura is palpable purpura on the buttocks and legs, arthralgias, and abdominal pain"
"Henoch-Schonlein purpura is associated with IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)"
"Henoch-Schonlein purpura often occurs following a(n) upper respiratory tract infection, which leads to generation of IgA"
"What is the treatment for Henoch-Schonlein purpura? Disease is self-limited; treat with steroids if severe"
"Hypertension is defined as persistent systolic BP > 130 mmHg and/or diastolic BP > 80 mmHg"
"What ethnicity has the highest risk of developing hypertension? African Americans"
"What ethnicity has the lowest risk of developing hypertension? Asians"
"Primary (essential) hypertension (90-95% of cases) has no known etiology"
"Primary hypertension is related to increased cardiac output and TPR"
"Secondary hypertension (5-10% of cases) is due to an identifiable etiology"
"Secondary hypertension may be caused by renal artery stenosis, which leads to increased plasma renin and unilateral atrophy of the affected kidney"
"What is the most common cause of secondary hypertension in elderly males? Atherosclerosis"
"What is a possible cause of secondary hypertension that occurs in young females? Fibromuscular dysplasia"
"Fibromuscular dysplasia results in the irregular thickening of medium/large arteries which manifests as a \string of beads\\" appearance on imaging\""
"Secondary hypertension may be caused by primary hyper-aldosteronism"
"Hypertensive urgency is defined as severe hypertension (>180 / >120 mmHg) without acute end-organ damage"
"Hypertensive emergency is defined as severe hypertension (>180 / >120 mmHg) with acute end-organ damage"
"Arteriosclerosis is defined as the hardening of arteries, with arterial wall thickening and loss of elasticity"
"Atherosclerosis is a form of arteriosclerosis that damages large- and medium-sized vessels due to buildup of cholesterol plaques"
"Which part of the blood vessel wall is affected by atherosclerosis? Intima"
"Atherosclerosis is caused by a buildup of intimal plaques that obstruct blood flow"
"The intimal plaque that causes atherosclerosis consists of a necrotic lipid core (mostly cholesterol) with a(n) fibromuscular cap"
"The intimal plaque that causes atherosclerosis often undergoes dystrophic calcification"
"What four arteries are most commonly affected by atherosclerosis? Lower abdominal aorta > coronary > popliteal > carotid artery"
"What are the four modifiable risk factors for atherosclerosis? Hypertension, hypercholesterolemia (LDL), smoking, diabetes"
"What are the three non-modifiable risk factors for atherosclerosis? Age, gender, genetics"
"Atherosclerosis begins with endothelial cell dysfunction which allows lipids to leak into the intima"
"Lipids in the intima of an artery are oxidized and then consumed by macrophages via scavenger receptor A receptors"
"Macrophage consumption of oxidized lipids in the intima results in foam cell formation and \fatty streaks\\"\""
"In response to fatty streaks in the intima, there is smooth muscle cell migration/proliferation and extracellular matrix deposition"
"Smooth muscle proliferation and ECM deposition in the arterial intima leads to the formation of fibrous plaques and ultimately complex atheromas"
"Symptoms of atherosclerosis generally present when >70% of a vessel has been occluded (stenosis)"
"One complication of atherosclerosis is peripheral vascular disease, which may result from stenosis of the popliteal artery"
"One complication of atherosclerosis is angina, which may result from stenosis of the coronary artery"
"One complication of atherosclerosis is chronic mesenteric ischemia, which may result from stenosis of the mesenteric artery"
"One complication of atherosclerosis is myocardial infarction, which may result from plaque rupture with thrombosis of the coronary artery"
"One complication of atherosclerosis is stroke, which may result from plaque rupture with thrombosis of the middle cerebral artery"
"Plaque rupture from atherosclerosis may result in atherosclerotic emboli, which are characterized by cholesterol clefts"
"Atherosclerosis may cause weakening of the blood vessel wall, which can result in aneurysm"
"Arteriolosclerosis is a form of arteriosclerosis that damages small arteries and arterioles"
"Hyaline arteriolosclerosis is caused by proteins leaking into the vessel wall, producing vascular thickening"
"What type of arteriolosclerosis is demonstrated in the image below? Hyaline arteriolosclerosis"
"Hyaline arteriolosclerosis results in reduced vessel caliber with end-organ ischemia, which classically produces glomerular scarring"
"Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis is caused by hyperplasia of smooth muscle, resulting in thickening of the vessel wall"
"What type of arteriolosclerosis is demonstrated in the image below? Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis"
"Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis has an 'onion-skin' appearance on histology"
"What underlying pathology is associated with hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis? Severe (malignant) hypertension"
"Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis may lead to fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall with hemorrhage"
"Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis classically causes acute kidney injury with a 'flea-bitten::gross' appearance"
"Monckeberg sclerosis is an uncommon form of arteriosclerosis that involves calcification of the media of the blood vessel wall"
"Monckeberg sclerosis is non-obstructive and therefore is not clinically significant"
"Monckeberg sclerosis is characterized by a \pipestem\\" appearance on x-ray\""
"Risk of atherosclerosis is increased in men and postmenopausal women"
"Aortic dissection is a longitudinal intimal tear with transmission of blood through the media of the aortic wall"
"Aortic dissection usually occurs in the proximal 10 cm of the aorta (high stress region)"
"The most common cause of aortic dissection in older adults is hypertension"
"Hyaline arteriolosclerosis of the vasa vasorum results in atrophy of the aortic media and weakening of the vessel wall"
"Aortic dissection is associated with inherited connective tissue disorders"
"Aortic dissection is associated with a(n) bicuspid aortic valve"
"Aortic dissection may present with sudden sharp, tearing chest pain that radiates to the back"
"Chest X-ray of a patient with aortic dissection shows mediastinal widening"
"Aortic dissection may lead to obstruction of branching arteries, thus causing end-organ ischemia"
"Aortic dissection may result in rupture into the mediastinum, causing fatal hemorrhage"
"Aortic dissection may result in cardiac tamponade as a result of backflow into the pericardium"
"Stanford type A (proximal) aortic dissection involves the ascending aorta"
"Stanford type B (distal) aortic dissection involves the descending aorta and/or the aortic arch"
"What is the treatment for Stanford type A aortic dissection? Surgery"
"What is the treatment for Stanford type B aortic dissection? β-blockers, then vasodilators"
"Aortic aneurysm is a localized pathologic dilatation of the aorta"
"Aortic aneurysm may cause abdominal and/or back pain, which is a sign of leaking, dissection, or imminent rupture"
"Thoracic aortic aneurysm is classically seen in patients with tertiary syphilis due to endarteritis of the vasa vasorum"
"Tertiary syphilis results in a 'tree-bark' appearance of the aorta"
"Thoracic aortic aneurysm is associated with cystic medial degeneration (e.g. Marfan syndrome)"
"Risk factors for thoracic aneurysm include bicuspid aortic valve and hypertension"
"Thoracic aneurysm is associated with inherited connective tissue disorders"
"A major complication of thoracic aneurysm is dilation of the aortic valve root resulting in aortic regurgitation (insufficiency)"
"Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) usually arises below the renal arteries, but above the aortic birfucation"
"The two underlying pathological processes that are associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm are chronic transmural inflammation and atherosclerosis"
"What demographic is commonly associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm? Males > 60 (usually a smoker with HTN)"
"Abdominal aortic aneurysm may present as a palpable, pulsatile abdominal mass that grows with time"
"A major complication associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm is rupture, especially when >5 cm in diameter"
"Abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture presents with a triad of hypotension, a pulsatile abdominal mass, and flank pain"
"Traumatic aortic rupture (due to trauma and/or deceleration injury) most commonly occurs at the aortic isthmus"
"Hemangiomas are benign tumors comprised of blood vessels"
"Hemangiomas most often involve the skin and liver"
"Hemangiomas commonly present at birth and often regress during childhood"
"Angiosarcomas are highly aggressive malignant proliferations of endothelial cells"
"Where is a murmur due to aortic regurgitation the loudest? Left sternal border"
"Where is a murmur due to atrial septal defect the loudest? Pulmonic Area"
"Where is a murmur due to pulmonic stenosis the loudest? Pulmonic area"
"Ischemic heart disease is usually due to atherosclerosis of coronary arteries"
"Angina is chest pain due to myocardial ischemia (secondary to coronary artery narrowing or spasm)"
"Does angina cause myocyte necrosis? No, damage is reversible"
"Stable angina is characterized by chest pain that arises with exertion or emotional stress"
"Stable angina is often due to atherosclerosis of coronary arteries with >70% stenosis"
"Stable angina often presents with chest pain lasting < 20 minutes that radiates to the left arm or jaw"
"Stable angina is often relieved by rest or with nitroglycerin"
"What ECG findings are associated with stable angina? ST-segment depression (subendocardial ischemia)"
"Unstable angina is characterized by chest pain that occurs during rest"
"Unstable angina is due to rupture of atherosclerotic plaque with thrombosis and incomplete occlusion of a coronary artery"
"What ECG findings are associated with unstable angina? ST-segment depression and/or T-wave inversion::2"
"What drug may be used to relieve symptoms due to unstable angina? Nitroglycerin"
"Unstable angina has a high risk of progression to myocardial infarction"
"Vasospastic (variant/prinzmetal) angina is characterized by episodic chest pain during rest due to coronary artery spasm"
"What ECG findings are associated with vasospastic angina? ST-segment elevation (transmural ischemia)"
"Vasospastic angina is relieved by nitrate drugs, dihydropyridine Ca2+ channel blockers, and smoke cessation (if applicable)"
"Known triggers of Vasospastic angina include tobacco, cocaine, and triptans"
"Coronary steal syndrome occurs when administration of vasodilators shunts blood towards well-perfused areas, increasing ischemia in post-stenotic regions"
"Coronary steal syndrome occurs because distal to coronary stenosis, vessels are maximally dilated at baseline"
"Coronary steal syndrome is the principle behind pharmacologic stress tests"
"Does myocardial infarction cause myocyte necrosis? Yes, damage is irreversible"
"Myocardial infarction is often due to rupture of atherosclerotic plaque with thrombosis and complete occlusion of a coronary artery"
"Myocardial infarction often presents with severe crushing chest pain lasting > 20 minutes that radiates to the left arm or jaw"
"One less common cause of myocardial infarction is coronary artery vasospasm (e.g. vasospastic angina, cocaine use)"
"One less common cause of myocardial infarction is vasculitis (e.g. Kawasaki disease)"
"Myocardial infarction may present with dyspnea due to pulmonary congestion and edema"
"What heart chamber is most commonly affected by myocardial infarction? Left ventricle"
"Myocardial infarction most commonly involves the left anterior descending (LAD) artery (45%)"
"The second most common artery involved in a myocardial infarction is the right coronary artery"
"The third most common artery involved in a myocardial infarction is the left circumflex artery"
"The initial phase of myocardial infarction leads to subendocardial::region necrosis involving < 50% of the myocardial thickness"
"The initial phase of myocardial infarction (subendocardial infarcts) shows ST-segment depression on ECG"
"The later phase of myocardial infarction (transmural infarcts) shows ST-segment elevation and Q waves on ECG"
"When suspecting a myocardial infarction, laboratory tests are used to detect elevated cardiac enzymes"
"In the first 6 hours, either ECG or troponin are the gold standards for diagnosis of myocardial infarction"
"What is the most sensitive and specific cardiac biomarker used for diagnosis of myocardial infarction? Troponin I"
"Troponin I levels rise 2-4 hours after an MI and peak at 24 hours"
"Troponin I levels return to normal 7-10 days after an MI"
"CK-MB is a cardiac biomarker that is useful for detecting reinfarction following acute MI"
"CK-MB levels rise 6-12 hours after an MI and peak at 16-24 hours"
"CK-MB levels return to normal 48-72 hours after an MI"
"Large myocardial infarctions lead to greater elevations in troponin I and CK-MB"
"CK-MB is predominantly found in myocardium, but can also be released from skeletal muscle"
"What anti-coagulation drug is frequently used to treat acute coronary syndromes (e.g. unstable angina, STEMI, NSTEMI)? Heparin"
"Treatment of acute coronary syndromes (e.g. unstable angina, STEMI, NSTEMI) often includes antiplatelet therapy such as aspirin"
"Treatment of acute coronary syndromes often includes a(n) ADP receptor inhibitor such as clopidogrel"
"Treatment of acute coronary syndromes often includes β-blockers, which decrease heart rate and reduces risk of arrhythmia"
"Treatment of acute coronary syndromes often includes ACE inhibitors to decrease left ventricular dilation"
"Treatment of acute coronary syndromes often includes supplemental O2 to minimize ischemia"
"Initial treatment of acute coronary syndrome includes MONA (MONA greets chest pain patients at the door) - Morphine - Oxygen - Nitroglycerin - Aspirin"
"The most important treatment for STEMI is reperfusion therapy, such as angioplasty (preferred) or fibrinolysis"
"Reperfusion of irreversibly-damaged cells post-MI may result in Ca2+ influx, leading to hypercontraction of myofibrils (contraction band necrosis)"
