"Reperfusion of irreversibly-damaged cells post-MI may result in free radical formation (due to O2), further damaging myocytes (known as reperfusion injury)"
"What gross changes occur during the first 4 hours of a myocardial infarction? None :)"
"What microscopic changes occur during the first 4 hours of a myocardial infarction? None :)"
"One complication that may occur during the first 4 hours post-MI is cardiogenic shock, which occurs due to lack of blood flow to vital organs"
"One complication that may occur during the first 4 hours post-MI is congestive heart failure, which occurs due to inefficient pumping of the left ventricle"
"One complication that may occur during the first 24 hours post-MI is arrhythmia, which is an important cause of death before reaching the hospital"
"What gross changes occur from 4 - 24 hours post-MI? Dark discoloration"
"What microscopic changes occur from 4 - 24 hours post-MI? Coagulative necrosis"
"What gross changes occur from 1 - 3 days post-MI? Yellow pallor"
"What microscopic changes occur from 1 - 3 days post-MI? Neutrophils (acute inflammation)"
"Fibrinous pericarditis is an inflammatory post-MI complication that occurs after 2* to 4* days"
"Fibrinous pericarditis is a post-MI complication that presents as chest pain with friction rub"
"What gross changes occur from 4 - 7 days post-MI? Yellow pallor"
"What microscopic changes occur from 3 - 10 days post-MI? Macrophage infiltration (acute inflammation)*"
"One complication that may occur 5 - 14 days post-MI is ventricular free wall rupture, which causes cardiac tamponade"
"One complication that may occur 3 - 5 days post-MI is interventricular septal rupture, which causes a ventricular septal defect (VSD)"
"One complication that may occur 3 - 5 days post-MI is papillary muscle rupture, which often causes mitral regurgitation"
"At 10 - 14 days post-MI, the following gross changes occur: emergence of the red border; due to granulation tissue entering from the edge of the infarct"
"What microscopic changes occur from 3 - 14 days post-MI? Granulation tissue*"
"What gross changes occur months after an MI? White scar"
"What microscopic changes occur months after an MI? Fibrosis"
"True ventricular aneurysm is a complication that may occur months after an MI and increases risk for mural thrombus"
"Dressler syndrome is an autoimmune complication that may occur several weeks (6-8) after an MI"
"Dressler syndrome is a(n) autoimmune phenomenon that results in fibrinous pericarditis following an MI (> 1 month)"
"Sudden cardiac death is death from cardiac causes within 1 hour of onset of symptoms"
"Sudden cardiac death is most commonly due to a lethal arrhythmia (e.g. ventricular fibrillation)"
"Sudden cardiac death may be prevented with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD)"
"90% of patients who suffer sudden cardiac death have pre-existing severe atherosclerosis"
"Chronic ischemic heart disease is the progressive onset of heart failure over many years due to chronic ischemic myocardial damage"
"Ventricular pseudo-aneurysm is a contained free wall rupture that may occur 3 - 14 days post-MI"
"Which artery is associated with anteroseptal myocardial infarction? Left anterior descending (LAD) artery"
"What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in an anteroseptal myocardial infarction? V1 - V2::2"
"Which artery is associated with anteroapical myocardial infarction? Distal left anterior descending (LAD) artery"
"What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in an anteroapical myocardial infarction? V3 - V4::2"
"Which arteries may be associated with anterolateral myocardial infarction? LAD or LCX::2"
"What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in an anterolateral myocardial infarction? V5 - V6::2"
"Which artery is associated with lateral myocardial infarction? Left circumflex (LCX) artery"
"What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in a lateral myocardial infarction? I, aVL::2"
"Which artery is typically associated with inferior myocardial infarction? Right coronary artery (RCA)"
"What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in an inferior myocardial infarction? II, III, aVF::3"
"Which artery is associated with posterior myocardial infarction? Posterior descending artery (PDA)"
"What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in a posterior myocardial infarction? V7 - V9"
"Heart failure is a clinical syndrome of cardiac pump dysfunction which causes congestion and low perfusion"
"How does ejection fraction change in heart failure with systolic dysfunction? Reduced EF"
"How does EDV change in heart failure with systolic dysfunction? Increased EDV"
"Systolic dysfunction (heart failure) occurs due to decreased contractility, often secondary to ischemia/MI or dilated cardiomyopathy"
"How does ejection fraction change in heart failure with diastolic dysfunction? Preserved EF"
"How does EDV change in heart failure with diastolic dysfunction? Normal EDV"
"Diastolic dysfunction (heart failure) occurs due to decreased compliance, often secondary to myocardial concentric hypertrophy"
"What is the most common cause of right heart failure? Left heart failure"
"Right heart failure may be caused by a long-standing left-to-right shunt"
"Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure due to pulmonary cause"
"Clinical features of left heart failure are due to decreased forward perfusion with consequent pulmonary congestion"
"Left::Left or Right heart failure may present with orthopnea, which is shortness of breath when supine"
"Left heart failure may present with paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, which is breathless awakening from sleep"
"Left heart failure may present with pulmonary edema due to increased pulmonary venous pressure"
"Left heart failure may present with hemosiderin-laden macrophages, known as heart failure cells, in the lungs"
"Left heart failure causes decreased forward perfusion to the kidneys, resulting in activation of the renin-angiotensin system"
"Clinical features of right heart failure are due to systemic congestion"
"Right heart failure may cause jugular venous distension due to increased systemic venous pressure"
"Right heart failure may cause painful hepatosplenomegaly, which rarely may progress to \cardiac cirrhosis\\"\""
"Right heart failure is associated with a characteristic \nutmeg\\" appearance of the liver\""
"Right heart failure is associated with peripheral edema due to increased venous pressure and thus fluid transudation"
"Heart failure may present with dependent pitting edema due to increased hydrostatic pressure"
"What sound on respiratory exam may be associated with heart failure? Rales / crackles"
"A mainstay of treatment for left heart failure is ACE inhibitors, which help counteract fluid retention and prevent heart remodeling"
"Congenital heart defects arise during embryogenesis, usually in weeks 3 through 8"
"Defects with left-to-right shunting may be relatively asymptomatic at birth, but the shunt can eventually reverse"
"Left-to-right shunting results in increased flow through the pulmonary circulation, causing pulmonary hypertension"
"The pulmonary hypertension seen with long-standing left-to-right shunts causes the right ventricle to hypertrophy"
"The combination of right ventricle hypertrophy and pulmonary hypertension in response to left-to-right shunting results in shunt reversal"
"Uncorrected left-to-right shunting eventually results in reversal, which presents with late cyanosis (Eisenmenger syndrome)"
"Eisenmenger syndrome is characterized by a triad of late cyanosis, clubbing, and polycythemia"
"Compared to right-to-left shunts, left-to-right shunts lead to cyanosis at a(n) later age"
"Compared to left-to-right shunts, right-to-left shunts lead to cyanosis at a(n) earlier age"
"What is the most common congenital heart defect? Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)"
"Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is associated with fetal alcohol syndrome"
"Ventricular septal defect (VSD) results in a(n) left-to-right shunt"
"Smaller ventricular septal defects are often asymptomatic and may close spontaneously, but on physical exam will present with a(n) murmur"
"How is a large ventricular septal defect treated? Surgical closure"
"What symptoms does ventricular septal defect typically present with at birth? Typically asymptomatic"
"Larger ventricular septal defects may lead to left ventricle overload and, consequently, heart failure"
"What is the most common type of Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)? Ostium secundum (90%)"
"Ostium primum is a less common type of atrial septal defect that is associated with Down syndrome"
"Atrial septal defect (ASD) results in a(n) left-to-right shunt"
"What effect does atrial septal defect (ASD) have on S2 splitting? Causes a wide, fixed split"
"Paradoxical emboli, an important complication of atrial septal defect, are emboli that arise on the right-side of the body and crossover to lodge on the left side"
"Atrial septal defect may be distinguished from a patent foramen ovale in that the septa are missing tissue rather than unfused"
"Patent ductus arteriosus is associated with congenital rubella infection"
"In the fetal period, the ductus arteriosus acts as a(n) right-to-left shunt"
"In the neonatal period, a patent ductus arteriosus becomes a(n) left-to-right shunt as pulmonary vascular resistance decreases"
"Patency of a patent ductus arteriosus is maintained by PGE synthesis and low O2 tension"
"Uncorrected patent ductus arteriosus may eventually result in late cyanosis in the lower extremities"
"Treatment of a patent ductus arteriosus involves indomethacin, which decreases PGE, resulting in PDA closure"
"Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart disease that is characterized by: 1. Pulmonary infundibular stenosis 2. Right ventricular hypertrophy 3. Overriding aorta 4. Ventricular septal defect (VSD)"
"Tetralogy of Fallot results in a(n) right-to-left shunt with early cyanosis"
"The degree of shunting in Tetralogy of Fallot is determined by the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (from pulmonary stenosis)"
"Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by a(n) boot-shaped heart on CXR"
"Patients with Tetralogy of Fallot often experience \tet spells\\" which may be caused by crying"
"Patients with Tetralogy of Fallot may squat in response to cyanotic spells, which decreases right-to-left shunting by increasing systemic vascular resistance (SVR)"
"What is the most common congenital heart defect that causes early cyanosis? Tetralogy of Fallot"
"Tetralogy of Fallot is caused by anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum"
"D-transposition of the great vessels is characterized by the pulmonary artery arising from the left ventricle and aorta from the right ventricle"
"D-transposition of the great vessels and VSD are associated with maternal diabetes::endocrine disorder"
"D-transposition of great vessels is not compatible with life unless a(n) shunt is created"
"D-transposition of great vessels is due to failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral"
"PGE may be administered to patients with D-transposition of great vessels to maintain a PDA until definitive surgical repair is performed"
"D-transposition of great vessels results in hypertrophy of the right ventricle and atrophy of the left ventricle"
"D-transposition of great vessels is an example of a(n) right-to-left shunt"
"Persistent truncus arteriosus is a congenital heart disease characterized by a single large vessel arising from both ventricles before eventually splitting"
"Truncus arteriosus is an example of a(n) right-to-left shunt"
"Most patients with truncus arteriosus have accompanying ventricular septal defect"
"Tricuspid atresia is the failure of the tricuspid valve orifice to develop"
"Tricuspid atresia leads to right ventricle hypoplasia"
"Tricuspid atresia requires both ASD and VSD for viability"
"Tricuspid atresia is an example of a(n) right-to-left shunt"
"Coarctation of the aorta is the narrowing of the aorta near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus"
"The infantile form of coarctation of the aorta is associated with a(n) PDA"
"In the infantile form, coarctation of the aorta lies after the aortic arch, but before the PDA"
"Coarctation of the aorta in infants presents as lower extremity cyanosis, often at birth"
"The infantile form of coarctation of the aorta is associated with Turner syndrome"
"In the adult form, coarctation of the aorta lies after the aortic arch"
"Coarctation of the aorta in adults presents as hypertension in the upper extremities and hypotension in the lower extremities"
"In the adult form of coarctation of the aorta, collateral circulation develops most notably across the intercostal arteries"
"What X-ray finding is associated with the adult form of coarctation of the aorta? 'Notching' of ribs (due to engorged intercostal arteries)"
"Coarctation of the aorta is associated with a(n) bicuspid aortic valve and an increased risk of developing berry aneurysms"
"What congenital heart defect is associated with lithium exposure in utero? Ebstein anomaly"
"Ebstein anomaly is a congenital heart disease characterized by downward displacement of tricuspid leaflets into the right ventricle"
"Ebstein anomaly is associated with tricuspid regurgitation and right heart failure"
"Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR) is a congenital heart disease characterized by drainage of pulmonary veins into the right circulation"
"Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR) is associated with ASD and sometimes PDA to allow for right-to-left shunting"
"Class I antiarrhythmics exert their actions by blocking Na+ channels"
"Class I antiarrhythmics decrease the slope of phase 0 (upstroke) of the myocardial action potential"
"What effect do class I antiarrhythmics have on conduction velocity of the myocardial action potential? Decreased CV"
"Class I antiarrhythmics bind to Na+ channels in their open or inactivated state"
"Na+ channels in rapidly depolarizing tissue (e.g. tachycardia) spend the most time in open or inactivated states"
"Class I antiarrhythmics have use dependence and thus selectively depress tissue that is frequently depolarized"
"What effect do class I antiarrhythmics have on the action potentials of the SA and AV nodes? No effect (only affects Na+-dependent action potentials)"
"Class I antiarrhythmics widen the QRS complex on ECG"
"What drug class does quinidine belong to? Class IA antiarrhythmics"
"Toxic doses of quinidine, an antiarrhythmic drug, may cause cinchonism, which is a syndrome of tinnitus, headache, and dizziness"
"Quinidine is an anti-arrhythmic that rarely causes immunologic reactions, resulting in thrombocytopenia"
"What drug class does procainamide belong to? Class IA antiarrhythmics"
"Procainamide, a class IA antiarrhythmic, can cause a reversible SLE-like syndrome as an adverse effect"
"What drug class does disopyramide belong to? Class IA antiarrhythmics"
"One adverse effect associated with disopyramide is exacerbation of heart failure, due to its negative inotropic effects"
"Class IA antiarrhythmics can cause QT interval prolongation which precipitates torsades de pointes"
"Class IA antiarrhythmics have a(n) intermediate binding affinity for the Na+ channel"
"In addition to Na+ channels, Class IA antiarrhythmics also block K+ channels"
"What effect do class IA antiarrhythmics have on action potential duration? Increased duration"
"What effect do class IA antiarrhythmics have on the effective refractory period in the ventricular tissue? Increased ERP"
"Are class IA antiarrhythmics used to treat supraventricular or ventricular arrhythmias? Both :)"
"Class IA antiarrhythmics may be used to treat Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, a type of SVT"
"What drug class does lidocaine belong to? Class IB antiarrhythmics"
"What antiarrhythmic drug class does phenytoin belong to? Class IB antiarrhythmics (anti-epileptic but has class IB properties)"
"What drug class does mexiletine belong to? Class IB antiarrhythmics"
"Class IB antiarrhythmics have a(n) low binding affinity for the Na+ channel"
"What effect do class IB antiarrhythmics have on action potential duration? Shortened duration"
"Class IB antiarrhythmics treat ventricular arrhythmias, especially in ischemic tissue (e.g. post-MI)"
"Class IB antiarrhythmics may be used to treat digitalis-induced arrhythmias"
"Class IB antiarrhythmics can cause neurological side effects (e.g. paresthesias, tremor, convulsions)"
"What drug class does flecainide belong to? Class IC antiarrhythmics"
"What drug class does propafenone belong to? Class IC antiarrhythmics"
"Class IC antiarrhythmics have a(n) strong binding affinity for the Na+ channel"
"What effect do class IC antiarrhythmics have on action potential duration? No effect"
"What effect do class IC antiarrhythmics have on the effective refractory period in the AV node and accessory bypass tracts? Significant prolongation of ERP"
"What effect do class IC antiarrhythmics have on the effective refractory period in the Purkinje and ventricular tissue? No effect"
"Are class IC antiarrhythmics used to treat supraventricular or ventricular arrhythmias? Both :)"
"Class IC antiarrhythmics are especially effective at treating atrial fibrillation (and flutter)"
"Class IC antiarrhythmics can restore and maintain normal sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation and flutter"
"Class IC antiarrhythmics may have proarrhythmic effects and are thus contraindicated in patients with structural heart disease or ischemic heart disease"
"Acute rheumatic fever is a consequence of pharyngeal infection with group A β-hemolytic streptococci"
"Acute rheumatic fever most commonly affects children 2 - 3 weeks after an episode of streptococcal pharyngitis (\strep throat\\")\""
"Acute rheumatic fever is immune-mediated, not a direct effect of bacteria"
"Acute rheumatic fever is caused by molecular mimicry due to resemblance of bacterial M protein with proteins in human tissue"
"Evidence of prior group A β-hemolytic streptococcal infection includes elevated anti-streptolysin O (ASO) or anti-DNase B titers"
"Minor criteria for rheumatic fever are nonspecific and include fever and elevated ESR"
"The major criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are the J♥NES criteria"
"What does the J in J♥NES criteria represent? Joint (migratory polyarthritis)"
"What does the ♥ in J♥NES criteria represent? Pancarditis (includes endocarditis, myocarditis, and pericarditis)"
"Endocarditis secondary to rheumatic fever most commonly affects the mitral valve"
"Endocarditis, secondary to rheumatic fever, is characterized by small vegetations along valvular lines of closure, which cause regurgitation"
"Severe pancarditis is the most common cause of death during the acute phase of rheumatic fever"
"Myocarditis, secondary to rheumatic fever, is associated with Aschoff bodies, which are granulomas with giant cells and fibrinoid material"
"Myocarditis, secondary to rheumatic fever, is associated with Anitschkow cells, which are reactive histiocytes with slender, wavy nuclei"
"Pericarditis most often presents with friction rub and chest pain"
"What does the N in J♥NES criteria represent? Nodules in skin (subcutaneous)"
"What does the E in J♥NES criteria represent? Erythema marginatum"
"What does the S in J♥NES criteria represent? Sydenham chorea"
"Acute rheumatic fever attack usually resolves, but may progress to chronic rheumatic heart disease"
"What drug is used for treatment or prophylaxis of rheumatic fever? Penicillin"
"What is the most common heart valve affected by rheumatic heart disease? Mitral valve"
"What is the second most common heart valve affected by rheumatic heart disease? Aortic valve"
"Early (acute) lesions of rheumatic heart disease cause mitral regurgitation"
"Late (chronic) lesions of rheumatic heart disease cause mitral stenosis"
"Chronic rheumatic heart disease results in stenosis with a classic 'fish-mouth' appearance"
"Occasionally, chronic rheumatic heart disease involves the aortic valve, leading to fusion of the commissures"
"Complications of chronic rheumatic heart disease include infectious endocarditis"
"The most common cause of aortic stenosis is degenerative calcification from \wear and tear\\"\""
"What demographic is most commonly affected by aortic stenosis? Older adults (> 60)::age group"
"Symptomatic aortic stenosis may present in patients around age 50 with a(n) bicuspid aortic valve"
"Aortic stenosis may arise as a consequence of chronic rheumatic valve disease"
"Aortic stenosis due to rheumatic disease may be distinguished from stenosis due to \wear and tear\\" by the presence of: 1. Coexisting mitral stenosis 2. Fusion of the commissures\""
"Compensation for aortic stenosis leads to a prolonged asymptomatic stage"
"Aortic stenosis may present with syncope, angina, and dyspnea on exertion"
"Aortic stenosis may lead to concentric::con/e-centric left ventricular hypertrophy, which can further progress to heart failure"
"Aortic stenosis may cause macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia as RBCs are damaged while crossing the calcified valve, producing schistocytes"
"Aortic stenosis is associated with \Pulsus parvus et tardus\\""
"Treatment for aortic stenosis is valve replacement after the onset of complications"
"What is the most common cause of aortic regurgitation? Isolated aortic root dilation"
"Aortic regurgitation arises due to aortic root dilation (e.g. syphilitic aneurysm, aortic dissection) or valve damage (e.g. infectious endocarditis)"
"One clinical feature of aortic regurgitation is hyperdynamic circulation due to increased (widened) pulse pressure"
"What is the effect of aortic regurgitation on diastolic pressure? Decreased pressure"
"What is the effect of aortic regurgitation on systolic pressure? Increased pressure"
"Aortic regurgitation may present with a(n) bounding pulse (Corrigan / Water-hammer pulse), pulsating nail bed (Quincke pulse), and head bobbing when severe"
"Aortic regurgitation may lead to left ventricle dilation with eccentric hypertrophy, which can progress to left heart failure"
"Treatment for aortic regurgitation is valve replacement before LV dysfunction develops"
"Mitral valve prolapse is the ballooning of the mitral valve into the left atrium during systole"
"Mitral valve prolapse is caused by myxoid degeneration of the valve, making it floppy"
"Mitral valve prolapse complications are rare but include infective endocarditis, arrhythmia, and severe mitral regurgitation"
"What is the treatment for mitral valve prolapse? Valve replacement"
"Mitral regurgitation usually arises as a complication of mitral valve prolapse"
"Mitral regurgitation may be caused by left ventricle dilatation"
"Chronic mitral regurgitation may result in volume overload and left-sided heart failure"
"Mitral stenosis is usually due to chronic rheumatic valve disease"
"A(n) decreased interval between A2/S2 and the opening snap of a mitral stenosis murmur correlates with increased disease severity"
"Chronic mitral stenosis may result in left atrium dilatation due to volume overload"
"Increased LA pressure as a result of mitral stenosis may lead to pulmonary congestion with edema and alveolar hemorrhage"
"One possible complication of mitral stenosis is pulmonary hypertension and eventual right-sided heart failure"
"One possible complication of mitral stenosis is atrial fibrillation with associated risk for mural thrombi"
"Endocarditis is inflammation of endocardium that lines the surface of cardiac valves (usually due to bacterial infection)"
"What bacteria is the most common cause of subacute endocarditis? Viridans streptococci"
"What type of heart valve does viridans streptococci infect? Previously damaged valves::normal vs damaged"
"viridans streptococci cause subacute endocarditis, which is characterized by small::size vegetations that do not destroy the valve"
"When the surface of the endocardium is damaged, thrombotic vegetations of platelets and fibrin may develop"
"Subacute endocarditis is often a sequela of dental procedures"
"Prophylactic antibiotics decrease risk of subacute endocarditis"
"What bacteria is the most common cause of endocarditis in IV drug users? Staphylococcus aureus"
"Which heart valve is most frequently involved in bacterial endocarditis? Mitral valve"
"Which heart valve is most frequently involved in bacterial endocarditis in IV drug users? Tricuspid valve"
"What type of heart valve does Staphylococcus aureus infect? Normal heart valves (undamaged)::damaged vs normal"
"Staphylococcus aureus causes acute endocarditis, which is characterized by large::size vegetations that destroy the valve"
"Staphylococcus epidermidis infection is associated with endocarditis in patients with prosthetic valves"
"Streptococcus bovis (gallolyticus) infection is associated with endocarditis in patients with underlying colorectal carcinoma"
"Endocarditis due to S. aureus is characterized by high virulence and rapid onset"
"Endocarditis due to viridans streptococci is characterized by low virulence and gradual onset"
"The HACEK organisms (Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella) are associated with endocarditis with negative blood cultures"
"What is the most common symptom of bacterial endocarditis? Fever"
"One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is Roth spots, which are round, white spots on the retina surrounded by hemorrhage"
"One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is Osler nodes, which are tender, raised lesions on the finger or toe pads"
"One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is murmur, which occurs as blood flows over vegetations on the heart valve"
"One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is Janeway lesions, which are small, nontender, erythematous lesions on the palm or sole"
"One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is anemia of chronic disease, which occurs as a result of increased release of hepcidin"
"One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is splinter hemorrhages in the nail bed"
"One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is septic arterial or pulmonary emboli"
"Bacterial endocarditis requires multiple blood cultures for diagnosis"
"Transesophageal echocardiogram may be used to detect lesions on heart valves, which aids in the diagnosis of bacterial endocarditis"
"Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis is due to sterile vegetations that arise in association with a(n) hypercoagulable state or underlying adenocarcinoma"
"Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis often results in sterile vegetations on the mitral valve along lines of closure, which results in regurgitation"
"Libman-Sacks (verrucous) endocarditis is due to sterile vegetations that arise in association with SLE"
"Libman-Sacks (verrucous) endocarditis is unique in that vegetations typically present on both side(s) of the mitral valve, resulting in regurgitation"
"Dilated cardiomyopathy is the dilation of all four chambers of the heart"
"What is the most common form of cardiomyopathy (90%)? Dilated cardiomyopathy"
"Dilated cardiomyopathy results in systolic::systolic or diastolic dysfunction"
"Systolic dysfunction as a result of dilated cardiomyopathy may lead to biventricular congestive heart failure"
"Dilated cardiomyopathy may result in mitral and tricuspid valve regurgitation due to stretching of the valves"
"What type of hypertrophy is seen in dilated cardiomyopathy? Eccentric hypertrophy (sarcomeres added in series)"
"The cause of dilated cardiomyopathy is most commonly idiopathic"
"Familial dilated cardiomyopathy is often due to autosomal dominant diseases"
"Dilated cardiomyopathy may be caused by myocarditis, secondary to coxsackie B infection"
"Myocarditis, secondary to coxsackie B infection, is characterized by a(n) lymphocytic infiltrate in the myocardium"
"Chronic alcohol abuse increases risk for dilated cardiomyopathy"
"Chronic cocaine abuse increases risk for dilated cardiomyopathy"
"Dilated cardiomyopathy may be caused by Chagas disease, which is the result of a parasitic infection"
"What anti-neoplastic agent is associated with dilated cardiomyopathy? Doxorubicin"
"Dilated cardiomyopathy may be seen during the last month of pregnancy or within five months of childbirth (\peripartum cardiomyopathy\\")\""
"Dilated cardiomyopathy may be caused by wet beriberi, which is the result of a vitamin B1 deficiency"
"What pathologic heart sound may be heard with dilated cardiomyopathy? S3"
"Dilated cardiomyopathy is associated with a(n) balloon appearance of the heart on CXR"
"One possible treatment for dilated cardiomyopathy is heart transplant"
"Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by massive ventricular hypertrophy, often with septal predominance"
"Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy usually arises due to genetic mutations (60-70%), especially in sarcomere proteins"
"Mutations that cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy most commonly have a(n) autosomal dominant inheritance pattern"
"Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is associated with the trinucleotide repeat expansion disease Friedreich ataxia"
"Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy causes diastolic::systolic or diastolic dysfunction"
"Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy leads to decreased cardiac output due to decreased compliance of the left ventricle"
"Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is associated with sudden death in young athletes due to ventricular arrhythmia"
"Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy causes syncope with exercise due to subaortic hypertrophy of the ventricular septum, resulting in functional aortic stenosis"
"Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by myofibrillar hypertrophy with disarray and fibrosis on biopsy"
"What pathologic heart sound may be heard with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy? S4"
"Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may impair mitral valve closure, thus causing regurgitation"
"Restrictive cardiomyopathy is primarily characterized by decreased compliance of the ventricular endomyocardium"
"Causes of restrictive cardiomyopathy include amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, post-radiation fibrosis, and eosinophilic syndromes of the heart (loeffler endocarditis, endomyocardial fibrosis)"
"Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes diastolic::systolic or diastolic dysfunction"
"Restrictive cardiomyopathy may be caused by endocardial fibroelastosis, which is a thick fibroelastic tissue in the endocardium; most commonly affects young children"
"Restrictive cardiomyopathy may be caused by Loeffler syndrome, which is an endomyocardial fibrosis with a prominent eosinophilic infiltrate"
"Restrictive cardiomyopathy presents with a(n) low-voltage ECG with a diminished QRS amplitude"
"Cardiac myxomas are benign mesenchymal tumors with a gelatinous appearance and abundant ground substance on histology"
"What is the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults? Myxoma"
"Cardiac myxomas usually form a pedunculated mass in the left atrium (80%), which may cause syncope due to obstruction of the mitral valve"
"Rhabdomyomas are benign hamartomas of cardiac muscle"
"What is the most common primary cardiac tumor in children? Rhabdomyoma"
"Rhabdomyoma is a cardiac tumor associated with tuberous sclerosis::other pathology"
"The most common heart tumor is a(n) metastasis"
"Metastases to the heart most commonly involve the pericardium, resulting in a pericardial effusion"
"What type of drug are class II antiarrhythmics? β-blockers"
"Metoprolol, propranolol, and esmolol are all examples of class II antiarrhythmics"
"Atenolol, timolol, and carvedilol are all examples of class II antiarrhythmics"
"Class II antiarrhythmics treat arrhythmias by blocking sympathetic input to the SA and AV nodes"
"What effect do Class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) have on cAMP levels? Decreased cAMP"
"Decreased cAMP as a result of class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) leads to the closure of membrane Ca2+ channels"
"Class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) suppress abnormal pacemakers by decreasing the slope of phase 4 of the nodal action potential"
"The AV node is particularly sensitive to class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers)"
"Are class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) used to treat supraventricular or ventricular arrhythmias? Supraventricular"
"Intravenous::mode of delivery class II antiarrhythmics, such as esmolol, can be used for intra-operative or other acute supraventricular arrhythmias (very short acting)"
"One possible adverse effect of class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) is heart block due to decreased conduction through the AV node"
"Class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) may induce heart (AV) block, which manifests as a prolonged PR interval on ECG"
"Class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) are useful in the treatment of atrial fibrillation (and flutter)"
"Class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) are useful in preventing rapid ventricular response (RVR) in atrial fibrillation and flutter (\rate control\\")\""
"What classes of antiarrhythmics are used for ventricular rate control in atrial fibrillation and flutter? Class II and IV::2"
"What classes of antiarrhythmics are used for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation and flutter? Class IC and III::2"
"What type of drug are class III antiarrhythmics? K+ channel blockers"
"What effect do class III antiarrhythmics have on action potential duration? Increased AP duration"
"What effect do class III antiarrhythmics have on effective refractory period? Increased ERP"
"Class III antiarrhythmics (K+ channel blockers) exert their effects by prolonging phase 2 and 3 of the myocardial action potential"
"Amiodarone is a lipophilic class III antiarrhythmic that also shares properties with class I, II, and IV antiarrhythmics"
"What drug class do dofetilide and ibutilide belong to? Class III antiarrhythmics (K+ channel blockers)"
"Sotalol is a class III antiarrhythmic that also has class II (β-blocker) activity"
"Are class III antiarrhythmics used to treat supraventricular or ventricular arrhythmias? Both :)"
"Class III antiarrhythmics may be used to treat atrial fibrillation (and flutter)"
"Class III antiarrhythmics can restore and maintain normal sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation and flutter"
"Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, has many neurologic side effects (e.g. tremor, ataxia, peripheral neuropathy, sleep disturbances)"
"Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, can act as a(n) hapten, resulting in gray corneal microdeposits"
"Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, can cause both hyper- or hypo-thyroidism"
"Amiodarone can cause pulmonary fibrosis with progression to restrictive lung disease"
"Amiodarone can cause heart block as a result of its class II antiarrhythmic activity"
"Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, can induce heart failure, especially with rapid IV administration"
"Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, can cause hypersensitivity hepatitis"
"Amiodarone may act as a hapten resulting in gray-blue skin discoloration with photodermatitis"
"Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, is a(n) inhibitor of cytochrome P450 and thus may have many drug interactions"
"What adverse effect is common to sotalol, dofetilide, and ibutilide (class III antiarrhythmics)? Torsades de pointes"
"All type III antiarrhythmics (K+ channel blockers) can widen the QT interval on ECG"
"Amiodarone and sotalol (class III antiarrhythmics) may be used to treat ventricular tachycardia"
"What laboratory function tests should be checked when using amiodarone? Pulmonary (PFTs), Liver (LFTs), and Thyroid (TFTs)::3"
"What adverse effect may amiodarone have on bowel movement? Constipation"
"During the early stages of exercise, cardiac output is maintained by increased heart rate and stroke volume"
"During the late stages of exercise, cardiac output is maintained by increased heart rate only as stroke volume plateaus"
"Which phase of the cardiac cycle (systole or diastole) is preferentially shortened with increased heart rate? Diastole"
"What is the effect of hyperthyroidism on pulse pressure? Increased pulse pressure"
"What is the effect of aortic stiffening on pulse pressure? Increased pulse pressure"
"What is the effect of obstructive sleep apnea on pulse pressure? Increased pulse pressure"
"What is the effect of exercise on pulse pressure? Increased pulse pressure, transiently"
"Decreased pulse pressures are seen in conditions that decrease left ventricular stroke volume"
"What is the effect of aortic stenosis on pulse pressure? Decreased pulse pressure"
"What is the effect of cardiogenic shock on pulse pressure? Decreased pulse pressure"
"What is the effect of cardiac tamponade on pulse pressure? Decreased pulse pressure"
"What is the effect of advanced heart failure on pulse pressure? Decreased pulse pressure"
"What is the effect of β1-blockade on contractility (and SV)? Decreased contractility"
"What is the effect of acidosis on contractility (and SV)? Decreased contractility"
"What is the effect of hypoxia (low O2) and hypercapnia (high CO2) on contractility (and SV)? Decreased"
"Veno-dilators (e.g. nitroglycerin) cause decreased pre-load"
"Vaso-dilators (e.g. hydralazine) cause decreased after-load"
"ACE inhibitors and ARBs decrease both preload and afterload"
"What is the effect of dilated cardiomyopathy on contractility? Decreased (systolic dysfunction)"
"Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may present with a(n) systolic::systolic/diastolic murmur"
"Where is a murmur due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy best heard? Left sternal border"
"What effect does inspiration have on venous return to the right atrium? Increased venous return"
"Inspiration as a bedside maneuver may be used to increase the intensity of right heart sounds"
"The hand grip maneuver is used to increase after-load"
"What effect does the hand grip maneuver have on the intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs? Increased intensity"
"What effect does the hand grip maneuver have on the intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmurs? Decreased intensity"
"What effect does the hand grip maneuver have on the \click\\" onset time of MVP murmurs? Later onset of click/murmur\""
"Standing up and the valsalva maneuver are both used to decrease pre-load"
"What effect does standing up or the valsalva maneuver have on the intensity of MR, AR, MS, and AS murmurs? Decreased intensity"
"What effect does standing up or the valsalva maneuver have on the intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmurs? Increased intensity"
"What effect does standing up or the valsalva maneuver have on the \click\\" onset time of MVP murmurs? Earlier onset of click/murmur\""
"Rapid squatting is a maneuver that is used to increase preload, afterload, and venous return"
"What effect does the rapid squatting maneuver have on the intensity of aortic stenosis murmurs? Increased intensity"
"What effect does the rapid squatting maneuver have on the intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmurs? Decreased intensity"
"What effect does the rapid squatting maneuver have on the \click\\" onset time of MVP murmurs? Later onset of click/murmur\""
"Where is a murmur due to patent ductus arteriosus best heard? Left infraclavicular area"
"The Cushing reaction is a triad of hypertension, bradycardia, and respiratory depression due to increased intracranial pressure"
"What effect does carotid massage have on conduction through the AV node? Slowed conduction"
"Atrial fibrillation is characterized by a chaotic and erratic baseline with no discrete P waves in between irregularly spaced QRS complexes on ECG"
"Atrial fibrillation is characterized by a(n) irregularly, irregular patterned rhythm"
"Atrial fibrillation can lead to thromboembolic events, particularly stroke (brain complication)"
"The most common risk factors for atrial fibrillation include hypertension and coronary artery disease (CAD)"
"Atrial flutter is characterized by a rapid succession of identical, back-to-back atrial depolarization waves"
"Atrial flutter typically has a 4:1 \sawtooth\\" pattern appearance on ECG\""
"What is the definitive treatment for atrial flutter? Catheter ablation"
"Ventricular fibrillation is characterized by a completely erratic rhythm with no identifiable waves on ECG"
"Ventricular fibrillation is a fatal arrhythmia without immediate CPR and defibrillation"
"1st degree AV block is characterized by a PR interval > 200 msec on ECG"
"2nd degree Mobitz type I (Wenckebach)::(aka) AV block is characterized by progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a beat is \dropped\\"\""
"2nd degree Mobitz type I AV block is characterized by a(n) regularly, irregular patterned rhythm on ECG"
"2nd degree Mobitz type II AV block is characterized by dropped beats that are not preceded by a change in length of the PR interval on ECG"
"2nd degree Mobitz type II AV block may progress to 3rd-degree block"
"2nd degree Mobitz type II AV block is often treated with a(n) pacemaker"
"3rd degree AV block is characterized by independent beating of the atria and ventricles (P waves and QRS complexes are not rhythmically associated)"
"3rd degree AV block is usually treated with a(n) pacemaker"
"3rd degree AV block can be caused by Lyme disease"
"What pathology is indicated on the ECG below? Atrial fibrillation"
"What pathology is indicated on the ECG below? Atrial flutter"
"What pathology is indicated on the ECG below? Ventricular fibrillation"
"What pathology is indicated on the ECG below? 1st degree AV block"
"What pathology is indicated on the ECG below? 2nd degree AV block, Mobitz type I (Wenckebach)"
"What pathology is indicated on the ECG below? 2nd degree AV block, Mobitz type II"
"What pathology is indicated on the ECG below? 3rd degree AV block"
"Ventricular septal defect leads to an increased O2 saturation in the RV and pulmonary artery"
"Atrial septal defect leads to an increased O2 saturation in the RA, RV and pulmonary artery"
"One sign of hyperlipidemia is xanthomas, which are plaques or nodules composed of lipid-laden histiocytes in skin"
"When a xanthoma affects the eyelids, it is known as xanthelasma"
"One sign of hyperlipidemia is tendinous xanthomas, which are plaques or nodules composed of lipid-laden histiocytes in tendon (especially Achilles)"
"One sign of hyperlipidemia is corneal arcus, which are lipid deposits in the cornea"
"Corneal arcus is common in the elderly (arcus senilis), but appears earlier in life in patients with hypercholesterolemia"
"Diagnosis of a current or previous myocardial infarction may be aided by the presence of pathologic Q waves on ECG"
"There is an increased risk for posteromedial papillary muscle rupture (post-MI) due to its single blood supply from the posterior descending artery"
"Obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a subset of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in which asymmetric septal hypertrophy interferes with the outflow of blood from the left ventricle"
"Shock is inadequate organ perfusion and delivery of nutrients necessary for normal tissue and cellular function"
"Hypovolemic shock may be caused by hemorrhage, dehydration, and burns"
"Hypovolemic shock is characterized by skin that is cold and clammy"
"How do PCWP and preload change during hypovolemic shock? Severely decreased"
"How does cardiac output change during hypovolemic shock? Decreased"
"How do SVR and afterload change during hypovolemic shock? Increased"
"What is the treatment for hypovolemic shock? IV fluids"
"Cardiogenic shock may be caused by acute MI, HF, valvular dysfunction, and arrhythmia (pump failure)"
"Obstructive shock may be caused by cardiac tamponade and pulmonary embolism"
"Cardiogenic and obstructive shock are characterized by skin that is cold and clammy"
"How do PCWP and preload change during cardiogenic and obstructive shock? Increased or decreased"
"How does cardiac output change during cardiogenic and obstructive shock? Severely decreased"
"How do SVR and afterload change during cardiogenic and obstructive shock? Increased"
"What is the main treatment for cardiogenic shock? IV Inotropes"
"What is the treatment for obstructive shock? Relieve obstruction"
"Distributive shock may be caused by sepsis, anaphylaxis, or CNS injury (excessive vasodilation)"
"Distributive shock is characterized by skin that is warm and dry"
"How do PCWP and preload change during distributive shock? Decreased"
"How does cardiac output change during distributive shock due to sepsis and anaphylaxis? Increased"
"How does cardiac output change during distributive shock due to CNS injury? Decreased"
"How do SVR and afterload change during distributive shock? Severely decreased"
"What is the treatment for distributive shock? IV fluids, pressors::2"
"What kidney complication may be associated with bacterial endocarditis? Glomerulonephritis"
"Kussmaul sign is increased jugular venous pressure on inspiration"
"The Kussmaul sign (increased JVP on inspiration) occurs due to failure of negative intrathoracic pressure to be transmitted to the heart during inspiration"
"Failure of negative intrathoracic pressure to be transmitted to the heart results in impaired filling of the right ventricle, with a consequent back-up of blood into the vena cava::one step past the atria (Kussmaul sign)"
"Kussmaul sign (increased JVP on inspiration) may be seen with constrictive pericarditis and restrictive cardiomyopathies"
"Kussmaul sign (increased JVP on inspiration) may be seen with right::left or right atrial or ventricular tumors"
"Tertiary syphilis disrupts the vasa vasorum of the aorta with consequent atrophy of the vessel wall and dilatation of the aorta and valve ring"
"Acute pericarditis is defined as inflammation of the pericardium"
"Acute pericarditis commonly presents with sharp pain that is aggravated by inspiration and relieved by sitting up and leaning forward"
"Acute pericarditis is often complicated by pericardial effusion"
"ECG changes associated with acute pericarditis include widespread, diffuse ST segment elevation and/or PR depression"
"What is the most common cause of acute pericarditis? Idiopathic (presumed viral)"
"Cardiac tamponade is defined as compression of the heart by fluid"
"What is the effect of cardiac tamponade on cardiac output? Decreased CO"
"What is the effect of cardiac tamponade on heart rate? Increased HR"
"Cardiac tamponade leads to equilibration of diastolic pressures in all 4 chambers"
"Cardiac tamponade may present with Beck's triad of hypotension, distended neck veins, and distant heart sounds"
"One ECG change associated with cardiac tamponade is a(n) low-voltage QRS complex"
"One ECG change associated with cardiac tamponade is electrical alternans, which occurs due to \swinging\\" movement of the heart in a large effusion\""
"Cardiac tamponade may be associated with pulsus paradoxus, which is a(n) decrease in amplitude of systolic BP > 10 mmHG during inspiration"
"What type of drug are class IV antiarrhythmics? Non-dihydropyridine Ca2+ channel blockers"
"Class IV antiarrhythmics block activated and inactivated L-type calcium channels"
"Class IV antiarrhythmics (non-dihydropyridine CCBs) are specific for the L-type calcium channel receptors in the heart::overall location in the body"
"What drug class do diltiazem and verapamil belong to? Class IV antiarrhythmics (non-dihydropyridine Ca2+ channel blockers)"
"Class IV antiarrhythmics treat arrhythmias by directly blocking Ca2+ current in the SA and AV nodes"
"Class IV antiarrhythmics decrease pacemaker activity by decreasing the slope of phase 0 of the nodal action potential"
"What is the effect of class IV antiarrhythmics (non-dihydropyridine Ca2+ channel blockers) on effective refractory period? Increased ERP"
"Class IV antiarrhythmics (non-dihydropyridine CCBs) decrease conduction velocity through the AV node"
"Are class IV antiarrhythmics used to treat supraventricular or ventricular arrhythmias? Supraventricular"
"Class IV antiarrhythmics may prolong the PR interval on ECG"
"One possible adverse effect of class IV antiarrhythmics is AV block due to decreased conduction through the AV node"
"Class IV antiarrhythmics are useful in the treatment of atrial fibrillation (and flutter)"
"Class IV antiarrhythmics are useful in preventing rapid ventricular response (RVR) in atrial fibrillation and flutter (\rate control\\")\""
"Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that has antiarrhythmic properties"
"Digoxin exerts parasympathomimetic effects via direct stimulation of the vagus nerve, causing AV nodal inhibition"
"Digoxin is useful in the treatment of atrial fibrillation (and flutter)"
"Digoxin is useful in preventing rapid ventricular response (RVR) in atrial fibrillation and flutter (\rate control\\")\""
"Magnesium is an ion that may be used as an antiarrhythmic to treat torsades de pointes"
"Magnesium may be used as an antiarrhythmic to treat digoxin toxicity"
"What changes in potassium levels (hyper- or hypokalemia) can induce arrhythmias? Both hyper- and hypokalemia :)"
"Hyper-kalemia induced arrhythmias may present on ECG with peaked T waves and a(n) shortened QT interval"
"Hypo-kalemia induced arrhythmias may present on ECG with U waves at the end of the T wave"
"Adenosine is a purine nucleoside with antiarrhythmic properties"
"Adenosine activates inhibitory A1 receptors on the myocardium of the SA and AV nodes"
"Activation of A1 receptors in the myocardium by adenosine increases outward K+ current"
"Activation of A1 receptors in the myocardium by adenosine decreases inward Ca2+ current"
"Adenosine decreases conduction velocity through the AV node"
"What is the effect of adenosine on effective refractory period? Increased ERP"
"Adenosine may cause transient high grade heart block due to direct AV node inhibition"
"Adenosine may be used as a very short acting antiarrhythmic"
"Adenosine is a first line agent for acute treatment of supraventricular arrhythmias"
"Adenosine causes coronary dilation via its action on A2 receptors"
"One adverse effect associated with adenosine is cutaneous flushing"
"Adverse effects associated with adenosine include chest pain and a sense of impending doom"
"What effect may adenosine have on blood pressure? Decreased (hypotension)"
"Adenosine is an antiarrhythmic that is less effective in the presence of theophylline and caffeine (methylxanthines)"
"What pulmonary side effect is associated with adenosine? Bronchospasm"
"Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is commonly due to β-myosin heavy chain or myosin-binding protein C mutations"
"The heart is maximally softened 7 to 10 days post-MI"
"The embryonic truncus arteriosus gives rise to the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk"
"The embryonic bulbus cordis gives rise to the smooth parts (outflow tracks) of the left and right ventricles"
"The embryonic primitive atria gives rise to the trabeculated parts of the left and right atria"
"The embryonic primitive ventricle gives rise to the trabeculated parts of the left and right ventricles"
"The embryonic primitive pulmonary vein gives rise to the smooth part of the left atrium"
"The embryonic right horn of sinus venosus gives rise to the smooth part of the right atrium"
"The embryonic left horn of sinus venosus gives rise to the coronary sinus"
"The embryonic right common cardinal vein and right anterior cardinal vein give rise to the superior vena cava"
"The embryonic endocardial cushion gives rise to the atrial septum and membranous interventricular septum"
"The embryonic endocardial cushion gives rise to the AV and semilunar valves"
"The heart is the first functional organ to develop in vertebrate embryos"
"The heart beats spontaneously by week 4 of embryonic development"
"The primary heart tube loops to establish left-right polarity beginning in week 4 of gestation"
"A defect in left-right dynein during heart morphogenesis can result in dextrocardia"
"In the first step of atrial partitioning, the septum primum grows toward the endocardial cushions, forming a narrow ostium primum"
"In the second step of atrial partitioning, the ostium secundum forms in place of the ostium primum"
"In the third step of atrial partitioning, the sinus venosus is \pulled\\" into the developing right atrium"
"In the fourth step of atrial partitioning, the septum secundum expands and covers most of the foramen secundum, leaving the residual foramen ovale"
"The remaining portion of the septum primum, following foramen ovale formation, forms the valve of foramen ovale"
"Shortly after birth, the septum secundum and septum primum fuse to form the atrial septum"
"The foramen ovale usually closes shortly after birth because of increased left atrial pressure"
"Failure of the septum primum and septum secundum to fuse after birth results in a(n) patent foramen ovale"
"Patent foramen ovale can lead to paradoxical emboli, which are venous thromboemboli that enter systemic arterial circulation"
"In the first step of ventricular partitioning, the muscular interventricular septum develops and forms the interventricular foramen"
"In the second step of ventricular partitioning, the aorticopulmonary septum rotates and fuses with the muscular interventricular septum to form the membranous interventricular septum, resulting in closure of the interventricular foramen"
"In the third step of ventricular partitioning, growth of endocardial cushions separates atria from ventricles"
"Ventricular septal defects usually occur in the membranous portion of the interventricular septum"
"The mitral and tricuspid valves are derived from the fused endocardial cushions of the common AV canal"
"Outflow tracts from the heart are formed by migrations of neural crest and endocardial cells, which spiral and fuse to form the aorticopulmonary::long septum"
"What is the embryonic origin of endocardial cushion cells? Neural crest cells and lateral plate mesoderm::2"
"What is the embryonic origin of the aorticopulmonary septum? Neural crest cells"
"Blood in the umbilical vein has a Po2 of approximately 30 mmHg"
"Blood in the umbilical vein has a O2 saturation of approximately 80%"
"Compared to the umbilical vein, the umbilical arteries have low O2 saturation"
"Oxygenated blood from the placenta enters the fetal circulation via the umbilical vein"
"From the umbilical vein, blood is conducted into the IVC via the ductus venosus, which bypasses hepatic circulation"
"Mixed blood in the fetal IVC enters the right atrium"
"Most of the highly oxygenated blood reaching the heart via the fetal IVC is directed from the RA to the LA via the foramen ovale and pumped into the aorta to supply the head and body"
"Most of the deoxygenated blood from the fetal SVC is conducted to the descending aorta via the ductus arteriosus, which bypasses the lungs"
"Deoxygenated blood is returned to the placenta via the umbilical arteries"
"Once the foramen ovale has closed, it is re-named the fossa ovalis"
"Closure of the ductus arteriosus occurs in response to increased O2 and decreased PGE (from respiration and placental separation, respectively)"
"The remnant of the ductus arteriosus is the ligamentum arteriosum, which connects the aorta and pulmonary artery"
"The remnant of the ductus venosus is the ligamentum venosum"
"The remnant of the umbilical arteries is the medial umbilical ligaments"
"The remnant of the umbilical vein is the ligamentum teres hepatis, which is contained in the falciform ligament"
"The SA node is commonly supplied by the right coronary artery while the AV node is supplied by the Posterior Descending Artery"
"The posterior descending artery (PDA) most commonly arises from the right coronary artery (85%)"
"When the posterior descending artery (PDA) arises from the right coronary artery, it is referred to as right-dominant circulation (85%)"
"When the posterior descending artery (PDA) arises from the left circumflex artery, it is referred to as left-dominant circulation (8%)"
"When the posterior descending artery (PDA) arises from both the right coronary artery and left circumflex artery, it is referred to as codominant circulation (7%)"
"Coronary artery occlusion most commonly occurs in the left anterior descending artery"
"Coronary blood flow peaks in early diastole::systolic/diastolic"
"The most posterior chamber of the heart is the left atrium"
"Enlargement of the heart can cause dysphagia due to compression of the esophagus"
"Enlargement of the heart can cause hoarseness due to compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve"
"The outermost layer of the pericardium is the fibrous pericardium"
"The middle layer of the pericardium is the parietal layer of serous pericardium"
"The inner layer of the pericardium is the visceral layer of serous pericardium"
"The pericardial cavity lies between parietal and visceral layers of serous pericardium"
"Which artery supplies the posterior third of the interventricular septum? Posterior descending artery (PDA)"
"Which artery supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum? Left anterior descending artery (LAD)"
"Which arteries supply the anterolateral papillary muscle? LCX, LAD::2"
"Only L-amino acids are found in proteins"
"Which amino acids are characterized by branched side chains? Valine, Leucine, Isoleucine::3"
"Which amino acids are the precursors to catecholamines and melanin? Tyrosine, Phenylalanine::2"
"Which amino acid is the precursor to serotonin and niacin? Tryptophan"
"The amino acids aspartate and glutamate are negatively charged at body pH (acidic)"
"The amino acids lysine and arginine are positively charged at body pH (basic)"
"What is the charge of the amino acid histidine at body pH? No charge"
"Which amino acids are the target of protein kinase A and protein kinase C? Serine, Threonine::2"
"Which amino acids have sulfur groups? Cysteine, Methionine::2"
"Which amino acids are required during periods of growth? Arginine, Histidine::2"
"What are the 9 (10*) essential amino acids? MethionineThreonineHistidine PhenylalanineLysineArginine ** during times of growth IsoleucineLeucineTryptophanValine"
"Which amino acids are ketogenic? Leucine, Lysine::2"
"Are the essential amino acids methionine, valine, and histidine ketogenic or glucogenic? Glucogenic"
"Are the amino acids phenylalanine, isoleucine, threonine, tryptophan, and tyrosine ketogenic or glucogenic? Both :)"
"The amino acid arginine is essential during periods of positive nitrogen balance"
"If ΔG for a reaction is less than zero, the reaction happens spontaneously"
"If ΔG for a reaction is greater than zero, energy must be added for the reaction to occur"
"Enzymes exert their effects by decreasing the energy of activation"
"The rate of a reaction depends on the concentration of both the enzyme and the substrate"
"The Michaelis-Mentin constant, Km is inversely proportional to the affinity of the enzyme for its substrate"
"The Vmax of a reaction is directly proportional to enzyme concentration"
"In first order kinetics, the rate of reaction is directly proportional to the substrate (drug) concentration"
"In zero order kinetics, the rate of reaction is constant"
"If the amount of enzymes doubles, the Vmax doubles, while Km remains constant"
"The X-intercept of a lineweaver-burke plot represents -1/Km"
"The Y-intercept of a lineweaver-burke plot represents 1/Vmax"
"If the Y-intercept increases on a lineweaver-burke plot, the Vmax has decreased"
"When using a(n) reversible competitive inhibitor, the Km changes, while the Vmax remains the same"
"When using either noncompetitive or suicide-competitive inhibitors, the Vmax changes, while the Km remains the same"
"When using an irreversible competitive inhibitor, the Vmax changes, while the Km remains the same"
"Do reversible competitive inhibitors resemble the substrate? Yes"
"Do irreversible competitive inhibitors resemble the substrate? Yes"
"Do noncompetitive inhibitors resemble the substrate? No"
"Can reversible competitive inhibitors be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration, [S]? Yes"
"Can irreversible competitive inhibitors be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration, [S]? No"
"Can noncompetitive inhibitors be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration, [S]? No"
"Do reversible competitive inhibitors bind to the active site of the enzyme? Yes"
"Do irreversible competitive inhibitors bind to the active site of the enzyme? Yes"
"Do noncompetitive inhibitors bind to the active site of the enzyme? No"
"While most enzymatic reactions follow a hyperbolic curve (Michaelis-Menten kinetics), allosteric kinetics follow a(n) sigmoidal curve"
"Methyl xanthines (e.g. caffeine) are inhibitors of the enzyme phosphodiesterase (PDE), which normally degrades cAMP into 5' AMP"
"Protein kinase G activates the enzyme phosphatase, which dephosphorylates myosin light chain causing smooth muscle relaxation"
"When insulin binds its receptor, the receptor dimerizes and is activated via tyrosine kinase activity"
"Autophosphorylation of the insulin receptor allows binding of insulin receptor substrate 1 (IRS-1)"
"Following binding of insulin receptor substrate 1 to the insulin receptor, SH2-domain proteins bind to IRS-1"
"Downstream effects of glucagon cause protein phosphorylation::phosphorylation/dephosphorylation"
"Downstream effects of insulin cause protein dephosphorylation::phosphorylation/dephosphorylation"
"Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase causes enzyme activation::activation/inactivation"
"Phosphorylation of glycogen synthase causes enzyme inactivation::activation/inactivation"
"Dephosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase causes enzyme inactivation::activation/inactivation"
"Dephosphorylation of glycogen synthase causes enzyme activation::activation/inactivation"
"Digoxin is derived from the foxglove plant"
"Cardiac glycosides (e.g. digoxin) exert their effects via inhibition of the Na+-K+ ATPase pump"
"Cardiac glycosides lead to increased levels of intracellular Na+"
"Cardiac glycosides (e.g. digoxin) lead to increased levels of intracellular Ca2+"
"Cardiac glycosides (e.g. digoxin) cause increased cardiac contractility due to increased sarcoplasmic Ca2+ stores"
"Digoxin is used for symptomatic relief of chronic systolic heart failure"
"Does digoxin reduce mortality in patients with chronic heart failure? No; only used for symptomatic relief"
"One adverse effect associated with digoxin is hyperkalemia, which is an indicator of poor prognosis"
"Digitalis toxicity may induce arrhythmias, such as premature ventricular contractions"
"Chronic digoxin use leads to Peaked T wave and QT interval shortening (due to hyperkalemia), and ST depression with a \scooped\\" appearance on ECG\""
"One adverse effect associated with digoxin is bradycardia::HR"
"One adverse effect associated with digoxin is heart block due to parasympathetic activity at AV node"
"Digoxin is contraindicated in patients with significant SA or AV block"
"Cholinergic stimulation due to digoxin may cause GI side effects"
"Digitalis toxicity may cause blurry yellow vision, known as xanthopsia"
"One factor that predisposes to digoxin toxicity is hypokalemia, which increases binding of digoxin to Na+-K+ ATPase"
"One factor that predisposes to digoxin toxicity is renal insufficiency, which decreases drug excretion"
"Renal clearance of digoxin is decreased with antiarrhythmic drugs such as verapamil, amiodarone, and quinidine"
"One possible treatment for digoxin toxicity is anti-digoxin Fab fragments"
"Milrinone and inamrinone are PDE-3 inhibitors used in the treatment of acute heart failure"
"What effect does milrinone have on cardiac contractility? Increased contractility"
"Milrinone causes arteriolar dilation and thus decreased afterload"
"Nesiritide is a synthetic form of B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) used in the treatment of acute heart failure"
"Nesiritide causes arteriolar and venous dilation and thus decreased afterload and preload"
"Nesiritide, a(n) BNP analog, causes Na+ loss through diuresis"
"Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) target voltage-gated L-type calcium channels"
"Dihydropyridine CCBs primarily block L-type calcium channels in smooth muscle"
"Non-dihydropyridine CCBs primarily block L-type calcium channels in cardiac muscle"
"Dihydropyridine CCBs cause vaso-dilation"
"Dihydropyridine CCBs have a(n) -dipine suffix"
"Verapamil and diltiazem are both examples of non-dihydropyridine Ca2+ channel blockers"
"Diltiazem has some vaso-dilatory activity"
"Non-dihydropyridine CCBs decrease cardiac contractility and cardiac output"
"Inhibition of the SA node by non-dihydropyridine CCBs can cause bradycardia"
"Ca2+ channel blockers are useful for treating hypertension"
"Nifedipine is a dihydropyridine CCB that is used to treat hypertension during pregnancy"
"Ca2+ channel blockers may be used to treat stable angina if β-blockers/nitrates have not worked or are contraindicated"
"Dihydropyridine CCBs are useful for treating angina due to their ability to cause coronary vaso-dilation"
"What effect do dihydropyridine CCBs have on afterload? Decreased afterload (via peripheral vasodilation)"
"Non-dihydropyridine CCBs are useful for treating angina due to their ability to decrease myocardial oxygen demand"
"Ca2+ channel blockers are a first-line treatment for Prinzmetal angina, due to their ability to prevent vasoconstriction in the coronary vasculature"
"Dihydropyridine CCBs may be used to treat Raynaud's phenomenon, which is an exaggerated vascular response to cold temperature or emotional stress"
"Nimodipine is a Ca2+ channel blocker that is used to prevent cerebral vasospasm following a(n) subarachnoid hemorrhage"
"Calcium channel blockers, such as verapamil, may be used for migraine prophylaxis"
"Nonspecific adverse effects of dihydropyridine CCBs include headache, dizziness, and flushing"
"One adverse effect associated with dihydropyridine CCBs is peripheral edema, secondary to dilation of pre-capillary vessels"
"Dihydropyridine CCBs may cause reflex tachycardia::HR"
"Which Ca2+ channel blocker is contraindicated in patients with unstable angina or MI due to its ability to exacerbate myocardial ischemia? Nifedipine"
"What major GI side effect is associated with verapamil? Constipation"
"One adverse effect associated with Ca2+ channel blockers (e.g. verapamil) is gingival hyperplasia"
"Non-dihydropyridine CCBs are relatively contraindicated in patients with heart block or heart failure due to their ability to cause cardiac depression"
"Dihydropyridine CCBs can worsen heart failure due to increased sympathetic activity induced by baroreceptor reflex activation"
"Which Ca2+ channel blockers have the most potent effects on vascular smooth muscle? Amlodipine, Nifedipine::2"
"Which Ca2+ channel blocker has the most potent effects on cardiac muscle? Verapamil"
"What four drug classes are used in the treatment of primary hypertension? 1. Thiazide diuretics 2. ACE inhibitors 3. Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) 4. Dihydropyridine Ca2+ channel blockers"
"Patients with BP > 20/10 mmHg above goal should use two antihypertensives"
"Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, is a first line agent for treating primary hypertension"
"Black and elderly patients respond well to hydrochlorothiazide and long-acting dihydropyridine Ca2+ channel blockers for treatment of primary hypertension"
"ACE inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers are first line treatment for hypertension in patients with heart failure, MI, and/or diabetes"
"Hypertensive emergency occurs when systolic BP >180 or diastolic BP >120 with end-organ damage"
"IV β1 antagonists, such as esmolol and metoprolol, can be used for hypertensive emergency"
"Labetalol, an α- and β-antagonist, can be used for hypertensive emergency"
"Many agents used in hypertensive emergencies are potent vaso-dilators"
"Potent vasodilation (e.g. following hypertensive therapy) may cause hypotension followed by reflex tachycardia and increased renin levels"
"Vasodilation (e.g. following hypertensive therapy) reduces after-load"
"IV Ca2+ channel blockers such as nicardipine and clevidipine may be used in hypertensive emergency"
"IV Ca2+ channel blockers, such as nicardipine and clevidipine, cause arteriolar dilation, which is useful for the treatment of hypertensive emergency"
"Hydralazine is safe to use in pregnant women experiencing hypertensive emergency"
"Hydralazine primarily dilates arterioles, leading to a decreased after-load"
"Hydralazine can cause hypotension, which may induce a reflex tachycardia that can worsen angina"
"Hydralazine is contraindicated in patients with angina and CAD"
"Hydralazine is often co-administered with a(n) β-blocker to minimize the reflexive sympathetic activation and tachycardia"
"Hydralazine is often combined with a(n) organic nitrate to treat heart failure due to LV systolic dysfunction"
"Hydralazine combined with a(n) nitrate provides a(n) mortality benefit for some patients with heart failure"
"Hydralazine can rarely cause drug-induced lupus, which may manifest as myalgias, arthralgias, and joint swelling"
"Hydralazine exerts its effects by increasing levels of cGMP, causing smooth muscle relaxation"
"Nitroprusside causes vasodilation equally at the arteries and veins via nitric oxide, which is useful during the treatment of hypertensive emergency"
"Nitroprusside promotes smooth muscle relaxation by increasing cGMP (via direct release of NO)"
"Does nitroprusside cause arteriolar or venous dilation? Both :)"
"Nitroprusside is associated with cyanide poisoning, which may present as - lactic acidosis - seizures - altered mental status"
"Fenoldopam is a(n) D1 receptor agonist that may be used in the treatment of hypertensive emergency to prevent kidney damage"
"Fenoldopam exerts its effects by acting on the D1 receptor (A Gs receptor), thus increasing levels of cAMP, causing vasodilation in most arterial beds"
"What effect does fenoldopam have on renal arteries? Dilation::dilation/constriction"
"Fenoldopam stimulation of dopamine receptors in the kidneys causes increased excretion of Na+ and water"
"In addition to its use during hypertensive emergency, fenoldopam is also used postoperatively as an antihypertensive"
"What adverse effects are associated with fenoldopam? Hypotension, Reflex Tachycardia::2"
"Which organ is responsible for the import and export of lipoproteins? Liver"
"The lumen of the small intestine is the site of free fatty acid, bile acid, and cholesterol absorption"
"After being absorbed from the GI tract, free cholesterol is packaged into a(n) chylomicron as cholesterol ester"
"The main component of chylomicrons is triglycerides"
"Which apolipoproteins do chylomicrons express on their surface? Apolipoproteins A-I, B-48, C-II, and E::4"
"Chylomicrons deliver triglycerides from the intestine to peripheral tissues"
"Triglycerides in chylomicrons are hydrolyzed by the enzyme lipoprotein lipase (LPL), releasing free fatty acids"
"Free fatty acids (from triglycerides) can be used for energy by the heart and skeletal muscle"
"Free fatty acids can be converted back to triglycerides and stored in adipose tissue"
"Once depleted of their triglycerides, chylomicron remnants return to the liver"
"The remnant receptor on the liver binds to ApoE of the chylomicron remnant, causing subsequent endocytosis"
"Hepatocytes synthesize cholesterol using the rate-limiting enzyme HMG CoA reductase"
"The first intermediate in cholesterol synthesis is mevalonate (from HMG CoA)"
"Cholesterol from the liver may be repackaged into the interior of VLDLs"
"The main component of VLDL is triglycerides (60%)"
"Apolipoprotein B-100 is found on the lipoproteins LDL, IDL, and VLDL"
"VLDLs deliver triglycerides directly from the liver to peripheral tissues"
"Depletion of triglycerides from VLDLs produces IDLs, which may undergo further removal of triglycerides via the enzyme hepatic TG lipase, forming LDL"
"The main component of LDL is a core of cholesterol esters"
"LDLs are the main source of cholesterol delivery to peripheral tissues in the body"
"The LDL receptor on the liver binds to ApoB-100 of the LDL particle, causing subsequent endocytosis"
"Nascent HDL is secreted by the liver and intestine"
"Lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) converts free cholesterol into cholesterol esters for transport by HDL"
"Mature HDL particles contain LCAT-generated cholesterol esters"
"HDL transfers cholesterol esters to LDLs, IDLs, and VLDLs via cholesterol ester transfer protein (CETP) to be transported back to the liver"
"HDL delivers cholesterol esters directly to the liver via scavenger receptor B-1 receptors"
"Statins (e.g. simvastatin, atorvastatin, rosuvastatin) exert their effects by inhibiting the enzyme HMG CoA reductase, thus decreasing cholesterol production"
"Statins indirectly cause increased LDL receptor expression on hepatocytes"
"Statins significantly reduce LDL levels (30-60% reductions)"
"What effect do statins have on triglyceride levels? Mild decrease"
"What effect do statins have on HDL levels? Mild increase"
"The first line treatment for hypercholesterolemia (LDL) is with lifestyle modification and statins"
"Statins are the most effective lipid lowering medications for preventing future cardiovascular events"
"Statins are the only lipid-lowering drugs consistently proven to reduce risk of atherosclerotic heart disease"
"Statin therapy may be used to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events and mortality in high-risk diabetics"
"Statins reduce risk of future vascular events in patients with a history of TIA or stroke"
"Statins may be teratogenic, therefore avoid during the first trimester of pregnancy"
"The most common side effect of statins is myopathy, which occurs weeks to months after starting therapy"
"Statins can cause elevations in serum CK, which may be indicative of myopathy"
"Statins may cause mild hepato-toxicity, and thus mild elevations in liver function tests"
"All statins, except for pravastatin, are metabolized by cytochrome p450"
"What drug class do cholestyramine, colestipol, and colesevelam belong do? Bile acid resins"
"Bile acids, derived from cholesterol, are released into the intestinal lumen"
"Normally, 95% of bile acids in the ileum are recycled back to the liver through enterohepatic circulation"
"Bile acid resins (e.g. cholestyramine) bind bile acids in the intestinal lumen, preventing absorption and recycling to the liver"
"Bile acid resins (e.g. cholestyramine) interrupt bile acid recycling and promote synthesis of new bile acids, depleting liver cholesterol stores"
"Bile acid resins (e.g. cholestyramine) indirectly increase HMG CoA reductase activity and thus increase cholesterol synthesis by the liver"
"Bile acid resins indirectly cause increased LDL receptor expression"
"What effect do bile acid resins have on LDL levels? Moderately decreased"
"What effect do bile acid resins have on HDL levels? Slightly increased"
"Bile acid resins are used in patients with primary hypercholesterolemia, usually in conjunction with statins"
"What effect do bile acid resins have on serum triglycerides levels? Slightly increased"
"Bile acid resins increase the cholesterol content of bile acids and thus may cause cholesterol gallstones"
"Bile acid resins frequently cause GI side effects, such as constipation and bloating"
"Bile acid resins can lead to steatorrhea, which may impair the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K)"
"Bile acid resins are lipid-lowering agents that may decrease the absorption of statins, thus these drugs should be given 4 hours apart"
"Ezetimibe is a lipid-lowering agent that blocks absorption of cholesterol at the small intestinal brush border"
"Ezetimibe restricts the liver's access to exogenous cholesterol"
"Ezetimibe indirectly increases HMG CoA reductase activity and thus increases cholesterol synthesis by the liver"
"Ezetimibe indirectly causes increased LDL receptor expression"
"What effect does ezetimibe have on LDL levels? Moderately decreased"
"What GI side effect is associated with ezetimibe? Diarrhea/steatorrhea::2"
"Ezetimibe may cause increased liver function tests"
"Evolocumab and alirocumab are lipid-lowering agents that inhibit PCSK9::what enzyme?"
"PCSK9 is a protease produced by the liver that leads to degradation of hepatocyte LDL receptors"
"Evolocumab binds PCSK9 and prevents degradation of hepatic LDL receptors"
"What drug class do gemfibrozil and fenofibrate belong to? Fibrates"
"Fibrates upregulate the enzyme lipoprotein lipase (LPL) by activating PPAR-α"
"Fibrates significantly decrease serum triglycerides by increasing hydrolysis of VLDLs and chylomicrons"
"One way Fibrates decrease serum triglycerides is by decreasing hepatic VLDL secretion"
"Fibrates lead to mild decreases in serum LDL by reducing VLDL"
"What effect do fibrates have on HDL levels? Mildly increased HDL"
"Fibrates may cause myopathy as an adverse effect, especially when combined with statins"
"Fibrates increase risk of cholesterol gallstones and thus should be used with caution in patients with biliary tract disease"
"Niacin (B3) is the most effective drug for increasing serum HDL"
"Fibrates are the most effective drugs for decreasing serum triglycerides"
"Niacin (Vitamin B3) mildly decreases serum triglycerides by decreasing hepatic VLDL secretion"
"Niacin leads to moderately decreased serum LDL by reducing VLDL synthesis"
"A common adverse effect associated with niacin is cutaneous flushing and warmth due to increased prostaglandin activity"
"Flushing and warmth, secondary to niacin use, may be prevented with NSAIDs"
"What effect may niacin have on blood glucose levels? Increased (Hyperglycemia)"
"Niacin may cause hyperuricemia as an adverse effect, which can precipitate gout"
"Niacin can cause elevated liver function tests with severe hepato-toxicity"
"Fish oil, a supplement high in omega-3 fatty acids, may be used to lower serum triglyceride levels"
"Organic nitrates are metabolized and release nitric oxide"
"Nitric oxide increases levels of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells"
"Increased levels of cGMP cause myosin light chain dephosphorylation, preventing its interaction with actin"
"Nitrates primarily cause venous dilation, causing decreased pre-load"
"Nitrates may provide symptomatic relief of chronic, stable angina"
"Nitrates reduce myocardial oxygen requirements"
"Sublingual administration of nitroglycerine avoids first pass metabolism, which is useful for immediate relief of angina"
"Oral nitrate preparations have a longer duration of action than sublingual"
"What drug class do isosorbide mononitrate/dinitrate and nitroglycerin belong to? Nitrates"
"Oral nitrate preparations require large dosing due to first pass metabolism"
"Nitrates may be used to treat Prinzmetal angina, which is characterized by vasospasm"
"Nitrates are useful in treatment of acute coronary syndromes"
"Nitrates should be avoided in right-sided myocardial infarction"
"IV nitroglycerine can be used in the treatment of hypertensive emergency"
"Nitroglycerine may be used as an acute treatment for pulmonary edema"
"Adverse effects associated with nitrates include orthostatic hypotension and syncope due to pooling of blood in veins"
"Nitrate-induced hypotension may cause reflex tachycardia"
"Nitrates are often combined with β-blockers to help prevent reflex sympathetic activation"
"What calcium channel blocker may be combined with nitrates, producing similar effects to β-blockers? Verapamil"
"Nitrates may cause throbbing headaches and cutaneous flushing as possible side effects"
"What hematological complication is associated with nitrates? Methemoglobinemia"
"Patients on nitrates have a nitrate-free interval everyday to prevent tolerance"
"Industrial workers may develop \Monday disease\\" due to excessive nitrate exposure"
"Patients on PDE-5 inhibitors should avoid nitrate therapy for 24 hours"
"Nitrates are contraindicated in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy"
"Ranolazine is a drug used to treat angina refractory to other medical therapies"
"What effect does ranolazine have on heart rate and blood pressure? No effect"
"Ranolazine inhibits the late phase of Na+ current, thereby reducing diastolic wall tension and O2 consumption"
"Ranolazine may cause QT prolongation on ECG"
