"Adverse effects of ranolazine include dizziness, headache, and nausea"
"What GI side effect may be caused by ranolazine? Constipation"
"Pindolol and acebutolol are both partial β-agonists that are contraindicated in angina"
"What is the effect of nitrates alone on heart rate? Increased (reflex response)"
"What is the effect of β-blockers alone on heart rate? Decreased"
"What is the effect of nitrates and β-blockers on heart rate? No effect or decreased"
"What is the effect of nitrates alone on ejection time? Decreased"
"What is the effect of β-blockers alone on ejection time? Increased"
"What is the effect of nitrates and β-blockers on ejection time? Little/no effect"
"What is the effect of nitrates alone on myocardial O2 consumption? Decreased"
"What is the effect of β-blockers alone on myocardial O2 consumption? Mildly decreased"
"What is the effect of nitrates and β-blockers on myocardial O2 consumption? Very decreased"
"Which aneurysm, true ventricular aneurysm or pseudo-aneurysm, is more likely to rupture? Pseudo-aneurysm"
"Exercise may increase the expression of the GLUT-4 receptor in muscle tissue, only"
"The large airways of the conducting zone of the lung consists of the nose, pharynx, larynx, trachea, and bronchi"
"The small airways of the conducting zone of the lung consist of bronchioles that further divide into terminal bronchioles"
"The conducting zone of the lung is responsible for warming, humidifying, and filtering the air"
"The volume of the conducting zone of the lung comprises the \anatomic dead space\\"\""
"Cartilage (NOT Cilia) and goblet cells extend to the end of the bronchi of the conducting zone"
"The cilia lining the epithelium of the respiratory tract help clear mucus and debris from the lungs via the mucociliary escalator"
"Airway smooth muscle cells extend to the terminal bronchioles of the conducting zone (sparse beyond this point)"
"The smooth muscle of the conducting airways of the lung relaxes in response to sympathetic activation of the β2::typenumber adrenergic receptors"
"The smooth muscle of the conducting airways of the lung constrict in response to parasympathetic activation of muscarinic::specific receptors"
"What is the effect of sympathetic innervation on the smooth muscle of the conducting airways of the lung? Relaxation"
"The respiratory zone of the lung consists of the respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and alveolar sacs"
"Does the respiratory zone of the lung participate in gas exchange? Yes"
"Which part of the respiratory zone still contains some smooth muscle? Respiratory bronchioles"
"Where in the respiratory tract do cilia terminate? Respiratory bronchioles"
"Do the alveolar ducts and/or sacs have cilia? No"
"The alveolar walls are lined with epithelial cells called type I and type II pneumocytes"
"Type II pneumocytes are responsible for synthesis of pulmonary surfactant"
"Type II pneumocytes have regenerative capacity for both type I and type II pneumocytes"
"The alveoli contain phagocytic cells called alveolar macrophages (dust cells), which clear debris and participate in the immune response"
"Pulmonary blood flow is equal to the cardiac output of the right heart"
"When a person is standing, pulmonary blood flow is lowest at the apex (top) of the lungs"
"When a person is standing, pulmonary blood flow is highest at the base (bottom) of the lungs"
"The volume that moves into the lung with each quiet inspiration is the tidal volume"
"What is the typical normal value for tidal volume (mL)? 500 mL"
"The additional volume that can be inspired above tidal volume is the inspiratory reserve volume"
"The additional volume that can be expired below tidal volume is the expiratory reserve volume"
"The volume that remains in the lungs after maximal forced expiration is the residual volume"
"Which lung volume cannot be measured on spirometry? Residual volume"
"The sum of the tidal volume plus the inspiratory reserve volume is known as inspiratory capacity"
"The sum of the residual volume plus the expiratory reserve volume is known as functional residual capacity"
"The volume of gas remaining in the lungs after normal expiration is the functional residual capacity"
"The sum of the tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, and expiratory reserve volume is known as the vital capacity"
"The sum of the tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume is known as the total lung capacity"
"The volume of gas present in the lungs after a maximal inspiration is known as the total lung capacity"
"Which lung capacities cannot be measured on spirometry? Functional residual capacity, Total lung capacity::2"
"Functional residual capacity may be measured using helium dilution or body plethysmograph"
"What is the typical normal value for anatomic dead space (mL)? 150 mL"
"The volume of the anatomic dead space plus the alveolar dead space comprises the \physiologic dead space\\"\""
"The apex of a healthy lung is the largest contributor of alveolar dead space"
"Physiologic dead space is the total volume of the lungs that does not participate in gas exchange"
"In healthy lungs, the physiologic dead space is approximately equal to the anatomic dead space"
"In certain pathologic situations, the physiologic dead space may become greater than the anatomic dead space, suggesting a(n) ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) defect"
"Pathologic dead space is when part of the respiratory zone is ventilated::perfused/ventilated, but not perfused::perfused/ventilated"
"What equation may be used to determine the physiologic dead space (VD)? "
"Minute ventilation is the total volume of gas that enters the lungs per unit time"
"Alveolar ventilation is the volume of gas per unit time that reaches the alveoli (accounts for physiologic dead space)"
"What equation may be used to calculate minute ventilation? Minute Ventilation (VE) = VT * Respiratory Rate"
"What equation may be used to calculate alveolar ventilation? Alveolar Ventilation (VA) = (VT - VD) * Respiratory Rate"
"What is the normal range of respiratory rates for a healthy adult (breaths/min)? 12-20 breaths/min"
"If CO2 production is constant, then the arterial and alveolar Pco2 is determined by alveolar ventilation"
"What is the effect of increased alveolar ventilation on arteriolar (and alveolar) Pco2? Decreased Pco2"
"What is the effect of decreased alveolar ventilation on arteriolar (and alveolar) Pco2? Increased Pco2"
"The alveolar gas equation states that the alveolar Po2 (PAo2) equals: "
"When using the alveolar gas equation, the respiratory quotient (R) is equal to the ratio of CO2 produced / O2 consumed"
"The approximate Po2 in inspired, humidified air (PIO2) at sea level is 150 mmHg"
"The gradient between PAo2 - Pao2 is known as the A-a gradient and is normally 10 - 15 mmHg"
"The total volume of air that can be forcibly expired after a maximal inspiration is known as the forced vital capacity (FVC)"
"The volume of air that can be forcibly expired after a maximal inspiration in one second is known as the FEV1"
"The normal value for the ratio of FEV1/FVC is approximately 0.8"
"In obstructive lung disease, the FEV1/FVC is decreased"
"In restrictive lung disease, the FEV1/FVC is normal or increased"
"The diaphragm is the most important muscle for inspiration"
"When the diaphragm contracts, the abdominal contents are pushed downwards"
"During exercise or respiratory distress, the external intercostal muscles and accessory muscles may be used for vigorous inspiration"
"What muscles are normally used for expiration at rest? none :) (normally passive)"
"During exercise or in diseases with increased airway resistance (e.g. asthma), abdominal muscles and internal intercostal muscles may be used to aid expiration"
"Lung compliance may be calculated by the equation C = ΔV/ΔP"
"The compliance of the lungs and chest wall is inversely proportional to their elastance"
"The compliance of the lungs and chest wall is inversely proportional to the wall stiffness"
"Elastic recoil generates the force corresponding to the tendency for the lungs to collapse inward and the chest wall to spring outward"
"Elastic recoil is inversely proportional to compliance and directly proportional to elastance"
"A lung with high compliance is easier to fill"
"A lung with low compliance is harder to fill"
"The slope of a respiratory system pressure-volume curve represents lung compliance"
"The slope (compliance) of the pressure-volume loop curves for inspiration and expiration are different, exhibiting a phenomenon known as hysteresis"
"Hysteresis occurs due to the need to overcome surface tension forces during lung inflation (inspiration)"
"Are the lungs generally more compliant during inspiration or expiration? Expiration (think hysteresis)"
"The intermolecular forces between liquid molecules lining the lung are much stronger than the forces between liquid and air"
"During initial inspiration, liquid molecules are close together and intermolecular forces are high"
"During expiration, the slope of the pressure-volume loop increases as the density of surfactant molecules rapidly increases"
"At FRC, the intrapleural space normally has a(n) negative pressure relative to the atmosphere"
"At functional residual capacity, the inward pull of the lung is balanced by the outward pull of the chest"
"If a sharp object punctures the intrapleural space (pneumothorax), the intrapleural pressure becomes equal to atmospheric pressure"
"The compliance of the lung-chest wall system is less than that of the lungs or chest wall alone"
"At FRC, airway and alveolar pressures are equal to 0 (atmospheric pressure)"
"When lung volume is less than FRC, there is a net expanding force on the lung-chest wall system"
"When lung volume is greater than FRC, there is a net collapsing force on the lung-chest wall system"
"At highest lung volumes, both the lungs and the chest wall contribute to collapsing forces on the lung-chest wall system"
"What is the effect of emphysema on lung compliance? Increased compliance"
"At the original FRC, the tendency of the lung to collapse in a patient with emphysema is less than the tendency of the chest wall to expand"
"What is the effect of emphysema on functional residual capacity (FRC)? Increased FRC"
"A patient with emphysema breathes at a higher lung volume and will thus have a(n) barrel-shaped chest (increased anterior-posterior diameter)"
"What is the effect of normal aging on lung compliance? Increased compliance"
"What is the effect of pulmonary fibrosis on lung compliance? Decreased compliance"
"At the original FRC, the tendency of the lung to collapse in a patient with pulmonary fibrosis is greater than the tendency of the chest wall to expand"
"What is the effect of pulmonary fibrosis on functional residual capacity (FRC)? Decreased FRC"
"What is the effect of pulmonary edema on lung compliance? Decreased compliance"
"What is the effect of pneumonia on lung compliance? Decreased compliance"
"What is the effect of surfactant on lung compliance? Increased compliance"
"The law of Laplace states that the collapsing pressure of an alveoli, P, is equal to 2T / r"
"According to the law of Laplace, a large alveolus will have a(n) low collapsing pressure"
"According to the law of Laplace, a small alveolus will have a(n) high collapsing pressure"
"Surfactant is a mixture of phospholipids that line the alveoli and reduce their surface tension"
"Surfactant reduces surface tension by disrupting the intermolecular forces between liquid molecules"
"Without surfactant, small alveoli are more likely to collapse, which is termed atelectasis"
"In the developing fetus, surfactant synthesis begins as early as gestastional week 20"
"In the developing fetus, mature levels of surfactant are not achieved until around week 35"
"Alveoli have increased tendency to collapse on expiration::inspiration/expiration"
"What equation may be used to calculate the airflow (Q) given the pressure and resistance of the airway? Q = ΔP/R"
"Airflow is inversely proportional to airway resistance"
"Airflow is directly proportional to the pressure gradient"
"The resistance of an airway may be calculated using Poiseuille's equation, which states R = 8ηl/πr4"
"Airway resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius of the airway"
"The major site of airway resistance is the medium-sized bronchi"
"What is the effect of parasympathetic innervation on airway resistance? Increased resistance"
"What is the effect of sympathetic innervation on airway resistance? Decreased resistance"
"What is the effect of high lung volumes on airway resistance? Decreased resistance"
"What is the effect of low lung volumes on airway resistance? Increased resistance"
"What is the effect of increased viscosity (e.g. deep-sea diving) on airway resistance? Increased resistance"
"What is the effect of decreased viscosity (e.g. helium inhalation) on airway resistance? Decreased resistance"
"What equation may be used to calculate the pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR)? PVR = (Ppulm artery - PL atrium) / cardiac output"
"The transpulmonary pressure across the lungs is calculated as alveolar pressure minus intrapleural pressure"
"How does the volume of breath change during inspiration? Increased"
"How does the intrapleural pressure change during inspiration (relative to atmosphere)? More negative relative to atmosphere"
"How does the alveolar pressure change during mid-inspiration (relative to atmosphere)? More negative relative to atmosphere"
"As the alveolar pressure becomes negative relative to the atmosphere (mid-inspiration), air flows inwards"
"How does the volume of breath change during expiration? Decreased"
"How does the intrapleural pressure change during expiration (relative to atmosphere)? Less negative relative to atmosphere"
"How does the alveolar pressure change during mid-expiration (relative to atmosphere)? More positive relative to atmosphere"
"As the alveolar pressure becomes positive relative to the atmosphere (mid-expiration), air flows outwards"
"In what normal scenario may intrapleural pressure be positive (relative to the atmosphere)? Forced expiration::specific"
"The partial pressure of a gas (Px) in humidified tracheal air is equal to (PB - PH2O) * F::equation"
"The partial pressure of a gas (Px) in dry expired air is equal to PB * F::equation"
"The concentration of a dissolved gas (Cx) is equal to Px * Solubility"
"Transfer of gases across cell membranes or capillary walls occurs by simple diffusion"
"According to Fick's law, the rate of diffusion of a gas (Vgas) is equal to: "
"The diffusion coefficient (DK) for CO2 is approximately 20x higher than that of O2"
"The lung diffusing capacity (DL) is directly correlated with the permeability of the alveolar-pulmonary capillary barrier"
"The lung diffusing capacity (DL) can be measured with carbon monoxide (CO) because it is exclusively diffusion-limited"
"DLCO may be used to estimate the extent to which oxygen passes from the air sacs of lungs into blood"
"The lung diffusing capacity, DL, is directly proportional to the surface area available for diffusion"
"The lung diffusing capacity, DL, is directly proportional to the diffusion coefficient of the gas"
"The lung diffusing capacity, DL, is inversely proportional to the alveolar wall thickness"
"The lung diffusing capacity, DL, decreases in emphysema due to decreased surface area (A)"
"The lung diffusing capacity, DL, decreases in pulmonary fibrosis due to increased wall thickness (Δx)"
"The lung diffusing capacity, DL, increases during exercise due to increased surface area (A)"
"The Po2 in dry inspired air is normally approximately 160 mmHg"
"The Po2 in humidified tracheal air is normally approximately 150 mmHg"
"The partial pressure of oxygen in the alveolar air (PAO2) and arterial blood (PaO2) is normally approximately 100 mmHg"
"The partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the alveolar air (PACO2) and arterial blood (PaCO2) is normally approximately 40 mmHg"
"The partial pressure of oxygen in the venous blood (PvO2) is normally approximately 40 mmHg"
"The partial pressure of carbon dioxide in mixed venous blood (PvCO2) is normally approximately 46 mmHg"
"The partial pressure of O2 in arteriolar blood is slightly lower than alveolar air due to the \physiologic shunt\\"\""
"Physiologic shunt sources are bronchial blood flow and some coronary venous blood (via the thebesian vein to the left ventricle)."
"The total gas concentration in solution is the sum of the dissolved gas plus bound gas plus chemically modified gas"
"The partial pressure gradient is the driving force for the diffusion of a gas"
"Only free, dissolved gas contributes to the partial pressure of a gas in solution"
"In diffusion-limited gas exchange, the gas does not equilibrate by the time blood reaches the end of the capillary"
"In perfusion-limited gas exchange, the gas equilibrates early along the length of the capillary"
"In perfusion-limited gas exchange, diffusion can be increased only if blood flow increases"
"In normal health, O2 exhibits perfusion-limited gas exchange"
"CO2 exhibits perfusion-limited gas exchange"
"N2O exhibits perfusion-limited gas exchange"
"CO exhibits diffusion-limited gas exchange"
"When patients have diseased lung tissue (e.g. fibrosis/emphysema) O2 transfer becomes diffusion-limited"
"At high altitude the partial pressure gradient of O2 is lower and thus equilibration takes longer"
"O2 is carried in blood in two forms: dissolved (2%) or bound to hemoglobin (98%)"
"Hemoglobin is a globular protein consisting of four subunits"
"Each subunit of hemoglobin contains a(n) heme moiety, which is a(n) iron-binding porphyrin, and a polypeptide chain"
"Iron in hemoglobin is normally in the ferrous (Fe2+) state"
"If the iron in hemoglobin is in the ferric (Fe3+) state, it is called methemoglobin"
"Methemoglobin has a(n) increased affinity for cyanide relative to hemoglobin"
"Methemoglobinemia may present with cyanosis and chocolate-colored blood"
"Induced-methemoglobinemia (i.e. nitrites followed by thiosulfate) may be used to treat cyanide poisoning"
"Methemoglobinemia can be treated with methylene blue or vitamin C"
"Polluted/high altitude H2O may contain nitrites, which can cause methemoglobinemia"
"Benzocaine is a local anesthetic that may cause methemoglobinemia in toxic doses"
"Methemoglobinemia is associated with decreased SaO2, decreased O2 content, and normal PaO2"
"Most adult hemoglobin is composed of 2 α and 2 β subunits; known as HbA"
"Fetal hemoglobin, known as HbF, is composed of 2 alpha and 2 gamma subunits"
"Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) has a much higher binding affinity for O2 than adult hemoglobin (HbA)"
"Why must fetal hemoglobin have a much higher O2 binding affinity than HbA? Drives O2 diffusion across placenta from mother to fetus"
"The increased O2 binding affinity of fetal hemoglobin results from decreased affinity of HbF for 2,3-BPG"
"Hemoglobin exists in two forms: taut (deoxygenated) and relaxed (oxygenated)"
"The taut form of hemoglobin has a(n) low affinity for O2"
"The relaxed form of hemoglobin has a(n) high affinity for O2"
"The taut form of hemoglobin is found in most tissues"
"The relaxed form of hemoglobin is found in the respiratory tract"
"Normally 1g of hemoglobin can bind 1.34 mL of O2"
"Normally there is ~15 g/dL of hemoglobin in blood"
"The O2-binding capacity of blood is 20.1 mL O2/ 100 mL blood"
"What equation may be used to calculate the O2 content of blood? O2 content =  \(1.34*Hb*SaO_2 + 0.003*PaO_2\)"
"What equation may be used to calculate O2 delivery to tissues? O2 delivery = cardiac output * O2 content of blood"
"The sigmoidal shape of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is due to positive cooperativity (increased affinity for each sucessive O2 bound)"
"A(n) hemo-globin molecule has the potential to bind 4 O2 molecule(s)"
"A(n) myo-globin molecule has the potential to bind 1 O2 molecule(s)"
"The P50 of the oxygen-Hb dissociation curve is the Po2 at which hemoglobin is 50% saturated"
"Does the oxygen-myoglobin dissociation curve have a sigmoidal shape? Why? No, myoglobin is monomeric (no positive cooperativity)"
"Shifts of the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the right occur when there is decreased affinity of hemoglobin for O2"
"Shifts of the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the right cause increased unloading of O2 at tissues"
"Increased pCO2 and resulting decrease of pH enhancing the release of O2 from hemoglobin is called the Bohr effect"
"Increases in Pco2 cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the right"
"Decreases in pH cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the right"
"Increases in temperature cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the right"
"Increases in 2,3-BPG cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the right"
"2,3-BPG decreases the affinity of hemoglobin for O2 by binding to hemoglobin β chains"
"How do levels of 2,3-BPG change at high altitudes? Increased"
"2,3-BPG increases under hypoxic conditions (e.g. high altitude)"
"High altitudes indirectly cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the right"
"Factors that shift the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the right favor the taut form of hemoglobin"
"Shifts of the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the left occurs when there is increased affinity of hemoglobin for O2"
"Shifts of the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the left cause decreased unloading of O2 at tissues"
"Decreases in Pco2 cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the left"
"Increases in pH cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the left"
"Decreases in temperature cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the left"
"Decreases in 2,3-BPG cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the left"
"Increases in hemoglobin F cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the left"
"Carboxyhemoglobin is a form of hemoglobin bound to CO in place of O2"
"Carbon monoxide binds competitively to Hb and with 200-250x greater affinity than O2"
"Carboxyhemoglobin causes the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the left"
"Carboxyhemoglobin heme groups not bound by CO have a(n) increased affinity for O2"
"Carboxyhemoglobin causes decreased unloading of O2 at tissues"
"Carboxyhemoglobin causes decreased O2-binding capacity"
"Carboxyhemoglobinemia (CO poisoning) may be treated with 100% O2 and hyperbaric O2"
"Carboxyhemoglobinemia is associated with decreased* SaO2, decreased O2 content, and normal PaO2"
"What is the hemoglobin concentration in carboxyhemoglobinemia? Normal"
"Anemia is associated with normal SaO2, decreased O2 content, and normal PaO2"
"How does the hemoglobin concentration change in anemia? Decreased"
"Polycythemia is associated with normal SaO2, increased O2 content, and normal PaO2"
"How does the hemoglobin concentration change in polycythemia? Increased"
"Erythropoietin (EPO) is a hormone synthesized in the kidneys in response to hypoxia"
"Decreased O2 delivery to the kidneys due to hypoxia causes increased production of hypoxia-inducible factor 1α, which then stimulates synthesis of EPO"
"Hypoxia-inducible factor 1α acts on renal fibroblasts to cause synthesis of the mRNA for erythropoietin"
"Erythropoietin (EPO) causes differentiation of proerythroblasts, which undergo further development to form mature erythrocytes"
"Hemoglobin may act as a(n) buffer for H+ ions"
"One way in which CO2 is carried in the blood is bound to hemoglobin, known as carbaminohemoglobin (HbCO2) (5%)"
"The majority of CO2 transported in blood is in the form of HCO3- (bicarbonate) (90%)"
"CO2 binding to hemoglobin favors the taut form, thus reducing Hb affinity for O2"
"Decreased O2 binding to hemoglobin causes increased affinity for CO2 and H+ (Haldane effect)"
"Increased O2 binding to hemoglobin causes decreased affinity for CO2 (Haldane effect)"
"In red blood cells (in plasma), CO2 is combined with H2O via the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, forming H2CO3"
"H2CO3, formed from CO2 and H2O in red blood cells, dissociates into H+ and HCO3-"
"The H+ in red blood cells (from H2CO3) is buffered by deoxyhemoglobin"
"The HCO3- in red blood cells (from H2CO3) is transported into the plasma in exchange for Cl-"
"The HCO3- transported out of RBCs is carried to the lungs in the plasma of venous blood"
"In the lungs, oxygenation of hemoglobin promotes H+ release from its buffering sites"
"In the lungs, HCO3- enters the red blood cells in exchange for Cl-"
"In the lungs, H2CO3 in the red blood cell is reconverted to CO2 and H2O and expired"
"Somatostatinoma may present with gallstones and steatorrhea due to inhibition of secretin and CCK"
"Somatostatinoma may present with achlorhydria due to inhibition of gastrin"
"The mnemonic FROM JANE describes the symptoms of bacterial endocarditis"
"Which two vasculitides are associated with positive serum p-ANCA? Churg-Strauss syndrome and Microscopic polyangiitis"
"The Cl--HCO3- exchange that occurs across the RBC membrane is accomplished by an anion exchange protein called band three protein"
"The pulmonary circulation is normally characterized as a(n) low::high/low resistance, high::high/low compliance system"
"A decrease in PAO2 causes a hypoxic vasoconstriction that shunts blood away from poorly ventilated regions of the lung"
"Fetal pulmonary vascular resistance is very high because of generalized hypoxic vaso-constriction"
"Decreased Po2 (hypoxia) causes vaso-constriction in the pulmonary circulation"
"Increased Pco2 (hypercapnia) causes vaso-constriction in the pulmonary circulation"
"Decreased Po2 (hypoxia) causes vaso-dilation in the systemic circulation"
"In zone 1 (apex) of the lung, blood flow (Q) is lowest"
"In zone 3 (base) of the lung, blood flow (Q) is highest"
"Rank the following variables for zone 1 of the lung: PA, Pa, and Pv PA > Pa > Pv"
"Rank the following variables for zone 2 of the lung: PA, Pa, and Pv Pa > PA > Pv"
"Rank the following variables for zone 3 of the lung: PA, Pa, and Pv Pa > Pv > PA"
"In zone 1 of the lung, high alveolar pressure may compress the capillaries and reduce blood flow in this zone"
"In zone 2 of the lung, blood flow is driven by the difference between arteriolar and alveolar pressure"
"In zone 3 of the lung, blood flow is driven by the difference between arteriolar and venous pressure"
"In right-to-left shunts, hypoxemia always occurs because a significant fraction of the cardiac output is not delivered to the lungs"
"A defining characteristic of hypoxemia caused by a right-to-left shunt is that it cannot be corrected with high O2 gas"
"Do left-to-right shunts result in hypoxemia? No"
"A consequence of pulmonary hypertension is right ventricular hypertrophy with eventual cor pulmonale"
"The ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) ratio is the ratio of alveolar ventilation to pulmonary blood flow"
"The normal average value for V/Q is 0.8"
"In zone 1 (apex) of the lung, alveolar ventilation (V) is lowest"
"In zone 3 (base) of the lung, alveolar ventilation (V) is highest"
"The V/Q ratio is highest in zone 1 (apex) of the lung"
"The V/Q ratio is lowest in zone 3 (base) of the lung"
"The V/Q ratio at the apex of the lung is normally 3, indicating wasted ventilation"
"The V/Q ratio at the base of the lung is normally 0.6, indicating wasted perfusion"
"What is the ideal V/Q ratio for adequate gas exchange? 1 (ventilation matches perfusion)"
"If there is a(n) blood flow obstruction, the V/Q ratio = ∞ (dead space)*"
"If there is a(n) airway obstruction, the V/Q ratio = 0 (shunt)"
"What type of V/Q mismatch occurs due to pulmonary embolus? Dead space*"
"What type of V/Q mismatch occurs due to airway obstruction? Shunt (perfusion but no ventilation)"
"Does 100% O2 improve PaO2 in V/Q mismatch due to physiologic dead space? Yes, assuming < 100% dead space"
"Does 100% O2 improve PaO2 in V/Q mismatch due to shunt? No"
"Certain organisms that thrive in high O2 (e.g. TB) flourish in the apex of the lung"
"With exercise (increased cardiac output), there is vasodilation of apical capillaries in the lung, which causes the V/Q ratio to approach a value of 1"
"Breathing as an involuntary process is controlled by the medulla and pons of the brain stem"
"The medullary respiratory center is located in the reticular formation and contains an inspiratory and expiratory center"
"The dorsal and ventral respiratory groups are located in the medulla of the brain stem"
"The dorsal respiratory group is primarily responsible for inspiration and generates the basic rhythm for breathing"
"The dorsal respiratory group receives sensory input from peripheral chemoreceptors via the glossopharyngeal (CN IX) and vagus (CN X) nerves"
"The dorsal respiratory group receives sensory input from lung stretch receptors via the vagus (CN X) nerve"
"The dorsal respiratory group sends its motor output to the diaphragm via the phrenic nerve"
"The ventral respiratory group is primarily responsible for expiration and is not active during normal, quiet breathing"
"The apneustic center is located in the lower pons and stimulates inspiration"
"The pneumotaxic center is located in the upper pons and inhibits inspiration"
"Commands from the cerebral cortex can temporarily override the automatic respiratory brain stem centers"
"Where are the central chemoreceptors located? Medulla"
"Central chemoreceptors are especially sensitive to the pH of the cerebrospinal fluid"
"In response to decreased pH sensed by chemoreceptors, the breathing rate increases (hyperventilation)"
"Central chemoreceptors respond indirectly to increased Pco2 and directly to decreased pH"
"Where are the peripheral chemoreceptors located? Carotid bodies and aortic bodies::2"
"Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to decreases in Pao2 and pH"
"Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to increases in Pco2"
"Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to decreased Po2 when the arterial Po2 is less than 60 mmHg"
"Increases in arterial H+ stimulate the carotid body peripheral chemoreceptors only, independent of changes in Pco2"
"Lung stretch receptors are mechanoreceptors located in the smooth muscle of the airways"
"Lung stretch receptors cause a(n) decreased breathing frequency in response to distention of the lungs (Hering-Breuer reflex)"
"Irritant receptors are located between the airway epithelial cells and are stimulated by noxious substances"
"Joint and muscle receptors are activated during movement of the limbs and stimulate early breathing during exercise"
"Juxtacapillary (J) receptors are located in the alveolar walls and cause rapid, shallow breathing in response to pulmonary capillary engorgement (e.g. left heart failure)"
"In response to exercise, there is increased CO2 production"
"In response to exercise, there is increased ventilation rate to meet O2 demand"
"In response to exercise, the V/Q ratio from apex to base becomes more even (even or uneven)"
"In response to exercise, there is increased pulmonary blood flow, due to increased cardiac output"
"There is a(n) decrease in pulmonary resistance associated with increased perfusion of pulmonary capillary beds"
"In response to strenuous exercise, there is decreased pH, secondary to lactic acidosis"
"How does Paco2 change in response to exercise? No change"
"How does Pao2 change in response to exercise? No change"
"In response to exercise, there is increased venous CO2 content"
"In response to exercise, there is decreased venous O2 content"
"In response to decreased atmospheric oxygen (e.g. high altitude), there is a(n) decreased Pao2"
"In response to decreased Pao2 (e.g. high altitude), there is increased ventilation"
"Increased ventilation (e.g. high altitude) causes decreased Paco2"
"High altitude initially causes respiratory alkalosis and hypoxia, which may cause acute altitude sickness"
"In response to high altitude, there is a chronic increase in ventilation"
"The respiratory alkalosis that occurs as a result of ascent to high altitude may be treated with carbonic anhydrase inhibitors"
"Living at high altitude chronically causes hypoxia which increases the synthesis of erythropoietin, causing polycythemia"
"In response to high altitude, there is a(n) increase in 2,3-BPG"
"In response to high altitude, there are cellular changes, such as increased mitochondria"
"In response to respiratory alkalosis (e.g. due to high altitude), there is increased renal excretion of HCO3-"
"In response to high altitude, there is chronic hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction which results in pulmonary hypertension and RV hypertrophy"
"Hypoxemia is defined as a decrease in Pao2"
"Is the A - a gradient normal, increased, or decreased, in response to high altitude? Normal"
"Is the A - a gradient normal, increased, or decreased, in response to hypoventilation (e.g. opioid use, obesity hypoventilation syndrome)? Normal"
"Is the A - a gradient normal, increased, or decreased, in response to diffusion defects (e.g. fibrosis, pulmonary edema)? Increased"
"Is the A - a gradient normal, increased, or decreased, in response to V/Q mismatch? Increased"
"Is the A - a gradient normal, increased, or decreased, in response to right-to-left shunts? Increased"
"What cause of hypoxemia is not greatly helped by supplemental O2? Right-to-left shunt"
"Hypoxia is defined as a decrease of O2 delivery to tissues"
"Hypoxia may be caused by a(n) decreased cardiac output"
"Hypoxia::hypoxia or hypoxemia may be caused by hypoxemia::hypoxia or hypoxemia"
"Hypoxia may be caused by anemia, due to decreased levels of hematocrit and Hb"
"Hypoxia may be caused by carbon monoxide poisoning, which decreases the O2 content of blood"
"Ischemia is a cause of O2 deprivation due to a loss of blood flow (e.g. impeded arterial flow, decreased venous drainage)"
"Peptide and Protein Hormone Synthesis: The signal peptide of preprohormone attaches to docking proteins on the endoplasmic reticulum, where translation is completed"
"Rhinitis is the inflammation of the nasal mucosa"
"What is the most common cause of rhinitis? Rhinovirus"
"Rhinitis presents with sneezing, congestion, and runny nose (common cold)"
"Allergic rhinitis is a subtype of rhinitis due to a type I hypersensitivity reaction (e.g. to pollen)"
"Allergic rhinitis is characterized by an inflammatory infiltrate with eosinophils::WBC type"
"Allergic rhinitis is associated with other atopic disorders, such as asthma and eczema"
"Nasal polyps are protrusions of edematous, inflamed nasal mucosa"
"Nasal polyps are usually secondary to repeated bouts of rhinitis"
"Nasal polyps are associated with cystic fibrosis in children"
"Nasal polyps are associated with aspirin-induced asthma in adults"
"Aspirin-induced asthma is characterized by a triad of asthma, aspirin-induced bronchospasms, and nasal polyps"
"Angiofibromas are benign tumors of nasal mucosa composed of large blood vessels and fibrous tissues"
"What demographic is classically associated with angiofibroma? Adolescent males"
"Nasopharyngeal angiofibromas often present with profuse epistaxis"
"Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of nasopharyngeal epithelium"
"What virus is nasopharyngeal carcinoma associated with? Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)"
"Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is classically seen in African children"
"Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is classically seen in Chinese adults"
"Biopsy of nasopharyngeal carcinoma usually reveals pleomorphic keratin-positive epithelial cells in a background of lymphocytes"
"Nasopharyngeal carcinoma often presents with involvement of cervical lymph nodes"
"What is the most common cause of acute epiglottitis? H. influenzae type B"
"Acute epiglottitis presents with high fever, sore throat, and drooling with dysphagia"
"Acute epiglottitis may present with muffled voice and inspiratory stridor"
"Acute epiglottitis is associated with risk of acute airway obstruction"
"What is the most common cause of laryngotracheobronchitis (croup)? Parainfluenza virus"
"Laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) presents with a hoarse, \seal bark\\" cough and inspiratory stridor\""
"Vocal cord nodules arise on the true vocal cords"
"Vocal cord nodules are due to excessive use of vocal cords and are usually bilateral::uni- or bilateral"
"Vocal cord nodules are composed of degenerative myxoid connective tissue"
"Vocal cord (Singer's) nodules present with hoarseness and resolve with resting of voice"
"Laryngeal papilloma is a benign papillary tumor of the vocal cord"
"What virus is associated with laryngeal papilloma? HPV (strains 6, 11)"
"Laryngeal papillomas are usually single::# of lesions in adults"
"Laryngeal papillomas are usually multiple::# of lesions in children"
"Laryngeal papillomas may have koilocytic change on biopsy"
"Laryngeal papilloma often presents with hoarseness"
"Laryngeal carcinoma is a squamous cell carcinoma usually arising from the epithelial lining of the vocal cord"
"The major risk factors for laryngeal carcinoma are alcohol and tobacco"
"Laryngeal carcinoma can rarely arise from a laryngeal papilloma"
"Laryngeal carcinoma often presents with hoarseness; other signs include cough and stridor"
"Pneumonia is defined as an infection of the lung parenchyma"
"Pneumonia often occurs when normal defenses are impaired"
"Viral pneumonia may damage the mucociliary escalator, which consequently predisposes to superimposed bacterial pneumonia"
"Clinical features of pneumonia include productive cough with yellow-green or rusty-colored sputum (due to pus and blood, respectively)"
"Pneumonia may present with decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion"
"Pneumonia may present with fever, chills, and elevated WBC count"
"Pneumonia may present as tachypnea (respiratory rate) with pleuritic chest pain"
"Diagnosis of pneumonia is made by CXR and sputum & blood gram stain/culture"
"Lobar pneumonia is characterized by consolidation of an entire lobe or lung"
"Lobar pneumonia is characterized by neutrophils in the air sacs with a(n) intra-alveolar::location exudate"
"Lobar pneumonia is commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae (95%) and Klebsiella pneumoniae (5%)"
"Initially, lobar pneumonia presents with congestion on gross imaging due to congested vessels and proteinaceous edema in the alveolar airspaces"
"Following the congestion phase, lobar pneumonia presents grossly with red hepatization, due to exudate, neutrophils, and hemorrhage filling the alveolar air spaces"
"Following red hepatization, lobar pneumonia presents grossly with gray hepatization, due to degradation of red blood cells within exudate"
"The final phase of lobar pneumonia is resolution with regeneration of tissue via type II pneumocytes"
"Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia"
"Klebsiella pneumoniae::bug is a cause of pneumonia that most commonly affects the elderly, alcoholics, and diabetics (due to aspiration)"
"Pneumonia due to Klebsiella pneumoniae is caused by enteric flora that are aspirated"
"Klebsiella pneumoniae infection is characterized by a thick mucoid capsule that results in gelatinous, 'currant jelly' sputum"
"Klebsiella pneumoniae is often complicated by abscess formation in the lungs and liver"
"Bronchopneumonia is characterized by scattered, patchy consolidation centered around bronchioles"
"Bronchopneumonia is often multifocal and bilateral::uni- or bilateral"
"What type of pneumonia is characterized by acute inflammatory infiltrates from bronchioles into adjacent alveoli? Bronchopneumonia"
"What type of pneumonia is typically caused by S. pneumoniae, S. aureus, H. influenzae, and Klebsiella? Bronchopneumonia"
"Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of secondary pneumonia 2nd and 3rd are..."
"Pneumonia due to Staphylococcus aureus is often complicated by abscess formation or empyema (pus in the pleural space)"
"Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis, and Legionella are common causes of pneumonia superimposed on COPD"
"Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of pneumonia in cystic fibrosis patients"
"Legionella pneumophila is a cause of pneumonia that is transmitted from water sources"
"Legionella pneumophila is a cause of pneumonia in immunocompetent patients that is best visualized by silver stain"
"Interstitial (atypical) pneumonia is characterized by diffuse interstitial infiltrates"
"Atypical pneumonia is characterized by diffuse, patchy inflammation that is localized to interstitial areas at alveolar walls"
"How many lobes does interstitial (atypical) pneumonia typically involve? > 1"
"Interstitial (atypical) pneumonia presents with relatively mild upper respiratory symptoms"
"What type of pneumonia is typically caused by Mycoplasma, Chlamydia, Legionella and viruses (RSV, CMV, influenza, adenovirus)? Interstitial (atypical) pneumonia"
"Mycoplasma pneumoniae is the most common cause of atypical pneumonia in young adults"
"What demographic is commonly affected by Mycoplasma pneumoniae? Young adults, especially those living in close quarters"
"One complication of Mycoplasma pneumoniae is autoimmune hemolytic anemia due to high concentrations of cold agglutinins (IgM)"
"What gram stain is Mycoplasma pneumoniae characterized by? No stain (lacks cell wall)"
"Chlamydia pneumoniae is the second most common cause of atypical pneumonia in young adults"
"Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is the most common cause of atypical pneumonia in infants"
"Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common cause of atypical pneumonia in post-transplant patients on immunosuppressive therapy"
"Influenza is a common viral cause of atypical pneumonia in the elderly"
"Influenza virus increases the risk for superimposed bacterial pneumonia (e.g. by S. aureus, H. influenzae)"
"Coxiella burnetii infection is a cause of atypical pneumonia with high fever (Q fever)"
"What demographic is associated with Coxiella burnetii pneumonia? Farmers and veterinarians"
"Lung abscess is a localized collection of pus within the parenchyma"
"Lung abscess is often caused by aspiration of oropharyngeal contents"
"Lung abscess commonly occurs in patients predisposed to loss of consciousness (e.g. alcoholics, epileptics)"
"Lung abscess may occur in patients with bronchial obstruction (e.g. cancer)"
"Lung abscesses are commonly due to anaerobic bacteria such as Bacteroides, Fusobacterium, Peptostreptococcus, and Prevotella"
"Lung abscesses may present with air-fluid levels on CXR, which suggests cavitation"
"What drug is commonly used to treat lung abscesses? Clindamycin"
"Lung abscess secondary to aspiration is most commonly found in the right::left/right lung"
"If a patient is upright during aspiration, an abscess is most likely to form in the basal segments of the right lower lobe of the lung"
"If a patient is lying on their right side during aspiration, an abscess may form in the posterior segment of the right upper lobe of the lung"
"Tuberculosis is due to inhalation of aerosolized Mycobacterium tuberculosis"
"Primary TB results in focal caseating necrosis in the lower or middle lobes of the lung and hilar lymph nodes"
"Primary TB classically forms a(n) Ghon complex, which is a calcified granulomatous lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy"
"What symptoms does primary TB typically present with? Generally asymptomatic"
"Secondary TB typically affects the apex of the lung due to high oxygen tension"
"Primary tuberculosis may progress to miliary tuberculosis, which is a systemic spread of TB that may lead to multi-organ failure"
"What type of pneumonia may be caused by tuberculosis? Tuberculous bronchopneumonia"
"Clinical features of secondary TB include fever and night sweats"
"Clinical features of secondary TB include cough with hemoptysis and weight loss"
"Biopsy of tuberculosis reveals caseating granulomas"
"What stain is Mycobacterium tuberculosis characterized by? Acid fast"
"Secondary TB may involve the CNS, causing meningitis with granulomas at the base of the brain"
"Secondary TB may involve the kidneys, causing sterile pyuria"
"Secondary TB may involve the lumbar vertebrae, causing Pott disease"
"Which zone of the lung has the highest Pao2? Zone 1"
"In paradoxical splitting, the split sound is \paradoxically\\" eliminated with inspiration\""
"After preprohormone has been formed, signal peptides are cleaved, producing a(n) prohormone, which is transferred to the golgi apparatus"
"In the golgi apparatus, peptide sequences are cleaved from the prohormone to form the hormone, which is stored in secretory vesicles for later release"
"Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by obstruction of air flow resulting in air trapping in lungs"
"Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by a(n) decreased FEV1/FVC ratio"
"Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by a(n) increased total lung capacity"
"Chronic bronchitis is defined as a(n) productive cough lasting > 3 months per year for > 2 years"
"Chronic bronchitis is highly associated with smoking::risk factor"
"Chronic bronchitis is characterized by hypertrophy/hyperplasia of bronchial mucinous glands"
"Chronic bronchitis leads to an increased Reid index, which is the thickness of mucus glands relative to the overall bronchial wall thickness"
"In chronic bronchitis, the Reid index is > 50% (normal is < 40%)"
"Chronic bronchitis is associated with cyanosis, due to early-onset hypoxemia from shunting"
"Chronic bronchitis is associated with (hypercapnia) CO2 retention due to mucus plug trapping"
"What sounds may be heard on respiratory exam in a patient with chronic bronchitis? Wheezing, crackles::2"
"Chronic complications of chronic bronchitis include pulmonary hypertension with progression to cor pulmonale"
"Chronic bronchitis patients have increased risk of acquiring infection"
"What effect may chronic bronchitis secondarily have on RBC levels? Increased (polycythemia)"
"Chronic bronchitis presents with productive cough due to excessive mucus production and late-onset dyspnea"
"Emphysema is characterized by enlargement of air spaces"
"Emphysema is characterized by the destruction of alveolar air sacs"
"Emphysema is characterized by loss of elastic recoil, which inhibits the ability to exhale air from the alveoli (air trapping)"
"Emphysema is characterized by loss of elastic recoil, which may lead to airway collapse during exhalation"
"Emphysema is due to an imbalance of proteases (e.g. elastase) and antiproteases (e.g. α1-antitrypsin)"
"Inflammation in the lung normally leads to release of proteases by neutrophils and macrophages"
"α1-antitrypsin is an enzyme that neutralizes proteases (e.g. elastase) in the lung"
"Emphysema may be caused by excessive inflammation/proteases::general or lack of α1-antitrypsin"
"The most common cause of emphysema is smoking"
"Smoking results in centriacinar emphysema that is most severe in the upper lobes of the lung"
"α1-antitrypsin deficiency results in panacinar emphysema that is most severe in the lower lobes of the lung"
"α1-antitrypsin deficiency is caused by a mutation in the SERPINA1 gene which leads to misfolding of the mutated protein"
"What liver pathology is associated with α1-antitrypsin deficiency? Cirrhosis"
"Mutant α1-antitrypsin polymerizes and accumulates in the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes, resulting in liver damage (e.g. cirrhosis)"
"α1-antitrypsin deficiency is characterized by pink/purple colored, PAS-positive globules in hepatocytes"
"What is the normal allele for α1-antitrypsin? PiM"
"What is the most clinically significant mutant allele for α1-antitrypsin? PiZ"
"What genotype is associated with an asymptomatic phenotype with decreased α1-antitrypsin? PiMZ heterozygotes"
"PiMZ heterozygotes (α1-antitrypsin) are at significant risk for emphysema if they smoke"
"What genotype is associated with significant risk for panacinar emphysema and liver cirrhosis (α1-antitrypsin)? PiZZ homozygotes"
"Clinical features of emphysema include dyspnea and cough with minimal::quantity sputum production"
"Emphysema often presents with prolonged expiration with pursed lips"
"Emphysema may present with weight loss"
"Emphysema is characterized by increased AP diameter with a flattened diaphragm on CXR"
"Emphysema may present with increased lung field lucency on CXR"
"Chronic complications of emphysema include hypoxemia (due to destruction of capillaries in the alveolar sac) with eventual cor pulmonale"
"Asthma is defined as bronchial hyperresponsiveness with reversible airway bronchoconstriction"
"Asthma is most often due to allergic stimuli (type I HSR), but may also be triggered by viral URIs and stress"
"Asthma is often associated with allergic rhinitis, eczema, and a family history of atopy"
"Asthma most commonly presents in childhood::age group"
"Pathogenesis of asthma involves allergens inducing a TH2 phenotype in CD4+ T cells of genetically susceptible individuals"
"Asthma pathogenesis: TH2 cells secrete IL-4 which mediates class switching to IgE"
"Asthma pathogenesis: TH2 cells secrete IL-5 which attracts eosinophils"
"Asthma pathogenesis: TH2 cells secrete IL-10 which stimulates TH2 cells and inhibits TH1 cells"
"Re-exposure to an allergen in asthmatics leads to IgE-mediated activation of mast cells"
"In an asthmatic response, mast cells release preformed histamine granules (early-phase reaction)"
"In an asthmatic response, mast cells lead to generation of leukotrienes C4, D4, and E4 (early-phase reaction)"
"In an asthmatic response, inflammatory mediators, especially major basic protein from eosinophils, damages cells and perpetuates bronchoconstriction (late-phase reaction)"
"One clinical feature of asthma is a productive cough with spiral-shaped mucus plugs, known as Curschmann spirals"
"One clinical feature of asthma is a productive cough with eosinophil-derived crystals, known as Charcot-Leyden crystals"
"Asthma is associated with bronchial smooth muscle hypertrophy"
"Clinical diagnosis of asthma may be aided with spirometry (PFTs) and methacholine challenge"
"Asthma classically presents with episodic cough, dyspnea, and wheezing (lung sound)"
"Asthma may present with tachypnea::respiratory rate"
"Which form of lung disease is associated with pulsus paradoxus? Obstructive::restrictive or obstructive?"
"Asthma may present with a(n) decreased inspiratory/expiratory ratio"
"Asthma may cause excessive production of mucus with resultant mucus plugging"
"Asthma may present with peribronchial cuffing on CXR"
"Severe, unrelenting asthma attacks can result in status asthmaticus and death"
"Bronchiectasis is due to chronic necrotizing inflammation or obstruction which results in permanently dilated airways"
"Bronchiectasis is an obstructive lung disease that may be caused by cystic fibrosis"
"Which obstructive lung disease may be caused by Kartagener syndrome? Bronchiectasis"
"Bronchiectasis is associated with bronchial obstruction, such as a tumor or foreign body"
"Bronchiectasis is associated with poor ciliary motility (e.g. smoking, Kartagener syndrome)"
"Bronchiectasis is associated with allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, which is a hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus"
"Which obstructive lung disease may be caused by allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis? Bronchiectasis"
"Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is usually seen in individuals with asthma or cystic fibrosis"
"Bronchiectasis may present with dyspnea and cough with hemoptysis"
"Bronchiectasis is associated with recurrent infections and foul-smelling, purulent sputum"
"Bronchiectasis may cause digital clubbing"
"Secondary (AA) amyloidosis and hypoxemia with cor pulmonale are complications of bronchiectasis::which lung problem"
"Which obstructive lung disease is associated with secondary (AA) amyloidosis? Bronchiectasis"
"Generally, obstructive lung diseases increase risk for chronic, hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction with subsequent cor pulmonale"
"Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by a FEV1/FVC ratio > 80%"
"Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by a(n) decreased total lung capacity"
"Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by a(n) decreased residual volume and functional residual capacity"
"Restrictive lung diseases are most commonly due to interstitial diseases of the lung"
"Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is fibrosis of the lung interstitium with unknown cause"
"Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is likely related to cyclical lung injury, with TGF-β from injured pneumocytes inducing increased collagen deposition and fibrosis"
"Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis presents clinically with progressive dyspnea, cough, and digital clubbing"
"Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is initially seen on CT in subpleural patches"
"Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis eventually results in diffuse fibrosis with end-stage 'honeycomb' lung on CT"
"What is the treatment for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis? Lung transplant"
"Pneumoconioses are a subset of restrictive lung diseases characterized by interstitial fibrosis due to occupational exposure"
"Pneumoconioses requires chronic exposure to small particles that are fibrogenic"
"Pneumoconioses are due to release of fibrogenic factors from alveolar macrophages that have engulfed foreign, fibrogenic particles"
"Coal workers' pneumoconiosis results from prolonged coal (carbon) dust exposure"
"Coal workers' pneumoconiosis is also known as \black lung disease\\"\""
"Mild exposure to carbon (e.g. pollution) results in anthracosis, which is an asymptomatic condition characterized by collections of carbon-laden macrophages"
"Coal workers' pneumoconiosis most commonly affects the upper lobes of the lung"
"Coal workers' pneumoconiosis is characterized by macrophages laden with carbon, causing inflammation and fibrosis"
"Silicosis is a pneumoconiosis that results from prolonged silica exposure"
"Silicosis is seen in sandblasters, silica miners, and foundries"
"Silica may impair macrophages and disrupt phagolysosome formation, increasing susceptibility to TB"
"What pneumoconiosis has an increased risk for TB? Silicosis"
"Silicosis presents with fibrotic nodules in the upper lobes of the lung"
"Silicosis may present with \eggshell\\" calcification of the hilar lymph nodes\""
"Berylliosis results from prolonged beryllium exposure"
"Berylliosis is a pneumoconiosis that is seen in miners and workers in the aerospace and electronic manufacturing industries"
"Berylliosis most commonly affects the upper lobes of the lung"
"Berylliosis is characterized by a(n) granulomatous histology and therefore is occasionally responsive to treatment with steroids"
"Berylliosis is a pneumoconiosis that presents with noncaseating granulomas in the lung, hilar lymph nodes, and systemic organs"
"Berylliosis increases risk for lung cancer"
"Asbestosis results from prolonged exposure to asbestos fibers"
"Asbestosis is commonly seen in construction workers, shipyard workers, and plumbers"
"Which is more common in individuals exposed to asbestos: lung (bronchogenic) carcinoma or mesothelioma? Lung carcinoma"
"Asbestosis presents with \Ivory white\\""
"Asbestosis lesions may contain Asbestos (ferruginous) bodies, which are golden-brown fusiform rods resembling dumbbells"
"Asbestos bodies may be found in an alveolar septum sputum sample, often obtained by bronchoalveolar lavage"
"Asbestos bodies contain iron and thus may be visualized using a(n) Prussian blue stain"
"Asbestosis most commonly affects the lower lobes of the lung"
"Caplan syndrome is a combination of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis with intrapulmonary nodules"
"Sarcoidosis is a systemic disease characterized by widespread noncaseating granulomas"
"What demographic is associated with sarcoidosis? African American females"
"Granulomas due to sarcoidosis often have characteristic stellate-shaped inclusions ('asteroid bodies') within giant cells"
"Granulomas due to sarcoidosis may have Schaumann bodies, which are calcium and protein inclusions inside of giant cells"
"Granulomas due to sarcoidosis most commonly involve the hilar lymph nodes and the lung, leading to restrictive lung disease"
"What eye pathology is associated with sarcoidosis? Uveitis"
"What skin pathologies are associated with sarcoidosis? Cutaneous nodules, Erythema nodosum, Lupus Pernio"
"Sarcoidosis is associated with lupus pernio, which are skin lesions on the face resembling lupus"
"Sarcoidosis may involve the salivary and lacrimal glands, which mimics Sjögren's syndrome"
"Sarcoidosis is associated with Bell palsy, a type of facial paralysis"
"Sarcoidosis is associated with hypercalcemia due to increased 1α-hydroxylase activity in epithelioid histiocytes"
"Sarcoidosis is associated with elevated serum levels of the enzyme angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE)::lung"
"What is the treatment for sarcoidosis? Steroids (if symptomatic)"
"What are the most common presenting symptoms of pulmonary sarcoidosis? Dyspnea, Cough::2"
"Sarcoidosis is associated with elevated CD4+/CD8+ ratio in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid"
"Sarcoidosis is often asymptomatic except for enlarged lymph nodes"
"Sarcoidosis may be visualized on CXR as bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and coarse reticular opacities"
"Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an autoimmune reaction that generates granulomas in response to inhaled organic antigens (e.g. pigeon breeders lung)"
"Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a mixed type III/IV hypersensitivity reaction"
"Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is often seen in farmers and those exposed to birds"
"Hypersensitivity pneumonitis presents with fever, cough, and dyspnea hours after exposure; resolves with removal of exposure"
"Hypersensitivity pneumonitis can lead to interstitial fibrosis and restrictive lung disease with chronic exposure to the inhaled antigen"
"Which dyslipidemia drug is associated with hyperglycemia and hyperuricemia as possible adverse effects? Niacin"
"Verapamil::Drug is a Ca2+ channel blocker that may cause hyper-prolactinemia as an adverse effect"
"The normal mean pulmonary artery pressure is between 10 and 14 mmHg"
"Pulmonary hypertension is defined as a mean pulmonary artery pressure > 25 at rest"
"Pulmonary hypertension is characterized by atherosclerosis of the pulmonary trunk"
"Pulmonary hypertension is characterized by smooth muscle (medial) hypertrophy of pulmonary arteries"
"Pulmonary hypertension is characterized by intimal fibrosis of pulmonary arteries"
"Plexiform lesions are small, vascular channels that may be seen with severe, long standing pulmonary hypertension"
"Pulmonary hypertension leads to RV hypertrophy with eventual cor pulmonale"
"Pulmonary hypertension may present with exertional dyspnea and right-sided heart failure"
"What demographic is classically associated with primary pulmonary hypertension? Young adult females"
"Heritable pulmonary hypertension can be due to inactivating mutations of the BMPR2 gene"
"The BMPR2 gene normally inhibits vascular smooth muscle proliferation"
"What is the prognosis of heritable pulmonary hypertension? Poor prognosis"
"2nd pulm htn from Lung Disease is due to: (1) dmg/ inflammation to parenchyma (COPD / Interstitial lung disease) (2) hypoxic pulm vasoconstriction (OSA / high altitude)"
"Secondary pulmonary hypertension due to Heart Disease may arise due to increased volume in the pulmonary circuit (e.g. left heart failure, congenital heart disease)"
"Secondary pulmonary hypertension due to Chronic Thromboemboli may arise with recurrent pulmonary embolism or microthrombi"
"Another type of secondary pulmonary hypertension may arise due to multifactorial causes, such as hematologic, systemic, and metabolic disorders"
"Acute (aka Adult) respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is caused by diffuse alveolar damage with impairment of the alveolar-capillary interface"
"Damage to the alveolar-capillary interface leads to increased alveolar-capillary permeability"
"In ARDS, leakage of protein-rich fluid leads to noncardiogenic pulmonary edema (normal PCWP)"
"In ARDS, leakage of protein-rich fluid leads to formation of intra-alveolar hyaline membranes"
"Clinical features of ARDS include hypoxemia and cyanosis with respiratory distress due to a(n) thickened diffusion barrier"
"Clinical features of ARDS include hypoxemia and cyanosis with respiratory distress due to collapse of air sacs"
"Acute respiratory distress syndrome presents with a \white-out\\" appearance on CXR\""
"Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a clinical syndrome characterized by acute onset respiratory failure with bilateral lung opacities and no evidence of HF/fluid overload"
"ARDS is a diagnosis of exclusion with the following criteria (ARDS) - Abnormal chest x-ray - Respiratory failure within 1 week of insult - Decreased Pao2 / FIO2 ratio - Symptoms of respiratory failure are not due to HF/fluid overload"
"The causes of acute respiratory distress syndrome may be remembered with \SPARTAS\\" S: Sepsis P: Pancreatitis"
"In ARDS, activation of neutrophils by proinflammatory cytokines induces free radical and protease-mediated damage of both type I and II pneumocytes"
"Treatment of ARDS includes addressing the underlying cause"
"Treatment of ARDS includes mechanical ventilation with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) and most importantly low tidal volumes"
"Recovery of ARDS may be complicated by interstitial fibrosis/scarring due to loss of type II pneumocytes"
"Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is respiratory distress due to inadequate surfactant (not oxygen) levels"
"Surfactant decreases surface tension in the lung, preventing collapse of alveolar air sacs after expiration"
"Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is associated with premature birth"
"The lecithin:sphingomyelin ratio in amniotic fluid is used to screen for lung maturity"
"As surfactant production is increased (fetal lung maturation), lecithin levels increase, while sphingomyelin levels remain constant"
"What lecithin:sphingomyelin ratio is indicative of adequate surfactant production? > 2"
"What lecithin:sphingomyelin ratio is predictive of NRDS? < 1.5"
"Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is associated with maternal diabetes due to increased levels of fetal insulin"
"What is the effect of increased fetal insulin on surfactant production? Decreased surfactant production"
"NRDS presents with increased respiratory effort after birth"
"NRDS may present with tachypnea (respiratory rate) with use of accessory muscles and grunting"
"NRDS increases risk for persistence of a(n) patent ductus arteriosus due to persistently low O2 tension (hypoxemia)"
"In patients with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, supplemental O2 therapy increases the risk for free radical injury"
"Retinopathy of prematurity is an eye complication associated with supplemental O2 therapy in NRDS patients (due to neovascularization)"
"Bronchopulmonary dysplasia is a respiratory complication associated with supplemental O2 therapy in NRDS patients"
"Intraventricular hemorrhage is a CNS complication associated with supplemental O2 therapy in NRDS patients"
"What treatment may be used to treat neonatal respiratory distress syndrome before birth? Maternal steroids"
"What treatment may be used to treat neonatal respiratory distress syndrome after birth? Artificial surfactant for the infant"
"One test for fetal lung maturity is the surfactant:albumin ratio in the amniotic fluid"
"One test for fetal lung maturity is the foam stability index test"
"Lung cancer is the most common cause of cancer mortality in the U.S."
"The average age of presentation for lung cancer is 60 years old"
"The key risk factors for lung cancer are cigarette smoke, radon::not arsenic, and asbestos; family history is also a risk factor"
"Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons::main and arsenic are particularly mutagenic carcinogens found in cigarette smoke"
"Lung cancer risk is directly related to the duration and the amount of smoking, which is measured in 'pack-years'"
"Radon is formed by radioactive decay of uranium, which is present in soil"
"Radon accumulates in closed spaces, such as basements"
"Radon is responsible for most of the public exposure to ionizing radiation"
"Radon exposure is the 2nd most frequent cause of lung carcinoma in the U.S."
"Increased risk of lung cancer is seen in uranium miners, due to increased exposure to radon"
"Presenting symptoms of lung cancer are non-specific and include cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, and post-obstructive pneumonia"
"Lung cancer often presents on CXR with a \coin-lesion\\" or on CT with a non-calcified nodule\""
"One benign cause of a 'coin-lesion' on CXR is granuloma (e.g.TB or fungus)"
"One benign cause of a 'coin-lesion' on CXR is bronchial hamartoma, which is benign tumor of lung tissue and cartilage"
"Lung carcinoma is classically divided into two categories: small cell carcinoma (15%) and non-small cell carcinoma (85%)"
"Small cell carcinoma of the lung is usually not amenable to surgical resection and is thus treated with chemotherapy +/- radiation"
"Non-small cell carcinomas of the lung usually do not respond well to chemotherapy and are thus treated upfront with surgical resection"
"Small (oat) cell lung carcinoma arises from neuroendocrine (Kulchitsky)::general (specific name) cells, which are small, dark blue cells"
"What demographic is associated with small (oat) cell carcinoma? Male smokers"
"Small (oat) cell carcinoma is centrally located"
"Small cell carcinoma is characterized histologically by poorly differentiated small cells and is thus very aggressive"
"Small (oat) cell lung carcinoma may produce the anterior pituitary hormone ACTH leading to Cushing syndrome"
"Small (oat) cell lung carcinoma may produce the posterior pituitary hormone ADH leading to SIADH"
"Small (oat) cell lung carcinoma may produce antibodies against presynaptic Ca2+ channels, causing Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome"
"Small (oat) cell lung carcinoma may produce antibodies against neurons, which may cause paraneoplastic myelitis, encephalitis, and subacute cerebellar degeneration"
"Small (oat) cell carcinoma is commonly associated with amplification of the myc oncogene"
"Small (oat) cell carcinoma of the lung is characterized by positive staining for chromogranin A, neuron-specific enolase, synaptophysin, and NCAM (CD56)"
"Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is centrally located"
"Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is characterized histologically by keratin pearls and intercellular bridges"
"Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is the most common tumor in male smokers"
"Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung may produce PTHrP leading to hyper-calcemia"
"Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung commonly presents as a hilar mass arising from the bronchus"
"Adenocarcinoma of the lung is peripherally located"
"Adenocarcinoma of the lung is characterized histologically by a(n) glandular pattern that often stains positive for mucin"
"Adenocarcinoma of the lung is the most common cancer in nonsmokers and female smokers"
"Adenocarcinoma of the lung is associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy (clubbing)"
"Adenocarcinoma of the lung is associated with activating mutations in the KRAS, EGFR, and ALK genes"
"Large cell carcinoma is characterized histologically by poorly differentiated large cells"
"Large cell carcinoma of the lung may present histologically with pleomorphic giant cells"
"Large cell carcinoma of the lung may secrete the hormone β-hCG"
"Is large cell carcinoma related to smoking? Yes"
"Large cell carcinoma of the lung is peripherally located"
"What is the prognosis of large cell carcinoma? Poor"
"Adenocarcinoma in situ is characterized histologically by columnar::shape cells containing mucus that grow along pre-existing bronchioles and alveoli"
"Adenocarcinoma in situ is a subtype of adenocarcinoma that typically arises from club (Clara) cells"
"Is bronchioloalveolar carcinoma related to smoking? No"
"In regards to lung neoplasias; adenocarcinoma in situ is peripherally located"
"Adenocarcinoma in situ of the lung presents similarly to pneumonia on CXR (hazy infiltrates, consolidation)"
"What is the prognosis of bronchioloalveolar carcinoma? Excellent"
"Bronchial carcinoid tumor is characterized histologically by nests of well differentiated neuroendocrine cells"
"Bronchial carcinoid tumor is characterized by positive staining for chromogranin A"
"Is bronchial carcinoid tumor related to smoking? No"
"What is the prognosis of bronchial carcinoid tumor? Excellent (low-grade malignancy; rarely metastasizes)"
"Bronchial carcinoid tumor classically forms a polyp-like mass in the bronchus"
"Symptoms of bronchial carcinoid tumor are related to mass effect or carcinoid syndrome"
"What does the T of TNM staging for lung cancer represent? Tumor size and local extension"
"What does the N of TNM staging for lung cancer represent? Spread to regional lymph nodes (hilar and mediastinal)"
"What does the M of TNM staging for lung cancer represent? Metastasis"
"The adrenal gland is a unique site of distant metastasis from lung cancer"
"Lung cancer has a(n) low 5-year survival rate because the disease often presents late in its course"
"Which is more common, primary lung tumors or metastasis to the lung? Metastasis"
"Metastasis to the lung usually presents as multiple 'cannon ball' nodules on imaging"
"Does metastasis to the lung typically present as single or multiple lesions? Multiple"
"Metastasis to the lung is most often from breast, colon, prostate, and bladder cancer"
"Common sites of metastasis from lung cancer include the adrenal gland, brain, bone, and liver"
"Lung cancer is the most common cause of metastasis to the brain"
"One complication associated with lung cancer is pleural effusion, which is classically seen with adenocarcinoma"
"Superior sulcus tumor (pancoast tumor) is any kind of lung carcinoma that occurs in the apex of the lung"
"Pancoast tumors may cause Pancoast syndrome, which is characterized by shoulder pain, Horner syndrome, atrophy of hand/arm muscles, and edema (due to vascular compression)"
"One complication associated with lung cancer is hoarseness due to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve"
"One complication associated with lung cancer is diaphragmatic paralysis due to compression of the phrenic nerve"
"One complication associated with lung cancer is superior vena cava syndrome due to compression of the SVC"
"One complication associated with lung cancer is Horner syndrome due to compression of the superior cervical or stellate ganglia"
"Horner syndrome is a triad of ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis"
"SVC syndrome is characterized by impaired drainage of the upper extremities, resulting in edema and dilated collateral veins in the upper torso"
"SVC syndrome is characterized by impaired drainage of the head, resulting in \facial plethora\\"\""
"SVC syndrome is characterized by impaired drainage of the neck, resulting in jugular venous distention"
"SVC syndrome can be caused by thromboemboli from indwelling central venous catheters"
"SVC syndrome can raise intracranial pressure (if obstruction is severe), leading to headaches and dizziness"
"Pneumothorax is defined as the accumulation of air in the pleural space"
"Pneumothorax presents with unilateral::uni- or bilateral chest pain and expansion, as well as dyspnea"
"Pneumothorax presents with decreased tactile fremitus on the affected side"
"Pneumothorax presents with hyper-resonance on the affected side"
"Pneumothorax presents with diminished breath sounds on the affected side"
"Primary spontaneous pneumothorax is due to rupture of apical subpleural blebs or cysts"
"What demographic is associated with primary spontaneous pneumothorax? Tall, thin, young males"
"Secondary spontaneous pneumothorax may be due to diseased lung (e.g. bullae in emphysema, infections) or meconium aspiration"
"Traumatic pneumothorax may be due to iatrogenic causes, such as bronchoscopy, subclavian line placement, thoracentesis, barotrauma"
"In tension pneumothorax, the trachea +/- mediastinum shifts away from the side of collapse"
"Traumatic pneumothorax is caused by blunt or penetrating trauma"
"Tension pneumothorax arises when air enters the pleural space but cannot exit"
"Tension pneumothorax needs immediate needle decompression and chest tube placement"
"Mesothelioma is a malignancy of the lung pleura that is highly associated with asbestosis"
"Mesothelioma presents with recurrent pleural effusions, dyspnea, and chest pain"
"Mesothelioma may result in hemorrhagic pleural effusion (exudative) and pleural thickening"
"What histological finding may be associated with mesothelioma? Psammoma bodies"
"Almost all mesotheliomas are calretinin positive, which is negative in most carcinomas"
"Is smoking a risk factor for mesothelioma? No"
"Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of primary lung carcinoma (40%)"
"Primary hemostasis forms a weak platelet plug"
"Primary hemostasis is mediated by interactions between platelets and the vessel wall"
"Secondary hemostasis stabilizes the platelet plug"
"Secondary hemostasis is mediated by the coagulation cascade"
"The first step of primary hemostasis is transient vasoconstriction of the damaged vessel; which is mediated by reflex neural stimulation and endothelin-1 release from endothelial cells"
"Aggregation is a balance between pro and anti-aggregation factors: Pro-aggregation - TXA2 - released by platelets Anti-aggregation - PGI2 and NO - released by endothelial cells"
"Is the plug formed by primary hemostasis stable? No"
"Following transient vasoconstriction (primary hemostasis), there is platelet adhesion to the surface of the disrupted vessel"
"When a blood vessel is injured, von Willebrand factor (vWF) binds exposed subendothelial collagen"
"In order to adhere to the damaged endothelium, platelets bind vWF using the GPIb receptor"
"One source of von Willebrand factor (vWF) is from the Weibel-Palade bodies of endothelial cells"
"One source of von Willebrand factor (vWF) is from the α granules of platelets"
"Following platelet adhesion (primary hemostasis), there is platelet degranulation::not aggregation"
"Binding of ADP to the P2Y12 receptor in primary hemostasis causes shape change by upregulating intracellular Ca2+, promoting effective platelet plug formation"
"Binding of ADP to the P2Y12 receptor promotes optimal exposure of the GPIIb/IIIa receptor on platelets"
"Binding of ADP to the P2Y12 receptor leads to decreased cAMP formation which favors platelet activation"
"What ion is released from dense granules of platelets during degranulation? Ca2+"
"Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is synthesized by the platelet enzyme cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1)::specific"
"Thromboxane A2 promotes platelet aggregation"
"Following upregulation of GpIIb/IIIa, platelets aggregate at the site of injury via crosslinking of GpIIb/IIIa receptors with fibrinogen to make a temporary platelet plug"
"Aggregation is a balance between pro and anti-aggregation factors: Pro-aggregation - decreased blood flow Anti-aggregation - increased blood flow"
"Binding between GPIIb/IIIa and fibrinogen results in formation of a(n) weak platelet plug"
"Disorders of primary hemostasis are divided into qualitative and quantitative disorders"
"Disorders of primary hemostasis present with symptoms of mucosal and skin bleeding"
"Disorders of primary hemostasis present with symptoms of mucosal bleeding, such as epistaxis (most common overall symptom)"
"A feared complication of severe thrombocytopenia is intracranial bleeding"
"Quantitative disorders of primary hemostasis present with symptoms of skin bleeding, such as petechiae (1-2 mm)"
"Disorders of primary hemostasis present with symptoms of skin bleeding, such as purpura (> 3 mm)"
"Disorders of primary hemostasis present with symptoms of skin bleeding, such as ecchymoses (> 1 cm)"
"Disorders of primary hemostasis present with symptoms of skin bleeding, such as easy bruising"
"Petechiae are a sign of thrombocytopenia and are not usually seen with qualitative platelet disorders"
"Platelet counts < 50K/μL lead to symptoms"
"Normal platelet counts are between 150K and 400K/μL"
"Bleeding time is normally between 2 and 7 minutes"
"Bleeding time is prolonged in all platelet disorders (both quantitative and qualitative)"
"Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is due to autoimmune production of IgG against GPIIb/IIIa"
"Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia in children and adults"
"The autoantibodies in ITP are produced by plasma cells in the spleen"
"The antibody-bound platelets in ITP are consumed by splenic macrophages, resulting in thrombocytopenia"
"Immune thrombocytopenic purpura commonly follows viral infection"
"The acute form of ITP commonly arises in children::age group weeks after a viral infection or immunization"
"The acute form of ITP is typically self-limited, usually resolving within weeks of presentation"
"What demographic is associated with the chronic form of immune thrombocytopenic purpura? Women of childbearing age"
"Maternal ITP may cause short-lived thrombocytopenia in offspring since anti-platelet IgG can cross the placenta"
"Immune thrombocytopenic purpura presents with increased bleeding time / PFA"
"Immune thrombocytopenic purpura presents with decreased platelet count"
"Immune thrombocytopenic purpura presents with normal PT and normal PTT"
"Immune thrombocytopenic purpura presents with increased megakaryocytes on bone marrow biopsy"
"The initial treatment for immune thrombocytopenic purpura is corticosteroids"
"What is used to transiently raise the platelet count due to symptomatic bleeding in immune thrombocytopenic purpura? IVIG"
"The treatment for refractory cases of ITP is splenectomy"
"Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia occurs when RBCs are \sheared\\" as they cross microthrombi\""
"Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is often associated with formation of platelet microthrombi in small vessels"
"Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is seen in TTP, HUS, and HELLP syndrome"
"What type of red blood cell is associated with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia? Schistocytes (\helmet cells\\")\""
"Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is due to inhibition or deficiency of the ADAMTS13 (vWF metalloprotease) enzyme"
"ADAMTS13 (vWF metalloprotease) is an enzyme that normally cleaves vWF multimers into smaller monomers for eventual degradation"
"In TTP, large, uncleaved vWF multimers lead to increased platelet adhesion with consequent microthrombi formation"
"What demographic is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura? Adult females"
"Decreased ADAMTS13 (e.g. TTP) is usually due to an acquired autoantibody"
"The pentad of classical symptoms seen in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) may be remembered using the mnemonic FAT RN: F: Fever (1/5 patients) A*: Anemia (Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anemia) T*: Thrombocytopenia R: Renal symptoms (1/2 of patients)-More common in HUS N: Neurologic symptoms (2/3 of patients)-More common in TTP"
"Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is associated with elevated serum LDH"
"What is the treatment (3) for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)? plasmapheresis, corticosteroids, rituximab"
"Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is characterized by thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and acute renal failure"
"Hemolytic uremic syndrome is classically seen in children with E. coli O157:H7 dysentery, which results from exposure to undercooked beef"
"In children, typical HUS symptoms are accompanied by diarrhea due to infection with E. coli"
"Does HUS in adults typically present with diarrhea? No (E. coli infection not required in adults)"
"The E. coli O157:H7 vero-toxin damages endothelial cells, resulting in platelet microthrombi (e.g. HUS)"
"TTP and HUS present with increased bleeding time"
"TTP and HUS present with decreased platelet count"
"TTP and HUS typically present with normal PT and normal PTT"
"The initial treatment for hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is plasmapheresis"
"Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a qualitative platelet disorder due to a genetic GPIb deficiency"
