"Bernard-Soulier syndrome is characterized by enlarged platelets on blood smear"
"In Bernard-Soulier syndrome there is a defect in platelet adhesion"
"Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a qualitative platelet disorder due to a genetic GPIIb/IIIa deficiency"
"In Glanzmann thrombasthenia there is a defect in platelet aggregation"
"Glanzmann thrombasthenia is characterized by no platelet clumping on blood smear"
"Bernard-Soulier syndrome presents with increased bleeding time"
"Bernard-Soulier syndrome presents with normal or decreased platelet count"
"Glanzmann thrombasthenia presents with increased bleeding time"
"Glanzmann thrombasthenia presents with normal platelet count"
"Aspirin irreversibly inactivates the enzyme cyclooxygenase, thus decreasing synthesis of TXA2 and impairing platelet aggregation"
"The coagulation cascade generates thrombin (factor IIa), which converts fibrinogen in the platelet plug to fibrin (factor Ia) *BnB expansion: which 4 factors does this activate (positive feedback)?"
"After fibrin is formed from fibrinogen, it is cross-linked by factor XIII yielding a stable platelet-fibrin thrombus"
"Factors of the coagulation cascade are produced by the liver in an inactive state"
"Activation of the coagulation cascade requires the phospholipid surface of platelets"
"Activation of the coagulation cascade requires Ca2+ ions derived from platelet dense granules"
"Disorders of secondary hemostasis typically present with deep tissue::location bleeding"
"Disorders of secondary hemostasis typically present with re-bleeding after surgical procedures (e.g. dental procedures)"
"Prothrombin time (PT) measures the extrinsic and common pathways of the coagulation cascade"
"Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) measures the intrinsic and common pathways of the coagulation cascade"
"International normalized ratio (INR) is calculated from PT::PT or PTT"
"Which test is used to follow the effects of heparin? PTT::PT or PTT"
"Which test is used to follow the effects of warfarin (coumadin)? PT (via INR), but both are increased::PT or PTT"
"Which coagulation factor(s) are part of the extrinsic coagulation cascade? Factor VII"
"Which coagulation factor(s) are part of the intrinsic coagulation cascade? Factor 8, 9, 11, 12"
"Which coagulation factor(s) are part of the common coagulation cascade? Factor 10, 5, 2 (thrombin), 1 (fibrinogen)"
"Factor XI of the coagulation cascade is activated by factor XIIa"
"Factor IX of the coagulation cascade is activated by factor XIa"
"Factor X of the coagulation cascade may be activated by factor VIIa (extrinsic pathway)"
"Factor V of the coagulation cascade is activated by factor IIa"
"Factor II (prothrombin) is activated to thrombin by factor Xa"
"Tissue thromboplastin activates factor VII, which initiates the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade"
"Subendothelial collagen activates factor XII, which initiates the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade"
"Hemophilia A is a coagulation disorder due to a genetic factor VIII deficiency"
"What is the mode of inheritance of hemophilia A? X-linked recessive"
"Hemophilia A can arise from a(n) new (de novo) mutation without any family history (20%)"
"Which coagulation disorder presents with recurrent hemarthroses, spontaneous / easy bruising, and bleeding after surgery? Hemophilia (A, B, C)"
"Hemophilia B (Christmas disease) is a coagulation disorder due to a genetic factor IX deficiency"
"What is the mode of inheritance of hemophilia B? X-linked recessive"
"Hemophilia C is a coagulation disorder due to a genetic factor XI deficiency"
"What is the mode of inheritance of hemophilia C? Autosomal recessive"
"Treatment of hemophilia A involves desmopressin plus recombinant factor VIII"
"Hemophilia (A, B, C) presents with normal bleeding time"
"Hemophilia (A, B, C) presents with normal platelet count"
"Hemophilia (A, B, C) presents with normal PT and increased PTT"
"A coagulation factor inhibitor is a(n) acquired antibody against a coagulation factor, resulting in impaired factor function"
"What is the most common coagulation factor inhibitor? Anti-Factor VIII"
"In hemophilia A, mixing normal plasma with the patient's plasma (mixing study) does::does/doesn't correct the PTT"
"With a factor VIII coagulation factor inhibitor, mixing normal plasma with a patient's plasma doesn't::does/doesn't correct the PTT"
"Von Willebrand disease is characterized by a genetic vWF deficiency"
"What is the most common inherited bleeding/coagulation disorder? von Willebrand disease"
"What is the mode of inheritance of the most common subtype of von Willebrand disease? Autosomal dominant"
"The most common subtype of von Willebrand disease presents with decreased vWF levels"
"von Willebrand disease typically presents with mild mucosal::locations and skin bleeding"
"Low vWF in von Willebrand disease impairs platelet adhesion"
"von Willebrand disease presents with increased bleeding time"
"von Willebrand disease presents with normal platelet count"
"von Willebrand disease presents with normal PT and normal or increased PTT"
"Why may PTT be elevated in von Willebrand disease? Decreased factor VIII half-life (vWF normally stabilizes factor VIII)"
"von Willebrand disease is associated with an abnormal Ristocetin assay"
"Ristocetin induces platelet aggregation by causing vWF to bind platelet GPIb"
"What is the treatment for von Willebrand disease? Desmopressin"
"Desmopressin increases release of vWF from Weibel-Palade bodies"
"Vitamin K is activated by the enzyme epoxide reductase in the liver"
"Activated vitamin K acts as a co-factor for the enzyme γ-glutamyl carboxylase"
"Vitamin K is necessary for gamma carboxylation of factors II, VII, IX, X, and proteins C and S"
"Which coagulation factors have decreased activity due to vitamin K deficiency? 2, 7, 9, 10::4"
"What proteins have decreased activity due to vitamin K deficiency? Protein C and protein S::2"
"Vitamin K deficiency may occur in newborns due to lack of colonic bacteria that normally synthesize vitamin K"
"Vitamin K deficiency may occur due to long-term antibiotic therapy, which disrupts the gut flora"
"Vitamin K deficiency may occur due to fat malabsorption, which leads to deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins"
"Vitamin K deficiency presents with normal bleeding time"
"Vitamin K deficiency presents with increased PT and increased (in severe cases) PTT"
"Abnormal secondary hemostasis may occur due to liver failure, which causes decreased production of coagulation factors and decreased activation of vitamin K"
"Abnormal secondary hemostasis may occur due to liver failure, which causes decreased activation of vitamin K"
"The effects of liver failure on coagulation is followed using PT::PT or PTT"
"Abnormal secondary hemostasis may occur due to large-volume transfusion, which dilutes coagulation factors, resulting in a relative deficiency"
"Alpha granules of platelets contain vWF and fibrinogen"
"Dense granules of platelets contain Ca2+ and ADP"
"Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is a disorder that results in platelet activation secondary to heparin therapy"
"Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia occurs due to production of IgG antibodies against heparin-platelet factor IV complexes"
"The antibody-heparin-PF4 complex may activate platelets, leading to thrombosis and thrombocytopenia"
"Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) occurs due to pathologic activation of the coagulation cascade"
"Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is characterized by widespread microthrombi formation, resulting in ischemia and infarction"
"In disseminated intravascular coagulation, consumption of platelets and factors results in bleeding"
"DIC is associated with bleeding, especially from IV sites and mucosal surfaces"
"Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) is almost always secondary to another disease, which may be remembered with \STOP Making New Thrombi\\" S:Sepsis"
"Disseminated intravascular coagulation may occur secondary to obstetric complications due to activation of the coagulation cascade by tissue thromboplastin in the amniotic fluid"
"Disseminated intravascular coagulation may occur secondary to sepsis, especially gram negative bacteria"
"Disseminated intravascular coagulation may occur secondary to malignancy, such as adenocarcinoma, due to activation of the coagulation cascade by mucin"
"Disseminated intravascular coagulation may occur secondary to malignancy, such as acute promyelocytic leukemia, due to activation of the coagulation cascade by primary granules"
"DIC typically presents with increased PT and increased PTT"
"DIC typically presents with decreased platelet count"
"DIC typically presents with increased bleeding time"
"DIC typically presents with decreased fibrinogen"
"What type of red blood cell is associated with disseminated intravascular coagulation? Schistocytes (due to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia)"
"DIC typically presents with increased fibrin split products, particularly D-dimer"
"What is the best screening test for DIC? Elevated D-dimer"
"D-dimers are derived from splitting of cross-linked fibrin"
"Are D-dimers generated from the splitting of fibrinogen? No"
"DIC is associated with decreased factors V and VIII, which helps distinguish it from vitamin K deficiency"
"Treatment of DIC involves addressing the underlying cause"
"Treatment of DIC includes transfusion of blood products and cryoprecipitate as needed"
"Normal fibrinolysis::process removes a thrombus after a damaged vessel heals"
"In the first step of fibrinolysis, plasminogen is converted to plasmin via tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)"
"One role of plasmin is cleavage of fibrin and serum fibrinogen"
"One role of plasmin is destruction of coagulation factors"
"One role of plasmin is inhibition of platelet aggregation"
"Plasmin is inactivated by α2-antiplasmin, which is produced in the liver"
"Disorders of fibrinolysis are due to plasmin overactivity, resulting in excessive cleavage of serum fibrinogen"
"Over-activity of plasmin may occur due to activation by urokinase, which is released following radical prostatectomy"
"Over-activity of plasmin may occur due to reduced production of α2-antiplasmin by the liver (e.g. cirrhosis)"
"Disorders of fibrinolysis present with increased bleeding (resembles DIC)"
"Disorders of fibrinolysis typically present with increased PT and increased PTT"
"Disorders of fibrinolysis typically present with normal platelet count"
"Disorders of fibrinolysis typically present with increased bleeding time"
"Disorders of fibrinolysis typically present with decreased fibrinogen"
"Disorders of fibrinolysis typically present with increased fibrinogen split products"
"Do disorders of fibrinolysis present with elevated D-dimers? No"
"Treatment for disorders of fibrinolysis is aminocaproic acid, which blocks activation of plasminogen"
"Factor X of the coagulation cascade may be activated by factor IX with factor VIII as a cofactor (intrinsic pathway)"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction occurs in polyarteritis nodosa? Type III (immune-complex mediated)"
"Fibrates mildly increase the synthesis of HDL::lipoprotein via upregulation of PPAR-α"
"What is the next step if a coin-lesion is identified in a patient on CXR? Review previous CXRs and compare"
"What is the only metabolic pathway for generating ATP, anaerobically? Glycolysis"
"Where in the cell does glycolysis occur? Cytoplasm"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis? Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1)"
"Anaerobic glycolysis produces a net of 2 ATP per glucose molecule"
"Anaerobic glycolysis produces a net of 2 NADH per glucose molecule"
"Hexokinase is characterized by a(n) low Km relative to glucokinase"
"Hexokinase is characterized by a(n) low Vmax relative to glucokinase"
"Glucokinase is characterized by a(n) high Vmax relative to hexokinase"
"Is hexokinase activity induced by insulin? No"
"Is hexokinase activity inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate? Yes"
"Is glucokinase activity inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate? No"
"Is a hexokinase gene mutation associated with maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY)? No"
"Is a glucokinase gene mutation associated with maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY)? Yes"
"What is the purpose of phosphorylating a sugar (e.g. glucose to glucose-6-phosphate)? Prevent the sugar from leaving the cell"
"Glucose is converted to glucose-6-phosphate by the enzyme hexokinase in most tissues"
"Glucose is converted to glucose-6-phosphate by the enzyme glucokinase in the liver and β cells of the pancreas"
"Hexokinase is regulated via negative feedback by glucose-6-phosphate"
"Glucokinase is regulated via negative feedback by fructose-6-phosphate"
"Glucokinase is regulated via positive feedback by insulin"
"Glucose-6-phosphate is converted to fructose-6-phosphate via the enzyme isomerase"
"Fructose-6-phosphate is converted to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate via the enzyme phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1)"
"Phosphofructokinase-1 is regulated via negative feedback by ATP and citrate"
"Phosphofructosekinase-1 is regulated via positive feedback by AMP and fructose-2,6-bisphospate"
"Fructose-6-phosphate is converted to fructose-2,6-bisphosphate via the enzyme phosphofructokinase-2 (PFK-2)"
"Which organs contains the enzyme phosphofructokinase-2? Liver, Kidney, Heart::3"
"Phosphofructokinase-2 is regulated via positive feedback by insulin"
"Phosphofructokinase-2 is regulated via negative feedback by glucagon"
"Fructose bisphosphatase-2 and phosphofructokinase-2 are the same bifunctional enzyme whose function is reversed by phosphorylation by protein kinase A"
"Increased glucagon (fasting) leads to increased cAMP and protein kinase A, thus increasing activity of FBPase-2 and decreasing activity of PFK-2"
"Increased phosphofructokinase-2 stimulates glycolysis and inhibits gluconeogenesis"
"Which steps of glycolysis require ATP? ::2"
"Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate is converted into glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and dihydroxyacetone-phosphate via the enzyme aldolase"
"Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate is converted into 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate (1,3-BPG) via the enzyme glyceraldehyde-3P-dehydrogenase (glycolysis)"
"Conversion of glyceraldehyde-3P into 1,3-BPG (glycolysis) produces a molecule of NADH"
"1,3-bisphosphoglycerate is converted into 3-phosphoglycerate via the enzyme phosphoglycerate kinase"
"Conversion of 1,3-BPG into 3-phosphoglycerate (glycolysis) produces a molecule of ATP"
"1,3-bisphosphoglycerate may be converted to 2,3-BPG via the enzyme bisphosphoglycerate mutase in red blood cells"
"3-phosphoglycerate is converted into 2-phosphoglycerate via the enzyme mutase"
"2-phosphoglycerate is converted into phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) via the enzyme enolase"
"Phosphoenolpyruvate is converted into pyruvate via the enzyme pyruvate kinase"
"Conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate into pyruvate (glycolysis) produces a molecule of ATP"
"Pyruvate kinase is regulated via negative feedback by ATP and alanine"
"Pyruvate kinase is regulated via positive feedback by fructose-1,6-bisphosphate (glycolysis)"
"Which steps of glycolysis produce ATP? ::2"
"Which glycolysis enzyme deficiency is the second most common cause of hemolytic anemia? Pyruvate kinase deficiency"
"Pyruvate kinase deficiency presents with increased levels of 2,3-BPG"
"Pyruvate kinase deficiency presents as hemolytic anemia without::with or without Heinz bodies"
"In red blood cells, lack of ATP impairs membrane integrity due to lack of cation transport, causing a(n) extravascular hemolytic anemia"
"In red blood cells, lack of NADH impairs the ability to reduce Fe3+ to Fe2+, predisposing to methemoglobinemia"
"Effect of diabetes on hepatic glycolysis: no answer :) - No PFK-2 due to lack of insulin - No glucose trapping in liver leads to elevated blood glucose (hyperglycemia)"
"Which two organs does galactose primarily enter? Liver, Brain"
"Lactose is converted into galactose and glucose by the enzyme lactase (intestinal brush border)"
"Lactase deficiency may present with diarrhea due to the osmotic effects of undigested lactose"
"Lactase deficiency may present with flatulence and bloating due to anaerobic fermentation of undigested lactose"
"Primary lactase deficiency is characterized by a(n) age-dependent decline in lactose tolerance after childhood"
"Primary lactase deficiency occurs due to absence of the lactase-persistence allele"
"Primary lactase deficiency is common in people of Asian, African, and Native-American descent"
"Secondary lactase deficiency occurs due to loss of the intestinal brush border"
"Congenital primary lactase deficiency is rare::frequency; due to a defective gene"
"Lactase deficiency is characterized by a(n) decreased stool pH"
"Lactase deficiency is characterized by increased hydrogen content with a lactose hydrogen breath test"
"In patients with hereditary lactose intolerance, intestinal biopsy reveals normal mucosa"
"Galactose is converted to galactose-1-phosphate via the enzyme galactokinase"
"Conversion of galactose into galactose-1-phosphate requires a molecule of ATP"
"What eye pathology is associated with galactokinase deficiency? Cataracts"
"What is the inheritance of galactokinase deficiency? Autosomal recessive"
"How soon after birth do symptoms of galactose metabolism disorders present? When feeding begins (lactose is in both breast milk and routine formula)"
"Galactokinase deficiency may present as failure to track objects or failure to develop a(n) social smile"
"Compared to classic galactosemia, galactokinase deficiency is a relatively mild::severity condition"
"Galactose-1-phosphate is ultimately converted to glucose-1-phosphate via the enzyme Gal 1-P uridyltransferase"
"Classic galactosemia is characterized by the absence of the Gal-1-P uridyltransferase enzyme"
"What is the inheritance of classic galactosemia? Autosomal recessive"
"Classic galactosemia causes liver damage and renal damage, which manifests as jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a metabolic acidosis"
"Classic galactosemia causes brain damage, which manifests as intellectual disability"
"Classic galactosemia may lead to E. coli sepsis in neonates"
"Galactose is converted to galactitol via the enzyme aldose reductase"
"Disorders of galactose metabolism may present with cataracts due to accumulation of galactitol in the lens"
"The more serious defects in galactose and fructose metabolism may lead to phosphate (PO43-) depletion"
"Glucose is converted to sorbitol via the enzyme aldose reductase"
"Sorbitol is converted to fructose via the enzyme sorbitol dehydrogenase"
"The tissues/organs that have only aldose reductase (no sorbitol dehydrogenase) may be remembered with the mnemonic \LuRKS\\": L: Lens (primarily aldose reductase) u R: Retina K: Kidneys S: Schwann cells\""
"Sucrose is converted into fructose and glucose by the enzyme sucrase"
"Fructose is converted into fructose-1-phosphate by the enzyme fructokinase"
"Conversion of fructose into fructose-1-phosphate requires a molecule of ATP"
"Essential fructosuria is characterized by a defect in the fructokinase enzyme"
"What is the inheritance of essential fructosuria? Autosomal recessive"
"What symptoms does essential fructosuria typically present with? Asymptomatic; fructose appears in blood and urine"
"How soon after birth do symptoms of fructose metabolism disorders present? Months after; when feeding ends (sucrose/fructose is not found in breast milk)"
"Compared to disorders of galactose metabolism, disorders of fructose metabolism are more mild::severity"
"Fructose-1-phosphate is converted to glyceraldehyde and dihydroxyacetone-P via the enzyme aldolase B *primarily in the liver"
"Hereditary fructose intolerance is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B"
"What is the inheritance of hereditary fructose intolerance? Autosomal recessive"
"In hereditary fructose intolerance, fructose-1-P accumulates, causing a decrease in available phosphate"
"In hereditary fructose intolerance, decreased available phosphate leads to inhibition of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis"
"What foods are a natural source of fructose? Fruits, Honey::2"
"Hereditary fructose intolerance presents with a(n) negative urine dipstick (positive or negative)"
"In hereditary fructose intolerance, reducing sugars can be detected in the urine"
"Hereditary fructose intolerance may present with hypoglycemia::blood sugar levels"
"Hereditary fructose intolerance may cause liver damage, which manifests as jaundice and cirrhosis"
"Which two organs does fructose primarily enter? Liver, Kidney"
"Compared to fructose intolerance, essential fructosuria is a relatively mild::severity condition"
"Why don't disorders of fructose metabolism present with increased risk for cataracts? fructose isn't reduced by aldose reductase"
"What substrate overrides inhibition of the enzyme phosphofructokinase-1 by ATP in the liver? Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate"
"What carbohydrate metabolism enzyme deficiency may present with failure to track objects or develop a social smile? Galactokinase deficiency"
"The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a mitochondrial enzyme complex linking glycolysis and the TCA cycle"
"Pyruvate is converted to acetyl CoA by the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase"
"Conversion of pyruvate into acetyl CoA releases a molecule of CO2 and NADH"
"Pyruvate dehydrogenase is regulated via negative feedback by ATP, NADH, and acetyl-CoA"
"Pyruvate dehydrogenase is regulated via positive feedback by ADP, Ca2+, and increased NAD+/NADH ratio"
"Pyruvate dehydrogenase requires five enzymes/cofactors: 1. Thiamine pyrophosphate (B1) 2. Lipoic acid 3. Coenzyme A (B5, pantothenic acid) 4. FAD (B2, riboflavin) 5. NAD (B3, niacin)"
"Acetyl-CoA is combined with oxaloacetate via the enzyme citrate synthase, forming citrate"
"Citrate synthase is regulated via negative feedback by ATP"
"Citrate is converted into isocitrate via the enzyme cis-Aconitase (Kreb's cycle)"
"Isocitrate is converted to α-ketoglutarate via the enzyme isocitrate dehydrogenase"
"Conversion of isocitrate into α-ketoglutarate releases a molecule of CO2 and NADH"
"Isocitrate dehydrogenase is regulated via negative feedback by ATP and NADH"
"Isocitrate dehydrogenase is regulated via positive feedback by ADP"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme for the Krebs cycle (TCA cycle)? Isocitrate dehydrogenase"
"α-ketoglutarate is converted to succinyl CoA via the enzyme α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase"
"Conversion of α-ketoglutarate into succinyl CoA releases a molecule of CO2 and NADH"
"α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase is regulated via negative feedback by succinyl-CoA, ATP, and NADH"
"Succinyl CoA is converted to succinate via the enzyme succinyl CoA synthetase"
"Conversion of succinyl CoA into succinate produces a molecule of GTP"
"Which step of the Krebs cycle directly produces a molecule of GTP? Succinyl CoA --> Succinate"
"Succinate is converted to fumarate via the enzyme succinate dehydrogenase"
"Conversion of succinate into fumarate produces a molecule of FADH2"
"Fumarate is converted to malate via the enzyme fumarase"
"Malate is converted to oxaloacetate via the enzyme malate dehydrogenase"
"Conversion of malate into oxaloacetate produces a molecule of NADH"
"Which Krebs cycle enzyme requires the same 5 cofactors as pyruvate dehydrogenase (TLCFN)? α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase"
"Where in the cell does the Krebs cycle take place? Mitochondria"
"In total, the TCA cycle produces 3 NADH per acetyl-CoA"
"In total, the TCA cycle produces 1 FADH2 per acetyl-CoA"
"In total, the TCA cycle produces 1 GTP per acetyl-CoA"
"How much ATP is produced from one molecule of NADH via ATP synthase (ETC)? 2.5 ATP"
"How much ATP is produced from one molecule of FADH2 via ATP synthase (ETC)? 1.5 ATP"
"After complete metabolism, what is the total amount of ATP (or GTP) produced from 1 round of the Krebs cycle? 10 ATP equivalents"
"Where in the cell does acetyl CoA production (from pyruvate) take place? Mitochondria"
"Where in the cell does oxidative phosporylation take place? Mitochondria"
"NADH electrons from glycolysis enter the mitochondria via the malate-aspartate or glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle"
"FADH2 electrons from glycolysis are transferred to complex II of the ETC, also known as succinate dehydrogenase"
"Electrons from complex I and II of the ETC are transferred to Coenzyme Q, also known as ubiquinone"
"Electrons from coenzyme Q (ubiquinone) of the ETC are transferred to complex III (Cyto b/c1)::2 names"
"Electrons from complex III of the ETC are transferred to cytochrome C"
"Electrons from cytochrome C of the ETC are transferred to complex IV (Cyto a/a3)::2 names"
"In complex IV, Fe3+ accepts electrons, forming Fe2+, which then donates the electrons to oxygen (forming H2O)"
"The passage of electrons in the ETC results in the formation of a(n) proton gradient across the mitochondrial inner membrane"
"In the ETC, protons travel down their gradient through the F0/F1 ATP Synthase pump, generating ATP and heat"
"ATP is transferred from mitochondrial matrix to the intermembrane space through the ATP/ADP translocase antiporter (electron transport chain)"
"Rotenone is an insectiside that inhibits complex I of the ETC"
"What class of drugs may bind to and inhibit complex I of the ETC? Barbiturates"
"Antimycin A is an inhibitor of complex III of the ETC"
"Carbon monoxide, cyanide and sodium azide are inhibitors of complex IV of the ETC"
"Cyanide may inhibit the ETC by binding Fe3+, preventing transfer of electrons to O2 in complex IV"
"One treatment for cyanide poisoning is amyl nitrite, which induces methemoglobinemia"
"One treatment for cyanide poisoning is sodium thiosulfate, which helps restore rhodanese-mediated metabolism of cyanide to thiocyanate"
"One treatment for cyanide poisoning is vitamin (hydroxycobalamin) B12 which may bind cyanide"
"Carbon monoxide::CO, CN-, or N3- may inhibit the ETC by binding Fe2+, preventing transfer of electrons to O2 in complex IV"
"Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase of the ETC"
"2,4-dinitrophenol is a(n) uncoupling agent of oxidative phosphorylation"
"What uncoupling agent of oxidative phosphorylation is used illicitly for weight loss? 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP)"
"In high doses, aspirin may act as an uncoupling agent of oxidative phosphorylation"
"Thermogenin in brown fat may act as a(n) uncoupling agent of oxidative phosphorylation"
"What is the cause of death in a patient that overdosed on an uncoupling agent (e.g. 2,4-DNP)? Hyperthermia"
"Electron transport inhibitors cause a(n) decreased proton gradient and block of ATP synthesis"
"ATP synthase inhibitors cause a(n) increased proton gradient and a block of ATP synthesis"
"Uncoupling agents cause a(n) decreased proton gradient and a block of ATP synthesis"
"What is the effect of uncoupling agents (ETC) on O2 consumption? Increased"
"Does electron transport continue with electron transport inhibitors (e.g. CO, CN)? No"
"Does electron transport continue with ATP synthase inhibitors (e.g. oligomycin)? No"
"Does electron transport continue with uncoupling agents (e.g. 2,4-DNP)? Yes**"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme for glycogenesis? Glycogen synthase"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme for glycogenolysis? Glycogen phosphorylase"
"Glucose-1-phosphate is converted to UDP-glucose via the enzyme UDP-glucose pyrophosphorylase (glycogen synthesis)"
"UDP-glucose contributes to glycogen formation via the enzyme glycogen synthase"
"The enzyme glycogen synthase catalyzes the formation of α-(1,4) bonds between glucose molecules"
"Branching enzyme results in the formation of α-(1,6) bonds between glucose molecules"
"Glycogen synthase is regulated via negative feedback by epinephrine and glucagon"
"Glycogen synthase is regulated via positive feedback by insulin, cortisol, and glucose-6-phosphate"
"Glycogen phosphorylase liberates glucose-1-phosphate residues off branched glycogen until 4 glucose units remain on a branch"
"When four glucose units remain on a branch of glycogen, debranching enzyme (4-α-D-glucanotransferase) moves 3 molecules of glucose-1-phosphate from the branch to the linkage"
"When one glucose unit remains on a branch of glycogen, debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase) cleaves off the last residue, liberating glucose"
"The branched glycogen molecule (pre-debranching enzyme) is cleaved by the enzyme α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) in the lysosomes, only"
"The one to four glucose residues remaining on a branch after glycogen phosphorylase has shortened it are referred to as \limit dextrins\\"\""
" Glycogen phosphorylase::glycogen metabolism enzyme is regulated by positive feedback by epinephrine via the β receptor (liver and muscle)"
"Glycogen phosphorylase is regulated by positive feedback by epinephrine via the α receptor (liver only)"
"Glycogen phosphorylase is regulated via positive feedback by glucagon (liver)"
"Glycogen phosphorylase is regulated via positive feedback by AMP (muscle)"
"Glycogen phosphorylase is regulated via negative feedback by ATP, insulin, and glucose-6-phosphate"
"In skeletal muscle, glycogenolysis ultimately produces glucose-6-phosphate, which is rapidly metabolized during exercise"
"Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain identifies glycogen and is thus useful in identifying glycogen storage diseases"
"What is the mode of inheritance of glycogen storage diseases? Autosomal recessive"
"Von Gierke disease is also known as glycogen storage disease type I"
"Von Gierke disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase"
"Von Gierke disease is characterized by severe fasting hypoglycemia"
"Von Gierke disease is characterized by very increased levels of glycogen in the liver and kidneys, with subsequent hepatomegaly and renomegaly"
"Von Gierke disease is associated with increased blood lactate, triglycerides::lipid, and uric acid"
"Which glycogen storage disease has an increased risk for gout? Von Gierke disease"
"Von Gierke disease is characterized by impaired::impaired or functional gluconeogenesis and impaired::impaired or functional glycogenolysis"
"Treatment of Von Gierke disease includes frequent oral glucose or cornstarch between meals"
"Treatment of Von Gierke disease includes avoidance of fructose, galactose, sucrose, and lactose"
"Pompe disease is also known as glycogen storage disease type II"
"Pompe disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase)"
"Pompe disease is characterized by cardio-megaly"
"Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disease associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy"
"Pompe disease is associated with exercise intolerance"
"Cori disease is also known as glycogen storage disease type III"
"Cori disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase & 4-α-d-glucanotransferase)"
"Cori disease is associated with accumulation of limit dextrin-like structures in the cytosol"
"Cori disease presents as a milder form of Von Gierke with normal blood lactate levels"
"Cori disease is characterized by functional::impaired or functional gluconeogenesis and impaired::impaired or functional glycogenolysis"
"Andersen disease is also known as glycogen storage disease type IV"
"Andersen disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme branching (not debranching!) enzyme"
"McArdle disease is also known as glycogen storage disease type V"
"McArdle disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme muscle glycogen phosphorylase (myophosphorylase)"
"McArdle disease is associated with painful muscle cramps that occur with strenuous exercise"
"McArdle disease may present with red-colored urine due to myoglobinuria"
"McArdle disease is associated with arrhythmia from electrolyte abnormalities"
"Patients with McArdle disease may experience the \second-wind\\" phenomenon during exercise due to increased muscular blood flow\""
"Hers disease is also known as glycogen storage disease type VI"
"Hers disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hepatic glycogen phosphorylase"
"Hers disease is characterized by functional::impaired or functional gluconeogenesis and impaired::impaired or functional glycogenolysis"
"Hers disease classically presents with mild fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and cirrhosis"
"Which glycogen storage disorder is associated with severe fasting hypoglycemia? Von Gierke disease"
"Which glycogen storage disorder is associated with cardiomegaly? Pompe disease"
"Which glycogen storage disorder is associated with accumulation of limit dextrin-like structures? Cori disease"
"Which glycogen storage disorder is associated with increased glycogen in muscle? McArdle disease"
"Gluconeogenesis occurs primarily in the liver, but necessary enzymes are also found in the kidney and intestinal epithelium"
"Muscle cannot participate in gluconeogenesis because it lacks the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase"
"Pyruvate may be converted to oxaloacetate via the enzyme pyruvate carboxylase"
"Pyruvate carboxylase requires ATP, biotin, and CO2"
"Acetyl-CoA is a(n) obligate activator of pyruvate carboxylase"
"Pyruvate carboxylase is regulated via positive feedback by acetyl-CoA"
"Where in the cell does conversion of pyruvate -> oxaloacetate take place? Mitochondria"
"After oxaloacetate has been formed from pyruvate (gluconeogenesis), it may exit the mitochondria and enter the cytosol via the malate shuttle"
"Oxaloacetate may be converted to phosphoenolpyruvate via the enzyme PEP carboxykinase"
"Conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate requires a molecule of GTP"
"PEP carboxykinase is regulated via positive feedback by glucagon and cortisol"
"Where in the cell does conversion of oxaloacetate -> PEP take place? Cytosol"
"Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate may be converted to fructose-6-phosphate via the enzyme fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase"
"Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase is regulated via positive feedback by citrate and ATP"
"Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase is regulated via negative feedback by fructose-2,6-bisphosphate and AMP"
"Where in the cell does conversion of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate -> fructose-6-phosphate take place? Cytosol"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme of gluconeogenesis? Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase"
"Glucose-6-phosphate is converted to glucose via the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase"
"Where in the cell does conversion of glucose-6-phosphate -> glucose take place? Endoplasmic reticulum"
"Where does the energy to power gluconeogenesis come from in a starvation state? β-oxidation of fatty acids"
"What organ is responsible for metabolism of ethanol? Liver"
"Ethanol may be converted to acetaldehyde via the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase"
"Where in the cell does conversion of alcohol -> acetaldehyde take place? Cytosol"
"Acetaldehyde may be converted to acetate via the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase"
"Where in the cell does conversion of acetaldehyde -> acetate (ethanol metabolism) take place? Mitochondria"
"In the peroxisome::organelle, ethanol may be converted to acetaldehyde via the enzyme catalase"
"In liver microsomes, ethanol may be converted to acetaldehyde via the enzyme CYP2E1"
"Ethanol metabolism increases the ratio of NADH:NAD+ in the liver"
"What is the limiting reagent in ethanol metabolism? NAD+"
"Alcohol dehydrogenase operates via zero-order kinetics"
"Fomepizole inhibits the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase"
"Fomepizole is used as an antidote for methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning"
"Disulfiram inhibits the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase"
"Disulfiram exacerbates hangover symptoms, which is useful for the treatment of alcoholism"
"Many Asians::ethnicity are deficient of the ethanol metabolism enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase"
"Increased NADH/NAD+ (e.g. due to ethanol) causes increased conversion of pyruvate -> lactate, thus increasing risk for lactic acidosis"
"Increased NADH/NAD+ (e.g. due to ethanol) causes increased conversion of oxaloacetate -> malate, thus preventing gluconeogenesis"
"Alcoholics commonly have fasting hypoglycemia::blood sugar"
"Thrombosis is the pathologic formation of an intravascular blood clot"
"Does thrombosis occur in arteries or veins? Both :)"
"Thrombosis most commonly occurs in the deep veins (DVT) of the leg below the knee"
"Thrombosis is characterized by lines of Zahn, which are alternating layers of platelets/fibrin and RBCs"
"Thrombosis is characterized by attachment to a vessel wall"
"The three major risk factors for thrombosis are disruption in blood flow (stasis), hypercoagulability, and endothelial cell damage (Virchow triad)"
"Stasis and turbulence of blood flow increases risk for thrombosis"
"Immobilization, cardiac wall dysfunction (arrhythmia, MI), and aneurysm increase risk of thrombosis due to disruption of blood flow"
"Endothelial cells prevent thrombosis by blocking exposure to underlying subendothelial collagen and tissue thromboplastin"
"Endothelial cells prevent thrombosis by producing prostacyclin (PGI2) and NO"
"Prostacyclin (PGI2) and NO from endothelial cells cause vaso-dilation"
"Prostacyclin (PGI2) and NO from endothelial cells cause inhibition of platelet aggregation"
"Endothelial cells prevent thrombosis by secreting heparin-like molecules, which augment antithrombin III (ATIII)"
"Antithrombin III inactivates::activates or inactivates thrombin and coagulation factors"
"Endothelial cells prevent thrombosis by secreting tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), which converts plasminogen to plasmin"
"Endothelial cells prevent thrombosis by producing thrombomodulin, which redirects thrombin to activate protein C"
"Which amino acid may cause endothelial cell damage when serum levels are elevated? Homocysteine"
"Vitamin B12 and folate deficiency result in mildly elevated homocysteine levels, increasing risk for thrombosis"
"Which vitamin deficiencies are associated with increased risk for thrombosis? Vitamin B12 and B9 (folate)::2"
"Cystathionine beta synthase (CBS) deficiency results in high homocysteine levels, increasing risk for thrombosis"
"A(n) hypercoagulable state is due to excessive procoagulant proteins or defective anticoagulant proteins"
"The classic presentation of a hypercoagulable state is recurrent DVTs or DVT at a young age"
"What is the mode of inheritance of protein C or S deficiency? Autosomal dominant"
"Protein C and S normally inactivate factors Va and VIIIa"
"Protein C deficiency causes increased risk of thrombotic skin necrosis with hemorrhage after warfarin administration"
"Warfarin (coumadin) is a drug that inhibits the enzyme epoxide reductase"
"In the initial stages of warfarin therapy, there is a temporary deficiency of protein C compared to factors II, VII, IX, and X"
"Why is there a relative protein C and S deficiency in the initial stages of warfarin therapy? Protein C and S have a shorter half-life than factors II, VII, IX, and X"
"Factor V Leiden is a mutated form of factor V that is resistant to degradation by activated protein C"
"Factor V Leiden is due to a point mutation near the cleavage site of factor V"
"What point mutation is the cause of Factor V Leiden? Arg506Gln (G -> A point mutation)"
"What is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulable state in Caucasians? Factor V Leiden"
"Prothrombin 20210A is an inherited point mutation in the prothrombin gene that results in increased gene expression"
"Prothrombin 20210 mutation is a point mutation in the 3' untranslated region of the gene"
"ATIII deficiency decreases the protective effect of heparin-like molecules produced by the endothelium"
"What drug enhances activity of antithrombin? Heparin"
"In ATIII deficiency, PTT doesn't rise with standard heparin dosing"
"What coagulation factors are inhibited by antithrombin? 2, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12::6"
"What coagulation factors are the principal targets of antithrombin? IIa (thrombin) and Xa::2"
"What is the treatment for ATIII deficiency? High dose heparin, followed by warfarin::specific"
"What is the effect of oral contraceptives on coagulability? Increases coaguability"
"What is the effect of estrogen on production of coagulation factors? Increased production"
"Hyper-coagulable states are often complicated by recurrent pregnancy loss (women)"
"Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) may be administered clinically as a(n) thrombolytic"
"The three major risk factors for thrombosis are disruption in blood flow (stasis), hypercoagulability, and endothelial cell damage (Virchow triad)"
"The imaging test of choice for deep venous thrombosis is compression ultrasound"
"DVT is a blood clot within a deep vein, causing swelling, redness, warmth, and pain"
"What lab test is used clinically to rule out DVT (high sensitivity, low specificity)? D-dimer"
"Lower limb DVT may be associated with calf pain upon dorsiflexion of the foot (Homan sign)"
"Unfractioned or LMW heparin is used for prophylaxis and acute management of DVT"
"Oral anticoagulants (e.g. warfarin) are used for treatment and long-term prevention of DVT"
"A(n) thromboembolus is due to a thrombus that dislodges (most common type of embolus, >95%)"
"Atherosclerotic embolus is due to an atherosclerotic plaque that embolizes"
"Atherosclerotic embolus is characterized by the presence of cholesterol clefts in the embolus"
"Fat embolus is associated with bone fractures, particularly long bones and soft tissue trauma"
"When (chronologically) does a fat embolus typically occur following a bone fracture? While fracture still present or shortly after repair"
"What surgical procedure is associated with fat embolus? Liposuction"
"Fat emboli are characterized by a triad of: - hypoxemia - neurologic abnormalities - petechial rash overlying the chest"
"Fat emboli commonly presents with dyspnea::symptom due to fat, often with bone marrow elements, in the pulmonary vessels"
"Gas (air) embolus is classically seen in decompression sickness (Caisson disease)"
"Gas emboli occur due to bubbling of nitrogen gas out of blood, due to rapid ascent by a diver"
"Gas emboli present with joint and muscle pain ('bends') and respiratory symptoms ('chokes')"
"Chronic Caisson disease (decompression sickness) is characterized by multifocal ischemic necrosis of bone"
"What is the treatment for a gas (air) embolus? Hyperbaric O2"
"Gas emboli may be iatrogenic, secondary to laparoscopic procedures as air is pumped into the abdomen"
"Amniotic fluid emboli enter maternal circulation during labor or delivery"
"Amniotic fluid emboli are characterized by squamous cells and keratin debris in the embolus"
"Systemic embolism is usually due to a thromboembolus that arises from the left heart (most common)"
"The most common site for systemic emboli to lodge is in the lower extremities"
"Most pulmonary emboli arise via a thromboembolus from the proximal deep veins of the lower extremity"
"What is the most common symptom of pulmonary embolus? Most often clinically silent"
"Pulmonary emboli are usually clinically silent due to the dual blood supply of the lungs via the pulmonary and bronchial arteries"
"Pulmonary emboli are usually clinically silent as the embolus is usually small::size and self-resolves"
"Pulmonary infarction due to PE occurs if a large- or medium-sized artery is obstructed in patients with pre-existing cardiopulmonary compromise"
"Pulmonary infarction due to PE may present with pleuritic chest pain and pleural effusion"
"Pulmonary infarction due to PE may present with tachypnea::RR and tachycardia::HR"
"Pulmonary infarction due to PE may present with hemoptysis and sudden-onset dyspnea and chest pain"
"In a patient with a pulmonary emboli, V/Q lung scan shows mismatch due to abnormal perfusion"
"Pulmonary embolism's V/Q mismatch can lead to hypoxemia, triggering hyper-ventilation and subsequent respiratory alkalosis."
"Spiral CT (CT pulmonary angiography) is the imaging test of choice for pulmonary embolism"
"What may be seen on spiral CT in a patient with a pulmonary embolism? Vascular filling defects"
"Pulmonary embolism may present with elevated D-dimer"
"Gross examination of pulmonary infarction due to PE reveals a hemorrhagic, wedge-shaped infarct"
"The wedge-shaped infarct due to pulmonary embolism points towards::towards or away the area of occlusion"
"Large saddle pulmonary emboli may cause sudden death"
"Death from a saddle pulmonary emboli is due to electromechanical dissociation"
"Pulmonary hypertension may arise with chronic emboli that are reorganized over time"
"A pre-mortem thrombi is distinguishable from a post-mortem thrombi by the presence of lines of Zahn and attachment to a vessel wall"
"Rhinosinusitis (Sinusitis) is caused by obstruction of sinus drainage into the nasal cavity causing inflammation and pain over the affected area"
"Rhinosinusitis most commonly affects the maxillary sinus in adults"
"The maxillary sinus drains into the middle meatus"
"Rhinosinusitis is most commonly caused by a(n) viral::bacterial or viral upper respiratory infection (URI)"
"Superimposed bacterial infection on top of rhinosinusitis is most commonly due to S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and M. catarrhalis"
"Epistaxis is the medical term for nose bleed"
"Epistaxis most commonly occurs in the anterior segment of the nostril (Kiesselbach plexus)"
"Epistaxis may cause life-threatening hemorrhages if they occur in the posterior segment of the nostril (Woodruff's plexus)"
"What type of carcinoma are most head and neck cancers? Squamous cell carcinoma"
"What virus is oropharyngeal carcinoma associated with? HPV-16"
"Field cancerization is a process by which a carcinogen damages a wide mucosal area, causing multiple tumors"
"Interstitial restrictive lung diseases are characterized by decreased diffusing capacity"
"Interstitial restrictive lung diseases are characterized by increased A-a gradients"
"Extrapulmonary restrictive lung diseases are characterized by normal A-a gradients"
"Extrapulmonary restrictive lung diseases are associated with hypoventilation of peripheral::central or peripheral origin"
"Acute respiratory distress syndrome is a cause of interstitial restrictive lung disease"
"Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (hyaline membrane disease) is a cause of interstitial restrictive lung disease"
"What vasculitis may cause interstitial restrictive lung disease? Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener)"
"What anti-arrhythmic agent may cause interstitial restrictive lung disease? Amiodarone"
"What anti-neoplastic agents may cause interstitial restrictive lung disease? Bleomycin, busulfan, methotrexate, and procarbazine"
"Interstitial restrictive lung disease may be caused by pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (Eosinophilic granuloma)"
"Restrictive lung disease may be caused by poor structural apparatus, such as scoliosis and morbid obesity"
"Restrictive lung disease may be caused by poor muscular effort, such as polio, myasthenia gravis::paraneoplastic syndrome and Guillain-Barré syndrome"
"In obstructive::obstructive or restrictive lung disease, the flow volume loops shifts to the *left"
"In restrictive::obstructive or restrictive lung disease, the flow volume loops shifts to the right*"
"Sleep apnea is defined as repeated (>5x/hr) cessation of breathing > 10 seconds during sleep"
"Sleep apnea often presents clinically with daytime sleepiness"
"Sleep apnea is characterized by a(n) normal Pao2 and Paco2 during the day"
"Sleep apnea is associated with pulmonary hypertension due to nocturnal hypoxia"
"Obstructive sleep apnea is associated with difficult to manage systemic hypertension due to increased sympathetic tone"
"Sleep apnea is associated with arrhythmias, especially atrial fibrillation/flutter"
"What effect may sleep apnea secondarily have on RBC levels? Increased (polycythemia)"
"Obstructive sleep apnea is caused by respiratory effort against an airway obstruction"
"Obstructive sleep apnea is associated with obesity, loud snoring with periods of apnea, and daytime sleepiness"
"Obstructive sleep apnea may be caused by excess parapharyngeal tissue in adults::age group"
"Obstructive sleep apnea may be caused by adenotonsillar hypertrophy in children::age group"
"Treatment for obstructive sleep apnea includes weight loss, surgery, and CPAP"
"Central sleep apnea can occur due patients having marginal ventilation when awake (e.g. CNS disease, neuromuscular disease, severe kyphoscoliosis, heavy dose narcotics)"
"Obesity hypoventilation syndrome is a condition in which severely overweight people fail to breathe rapidly or deeply enough"
"Obesity hypoventilation syndrome is characterized by decreased Pao2 and increased Paco2 during sleep"
"Obesity hypoventilation (Pickwickian) syndrome is characterized by increased Paco2 during waking hours"
"Pleural effusion is the excess accumulation of fluid between lung pleural layers"
"Pleural effusion causes restricted lung inspiration::inspiration or expiration"
"Pleural effusion can be treated with thoracentesis to remove fluid"
"Transudative pleural effusion may be caused by increased hydrostatic pressure (e.g. HF)"
"Transudative pleural effusion may be caused by decreased oncotic pressure (e.g. nephrotic syndrome, cirrhosis)"
"Transudative pleural effusion is characterized by low protein content"
"Exudative pleural effusion is caused by states of increased vascular permeability (e.g. malignancy, pneumonia, trauma, collagen vascular disease)"
"Exudative pleural effusions must be drained due to risk of infection"
"What is an empyema? Pus in the pleural space"
"A(n) lymphatic pleural effusion is also known as chylothorax"
"Lymphatic pleural effusion occurs due to thoracic duct injury from trauma or malignancy"
"Lymphatic pleural effusion is characterized by a(n) milky-appearing fluid with increased triglycerides"
"Pleural effusion presents with decreased::increased or decreased breath sounds"
"Pleural effusion presents with dullness to percussion"
"Pleural effusion presents with decreased fremitus"
"In large pleural effusions, the trachea may deviate away from the side of the lesion"
"Atelectasis (bronchial / bronchiole obstruction) presents with decreased::increased or decreased breath sounds"
"Atelectasis (bronchial / bronchiole obstruction) presents with dullness to percussion"
"Atelectasis (bronchial / bronchiole obstruction) presents with decreased fremitus"
"In atelectasis, the trachea may deviate towards the side of the lesion"
"Consolidation (lobar pneumonia, pulmonary edema) may present with bronchial breath sounds along with: - Egophony - Bronchophony - Whispered Pectoriloquy"
"Consolidation (lobar pneumonia, pulmonary edema) may present with late inspiratory crackles"
"Consolidation (lobar pneumonia, pulmonary edema) presents with dullness to percussion"
"Consolidation (lobar pneumonia, pulmonary edema) presents with increased fremitus"
"Lung development begins with development of a(n) lung bud from the distal end of the respiratory diverticulum"
"What week does lung development begin? Week 4"
"The embryonic lung bud divides into two bronchial buds that branch off into bronchi"
"The embryonic period of lung development occurs from weeks 4 to 7"
"Errors at what stage of lung development can lead to the formation of a Tracheoesophageal Fistula? Embryonic Period (Weeks 4-7)"
"The pseudoglandular period of lung development occurs from weeks 5 to 17"
"During the pseudoglandular period (lung development), the endodermal tubules form the terminal bronchioles"
"During the pseudoglandular period of lung development, the bronchioles are surrounded by a(n) modest capillary network"
"Is respiration possible during the pseudoglandular period of lung development? No; incompatible with life"
"The canalicular period of lung development occurs from weeks 16 to 25"
"During the canalicular period (lung development), the terminal bronchioles form the respiratory bronchioles, which then form the alveolar ducts"
"During the canalicular period of lung development, the bronchioles are surrounded by a(n) prominent capillary network"
"During the canalicular period of lung development, airways increase in diameter"
"Respiration may be possible at week 25 (canalicular period), but it's better to wait until week 36"
"The saccular period of lung development occurs from weeks 26 to birth"
"During the saccular period (lung development), the alveolar ducts form the terminal sacs"
"During the saccular period (lung development), terminal sacs are separated by primary septa"
"In which period of lung development do pneumocytes develop? Saccular period (weeks 26 - birth)"
"The alveolar period of lung development occurs from weeks 36 to 8 years"
"During the alveolar period (lung development), the terminal sacs form the adult alveoli"
"Terminal sacs form into adult alveoli due to secondary septation"
"In utero, \breathing\\" occurs via aspiration and expulsion of amniotic fluid"
"Pulmonary hypoplasia is characterized by a poorly-developed bronchial tree with abnormal histology"
"Pulmonary hypoplasia is associated with bilateral renal agenesis (Potter sequence) and congenital diaphragmatic hernia"
"Congenital bronchogenic cysts are caused by abnormal budding of the foregut and dilation of terminal or large bronchi"
"Bronchogenic cyst is a congenital lung malformation that presents as discrete, round, sharply defined and air-filled densities on CXR"
"Type I pneumocytes line the alveoli (97% of alveolar surfaces)"
"Type I pneumocytes are squamous cells; thin for optimal gas diffusion"
"Type II pneumocytes are clustered, cuboidal::shape cells"
"Type II pneumocytes proliferate during lung damage"
"Club (Clara) cells are non-ciliated, low columnar/cuboidal cells with secretory granules in the lung"
"Club (clara) cells of the lung secrete a component of surfactant and act as reserve cells"
"Club (clara) cells of the lung may degrade toxins"
"The right lung has three lobes"
"The left lung has two lobes"
"Which lung (right or left) has a lingula? Left"
"The right lung is the more common site for inhaled foreign bodies because it has a wider and more vertical bronchus"
"In the right lung, the pulmonary artery is anterior to the bronchus"
"In the left lung, the pulmonary artery is superior to the bronchus"
"The IVC perforates the diaphragm at the level of T8"
"The esophagus and vagus nerve perforate the diaphragm at the level of T10"
"The aorta, thoracic duct, and azygos vein perforate the diaphragm at the level of T12"
"The diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerve"
"What are the roots of the phrenic nerve? C3, C4, C5"
"Pain from diaphragm irritation can be referred to the shoulder (C5) or trapezius ridge (C3, 4)"
"The trachea bifurcates at the level of T4"
"The common carotid artery bifurcates at the level of C4"
"Exudative pleural effusion is characterized by high protein content"
"Rank the following from highest to lowest prevalence: ASD, PDA, VSD VSD > ASD > PDA"
"What is the remnant of the mesonephric (wolffian) duct in females? Gartner duct"
"Most tissue histamine is sequestered inside the granules of mast cells and basophils"
"Once mast cells are sensitized by IgE antibodies on their surface, they burst open when exposed to appropriate antigens"
"Allergic inflammation is mediated by histamine, which acts on the H1 histamine receptor"
"What G protein is the H1 histamine receptor coupled to? Gq"
"What G protein is the H2 histamine receptor coupled to? Gs"
"H2 histamine receptors are located on gastric parietal cells and mediate gastric acid secretion"
"Histamine causes increased nasal and bronchial mucus production (H1 receptor activation)"
"Activation of the H1 histamine receptor may cause pain, pruritus, and vasodilation"
"Histamine increases vascular permeability, which is responsible for urticaria/hives (H1 receptor activation)"
"Histamine causes constriction of bronchial smooth muscle, especially in patients with asthma (H1 receptor activation)"
"Histamine functions as a neurotransmitter in the brain"
"In the brain, histamine may regulate sleep and arousal via its H1 receptor"
"Which generation of H1 histamine receptor antagonists are used to treat allergies? Both 1st and 2nd generation :)"
"What drug class do diphenhydramine and dimenhydrinate belong to? 1st generation H1 receptor antagonists"
"What drug class does chlorpheniramine belong to? 1st generation H1 receptor antagonist"
"What drug class do hydroxyzine, meclizine and promethazine belong to? 1st generation H1 receptor antagonists"
"Histamine mediates type 1 hypersensitivity reactions via activation of H1 receptors"
"1st generation H1 histamine receptor antagonists may be used to treat vestibular nausea and motion sickness"
"Do 1st generation H1 receptor antagonists cross the blood-brain-barrier? Yes (lipophilic)"
"Are 1st generation H1 receptor antagonists associated with drowsiness? Yes (cross BBB and have central effects)"
"1st generation H1 receptor antagonists, especially diphenhydramine, may be used as a(n) sleep aid"
"1st generation H1 receptor antagonists may antagonize muscarinic receptors, leading to significant anti-cholinergic effects"
"1st generation H1 receptor antagonists may acutely suppress the extrapyramidal side effects associated with certain anti-psychotic drugs"
"1st generation H1 receptor antagonists may stimulate appetite and cause weight gain due to anti-serotonergic effects"
"1st generation H1 receptor antagonists may cause dizziness::vestibular and hypotension::blood pressure due to anti-α1-adrenergic effects"
"1st generation H1 receptor antagonists may cause cognitive impairment and delirium, especially in the elderly"
"Adverse effects of 1st generation H1 receptor antagonists may be more common and more severe in elderly patients"
"What drug class does fexofenadine belong to? 2nd generation H1 receptor antagonist"
"What drug class does cetirizine belong to? 2nd generation H1 receptor antagonists"
"What drug class does loratadine belong to? 2nd generation H1 receptor antagonists"
"Do 2nd generation H1 receptor antagonists cross the blood-brain-barrier? No"
"Are 2nd generation H1 receptor antagonists associated with drowsiness? No (do not cross BBB therefore less sedation)"
"What are 2nd generation H1 receptor antagonists used to treat? Allergies"
"Asthmatic bronchoconstriction is mediated by inflammatory processes and parasympathetic::SNS or PNS? tone"
"Classic allergic asthma is mediated by IgE, produced in response to exposure to foreign antigens (i.e. dust, dander, pollen)"
"Once produced, IgE binds to high affinity (FcεRI)::specific receptors on mast cells in the airway mucosa"
"Selective β2 agonists, such as albuterol, treat bronchoconstriction in asthma"
"Albuterol, pirbuterol, and metaproterenol are short-acting β2 agonists"
"Terbutaline is a selective β2 agonist that treats bronchoconstriction in asthma"
"Short-acting β2 agonists (e.g. albuterol) are administered as metered-dose inhalers for acute relief of symptoms"
"More severe forms of asthma are associated with more frequent and severe symptoms, especially during nighttime::daytime or nighttime"
"Inhaled corticosteroids (e.g. budesonide, fluticasone) can be added as daily maintenance therapy for persistent asthma"
"Corticosteroids treat asthma by blocking inflammation and cellular infiltration"
"Inhaled corticosteroids (e.g. asthma therapy) inhibit the synthesis of virtually all cytokines"
"Inhaled corticosteroids inactivate NF-κB, the transcription factor that induces production of TNF-α and other inflammatory agents"
"Inhaled corticosteroids are the first line therapy for chronic asthma"
"What adverse effect is associated with inhaled corticosteroids? Oropharyngeal candidiasis"
"The risk of oropharyngeal candidiasis following inhaled corticosteroids is reduced by gargling water and spitting after each treatment"
"What drug class do fluticasone, budesonide, and beclomethasone belong to? Inhaled corticosteroids"
"A major step in the conversion of Arachidonic acids (AA) to leukotrienes is the conversion to 5-HPETE by the enzyme 5-lipoxygenase"
"Leukotriene B4 and 5HETE are potent chemoattractants for numerous inflammatory cells (particularly neutrophils)"
"Leukotrienes C4, D4 and E4 increase airway vascular permeability, mucus production, and bronchoconstriction (bronchospasm)"
"Leukotriene D4 is the most potent bronchoconstrictor"
"Leukotriene D4 exerts its effects by binding to the CysLT1 receptor"
"What drug class do montelukast and zafirlukast belong to? Leukotriene D4-receptor antagonists"
"What is the route of administration of leukotriene D4-receptor antagonists (e.g. montelukast, zafirlukast)? Oral administration"
"What is the effect of COX inhibition (e.g. aspirin) on production of leukotrienes? Increased"
"Montelukast and zafirlukast are especially effective at treating aspirin-induced asthma"
"What is the mechanism of action of zileuton (asthma treatment)? 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor"
"What adverse effect is associated with zileuton? Hepatotoxicity"
"Salmeterol and formoterol are long-acting β2 agonists"
"Long-acting β2 agonists are used for prophylaxis in moderate or severe persistent asthma"
"Long-acting β2 agonists (e.g. salmeterol) achieve their long duration due to high lipid solubility"
"Long-acting β2 agonists (e.g. salmeterol) are given as a daily inhaler and are always combined with a regimen of inhaled corticosteroids"
"Adverse effects of long-acting β2 agonists (e.g. salmeterol, formoterol) include tremor and arrhythmia"
"An increased dose of inhaled cortisteroids may be useful for treatment of moderate or severe persistent asthma"
"Theophylline is a methylxanthine that may be used for asthma therapy"
"Theophylline causes broncho-dilation by inhibiting phosphodiesterase"
"What effect does theophylline have on levels of cAMP? Increased cAMP"
"What is the route of administration of theophylline (asthma therapy)? Oral administration"
"Theophylline use is limited due to its narrow therapeutic index"
"Theophylline may have CNS side effects including nervousness and tremor"
"Theophylline can cause tachycardia::HR"
"Theophylline is metabolized by cytochrome P-450"
"Theophylline blocks the actions of adenosine (local metabolite)"
"Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against the Fc portion of IgE, preventing mast cell sensitization"
"Omalizumab is used in allergic asthma with increased IgE levels and resistance to inhaled steroids and long-acting β2 agonists"
"Cromolyn sodium is an asthma therapeutic that inhibits mast cell degranulation"
"What is the treatment for an acute, severe asthma exacerbation? Short-acting β2 agonist +/- systemic corticosteroids OR Epinephrine"
"In acute, severe asthma exacerbation, corticosteroids are administered IV or orally"
"Nebulized ipratropium is a muscarinic antagonist that may be used to treat acute, severe asthma exacerbation"
"Ipratropium is a competitive M3 receptor antagonist that is used to prevent bronchoconstriction in asthmatic and COPD patients"
"In addition to asthma, ipratropium may also be used to treat COPD"
"Tiotropium is a(n) long-acting M3 antagonist"
"What catecholamine may be administered to treat acute, severe asthma exacerbation? Epinephrine"
"Methacoline is a(n) M3 receptor agonist used in the bronchial challenge to help diagnose asthma"
"Adenosine causes broncho-constriction"
"Acetylcholine causes broncho-constriction"
"Theophylline causes broncho-dilation"
"Muscarinic antagonists cause broncho-dilation"
"Increased cAMP causes broncho-dilation"
"What classes of drugs are used to treat asthma by blocking inflammation (late response)? Inhaled corticosteroids, anti-leukotrienes, and anti-IL-5 monoclonal antibodies"
"What classes of drugs are used to treat asthma by blocking bronchoconstriction (early response)? β2 agonists, theophylline (methylxanthines), muscarinic antagonists"
"Guaifenesin is a(n) expectorant that thins respiratory secretions"
"Does guaifenesin suppress the cough reflex? No"
"N-acetylcysteine is a(n) mucolytic agent that liquifies mucus by disrupting disulfide bonds; useful in Chronic Bronchitis / COPD and Cystic Fibrosis patients"
"Pseudoephedrine and phenylephrine are α-adrenergic agonists that may be used as nasal decongestants"
"Pseudoephedrine and phenylephrine may be used clinically to reduce - hyperemia - edema - nasal congestion"
"Pseudoephedrine and phenylephrine may be used to open an obstructed eustachian tube"
"Pseudoephedrine is a decongestant that may be used illicitly to make methamphetamine"
"What adverse effect may pseudoephedrine and phenylephrine have on blood pressure? Increased BP (Hypertension)"
"Adverse effects associated with pseudoephedrine include - CNS stimulation - anxiety (mood altering)"
"Dextromethorphan is a synthetic codeine::which specific drug? analog that is used clinically as a(n) anti-tussive"
"Dextromethorphan is an anti-tussive that exerts its effects via antagonism of the NMDA glutamate receptor"
"Dextromethorphan is an antitussive that has mild opioid effects when used in excess and thus has mild abuse potential"
"What drug is given for overdose of dextromethorphan? Naloxone"
"Dextromethorphan may cause serotonin syndrome if combined with other serotonergic agents"
"Bosentan is a competitive endothelin-1 receptor antagonist used to treat pulmonary hypertension"
"Bosentan antagonizes endothelin-1 receptors, causing decreased pulmonary vascular resistance"
"What adverse effect is associated with bosentan? Hepatotoxicity (thus monitor LFTs)"
"Sildenafil inhibits PDE-5 and prolongs the vasodilatory effect of nitric oxide"
"In addition to erectile dysfunction, sildenafil may also be used to treat pulmonary hypertension"
"Epoprostenol and iloprost are synthetic forms of PGI2 (prostacylin)"
"Epoprostenol and iloprost inhibit platelet aggregation"
"Epoprostenol and iloprost have direct vaso-dilatory effects on pulmonary and systemic arterial vascular beds"
"Epoprostenol and iloprost may be used to treat pulmonary hypertension"
"Adverse effects of epoprostenol and iloprost include flushing and jaw pain"
"What is the mode of inheritance of cystic fibrosis? Autosomal recessive"
"Cystic fibrosis is due to a defect in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7"
"Cystic fibrosis most commonly occurs due to a(n) in-frame deletion of Phe508"
"What is the most common lethal, genetic disease in Caucasians? Cystic fibrosis"
"The CFTR gene encodes a(n) ATP-gated Cl- channel"
"The CFTR Cl- channel secretes::secretes or absorbs Cl- in the lungs and GI tract"
"The CFTR Cl- channel reabsorbs::secretes or absorbs Cl- in the sweat glands"
"The most common CFTR gene mutation (cystic fibrosis) results in a misfolded protein that is retained in the RER"
"In cystic fibrosis, increased intracellular Cl- results in compensatory increased Na+ reabsorption via epithelial Na+ channels"
"Increased Na+ reabsorption due to decreased Cl- secretion (cystic fibrosis) results in increased H2O reabsorption"
"Increased H2O reabsorption in CF results in abnormally thick mucus secreted into the lungs and GI tract"
"Increased Na+ reabsorption in cystic fibrosis causes a more negative transepithelial potential difference (TEPD)"
"Increased Cl- concentration (> 60 meQ/L) in sweat is diagnostic of cystic fibrosis"
"Cystic fibrosis may present with contraction::volume alkalosis::pH"
"How does cystic fibrosis affect K+ levels? Decreased (hypokalemia)"
"What newborn screening blood test is used to screen for cystic fibrosis? Immunoreactive trypsinogen"
"A(n) increased immunoreactive trypsinogen may be indicative of cystic fibrosis"
"What organism is responsible for recurrent pulmonary infections in an infant cystic fibrosis patient? Staphylococcus aureus"
"What organism is responsible for recurrent pulmonary infections in an adult cystic fibrosis patient? Pseudomonas aeruginosa"
"Chronic bronchitis and bronchiectasis in a cystic fibrosis patient leads to a(n) reticulonodular pattern on CXR"
"Cystic fibrosis may cause pancreatic insufficiency, resulting in malabsorption"
"Cystic fibrosis may cause malabsorption with steatorrhea::bowel condition and consequent fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies"
"Cystic fibrosis may cause biliary cirrhosis and/or liver disease"
"Cystic fibrosis may present as meconium ileus (10-20% of patients) in newborns due to abnormally thick (\inspissated\\") stool\""
"Cystic fibrosis may cause infertility in men due to congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens"
"Is spermatogenesis possible in a patient with cystic fibrosis? Yes"
"Cystic fibrosis may cause subfertility in women due to abnormally thick cervical mucus and amenorrhea"
"Cystic fibrosis may present with nasal polyps and nail clubbing"
"Treatment of cystic fibrosis includes replacement of pancreatic enzymes"
"Treatment of cystic fibrosis includes azithromycin, which is used as an anti-inflammatory agent"
"Treatment of cystic fibrosis includes hyper-tonic saline, which facilitates mucus clearing"
"Treatment of cystic fibrosis includes aerosolized dornase alfa (DNase), which hydrolyzes DNA in mucus causing decreased viscosity"
"Treatment of cystic fibrosis includes albuterol, a β2 agonist"
"Treatment of cystic fibrosis includes chest physiotherapy, which aids in mucus clearance"
"The site of synthesis, storage, and release of renin is the juxtaglomerular apparatus of the kidney"
"Renin is responsible for the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I"
"ACE is primarily located in the vascular endothelium of the lungs"
"Angiotensin I is converted to angiotensin II by ACE in the lungs (primarily)"
"Angiotensin II is a potent vaso-constrictor"
"What effect do normal levels of angiotensin II have on GFR? Increased GFR"
"Angiotensin II normally constricts the efferent arteriole of the kidney"
"Angiotensin II acts directly at the PCT::location to increase NaHCO3 reabsorption"
"Angiotensin II increases aldosterone release from the adrenal cortex"
"What effect does angiotensin II indirectly have on serum potassium levels? Decreased K+ (via aldosterone)"
"What drug class do captopril, enalapril, lisinopril, and ramipril belong to? ACE inhibitors"
"What effect do ACE inhibitors have on levels of angiotensin II? Decreased AT II"
"What effect do ACE inhibitors and ARBs have on GFR? Decreased GFR"
"ACE inhibitors and ARBs primarily cause dilation of the efferent arteriole of the kidney"
"ACE inhibitors and ARBs decrease sodium and bicarbonate reabsorption at the proximal convoluted tubule"
"ACE inhibitors and ARBs decrease aldosterone release from the adrenal cortex"
"ACE inhibitors can cause a(n) elevation in creatinine levels within the first few days of starting treatment"
"ACE inhibitors can cause significant hypotension which can lead to syncope in patients with high renin levels (e.g. heart failure, diuretic use)"
"What effect do ACE inhibitors have on levels of angiotensin I and renin? Increased levels"
"What effect may ACE inhibitors have on potassium levels? Increased (hyperkalemia)"
"ACE inhibitors are first line agents in the treatment of heart failure"
"Do ACE inhibitors reduce mortality in patients with heart failure and MI? Yes"
"ACE inhibitors decrease heart remodeling induced by high levels of angiotensin II (e.g. chronic hypertension)"
"ACE inhibitors are a first line agent in the treatment of primary hypertension"
"ACE inhibitors slow the progression of diabetic nephropathy"
"In diabetics, ACE inhibitors decrease intraglomerular pressure, thus slowing glomerular basement membrane thickening"
"ACE inhibitors may cause a(n) dry cough due to lung irritation, secondary to increased bradykinin"
"What effect do ACE inhibitors have on bradykinin activity? Increased"
"What effect do ARBs have on bradykinin activity? No effect"
"ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with hereditary angioedema, which is characterized by a(n) C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency"
"ACE inhibitors may cause angioedema due to increased bradykinin"
"ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to possible teratogenic effects"
"Coadministration of ACE inhibitors with NSAIDs can precipitate acute kidney injury"
"NSAIDs decrease prostaglandins, which normally dilate the afferent arterioles of the kidney"
"What effect may NSAIDs have on GFR? Decreased GFR"
"ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in bilateral renal artery stenosis"
"ACE inhibitors may precipitate acute renal failure in bilateral renal artery stenosis, causing significantly increased serum creatinine"
"What drug class do losartan, candesartan, and valsartan belong to? Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs)"
"ARBs selectively block binding of angiotensin II to the AT1 receptor"
"What effect may ARBs have on potassium levels? Increased (hyperkalemia)"
"ARBs are contraindicated during pregnancy due to possible teratogenic effects"
"What effect may ARBs have on blood pressure? Decreased (hypotension)"
"Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor"
"What effect may aliskiren have on potassium levels? Increased (hyperkalemia)"
"What effect may aliskiren have on blood pressure? Decreased (hypotension)"
"What effect does aliskiren have on GFR? Decreased GFR"
"Aliskiren is relatively contraindicated in patients already taking ACE inhibitors or ARBs"
"What is the primary clinical use for aliskiren? Treatment of hypertension"
"The kidneys lie in the retroperitoneal cavity of the body"
"The outer region of the kidney is the cortex"
"The central region of the kidney is the medulla"
"The innermost tip of the kidney medullary pyramid is called the papilla"
"The medullary pyramids (papillae) of the kidney empty into major and minor calyces"
"The major and minor calyces of the kidney drain into the renal pelvis, which is the dilated proximal part of the ureter"
"The functional units of the kidney are nephrons, which consist of a(n) glomerulus and a(n) renal tubule"
"Glomerular capillaries are surrounded by Bowman's capsule (space), which is continuous with the first portion of the nephron"
"Following Bowman's capsule, glomerular filtrate enters the proximal convoluted tubule"
"Following the proximal convoluted tubule, glomerular filtrate enters the proximal straight tubule"
"Following the proximal straight tubule, glomerular filtrate enters the thin descending limb (loop of Henle)"
"Following the thin descending limb, glomerular filtrate enters the thin ascending limb (loop of Henle)"
"Following the thin ascending limb, the glomerular filtrate enters the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle)"
"The thin descending limb, thin ascending limb, and thick ascending limb of the kidney form the loop of Henle"
"Following the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle), glomerular filtrate enters the distal convoluted tubule"
"At the beginning of the distal convoluted tubule, glomerular filtrate passes the macula densa"
"Following the distal convoluted tubule, glomerular filtrate enters the collecting ducts"
"Superficial cortical nephrons have glomeruli located in the outer cortex and have a relatively short loop of Henle"
"Juxtamedullary nephrons have glomeruli located near the corticomedullary border and have a relatively long loop of Henle"
"Juxtamedullary nephrons have larger::size glomeruli and thus higher GFR than superficial cortical nephrons"
"Blood enters the kidney via a(n) renal artery, which branches into segmental arteries"
"Segmental arteries of the kidney further branch into interlobar arteries"
"Interlobar arteries of the kidney further branch into arcuate arteries"
"Arcuate arteries of the kidney further branch into interlobular arteries"
"The interlobular arteries of the kidney divide into the afferent arterioles"
"Blood enters the glomerular capillaries via the afferent arterioles"
"Blood exits the glomerular capillaries via the efferent arterioles"
"Blood from the efferent arterioles is delivered to the peritubular capillaries"
"In the juxtamedullary nephrons, the peritubular capillaries give off vasa recta (straight arterioles) which run parallel to the loop of Henle"
"Which kidney is taken during donor transplantation? Why? Left; has a longer renal vein"
"In females, the ureters pass under the uterine artery"
"Gynecologic procedures, such as ligation of uterine or ovarian vessels, may damage the ureter"
"In males, the ureters pass under the vas deferens"
"On average, total body water (TBW) is 60% of body weight"
"What gender is associated with a greater % total body water? Males (due to less adipose tissue)"
"On average, intracellular fluid is 40% of body weight"
"On average, extracellular fluid is 20% of body weight"
"Extracellular fluid is divided into interstitial fluid (75% of ECF) and plasma (25% of ECF)"
"In addition to ICF and ECF, a small transcellular fluid compartment consists of cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, and digestive fluids"
"Intracellular fluid comprises two-thirds of total body water"
"The major cations of intracellular fluid are K+ and Mg2+"
"The major anions of intracellular fluid are proteins and organic phosphates"
"Extracellular fluid comprises one-third of total body water"
"The major cation of extracellular fluid is Na+"
"The major anions of extracellular fluid are Cl- and HCO3- (bicarbonate)"
"Plasma is the aqueous component of blood in which the blood cells are suspended"
"Plasma constitutes 55% of blood volume, while RBCs constitute the remaining 45%"
"The percent of blood volume occupied by RBCs is called the hematocrit, which averages 45%"
"Interstitial fluid is an ultrafiltrate of plasma"
"Plasma contains more proteins than interstitial fluid"
"Plasma volume can be measured by using radiolabeled albumin or Evan's blue"
"Measure Extracellular fluid volume with inulin or mannitol"
"Total body water volume can be measured using D2O or tritiated water (THO)"
"The volume of a body fluid compartment depends on the amount of solute it contains"
"Osmolarity is the concentration of osmotically active particles, expressed in mOsm/L"
"Plasma osmolarity may be estimated by Posm = (2 * Na+) + (Glucose/18) + (BUN/2.8)"
"In the steady state, intracellular osmolarity is equal to extracellular osmolarity (less than, greater than, or equal to)"
"Solutes such as NaCl and mannitol do not cross cell membranes and are thus confined to the extracellular fluid compartment"
"Volume contraction refers to a decrease in ECF volume"
"Volume expansion refers to an increase in ECF volume"
"A hyper-osmotic disturbance refers to an increase in ECF osmolarity"
"A hypo-osmotic disturbance refers to an decrease in ECF osmolarity"
"How does ECF volume change with diarrhea? Decreased"
"How does ICF volume change with diarrhea? No change"
"How does osmolarity change with diarrhea? No change"
"Diarrhea is a cause of iso-osmotic volume contraction"
"How does plasma protein concentration change with diarrhea? Increased"
"How does hematocrit change with isosmotic diarrhea? Increased"
"How does ECF volume change with sweating in a desert? Decreased"
"How does ICF volume change with sweating in a desert? Decreased"
"How does osmolarity change with sweating in a desert? Increased (sweat is hypo-osmotic)"
"Sweating in a desert is a cause of hyper-osmotic volume contraction"
"How does plasma protein concentration change with sweating in a desert? Increased"
"How does hematocrit change with sweating in a desert? No change"
"How does ECF volume change with adrenal insufficiency? Decreased"
"How does ICF volume change with hyposmotic volume contraction (e.g. adrenal insufficiency)? Increased"
"How does osmolarity change with adrenal insufficiency? Decreased (loss of Na+ due to lack of aldosterone)"
"Adrenal insufficiency is a cause of hypo-osmotic volume contraction"
"How does plasma protein concentration change with hyposmotic volume contraction (e.g. adrenal insufficiency)? Increased"
"How does hematocrit change with hyposmotic volume contraction (e.g. adrenal insufficiency)? Increased"
"How does ECF volume change with isotonic NaCl infusion? Increased"
"How does ICF volume change with isotonic NaCl infusion? No change"
"How does osmolarity change with isotonic NaCl infusion? No change"
"Isotonic NaCl infusion is a cause of iso-osmotic volume expansion"
"How does plasma protein concentration change with isotonic NaCl infusion? Decreased"
