"How does hematocrit change with isotonic NaCl infusion? Decreased"
"How does ECF volume change with excessive NaCl intake? Increased"
"How does ICF volume change with excessive NaCl intake? Decreased"
"How does osmolarity change with excessive NaCl intake? Increased"
"Excessive NaCl intake is a cause of hyper-osmotic volume expansion"
"How does plasma protein concentration change with excessive NaCl intake? Decreased"
"How does hematocrit change with excessive NaCl intake? Decreased"
"How does ECF volume change with SIADH? Increased"
"How does ICF volume change with hyposmotic volume expansion (e.g. SIADH)? Increased"
"How does osmolarity change with SIADH? Decreased (hyposmolarity)"
"SIADH is a cause of hypo-osmotic volume expansion"
"How does plasma protein concentration change with hyposmotic volume expansion (e.g. SIADH)? Decreased"
"How does hematocrit change with hyposmotic volume expansion (e.g. SIADH)? No change"
"Normal serum osmolality is ~ 290 mOsm/kg H2O"
"Renal clearance is the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per unit time"
"What equation is used to calculate renal clearance? Cx = UxV / Px"
"The renal clearance of albumin is normally zero because albumin is not filtered across glomerular capillaries"
"If Cx < GFR, there is net tubular reabsorption of X"
"If Cx > GFR, there is net secretion of X"
"The kidneys receive approximately 25% of the cardiac output"
"In both the afferent and efferent arterioles of the kidney, SNS activity causes vaso-constriction"
"What type of adrenergic receptor is found on the renal afferent and efferent arterioles? α1-adrenergic receptors"
"Which arterioles of the kidney (afferent or efferent) have more α1 receptors? Afferent arterioles"
"SNS activity and catecholamines primarily cause vasoconstriction of the renal afferent arterioles"
"What effect does SNS activity have on renal blood flow and GFR? Decreased RBF/GFR"
"In both the afferent and efferent arterioles of the kidney, angiotensin II activity causes vaso-constriction"
"Which arterioles of the kidney (afferent or efferent) are more sensitive to angiotensin II? Efferent arterioles"
"Low (normal) levels of angiotensin II primarily causes vasoconstriction of the renal efferent arterioles"
"What effect does angiotensin II activity have on renal blood flow? Decreased RBF"
"What effect does normal levels of angiotensin II have on GFR? Increased GFR"
"What effect do high levels of angiotensin II have on GFR? Decreased GFR"
"Atrial natriuretic peptide causes vaso-dilation of afferent arterioles and, to a lesser extent, vaso-constriction of efferent arterioles"
"The dilatory effect of ANP on afferent arterioles is greater than the constrictor effect on efferent arterioles"
"What effect does ANP have on renal blood flow and GFR? Increased RBF/GFR"
"Prostaglandins E2 and I2 cause vaso-dilation of both afferent and efferent arterioles in the kidney"
"What drug class inhibits synthesis of prostaglandins and thus interferes with the protective effect of PGs on renal function? NSAIDs"
"At low levels, dopamine causes vaso-dilation of renal arterioles and interlobular arteries"
"Renal blood flow (RBF) remains relatively constant between blood pressure ranges of 80 to 200 mmHg"
"Renal autoregulation is primarily controlled by changing vascular resistance of the afferent arteriole"
"The myogenic mechanism of renal autoregulation states that renal afferent arterioles contract in response to increased stretch on the arterial wall"
"The tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism of renal autoregulation states that renal afferent arterioles contract in response to vasoactive substances released by the macula densa"
"Para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) clearance can be used to calculate effective renal plasma flow (eRPF) because it is both filtered and secreted"
"Effective RPF (eRPF) under-estimates true renal plasma flow slightly (~10%)"
"Effective renal plasma flow may be estimated using the equation: eRPF = CPAH = [U]PAH * V / [P]PAH"
"Renal blood flow (RBF) is calculated using the equation: RBF = RPF / (1 - Hct)"
"The fraction of blood volume occupied by plasma = 1 - hematocrit"
"The glomerular filtration barrier is responsible for filtering the plasma according to the properties of a compounds size and net charge"
"One component of the glomerular filtration barrier is a(n) endothelial cell layer with large fenestrations"
"One component of the glomerular filtration barrier is a(n) basement membrane"
"One component of the glomerular filtration barrier is a layer of epithelial cells, called podocytes, which attach to the basement membrane by foot processes"
"Does the basement membrane of the glomerular filtration barrier normally permit plasma proteins? No"
"The basement membrane of the glomerular filtration barrier contains heparan sulfate, which acts as a(n) negative charge barrier"
"Are small, charged solutes (e.g. Na+, K+, Cl-) affected by the negatively charged glomerular filtration barrier? No"
"Are large, charged solutes (e.g. plasma proteins) affected by the negatively charged glomerular filtration barrier? Yes"
"In nephrotic syndrome, the charge barrier of the glomerular filtration barrier is lost"
"Loss of the charge barrier of the glomerular filtration barrier (e.g. nephrotic syndrome) results in protein-uria"
"The Starling equation may be used to calculate glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and states that GFR = Kf [(PGC - PBS) - πGC]"
"What does Kf represent in regards to GFR (fluid exchange)? Permeability to water"
"What two factors contribute to the Kf of a glomerular capillary? Water permeability and total surface area"
"What does PGC represent in regards to GFR (fluid exchange)? Glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure"
"What does PBS represent in regards to GFR (fluid exchange)? Bowman's space hydrostatic pressure"
"What does πGC represent in regards to GFR (fluid exchange)? Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure"
"The oncotic pressure of Bowman's space (πBS) normally equals zero"
"How does the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure (PGC) change along the length of the glomerular capillaries? Remains constant"
"How does the glomerular capillary oncotic pressure (πGC) change along the length of the glomerular capillaries? Increases"
"At the end of a glomerular capillary, the ultrafiltration pressure equals zero, a point called filtration equilibrium"
"Which Starling force changes, causing filtration equilbrium at the end of a glomerular capillary? Capillary oncotic pressure (πC)"
"What effect does afferent arteriolar constriction have on RPF? Decreased"
"What effect does afferent arteriolar constriction have on GFR? Decreased"
"What effect does efferent arteriolar constriction have on RPF? Decreased"
"What effect does efferent arteriolar constriction have on GFR? Increased"
"What effect does increased plasma protein concentration (πGC) have on GFR? Decreased GFR"
"What effect does increased plasma protein concentration (πGC) have on RPF? No change"
"What effect does decreased plasma protein concentration (πGC) have on GFR? Increased GFR"
"What effect does decreased plasma protein concentration (πGC) have on RPF? No change"
"What effect does constriction of the ureter have on GFR? Decreased GFR"
"What effect does constriction of the ureter have on RPF? No change"
"Inulin clearance can be used to calculate GFR because it is freely filtered and is not reabsorbed or secreted"
"Glomerular filtration rate may be estimated using the equation: GFR = Cinulin = [U]inulin * V / [P]inulin"
"What is the approximate normal GFR (mL/min)? 100 mL/min"
"In addition to inulin, creatinine clearance may also be used to estimate GFR"
"Creatinine clearance slightly over-estimates GFR because creatinine is moderately secreted by renal tubules"
"Volume contraction results in decreased renal perfusion with consequent decreased GFR, thus increasing nitrogenous waste products in the blood (prerenal azotemia)"
"In prerenal azotemia, decreased GFR causes increased levels of BUN and serum creatinine"
"In prerenal azotemia, there is a(n) increase in the ratio of BUN/creatinine to more than 20"
"The filtration fraction may be calculated using the equation FF = GFR / RPF"
"The value for the filtration fraction is normally about 0.20 (20%)"
"Increased filtration fraction causes increased protein concentration (and thus πc) of peritubular capillary blood"
"What effect does afferent arteriolar constriction have on filtration fraction? No change"
"What effect does efferent arteriolar constriction have on filtration fraction? Increased FF"
"What effect does increased plasma protein concentration (πGC) have on filtration fraction? Decreased FF"
"What effect does decreased plasma protein concentration (πGC) have on filtration fraction? Increased FF"
"What effect does constriction of the ureter have on filtration fraction? Decreased FF"
"What effect does dehydration have on GFR? Decreased GFR"
"What effect does dehydration have on RPF? Decreased RPF"
"What effect does dehydration have on filtration fraction? Increased FF"
"Fluid exits PCT cells and enters the peritubular capillaries via the process of reabsorption"
"Fluid exits peritubular capillaries and enters PCT cells via the process of secretion"
"The sum of filtration, secretion, and reabsorption is excretion"
"The amount of substance filtered in Bowman's space per unit time is called the filtered load"
"Filtered load (mg/min) can be calculated using the equation: Filtered load = GFR (mL/min) * [Px] (mg/mL)"
"Excretion rate can be calculated using the equation: Excretion rate = V * [U]x"
"If the filtered load is less than the excretion rate, there has been net secretion::reabsorption or secretion"
"If the filtered load is greater than the excretion rate, there has been net reabsorption::reabsorption or secretion"
"The rate of reabsorption is equal to filtered load - excretion rate"
"The rate of secretion is equal to excretion rate - filtered load"
"Glucose is reabsorbed in the early PCT by Na+/glucose (SGLT) cotransporters"
"What type of transport mechanism is Na+/glucose cotransport? Secondary active transport"
"Glucose in the cells of the PCT enter the peritubular capillary blood through GLUT1 and GLUT2 transporters"
"What type of transport mechanism is glucose transport through GLUT1 and GLUT2? Facilitated diffusion"
"Glucose at a normal plasma level (60 - 120 mg/dL) is completely reabsorbed in the PCT"
"The plasma concentration at which glucose is first excreted in the urine is called threshold"
"In adults, glucosuria begins (threshold) at a plasma glucose of ~ 200 mg/dL"
"The point at which all glucose transporters in the PCT are fully saturated is known as the transport maximum (Tm)"
"In adults, all glucose transporters are fully saturated (Tm) at a plasma glucose of ~ 350 mg/dL"
"All glucose transporters are fully saturated (Tm) at a rate of ~ 375 mg/min"
"The region of substance clearance (e.g. glucose) between threshold and Tm is known as splay"
"The phenomenon of splay occurs due to heterogeneity of the nephrons"
"What pathology is commonly associated with glucosuria? Diabetes mellitus"
"What non-pathologic state is commonly associated with glucosuria? Pregnancy"
"Normal pregnancy may decrease the ability of the PCT to reabsorb glucose and amino acids by increasing GFR"
"In the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron, 50% of the filtered urea is reabsorbed by simple diffusion"
"In the thin descending limb (Henle's loop) of the nephron, urea is secreted by simple diffusion"
"The thick ascending limb, distal tubule, and cortical/outer medullary collecting ducts are impermeable to urea (permeable or impermeable)"
"In the inner medullary collecting ducts, 70% of the filtered urea is reabsorbed via facilitated diffusion (if ADH is present)"
"In the inner medullary collecting ducts, urea is reabsorbed by the UT1 transporter, which is activated by ADH"
"At acidic urine pH, the HA form of a weak acid exists, thus decreasing excretion"
"At alkaline urine pH, the A- form of a weak acid exists, thus increasing excretion"
"At alkaline urine pH, the B form of a weak base exists, thus decreasing excretion"
"At acidic urine pH, the BH+ form of a weak base exists, thus increasing excretion"
"With regards to renal physiology, what does [TF] stand for? Concentration in tubular fluid"
"The [TF/P]x ratio compares the concentration of a substance in tubular fluid with its concentration in systemic plasma"
"For any freely filtered substance, the [TF/P]x at Bowman's space is equal to 1.0"
"[TF/P]x = 1 when the solute and water are reabsorbed at the same rate"
"[TF/P]x < 1 when the solute is reabsorbed more quickly than water"
"[TF/P]x > 1 when the solute is reabsorbed less quickly than water"
"[TF/P]x > 1 when the solute is secreted into the tubular fluid"
"The [TF/P]inulin ratio is used as a marker for water reabsorption along the nephron"
"Tubular inulin increases in concentration along the PCT as a result of water reabsorption"
"The fraction of filtered water absorbed may be measured using the equation: "
"The [TF/P]x/[TF/P]inulin ratio gives the fraction of filtered load remaining of a solute at any point along the nephron"
"The bulk of Na+ reabsorption occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule (67%)"
"The proximal tubule is characterized by iso-osmotic reabsorption"
"HCO3- is the major anion reabsorbed in the early PCT"
"Usually, 100% of glucose and amino acids are reabsorbed in the early PCT"
"Phosphate is primarily reabsorbed in the early PCT through Na+-phosphate cotransport"
"Citrate is primarily reabsorbed in the early PCT through Na+-citrate cotransport"
"Lactate is primarily reabsorbed in the early PCT through Na+-lactate cotransport"
"H+ is secreted into the lumen of the early PCT via the Na+-H+ exchanger, where it combines with filtered HCO3-, forming H2CO3"
"In the lumen of the early PCT, H2CO3 is converted into H2O and CO2 via the enzyme carbonic anhydrase"
"The H2O and CO2 in the lumen of the early PCT (from H2CO3) is reabsorbed into::excreted out or reabsorbed into the cell"
"Inside the cells of the early PCT, H2O and CO2 form H2CO3, which then dissociates into H+ and HCO3-"
"The HCO3- inside the cells of the early PCT (from H2CO3) is reabsorbed (into the blood) via facilitated diffusion"
"The H+ inside the cells of the early PCT (from H2CO3) is re-secreted (into the lumen) by the Na+-H+ exchanger"
"Na+-glucose and Na+-amino acid cotransport create a lumen-negative potential difference across cells of the early PCT"
"Cl- is the major anion reabsorbed in the late PCT of the nephron"
"Cl- is partially reabsorbed via the Cl--formate- anion exchanger in the luminal membrane of the late PCT"
"In the late PCT, Na+ reabsorption may occur through the Na+-H+ exchange"
"What is the driving force for reabsorption of NaCl in the late PCT? High Cl- gradient"
"Cl- is partially reabsorbed by diffusion through tight junctions between cells of the late PCT"
"The major solutes absorbed in the proximal tubule are NaCl and NaHCO3"
"Does solute follow water reabsorption, or does water follow solute reabsorption? Water follows solute"
"How is Na+ pumped out of the cell of the proximal tubule and into the blood? Na+-K+-ATPase pump"
"What is the major Starling force driving reabsorption into the peritubular capillaries of the proximal tubule? High capillary oncotic pressure (πC)"
"The [TF/P]Na and [TF/P]osmolarity ratios both remain at 1 over the course of the PCT"
"The [TF/P]Cl ratio initially increases over the course of the PCT"
"The [TF/P]inulin ratio increases over the course of the PCT"
"The [TF/P]HCO3 ratio decreases over the course of the PCT"
"The [TF/P]glucose and [TF/P]AA ratios decrease over the course of the PCT"
"The major regulatory mechanism of the proximal tubule is glomerulotubular balance"
"Glomerulotubular balance describes a balance between filtration in the glomerulus and reabsorption in the proximal tubule"
"ECF volume expansion produces a(n) increase in capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc)"
"The effects of ECF volume expansion on the Starling forces result in decreased fractional reabsorption of isosmotic fluid in the proximal tubule"
"ECF volume contraction produces a(n) decrease in capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc)"
"The effects of ECF volume contraction on the Starling forces result in increased fractional reabsorption of isosmotic fluid in the proximal tubule"
"ECF volume contraction produces a(n) increase in capillary oncotic pressure (πC)"
"ECF volume expansion produces a(n) decrease in capillary oncotic pressure (πC)"
"The thin descending limb (loop of Henle) is permeable to water"
"The thin descending limb (loop of Henle) is impermeable to Na+"
"In the thin descending limb (loop of Henle), tubular fluid becomes progressively hyper-osmotic as it descends"
"The thin descending limb absorbs water passively::actively or passively"
"The thin and thick ascending limbs (loop of Henle) are impermeable to water"
"The thin and thick ascending limbs (loop of Henle) are permeable to Na+"
"In the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle), tubular fluid becomes progressively hypo-osmotic as it ascends"
"The thin ascending limb absorbs Na+ passively::actively or passively"
"The thick ascending limb absorbs Na+ actively::actively or passively"
"The thick ascending limb (of Henle) normally reabsorbs approximately 10-20% of the filtered Na+"
"The Na+ reabsorption mechanism of the thick ascending limb is load-dependent (increased Na+ delivery causes increased reabsorption)"
"Na+ is reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb (of Henle) via the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter in the luminal membrane"
"In addition to Na+, what two other ions are reabsorbed through the lumen of the thick ascending limb? K+, Cl- (Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter)"
"What type of transport mechanism is Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter? Secondary active transport"
"How is Na+ extruded out of the cell of the thick ascending limb and into the blood? Na+-K+-ATPase pump"
"How is Cl- extruded out of the cell of the thick ascending limb and into the blood? Diffusion down its electrochemical gradient (via membrane channels)"
"How is K+ extruded out of the cell of the thick ascending limb and into the blood? Diffusion down its electrochemical gradient (via membrane channels)"
"Some K+ in the cells of the thick ascending limb diffuse back into the lumen, creating a lumen positive potential difference"
"The thick ascending limb (of Henle) is the site of action of loop diuretics"
"Loop diuretics attach to the Cl--binding site of the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter"
"Travel through the thick ascending limb (of Henle) results in dilution::concentration or dilution of the tubular fluid"
"After the thick ascending limb, the [TF/P]Na and [TF/P]osmolarity are both < 1.0"
"The early DCT normally reabsorbs approximately 5% of the filtered Na+"
"Na+ is reabsorbed in the early DCT via the Na+-Cl- cotransporter in the luminal membrane"
"In addition to Na+, what other ion is reabsorbed through the lumen of the early DCT? Cl- (Na+-Cl- cotransporter)"
"How is Na+ extruded out of the cell of the early DCT and into the blood? Na+-K+-ATPase pump"
"How is Cl- extruded out of the cell of the early DCT and into the blood? Diffusion down its electrochemical gradient (via membrane channels)"
"The early DCT is always impermeable::permeability to water"
"Travel through the early DCT results in dilution::concentration or dilution of the tubular fluid"
"The early DCT is the site of action of thiazide diuretics"
"Thiazide diuretics attach to the Cl--binding site of the Na+-Cl- cotransporter"
"What are the two main cell types of the late distal tubule and collecting duct? Principal cells, α-intercalated cells"
"The principal cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct reabsorb Na+ and H2O"
"The principal cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct secrete K+"
"The α-intercalated cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct reabsorb K+"
"The α-intercalated cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct secrete H+"
"The late distal convoluted tubule and collecting ducts normally reabsorb approximately 3% of the filtered Na+"
"Na+ is reabsorbed in the principal cells of the late DCT and collecting duct via the epithelial Na+ channels in the luminal membrane"
"How is Na+ extruded out of the cells of the late DCT & collecting duct and into the blood? Na+-K+-ATPase pump"
"Aldosterone leads to increased epithelial Na+ channel (ENaC) activity"
"Aldosterone leads to increased apical K+ conductance"
"In principal cells, increased ENaC activity (due to aldosterone) causes increased lumen negativity::charge"
"Increased lumen negativity in principal cells causes increased K+ secretion"
"K+-sparing diuretics inhibit Na+ reabsorption in the principal cells of the late DCT and collecting ducts"
"In response to increased Na+ intake (and ECF volume), there is decreased sympathetic activity"
"In response to increased Na+ intake (and ECF volume), there is increased ANP activity"
"In response to increased Na+ intake (and ECF volume), there is decreased peritubular capillary oncotic pressure"
"In response to increased Na+ intake (and ECF volume), there is decreased renin-angiotensin-aldosterone activity"
"Insulin causes K+ to shift into cells, causing hypokalemia"
"How does insulin cause K+ to shift into cells? Increased Na+-K+ ATPase"
"Insulin deficiency (e.g. T1DM) causes K+ to shift out of cells, causing hyperkalemia"
"What acid-base disturbance is associated with hypokalemia? Alkalosis"
"What acid-base disturbance is associated with hyperkalemia? Acidosis"
"Acid-base disturbances may affect serum K+ levels via altering activity and directionality of the H+-K+ exchanger"
"Alkalosis may cause K+ to shift into cells, causing hypokalemia"
"Acidosis may cause K+ to shift out of cells, causing hyperkalemia"
"α-adrenergic agonists cause K+ to shift out of cells, causing hyperkalemia"
"β-adrenergic antagonists cause K+ to shift out of cells, causing hyperkalemia"
"β-adrenergic agonists cause K+ to shift into cells, causing hypokalemia"
"α-adrenergic antagonists cause K+ to shift into cells, causing hypokalemia"
"How do β-adrenergic agonists cause K+ to shift into cells? Increased Na+-K+ ATPase activity"
"Hyper-osmolarity may cause K+ to shift out of cells, causing hyperkalemia"
"Hypo-osmolarity may cause K+ to shift into cells, causing hypokalemia"
"Lysis of cells may cause K+ to shift out of cells, causing hyperkalemia"
"Exercise may cause K+ to shift out of cells"
"The bulk of K+ reabsorption occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule (67%)"
"Approximately 20% of K+ reabsorption occurs in the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle)"
"Which areas of the nephron are responsible for adjustments of K+ excretion? Late distal tubule, Collecting ducts::2"
"When a person is on a low K+ diet, K+ can be reabsorbed in the terminal nephron segments by the α-intercalated cells"
"K+ reabsorption in the α-intercalated cells occurs through the H+-K+ ATPase pump"
"What type of transport mechanism is the H+-K+ ATPase? Primary active transport"
"When a person has high K+ levels, K+ can be secreted in the terminal nephron segments by the principal cells"
"The magnitude of K+ secretion in the principal cells is determined by the size of the electrochemical gradient for K+ across the luminal membrane"
"On a high K+ diet, K+ secretion increases"
"On a low K+ diet, K+ secretion is decreased"
"Hyperaldosteronism increases K+ secretion and causes hypo-kalemia"
"Hypoaldosteronism decreases K+ secretion and causes hyper-kalemia"
"Thiazide and loop diuretics increase K+ excretion and cause hypo-kalemia"
"Thiazide and loop diuretics increase delivery of Na+ to principal cells"
"Increased Na+ delivery to principal cells (e.g. thiazide and loop diuretics) causes increased K+ secretion"
"Thiazide and loop diuretics increase flow rate through the late DCT and collecting duct, thus decreasing luminal K+ concentration"
"K+-sparing diuretics decrease K+ secretion and cause hyper-kalemia"
"Increased luminal anions (e.g. HCO3-) may cause a(n) increase in K+ secretion and thus hypo-kalemia"
"After the α subunit is bound by GTP (cellular signaling), the α-GTP subunit detaches from its respective G protein (i.e. Gs, Gi, or Gq)"
"85% of the filtered phosphate is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule"
"Un-reabsorbed phosphate (15%) serves as a urinary buffer for H+"
"PTH is a hormone that inhibits Na+-phosphate cotransport in the proximal tubule"
"PTH action causes increased urinary cAMP and phosphat-uria"
"What percent of plasma Ca2+ is filtered across glomerular capillaries? 60% (40% bound to plasma proteins)"
"The bulk of Ca2+ reabsorption occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule (67%)"
"The thick ascending limb (loop of Henle) is responsible for approximately 25% of Ca2+ reabsorption"
"Ca2+ is reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb (on Henle) via a(n) paracellular route"
"What drives Ca2+ reabsorption in the thick ascending limb (of Henle)? Lumen-positive potential difference"
"Loop diuretics indirectly inhibit Ca2+ and Mg2+ reabsorption in the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle)"
"What effect do loop diuretics have on serum Ca2+ levels? Decreased"
"The distal tubule is responsible for approximately 8% of Ca2+ reabsorption"
"What is the site of regulation for Ca2+ reabsorption? Distal tubule"
"Parathyroid hormone stimulates Ca2+-Na+ exchange in the basolateral membrane of distal tubule cells"
"PTH action causes hypo-calciuria"
"Thiazide diuretics stimulate Ca2+ reabsorption in the distal tubule"
"What effect do thiazide diuretics have on serum Ca2+ levels? Increased"
"The bulk of Mg2+ reabsorption occurs in the thick ascending limb (of Henle) (60%)"
"Mg2+ is reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb (on Henle) via a(n) paracellular route"
"What drives Mg2+ reabsorption in the thick ascending limb (of Henle)? Lumen-positive potential difference"
"What effect do loop diuretics have on serum Mg2+ levels? Decreased (hypomagnesemia)"
"The proximal tubule of the nephron is responsible for approximately 30% of Mg2+ reabsorption"
"The distal tubule is responsible for approximately 5% of Mg2+ reabsorption"
"Changes in osmolarity are sensed by osmoreceptors in the anterior hypothalamus"
"Stimulation of hypothalamic osmoreceptors stimulates thirst and secretion of ADH"
"The corticopapillary osmotic gradient is the gradient of osmolarity from the cortex (300 mOsm/L) to the papilla (1200 mOsm/L)"
"The corticopapillary osmotic gradient is established, in part, by countercurrent multiplication"
"In the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle), osmolarity of the interstitial fluid increases (\single effect\\")\""
"In the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle), osmolarity of the tubular fluid decreases"
"ADH increases activity of the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter"
"The corticopapillary osmotic gradient is established, in part, by the urea cycle"
"The cortical and outer medullary collecting ducts are permeable to H2O and impermeable to urea (ADH present)"
"How does the [TF]urea change in the cortical and outer medullary collecting ducts (ADH present)? Increased [TF]urea"
"The inner medullary collecting duct is permeable to both H2O and urea (ADH present)"
"What effect does the urea cycle have on interstitial fluid osmolarity? Increased osmolarity"
"ADH enhances the activity of the urea cycle"
"In the absence of ADH, the principal cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct are impermeable to water"
"In the presence of ADH, aquaporin 2 channels are inserted in the luminal membrane of principal cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct"
"Hyper-osmotic urine is produced when the circulating levels of ADH are high"
"In the proximal tubule, [TF/P]osm = 1"
"In the late distal tubule, [TF/P]osm = 1 (high ADH)"
"In the collecting duct, [TF/P]osm > 1 (high ADH)"
"The thick ascending limb (loop of Henle) is also known as the diluting segment"
"The early distal tubule is also known as the cortical diluting segment"
"Hypo-osmotic urine is produced when the circulating levels of ADH are low"
"In the absence of ADH, the corticopapillary osmotic gradient is smaller::larger or smaller"
"The early distal tubule is impermeable to H2O"
"Without ADH, the late distal tubule and collecting ducts are impermeable to H2O"
"In the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle), TF/Posm < 1"
"In the early distal tubule, [TF/P]osm < 1"
"In the late distal tubule, [TF/P]osm < 1 (low ADH)"
"In the collecting duct, [TF/P]osm < 1 (low ADH)"
"Free water is defined as distilled water that is free of solutes"
"Free-water clearance (CH2O) is used to estimate the ability to concentrate or dilute the urine"
"In the absence of ADH, free-water clearance (CH2O) is positive"
"In the presence of ADH, free-water clearance (CH2O) is negative"
"What equation may be used to calculate free-water clearance (CH2O)? "
"When CH2O is zero, urine is iso-osmotic relative to plasma"
"A patient taking loop diuretics may have a CH2O = 0"
"When CH2O is positive, urine is hypo-osmotic relative to plasma"
"When CH2O is negative, urine is hyper-osmotic relative to plasma"
"Cholinomimetic drugs mimic the neurotransmitter acetylcholine"
"Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors are found on autonomic ganglia"
"Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors are found on motor end plates at the NMJ of skeletal muscle"
"Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors are found on the adrenal gland"
"Muscarinic::Muscarinic or Nicotinergic? acetylcholine receptors are found in effector tissues (e.g. heart, smooth muscle, brain, glands)"
"Nicotinic Ach receptors are ligand-gated Na+/K+ (ion) channels"
"Muscarinic Ach receptors are G-protein coupled receptors"
"What G-protein is the M1 muscarinic receptor coupled to? Gq"
"What G-protein is the M2 muscarinic receptor coupled to? Gi"
"What G-protein is the M3 muscarinic receptor coupled to? Gq"
"Gq proteins activate the IP3-DAG signaling cascade"
"Gi proteins inhibit the cAMP signaling cascade"
"M1 muscarinic receptors are found in the - Central NS - Enteric NS"
"What organ does the M2 receptor primarily effect? Heart"
"M2 muscarinic receptors are found in the atria, SA node, and AV node of the heart"
"What is the effect of M2 muscarinic agonists on heart rate? Decreased HR (SA node)"
"What is the effect of M2 muscarinic agonists on conduction velocity? Decreased CV (AV node)"
"What is the effect of M2 muscarinic agonists on heart contractility? Decreased atrial contractility"
"The M3 muscarinic receptor is found in glands, the bladder, and smooth muscle"
"In healthy patients, M3 receptor activation indirectly causes vaso-dilation via release of nitric oxide"
"In atherosclerotic patients, M3 receptor activation directly causes vaso-constriction"
"What drug class does bethanechol belong to? Cholinomimetics (muscarinic agonists)"
"Bethanechol activates bowel and bladder smooth muscle"
"Bethanechol is a cholinomimetic agent used to treat post-operative and neurogenic ileus"
"Bethanechol is a cholinomimetic agent used to treat urinary retention"
"What drug class does pilocarpine belong to? Cholinomimetics (muscarinic agonists)"
"Pilocarpine is a potent stimulator of tears, sweat, and salivary secretion"
"Pilocarpine contracts the ciliary muscle, which may be used to treat open-angle glaucoma"
"Pilocarpine contracts pupillary sphincter muscle, which may be used to treat closed-angle glaucoma"
"Carbachol contracts pupillary sphincter muscle, which may be used to treat closed-angle glaucoma"
"Is carbachol a muscarinic or nicotinic Ach agonist? Both :)"
"What drug class does methacholine belong to? Cholinomimetics (muscarinic agonists)"
"Methacholine challenge instigates asthma for pulmonary testing"
"Cholinomimetics cause contraction of bronchial smooth muscle, which may exacerbate asthma or COPD"
"Varenicline is a(n) nicotinic receptor partial agonist used for smoking cessation"
"The normal range for arterial pH is 7.35 to 7.45 compatible with life is between 6.8 and 8"
"What is the normal average arterial pH? 7.4"
"CO2 is also known as volatile acid"
"CO2 combines with H2O to form the weak acid H2CO3 via the enzyme carbonic anhydrase"
"H2CO3 dissociates into H+ and HCO3-"
"Non-volatile acids are also called fixed acids"
"One non-volatile acid is sulfuric acid, which is generated from metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids (protein)"
"One non-volatile acid is phosphoric acid, which is generated from metabolism of phospholipids"
"What non-volatile acid may be elevated with strenuous exercise? Lactic acid"
"What non-volatile acid may be elevated with aspirin overdose? Salicylic acid"
"What non-volatile acid may be elevated with methanol ingestion? Formic acid"
"What non-volatile acid may be elevated with ethylene glycol ingestion? Oxalic acid"
"A(n) buffer prevents a significant change in pH when H+ ions are added to or removed from a solution"
"The Henderson-Hasselbalch equation for any buffer states that: pH = pK + log [A-]/[HA]"
"A strong acid (e.g. HCl) has a(n) lower pK than a weak acid"
"When the pH of a solution equals the pK, the concentrations of the [A-] and [HA] form of the buffer are equal"
"Buffers are most effective within 1.0 pH unit of the pK of the buffer"
"The major buffers of the extracellular fluid are HCO3- and phosphate"
"The [A-] form of the bicarbonate buffer is HCO3-"
"The [HA] form of the bicarbonate buffer is CO2, which is in equilibrium with H2CO3"
"The Henderson-Hasselbalch equation for the HCO3-/CO2 buffer states that: pH = 6.1 + log ([HCO3-] / (0.03 * PCO2))"
"The pK of the HCO3-/CO2 buffer is 6.1"
"The pK of the H2PO4-/HPO42- buffer pair is 6.8"
"Plasma proteins may act as a buffer for H+, which subsequently affects Ca2+ levels as well"
"The most significant intracellular buffer for H+ is deoxyhemoglobin"
"Which is a better intracellular buffer in physiologic pH range, oxy- or deoxyhemoglobin? Deoxyhemoglobin"
"In the lumen of the early PCT, H2CO3 is converted to CO2 and H2O by brush border carbonic anhydrase"
"In the cells of the early PCT, H2CO3 is converted to CO2 and H2O by intracellular carbonic anhydrase"
"HCO3- is transported from the cells of proximal tubule into the blood by Na+-HCO3- cotransport and Cl--HCO3- exchange"
"Does reabsorption of HCO3- result in net secretion of H+? No"
"When the plasma [HCO3-] is greater than 40 mEq/L, the reabsorption mechanisms are fully saturated and excess HCO3- is secreted"
"ECF volume expansion results in decreased HCO3- reabsorption"
"ECF volume contraction results in increased HCO3- reabsorption"
"Angiotensin II stimulates Na+-H+ exchange in the proximal tubule"
"What effect does angiotensin II have on HCO3- reabsorption? Increased reabsorption"
"Increased PCO2 (respiratory acidosis) results in increased HCO3- reabsorption"
"Decreased PCO2 (respiratory alkalosis) results in decreased HCO3- reabsorption"
"Fixed H+ (e.g. from protein and phospholipid catabolism) is excreted in the urine as titratable acid (e.g. H2PO4-) and NH4+"
"Titratable acid is primarily excreted in the α-intercalated cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct"
"H+ secretion from α-intercalated cells occurs via the luminal membrane H+ ATPase and H+-K+ ATPase pumps"
"In the lumen of late distal tubule and collecting duct, secreted H+ combines with the HPO4- to form H2PO4, which is a(n) titratable acid"
"For each H+ excreted as titratable acid, one new HCO3- is synthesized and reabsorbed"
"The amount of H+ excreted as titratable acid depends on the amount of urinary buffer present and the pK of the buffer"
"In the cells of the proximal tubule, the enzyme glutaminase metabolizes glutamine to glutamate and NH4+"
"In the proximal tubule, glutamate is ultimately metabolized to HCO3-, which is reabsorbed"
"For each NH4+ generated in the proximal tubule, one new HCO3- is synthesized and reabsorbed"
"In the proximal tubule cells, NH4+ is in equilibrium with NH3 and H+"
"Which form (NH4+ or NH3) is secreted into the lumen of the cells of the proximal tubule? NH3"
"The H+ from NH4+ (glutamine breakdown) in the proximal tubule cells is secreted into the lumen via the Na+-H+ exchanger"
"In the lumen of the proximal tubule, NH3 and H+ combine to form NH4+"
"A portion of the NH4+ from the proximal tubule is excreted directly in the urine"
"A portion of NH4+ from the proximal tubule is reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle)"
"In the thick ascending limb, NH4+ is reabsorbed and added to the corticopapillary osmotic gradient"
"In the thick ascending limb, NH4+ may be reabsorbed by substituting for K+ on the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter"
"In the α-intercalated cells of the collecting duct, NH3 and H+ are secreted into the lumen"
"In the lumen of the collecting duct, NH3 and H+ form NH4+, which is trapped in the tubular fluid and excreted (\diffusion trapping\\")\""
"NH3 is secreted into the lumen of the collecting duct from the medullary interstitial fluid"
"As pH of the tubular fluid decreases, the excretion of H+ as NH4+ increases"
"In chronic acidosis, there is an adaptive increase in NH3 synthesis in the cells of the proximal tubule"
"Hyper-kalemia inhibits NH3 synthesis"
"Hypo-kalemia stimulates NH3 synthesis"
"What is the normal average blood HCO3- concentration (mEq/L)? 24 mEq/L"
"The plasma anion gap represents unmeasured ions in serum and is equal to [Na+] - ([HCO3-] + [Cl-])::formula"
"The range of normal values for the plasma anion gap is 8 to 16 mEq/L"
"The plasma anion gap is useful primarily in the differential diagnosis of metabolic acidosis"
"If the \lost\\" HCO3- in metabolic acidosis is replaced by Cl-"
"If the \lost\\" HCO3- in metabolic acidosis is replaced by unmeasured ions"
"Osmolar gap is the difference between measured plasma osmolarity and estimated plasma osmolarity"
"Which acid-base disturbance is caused by decreased HCO3-? Metabolic acidosis"
"The primary disturbance in metabolic acidosis is a(n) decrease in HCO3-"
"Decreased HCO3- (metabolic acidosis) causes a(n) decrease in arterial pH"
"Decreased arterial pH (metabolic acidosis) causes compensatory hyper-ventilation with consequent decreased PCO2"
"The arterial blood profile seen in compensated metabolic acidosis is: pH: decreased [HCO3-]: decreased PCO2: decreased"
"Hyperventilation as a respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis is known as Kussmaul breathing"
"Respiratory compensation in response to metabolic acidosis or alkalosis is immediate::timing"
"Which acid-base disturbance is caused by increased HCO3-? Metabolic alkalosis"
"The primary disturbance in metabolic alkalosis is a(n) increase in HCO3- OR a(n) decrease in H+"
"Increased HCO3- causes a(n) increase in arterial pH"
"Increased arterial pH (metabolic alkalosis) causes compensatory hypo-ventilation with consequent increased PCO2"
"The arterial blood profile seen in compensated metabolic alkalosis is: pH: increased [HCO3-]: increased PCO2: increased"
"If metabolic alkalosis is accompanied by ECF volume contraction, the reabsorption of HCO3- increases, worsening the metabolic alkalosis"
"The primary disturbance in respiratory acidosis is hypo-ventilation, which results in increased CO2"
"Increased CO2 causes a(n) decrease in arterial pH"
"Increased CO2 (respiratory acidosis) causes a(n) increase in HCO3- by mass action"
"The arterial blood profile seen in compensated respiratory acidosis is: pH: decreased [HCO3-]: increased PCO2: increased"
"Renal correction of respiratory acidosis includes increased excretion of excess fixed H+ as titratable acid and NH4+"
"Renal correction of respiratory acidosis includes increased reabsorption of \new\\" HCO3-\""
"Metabolic compensation in response to respiratory acidosis or alkalosis is delayed::timing"
"The primary disturbance in respiratory alkalosis is hyper-ventilation, which results in decreased CO2"
"Decreased CO2, secondary to hyperventilation, causes a(n) increase in arterial pH"
"Decreased CO2 (respiratory alkalosis) causes a(n) decrease in HCO3- by mass action"
"The arterial blood profile seen in compensated respiratory alkalosis is: pH: increased [HCO3-]: decreased PCO2: decreased"
"Renal compensation of respiratory alkalosis includes decreased excretion of fixed H+ as titratable acid and NH4+"
"Renal compensation of respiratory alkalosis includes decreased reabsorption of \new\\" HCO3-\""
"The compensatory response to an acid-base disturbance is always in the same::(same or different) direction as the original acid-base disturbance"
"Winters formula is used to calculate the predicted respiratory compensation for a simple metabolic acidosis"
"Winter's formula for simple metabolic acidosis states that: PCO2 = 1.5[HCO3-] + 8 +/- 2"
"If the measured PCO2 > predicted PCO2 using Winters formula, then the metabolic acidosis has a concomitant respiratory acidosis"
"If the PCO2 < predicted PCO2 using Winters formula, then the metabolic acidosis has a concomitant respiratory alkalosis"
"Horseshoe kidney occurs when the inferior poles of the kidney are fused together"
"What is the most common congenital renal anomaly? Horseshoe kidney"
"As horseshoe kidneys ascend from the pelvis during fetal development, they get trapped under the inferior mesenteric artery and remain low in the abdomen"
"Is kidney function in horseshoe kidney normal or abnormal? Normal"
"Horseshoe kidney is associated with increased risk for kidney stones and infection"
"What sex chromosome disorder is associated with horseshoe kidney? Turner syndrome"
"Which congenital kidney disease is associated with chromosomal aneuploidy (e.g. trisomy 13, 18, 21)? Horseshoe kidney"
"Horseshoe kidney is rarely associated with renal cancer"
"What congenital kidney disease is associated with unilateral or bilateral absent kidney and ureter formation? Renal agenesis"
"Renal agenesis occurs due to failure of the ureteric buds to develop and induce differentiation of metanephric mesenchyme"
"Renal agenesis is often diagnosed prenatally via ultrasound"
"Unilateral renal agenesis leads to hypertrophy of the existing kidney"
"Hyperfiltration of the existing kidney in unilateral renal agenesis increases risk of renal failure later in life"
"Bilateral renal agenesis increases risk for Potter sequence"
"The primary abnormality in Potter sequence is oligo-hydramnios"
"In Potter sequence, compression of the developing fetus results in a(n) flat face with low-set ears"
"Which form of polycystic kidney disease may cause Potter sequence? Autosomal recessive PKD"
"Is dysplastic kidney heritable? No"
"What cystic congenital kidney disease is non-inherited? (Multicystic) dysplastic kidney"
"Dysplastic kidney occurs due to failure of the ureteric buds to induce differentiation of metanephric mesenchyme"
"Multicystic dysplastic kidney is often diagnosed prenatally via ultrasound"
"Dysplastic kidney is characterized by a cystic kidney with abnormal tissue (especially cartilage)"
"In dysplastic kidney, cysts are usually uni-lateral"
"In polycystic kidney disease, cysts are usually bi-lateral"
"Is polycystic kidney disease heritable? Yes"
"Is polycystic kidney disease associated with enlargement of the kidneys? Yes"
"Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is characterized by cysts in the renal cortex and medulla"
"Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease is characterized by cystic dilation of the renal collecting ducts"
"The autosomal recessive form of polycystic kidney disease typically presents in infants"
"Autosomal recessive PKD presents in infants as worsening renal failure and hypertension::BP"
"Which form of PKD (autosomal dominant or recessive) is associated with hepatic cysts? Both :)"
"Autosomal recessive PKD is associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis which may lead to portal hypertension"
"What congenital renal defect may cause portal hypertension in an infant? Autosomal recessive PKD"
"The autosomal dominant form of polycystic kidney disease typically presents in the 4th or 5th decade"
"Autosomal dominant PKD may present in young adults with hypertension due to increased renin"
"Autosomal dominant PKD may present in young adults with flank pain and urinary infection"
"Autosomal dominant PKD may present in young adults as worsening renal failure and hemat-uria"
"What % of patients with autosomal dominant PKD experience progressive renal failure? 50%"
"85% of autosomal dominant PKD is due to a(n) PKD1 mutation on chromosome 16"
"15% of autosomal dominant PKD is due to a(n) PKD2 mutation on chromosome 4"
"Autosomal dominant PKD is associated with berry aneurysm, which is an important cause of death"
"Autosomal dominant and recessive PKD are associated with hepatic cysts in addition to renal cysts (benign)"
"What heart defect is associated with autosomal dominant PKD? Mitral valve prolapse"
"When patients with Autosomal Dominant PKD develop hypertension or proteinuria, you may treat with ACE inhibitors or ARBs::two types of drugs?"
"Is Autosomal Dominant Tubulointerstitial Kidney Disease (Medullary Cystic Kidney Disease) heritable? Yes"
"What is the mode of inheritance of medullary cystic kidney disease? Autosomal dominant"
"Autosomal Dominant Tubulointerstitial Kidney Disease (ADTKD) has the potential to present with cysts in the medullary collecting ducts"
"ADTKD is associated with tubulointerstitial fibrosis, resulting in shrunken kidneys"
"Patients with Autosomal Dominant Tubulointerstitial Kidney Disease often have early onset gout"
"Autosomal Dominant Tubulointerstitial Kidney Disease is associated with an inability to concentrate urine"
"What is the prognosis of Autosomal Dominant Tubulointerstitial Kidney Disease? Poor prognosis"
"What congenital renal defect is a condition of being born with only one functioning kidney (one non-functional)? Congenital solitary functioning kidney"
"Congenital solitary functioning kidney leads to hypertrophy of the functioning kidney"
"Simple renal cysts are filled with ultrafiltrate and are anechoic on ultrasound"
"Simple renal cysts are very common and account for majority of all renal masses; typically asymptomatic"
"Complex renal cysts are septated, enhanced, or have solid components on imaging"
"Complex renal cysts require follow-up or removal due to risk of renal cell carcinoma"
"Fetal kidney development begins with the pronephros, which develops by week 4"
"After the pronephros develops, it then degenerates"
"The mesonephros forms after the pronephros and functions as an interim kidney for the 1st trimester"
"The mesonephros later contributes to the male genital system"
"Which embryologic kidney becomes the permanent kidney? Metanephros"
"The metanephros first appears in the 5th week of gestation"
"Nephrogenesis continues through 32 to 36 weeks of gestation"
"The ureteric bud is derived from the caudal end of the mesonephric duct"
"The embryonic ureteric bud gives rise to the ureter, pelvises, calyces, and collecting ducts"
"The ureteric bud is fully canalized by the 10th week of gestation, allowing the metanephros to make urine"
"The embryonic metanephric mesenchyme (blastema) differentiates into renal structures from the glomerulus through the DCT"
"The embryonic metanephric mesenchyme interacts via reciprocal-inductive signaling with the ureteric bud, inducing differentiation of these tissues into their respective parts of the kidney"
"The ureteropelvic junction is the last structure of the embryologic kidney to canalize"
"What is the most common site of obstruction (hydronephrosis) in the fetal kidney? Ureteropelvic junction"
"Duplex collecting system is a congenital renal disease characterized by bifurcation of the ureteric bud before it enters the metanephric mesenchyme"
"What congenital renal disease is characterized by a Y-shaped bifid ureter? Duplex collecting system"
"Duplex collecting system may occur due to two ureteric buds reaching and interacting with one metanephric mesenchyme"
"Duplex collecting system is strongly associated with vesicoureteral reflux and/or ureteral obstruction"
"Duplex collecting system is associated with increased risk for urinary tract infection"
"The hallmark of acute kidney injury is azotemia, often with oliguria::urinary change"
"Azotemia typically refers to an increase in serum BUN and creatinine"
"Prerenal azotemia is due to decreased renal blood flow (e.g. cardiac failure, hypotension)"
"What is the effect of prerenal azotemia on GFR? Decreased GFR"
"Is BUN normally reabsorbed by the kidney? Yes"
"Is creatinine normally reabsorbed by the kidney? No"
"What is the normal serum BUN:creatinine ratio? ~ 15:1"
"In prerenal azotemia, the BUN:creatinine ratio is > 15"
"In prerenal azotemia, there is increased reabsorption of Na+ and H2O"
"How does the fractional excretion of Na+ (FENa) change in prerenal azotemia? Decreased; < 1%"
"What is the urine osmolality (mOsm/kg) in prerenal azotemia? > 500 mOsm/kg (normal)"
"What is the urine Na+ (mEq/L) in prerenal azotemia? < 20 mEq/L"
"Postrenal azotemia is due to obstruction of the urinary tract downstream from the kidney (e.g. stones, BPH, neoplasia)"
"Does postrenal azotemia occur with unilateral or bilateral obstruction? Bilateral"
"What is the effect of postrenal azotemia on GFR? Decreased GFR"
"In early postrenal azotemia, the BUN:creatinine ratio is > 15"
"What is the fractional excretion of Na+ (FENa) in early postrenal azotemia? < 1% (normal)::>2% or <1%?"
"What is the urine osmolality (mOsm/kg) in early postrenal azotemia? > 500 mOsm/kg (normal)::>500 or <350?"
"In long-standing postrenal azotemia, the BUN:creatinine ratio is < 15"
"What is the fractional excretion of Na+ (FENa) in long-standing (severe) postrenal azotemia? > 2% (elevated)::>2% or <1%?"
"What is the urine osmolality (mOsm/kg) in long-standing postrenal azotemia? < 350 mOsm/kg (low)"
"What is the urine Na+ (mEq/L) in postrenal azotemia? > 40 mEq/L*::>40 or <20?"
"Intrarenal azotemia is generally due to acute tubular necrosis or ischemia/toxins"
"What is the most common cause of acute renal failure in hospitalized patients? Acute tubular necrosis"
"What is the effect of acute tubular necrosis on GFR? Decreased GFR"
"Acute tubular necrosis is characterized histologically by loss of nuclei and detachment of tubular cells from the basement membrane"
"In acute tubular necrosis, the BUN:creatinine ratio is < 15"
"What is the fractional excretion of Na+ (FENa) in acute tubular necrosis? > 2% (elevated)"
"What is the urine osmolality (mOsm/kg) in acute tubular necrosis? < 350 mOsm/kg (low)"
"What is the urine Na+ (mEq/L) in acute tubular necrosis? > 40 mEq/L"
"Acute tubular necrosis is caused by ischemic or nephrotoxic injury"
"Acute tubular necrosis caused by ischemia is due to decreased renal blood flow"
"Acute tubular necrosis due to ischemic injury is often preceded by prerenal azotemia"
"Acute tubular necrosis due to ischemic injury most commonly affects the proximal tubule and the medullary segment of the thick ascending limb"
"Acute tubular necrosis caused by nephrotoxicity is due to toxic substances"
"Acute tubular necrosis due to nephrotoxic injury most commonly affects the proximal tubule"
"What class of anti-microbials is a common cause of acute tubular necrosis? Aminoglycosides"
"Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by heavy metals such as lead"
"Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by myoglobinuria, which can occur with crush injuries"
"Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by ingestion of ethylene glycol, which is associated with oxalate crystals in the urine"
"Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by radio-contrast dyes"
"Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by high levels of uric acid (e.g. tumor lysis syndrome)"
"What chemotherapeutic agent may cause acute tubular necrosis? Cisplatin"
"Hydration and allopurinol are used prior to initiation of chemotherapy to decrease risk of urate-induced acute tubular necrosis"
"Acute tubular necrosis is associated with granular \muddy brown\\" casts in the urine\""
"The first stage of acute tubular necrosis is the inciting event"
"The second stage of acute tubular necrosis is the maintenance phase"
"Does the maintenance phase of acute tubular necrosis present with oliguria or polyuria? Oliguria"
"How long does the maintenance phase of acute tubular necrosis last? 1-3 weeks"
"During the maintenance phase of acute tubular necrosis, there is increased risk for hyper-kalemia and uremia"
"What acid-base disturbance is associated with the maintenance phase of acute tubular necrosis? Metabolic acidosis"
"The third (final) stage of acute tubular necrosis is the recovery phase"
"Does the recovery phase of acute tubular necrosis present with oliguria or polyuria? Polyuria"
"During the recovery phase of acute tubular necrosis, there is increased risk for hypo-kalemia and renal wasting of other electrolytes and minerals"
"During the recovery phase of acute tubular necrosis, BUN and serum creatinine levels decrease"
"Acute tubular necrosis is reversible but often requires supportive dialysis due to electrolyte imbalances (e.g. hypokalemia)"
"Intrarenal azotemia is less commonly due to acute glomerulonephritis or acute interstitial nephritis"
"Acute interstitial nephritis is a drug-induced hypersensitivity reaction involving the interstitium and tubules of the kidney"
"Acute interstitial nephritis is characterized histologically by inflammatory infiltrate in the connective tissue between renal tubules"
"Acute interstitial nephritis may present with fever and rash, days to weeks after starting a drug"
"Acute interstitial nephritis is associated with hemat-uria and pyuria (classically eosinophils)"
"What physical exam finding may be associated with acute interstitial nephritis? CVA tenderness"
"Drugs that cause acute interstitial nephritis may be remembered with the 5 \P's\\" Pee (diuretics) Pain-free (NSAIDs) Penicillins (and cephalosporins) Proton pump inhibitors RifamPin\""
"What is the treatment for drug-induced acute interstitial nephritis? Cessation of the drug"
"Acute interstitial nephritis is less commonly secondary to systemic infections (e.g. mycoplasma)"
"Acute interstitial nephritis is less commonly secondary to autoimmune diseases (e.g. Sjögren's syndrome, SLE, sarcoidosis)"
"Acute interstitial nephritis may progress to renal papillary necrosis"
"Renal papillary necrosis is characterized by sloughing of necrotic renal papillae"
"Renal papillary necrosis presents with gross hemat-uria and colicky flank pain"
"In addition to hematuria, renal papillary necrosis may also present with protein-uria"
"Renal papillary necrosis may be caused by chronic analgesic abuse"
"Renal papillary necrosis may be caused by sickle cell disease or trait"
"Renal papillary necrosis may be caused by severe acute pyelonephritis"
"What endocrine pathology may cause renal papillary necrosis? Diabetes mellitus"
"Nephrotic syndrome is a group of glomerular disorders characterized by protein-uria > 3.5 g/day"
"Nephrotic syndrome results in hypoalbuminemia, which manifests as pitting edema and secondary hyperaldosteronism"
"Nephrotic syndrome results in hypogammaglobulinemia, which increases risk of infection"
"Nephrotic syndrome causes a(n) hyper-coagulable state due to loss of antithrombin III"
"Nephrotic syndrome is associated with hyper-lipidemia and hyper-cholesterolemia"
"Nephrotic syndrome is associated with frothy urine with fatty casts"
"Minimal change disease (lipoid nephrosis) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children"
"The cause of minimal change disease is often idiopathic and may be triggered by recent URI, immunization, or immune stimulus (ex. insect bite)"
"Minimal change disease (lipoid nephrosis) is rarely secondary to Hodgkin lymphoma"
"Minimal change disease is characterized by cytokine-mediated damage of foot processes and loss of glomerular basement anions"
"Minimal change disease is characterized by normal glomeruli on light microscopy"
"In minimal change disease (lipoid nephrosis), lipids may be seen in proximal tubule cells of the nephron (light microscopy)"
"Minimal change disease is characterized by effacement of foot processes on electron microscopy"
"What immunofluorescence findings are associated with minimal change disease? None (no immune complex deposits)"
"Minimal change disease is characterized by loss of albumin, but not immunoglobulin in the urine (selective proteinuria)"
"Minimal change disease has a(n) excellent response to corticosteroids"
"Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in Hispanics::ethnicity and African Americans::ethnicity"
"The cause of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is usually idiopathic, but may be secondary to: - massive obesity - interferon treatment - congenital kidney malformations that cause chronic kidney disease"
"What hematologic pathology is associated with increased risk for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis? Sickle cell disease"
"What infectious disease is associated with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis? HIV"
"Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is a type of nephrotic syndrome associated with heroin abuse"
"Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is characterized by focal and segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis on light microscopy"
"Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is characterized by effacement of foot processes on electron microscopy"
"What immunofluorescence findings are usually associated with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis? None (no immune complex deposits)"
"Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis has a(n) poor response to corticosteroids"
"Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis ultimately progresses to chronic renal failure"
"Membranous nephropathy is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in Caucasian adults"
"Primary membranous nephropathy is associated with autoantibodies against the transmembrane phospholipase A2 receptor found in high concentrations in glomerular podocytes"
"What type of nephrotic syndrome is a patient with SLE most likely to get? Membranous nephropathy"
"What infectious diseases is membranous nephropathy associated with? HBV, HCV::2"
"Membranous nephropathy may occur secondary to drugs, such as NSAIDs and penicillamine"
"Which type of nephrotic syndrome is commonly seen secondary to solid tumors? Membranous nephropathy"
"Membranous nephropathy is characterized by diffuse capillary and GBM thickening on light microscopy"
"What immunofluorescence findings are associated with membranous nephropathy? Granular deposits (immune complex deposition)"
"Membranous nephropathy is characterized by subepithelial deposits with a 'spike and dome' appearance on electron microscopy"
"Membranous nephropathy has a(n) poor response to corticosteroids"
"Membranous nephropathy ultimately progresses to chronic renal failure"
"Is membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) a nephritic or nephrotic syndrome? Can be either or both"
"Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is associated with basement membrane thickening and splitting on light microscopy"
"Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is associated with a 'tram-track' appearance on PAS and H&E stain"
"The 'tram-track' appearance associated with MPGN is due to basement membrane splitting caused by mesangial cell ingrowth"
"What immunofluorescence findings are associated with membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis? Granular deposits (immune complex deposition)"
"MPGN type I is associated with subendothelial immune complex deposits"
"MPGN type II is associated with intramembranous immune complex deposits"
"Which type of MPGN is more often associated with a 'tram track' appearance on H&E stain? Type I"
"What infectious diseases are associated with type I MPGN? HBV, HCV::2"
"Type II MPGN is also known as dense deposit disease"
"Type II MPGN is associated with C3 nephritic factor, an autoantibody that stabilizes C3 convertase"
"Type II MPGN is associated with low circulating levels of C3"
"Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis has a(n) poor response to corticosteroids"
"Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis ultimately progresses to chronic renal failure"
"Non-enzymatic glycosylation of the GBM results in hyaline arteriolosclerosis"
"Which renal arteriole is initially affected by non-enzymatic glycation? Efferent arteriole"
"What drug class is used to slow progression of hyperfiltration-induced damage in diabetic glomerulonephropathy? ACE inhibitors"
"What is the first change that occurs in the kidney in a diabetes mellitus patient? Non-enzymatic glycosylation of GBM"
"Nephrotic syndrome may be caused by systemic amyloidosis"
"The most commonly involved organ in systemic amyloidosis is the kidney"
"Where in the kidney does amyloid deposit, causing nephrotic syndrome? Mesangium"
"Amyloidosis is characterized by apple-green birefringence under polarized light after staining with Congo red"
"Nephrotic syndrome occurs due to podocyte damage disrupting the glomerular filtration charge barrier"
"Nephritic syndrome is a group of glomerular disorders characterized by glomerular inflammation and bleeding"
"Nephritic syndrome is characterized by limited protein-uria < 3.5 g/day"
"How does nephritic syndrome affect urine output? Decreased (oliguria)"
"Nephritic syndrome is associated with increased BUN and creatinine"
"Nephritic syndrome is associated with salt retention with consequent periorbital edema and hypertension"
"Nephritic syndrome may lead to hematuria and RBC casts in the urine"
"Biopsy of nephritic syndrome reveals hyper-cellular, inflamed glomeruli"
"Nephritic syndrome is typically associated with immune-complex deposition, which activates complement (e.g. C5a)"
"Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a type of nephritic syndrome that arises after a(n) group A β-hemolytic streptococcal infection of the skin (impetigo) or pharynx"
"PSGN occurs with nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococcus, which carry the M protein virulence factor and is caused by glomerular deposition of nephritogenic antigens such as SpeB"
"PSGN typically presents 2 to 4 weeks after a group A β-hemolytic streptococcal infection"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis? Type III (immune complex-mediated)"
"Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis may present with hemat-uria and cola / tea-colored urine"
"PSGN may present with peripheral and periorbital edema"
"PSGN may present with hypertension::BP"
"What demographic is more commonly associated with PSGN? Children::age group"
"Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is characterized by enlarged and hyper-cellular glomeruli on light microscopy"
"PSGN is characterized by a \lumpy bumpy (granular)\\" immunofluorescence pattern due to immune complex deposition\""
"The \lumpy-bumpy\\" appearance of PSGN on immunofluorescence is due to deposits with immune complexes consisting of IgG / IgM and C3\""
"PSGN is characterized by subepithelial immune complex \humps\\" on electron microscopy\""
"What is the treatment for post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis? Supportive (resolves spontaneously)"
"Children with PSGN rarely (1%)::frequency progress to renal failure"
"About 25% of adults with PSGN develop rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis"
"Diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis may be aided by positive strep titers/serologies"
"Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is associated with decreased levels of complement"
"Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis is a nephritic syndrome that progresses to renal failure in days to weeks"
"What is the prognosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis? Poor prognosis"
"Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis is characterized by crescents in Bowman's space of the glomeruli (light microscopy)"
"The crescents seen in RPGN are composed of fibrin and macrophages"
"Goodpasture syndrome is a form of RPGN that presents with a(n) linear pattern on immunofluorescence"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is Goodpasture syndrome? Type II HSR"
"Goodpasture syndrome occurs due to antibodies against the glomerular and alveolar basement membranes"
"Goodpasture syndrome presents with hematuria and hemoptysis"
"What demographic is associated with Goodpasture syndrome? Young adult males"
"What is the treatment for Goodpasture syndrome? Emergent plasmapheresis"
"RPGN with a granular immunofluorescence pattern is more commonly due to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis"
"RPGN with a granular immunofluorescence pattern is less commonly due to diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis"
"What type of nephritic syndrome is a patient with SLE most likely to get? Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis"
"Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis is a common cause of death in patients with SLE"
"Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis is characterized by \wire looping\\" of capillaries on light microscopy\""
"Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis is characterized by a(n) granular pattern on immunofluorescence"
"DPGN is characterized by subendothelial and sometimes intramembranous immune complexes on electron microscopy"
"The immune complexes in DPGN are IgG-based and often have C3 deposition"
"If RPGN has no immunofluorescence pattern, it is termed pauci-immune glomerulonephritis"
"Which cause of pauci-immune glomerulonephritis is associated with c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA)? Wegener granulomatosis"
"Which causes of pauci-immune glomerulonephritis are associated with p-ANCA (MPO-ANCA)? Microscopic polyangiitis, Churg-strauss syndrome::2"
"What is the most common nephropathy worldwide? IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)"
"IgA nephropathy (Berger disease) is the renal pathology associated with Henoch-Schonlein purpura"
"IgA nephropathy typically presents during childhood with episodic gross or microscopic hemat-uria or RBC casts"
"IgA nephropathy typically follows a(n) respiratory or GI tract infection"
"IgA nephropathy is characterized by mesangial proliferation on light microscopy"
"IgA nephropathy is characterized by mesangial::location immune complex deposits on electron microscopy"
"Berger disease is characterized by IgA-based immune complex deposits in the mesangium (seen with immunofluorescence)"
"IgA nephropathy (Berger disease) may slowly progress to renal failure"
"Alport syndrome is an inherited defect in type IV collagen"
"What is the most common mode of inheritance of Alport syndrome? X-linked dominant"
"Alport syndrome is characterized by thinning and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane"
"Alport syndrome often presents with a triad of ocular disturbances, isolated hematuria, and sensory hearing loss"
"Alport syndrome is associated with a \basket-weave\\" appearance on electron microscopy\""
"Urinary tract infection is an infection of the urethra, bladder, or kidney"
"UTI most commonly arises due to ascending::ascending or descending infection"
"Females::gender have increased risk for UTI due to a relatively short urethra"
"What endocrine pathology is associated with UTI? Diabetes mellitus"
"Impaired bladder emptying increases risk for UTI"
"One risk factor for UTI is sexual activity"
"One risk factor for UTI is indwelling catheters"
"Cystitis is an infection/inflammation of the bladder"
"Cystitis typically presents with dys-uria, urinary frequency, urgency, and suprapubic pain"
"Does cystitis typically present with systemic signs (e.g. fever)? No"
"Cystitis is characterized by cloudy urine with > 10::# WBCs/hpf (urinalysis)"
"Cystitis is characterized by positive leukocyte esterase due to pyuria"
"Cystitis is characterized by positive nitrites, which indicates gram negative organisms"
"The gold standard for diagnosis of cystitis is culture showing > 100,000 colony forming units"
"What infectious organism is the most common (80%) cause of cystitis? E. coli"
"The second most common infectious cause of cystitis is Staphyloccocus saprophyticus"
"What demographic is associated with Staphylococcus saprophyticus? Young, sexually active women"
"What urease positive, pneumonia-causing bacteria is a common cause of UTI? Klebsiella pneumoniae"
"Cystitis caused by Proteus mirabilis is characterized by alkaline urine (pH) with a(n) ammonia scent"
"Which bacteria is associated with endocarditis, biliary tree infection, and UTI? Enterococcus faecalis"
"Sterile pyuria is the presence of pyuria (> 10 WBCs/hpf and leukocyte esterase) with a negative urine culture"
"UTI with sterile pyuria suggests urethritis due to Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae"
"The dominant presenting sign of urethritis is dysuria"
"Pyelonephritis is an infection of the kidney"
"Acute pyelonephritis is characterized by neutrophilic infiltration of the renal interstitium"
"Acute pyelonephritis affects the cortex of the kidney with relative sparing of glomeruli/vessels"
"One risk factor for pyelonephritis is vesicoureteral reflux"
"What non-pathologic state is associated with increased risk for pyelonephritis? Pregnancy"
"One risk factor for pyelonephritis is urinary tract obstruction::not infection"
"Does acute pyelonephritis typically present with systemic signs (e.g. fever, chills)? Yes"
"What gastrointestinal symptoms may be associated with acute pyelonephritis? Nausea, vomiting::2"
"Acute pyelonephritis may present with flank pain due to sensitization of the nerves of the kidney capsule"
"Acute pyelonephritis may present with WBCs in the urine +/- WBC casts"
"What is the most common bacterial cause (90%) of acute pyelonephritis? E. coli"
"Acute pyelonephritis may be characterized by striated parenchymal enhancement of the kidney on CT"
"In addition to ascending UTI (most common), acute pyelonephritis may be caused by hematogenous spread to the kidney"
"One complication of acute pyelonephritis is renal papillary necrosis"
"One complication of acute pyelonephritis is perinephric abscess"
"One complication of acute pyelonephritis is uro-sepsis"
"What is the general treatment for acute pyelonephritis? Antibiotics"
"Chronic pyelonephritis is the result of recurrent episodes of acute pyelonephritis"
"Chronic pyelonephritis is characterized by interstitial fibrosis and atrophy of tubules"
"Chronic pyelonephritis typically requires predisposition to infection, such as vesicoureteral reflux (children) or obstruction"
"Chronic pyelonephritis is characterized by coarse, asymmetric corticomedullary scarring and blunted calyces in the kidney"
"Chronic pyelonephritis with scarring at the upper and lower poles is characteristic of vesicoureteral reflux"
"Chronic pyelonephritis is characterized histologically by renal tubules containing eosinophilic proteinaceous material resembling thyroid follicles"
"Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is characterized by widespread kidney damage due to granulomatous tissue containing foamy macrophages (rare)"
"Nephrolithiasis is the precipitation of a urinary solute as a stone"
"Risk factors for nephrolithiasis include: - high solute concentration in the urinary filtrate - low urine volume"
"Nephrolithiasis may present as colicky::character flank pain that radiates to the groin"
"An obstructed kidney stone may present with unilateral flank tenderness that radiates to the groin"
"Kidney stones may be treated and prevented by encouraging fluid intake"
"What is the most common type of kidney stone? Calcium stone (80%)"
"Which type of calcium kidney stone (calcium-oxalate or calcium-phosphate) is more common? Calcium oxalate"
"Calcium oxalate kidney stones often precipitate due to hypocitrat-uria"
"Hypocitraturia is often associated with decreased urine pH"
"Calcium phosphate kidney stones precipitate with increased urine pH"
"The most common kidney stone presentation is a(n) calcium oxalate stone in a patient with hyper-calciuria and normo-calcemia"
"What GI pathology is associated with calcium oxalate kidney stones? Crohn's disease"
"Crohn disease is associated with calcium oxalate kidney stones due to increased levels of oxalate"
"What is the appearance calcium kidney stones on X-ray and CT? Radiopaque"
"Calcium oxalate kidney stones are characterized by urine crystals in the shape of a(n) envelope or dumbbell"
"Calcium phosphate kidney stones are characterized by urine crystals in the shape of a(n) wedge-shaped prism"
"Calcium kidney stones may be treated with thiazide diuretics"
"In addition to thiazides, calcium oxalate kidney stones may be treated with citrate supplementation and a low-sodium diet"
"What type of kidney stone may result from ethylene glycol (antifreeze) ingestion? Calcium oxalate"
"Calcium oxalate kidney stones may result from vitamin C abuse"
"The second most common type of kidney stone (15%) is a(n) ammonium magnesium phosphate stone, also known as struvite"
"Ammonium magnesium phosphate kidney stones precipitate with high urine pH"
"What is the appearance of ammonium magnesium phosphate kidney stones on X-ray and CT? Radiopaque"
"Ammonium magnesium phosphate kidney stones are characterized by urine crystals in the shape of a(n) coffin lid"
"Ammonium magnesium phosphate kidney stones are caused by urease positive organisms"
"Urease positive organisms hydrolyze urea to ammonia, causing urine alkalinization"
"Ammonium magnesium phosphate (struvite) kidney stones classically form staghorn calculi in renal calyces"
"The staghorn calculi seen in struvite kidney stones may act as a nidus for urinary tract infection"
"What type of kidney stone commonly requires surgical removal due to its size? Ammonium magnesium phosphate (struvite) stones"
"In addition to surgical removal, treatment of struvite stones involves eradication of underlying infection"
"The third most common type of kidney stone (5%) is a(n) uric acid stone"
"Uric acid kidney stones precipitate with low urine pH"
"What is the appearance of uric acid kidney stones on X-ray? Radiolucent"
"What is the appearance of uric acid kidney stones on CT? Minimally visible"
"Uric acid kidney stones are characterized by urine crystals in the shape of a(n) rhomboid or rosettes"
"What imaging modality may be used to visualize uric acid kidney stones? Ultrasound"
"Risk factors for uric acid kidney stones include hot/arid climates and low urine volume"
"What type of kidney stone is seen in patients with gout? Uric acid stone"
"Uric acid kidney stones are often seen in diseases with increased cell turnover (e.g. leukemia, myeloproliferative disorders)"
"Treatment of uric acid kidney stones involves alkalinization of urine (e.g. potassium bicarbonate)"
"Treatment of uric acid kidney stones may include allopurinol, especially in patients with gout"
"Cystine stones are a rare form of nephrolithiasis, most commonly seen in children::age group"
"Cystine kidney stones precipitate with low urine pH"
"What is the appearance of cystine kidney stones on X-ray? Faintly radioopaque"
"What is the appearance of cystine kidney stones on CT? Moderately radioopaque (sometimes visible)"
"Cystine kidney stones are characterized by urine crystals that are hexagonal in shape"
"What inherited pathology are cystine kidney stones associated with? Cystinuria"
"Patients with cystinuria have decreased reabsorption of cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine"
"Cystine kidney stones may form staghorn calculi"
"A positive sodium cyanide nitroprusside test may help in the diagnosis of cystine kidney stones"
"Treatment of cystine kidney stones involves alkalinization of urine and a low-sodium diet"
"What treatment may be used for refractory cases of cystine kidney stones? Chelating agents (e.g. penicillamine)"
"Kidney stones can lead to severe complications including hydronephrosis and pyelonephritis"
"Chronic renal failure is most commonly caused by diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and glomerular disease"
"Renal failure is associated with an inability to make urine and excrete nitrogenous wastes"
"One clinical feature of renal failure is uremia, which is a symptomatic clinical syndrome marked by increased nitrogenous waste products in the blood (azotemia)"
"What cardiac pathology is a consequence of uremia (renal failure)? Pericarditis"
"Uremia, a consequence of renal failure, may cause platelet dysfunction in the blood"
"Uremia, a consequence of renal failure, may cause encephalopathy with asterixis"
"What GI symptoms are associated with uremia (renal failure)? Nausea, anorexia::2"
"Uremia, a consequence of renal failure, may cause deposition of urea crystals in the skin"
"What acid-base disorder is a consequence of renal failure? Metabolic acidosis"
"The consequences of renal failure may be remembered using the mnemonic \MAD HUNGER\\": M.A: Metabolic Acidosis D: Dyslipidemia (especially increased triglycerides) H: Hyperkalemia U: Uremia N: Na+ / H2O retention G: Growth retardation and developmental delay E: Erythropoietin failure (anemia) R: Renal osteodystrophy\""
"What potassium imbalance is a consequence of renal failure? Hyperkalemia"
"One consequence of renal failure is Na+ and H2O retention with resulting hypertension, heart failure, and pulmonary edema"
"One consequence of renal failure is anemia due to decreased erythropoietin production"
"Erythropoietin is produced by renal peritubular interstitial cells"
"What bone pathology is associated with chronic renal failure? Renal osteodystrophy"
"Chronic renal disease is characterized by hypo-calcemia"
"Chronic renal disease is characterized by hyper-phosphatemia"
"Hypocalcemia in chronic renal disease is caused, in part, by decreased 1-α-hydroxylation of vitamin D"
"How do levels of parathyroid hormone change in chronic renal disease? Increased (secondary hyperparathyroidism)"
"Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by subperiosteal thinning of bones"
"Treatment of renal failure involves dialysis or renal transplant"
"End-stage kidneys are often shrunken::size"
"During dialysis, end-stage kidneys often develop cysts"
"Cyst formation within end-stage kidneys during dialysis increases risk for renal cell carcinoma"
"Renal cell carcinoma is associated with \PEAR-aneoplastic\\" syndromes"
"Which renal neoplasia is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes? Renal cell carcinoma"
"Renal cell carcinoma rarely may present with left-sided varicocele in males"
"Gross examination of a renal cell carcinoma reveals a(n) golden-yellow::color mass"
"Loss of the VHL tumor suppressor gene (renal cell carcinoma) leads to increased IGF-1, which promotes growth"
"Loss of the VHL tumor suppressor gene (renal cell carcinoma) leads to increased HIF transcription factor, which increases VEGF and PDGF"
"Renal cell carcinoma tumors may be caused by hereditary or sporadic etiologies"
"The sporadic form of renal cell carcinoma arises as a single tumor(s) in the upper pole of the kidney"
"The hereditary form of renal cell carcinoma classically rises in younger adults::age group"
"Is the hereditary form of renal cell carcinoma typically uni- or bilateral? Bilateral"
"Von Hippel-Lindau disease is an inherited disease associated with increased risk for renal cell carcinoma and hemangioblastoma of the cerebellum"
"The T of TNM staging for renal cell carcinoma represents the tumor size and involvement of the renal vein"
"Renal cell carcinoma may invade the renal vein, then IVC, before spreading hematogenously"
"What is the treatment for advanced/metastatic renal cell carcinoma? Immunotherapy or targeted therapy::2"
"Wilms tumor is caused by \loss of function\\" mutations of tumor suppression genes WT1 or WT2 on chromosome 11\""
"Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is associated with a(n) WT2 gene mutation"
"Denys-Drash syndrome is a combination of: 1. Wilms tumor 2. Early-onset nephrotic syndrome 3. Male pseudohermaphroditism"
"Denys-Drash syndrome is associated with a(n) WT1 gene mutation"
"The major risk factor for transitional cell carcinoma is cigarette smoke"
"Which urinary tract cancer is associated with naphthylamine? Transitional cell carcinoma"
"Transitional cell carcinoma may arise via two distinct pathways: flat and papillary"
"Transitional cell (urothelial) carcinoma via the flat pathway is associated with early p53 mutations"
