"Does transitional cell carcinoma via the flat pathway develop as a high-grade or low-grade tumor? High-grade tumor"
"Is transitional cell carcinoma via the papillary pathway associated with early p53 mutations? No"
"Does transitional cell carcinoma via the papillary pathway develop as a high-grade or low-grade tumor? Low-grade tumor"
"Chronic irritation of the bladder can cause squamous metaplasia, which may progress to squamous cell carcinoma"
"Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder arises in a background of squamous metaplasia"
"Schistosoma haematobium infection is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder in Middle eastern::ethnicity males"
"Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder typically presents with painless hematuria"
"Adenocarcinoma is a cancer of the bladder that usually arises from a(n) urachal remnant"
"Adenocarcinoma of the bladder may arise from cystitis glandularis, which is a(n) columnar metaplasia in response to chronic inflammation"
"If a patient is supine during aspiration, an abscess may form in the superior segment of the right lower lobe of the lung"
"Where in the nephron do acetazolamide and mannitol primarily exert their effects? Proximal convoluted tubule"
"The Na+-K+ ATPase is located on the basolateral membrane of the nephron"
"The Na+-H+ exchanger is located on the apical (luminal) membrane in the PCT of the nephron"
"The H+ secreted into the lumen of the PCT combines with HCO3- to form carbonic acid (H2CO3)"
"What enzyme catalyzes the conversion of H2CO3 into CO2 and H2O (and its reverse reaction)? Carbonic anhydrase"
"H2CO3 is converted into H2O and CO2 by carbonic anhydrase"
"Inside the cells of the PCT, H2O and CO2 are converted back into H2CO3"
"The H2CO3 formed inside the cells of the PCT dissociates into H+ and HCO3-"
"H+ in the PCT cells, from H2CO3, is transported into the lumen of the PCT"
"HCO3- in the PCT cells, from H2CO3, is transported into the interstitium of the PCT"
"Acetazolamide is a diuretic that inhibits the enzyme carbonic anhydrase"
"Acetazolamide primarily prevents reabsorption of HCO3-"
"Acetazolamide causes urine alkalinization::pH"
"In addition to HCO3-, acetazolamide also prevents the reabsorption of Na+ and H2O"
"Acetazolamide causes increased::increased or decreased excretion of HCO3-"
"Besides a type II RTA, what acid-base disorder may be caused by acetazolamide? Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis"
"Acetazolamide causes decreased production of aqueous humor, which is useful in the management of glaucoma"
"Acetazolamide causes decreased production of CSF, which is useful in the management of pseudotumor cerebri"
"Acetazolamide is useful in the treatment and prevention of acute altitude sickness"
"Urinary alkalinization (e.g. acetazolamide) can increase solubility of cystine and uric acid kidney stones"
"What effect may acetazolamide have on serum K+ levels? Decreased (hypokalemia)"
"What type of renal tubular acidosis may be caused by acetazolamide? Type 2 (Proximal)"
"Which diuretic can cause type 2 renal tubular acidosis as an adverse effect? Acetazolamide"
"Acetazolamide may promote the formation of calcium phosphate kidney stones OR struvite stones"
"Acetazolamide is a(n) sulfa drug and thus may cause adverse reactions in allergic patients"
"One adverse effect associated with acetazolamide is NH3::compound toxicity"
"What neurological adverse effect may be caused by acetazolamide? Paresthesias"
"What acid-base disorder may be treated with acetazolamide? Metabolic alkalosis"
"Mannitol is a(n) osmotic diuretic that acts at the proximal tubule and descending limb (of Henle)::location"
"Mannitol may be used to decrease intracranial and intraocular pressure"
"What effect does mannitol have on urine flow? Increased urine flow (diuretic)"
"Mannitol may be used clinically for drug overdose"
"Mannitol may be used to treat elevated intracranial and/or intraocular pressure"
"Mannitol-induced expanded ECF volume can cause pulmonary edema"
"Mannitol-induced expanded ECF volume can exacerbate heart failure"
"Is mannitol associated with hypernatremia or hyponatremia as a possible adverse effect? Both :)"
"Mannitol is contraindicated in patients with anuria and/or heart failure"
"Which osmotic diuretic may cause dehydration as a possible adverse effect? Mannitol"
"The fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) is the ratio of the Na+ excreted/ Na+ filtered"
"What equation may be used to calculate the fractional excretion of sodium given the patient's GFR? FENa = (V * UNa) / (GFR * PNa)"
"What equation may be used to calculate the fractional excretion of sodium using creatinine as an estimate of GFR? FENa = (PCr * UNa) / (UCr * PNa)"
"Where in the nephron does most uric acid reabsorption take place? Early PCT"
"Where in the nephron is reabsorption isotonic? PCT"
"On the apical membrane of β-intercalated cells is a(n) Cl--HCO3- exchanger"
"On the basolateral membrane of β-intercalated cells is a(n) H+-ATPase pump"
"Fanconi syndrome is a renal tubular defect characterized by a generalized reabsorptive defect in the PCT::location of the nephron"
"Which renal tubular defect is associated with increased excretion of nearly all amino acids, glucose, HCO3-, and PO43- and all substances reabsorbed by the PCT Fanconi syndrome"
"What acid-base disorder may be seen with Fanconi syndrome? Metabolic acidosis"
"Which type of renal tubular acidosis may be caused by Fanconi syndrome? Type 2 (proximal renal tubular acidosis)"
"Which renal tubular defect may be caused by Wilson disease? Fanconi syndrome"
"Which renal tubular defect may be caused by metabolism disorders (e.g. glycogen storage disease, tyrosinemia, cystinosis)? Fanconi syndrome"
"What renal tubular defect may be caused by ischemia, multiple myeloma, or lead poisoning? Fanconi syndrome"
"What renal tubular defect may be caused by nephrotoxins/drugs (e.g. ifosfamide, cisplatin, tenofovir, expired tetracyclines)? Fanconi syndrome"
"Bartter syndrome is a renal tubular defect characterized by a defect in the thick ascending limb (of Henle)::location of the nephron"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Bartter syndrome? Autosomal recessive"
"Bartter syndrome is a renal tubular defect that affects the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter"
"Which renal tubular defect presents similarly to chronic loop diuretic use? Bartter syndrome"
"How do serum K+ levels change in Bartter syndrome? Decreased (hypokalemia)"
"What acid-base disorder may be seen with Bartter syndrome? Metabolic alkalosis"
"How does urinary excretion of Ca2+ change in Bartter syndrome? Increased (hypercalciuria)"
"How do levels of plasma renin and aldosterone change in Bartter syndrome? Increased (due to decreased Na+ reabsorption)"
"Gitelman syndrome is a renal tubular defect characterized by a defect in the DCT::location of the nephron"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Gitelman syndrome? Autosomal recessive"
"Gitelman syndrome is a renal tubular defect that affects the Na+-Cl- cotransporter"
"Which renal tubular defect presents similarly to lifelong thiazide diuretic use? Gitelman syndrome"
"Compared to Bartter syndrome, Gitelman syndrome is more mild::severity"
"How do serum K+ levels change in Gitelman syndrome? Decreased (hypokalemia)"
"How do serum Mg2+ levels change in Gitelman syndrome? Decreased (hypomagnesemia)"
"What acid-base disorder may be seen with Gitelman syndrome? Metabolic alkalosis"
"How does urinary excretion of Ca2+ change in Gitelman syndrome? Decreased (hypocalciuria)"
"How do levels of plasma renin and aldosterone change in Gitelman syndrome? Increased (due to decreased Na+ reabsorption)"
"Liddle syndrome is a renal tubular defect characterized by a gain of function mutation in the ENaC channel in the collecting duct of the nephron"
"Liddle syndrome is a renal tubular defect that increases activity of the epithelial Na+ channel"
"How do serum Na+ levels change in Liddle syndrome? Increased (hypernatremia)"
"Which renal tubular defects present similarly to hyperaldosteronism? Liddle syndrome, Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess::2"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Liddle syndrome? Autosomal dominant"
"How do serum K+ levels change in Liddle syndrome? Decreased (hypokalemia)"
"How does blood pressure change in Liddle syndrome? Increased (hypertension)"
"What acid-base disorder may be seen with Liddle syndrome? Metabolic alkalosis"
"How do serum aldosterone levels change in Liddle syndrome? Decreased"
"How do levels of plasma renin change in Liddle syndrome? Decreased"
"What is the treatment for Liddle syndrome? Amiloride"
"In cells containing mineralocorticoid receptors, cortisol may be converted to cortisone by the enzyme 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase"
"Can cortisol activate mineralocorticoid receptors? Yes"
"Can cortisone activate mineralocorticoid receptors? No"
"In syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess, excess cortisol causes increased mineralocorticoid receptor activity"
"How do serum K+ levels change in syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess? Decreased (hypokalemia)"
"How does blood pressure change in syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess? Increased (hypertension)"
"What acid-base disorder may be seen with syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess? Metabolic alkalosis"
"How do serum aldosterone levels change in syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess? Decreased"
"Glycyrrhetinic acid is a substance present in licorice that may block activity of the enzyme 11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase"
"Which renal tubular defect may be caused by ingestion of licorice? Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess"
"The [TF/P]K ratio slightly increases over the course of the PCT"
"The [TF/P]PAH ratio greatly increases over the course of the PCT"
"The [TF/P]creatinine ratio greatly increases over the course of the PCT"
"The [TF/P]urea ratio increases over the course of the PCT"
"Which cell type in the nephron secretes renin? Juxtaglomerular cells"
"Juxtaglomerular (JG) cells are modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole"
"Which cells of the kidney detect changes in blood pressure? Juxtaglomerular cells"
"In response to decreased blood pressure, the JG cells of the kidney cause increased renin release"
"In response to decreased Na+ delivery, the macula densa cells of the kidney cause increased renin release"
"In response to increased sympathetic tone, there is increased renin release"
"Increased sympathetic tone increases renin release via stimulation of the β1 adrenergic receptors of the JGA"
"β-blockers may decrease BP by inhibiting β1 receptors of the JGA, thus decreasing renin release"
"Angiotensin II causes vaso-constriction of vascular smooth muscle"
"Angiotensin II acts on the posterior pituitary to increase release of ADH"
"Angiotensin II affects baroreceptor function, limiting reflex bradycardia that would normally accompany its pressor effects"
"Which hormones are released in response to increased volume, and thus act as a \check\\" on the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system? ANP"
"ADH::aldosterone or ADH primarily regulates osmolarity; may also respond to low volume states"
"Aldosterone::aldosterone or ADH primarily regulates ECF volume and Na+ content"
"The juxtaglomerular apparatus consists of JG cells, macula densa, extraglomerular mesangial cells"
"In response to increased Na+ delivery (e.g. increased GFR/RPF), the macula densa releases ATP (adenosine), which constricts the afferent arterioles"
"In response to decreased Na+ delivery, the macula densa releases PGE2, which relaxes the afferent arterioles"
"In response to decreased Na+ delivery, the macula densa causes increased renin release, which ultimately constricts the efferent arterioles"
"In response to increased Na+ delivery, the macula densa causes decreased renin release, which ultimately relaxes the efferent arterioles"
"Erythropoietin is often supplemented in chronic kidney::organ disease"
"25-OH vitamin D3 is converted to 1,25 (OH)2 vitamin D3 in cells of the PCT of the nephron"
"What renal enzyme facilitates the conversion of 25-OH vitamin D3 to 1,25 (OH)2 vitamin D3? 1α-hydroxylase"
"PTH is a hormone that increases the production of 1,25-(OH)2 D3 via increased 1α-hydroxylase activity"
"Parathyroid hormone is secreted in response to decreased plasma Ca2+ and 1,25-(OH)2 D3"
"Parathyroid hormone is secreted in response to increased plasma PO43-"
"Prostaglandins act via a(n) paracrine mechanism to vaso-dilate the afferent arterioles"
"Dopamine is a neurotransmitter that may be secreted by cells of the PCT of the nephron"
"What effect do low doses of dopamine have on renal afferent and efferent arterioles? Dilation::dilation or constriction"
"What effect do low doses of dopamine have on RBF? Increased"
"What effect do low doses of dopamine have on GFR? Little or no change"
"At higher doses, dopamine acts as a vaso-constrictor of renal arterioles"
"How do levels of plasma renin change in primary hyperaldosteronism? Decreased (negative feedback)"
"How do levels of plasma renin change in a renin-secreting tumor? Increased"
"Which electrolyte disturbance causes nausea, malaise, stupor, coma, and seizures? Low Na+ (hyponatremia)"
"Which electrolyte disturbance causes irritability, stupor, coma? High Na+ (hypernatremia)"
"Which electrolyte disturbance causes U waves and flattened T waves on ECG? Low K+ (hypokalemia)"
"Which electrolyte disturbances cause arrhythmias, muscle cramps, spasm, and weakness? Low and high K+::2"
"Which electrolyte disturbance causes wide QRS and peaked T waves on ECG? High K+ (hyperkalemia)"
"Which electrolyte disturbance causes tetany, seizures, QT prolongation, twitching, and spasm? Low Ca2+ (hypocalcemia)"
"Which electrolyte disturbance causes stones, bones, groans, and psychiatric overtones? High Ca2+ (hypercalcemia)"
"Which electrolyte disturbance causes tetany, torsades de pointes, and hypokalemia? Low Mg2+ (hypomagnesemia)"
"Which electrolyte disturbance causes decreased DTRs, cardiac arrest, bradycardia, hypotension, and hypocalcemia? High Mg2+ (hypermagnesemia)"
"Which electrolyte disturbance causes bone loss, osteomalacia (adults), and rickets (children)? Low PO43-"
"Which electrolyte disturbance causes renal stones, metastatic calcifications, and hypocalcemia? High PO43-"
"The causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis may be remembered with the mnemonic MUDPILES: M: methanol (formic acid) U: uremia D: diabetic ketoacidosis P: propylene glycol I: iron tablets or isoniazid L: lactic acidosis E: ethylene glycol (-> oxalic acid) S: salicylates (late)"
"The causes of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis may be remembered with the mnemonic HARDASS: H: hyperalimentation (artificial supply of nutrition) A: Addison disease R: renal tubular acidosis D: diarrhea A: acetazolamide S: spironolactone S: saline infusion"
"Acidemia is characterized by arterial pH < 7.35"
"Alkalemia is characterized by arterial pH > 7.45"
"What acid-base disorder may be caused by vomiting? Metabolic alkalosis"
"Renal tubular acidosis is a group of disorders of the renal tubules that lead to normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis"
"Distal renal tubular acidosis is also known as type 1 RTA"
"Distal renal tubular acidosis is characterized by a urine pH > 5.5"
"Distal renal tubular acidosis is due to a defect in the ability of α-intercalated cells to secrete H+"
"Inability to secrete H+ by the α-intercalated cells (distal RTA) results in no new HCO3- generation"
"Distal renal tubular acidosis is associated with hypo-kalemia"
"Distal renal tubular acidosis is associated with increased risk for calcium phosphate kidney stones"
"Which renal tubular acidosis may be caused by amphotericin B toxicity? Distal RTA (type 1)"
"Which renal tubular acidosis may be caused by analgesic nephropathy? Distal RTA (type 1)"
"Which renal tubular acidosis is highly associated with autoimmune diseases? Distal RTA (type 1)"
"Proximal renal tubular acidosis is also known as type 2 RTA"
"Proximal renal tubular acidosis is characterized by a urine pH < 5.5"
"Proximal renal tubular acidosis is due to a defect in the ability of PCT cells to reabsorb HCO3-"
"Which renal tubular acidosis is associated with increased urinary excretion of HCO3-? Proximal RTA (type 2)"
"Proximal renal tubular acidosis is associated with hypo-kalemia"
"There is an increased risk for hypophosphatemic rickets with proximal renal tubular acidosis due to Fanconi Syndrome"
"Fanconi Syndrome and Multiple Myeloma can both cause proximal (type 2) renal tubular acidosis"
"Proximal renal tubular acidosis may be caused by carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, aminoglycosides::antimicrobial, and lead::metal"
"Hyperkalemic renal tubular acidosis is also known as type 4 RTA"
"Hyperkalemic renal tubular acidosis may be characterized by a urine pH < 5.5"
"In hyperkalemic RTA, hypoaldosteronism causes hyperkalemia"
"In hyperkalemic RTA, hyperkalemia causes decreased NH3 synthesis in the PCT"
"In hyperkalemic RTA, decreased NH3 synthesis in the PCT causes decreased NH4+ excretion"
"Which renal tubular acidosis may be caused by decreased aldosterone production? Hyperkalemic (type 4) RTA"
"Which renal tubular acidosis may be caused by aldosterone resistance? Hyperkalemic (type 4) RTA"
"The presence of casts in the urine indicates that hematuria/pyuria is of glomerular or renal tubular origin"
"What pathologies are characterized by hematuria with no casts? Bladder cancer, Kidney stones::2"
"What pathology is characterized by pyuria with no casts? Acute cystitis"
"Which type of cast is classically seen in glomerulonephritis and hypertensive emergency? RBC casts"
"What type of cast may be seen with transplant rejection and tubulointerstitial inflammation? WBC casts"
"Fatty casts (\oval fat bodies\\") are often associated with the \\"Maltese cross\\" sign\""
"What type of cast may be seen in end-stage renal disease and chronic renal failure? Waxy casts"
"Hyaline casts are nonspecific and are often seen in concentrated urine samples (can be a normal finding)"
"A \focal\\" glomerular disorder involves < 50% of glomeruli\""
"A \diffuse\\" glomerular disorder involves > 50% of glomeruli\""
"A \proliferative\\" glomerular disorder is characterized by hypercellular glomeruli\""
"A \membranous\\" glomerular disorder is characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane\""
"Nephritic syndrome occurs due to GBM disruption"
"Is diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) a nephritic or nephrotic syndrome? Can be either or both"
"Which two pathologies may present as nephritic and/or nephrotic syndrome? DPGN, MPGN"
"Hydronephrosis is the distention or dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces"
"Hydronephrosis is usually caused by urinary tract obstruction"
"Less common causes of hydronephrosis include retroperitoneal fibrosis, vesicoureteral reflux, and Unilateral Renal Agenesis"
"In hydronephrosis, the dilation occurs proximal::proximal or distal to the site of pathology"
"Is serum creatinine usually elevated in unilateral hydronephrosis? No"
"Hydronephrosis may lead to the compression and possible atrophy of the renal cortex and medulla"
"Renal oncocytoma is a benign epithelial cell tumor arising from the collecting ducts::location"
"Is renal oncocytoma benign or malignant? Benign"
"Which renal tumor is characterized by large eosinophilic cells with abundant mitochondria, but without perinuclear clearing? Renal oncocytoma"
"Renal oncocytoma presents with painless hematuria, flank pain, and a(n) abdominal mass"
"Diffuse cortical necrosis is an acute generalized cortical infarction of both kidneys"
"Diffuse cortical necrosis is likely due to a combination of vasospasm and DIC"
"Diffuse cortical necrosis is a renal pathology associated with obstetric catastrophes and septic shock"
"Stress incontinence is characterized by leakage when there is an increased intra-abdominal pressure (e.g. sneezing, lifting)"
"Vaginal delivery, prostate surgery / hysterectomy, post-menopausal state, obesity increase risk for stress incontinence"
"Stress incontinence is due to outlet incompetence (e.g. urethral hypermobility or intrinsic sphincter deficiency)"
"Stress incontinence is associated with a positive bladder stress test"
"The first line treatment for stress incontinence includes strengthening pelvic floor muscles (e.g. Kegels)"
"Treatment for stress incontinence may include weight loss and pessaries"
"Urgency incontinence is due to an overactive bladder (detrusor muscle overstimulation)"
"Urgency incontinence is characterized by leakage with the need to void immediately"
"Treatment for urgency incontinence includes Kegel exercises and bladder training"
"Urgency incontinence may be treated with M3 antagonists or β3 agonists"
"Mixed incontinence has features of both stress and urgency incontinence"
"Overflow incontinence is due to incomplete emptying, due to detrusor underactivity or outlet obstruction"
"Overflow incontinence is characterized by leakage with overfilling of the bladder"
"Overflow incontinence is associated with increased post-void residual on catheterization or ultrasound"
"Treatment for overflow incontinence includes catheterization and/or relief of obstruction (e.g. α-blockers for BPH)"
"Buerger disease may also be referred to as thromboangiitis obliterans"
"Kawasaki disease may also be referred to as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome"
"Granulomatosis with polyangiitis used to be referred to as Wegeners granulomatosis"
"Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis may present with paranasal sinus abnormalities and skin nodules / palpable purpura"
"Secondary hyperaldosteronism is seen in patients with juxtaglomerular cell tumor due to independent activation of the RAAS"
"Secondary hyperaldosteronism is seen in patients with renovascular hypertension due to independent activation of the RAAS"
"Loop diuretics exert their effects on the thick ascending limb of Henle::location of the nephron"
"The Na+-K+ ATPase is located on the basolateral membrane of the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle)"
"The Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter is present on the luminal membrane of the thick ascending limb (of Henle)"
"The thick ascending limb (of Henle) is impermeable to water (permeability)"
"What drug class do furosemide, bumetanide, and torsemide belong to? Loop diuretics"
"Loop diuretics block the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter on the luminal membrane of the thick ascending limb"
"What class of diuretics are the most effective? Loop diuretics"
"What drug class does ethacrynic acid belong to? Loop diuretics"
"Loop diuretics decrease the lumen positive potential, thus promoting the excretion of Ca2+ and Mg2+"
"Loop diuretics may cause hypo-magnesemia as an adverse effect"
"Loop diuretics may cause hypo-calcemia as an adverse effect"
"Loop diuretics induce expression of COX-2, which leads to synthesis of prostaglandins (e.g. PGE)"
"Increased prostaglandin (e.g. loop diuretics) causes vaso-dilation of the afferent arteriole"
"What class of drugs may inhibit the renal-protective aspect of loop diuretics? NSAIDs (decreased prostaglandin synthesis)"
"Loop diuretics are the 1st line treatment for the symptomatic treatment of acute decompensated heart failure with fluid overload"
"Loop diuretics may be used to treat the symptoms of pulmonary edema in an acute heart failure exacerbation"
"Do loop diuretics prolong life in heart failure? No"
"Loop diuretics may be used to treat ascites in liver failure (e.g. cirrhosis)"
"Loop diuretics can be useful in the treatment of hypertension, especially if other comorbidities are present (e.g. heart failure with edema)"
"Loop diuretics may be used in the treatment of hyper-calcemia"
"What class of renal disorders may be treated with loop diuretics? Nephrotic syndrome"
"What effect may loop diuretics have on serum K+ levels? Decreased (hypokalemia)"
"Loop diuretics may cause oto-toxicity as an adverse effect"
"Which loop diuretic is more ototoxic, furosemide or ethacrynic acid? Ethacrynic acid"
"Most loop diuretics are sulfa drugs and thus may cause adverse reactions in allergic patients"
"Ethacrynic acid is a non-sulfonamide loop diuretic"
"What renal pathology may be caused by loop diuretics? Interstitial nephritis"
"Loop and thiazide diuretics can cause hyperuricemia, which may lead to precipitation of gout"
"What acid-base disorder may be caused by loop diuretics? Metabolic alkalosis"
"The potent diuretic effects of loop diuretics may lead to significant volume loss and thus dehydration"
"Ethacrynic acid is used for diuresis in patients allergic to sulfa drugs, who thus cannot tolerate other loop diuretics"
"Loop diuretics cause decreased::increased or decreased hypertonicity of the renal medulla"
"Decreased medullary hypertonicity (e.g. due to loop diuretics) results in an inability to concentrate urine"
"Thiazide diuretics exert their effects on the DCT::location of the nephron"
"The Na+-Cl- cotransporter is present on the luminal membrane of the DCT"
"In the DCT of the nephron, Ca2+ is reabsorbed by an apical Ca2+ channel and a basolateral Na+-Ca2+ exchanger"
"The early distal convoluted tubule is impermeable to water (permeability)"
"Thiazide diuretics decrease the diluting capacity of the nephron"
"What drug class does hydrochlorothiazide belong to? Thiazide diuretics"
"What drug class do chlorthalidone, metolazone and indapamide belong to? Thiazide diuretics"
"Thiazide diuretics block the Na+-Cl- cotransporter on the luminal membrane of the DCT"
"Thiazide diuretics increase Ca2+ reabsorption (excretion or reabsorption)"
"Thiazide diuretics are a 1st line agent for treatment of mild or moderate hypertension"
"Thiazide diuretics can be useful in the symptomatic treatment of heart failure (loop diuretics are first line)"
"Thiazide diuretics may be useful in the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus"
"Thiazide diuretics can be used to prevent calcium kidney stones"
"Thiazide diuretics may be useful for attenuating bone loss in patients with osteoporosis"
"Thiazide diuretics may be useful in the treatment of idiopathic hypercalciuria"
"Thiazide diuretics may cause hyper-calcemia as an adverse effect"
"What effect may thiazide diuretics have on serum glucose levels? Increased (hyperglycemia)"
"What effect may thiazide diuretics have on serum lipid levels (e.g. cholesterol, triglycerides)? Increased (hyperlipidemia)"
"Thiazide diuretics may decrease renal excretion of lithium, which is commonly used as an anti-psychotic drug"
"What effect may thiazide diuretics have on serum K+ levels? Decreased (hypokalemia)"
"Thiazide diuretics may cause hypo-natremia as an adverse effect"
"Thiazide diuretics are sulfa drugs and thus may rarely cause allergic reactions"
"What acid-base disorder may be caused by thiazide diuretics? Metabolic alkalosis"
"K+ sparing diuretics exert their effects on the cortical collecting tubules::location of the nephron"
"Which part of the nephron do mineralocorticoids exert their effects? Collecting duct"
"The principal cells of the collecting duct are the major site of Na+, K+, and H2O transport"
"Na+ is reabsorbed on the luminal membrane of the collecting duct through epithelial Na+ channels"
"K+ channels on the luminal membrane of the principal cells of the collecting duct secrete::absorb/secrete K+"
"Reabsorption of Na+ in the collecting duct creates a(n) negative luminal potential that facilitates K+ excretion"
"The α-intercalated cells of collecting duct are the major site of H+ secretion"
"H+ is secreted by H+-ATPase on the luminal membrane of the α-intercalated cells of the collecting duct"
"Is the mineralocorticoid receptor an intracellular or membrane receptor? Intracellular"
"Triamterene and amiloride are K+ sparing diuretics that act by blocking Na+ reabsorption through ENaCs"
"Eplerenone and spironolactone are K+ sparing diuretics that act by competitively antagonizing the mineralocorticoid receptor"
"K+ sparing diuretics are useful in the treatment of primary and secondary hyper-aldosteronism"
"K+ sparing diuretics (e.g. spironolactone, eplerenone) are useful in the treatment of heart failure, especially in combination with loop diuretics"
"Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists prevent myocardial remodeling induced by high levels of aldosterone"
"Do mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (e.g. spironolactone, eplerenone) prolong life in heart failure? Yes"
"Amiloride, a K+ sparing diuretic, is useful in the treatment of Li+-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus"
"Amiloride and triamterene are K+ sparing diuretics that may be used to treat Liddle's syndrome, which is characterized by overactive ENaCs"
"Which ion depletion may be treated with K+ sparing diuretics? K+ depletion (hypokalemia)"
"Spironolactone, a K+ sparing diuretic, may be used in the treatment of hepatic ascites"
"One adverse effect of K+ sparing diuretics is hyperkalemia, which increases risk for arrhythmia"
"What acid-base disorder may be caused by K+-sparing diuretics? Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis"
"What type of renal tubular acidosis may be caused by K+ sparing diuretics? Type 4 RTA"
"Type 4 renal tubular acidosis is associated with hyper-kalemia"
"Spironolactone may inhibit 17α-hydroxylase, an enzyme in the testosterone synthesis pathway"
"Spironolactone, a K+ sparing diuretic, may be used to treat symptoms of androgen excess in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)"
"Spironolactone may ALSO have anti-androgenic effects via direct antagonism of the androgen receptor"
"What adverse anti-androgenic effect may be caused by spironolactone use in males? Gynecomastia"
"Spironolactone may cause impotence and decreased libido as adverse effects"
"Which diuretics cause an increase in urine NaCl? All diuretics :)"
"What classes of diuretics are characterized by increased urine K+? Loop and thiazide diuretics::2"
"What classes of diuretics are characterized by decreased blood pH (acidemia)? Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, K+ sparing diuretics::2"
"What classes of diuretics cause increased blood pH (alkalemia)? Loop and thiazide diuretics::2"
"In a low K+ state, H+ is exchanged for Na+ in the basolateral membrane of cortical collecting tubule, causing alkalosis and \paradoxical aciduria\\"\""
"What class of diuretics is characterized by increased urine Ca2+? Loop diuretics"
"What class of diuretics is characterized by decreased urine Ca2+? Thiazide diuretics"
"Which type of nephrotic syndrome is most commonly seen in HIV patients? Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis"
"Which type of kidney stone is associated with staghorn calculi in children? Cystine kidney stones"
"Where in the cell does hexosemonophosphate (HMP) shunt activity occur? Cytoplasm"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme of the HMP shunt? Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD)"
"Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is regulated via positive feedback by NADP+"
"Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is regulated via negative feedback by NADPH"
"One function of the HMP shunt is to provide a source of NADPH, which is required for reductive reactions"
"One function of the HMP shunt is to provide a source of ribose, which is used for nucleotide synthesis and glycolytic intermediates"
"The HMP shunt may be referred to as the pentose phosphate pathway"
"Does activity of the HMP shunt use ATP? No"
"Does activity of the HMP shunt produce ATP? No"
"HMP shunt activity is primarily found in the adrenal glands, liver, lactating mammary glands (females), and RBCs"
"Glucose-6-phosphate is ultimately converted to ribulose-5-phosphate via the enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase"
"Conversion of glucose-6-P into ribulose-5-P (HMP shunt) produces one molecule of CO2 and two molecules of NADPH"
"Is the conversion of glucose-6-P into ribulose-5-P (HMP shunt) a reversible or irreversible reaction? Irreversible"
"Ribulose-5-phosphate may be converted to ribose-5-phosphate via the enzyme phosphopentose isomerase (HMP shunt)"
"Is the conversion of ribulose-5-P into ribose-5-P (HMP shunt) a reversible or irreversible reaction? Reversible"
"In the liver, the HMP shunt provides a source of NADPH for biosynthesis of fatty acids, cholesterol, and steroids"
"In neutrophils, the HMP shunt provides a source of NADPH for NADPH oxidase activity, which is used for respiratory burst"
"In the RBCs, the HMP shunt provides a source of NADPH for reduction of H2O2 (via reduced glutathione)"
"Oxidized glutathione may be converted to reduced glutathione via the enzyme glutathione reductase"
"The enzyme glutathione reductase requires a molecule of NADPH, which is provided by the activity of the enzyme G6PD"
"Conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphogluconate, via G6PD, produces a molecule of NADPH"
"Reduced glutathione may be converted to oxidized glutathione via the enzyme glutathione peroxidase"
"What is the molecular formula for oxidized glutathione? Glutathione-sulfur-sulfur-Glutathione (GS-SG)"
"What is the molecular formula for reduced glutathione? 2x Glutathione-sulfhydryl (G-SH)"
"H2O2 may be converted to H2O via the enzyme glutathione peroxidase"
"The enzyme glutathione peroxidase requires a reducing agent, which is provided in the form of reduced glutathione (G-SH)"
"What inclusion body may be seen inside the RBCs of patients with G6PD deficiency? Heinz bodies"
"Heinz bodies form due to precipitation of denatured globin chains within RBCs"
"Which poisonous substance is characterized by a \bitter almond\\" odor? Cyanide\""
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis? Acetyl-CoA carboxylase"
"Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is regulated via negative feedback by glucagon and palmitoyl CoA"
"Where in the cell does fatty acid synthesis occur? Cytoplasm"
"Fatty acid synthesis requires acetyl CoA, which is provided directly from citrate"
"Fatty acid synthesis requires NADPH, which is provided by the HMP shunt and malic enzyme"
"In the cytosol, malate may be converted to pyruvate via the enzyme malic enzyme (fatty acid synthesis)"
"Conversion of malate to pyruvate via malic enzyme produces a molecule of NADPH (fatty acid synthesis)"
"Fatty acid synthesis predominantly occurs in the liver, lactating mammary glands (women), and adipose tissue"
"The first step of fatty acid synthesis is transport of citrate from the mitochondria to the cytosol through its shuttle"
"In the cytosol, citrate may be converted to acetyl-CoA via the enzyme ATP citrate lyase (fatty acid synthesis)"
"Acetyl-CoA is converted to malonyl-CoA via the enzyme acetyl-CoA carboxylase (fatty acid synthesis)"
"Acetyl-CoA carboxylase requires ATP, biotin, and CO2"
"Malonyl-CoA may be converted to palmitate via the enzyme fatty acid synthase"
"Which enzyme of the fatty acid synthesis pathway utilizes NADPH? Fatty acid synthase"
"Palmitate is a(n) 16::#-carbon fatty acid"
"What two fatty acids are essential in humans? Linoleic acid (omega-6), linolenic acid (omega-3)"
"Fatty Acid Nomenclature: C18:2 (9,12) is a(n) 18-carbon fatty acid with two double bonds"
"In naturally occurring fatty acids, double bonds are in the cis::cis or trans configuration"
"When membrane phospholipids are in the trans (cis or trans) configuration, they cause decreased membrane fluidity"
"Are fatty acids polar or nonpolar? Non-Polar"
"Is glycerol polar or nonpolar? Polar"
"Triglycerides are composed of three fatty acids and one glycerol"
"Are triglycerides polar or nonpolar? Non-polar"
"What type of bond exists between fatty acids and glycerol (e.g. triglycerides)? Ester bonds"
"What type of enzyme cleaves triglyceride ester bonds? Lipases"
"What type of enzyme cleaves phospholipid ester bonds? Phospholipases"
"Is cholesterol polar or nonpolar? Non-Polar"
"Is cholesterol ester polar or nonpolar? Non-polar"
"What is the purpose of converting cholesterol into cholesterol ester? More space-efficient (anhydrous)"
"Lipoproteins are a physical complex of lipids and proteins (apoproteins)"
"Apoprotein A-1 is an activator of the enzyme LCAT (lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase)"
"Apoprotein A-1 is a major component of high density lipoprotein"
"Apo B-48 is found only on particles originating from the intestines, whereas Apo B-100 is found only on particles originating from the liver"
"Apoprotein E mediates chylomicron remnant uptake in the liver"
"Apoprotein E may be found on every lipoprotein except LDL"
"Apoprotein C-II is a cofactor and activator of the enzyme LPL (lipoprotein lipase)"
"Which three lipoproteins is apoprotein C-II found on? HDL, VLDL, chylomicrons"
"Apoprotein B-48 mediates chylomicron secretion by the intestines"
"Which lipoprotein is apoprotein B-48 found on? Chylomicrons (and their remnants)"
"Apoprotein B-100 binds the LDL receptor on the liver"
"Which three lipoproteins is apoprotein B-100 found on? VLDL, IDL, LDL"
"The intestines package triglycerides and cholesterol esters into chylomicrons, which initially enter the lymph"
"In the lymph, chylomicrons only express apoprotein B-48"
"What is the main component of chylomicrons? Triglycerides"
"From the lymph, chylomicrons enter the blood via the thoracic duct"
"In the blood, chylomicrons pick up apoprotein C-II and E from circulating HDL"
"Once in the vicinity of adipocytes, apoprotein C-II on the chylomicron activates the enzyme lipoprotein lipase (LPL)"
"The triglycerides inside the chylomicron are broken down into fatty acids by lipoprotein lipase in the vicinity of the adipocytes (or peripheral tissue)"
"Once inside the adipocyte, fatty acids are reconverted into triglycerides"
"As triglycerides are removed from the chylomicron, the chylomicron shrinks, forming a(n) chylomicron remnant"
"The chylomicron remnant expresses only apolipoprotein B-48 and E on its surface"
"What happens to apoprotein C-II on the chylomicron as it forms a chylomicron remnant? Recycled back to HDL"
"Once in the vicinity of the liver, the chylomicron remnant binds the remnant receptor via apoprotein E"
"The liver packages triglycerides and cholesterol into VLDLs, which enter the blood"
"Initially, VLDLs only express apoprotein B-100"
"What is the main component of VLDLs? Triglycerides"
"In the blood, VLDLs pick up apoprotein C-II and E from circulating HDL"
"Once in the vicinity of adipocytes, apoprotein C-II on the VLDL activates the enzyme lipoprotein lipase (LPL)"
"The triglycerides inside the VLDL are broken down into fatty acids by lipoprotein lipase in the vicinity of the adipocytes (or peripheral tissue)"
"As triglycerides are removed from the VLDLs, the VLDL shrinks, forming IDL"
"The IDL expresses only apolipoprotein B-100 and E on its surface"
"What happens to apoprotein C-II on the VLDL as it forms an IDL? Recycled back to HDL"
"Once in the vicinity of the liver, the IDL may directly bind a(n) LDL receptor via apoprotein B-100"
"Further removal of triglycerides from IDL, via the enzyme hepatic TG lipase, leads to the formation of LDL"
"LDL only expresses a single copy of apoprotein B-100 on its surface"
"What is the main component of LDLs? Cholesterol ester"
"Which two organs produce nascent HDL? Liver, Intestines"
"The enzyme LCAT may convert cholesterol to cholesterol ester in the blood in the presence of apoprotein A (found on HDL)"
"Cholesterol ester inside of mature HDL may be transferred to VLDL, IDL, or LDL via the enzyme cholesterol ester transport protein (CETP)"
"Which lipid transport enzyme is responsible for the degradation of triglycerides in the small intestine? Pancreatic lipase"
"Which lipid transport enzyme is responsible for the degradation of triglycerides in the chylomicrons and VLDLs? Lipoprotein lipase"
"Lipoprotein lipase is regulated via positive feedback by insulin and apoprotein C-II"
"Which lipid transport enzyme is responsible for the degradation of remaining triglycerides in IDLs? Hepatic TG lipase"
"Which lipid transport enzyme is responsible for the degradation of triglycerides stored in adipocytes? Hormone-sensitive lipase"
"Which lipoproteins carry the most cholesterol? LDL and HDL::2"
"Which lipoprotein is secreted by intestinal epithelial cells and delivers dietary TGs to peripheral tissue? Chylomicrons"
"Which lipoprotein is secreted by the liver and delivers hepatic TGs to peripheral tissue? VLDL"
"Which lipoprotein is formed by the degradation of VLDL and delivers TGs and cholesterol to the liver? IDL"
"Which lipoprotein is formed by modification of IDL and delivers hepatic cholesterol to peripheral tissue? LDL"
"Which lipoprotein mediates reverse cholesterol transport from the periphery to the liver? HDL"
"Which lipoprotein is a repository for apoproteins C and E? HDL"
"What is the effect of alcohol on HDL synthesis? Increased synthesis"
"On the cellular surface of hepatocytes, the LDL particle binds a(n) LDL receptor via apoprotein B-100"
"Following binding of LDL to its LDL receptor, the ligand-receptor complex is endocytosed in clathrin-coated pits"
"The LDL-containing clathrin-coated pits fuse with lysosomes, which break down cholesterol ester into cholesterol"
"What happens to most of the endocytosed LDL receptors? Recycled to cell membrane"
"Inside the hepatocyte, cholesterol may be converted to cholesterol ester via the enzyme acyl cholesterol acyltransferase (ACAT) for storage"
"Increased levels of cholesterol inside the hepatocyte leads to decreased activity of the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase"
"Increased levels of cholesterol inside the hepatocyte leads to increased activity of the enzyme ACAT"
"Increased levels of cholesterol inside the hepatocyte leads to decreased LDL-receptor gene expression"
"In the blood, free radicals may take an electron from apoprotein B-100 on LDL, forming oxidized LDL"
"Oxidized LDL has a defect in its single apoB-100 and is no longer recognized; consequently, it is consumed by macrophages"
"Oxidized LDL is consumed by macrophages via the scavenger receptor-A receptor"
"Is scavenger receptor A on macrophages down-regulated by cholesterol? No"
"Macrophages bloated with cholesterol eventually form foam cells within the subendothelium"
"The foam cell from the cholesterol-laden macrophages eventually dies, causing cholesterol to precipitate out, forming a(n) atherosclerotic plaque"
"The precipitated cholesterol in blood vessels may be picked up by HDL (lipoprotein) and esterified to cholesterol ester"
"HDL may directly bring cholesterol back to the liver via the scavenger receptor B-1 receptor (reverse cholesterol transport)"
"Type I hyperlipoproteinemia is also known as familial hyperchylomicronemia syndrome"
"What is the mode of inheritance of type I hyperlipoproteinemia? Autosomal recessive"
"Type I lipoproteinemia is due to a(n) LPL or apo-CII deficiency"
"Which serum lipoprotein is elevated in type I hyperlipoproteinemia? Chylomicrons"
"Which serum lipids are elevated in type I hyperlipoproteinemia? Triglycerides and cholesterol::2"
"Type I hyperlipoproteinemia commonly presents with red-orange eruptive/pruritic xanthomas"
"Which type of familial dyslipidemia is associated with pancreatitis and hepatosplenomegaly? Type I (hyperchylomicronemia)"
"Does type I familial dyslipidemia cause an increased risk for atherosclerosis? No"
"Type I familial dyslipidemia is characterized by a \creamy\\" layer in supernatant\""
"Type IIa familial dyslipidemia is also known as familial hypercholesterolemia"
"What is the mode of inheritance of type IIa familial dyslipidemia? Autosomal dominant"
"Type IIa familial dyslipidemia is due to either: - absent or defective LDL receptors - defective Apo B-100"
"Which serum lipoprotein is elevated in type IIa familial dyslipidemia? LDL"
"Which serum lipid is elevated in type IIa familial dyslipidemia? Cholesterol"
"Type II familial dyslipidemia commonly presents with tendinous xanthomas, especially on the Achilles tendon"
"Which type of familial dyslipidemia is associated with corneal arcus? Type IIa (familial hypercholesterolemia)"
"Does type IIa familial dyslipidemia cause an increased risk for atherosclerosis? Yes, accelerated atherosclerosis may cause MI before age 20"
"Patients with heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia (1:500) have cholesterol levels of ~ 300 mg/dL"
"Patients with homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia (very rare) have cholesterol levels of ~ 700+ mg/dL"
"Type IV familial dyslipidemia is also known as familial hypertriglyceridemia"
"What is the mode of inheritance of type IV familial dyslipidemia? Autosomal dominant"
"Type IV familial dyslipidemia is due to hepatic overproduction of VLDL"
"Which serum lipoprotein is elevated in type IV familial dyslipidemia? VLDL"
"Which serum lipid is elevated in type IV familial dyslipidemia? Triglycerides"
"Patients with type IV familial dyslipidemia often have triglyceride levels around 200 to 500 mg/dL, which typically is not enough to cause pancreatitis"
"Cholesterol synthesis begins with acetyl CoA"
"Where in the cell does cholesterol synthesis occur? Cytoplasm"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme for cholesterol synthesis? HMG CoA reductase"
"HMG CoA reductase is regulated via positive feedback by insulin and thyroxine (T4)"
"HMG CoA reductase is regulated via negative feedback by glucagon and cholesterol"
"HMG CoA is converted to mevalonate via the enzyme HMG CoA reductase (cholesterol synthesis)"
"HMG CoA reductase requires two molecules of NADPH"
"Farnesyl PPi is an intermediate of cholesterol synthesis that is important for synthesis of coenzyme Q (ETC)"
"Dolichol PPi is an intermediate of cholesterol synthesis that is important for N glycosylation of proteins"
"What substance is the primary regulator of membrane fluidity? Cholesterol"
"What substance is the precursor to bile acids, steroids, and vitamin D? Cholesterol"
"What % of plasma cholesterol is esterified by the enzyme LCAT? 67% (2/3rds)"
"What class of drugs inhibits the enzyme HMG CoA reductase? Statins"
"Are statins competitive or non-competitive inhibitors of HMG-CoA reductase? Reversible or irreversible? Reversible competitive inhibitors"
"In adipose tissue, triglycerides are broken down into glycerol and fatty acids by the enzyme hormone sensitive lipase"
"Hormone sensitive lipase is regulated via positive feedback by epinephrine and cortisol"
"Glycerol, from triglyceride breakdown, travels to the liver and is converted to glucose via the process of gluconeogenesis"
"Fatty acids, from triglyceride breakdown, are broken down into acetyl CoA via the process of β-oxidation"
"In preparation for β-oxidation, fatty acids in the cytosol are converted to fatty acyl-CoA via the enzyme fatty acyl-CoA synthetase"
"In the intermembrane space, fatty acyl-CoA is converted to fatty acyl-carnitine via the enzyme carnitine palmitoyl transferase 1 (CPT1)"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid β-oxidation? Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-1 (CPT-1)"
"Where in the cell does β-oxidation occur? Mitochondria"
"Carnitine acyltransferase-1 (CPT-1) is regulated via negative feedback by malonyl CoA"
"Fatty acyl-carnitine is transported from the intermembrane space into the mitochondrial matrix via the carnitine transporter"
"Fatty acyl-carnitine is converted into fatty acyl-CoA via the enzyme carnitine palmitoyl transferase 2 (CPT2)"
"Fatty acyl-CoA is broken down into molecules of acetyl CoA via the enzyme fatty acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (β-oxidation)"
"Each cycle of β-oxidation produces one molecule of FADH2 and one molecule of NADH"
"The acetyl CoA generated through β-oxidation is used for ketogenesis (liver) or the TCA cycle"
"Primary carnitine deficiency is an inherited defect in the transport of long chain fatty acids into the mitochondria"
"Primary carnitine deficiency is characterized by muscle weakness and hypotonia, which is provoked by prolonged exercise (especially if fasting)"
"Primary carnitine deficiency may present with myoglobin-uria"
"Muscle biopsy of a patient with primary carnitine deficiency shows elevated triglycerides"
"The oil red O and sudan black stains are useful for staining lipids"
"The PAS stain is useful for staining glycogen"
"Medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency is characterized by an inability to break down medium-sized fatty acids"
"What is the mode of inheritance of medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency? Autosomal recessive"
"Medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency is characterized by the accumulation of 8 to 10-carbon acyl carnitines in the blood"
"Medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency is characterized by hypo-ketotic, hypo-glycemia"
"Medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency may cause dicarboxylic acidemia/aciduria due to omega oxidation of fatty acids"
"Which type of acyl-CoA dehydrogenase is used to breakdown 8-10 carbon fatty acyl-CoA? Medium (medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase)"
"Medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency may present in infancy or early childhood with vomiting, hyperammonemia, lethargy, seizures, coma, and liver dysfunction"
"Treatment for medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency includes avoiding fasting"
"Where in the cell does ketogenesis occur? Mitochondria"
"In which organ does ketogenesis occur? Liver"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme of ketogenesis? HMG-CoA synthase"
"What are the three ketone bodies? 1. Acetoacetate 2. β-hydroxybutyrate 3. Acetone"
"Ketogenesis begins with acetyl-CoA, which is provided by β-oxidation of fatty acids"
"Acetyl-CoA is converted to HMG-CoA via the enzyme HMG-CoA synthase (ketogenesis)"
"HMG-CoA may be converted to acetoacetate via the enzyme HMG-CoA lyase (ketogenesis)"
"Acetoacetate may spontaneously be converted to acetone, which is expired in the lungs"
"In the liver, acetoacetate may be converted to β-hydroxybutyrate, which then travels to extrahepatic tissues (ketone body metabolism)"
"In extrahepatic tissues, β-hydroxybutyrate may be converted back to acetoacetate via the enzyme β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase"
"In extrahepatic tissues, acetoacetate is activated to acetoacetyl-CoA via the enzyme thiophorase (ketone body metabolism)"
"The acetyl-CoA from acetoacetyl-CoA (ketone body metabolism) is used to generate energy via the Kreb's cycle"
"How many molecules of acetyl CoA are produced from a single ketone body? Two"
"Ketone bodies are primarily used for energy in the brain (starvation state), muscle, and kidney"
"Ketogenesis occurs in alcoholism due to excess NADH, which causes shunting of oxaloacetate to malate"
"Ketoacidosis may cause the breath to have a(n) fruity odor due to exhaled acetone"
"Can a urine test for ketones detect acetoacetate? Yes"
"Can a urine test for ketones detect β-hydroxybutyrate? No"
"A ceramide attached to a sugar (e.g. glucose, galactose) is known as a(n) cerebroside"
"A cerebroside attached to an additional sugar and sialic acid is a(n) ganglioside"
"A ceramide attached to phosphate and choline is a(n) sphingomyelin"
"GM2 ganglioside is converted to GM3 via the enzyme hexosaminidase A"
"The enzyme hexosaminidase A is deficient in Tay-Sachs disease"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Tay-Sachs disease? Autosomal recessive"
"What substrate accumulates in the lysosomes of a patient with Tay-Sachs disease? GM2 ganglioside"
"What ocular finding is classically seen in Tay-Sachs disease? \Cherry-red\\" spot on macula\""
"Does Tay-Sachs disease present with hepatosplenomegaly? No"
"Tay-Sachs disease may present with progressive neurodegeneration and developmental delay"
"Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by an \onion-skin\\" appearance to the lysosomes\""
"Sphingomyelin is converted to ceramide via the enzyme sphingomyelinase"
"The enzyme sphingomyelinase is deficient in Niemann Pick disease"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Niemann Pick disease? Autosomal recessive"
"What substrate accumulates in the lysosomes of a patient with Niemann Pick disease? Sphingomyelin"
"What ocular finding is classically seen in Niemann Pick disease? \Cherry-red\\" spot on macula\""
"Does Niemann Pick disease present with hepatosplenomegaly? Yes"
"Niemann Pick disease may present with progressive neurodegeneration"
"Niemann Pick disease is characterized by foam cells, which are lipid-laden macrophages"
"Glucocerebroside is converted to ceramide via the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase)"
"The enzyme glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase) is deficient in Gaucher disease"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Gaucher disease? Autosomal recessive"
"What substrate accumulates in the lysosomes of a patient with Gaucher disease? Glucocerebroside"
"Does Gaucher disease present with hepatosplenomegaly? Yes"
"Gaucher disease is associated with avascular necrosis of the femur"
"Gaucher disease is characterized by \Gaucher cells\\" which are lipid-laden macrophages resembling crumpled tissue paper\""
"Ceramide trihexoside is converted to glucocerebroside via the enzyme α-galactosidase A"
"The enzyme α-galactosidase A is deficient in Fabry disease"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Fabry disease? X-linked recessive"
"What substrate accumulates in the lysosomes of a patient with Fabry disease? Ceramide trihexoside (globotriaosylceramide)"
"Early Fabry disease presents with a triad of peripheral neuropathy, angiokeratomas, and hypohidrosis"
"Late Fabry disease presents with progressive renal failure and cardiovascular disease"
"Galactocerebroside is converted to ceramide via the enzyme galactocerebrosidase"
"The enzyme galactocerebrosidase is deficient in Krabbe disease"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Krabbe disease? Autosomal recessive"
"What substrates accumulate in the lysosomes of a patient with Krabbe disease? Galactocerebroside and psychosine"
"What ocular pathology does Krabbe disease often present with? Optic atrophy"
"Krabbe disease often presents with peripheral neuropathy and developmental delay"
"Sulfatides are converted to galactocerebroside via the enzyme arylsulfatase A"
"The enzyme arylsulfatase A is deficient in metachromatic leukodystrophy"
"What is the mode of inheritance of metachromatic leukodystrophy? Autosomal recessive"
"What substrate accumulates in the lysosomes of a patient with metachromatic leukodystrophy? Cerebroside sulfate"
"The enzyme α-L-iduronidase is deficient in HurLer syndrome"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Hurler syndrome? Autosomal recessive"
"What substrates accumulate in the lysosomes of a patient with Hurler syndrome? Heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate"
"Does Hurler syndrome present with corneal clouding? Yes"
"Hurler syndrome is also known as gargoylism due to the physical appearance of those afflicted by this disease"
"Hurler syndrome may present with developmental delay, airway obstruction, and hepatosplenomegaly"
"The enzyme iduronaTe-2-sulfatase is deficient in HunTer syndrome"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Hunter syndrome? X-linked recessive"
"What substrates accumulate in the lysosomes of a patient with Hunter syndrome? Heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate"
"Does Hunter syndrome present with corneal clouding? No"
"Hunter syndrome presents as a(n) milder::severity form of Hurler syndrome with aggressive behavior"
"Which lysosomal storage disease is characterized by an \onion skin\\" lysosome? Tay-Sachs disease\""
"Which lysosomal storage disease is characterized by \foam cells\\" (lipid-laden macrophages)? Niemann Pick disease\""
"Which lysosomal storage disease is characterized by a cherry red spot on the macula and no hepatosplenomegaly? Tay-Sachs disease"
"Which lysosomal storage disease is characterized by a cherry red spot on the macula and hepatosplenomegaly? Niemann Pick disease"
"Which lysosomal storage disease is the most common? Gaucher disease"
"Which lysosomal storage disease may be treated with recombinant enzyme therapy? Gaucher disease (i.e. recombinant glucocerebrosidase)"
"Which lysosomal storage disease is characterized by macrophages resembling crumpled tissue paper? Gaucher disease"
"Which lysosomal storage disease is associated with osteoporosis, bone crises, avascular necrosis, and pancytopenia? Gaucher disease"
"Which lysosomal storage disease may present with progressive renal failure and cardiovascular disease? Fabry disease (late)"
"Which lysosomal storage diseases have an X-linked recessive inheritance? Fabry disease, Hunter syndrome::2"
"What lysosomal storage disease presents with globoid cells? Krabbe disease"
"What lysosomal storage disease presents with optic atrophy? Krabbe disease"
"What lysosomal storage disease presents with central and peripheral demyelination with ataxia and dementia? Metachromatic leukodystrophy"
"Which lysosomal storage disease presents with corneal clouding? Hurler syndrome"
"What demographic has an increased incidence of Tay-Sachs, Niemann Pick, and some forms of Gaucher disease? Ashkenazi Jews"
"Incremental reductions in GFR define the stages of chronic kidney disease"
"When an amino acid is metabolized, it is broken down into a carbon skeleton and NH3 (highly toxic)"
"Urea has two nitrogen molecules, one from NH3 and one from aspartate. Note that it's not from  arginine even though it's also involved in the urea cycle"
"In the muscle, amino acids transfer their NH3 group to α-ketoglutarate, forming glutamate and α-ketoacids"
"In the muscle, glutamate transfers its NH3 group to pyruvate, forming alanine and α-ketoglutarate"
"The NH3 from amino acid breakdown in muscle is transported into the blood in the form of alanine"
"What class of enzymes is used in the transfer of NH3 groups during nitrogen metabolism? Aminotransferases"
"What vitamin acts as a cofactor for aminotransferase enzymes? B6 (Pyridoxal phosphate)"
"In the liver, alanine transfers its NH3 group to α-ketoglutarate, forming glutamate and pyruvate"
"In the liver, glutamate may transfer a molecule of NH3 to the urea cycle, reforming α-ketoglutarate"
"In the liver, amino acids transfer their NH3 group to α-ketoglutarate, forming glutamate and α-ketoacids"
"In the liver, glutamate may transfer its NH3 to oxaloacetate, forming aspartate and α-ketoglutarate"
"In the intestine, NH3 may be produced by intestinal bacteria"
"In the intestine, NH3 may be produced via the breakdown of the amino acid glutamine"
"The NH3 in the intestine may be transported to the liver in the form of NH3 in the portal blood"
"What is the major transport form of NH3 in the blood (from most tissues)? Glutamine"
"In the kidney, glutamine may be broken down into NH3 and glutamate via the enzyme glutaminase"
"NH3 is excreted in the urine primarily in the form of urea (from the liver) and NH4+ (from glutamine breakdown)"
"Which tissue/organ uses alanine as its major transport form of NH3? Muscle"
"Which tissue/organ uses NH3 as its major transport form of NH3? Intestines (via portal blood)"
"Does glutamine cause a change in blood pH? No"
"Does glutamate cause a change in blood pH? Yes (decreased)"
"Does the urea cycle occur in the cytoplasm or mitochondria? Both :)"
"Most excess nitrogen generated by catabolism of amino acids is excreted as urea, which is made in the liver"
"The urea cycle begins with NH3, CO2, and 2 ATP"
"In the first step of the urea cycle, CO2 and NH4+ are combined to form carbamoyl phosphate via the enzyme carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (requires 2 ATP)"
"Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I is regulated via positive feedback by N-acetylglutamate"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme of the urea cycle? Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I"
"N-acetylglutamate is a(n) obligate activator of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I"
"Which metabolic enzymes require an obligate activator? 1. Pyruvate carboxylase (acetyl-CoA), not decarboxylase b/c that's different 2. Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (N-acetylglutamate)"
"Which metabolic pathways require an obligate activator? 1. Gluconeogenesis 2. Urea cycle"
"Carbamoyl phosphate may be combined with ornithine to form citrulline via the enzyme ornithine transcarbamylase"
"Citrulline may be combined with aspartate to form argininosuccinate via the enzyme argininosuccinate synthetase (requires 1 ATP)"
"Argininosuccinate may be broken down into arginine and fumarate via the enzyme argininosuccinase"
"Arginine may be broken down into ornithine and urea via the enzyme arginase"
"What happens to the urea that is formed via the breakdown of arginine? Excreted in the urine"
"What happens to the ornithine that is formed via the breakdown of arginine (urea cycle)? It is recycled"
"How do levels of serum BUN change with liver dysfunction? Decreased"
"How do levels of serum BUN change with kidney dysfunction? Increased BUN"
"Disorders of the urea cycle interfere with the body's ability to eliminate ammonia (NH3)"
"Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency presents with increased NH4+ and hyper-ammonemia"
"Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency presents with increased glutamine"
"Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency presents with decreased BUN"
"What is the mode of inheritance of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency? Autosomal recessive"
"Does carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency present with orotic aciduria? No"
"What other enzyme deficiency presents identically to carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency? N-acetylglutamate synthase deficiency"
"Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency presents in neonates::age group as poorly regulated respiration and body temperature, poor feeding, developmental delay, and intellectual disability"
"What is the most common urea cycle disorder? Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency"
"What is the mode of inheritance of ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? X-linked recessive"
"Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency often presents within the first few days of life but may present later"
"Does ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency present with orotic aciduria? Yes"
"Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency presents with increased NH4+ and hyper-ammonemia"
"Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency presents with increased serum glutamine"
"Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency presents with decreased BUN"
"Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency presents with increased orotic acid in the blood and urine"
"Does ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency present with megaloblastic anemia? No"
"Hyperammonemia results in excess NH3, which depletes α-ketoglutarate, leading to inhibition of the TCA cycle"
"Part of the treatment for hyperammonemia is limiting protein in the diet"
"What treatment for hyperammonemia acts by acidifying the GI tract, thus trapping NH4+ for excretion? Lactulose"
"What treatment for hyperammonemia acts by decreasing colonic ammoniagenic bacteria? Rifaximin"
"Symptoms of hyperammonemia include tremor (asterixis), slurred speech, somnolence, vomiting, cerebral edema, and blurry vision"
"Phenylalanine may be converted to tyrosine via the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (with tetrahydrobiopterin as a cofactor) BH4 is also a cofactor for  tyrosine hydroxylases"
"Deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase causes phenylketonuria (PKU)"
"In addition to phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency (classic PKU), Malignant phenylketonuria is most commonly caused by a(n) dihydrobiopterin reductase deficiency"
"What amino acid becomes essential in patients with phenylketonuria? Tyrosine"
"Increased phenylalanine (e.g. in PKU) results in excess phenylketones in the urine"
"What is the mode of inheritance of phenylketonuria (PKU)? Autosomal recessive (incidence ~ 1:10,000)"
"When are patients screened for phenylketonuria? 2-3 days after birth"
"Why is screening for phenylketonuria performed 2-3 days after birth? May be normal at birth due to maternal enzymes"
"Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a metabolic disorder characterized by a(n) musty body odor"
"Patients with phenylketonuria must avoid the artificial sweetener aspartame, which contains phenylalanine"
"Phenylketones include phenylacetate, phenyllactate, and phenylpyruvate"
"Phenylketonuria may present with fair skin, eczema, intellectual disability, growth retardation, and seizures"
"Maternal phenylketonuria is due to lack of proper dietary therapy during pregnancy"
"Maternal PKU, infant presents with: micro-cephaly intellectual disability growth retardation congenital heart defects::[4]"
"Treatment for phenylketonuria includes a diet low in phenylalanine with supplemental tyrosine +/- tetrahydrobiopterin"
"Homogentisic acid (from tyrosine) may be converted to maleylacetoacetate (MAA)  via the enzyme homogentisate oxidase"
"Deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase causes alkaptonuria"
"What is the mode of inheritance of alkaptonuria? Autosomal recessive"
"Which metabolic disorder is associated with bluish-black connective tissue and sclerae (ochronosis)? Alkaptonuria"
"Alkaptonuria is associated with bluish-black connective tissue and sclerae, which is termed ochronosis"
"Alkaptonuria is a metabolic disorder associated with black-colored urine after prolonged exposure to air"
"Alkaptonuria is usually benign but may present with debilitating arthralgias"
"Maleylacetoacetate, from homogentisic acid, is used to make fumarate, which then enters the Kreb's cycle"
"Leucine is eventually broken down into acetyl-CoA via the enzyme branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase"
"Isoleucine and valine are eventually broken down into propionyl-CoA via the enzyme branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase"
"Deficiency of the enzyme branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase causes maple syrup urine disease"
"Maple syrup urine disease is characterized by blocked degradation of branched amino acids"
"Maple syrup urine disease causes increased α-ketoacids in the blood, especially those of leucine"
"What is the mode of inheritance of maple syrup urine disease? Autosomal recessive"
"Maple syrup urine disease presents with vomiting, poor feeding, and urine that smells like burnt sugar"
"Maple syrup urine disease may cause severe CNS defects, intellectual disability, and death"
"Dietary ingestion of which amino acids should be restricted in patients with maple syrup urine disease? Leucine, Isoleucine, Valine::3"
"Treatment of maple syrup urine disease includes high-dose thiamine supplementation"
"Propionyl-CoA may be generated via the \VOMIT\\" pathway: V: valine O: odd-carbon fatty acids M: methionine I: isoleucine T: threonine\""
"Propionyl-CoA is converted to methylmalonyl-CoA via the enzyme propionyl-CoA carboxylase"
"Propionyl-CoA carboxylase requires ATP, biotin, and CO2"
"Methylmalonyl-CoA may be converted to succinyl-CoA via the enzyme methylmalonyl-CoA mutase (with vitamin B12 as a cofactor)"
"If methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is dysfunctional, methylmalonic acid accumulates in the blood and urine"
"Homocysteine may be converted to cystathionine via the enzyme cystathionine synthase (with B6 as a cofactor)"
"Homocysteine may be converted to methionine via the enzyme methionine synthase (with methyl-THF and vitamin B12 as cofactors)"
"Methionine is combined with adenosine (using ATP) to form S-adenosylmethionine (SAM)"
"S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) is a(n) methyl donor"
"S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) donates a CH3 group to anabolic pathways, forming S-adenosylhomocysteine"
"S-adenosylhomocysteine breaks down into adenosine and homocysteine"
"Homocystinuria is a metabolic disorder characterized by excess homocysteine"
"What is the mode of inheritance of homocystinuria? Autosomal recessive"
"What enzyme deficiencies may cause homocystinuria? Cystathionine synthase and methionine synthase deficiencies"
"In addition to enzyme deficiencies, homocystinuria may be caused by decreased affinity of cystathionine synthase for pyridoxal phosphate (B6, active form)"
"Homocystinuria due to cystathionine synthase deficiency is treated with decreased methionine and increased cysteine, B6, B12, and folate in the diet"
"Homocystinuria due to decreased affinity of cystathionine synthase for B6 is treated with very increased B6 and increased cysteine in the diet"
"Homocystinuria due to methionine synthase deficiency is treated with increased methionine in the diet"
"Homocystinuria is usually caused by vitamin deficiencies"
"Homocystinuria is a metabolic disorder that may present with marfanoid habitus, however with lens dislocation that subluxes down and in"
"Homocystinuria typically presents with subluxation of the lenses downward::direction and inward::direction"
"Homocystinuria may present with intellectual disability, osteoporosis, and kyphosis"
"Homocystinuria causes increased risk for thrombosis and atherosclerosis, which may cause stroke and MI"
"Aortic dissection may present with markedly unequal blood pressure in the arms"
"Folate may be converted to dihydrofolate via the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase"
"Dihydrofolate may be converted to tetrahydrofolate via the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase"
"Tetrahydrofolate (THF) serves as a 1-carbon carrier"
"Active tetrahydrofolate is used in the synthesis of purines and thymidine, which may then be used for DNA and RNA cell division"
"Reduced tetrahydrofolate (methyl-THF) is the storage form of THF"
"Methyl-THF (reduced THF) is used by the enzyme methionine synthase to convert homocysteine to methionine"
"Tyrosine is converted to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) via the enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase (with tetrahydrobiopterin as a cofactor)"
"Dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) may be converted to melanin via the enzyme tyrosinase"
"Deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase causes albinism"
"Dihydroxyphenylalaline (DOPA) may be converted to dopamine via the enzyme DOPA decarboxylase (with vitamin B6 as a cofactor)"
"Dopamine may be converted to norepinephrine via the enzyme dopamine β-hydroxylase (with vitamin C as a cofactor)"
"Norepinephrine may be converted to epinephrine via the enzyme phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase (with SAM as a cofactor) and stimulated by cortisol"
"What is the initial breakdown product of epinephrine? Metanephrine"
"Norepinephrine may be broken down into normetanephrine via the enzyme catechol-O-methyl transferase"
"What is the breakdown product of normetanephrine (from NE) and metanephrine (from EPI)? Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA)"
"What is the breakdown product of dopamine? Homovanillic acid (HVA)"
"What is the male remnant of the müllerian (paramesonephric) duct? Appendix testis +bonus"
"Which type of lung carcinoma may present with cavitations on CXR? Squamous cell carcinoma"
"Where in the cell does nucleotide synthesis (purines, pyrimidines) occur? Cytoplasm"
"Pyrimidine synthesis begins with glutamine, CO2, and 2ATP"
"In the first step of pyrimidine synthesis, glutamine and CO2 are combined to form carbamoyl phosphate via the enzyme carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (requires 2 ATP)"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme of de novo pyrimidine synthesis? Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II"
"Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II is regulated by positive feedback via ATP and PRPP"
"Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II is regulated by negative feedback via UTP"
"Carbamoyl phosphate is combined with aspartate to form orotic acid (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"Leflunomide inhibits the enzyme dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, which normally catalyzes the formation of orotic acid from carbamoyl phosphate and aspartate (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"Orotic acid is combined with phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) to form UMP (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"Orotic aciduria occurs due to the inability to convert orotic acid to UMP due to a defect in the enzyme UMP synthase (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"What is the mode of inheritance of orotic aciduria? Autosomal recessive"
"Orotic aciduria presents in children as failure to thrive, developmental delay, and megaloblastic anemia refractory to folate and B12 "
"Does orotic aciduria present with hyperammonemia? No"
"Does orotic aciduria present with decreased BUN? No"
"Orotic aciduria is treated with UMP or uridine triacetate to bypass the mutated enzyme"
"UMP is converted to UDP (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"UDP is converted to dUDP via the enzyme ribonucleotide reductase (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"Hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleotide reductase, which normally catalyzes conversion of UDP to dUDP (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"dUDP is converted to dUMP (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"dUMP is converted to dTMP via the enzyme thymidylate synthase (with N5,N10-methylene THF as a cofactor)"
"5-fluorouracil (5-FU) inhibits thymidylate synthase, which catalyzes conversion of dUMP to dTMP (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"Methotrexate (MTX) inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase in eukaryotes::eu/pro (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"Trimethoprim (TMP) inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase in prokaryotes::eu/pro (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"Pyrimethamine inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase in protozoa (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"Conversion of dUMP to dTMP via thymidylate synthase requires conversion of methylene THF to DHF"
"In addition to glutamine, what other amino acid is necessary for pyrimidine synthesis? Aspartate"
"Where in the cell is the carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I enzyme found? Mitochondria (urea cycle)"
"Where in the cell is the carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II enzyme found? Cytoplasm (pyrimidine synthesis)"
"Purine synthesis begins with ribose-5-phosphate (salvage pathway)"
"Ribose-5-phosphate is converted to phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) via the enzyme PRPP synthetase"
"Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) is converted to 5-phosphoribosylamine via the enzyme PRPP amidotransferase (purine synthesis)"
"6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) and azathioprine directly inhibit PRPP amidotransferase, which normally catalyzes conversion of PRPP to 5-phosphoribosylamine (purine synthesis)"
"What prodrug is metabolized to 6-mercaptopurine and thus inhibits de novo purine synthesis? Azathioprine"
"5-phosphoribosylamine is converted to IMP, which may then be converted to AMP or GMP (purine synthesis)"
"Mycophenolate and ribavirin inhibit IMP dehydrogenase, preventing conversion of IMP to GMP (purine synthesis)"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme of de novo purine synthesis? Glutamine-PRPP amidotransferase"
"Glutamine-PRPP amidotransferase (purine synthesis) is regulated by negative feedback via AMP, IMP, and GMP"
"Inosine is a ribose plus a(n) hypoxanthine"
"AMP is broken down into adenosine (purine salvage)"
"Adenosine is converted to inosine via the enzyme adenosine deaminase (purine salvage)"
"Adenosine deaminase deficiency is one of the major causes of autosomal recessive severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)"
"In adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency, dATP accumulates to toxic levels in lymphocytes"
"GMP is broken down into guanosine (purine salvage)"
"Guanosine is converted to guanine via the enzyme purine nucleoside phosphorylase (purine salvage)"
"Inosine is converted to hypoxanthine via the enzyme purine nucleoside phosphorylase (purine salvage)"
"Hypoxanthine may be converted to xanthine via the enzyme xanthine oxidase"
"Xanthine may be converted to uric acid via the enzyme xanthine oxidase"
"Allopurinol and febuxostat inhibit the enzyme xanthine oxidase, thus decreasing urinary excretion of uric acid"
"Probenecid is a drug used to increase the renal excretion of uric acid"
"Hypoxanthine may be converted to IMP via the enzyme HGPRT (purine salvage)"
"Guanine may be converted to GMP via the enzyme HGPRT (purine salvage)"
"The enzyme HGPRT is deficient in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome"
"HGPRT deficiency (Lesch-Nyhan syndrome) results in increased production of uric acid"
"HGPRT deficiency (Lesch-Nyhan syndrome) results in increased de novo purine synthesis"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome? X-linked recessive"
"The symptoms of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome may be remembered with the mnemonic \HGPRT\\": H: Hyperuricemia G: Gout P: Pissed off (aggression"
"Lesch-Nyhan syndrome may present with orange \sand\\" sodium urate crystals in the diaper of an infant\""
"Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is treated with allopurinol or febuxostat::2nd line"
"How much energy (kcal) can be produced from 1g of protein or carbohydrate (ex. whey)? 4 kcal"
"How much energy (kcal) can be produced from 1g of fat? 9 kcal"
"How much energy (kcal) can be produced from 1g of alcohol? 7 kcal"
"During fasting and starvation, the priority is to supply sufficient glucose to the brain and RBCs while preserving protein"
"The main sources of energy in a fed state are glycolysis and aerobic respiration"
"What is the major source of energy while fasting between meals? Hepatic glycogenolysis"
"Glycogen stores typically are depleted after 12 - 18 hours"
"Can red blood cells use ketones for energy? Why? No, they lack mitochondria"
"Propionyl CoA is the only fatty acid carbon that may be used to make glucose (via gluconeogenesis)"
"After 1 - 3 days of starvation, the muscle and liver shift fuel use from glucose to free fatty acids"
"What is the major source of energy during fasting (1-3 days)? Hepatic gluconeogenesis"
"After three days of starvation, the main source of energy for the brain becomes ketone bodies from adipose stores"
"After adipose stores have been depleted (prolonged starvation), vital protein degradation accelerates, leading to organ failure and death"
"What is the major source of energy during the first 2 seconds of exercise? Stored ATP"
"What is the major source of energy during the first 2 - 7 seconds of exercise? Creatine phosphate"
"What is the major source of energy during the first minute of exercise? Anaerobic metabolism"
"What is the major source of energy after a few minutes of exercise? Aerobic metabolism"
"Which vitamins are fat-soluble? A, D, E, K::4"
"Is toxicity more common for water-soluble or fat-soluble vitamins? Fat-soluble (vitamins can accumulate in fat)"
"Fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies may occur with mineral oil intake, which can be used to treat constipation"
"Fat-soluble deficiencies may occur with syndromes that cause steatorrhea (e.g. cystic fibrosis and sprue)"
"Absorption of fat-soluble vitamins is dependent on the gut and pancreas"
"Vitamin A is also known as retinol"
"The retinal form of vitamin A is a constituent of visual pigments"
"Vitamin A is a co-factor for the synthesis of the visual pigment rhodopsin"
"Vitamin A is essential for normal differentiation of epithelial cells into specialized tissue (e.g. pancreatic cells, mucus secreting cells)"
"Vitamin A prevents squamous metaplasia"
"Vitamin A may be used to treat measles and acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML)"
"Vitamin A is found in liver and leafy vegetables::food"
"Oral isotretinoin (vitamin A) is used to treat severe cystic acne"
"What vitamin is used topically for wrinkles and acne? Vitamin A"
"All-trans-retinoic acid (vitamin A) is used to treat acute promyelocytic leukemia"
"One sign of vitamin A deficiency is night blindness (nyctalopia)"
"One sign of vitamin A deficiency is dry, scaly skin (xerosis cutis)"
"One sign of vitamin A deficiency is corneal degeneration, known as keratomalacia"
"One sign of vitamin A deficiency is bitot spots on conjunctiva due to squamous metaplasia of corneal epithelium"
"What effect does vitamin A deficiency have on the immune system? Immunosuppression"
"Acute vitamin A toxicity presents with nausea, vomiting, vertigo, and blurred vision"
"Chronic vitamin A toxicity may cause alopecia::hair complication and dry skin"
"Chronic vitamin A toxicity may cause hepatic toxicity and enlargement"
"Chronic vitamin A toxicity may cause pseudotumor cerebri::CNS complication"
"Chronic vitamin A toxicity may cause arthralgias::joint complication"
"Which vitamin supplement may be contraindicated during pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects? Vitamin A (isotretinoin)"
"Teratogenic effects of vitamin A include cardiac abnormalities and cleft palate"
"A negative pregnancy test and two forms of contraception are required before isotretinoin (vitamin A) is prescribed"
"Vitamin A exerts its teratogenic effects by interfering with homeobox genes"
"Vitamin B1 is also known as thiamine"
"What is the coenzyme (active) form of vitamin B1? Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)"
"Thiamine pyrophosphate (B1) is a cofactor for the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase (glycolysis)"
