"Thiamine pyrophosphate (B1) is a cofactor for the enzyme α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (TCA cycle)"
"Thiamine pyrophosphate (B1) is a cofactor for the enzyme transketolase (HMP shunt)"
"Thiamine pyrophosphate (B1) is a cofactor for the enzyme branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase (amino acid metabolism)"
"Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency causes impaired glucose breakdown with consequent ATP depletion"
"Which tissues are affected first in vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency? Highly aerobic tissue (e.g. brain, heart)"
"Vitamin B1 deficiency is seen in alcoholism and malnutrition"
"One complication of vitamin B1 deficiency is Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome"
"Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion"
"Is the memory loss associated with Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome temporary or permanent? Permanent"
"Vitamin B1 deficiency is associated with wet and dry beriberi"
"Wet beriberi is characterized by high-output cardiac failure (dilated cardiomyopathy) and edema +/- dry beriberi symptoms"
"Dry beriberi is characterized by polyneuritis and symmetrical muscle wasting"
"Diagnosis of B1 (thiamine) deficiency is made by measuring increased transketolase activity in red blood cells following thiamine administration"
"Vitamin B2 is also known as riboflavin"
"Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) is a precursor to FAD and FMN"
"Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) is involved in many redox reactions"
"Vitamin B2 deficiency is characterized by cheilosis and corneal vascularization"
"Inflammation of the lips with scaling and fissures at the corners of the mouth is known as cheilosis"
"Vitamin B2 deficiency may be associated with a(n) magenta-colored tongue"
"Vitamin B3 is also known as niacin"
"Vitamin B3 (niacin) is a constituent of NAD+ and NADP+"
"Synthesis of vitamin B3 (niacin) requires vitamins B2 and B6"
"Vitamin B3 (niacin) is involved in many redox reactions"
"What vitamin is derived from the amino acid tryptophan? Vitamin B3 (niacin)"
"Vitamin B3 (niacin) is used to treat dyslipidemia"
"Mild deficiencies of vitamin B3 cause glossitis"
"Severe deficiencies of vitamin B3 can lead to pellagra"
"Pellagra (from severe B3 deficiency) may be caused by Hartnup disease, malignant carcinoid syndrome, and isoniazid therapy"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Hartnup disease? Autosomal recessive"
"Hartnup disease is due to a deficiency of neutral amino acid transporters (especially tryptophan) in the proximal renal tubular cells and enterocytes"
"Hartnup disease is characterized by neutral aminoaciduria and decreased neutral AA absorption (esp. tryptophan) from the gut"
"Hartnup disease is treated with a high-protein diet and nicotinic acid (niacin)"
"Malignant carcinoid syndrome is characterized by increased metabolism of the amino acid tryptophan"
"Isoniazid therapy indirectly decreases vitamin B3 by decreasing levels of vitamin B6"
"What change in bowel movement is associated with pellagra (B3 deficiency)? Diarrhea"
"What CNS complication is associated with pellagra (B3 deficiency)? Dementia (also hallucinations)"
"Pellagra is a vitamin deficiency complication associated with dermatitis in a(n) C3/C4 dermatome distribution"
"Pellagra (B3 deficiency) is associated with hyper-pigmentation of sun-exposed limbs"
"Vitamin B3 (niacin) excess is characterized by facial flushing; can be avoided by taking NSAIDs if given 30-60 minutes before administration"
"The facial flushing seen with vitamin B3 excess is mediated by prostaglandins"
"Vitamin B3 (niacin) excess is associated with hyper-glycemia and hyper-uricemia"
"Vitamin B5 is also known as pantothenic acid"
"Vitamin B5 (pantothenic acid) is an essential component of coenzyme A and fatty acid synthase"
"Vitamin B5 deficiency (rare) presents with dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, and adrenal insufficiency"
"Vitamin B6 is also known as pyridoxine"
"What is the coenzyme (active) form of vitamin B6? Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP)"
"What vitamin is used as a cofactor for transamination, decarboxylation reactions, and glycogen phosphorylase? B6 (pyridoxal phosphate)"
"B6 (pyridoxal phosphate) is used as a cofactor for synthesis of cystathionine, heme, histamine, neurotransmitters, and niacin::5 things?"
"Vitamin B6 deficiency may occur with isoniazid and oral contraceptive use"
"Vitamin B6 deficiency is characterized by sideroblastic anemia and peripheral neuropathy"
"Vitamin B7 is also known as biotin"
"Vitamin B7 (biotin) is a cofactor for carboxylation reactions"
"Vitamin B7 (biotin) is a cofactor for the enzyme pyruvate carboxylase (gluconeogenesis)"
"Vitamin B7 (biotin) is a cofactor for the enzyme acetyl-CoA carboxylase (fatty acid synthesis)"
"Vitamin B7 (biotin) is a cofactor for the enzyme propionyl-CoA carboxylase (propionyl CoA metabolism)"
"Vitamin B7 (biotin) deficiency may be caused by excessive ingestion of raw eggs, which contain avidin"
"In addition to ingestion of raw eggs, vitamin B7 (biotin) deficiency may occur with antibiotic use or biotinidase deficiency"
"Vitamin B7 (biotin) deficiency presents with alopecia, macular dermatitis, mental status changes, enteritis, and lactic acidosis"
"Vitamin B9 is also known as folate"
"Vitamin B9 (folate) is converted to tetrahydrofolate (THF), a coenzyme for 1-carbon::# transfer/methylation reactions"
"Which vitamin is important for synthesis of nitrogenous bases in DNA and RNA? B9 (folate)"
"Vitamin B9 (folate) is absorbed in the jejunum of the small intestine"
"Vitamin B9 (folate) is found in leafy green vegetables"
"Vitamin B9 (folate) is stored in the liver for up to 3-4 months"
"What is the most common vitamin deficiency in the U.S.? Folate (vitamin B9)"
"Vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency most commonly occurs due to pregnancy, alcoholism, or drugs (e.g. phenytoin, sulfonamides, methotrexate)"
"Supplemental maternal folic acid in early pregnancy decreases risk of neural tube defects"
"What type of anemia is seen with vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency? Macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia"
"Vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency is characterized by hypersegmented polymorphonuclear cells (PMNs)"
"Does vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency cause neurologic symptoms? No"
"Vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency is characterized by normal methylmalonic acid levels"
"Vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency is characterized by increased homocysteine levels"
"A nonspecific symptom of vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency is glossitis::tongue"
"Vitamin B12 is also known as cobalamin"
"Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is a cofactor for methionine synthase and methylmalonyl-CoA mutase"
"Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is found in animal products"
"Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is synthesized only by microorganisms"
"Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is stored in the liver for up to 3-4 years"
"One cause of pernicious anemia is lack of intrinsic factor, which leads to vitamin B12 deficiency"
"Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are diagnostic for pernicious anemia"
"One cause of vitamin B12 deficiency is gastric bypass surgery (ex. Roux-en-Y, Sleeve Gastrectomy)"
"One cause of vitamin B12 deficiency is damage to or resection of the terminal ileum (e.g. Crohn disease)"
"One cause of vitamin B12 deficiency is insufficient intake, which may occur with vegan diets"
"One cause of vitamin B12 deficiency is malabsorption (e.g. sprue, enteritis)"
"What parasite is associated with vitamin B12 deficiency? Diphyllobothrium latum"
"The Schilling test is useful in determining the etiology of vitamin B12 deficiency"
"What type of anemia is seen with vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency? Macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia::caused by B12, not causes B12"
"Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency is characterized by hypersegmented polymorphonuclear cells (PMNs)"
"Does vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency cause neurologic symptoms? Yes"
"Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency is characterized by increased methylmalonic acid levels"
"Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency is characterized by increased homocysteine levels"
"Prolonged vitamin B12 deficiency causes irreversible nerve damage"
"Vitamin C is also known as ascorbic acid"
"Vitamin C keeps iron in the Fe2+ state which increases absorption"
"Vitamin C is necessary for hydroxylation of proline and lysine in collagen synthesis"
"Vitamin C is necessary for the enzyme dopamine β-hydroxylase, which converts dopamine to norepinephrine"
"Vitamin C is found in fruits and vegetables"
"Vitamin C is used as an ancillary treatment for methemoglobinemia"
"What pathology is associated with vitamin C deficiency? Scurvy"
"What vitamin deficiency is commonly characterized by swollen gums, bruising, petechiae, and hemarthrosis? Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy)"
"Scurvy (vitamin C deficiency) is associated with poor wound healing"
"Scurvy is associated with perifollicular hemorrhages and subperiosteal hemorrhages"
"Scurvy is associated with \corkscrew\\" hair and loosening of the teeth\""
"What effect does vitamin C deficiency have on the immune system? Weakened immune response"
"Vitamin C deficiency is characterized by a(n) increased bleeding time"
"Vitamin C deficiency is characterized by a(n) normal PT and increased PTT"
"Vitamin C excess may cause calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis"
"Vitamin C excess can increase risk of iron toxicity in predisposed individuals (e.g. those with transfusions, hemochromatosis)"
"Vitamin D2, known as ergocalciferol, is the form ingested from plants, fungi, and yeasts"
"Vitamin D3, known as cholecalciferol, is the form consumed in milk, fish, plants, and formed in sun-exposed skin"
"In which layer of sun-exposed skin is cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) formed? Stratum basale"
"What is the storage form of vitamin D? 25-OH D3"
"What is the active form of vitamin D? 1,25-(OH)2 D3"
"Vitamin D increases intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate"
"At low levels, vitamin D increases bone mineralization"
"At high levels, vitamin D increases bone resorption"
"Vitamin D deficiency causes rickets in children; presents as bone pain and deformity"
"Vitamin D deficiency causes osteomalacia in adults; presents as bone pain, muscle weakness"
"Vitamin D deficiency is associated with hypocalcemic tetany"
"What vitamin should be orally supplemented in breastfed infants? Vitamin D"
"Vitamin D deficiency is exacerbated by low sun exposure, pigmented skin, and prematurity"
"Vitamin D excess presents with hyper-calcemia and hyper-calciuria"
"Vitamin D excess may present with stupor and decreased appetite"
"Vitamin D excess is seen in granulomatous diseases due to increased activation of vitamin D by epithelioid macrophages"
"Vitamin E is also referred to as tocopherol or tocotrienol"
"Vitamin E primarily functions as a(n) antioxidant; protects RBCs and membranes from free radical damage"
"Vitamin E can enhance the anticoagulant effects of warfarin"
"Vitamin E deficiency may cause hemolytic anemia and acanthocytosis::cells (hematologic complications)"
"Vitamin E deficiency may cause muscle weakness"
"What vitamin deficiency has similar neurologic presentation to B12 deficiency but lacks megaloblastic anemia? Vitamin E deficiency"
"Vitamin K is also referred to as phytomenadione, phylloquinone, and phytonadione"
"Vitamin K is a cofactor for the γ-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues on various proteins required for blood clotting"
"Vitamin K is synthesized by colonic bacteria"
"Vitamin K injection is given at birth to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn"
"Does breast milk contain vitamin K? No"
"Vitamin K deficiency may cause neonatal hemorrhage"
"Vitamin K deficiency is characterized by a(n) normal bleeding time"
"Vitamin K deficiency is characterized by a(n) increased PT and increased PTT"
"Vitamin K deficiency can occur after prolonged use of broad-spectrum antibiotics"
"What vitamins function as antioxidants? Vitamins A, C, and E::3"
"Zinc is a mineral that is essential for the activity of 100+ enzymes"
"Zinc is a mineral that is important in the formation of zinc fingers::transcription factor motif"
"Zinc deficiency is associated with delayed wound healing"
"Zinc deficiency is a trace mineral deficiency that is associated with hypo-gonadism"
"Zinc deficiency is a trace mineral deficiency that is associated with decreased adult hair (axillary, facial, pubic)"
"What senses are impaired with zinc deficiency? Taste (dysgeusia) and smell (anosmia)"
"What mineral deficiency is associated with acrodermatitis enteropathica? Zinc deficiency"
"Zinc deficiency may predispose to alcoholic cirrhosis"
"Kwashiorkor is a malnutrition disorder that results from a(n) protein-deficient diet"
"The symptoms of Kwashiorkor may be remembered with the mnemonic \MEALS\\": M: Malnutrition E: Edema A: Anemia L: Liver (fatty) S: Skin lesions (dyspigmentation"
"Kwashiorkor may present with edema (due to decreased plasma oncotic pressure) and skin lesions"
"Kwashiorkor may present as liver malfunction with fatty change due to decreased apolipoprotein synthesis"
"What malnutrition disorder presents as a small child with a swollen abdomen? Kwashiorkor"
"Marasmus is a malnutrition disorder that results from a(n) calorie-deficient diet"
"Marasmus is a malnutrition disorder characterized by emaciation with tissue and muscle wasting and loss of subcutaneous fat +/- edema"
"The neurologic symptoms seen in vitamin B12 deficiency are due to abnormal myelin"
"Vitamin B12 deficiency presents with paresthesias and subacute combined degeneration (neurologic symptoms)"
"Subacute combined degeneration in vitamin B12 deficiency affects the dorsal columns, corticospinal tracts, and spinocerebellar tracts"
"Vitamin E deficiency may cause Posterior (Dorsal) Column and Spinocerebellar tract demyelination"
"Increased NADH/NAD+ (e.g. due to ethanol) causes increased conversion of dihydroxyacetone phosphate -> glycerol-3-phosphate, which combines with fatty acids to make triglycerides, leading to hepatosteatosis (liver pathology)"
"Increased NADH/NAD+ (e.g. due to ethanol) causes decreased TCA activity, thus increasing utilization of acetyl-CoA for ketogenesis and lipogenesis"
"A(n) kinase enzyme catalyzes transfer of a phosphate group from a high-energy molecule (e.g. ATP) to a substrate"
"A(n) phosphorylase enzyme adds inorganic phosphate onto a substrate without using ATP"
"A(n) phosphatase enzyme removes phosphate from a substrate"
"A dehydrogenase enzyme catalyzes redox reactions"
"A(n) hydroxylase enzyme adds a hydroxyl group onto a substrate"
"A(n) carboxylase enzyme transfers CO2 groups (usually with the help of biotin)"
"A(n) mutase enzyme relocates a functional group within a molecule"
"Aerobic metabolism of glucose produces 32 net ATP via the malate-aspartate shuttle (heart and liver)"
"Aerobic metabolism of glucose produces 30 net ATP via the glycerol-3-phosphate shuttle (muscle)"
"Arsenic is a heavy metal that causes glycolysis to produce zero net ATP"
"NAD+ is generally used as an electron carrier in catabolic::anabolic or catabolic processes"
"NADPH is generally used as an electron carrier in anabolic::anabolic or catabolic processes"
"Which universal electron carrier is used in the cytochrome P-450 system of the liver? NADPH"
"What does the carrier molecule ATP carry in its activated form? Phosphoryl groups"
"What do the carrier molecules NADH, NADPH, and FADH2 carry in their activated forms? Electrons"
"What do the carrier molecules CoA and lipoamide carry in their activated forms? Acyl groups"
"What does the carrier molecule biotin carry in its activated form? CO2"
"What does the carrier molecule tetrahydrofolate carry in its activated form? 1-carbon units"
"What does the carrier molecule S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) carry in its activated form? CH3 groups"
"What does the carrier molecule thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) carry in its activated form? Aldehydes"
"Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency causes a buildup of pyruvate that gets shunted to lactate (via LDH) and alanine (via ALT)"
"What is the most common mode of inheritance of pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency? X-linked"
"Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency presents with neurologic defects and lactic acidosis::breakdown"
"Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is characterized by increased serum alanine starting at infancy"
"Treatment for pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency includes increased intake of ketogenic nutrients"
"Which amino acid is the precursor to nitric oxide? Arginine"
"Which amino acid is the precursor to creatine? Arginine"
"Which amino acid is the precursor to glutathione? Glutamate"
"Which amino acid is the precursor to GABA? Glutamate"
"Which amino acid is the precursor to heme? Glycine"
"Cystinuria is caused by a defect of renal PCT and intestinal amino acid transporters, preventing reabsorption of cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine"
"What is the mode of inheritance of cystinuria? Autosomal recessive (1:7000, common)"
"Treatment for cystinuria includes urinary alkalinization (e.g. potassium citrate, acetazolamide)"
"Cystinuria may be treated with chelating agents, such as penicillamine"
"Cystine is made of two cysteine amino acids connected by a disulfide bond"
"Pyruvate is converted to lactate via the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) (Cori cycle)"
"Conversion of pyruvate -> lactate (Cori cycle) recycles one molecule of NAD+"
"Does the Cori cycle result in regeneration of NAD+? Yes"
"Pyruvate is converted to alanine via the enzyme alanine aminotransferase (ALT) (Cahill cycle)"
"Does the Cahill cycle result in regeneration of NAD+? No"
"Symptoms of acute arsenic toxicity include vomiting, rice-water stools, garlic breath, and QT prolongation"
"Which \Tender Loving Care for Nancy\\" cofactor is inhibited by arsenic? Lipoic acid\""
"Iron is absorbed by enterocytes in the duodenum of the small intestine"
"Heme iron (meat-derived) is readily absorbed and enters the duodenal cell via the heme transporter"
"Non-heme (Fe3+) iron (vegetable-derived) must be converted to Fe2+ in the duodenum / proximal jejunum by cytochrome B and/or Vitamin C for absorption"
"After non-heme iron is converted to Fe2+ by cytochrome B, it enters the duodenal cell by the divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1) transporter"
"Ferrous (Fe2+) iron within the duodenal cell is transported into the blood by the ferroportin transporter"
"In the plasma, Fe2+ is oxidized to Fe3+ by ferroxidase enzymes (e.g. *hephaestin, ceruloplasmin)"
"The Fe3+ iron in the plasma is bound to transferrin for transport in the blood"
"Hepcidin binds to the ferroportin transporter on intestinal mucosal cells and macrophages, thus inhibiting iron absorption"
"What gene (and its respective gene product) regulates hepcidin? HFE"
"Some of the iron absorbed in the duodenum is taken up by hepatocytes for storage as ferritin"
"Some of the iron absorbed in the duodenum is taken up by erythroid precursors in bone marrow to make hemoglobin for RBCs"
"After ~120 days, red blood cells are removed by macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system"
"In the stomach, dietary vitamin B12 is bound to the protein R-binder, which is secreted from the salivary glands"
"In the duodenum, B12 dissociates from R-binder via pancreatic proteases and attaches to intrinsic factor"
"The B12-IF complex from the duodenum is transported to the terminal ileum, where it binds to IF receptors and is endocytosed"
"In the cells of the ileum, the vitamin B12-IF complex dissociates and B12 is bound to transcobalamin II"
"The transcobalamin II-B12 complex is transported to the bone marrow (hematopoiesis) and liver (storage)"
"In the first step of heme synthesis, glycine and succinyl-CoA are combined to form δ-aminolevulinic acid via the enzyme δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase (with vitamin B6 as a cofactor)"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme of heme synthesis? δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase (ALAS)"
"δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase is regulated via negative feedback by glucose and heme"
"Does heme synthesis occur in the cytoplasm or mitochondria? Both :)"
"δ-aminolevulinic acid is converted to porphobilinogen via the enzyme δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (heme synthesis)"
"Porphobilinogen is converted to hydroxymethylbilane via the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase (heme synthesis)"
"Hydroxymethylbilane is converted to uroporphyrinogen III via the enzyme uroporphyrinogen III synthase (heme synthesis)"
"Uroporphyrinogen III is converted to coproporphyrinogen III via the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (heme synthesis)"
"Coproporphyrinogen III is converted to protoporphyrin (heme synthesis)"
"Protoporphyrin and Fe2+ combine to form heme via the enzyme ferrochelatase"
"Lead (Pb) poisoning leads to inhibition of the enzymes δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase and ferrochelatase (heme synthesis)"
"In splenic macrophages, heme is metabolized to biliverdin by the enzyme heme oxygenase"
"In splenic macrophages, biliverdin is reduced to (unconjugated) bilirubin"
"What type of bilirubin (conjugated or unconjugated) is formed in the splenic macrophages? Unconjugated/indirect bilirubin"
"Unconjugated bilirubin travels in the blood bound to albumin"
"Unconjugated bilirubin is removed from the blood by the liver::organ"
"In the liver, unconjugated bilirubin is converted to conjugated bilirubin via the enzyme UDP-glucuronyl transferase"
"Conjugated (direct) bilirubin is excreted in bile and metabolized by bacterial flora, producing urobilinogen"
"Most (80%) of urobilinogen is excreted in feces as stercobilin, which gives stool its brown color"
"~ 18% of urobilinogen is returned to the liver via enterohepatic circulation"
"~ 2% of urobilinogen is excreted in urine as urobilin, which gives urine its yellow color"
"Is unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin water soluble? No (insoluble)"
"Is conjugated (direct) bilirubin water soluble? Yes"
"The \-ogen\\" suffix (e.g. urobilinogen) indicates a(n) colorless::colored or colorless compound\""
"The \-in\\" suffix (e.g. stercobilin) indicates a(n) colored::colored or colorless compound\""
"What chromosomal abnormality is commonly associated with endocardial cushion defects? Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome)"
"The effects of {{c10::cholinergic toxicity may be remembered with the mnemonic \DUMBBELSS\\": D: diarrhea U: urination M: miosis B: bronchospasm B: bradycardia/bradypnea E: excitation of skeletal muscle and CNS L: lacrimation S: salivation S: sweating\""
"Anti-muscarinics block the action of acetylcholine at M receptors"
"What drug class does atropine belong to? Anti-muscarinics"
"Atropine is found in belladona flowers and jimson weed, which are natural antimuscarinic alkaloids"
"What effect do anti-muscarinics have on pupils? Dilation (mydriasis)::dilation or constriction"
"What effect do anti-muscarinics have on accommodation? Inhibition (cycloplegia)"
"What anti-muscarinic is administered as a transdermal patch to treat motion sickness (vestibular nausea)? Scopolamine"
"Scopolamine primarily affects the CNS::organ system via inhibition of M1 muscarinic receptors"
"What effect do anti-muscarinics have on heart rate? Increased HR"
"What effect do anti-muscarinics have on AV conduction velocity? Increased conduction velocity"
"What drug class do ipratropium and tiotropium belong to? Inhaled::ROA M3 antimuscarinics::class"
"Ipratropium and tiotropium primarily affect the lungs::organ via inhibition of M3 muscarinic receptors"
"Anti-muscarinics may be used to dilate bronchial airways and to reduce secretions"
"Which anti-muscarinic (tiotropium or ipratropium) is longer-acting? Tiotropium"
"What drug class do oxybutynin, tolterodine, and solifenacin belong to? Oral M3 muscarinic antagonists"
"Oxybutynin and tolterodine primarily affect the genitourinary system::organ system via inhibition of M3 muscarinic receptors"
"Oxybutynin and tolterodine are primarily used to treat urgency incontinence (overactive bladder)"
"What drug class do benztropine and trihexyphenidyl belong to? M1 Muscarinic antagonists"
"Benztropine and trihexyphenidyl primarily affect the CNS::organ system via inhibition of M1 muscarinic receptors"
"M1 muscarinic antagonists (e.g. Benztropine) can reduce pill rolling tremors and cogwheel rigidity in Parkinson's disease"
"Benztropine may be used to treat extrapyramidal side effects caused by anti-psychotic drugs (e.g. dystonia, akathisia, parkinsonism)"
"What effect does atropine have on the stomach acid secretion? Decreased acid secretion"
"What effect does atropine have on the gut motility? Decreased motility"
"What effect does atropine have on airway secretions? Decreased secretions"
"Atropine may be used to decrease urinary urgency in cystitis"
"Which \DUMBBELSS\\" symptom is NOT alleviated by atropine administration in cholinesterase inhibitor poisoning? Excitation of skeletal muscle and CNS\""
"One adverse effect of anti-muscarinics (e.g. atropine) is tachycardia::HR"
"One adverse effect of anti-muscarinics is hyperthermia, especially in infants"
"Anti-muscarinics cause hyperthermia due to inhibition of sweat glands via antagonism of M3 receptors"
"Adverse effects of anti-muscarinics include dry eyes and mouth"
"One adverse effect of anti-muscarinics is dry, flushed skin"
"Adverse effects of anti-muscarinics on the eye and its muscles (not including glands) include mydriasis and cycloplegia"
"One adverse effect of anti-muscarinics is acute angle-closure glaucoma, especially in elderly patients"
"Anti-muscarinics may cause acute angle-closure glaucoma due to decreased outflow of aqueous humor, secondary to mydriasis"
"One adverse effect of anti-muscarinics is urinary retention, especially in men with prostatic hyperplasia"
"Adverse effects of antimuscarinics include agitation, hallucination, and coma, especially in elderly patients"
"The α1 adrenergic receptor is coupled to Gq"
"The α2 adrenergic receptor is coupled to Gi"
"The β1 and β2 adrenergic receptors are coupled to Gs"
"Activation of the α1 adrenergic receptor causes vaso-constriction"
"Activation of the α1 adrenergic receptor increases mean arterial pressure (MAP)"
"Activation of the α1 adrenergic receptor causes veno-constriction"
"Activation of the α1 adrenergic receptor causes contraction of the pupillary dilator muscle, causing mydriasis"
"Activation of the α1 adrenergic receptor causes contraction of the intestinal and bladder sphincter muscles"
"Activation of the α1 adrenergic receptor may cause urinary retention"
"What effect do α2 agonists have on sympathetic tone? Decreased (sympatholytic)"
"Activation of the α2 adrenergic receptor causes decreased levels of intracellular cAMP"
"Activation of the presynaptic α2 adrenergic receptors can inhibit neurotransmitter release"
"Activation of α2 adrenergic receptors on pancreatic islet cells causes decreased insulin release"
"Activation of α2 adrenergic receptors inhibits lipolysis and release of fatty acids"
"Activation of α2 adrenergic receptors on ciliary bodies causes decreased aqueous humor production"
"Activation of α2 adrenergic receptors causes increased platelet aggregation"
"Brimonidine is a(n) α2 adrenergic agonist used to treat chronic open angle glaucoma"
"Activation of β adrenergic receptors causes increased levels of intracellular cAMP"
"Activation of β1 adrenergic receptors on the SA node causes increased heart rate"
"Activation of β1 adrenergic receptors on the cardiac myocytes causes increased cardiac contractility"
"Activation of β1 adrenergic receptors results in increased cardiac output"
"Activation of β1 adrenergic receptors on the juxtaglomerular cells causes increased renin release"
"Activation of β2 adrenergic receptors causes broncho-dilation"
"Activation of β2 adrenergic receptors causes coronary and skeletal muscle vaso-dilation"
"Activation of β2 adrenergic receptors causes decreased systemic vascular resistance (SVR)"
"Activation of β2 adrenergic receptors causes decreased diastolic blood pressure"
"Activation of β1 and β2 adrenergic receptors stimulates lipolysis and release of fatty acids"
"Activation of β2 adrenergic receptors stimulates gluconeogenesis in the liver"
"Activation of β2 adrenergic receptors on pancreatic islet cells causes increased insulin release"
"What effect does β2 adrenergic activation have on serum K+ levels? Decreased (hypokalemia)"
"Activation of β2 adrenergic receptors on ciliary bodies causes increased aqueous humor production"
"Phenylephrine is primarily a(n) α1::alpha 1 or 2 agonist"
"Phenylephrine may be used to treat nasal congestion"
"Phenylephrine may be used as a(n) mydriatic for ocular procedures"
"Phenylephrine may be used to treat hypo-tension"
"Phenylephrine causes increased systolic pressure"
"Phenylephrine causes increased diastolic pressure through α1-mediated venoconstriction"
"Phenylephrine causes reflex bradycardia::HR"
"Rank the following receptors for affinity to norepinephrine, from highest to lowest: β1, α1, α2, α1> α2 > β1"
"Norepinephrine may be used to treat hypo-tension"
"Norepinephrine causes increased diastolic pressure"
"Norepinephrine causes increased pulse pressure"
"Norepinephrine causes reflex bradycardia::HR"
"Unlike phenylephrine, norepinephrine causes increased cardiac contractility due to β1 activation which results in increased pulse pressure"
"What sympathomimetic catecholamine is used to treat septic shock? Norepinephrine"
"Rank the following receptors for affinity to dobutamine, from highest to lowest: β1, β2, α β1 > β2 > α"
"What effect does dobutamine have on HR and contractility? Increased HR/contractility (β1 agonist)"
"Dobutamine causes mild vaso-dilation"
"Dobutamine causes increased pulse pressure via Beta-1 receptor agonism"
"Dobutamine causes increased systolic pressure"
"Dobutamine causes decreased diastolic pressure"
"What sympathomimetic is used to treat cardiogenic shock? Dobutamine"
"Which sympathomimetic is useful for cardiac stress testing? Dobutamine"
"Isoproterenol acts on β1 and β2 adrenergic receptors"
"Isoproterenol causes increased HR and contractility"
"Isoproterenol causes vaso-dilation"
"Isoproterenol causes decreased diastolic pressure"
"Isoproterenol causes decreased mean arterial pressure via β2-mediated vasodilation"
"Isoproterenol causes increased pulse pressure"
"At low doses, epinephrine primarily activates β adrenergic receptors"
"At high doses, epinephrine primarily activates α adrenergic receptors"
"Epinephrine causes broncho-dilation"
"Epinephrine causes increased HR and cardiac contractility"
"Epinephrine causes increased mean arterial pressure"
"Epinephrine causes increased systolic pressure"
"Epinephrine causes decreased diastolic pressure"
"Epinephrine causes increased pulse pressure"
"What catecholamine is used to treat anaphylactic shock? Epinephrine"
"Catecholamine synthesis begins with transport of the amino acid tyrosine into the nerve terminal"
"Inside the nerve terminal, tyrosine is converted to L-DOPA via tyrosine hydroxylase"
"Metyrosine is a tyrosine analog that prevents conversion of  tyrosine to L-DOPA"
"Dopamine is converted into norepinephrine in the vesicle by dopamine β-hydroxylase"
"Norepinephrine (and dopamine) in the synapse is transported back into the nerve terminal via the (NET) norepinephrine transporter"
"Dopamine in the synapse is transported back into the nerve terminal via the (DAT) dopamine transporter"
"Cocaine exerts its effects via inhibition of the NET and DAT transporters (reuptake inhibitor)"
"Cocaine intoxication can cause agitation, hypertension::BP, tachycardia::HR, and pupillary dilation"
"Cocaine causes vaso-constriction::dilation or constriction"
"Cocaine can cause nasal mucosal atrophy or septal perforation due to vasoconstriction"
"Cocaine may induce coronary vasospasm, which can cause myocardial ischemia and Prinzmetal angina"
"What class of autonomic drugs are contraindicated in cocaine toxicity? β-blockers"
"Administration of β-blockers for cocaine intoxication causes extreme hypertension::BP due to unopposed α1 activation"
"Atomoxetine is a(n) NET inhibitor used to treat ADHD (reuptake inhibitor)"
"Catecholamines are transported into pre-synaptic vesicles by the (VMAT) vesicular monoamine transporter"
"Reserpine inhibits VMAT, thus depleting neurotransmitter stores"
"Amphetamines exert their effects by displacing catecholamines (NE, dopamine) into the synapse"
"Methylphenidate is an amphetamine derivative used to treat ADHD"
"Modafinil is a stimulant used to treat narcolepsy"
"Stimulants (e.g. amphetamine, methylphenidate) may suppress appetite"
"The D1 dopamine receptor is coupled to Gs"
"The D2 dopamine receptor is coupled to Gi"
"At low doses, dopamine stimulates D1 receptors, especially in the renal vasculature"
"What effect do low levels of dopamine have on renal blood flow? Increased RBF"
"At medium doses, dopamine stimulates β1 receptors"
"At high doses, dopamine stimulates α1 receptors"
"Dopamine may be used for the treatment of heart failure and unstable bradycardia"
"Dopamine may be used as a pressor in the treatment of shock refractory to other agents (e.g. norepinephrine)"
"D2 dopamine receptors are primarily found in the CNS::organ system"
"Clonidine is a(n) α2-adrenergic agonist that primary affects the CNS::organ system"
"Which adrenergic receptor is sympatholytic? α2"
"What effect does clonidine have on blood pressure? Decreased (via reduced sympathetic tone)"
"Clonidine is an α2 agonist that may be used to treat hypertensive urgency (limited situations)"
"Clonidine is an α2 agonist that may be used to treat ADHD that is refractory to treatment with stimulants"
"Clonidine is an α2 agonist that may be used to treat Tourette's syndrome"
"Adverse effects of clonidine include CNS and respiratory depression"
"One adverse effect associated with clonidine is hypotension::BP"
"One adverse effect associated with clonidine is bradycardia::HR"
"One adverse effect associated with clonidine is miosis::pupil size"
"α-methyldopa is a(n) α2 adrenergic agonist that primary affects the CNS::organ system"
"α-methyldopa is an α2 agonist that is primarily used to treat gestational hypertension"
"Which α2 agonist may cause a SLE-like syndrome as an adverse effect? α-methyldopa"
"Which α2 agonist may cause a direct Coombs (+) hemolysis as an adverse effect? α-methyldopa"
"α-methyldopa may cause a direct Coombs test (+) hemolysis"
"Tizanidine is an α2 agonist that may be used as a muscle relaxant"
"Phentolamine is a non-selective reversible α1 and α2 adrenergic receptor antagonist"
"Is phentolamine (α-blocker) reversible or irreversible? Reversible"
"Is phentolamine (α-blocker) selective or non-selective? Non-selective"
"Phentolamine causes vaso-dilation"
"Phenoxybenzamine is a non-selective irreversible α1 and α2 adrenergic receptor antagonist"
"Is phenoxybenzamine (α-blocker) reversible or irreversible? Irreversible"
"Is phenoxybenzamine (α-blocker) selective or non-selective? Non-selective"
"α antagonists (e.g. phentolamine) can be used to treat cocaine::illicit drug toxicity"
"Wine and aged cheese contain the sympathomimetic tyramine, which is metabolized by the enzyme monoamine oxidase-A"
"Monoamine oxidase inhibitors can prevent the metabolism of tyramine (e.g. from wine or cheese ingestion), causing a(n) hypertensive crisis"
"Phentolamine may be given to patients on MAO inhibitors who eat tyramine containing foods (e.g. wine, cheese)"
"Phenoxybenzamine is used pre-operatively to prevent hypertensive crisis during removal of a(n) pheochromocytoma"
"α-receptor antagonists may cause orthostatic hypotension::BP as an adverse effect"
"α-receptor antagonists may cause reflex tachycardia::HR as an adverse effect"
"What drug class do prazosin, terazosin, doxazosin, and tamsulosin belong to? Selective α1 antagonists (\-osins\\")\""
"α1 adrenergic antagonists may be used to treat urinary symptoms of BPH"
"Selective α1 adrenergic antagonists (except tamsulosin) may be used to treat hypertension::BP"
"Prazosin is a selective α1 antagonist that may be used to treat post-traumatic stress disorder"
"One adverse effect associated with selective α1 adrenergic antagonists is 1st-dose orthostatic hypotension"
"Mirtazapine is a selective α2 adrenergic antagonist"
"Is mirtazapine (α-blocker) selective or non-selective? Selective"
"Mirtazapine is an α2 antagonist that may be used to treat depression"
"Adverse effects of selective α2 antagonists (e.g. mirtazapine) include sedation, increased appetite, and increased serum cholesterol"
"β-blockers all have a \-lol\\" suffix\""
"β-blockers decrease cardiac contractility"
"β-blockers may cause bradycardia::HR as a direct adverse effect"
"β-blockers can cause or exacerbate heart block due to excessive AV nodal inhibition"
"β-blockers are useful in the management of chronic, stable angina"
"β-blockers treat angina by reducing HR and contractility, thus decreasing myocardial O2 demand"
"What type of β-blocker is atenolol? Selective β1 antagonist (cardioselective)"
"What type of β-blocker is betaxolol? Selective β1 antagonist (cardioselective)"
"What type of β-blocker is esmolol? Selective β1 antagonist (cardioselective)"
"What type of β-blocker is acebutolol? Selective β1 antagonist (cardioselective)"
"What type of β-blocker is metoprolol? Selective β1 antagonist (cardioselective)"
"β1 selective antagonists primarily suppress adrenergic stimulation of the heart (cardioselective)"
"Cardioselective β-blockers are useful in the acute treatment of MI and other ACS (e.g. unstable, NSTEMI)"
"Cardioselective β-blockers are useful in the management of chronic heart failure"
"What non-selective β-blocker may be used in the treatment of CHF? Carvedilol"
"What type of β-blocker is carvedilol? Non-selective β- and α1-antagonist"
"Do cardioselective β-blockers reduce mortality in CHF and post-MI? Yes"
"β-blockers reduce cardiac remodeling by protecting the heart from excess circulating catecholamines"
"β-blockers are useful in the treatment of hypertension, especially in patients with heart failure or post-MI"
"β-blockers inhibit production of renin"
"What type of β-blocker is labetalol? Non-selective α1- and β-antagonist"
"Which two β-blockers are non-selective α1- and β-antagonists? Labetalol and carvedilol"
"Labetalol causes vaso-dilation"
"Which β-blocker is used to treat hypertension during pregnancy (aka gestational hypertension)? Labetalol"
"Labetalol is useful in the treatment of hypertensive emergency"
"IV β-blockers (e.g. labetalol, esmolol) are useful in the acute management of aortic dissection"
"β-blockers are useful in the management of hypertrophic obstructive and dilated cardiomyopathy"
"β-adrenergic blockers can be used for migraine prophylaxis"
"β-blockers are a first line treatment for essential tremor"
"What class of anti-arrhythmic are β-blockers? Class II antiarrhythmics"
"Adverse effects of non-selective β-blockers include exacerbation of asthma and COPD"
"Timolol is a topical non-selective β-blocker that is used to treat open angle glaucoma"
"β-blockers can cause impotence in men as an adverse effect"
"Which two β-blockers have partial agonist activity? Acebutolol and pindolol"
"Acebutolol and pindolol are contraindicated in heart failure, MI, and angina"
"β-blockers may have CNS adverse effects, including seizures, sedation, and sleep alterations"
"Metoprolol is a β-blocker that is associated with dyslipidemia as an adverse effect"
"β-blockers may mask the effects of hypoglycemia"
"Propranolol is a β-blocker that may exacerbate vasospasm in Prinzmetal angina"
"β-blockers may cause unopposed α1 agonism if given alone for cocaine toxicity or pheochromocytoma"
"Are β-blockers contraindicated in diabetic patients? No"
"What type of cardiac tumor is associated with a diastolic \plop\\" sound (mid-diastolic rumbling murmur best heard at the apex) on auscultation? Myxomas\""
"What renal pathology is associated with eosinophils in the urine? Acute interstitial nephritis"
"Anemia is defined as a reduction in circulating red blood cell (RBC) mass"
"Anemia may present with signs and symptoms of hypoxia"
"Anemia may present with pale conjunctiva and skin"
"Anemia may present with angina, especially with pre-existing coronary artery disease"
"Anemia is defined as Hb < 13.5 g/dL in males"
"Anemia is defined as Hb < 12.5 g/dL in females"
"Hemoglobin (Hb), hematocrit (Hct) and RBC count are used as surrogates for RBC mass, which is difficult to measure"
"What measurement is used to classify anemia as microcytic, normocytic, or macrocytic? Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)"
"Anemia is classified as microcytic if the MCV < 80 μm3"
"Anemia is classified as normocytic when the MCV is between 80 to 100 μm3"
"Anemia is classified as macrocytic when the MCV > 100 μm3 "
"Microcytic anemias are due to decreased production of hemoglobin"
"Hemoglobin is made of heme and globin"
"Heme is composed of iron and protoporphyrin"
"What is the most common type of anemia? Iron deficiency anemia"
"What is the most common nutritional deficiency in the world? Iron deficiency"
"Stored intracellular iron is bound to ferritin, which prevents iron from forming free radicals via the Fenton reaction"
"Serum iron is a measure of iron in the blood"
"Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) is a measure of transferrin molecules in the blood"
"% saturation is a measure of the percent of transferrin molecules that are bound by iron"
"What % of transferrin molecules are normally bound by iron? ~ 33%"
"Serum ferritin is a reflection of iron stores in macrophages and the liver"
"In general, iron deficiency is usually caused by dietary lack or blood loss"
"What is the most common cause of iron deficiency in infants? Breastfeeding (human milk is low in iron)"
"What is the most common cause of iron deficiency in children? Poor diet"
"What is the most common cause of iron deficiency in male adults (20-50 years old)? Peptic ulcer disease"
"What are the most common causes of iron deficiency in female adults (20-50 years old)? Menorrhagia or pregnancy::2"
"What is the most common cause of iron deficiency in the elderly (Western world)? Colon polyps/carcinoma"
"What is the most common cause of iron deficiency in the elderly (developing world)? Hookworm infection"
"What hookworms are associated with iron deficiency anemia? Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus::2"
"What surgical procedure is associated with iron deficiency anemia? Gastrectomy *Why"
"Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by decreased ferritin"
"Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by increased TIBC"
"Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by decreased serum iron"
"Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by decreased % saturation"
"Early stages of iron deficiency cause a(n) normocytic::MCV anemia"
"Later stages of iron deficiency cause a(n) microcytic::MCV anemia"
"In addition to symptoms of anemia, iron deficiency also presents with pica and koilonychia (spoon nails)"
"Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by hypo-chromic RBCs"
"Iron deficiency anemia is associated with a(n) increased red cell distribution width (RDW)"
"What microcytic anemia is associated with an increased RDW? Iron deficiency anemia"
"Iron deficiency anemia is associated with a(n) increased free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP)"
"Treatment of iron deficiency anemia involves supplemental iron (ferrous sulfate)"
"Plummer-Vinson syndrome is iron deficiency anemia with esophageal webs and atrophic glossitis"
"What pathology is characterized by a triad of iron deficiency anemia, dysphagia, and a beefy red tongue? Plummer-Vinson syndrome"
"Anemia of chronic disease is an anemia associated with cancer and chronic inflammation"
"What is the most common type of anemia in hospitalized patients? Anemia of chronic disease (ACD)"
"Chronic disease results in increased hepcidin release from the liver"
"Hepcidin suppresses production of the hormone erythropoietin (EPO)"
"Anemia of chronic disease is characterized by increased ferritin"
"Anemia of chronic disease is characterized by decreased TIBC"
"Anemia of chronic disease is characterized by decreased serum iron"
"Anemia of chronic disease is characterized by decreased % saturation"
"Early stages of anemia of chronic disease cause a(n) normocytic::MCV anemia"
"Later stages of anemia of chronic disease cause a(n) microcytic::MCV anemia"
"Anemia of chronic disease is associated with a(n) increased free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP)"
"Which microcytic anemias present with increased free erythrocyte protoporphyrin? Iron deficiency anemia, Anemia of chronic disease::2"
"Treatment for anemia of chronic disease involves addressing the underlying cause"
"Sideroblastic anemia is an anemia due to defective protoporphyrin synthesis"
"If protoporphyrin is deficient (e.g. sideroblastic anemia), iron remains trapped in the mitochondria"
"Sideroblastic anemia is associated with ringed sideroblasts, in which iron-laden mitochondria form a ring around the nucleus of erythroid precursors"
"What histological stain is used to visualize iron? Prussian blue"
"Congenital sideroblastic anemia is most commonly due to a defect in the enzyme δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase (ALAS)"
"Is the ALAS gene defect in congenital sideroblastic anemia an autosomal or X-linked defect? X-linked"
"What is the most common reversible cause of sideroblastic anemia? Alcoholism"
"Sideroblastic anemia may be caused by lead poisoning"
"Sideroblastic anemia may be caused by vitamin B6 deficiency"
"What mineral deficiency can cause sideroblastic anemia? Copper deficiency"
"Sideroblastic anemia is a cause of microcytic::MCV anemia"
"Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by increased ferritin"
"Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by decreased TIBC"
"Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by increased serum iron"
"Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by increased % saturation"
"What is the treatment for sideroblastic anemia? Pyridoxine (vitamin B6)"
"Thalassemia is an anemia due to decreased synthesis of globin chains"
"Thalassemia is a cause of microcytic::MCV anemia"
"Thalassemia is an inherited mutation that protects carriers against Plasmodium falciparum malaria"
"One normal type of hemoglobin is HbF which is composed of two α and two γ chains"
"One normal type of hemoglobin is HbA which is composed of two α and two β chains"
"One normal type of hemoglobin is HbA2 which is composed of two α and two δ chains"
"α-thalassemia is usually due to gene deletions"
"There are normally four total α-globin alleles present on chromosome 16"
"How does α-thalassemia with one gene deleted present? Asymptomatic"
"α-thalassemia due to a two gene deletion presents with mild anemia with a(n) increased RBC count"
"α-thalassemia with a(n) cis::cis or trans deletion is more prevalent in Asian populations"
"α-thalassemia with a(n) trans::cis or trans deletion is more prevalent in African populations"
"Which type of gene deletion (cis or trans) is associated with an increased risk of severe thalassemia in offspring? Cis deletion"
"α-thalassemia due to a three gene deletion presents with HbH disease and severe anemia"
"α-thalassemia due to a(n) three gene deletion is characterized by formation of β4 tetramers, known as HbH"
"Do patients with α-thalassemia due to a three gene deletion have any α-globin? Yes (very little)"
"α-thalassemia due to a four gene deletion causes hydrops fetalis (lethal in utero)"
"α-thalassemia due to a(n) four gene deletion is characterized by formation of γ4 tetramers, known as Hb Barts"
"Do patients with α-thalassemia due to a four gene deletion have any α-globin? No"
"β-thalassemia is usually due to gene mutations"
"β-thalassemia is often due to mutations in splice sites and promoter sequences"
"β-thalassemia is most commonly seen in individuals of African or Mediterranean descent"
"There are two total β-globin alleles present on chromosome 11"
"β-thalassemia mutations in β-globin genes result in absent (β0) or diminished (β+) production of the β-globin chain"
"β-thalassemia minor (β/β+) is the mildest form of disease; asymptomatic with increased RBC count"
"What type of pathologic RBC is seen with β-thalassemia? Target cells"
"Diagnosis of β-thalassemia minor is confirmed by an isolated increase in HbA2 (> 3.5%) on electrophoresis"
"β-thalassemia major (β0/β0) is the most severe form of the disease; causes severe anemia a few months after birth"
"When does β-thalassemia major (β0/β0) typically present? Months after birth"
"Why is β-thalassemia major not problematic at birth? High HbF is temporarily protective"
"In β-thalassemia major, α4 tetramers precipitate and damage RBCs"
"In β-thalassemia major, α4 tetramers result in ineffective erythropoiesis and extravascular hemolysis"
"β-thalassemia major is characterized by expansion of hematopoiesis into the skull, leading to a \crewcut\\" appearance on X-ray\""
"β-thalassemia major is characterized by expansion of hematopoiesis into facial bones, leading to \chipmunk facies\\"\""
"Which type of thalassemia (α or β) is associated with a \crewcut\\" skull appearance on X-ray? β-thalassemia (major)\""
"β-thalassemia major is associated with extramedullary hematopoiesis, which can be observed on abdominal physical exam as an enlargement of the liver and spleen"
"Patients with β-thalassemia major are at risk of aplastic crisis with parvovirus B19 infection of erythroid precursors"
"Treatment of β-thalassemia major involves chronic transfusions, which increases risk for secondary hemochromatosis"
"β-thalassemia major may be associated with nucleated::feature RBCs on blood smear"
"β-thalassemia major may have increased anisopoikilocytosis, which refers to the presence of abnormally shaped and unequally sized RBCs on blood smear"
"Hemoglobin electrophoresis of a patient with β-thalassemia major shows little or no HbA"
"Most microcytic anemias are also hypo-chromic"
"Vitamins B9 (folate) and B12 are necessary for synthesis of DNA precursors"
"Lack of folate or vitamin B12 impairs synthesis of DNA precursors"
"Impaired division and enlargement of RBC precursors leads to megaloblastic, macrocytic anemia"
"Megaloblastic anemia occurs due to delayed maturation of the nucleus relative to the cytoplasm of precursor RBCs"
"Impaired division of granulocytic precursors in megaloblastic anemia leads to hypersegmented neutrophils"
"Megaloblastic anemia is a cause of macrocytic::MCV anemia"
"Megaloblastic anemia is associated with glossitis::tongue"
"In addition to RBCs, megaloblastic anemia also leads to megaloblastic change in cells that are rapidly-dividing"
"Folate deficiency develops within months, as body stores are minimal"
"One cause of folate deficiency is poor diet, which is often seen in alcoholics::not children and the elderly"
"One cause of folate deficiency is increased demand, which is often seen with pregnancy, hemolytic anemia, and cancer"
"One cause of folate deficiency is drugs, such as folate antagonists"
"Folate deficiency is characterized by macrocytic::MCV RBCs"
"Folate deficiency is characterized by hypersegmented neutrophils"
"Folate deficiency is characterized by increased serum homocysteine"
"Folate deficiency is characterized by normal serum methylmalonic acid"
"Does folate deficiency present with neurologic symptoms? No"
"Dietary vitamin B12 is complexed to animal-derived proteins"
"Salivary gland enzymes liberate vitamin B12 from animal-derived proteins"
"Which is more common, vitamin B12 or folate deficiency? Folate deficiency"
"Vitamin B12 deficiency takes years to develop due to large hepatic stores"
"What is the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency? Pernicious anemia"
"Vitamin B12 deficiency may occur with pancreatic insufficiency; due to inability to cleave R-binder from B12"
"Vitamin B12 deficiency is characterized by macrocytic::MCV RBCs"
"Vitamin B12 deficiency is characterized by hypersegmented neutrophils"
"Vitamin B12 deficiency is characterized by increased serum homocysteine"
"Vitamin B12 deficiency is characterized by increased serum methylmalonic acid"
"Vitamin B12 deficiency may cause subacute combined degeneration::long name of the spinal cord"
"Vitamin B12 deficiency may result in poor proprioception and vibratory sense due to damage to the dorsal (posterior) column of the spinal cord"
"Vitamin B12 deficiency may result in spastic::type paresis due to damage to the lateral corticospinal tract of the spinal cord"
"Non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia occurs when DNA synthesis is unimpaired::impaired or unimpaired"
"Does non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia present with hypersegmented neutrophils? No"
"Non-hereditary causes of non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia include liver disease and alcoholism"
"Normocytic anemia is either due to peripheral destruction (hemolysis) or underproduction"
"What measure is used to distinguish between peripheral destruction and underproduction in normocytic anemia? Reticulocyte count"
"Reticulocytes are young RBCs released from the bone marrow"
"Reticulocytes are identified on blood smear as large::size RBCs with a(n) bluish::color cytoplasm"
"Reticulocytes have a bluish cytoplasm on Wright-Giemsa stain due to presence of residual ribosomal RNA"
"A normal reticulocyte count is between 1 to 2%"
"A properly functioning marrow responds to anemia by increasing the reticulocyte count to > 3%"
"Reticulocyte count may be falsely elevated in anemia"
"Reticulocyte count in anemia can be corrected by multiplying reticulocyte count by Hct/45"
"What is the general underlying cause of a normocytic anemia with a corrected reticulocyte count > 3%? Peripheral destruction (hemolysis)"
"What is the general underlying cause of a normocytic anemia with a corrected reticulocyte count < 3%? Underproduction"
"Normocytic anemia due to peripheral destruction is further divided into extravascular and intravascular hemolysis"
"Extra-vascular hemolysis involves RBC destruction by the reticuloendothelial system (RES)"
"The hemoglobin within macrophages that have consumed RBCs is broken down into heme and globin"
"The globin within macrophages that have consumed RBCs is further broken down into amino acids"
"The heme within macrophages that have consumed RBCs is further broken down into iron and protoporphyrin"
"What happens to the iron (from heme) within macrophages that have consumed RBCs? It is recycled"
"The protoporphyrin (from heme) within macrophages that have consumed RBCs is broken down into unconjugated bilirubin"
"Normocytic anemia with extra-vascular hemolysis is associated with enlargement of the spleen (splenomegaly)"
"Why does extravascular hemolysis result in splenomegaly? Hyperplasia of splenic macrophages (red pulp hyperplasia)"
"Normocytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis is associated with jaundice due to increased serum unconjugated bilirubin"
"Normocytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis is associated with increased risk for bilirubin gallstones"
"Normocytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis is associated with marrow hyperplasia with corrected reticulocyte count > 3%"
"Intra-vascular hemolysis involves destruction of RBCs within vessels"
"Intra-vascular hemolysis results in passage of hemoglobin into the blood"
"Some of the hemoglobin in the blood due to intravascular hemolysis is returned to the spleen by haptoglobin molecules"
"Normocytic anemia with intra-vascular hemolysis is associated with decreased serum haptoglobin"
"Normocytic anemia with intra-vascular hemolysis may cause leakage of hemoglobin into the blood and urine"
"Days after an episode of intra-vascular hemolysis, hemosiderin may be seen in the urine"
"What enzyme may be elevated in hemolytic anemia (both extra- and intravascular)? Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)"
"Extra- and intravascular hemolysis may present with increased urobilinogen in the urine, which results from increased conjugated bilirubin"
"Does extravascular hemolysis present with hemoglobinuria and/or hemosiderinuria? No"
"Hereditary spherocytosis is a cause of microcytic or normocytic::MCV anemia"
"Hereditary spherocytosis is primarily characterized by extravascular hemolysis"
"Hereditary spherocytosis is due to an inherited defect of RBC cytoskeleton-membrane tethering proteins"
"Hereditary spherocytosis most commonly involves defects in ankyrin, spectrin, band 3.1, or protein 4.2"
"What RBC pathology is characterized by formation and loss of membrane blebs over time? Hereditary spherocytosis"
"Loss of membrane blebs in hereditary spherocytosis renders RBCs round (spherocytes) instead of disc-shaped"
"Spherocytes are less able to maneuver through splenic sinusoids and are thus consumed by splenic macrophages"
"Spherocytes are characterized by no central pallor"
"Spherocytes are pathologic RBCs that have a(n) increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)"
"Hereditary spherocytosis is characterized by a(n) increased RDW"
"Compared to younger spherocytes, older spherocytes are smaller::size"
"Patients with hereditary spherocytosis are at risk of aplastic crisis with parvovirus B19 infection of erythroid precursors"
"Hereditary spherocytosis is diagnosed by the osmotic fragility test"
"Hereditary spherocytosis demonstrates increased spherocyte fragility in hypo-tonic solution (osmotic fragility test)"
"What is the treatment for severe or refractory hereditary spherocytosis? Splenectomy"
"Does anemia persist following splenectomy in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis? No"
"Do spherocytes persist following splenectomy in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis? Yes"
"What finding emerges on blood smear following splenectomy in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis? Howell-Jolly bodies"
"Sickle cell anemia is a cause of normocytic::MCV anemia"
"Does sickle cell anemia result in extravascular or intravascular hemolysis? Both :)"
"Sickle cell anemia is caused by a mutation in the β chain of hemoglobin"
"What is the mode of inheritance of sickle cell anemia? Autosomal recessive"
"Sickle cell anemia occurs due to a point mutation that substitutes glutamic acid (hydrophilic) with valine (hydrophobic)"
"The sickle cell (HbS) allele is carried by 8 - 10% of African Americans"
"The high prevalence of the sickle cell allele in Africans is likely due to its protective role against Plasmodium falciparum malaria"
"Does sickle cell trait (one HbS allelle) protect against malaria? Yes"
"Sickle cell disease arises when two abnormal β genes are present; results in >90% HbS in RBCs"
"When exposed to conditions that favor the taut form of Hemoglobin, HbS polymerizes and forms needle-like structures (\sickle cells\\")\""
"In addition to sickle cells, what other pathological RBC is seen on blood smear in a sickle cell disease patient? Target cells"
"What are the three main conditions which precipitate sickling in sickle cell anemia? Hypoxemia, dehydration, and acidosis"
"How does sickle cell anemia present in newborns? Why? Asymptomatic (high HbF, low HbS)"
"What form of hemoglobin protects against sickling in sickle cell anemia? HbF"
"Sickle cell anemia is associated with extramedullary hematopoiesis, which initially leads to enlargement of the liver and the spleen"
"Sickle cell anemia is characterized by expansion of hematopoiesis into facial bones, leading to \chipmunk facies\\"\""
"Sickle cell anemia is characterized by expansion of hematopoiesis into the skull, leading to a \crewcut\\" appearance on X-ray\""
"Patients with sickle cell anemia are at risk of aplastic crisis with parvovirus B19 infection of erythroid precursors"
"Irreversible sickling in sickle cell anemia leads to complications of vaso-occlusion"
"Vaso-occlusive infarcts in bones of the hands and feet due to sickle cell anemia cause dactylitis (painful swelling of hands and feet)"
"Dactylitis is a common presenting sign of sickle cell anemia in infants::age group"
"One complication of sickle cell anemia is auto-splenectomy"
"One consequence of autosplenectomy in sickle cell disease is increased risk of infection with encapsulated organisms"
"Asplenic sickle cell disease patients are commonly infected with Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae"
"One consequence of autosplenectomy in sickle cell disease is increased risk of osteomyelitis due to Salmonella paratyphi infection"
"One consequence of autosplenectomy in sickle cell disease is presence of Howell-Jolly bodies and target cells on blood smear"
"Vaso-occlusive infarcts in the pulmonary microcirculation due to sickle cell anemia causes acute chest syndrome"
"What complication of sickle cell anemia presents with chest pain, SOB, and lung infiltrates? Acute chest syndrome"
"Acute chest syndrome in patients with sickle cell anemia is often precipitated by pneumonia"
"What renal pathology is associated with sickle cell anemia? Renal papillary necrosis"
"Sickle cell disease (and trait) may cause microhematuria due to medullary infarcts"
"What is the most common cause of death in children with sickle cell anemia? Infection with encapsulated organisms"
"What is the most common cause of death in adult sickle cell anemia patients? Acute chest syndrome"
"What is the cause of painful crisis in patients with sickle cell anemia? Vaso-occlusion"
"Sickle cell trait is characterized by the presence of only one mutated β-chain"
"Sickle cell trait results in < 50% HbS in RBCs"
"How does sickle cell trait typically present? Generally asymptomatic (no anemia)"
"The extreme hypoxia and hypertonicity of the renal medulla may cause sickling in patients with sickle cell trait"
"Microinfarctions in the renal medulla due to sickle cell trait eventually result in decreased ability to concentrate urine"
"The metabisulfite screen causes cells with any amount of HbS to sickle"
"Is the metabisulfite screen positive in sickle cell disease or trait? Both :)"
"Diagnosis of sickle cell anemia is confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis::test"
"What RBC pathology is characterized by the following Hb electrophoresis findings: 90% HbS, 8% HbF, and 2% HbA2 (no HbA) Sickle cell disease"
"What RBC pathology is characterized by the following Hb electrophoresis findings: 55% HbA, 43% HbS, and 2% HbA2 Sickle cell trait"
"Sickle cell anemia is treated with hydroxyurea and hydration"
"Hydroxyurea is useful in the treatment of sickle cell anemia because it increases levels of HbF (typically greater than 15%)"
"Hemoglobin C disease is a cause of normocytic::MCV anemia"
"Hemoglobin C disease is primarily characterized by extravascular hemolysis"
"Hemoglobin C disease is caused by a mutation in the β chain of hemoglobin"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Hemoglobin C disease? Autosomal recessive"
"Hemoglobin C disease occurs due to a point mutation that substitutes glutamic acid with lysine"
"Blood smear of a patient with hemoglobin C disease may show target cells and/or HbC crystals within RBCs"
"Patients with HbSC (1 of each mutant gene) have milder::severity disease than HbSS patients"
"Evolutionarily, hepcidin is upregulated to prevent pathogens from accessing iron"
"Decay accelerating factor (DAF) on the surface of blood cells protects against complement-mediated damage by inhibiting C3 convertase::specific"
"Decay accelerating factor (DAF/CD55) and Membrane Inhibitor of Reactive Lysis (MIRL/CD59) are secured to the RBC cell membrane by GPI, which serves as an anchoring glycolipid"
"Absence of GPI in blood cells leads to absence of DAF and MIRL, thus rendering cells susceptible to complement-mediated destruction"
"Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is caused by an acquired defect in hematopoeitic stem cells, resulting in absent GPI"
"Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is a cause of normocytic::MCV anemia"
"Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is primarily characterized by intravascular hemolysis"
"The intravascular hemolysis caused by paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria occurs episodically, often while sleeping"
"During sleep, mild respiratory acidosis develops due to shallow breathing causing activation of complement, which may then trigger PNH"
"What test is used to screen for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria? Sucrose test"
"Patients with Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria can present with Abdominal Pain, Dysphagia, and Erectile Dysfunction because hemoglobin can act as a(n) Nitric Oxide scavenger"
"Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria may be confirmed via flow cytometry, which detects a lack of CD-55 and CD-59"
"Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is characterized by (PNH Thrombosis) - Pancytopenia - Nocturnal build up of Red/Pink Urine - coombs (-) Hemolytic anemia - venous Thrombosis"
"What is the main cause of death in patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria? Venous thrombosis"
"What type of microcytic anemia may be caused by paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria? Iron deficiency anemia"
"What cancer has a higher incidence in patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria? Acute myeloid leukemia (AML)::specific"
"Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria may be treated with eculizumab, which is a terminal complement inhibitor"
"Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is a disorder resulting in reduced half-life of G6PD"
"What is the mode of inheritance of G6PD deficiency? X-linked recessive"
"RBCs are normally exposed to oxidative stress, especially by H2O2::chemical"
"H2O2 may be neutralized by reduced glutathione (an antioxidant)"
"NADPH, a by-product of G6PD, is needed to regenerate reduced glutathione"
"G6PD deficiency renders RBCs susceptible to oxidative stress"
"G6PD deficiency is a cause of normocytic::MCV anemia"
"G6PD deficiency is characterized primarily by intravascular hemolysis"
"The African variant of G6PD deficiency results in mildly reduced half-life of G6PD"
"The Mediterranean variant of G6PD deficiency results in markedly reduced half-life of G6PD"
"High carrier frequency of the mutant G6PD allele is likely due to its protective role against Plasmodium falciparum malaria"
"In G6PD deficiency, oxidative stress precipitates denaturated hemoglobin as Heinz bodies"
"In G6PD deficiency, Heinz bodies are removed from RBCs by splenic macrophages, resulting in formation of bite cells"
"G6PD deficiency presents with hemoglobin-uria and back pain hours after exposure to oxidative stress"
"What is the most common cause of oxidative stress in patients with G6PD deficiency? Infection"
"What mediterranean food may be a source of oxidative stress in patients with G6PD deficiency? Fava beans"
"What class of drugs are contraindicated in patients with G6PD deficiency? Sulfa drugs"
"Anti-malarial drugs, such as primaquine, may induce oxidative stress and are thus contraindicated in patients with G6PD deficiency"
"Anti-tuberculosis drugs, such as dapsone, may induce oxidative stress and are thus contraindicated in patients with G6PD deficiency"
"What is the most common enzymatic disorder of RBCs? G6PD deficiency"
"What test is performed to screen for G6PD deficiency? Heinz preparation"
"The diagnosis of G6PD deficiency is confirmed via enzyme studies, which are performed weeks after a hemolytic episode resolves"
"Immune hemolytic anemia (IHA) is the antibody-mediated destruction of RBCs"
"The antibodies in immune hemolytic anemia are either IgG or IgM"
"IgG-mediated immune hemolytic anemia usually causes extravascular hemolysis"
"Which form of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (IgG or IgM) is also known as warm agglutinin disease? IgG"
"In IgG-mediated hemolytic anemia, the membrane of the antibody-coated RBCs is consumed by splenic macrophages, resulting in spherocyte formation"
"What is the most common cause of IgG-mediated immune hemolytic anemia? SLE"
"Which form of immune hemolytic anemia is associated with SLE? IgG::IgG or IgM"
"What cancer is associated with IgG-mediated immune hemolytic anemia? Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)"
"Which form of immune hemolytic anemia may be caused by drugs? IgG::IgG or IgM"
"Certain drugs (e.g. penicillin), bind to RBC membranes, leading to formation of antibodies against the drug-RBC complex (IgG-mediated hemolytic anemia)"
"Certain drugs (e.g. α-methyldopa) induce production of autoantibodies against RBCs (IgG-mediated hemolytic anemia)"
"Treatment of IgG-mediated hemolytic anemia involves cessation of the offending drug (if applicable) and steroids; may also use IVIG for temporary relief"
"What is the last resort treatment for IgG-mediated hemolytic anemia? Splenectomy"
"IgM-mediated immune hemolytic anemia usually causes intravascular hemolysis"
"Which form of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (IgG or IgM) is also known as cold agglutinin disease? IgM"
"When temperatures drop below 30*C, IgM AIHA antibodies may bind RBCs and activate complement"
"In IgM-mediated hemolytic anemia, RBCs inactivate complement but residual C3b serves as an opsonin for splenic macrophages, resulting in spherocyte formation"
"IgM-mediated hemolytic anemia is commonly associated with Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection and infectious mononucleosis"
"What cancer may be associated with IgM-mediated immune hemolytic anemia? Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)"
"Which form of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (IgG or IgM) causes painful, blue fingers and toes with cold exposure? IgM (cold agglutinin)"
"What test is used to diagnose immune hemolytic anemia? Coombs test"
"The direct Coombs test adds anti-human globulin (Coombs reagent) to a sample of a patient's RBCs"
"The direct Coombs test answers the question: \Are the patient's RBCs already bound by immunoglobulin (or complement)?\\"\""
"The indirect Coombs test adds donor blood and anti-Ig antibody (Coombs reagent) to the patient's serum"
"The indirect Coombs test answers the question: \Does the patient have antibodies in their serum?\\"\""
"Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) is primarily characterized by intravascular hemolysis"
"Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia occurs due to damage of RBCs as they pass through obstructed or narrowed vessels (e.g. due to microthrombi)"
"What type of anemia is caused by TTP, HUS, DIC, and HELLP? Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia"
"Macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia may be seen with prosthetic heart valves and aortic stenosis"
"What pathological RBC is associated with micro- and macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia? Schistocytes (\helmet cells\\")\""
"Malaria is due to infection of RBCs and the liver with Plasmodium species"
"Plasmodium malaria is transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito"
"In malaria, RBCs rupture as part of the Plasmodium life cycle, resulting in intravascular hemolysis and cyclical fever"
"Malaria due to Plasmodium falciparum is characterized by fever everyday::everyday or every other day"
"Malaria due to Plasmodium vivax or Plasmodium ovale is characterized by fever every other day (everyday or every other day)"
"What other infectious organism causes symptoms similar to malaria (fever, hemolytic anemia)? Babesia"
"Anemia due to underproduction may occur with chronic kidney disease, due to decreased production of EPO"
"One cause of anemia due to underproduction is parvovirus B19, which infects progenitor red cells and temporarily halts erythropoiesis"
"What is the treatment for parvovirus B19 infection? supportive (infection is self-limited)"
"Aplastic anemia occurs due to damage to hematopoietic stem cells, resulting in pancytopenia (anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia)"
"Aplastic anemia may be induced by radiation and drugs (e.g. benzene, chloramphenicol, alkylating agents, antimetabolites)"
"Aplastic anemia may be induced by viral agents (e.g. parvovirus B19, EBV, HIV, hepatitis)"
"Aplastic anemia may be caused by Fanconi anemia, which occurs due to a(n) dsDNA repair defect, resulting in bone marrow failure"
"Fanconi anemia is associated with short stature, café au lait spots, and malformed forearms and/or thumbs"
"Fanconi anemia is associated with an increased risk of developing cancer (e.g. tumors, leukemia)"
"The cause of aplastic anemia may be immune-mediated and sometimes follows acute hepatitis"
"Aplastic anemia is characterized by decreased reticulocyte count and increased erythropoietin"
"Aplastic anemia is characterized by an empty, fatty::characteristic marrow on biopsy (\dry marrow tap\\")\""
"Treatment of aplastic anemia includes marrow-stimulating factors, such as EPO, GM-CSF, and G-CSF"
"Treatment of aplastic anemia involves transfusions of RBCs and platelets"
"Treatment of aplastic anemia with immunosuppression may be helpful as some idiopathic cases are due to abnormal T-cell activation with release of cytokines"
"What is a last resort treatment for aplastic anemia? Bone marrow transplant"
"Myelophthisic process is a pathologic process that replaces bone marrow (e.g. metastatic cancer)"
"The levels of TBG and total thyroid hormone are decreased with hepatic failure, steroid use, and nephrotic syndrome"
"Erythrocytes (RBCs) carry O2 to tissues and CO2 to lungs"
"Do erythrocytes (RBCs) contain a nucleus? No (anucleate)"
"Do erythrocytes (RBCs) contain organelles? No"
"Erythrocytes are biconcave in shape, with a large surface area-to-volume ratio for rapid gas exchange"
"The average life-span of an erythrocyte is approximately 120 days"
"What is the source of energy in erythrocytes? Glucose"
"In erythrocytes, 90% of glucose is used for glycolysis"
"In erythrocytes, 10% of glucose is used for the HMP shunt"
"What antiporter is present in the membrane of erythrocytes? Cl-/HCO3- antiporter"
"Aniso-cytosis refers to cells of varying sizes"
"Poikilo-cytosis refers to cells of varying shapes"
"Platelets (thrombocytes) are small cytoplasmic fragments derived from megakaryocytes"
"Platelets (thrombocytes) have a life span of 8 to 10 days"
"Approximately one-third of the platelet pool is stored in the spleen"
"What skin finding is associated with thrombocytopenia and/or decreased platelet function? Petechiae"
"The dense granules of platelets contain ADP and Ca2+"
"The α granules of platelets contain vWF, fibrinogen, and fibronectin"
"Leukocytes (WBCs) are divided into mononuclear cells and granulocytes"
"What is the most common type of leukocyte (54 - 62%)? Neutrophils"
"Which leukocyte is most involved in an acute inflammatory response? Neutrophils"
"Neutrophils are increased in response to bacterial infections"
"What type of cell is represented in the image below? Neutrophil"
"Are neutrophils phagocytic? Yes"
"Which type of leukocyte differentiates into macrophages in tissue? Monocytes"
"Which type of leukocyte has a large, kidney shaped nucleus with a \frosted glass\\" cytoplasm? Monocyte\""
"What type of cell is represented in the image below? Monocyte"
"Macrophages differentiate from circulating blood monocytes"
"Macrophages phagocytose bacteria, cellular debris, and RBCs"
"What type of leukocyte defends against helminthic infections? Eosinophils"
"Which type of leukocyte has a bilobulate nucleus? Eosinophil"
"What type of cell is represented in the image below? Eosinophil"
"Eosinophils produce major basic protein, which destroys parasites and is responsible for epithelial cell damage in asthma"
"Eosinophils produce compounds that deal with parasites, including major basic protein, histaminase and arylsulfatase B"
"Eosinophils are highly phagocytic for antigen-antibody complexes"
"The causes of eosinophilia may be remembered with the mnemonic \PACCMAN\\": P: parasites A: asthma C: Churg-Strauss syndrome C: chronic adrenal insufficiency M: Myeloproliferative disorders A: allergic processes N: neoplasia (ex. Hodgkin lymphoma)\""
"Which type of leukocyte is able to synthesize and release leukotrienes on demand? Basophil"
"The granules of basophils contain heparin and histamine (anticoagulant and vasodilator, respectively)"
"Baso-philia is uncommon, but can be a sign of myeloproliferative disease, particularly CML"
"What type of cell is represented in the image below? Basophil"
"Basophils mediate allergic reactions"
"Mast cells mediate allergic reactions in local tissues"
"Mast cells can bind the Fc portion of IgE"
"Cromolyn sodium and Nedocromil prevent mast cell degranulation (used for asthma prophylaxis)"
"Dendritic cells function as a link between the innate and adaptive immune systems"
"Dendritic cells are called Langerhans cells in the skin"
"What class of cells have a round, densely stained nucleus with a small amount of cytoplasm? Lymphocytes (e.g. B cells, T cells, NK cells)"
"Plasma cells produce a large amount of antibody specific to a particular antigen"
"Which type of cell has a \clock-face\\" chromatin distribution and an eccentric nucleus? Plasma cell\""
"What type of cell is represented in the image below? Plasma cell"
"Where are plasma cells typically found? Bone marrow"
"Do plasma cells normally circulate in peripheral blood? No"
"Fetal erythropoiesis occurs in the yolk sac from 3 to 8 weeks"
"Fetal erythropoiesis occurs in the liver from 6 weeks to birth"
"Fetal erythropoiesis occurs in the spleen from 10 to 28 weeks"
"Fetal erythropoiesis occurs in the bone marrow from 18 weeks to adulthood"
"The two embryonic globins are zeta (ζ) and epsilon (ε)"
"The central nervous system consists of the brain and spinal cord"
"What is the embryonic origin of CNS neurons? Neural tube (neuroectoderm)"
"The peripheral nervous system consists of the cranial and spinal nerves, which give rise to axons and neurons"
"What is the embryonic origin of PNS neurons? Neural crest"
"What is the embryonic origin of chromaffin cells? Neural crest"
"Chromaffin cells migrate into the adrenal medulla to form post-ganglionic sympathetic neurons"
"Neurulation begins in the third week of fetal development"
"The notochord induces the overlying ectoderm to form the neural plate (neuroectoderm) and not the neural tube"
"By the end of the third week, neural folds grow over the midline and fuse to form the neural tube"
"During closure of neural folds, the neural crest cells form from neuroectoderm"
"The neural tube begins as three::number primary vesicles"
"The most superior of the 3 primary vesicles (developing brain) is the forebrain (prosencephalon)"
"The middle of the 3 primary vesicles (developing brain) is the midbrain"
"The most inferior of the 3 primary vesicles (developing brain) is the hindbrain (rhombencephalon)"
"The forebrain/prosencephalon (primary vesicle) matures into the telencephalon and diencephalon (secondary vesicles)"
"What is the adult derivative of the wall of the telencephalon? Cerebral hemispheres"
"What is the adult derivative of the cavity of the telencephalon? Lateral ventricles::specific"
"What are the adult derivatives of the wall of the diencephalon? Thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus and optic cup/nerves (retina)"
"The midbrain (primary vesicle) matures into the mesencephalon (secondary vesicle)"
"What is the adult derivative of the wall of the mesencephalon? Midbrain"
"What is the adult derivative of the cavity of the mesencephalon? Cerebral aqueduct"
"The hindbrain (primary vesicle) matures into the metencephalon and myelencephalon (secondary vesicles)"
"What are the adult derivatives of the wall of the metencephalon? Pons and cerebellum"
"What is the adult derivative of the cavity of the metencephalon? Upper part of 4th ventricle"
"What is the adult derivative of the wall of the myelencephalon? Medulla"
"What is the adult derivative of the cavity of the myelencephalon? Lower part of 4th ventricle"
"The embryonic brain stem and spinal cord have a(n) dorsally-located alar plate"
"The embryonic alar plate gives rise to sensory::motor or sensory derivatives"
"The embryonic brain stem and spinal cord have a(n) ventrally-located basal plate"
"The embryonic basal plate gives rise to motor::motor or sensory derivatives"
"The alar plate and basal plate are separated by the sulcus limitans"
"The autonomic nervous system is composed of two divisions: sympathetic and parasympathetic"
"The autonomic nervous system usually reaches its target via two neuron(s)"
"The pre-ganglionic neurons of the ANS have cell bodies in the central nervous system"
"The post-ganglionic neurons of the ANS have cell bodies in the peripheral nervous system"
"All pre-ganglionic neurons utilize acetylcholine as their neurotransmitter"
