"The acetylcholine from pre-ganglionic neurons of the ANS binds to neural nicotinic (NN) receptors"
"All post-ganglionic parasympathetic neurons utilize acetylcholine as their neurotransmitter"
"The acetylcholine from post-ganglionic neurons of the ANS binds to muscarinic (M) receptors"
"Post-ganglionic sympathetic neurons may utilize norepinephrine as a neurotransmitter, which binds to α1, α2, and β1 receptors"
"Post-ganglionic sympathetic neurons may utilize epinephrine as a neurotransmitter, which binds to α1, α2, β1, and β2 receptors"
"Post-ganglionic sympathetic neurons utilize acetylcholine as a neurotransmitter in sweat glands"
"The adrenal medulla exerts its post-ganglionic sympathetic effects via neurohumoral transmission"
"Parasympathetic neurons have long pre-ganglionic and short post-ganglionic neurons"
"Sympathetic neurons have short pre-ganglionic and long post-ganglionic neurons"
"The somatic nervous system reaches its target via one::# neuron(s)"
"The somatic nervous system utilizes acetylcholine as its neurotransmitter"
"The acetylcholine from the somatic nervous system binds to muscle nicotinic (NM) receptors in the NMJ of skeletal muscle"
"Nerves of the somatic nervous system innervate skeletal muscle"
"The parasympathetic NS is characterized by a(n) craniosacral distribution of parasympathetic neurons"
"Which cranial nerves carry parasympathetics? III, VII, IX, X::4"
"Which sacral nerves carry parasympathetics? S2 - S4"
"The sympathetic NS is characterized by a(n) thoracolumbar distribution of sympathetic neurons"
"All pre-ganglionic sympathetic neurons can synapse in sympathetic chain (paravertebral) ganglia"
"Pre-ganglionic sympathetic neurons from T5 - L2 can bypass the sympathetic chain and synapse in prevertebral (pre-aortic) ganglia (splanchnic nerves)"
"What is the adult derivative of the cavity of the diencephalon? Third ventricle"
"What type of cell (permanent, labile, stable) are neurons? Permanent (do not divide in adulthood)"
"Which part of the neuron receives input from the axons of other neurons? Dendrites"
"Which part of the neuron contains organelles (e.g. Golgi, ER, etc.)? Cell body (Soma)"
"Which part of the neuron sends output (electrical impulses) to other neurons? Axons"
"The proximal part of an axon is usually marked by a(n) axon hillock, which is a tapered extension of the cell body that lacks Nissl substance"
"Which part of the neuron contains synaptic vesicles that store and release neurotransmitter into the synapse? Axon (nerve) terminal"
"The cell body and dendrites, but not the axon of a neuron can be seen histologically with Nissl staining, which stains RER"
"Glial cells refer to the non-neuronal cells of nervous system"
"Oligodendrocytes are responsible for myelinating axons of neurons in the central nervous system"
"Each oligodendrocyte can myelinate many axon(s)"
"Oligodendrocytes are the predominant type of glial cell in white matter"
"Oligodendrocytes have a \fried egg\\" appearance histologically\""
"What is the embryonic origin of oligodendrocytes? Neural tube (neuroectoderm)::specific"
"Astrocytes are glial cells that help mediate K+ ion metabolism"
"Which type of glial cell acts as a glycogen fuel reserve buffer? Astrocytes"
"Astrocytes are glial cells that provide physical support and repair for the nervous system"
"Astrocytes help maintain the blood-brain-barrier via foot processes"
"Astrocytes are glial cells that are capable of removing excess neurotransmitters"
"What protein is used as an astrocyte marker? GFAP (glial fibrillary acidic protein)"
"Astrocytes are glial cells that are responsible for reactive gliosis::specific repair in response to neural injury"
"What is the embryonic origin of astrocytes? Neural tube (neuroectoderm)"
"Schwann cells are responsible for myelinating axons of neurons in the peripheral nervous system"
"Each Schwann cell can myelinate one axon(s)"
"In myelinated cells, nodes of Ranvier increase conduction velocity via saltatory conduction"
"At the nodes of Ranvier, there is a high concentration of Na+ channels"
"Myelin wraps and insulates axons, thus increasing the space (length) constant"
"Myelin wraps and insulates axons, thus decreasing the time constant"
"Conduction velocity is increased when the time constant is decreased"
"Conduction velocity is increased when the space (length) constant is increased"
"What is the embryonic origin of Schwann cells? Neural crest"
"Ependymal cells line the ventricles in the adult brain"
"Ependymal cells have cilia, which helps circulate CSF"
"Some ependymal cells differentiate into choroid epithelial cells, which produce CSF"
"What is the embryonic origin of ependymal cells? Neural tube (neuroectoderm)"
"Which type of glial cell is a derivative of mononuclear phagocytes? Microglia"
"Microglia are activated in response to tissue damage"
"Can microglia be distinguished by Nissl stain histologically? No"
"What is the embryonic origin of microglia? Mesoderm"
"Pericytes are microglia that contribute to the blood-brain barrier"
"Microglia fuse to form multinucleated giant cells in the CNS when infected by HIV"
"What type of filament is used by axons for axonal transport (retrograde and anterograde)? Microtubules"
"Which molecular motor protein is used for anterograde axonal transport? Kinesin"
"Which molecular motor protein is used for retrograde axonal transport? Dynein"
"The blood-brain barrier prevents circulating blood substances (e.g. bacteria, drugs) from reaching the CSF / CNS"
"One component of the blood-brain barrier is tight junctions between non-fenestrated capillary endothelial cells"
"One component of the blood-brain barrier is a(n) basement membrane"
"One component of the blood-brain barrier is foot processes from astrocytes"
"Non-polar and lipid-soluble substances cross the blood-brain barrier rapidly via diffusion"
"Glucose and amino acids cross the blood-brain barrier slowly via carrier-mediated transport mechanisms"
"Na+ and K+ ions cross the blood-brain barrier via ion channels"
"Distal to a site of CNS or PNS axon injury there is anterograde (Wallerian) degeneration"
"The closer a destructive axon lesion is to the neuronal cell body, the more likely the neuron is to die"
"Proximal to a site of CNS or PNS axon injury there is retrograde degeneration"
"In response to axon damage, the neuron cell body undergoes Axonal reaction, which is the swelling of the cell body and dispersion of Nissl substance (this process is called chromatolysis)"
"Axons that are myelinated by Schwann cells have the potential to regenerate following injury"
"Do axons myelinated by oligodendrocytes have the potential to regenerate following injury? No"
"The lateral ventricles consist of a body and anterior, posterior, and inferior horns"
"The lateral ventricle drains into the 3rd ventricle via the foramen of Monro"
"The 3rd ventricle drains into the 4th ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct (of Sylvius)"
"The CSF in the 4th ventricle may enter the subarachnoid space via the lateral foramina (2) of Luschka"
"The CSF in the 4th ventricle may enter the subarachnoid space via the medial foramen (1) of Magendie"
"Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is made by ependymal cells of choroid plexus"
"CSF in the subarachnoid space is reabsorbed through arachnoid granulations, which drain into dural venous sinuses"
"Which dural venous sinus is the main location of CSF return via arachnoid granulations? Superior sagittal sinus"
"The superior sagittal sinus drains into the confluence of sinuses"
"The confluence of sinuses drain into transverse sinuses"
"The transverse sinuses drain into the sigmoid sinuses"
"Each sigmoid sinus exits the skull via the jugular foramen as an internal jugular vein"
"The inferior sagittal sinus terminates by joining with the great cerebral vein of Galen to form the straight sinus"
"The straight sinus drains into the confluence of sinuses"
"The spinal cord is housed in the vertebral canal"
"There are 31 pairs of spinal nerves in total"
"There are 8 cervical pairs of spinal nerves"
"There are 12 thoracic pairs of spinal nerves"
"There are 5 lumbar pairs and sacral pairs of spinal nerves"
"There is/are one coccygeal pair of spinal nerves"
"Nerves C1 - C8 exit above the corresponding vertebra"
"The L2 nerve exits below the L2 vertebra"
"Inside the spinal cord, gray matter is centrally located"
"Which matter in the spinal cord contains neuronal cell bodies, their dendrites, and the proximal parts of axons? Gray matter"
"Inside the spinal cord, white matter is peripherally located"
"Which matter in the spinal cord contains functionally similar axons called tracts or fasciculi? White matter"
"In adults, the spinal cord ends at the lower border of the L1 - L2 vertebrae"
"In the adult spinal cord, subarachnoid space extends to the lower border of S2 vertebrae"
"Lumbar puncture is usually performed between L3 and L5"
"Do dorsal rami of spinal nerves contain sensory or motor neurons? Both :)"
"Do dorsal roots of spinal nerves contain sensory or motor neurons? Sensory neurons"
"Do ventral roots of spinal nerves contain sensory or motor neurons? Motor neurons"
"The neuronal cell bodies of the dorsal roots of spinal nerves are found in dorsal root ganglia"
"The neuronal cell bodies of the ventral roots of spinal nerves are found in the ventral horn of the spinal cord"
"The dorsal horn of gray matter contains sensory neurons"
"The ventral horn of gray matter contains motor neurons"
"The conus medullaris is the caudal end of the spinal cord; ends at L2 vertebra in adults"
"The cauda equina comprises the nerve roots of lumbar, sacral, and coccygeal spinal nerves below the conus medullaris"
"The filum terminale is slender pial extension that tethers the spinal cord to the bottom of the vertebral column"
"What type of nerve fibers sense proprioception in the medial dorsal horn of the spinal cord? Ia and Ib::2"
"What type of nerve fibers sense touch in the medial dorsal horn of the spinal cord? II and A-beta::2"
"What type of nerve fibers sense sharp pain & cold in the lateral dorsal horn of the spinal cord? III and A-delta::2"
"What type of nerve fibers sense dull pain & warmth in the lateral dorsal horn of the spinal cord? IV and C::2"
"The ventral horn of the spinal cord contains both alpha and gamma motor neurons, which make muscles contract and regulate muscle spindle sensitivity, respectively"
"Αlpha::alpha or gamma motor neurons make skeletal muscle contract"
"Gamma::alpha or gamma motor neurons make muscle spindles more sensitive to stretch"
"Within the ventral horn, alpha and gamma motoneurons that innervate flexors are located more dorsally"
"Within the ventral horn, alpha and gamma motoneurons that innervate extensors are located more ventrally"
"Within the ventral horn, alpha and gamma motoneurons that innervate more proximal structures are located medially"
"Within the ventral horn, alpha and gamma motoneurons that innervate more distal structures are located laterally"
"How many neurons are required for the lateral corticospinal tract pathway (voluntary muscle movement)? Two (UMN & LMN)"
"Lower motoneurons are found in the ventral horn of the spinal cord and cranial nerve nuclei in the brain stem"
"The cell bodies of upper motoneurons are primarily found in the primary motor cortex (precentral gyrus)"
"The axons of upper motoneurons of peripheral nerves are found in the corticospinal tract"
"The fibers in the corticospinal tract leave the cerebral cortex in the posterior limb of the internal capsule"
"Most (80-90%) of the corticospinal tract fibers decussate just below the caudal medulla at the pyramidal decussation"
"Upper motoneurons synapse with the cell bodies of lower motoneurons in the ventral (anterior) horn of the spinal cord"
"Lower motoneurons leave the spinal cord and synapse at the neuromuscular junction of skeletal muscle"
"Lower motoneurons are always ipsi-lateral to the muscle they innervate"
"Upper motoneurons initially descend contra-lateral to the LMNs they innervate"
"The corticospinal tract in the brain is responsible for voluntary movement of contra-lateral limbs"
"Is the lateral corticospinal tract an ascending or descending tract? Descending"
"The motor component of skeletal muscle reflexes is mediated by lower::upper or lower motoneurons"
"Upper motoneurons provide descending control over reflexes"
"Alpha motoneurons innervate extra-fusal muscle fibers"
"Gamma motoneurons innervate intra-fusal muscle fibers"
"In the muscle stretch reflex, stretch increases afferent impulses via Ia nerve fibers"
"In the muscle stretch reflex, some Ia afferent fibers stimulate agonist::agonist or antagonist muscles causing muscle contraction"
"In the muscle stretch reflex, some Ia afferent fibers inhibit antagonist::agonist or antagonist muscles through interneurons causing muscle relaxation"
"The inverse muscle stretch reflex uses Golgi tendon organs to monitor muscle tension"
"In the inverse muscle stretch reflex, increased tension increases afferent impulses via Ib nerve fibers"
"In the inverse muscle stretch reflex, some Ib afferent fibers inhibit agonist::agonist or antagonist muscles causing muscle relaxation"
"The Achilles reflex tests nerve roots S1 and S2 (tibial nerve)"
"The patella reflex tests nerve roots L3 and L4 (femoral nerve)"
"The biceps reflex tests nerve roots C5 and C6 (musculocutaneous nerve)"
"The triceps reflex tests nerve roots C7 and C8 (radial nerve)"
"The cremasteric reflex tests nerve roots L1 and L2"
"The anal wink reflex tests nerve roots S3 and S4"
"Do upper motoneuron lesions present with weakness? Yes"
"Do upper motoneuron lesions typically present with atrophy? No*"
"Do upper motoneuron lesions present with fasciculations? No"
"Upper motoneuron lesions may cause hyper-reflexia"
"Upper motoneuron lesions may cause increased tone"
"Do upper motoneuron lesions present with the Babinski sign? Yes"
"Upper motoneuron lesions may cause spastic::spastic or flaccid paralysis"
"Do upper motoneuron lesions present with clasp knife spasticity? Yes"
"Do lower motoneuron lesions present with weakness? Yes"
"Do lower motoneuron lesions present with atrophy? Yes"
"Do lower motoneuron lesions present with fasciculations? Yes"
"Lower motoneuron lesions may cause hypo-reflexia"
"Lower motoneuron lesions may cause decreased tone"
"Do lower motoneuron lesions present with the Babinski sign? No"
"Lower motoneuron lesions may cause flaccid::spastic or flaccid paralysis"
"Do lower motoneuron lesions present with clasp knife spasticity? No"
"In what demographic is a Babinski reflex normal? Infants"
"LMN lesions cause ipsi-lateral flaccid paralysis at the level of the lesion"
"UMN lesions in the spinal cord cause ipsi-lateral spastic paralysis at levels below the lesion"
"UMN lesions in the cerebral cortex cause contra-lateral spastic paralysis at levels below the lesion"
"How many neurons are required for the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway? Three"
"The dorsal column-medial lemniscal tract carries information for pressure, vibration, fine (discriminative) touch, and proprioception"
"The 1st-order neurons of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal tract are sensory nerve endings with cell bodies located in a(n) DRG"
"The 1st-order neuron of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal tract synapses with a(n) ipsi-lateral nucleus cuneatus or nucleus gracilis"
"The nucleus cuneatus and nucleus gracilis are located in the caudal medulla"
"The 2nd-order neuron of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal tract decussates in the caudal medulla"
"The 2nd-order neuron of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal tract ascends contra-laterally in the medial lemnicscus (brainstem and above)"
"The axons of the 2nd-order neurons of the dorsal column tract coalesce into an axon bundle, known as the medial lemniscus"
"The 2nd-order neurons of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal tract synapse in the ventral posterolateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus"
"The 3rd-order neuron of the dorsal column-medial lemniscal tract travels to the primary somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus)"
"The fasciculus gracilis is the medial::medial or lateral dorsal column"
"The fasciculus cuneatus is the lateral::medial or lateral dorsal column"
"The fasciculus gracilis carries input from the spinal level T7 and below"
"The fasciculus cuneatus carries input from the spinal level T6 and above"
"Lesions of the dorsal column-medial lemniscus tract in the spinal cord present on the ipsi-lateral side below the lesion"
"Lesions of the dorsal column-medial lemniscus tract in the thalamus and cerebral cortex present on the contra-lateral side below the lesion"
"How many neurons are required for the spinothalamic tract (anterolateral system) pathway? Three"
"The lateral spinothalamic tract carries information for pain and temperature from the body and limbs"
"The anterior spinothalamic tract carries information for crude (non-discriminative) touch and pressure"
"The 1st-order neurons of the spinothalamic tract are sensory nerve endings with cell bodies located in a(n) DRG"
"The 1st-order neuron of the spinothalamic tract synapses with a(n) ipsi-lateral cell body in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord"
"The 2nd-order neuron of the spinothalamic tract decussates at the anterior white commissure"
"The 2nd-order neuron of the spinothalamic tract ascends contra-laterally in the spinal cord"
"The 2nd-order neurons of the spinothalamic tract synapse in the ventral posterolateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus"
"The 3rd-order neuron of the spinothalamic tract travels to the primary somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus)"
"Any unilateral lesion of the spinothalamic tract in the spinal cord or brain stem will present on the contra-lateral side 1-2 segments below the lesion"
"The spinocerebellar tracts carry unconscious proprioceptive input from the ipsi-lateral muscle spindles and GTOs to the cerebellum"
"How many neurons are required for the spinocerebellar tract pathway? Two"
"The dorsal spino-cerebellar tract carries unconscious proprioceptive input from the lower extremities/trunk"
"The cuneo-cerebellar tract carries unconscious proprioceptive input from the upper extremities/trunk"
"The cell bodies of the dorsal spinocerebellar tract are found in Clarke’s nucleus, which is situated in the spinal cord from T1 to L2"
"The cell bodies of the cuneocerebellar tract are found in the medulla in the external cuneate nucleus"
"The dorsal spinocerebellar and cuneocerebellar tracts enter the cerebellum via the inferior cerebellar peduncle"
"If there is a large ventral horn, the spinal cord level is between C5 - T1 or L2 - S2"
"If there is a small ventral horn, the spinal cord level is between C1 - C4 or T2 - L1"
"If both dorsal columns are present, the spinal cord is above T5"
"If only one dorsal column is present, the spinal cord is below T5"
"If a lateral horn is present, the spinal cord is between T1 - L2"
"If a lateral horn is absent, the spinal cord is between C1 - C8 or L3 - S5"
"Which spinal cord level contains mostly gray matter (relative to white matter)? Sacral"
"ID Spinal Cord Section: Cervical"
"ID Spinal Cord Section: Thoracic"
"ID Spinal Cord Section: Lumbar"
"ID Spinal Cord Section: Sacral"
"Brown-Sequard syndrome is caused by hemisection of the spinal cord"
"Brown-Sequard syndrome presents with ipsi-lateral upper motoneuron signs below the level of the lesion (due to corticospinal tract damage)"
"Brown-Sequard syndrome presents with ipsi-lateral loss of vibration, proprioception, and touch below the level of the lesion (due to dorsal column damage)"
"Brown-Sequard syndrome presents with contra-lateral loss of pain and temperature below the level of the lesion (due to spinothalamic tract damage)"
"Brown-Sequard syndrome presents with ipsi-lateral loss of all sensation at the level of the lesion"
"Brown-Sequard syndrome presents with ipsi-lateral lower motoneuron signs at the level of the lesion"
"If the lesion in Brown-Sequard syndrome occurs above T1, patients may present with ipsi-lateral Horner syndrome"
"Sensory fibers containing pain and temperature information ascend or descend 1 - 2 spinal segments in Lissauer's tract before synapsing in the dorsal horn with a 2nd-order neuron"
"Poliomyelitis is caused by poliovirus infection"
"Poliovirus is transmitted via a(n) fecal-oral route"
"Poliovirus replicates in the oropharynx and small intestine before spreading via bloodstream to the CNS"
"Poliovirus infection causes selective destruction of lower motoneurons"
"Which horn of the spinal cord is most affected by poliovirus infection? Ventral (anterior) horn"
"What spinal cord level is most commonly affected by poliovirus? Lumbar levels"
"Does poliomyelitis present with symmetric or asymmetric weakness? Asymmetric"
"Poliomyelitis presents with bi-lateral asymmetric weakness"
"What infection can cause this spinal cord lesion? Poliovirus"
"Poliovirus may be recovered from the stool or throat, even before the onset of illness"
"Spinal muscular atrophy is the congenital degeneration of the anterior horns of the spinal cord"
"Werdnig-Hoffmann (SMA Type 1) is caused by a(n) autosomal recessive inherited mutation in the SMN1 gene on chromosome 5q, which factilitates the assembly of snRNPs"
"Werdnig-Hoffmann disease is the infantile form (type 1) of Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA)"
"Werdnig-Hoffmann disease presents as a \floppy baby\\" with marked hypotonia and tongue fasciculations\""
"Does spinal muscular atrophy damage upper or lower motoneurons? Lower"
"The infantile type (Werdnig-Hoffman) of Spinal Muscular Atrophy has a median age of death of 7 months"
"Does Spinal muscular atrophy present with symmetric or asymmetric weakness? Symmetric"
"Spinal muscular atrophy presents with bi-lateral symmetric weakness"
"What congenital disorder can cause this spinal cord lesion? Werdnig-Hoffmann (Spinal Muscular Atrophy type 1) disease::specific"
"Tabes dorsalis is a neurologic complication of tertiary syphilis"
"Tabes dorsalis is a progressive demyelination of the dorsal columns and dorsal roots"
"Tabes dorsalis may present with progressive sensory ataxia due to impaired proprioception"
"Tabes dorsalis presents with a(n) positive Romberg sign"
"Tabes dorsalis presents with absence of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs)"
"Tabes dorsalis is associated with Argyll Robertson pupils"
"Tabes dorsalis is associated with paroxysmal pains"
"What joint complication is associated with tabes dorsalis? Charcot joint (especially knee)"
"Tabes dorsalis may present with urinary overflow incontinence"
"Tabes dorsalis patients present with the \three P's\\": paresthesias"
"What spinal cord level is most commonly affected by tabes dorsalis? Lumbar levels"
"What disease is associated with this spinal cord lesion? Tabes dorsalis (tertiary syphilis)"
"Does amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) damage upper or lower motoneurons? Both :)"
"Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) typically begins at cervical levels of the spinal cord"
"ALS presents with asymmetric flaccid paralysis in the upper limbs"
"ALS presents with asymmetric spastic::spastic or flaccid paralysis in the lower limbs"
"Does ALS present with symmetric or asymmetric weakness? Asymmetric"
"An early sign of ALS is atrophy and weakness of hands"
"What sensory deficits does ALS present with? None :)"
"What bladder/bowel deficits does ALS present with? None :)"
"Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is commonly known as Lou Gehrig disease"
"Most cases of ALS are sporadic and arise in middle-aged adults::age group"
"Familial cases of ALS may be associated with zinc-copper superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) mutations, which leads to free radical injury in neurons"
"Whichdrug is used to treat ALS? Riluzole"
"What disease is associated with this spinal cord lesion? Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)"
"Which areas of the spinal cord are spared in a complete occlusion of the anterior spinal artery? Dorsal column and Lissauer's tract"
"Anterior spinal artery occlusion results in signs of bilateral upper motoneuron lesion below the infarct"
"Anterior spinal artery occlusion results in signs of bilateral lower motoneuron lesion at the level of the infarct"
"What sensory deficits are associated with anterior spinal artery occlusion? Loss of pain and temperature::2"
"What bladder deficit is associated with anterior spinal artery occlusion? Spastic bladder"
"Spastic bladder results from lesions above the sacral spinal cord levels"
"Atonic bladder results from lesions at the level of the sacral spinal cord"
"Which region of the spinal cord supplied by the anterior spinal artery lacks strong collateral flow and is most susceptible to watershed infarction? Mid-thoracic (T3-T8)"
"What infarcted artery is associated with this spinal cord lesion? Complete occlusion of anterior spinal artery"
"Subacute combined degeneration is a spinal cord lesion most commonly seen with vitamin B12 deficiency"
"Subacute combined degeneration is characterized by demyelination of spinocerebellar tracts, lateral corticospinal tracts, and dorsal columns"
"What disease is associated with this spinal cord lesion? Subacute combined degeneration (B12 deficiency)"
"Syringomyelia is a cystic cavity within the central canal of the spinal cord (yellow arrows)"
"Syringomyelia most commonly occurs at spinal cord levels C8 - T1"
"Syringomyelia results in damage to the spinothalamic tract 2nd-order neurons crossing in the anterior white commissure"
"Syringomyelia results in bi-lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in a \cape-like\\" distribution\""
"Syringomyelia typically results in pain/temperature deficits in the upper extremity"
"Syrinx expansion in syringomyelia may lead to damage to the lower motoneurons of the anterior horn"
"Syrinx expansion in syringomyelia (late stage) may cause Horner syndrome"
"The 1st-order neuron of the hypothalamospinal tract arises from the hypothalamus and synapses in the lateral horn of the spinal cord at the level of T1"
"The 2nd-order neuron of the hypothalamospinal tract arises from the lateral horn of T1 and synapses on the superior cervical ganglion"
"The 3rd-order neuron of the hypothalamospinal tract carries sympathetics to the eyelids, pupil, and skin of the face"
"What neural tract is responsible for the sympathetic input of the face? Hypothalamospinal tract"
"Syringomyelia is a spinal cord lesion that arises with trauma and tumors or in association with Chiari I malformation"
"Chiari I malformation is characterized by downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum"
"Chiari I malformation is congenital and is mostly asymptomatic in childhood"
"Chiari I malformation may present as paroxysmal occipital headaches and cerebellar symptoms"
"What disease is associated with this spinal cord lesion? Syringomyelia"
"Friedreich ataxia is a trinucleotide repeat disorder that causes degeneration of the cerebellum and multiple spinal cord tracts"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Friedreich ataxia? Autosomal recessive"
"Friedreich ataxia is caused by a mutated frataxin gene on chromosome 9"
"The frataxin gene is essential for mitochondrial iron regulation"
"Mutation of the frataxin gene in Friedreich ataxia leads to impairment of mitochondrial function"
"Friedreich ataxia presents in childhood::age group with kyphoscoliosis"
"What is commonly the cause of death in Friedreich ataxia? Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy"
"Friedreich ataxia patients often have pes cavus::foot type with hammer toes"
"What eye movement disorder may be present in patients with Friedreich ataxia? Nystagmus"
"Neural tube defects arise due to failure of the neuropores to fuse by the 4th week of pregnancy"
"Neural tube defects are associated with low folate levels prior to conception and during pregnancy"
"Neural tube defects are detected during prenatal care by elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels in the amniotic fluid and maternal blood"
"Elevated acetylcholinesterase (AChE) in amniotic fluid is a helpful confirmatory test for neural tube defects"
"Anencephaly is the absence of the skull and brain, resulting in an open calvarium with an absent forebrain"
"What pathology is associated with disruption of the cranial end of the neural tube? Anencephaly"
"Anencephaly leads to a \frog-like\\" appearance of the fetus due to prominent eyes\""
"Anencephaly is characterized by elevated levels of AFP in utero"
"Anencephaly may result in poly-hydramnios"
"Anencephaly is a neural tube defect associated with maternal type I diabetes"
"Holoprosencephaly is due to failure of the left and right hemispheres to separate"
"The left and right hemispheres usually separate during weeks 3 - 4 of development"
"Holoprosencephaly may be related to mutations in the sonic hedgehog signaling pathway"
"The moderate form of holoprosencephaly presents with cleft lip/palate"
"The severe form of holoprosencephaly results in cyclopia (one eye) and a primitive nasal structure (proboscis)"
"Holoprosencephaly is seen in Patau syndrome and fetal alcohol syndrome"
"Spina bifida is due to failure of the posterior vertebral arch to close"
"What pathology is associated with disruption of the caudal end of the neural tube? Spina bifida"
"Which form of spina bifida is associated with failure of the bony spinal canal to close but with no herniation? Spina bifida occulta"
"Spina bifida occulta is usually seen at lower::upper or lower vertebral levels"
"Is the dura intact in spina bifida occulta? Yes"
"Which form of spina bifida is associated with a tuft of hair or skin dimple at the level of the bone defect? Spina bifida occulta"
"Spina bifida occulta is characterized by normal levels of AFP in utero"
"Which form of spina bifida is associated with herniation of meninges (but no neural tissue) through the bony defect? Meningocele"
"Which form of spina bifida is associated with herniation of meninges and neural tissue through the bony defect? Meningomyelocele"
"Cerebral aqueduct stenosis is a congenital stenosis of the channel that drains CSF from the 3rd ventricle into the 4th ventricle"
"Cerebral aqueduct stenosis leads to accumulation of CSF in the ventricular space"
"Cerebral aqueduct stenosis is the most common cause of hydrocephalus in newborns"
"Cerebral aqueduct stenosis presents with a(n) enlarged head circumference due to dilation of the ventricles"
"Dandy-Walker malformation is a congenital failure of the cerebellar vermis to develop"
"Dandy-Walker malformation presents as a massively dilated 4th ventricle and an absent cerebellar vermis"
"Dandy-Walker malformation is associated with non-communicating hydrocephalus and spina bifida"
"Chiari II malformation is characterized by downward displacement of the cerebellar vermis and tonsils and the medulla through the foramen magnum"
"Chiari II malformation commonly results in aqueductal stenosis, which causes hydrocephalus"
"Chiari II malformation is often associated with lumbosacral meningomyelocele"
"Hematopoiesis occurs via a stepwise maturation of CD-34+ hematopoietic stem cells"
"The CD34+ hematopoietic stem cell may differentiate into a(n) myeloid or lymphoid stem cell"
"Myeloid stem cells may differentiate into erythroblasts, which mature into RBCs"
"Myeloid stem cells may differentiate into myeloblasts, which mature into granulocytes"
"Myeloid stem cells may differentiate into monoblasts, which mature into monocytes"
"Myeloid stem cells may differentiate into megakaryoblasts, which mature into megakaryocytes"
"Lymphoid stem cells may differentiate into B lymphoblasts, which mature into naive B cells and then plasma cells"
"Lymphoid stem cells may differentiate into T lymphoblasts, which mature into naive T cells and then CD4+/CD8+ T cells"
"A normal WBC count is approximately 5 - 10 K/μL"
"A low WBC count (< 5K) is called leukopenia"
"A high WBC count (> 10K) is called leukocytosis"
"Neutropenia refers to a decreased number of circulating neutrophils"
"Neutropenia may result from drug toxicity, especially chemotherapy"
"Neutropenia may result from severe infection (e.g. gram-negative sepsis)"
"In addition to drugs and infection, neutropenia also occurs with aplastic anemia, SLE, and radiation"
"What treatments are used to boost granulocyte production and thus decrease risk of infection in neutropenic patients? GM-CSF or G-CSF::2"
"Lymphopenia refers to a decreased number of circulating lymphocytes"
"Lymphopenia may be caused by immunodeficiency (e.g. HIV, DiGeorge syndrome, SCID)"
"What is the effect of corticosteroids on lymphocyte levels? Decreased (lymphopenia)"
"Lymphopenia may occur due to autoimmune destruction (e.g. SLE)"
"Lymphopenia may occur with whole body radiation"
"Which type of WBC is the most sensitive to radiation? Lymphocytes"
"Eosinopenia refers to a decreased number of circulating eosinophils"
"What is the effect of corticosteroids on eosinophil levels? Decreased (eosinopenia)"
"Neutrophilia refers to an increased number of circulating neutrophils"
"A(n) left shift is an increase in neutrophil precursors, such as band cells and metamyelocytes, in peripheral blood"
"Left shifts are usually seen with neutrophilia in the acute response to bacterial infection or tissue necrosis"
"When a left shift is seen with immature RBCs it is called a(n) leukoerythroblastic reaction"
"Immature neutrophils (e.g. left shift) are characterized by decreased Fc receptors (CD-16)"
"What is the effect of corticosteroids on neutrophil levels? Increased (neutrophilia)"
"Monocytosis (increased monocytes) is seen with chronic inflammatory states and malignancy"
"Lymphocytosis refers to an increased number of circulating lymphocytes"
"Lymphocytosis often occurs in response to viral infections"
"What bacteria causes lymphocytosis via production of lymphocytosis-promoting factor? Bordetella pertussis"
"Infectious mononucleosis most commonly occurs due to a(n) EBV infection"
"Infectious mononucleosis less commonly occurs due to a(n) CMV infection"
"Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is transmitted by saliva (\kissing disease\\")\""
"What demographic is associated with infectious mononucleosis due to EBV infection? Teenagers::age group"
"Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) primarily infects the oropharynx, liver, and B cells"
"EBV infection results in lymphocytosis comprised of reactive CD8+ T cells"
"The CD8+ T-cell response in infectious mononucleosis leads to lymphadenopathy, especially in the posterior cervical::specific nodes"
"The lymphadenopathy seen with infectious mononucleosis is due to T-cell hyperplasia in the lymph node paracortex"
"The CD8+ T-cell response in EBV infection leads to spleno-megaly"
"The splenomegaly seen with infectious mononucleosis is due to T-cell hyperplasia in the periarterial lymphatic sheath (PALS) of the spleen"
"What abnormal cell (seen on blood smear) is associated with infectious mononucleosis? Atypical lymphocytes (reactive CD8+ T-cells)"
"What test is used to screen for infectious mononucleosis? Monospot test"
"The monospot test detects IgM heterophile antibodies that cross-react with horse or sheep RBCs"
"A(n) negative monospot test with symptoms of infectious mononucleosis suggests CMV infection"
"A definitive diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis is made by serologic testing for the EBV viral capsid antigen"
"Infectious mononucleosis is associated with increased risk for splenic rupture"
"Patients with infectious mononucleosis are advised to avoid contact sports for one month"
"Infectious mononucleosis patients develop a(n) rash if exposed to ampicillin"
"Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) remains dormant in B cells, which increases risk for lymphoma, especially if immunodeficiency develops (e.g. HIV)"
"Acute leukemia is defined as a neoplastic proliferation of blasts > 20% in the bone marrow"
"Acute leukemia may present acutely with symptoms of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and/or neutropenia"
"Acute leukemias are typically associated with increased circulating WBCs"
"The blasts seen in acute leukemia are large::size, immature cells, often with \punched out\\" nucleoli\""
"Acute leukemia is subdivided into ALL or AML based on the phenotype of the blasts"
"ALL is a neoplastic accumulation of lymphoblasts (>20%) in the bone marrow"
"Lympho-blasts are characterized by positive nuclear staining for TdT, which is a(n) DNA polymerase"
"What demographic is most commonly associated with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)? Children::age group"
"Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is associated with Down syndrome; usually arises after the age of 5 years"
"Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is subclassified into B-ALL and T-ALL based on surface markers"
"Which type of ALL (B- or T-ALL) is the most common? B-ALL"
"B-ALL is usually characterized by lymphoblasts (TdT+) that express CD-10, CD-19, and CD-20"
"B-ALL has a(n) excellent response to chemotherapy"
"Treatment of B-ALL requires prophylaxis to the scrotum and CSF"
"B-ALL with t(12;21) has a(n) good prognosis and is more commonly seen in children"
"B-ALL with t(9;22) has a(n) poor prognosis and is more commonly seen in adults::age group"
"T-ALL is characterized by lymphoblasts (TdT+) that express markers ranging from CD-2 to CD-8"
"Do the lymphoblasts in T-ALL express CD10? No"
"T-ALL usually presents in teenagers::age group as a(n) mediastinal mass, thus it is often referred to as acute lymphoblastic lymphoma"
"AML is a neoplastic accumulation of myeloblasts (>20%) in the bone marrow"
"Myeloblasts::-blasts are usually characterized by positive cytoplasmic staining for myeloperoxidase (MPO)"
"Myeloblasts may have crystal aggregates of MPO, which are seen on blood smear as Auer rods"
"Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) most commonly arises in older adults (median onset 65 years)"
"One subtype of AML is acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is characterized by t(15;17)"
"The t(15;17) translocation seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia results in disruption of the retinoic acid receptor on chromosome 17"
"The abnormal promyelocytes seen in APML contain numerous primary granules that increase risk for DIC"
"Acute promyelocytic leukemia is treated with all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA), a vitamin A derivative, as well as arsenic"
"All-trans-retinoic acid binds the altered retinoic acid receptor in APL and causes blasts to mature"
"One subtype of AML is acute monocytic leukemia, which presents with proliferation of monoblasts"
"Do the monoblasts seen in acute monocytic leukemia typically contain myeloperoxidase (MPO)? No"
"In acute monocytic leukemia, blasts characteristically infiltrate the gums"
"One subtype of AML is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia, which presents with proliferation of megakaryoblasts"
"Do the megakaryoblasts seen in acute megakaryoblastic leukemia typically contain myeloperoxidase (MPO)? No"
"Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia is associated with Down syndrome; usually arises before the age of 5"
"AML may arise from pre-existing myelodysplastic syndromes"
"Risk factors for acute myeloid leukemia include prior exposure to alkylating chemotherapy and radiation"
"Myelodysplastic syndromes usually present with increased blasts < 20%"
"Myelodysplastic syndromes rarely may progress to acute myeloid leukemia"
"The brain stem is divisible into three continuous parts: the midbrain, pons, and medulla"
"Which cranial nerves are NOT located in the brain stem? I and II::2"
"Which cranial nerves are located above the pons? I, II, III, and IV::4"
"Which cranial nerves are located in the pons? V, VI, VII, and VIII::4"
"Which cranial nerves are located in the medulla? IX, X, XI*, and XII::4"
"Which cranial nerve nuclei are located medially? III, IV, VI, and XII::4"
"The cranial nerve nuclei that exit medially are motor::motor, sensory, or mixed CNs"
"The cranial nerve nuclei that exit laterally are typically mixed or sensory CNs"
"Which cranial nerve arises from the dorsal aspect of the midbrain? Trochlear nerve (CN IV)"
"ID the structure: Superior colliculus"
"The superior colliculi help coordinate conjugate vertical gaze"
"The superior colliculi directs eye movements to stimuli (noise / movements) or objects of interest"
"ID the structure: Inferior colliculus"
"The inferior colliculi are auditory structures"
"ID Cranial Nerve: Trochlear (CN IV)"
"ID the structure: Pretectal nuclei (light reflex)"
"ID the structure: Pineal gland"
"ID the structure: Cerebral peduncle"
"ID the structure: Mammillary body"
"ID Cranial Nerve: Trochlear (CN IV)"
"ID Cranial Nerve: Trigeminal (CN V)"
"ID Cranial Nerve: Abducens (CN VI)"
"ID Cranial Nerve: Facial (CN VII)"
"ID Cranial Nerve: Vestibulocochlear (CN VIII)"
"ID Cranial Nerve: Glossopharyngeal (CN IX)"
"ID Cranial Nerve: Vagus (CN X)"
"ID the structure: Olive"
"ID Cranial Nerve: Hypoglossal (CN XII)"
"ID Cranial Nerve: Accessory (CN XI)"
"ID the structure: Medullary pyramid"
"Cranial nerve I is the olfactory nerve"
"What type of cranial nerve is the olfactory nerve (CN I)? Sensory::motor, sensory, or both"
"What is the function of CN I (olfactory)? Smell"
"What is the only cranial nerve that lacks thalamic relay to the cortex? CN I (olfactory)"
"Lesions to CN I (olfactory) result in anosmia"
"Cranial nerve II is the optic nerve"
"What type of cranial nerve is the optic nerve (CN II)? Sensory::motor, sensory, or both"
"What is the function of CN II (Optic)? Sight"
"Lesions to CN II (optic) result in loss of the sensory limb of the light reflex"
"Lesions to CN II (optic) result in visual field deficits (anopsia)"
"Cranial nerve III is the oculomotor nerve"
"What type of cranial nerve is the oculomotor nerve (CN III)? Motor::motor, sensory, or both"
"Which cranial nerve innervates the superior rectus muscle? CN III (oculomotor)"
"Which cranial nerve innervates the inferior rectus muscle? CN III (oculomotor)"
"Which cranial nerve innervates the medial rectus muscle? CN III (oculomotor)"
"Which cranial nerve innervates the inferior oblique muscle? CN III (oculomotor)"
"Cranial nerve III (oculomotor) contributes to pupillary constriction::dilation or constriction"
"Cranial nerve III (oculomotor) is responsible for accommodation via innervation of ciliary muscle"
"What cranial nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle? CN III (oculomotor)"
"The motor component of CN III is located centrally::centrally or peripherally"
"The parasympathetic component of CN III is located peripherally::centrally or peripherally"
"Which CN III fibers (motor or parasympathetic) are affected first by vascular disease? Motor"
"Which CN III fibers (motor or parasympathetic) are affected first by compression? Parasympathetics"
"Lesions to CN III (oculomotor) result in ptosis and a \down and out\\" gaze\""
"Lesions to CN III (oculomotor) result in loss of the motor limb of the light reflex"
"Lesions to CN III (oculomotor) result in a \blown/dilated::size\\" pupil\""
"Lesions to CN III (oculomotor) result in inability to accommodate (cycloplegia)"
"Cranial nerve IV is the trochlear nerve"
"What type of cranial nerve is the trochlear nerve (CN IV)? Motor::motor, sensory, or both"
"CN IV (trochlear) contributes to eye movement via innervation of the superior oblique muscle"
"The strongest action of the superior oblique muscle is depression while adducted"
"Lesions to CN IV (trochlear) may present with head tilting away from the lesioned side"
"Lesions to CN IV (trochlear) result in upward movement of the eye, particularly with contralateral gaze"
"Which cranial nerve lesion presents with difficulty walking downstairs? CN IV (trochlear)"
"Cranial nerve VI is the abducens nerve"
"What type of cranial nerve is the abducens nerve (CN VI)? Motor::motor, sensory, or both"
"CN VI (abducens) contributes to eye movement via innervation of the lateral rectus muscle"
"The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for eye abduction"
"Lesions to CN VI (abducens) result in a medially-directed eye (at rest) that cannot abduct"
"Patients with CN VI lesions may squint to reduce diplopia, producing a \pseudo-ptosis\\"\""
"The superior oblique muscle is isolated by having the patient adduct and depress their eye"
"The inferior rectus muscle is isolated by having the patient abduct and depress their eye"
"The inferior oblique muscle is isolated by having the patient adduct and elevate their eye"
"The superior rectus muscle is isolated by having the patient abduct and elevate their eye"
"Cranial nerve V is the trigeminal nerve"
"What type of cranial nerve is the trigeminal nerve (CN V)? Both (motor and sensory)::motor, sensory, or both"
"Which branch of the trigeminal nerve provides general sensation to the forehead, scalp, and cornea? Ophthalmic (V1)"
"Which branch of the trigeminal nerve provides general sensation to the palate, nasal cavity, maxillary face, and maxillary teeth? Maxillary (V2)"
"Which branch of the trigeminal nerve provides general sensation to the jaw and mandibular teeth? Mandibular (V3)"
"Which cranial nerve provides somatosensation to the anterior 2/3rds of the tongue? Mandibular branch of trigeminal (V3)::specific"
"Which cranial nerve provides motor innervation to the muscles of mastication? Mandibular branch of trigeminal (V3)::specific"
"The masseter, temporalis, and medial pterygoid muscles are responsible for closing the jaw (muscles of mastication)"
"The lateral pterygoid muscle is responsible for opening the jaw (muscles of mastication)"
"Lesions to CN V3 (trigeminal) result in deviation of the jaw toward the side of the lesion"
"What cranial nerve pathology causes repetitive, unilateral, shooting pain in a distribution of CN V lasting < 1 minute? Trigeminal neuralgia (tic douloureux)"
"Episodes of trigeminal neuralgia (tic douloureux) typically last < 1 minute"
"Cranial nerve VII is the facial nerve"
"What type of cranial nerve is the facial nerve (CN VII)? Both (motor and sensory)::motor, sensory, or both"
"Which cranial nerve provides taste to the anterior 2/3rds of the tongue? Facial nerve (CN VII) *bonus-which branch"
"Which cranial nerve provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression? Facial nerve (CN VII)"
"CN VII (facial) provides parasympathetic innervation to the lacrimal gland for tear formation *bonus: which branch?"
"CN VII (facial) provides parasympathetic innervation to the submandibular and sublingual glands for salivation bonus: which branch?"
"Which cranial nerve innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle (facilitates eyelid closing)? Facial nerve (CN VII)"
"CN VII (facial) innervates the stapedius muscle, which facilitates auditory volume modulation"
"CN VII (facial) provides some cutaneous innervation to the skin behind the ear"
"Cranial nerve VIII is the vestibulocochlear nerve"
"What type of cranial nerve is the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII)? Sensory::motor, sensory, or both"
"What are the functions of CN VIII (Vestibulocochlear)? Hearing and balance::2"
"Lesions to CN VIII (vestibulocochlear) may cause sensorineural hearing loss and loss of balance"
"Cranial nerve IX is the glossopharyngeal nerve"
"What type of cranial nerve is the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)? Both (motor and sensory)::motor, sensory, or both"
"Which cranial nerve provides taste to the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue? Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)"
"Which cranial nerve provides somatosensation to the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue? Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) *where else does this nerve innervate?"
"Which cranial nerve monitors the carotid body and sinus chemo- and baroreceptors? Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)"
"CN IX (glossopharyngeal) provides parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland for salivation"
"CN IX (glossopharyngeal) provides motor innervation to the stylopharyngeus muscle"
"Lesions to CN IX (glossopharyngeal) result in loss of the sensory limb of the gag reflex"
"Cranial nerve X is the vagus nerve"
"What type of cranial nerve is the vagus nerve (CN X)? Both (motor and sensory)::motor, sensory, or both"
"Which cranial nerve monitors the aortic body and arch chemo- and baroreceptors? Vagus nerve (CN X)"
"Which cranial nerve provides taste to the supraglottic region? Vagus nerve (CN X)"
"CN X (vagus) provides parasympathetic innervation to the thoracoabdominal viscera"
"Which cranial nerve is most responsible for swallowing and soft palate elevation? Vagus nerve (CN X)"
"Which cranial nerve is most responsible for talking and coughing? Vagus nerve (CN X)"
"Which cranial nerve is responsible for keeping the uvula in the midline? Vagus nerve (CN X)"
"Lesions to CN X (vagus) result in loss of the motor limb of the gag reflex"
"Lesions to CN X (vagus) result in deviation of the uvula away from the side of the lesion"
"Cranial nerve XI is the accessory nerve"
"What type of cranial nerve is the accessory nerve (CN XI)? Motor::motor, sensory, or both"
"CN XI (accessory) provides motor innervation to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles"
"The left sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle contracts to turn the head to the right"
"Lesions to CN XI (accessory) result in weakness turning the head to the contra-lateral side of the lesion"
"Lesions to CN XI (accessory) result in shoulder droop on the ipsi-lateral side of the lesion"
"Cranial nerve XII is the hypoglossal nerve"
"What type of cranial nerve is the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)? Motor::motor, sensory, or both"
"What is the function of CN XII (Hypoglossal)? Tongue movement"
"Lesions to CN XII (hypoglossal) result in deviation of the tongue toward the side of the lesion"
"Myelodysplastic syndromes are caused by de novo mutations::genetics or environmental exposure (e.g. radiation, benzene, chemotherapy)"
"Myelodysplastic syndromes may be associated with a(n) Pseudo-Pelger-Huet anomaly, which are neutrophils with bilobed nuclei"
"Pseudo-Pelger Huet anomaly is typically seen after chemotherapy"
"Chronic::acute or chronic leukemia is a neoplastic proliferation of mature circulating lymphocytes"
"Chronic leukemia is usually insidious in onset and seen in older adults::age group"
"Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is a neoplastic proliferation of naive B cells that co-express CD-5 and CD-20"
"What is the most common leukemia in adults? Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)"
"Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is associated with smudge cells and increased lymphocytes on blood smear"
"Chronic lymphocytic leukemia commonly involves lymph nodes, leading to generalized lymphadenopathy; thus called small lymphocytic lymphoma"
"One complication of chronic lymphocytic leukemia is hypogammaglobulinemia, which predisposes to infection"
"What is the most common cause of death in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia? Infection (due to hypogammaglobulinemia)"
"One complication of chronic lymphocytic leukemia is autoimmune hemolytic::very specific anemia"
"Chronic lymphocytic leukemia may transform into diffuse, large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) via the Richter transformation"
"Transformation of CLL into diffuse, large B-cell lymphoma presents clinically as a(n) enlarging lymph node or spleen"
"Hairy cell leukemia is a neoplastic proliferation of mature B cells characterized by hairy cytoplasmic processes"
"The cells in hairy cell leukemia stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP)"
"Positive TRAP stain for diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia has been largely replaced with flow cytometry"
"Patients with hairy cell leukemia typically present with massive splenomegaly due to expansion of the red pulp"
"Hairy cell leukemia causes marrow fibrosis, which results in a \dry tap\\" on bone marrow aspiration\""
"Does hairy cell leukemia typically present with lymphadenopathy? No"
"Hairy cell leukemia has an excellent response to cladribine (2-CDA), which is an adenosine deaminase inhibitor"
"In addition to cladribine (2-CDA), hairy cell leukemia may also be treated with pentostatin"
"What demographic is associated with hairy cell leukemia? Adult males::age/gender"
"Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL) is a neoplastic proliferation of mature CD4+ T::specific cells"
"Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma is caused by the HTLV-1 virus"
"The HTLV-1 virus (cause of ATLL) is associated with IV drug users"
"What regions are most commonly affected by adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma? Japan, West Africa, and the Caribbean"
"Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma may present with cutaneous lesions (rash) due to skin infiltration"
"Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma may present with lytic (punched-out) bone lesions and hypercalcemia"
"How can adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma be distinguished from multiple myeloma? ATLL causes a rash"
"Mycosis fungoides is a neoplastic proliferation of mature CD4+ T::name and type cells"
"Mycosis fungoides typically presents in adults with skin patches/plaques"
"The aggregates of neoplastic cells in the epidermis seen with mycosis fungoides are called Pautrier microabscesses"
"Mycosis fungoides may spread to involve the blood, producing Sézary syndrome (T-cell leukemia)"
"Sézary syndrome is characterized by atypical CD4+ cells with cerebriform nuclei seen on blood smear"
"ID Brainstem Level: Rostral midbrain - Presence of colliculi - Presence of cerebral aqueduct - Presence of cerebral peduncles - Presence of CN III"
"ID Structure: Cerebral aqueduct"
"ID Structure: Spinothalamic tract"
"ID Structure: Medial lemniscus"
"ID Structure: Red nucleus"
"ID Structure: Substantia nigra"
"The substantia nigra appears black to dark brown because nigral cells contain melanin pigment"
"ID Tracts: Corticospinal and Corticobulbar tracts::2"
"ID Structure: Medial longitudinal fasciculus"
"ID Nucleus: Nucleus of CN III - Located in rostral midbrain - Anterolateral to cerebral aqueduct - Anterior to nucleus of Edinger-Westphal"
"ID Nucleus: Nucleus of Edinger-Westphal - Located in rostral midbrain - Anterolateral to cerebral aqueduct - Posterior to nucleus of CN III"
"The nucleus of Edinger-Westphal gives rise to pre-ganglionic parasympathetic axons that travel with CN III (oculomotor)"
"The Edinger-Westphal nucleus provides parasympathetic innervation to the pupillary sphincter and ciliary muscles"
"ID Brainstem Level: Caudal midbrain - Presence of colliculi - Presence of cerebral aqueduct - Presence of CN IV"
"ID Nucleus: Trochlear nucleus"
"Which cranial nerve decussates prior to exiting the brainstem? CN IV (Trochlear)"
"ID Structure: Medial longitudinal fasciculus"
"ID Structure: Spinothalamic tract"
"ID Structure: Medial lemniscus"
"Which part of the brainstem contains the nuclei of CN III and IV? Midbrain"
"ID Brainstem Level: Rostral pons - Presence of 4th ventricle - Ventral enlargement - Presence of CN V"
"ID Cranial Nerve: CN V (Trigeminal)"
"ID Structure: Principal sensory nucleus of V"
"Which trigeminal nerve nucleus innervates the muscles of mastication? Trigeminal motor nucleus"
"Which trigeminal nerve nucleus receives tactile and pressure sensations from CN V distributions? Main sensory nucleus"
"ID Structure: Spinal trigeminal nucleus"
"Which trigeminal nerve nucleus receives pain and temperature sensations from CN V distributions? Spinal trigeminal nucleus"
"ID Structure: Spinothalamic tract"
"ID Structure: Medial lemniscus"
"ID Brainstem Level: Caudal pons - Presence of 4th ventricle - Ventral enlargement - Presence of CN VI and VII"
"ID Nucleus: Facial nucleus - Located ventrolateral to the abducens nucleus"
"The facial nerve exits the facial nucleus and loops around the abducens nucleus, forming the internal genu of the facial nerve"
"ID Nucleus: Abducens nucleus - Found near the midline in the floor of the fourth ventricle, just lateral to the MLF"
"ID Nucleus: Spinal trigeminal nucleus"
"The superior olivary nucleus lies immediately ventral to the nucleus of CN VII and receives auditory impulses from both ears by way of the cochlear nuclei"
"Which part of the brainstem contains the nuclei of CN V, VI, VII and VIII? Pons"
"ID Brainstem Level: Open medulla - Presence of 4th ventricle - Inferior olivary nucleus - Presence of CN IX, X and XII"
"ID Cranial Nerve: CN VIII (Vestibulocochlear)"
"ID Cranial Nerve: CN IX (Glossopharyngeal)"
"ID Cranial Nerve: CN X (Vagus)"
"ID Nucleus: Inferior olivary nucleus"
"ID Nucleus: Hypoglossal nucleus - Situated near the midline just beneath the fourth ventricle"
"ID Nucleus: Spinal trigeminal nucleus"
"ID Structure: Medial lemniscus"
"ID Nucleus: Vestibular nucleus"
"ID Nucleus: Cochlear nucleus - Just lateral to the inferior cerebellar peduncle"
"ID Nucleus: Dorsal motor nucleus of X - Adjacent and lateral to the hypoglossal nucleus"
"Which cranial nerve(s) does the dorsal motor nucleus contribute to? CN X (Vagus)"
"The dorsal motor nucleus sends parasympathetic fibers to the heart, lungs, and upper GI tract"
"ID Nucleus: Nucleus solitarius"
"Which cranial nerve(s) does the nucleus solitarius contribute to? CN VII, IX, and X"
"The nucleus solitarius receives visceral sensory information (e.g. taste, baroreceptors, gut distention)"
"ID Nucleus: Nucleus ambiguus"
"Which cranial nerve(s) does the nucleus ambiguus contribute to? CN IX, X, and XI (cranial portion)"
"The nucleus ambiguus supplies motor innervation of the pharynx, larynx, and upper esophagus (e.g. swallowing, palate elevation)"
"ID Brainstem Level: Closed medulla - Absence of 4th ventricle - Decussation of medullary pyramids"
"ID Nucleus: Nucleus gracilis"
"ID Nucleus: Nucleus cuneatus"
"The axons of the nucleus gracilis and cuneatus are termed internal arcuate fibers before decussating"
"ID Nucleus: Spinal trigeminal nucleus"
"ID Tract: Spinocerebellar tract"
"Which part of the brainstem contains the nuclei of CN IX, X and XII? Medulla"
"Where is the nucleus of CN XI (accessory nucleus) located? Spinal cord"
"Do intramedullary lesions affect fibers of the spinal accessory nerve? No"
"What structure in the medulla separates CN IX and X from CN XII? Olive"
"The rootlets of CN IX and X exit between the olive and inferior cerebellar peduncle"
"The rootlets of CN XII exit between the olive and medullary pyramid"
"The medial lemniscus is initially positioned medially::medially or laterally in the caudal medulla"
"The medial lemniscus is positioned more laterally::medially or laterally as it ascends through the midbrain"
"Lesions to the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) cause internuclear ophthalmoplegia"
"The corticospinal tract is located medially::medially or laterally throughout the brainstem"
"The spinothalamic tract is accompanied by the hypothalamospinal tract throughout the brain stem"
"Horner syndrome presents with ptosis due to denervation of the superior tarsal muscle"
"Horner syndrome is associated with lesions of the spinal cord above T1"
"Horner syndrome is a triad of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis due to sympathetic denervation of the face"
"The spinal trigeminal nucleus receives information about pain and temperature from the ipsilateral face"
"The mesencephalic nucleus of V receives proprioceptive input from the face"
"Which trigeminal nerve nuclei forms the sensory limb of the jaw jerk reflex? Mesencephalic nucleus"
"The 2nd-order neurons of trigeminal nerve nuclei synapse in the ventral posteromedial (VPM) nucleus of the thalamus"
"Lesions to CN V result in loss of facial sensations on the ipsi-lateral side"
"Corticobulbar tracts serve as a source of UMN innervation of LMNs in cranial nerve nuclei"
"Corticobulbar fibers arise in the primary motor cortex"
"The corticobulbar innervation of cranial nerve lower motoneurons is predominantly bi-lateral"
"Which cranial nerve has some LMNs that receive only contralateral corticobulbar innervation? Facial nerve (CN VII)"
"The corticobulbar innervation of facial motoneurons to muscles of the upper face is bi-lateral"
"The corticobulbar innervation of facial motoneurons to muscles of the lower face is contra-lateral"
"Upper motor neuron lesions of the facial nerve result in contra-lateral paralysis of the lower muscles of facial expression"
"Lower motor neuron lesions of the facial nerve result in ipsi-lateral paralysis of the upper and lower muscles of facial expression"
"Lesions to LMNs of CN VII (facial) may result in hyperacusis::auditory complication"
"Lesions to CN VII (facial) may result in loss of taste sensation to the anterior tongue"
"Facial nerve palsy is a clinical syndrome of CN VII upper or lower motoneuron lesion"
"When facial nerve palsy is idiopathic it is called Bell palsy"
"Ramsay Hunt syndrome is a combination of herpes zoster (shingles) and facial nerve palsy"
"Treatment for facial nerve palsy may include corticosteroids and acyclovir"
"ID Structure: Fasciculus cuneatus"
"ID Structure: Fasciculus gracilis"
"ID Tract: Lateral corticospinal tract"
"ID Tract: Spinothalamic tract"
"ID Structure: Anterior (ventral) horn"
"ID Structure: Anterior white commissure"
"ID Tract: Lissauer's tract"
"ID Tract: Spinocerebellar tract"
"The external ear consists of the pinna and the external auditory meatus (auditory canal)"
"The function of the external ear is to transfer sound waves via vibration of the eardrum"
"The external ear is separated from the middle ear by the tympanic membrane"
"The middle ear consists of the auditory ossicles (malleus, incus, stapes)"
"The middle ear is a(n) air::air or fluid-filled space"
"What are the three auditory ossicles of the middle ear? Malleus, incus, & stapes::3"
"The stapes inserts into the oval window, a membrane between the middle and inner ear"
"The auditory ossicles of the middle ear conduct and amplify sound from the eardrum to the inner ear"
"The inner ear consists of a bony and membranous labyrinth"
"The bony labyrinth of the inner ear consists of the semicircular canals, vestibule, and cochlea"
"The membranous labyrinth of the inner ear consists of a series of ducts (scala vestibuli, scala tympani, scala media)"
"The inner ear is a(n) fluid::air or fluid-filled space"
"The fluid in the scala vestibuli and scala tympani is called perilymph (inner ear)"
"Peri-lymph (inner ear) is characterized by high Na+ and low K+ concentration"
"The fluid in the scala media is called endolymph (inner ear)"
"Endo-lymph (inner ear) is characterized by low Na+ and high K+ concentration"
"The cochlea is a spiral-shaped structure in the inner ear that contains the organ of Corti"
"The organ of Corti lies on the basilar membrane of the cochlea and is bathed in the endolymph contained in the scala media"
"The organ of Corti contains two types of receptor cells: inner and outer hair cells"
"The inner and outer hair cells of the organ of Corti have sterocilia, which make contact with the tectorial membrane"
"Bending of cilia in response to basilar membrane vibration produces a change in K+ conductance of the hair cell"
"High frequencies are best heard at the base of the cochlea (basilar membrane)"
"The base of the cochlea (basilar membrane) is thin and rigid"
"Low frequencies are best heard at the apex of the basilar membrane (near the helicotrema)"
"The apex of the basilar membrane is wide and flexible"
"The processing of different frequencies based on spatial arrangement is referred to as tonotopy"
"The endolymph of the inner ear is produced by the stria vascularis"
"If there is unilateral conductive hearing loss, the Weber test localizes to the affected ear"
"If there is unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, the Weber test localizes to the normal ear"
"If there is unilateral conductive hearing loss, the Rinne test demonstrates bone > air conduction"
"If there is unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, the Rinne test demonstrates air > bone conduction"
"Causes of conductive hearing loss include obstruction, otosclerosis, and otitis media"
"Causes of sensorineural hearing loss include damage to the cochlea, CN VIII, or central auditory connections"
"Presbycusis is defined as age-related hearing loss"
"Presbycusis is a form of sensorineural hearing loss, often at higher frequencies"
"Presbycusis occurs due to destruction of hair cells at the cochlear base"
"Noise-induced hearing loss is due to damage to stereociliated cells in the organ of Corti"
"Which frequencies (high or low) are typically lost first with noise-induced hearing loss? High frequencies"
"Sudden extremely loud noises can produce hearing loss due to tympanic membrane rupture (noise-induced hearing loss)"
"The spiral ganglion contains cell bodies whose peripheral axons innervate hair cells of the organ of Corti"
"The central axons from the spiral ganglion form the cochlear part of CN VIII"
"All the axons in the cochlear part of CN VIII enter the pontomedullary junction and synapse in the ventral and dorsal cochlear nuclei"
"Axons of cells in the cochlear nuclei bi-laterally innervate the superior olivary nuclei in the pons"
"The auditory input from the superior olivary nucleus travels via the lateral lemniscus to the inferior colliculus (midbrain)"
"The inferior colliculus sends auditory information to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus"
"The auditory information from the medial geniculate body projects to the primary auditory cortex of the superior temporal gyrus"
"Lesions of the cochlear part of CN VIII or cochlear nuclei result in profound uni::uni- or bilateral-lateral sensorineural hearing loss"
"Lesions at or above superior olivary nucleus result in diminished hearing loss bi::uni- or bilateral-laterally and decreased ability to localize sound"
"The semicircular canals of the vestibular system detect angular acceleration of the head *bonus-name of wall"
"The semicircular canals of the inner ear are filled with endo-lymph"
"At the end of each semicircular canal (ampulla) are hair cells, which act as receptors"
"The cilia on the hair cells of the semicircular canal are embedded in a gelatinous structure called the cupula"
"The hair cells of the semicircular canals have a single long cilium, called a(n) kinocilium, and several smaller stereocilia"
"If the stereocilia are bent toward the kinocilium, the hair cell de-polarizes"
"If the stereocilia are bent away from the kinocilium, the hair cell hyper-polarizes"
"The utricle and saccule (otolith organs) of the vestibular system detect linear acceleration of the head"
"Primary vestibular fibers synapse with secondary fibers in the vestibular nuclei"
"Secondary vestibular fibers, arising from the vestibular nuclei, join the medial longitudinal fasciculus and supply the motor nuclei of CN III, IV, and VI (vestibulo-ocular reflex)"
"A lesion of the vestibular nuclei or nerve produces a vestibular-evoked nystagmus (vestibulo-ocular reflex)"
"Vestibular-evoked nystagmus begins with a slow deviation toward::toward or away from the lesion"
"Vestibular-evoked nystagmus is characterized by a fast corrective phase away from::toward or away from the lesion"
"Cold water irrigation of the ear produces nystagmus to the opposite side (Caloric test)"
"Warm water irrigation of the ear produces nystagmus to the same side (Caloric test)"
"The medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) is a pair of tracts that allows for crosstalk between CN VI and CN III nuclei"
"One control center for horizontal gaze is located in the frontal eye field, which is responsible for contra-lateral gaze"
"One control center for horizontal gaze is located in the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), which is responsible for ipsi-lateral gaze"
"The abducens nucleus is coexistent with the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), the center for ipsilateral horizontal gaze"
"The frontal eye fields send axons that decussate and synapse on neurons of the contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF)"
"The paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) sends axons to synapse with cell bodies of the ipsilateral abducens nucleus"
"The abducens nucleus sends axons that course within the contralateral MLF to reach the oculomotor nucleus"
"Lesions to the paramedian pontine reticular formation result in eyes that look away from the side of the lesion"
"Lesions to the frontal eye fields result in eyes that look towards the side of the lesion"
"Lesions to the abducens nucleus may result in complete, ipsilateral facial paralysis, in addition to symptoms of abducens/PPRF lesion"
"The medial longitudinal fasciculus is heavily::heavily or lightly myelinated"
"Are the MLF lesions seen with multiple sclerosis classically uni- or bilateral? Bilateral"
"What neurological pathology commonly causes medial longitudinal fasciculus lesions? Multiple sclerosis"
"The directional term of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (e.g. right or left) refers to which eye is paralyzed"
"Internuclear ophthalmoplegia results in inability to adduct the ipsi-lateral eye"
"Internuclear ophthalmoplegia results in nystagmus of the contra-lateral eye"
"Internuclear ophthalmoplegia has normal convergence, which is a distinguishing feature from a CN III lesion"
"What arteries supply the medial medulla? Anterior spinal artery or vertebral artery::2"
"What artery supplies the lateral medulla? Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA)"
"What artery supplies the medial pons? Basilar artery (via paramedian pontine branches)"
"What artery supplies the lateral pons? Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA)"
"What artery supplies the medial and lateral midbrain? Posterior cerebral artery"
"Rules of 4: There are four midline structures that start with \M\\" 1. Motor pathway (corticospinal tract) 2. Medial lemniscus 3. Medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) 4. Motor nuclei/nerves (CN III"
"Rules of 4: Lesions in the brain stem that affect the corticospinal tract result in contra-lateral weakness of the arm and leg"
"Rules of 4: Lesions in the brain stem that affect the medial lemniscus result in contra-lateral loss of vibration sense and proprioception in the arm and leg"
"Rules of 4: Lesions in the brain stem that affect the MLF result in ipsi-lateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia"
"Rules of 4: Lesions in the brain stem that affect the motor nuclei or nerves typically result in ipsi-lateral loss of the affected nerve"
"Rules of 4: There are four lateral structures that start with \S\\" 1. Spinocerebellar pathway 2. Spinothalamic tract 3. Spinal trigeminal nucleus 4. Sympathetic (hypothalamospinal) pathway\""
"Rules of 4: Lesions in the brain stem that affect the spinocerebellar pathway result in ipsi-lateral ataxia of the arm and leg"
"Rules of 4: Lesions in the brain stem that affect the spinothalamic tract result in contra-lateral alteration of pain and temperature in the arm and leg"
"Rules of 4: Lesions in the brain stem that affect the spinal trigeminal nucleus result in ipsi-lateral alteration of pain and temperature on the face in the distribution of CN V"
"Rules of 4: Lesions in the brain stem that affect the sympathetic pathway result in ipsi-lateral Horner's syndrome"
"Medial medullary syndrome is caused by occlusion of paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery and/or vertebral arteries"
"What syndrome is associated with lesion of the following areas? Medial medullary syndrome (Inferior alternating hemiplegia) 1. Corticospinal tract 2. Medial lemniscus 3. Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)"
"Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome is caused by: - occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery - most commonly due to traumatic vascular dissection / occlusion of the distal vertebral artery"
"What syndrome is associated with lesion of the following areas? Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome 1. Spinothalamic tract 2. Spinal trigeminal nucleus 3. Hypothalamospinal tract 4. Nucleus ambiguus (CN IX, X) 5. Vestibular nucleus (CN VIII) 6. Inferior cerebellar peduncle"
"Lesion to which artery affects the nucleus ambiguus? Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA)"
"Medial pontine (middle alternating hemiplegia) syndrome is caused by occlusion of paramedian branches of the basilar artery"
"What syndrome is associated with lesion of the following areas? Medial pontine (middle alternating hemiplegia) syndrome 1. Corticospinal tract 2. Medial lemniscus 3. Abducens nerve (CN VI)"
"Lateral pontine syndrome is caused by occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery"
"What syndrome is associated with lesion of the following areas? Lateral pontine syndrome (Marie-Foix) 1. Spinothalamic tract 2. Spinal trigeminal nucleus 3. Hypothalamospinal tract 4. Facial nucleus (CN VII) 5. Cochlear nucleus (CN VIII) 6. Vestibular nucleus (CN VIII) 7. Middle and inferior cerebellar peduncles 8. Labyrinthine artery"
"Lesion to which artery affects the facial nucleus? Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA)"
"Vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma) is a slow-growing tumor that typically arises from Schwann cells in the vestibular nerve"
"Vestibular schwannomas are typically located on CN VIII in the internal acoustic meatus"
"Vestibular schwannomas may extend outside the internal acoustic meatus to the cerebellopontine angle"
"Cerebellopontine angle syndrome lacks signs of long tract lesions, thus indicating the lesion is outside the brainstem"
"Cerebellopontine angle syndrome may initially present with vertigo, vomiting, and progressive hearing loss on the ipsi-lateral side (CN VIII involvement)"
"Cerebellopontine angle syndrome may later involve compression of CN V and VII as the vestibular schwannoma grows and expands"
"Medial midbrain (Weber) syndrome is caused by occlusion of the paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery"
"What syndrome is associated with lesion of the following areas? Medial midbrain (Weber) syndrome 1. Corticospinal tract 2. Corticobulbar tract 3. Fibers of CN III"
"Parinaud syndrome is characterized by paralysis of conjugate vertical gaze due to a lesion in the dorsal midbrain (e.g. stroke, hydrocephalus, pinealoma)"
"Parinaud syndrome often results from a tumor of the pineal gland"
"The raphe nucleus of the reticular formation is responsible for synthesis of serotonin"
"The locus coeruleus of the reticular formation is located in the posterior rostral pons and is responsible for synthesis of norepinephrine"
"The periaqueductal (central) gray of the reticular formation is a collection of nuclei surrounding the cerebral aqueduct in the midbrain"
"The vestibular nuclei sends axons to ipsilateral antigravity muscles via the lateral vestibulospinal tract to maintain upright and balanced posture"
"Which part of the brain \fine-tunes\\" movement and aids in coordination/balance? Cerebellum\""
"The cerebellum consists of a midline vermis and two lateral hemispheres on each side"
"The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum spans through the vermis and lateral hemispheres"
"The vermis of the cerebellum controls the truncal and proximal musculature of limbs"
"The intermediate hemisphere of the cerebellum controls distal musculature"
"The lateral hemisphere of the cerebellum is involved in motor planning"
"The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum is involved in control of balance and eye movements"
"The cerebellum receives ipsi-lateral proprioceptive information from the spinal cord via the inferior cerebellar peduncle"
"The cerebellum receives contra-lateral input from the cerebral cortex via the middle cerebellar peduncle"
"The outer layer of the cerebellar cortex is the molecular layer"
"The molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex contains basket and stellate cells"
"What is the neurotransmitter used by stellate and basket cells (cerebellar cortex)? GABA (Inhibitory)"
"The molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex contains parallel fibers, which are the axons of granule cells"
"The middle layer of the cerebellar cortex is the Purkinje layer"
"All of the inputs to the cerebellum are directed towards influencing the firing of Purkinje cells"
"The only axons that leave the cerebellar cortex are those of Purkinje cells"
"What is the neurotransmitter used by Purkinje cells (cerebellar cortex)? GABA (Inhibitory)"
"The inner layer of the cerebellar cortex is the granule cell layer"
"The granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex contains Golgi cells and granule cells"
"The granule cell is the only excitatory neuron with its cell body in the cerebellar cortex"
"What is the neurotransmitter used by Golgi cells (cerebellar cortex)? GABA (Inhibitory)"
"What is the neurotransmitter used by granule cells (cerebellar cortex)? Glutamate (Excitatory)"
"What is the target of Golgi cells (cerebellar cortex)? Granule cells"
"What is the target of granule, stellate, and basket cells (cerebellar cortex)? Purkinje cells"
"What is the target of Purkinje cells (cerebellar cortex)? Deep cerebellar nuclei"
"Two kinds of excitatory input enter the cerebellum in the form of climbing fibers and mossy fibers"
"Climbing fibers that enter the cerebellum originate from the inferior olivary nuclei of the contralateral medulla"
"The climbing fibers that enter the cerebellum target excitatory terminals on Purkinje cells"
"Mossy fibers that enter the cerebellum are from numerous sources (e.g. pontine nuclei, spinal cord, vestibular nuclei)"
"The mossy fibers that enter the cerebellum target excitatory terminals on granule cells"
"The deep cerebellar nuclei from lateral to medial are dentate, emboliform, globose, and fastigial"
"Cerebellar circuitry begins with Purkinje cells that receive excitatory input from climbing fibers and parallel fibers (of granule cells)"
"Purkinje cells in the flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum project to the fastigial nucleus which projects to the lateral vestibular nucleus"
"Purkinje cells in the vermis of the cerebellum project to the fastigial nuclei"
"Purkinje cells in the intermediate hemisphere of the cerebellum project to the globose and emboliform nuclei"
"Purkinje cells in the lateral hemisphere of the cerebellum project to the dentate nucleus"
"The output of the Purkinje cells is always inhibitory::excitatory or inhibitory"
"The dentate nucleus sends axons that decussate in the superior cerebellar peduncle and then synapse in the contralateral ventral lateral (VL) nucleus of the thalamus"
"Neurons of the ventral lateral nucleus (thalamus) synapse with UMNs in the motor cortex (precentral gyrus)"
"The UMNs of the motor cortex that receive input from the VL nucleus (thalamus) send descending axons via the contralateral corticospinal tract"
"The emboliform and globose nuclei send axons that decussate in the superior cerebellar peduncle and then synapse in the red nucleus of the midbrain"
"Neurons of the red nucleus (midbrain) that receive input from the emboliform and globose nuclei send descending axons via the contralateral rubrospinal tract"
"The major outflow from the cerebellum travels in the superior cerebellar peduncle"
"The hallmark of cerebellar dysfunction is intention tremor without paralysis or paresis"
"Which movement disorder presents as a slow, zigzag motion when pointing/extending toward a target? Intention tremor"
"Lesions that involve the lateral::medial or lateral cerebellum produce a number of dysfunctions, mostly involving the ipsi-lateral extremities (distal musculature)"
"Patients with lateral cerebellar lesions have propensity to fall toward the lesioned side"
"One sign of lateral cerebellar lesion is dysmetria, which is the inability to stop a movement at the proper place (e.g. finger to nose)"
"One sign of lateral cerebellar lesion is dysdiadochokinesia, which is the reduced ability to perform alternating movements quickly (e.g. pronation and supination of forearm)"
"One sign of cerebellar lesions is scanning dysarthria, in which patients divide words into syllables"
"One sign of lateral cerebellar lesion is gaze dysfunction when the eyes try to fix on a point"
"Lesions that involve the medial cerebellum generally result in bi-lateral motor deficits affecting truncal and proximal musculature"
"Lesions of the anterior cerebellar vermis are usually the result of degeneration from alcohol abuse and present with gait::specific ataxia"
"Lesions of the posterior cerebellar vermis usually result from medulloblastomas or ependymomas and present with truncal ataxia"
"Lesions of the medial::medial or lateral cerebellum may result in nystagmus and head tilting"
