"Do patients with cerebellar lesions sway with their eyes open or closed? Both :)"
"Do patients with dorsal column lesions sway with their eyes open or closed? Closed (Romberg sign)"
"Which part of the brain initiates and provides gross control over skeletal muscle movement? Basal ganglia"
"One component of the basal ganglia is the striatum, which consists of the putamen::motor and caudate::cognitive"
"One component of the basal ganglia is the lentiform nucleus, which consists of the putamen and globus pallidus"
"The globus pallidus is divided into a(n) internal and external segment"
"One component of the basal ganglia is the substantia nigra, which is located in the rostral midbrain"
"One component of the basal ganglia is the subthalamic nucleus, which is located in the diencephalon"
"The direct basal ganglia pathway facilitates movement"
"In both the direct and indirect basal ganglia pathways, neurons from the cerebral cortex lead to excitation of neurons of the striatum"
"What neurotransmitter is released by the motor cortex in the basal ganglia pathway (direct and indirect)? Glutamate (excitatory)"
"In the direct basal ganglia pathway, the neurons of the striatum lead to inhibition of neurons of the globus pallidus internus"
"What neurotransmitters are released by the striatum in the direct basal ganglia pathway? GABA and Substance P (Inhibitory)::2"
"What neurotransmitter is released by the globus pallidus internus in the basal ganglia pathway (direct and indirect)? GABA (Inhibitory)"
"Inhibition of the globus pallidus internus results in excitation of the ipsilateral ventral lateral (VL) nucleus of the thalamus (basal ganglia pathway)"
"The indirect basal ganglia pathway inhibits movement"
"In the indirect basal ganglia pathway, the neurons of the striatum lead to inhibition of neurons of the globus pallidus externus"
"What neurotransmitters are released by the striatum in the indirect basal ganglia pathway? GABA and Enkephalin (Inhibitory)::2"
"In the indirect basal ganglia pathway, inhibition of the globus pallidus externus leads to excitation of neurons of the subthalamic nucleus"
"What neurotransmitter is released upon stimulation of the globus pallidus externus (basal ganglia pathway)? GABA (Inhibitory)"
"In the indirect basal ganglia pathway, the neurons of the subthalamic nucleus lead to excitation of neurons of the globus pallidus internus"
"What neurotransmitter is released by the subthalamic nucleus in the indirect basal ganglia pathway? Glutamate (Excitatory)"
"Excitation of the globus pallidus internus results in inhibition of the ipsilateral ventral lateral (VL) nucleus of the thalamus (basal ganglia pathway)"
"Which part of the basal ganglia sends dopaminergic neurons to the striatum to alter activity of both basal ganglia pathways? Substantia nigra"
"Dopamine excites the direct basal ganglia pathway through D1 receptors"
"Dopamine inhibits the indirect basal ganglia pathway through D2 receptors"
"Cholinergic neurons within the striatum stimulate the indirect basal ganglia pathway"
"Which movement disorder presents as sudden, wild flailing of 1 arm +/- the leg on the same side? Hemiballismus"
"Hemiballismus results from a lesion to the contra-lateral subthalamic nucleus (e.g. lacunar stroke)"
"Hemiballismus is usually seen in patients with hypertension, which increases risk for a lacunar stroke"
"ID Structure: Head of caudate"
"ID Structure: Putamen"
"ID Structure: Globus pallidus"
"ID Structure: Thalamus"
"ID letter \a\\": Thalamus\""
"ID letter \b\\": Head of caudate\""
"ID letter \c\\": Genu of internal capsule\""
"ID letter \g\\": Putamen\""
"ID Structure: Sclera - Outer layer, posterior 4/5th of the eye"
"ID Structure: Choroid - Middle layer, posterior 4/5th of the eye - Vascular layer"
"ID Structure: Retina - Inner layer, posterior 4/5th of the eye - Neural layer"
"ID Structure: Fovea - Small depression in the macula, which is the central point of the retina"
"ID Structure: Cornea - Outer layer, anterior 1/5th of the eye"
"ID Structure: Iris - Middle layer, anterior 1/5th of the eye"
"ID Structure: Lens"
"ID Chamber: Posterior chamber"
"ID Chamber: Anterior chamber"
"ID Chamber: Vitreous chamber"
"ID Structure: Ciliary body"
"ID Structure: Zonular fibers (suspensory ligaments)"
"ID Structure: Optic disc"
"Which part of the posterior eye is not covered by the retina (blind spot)? Optic disc"
"Visual acuity is highest at a central point of the retina, called the macula"
"Light is focused in a depression within the macula, called the fovea"
"The lens is suspended from the ciliary body by zonular fibers"
"What two types of photoreceptors are used for vision? rods and cones"
"Which photoreceptor is used for night vision? Rods"
"Which photoreceptor is sensitive to low-intensity light? Rods"
"Rods are characterized by low::high/low acuity and high::high/low sensitivity"
"Cones are characterized by high::high/low acuity and low::high/low sensitivity"
"Which photoreceptor is used for day and color vision? Cones"
"Which photoreceptor is sensitive to high-intensity light? Cones"
"Which type of photoreceptor is found in the fovea? Cones"
"Which layer of the retina absorbs stray light and prevents scatter of light? Pigment epithelial layer"
"The nuclei of photoreceptors are contained in the outer nuclear layer of the retina"
"Output from photoreceptors (rods, cones) is transmitted to bipolar cells, which reside in the inner nuclear layer of the retina"
"The bipolar cells of the retina synapse with ganglion cells, which are the output cells of the retina"
"Axons of the retinal ganglion cells leave the eye via the optic nerve"
"When light strikes the retina, 11-cis retinal is converted to all-trans retinal"
"Regeneration of 11-cis retinal (from all-trans retinal) requires vitamin A"
"Aqueous humor is produced by nonpigmented epithelium on the ciliary body"
"Aqueous humor fills the anterior and posterior chambers of the eye"
"Aqueous humor from the posterior::anterior or posterior chamber enters the anterior::anterior or posterior chamber"
"From the anterior chamber, most aqueous humor (90%) drains through the trabecular meshwork into the canal of Schlemm (scleral venous sinus)"
"From the anterior chamber, some aqueous humor (10%) drains into the uvea and sclera"
"Trabecular outflow of aqueous humor is increased with M3 agonists"
"Uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor is increased with prostaglandin agonists"
"Aqueous humor production is decreased with β antagonists::agonists or antagonists"
"Aqueous humor production is decreased with α2 agonists::agonists or antagonists"
"Aqueous humor production is decreased by carbonic anhydrase::enzyme inhibitors"
"Vitreous humor fills the vitreous chamber of the eye"
"What is the predominant autonomic receptor on the pupillary sphincter muscle? M3"
"What is the predominant autonomic receptor on the pupillary dilator muscle? α1"
"What is the predominant autonomic receptor on the ciliary muscle? M3"
"Is the pupillary sphincter muscle under parasympathetic or sympathetic control? Parasympathetic"
"Light reflex: Light in either retina sends a signal via CN II to the pretectal nuclei"
"Light reflex: Cells in the pretectal area send axons to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus, bilaterally"
"Light reflex: The Edinger-Westphal nuclei send pre-ganglionic parasympathetic neurons to the ciliary ganglia via CN III"
"Light reflex: The ciliary ganglia send post-ganglionic parasympathetic neurons to the pupillary constrictor muscle via short ciliary nerves"
"Which cranial nerve is responsible for the afferent limb of the pupillary light reflex? CN II (Optic)"
"Which cranial nerve is responsible for the efferent limb of the pupillary light reflex? CN III (Oculomotor)"
"Is the ciliary muscle under parasympathetic or sympathetic control? Parasympathetic"
"Accommodation (near response) occurs via contraction of the ciliary muscle, which relaxes the suspensory ligaments and allows the lens to become more round"
"The accommodation reflex is accompanied by convergence and miosis"
"Is the pupillary dilator muscle under parasympathetic or sympathetic control? Sympathetic"
"The first neuron involved in mydriasis projects from the hypothalamus to the ciliospinal center of Budge (C8 - T2)"
"Axons from the ciliospinal center of Budge exit at T1 and synapse on the superior cervical ganglion"
"The sympathetic fibers of the superior cervical ganglion travel in the internal carotid artery and cavernous sinus en route to the orbit"
"Sympathetic fibers from the superior cervical ganglion innervate the pupillary dilator muscle via long ciliary nerves"
"Argyll-Robertson pupil is a pupil that has a functional accommodation reflex, but no light reflex"
"Marcus Gunn pupil is characterized by decreased bilateral pupillary constriction when light is shone in the affected eye relative to the unaffected eye"
"Marcus Gunn pupil is also referred to as relevant afferent pupillary defect (RAPD)"
"Marcus Gunn pupil occurs due to optic nerve damage or severe retinal injury"
"Marcus Gunn pupil is tested with the \swinging flashlight\\" test\""
"Adie pupil is a unilaterally dilated pupil that reacts sluggishly to light, but better to accommodation"
"Adie pupil is more commonly seen in women::gender and is often associated with loss of the knee jerk reflex"
"Visual fields are subdivided into two hemifields: nasal and temporal"
"Visual images perceived on the nasal hemifield will stimulate cells on the temporal half of the ipsilateral retina (and vice versa)"
"At the optic chiasm, 60% of the optic fibers from the nasal half of each retina cross and project into the contralateral optic tracts"
"Most fibers in the optic tract project to the lateral geniculate body of the thalamus"
"The axons from the lateral geniculate body that project to the primary visual (striate) cortex are known as optic radiations"
"The primary visual (striate) cortex is divided into cuneus::superior and lingual::inferior gyri via the calcarine fissure"
"Visual information from the inferior retina travels in Meyer's loop (temporal lobe) before synapsing in the lingual gyrus"
"Visual information from the superior retina travels in the dorsal optic radiation (parietal lobe) before synapsing in the cuneus gyrus"
"What is the orientation of an image when it hits the primary visual cortex? Upside down with left-right reversed"
"Lesions to the optic nerve result in mon-ocular and ipsi-lateral deficits in vision"
"What visual deficit results from complete lesion of the optic nerve (e.g. central retinal artery occlusion, central retinal vein occlusion)? Ipsilateral anopia"
"What visual deficit results from lesion of the optic nerve just outside the optic chiasm (e.g. medially expanding ICA aneurysm)? Ipsilateral nasal hemianopia"
"What visual deficit results from lesion of the optic chiasm (e.g. pituitary adenoma, craniopharyngioma)? Bitemporal hemianopia"
"Lesion to areas after the optic chiasm result in bin-ocular and homonymous contra-lateral deficits in vision"
"What visual deficit results from lesion of the optic tract or lateral geniculate body? Contralateral homonymous hemianopia"
"What visual deficit results from a lesion of Meyer's loop (e.g. temporal lesion, MCA occlusion)? Contralateral homonymous superior quadrantanopia (\pie in the sky\\")\""
"What visual deficit results from lesion of Baum's Loop (dorsal optic radiation) (e.g. parietal lesion, MCA occlusion)? Contralateral homonymous inferior quadrantanopia (\Pie on the floor\\")\""
"What visual deficit results from a lesion of primary visual cortex (e.g. PCA occlusion)? Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing"
"The macula is spared during posterior cerebral artery infarct due to collateral circulation with the middle cerebral artery"
"What visual deficit results from lesion of the macula? Central scotoma"
"Patients with optic tract lesions will have a slightly suppressed pupillary light reflex"
"Myeloproliferative disorders are neoplastic proliferations of mature cells of myeloid lineage"
"Myeloproliferative disorders most commonly present in late adulthood (50 - 60 years old)::age group"
"Myeloproliferative disorders may cause hyperuricemia and gout due to high turnover of cells"
"Myeloproliferative disorders may progress to marrow fibrosis or transform to acute leukemia"
"Chronic myeloproliferative disorders (except CML) are associated with V617F JAK2 mutations"
"Chronic myeloid leukemia is a neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially granulocytes and their precursors (basophil, neutrophil, eosinophils)"
"Chronic myeloid leukemia is defined by the t(9;22) translocation"
"The t(9;22) translocation generates a(n) BCR-ABL fusion protein with increased tyrosine kinase activity"
"Chronic myeloid leukemia* responds well to tyrosine kinase inhibitors, such as imatinib"
"Chronic myeloid leukemia commonly results in spleno-megaly"
"An enlarging spleen in CML suggests progression to accelerated disease (\blast crisis\\")\""
"CML may transform to acute myeloid leukemia (2/3rd of cases)"
"CML may transform to acute lymphoid leukemia (1/3rd of transformations)"
"CML is distinguished from a leukemoid reaction (benign neutrophilia) by presence of increased basophils"
"CML is distinguished from a leukemoid reaction (benign neutrophilia) by a(n) negative leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) stain"
"Polycythemia vera is a neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially red blood cells"
"Polycythemia vera is a form of primary::primary or secondary polycythemia"
"Polycythemia vera may present with symptoms of hyperviscosity of the blood (e.g. blurry vision, headache)"
"Polycythemia vera increases risk of venous and arterial thrombosis"
"Polycythemia vera rarely may cause erythromelalgia, which is characterized by severe, burning pain and red-blood discoloration"
"Polycythemia vera classically presents with intense itching, especially after a hot shower"
"The 1st line treatment for polycythemia vera is phlebotomy; second-line therapy is hydroxyurea"
"Patients with polycythemia vera may take low-dose aspirin to decrease risk of thrombosis"
"Polycythemia vera is characterized by increased plasma volume"
"Polycythemia vera is characterized by significantly increased RBC mass"
"Polycythemia vera is characterized by decreased EPO"
"Relative polycythemia is characterized by decreased plasma volume"
"Relative polycythemia is characterized by normal RBC mass"
"Relative polycythemia is characterized by normal EPO"
"Which form of polycythemia is associated with dehydration and burns? Relative polycythemia (relative erythrocytosis / hemoconcentration)"
"Appropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by increased RBC mass"
"Appropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by increased EPO"
"Appropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by decreased O2 saturation"
"Which form of polycythemia is associated with lung disease (ex. COPD / obstructive sleep apnea), congenital heart disease, high altitude, or low birth weight? Appropriate absolute polycythemia (appropriate secondary erythrocytosis)"
"Inappropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by increased RBC mass"
"Inappropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by increased EPO"
"Inappropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by normal O2 saturation"
"Which form of polycythemia is associated with ectopic EPO production (e.g. malignancy, hydronephrosis & renal cysts) or exogenous EPO? Inappropriate absolute polycythemia (innapropriate secondary erythrocytosis)"
"Essential thrombocythemia (ET) is a neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially platelets"
"Blood smear of essential thrombocythemia shows markedly increased number of platelets, which may be large or abnormally formed"
"Symptoms of essential thrombocythemia are related to an increased risk of bleeding and/or thrombosis"
"Are patients with essential thrombocythemia (ET) at risk for marrow fibrosis and/or acute leukemia? No (rare)"
"Does essential thrombocythemia (ET) present with significant risk for hyperuricemia and gout? No"
"Myelofibrosis is a neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially megakaryocytes"
"In myelofibrosis, megakaryocytes produce excess platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and TGF-b, causing marrow fibrosis"
"Myelofibrosis is often associated with massive splenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis"
"Myelofibrosis is characterized by a(n) leukoerythroblastic smear (increased nucleated RBCs and immature granulocytes) Why?"
"Myelofibrosis causes increased risk of infection, thrombosis, and bleeding due to pancytopenia"
"What pathologic RBC is associated with myelofibrosis? \Tear drop\\" cells (dacrocyte)\""
"Polycythemia vera is characterized by increased WBCs"
"Polycythemia vera is characterized by increased platelets"
"Is polycythemia vera associated with JAK2 mutations? Yes"
"Is essential thrombocythemia associated with JAK2 mutations? Yes (30-50%)"
"Is myelofibrosis associated with JAK2 mutations? Yes (30-50%)"
"Is chronic myeloid leukemia associated with JAK2 mutations? No (associated with Philadelphia chromosome)"
"Lymphadenopathy (LAD) refers to enlarged lymph nodes"
"Painful::painful or painless lymphadenopathy is usually seen in lymph nodes that are draining a region of acute infection"
"Painless::painful or painless lymphadenopathy can be seen with chronic inflammation, metastatic carcinoma, or lymphoma"
"Proliferation of the B cell compartment of lymph nodes causes follicular hyperplasia (e.g. rheumatoid arthritis, early stages of HIV infection)"
"Proliferation of the T cell compartment of lymph nodes causes paracortex hyperplasia (e.g. viral infections)"
"Hyperplasia of sinus histiocytes is seen in lymph nodes that are draining a tissue with cancer"
"Lymphomas::leukemias or lymphomas are neoplastic proliferations of lymphoid cells that form a mass"
"Lymphoma is divided into non-Hodgkin (60%) and Hodgkin lymphoma (40%) *bonus: age groups"
"Follicular lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of small B cells (CD20+) that form follicle-like nodules"
"What form of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma is seen in the image below? Follicular lymphoma"
"Follicular lymphoma typically presents in late adulthood::age group"
"Follicular lymphoma is characterized by painless \waxing and waning\\" lymphadenopathy\""
"Follicular lymphoma is driven by a t(14;18) translocation"
"What chromosome is BCL2 located on? Chromosome 18"
"What chromosome is Ig heavy chain located on? Chromosome 14"
"The Ig heavy chain genes on chromosome 14 are constitutively expressed"
"The t(14;18) translocation results in overexpression of Bcl2, resulting in inhibition of apoptosis"
"Treatment of follicular lymphoma is reserved for symptomatic patients and involves low-dose chemotherapy or rituximab (anti-CD20 antibody)"
"Follicular lymphoma may progress to diffuse, large B-cell lymphoma, which presents as an enlarging lymph node"
"Follicular lymphoma is distinguished from reactive follicular hyperplasia by disruption of normal lymph node architecture"
"Follicular lymphoma is distinguished from reactive follicular hyperplasia by lack of tingible body macrophages::long name (3) in germinal centers"
"Follicular lymphoma is distinguished from reactive follicular hyperplasia by expression of Bcl2 in follicles"
"Follicular lymphoma is distinguished from reactive follicular hyperplasia by mono-clonality"
"Grade 1 follicular lymphoma is characterized by small cleaved cells"
"Grade 2 follicular lymphoma is characterized by a mixture of small cleaved cells and large noncleaved cells"
"Grade 3 follicular lymphoma is characterized by large noncleaved cells"
"Is follicular lymphoma typically aggressive or indolent? Indolent"
"Mantle cell lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of small B cells (CD20+ & CD5+) that expands into the mantle zone"
"Which region of the lymph node is immediately adjacent to the follicle? Mantle zone"
"What demographic is associated with mantle cell lymphoma? Adult males"
"Mantle cell lymphoma is driven by a t(11;14) translocation"
"What chromosome is cyclin D1 located on? Chromosome 11"
"The t(11;14) translocation results in overexpression of Cyclin D1, which promotes the G1/S transition in the cell cycle, facilitating neoplastic proliferation"
"Is mantle cell lymphoma typically aggressive or indolent? Aggressive"
"Marginal zone lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of small B cells (CD20+) that expands into the marginal zone"
"Marginal zone lymphoma is associated with chronic inflammatory states (e.g. Hashimoto thyroiditis, Sjögren's syndrome, H. pylori gastritis)"
"MALToma is a form of marginal zone lymphoma in mucosal sites"
"Gastric MALTomas may regress with treatment of H. pylori"
"Burkitt lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of intermediate-sized B cells (CD20+)"
"Endemic Burkitt lymphoma is associated with EBV infection"
"Burkitt lymphoma classically presents as an extranodal mass in a(n) child or young adult::age group"
"The African form of Burkitt lymphoma typically involves the jaw"
"The sporadic form of Burkitt lymphoma typically affects children and involves the pelvis or abdomen"
"Burkitt lymphoma is driven by a t(8;14) translocation"
"What chromosome is c-myc located on? Chromosome 8"
"The t(8,14) translocation results in overexpression of c-myc, which promotes growth"
"Burkitt lymphoma is characterized by a high mitotic index and \starry-sky\\" appearance on microscopy\""
"Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of large B cells (CD20+) that grow diffusely in sheets"
"What is the most common form of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma? Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL)"
"Is diffuse large B-cell lymphoma typically aggressive or indolent? Aggressive"
"Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma arises sporadically or from transformation of low-grade lymphoma (e.g. follicular lymphoma)"
"Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma often presents in late adulthood::age group as an enlarging lymph node or an extranodal mass"
"While diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is usually seen in older adults, 20% of cases occur in children"
"Primary CNS lymphoma is most commonly seen in patients with AIDS::disease"
"Primary CNS lymphoma typically presents in adults with confusion, memory loss, and seizures (variable presentation)"
"Primary CNS lymphoma typically presents as a single, solid brain lesion on MRI"
"Primary CNS lymphoma must be distinguished from toxoplasmosis infection via CSF analysis or other lab tests"
"Hodgkin lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of Reed-Sternberg cells"
"Reed-Sternberg cells are large B cells with multilobed nuclei and prominent nucleoli (\owl eye\\" appearance)\""
"Reed-Sternberg cells are classically positive for CD-15 and CD-30"
"Reed-Sternberg cells secrete cytokines, which attract other inflammatory cells"
"Reed-Sternberg cells occasionally result in \B\\" symptoms (fever"
"The tumors seen in Hodgkin lymphoma are mostly composed of reactive inflammatory cells"
"What is the most common subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma (70%)? Nodular sclerosis"
"What demographic is classically associated with the nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma? Young adult females::age and gender"
"The nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma typically presents as an enlarging cervical or mediastinal lymph node in a female"
"Which subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma is seen in the image below? Nodular sclerosis - Lymph node divided by bands of sclerosis"
"The nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized histologically by presence of Reed-Sternberg cells in lake-like spaces (lacunar cells)"
"Which subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma has the best prognosis? Lymphocyte-rich"
"Which subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma is often associated with abundant eosinophils? Mixed-cellularity"
"Hodgkin lymphoma may present with eosinophilia due to production of IL-5 by Reed-Sternberg cells (especially mixed cellularity subtype)"
"Which subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma is the most aggressive? Lymphocyte-depleted"
"Which subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma is usually seen in the elderly and HIV+ individuals? Lymphocyte-depleted"
"Most subtypes of Hodgkin lymphoma are more common in men::gender"
"Which type of lymphoma is associated with masses composed of lymphoid cells? Non-Hodgkin lymphoma::Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin"
"Which type of lymphoma is associated with masses composed of reactive inflammatory cells? Hodgkin lymphoma::Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin"
"Which type of lymphoma is characterized by contiguous spread? Hodgkin lymphoma::Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin"
"Which type of lymphoma is characterized by non-contiguous spread? Non-Hodgkin lymphoma::Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin"
"Which type of lymphoma is associated with extranodal involvement? Non-Hodgkin lymphoma::Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin"
"Staging is important and the strongest predictor of prognosis for Hodgkin::Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin lymphoma"
"Radiation is the mainstay of treatment for Hodgkin lymphoma"
"Hodgkin lymphoma has a bimodal distribution: common in young adulthood and adults > 55 years"
"Multiple myeloma is a malignant proliferation of mono-clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow"
"Multiple myeloma is the most common primary malignancy of bone in people > 40 - 50 years old"
"What is the most common bone malignancy? Metastatic cancer"
"Multiple myeloma is associated with high serum IL-6, which stimulates plasma cell growth and immunoglobulin production"
"Multiple myeloma presents with lytic (punched-out) bone lesions and hypercalcemia"
"The bone lesions seen with multiple myeloma are most common in the vertebrae and skull"
"In multiple myeloma, neoplastic plasma cells produce IL-1, which stimulates osteoclast maturation that will lead to bone resorption"
"Multiple myeloma is associated with elevated serum protein"
"Multiple myeloma is associated with M spike on serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP)"
"The M spike seen in multiple myeloma is most commonly due to monoclonal IgG (55%) or IgA (25%)"
"Multiple myeloma is associated with increased risk of infection due to lack of antigenic diversity of monoclonal antibodies"
"What is the most common cause of death in multiple myeloma? Infection"
"Multiple myeloma is associated with Rouleaux formation of RBCs on blood smear"
"Multiple myeloma may deposit in tissue, causing primary (AL) amyloidosis"
"Multiple myeloma is associated with free light chain excretion in the urine, known as Bence Jones proteinuria"
"In multiple myeloma, free light chain (Bence Jones protein) may deposit in kidney tubules, leading to risk for renal failure (myeloma kidney)"
"The signs/symptoms of multiple myeloma may be remembered with the mnemonic \CRAB\\": C: hyperCalcemia R: Renal involvement"
"Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is an asymptomatic condition characterized by an M spike on SPEP without other features of multiple myeloma"
"Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is common in the elderly::age group"
"1-2% of patients with monoclonal gammopathy of underdetermined significance (MGUS) develop multiple myeloma per year"
"Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is a B-cell lymphoma with monoclonal IgM production"
"Does Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia present with lytic bone lesions? No"
"The M spike seen in Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is due to monoclonal IgM"
"Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia typically presents with visual and neurologic deficits without CRAB symptoms of multiple myeloma"
"Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is associated with symptoms of hyperviscosity (due to large size of IgM pentamer)"
"Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia may present with bleeding due to defective platelet aggregation"
"Acute complications of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia are treated with plasmapheresis, which removes IgM from the serum"
"Langerhans cells are specialized dendritic cells predominantly found in skin"
"Langerhans cells are derived from bone marrow monocytes"
"Langerhans cells present antigen to naive T cells"
"Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a neoplastic proliferation of Langerhans cells"
"Langerhans cell histiocytosis is characterized by Birbeck (tennis racket) granules on electron microscopy"
"Langerhans cells are positive for CD1a and S100 on immunohistochemistry"
"S100 is an immunohistochemical stain that stains cells of neural crest origin"
"Langerhans cell histiocytosis may present as recurrent otitis media with a mass involving the mastoid bone"
"Do the Langerhans cells in Langerhans cell histiocytosis effectively stimulate primary T cells via antigen presentation? No (functionally immature)"
"Letterer-Siwe disease is a(n) malignant::benign or malignant proliferation of Langerhans cells"
"Which Langerhans cell histiocytosis presents as skin rash and cystic skeletal defects? Letterer-Siwe disease"
"Letterer-Siwe disease is often seen in infants < 2 years old::age group"
"Eosinophilic granuloma is a(n) benign::benign or malignant proliferation of Langerhans cells"
"Which Langerhans cell histiocytosis presents as pathologic fracture with no skin involvement? Eosinophilic granuloma"
"Eosinophilic granuloma is often seen in adolescents::age group"
"Hand-Schüller-Christian disease is a(n) malignant::benign or malignant proliferation of Langerhans cells"
"Which Langerhans cell histiocytosis presents as scalp rash, lytic skull lesions, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos? Hand-Schüller-Christian disease"
"Hand-Schüller-Christian disease is often seen in children > 3 years old::age group"
"Which thalamic nucleus receives input from the spinothalamic tract and dorsal columns? Ventral posterolateral (VPL)"
"What is the destination of the ventral posterolateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus? Primary somatosensory cortex"
"Which thalamic nucleus receives input from the trigeminal nerve and gustatory pathway? Ventral posteromedial (VPM)"
"What is the destination of the ventral posteromedial (VPM) nucleus of the thalamus? Primary somatosensory cortex"
"Which thalamic nucleus receives visual input from CN II? Lateral geniculate body (LGB)"
"What is the destination of the lateral geniculate body (LGB) of the thalamus? Primary visual cortex (calcarine sulcus)"
"Which thalamic nucleus receives auditory input from the inferior colliculus and superior olive? Medial geniculate body (MGB)"
"What is the destination of the medial geniculate body (MGB) of the thalamus? Primary auditory cortex (temporal lobe)"
"Which thalamic nuclei receive motor input from the basal ganglia and cerebellum? Ventral anterior (VA) / Ventral lateral (VL)::2"
"What is the destination of the ventral anterior (VA) / ventral lateral (VL) nuclei of the thalamus? Premotor and primary motor cortex"
"Thalamic Pain Syndrome aka Central Post-Stroke Pain syndrome is caused by a(n) thalamic stroke that manifests with pure contralateral::ipsilateral or contralateral? sensory loss and initial paresthesias followed in weeks to months by: - abnormal, unpleasant sense of touch (dysesthesia) - hypersensitivity to pain (allodynia/hyperalgesia)"
"Does central post-stroke pain (thalamic pain) syndrome respond to analgesic medications? No (resistant)"
"The supraoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus primarily makes ADH"
"The paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus primarily secretes oxytocin"
"The suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus is responsible for the circadian rhythm, which regulates the sleep cycle"
"Circadian rhythm: The suprachiasmatic nucleus is regulated by environmental (e.g. light) input"
"Circadian rhythm: The suprachiasmatic nucleus releases norepinephrine, which stimulates the pineal gland to secrete melatonin"
"The ventromedial area of the hypothalamus is responsible for satiety"
"Lesion of the ventromedial area of the hypothalamus results in hyperphagia"
"The ventromedial area of the hypothalamus is stimulated by leptin"
"The lateral area of the hypothalamus is responsible for hunger"
"Lesion of the lateral area of the hypothalamus results in anorexia and failure to thrive (infants)"
"The lateral area of the hypothalamus is stimulated by ghrelin"
"Stimulation of the lateral area of the hypothalamus is inhibited by leptin"
"The anterior hypothalamus senses elevated body temperatures and mediates responses to dissipate heat"
"Lesion of the anterior hypothalamus results in hyperthermia"
"The anterior hypothalamus is controlled by the parasympathetic nervous system"
"The posterior hypothalamus senses decreased body temperatures and mediates responses to conserve heat"
"Lesion of the posterior hypothalamus results in poikilothermy (cold-blooded)"
"The posterior hypothalamus is controlled by the sympathetic nervous system"
"Stimulation of the dorsomedial nucleus of the hypothalamus results in savage behavior and obesity"
"Circumventricular organs (CVOs) are structures in the brain that are characterized by extensive vasculature and lack of blood-brain-barrier"
"The OVLT (organum vasculosum of the lamina terminalis) is a circumventricular organ that senses changes in serum osmolarity"
"The area postrema (chemoreceptor trigger zone) is a circumventricular organ found in the medulla that responds to emetics"
"The epithalamus consists of the pineal gland and habenular nuclei"
"The pineal gland is responsible for melatonin secretion and circadian rhythms"
"Lateral medullary syndrome is also known as Wallenberg syndrome"
"Medial midbrain syndrome is also known as Weber syndrome"
"Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is associated with the t(12;21) translocation"
"The t(9;22) translocation (BCR-ABL) is also known as the Philadelphia chromosome"
"Is this the left or right lateral hemisphere of the brain? Left - The temporal lobe points toward the direct of the hemisphere"
"The lateral (Sylvian) fissure separates the temporal lobe from parietal and frontal lobes"
"The central sulcus separates the frontal and parietal lobes"
"The parieto-occipital sulcus separates the parietal and occipital lobes"
"The pre-central gyrus is the area of the primary motor cortex (frontal lobe)"
"The post-central gyrus is the area of the primary somatosensory cortex (parietal lobe)"
"The motor/sensory areas corresponding to the face are located in the lateral::medial or lateral aspects of the pre-/post-central gyri"
"The motor/sensory areas corresponding to the upper limbs are located in the lateral::medial or lateral aspects of the pre-/post-central gyri"
"The motor/sensory areas corresponding to the lower limbs are located in the medial::medial or lateral aspects of the pre-/post-central gyri"
"The lateral aspect of the pre-/post-central gyrus is supplied by the middle cerebral artery"
"The medial aspect of the pre-/post-central gyrus is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery"
"Which layer of the six-layered neocortex contains cell bodies of neurons that form the corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts? Internal pyramidal layer (layer V)"
"Which layer of the six-layered neocortex is the site of termination of the thalamocortical projections? Internal granular layer (layer IV)"
"Which cerebral artery supplies the medial surface of the frontal/parietal lobes? Anterior cerebral artery"
"Which cerebral artery supplies the superior ~1 inch of the frontal/parietal cortex? Anterior cerebral artery"
"Which cerebral artery supplies the anterior four-fifths of the corpus callosum? Anterior cerebral artery"
"Which cerebral artery supplies the anterior limb of the internal capsule? Anterior cerebral artery"
"Which cerebral artery supplies most of the lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere? Middle cerebral artery"
"Which main cerebral artery supplies the genu/posterior limb of the internal capsule? Middle cerebral artery"
"Which cerebral artery supplies the occipital lobe? Posterior cerebral artery"
"Which cerebral artery supplies the inferior temporal lobe? Posterior cerebral artery"
"Which cerebral artery supplies the splenium of the corpus callosum? Posterior cerebral artery"
"The area between the ACA/MCA, PCA/MCA (Cortical Border Zone) and the Deep / Superficial branches of the MCA (Internal Border Zone) represent watershed zones"
"Damage to watershed zones occurs with severe hypotension"
"Damage to the internal border zone results in bilateral proximal extremity weakness"
"Damage to the watershed zone between the middle and posterior cerebral arteries results in defects in higher-order visual processing"
"What does Brodmann area 3, 1, 2 refer to? Primary somatosensory cortex"
"What does Brodmann area 4 refer to? Primary motor cortex"
"Neurons of the premotor cortex are involved in planning of motor activities"
"Neurons of the prefrontal cortex are involved in organizing and planning the intellectual and emotional aspects of behavior"
"Lesions to the frontal lobe may result in disinhibition, apathy, and deficits in concentration, orientation, and judgment"
"Lesions to the frontal lobe may present with re-emergence of primitive reflexes"
"Neurons of the somatosensory association cortex are involved in integration of information processed in the primary somatosensory cortex"
"Lesions to the somatosensory association cortex result in astereognosis, which is the inability to recognize objects by touch"
"The language centers are found in the \dominant\\" hemisphere"
"Which cerebral artery supplies the language centers (Broca's area, Wernicke's area)? Middle cerebral artery"
"Which \language center\\" is the center for motor speech? Broca's area\""
"Which \language center\\" is located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the frontal lobe? Broca's area\""
"Which \language center\\" is the center for language comprehension? Wernicke's area\""
"Which \language center\\" is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the temporal lobe? Wernicke's area\""
"Aphasia is a higher-order language deficit (inability to understand, speak, read, and/or write) caused by pathology in the language centers of the brain"
"Dysarthria is a motor inability to speak"
"Broca (expressive) aphasia is characterized by nonfluent::fluent or nonfluent speech"
"Broca's (expressive) aphasia is characterized by intact::intact or impaired comprehension"
"Broca's (expressive) aphasia is characterized by impaired::intact or impaired repetition"
"Which type of aphasia is characterized by the following: Broca (expressive) aphasia 1. Nonfluent speech 2. Intact comprehension 3. Impaired repetition"
"Wernicke (receptive) aphasia is characterized by fluent::fluent or nonfluent speech"
"Wernicke (receptive) aphasia is characterized by impaired::intact or impaired comprehension"
"Wernicke (receptive) aphasia is characterized by impaired::intact or impaired repetition"
"Which type of aphasia is characterized by the following: Wernicke (receptive) aphasia 1. Fluent speech 2. Impaired comprehension 3. Impaired repetition"
"Conduction aphasia is characterized by fluent::fluent or nonfluent speech"
"Conduction aphasia is characterized by intact::intact or impaired comprehension"
"Conduction aphasia is characterized by impaired::intact or impaired repetition"
"Which type of aphasia is characterized by the following: Conduction aphasia 1. Fluent speech 2. Intact comprehension 3. Impaired repetition"
"Conduction aphasia is caused by damage to the arcuate fasciculus, which is a large fiber bundle that connects Broca's area with Wernicke's area"
"Global aphasia is characterized by nonfluent::fluent or nonfluent speech"
"Global aphasia is characterized by impaired::intact or impaired comprehension"
"Global aphasia is characterized by impaired::intact or impaired repetition"
"Which type of aphasia is characterized by the following: Global aphasia 1. Nonfluent speech 2. Impaired comprehension 3. Impaired repetition"
"Global aphasia is caused by damage to Broca's area, Wernicke's area, and the arcuate fasciculus"
"Transcortical motor aphasia is characterized by nonfluent::fluent or nonfluent speech"
"Transcortical motor aphasia is characterized by intact::intact or impaired comprehension"
"Transcortical motor aphasia is characterized by intact::intact or impaired repetition"
"Which type of aphasia is characterized by the following: Transcortical motor aphasia 1. Nonfluent speech 2. Intact comprehension 3. Intact repetition"
"Transcortical motor aphasia is caused by damage to the areas around Broca's area; Broca's area itself is spared"
"Transcortical sensory aphasia is characterized by fluent::fluent or nonfluent speech"
"Transcortical sensory aphasia is characterized by impaired::intact or impaired comprehension"
"Transcortical sensory aphasia is characterized by intact::intact or impaired repetition"
"Which type of aphasia is characterized by the following: Transcortical sensory aphasia 1. Fluent speech 2. Impaired comprehension 3. Intact repetition"
"Transcortical sensory aphasia is caused by damage to the areas around Wernicke's area; Wernicke's area itself is spared"
"Transcortical mixed aphasia is characterized by nonfluent::fluent or nonfluent speech"
"Transcortical mixed aphasia is characterized by impaired::intact or impaired comprehension"
"Transcortical mixed aphasia is characterized by intact::intact or impaired repetition"
"Which type of aphasia is characterized by the following: Transcortical mixed aphasia 1. Nonfluent speech 2. Impaired comprehension 3. Intact repetition"
"Transcortical mixed aphasia is caused by damage to the watershed areas around (but not including) Broca and Wernicke areas and the arcuate fasciculus"
"Gerstmann syndrome is caused by lesion to the angular gyrus of the dominant parietal cortex"
"Gerstmann syndrome is characterized by agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia, and left-right disorientation"
"Hemispatial neglect syndrome is caused by lesion to the non-dominant parietal cortex"
"Hemispatial neglect syndrome is characterized by inability to process sensory information (agnosia) of the contra-lateral half of the world"
"Strokes involving the anterior cerebral artery may cause paralysis and sensory loss of the contra-lateral lower limb"
"Strokes involving the middle cerebral artery may cause paralysis and sensory loss of the contra-lateral upper limb and face"
"Strokes involving the middle cerebral artery may cause aphasia if in the dominant hemisphere"
"Strokes involving the middle cerebral artery may cause hemineglect if in the non-dominant hemisphere"
"Strokes involving the lenticulostriate artery may cause paralysis and sensory loss of the contra-lateral entire body"
"Which anterior circulation stroke causes paralysis/sensory loss of the face and upper limb with cortical signs (e.g. aphasia, neglect)? Middle cerebral artery stroke"
"Which anterior circulation stroke causes paralysis/sensory loss of the face and upper limb without cortical signs (e.g. aphasia, neglect)? Lenticulostriate artery stroke"
"The limbic system is a collection of neural structures involved in emotion, long-term memory, olfaction, behavior modulation, and ANS function"
"Structures of the limbic system include the hippocampus, amygdala, fornix, mammillary bodies, and cingulate gyrus"
"Olfactory deficits are often caused by head injuries that fracture the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone"
"In addition to olfactory deficits, cribriform plate injuries may also cause CSF rhinorrhea"
"Which part of the limbic system is responsible for learning and memory? Hippocampus"
"Which part of the limbic system is responsible for attaching an emotional significance to a stimulus? Amygdala"
"Bilateral lesions of the hippocampus result in anterograde amnesia, which is the inability to create new memories"
"Bilateral lesions of the amygdala result in Kluver-Bucy syndrome"
"Kluver-Bucy syndrome is characterized by disinhibited behavior, such as hyperphagia, hypersexuality, and hyperorality"
"Bilateral lesions of the amygdala (and thus Kluver-Bucy syndrome) are associated with HSV-1 encephalitis"
"Wernicke encephalopathy is characterized by a triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia"
"Korsakoff syndrome is a late manifestion of Wernicke encephalopathy characterized by confabulations, irreversible memory loss, and personality changes"
"Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by: - damage bilaterally to the mammillary bodies - periventricular hemorrhagic lesions to the dorsomedial nucleus of the thalamus"
"Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is associated with thiamine (B1) deficiency and excessive alcohol use"
"Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome can be precipitated by giving glucose without B1 to a B1 deficient patient"
"ID Sulcus: Central sulcus"
"ID Gyrus: Precentral gyrus"
"ID Gyrus: Postcentral gyrus"
"ID Sulcus: Lateral fissure/sulcus"
"ID Sulcus: Parieto-occipital sulcus"
"ID Sulcus: Calcarine sulcus"
"ID Gyrus: Lingual gyrus"
"ID Gyrus: Cuneus gyrus"
"ID Sulcus: Cingulate sulcus"
"ID Vessel: Anterior spinal artery"
"ID Vessel: Posterior inferior cerebellar artery"
"ID Vessel: Anterior inferior cerebellar artery"
"ID Vessel: Vertebral artery"
"ID Vessel: Basilar artery"
"ID Vessel: Superior cerebellar artery"
"ID Vessel: Posterior cerebral artery"
"ID Vessel: Posterior communicating artery"
"ID Vessel: Anterior cerebral artery"
"ID Vessel: Anterior communicating artery"
"ID Vessel: Middle cerebral artery"
"ID Vessel: Anterior cerebral artery"
"ID Vessel: Middle cerebral artery"
"ID Cortical Area: Frontal eye field (Brodmann area 8)"
"ID Cortical Area: Premotor cortex (Brodmann area 6)"
"ID Cortical Area: Primary motor cortex (Brodmann area 4)"
"ID Cortical Area: Primary somatosensory cortex (Brodmann area 3, 1, 2)"
"ID Cortical Area: Somatosensory association cortex"
"ID Cortical Area: Primary visual cortex"
"ID Cortical Area: Wernicke's area (Brodmann area 22)"
"ID Cortical Area: Primary auditory cortex (Brodmann area 41 & 42)"
"ID Cortical Area: Broca's area (Brodmann area 44 & 45)"
"ID Cortical Area: Prefrontal cortex"
"ID Red-Curvy Structure: Arcuate fasciculus"
"Meningitis is defined as inflammation of the leptomeninges"
"The meninges are composed of three layers: dura, arachnoid, pia"
"The pia and arachnoid, together, are termed leptomeninges"
"The most common cause of meningitis in neonates is group B streptococci (S. agalactiae) infection"
"In addition to group B streptococci, neonatal meningitis is also commonly caused by E. coli and Listeria monocytogenes infection"
"The most common cause of meningitis in teenagers is Neisseria meningitidis infection"
"The most common cause of meningitis in adults and the elderly is Streptococcus pneumoniae infection"
"What is a common cause of meningitis in an unvaccinated child? H. influenzae type B"
"Common viral causes of meningitis include enteroviruses (especially coxsackievirus) and HSV-2"
"What is a common cause of fungal meningitis in an HIV+ individual? Cryptococcus species"
"Which enterovirus most commonly causes meningitis? Coxsackievirus"
"In addition to S. pneumoniae infection, meningitis in the elderly is also commonly caused by infection with gram negative rods and Listeria monocytogenes"
"Meningitis presents with a classic triad of: - altered level of consciousness - nuchal rigidity - high fever"
"Diagnosis of meningitis is made by lumbar puncture"
"What is the deepest layer crossed when doing a lumbar puncture? Arachnoid mater"
"Does a lumbar puncture normally pierce the pia mater? No"
"What opening pressure (lumbar puncture) is associated with bacterial meningitis? Increased pressure"
"Bacterial meningitis is associated with significantly increased Neutrophils::cell type in the CSF"
"Bacterial meningitis is associated with increased protein in the CSF"
"Bacterial meningitis is associated with decreased glucose in the CSF"
"Which type of meningitis presents with decreased sugar and increased PMNs in the CSF? Bacterial meningitis"
"What opening pressure (lumbar puncture) is associated with fungal/TB meningitis? Increased pressure"
"Fungal/TB meningitis is associated with increased lymphocytes::cell type in the CSF"
"Fungal/TB meningitis is associated with increased protein in the CSF"
"Fungal/TB meningitis is associated with decreased glucose in the CSF"
"Which type of meningitis presents with decreased sugar and increased lymphocytes in the CSF? Fungal/TB meningitis"
"What opening pressure (lumbar puncture) is associated with viral meningitis? Normal or increased pressure"
"Viral meningitis is associated with increased lymphocytes::cell type in the CSF"
"Viral meningitis is associated with normal or increased protein in the CSF"
"Viral meningitis is associated with normal glucose in the CSF"
"Which type of meningitis presents with normal sugar and increased lymphocytes in the CSF? Viral meningitis"
"Complications of meningitis are classically seen with bacterial meningitis and are a result of the massive inflammatory response in the CSF"
"Bacterial meningitis may cause death due to herniation, secondary to cerebral edema"
"Bacterial meningitis may lead to high pressure hydrocephalus, hearing loss, and seizures, secondary to fibrosis"
"Meningitis is treated empirically with ceftriaxone and vancomycin; add ampicillin if Listeria is suspected"
"Cerebrovascular disease is caused by ischemia (85%) or hemorrhage (15%)"
"Cerebrovascular disease due to ischemia is characterized as focal or global ischemia"
"Mild global cerebral ischemia results in transient confusion with prompt recovery"
"Mild global cerebral ischemia may occur with repeat episodes of hypoglycemia (e.g. insulinoma)"
"Severe global cerebral ischemia results in diffuse necrosis; survival leads to a \vegetative state\\"\""
"Moderate global cerebral ischemia typically affects the hippocampus (most vulnerable), neocortex, cerebellum, and watershed areas"
"Cerebral ischemia of the neocortex typically affects layers 3, 5, and 6, causing cortical laminar necrosis"
"Which layer of the cerebellum is most affected by global cerebral ischemia? Purkinje layer"
"Is the neuronal injury due to cerebral ischemia reversible or irreversible? Irreversible"
"Irreversible damage due to cerebral ischemia begins after 5 minutes of hypoxia"
"Ischemic stroke is a regional cerebral ischemia that results in focal neurologic deficits lasting > 24 hours"
"Thrombotic ischemic strokes are due to clot forming directly at the site of infarction, usually over a(n) atherosclerotic plaque"
"Thrombotic ischemic strokes commonly affect the middle cerebral artery"
"Thrombotic ischemic strokes result in a(n) pale infarct at the periphery of the cortex"
"Embolic ischemic strokes are due to an embolus from another part of the body that obstructs a vessel"
"One common cause of an embolic ischemic stroke is atrial fibrillation::heart"
"One common cause of an embolic ischemic stroke is DVT in a patient with a(n) patent foramen ovale"
"Embolic ischemic strokes result in a(n) hemorrhagic (red) infarct at the periphery of the cortex"
"Embolic ischemic strokes commonly affect the middle cerebral artery"
"Lacunar strokes often occur secondary to hyaline arteriolosclerosis, a complication of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and smoking"
"Lacunar strokes most commonly involve the lenticulostriate vessels, resulting in small cystic areas of infarction"
"Hypoxic ischemic strokes are due to hypoperfusion or hypoxemia; common during cardiovascular surgeries"
"Ischemic strokes result in liquefactive necrosis"
"One histological feature seen after an ischemic stroke is the presence of red neurons, which appear between 12 - 24 hours"
"One histological feature seen after an ischemic stroke is the presence of neutrophils which cause liquefactive necrosis, appearing between 1 - 3 days"
"One histological feature seen after an ischemic stroke is the presence of microglia, which appear between 3 - 5 days"
"One histological feature seen after an ischemic stroke is the presence of reactive gliosis and vascular proliferation, which appear between 1 - 2 weeks"
"One histological feature seen after an ischemic stroke is the presence of a(n) glial scar, which appears after 2 weeks"
"Ischemic strokes result in the formation of a fluid-filled cystic space surrounded by gliosis (reactive astrocytes that line cystic space)"
"If a stroke is suspected, noncontrast CT is used to exclude hemorrhage before tPA can be given"
"Ischemic strokes may be visualized on CT after 6 - 24 hours"
"Ischemic strokes may be visualized on diffusion-weighted MRI after 3 - 30 minutes"
"The treatment for ischemic stroke is tPA if within 3 - 4.5 hours of onset and there's no hemorrhage/risk of hemorrhage"
"Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a brief, reversible episode of focal neurologic dysfunction without acute infarction (negative MRI)"
"Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a regional cerebral ischemia that results in focal neurologic deficits lasting < 24 hours (majority resolve in < 15 minutes)"
"Intraparenchymal hemorrhage is characterized by bleeding into the brain parenchyma"
"Intraparenchymal hemorrhage most commonly occurs due to rupture of Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms, secondary to chronic hypertension"
"Intraparenchymal hemorrhage may be seen with amyloid angiopathy, which is characterized by recurrent lobar hemorrhagic strokes in the elderly"
"Less common causes of intraparenchymal hemorrhage include vasculitis and neoplasm"
"Intraparenchymal hemorrhage may occur secondary to reperfusion injury following an ischemic stroke"
"Intraparenchymal hemorrhage typically occurs in the basal ganglia and internal capsule, but can occur in the cerebral hemispheres, brainstem, and cerebellum"
"Which type of intracranial hemorrhage is seen in the image below? Subarachnoid hemorrhage - Bleed on the bottom of the brain"
"Subarachnoid hemorrhage presents with sudden headache and nuchal rigidity"
"Which intracranial hemorrhage presents as the \worst headache of my life\\"? Subarachnoid hemorrhage\""
"Subarachnoid hemorrhage is characterized by a(n) yellow (xanthochromic) spinal tap"
"Subarachnoid hemorrhage is frequently due to rupture of a(n) berry (saccular) aneurysm"
"Less common causes of subarachnoid hemorrhage include arteriovenous (AV) malformations and an anticoagulated state"
"3 - 10 days after a subarachnoid hemorrhage, vasospasm can occur in the areas surrounding the ruptured aneurysm, which may cause an ischemic infarct"
"Subarachnoid hemorrhage is associated with increased risk of developing communicating high pressure and/or obstructive hydrocephalus"
"Which vascular layer do saccular (berry) aneurysms lack? Tunica Media"
"The most common site for a(n) berry (saccular) aneurysm is at the junction of the anterior communicating and anterior cerebral arteries"
"What connective tissue disease is associated with berry aneurysms? Ehlers-Danlos syndrome"
"What renal pathology is associated with berry aneurysms? Autosomal dominant PKD"
"Risk factors for berry aneurysms include advanced age, hypertension, smoking, and race (increased risk in African Americans)"
"Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms are common and associated with chronic hypertension"
"Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms affect small::size vessels"
"Are Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms seen on angiogram? No"
"Saccular aneurysms of the anterior communicating artery may cause compression of the optic chiasm"
"Saccular aneurysms of the posterior communicating artery may cause compression of the CN III"
"Epidural hematoma is a collection of blood between the dura and the skull"
"Epidural hematoma is classically due to a(n) fracture at the pterion of the temporal bone"
"Epidural hematoma is due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery (branch of maxillary artery)"
"Epidural hematoma is characterized by a(n) hyper-dense lens (biconvex)-shaped collection of blood on CT"
"Epidural hematoma is characterized by rapid expansion due to high arterial pressure and can present with a(n) scalp hematoma as well"
"Epidural hematoma often presents with a loss of consciousness followed by a(n) lucid interval for up to 48 hours"
"Epidural hematoma may present on physical exam with CN III palsy"
"Transtentorial herniation is a potentially lethal complication of epidural hematoma"
"Can epidural hematomas cross suture lines? No"
"Subdural hematoma is a collection of blood underneath the dura"
"Subdural hematoma is due to tearing of bridging veins that lie between the dura and arachnoid"
"Acute subdural hematomas arise with trauma and appear hyper-dense on CT"
"Chronic subdural hematomas appear hypo-dense on CT"
"Chronic subdural hematoma is more common in alcoholics and the elderly due to cerebral atrophy, which stretches the bridging veins"
"Which intracranial hemorrhage is seen in shaken babies? Subdural hematoma"
"Which intracranial hemorrhage more commonly causes a midline shift? Subdural hematoma"
"Subdural hematoma is characterized by a(n) crescent-shaped hemorrhage on CT"
"Can subdural hematomas cross suture lines? Yes"
"Herniation is displacement of brain tissue due to mass effect or increased intracranial pressure"
"Tonsillar herniation involves displacement of the cerebellar tonsils into the foramen magnum"
"Tonsillar herniation results in compression of the brain stem, which causes cardiopulmonary arrest"
"Subfalcine (cingulate) herniation involves displacement of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri"
"Subfalcine herniation may result in compression of the anterior cerebral artery, which causes infarction"
"Uncal herniation involves displacement of the medial temporal lobe (uncus) under the tentorium cerebelli"
"Uncal herniation may cause compression of CN III, leading to an ipsilateral dilated pupil with a \down and out\\" gaze\""
"Uncal herniation may cause compression of the posterior cerebral artery, causing infarction of the occipital lobe"
"Uncal herniation typically compresses the cerebral peduncle on the same side of the herniation resulting in a(n) contralateral paresis"
"If uncal herniation is so severe that it is able to reach the opposite cerebral peduncle, it will cause a(n) ipsilateral paresis and/or contralateral CNIII palsy (this phenomenon is known as Kernohan's Notch)"
"Downward transtentorial (central) herniation may result in rupture of the paramedian branches of the basilar artery, which cause Duret hemorrhages"
"Demyelinating disorders are characterized by destruction of myelin or oligodendrocytes"
"Demyelinating disorders generally result in preservation::destruction or preservation of axons"
"Metachromatic leukodystrophy is due to deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A"
"In metachromatic leukodystrophy, sulfatides accumulate in the lysosomes of oligodendrocytes"
"Accumulation of sulfatides in metachromatic leukodystrophy results in destruction and impaired production of the myelin sheath"
"Metachromatic leukodystrophy is characterized by central and peripheral demyelination with subsequent ataxia and dementia"
"Krabbe disease is due to deficiency of the enzyme galactocerebrosidase"
"In Krabbe disease, galactocerebroside and psychosine accumulate in macrophages and destroy the myelin sheath"
"Which leukodystrophy presents with optic atrophy and globoid cells? Krabbe disease"
"Adrenoleukodystrophy is due to a mutation in a(n) peroxisomal membrane transporter, preventing very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) from being tagged with coenzyme A"
"Is adrenoleukodystrophy an X-linked or autosomal defect? X-linked"
"Adrenoleukodystrophy disrupts the peroxisomal metabolism of very-long-chain fatty acids, resulting in excessive buildup in the nervous system, adrenal gland, and testes"
"Adrenoleukodystrophy is a progressive disease that damages the adrenal glands and white matter of the brain"
"What is the most common leukodystrophy? Metachromatic leukodystrophy"
"Multiple sclerosis is a(n) autoimmune destruction of CNS myelin and oligodendrocytes"
"Multiple sclerosis is the most common chronic CNS disease of young adults"
"What demographic is most commonly affected by multiple sclerosis? Females in their 20s and 30s::age, gender"
"Multiple sclerosis is associated with HLA-DR2"
"Multiple sclerosis is more commonly seen in caucasians in regions away from::towards or away from the equator"
"What CNS pathology is characterized by \multiple lesions in time and space\\"? Multiple sclerosis\""
"Multiple sclerosis may cause optic neuritis, resulting in sudden loss of vision and Marcus Gunn pupils"
"Multiple sclerosis may present with vertigo and scanning speech due to involvement of the brainstem (mimics alcohol intoxication)"
"Which symptoms can be caused by multiple sclerosis: hemiparesis or hemisensory symptoms Both :)"
"Multiple sclerosis may present with bowel and bladder dysfunction due to involvement of the ANS"
"Multiple sclerosis most commonly manifests with fatigue, but may also present with (mnemonic = SIIIN) S: Scanning speech I: Intention tremor I: Incontinence I: INO N: Nystagmus"
"What imaging modality is the gold standard for diagnosis of multiple sclerosis? MRI"
"What MRI finding is associated with multiple sclerosis? Periventricular plaques"
"Multiple sclerosis is characterized by increased levels of IgG in the CSF"
"Oligoclonal bands of IgG on high resolution electrophoresis is diagnostic of multiple sclerosis"
"Multiple sclerosis is characterized by increased levels of myelin basic protein in the CSF"
"Multiple sclerosis is characterized by increased levels of lymphocytes in the CSF"
"Multiple sclerosis is characterized grossly by gray-appearing plaques in the white matter"
"Multiple sclerosis symptoms are often worsened upon exposure to heat::temperature"
"Treatment for acute attacks of multiple sclerosis include high-dose steroids"
"Long-term treatment of multiple sclerosis with disease-modifying therapies stop relapses and halt/slows progression of disease (options include interferon β, glatiramer and natalizumab)"
"Symptomatic treatment of neurogenic bladder in MS patients may include catheterization and/or muscarinic antagonists"
"Symptomatic treatment of spasticity in MS patients may include baclofen or other GABAB receptor agonists"
"Symptomatic treatment of pain in MS patients may include TCAs and anticonvulsants"
"Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is due to slowly progressing, persistent infection of the brain by measles virus"
"Does subacute sclerosing panencephalitis affect gray matter or white matter? Both :)"
"How soon after measles infection does subacute sclerosing panencephalitis typically present? Years later"
"Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is due to reactivation of JC virus in previously infected oligodendrocytes"
"Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is characterized by destruction of oligodendrocytes and astrocytes; typically in the parietal and occipital areas"
"Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is seen in immunosuppressed (e.g. AIDS, leukemia) patients due to reactivation of latent JC virus infection"
"Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is rapidly progressive and usually fatal"
"There is increased risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy in patients taking natalizumab and rituximab"
"Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome is also referred to as Central pontine myelinolysis"
"Osmotic demyelination syndrome is characterized by massive axonal demyelination of the pons::brain stem area"
"Rapid correction of hypo-natremia results in Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome"
"Rapid correction of hyper-natremia results in cerebral edema/herniation"
"Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome typically occurs in severely malnourished patients"
"Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome classically presents as \locked in\\" syndrome\""
"\Locked-in\\" syndrome is typically caused by stroke of the basilar artery\""
"\Locked-in\\" syndrome presents with quadriplegia and loss of voluntary facial"
"What movements are still possible in patients with \locked in\\" syndrome? Vertical eye movement"
"Does \locked in\\" syndrome result in loss of consciousness? No (preserved consciousness)\""
"Degeneration of the neurons of the cerebral cortex leads to dementia (e.g. Alzheimer's)"
"Degeneration of the neurons of the brainstem and basal ganglia leads to movement disorders (e.g. Parkinson's, Huntington's)"
"Dementia is defined as decreased cognitive ability, memory, or function with intact consciousness"
"What is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly? Alzheimer disease"
"Alzheimer disease presents with slow::speed-onset memory loss, beginning with short-term and progressing to long-term loss"
"Are focal neurologic deficits seen in early Alzheimer disease? No"
"Over 90% of Alzheimer disease cases are sporadic::sporadic or familial"
"The ε4 allele of apolipoprotein E is associated with increased risk for Alzheimer disease"
"The ε2 allele of apolipoprotein E is associated with decreased risk for Alzheimer disease"
"Familial cases of Alzheimer disease (10%) are characterized by a(n) earlier age of onset (relative to sporadic cases)"
"Patients with Down syndrome have an increased risk for developing Alzheimer disease"
"Down syndrome patients often develop Alzheimer disease by age 40"
"Familial cases of Alzheimer disease are associated with mutations in presenilin-1 and presenilin-2"
"Alzheimer disease is characterized by widespread cortical atrophy"
"Alzheimer disease is characterized by widening of sulci"
"Alzheimer disease is characterized by narrowing of gyri"
"What type of hydrocephalus may be seen with Alzheimer disease? Hydrocephalus ex vacuo"
"Alzheimer disease is characterized histologically by neuritic (senile) plaques in gray matter"
"The neuritic plaques seen in Alzheimer's are composed of Aβ amyloid with entangled neuritic processes"
"Aβ amyloid is derived from amyloid precursor protein, which is encoded on chromosome 21"
"The APP receptor on neurons is normally broken down by alpha::alpha or beta cleavage"
"The APP receptor on neurons is occasionally broken down by beta cleavage, resulting in formation of Aβ amyloid"
"The Aβ amyloid in Alzheimer's patients may deposit around vessels, causing amyloid angiopathy"
"Amyloid angiopathy increases risk for intracranial hemorrhage"
"What feature of Alzheimer disease is represented in the image below? Senile (neuritic) plaque"
"Alzheimer disease is characterized by neurofibrillary tangles, which are intracellular aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau protein"
"The tau protein that aggregates in Alzheimer's normally functions as a(n) microtubule-associated protein"
"The number of neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's correlates with degree of dementia"
"What feature of Alzheimer disease is represented in the image below? Neurofibrillary tangles"
"Alzheimer's disease is characterized by decreased acetylcholine"
"The diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease is confirmed by histology at autopsy (when possible)"
"Vascular dementia is a result of multiple arterial infarcts and/or chronic ischemia (e.g. hypertension, atherosclerosis, vasculitis)"
"Vascular dementia is characterized by a step-wise decline in cognitive ability with late-onset memory impairment"
"What is the 2nd most common cause of dementia in the elderly? Vascular dementia"
"Vascular dementia is characterized by presence of multiple cortical and/or subcortical infarcts on MRI or CT"
"Pick disease is a degenerative disease of the frontal and temporal cortex"
"Frontotemporal dementia (Pick disease) is characterized by round::shape aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau protein known as Pick bodies; may be seen with silver stain"
"Frontotemporal dementia (Pick disease) may have ubiquitinated TDP-43 inclusions seen on histology"
"Frontotemporal dementia is characterized by behavioral and/or language symptoms early in the disease course"
"Frontotemporal dementia may have associated movement disorders"
"Parkinson disease is characterized by degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the basal ganglia"
"Parkinson disease is characterized grossly by depigmentation of the substantia nigra pars compacta"
"Parkinson disease is a common disorder related to aging (risk factor)"
"What contaminant in illicit drugs historically is associated with Parkinson disease? MPTP"
"The clinical features of Parkinson disease may be remembered with the mnemonic \TRAPS\\": T: Tremor (pill-rolling tremor at rest; disappears with movement) R: Rigidity (cogwheel rigidity in the extremities) A: Akinesia/bradykinesia (slowing of voluntary movement; expressionless face) P: Postural instability S: Shuffling gait\""
"Which movement disorder presents as an uncontrolled movement of distal appendages at rest that is alleviated by intentional movement? Resting tremor"
"Parkinson disease is characterized histologically by Lewy bodies, which are round, eosinophilic inclusions composed of α-synuclein"
"What feature of Parkinson disease is represented in the image below? Lewy body"
"Parkinson disease is characterized by increased acetylcholine"
"Parkinson disease is characterized by decreased dopamine"
"Parkinson disease is characterized by decreased serotonin"
"Dementia is a common feature of late::early or late Parkinson disease"
"Early-onset dementia with Parkinsonian features is suggestive of Lewy body dementia"
"Lewy body dementia is characterized initially by dementia with fluctuating cognition / alertness, a(n) REM::which stage? sleep behavior disorder, visual hallucinations, followed by parkinsonian features"
"Lewy body dementia is characterized by intracellular lewy bodies primarily in the cortex::location in the brain"
"Huntington disease is characterized by degeneration of GABAergic neurons in the caudate nucleus and putamen of the basal ganglia"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Huntington disease? Autosomal dominant"
"Huntington disease is caused by expanded trinucleotide repeats of CAG in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4"
"Further expansion of CAG repeats (Huntington disease) occurs during spermatogenesis in males, which leads to anticipation in future generations"
"What movement disorders are associated with Huntington disease? Chorea and Athetosis"
"Which movement disorder presents as a sudden, jerky, purposeless movements? Chorea"
"Which movement disorder presents as a slow, writhing movements, especially in the fingers? Athetosis"
"Symptoms of Huntington disease typically manifest between ages 20 and 50"
"Huntington disease presents with chorea that can progress to depression and dementia; also may have aggression"
"Huntington disease is sometimes initially mistaken for substance abuse"
"Huntington disease is characterized by decreased GABA"
"Huntington disease is characterized by decreased acetylcholine"
"Huntington disease is characterized by increased dopamine"
"Neuronal death in Huntington disease occurs via NMDA-R binding and glutamate excitotoxicity"
"What type of hydrocephalus may be seen with Huntington disease? Hydrocephalus ex vacuo"
"What is a common unnatural cause of death in patients with Huntington disease? Suicide"
"Hydrocephalus is an increase in CSF volume that causes ventricular dilation +/- increased ICP"
"Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of communicating::communicating or non-communicating hydrocephalus"
"In normal pressure hydrocephalus, CSF pressure is episodically elevated"
"Normal pressure hydrocephalus typically affects the elderly::age group"
"Does normal pressure hydrocephalus result in increased subarachnoid space volume? No"
"Expansion of the ventricles in normal pressure hydrocephalus results in distortion of the fibers of the corona radiata"
"Normal pressure hydrocephalus classically presents with a triad of urinary incontinence, gait apraxia, and dementia"
"Normal pressure hydrocephalus often presents with a characteristic magnetic gait"
"The symptoms of normal pressure hydrocephalus improve with lumbar puncture"
"What is the treatment for normal pressure hydrocephalus? Ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunting"
"Which form of hydrocephalus is caused by decreased brain tissue (atrophy)? Hydrocephalus ex vacuo"
"Hydrocephalus ex vacuo is characterized by normal intracranial pressure (ICP)"
"Communicating high pressure hydrocephalus is almost always caused by decreased CSF absorption by arachnoid granulations (no obstruction of CSF flow from the ventriculi to subarachnoid space)"
"Communicating high pressure hydrocephalus is characterized by increased ICP, which may cause papilledema and herniation"
"Non-communicating (obstructive) hydrocephalus is caused by structural blockage of CSF within ventricular circulation"
"Spongiform encephalopathy is a degenerative disease due to abnormal prion proteins"
"Prion protein is normally expressed in CNS neurons in a(n) α-helical conformation, known as PrPc"
"Prion disease arises with conversion to a(n) β-pleated conformation, known as PrPsc"
"The conversion of prions from PrPc (normal) to PrPsc (diseased) can be sporadic, inherited, or transmitted"
"Are pathologic prion proteins degradable? No (resistant to proteases)"
"Can pathologic prions convert normal prions into pathologic prions? Yes"
"Spongiform encephalopathy is characterized histologically by intracellular vacuoles due to damage to neurons and glial cells"
"What is the most common form of spongiform encephalopathy? Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)"
"Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is usually sporadic, but can rarely can arise due to exposure to prion-infected human tissue"
"Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) presents as rapidly::speed progressive dementia with ataxia and myoclonus"
"What movement disorder is associated with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease? Myoclonus (\startle myoclonus\\")\""
"Which movement disorder presents as a sudden, brief, uncontrolled muscle contraction? Myoclonus"
"Myoclonus is a movement disorder common in metabolic abnormalities, such as renal and liver failure"
"Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is characterized by periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG"
"What is the prognosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease? Poor; usually fatal in < 1 year"
"Variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (vCJD) is a special form of disease that is related to exposure to bovine spongiform encephalopathy"
"Familial fatal insomnia is an inherited form a prion disease characterized by severe insomnia and an exaggerated startle response"
"What percent of CNS tumors are from metastasis? 50% (50% primary)"
"Metastatic CNS tumors characteristically present as multiple, well-circumscribed lesions at the gray-white junction"
"Cancer of what organ most commonly metastasizes to the brain? Lung"
"In adults, primary CNS tumors are usually supra-tentorial"
"In children, primary CNS tumors are usually infra-tentorial"
"Do primary malignant CNS tumors typically metastasize? No"
"Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is a(n) malignant::benign or malignant, high-grade tumor of astrocytes"
"What is the most common primary malignant CNS tumor in adults? Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM)"
"Glioblastoma multiforme is a CNS tumor that usually arises in the cerebral hemispheres and characteristically crosses the corpus callosum (\butterfly glioma\\")\""
"Glioblastoma multiforme is characterized histologically by \pseudo-palisading\\" tumor cells"
"Which CNS tumor is characterized by histologically by \pseudopalisading\\"? Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM)\""
"Glioblastoma multiforme is characterized by endothelial::type-not astrocyte cell proliferation"
"The tumor cells of glioblastoma multiforme stain positive for GFAP"
"What is the prognosis of glioblastoma multiforme? Poor; 1-year median survival"
"Meningioma is a(n) benign::benign or malignant tumor of arachnoid cells::specific"
"What is the most common primary benign CNS tumor in adults? Meningioma"
"What gender is more commonly affected by meningioma? Women"
"What receptor is expressed by meningiomas? Progesterone receptors"
"Meningiomas are often asymptomatic but may present with seizures or focal neurologic signs"
"Do meningiomas typically invade the cortex? No (external to brain parenchyma)"
"Meningiomas are characterized histologically by spindle cells concentrically arranged in a(n) whorled pattern"
"Meningiomas are characterized histologically by presence of psammoma bodies"
"Which CNS tumor is characterized histologically by a whorled pattern +/- psammoma bodies? Meningioma"
"Meningiomas most often occur near surfaces of the brain, especially parasagittal regions"
"Imaging of meningioma (CNS tumor) reveals a round mass attached to the dura (via a \tail\\")\""
"Meningiomas are treated with resection and/or radiosurgery"
"Schwannoma is a(n) benign::benign or malignant tumor of Schwann cells"
"Is Schwannoma typically seen in adults or children? Adults"
"Schwannomas classically arise at the cerebellopontine angle"
"Schwannomas most frequently involve CN VIII, but can involve any cranial or spinal nerve"
"The tumor cells of a Schwannoma stain positive for S-100"
"Bilateral vestibular schwannomas are seen in neurofibromatosis 2 (NF-2)"
"Schwannomas are treated with resection and/or stereotactic radiosurgery"
"Oligodendroglioma is a(n) malignant::benign or malignant tumor of oligodendrocytes"
"Imaging of oligodendroglioma typically reveals a(n) calcified tumor in the white matter, usually involving the frontal lobe"
"Oligodendroglioma may present with seizures"
"Oligodendroglioma is a primary CNS tumor characterized histologically by \fried egg\\" cells with a \\"chicken-wire\\" capillary pattern\""
"Pilocytic astrocytoma is a(n) benign::benign or malignant, well-circumscribed tumor of astrocytes"
"What is the most common primary CNS tumor in children? Pilocytic astrocytoma"
"Pilocytic astrocytomas are most often found in the posterior fossa, such as the cerebellum; may be supratentorial"
"Imaging of pilocytic astrocytomas::CNS tumor reveal a(n) cystic lesion with a mural nodule"
"Biopsy of a(n) pilocytic astrocytoma shows Rosenthal fibers, which are eosinophilic, corkscrew fibers"
"The tumor cells of pilocytic astrocytomas stain positive for GFAP"
"What is the prognosis of pilocytic astrocytoma? Good"
"Medulloblastoma is a(n) malignant::benign or malignant tumor derived from granule cells of the cerebellum"
"Medulloblastoma is a form of primitive neuroectodermal tumor (embryonic tissue origin)"
"Is medulloblastoma typically seen in adults or children? Children"
"Medulloblastoma is characterized histologically by small blue::color cells with Homer-Wright rosettes"
"What primary CNS tumor is associated with Homer-Wright rosettes? Medulloblastoma"
"Medulloblastoma can compress the 4th ventricle, causing noncommunicating hydrocephalus"
"Medulloblastomas grow rapidly and spread via CSF"
"Metastasis of medulloblastomas to the spinal cord is termed \drop metastasis\\"\""
"What is the prognosis of medulloblastoma? Poor"
"Ependymoma is a(n) malignant::benign or malignant tumor of ependymal cells"
"Is ependymoma typically seen in adults or children? Children"
"Ependymomas most commonly arise in the 4th ventricle"
"Ependymomas may present with hydrocephalus"
"Ependymomas are CNS tumors characterized histologically by perivascular pseudorosettes"
"Which CNS tumor may have rod-shaped blepharoblasts (basal ciliary bodies) found near the nucleus? Ependymoma"
"What is the prognosis of ependymoma? Poor"
"Craniopharyngioma is a CNS tumor that arises from epithelial remnants of Rathke's pouch (oral ectoderm)"
"Craniopharyngioma is the most common childhood supra-tentorial tumor"
"Craniopharyngioma typically presents as a(n) supra-tentorial mass in a(n) child or young adult::age group"
"Which CNS tumor compresses the optic chiasm, causing bitemporal hemianopsia, in children? Craniopharyngioma"
"Which CNS tumor is characterized by cholesterol crystals found in \motor-oil\\"-like fluid within the tumor? Craniopharyngioma\""
"Craniopharyngiomas commonly calcify, which is visible on imaging and histology"
"Are craniopharyngiomas benign or malignant? Benign"
"Craniopharyngiomas tend to recur after resection"
"The innermost layer of the gut wall is the mucosa"
"The mucosa of the gut wall consists of three layers: a(n) epithelium, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosa"
