"External to the mucosal layer of the gut wall is the submucosa"
"External to the submucosal layer of the gut wall is the muscularis externa"
"The muscularis externa of the gut wall consists of an inner circular and an outer longitudinal muscle layer"
"The myenteric (Auerbach) nerve plexus lies between the circular and longitudinal muscles layers of the gut wall"
"The submucosal (Meissner) nerve plexus lies between the submucosa and inner circular muscle layer of the gut wall"
"The outermost layer of the gut wall is the serosa (when intraperitoneal)"
"The outermost layer of the gut wall is the adventitia (when retroperitoneal)"
"Which gut wall layer contains Meissner's plexus? Submucosa"
"Which gut wall layer contains Auerbach's plexus? Muscularis externa"
"The parasympathetic nervous system is usually excitatory on functions of the GI tract"
"Which nerves carry parasympathetics to the GI tract? Vagus, Pelvic splanchnic::2"
"Reflexes in which both afferent and efferent pathways are contained in the vagus nerve are called vagovagal reflexes"
"The sympathetic nervous system is usually inhibitory on functions of the GI tract"
"Post-ganglionic sympathetic and Pre-ganglionic parasympathetic neurons supplying the GI tract synapse in the myenteric or submucosal plexuses"
"The enteric nervous system can direct all functions of the GI tract, even in the absence of extrinsic innervation (e.g. PNS/SNS)"
"The submucosal (Meissner's) plexus of the gut wall primarily controls secretion and blood flow"
"The myenteric (Auerbach) plexus of the gut wall primarily controls motility"
"Gastrin is secreted from G cells in the antrum of the stomach and the duodenum"
"One function of gastrin is to increase gastric H+ secretion"
"One function of gastrin is to increase growth of gastric mucosa and parietal cells"
"One function of gastrin is to increase gastric motility"
"Gastrin secretion is most stimulated by stomach distention"
"Gastrin secretion is stimulated by high pH of gastric contents"
"Gastrin secretion is stimulated by vagal stimulation via the neuropeptide gastrin-releasing peptide (GRP, bombesin)"
"Is the vagal stimulation of G cells (gastrin secretion) inhibited by atropine? No"
"Which nutrient stimulates gastrin secretion? Protein (amino acids)::glucose, fat, protein"
"Of the amino acids, phenylalanine and tryptophan are the most potent stimuli for gastrin secretion"
"Gastrin secretion is inhibited by low pH of gastric contents"
"Gastrin secretion is inhibited by somatostatin"
"The minimum fragment necessary for biologic activity of gastrin is the C-terminal tetrapeptide"
"How does gastrin secretion change with chronic PPI use? Increased"
"How does gastrin secretion change with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome? Very increased"
"Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is caused by a(n) gastrinoma of the pancreas (non-β cells) or duodenum"
"Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is characterized by acid hypersecretion, causing recurrent ulcers in the duodenum and jejunum"
"Zollinger-Ellison syndrome may present with abdominal pain, due to peptic ulcer disease and distal ulcers"
"Zollinger-Ellison syndrome may present with steatorrhea due to inactivation of pancreatic lipases"
"Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is diagnosed with a positive secretin stimulation test"
"A secretin stimulation test is positive if gastrin levels increase after administration of secretin"
"What endocrine disorder may be associated with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome? MEN 1"
"Cholecystokinin (CCK) is secreted from I cells in the duodenum and the jejunum"
"One function of cholecystokinin is to increase secretion of pancreatic enzymes"
"One function of cholecystokinin is to increase contraction of the gallbladder"
"One function of cholecystokinin is to increase relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi"
"One function of cholecystokinin is to decrease gastric emptying"
"One function of cholecystokinin is to potentiate the effects of secretin on HCO3- secretion"
"Cholecystokinin secretion is stimulated by fatty acids and amino acids"
"Which cholecystokinin receptor is selective for CCK? CCKA"
"Which cholecystokinin receptor is equally sensitive to gastrin and CCK? CCKB"
"The minimum fragment necessary for biologic activity of cholecystokinin (CCK) is the C-terminal heptapeptide"
"Secretin is secreted from S cells in the duodenum"
"One function of secretin is to increase secretion of pancreatic HCO3-"
"One function of secretin is to increase bile secretion"
"One function of secretin is to decrease gastric acid secretion and increase pyloric sphincter contraction"
"Secretin is secreted in response to H+ and fatty acids in the lumen of the duodenum"
"Glucose-insulinotropic peptide (GIP) is secreted from K cells in the duodenum and jejunum"
"Which nutrient stimulates glucose-insulinotropic peptide secretion? All three :)::glucose, fat, protein"
"Glucose-insulinotropic peptide causes increased release of insulin in response to a(n) oral glucose load (endocrine effect)"
"The oral::oral or IV? form of glucose administration leads to greater insulin release due to stimulation of GIP and GLP-1 secretion"
"Glucose-insulinotropic peptide decreases gastric H+ secretion (exocrine effect)"
"Motilin is secreted from the small intestine during fasting::fed or fasting states"
"Motilin is a hormone that initiates migrating motor complexes (MMCs) at 90-minute intervals between meals"
"Motilin receptor agonists, such as erythromycin, are used to stimulate intestinal peristalsis"
"Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) stimulates insulin secretion and inhibits glucagon secretion"
"Somatostatin is secreted from D cells in the GI mucosa"
"Somatostatin secretion is stimulated by low::high or low pH in the GI mucosa"
"Somatostatin secretion is decreased in response to vagal stimulation"
"What effect does somatostatin have on gastric acid secretion? Decreased secretion"
"What effect does somatostatin have on pancreatic/small intestinal fluid secretion? Decreased secretion"
"What effect does somatostatin have on gallbladder contraction? Decreased contraction"
"What effect does somatostatin have on insulin and glucagon secretion? Decreased secretion"
"Ghrelin is secreted by gastric cells and acts to increase appetite"
"Ghrelin is secreted from the stomach during fasting::fed or fasting states"
"Prader-Willi syndrome is characterized by increased levels of ghrelin"
"Ghrelin levels decrease after gastric bypass surgery"
"Leptin is secreted by fat cells and acts to decrease appetite"
"Peptide YY (PYY) is secreted by intestinal L cells and acts to decrease appetite"
"Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) is secreted from parasympathetic neurons in the gallbladder, small intestine, and sphincters"
"Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) causes relaxation of GI smooth muscle and sphincters (including LES)"
"Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) causes increased intestinal H2O and electrolyte secretion"
"Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) secretion is increased in response to distention and vagal stimulation"
"Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) secretion is decreased in response to adrenergic input"
"VIPoma is a non-α, non-β, non-δ islet cell pancreatic tumor that secretes VIP (also known as WDHA syndrome)"
"VIPoma is characterized by a triad of watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria"
"Phasic contractions of GI smooth muscle are periodic contractions followed by relaxation"
"Tonic contractions of GI smooth muscle maintain a constant level of contraction without regular periods of relaxation"
"Slow waves are oscillating membrane potentials inherent to the smooth muscle cells of some parts of the GI tract"
"The frequency of slow waves in the stomach is 3 waves/minute"
"The frequency of slow waves in the duodenum is 12 waves/minute"
"The frequency of slow waves in the ileum is 8 - 9 waves/minute"
"Which portion of the GI tract has the lowest rate of slow waves? Stomach (3 waves/min)"
"Which portion of the GI tract has the highest rate of slow waves? Duodenum (12 waves/min)"
"Slow waves originate in the interstitial cells of Cajal, which serve as the pacemaker for GI smooth muscle"
"Slow waves of the GI tract are produced via cyclic opening of Ca2+ channels (depolarization), followed by opening of K+ channels (repolarization)"
"During swallowing, the soft palate is pulled upward, preventing food from entering the nasopharynx"
"During swallowing, the epiglottis moves to cover the larynx, preventing food from entering the trachea"
"The pharynx and upper third of the esophagus are composed of striated muscle"
"The lower two-thirds of the esophagus are composed of smooth muscle"
"The upper esophageal sphincter prevents air from entering the esophagus"
"The lower esophageal sphincter prevents gastric contents from entering the esophagus"
"What neurotransmitter mediates relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter in response to swallowing? VIP"
"As the lower esophageal sphincter relaxes, the orad stomach also relaxes, a phenomenon known as receptive relaxation"
"The orad region of the stomach is thin-walled and includes the fundus and proximal body"
"The caudad region of the stomach is thick-walled and includes the distal body and antrum"
"Which region of the stomach (orad or caudad) is responsible for the strong contractions that mix food with gastric secretions? Caudad"
"The rate of gastric emptying is decreased primarily by fats and H+ in the duodenum"
"The function of the small intestine is digestion and absorption of nutrients"
"Segmentation contractions serve to mix intestinal contents; \back-and-forth movement\\"\""
"Peristaltic contractions are designed to propel the chyme along the small intestine towards the large intestine"
"Intestinal peristalsis occurs in response to binding of 5-HT (serotonin) to intrinsic primary afferent neurons (IPANs)"
"The gastrocolic reflex refers to an increase in mass movements due to the presence of food in the stomach"
"Saliva is formed by three major glands: parotid, submandibular, and sublingual"
"The acinar cells of salivary glands secrete the initial saliva, which is iso-tonic and in similar composition to plasma"
"The ductal cells modify the initial saliva via absorption of Na+ and Cl-"
"The ductal cells modify the initial saliva via secretion of K+ and HCO3-"
"Saliva is characterized by high K+ and HCO3- concentration relative to plasma"
"Saliva is characterized by low Na+ and Cl- concentration relative to plasma"
"Saliva is hypo-tonic relative to plasma"
"What salivary enzyme begins the initial digestion of carbohydrates? α-amylase"
"What salivary enzyme begins the initial digestion of fats? Lingual lipase"
"What salivary enzyme cleaves kininogen into bradykinin, a potent vasodilator? Kallikrein"
"At the highest flow rates, saliva is most similar to plasma (high Na+ and Cl-, low K+)"
"At the lowest flow rates, saliva is most dissimilar to plasma (high K+, low Na+ and Cl-)"
"The levels of salivary HCO3- increase with increased flow rate"
"What is the effect of parasympathetic innervation on salivary secretion? Increased secretion"
"What is the effect of sympathetic innervation on salivary secretion? Increased secretion"
"Parietal cells are located in the body of the stomach and secrete HCl and intrinsic factor"
"Chief cells are located in the body of the stomach and secrete pepsinogen *bonus: also secretes..."
"Pepsinogen (inactive) is converted into pepsin (active) in the presence of H+"
"In the first step of gastric acid secretion, CO2 and H2O combine to form H2CO3 via the enzyme carbonic anhydrase"
"The H+ from H2CO3 is secreted from the parietal cell via the H+-K+ ATPase pump"
"Cl- in the parietal cell follows H+ into the lumen by diffusing through Cl- channels"
"The HCO3- from H2CO3 is absorbed from the parietal cell into the blood via the Cl--HCO3- exchanger"
"The increased blood pH following gastric acid secretion is referred to as the \alkaline tide\\" (e.g. after meals"
"Histamine is released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa"
"Histamine binds to H2 receptors on parietal cells, causing increased H+ secretion"
"Vagal stimulation increases H+ secretion directly via binding of acetylcholine to M3 receptors on parietal cells"
"Vagal stimulation increases H+ secretion indirectly via binding of GRP to G cells"
"Gastrin increases H+ secretion directly via binding to CCKB receptors on parietal cells"
"Gastrin increases H+ secretion indirectly by causing histamine release from ECL cells"
"Gastrin increases acid secretion primarily through its effects on ECL::parietal or ECL cells"
"What type of signaling mechanism does gastrin use to reach parietal cells? Endocrine (enters systemic circulation)::endocrine or paracrine"
"What type of signaling mechanism does histamine use to reach parietal cells? Paracrine (locally diffuses)::endocrine or paracrine"
"Which second messenger is released upon binding of gastrin to CCKB receptors? IP3/Ca2+"
"Which second messenger is increased upon binding of histamine to H2 receptors? cAMP"
"The cephalic phase of gastric HCl secretion accounts for 30% of total HCl secreted"
"Gastric HCl secretion during the cephalic phase is mediated by vagal stimulation only"
"The gastric phase of gastric HCl secretion accounts for 60% of total HCl secreted"
"Gastric HCl secretion during the gastric phase is mediated by both vagal stimulation and direct gastrin release"
"What effect does alcohol and caffeine have on gastric HCl secretion? Increased secretion"
"Somatostatin decreases gastric acid secretion by decreasing levels of cAMP::second messenger"
"What effect do prostaglandins have on gastric acid secretion? Decreased secretion"
"Prostaglandins decrease gastric acid secretion by decreasing levels of cAMP (second messenger)"
"Pepsinogen is secreted in response to vagal stimulation and local H+"
"What is the only essential secretion of the stomach? Intrinsic factor"
"Mucus is secreted into the GI tract via mucous cells in the stomach, duodenum, salivary glands, and pancreas"
"Mucus is secreted into the GI tract via Brunner glands in the duodenum"
"The mucus that covers the gastric epithelium traps HCO3-, thus neutralizing any HCl that penetrates the mucus barrier"
"Are the concentrations of Na+ and K+ in pancreatic secretions similar or dissimilar to plasma? Similar"
"Pancreatic secretions are iso-tonic relative to plasma, regardless of flow rate"
"At low flow rates, the pancreatic secretions have high Cl- concentration"
"At high flow rates, the pancreatic secretions have high HCO3- concentration"
"The enzymatic component of pancreatic secretion is secreted by acinar cells"
"The aqueous component of pancreatic secretion is secreted by ductal and centroacinar cells"
"The ductal cells modify the initial pancreatic secretion via absorption of Cl-"
"The ductal cells modify the initial pancreatic secretion via secretion of HCO3-"
"What is the effect of parasympathetic innervation on pancreatic secretion? Increased secretion"
"What is the effect of sympathetic innervation on pancreatic secretion? Decreased secretion"
"Release of the aqueous (HCO3-) component of pancreatic secretion is primarily stimulated by secretin"
"Which second messenger is released upon binding of secretin to its receptor? cAMP"
"Release of the enzymatic component of pancreatic secretion is primarily stimulated by cholecystokinin (CCK)"
"Which second messenger is released upon binding of cholecystokinin to CCKA receptors? IP3/Ca2+"
"Bile is composed of bile salts, phospholipids, cholesterol, bilirubin, water, and ions"
"One component of bile is bilirubin, which is the major bile pigment"
"In the liver, bile acids are conjugated to the amino acids glycine or taurine to form bile salts"
"What is the purpose of conjugating bile acids in the liver? Increase water solubility"
"The bile salts and phospholipids in bile are amphipathic molecules, which allows for the emulsification and solubilization of lipids in an aqueous environment"
"Which organ is responsible for synthesis of bile? Liver"
"Which organ is responsible for the storage and concentration of bile? Gallbladder"
"Which hormone provides the major stimulus for bile ejection? Cholecystokinin (CCK)"
"Most of the secreted bile salts are recirculated to the liver via enterohepatic circulation"
"Which portion of the small intestine is responsible for absorption of bile salts? Terminal ileum"
"What is the rate-limiting enzyme for bile acid synthesis? 7α-hydroxylase"
"7α-hydroxylase is regulated via negative feedback by bile salts"
"One function of bile is to aid in the digestion and absorption of lipids"
"One function of bile is excretion of cholesterol"
"One function of bile is anti-microbial activity via membrane disruption"
"What is the only type of carbohydrate that can be absorbed by enterocytes? Monosaccharides"
"Pancreatic and salivary α-amylases hydrolyze 1,4-glycosidic bonds in starch"
"Lactose is a disaccharide that is digested into glucose and galactose by lactase"
"Sucrose is a disaccharide that is digested into glucose and fructose by sucrase"
"Trehalose is a disaccharide that is digested into glucose and glucose by trehalase"
"Is pancreatic α-amylase secreted in an active or inactive form? Active"
"Glucose and galactose are transported from the intestinal lumen into the cells by Na+-dependent cotransport (SGLT1)"
"Which monosaccharide(s) are absorbed from the intestine by Na+-dependent cotransport (SGLT1)? Glucose and galactose"
"Glucose, galactose and fructose are extruded from the intestinal cell into the blood by GLUT-2 (facilitated diffusion)"
"Which monosaccharide(s) are absorbed from the intestine by GLUT-5? Fructose"
"Fructose is extruded from the intestinal cell into the blood by GLUT-2 (facilitated diffusion)"
"Which monosaccharide(s) are extruded from the intestinal cell into the blood by GLUT-2? Glucose, galactose, and fructose"
"The D-xylose absorption test helps distinguish GI mucosal damage from other causes of malabsorption (e.g. lactose intolerance)"
"Decreased excretion of urinary D-xylose is indicative of GI mucosal damage or bacterial overgrowth (D-xylose absorption test)"
"Digestion of protein begins in the stomach with the action of pepsin"
"The first step in intestinal protein digestion involves activation of trypsinogen (inactive) to trypsin (active)"
"Trypsinogen is converted to trypsin via enteropeptidase (enterokinase), a brush-border enzyme on duodenal and jejunal mucosa"
"Are pancreatic proteases secreted in an active or inactive form? Inactive (proenzymes/zymogens)"
"Which pancreatic protease cleaves all pancreatic proenzymes to their active forms? Trypsin"
"Chymotripsinogen (inactive) is activated to chymotrypsin (active) via trypsin"
"Proelastase (inactive) is activated to elastase (active) via trypsin"
"Procarboxypeptidase (inactive) is activated to carboxypeptidase (active) via trypsin"
"Trypsin results in increased::increased or decreased cleavage of trypsinogen to trypsin"
"L-amino acids are transported from the intestinal lumen into the cells by Na+-mediated cotransport"
"Dipeptides and tripeptides are transported from the intestinal lumen into the cells by H+-mediated cotransport"
"Pancreatic lipases are responsible for fat digestion in the small intestine"
"Pancreatic lipase is inactivated by low::high or low duodenal pH"
"The hydrophobic products of lipid digestion are solubilized in micelles by bile acids"
"Micelles bring the products of lipid digestion into contact with the intestinal brush border, where the lipid products diffuse across the luminal membrane"
"Inside intestinal epithelial cells, the products of lipid digestion are re-esterified to reform the ingested lipid"
"Inside the intestinal epithelial cells, re-esterified lipids are packaged with apoproteins into chylomicrons"
"The chylomicrons in intestinal epithelial cells enter lymphatic capillaries known as lacteals"
"The chylomicrons in the lymphatic capillaries enter the bloodstream via the thoracic duct"
"Iron is absorbed in the Fe2+ state in the duodenum of the small intestine"
"Folate is primarily absorbed in the jejunum of the small intestine"
"Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum of the small intestine (requires intrinsic factor)"
"K+ is absorbed in the small intestine via passive diffusion"
"K+ is actively secreted in the large intestine"
"How does increased flow rate (e.g. diarrhea) affect K+ secretion in the colon? Increased secretion"
"What second messenger regulates the Cl- channels in the luminal membrane of the intestine? cAMP"
"In multiple myeloma, neoplastic plasma cells produce IL-6 which stimulates osteoclast activating factor"
"Aphthous ulcers (\canker sores\\") are painful"
"Aphthous ulcers arise in relation to stress and resolve spontaneously, however they often recur"
"Aphthous ulcers are characterized by a(n) grayish::color base surrounded by erythema"
"Behçet syndrome is characterized by a triad of recurrent aphthous ulcers with genital ulcers and uveitis"
"Behçet syndrome occurs due to immune-complex vasculitis involving primarily small vessels"
"Behçet syndrome can be seen after viral infection, but the etiology is unknown"
"Oral herpes (\cold sores\\") is characterized by painful"
"Oral herpes is usually due to HSV-1 infection"
"The HSV-1 virus that causes oral herpes remains dormant in the ganglia of the trigeminal nerve"
"Dormant HSV-1 virus may be reactivated by stress and sunlight, leading to an episode of oral herpes"
"The major risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma of the oral mucosa are alcohol and tobacco"
"What is the most common location for oral squamous cell carcinoma? Floor of the mouth"
"Oral leukoplakia and erythroplakia are precursor lesions to squamous cell carcinoma"
"Oral leukoplakia is a white deposit on the tongue that cannot be easily scraped away"
"Oral candidiasis is a white deposit on the tongue that can be easily scraped away"
"Hairy leukoplakia is a white, rough patch that arises on the lateral tongue"
"Hairy leukoplakia is a squamous cell hyperplasia (not dysplasia) induced by EBV infection"
"Is hairy leukoplakia pre-malignant for oral squamous cell carcinoma? No"
"Oral candidiasis and hairy leukoplakia are usually seen in immunocompromised individuals"
"Oral erythroplakia is a red plaque due to vascularization of leukoplakia"
"Erythroplakia is highly suggestive of squamous cell dysplasia::hyperplasia or dysplasia"
"Which lesion, leukoplakia or erythroplakia, is more suggestive of squamous cell dysplasia? Erythroplakia"
"What virus is associated with bilateral inflammation of the parotid glands? Mumps virus"
"In addition to parotitis, mumps may also present with orchitis, pancreatitis, and aseptic meningitis"
"What enzyme is elevated in mumps patients due to involvement of the pancreatic or salivary glands? α-amylase"
"Orchitis due to mumps infection carries risk of sterility, especially in teenagers"
"Sialadenitis is inflammation of a salivary gland"
"Sialadenitis most commonly occurs due to sialolithiasis, which often leads to Staphylococcus aureus mediated sialadenitis / parotitis"
"Is Warthin tumor typically unilateral or bilateral? Unilateral"
"Salivary gland tumors are most commonly benign::benign or malignant"
"Salivary gland tumors most commonly arise in the parotid gland"
"If a salivary gland tumor involves a non-parotid gland it is more likely to be malignant::benign or malignant"
"Salivary gland tumors typically present as a mobile, painless::painful or painless mass/swelling at the angle of the jaw"
"What is the most common salivary gland tumor? Pleomorphic adenoma"
"Pleomorphic adenoma is a salivary gland tumor composed of chondromyxoid stroma and epithelium"
"Is pleomorphic adenoma a benign or malignant salivary gland tumor? Benign"
"Pleomorphic adenoma is associated with a high rate of recurrence due to incomplete resection or intraoperative rupture"
"Which salivary gland tumor is associated with a high rate of recurrence following resection? Pleomorphic adenoma"
"Warthin tumor is a cystic salivary gland tumor with abundant lymphocytes and germinal centers"
"Is Warthin tumor typically a benign or malignant salivary gland tumor? Benign"
"Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is a malignant salivary gland tumor composed of mucinous and squamous cells"
"What is the most common malignant salivary gland tumor? Mucoepidermoid carcinoma"
"Malignant salivary gland tumors present with signs of facial nerve damage"
"Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) is a congenital defect resulting in a connection between the esophagus and trachea"
"The most common tracheoesophageal anomaly (85%) is proximal esophageal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula"
"Esophageal atresia with distal TEF presents with polyhydramnios in utero"
"Esophageal atresia with distal TEF presents as drooling, choking, and vomiting with the first feeding"
"Esophageal atresia with distal TEF may present with abdominal distention due to air in the stomach (visible on CXR)"
"Esophageal atresia with distal TEF may present with cyanosis, secondary to laryngospasm to avoid aspiration"
"Esophageal atresia with distal TEF is characterized by failure to pass a(n) nasogastric tube into the stomach"
"Which tracheoesophageal anomaly resembles the letter H? Pure TEF (\H-type\\")\""
"Which tracheoesophageal anomaly is associated with a gasless abdomen on CXR? Pure esophageal atresia"
"Esophageal web is a thin protrusion of esophageal mucosa, most often in the upper esophagus"
"Esophageal web presents with dysphagia for poorly chewed food"
"Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by a triad of iron deficiency anemia, esophageal web, and a beefy-red tongue (atrophic glossitis)"
"Zenker diverticulum is an outpouching of pharyngeal mucosa through an acquired defect in the muscular wall (false diverticulum) caused by cricopharyngeal motor dysfunction"
"Is Zenker diverticulum a true or false diverticulum? False (only involves mucosa and submucosa)"
"Zenker diverticulum classically arises at Killian's triangle, between the thyropharyngeal and cricopharyngeal parts of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor"
"Zenker diverticulum often presents with oropharyngeal dysphagia, obstruction, and halitosis (bad breath)"
"What demographic is most commonly affected by Zenker diverticulum? Elderly males"
"Mallory-Weiss syndrome is a linear mucosal laceration at the gastroesophageal (GE) junction"
"The tears in Mallory-Weiss syndrome are caused by a rapid increase in intraabdominal pressure (ex. retching, vomiting)"
"Mallory-Weiss syndrome is usually seen in alcoholics and bulimics"
"Mallory-Weiss syndrome presents with hematemesis that can be painful"
"Is the hematemesis seen with Mallory-Weiss syndrome typically painful or painless? Painful"
"Boerhaave syndrome is a(n) transmural laceration of the distal esophagus"
"Boerhaave syndrome presents as esophageal rupture with pneumomediastinum (air in the mediastinum) and subcutaneous emphysema"
"Boerhaave syndrome is usually due to violent retching"
"Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins in the lower 1/3rd of the esophagus"
"Esophageal varices arise secondary to portal hypertension"
"In portal hypertension, the left gastric vein backs up into the esophageal vein, resulting in varices"
"Esophageal varices may rupture, which presents with painless hematemesis"
"Is the hematemesis seen with esophageal varices typically painful or painless? Painless"
"Esophageal varices are a common cause of death in patients with cirrhosis"
"Achalasia is characterized by disordered esophageal motility due to inability to relax the lower esophageal sphincter"
"Primary achalasia is due to an autoimmune destruction of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus"
"Achalasia may be idiopathic or secondary to a known insult, such as Chagas disease and extraesophageal malignancies"
"Does achalasia present with dysphagia for solids or liquids? Both solids and liquids :)"
"Achalasia is characterized by high LES pressure on esophageal manometry"
"Achalasia is characterized by uncoordinated or absent peristalsis in the esophagus"
"Achalasia is characterized by the \Bird's beak\\" sign on barium swallow\""
"Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is caused by reflux of acid from the stomach due to transiently decreased LES tone"
"What type of hernia increases risk of developing GERD? Sliding hiatal hernia"
"Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) often presents with heartburn, which can mimic cardiac chest pain"
"Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) may present with chronic cough and adult-onset asthma"
"Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) may damage the enamel of teeth"
"Late complications of GERD include: - Barrett esophagus - ulcerations followed by esophageal strictures"
"Esophageal stricture is a narrowing of the esophagus"
"Esophageal strictures are associated with caustic ingestion and GERD"
"Barrett's esophagus is characterized by specialized intestinal metaplasia of the lower esophageal mucosa"
"In Barrett's esophagus, non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium is replaced with non-ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells (metaplasia)"
"Barrett's esophagus is seen in 10% of patients with GERD"
"Which type of esophageal cancer is associated with obesity, GERD and Barrett's esophagus? Adenocarcinoma::SCC or adenocarcinoma"
"Esophageal carcinoma is subclassified as adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma"
"Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus is a malignant proliferation of glands"
"Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus is the most common type of esophageal carcinoma in America::location"
"Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus most commonly arises from pre-existing Barrett esophagus"
"Which part of the esophagus is typically affected by adenocarcinoma? Lower 1/3rd"
"Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus is a malignant proliferation of squamous cells"
"Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus is the most common type of esophageal carcinoma worldwide::location"
"The most common causes of squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus are alcohol and tobacco"
"Which type of esophageal cancer (SCC or adenocarcinoma) is associated with esophageal web (e.g. Plummer-Vinson syndrome)? Squamous cell carcinoma"
"Which type of esophageal cancer (SCC or adenocarcinoma) is associated with achalasia? Both :)"
"Which type of esophageal cancer (SCC or adenocarcinoma) is associated with very hot tea? Squamous cell carcinoma"
"Which type of esophageal cancer (SCC or adenocarcinoma) is associated with esophageal injury (e.g. lye/caustic ingestion)? Squamous cell carcinoma"
"Which part of the esophagus is typically affected by squamous cell carcinoma? Upper 2/3rds"
"What is the prognosis of esophageal carcinoma? Poor (presents late)"
"Symptoms of esophageal carcinoma include progressive dysphagia (solids to liquids), weight loss, pain, and hematemesis"
"Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus may present with hoarseness due to involvement of the recurrent laryngeal nerve"
"Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus may present with cough due to tracheal involvement"
"Esophageal carcinoma in the upper third of the esophagus spreads to cervical lymph nodes"
"Esophageal carcinoma in the middle third of the esophagus spreads to mediastinal, tracheobronchial, or paratracheal lymph nodes"
"Esophageal carcinoma in the lower third of the esophagus spreads to celiac or gastric lymph nodes"
"Barrett esophagus is characterized by extension of the squamocolumnar junction (Z-line) into the esophageal mucosa"
"Eosinophilic esophagitis is characterized by eosinophilic infiltration of the esophagus, often in atopic patients"
"Eosinophilic esophagitis presents with esophageal rings and linear furrows, often seen on endoscopy"
"Eosinophilic esophagitis classically presents with dysphagia and food impaction in response to food allergens"
"Does eosinophilic esophagitis respond to GERD therapy (e.g. PPIs)? No"
"What infectious cause of esophagitis presents as punched-out ulcers? HSV-1"
"What infectious cause of esophagitis presents as linear ulcers? CMV"
"What infectious cause of esophagitis presents as white pseudomembranes? Candida"
"Infectious esophagitis is typically seen in immunocompromised patients"
"What connective tissue disease is associated with esophageal dysmotility? Scleroderma"
"Sclerodermal esophageal dysmotility is characterized by low LES pressure on esophageal manometry"
"The low LES pressure in scleroderma predisposes to acid reflux and dysphagia"
"Gastroschisis is a congenital malformation characterized by extrusion of abdominal contents through the anterior abdominal wall"
"Which congenital abdominal wall defect IS NOT covered by peritoneum? Gastroschisis"
"Omphalocele is a persistent herniation of bowel into umbilical cord"
"Omphalocele is caused by failure of the herniated intestines to return to the body cavity during embryologic development"
"Which congenital abdominal wall defect IS covered by peritoneum? Omphalocele"
"Gastroschisis and omphalocele occur due to failure of lateral fold closure of the anterior abdominal wall"
"Sternal defects occur due to failure of rostral fold closure of the anterior abdominal wall"
"Bladder exstrophy occurs due to failure of caudal fold closure of the anterior abdominal wall"
"Pyloric stenosis is a congenital hypertrophy of the pyloric smooth muscle"
"What is the most common cause of gastric outlet obstruction in infants? Pyloric stenosis (1:600)"
"What demographic is associated with pyloric stenosis? First-born males"
"How soon after birth does pyloric stenosis typically present? ~ 2 - 6 weeks"
"Pyloric stenosis typically presents with nonbilious::bilious or nonbilious, projectile vomiting"
"Pyloric stenosis often presents with a palpable \olive-like\\" mass in the epigastric region of the abdomen\""
"Pyloric stenosis may present with visible peristalsis"
"What drug class is associated with pyloric stenosis? Macrolides (antibiotics)"
"What acid-base disturbance is associated with pyloric stenosis? Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis"
"What is the treatment for pyloric stenosis? Surgical excision (pyloromyotomy)"
"Acute gastritis occurs due to acidic damage to the stomach mucosa"
"Acute gastritis arises due to imbalance between mucosal defenses and acidic environment"
"Mucosal defenses include secretion of mucus, HCO3-, prostaglandins, and normal blood supply"
"Mucosal defenses include normal blood supply, which provides nutrients and picks up leaked acids"
"Acute gastritis may arise with severe burns due to hypovolemia, which causes mucosal ischemia"
"What type of gastric ulcer is caused by severe burns? Curling ulcer"
"Acute gastritis may arise with NSAID use due to decreased PGE2"
"Acute gastritis may arise with increased ICP, which to increases vagal stimulation, which increases H+ production"
"What type of gastric ulcer is caused by increased intracranial pressure? Cushing ulcer"
"Acute gastritis may arise with shock, which presents as multiple stress ulcers secondary to ischemia"
"Acute gastritis is especially common among alcoholics and patients taking daily NSAIDs (e.g. rheumatoid arthritis patients)"
"Gastric erosions::erosions or ulcers involves loss of the mucosal layer only"
"Gastric ulcers::erosions or ulcers may extend into and beyond the submucosa"
"Chronic gastritis occurs due to chronic inflammation of the stomach mucosa"
"Chronic gastritis is associated with atrophy::hypertrophy or atrophy of the gastric mucosa"
"Chronic gastritis is associated with intestinal metaplasia"
"What is the effect of chronic gastritis on gastric HCl secretion? Decreased (achlorhydria or hypochlorhydria)"
"What is the effect of chronic gastritis on gastrin secretion? Increased (hypergastrinemia)"
"Chronic gastritis is divided into two types based on etiology: autoimmune and H. pylori gastritis"
"Chronic autoimmune gastritis is also referred to as type A gastritis"
"Chronic H. pylori gastritis is also referred to as type B gastritis"
"Chronic autoimmune gastritis is due to autoimmune destruction of parietal cells"
"Which areas of the stomach are affected in chronic autoimmune gastritis? body and fundus"
"Chronic autoimmune gastritis is associated with antibodies against parietal cells and/or intrinsic factor"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is chronic autoimmune gastritis? Type IV (T-cell mediated)"
"Chronic autoimmune gastritis is associated with increased risk for pernicious anemia"
"What is the most common (90%) form of chronic gastritis? Chronic H. pylori gastritis"
"Which area of the stomach is initially affected by chronic H. pylori gastritis? Antrum"
"Does H. pylori invade the stomach mucosa? No (sits on top of mucosa)"
"Chronic H. pylori gastritis causes increased risk for peptic ulcer disease"
"Chronic H. pylori gastritis causes increased risk for MALT lymphoma"
"What cytotoxin released by H. pylori breaks down the protective mucus barrier? CagA toxin"
"H. pylori produces urease, which alkalinizes the local environment, enabling bacterial survival"
"H. pylori infection may be diagnosed using the urea breath test"
"Is the intestinal metaplasia seen with H. pylori gastritis reversible? Yes (resolves with treatment of infection)"
"Peptic ulcer disease is a solitary mucosal ulcer involving the proximal duodenum (90%) or distal stomach (10%)"
"Duodenal ulcers are almost always due to H. pylori (~ 90%)"
"Duodenal ulcers rarely may be due to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome"
"Duodenal ulcers present with epigastric pain that improves with meals"
"Duodenal ulcers are diagnosed via endoscopic biopsy, which shows an ulcer with hypertrophy of Brunner glands"
"Duodenal ulcers usually arise in the anterior::anterior or posterior duodenum"
"Duodenal ulcers located in the posterior duodenum may rupture, leading to bleeding from the gastroduodenal artery"
"Gastric ulcers are usually due to H. pylori (~ 70%)"
"Less common causes of gastric ulcers include NSAIDs and bile reflux"
"Gastric ulcers present with epigastric pain that worsens with meals"
"What is the most common location for a gastric ulcer? Lesser curvature of stomach"
"Gastric ulcers on the lesser curvature of the stomach may rupture, leading to bleeding from the left gastric artery"
"Which type of ulcer (gastric or duodenal) is more likely to be malignant? Gastric"
"Benign::Benign or Malignant gastric ulcers are usually small (< 3 cm), sharply demarcated (\punched-out\\")"
"Malignant::Benign or Malignant gastric ulcers are usually large and irregular with heaped up margins"
"Gastric::gastric or duodenal ulcers should be biopsied at the margins to rule out malignancy"
"What is the most common ulcer complication (both gastric and duodenal)? Hemorrhage"
"Which type of duodenal ulcer is more commonly associated with hemorrhage? Posterior::anterior or posterior"
"One possible ulcer complication is obstruction of the pyloric channel or duodenum"
"Which type of duodenal ulcer is more commonly associated with perforation? Anterior::anterior or posterior"
"Perforation of an anterior duodenal ulcer is characterized by free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum)"
"Perforation of an anterior duodenal ulcer may present with referred pain to the shoulder via the phrenic nerve"
"What is the most common classification of gastric carcinoma (e.g. SCC, lymphoma, adenocarcinoma, etc.)? Adenocarcinoma"
"Gastric carcinoma is subclassified into intestinal and diffuse types"
"Which type of gastric carcinoma (intestinal or diffuse) is more common? Intestinal"
"The intestinal type of gastric carcinoma most commonly arises on the lesser curvature of the antrum"
"Which type of gastric carcinoma (intestinal or diffuse) is associated with H. pylori infection? Intestinal"
"Which type of gastric carcinoma (diffuse or intestinal) is associated with chronic gastritis? Intestinal"
"The intestinal type of gastric carcinoma is associated with nitrosamines, which are found in smoked foods (common in Japan)"
"The intestinal type of gastric carcinoma is associated with blood type A"
"The diffuse type of gastric carcinoma is characterized by signet ring cells that infiltrate the gastric wall"
"The diffuse type of gastric carcinoma may cause linitis plastica, which is a grossly thickened and leathery stomach wall"
"Gastric carcinoma typically presents late::timing with weight loss, early satiety, abdominal pain, and anemia"
"Gastric adenocarcinoma rarely may present with acanthosis nigricans, which is hyperpigmented velvety plaques in the axilla and neck"
"Gastric adenocarcinoma rarely may present with the Leser-Trélat sign, which is sudden onset of multiple seborrheic keratoses"
"Gastric carcinoma may spread and involve the left supraclavicular node, also known as Virchow's node"
"Distant metastasis of gastric adenocarcinoma most commonly involves the liver"
"Gastric carcinoma may spread and involve the periumbilical region, also known as a(n) Sister Mary Joseph nodule"
"Which type of gastric carcinoma (diffuse or intestinal) is associated with a Sister Mary Joseph nodule? Intestinal"
"Gastric carcinoma may spread and involve the bilateral ovaries, also known as a(n) Krukenberg tumor"
"Which type of gastric carcinoma (diffuse or intestinal) is associated with Krukenberg tumor? Diffuse"
"Ménétrier disease is characterized by hyperplasia of the gastric mucosa and atrophy of the parietal / chief cells"
"Ménétrier disease is characterized by hypertrophied gastric rugae that resemble brain gyri"
"Ménétrier disease is characterized by excess mucus production with resultant protein loss, leading to edema"
"Ménétrier disease is characterized by parietal cell atrophy with decreased acid production"
"Does ménétrier disease increase risk for gastric cancer? Yes (pre-cancerous lesion)"
"Intestinal atresia presents with abdominal distention and bilious::bilious or nonbilious vomiting"
"How soon after birth does intestinal atresia typically present? ~ 1 - 2 days"
"Duodenal atresia is a congenital failure of the duodenum to canalize"
"Duodenal atresia is associated with Down syndrome"
"Duodenal atresia presents with polyhydramnios in utero"
"Duodenal atresia is characterized by dilation of the stomach and proximal duodenum with a \double bubble\\" sign on X-ray\""
"Jejunal and ileal atresia occur due to disruption of mesenteric vessels during development, which causes ischemic necrosis and segmental resorption"
"Jejunal and ileal atresia are associated with an \apple peel\\" appearance of the bowel\""
"Meckel diverticulum is an outpouching of all three layers of the bowel wall (true diverticulum)"
"Is Meckel diverticulum a true or false diverticulum? True (outpouching of all layers)"
"Meckel diverticulum arises due to persistence of the vitelline (omphalomesenteric) duct"
"What is the most common congenital anomaly of the GI tract? Meckel diverticulum"
"Meckel diverticulum is associated with the \rule of 2s\\"\""
"Meckel diverticulum is two times more likely to occur in males::gender"
"Meckel diverticulum is typically two inches long"
"Meckel diverticulum is typically located in the small bowel, two feet from the ileocecal valve"
"Meckel diverticulum typically presents during the first two years of life"
"Meckel diverticulum may contain ectopic acid-secreting gastric mucosa and/or pancreatic tissue"
"Meckel diverticulum is diagnosed using a(n) 99mTc-pertechnetate study for uptake by heterotopic gastric mucosa"
"Meckel diverticulum is typically asymptomatic but may present with volvulus, intussusception, melena/hematochezia, RLQ pain, or obstruction"
"The vitelline duct connects the yolk sac to the midgut lumen"
"What week does the vitelline duct normally obliterate? Week 7"
"What congenital anomaly is caused by complete failure of the vitelline duct to close? Vitelline fistula"
"What congenital anomaly is caused by only partial closure of the vitelline duct? Meckel diverticulum"
"What congenital anomaly is caused by cystic dilation of the vitelline duct? Vitelline cyst (enterocyst)"
"What congenital anomaly presents with meconium discharge from the umbilicus? Vitelline fistula"
"Volvulus is caused by twisting of a portion of bowel around its mesentery"
"Volvulus can lead to obstruction and infarction of the affected bowel region"
"Volvulus of the sigmoid colon is more commonly seen in the elderly::age group"
"Volvulus of the midgut is more commonly seen in infants and children"
"Volvulus of the cecum is more common in young adults"
"Intussusception is telescoping of a(n) proximal::proximal or distal bowel segment into a(n) distal::proximal or distal segment"
"In children, the most common cause of intussusception is lymphoid hyperplasia (e.g. due to rotavirus or adenovirus)"
"What is the most common pathologic lead point for intussusception in children over 2? Meckel diverticulum"
"What is the most common lead point for intussusception in adults? Intraluminal mass or tumor"
"Where in the GI tract does intussusception most commonly occur? Ileocecal junction"
"Intussusception results in compromised blood supply, which causes intermittent::frequency abdominal pain with \currant jelly\\" stool\""
"Intussusception is characterized by a \bull's-eye (target sign)\\" appearance on ultrasound\""
"Acute mesenteric ischemia may occur due to a thrombotic or embolic occlusion of the superior mesenteric artery"
"Acute mesenteric ischemia may occur due to a thrombosis of the mesenteric vein"
"Acute mesenteric ischemia is associated with transmural infarction and perforation, which may cause septic shock"
"Acute mesenteric ischemia is associated with small bowel necrosis and abdominal pain out of proportion to physical findings"
"Acute mesenteric ischemia may present with \currant jelly\\" stool\""
"Chronic mesenteric ischemia may occur due to severe hypotension or atherosclerosis of the celiac artery, SMA, or IMA"
"Chronic mesenteric ischemia is associated with mucosal::mucosal or transmural infarction"
"Chronic mesenteric ischemia is typically caused by intestinal hypoperfusion as a result of narrowed vasculature"
"Chronic mesenteric ischemia presents with epigastric pain that occurs after::before or after eating"
"What risk factor is associated with Warthin tumors? Smoking"
"Boerhaave syndrome may present with subcutaneous emphysema, which is characterized by crepitus felt in the neck region or chest wall"
"Esophagitis may occur with medications such as bisphosphonates, tetracyclines, NSAIDs, iron, and potassium chloride"
"Loss of which hormones/neurotransmitters are implicated in the pathogenesis of achalasia? NO and VIP::2"
"Sigmoid volvulus is associated with the \coffee bean\\" sign on X-ray\""
"What GI pathology is associated with the rotavirus vaccine? Intussusception"
"Lactose intolerance is caused by decreased function of the lactase enzyme found in brush border enterocytes"
"Lactose intolerance presents with abdominal distention and diarrhea upon consumption of milk products"
"Lactose intolerance is typically characterized by normal-appearing villi"
"Temporary lactase deficiency may be seen after small bowel infection (e.g. viral enteritis)"
"Lactose intolerance is characterized by a(n)decreased stool pH"
"Lactose intolerance may be diagnosed using the lactose hydrogen breath test"
"The lactose hydrogen breath test is positive for lactose malabsorption if the post-lactose breath hydrogen rises > 20 ppm compared with baseline"
"Celiac disease is immune-mediated damage of small bowel villi due to gluten exposure"
"Celiac disease is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8"
"What malabsorption disorder is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8? Celiac disease"
"What is the most pathogenic component of gluten (celiac disease)? Gliadin"
"Once absorbed, gliadin is deamidated by the enzyme tissue transglutaminase (tTG)"
"In Celiac disease, deamidated gliadin is presented by APCs via MHC class II"
"Which immune cell mediates the tissue damage in Celiac disease? Helper T cells"
"Celiac disease in children::age group classically presents as abdominal distention, steatorrhea, and failure to thrive"
"Celiac disease in adults::age group classically presents with chronic steatorrhea and bloating"
"Celiac disease is classically seen in people of northern European descent"
"Celiac disease is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis, which are small, herpes-like vesicles on the skin"
"The dermatitis herpetiformis that arises with celiac disease is due to IgA deposition at the tips of the dermal papillae"
"Celiac disease is classically associated with IgA antibodies against endomysium, tissue transglutaminase (tTG), and/or deamidated gliadin"
"In patients with IgA deficiency and celiac disease, IgG antibodies against endomysium, tTG, or gliadin are useful for diagnosis"
"There is an increased incidence of IgA deficiency in patients with celiac disease"
"Celiac disease is characterized histologically by flattening of villi"
"Celiac disease is characterized histologically by hyperplasia of crypts"
"Celiac disease is characterized histologically by increased intraepithelial lymphocytes"
"Celiac disease primarily affects the distal duodenum or proximal jejunum"
"Which type of sprue (celiac or tropical) primarily affects the proximal small bowel? Celiac sprue"
"Celiac disease is associated with increased risk for small bowel carcinoma and T-cell lymphoma"
"Celiac disease is associated with decreased bone density"
"What is the treatment for celiac disease? Gluten-free diet"
"Is celiac disease associated with normal or decreased urinary excretion of D-xylose (D-xylose test)? Decreased"
"Tropical sprue is characterized by damage to small bowel villi due to an unknown organism, resulting in malabsorption"
"Which malabsorption disorder is more common in tropical regions? Tropical sprue"
"Tropical sprue classically arises after infectious diarrhea"
"Which type of sprue (celiac or tropical) can affect any part of the small bowel? Tropical sprue"
"Tropical sprue presents similarly to celiac disease but responds to antibiotics"
"Tropical sprue may be associated with megaloblastic anemia"
"Is tropical sprue associated with normal or decreased urinary excretion of D-xylose (D-xylose test)? Decreased"
"Whipple disease is characterized by systemic tissue damage with macrophages loaded with Tropheryma whipplei organisms"
"Tropheryma whipplei is an intracellular, gram positive organism"
"The granules in macrophages in Whipple disease stain positive for PAS and are diastase resistant"
"Which malabsorption syndrome is associated with PAS positive, foamy macrophages? Whipple disease"
"Whipple disease classically involves the lamina propria::mucosal layer of the small bowel"
"Whipple disease may present with fat malabsorption and steatorrhea due to compression of lacteals by macrophages"
"What lymph nodes are commonly affected in Whipple disease? Mesenteric nodes"
"The symptoms of Whipple disease may be remembered with the mnemonic \Foamy Whipped cream in a CAN\\": C: cardiac symptoms A: arthralgias N: neurologic symptoms\""
"What demographic is most commonly affected by Whipple disease? Older men"
"Pancreatic insufficiency causes malabsorption of fat, fat-soluble vitamins, and vitamin B12"
"What test is used to indirectly assess pancreatic function? Fecal elastase"
"Pancreatic insufficiency is associated with decreased excretion of fecal elastase"
"Pancreatic insufficiency is associated with decreased duodenal pH"
"Is pancreatic insufficiency associated with normal or decreased urinary excretion of D-xylose (D-xylose test)? Normal"
"What stain is used to screen for fecal fat? Sudan stain"
"A-beta-lipoproteinemia is characterized by a deficiency of apolipoprotein B-48 and B-100"
"Abetalipoproteinemia is a(n) autosomal recessive inherited malabsorption disorder that is caused by a mutation in the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein"
"Abetalipoproteinemia is associated with malabsorption due to defective chylomicron formation, which requires apoB-48"
"Abetalipoproteinemia is associated with absent plasma VLDL and LDL, which require apoB-100"
"Carcinoid tumor is a malignant proliferation of neuroendocrine cells; low-grade malignancy"
"The tumor cells in carcinoid tumors contain secretory granules that stain positive for chromogranin A, synaptophysin, as well as other neuroendocrine markers"
"Carcinoid tumors may arise anywhere in the gut, however, they most commonly arise in the small bowel"
"What is the most common malignancy in the small intestine? Carcinoid tumor (neuroendocrine cells)"
"What neurotransmitter is often secreted by carcinoid tumors? Serotonin"
"The serotonin released from carcinoid tumors in the small bowel is metabolized in the liver by monoamine oxidase (MAO), producing 5-HIAA"
"Carcinoid tumors are characterized by increased excretion of 5-HIAA in the urine"
"Metastasis of carcinoid tumor to the liver allows serotonin to bypass first-pass metabolism and enter systemic circulation"
"The symptoms of carcinoid syndrome may be remembered with the mnemonic \Be FDR\\": Be: bronchospasm F: flushing D: diarrhea R: right-sided heart disease\""
"The symptoms of carcinoid syndrome may be triggered by alcohol or emotional stress, which stimulate serotonin release from the tumor"
"Carcinoid syndrome may cause right-sided valvular heart lesions such as tricuspid regurgitation and pulmonic stenosis"
"Why are left-sided heart valve lesions NOT seen with Carcinoid syndrome? Lung contains MAO, which metabolizes serotonin"
"Does carcinoid syndrome occur with carcinoid tumors that are limited to the GI tract? No"
"What vitamin deficiency may be caused by malignant carcinoid syndrome? Niacin (B3) deficiency"
"Carcinoid syndrome may be treated with surgical resection or with a(n) somatostatin analog"
"Carcinoid syndrome is associated with the \rule of 1/3s\\"\""
"Appendicitis is defined as acute inflammation of the appendix"
"Appendicitis is related to obstruction of the appendix by lymphoid hyperplasia (children)"
"Appendicitis in adults is typically related to obstruction of the appendix by a(n) fecalith"
"Appendicitis presents with diffuse periumbilical pain that eventually localizes to McBurney's point"
"Appendicitis may lead to rupture, resulting in peritonitis with guarding and rebound tenderness on physical exam"
"One sign of appendicitis is the obturator sign, which is pain on passive flexion and internal rotation of the right hip"
"One sensitive sign of appendicitis and psoas abscess is the psoas sign, which is pain on passive extension of the right hip"
"One sign of appendicitis is the Rovsing sign, which is pain over the right iliac fossa with palpation of the left iliac fossa"
"Periappendiceal abscess is a common complication of appendicitis"
"What other pathologies should be on a differential when considering appendicitis? Diverticulitis (elderly) and ectopic pregnancy"
"Inflammatory bowel disease classically presents in young women::gender with recurrent bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain"
"Inflammatory bowel disease is more prevalent in the West, particularly in caucasians and Eastern European Jews"
"Inflammatory bowel disease is subclassified as ulcerative colitis or Crohn disease"
"Which form of IBD involves only mucosal and submucosal ulcers? Ulcerative colitis"
"Which form of IBD involves transmural inflammation with \knife-like\\" fissures? Crohn disease\""
"Ulcerative colitis (IBD) is characterized by continuous colonic lesions that always involve the rectum"
"Ulcerative colitis always involves the rectum and can extend proximally up to the cecum"
"Crohn disease (IBD) is characterized by skip lesions, which can occur anywhere from the mouth to the anus"
"Crohn disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum"
"Which form of inflammatory bowel disease typically spares the rectum? Crohn disease"
"Which form of IBD always causes bloody diarrhea? Ulcerative colitis"
"Which form of IBD may cause bloody or non-bloody diarrhea? Crohn disease"
"Ulcerative colitis is typically characterized by left::left or right lower quadrant pain"
"Crohn disease is typically characterized by right::left or right lower quadrant pain"
"Ulcerative colitis::IBD is characterized histologically by crypt abscesses with neutrophils, ulcers, and bleeding"
"Crohn disease (IBD) is characterized histologically by lymphoid aggregates with noncaseating granulomas"
"Ulcerative colitis::IBD is Th2 mediated"
"Crohn disease (IBD) is Th1 mediated"
"Crohn disease (IBD) appears grossly with cobblestone mucosa"
"Crohn disease (IBD) appears grossly with \creeping\\" fat\""
"Crohn disease appears grossly with strictures (lumen size) and bowel wall thickening"
"Crohn disease (IBD) is associated with the \string\\" sign on imaging"
"Ulcerative colitis::IBD appears grossly with friable mucosal pseudopolyps"
"Ulcerative colitis::IBD is associated with the \lead pipe\\" sign on imaging"
"Complications of both ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease include malabsorption and colorectal cancer"
"Risk for colorectal cancer development from IBD is based on extent of colonic involvement and duration of disease"
"Complications of ulcerative colitis include toxic megacolon, which may perforate, and fulminant colitis"
"Complications associated with Crohn disease (IBD) include gallstones and calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis"
"Which form of IBD is associated with fistula formation? Crohn disease"
"One complication of Crohn disease is a(n) enterovesical fistula, which can cause UTI and pneumaturia"
"Which form of IBD is associated with perianal disease, phlegmon/abscess formation, and strictures? Crohn disease"
"Extraintestinal manifestations of IBD include arthritis, such as ankylosing spondylitis, sacroiliitis, migratory polyarthritis, and peripheral joints"
"Extraintestinal manifestations of IBD include rash, such as erythema nodosum and pyoderma gangrenosum"
"Extraintestinal manifestations of IBD include eye inflammation, such as uveitis and episcleritis"
"Extraintestinal manifestations of IBD include oral ulcerations (aphthous stomatitis)"
"Ulcerative colitis::IBD is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis"
"What biliary tract disease is associated with ulcerative colitis? Primary sclerosing cholangitis"
"Ulcerative colitis::IBD may be associated with positive serum p-ANCA"
"Crohn disease (IBD) may be associated with positive serum anti-Saccharomyces cervisiae antibodies (ASCA)"
"Treatment for acute exacerbation of Crohn disease often involves corticosteroids"
"What 5-aminosalicylic preparations are useful in the management of ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease? Mesalamine and sulfasalazine::2"
"Treatment of IBD (Crohn's, UC) may involve TNF-α inhibitors, such as infliximab and adalimumab"
"Treatment of IBD (Crohn's, UC) may involve immunosuppressors, such as azathioprine and 6-mercaptopurine"
"What treatment is curative for ulcerative colitis? Colectomy"
"Smoking is protective against ulcerative colitis::IBD"
"Smoking increases risk for Crohn disease::IBD"
"What viruses fall under Papilloma viruses: HPV"
"HPV 1-4 causes verruca vulgaris (cutaneous common wart)::what symptom"
"Cutaneous common wart (verruca vulgaris) are caused by what strains of HPV? HPV 1-4"
"Laryngeal papillomatosis and condyloma acuminata are caused by what strains of HPV? HPV 6, HPV 11"
"E6 encoded by HPV promotes proteolysis of p53"
"E7 encoded by HPV promotes proteolysis of Rb"
"Buzz word for HPV cervical cancer: post-coital bleeding"
"HPV encodes E6 and E7 which promotes proteolysis of p53 and Rb"
"Pathological change seen in invasive carcinoma of the cervix: koilocytic change"
"Gardasil HPV vaccine protects against what strains of HPV? 6, 11, 16, 18"
"Gardasil HPV vaccine is what type of vaccine? Quadrivalent::valency Protein subunit::type"
"Squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, vulva, vagina, anus, and penis are associated with what DNA viruses? HPV 16, 18, 31, 33"
"Hirschsprung disease is characterized by defective relaxation and peristalsis of the rectum and distal sigmoid colon"
"Hirschsprung disease is a congenital megacolon associated with Down syndrome"
"Hirschsprung disease occurs due to a congenital failure of ganglion cells to descend into the myenteric and submucosal plexus"
"The ganglion cells that fail to descend in Hirschsprung disease are derived from neural crest"
"Hirschsprung disease is associated with inactivating mutations in the RET gene"
"Hirschsprung disease is characterized by failure to pass meconium within 48 hours and chronic constipation"
"Hirschsprung disease may present with abdominal distention and bilious::bilious or nonbilious vomiting"
"Hirschsprung disease is characterized by explosive expulsion of feces (\squirt sign\\") and an empty rectal vault on digital rectal exam\""
"Hirschsprung disease is characterized by massive dilation of the bowel proximal::proximal or distal to the aganglionic segment, resulting in a \transition zone\\"\""
"Hirschsprung disease is diagnosed by absence of ganglionic cells on rectal suction biopsy"
"Treatment of Hirschsprung disease involves resection of the involved bowel"
"Colonic diverticula are \blind pouches\\" that communicate with the lumen of the gut\""
"Are colonic diverticula typically true or false diverticula? False (only involves mucosa and submucosa)"
"Which gut wall layers are involved in a false diverticulum (pseudodiverticulum)? Mucosa and submucosa"
"Which gut wall layers are involved in a true diverticulum? All three (mucosa, submucosa, muscularis externa)"
"GI tract diverticula classically arise where the vasa recta perforates the muscularis externa (weak point in colonic wall)"
"Diverticulosis is characterized by many false diverticula in the colon"
"What is the most common location for diverticulosis? Sigmoid colon"
"Diverticulosis is related to wall stress (pulsion diverticulosis) (e.g. constipation, straining, low fiber diet) and obesity"
"Diverticulosis is associated with low fiber diets"
"What demographic is commonly associated with diverticulosis? Older adults (risk increases with age)::age group"
"Diverticulosis is usually asymptomatic or associated with vague discomfort"
"Complications of diverticulosis include painless rectal bleeding (hematochezia)"
"Diverticulitis is a complication of diverticulosis due to inflammation of diverticula"
"Diverticulitis classically presents with a triad of LLQ pain, fever, and leukocytosis"
"What GI tract pathology presents with appendicitis-like symptoms in the LLQ? Diverticulitis"
"Diverticulitis may lead to a(n) colovesical fistula, which presents with pneumaturia (e.g. air or stool in the urine)"
"Complications of diverticulitis include abscess, perforation, and obstruction (inflammatory stenosis)"
"What is the general treatment for diverticulitis? Antibiotics"
"Angio-dysplasia is an acquired malformation resulting in tortuous dilation of vessels of the GI tract"
"Angiodysplasia usually arises in the cecum and right::right or left colon due to high wall tension"
"Angiodysplasia classically presents as hematochezia in an older adult"
"Angiodysplasia is confirmed by angiography"
"Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia is a(n) autosomal dominant::inheritance disorder resulting in thin-walled blood vessels, especially in the mouth and GI tract"
"Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia is also known as Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome"
"Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia presents with blanching skin lesions, AV malformations, recurrent epistaxis, skin discoloration, GI bleeding, and hematuria"
"Ischemic colitis is caused by ischemic damage to the colon"
"Ischemic colitis usually occurs at the splenic flexure (griffith's point), which is the watershed area of the SMA and the IMA"
"Ischemic colitis is most commonly due to atherosclerosis of the SMA"
"Ischemic colitis presents with post-prandial abdominal pain followed by hematochezia"
"Ischemic colitis may present with the \thumbprint\\" sign on imaging due to mucosal edema/hemorrhage\""
"Irritable bowel syndrome is recurrent abdominal pain with > 2 of the following: - Pain related to defecation - Change in stool frequency - Change in stool consistency"
"What demographic is most commonly associated with irritable bowel syndrome? Middle-aged women"
"The chronic symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome may be diarrhea-predominant, constipation-predominant, or mixed"
"Is irritable bowel syndrome related to structural abnormalities? No"
"The first line treatment for Irritable bowel syndrome is lifestyle modification and increased dietary fiber"
"Colonic polyps are raised protrusions of colonic mucosa"
"Colonic polyps are grossly characterized as flat, sessile, or pedunculated (on a stalk)"
"Hyperplastic colonic polyps are due to hyperplasia of glands"
"Hyperplastic colonic polyps classically show a \serrated\\" appearance on microscopy\""
"What is the most common type of colonic polyp? Hyperplastic polyp"
"Hyperplastic colonic polyps are usually small::size and located in the rectosigmoid region"
"Hyperplastic colonic polyps are benign with no malignant potential"
"Hamartomatous colonic polyps are growths of normal colonic tissue with distorted architecture"
"Do hamartomatous colonic polyps have significant risk of malignant transformation? No"
"What type of colonic polyp is small (< 5 mm) and resembles normal mucosa? Mucosal polyps (clinically insignificant)"
"What type of colonic polyp is a result of mucosal erosion from inflammatory bowel disease? Inflammatory pseudopolyp::specific"
"What type of colonic polyp may include lesions such as lipomas, leiomyomas, fibromas, and others? Submucosal polyps"
"Adenomatous colonic polyps are due to a neoplastic proliferation of glands"
"Adenomatous colonic polyps are benign with some malignant potential"
"Adenomatous colonic polyps may progress to adenocarcinoma via the adenoma-carcinoma sequence"
"The adenoma-carcinoma sequence begins with APC gene mutations"
"Which adenoma-carcinoma sequence mutation results in increased risk for polyp formation? APC mutation"
"Following APC mutation (adenoma-carcinoma sequence), KRAS mutations lead to polyp formation (adenoma)"
"What type of gene is the APC gene? Tumor suppressor gene"
"Progression of colonic adenoma to carcinoma occurs with mutations in the p53 or loss of heterozygosity in the region that encodes for SMAD 2 / 4"
"Progression of colonic adenoma to carcinoma is associated with overexpression of COX-2"
"What drug class may be used to impede progression of colonic adenoma to carcinoma? NSAIDs (e.g. aspirin)"
"Sessile serrated colonic polyps have a \saw-tooth\\" pattern similar to hyperplastic polyps"
"Serrated colonic polyps are benign with some malignant potential"
"Serrated colonic polyps may develop into CRC via CpG hypermethylation with microsatellite instability and mutations in BRAF"
"Screening for colorectal polyps/carcinoma is performed by colonoscopy and testing for fecal occult blood (stool guaiac test)"
"Can an adenomatous polyp be distinguished from a hyperplastic polyp on gross examination (e.g. colonoscopy)? No (thus remove all polyps)"
"Which type of polyp has greater malignant potential, sessile or pedunculated? Sessile"
"Colonic polyps have a greater risk of progression to carcinoma if they are > 2 cm in size"
"Adenomatous polyps with a(n) tubular histology have less malignant potential than villous histology (tubular or villous)"
"Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is a(n) autosomal dominant::inheritance disorder characterized by 100s to 1000s of adenomatous colonic polyps"
"Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is due to an inherited mutation in the APC gene on chromosome 5q::arm"
"Colorectal cancer arises in patients with familial adenomatous polyposis via the \2-hit hypothesis\\"\""
"Familial adenomatous polyposis is pancolonic and always involves the rectum"
"Familial adenomatous polyposis is treated with prophylactic colectomy, or else 100% of patients progress to CRC"
"Gardner syndrome is a combination of familial adenomatous polyposis with osteomas and fibromatosis"
"Turcot syndrome is a combination of familial adenomatous polyposis with malignant CNS tumors (e.g. medulloblastoma, glioma)"
"Juvenile polyps usually present in childhood as a solitary rectal polyp that prolapses and bleeds"
"Juvenile polyposis syndrome is characterized by numerous hamartomatous polyps WITHOUT hyperpigmentation"
"What demographic is associated with juvenile polyposis syndrome? Children < 5 years old::age group- specific"
"Juvenile polyposis syndrome is characterized by many juvenile polyps in the stomach, colon, and small bowel"
"Juvenile polyposis syndrome is associated with increased risk for colorectal carcinoma"
"Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by numerous harmartomatous polyps WITH hyperpigmentation of the lips, mouth, hands, and genital skin"
"Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is associated with increased risk of breast, GI, and gynecologic cancers"
"Colorectal carcinoma is the third most common cause of cancer-related death"
"The peak incidence of colorectal carcinoma is 60 - 70 years of age"
"FAP and most sporadic colorectal carcinomas arise via the chromosomal instability pathway"
"Lynch syndrome and some sporadic colorectal carcinomas arise via the microsatellite instability pathway"
"Microsatellites are repeating sequences of non-coding::coding/non-coding DNA"
"The microsatellite instability pathway of colorectal cancer is characterized by mutations or methylation of mismatch repair genes"
"Lynch syndrome is due to an inherited defect in DNA mismatch repair enzymes, resulting in microsatellite instability"
"Lynch syndrome was previously known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Lynch syndrome (HNPCC)? Autosomal dominant"
"Lynch syndrome progresses to colorectal cancer in ~ 80% of patients"
"Lynch syndrome is usually right-sided and always involves the proximal::proximal or distal colon"
"Lynch syndrome is associated with increased risk for colorectal, endometrial, ovarian, and skin cancers"
"Screening for colorectal carcinoma in low-risk patients begins at 45 years of age (e.g. colonoscopy, fecal occult blood (stool guaiac test))"
"25% of colorectal cancers arise in patients with a positive family history"
"Patients with a first-degree relative with colon cancer should be screened via colonoscopy starting at age 40 or starting 10 years prior to their relative's presentation"
"Risk factors for colorectal carcinoma include adenomatous and serrated polyps"
"Risk factors for colorectal carcinoma include tobacco use, alcohol, and type 2 diabetes"
"Risk factors for colorectal carcinoma include diets with processed meat and low fiber"
"Which part of the colon does colorectal carcinoma most commonly arise? Rectosigmoid region"
"Left-sided colorectal carcinoma usually grows as a \napkin-ring (infiltrating)\\" lesion\""
"Left-sided colorectal carcinoma presents with decreased stool caliber due to partial obstruction"
"Left-sided colorectal carcinoma presents with colicky pain and hematochezia (stool)"
"Left-sided colorectal carcinoma usually arises as a result of the adenoma-carcinoma sequence"
"Right-sided colorectal carcinoma usually grows as a(n) raised (exophytic) mass"
"Right-sided colorectal carcinoma presents with vague pain, weight loss, and iron deficiency anemia"
"Right-sided colorectal carcinoma usually arises as a result of the microsatellite instability pathway"
"Iron deficiency anemia in males (especially > 50) and postmenopausal females raises suspicion of colorectal carcinoma"
"Colorectal carcinoma rarely presents with Streptococcus bovis (gallolyticus) bacteremia"
"Colorectal carcinoma may be visualized as an \apple core\\" lesion seen on barium enema X-ray\""
"The T of TNM staging for colorectal carcinoma represents the depth of invasion"
"The N of TNM staging for colorectal carcinoma represents regional lymph node involvement"
"The M of TNM staging for colorectal carcinoma represents distant metastasis"
"Colorectal cancer most commonly metastasizes to the liver"
"What tumor marker is useful for assessing treatment response and recurrence of colorectal carcinoma? CEA"
"Adhesions are fibrous bands of scar tissue that commonly form after GI surgery"
"What is the most common cause of small bowel obstruction? Adhesion"
"Ileus is an intestinal hypomotility without obstruction that results in constipation and decreased flatus"
"Ileus is associated with a distended/tympanic abdomen and decreased bowel sounds"
"Treatment of ileus includes bowel rest, electrolyte correction, and cholinergic drugs (stimulate intestinal motility)"
"Meconium ileus is characterized by a meconium plug that obstructs the intestine, preventing stool passage at birth"
"Necrotizing enterocolitis is a GI pathology seen in premature, formula-fed infants with immature immune systems"
"Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is characterized by necrosis of intestinal mucosa with possible perforation, which can lead to: - free air in the bowel wall (pneumatosis intestinalis) - free air in the abdomen (pneumoperitoneum) - portal venous gas on imaging"
"Malrotation is a congenital anomaly of midgut rotation during fetal development"
"Malrotation results in improper positioning of the bowel with improper formation of fibrous, \Ladd's bands\\"\""
"Malrotation can lead to volvulus and duodenal obstruction"
"Which embryological structure develops into the pancreas? Foregut"
"Which embryological pancreatic bud(s) contribute to the main pancreatic duct? Ventral pancreatic buds"
"Which embryological pancreatic bud(s) contribute to the uncinate process? Ventral pancreatic buds"
"Which embryological pancreatic bud(s) contribute to the body, tail, and isthmus of the pancreas? Dorsal pancreatic buds"
"Which embryological pancreatic bud(s) contribute to the accessory pancreatic duct? Dorsal pancreatic buds"
"Which embryological pancreatic bud(s) contribute to the head of the pancreas? Both ventral AND dorsal pancreatic buds :)"
"Annular pancreas is a congenital malformation in which the ventral pancreatic bud forms a ring around the 2nd part of the duodenum"
"Annular pancreas may cause duodenal obstruction and bilious::bilious/non-bilious vomiting"
"Pancreas divisum is a congenital malformation in which the ventral and dorsal parts fail to fuse at 8 weeks"
"Pancreas divisum is mostly asymptomatic, but may cause chronic abdominal pain and/or pancreatitis"
"Which embryological structure develops into the spleen? Mesoderm"
"What is the embryonic gut region of the blood supply to the spleen (e.g. foregut, midgut, hindgut)? Foregut (celiac trunk gives rise to the splenic artery)"
"Acute pancreatitis is due to autodigestion of pancreatic parenchyma by pancreatic enzymes"
"In acute pancreatitis, trypsin is prematurely activated, which leads to activation of other pancreatic enzymes"
"Acute pancreatitis results in liquefactive necrosis of the pancreas"
"Acute pancreatitis results in fat necrosis of the peripancreatic fat"
"Acute pancreatitis is most commonly due to alcohol or gallstones"
"The causes of {{c14::acute pancreatitis may be remembered with the mnemonic \I GET PP SMASHED\\": I: Idiopathic G: Gallstones E: Ethanol T: Trauma (e.g. automobile accident in children - seatbelt injury) P: {{c13::Posterior duodenal ulcer rupture P: {{c15::Pancreas Divisum S: Steroids M: Mumps A: Autoimmune disease S: Scorpion sting H: HYPERcalcemia or {{c10::Hypertriglyceridemia/Hyperchylomicronemia E: {{c11::ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) D: {{c12::Drugs (e.g. sulfa drugs"
"Acute pancreatitis is diagnosed by 2 of 3 criteria: - Acute epigastric pain that radiates to the back - Increased serum amylase or lipase to 3x upper limit of normal - Characteristic imaging findings"
"One criteria for diagnosis of acute pancreatitis is acute epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back"
"One criteria for diagnosis of acute pancreatitis is increased serum amylase or lipase"
"Which pancreatic enzyme is more specific for acute pancreatitis? Lipase::amylase or lipase"
"Acute pancreatitis may present with hypo-calcemia/magnesemia"
"Acute pancreatitis may progress to shock, due to pancreatic hemorrhage and fluid sequestration"
"Acute pancreatitis may be complicated by pancreatic pseudocysts, which are formed by fibrous tissue surrounding liquefactive necrosis and pancreatic enzymes"
"Pancreatic pseudocyst presents as an abdominal mass with persistently elevated serum amylase"
"Pancreatic pseudocysts may rupture, causing hemorrhage and release of enzymes into the abdominal cavity"
"Pancreatic abscess presents with abdominal pain, high fever, and persistently elevated serum amylase"
"Pancreatic abscess is often due to E. coli infection"
"Complications of acute pancreatitis include DIC due to activation of coagulation factors"
"Complications of acute pancreatitis include ARDS due to damage to the alveolar capillary interface"
"Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by fibrosis of pancreatic parenchyma"
"Chronic pancreatitis is most often secondary to recurrent acute pancreatitis"
"What are the major causes of chronic pancreatitis in adults? Alcohol and genetic predisposition (ex. Cystic Fibrosis)"
"What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis in children? Cystic fibrosis"
"Pancreatitis (acute and chronic) may present with epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back"
"Chronic pancreatitis may present with pancreatic insufficiency, which results in malabsorption with steatorrhea and fat-soluble vitamin deficiences"
"Are serum amylase and lipase useful serum markers for chronic pancreatitis? No (may or may not be elevated)"
"Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by atrophy and dystrophic calcification of pancreatic parenchyma on imaging"
"Contrast studies of chronic pancreatitis reveal a \chain of lakes\\" pattern due to dilatation of pancreatic ducts\""
"What endocrine pathology may arise secondary to chronic pancreatitis? Diabetes mellitus"
"Chronic pancreatitis results in increased risk for pancreatic carcinoma"
"What type of cancer (e.g. SCC, adenocarcinoma, etc.) is pancreatic carcinoma? Adenocarcinoma"
"Pancreatic adenocarcinoma is a very aggressive tumor arising from the pancreatic ducts::ducts or acini"
"What age group is most commonly affected by pancreatic adenocarcinoma? Elderly"
"The major risk factors for pancreatic adenocarcinoma are - smoking - chronic pancreatitis (especially > 20 years)"
"Pancreatic adenocarcinoma is more common in Jewish::ethnicity and African American::ethnicity males::gender"
"What endocrine pathology is a risk factor for pancreatic adenocarcinoma? Diabetes mellitus"
"Pancreatic adenocarcinoma often presents with epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back"
"Pancreatic adenocarcinoma often presents with weight loss, secondary to malabsorption and anorexia"
"Pancreatic adenocarcinoma often presents as obstructive jaundice with a(n) painless, palpable gallbladder"
"A painless, palpable gallbladder in pancreatic adenocarcinoma is also known as the Courvoisier sign"
"Pancreatic adenocarcinoma most commonly arises in the head of the pancreas"
"Pancreatic adenocarcinoma in the body or tail may present with secondary diabetes mellitus"
"Pancreatic adenocarcinoma may present with migratory thrombophlebitis, which is redness and tenderness in the extremities"
"Migratory thrombophlebitis in pancreatic adenocarcinoma is also known as the Trousseau syndrome"
"Pancreatic adenocarcinoma is associated with the serum tumor markers CA 19-9 and CEA (less specific)"
"Treatment of pancreatic adenocarcinoma includes the Whipple procedure, chemotherapy, and radiation"
"What surgical procedure involves the en bloc removal of the head/neck of the pancreas, proximal duodenum, and gallbladder? Whipple procedure"
"What is the prognosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma? Very poor (1-year survival < 10%)"
"Biliary atresia is a failure to form or early destruction of the extrahepatic biliary tree"
