"Biliary atresia typically leads to biliary obstruction within the first 2 months of life"
"Biliary atresia presents with jaundice (CB) and progresses to cirrhosis"
"Cholelithiasis (gallstones) are solid, round stones in the gallbladder"
"Cholelithiasis may arise due to increased cholesterol or bilirubin in bile"
"Cholelithiasis may arise due to decreased phospholipids and/or bile acids"
"Cholelithiasis may arise due to stasis of the gallbladder"
"There are two types of gallstones: cholesterol and pigmented"
"Which type of gallstone is the most common, especially in the West? Cholesterol stone (80%)"
"Are cholesterol gallstones typically radiolucent or radiopaque? Radiolucent"
"~ 10 - 20% of cholesterol gallstones are radiopaque due to calcifications"
"Risk factors for cholesterol gallstones may be remembered with the \4 F's\\": 1. Fat 2. Female (estrogen increases activity of HMG-CoA reductase) 3. Fertile (pregnant) 4. Forty\""
"What classes of lipid lowering drugs are associated with cholesterol gallstone formation? Fibrates and bile acid resins::2"
"Cholesterol gallstones are more common in people of Native American descent"
"Which type of gallstone (cholesterol or pigment) is associated with rapid weight loss? Cholesterol gallstone"
"Which form of IBD has increased risk for gallstones (both cholesterol and pigment)? Crohn disease"
"Black::color pigment gallstones are radio-opaque and composed of calcium bilirubinate"
"Brown::color pigment gallstones are radio-lucent and arise with biliary tract infection"
"Biliary tract infections may cause pigment gallstones by deconjugating bilirubin, which increases risk of precipitation"
"Which type of gallstone is associated with extravascular hemolysis? Bilirubin (pigment) stones"
"Ascaris lumbricoides is a common roundworm that infects the biliary tract, increasing the risk for gallstones"
"Clonorchis sinensis is a liver fluke that infects the biliary tract, increasing the risk for gallstones, cholangitis, and cholangiocarcinoma"
"Which type of gallstone is associated with alcoholic cirrhosis? Pigment stones"
"Which type of gallstone is associated with total parenteral nutrition (TPN)? Cholesterol stones"
"The most common gallstone complication is cholecystitis"
"What imaging technique is used to diagnose gallstones? Ultrasound"
"Gallstones may be treated with elective cholecystectomy if symptomatic"
"Biliary colic is a waxing and waning right upper quadrant pain associated with gallstones; may also have nausea and vomiting"
"Biliary colic occurs due to gallbladder contraction against a stone lodged in the cystic duct"
"Cholecystitis is an acute or chronic inflammation of the gallbladder with gallbladder wall thickening"
"Is cholecystitis typically calculous or acalculous? Calculous"
"Calculous cholecystitis results from an impacted stone in the cystic duct, resulting in dilatation with inflammation and bacterial overgrowth"
"What bacteria is a common cause of secondary infection in calculous cholecystitis? E. coli"
"Acalculous cholecystitis is due to gallbladder stasis, hypoperfusion, or infection (no obstruction); seen in critically ill patients"
"What infection is associated with acalculous cholecystitis? CMV"
"Acute cholecystitis presents with RUQ pain that often radiates to the right scapula"
"Cholecystitis may present with elevated serum alkaline phosphatase if the bile duct is involved"
"Cholecystitis is associated with a positive Murphy's sign, which is inspiratory arrest on RUQ palpation due to pain"
"Rokitansky-Aschoff sinus is a herniation of gallbladder mucosa into the muscular wall associated with chronic cholecystitis"
"Chronic cholecystitis presents with vague RUQ pain, especially after eating"
"Cholecystitis is diagnosed with ultrasound or HIDA scan"
"Porcelain gallbladder is a calcified gallbladder that results from chronic cholecystitis"
"Porcelain gallbladder is a shrunken, hard gallbladder due to chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and dystrophic calcification"
"Porcelain gallbladder is treated with prophylactic cholecystectomy due to high rates of gallbladder cancer (mostly adenocarcinoma)"
"Ascending cholangitis is a bacterial infection of the bile ducts"
"Ascending cholangitis is usually due to ascending infection with enteric gram-negative bacteria"
"Ascending cholangitis classically presents with the Charcot triad of jaundice, fever, and RUQ pain"
"In addition to the Charcot triad, Ascending cholangitis may also present with altered mental status and shock (Reynolds pentad)"
"There is an increased incidence of ascending cholangitis with choledocholithiasis (stones in the biliary ducts)"
"Choledocholithiasis is the presence of gallstones is the common bile duct, often leading to elevated ALP, GGT, direct bilirubin, and/or AST/ALT"
"Gallstone ileus typically involves obstruction of the ileocecal valve by a gallstone"
"Gallstone ileus occurs secondary to cholecystitis with fistula formation between the gallbladder and small bowel"
"Cholecystitis can cause fistula formation with the GI tract, resulting in air in the biliary tree (pneumobilia)"
"What type of cancer (e.g. SCC, adenocarcinoma, etc.) is gallbladder carcinoma? Adenocarcinoma"
"The major risk factor for gallbladder carcinoma is gallstones, especially when complicated by porcelain gallbladder"
"Gallbladder carcinoma classically presents as new-onset cholecystitis in an elderly woman::gender"
"What is the prognosis of gallbladder carcinoma? Poor"
"Which disease presents with starry sky appearance on histology, large jaw lesion and swelling assoc. with EBV? Endemic (African) Burkitt Lymphoma"
"LTB4 is an arachidonic acid pathway metabolite that causes neutrophil chemotaxis"
"Prostacyclin analogs (epoprostenol/iloprost) can cause decreased platelet aggregation and are potent vasodilators"
"The effects of thromboxane A2(TXA2) are increased platelet aggreggation and vasoconstriction"
"Leukotrienes are synthesized from arachidonic acid by 5-Lipoxygenase"
"PGI2, PGE1, PGE2, PGF2-alpha, and thromboxane A2 are synthesized from arachidonic acid by COX-1 and COX-2"
"The effect of aspirin on coagulation studies is increased bleeding time, no change in PT and PTT"
"The effect of low dose aspirin <300 mg/day is decreased platelet aggregation"
"The effect of intermediate dose aspirin 300-2400 mg/day is antipyretic and analgesic"
"The effect of high dose aspirin 2400-4000 mg/day is  anti-inflammatory"
"Acute adverse effects of aspirin use are gastric ulceration and tinnitus (CN VIII) (ears ringing)"
"Adverse effects of chronic aspirin use include: - acute renal injury - acute interstitial nephritis - GI bleeding"
"Which three drugs are used to treat acute gout? NSAIDs (do not use salicylates) > colchicine > glucocorticoids"
"What type of vaccine is used for HPV? Subunit"
"Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease that is associated with exposure to hydrocarbon solvents (e.g. dry-cleaning, paints, dyes) and cigarette smoke"
"What is the mode of inheritance of juvenile polyposis syndrome? Autosomal dominant"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome? Autosomal dominant"
"The most common cause of meningitis in children is Streptococcus pneumoniae::not neonates infection"
"Which intracranial hemorrhage is seen in the image below? Subarachnoid hemorrhage"
"Hodgkin lymphoma is associated with EBV infection"
"The embryonic notochord becomes the nucleus pulposus of the intervetebral discs in adults"
"Which form of spina bifida is associated with myelomeningocele? Spina bifida cystica"
"Holoprosencephaly is characterized by a monoventricle and fusion of basal ganglia on MRI"
"The 1st and 2nd branchial arches form the anterior two-thirds of the tongue"
"The 3rd and 4th branchial arches form the posterior one-third of the tongue"
"The motor innervation to most muscles of the tongue is via CN XII"
"The palatoglossus muscle is the only tongue muscle innervated by CN X"
"Which tongue muscle retracts and depresses the tongue? Hyoglossus"
"Which tongue muscle protrudes the tongue? Genioglossus"
"Which tongue muscle draws the sides of the tongue upwards (creates a trough for swallowing)? Styloglossus"
"Which tongue muscle elevates the posterior tongue when swallowing? Palatoglossus"
"Which nervous system cell is typically damaged by Guillain-Barré syndrome? Schwann cells"
"Infarction and/or neoplasm of the blood-brain-barrier destroys endothelial cell tight junctions, causing vasogenic edema"
"The ventral tegmentum and substantia nigra pars compacta are responsible for the synthesis of dopamine"
"Which dopaminergic pathway connects the ventral tegmentum (midbrain) to the prefrontal cortex? Mesocortical pathway"
"Blockage of the mesocortical dopamine pathway results in increased \negative\\" symptoms of schizophrenia\""
"Are 1st-generation anti-psychotic drugs effective at reducing the \negative symptoms\\" associated with schizophrenia? No (limited effect)\""
"Which dopaminergic pathway connects the ventral tegmentum (midbrain) to the limbic system? Mesolimbic pathway"
"Stimulation of the mesolimbic dopamine pathway results in increased \positive\\" symptoms of schizophrenia\""
"Are anti-psychotic drugs effective at reducing the \positive symptoms\\" associated with schizophrenia? Yes\""
"Which dopaminergic pathway is the primary target for the antipsychotic treatment of schizoprenia? Mesolimbic pathway"
"Which dopaminergic pathway connects the substantia nigra pars compacta to the neostriatum? Nigrostriatal pathway"
"Blockage of the nigrostriatal dopamine pathway results in increased extrapyramidal symptoms"
"Decreased activity of which dopaminergic pathway produces extrapyramidal symptoms? Nigrostriatal pathway"
"The nigrostriatal pathway is significantly affected by movement disorders and antipsychotic drugs"
"Which dopaminergic pathway connects the arcuate nucleus (hypothalamus) to the pituitary? Tuberoinfundibular pathway"
"Blockage of the tuberoinfundibular dopamine pathway results in symptoms of prolactin excess"
"Decreased activity of which dopaminergic pathway produces prolactin excess? Tuberoinfundibular pathway"
"Depression::depression or anxiety is characterized by decreased dopamine"
"The basal nucleus of Meynert is responsible for the synthesis of acetylcholine"
"What pathology is characterized by degeneration of the basal nucleus of Meynert? Alzheimer disease"
"GABA is the main inhibitory neurotransmitter of the CNS"
"γ-Aminobutyric acid (GABA) is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate"
"The nucleus accumbens is responsible for synthesis of the neurotransmitter GABA"
"Anxiety::depression or anxiety is characterized by decreased GABA"
"Glycine is the main inhibitory neurotransmitter of the spinal cord"
"Glutamate is the main excitatory neurotransmitter of the CNS"
"Depression::depression or anxiety is characterized by decreased norepinephrine"
"Anxiety::depression or anxiety is characterized by increased norepinephrine"
"Depression is characterized by decreased serotonin"
"Anxiety is characterized by decreased serotonin"
"The reticular activating system (RAS) is formed by the reticular formation, locus coeruleus, and raphe nucleus"
"The reticular activating system mediates consciousness, wakefulness, attentiveness"
"Lesion of the reticular activating system::midbrain results in reduced levels of arousal and wakefulness (i.e. coma)"
"The rostral interstitial nucleus is the portion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus responsible for vertical gaze"
"Strokes involving the lenticulostriate artery typically involve the striatum and internal capsule"
"What visual field defect is associated with Wernicke aphasia secondary to middle cerebral artery stroke? Contralateral homonymous superior quadrantanopia"
"CN I exits the skull through the cribriform foramina"
"CN II exits the skull through the optic canal"
"CNs III, IV, VI, and V1 exit the skull through the superior orbital fissure"
"CN V2 exits the skull through the foramen rotundum"
"CN V3 exits the skull through the foramen ovale"
"The middle meningeal artery enters the skull through the foramen spinosum"
"CN VII and VIII exit the skull through the internal auditory meatus"
"CN IX, X, and XI exit the skull through the jugular foramen"
"The jugular vein exits the skull through the jugular foramen"
"CN XII exits the skull through the hypoglossal canal"
"The brainstem, spinal root of CN XI, and vertebral arteries exit/enter the skull through the foramen magnum"
"ID Bony Opening: Cribriform plate - Exit for CN I"
"ID Bony Opening: Optic canal - Exit for CN II and ophthalamic artery::nerve and vessel"
"ID Bony Opening: Superior orbital fissure - Exit for CN III, IV, VI, and V1::4 nerves, 1 vessel"
"ID Bony Opening: Foramen rotundum - Exit for CN V2 I see (optic) Standing Room Only Sorry"
"ID Bony Opening: Foramen ovale - Exit for CN V3::2"
"ID Bony Opening: Foramen spinosum - Exit for middle meningeal artery::1 a.v.+ bonus nerve"
"ID Bony Opening: Internal auditory meatus - Exit for CN VII, VIII and labyrinthine artery::2 nerves, 1 artery"
"ID Bony Opening: Jugular foramen - Exit for CN IX, X, XI, and jugular vein::3 nerves, 1 vein, 2 sinus, 1 artery"
"ID Bony Opening: Hypoglossal canal - Exit for CN XII"
"ID Bony Opening: Foramen magnum - Exit/entry for brainstem, spinal root of CN XI, and vertebral arteries::1 nerve, 1 vessel"
"Which cranial nerve is responsible for the afferent limb of the corneal reflex? CN V1 (nasociliary br. of ophthalmic)"
"Which cranial nerve (and branch) is responsible for the efferent limb of the corneal reflex? Bilateral CN VII (temporal br. via orbicularis oculi)"
"Which cranial nerve is responsible for the afferent limb of the lacrimation reflex? CN V1"
"Which cranial nerve is responsible for the efferent limb of the lacrimation reflex? CN VII"
"Does loss of the lacrimation reflex prevent formation of emotional tears? No"
"Which two reflexes are mediated by CN V1 and VII (afferent and efferent, respectively)? Lacrimation and corneal"
"Which cranial nerve is responsible for the afferent limb of the jaw jerk reflex? CN V3 (sensory muscle spindle from masseter)"
"Which cranial nerve is responsible for the efferent limb of the jaw jerk reflex? CN V3 (motor from masseter)"
"Which reflex is mediated by CN V3 (afferent and efferent)? Jaw jerk reflex"
"Which reflex is mediated by CN II and III (afferent and efferent, respectively)? Pupillary light reflex"
"Which cranial nerve is responsible for the afferent limb of the gag reflex? CN IX"
"Which cranial nerve is responsible for the efferent limb of the gag reflex? CN X"
"The cavernous sinus is a collection of venous sinuses on either side of the pituitary"
"The cavernous sinus drains blood from the eye and superficial cortex"
"The cavernous sinus drains into the internal jugular vein"
"What nerve(s) are found on the lateral walls of the cavernous sinus? CN III, IV, V1, V2"
"What nerve(s) are found medially within the cavernous sinus? CN VI"
"In addition to CNs, the cavernous sinus also contains portions of the internal carotid artery and hypothalamospinal tract fibers en route to the orbit"
"Cavernous sinus syndrome may present with variable ophthalmoplegia due to compression of various CNs"
"Cavernous sinus syndrome may present with decreased corneal and/or maxillary sensation"
"Cavernous sinus syndrome may present with Horner syndrome due to disruption of sympathetic fibers in the carotid plexus"
"Cavernous sinus syndrome may be seen secondary to pituitary tumor mass effect"
"Cavernous sinus syndrome may arise due to a carotid-cavernous fistula"
"Cavernous sinus syndrome may arise with cavernous sinus thrombosis related to infection"
"Which cranial nerve is most susceptible to injury to the cavernous sinus? CN VI (abducens)"
"All RNA viruses replicate in the cytoplasm::cytoplasm or nucleus except for influenza and retroviruses"
"Papez circuit describes the neural circuit for emotional expression and includes the hippocampus, mammillary bodies, anterior thalamic nuclei, cingulate gyrus, and entorhinal cortex"
"Hypothalamic secretion of GnRH is mediated by the preoptic nucleus and arcuate nucleus"
"Idiopathic intracranial hypertension is also known as pseudotumor cerebri"
"Idiopathic intracranial hypertension is characterized by increased ICP with no apparent cause on imaging (e.g. no hydrocephalus, obstruction of CSF outflow)"
"What demographic is classically affected by Idiopathic intracranial hypertension? Obese females"
"Idiopathic intracranial hypertension is associated with vitamin A excess"
"Idiopathic intracranial hypertension can be associated with use of certain drugs, such as tetracyclines and danazol"
"Idiopathic intracranial hypertension may present with symptoms of daily headache, as well as transient visual changes that are exacerbated by valsalva"
"Is idiopathic intracranial hypertension associated with a change in mental status? No"
"Idiopathic intracranial hypertension may present with bilateral symmetric papilledema on funduscopy"
"Lumbar puncture in patients with idiopathic intracranial hypertension reveals increased opening pressure and provides headache relief"
"Conservative treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension includes weight loss"
"Pharmacologic treatment of Idiopathic intracranial hypertension often involves acetazolamide or topiramate"
"One treatment for refractory idiopathic intracranial hypertension is repeated lumbar puncture"
"One treatment for refractory Idiopathic intracranial hypertension is ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt placement to reroute CSF from the ventricles"
"One treatment for refractory idiopathic intracranial hypertension is optic nerve sheath fenestration surgery"
"What is a worrisome sequelae of idiopathic intracranial hypertension if left untreated? Vision loss"
"Partial (focal) seizures affect a single area of the brain"
"Partial seizures most commonly originate in the medial temporal lobe"
"Focal with impairment of awareness* seizures are often preceded by a(n) seizure aura"
"Focal with no impairment of awareness seizures are characterized by intact::intact or impaired consciousness"
"Focal with impairment of awareness* seizures are characterized by impaired::intact or impaired consciousness"
"Generalized seizures are diffuse and affect the entire brain"
"Which type of generalized seizure is characterized by a blank stare? Absence seizures"
"Absence seizures are characterized by impaired consciousness with no postictal confusion"
"Absence seizures are also known as petit mal seizures"
"Absence seizures are characterized by 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges on EEG"
"Myoclonic seizures are characterized by quick single or repetitive muscle jerks"
"Tonic-clonic seizures are characterized by alternating stiffening and movement"
"Tonic-clonic seizures are also known as grand mal seizures"
"Tonic seizures are characterized by stiffening"
"Atonic seizures are characterized by sudden loss of muscle tone, thus known as \drop\\" seizures\""
"Atonic seizures are commonly mistaken for fainting"
"Epilepsy is a disorder of recurrent seizures (non-febrile)"
"Status epilepticus is seizure activity for > 5 - 30 minutes (continuous or intermittent) without fully regaining consciousness between episodes, resulting in brain injury and possibly death"
"The most common cause of seizure in children is typically genetic"
"The most common cause of seizure in adults is typically tumor"
"The most common cause of seizure in the elderly is typically stroke"
"Cluster headaches are uni-lateral"
"Cluster headaches generally last from 15 minutes to 3 hours"
"Cluster headaches are more common in males::gender"
"Cluster headaches are characterized by repetitive, brief headaches that occur seasonally"
"Cluster headaches are associated with excruciating periorbital::location pain"
"Cluster headaches may be associated with lacrimation and rhinorrhea"
"Cluster headaches may present with Horner syndrome"
"Tension headaches are bi-lateral"
"Tension headaches generally last from 4 to 6 hours"
"Tension headaches are more common in females::gender"
"Do tension headaches cause throbbing or constant pain? Constant/steady pain"
"Are tension headaches associated with photo- and/or phonophobia? No"
"Are tension headaches associated with auras? No"
"Migraines are uni-lateral"
"Migraines generally last from 4 to 72 hours"
"Migraines are more common in females::gender"
"Do migraines cause throbbing or constant pain? Throbbing pain"
"Are migraines associated with photo- and phonophobia? Yes"
"Are migraines associated with auras? Yes (~20%)"
"Migraines typically present as a pulsating pain with nausea, photophobia, or phonophobia"
"Are headaches caused by irritation of dura, cranial nerves, and extracranial structures? Yes"
"Are headaches caused by irritation of the brain parenchyma? No"
"The pathophysiology of migraine headaches is related to release of vasoactive peptides, substance P, and calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP)"
"Sleep is divided into two stages, REM and non-REM"
"What EEG waveform is emitted when awake with eyes open? Beta (highest frequency, lowest amplitude)"
"What sleep EEG waveform has the highest frequency and lowest amplitude? Beta"
"What EEG waveform is emitted when awake with eyes closed? Alpha"
"Stage N1 of non-REM sleep is described as light sleep"
"What EEG waveform is emitted during light sleep (N1)? Theta"
"Stage N2 of non-REM sleep is described as deeper sleep"
"What EEG waveforms are emitted during deeper sleep (N2)? Sleep spindles and K complexes::2"
"Which stage of sleep does bruxism (teeth grinding) occur? Stage N2"
"Stage N3 of non-REM sleep is described as the deepest non-REM sleep (\slow-wave\\" sleep)\""
"What EEG waveform is emitted during deep \slow wave\\" sleep (N3)? Delta\""
"What sleep EEG waveform has the lowest frequency and highest amplitude? Delta"
"Which stage of sleep do sleepwalking and night terrors occur? Stage N3"
"Which stage of sleep does bedwetting occur? Stage N3"
"Which stage of sleep do young adults spend the most time in? Stage N2 (45%)"
"Which stage of sleep do young adults spend the least time in? Stage N1 (5%)"
"Which stage of sleep is associated with loss of motor tone? REM sleep"
"REM sleep is characterized by increased brain O2 use and variable pulse and blood pressure"
"REM sleep may play a role in memory processing"
"What neurotransmitter is increased during REM sleep? Acetylcholine (thus increased vagal tone)"
"Which stage of sleep do dreams and nightmares occur? REM sleep"
"Which stage of sleep do penile and clitoral tumescence occur? REM sleep"
"Extraocular movements during REM sleep are due to activity of the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF)"
"On average, REM sleep occurs every 90 minutes, with increasing duration through the night"
"Depression is associated with increased total REM sleep"
"Depression is associated with decreased REM latency"
"Sleep in the elderly is associated with decreased REM sleep"
"Sleep in the elderly is associated with increased REM latency"
"Both the elderly and depressed experience decreased slow wave sleep (stage N3)"
"Both the elderly and depressed experience increased early awakenings (terminal insomnia)"
"What demographic is associated with decreased REM sleep and increased REM latency? Elderly patients"
"What demographic is associated with increased REM sleep and decreased REM latency? Patients with depression"
"What is the effect of benzodiazepines and barbiturates on REM and slow-wave sleep (N3)? Decreased REM and slow-wave sleep"
"What is the effect of alcohol on REM and slow-wave sleep (N3)? Decreased REM and slow-wave sleep"
"What is the effect of norepinephrine on REM sleep? Decreased REM sleep"
"Pharmacologic treatment of night enuresis may include desmopressin (preferred) or imipramine"
"What is the first-line treatment for bedwetting in children? Motivational therapy (e.g. star chart)"
"Benzodiazepines are useful for treating night terrors and sleepwalking by decreasing N3 and REM sleep"
"Primitive reflexes normally disappear within the 1st year of life"
"Primitive reflexes are inhibited by a mature/developing frontal lobe"
"Primitive reflexes may re-emerge in adults following frontal lobe lesions due to loss of inhibition"
"What primitive reflex is described as a \hang on for life\\" reflex? Moro reflex\""
"What primitive reflex is characterized by nipple seeking (movement of head toward one side if cheek or mouth is stroked)? Rooting reflex"
"What primitive reflex is characterized by sucking when the roof of the mouth is touched? Sucking reflex"
"What primitive reflex is characterized by curling of fingers when the palm is stroked? Palmar reflex"
"What primitive reflex is characterized by large toe dorsiflexion and fanning of other toes with plantar stimulation? Plantar reflex"
"Do the toes of an infant dorsiflex or plantar flex in response to plantar stimulation? Dorsiflex (upward)"
"Do the toes of a healthy adult dorsiflex or plantar flex in response to plantar stimulation? Plantar flex (downward)"
"Which primitive reflex is characterized by lateral flexion of the lower body toward the stimulated side upon stroking along one side of the spine while newborn is facedown? Galant reflex"
"What dermatome is found at the posterior half of the skull? C2"
"What dermatome is found at the high turtleneck shirt level? C3"
"What dermatome is found at the low-collar shirt level? C4"
"What dermatome includes the thumbs? C6"
"What dermatome is found at the nipple? T4"
"What dermatome is found at the xiphoid process? T7"
"What dermatome is found at the umbilicus? T10"
"What dermatome is found at the inguinal ligament? L1"
"What dermatome includes the kneecaps? L4"
"What dermatomes are responsible for erections and sensation of the penile/anal zones? S2, S3, S4"
"Which dermatome is important for early appendicitis pain referral? T10 (Umbilicus)"
"Inflammation of the diaphragmatic pleura, gallbladder, pericardium, and mediastinal pleura refer pain to the right shoulder via the phrenic nerve (C3-C5)"
"Which movement disorder presents as subjective restlessness and an intense urge to move? Akathisia"
"Which movement disorder presents as \flapping\\" motion upon extension of the wrists? Asterixis\""
"Asterixis is associated with hepatic encephalopathy, Wilson disease, and other metabolic derangements"
"Which movement disorder presents as sustained, involuntary muscle contractions? Dystonia"
"Blepharospasm is a form of dystonia that involves involuntary contraction of the eyelids"
"Torticollis (cervical dystonia) is a form of dystonia that involves involuntary contracture of the neck"
"Which movement disorder presents as a high-frequency tremor with sustained posture (e.g. outstetched arms)? Essential tremor"
"Essential tremor is worsened::relieved or worsened with movement or when anxious"
"Which type of tremor is often familial? Essential tremor"
"Patients with essential tremor often self-medicate with alcohol, which decreases tremor amplitude"
"What is first-line treatment for essential tremor? Non-selective β-blockers (e.g. propranolol)"
"In addition to β-blockers, essential tremor may also be treated with primidone (a barbiturate)"
"Which type of free nerve ending (C or Aδ) is slow and unmyelinated? C"
"Which type of free nerve ending (C or Aδ) is fast and myelinated? Aδ"
"Which type of sensory receptor senses pain and temperature? Free nerve endings (e.g. C, Aδ)"
"Which type of sensory receptor is located on all skin, epidermis, and some viscera? Free nerve endings"
"Meissner corpuscles are large, myelinated::myelination fibers"
"Meissner corpuscles adapt quickly"
"Which type of sensory receptor is found on hairless (glabrous) skin? Meissner corpuscles"
"Which type of sensory receptor senses dynamic, light touch, and position sense? Meissner corpuscles"
"Pacinian corpuscles are large, myelinated::myelination fibers"
"Pacinian corpuscles adapt quickly"
"Which type of sensory receptor is found on deep skin layers, ligaments, and joints? Pacinian corpuscles"
"Which type of sensory receptor senses vibration and pressure? Pacinian corpuscles"
"Which type of sensory receptor is \onion shaped\\"? Pacinian corpuscles\""
"Merkel discs are large, myelinated::myelination fibers"
"Merkel discs adapt slowly"
"Which type of sensory receptor is found on finger tips and superficial skin? Merkel discs"
"Which type of sensory receptor senses pressure, deep static touch, and position sense? Merkel discs"
"Which type of sensory receptor is characterized as a dendritic ending with a capsule? Ruffini corpuscle"
"Ruffini corpuscles adapt slowly"
"Which type of sensory receptor is found on finger tips and joints? Ruffini corpuscles"
"Which type of sensory receptor senses pressure, slippage of objects along skin, and joint angle change? Ruffini corpuscles"
"Which types of sensory receptor adapt slowly? Ruffini corpuscles and Merkel discs"
"Which types of sensory receptor adapt quickly? Pacinian corpuscles and Meissner corpuscles"
"Which type of sensory receptor (slowly or quickly adapting) sends a continous signal? Slowly adapting"
"Which type of sensory receptor (slowly or quickly adapting) sends a signal at the beginning and end of a stimulus? Quickly adapting"
"The epineurium of a peripheral nerve is made of dense connective tissue that surrounds the entire nerve"
"The perineurium of a peripheral nerve surrounds a fascicle of nerve fibers"
"The endoneurium of a peripheral nerve invests single nerve fiber layers"
"Which peripheral nerve layer must be rejoined in microsurgery for limb attachment? Epineurium"
"Which peripheral nerve layer serves as the blood-nerve permeability barrier? Perineurium"
"Which peripheral nerve layer contains inflammatory infiltrate in Guillain-Barré syndrome? Endoneurium"
"Changes associated with chromatolysis reflect increased protein synthesis in effort to repair the damaged axon"
"Chromatolysis is characterized by displacement of the nucleus to the periphery"
"Chromatolysis is characterized by dispersion of Nissl substance throughout the cytoplasm"
"Chromatolysis is concurrent with Wallerian degeneration"
"What is the embryonic origin of dura mater? Mesoderm"
"What is the embryonic origin of arachnoid mater? Neural crest"
"What is the embryonic origin of pia mater? Neural crest"
"Which space in the meninges contains CSF? Subarachnoid space"
"Which space in the meninges is a potential space between the dura mater and skull, containing fat and blood vessels? Epidural space"
"Cerebral perfusion is primarily driven by changes in PCO2"
"PO2 increases cerebral perfusion pressure only when < 50 mmHg"
"Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is equal to the difference between MAP and ICP"
"Cerebral perfusion pressure is decreased with decreased MAP"
"Cerebral perfusion pressure is decreased with increased ICP"
"Therapeutic hyper-ventilation may be used to treat acute cerebral edema unresponsive to other interventions"
"Venous sinus thrombosis presents with signs/symptoms of increased ICP (e.g. headache, seizures, focal neurologic deficits)"
"Dural venous sinus thrombosis is associated with hypercoagulable states"
"Vertebral disc herniation is characterized by herniation of the nucleus pulposus through the annulus fibrosus"
"Vertebral disc herniation usually occurs posterolaterally::direction at the level of L4-L5 or L5-S1"
"Vertebral disc herniation typically affects the nerve below the level of herniation"
"Compression of the S1 nerve (e.g. vertebral disc herniation), results in an absent ankle reflex"
"MPTP, a contaminant in illicit drugs, is metabolized to MPP+, which causes Parkinsonian symptoms"
"Which area of the brain is particularly sensitive to damage in Alzheimer disease? Hippocampus"
"Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is associated with increased 14-3-3 protein in CSF"
"Multiple sclerosis is associated with a sensation of a(n) electric shock running down the spine upon neck flexion (Lhermitte phenomenon)"
"Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculopathy is the most common subtype of Guillain-Barré syndrome"
"Guillain-Barré syndrome is a(n) autoimmune condition that destroys Schwann cells"
"Guillain-Barré syndrome results in symmetric ascending::ascending or descending muscle weakness/paralysis"
"Guillain-Barré syndrome is associated with decreased DTRs beginning in the lower extremities"
"Cranial nerve involvement in Guillain-Barré syndrome commonly results in facial paralysis (50% of cases)"
"Guillain-Barré syndrome may be associated with cardiopulmonary irregularities and fluctuations in blood pressure (autonomic dysfunction)"
"Is Guillain-Barré syndrome typically fatal? No (almost all patients survive)"
"Guillain-Barré syndrome is associated with increased CSF protein and normal cell count, which may cause papilledema"
"The bugs that are associated with Guillain-Barré Syndrome are ICE MyCZ: Influenzavirus CMV EBV Mycoplasma Pneumoniae Campylobacter Zika"
"Guillain-Barré syndrome can arise due to the immunologic phenomenon known as molecular mimicry"
"In addition to post-viral/bacterial infection, Guillain-Barré syndrome also may arise due to vaccination or stress"
"Respiratory support is critical until recovery for patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome"
"In addition to respiratory support, Guillain-Barré syndrome may be treated with plasmapheresis and IV immunoglobulins"
"Are steroids useful in the management of Guillain-Barré syndrome? No"
"Acute disseminated (postinfectious) encephalomyelitis is a multifocal inflammation and demyelination of the CNS after infection or vaccination"
"Acute disseminated (postinfectious) encephalomyelitis presents with rapidly progressive multifocal neurologic symptoms and altered mental status"
"Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is also known as hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy (HMSN)"
"What is typically the mode of inheritance of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease? Autosomal dominant"
"What structural foot abnormalities are associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease? Pes cavus and hammer toes"
"Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease may present with lower extremity weakness (e.g. foot drop) and sensory deficits"
"Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a group of nerve disorders caused by defective production of proteins involved in the structure and function of peripheral nerves or myelin sheath"
"Sturge-Weber syndrome is a developmental anomaly of neural crest derivatives due to somatic mosaicism"
"Is Sturge-Weber syndrome inherited or sporadic? Sporadic (somatic mosaicism)"
"Sturge-Weber syndrome is caused by an activating mutation in one copy of the GNAQ gene"
"Sturge-Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder associated with a(n) port-wine stain of the face (nevus flammeus)"
"Sturge-Weber syndrome affects small, capillary-sized blood vessels"
"The port wine stain in Sturge-Weber syndrome classically arises in a CN V1/V2 distribution"
"Sturge-Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder associated with ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas, which may cause seizures or epilepsy"
"Sturge-Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder associated with episcleral hemangiomas, which may cause increased IOP and early-onset glaucoma"
"The characteristics of Sturge-Weber syndrome may be remembered with the mnemonic \STURGE\\": S: Sporadic"
"Sturge-Weber syndrome is also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis"
"Which neurocutaneous disorder is associated with somatic mosaicism? Sturge-Weber syndrome"
"Is tuberous sclerosis inherited or sporadic? Inherited"
"What is the mode of inheritance of tuberous sclerosis? Autosomal dominant"
"Tuberous sclerosis is associated with mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 genes"
"The TSC1 gene encodes for hamartin and is located on chromosome 9 (mutated in tuberous sclerosis)"
"The TSC2 gene encodes for tuberin and is located on chromosome 16 (mutated in tuberous sclerosis)"
"What genetic phenomenon is associated with tuberous sclerosis? Variable expressivity"
"The characteristics of tuberous sclerosis may be remembered with the mnemonic \HAMARTOMAS\\": H: Hamartomas in CNS and skin A: Angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) M: Mitral regurgitation::Cardiac A: Ash-leaf spots (hypopigmented macule) R: cardiac Rhabdomyoma T: Tuberous sclerosis O: autosomal dOminant M: Mental retardation (intellectual disability) A: renal Angiomyolipoma S: Seizures"
"What feature of tuberous sclerosis is seen in the image below? Angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum)"
"What feature of tuberous sclerosis is seen in the image below? Ash-leaf spots (hypopigmented macule)"
"What feature of tuberous sclerosis is seen in the image below? Shagreen patches (patches of localized leathery thickenings)"
"Tuberous sclerosis is a neurocutaneous disorder associated with ungual fibromas, which are flesh-colored lumps emerging from nail folds"
"What astrocyte-derived CNS tumor is associated with tuberous sclerosis? Subependymal giant cell astrocytomas"
"Neurofibromatosis type I is associated with mutations in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 17"
"The NF1 tumor suppressor gene normally codes for neurofibromin, a negative regulator of Reticular Activating System (RAS)"
"What is the mode of inheritance of neurofibromatosis I and II? Autosomal dominant"
"What is the penetrance of neurofibromatosis I? 100%"
"What cutaneous findings are associated with neurofibromatosis I? Cafe-au-lait spots and cutaneous neurofibromas"
"Neurofibromatosis I is associated with optic glioma and Lisch nodules (pigmented iris hamartomas)::eye findings"
"What endocrine disorder is associated with neurofibromatosis I? Pheochromocytoma"
"Which neurocutaneous disorder is associated with cafe-au-lait spots, cutaneous neurofibromas, and Lisch nodules? Neurofibromatosis I"
"Neurofibromatosis type I is also known as von Recklinghausen disease"
"Neurofibromatosis type II is associated with mutations in the NF2 tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 22"
"Neurofibromatosis II is a neurocutaneous disorder associated with bilateral acoustic schwannomas::ear findings"
"Neurofibromatosis II is associated with juvenile cataracts"
"What CNS tumors are associated with neurofibromatosis II? Meningioma and ependymoma"
"Von Hippel-Lindau disease is due to a deletion of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p, leading unregulated activity of HIF1a"
"What is the mode of inheritance of von Hippel-Lindau disease? Autosomal dominant"
"The characteristics of von Hippel-Lindau disease may be remembered with the mnemonic \HARP\\": H: Hemangioblastomas in retina"
"Which feature of von Hippel-Lindau disease is seen in the image below? Hemangioblastoma (high vascularity with hyperchromatic nuclei)"
"What part of the brain is most often affected by hemangioblastoma? Cerebellum"
"What hormone may be produced by hemangioblastomas? Erythropoietin"
"What CNS tumor is seen in the histology slide below? Hemangioblastoma (closely arranged, thin-walled capillaries with minimal intervening parenchyma)"
"Functional pituitary adenoma is most commonly from adenoma of lactotrophs (prolactinoma)"
"Functional pituitary adenoma is less commonly from adenoma of somatotrophs (GH) and corticotrophs (ACTH)"
"Functional pituitary adenoma is rarely from adenoma of thyrotrophs (TSH) and gonadotrophs (FSH, LH)"
"What visual deficit is associated with pituitary adenoma? Bitemporal hemianopsia"
"Sequelae of pituitary adenoma include hyper- and hypopituitarism, which may be caused by pituitary apoplexy"
"Pituitary adenoma is characterized by hyperplasia of only one::one or multiple type(s) of endocrine cell"
"Pinealoma is a tumor of the pineal gland"
"Pinealoma may cause obstructive hydrocephalus due to compression of the cerebral aqueduct"
"Pinealoma::CNS tumor may cause precocious puberty in males due to β-hCG production"
"Pinealoma is a CNS tumor that is similar to germ cell tumors (e.g. testicular seminoma)"
"Cauda equina syndrome is a spinal cord lesion due to compression of spinal roots from L2 and below"
"Cauda equina syndrome may be associated with \saddle (S3-S5) anesthesia\\"\""
"Cauda equina syndrome is commonly associated with uni::uni- or bilateral-lateral symptoms"
"Cauda equina syndrome may present with absent knee and ankle reflexes"
"Cauda equina syndrome is treated with emergent surgery and steroids"
"ID Eye Structure: Physiologic cup"
"ID Eye Structure: Optic disc"
"ID Eye Structure: Macula"
"ID Eye Structure: Fovea"
"ID Eye Structure: Retinal artery"
"ID Eye Structure: Retinal vein"
"Conjunctivitis is inflammation of the conjunctiva, resulting in a red eye"
"Allergic conjunctivitis is characterized by bilateral itchy eyes"
"Bacterial conjunctivitis is characterized by pus"
"Viral conjunctivitis is characterized by sparse mucous discharge and a swollen preauricular node"
"Viral conjunctivitis is the most common type of conjunctivitis"
"What virus commonly causes conjunctivitis? Adenovirus"
"Hyperopia is a refractive error that is also known as \far-sightedness\\"\""
"In hyperopia (farsightedness), light is focused behind the retina"
"Hyperopia is corrected with biconvex (converging) lenses"
"Myopia is a refractive error that is also known as \near-sightedness\\"\""
"In myopia (nearsightedness), light is focused in front of the retina"
"Myopia is corrected with biconcave (diverging) lenses"
"Astigmatism is a refractive error caused by uneven/irregular curvature of the cornea"
"Astigmatism is corrected with cylindrical lenses"
"Presbyopia is aging-related impaired accommodation"
"Presbyopia is primarily due to decreased lens elasticity, changes in lens curvature, and decreased strength of ciliary muscle"
"Patients with presbyopia often need \reading glasses\\" (magnifiers)\""
"Cataracts are painless, often bilateral, opacifications of the lens"
"One risk factor for cataracts is increased age"
"Modifiable risk factors for cataracts include smoking and excessive alcohol use"
"What drug class is associated with cataracts with prolonged use? Corticosteroids"
"One risk factor for cataracts is excessive sunlight"
"What endocrine pathology is associated with cataracts? Diabetes mellitus"
"Congenital risk factors for cataracts include disorders of galactose metabolism"
"Glaucoma is characterized by optic disc atrophy with characteristic cupping"
"Glaucoma is associated with elevated intraocular pressure"
"Glaucoma is associated with progressive peripheral visual field loss if untreated"
"Open-angle glaucoma is associated with increased age"
"Open-angle glaucoma is associated with African-American race and family history"
"Open-angle glaucoma is painless::painful or painless"
"Which form of glaucoma (open- or close-angle) is more common in the U.S.? Open-angle"
"Secondary open-angle glaucoma is due to obstruction of the trabecular meshwork (e.g. by WBCs, RBCs, retinal elements)"
"Primary closed-angle glaucoma is due to enlargement or forward movement of the lens against the iris"
"Closed-angle glaucoma is caused by obstruction of normal aqueous flow through the pupil"
"Secondary closed-angle glaucoma is caused by hypoxia from retinal disease, which induces vasoproliferation in the iris that contracts the angle (e.g. diabetes mellitus, vein occlusion)"
"Chronic closed-angle glaucoma is often asymptomatic with damage to the optic nerve and peripheral vision"
"Acute closed-angle glaucoma is a true ophthalmic emergency"
"Acute closed-angle glaucoma results in a(n) painful::painful or painless, red eye that is fixed and mid-dilated"
"Acute closed-angle glaucoma is characterized by sudden vision loss with halos around lights"
"Closed-angle glaucoma is characterized by frontal headache and a fixed, mid-dilated pupil"
"What catecholamine is contraindicated in closed-angle glaucoma? Epinephrine (mydriatic effect worsens the glaucoma)"
"Uveitis is inflammation of the uvea"
"Anterior uveitis is also known as iritis"
"Posterior uveitis includes choroiditis and/or retinitis"
"Uveitis may present with conjunctival redness and hypopyon, which is the accumulation of pus in the anterior chamber"
"Uveitis is associated with systemic inflammatory disorders (e.g. sarcoidosis, rheumatoid arthritis, juvenile idiopathic arthritis, HLA-B27 disorders)"
"Uveitis is associated with HLA-B27 disorders"
"Age-related macular degeneration is characterized by degeneration of the macula"
"Age-related macular degeneration causes distortion (metamorphopsia) and eventual loss of central vision"
"Which type of macular degeneration (dry or wet) is more common (>80%)? Dry (nonexudative)"
"Dry macular degeneration is characterized by drusen, which is deposition of yellowish extracellular material in between Bruch's membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium"
"Dry macular degeneration is treated with multivitamin and antioxidant supplements; also smoking cessation if applicable"
"Dry (nonexudative) macular degeneration is associated with gradual::speed decrease in vision"
"Wet (exudative) macular degeneration is associated with rapid::speed decrease in vision"
"Wet macular degeneration is due to bleeding, secondary to choroidal neovascularization"
"Wet macular degeneration is treated with smoking cessation (if applicable) and anti-VEGF injections"
"Diabetic retinopathy is retinal damage due to chronic hyperglycemia"
"Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy is characterized by leakage of blood from damaged capillaries, resulting in hemorrhages and macular edema"
"Proliferative diabetic retinopathy results in new blood vessel formation with resultant traction on the retina"
"Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is treated with peripheral retinal photocoagulation, surgery, and/or anti-VEGF therapy"
"Retinal vein occlusion is caused by blockage of a central or branch retinal vein due to compression from nearby arterial atherosclerosis"
"Retinal vein occlusion is characterized by retinal hemorrhage and venous engorgement with edema in the affected area"
"Retinal detachment is due to separation of the neurosensory layer of the retina (rods, cones) from the outer pigment epithelium layer"
"Retinal detachment may be secondary to retinal breaks, diabetic traction, and inflammatory effusions"
"Retinal detachment is visualized on funduscopy as crinkling retinal tissue and changes in vessel direction"
"Retinal detachment is more common in patients with high myopia and/or history of head trauma"
"Retinal detachment is often preceded by posterior vitreous detachment, which presents with \flashes\\" and \\"floaters\\"\""
"Retinal detachment eventually results in monocular loss of vision like a \curtain drawn down\\"\""
"What is the treatment for retinal detachment? Surgery (emergency)"
"Central retinal artery occlusion is characterized by acute, painless::painful or painless monocular vision loss"
"Central retinal artery occlusion is characterized by a pale retina with a(n) \cherry red\\" spot at the fovea\""
"Patients with central retinal artery occlusion should be evaluated for a(n) embolic source (e.g. carotid artery atherosclerosis, cardiac vegetation, patent foramen ovale)"
"Retinoblastoma is an eye cancer associated with a(n) white reflex, rather than the normal red reflex"
"Retinitis pigmentosa is a(n) inherited::acquired or inherited retinal degeneration"
"Retinitis pigmentosa is a painless, progressive vision loss beginning with night blindness"
"Retinitis pigmentosa is characterized by bone spicule-shaped deposits around the macula"
"Retinitis is characterized by retinal edema and necrosis, leading to scar formation"
"What class of microorganism is often the cause of retinitis? Viruses (e.g. CMV, HSV, VZV)"
"Papilledema presents with transient vision loss associated with changes in head position, and is secondary to increased intracranial pressure"
"On funduscopy, papilledema is characterized by optic disc swelling / elevation with blurred margins (usually bilateral)"
"Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing is a visual deficit associated with posterior cerebral artery infarct"
"Contralateral homonymous hemianopia is a visual deficit associated most commonly with a(n) optic tract or with a(n) lateral geniculate body lesion"
"Contralateral homonymous inferior quadrantanopia is a visual deficit associated with lesion of the parietal lobe (e.g. MCA infarct)"
"Contralateral homonymous superior quadrantanopia is a visual deficit associated with lesion of the temporal lobe (e.g. MCA infarct)"
"Cholesteatoma is an overgrowth of desquamated keratin debris within the middle ear space"
"Cholesteatoma may eventually lead to erosion of the ossicles and mastoid air cells, resulting in conductive::sensorineural or conductive hearing loss"
"Vertigo is a sensation of spinning while actually stationary"
"Which type of vertigo is more common? Peripheral::peripheral or central"
"Peripheral vertigo is most commonly due to benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is tested with the Dix-Hallpike maneuver"
"Peripheral vertigo may be caused by vestibular nerve infection"
"Ménière disease is a triad of recurrent vertigo, ear fullness / pain and unilateral hearing loss & tinnitus"
"Peripheral vertigo is caused by inner ear etiology (e.g. Ménière disease, BPPV, vestibular nerve infection, semicircular canal debris)"
"Peripheral vertigo is characterized by delayed nystagmus in the horizontal direction with positional testing"
"Central vertigo is caused by a brain stem or cerebellar lesion (e.g. stroke affecting vestibular nuclei or posterior fossa tumor)"
"Central vertigo is characterized by immediate nystagmus in any direction with positional testing"
"Classical conditioning is a type of conditioning where a natural response is elicited by a conditioned/learned stimulus that was previously presented with an unconditioned stimulus"
"Which type of conditioning usually deals with involuntary responses? Classical conditioning"
"Operant conditioning is a type of conditioning where a particular action is elicited because it produces a punishment or reward"
"Which type of conditioning usually deals with voluntary responses? Operant conditioning"
"Which operant conditioning technique involves addition of a stimulus in efforts to increase behavior? Positive reinforcement"
"Which operant conditioning technique involves removal of a stimulus in efforts to increase behavior? Negative reinforcement"
"Which operant conditioning technique involves addition of a stimulus in efforts to decrease behavior? Positive punishment"
"Which operant conditioning technique involves removal of a stimulus in efforts to decrease behavior? Negative punishment"
"Extinction is the idea that discontinuation of reinforcement (positive or negative) eventually eliminates a behavior"
"Transference is characterized by the patient projecting feelings about formative or other important persons onto the physician"
"Countertransference is characterized by the doctor projecting feelings about formative or other important persons onto the patient"
"Ego defenses, unconscious or conscious, are used to resolve conflict and prevent undesirable feelings (e.g. anxiety, depression)"
"Which ego defense is defined as expressing unacceptable feelings and thoughts through actions? Acting out (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as avoiding the awareness of some painful reality? Denial (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as redirection of emotions/impulses to a neutral person or object? Displacement (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as temporary, drastic change in personality, memory, consciousness, or motor behavior to avoid emotional stress? Dissociation (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as partially remaining at a more childish level of development? Fixation (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as expressing extremely positive thoughts of self/others while ignoring negative thoughts? Idealization (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as a largely unconscious assumption of the characteristics, qualities, or traits of another person or group that is perceived to be more powerful / prestigious? Identification (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as using facts and logic to emotionally distance oneself from a stressful situation? Intellectualization (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as separating feelings from ideas and events? Isolation of affect (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as demonstrating hostile feelings in a non-confrontational manner? Passive aggression (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as misattributing one's own unconscious, undesired thoughts or feelings to another person who does not actually have them? Projection (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as proclaiming logical reasons for actions actually performed for other reasons (usually to avoid self-blame)? Rationalization (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as replacing a warded-off idea or feeling by an unconsciously derived emphasis on its opposite? Reaction formation (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as involuntarily turning back the maturational clock and going back to earlier modes of dealing with the world? Regression (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as involuntarily withholding an idea or feeling from conscious awareness? Repression (immature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as believing that people are either all good or all bad at different times due to intolerance of ambiguity? Splitting (immature defense)"
"Splitting is a major defense mechanism seen in patients with borderline personality disorder"
"Which ego defense is defined as replacing an unacceptable wish with a course of action that is similar to the wish but does not conflict with one's value system? Sublimation (mature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as alleviating negative feelings via unsolicited generosity which provides gratification? Altruism (mature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as intentionally withholding an idea or feeling from conscious awareness (temporary)? Suppression (mature defense)"
"Which ego defense is defined as appreciating the amusing nature of an anxiety-provoking or adverse situation? Humor (mature defense)"
"The mature mechanisms of ego defense may be remembered with the mnemonic \SASH\\": S: sublimation A: altruism S: suppression H: humor\""
"Long-term infant deprivation of affection may result in failure to thrive"
"Long-term infant deprivation of affection may result in poor language/socialization skills"
"Long-term infant deprivation of affection may result in lack of basic trust"
"Long-term infant deprivation of affection may result in reactive attachment disorder, where the infant is emotionally withdrawn and unresponsive to comfort"
"Infant deprivation for > 6 months can lead to irreversible changes"
"Severe infant deprivation can result in infant death"
"Evidence of physical abuse in a child includes fractures (e.g. ribs, long bone spiral, multiple in different stages of healing)"
"Evidence of physical abuse in a child includes bruises (e.g. trunk, ear, neck; in pattern of implement)"
"Evidence of physical abuse in a child includes burns (e.g. cigarette, buttocks/thighs)"
"Evidence of Shaken Baby Syndrome includes subdural hematomas, retinal hemorrhages, cervical spine injury, and posterior rib fractures"
"Children who are victims of physical abuse often avoid eye contact on exam"
"The abuser in the case of physical abuse of a child is usually the biological mother"
"40% of deaths related to child abuse or neglect occur in children < 1 year(s) old"
"Evidence of sexual abuse includes genital, anal, or oral trauma"
"Evidence of sexual abuse includes urinary tract and sexually transmitted infections"
"The abuser in the case of sexual abuse is usually a(n) male::gender who is known to the victim"
"What is the peak incidence for sexual abuse? 9 - 12 years old::age"
"Child neglect is failure to provide a child with adequate food, shelter, supervision, education, and/or affection"
"What is the most common form of child maltreatment? Child neglect"
"Evidence of child neglect includes poor hygiene, malnutrition, withdrawal, impaired social/emotional development, and failure to thrive"
"Does child abuse need to be reported to local child protective services? Yes"
"Does child neglect or child abuse need to be reported to local child protective services? Yes"
"Vulnerable child syndrome is when the parents perceive the child as especially susceptible to illness or injury"
"Vulnerable child syndrome often results in missed school or overuse of medical services"
"Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) has an onset before age 12"
"Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is characterized by hyperactivity, impulsivity, and/or inattention in multiple settings (school, home, places of worship, etc.) for > 6 months::duration"
"Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is associated with normal intelligence that coexists with difficulties in school"
"Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) continues into adulthood in 50% of cases"
"ADHD is treated with stimulants +/- cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT)"
"Autism spectrum disorder is a childhood disorder characterized by poor social interactions, social communication deficits, repetitive/ritualized behaviors, and restricted interests"
"Autism spectrum disorder must present in early childhood::age group"
"Autism spectrum disorder is more commonly accompanied by intellectual disability"
"Autism spectrum disorder rarely is accompanied by unusual abilities (savants)"
"Autism spectrum disorder is more common in boys::gender"
"Autism spectrum disorder is associated with increased head/brain size"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Rett syndrome? X-linked dominant"
"Rett syndrome is almost exclusively seen in females::gender"
"The majority of cases of Rett syndrome are caused by de novo mutations in meCP2"
"Rett syndrome presents with regression, including loss of development and verbal abilities"
"Rett syndrome often presents with verbal regression, intellectual disability, ataxia, and stereotyped hand-wringing"
"Rett syndrome symptoms usually become apparent between ages 1 to 4"
"Conduct disorder is a childhood disorder characterized by repetitive and pervasive behavior that violates the basic rights of others or societal norms"
"After age 18, conduct disorder is often reclassified as antisocial personality disorder"
"What is the treatment for both conduct disorder and antisocial personality disorder? Psychotherapy (e.g. CBT)"
"Oppositional defiant disorder is a childhood disorder characterized by an enduring pattern of hostile, defiant behavior towards authority figures in the absence of serious violations of societal norms for > 6 months::duration"
"What is the treatment for oppositional defiant disorder? Psychotherapy (e.g. CBT) and parent management training"
"Separation anxiety disorder is a childhood disorder characterized by overwhelming fear of separation from home or an attachment figure lasting > 4 weeks"
"Separation anxiety disorder can be normal behavior up to age 3 - 4"
"Which childhood psychiatric disorder may lead to factitious physical complaints to avoid school? Separation anxiety disorder"
"Treatment for separation anxiety disorder includes CBT, play therapy, and family therapy"
"Tourette's syndrome is a childhood disorder characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, nonrhythmic, stereotyped motor and vocal tics that persist for > 1 year::duration"
"The onset of Tourette's syndrome symptoms is before age 18"
"Tourette's syndrome may present with coprolalia, which is involuntary obscene speech (40% of patients)"
"What other psychiatric disorders are associated with Tourette syndrome? OCD and ADHD::2"
"Non-pharmacological treatment for Tourette's syndrome includes psychoeducation and behavioral therapy"
"Pharmacological treatment for intractable and distressing tics in Tourette's syndrome may include high-potency antipsychotics"
"Pharmacological treatment for intractable and distressing tics in Tourette's syndrome may include α2-adrenergic agonists"
"Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder is a childhood disorder characterized by severe and recurrent temper outbursts out of proportion to a situation"
"The onset of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder symptoms is before age 10"
"Children with disruptive mood dysregulation disorder are constantly angry and irritable between outbursts"
"Treatment for disruptive mood dysregulation disorder includes psychostimulants, antipsychotics, and CBT"
"What neurotransmitter is decreased in Alzheimer disease? Acetylcholine"
"What neurotransmitters are decreased in depression? Serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine"
"What neurotransmitter is increased in anxiety? Norepinephrine"
"What neurotransmitters are decreased in anxiety? Serotonin and GABA"
"What neurotransmitter is increased in Huntington disease? Dopamine"
"What neurotransmitters are decreased in Huntington disease? Acetylcholine, GABA, and substance P"
"What neurotransmitter is increased in Parkinson disease? Acetylcholine"
"What neurotransmitters are decreased in Parkinson disease? Dopamine and serotonin"
"What neurotransmitter is increased in schizophrenia? Dopamine"
"Orientation describes a patient's ability to know person, place, and time"
"What is the order in which loss of orientation to person, place, and time occurs? Time -> place -> person"
"Retrograde amnesia is the inability to remember things that occurred before a CNS insult"
"Anterograde amnesia is the inability to remember things that occurred after a CNS insult (decreased acquisition of new memory)"
"Korsakoff syndrome causes both retro- and anterograde amnesia, however, anterograde amnesia is more prominent"
"Confabulations are characteristic of Korsakoff syndrome"
"Dissociative amnesia is an inability to recall important personal information, usually subsequent to severe trauma or stress"
"Dissociative fugue is an abrupt traveling or wandering during a period of dissociative amnesia; associated with traumatic circumstances"
"Dissociative identity disorder is characterized by the presence of 2 or more distinct identities or personality states, usually following psychological trauma"
"Dissociative identity disorder is more common in women::gender"
"Depersonalization/derealization disorder is characterized by persistent feelings of detachment from one's own body, thoughts, perceptions, and actions (depersonalization) or one's environment (derealization)"
"Which psychiatric disorder, delirium or dementia, is characterized by acute onset \waxing and waning\\" level of consciousness? Delirium\""
"Which psychiatric disorder, delirium or dementia, is characterized by decreased intellectual function without affecting level of consciousness? Dementia"
"Is dementia typically reversible or irreversible? Irreversible"
"Is delirium typically reversible or irreversible? Reversible"
"Which psychiatric disorder, delirium or dementia, is characterized by disorganized thinking, hallucinations, disturbances in sleep wake cycle, cognitive dysfunction, and agitation? Delirium"
"Which psychiatric disorder, delirium or dementia, is characterized by memory deficits, apraxia, aphasia, agnosia, behavioral/personality changes, and impaired judgment? Dementia"
"Can a patient with dementia develop delirium? Yes"
"Delirium::dementia or delirium is usually secondary to other illness (e.g. CNS disease, infection, trauma, substance abuse/withdrawal, metabolic disturbances, hemorrhage, urinary/fecal retention)"
"Delirium::Dementia or delirium is associated with a(n) diffuse, slowing pattern on EEG"
"Dementia::dementia or delirium is associated with a(n) normal pattern on EEG"
"Delirium::dementia or delirium is the most common presentation of altered mental status in an inpatient setting (especially in the ICU and with prolonged hospital stays)"
"What is the treatment for delirium? Address the underlying condition"
"Delirium may be caused by medications, such as anticholinergics, especially in the elderly"
"What GI pathology is an irreversible cause of dementia? Wilson disease (hepatolenticular degeneration)"
"What infectious disease is an irreversible cause of dementia? HIV"
"In elderly patients with suspected dementia, TSH and B12 levels should be measured to rule out other possible causes"
"In elderly patients with suspected dementia, a(n) RPR test should be administered to exclude neurosyphilis if there's high clinical suspicion"
"In elderly patients with suspected dementia, screening for depression should be performed to rule out other possible causes"
"What endocrine pathology is a reversible cause of dementia? Hypothyroidism"
"What infectious disease is a reversible cause of dementia? Neurosyphilis"
"What form of hydrocephalus is a reversible cause of dementia? Normal pressure hydrocephalus"
"Reversible dementia may occur with deficiencies in vitamins B1, B3, and B12"
"Psychosis is a distorted perception of reality characterized by delusions, hallucinations, and/or disorganized thought or speech"
"What feature of psychosis is characterized by unique, false, fixed idiosyncratic beliefs that persist despite the facts and are not typical of a patient's culture or religion? Delusions"
"What feature of psychosis is characterized by speech that is incoherent (\word salad\\")"
"What feature of psychosis is characterized by perceptions in the absence of external stimuli? Hallucinations"
"Illusions are misperceptions of real external stimuli"
"Visual hallucinations are more commonly a feature of medical illness than psychiatric illness (psychiatric or medical)"
"Auditory hallucinations are more commonly a feature of psychiatric illness than medical illness (psychiatric or medical)"
"Olfactory hallucinations often occur as an aura of temporal lobe epilepsy and in brain tumors"
"Gustatory hallucinations are rare, but may be seen in epilepsy"
"Tactile hallucinations are common in alcohol withdrawal and stimulant use (e.g. cocaine, amphetamines)"
"Hypnagogic hallucinations occur while going to sleep; sometimes seen in narcolepsy"
"Hypnopompic hallucinations occur while waking from sleep; sometimes seen in narcolepsy"
"Schizophrenia is a chronic mental disorder with periods of psychosis, disturbed behavior and thought, and decline in functioning lasting > 6 months::duration"
"Schizophrenia is associated with increased dopaminergic activity"
"Schizophrenia is associated with decreased dendritic branching"
"Diagnosis of schizophrenia requires at least 2 of following, and at least 1 of these should include 1 to 3: - Positive symptoms- 1. Delusions 2. Hallucinations 3. Disorganized speech 4. Disorganized or catatonic behavior 5. Negative symptoms (affective flattening, avolition, anhedonia, asociality, alogia)"
"Brief psychotic disorder is symptoms of schizophrenia lasting < 1 month::duration with >1 positive symptom"
"Brief psychotic disorder is usually stress related"
"Schizophreniform disorder is symptoms of schizophrenia lasting from 1 to 6::duration months"
"Schizoaffective disorder meets criteria for schizophrenia in addition to major mood disorder (major depressive or bipolar)"
"Diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder requires at least 2 weeks::duration of psychotic symptoms without major mood episode"
"If episodes of psychosis only occur during a major mood episode, the diagnosis is either major depressive disorder or bipolar disorder with psychosis"
"Are hallucinations involving a dead relative during a period of bereavement considered normal? Yes (within 6 months)"
"Schizophrenia/psychosis in teens is associated with frequent cannabis use"
"Is the prevalence of schizophrenia more common in a particular race? No"
"Is schizophrenia more common in men or women? Men"
"Schizophrenia is characterized by ventriculomegaly on CT"
"What group of drugs is the first line treatment for schizophrenia? Atypical antipsychotics (e.g. risperidone)"
"Delusional disorder is a fixed, persistent, false belief system lasting > 1 month::duration with otherwise normal functioning"
"Delusion disorder typically presents with non-bizarre::(bizarre or non-bizarre) delusions"
"Delusions can be shared by individuals in close relationships; termed folie à deux"
"SpeA and C of Streptococcus pyogenes are considered superantigens"
"What is the function of GAS M-protein? Antiphagocytic, inhibits activation of complement::2"
"The antiphagocytic virulence factors for streptococcus pyogenes (GAS) are M-protein, hyaluronic acid capsule::2"
"What GAS virulence factor can be given to patients with clots? Streptokinase: converts plasminogen to plasmin, which is fibrinolytic"
"Streptokinase is a virulence factor for what gram (+) species? GAS"
"Scarlet fever is associated with what toxin? Erythrogenic exotoxin (SPE)::specific"
"Patient with sore-throat has red-rash that begins on the trunk and neck, then spreads to the extremities before eventually desquamating Scarlet Fever"
"What clinical syndrome is associated with \beefy-red tongue\\" concurrent with pharyngitis? Scarlet Fever\""
"Toxic Shock Like Syndrome is caused by what organism? GAS (S. pyogenes)"
"Infection caused by Strep pyogenes that presents with erythematous, sandpaper-like rash with fever and sore throat: Scarlet Fever"
"Erysipelas is an infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics caused by GAS, and presents with a well-defined demarcation between infected and normal skin"
"Cellulitis::what skin pathology characterized by an infection of the deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissues is caused Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes::by what (2) organisms?"
"Necrotizing fasciitis is caused by GAS and enters through trauma openings causing infection and ultimately necrotic skin with large bullae"
"Rheumatic fever is a type II HR that is preceded by GAS pharyngitis"
"Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis is a type III HS that is preceded by GAS pharyngitis or skin infection"
"What GAS virulence factor causes antibody production that cross-reacts with myosin in the heart, causing rheumatic fever? M-protein"
"PSGN (post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis) is a complication of GAS pharyngitis or skin infection that presents with hematuria (cola-colored urine) and facial swelling"
"GAS erythrogenic toxin genes are encoded in a(n) lysogenic::lytic or lysogenic phage through specialized transduction"
"What drug class do diazepam, lorazepam, temazepam, and oxazepam belong to? Benzodiazepines"
"The short-acting benzodiazepines may be remembered with the mnemonic \ATOM\\": A: Alprazolam T: Triazolam O: Oxazepam M: Midazolam\""
"What drug class does chlordiazepoxide belong to? Benzodiazepines"
"Short-acting benzodiazepines have a(n) higher potential for addiction than long-acting"
"Benzodiazepines are metabolized by the liver"
"Long-acting benzodiazepines are typically metabolized by the liver into active metabolites"
"Benzodiazepines exert their effects via binding to an allosteric site on the GABAA receptor"
"Benzodiazepines enhance::enhance or inhibit the action of GABAA"
"The GABAA receptor is a ligand-gated Cl- channel"
"Benzodiazepines increase Cl- conductance by increasing the frequency::frequency or duration of channel opening"
"Benzodiazepines, barbiturates, and alcohol all bind different allosteric sites of the GABAA receptor"
"Non-specific symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, such as anxiety, insomnia, and tremors, typically occur after 3 - 36 hours"
"Seizures secondary to alcohol withdrawal typically occur after 6 - 48 hours"
"Delirium tremens, secondary to alcohol withdrawal, typically occurs after 48 - 96 hours"
"Long-acting benzodiazepines are useful in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal (if no cirrhosis or alcoholic hepatitis)"
"IV administration of benzodiazepines, is useful for management of alcohol withdrawal, seizures, and anesthesia"
"IV benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam and diazepam, are the 1st-line agents for treatment for acute status epilepticus"
"Which type of generalized seizure is acutely treated with benzodiazepines? Status epilepticus"
"IV benzodiazepines can be used in general anesthesia (muscle relaxation, amnesia)"
"IV benzodiazepines (e.g. midazolam) may be used to create a state of conscious sedation for minor procedures and surgeries (e.g. colonoscopy, endoscopy)"
"Benzodiazepines may be used as a hypnotic to treat insomnia, but they are not first line treatment due to physical dependence"
"Benzodiazepines may be used to treat parasomnias in children, such as sleep walking and night terrors"
"Benzodiazepines may be used to treat spasticity caused by UMN disorders (e.g. MS, stroke, spinal cord trauma, tetanus)"
"Benzodiazepines may be used to treat generalized anxiety disorder and panic disorder, though SSRIs and SNRIs are first line"
"What pregnancy complication may be treated with benzodiazepines? Eclampsia (not first line)"
"Benzodiazepines can cause tolerance by downregulating GABAA receptors"
"Do benzodiazepines have addictive potential? Yes"
"Compared to barbiturates, benzodiazepines have less risk of respiratory depression and coma"
"Benzodiazepines can cause dose-dependent antero-grade amnesia"
"Elderly patients are more sensitive to the side effects of benzodiazepines (e.g. somnolence, confusion, disorientation)"
"Benzodiazepines can cause central ataxia, leading to increased risk of falls in the elderly"
"Benzodiazepines may have additive CNS depression effects with alcohol, barbiturates, 1st generation antihistamines, and neuroleptics"
"Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine site of the GABA-A receptor, which is used to treat overdose or reverse sedative effects of benzodiazepines AND nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics::2"
"Flumazenil can precipate seizures by causing acute benzodiazepine withdrawal"
"The benzodiazepines that are safe to use in patients with liver disease may be remembered with the mnemonic \LOT\\": L: Lorazepam O: Oxazepam T: Temazepam\""
"The three nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics are Zolpidem, Zaleplon, and esZopiclone"
"Nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics exert their effects via binding to an allosteric site on the GABAA receptor"
"The nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics bind to the same GABAA receptor allosteric site as benzodiazepines (BZ1 subtype)"
"Nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics are primarily used for the treatment of insomnia"
"Nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics have a(n) short duration of action due to rapid metabolism by the liver"
"Are zaleplon and zolpidem (nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics) useful for sleep onset or sleep mainteinance? Sleep onset"
"Is eszopiclone (non-benzodiazepine hypnotic) useful for sleep onset or sleep maintenance? Both :)"
"Which non-benzodiazepine hypnotic has the longest half-life? Eszopiclone"
"Elderly patients are more sensitive to the side effects of nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics (e.g. cognitive impairment, headache, delirium)"
"Nonbenzodiazepines hypnotics can cause central ataxia, leading to increased risk of falls in the elderly"
"Nonbenzodiazepene hypnotics should not be combined with other CNS depressants"
"Compared to benzodiazepines, nonbenzodiazepine hynotics are less likely to cause tolerance"
"Compared to benzodiazepines, nonbenzodiazepine hynotics are less likely to affect the sleep cycle"
"Compared to benzodiazepines, nonbenzodiazepine hynotics are less likely to cause dependence"
"Flumazenil reverses the sedative actions of nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics"
"Do nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics cause significant day-after psychomotor depression and/or amnesia? No"
"Ramelteon is a(n) melatonin receptor agonist used to treat insomnia"
"Ramelteon binds the MT1 and MT2 receptors in the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus"
"Does ramelteon have addictive potential? No"
"Compared to other hypnotics, ramelteon has relatively few side effects and is safe to use in geriatric patients"
"Suvorexant is a(n) orexin (hypocretin) receptor antagonist used to treat insomnia"
"Does suvorexant have addictive potential? No"
"Suvorexant is contraindicated in patients with narcolepsy"
"Suvorexant is not recommended in patients with liver disease"
"Suvorexant is contraindicated in patients taking strong CYP3A4 inhibitors"
"Adverse effects of suvorexant include CNS depression, headache, dizziness, abnormal dreams, and upper respiratory tract infection"
"What drug class do phenobarbital, pentobarbital, and secobarbital belong to? Barbiturates"
"What drug class does thiopental belong to? Barbiturates"
"Barbiturates exert their effects via binding to an allosteric site on the GABAA receptor"
"Barbiturates enhance::enhance or inhibit the action of GABAA"
"Barbiturates increase Cl- conductance by increasing the duration::frequency or duration of channel opening"
"Barbiturates have long durations of action and thus \hangover\\" effects are more common\""
"IV thiopental is a barbiturate that can be used for induction of anesthesia"
"Thiopental is a barbiturate with a rapid onset and duration of action due to high potency and high lipid solubility"
"Plasma levels of thiopental decrease rapidly due to redistribution to skeletal muscle and adipose"
"Phenobarbital is a barbiturate used in the acute treatment of partial and tonic-clonic seizures"
"Phenobarbital is a first line agent for treatment of seizures in neonates"
"Primidone is a barbiturate used to treat seizures and essential tremor"
"Besides CNS depression, side effects of barbiturates include cardiac and respiratory depression, which can be fatal"
"Barbiturates can cause severe CNS depression (e.g. coma) and should be avoided in elderly patients"
"Does chronic barbiturate use lead to tolerance? Yes"
"Do barbiturates have addictive potential? Yes"
"Barbiturates are a(n) inducer of cytochrome P450 and thus may have many drug interactions"
"The treatment for barbiturate overdose is mainly supportive treatment, but excretion can be enhanced with urinary alkalinization"
"Barbiturates are contraindicated in patients with porphyrias::hematologic pathology"
"Mood disorder is characterized by an abnormal range of moods or internal emotional states and loss of control over them"
"A manic episode is a distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood with persistently increased activity or energy for at least 1 week::duration"
"Diagnosis of a(n) manic episode requires an elevated and/or irritable mood plus at least three \DIG FAST\\" criteria: D: Distractibility I: Irresponsibility (seeks pleasure without regard to consequences) G: Grandiosity (inflated self-esteem) F: Flight of ideas (racing thoughts) A: Agitation/increased Activity S: Sleeplessness T: Talkativeness or pressured speech\""
"Do patients with manic episodes need to be hospitalized? Yes (psychiatric emergency)"
"What is the general treatment for manic episodes? Atypical antipsychotics"
"Manic episodes may present similarly to stimulant intoxication"
"A(n) hypomanic episode is similar to a manic episode except mood disturbance doesn't cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning"
"Does a hypomanic episode present with psychotic features? No"
"A hypomanic episode must last at least 4 consecutive days"
"Bipolar I disorder is defined by presence of at least 1 manic episode +/- a hypomanic episode or depressive episode"
"Bipolar II disorder is defined by the presence of a hypomanic and a depressive episode"
"Does a patient with bipolar disorder typically return to normal mood and functioning between episodes? Yes"
"Patients with bipolar disorder have a high risk of suicide"
"What is the general treatment for bipolar disorder? Mood stabilizers"
"In addition to mood stabilizers, antipsychotics may be used as an adjunctive therapy for bipolar disorder"
"Use of antidepressants in patients with bipolar disorder can precipitate acute mania"
