"Cyclothymic disorder is a milder form of bipolar disorder lasting at least 2 years::duration, fluctuating between mild depressive and hypomanic symptoms"
"Does a patient with cyclothymia typically return to normal mood and functioning between episodes? No"
"{{c10::Major depressive disorder episodes are characterized by {{c11::depressed mood or {{c12::anhedonia and at least {{c13::four other \SIG E CAPS\\" symptoms lasting > 2 weeks::duration S: Sleep changes I: Interest decreases (anhedonia) G: Guilt or feelings of worthlessness E: Energy loss or fatigue C: Concentration problems A: Appetite/weight changes P: Psychomotor retardation or agitation S: Suicidal ideations\""
"Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) is depression, often milder, lasting at least 2 years::duration"
"Persistent depressive disorder is also known as dysthymia"
"What is the first line treatment for major depressive disorder? CBT + SSRIs"
"Electroconvulsive therapy is a(n) rapid acting method that may be used to treat certain patients with treatment resistant major depressive disorder"
"Atypical depression is associated with mood reactivity, which is being able to experience improved mood in response to positive events, albeit briefly"
"Atypical depression is associated with hyper-somnia"
"Atypical depression is associated with hyper-phagia"
"Atypical depression is associated with leaden paralysis (feeling of heaviness in limbs) and sensitivity to rejection"
"What is the first-line treatment for atypical depression? CBT and SSRIs"
"The onset of postpartum mood disturbances is within 4 weeks of delivery"
"Postpartum blues is characterized by depressed affect, tearfulness, and fatigue starting 2-3 days after delivery for < 2 weeks"
"What is the treatment for postpartum blues? Supportive"
"Postpartum depression is characterized by depressed affect, anxiety, and poor concentration for > 2 weeks"
"What is the treatment for postpartum depression? CBT and SSRIs"
"Postpartum psychosis is characterized by mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations, and thoughts of harming the baby or self"
"Risks factors for postpartum psychosis include first pregnancy, history of bipolar or psychotic disorder, family history, and recent discontinuation of psychotropic medication"
"What is the treatment for postpartum psychosis? Hospitalization and antipsychotics"
"The five stages of grief per the Kubler-Ross model are denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance"
"Pathologic grief is persistent (> 12 months time) and causes functional impairment"
"Can a person with grief meet the criteria for major depressive episode? Yes"
"Electroconvulsive therapy is used mainly for treatment-refractory depression, depression with psychotic symptoms, and acute suicidality"
"Electroconvulsive therapy produces a(n) grand mal seizure in a patient under anesthesia"
"Adverse effects of electroconvulsive therapy include temporary headache, disorientation, and partial amnesia; usually resolves within 6 months"
"Is electroconvulsive therapy safe to use during pregnancy and elderly? Yes"
"Is propofol used for the induction or maintenance of anesthesia? Both :)"
"Propofol and etomidate are IV anesthetics that exert their effects via potentiation of the GABAA receptor complex"
"Propofol causes profound vaso-dilation of arteries and veins"
"Which IV anesthetic causes profound vasodilation (and thus hypotension)? Propofol"
"Compared to thiopental, propofol has less post-operative nausea"
"Is etomidate used for the induction or maintenance of anesthesia? Induction"
"Which IV anesthetic preserves cardiovascular stability? Etomidate"
"Is ketamine used for the induction or maintenance of anesthesia? Induction"
"Ketamine is an IV anesthetic that exerts its effect via inhibition of NMDA receptors"
"Ketamine (an arylcyclohexylamine) is a PCP analog that causes \dissociative anesthesia\\"\""
"Ketamine is an IV anesthetic that can cause disorientation, hallucinations, and unpleasant dreams"
"Ketamine causes cardiovascular stimulation::depression or stimulation"
"Ketamine causes increased cerebral blood flow"

"Benzodiazepines (e.g. midazolam) can cause severe post-operative respiratory depression and hypo-tension"
"Thiopental is a barbiturate that may be used as an IV anesthetic"
"Is thiopental used for the induction or maintenance of anesthesia? Induction"
"Thiopental causes decreased cerebral blood flow"

"Staph aureus is the only Staph organism that is coagulase +"

"Staphylcoccus aureus will turn Mannitol agar bright yellow"
"Where does Staphylococcus aureus normally colonize? Nares"
"Which S. aureus toxin nonspecifically binds MHC-II (on APCs) and the T-cell receptor producing cytokine storm and toxic shock: TSST-1 superantigen"
"Scalded skin syndrome is caused by Staphylococcus aureus::which organism?"
"What kind of toxin produces scalded-skin syndrome? Exfoliative toxin A and B"
"What is the MOA of exfoliative toxin in Scalded-Skin Syndrome? Destroys keratinocyte attachments in stratum granulosum, causing skin to slough off"
"Enterotoxin is a pre-formed heat stable exotoxin found in Staphylococcus aureus that causes food poisoning from eating meat, cream-based foods"
"Rash that occurs in neonates; will have + Nikolsky sign: Scalded-Skin Syndrome"
"Protein A is a virulence factor of Staphylococcus aureus"
"What is the function of Protein A? binds IgG Fc region, preventing opsonization and ultimately phagocytosis"

"Furuncles and carbuncles are associated with what coagulase + organism? Staph aureus"

"What inhaled anesthetic is commonly known as \laughing gas\\"? Nitrous oxide (N2O)\""

"Which valve is most commonly affected with S. aureus endocarditis? Tricuspid"

"What foods can cause S. aureus gastroenteritis? Meats, cream-based foods"
"How does MRSA obtain methicillin resistance? Alters PBP (penicillin-binding proteins)"
"Alteration of penicillin-binding proteins (PBP) allows methicillin resistance in MRSA"
"What is the treatment for Staph aureus infections (not MRSA)? Nafcillin"
"What is the treatment for MRSA (methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus)? Vancomycin"
"Group B Strep (S. agalactiae) hydrolyzes sodium hippurate"
"Group B Strep (S. agalactiae) has a positive CAMP test, meaning it enhances the zone of hemolysis when plated with S. aureus"
"What is the most common cause of meningitis in neonates? Group B Strep (Streptococcus agalactiae)"
"Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) produces what neonatal respiratory complication? Neonatal pneumonia"
"What age demographic is typically affected with Strep agalactiae (GBS)? Neonates"
"What drug class do halothane, enflurane, methoxyflurane belong to? Inhaled anesthetics"
"Inhaled anesthetics with higher solubility in blood have a(n) slower onset of action"
"Inhaled anesthetics with higher solubility in blood have a(n) slower recovery"
"Inhaled anesthetics with lower solubility in blood have a(n) faster onset of action"
"Inhaled anesthetics with lower solubility in blood have a(n) faster recovery"
"The solubility of an inhaled anesthetic may also be referred to as the blood:gas partition coefficient"
"Does the blue curve represent an inhaled anesthetic with a high or low blood solubility? Low (quickly saturated, e.g. N2O)"
"Does the red curve represent an inhaled anesthetic with a high or low blood solubility? High (slowly saturated, e.g. halothane)"
"Minimal alveolar concentration (MAC) is the dose of inhaled anesthetic that causes 50% of patients to become unresponsive to noxious stimuli"
"Drugs with increased solubility in lipids have increased potency"
"Potency is inversely proportional to minimal alveolar concentration (MAC)"
"Halothane is an example of an inhaled anesthetic with high lipid and blood solubility"
"Nitrous oxide (N2O) is an example of an inhaled anesthetic with low lipid and blood solubility"
"Inhaled anesthetics can cause myocardial depression::stimulation or depression"
"Inhaled anesthetics can cause respiratory depression::stimulation or depression"
"Inhaled anesthetics can cause increased cerebral blood flow"
"The inhaled anesthetic halothane is most commonly associated with hepatotoxicity as an adverse effect"
"The inhaled anesthetic enflurane can induce seizures and cause nephro-toxicity as adverse effects"
"The inhaled anesthetic methoxyflurane is associated with nephrotoxicity as an adverse effect"
"The inhaled anesthetic N2O is associated with expansion of trapped gas in a body cavity as an adverse effect"
"Malignant hyperthermia is a skeletal muscle hypersensitivity to volatile anesthetics"
"In addition to inhaled anesthetics, malignant hyperthermia may also be caused by succinylcholine (muscle relaxant)"
"Malignant hyperthermia is usually related to a defect in ryanodine receptors, which causes increased Ca2+ release from the SR"
"Excessive heat production in malignant hyperthermia induces fever and muscle damage (e.g. rhabdomyolysis)"
"Malignant hyperthermia is treated by dantrolene, which is a(n) ryanodine receptor antagonist that prevents release of Ca2+ from the SR"
"What is the mode of inheritance of malignant hyperthermia? Autosomal dominant"
"What genetic phenomenon is associated with malignant hyperthermia? Incomplete penetrance"
"Which opioid receptor does β-endorphin bind to? μ-opioid receptor"
"Which opioid receptor does enkephalin bind to? δ-opioid receptor"
"Which opioid receptor does dynorphin bind to? κ-opioid receptor"
"The μ-opioid receptor mediates most of the clinical and adverse effects"
"Opiate receptor activation causes opening of K+ channels"
"Opiate receptor activation causes closure of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels"
"Opiate receptor activation causes closure of pre-synaptic Ca2+ channels, which decreases release of neurotransmitters (e.g. ACh, NE, 5-HT, glutamate, substance P)"
"Fentanyl and morphine are opioid agonists that may be used for pain relief"
"Loperamide and diphenoxylate are μ-opioid agonists that can be used as anti-diarrheals"
"Codeine and dextromethorphan are opioid agonists that may be used as anti-tussives"
"In addition to opioid agonist activity, dextromethorphan also antagonizes NMDA receptors"
"Opioid analgesics may be used to treat acute pulmonary edema"
"Opioid analgesics are associated with CNS depression as an adverse effect"
"Opioid analgesics may cause significant dose-dependent respiratory depression::depression or stimulation"
"Most opioid analgesics cause miosis::pupil size"
"What opioid analgesic causes mydriasis? Meperidine"
"What change in bowel movement is associated with activation of μ-opioid receptors? Constipation"
"What biliary tree complication may be caused by opiates? Biliary colic or Sphincter of Oddi Spasm"
"Do opiates have addictive potential? Yes"
"Does chronic opiate use lead to tolerance? Yes"
"What adverse effects of opiates persist even after tolerance develops? Miosis and constipation"
"Chronic opioid use can cause opioid-induced hyperalgesia, which is abnormal pain sensitivity"
"What change in bowel movement is associated with opioid withdrawal? Diarrhea"
"Opioid withdrawal is associated with mydriasis::pupil size"
"Opioid withdrawal is associated with fever, yawning, rhinorrhea, lacrimation, and piloerection (\cold turkey\\")\""
"Methadone is a long-acting μ-receptor agonist used to attenuate opioid withdrawal symptoms"
"Methadone and buprenorphine are useful for opioid detoxication due to their long half lives"
"Buprenorphine is a long-acting partial μ-opioid agonist used to attenuate opioid withdrawal symptoms"
"Neonatal abstinence syndrome occurs due to exposure to opiate drugs while in the mother's womb"
"Neonatal abstinence syndrome presents with diarrhea, sweating, irritability, and tachypnea::respiratory rate"
"Buprenorphine, and butorphanol are μ-opioid partial agonists"
"Partial opioid agonists can cause opioid withdrawal symptoms if the patient is also taking a full opioid agonist"
"Naloxone is a μ-opioid inverse agonist used to treat acute opioid toxicity (can precipitate withdrawal)"
"Naltrexone is a μ-opioid antagonist that helps maintain abstinence in opioid addicts once detoxified"
"Naltrexone is a μ-opioid antagonist that helps reduce cravings for alcohol and nicotine"
"Naltrexone is a μ-opioid antagonist that can help with weight loss"
"Tramadol is a very weak μ-opioid receptor agonist that also inhibits 5-HT and norepinephrine reuptake"
"What is the clinical use for tramadol? Chronic pain relief"
"In addition to typical opioid adverse effects, tramadol also may cause decreased seizure threshold and serotonin syndrome"
"Butorphanol is a κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor partial agonist"
"What is the clinical use for butorphanol? Severe pain relief (e.g. migraine, labor)"
"Is butorphanol overdose easily reversed with naloxone? No"
"Pentazocine and nalbuphine are κ-opioid receptor agonists and weak μ-opioid receptor antagonists or partial agonists"
"What is the clinical use for pentazocine? Moderate to severe pain relief"
"What type of local anesthetic are procaine, cocaine, tetracaine, and benzocaine? Esters"
"What type of local anesthetic are lidocaine, mepivacaine, and bupivacaine? Amides"
"Local anesthetics exert their actions by blocking Na+ channels (via binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the channel)"
"Local anesthetics are most effective in rapidly::speed-firing neurons"
"Tertiary amine local anesthetics penetrate the cell membrane in a(n) uncharged form and then bind to ion channels in a(n) charged form (charged or uncharged)"
"Local anesthetics are often given with vasoconstrictors to enhance local action"
"What vasoconstrictor is often given with local anesthetics? Epinephrine"
"Are local anesthetics typically acidic or alkaline? Alkaline (tertiary amines)"
"How does the pH change in infected tissue? Decreased (acidic)"
"In infected (acidic) tissue, more local anesthetics are required to achieve the desired effect"
"What size of nerve fiber, small or large diameter, is affected first by local anesthetics? Small-diameter fibers"
"What type of nerve fiber, myelinated or unmyelinated, is affected first by local anesthetics? Myelinated fibers"
"Which nerve fibers (size, myelination) are affected first by local anesthetics? Small, myelinated fibers"
"Would a small, unmyelinated or large, myelinated fiber be affected first by local anesthetics? Small, unmyelinated"
"What sensation is lost first with local anesthetics? Pain"
"Local anesthetics are often used for minor surgical procedures and spinal anesthesia"
"Local anesthetics can cause CNS excitation, which may decrease the seizure threshold"
"Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic that is associated with severe cardiovascular toxicity"
"Cocaine is a local anesthetic that is commonly associated with cardiac arrhythmias"
"Benzocaine is a local anesthetic that is associated with methemoglobinemia as an adverse effect"
"Do local anesthetics cause hypo- or hypertension? Can cause either :)"
"What should be given to a patient who is allergic to ester local anesthetics (e.g. procaine)? Amide anesthetics (e.g. lidocaine)"
"Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant that is used to treat malignant hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome"
"The risk factors for suicide completion may be remembered with the mnemonic \SAD PERSONS\\": S: Sex (male) A: Age (teenage or elderly) D: Depression P: Previous attempt (highest risk factor) E: Ethanol or drug use R: Rational thinking impaired (psychosis) S: Sickness (medical illness) O: Organized plan N: No spouse or other social support S: {{c10::Stated future intent\""
"Which \SAD PERSONS\\" risk factor carries the highest risk for suicide? Previous attempt\""
"Firearms in the house are an independent risk factor for suicide completion"
"What is the most common method of suicide in the U.S.? Firearms"
"Which gender attempts suicide more often? Females"
"Which gender completes suicide more often? Males"
"Anxiety disorders are characterized by an inappropriate experience of fear/worry and physical manifestations incongruent with the magnitude of the perceived stressor"
"Anxiety disorders include panic disorder, phobias, generalized anxiety disorder, and selective mutism"
"Diagnosis of panic disorder requires at least one panic attack, followed by at least one month::duration of preoccupations with the attack"
"The symptoms of panic attacks may be remembered with the mnemonic \PANICS\\": P: Palpitations"
"First-line treatment for panic disorder includes CBT + SSRIs or venlafaxine"
"Panic attacks may be treated acutely with benzodiazepines"
"Specific phobia is defined as severe, persistent fear or anxiety triggered by specific things, situations, or environments for > 6 months::duration"
"Specific phobias can be treated with systematic desensitization therapy (a form of behavioral therapy)"
"Social anxiety disorder is a phobia characterized by exaggerated fear of embarrassment in public situations (e.g. public speaking, using public restrooms)"
"First-line treatment for social anxiety disorder includes CBT + SSRIs or venlafaxine"
"What drugs may be used to treat social anxiety disorder for anxiety-inducing situations? Benzodiazepines or β-blockers::2"
"Agoraphobia is a phobia characterized by irrational fear/anxiety in uncontrollable environments (e.g. wide open or crowed spaces, public transportation)"
"Agoraphobia is associated with panic disorder"
"What is the first-line treatment for agoraphobia? CBT + SSRIs"
"Generalized anxiety disorder is defined as anxiety unrelated to a specific person, situation, or event for > 6 months::duration"
"What is the first line treatment for generalized anxiety disorder? CBT + SSRIs/SNRIs"
"To be diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder, patients must exhibit 3/6 of the following symptoms over course of at least 6 months (mnemonic: Worry WARTS) - Wound up (Irritability) - Worn out (Fatigue) - Absentminded (Difficulty concentrating) - Restlessness - Tension in muscle - Sleep disturbance"
"Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional symptoms (anxiety, depression) that occur within 3 months of an identifiable psychosocial stressor and lasting < 6 months once the stressor has ended"
"If a psychosocial stressor causes continued impairment > 6 months after the stressor ends, it is generalized anxiety disorder"
"What is the treatment for adjustment disorder? SSRIs + CBT; also attempt to address the stressor"
"Obessive-compulsive disorder is characterized by recurring intrusive thoughts, feelings, or sensations that cause severe distress and is temporarily relieved by the performance of repetitive actions"
"Patients with obsessive-compulsive disorder are ego-dystonic"
"First-line treatment for OCD includes CBT + SSRIs (preferred) or clomipramine (not preferred)"
"Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is associated with Tourette's syndrome"
"Body dysmorphic disorder is a preoccupation with a minor or imagined defect in appearance, causing significant emotional distress or impaired functioning"
"What is the treatment for body dysmorphic disorder? CBT"
"Post-traumatic stress disorder is a psychological trauma in response to life threatening situation (witnessing death, serious injury, or sexual violence)"
"The symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) may be remembered with the mnemonic \DREAMS\\": - Disinterest in usual activities"
"PTSD is diagnosed if the disturbance lasts > 1 month::duration with significant distress or impaired social-occupational functioning"
"First-line treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) includes CBT + SSRIs or venlafaxine"
"What drug may be used to reduce nightmares in PTSD? Prazosin"
"Acute stress disorder is characterized by symptoms of PTSD that last between 3 days and 1 month::duration"
"What is the treatment for acute stress disorder? CBT"
"Malingering is when a patient consciously fakes, profoundly exaggerates, or claims to have a disorder in order to attain a secondary (external) gain (e.g. avoid work, obtain compensation)"
"Do the complaints associated with malingering cease after the desired gain? Yes"
"Factitious disorders are when a patient consciously creates physical and/or psychological symptoms in order to assume a \sick role\\" and get medical attention and sympathy (primary/internal gain)\""
"Factitious disorder imposed by self is a factitious disorder characterized by a history of multiple hospital admissions and willingness to undergo invasive procedures"
"Factitious disorder imposed by self is a chronic factitious disorder with predominantly physical signs/symptoms"
"Factitious disorder imposed by self is more common in women::gender and healthcare workers"
"Factitious disorder imposed by another is a factitious disorder characterized by illness in a child or elderly patient that is caused or fabricated by the caregiver"
"Factitious disorder imposed by another is a form of child/elder abuse"
"Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by various unexplained bodily complaints lasting for months and years with persistent thoughts/anxiety about symptoms"
"The illness production and motivation in somatic symptom disorder are unconscious::conscious or unconscious drives"
"Illness anxiety disorder is an excessive preoccupation with acquiring or having a serious illness, often despite medical evaluation and reassurance; minimal somatic symptoms"
"Conversion disorder is a loss of sensory or motor function (e.g. paralysis, blindness, mutism), often following an acute stressor"
"Patients with conversion disorder are often aware but indifferent towards their symptoms (e.g. blindness, mutism); known as \la belle indifference\\"\""
"Conversion (functional neurological symptom) disorder is more common in females::gender, adolescents, and young adults"
"False pregnancy, or pseudocyesis, is the belief that one is pregnant when they aren't really"
"What drug class do fluoxetine and paroxetine belong to? SSRIs"
"What drug class do sertraline and fluvoxamine belong to? SSRIs"
"What drug class do citalopram and escitalopram belong to? SSRIs"
"What drug class do venlafaxine and desvenlafaxine belong to? SNRIs"
"What drug class does duloxetine belong to? SNRIs"
"What drug class do milnacipran and levomilnacipran belong to? SNRIs"
"SSRIs inhibit the pre-synaptic reuptake of serotonin (5-HT)"
"SNRIs inhibit the pre-synaptic reuptake of norepineprine and serotonin"
"What is the first-line pharmacologic treatment for depression? SSRIs"
"What are the first-line pharmacologic treatments for generalized anxiety disorder? SSRIs or SNRIs::2"
"What are the first-line pharmacologic treatments for panic disorder? SSRIs or SNRIs::2"
"What are the first-line pharmacologic treatments for PTSD? SSRIs or venlafaxine::2"
"What is the first-line pharmacologic treatment for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)? SSRIs"
"What is the first-line pharmacologic treatment for bulimia nervosa? SSRIs"
"What are the first-line pharmacologic treatments for social anxiety disorder? SSRIs or venlafaxine::2"
"What sexual dysfunction may be treated with SSRIs? Premature ejaculation"
"SSRIs may be used to treat premenstrual dysphoric disorder, a severe form of premenstrual syndrome (PMS)"
"What diabetes complication can be treated with SNRIs? Diabetic neuropathy"
"SNRIs may be used to treat chronic pain (e.g. neuropathic pain)"
"Duloxetine is an SNRI that is indicated for the treatment of fibromyalgia::musculoskeletal pathology"
"How long do SSRIs and SNRIs take to achieve maximum effect? 1 - 2 months"
"What endocrine pathology is rarely caused by SSRIs? SIADH"
"SSRIs can cause sexual dysfunction, such as anorgasmia and decreased libido"
"SSRIs can cause weight gain"
"Serotonin syndrome is a potentially lethal adverse effect associated with any drug that increases 5-HT"
"What anti-emetic can increase risk for serotonin syndrome? Ondansetron"
"What anti-tussive can increase risk for serotonin syndrome? Dextromethorphan"
"What antibiotic can increase risk for serotonin syndrome? Linezolid"
"The symptoms of serotonin syndrome can be remembered with the \3 A's\\": 1. neuromuscular hyperActivity (clonus"
"What abnormal movement is associated with serotonin syndrome? Clonus"
"Serotonin syndrome is associated with hyper-reflexia"
"Cyproheptadine is a(n) 5-HT2 receptor antagonist used to treat serotonin syndrome"
"What is the most common side effect of SNRIs? Hypertension"
"Sudden discontinuation of SSRIs or SNRIs can cause flu-like symptoms"
"What drug class do amitriptyline and nortriptyline belong to? Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)"
"What drug class do imipramine, desipramine, and clomipramine belong to? Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)"
"What drug class do doxepin and amoxapine belong to? Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)"
"TCAs inhibit the pre-synaptic reuptake of norepineprine and serotonin"
"Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) may be used for treatment-resistant depression"
"What diabetes complication can be treated with TCAs? Diabetic neuropathy"
"TCAs may be used to treat peripheral neuropathy and chronic pain (e.g. neuropathic pain)"
"TCAs, such as amitryptiline, may be used for migraine prophylaxis"
"Clomipramine is a TCA that may be used in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder"
"Imipramine is a TCA that is rarely used to treat nocturnal enuresis"
"Are tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) associated with sexual dysfunction? Yes"
"TCAs may cause anti-cholinergic side effects, such as tachycardia, urinary retention, dry mouth, and confusion"
"Which tricyclic antidepressant has the most anti-cholinergic effects? Amitriptyline (tertiary amine)"
"Which tricyclic antidepressants have the least anti-cholinergic effects? Nortriptyline::secondary amine and desipramine::secondary amine"
"TCAs are relatively contraindicated in elderly patients due to severe anticholinergic and antihistamine effects"
"Tricyclic antidepressants antagonize the H1 histamine receptor"
"Tricyclic antidepressants antagonize the α1 adrenergic receptor"
"What adverse effect is associated with TCAs due to α1 antagonism? Orthostatic hypotension"
"What is the most common cause of death in tricyclic antidepressant overdose? Fatal cardiac arrhythmia"
"TCAs can cause arrhythmias due to fast Na+ channel inhibition in the myocardium"
"TCAs are a class of antidepressants that can cause QT interval prolongation, which precipitates torsades de pointes"
"Arrhythmia secondary to tricyclic antidepressants is prevented with NaHCO3"
"Tricyclic antidepressants are associated with the \Tri-C\\" side effects: Convulsions"
"Adverse effects of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) include respiratory depression and hyperpyrexia"
"What drug class does tranylcypromine belong to? Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs)"
"What drug class does phenelzine belong to? Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs)"
"What drug class does isocarboxazid belong to? Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs)"
"What drug class does selegiline belong to? Selective MAO-B inhibitor"
"Which MAO inhibitors are selective MAO-B inhibitors? Selegiline and rasagiline::2"
"Which neurotransmitter(s) are broken down by monoamine oxidase A (MAO-A)? Serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine"
"Which neurotransmitter(s) are metabolized by monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B)? Dopamine"
"Are MAO inhibitors reversible or irreversible? Irreversible"
"Do MAO inhibitors typically inhibit MAO-A or MAO-B? Both :) (non-selective)"
"MAO inhibitors may be used to treat anxiety and treatment-resistant atypical depression (not first line)"
"Selegiline is a(n) MAO-B inhibitor used to treat Parkinson disease"
"Tyramine is a substance found in many aged foods (e.g. cheese, meats, alcohol)"
"Tyramine is metabolized by the enzyme MAO-A in the GI tract"
"In the presence of MAO inhibitors, tyramine enters the circulation and acts as a(n) sympathomimetic agent"
"Tyramine toxicity in patients on MAO inhibitors can precipitate hypertensive crisis"
"Phentolamine is an α1 and α2 antagonist that can be used to manage the hypertensive symptoms of tyramine toxicity"
"MAO inhibitors may cause CNS stimulation::stimulation or depression"
"MAO inhibitors are contraindicated in patients taking St. John's wort, which is a medicinal herb with antidepressant activity"
"MAO inhibitors are contraindicated in patients taking the anti-tussive dextromethorphan"
"MAO inhibitors are contraindicated in patients taking the opioid analgesic meperidine"
"Patients must wait 2 weeks after stopping MAO inhibitors before starting serotonergic drugs and/or stopping dietary restrictions"
"What drug class does bupropion belong to? Atypical antidepressants"
"Bupropion inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine"
"What sleep disturbance is associated with bupropion use? Insomnia"
"Bupropion may be used for smoking cessation"
"Bupropion may cause seizures, especially in anorexic or bulimic patients"
"Which atypical antidepressant may cause seizures in anorexic/bulimic patients? Bupropion"
"Is bupropion use associated with sexual dysfunction? No"
"Compared to other antidepressants, bupropion is less likely to cause weight gain"
"What drug class does mirtazapine belong to? Atypical antidepressants"
"Mirtazapine is a(n) α2-adrenergic antagonist, which increases pre-synaptic release of serotonin and norepinephrine"
"Which serotonin receptors are inhibited by mirtazapine? 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 receptors::2"
"Mirtazapine is a(n) H1 histamine receptor antagonist"
"Mirtazapine can cause sedation, which may be desirable in depressed patients with insomnia"
"Which atypical antidepressant is useful for treating depressed patients with insomnia? Mirtazapine"
"Mirtazapine causes increased appetite and weight gain"
"Which atypical antidepressant is useful for treating anorexic or elderly depressed patients? Mirtazapine"
"Is mirtazapine use associated with sexual dysfunction? No"
"Mirtazapine may cause dry mouth as an adverse effect"
"What drug class does trazodone belong to? Atypical antidepressants"
"Trazodone is a(n) α1-adrenergic antagonist"
"Which serotonin receptor is inhibited by trazodone? 5-HT2"
"Trazodone is a(n) H1 histamine receptor antagonist"
"Trazodone weakly inhibits the pre-synaptic reuptake of serotonin (5-HT)"
"Trazodone can cause orthostatic hypotension::BP as an adverse effect"
"Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant that is primarily used to treat insomnia"
"Is trazodone use associated with sexual dysfunction? Yes"
"What drug class does vilazodone belong to? Atypical antidepressants"
"Vilazodone inhibits the pre-synaptic reuptake of serotonin (5-HT)"
"Vilazodone is a(n) 5-HT1A receptor partial agonist"
"Vilazodone is primarily used to treat major depressive disorder and generalized anxiety disorder (off-label)"
"Adverse effects of vilazodone include anti-cholinergic effects and weight gain"
"What drug class does vortioxetine belong to? Atypical antidepressants"
"Vortioxetine inhibits the pre-synaptic reuptake of serotonin (5-HT)"
"Vortioxetine is a(n) 5-HT1A receptor agonist"
"Vortioxetine is a(n) 5-HT3 receptor antagonist"
"Adverse effects of vortioxetine include anti-cholinergic effects, sleep disturbances (abnormal dreams), and sexual dysfunction"
"What risk factor leads to Pseudomonas infection of the cornea, causing corneal ulcers/keratitis? Contact lens wearers"
"Buspirone exerts its effects via stimulation of the 5-HT1A receptor"
"Buspirone is primarily used to treat generalized anxiety disorder (2nd line)"
"Does buspirone use lead to tolerance and/or addiction? No"
"Does buspirone cause sedation as an adverse effect? No"
"Does buspirone interact with alcohol? No"
"What is the general treatment for bipolar disorder? Mood stabilizers"
"Lithium is an ion that is used as a mood stabilizer for bipolar disorder"
"Is lithium used to prevent relapse or treat acute mania in bipolar disorder? Both :)"
"The mechanism of action of lithium may be related to inhibition of the IP3 signaling pathway"
"Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index"
"Acute lithium toxicity presents with GI symptoms"
"Chronic lithium toxicity causes neurologic symptoms, such as tremor and ataxia"
"Lithium is a mood stabilizer that may cause hypo-thyroidism as an adverse effect"
"What type of diabetes is associated with lithium use? Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus"
"Renal clearance of lithium is reduced in patients taking thiazide diuretics or other nephrotoxic agents (e.g. NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors)"
"What teratogenic effect is associated with maternal lithium use? Ebstein anomaly"
"Which mood stabilizer is associated with ebstein anomaly in newborns? Lithium"
"Lithium is almost exclusively excreted by the kidneys"
"What part of the nephron is lithium primarily reabsorbed? PCT (with Na+)"
"What anti-epileptics may be used in the treatment of bipolar disorder? Valproate, carbamazepine, and lamotrigine"
"Is valproate used to prevent relapse or treat acute mania in bipolar disorder? Both :)"
"Is carbamazepine used to prevent relapse or treat acute mania in bipolar disorder? Both :)"
"Is lamotrigine used to prevent relapse or treat acute mania in bipolar disorder? Prevent relapse (maintenance), only"
"In addition to mood stabilizers, bipolar disorder may also be treated with antipsychotics"
"Are antipsychotics used to prevent relapse or treat acute mania in bipolar disorder? Acute mania, only"
"Valproic acid is a(n) broad spectrum anti-epileptic"
"What type(s) of seizures (partial, tonic-clonic, or absence) may be treated with valproic acid? All three (partial, tonic-clonic, absence)"
"Valproic acid and phenytoin are first-line agents for treatment of acute tonic-clonic seizures"
"Valproic acid exerts its effects by increasing Na+ channel inactivation and inhibiting GABA transaminase"
"Valproic acid increases levels of GABA in the CNS via inhibition of GABA transaminase"
"Valproic acid is an anti-epileptic that may cause GI distress and pancreatitis as adverse effects"
"Valproic acid causes increased appetite and weight gain"
"Valproic acid can cause neurologic side effects, such as tremor"
"Valproic acid is an anti-epileptic that rarely causes a fatal hepatotoxicity"
"What teratogenic effect is associated with valproic acid? Neural tube defects (e.g. spina bifida)"
"Valproic acid is useful in the management of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy"
"Valproic acid and topiramate are anti-epileptics that are useful for migraine prophylaxis"
"Topiramate is a(n) broad spectrum anti-epileptic"
"What type(s) of seizures (partial, tonic-clonic, or absence) may be treated with topiramate? Partial and tonic-clonic"
"Topiramate exerts its effects by increasing Na+ channel inactivation"
"Topiramate increases GABA action via allosterically binding to the GABAA receptor"
"Topiramate increases GABA action and thus may cause sedation and fatigue as adverse effects"
"Topiramate may cause confusion and cognitive slowing as adverse effects"
"Topiramate is an anti-epileptic associated with weight loss"
"What renal complication may be caused by topiramate? Kidney stones"
"Topiramate is an anti-epileptic that may cause myopia and acute angle closure glaucoma (eye complications)"
"Lamotrigine is a(n) broad spectrum anti-epileptic"
"What type(s) of seizures (partial, tonic-clonic, or absence) may be treated with lamotrigine? All three (partial, tonic-clonic, absence)"
"Lamotrigine exerts its effects by increasing Na+ channel inactivation"
"What is the most serious adverse effect associated with lamotrigine use? Stevens-Johnson syndrome"
"Levetiracetam is a(n) broad spectrum anti-epileptic"
"What type(s) of seizures (partial, tonic-clonic, or absence) may be treated with levetiracetam? Partial and tonic-clonic"
"Adverse effects associated with levetiracetam use include somnolence and neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g. behavioral change)"
"Carbamazepine is a(n) narrow spectrum anti-epileptic"
"What type(s) of seizures (partial, tonic-clonic, or absence) may be treated with carbamazepine? Partial and tonic-clonic"
"What is the first line treatment for partial (focal) seizures? Carbamazepine"
"Carbamazepine exerts its effects by blocking Na+ channels"
"What is the first line treatment for trigeminal neuralgia? Carbamazepine"
"Non-specific adverse effects associated with carbamazepine include diplopia and ataxia"
"What endocrine pathology may be caused by carbamazepine use? SIADH"
"Carbamazepine is an anti-epileptic associated with blood dyscrasias, such as aplastic anemia and agranulocytosis"
"Carbamazepine is a(n) inducer of cytochrome P450 and thus may have many drug interactions"
"Which anti-epileptic is most associated with DRESS syndrome (Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms)? Phenytoin"
"Is carbamazepine use associated with teratogenic effects? Yes"
"What dermatologic complication is associated with carbamazepine use? Stevens-Johnson syndrome"
"Carbamazepine is associated with liver toxicity as an adverse effect"
"Phenytoin is a(n) narrow spectrum anti-epileptic"
"What type(s) of seizures (partial, tonic-clonic, or absence) may be treated with phenytoin? Partial and tonic-clonic"
"Phenytoin exerts its effects by blocking Na+ channels"
"Adverse effects associated with phenytoin include diplopia and nystagmus (eye complications)"
"Phenytoin may cause neurologic side effects, such as peripheral neuropathy and ataxia"
"What hematologic complication is associated with phenytoin? Megaloblastic anemia::not lupus"
"Phenytoin is an anti-epileptic associated with gingival hyperplasia"
"Phenytoin is an anti-epileptic associated with hirsutism in women"
"What dermatologic complication is associated with phenytoin use? Stevens-Johnson syndrome"
"What teratogenic effect is associated with maternal phenytoin use? Fetal hydantoin syndrome"
"Phenytoin is a(n) inducer of cytochrome P450 and thus may have many drug interactions"
"Phenytoin is an anti-epileptic associated with osteopenia::bone complication"
"Which anti-epileptic is most associated with drug-induced lupus? Phenytoin"
"Phenytoin is first line for prophylaxis of status epilepticus"
"Stevens-Johnson syndrome in patients taking carbamazepine or phenytoin is associated with HLA-B1502, which is typically seen in those of Asian ancestry"
"Which anti-epileptic is eliminated via zero order kinetics? Phenytoin"
"Gabapentin is a(n) narrow spectrum anti-epileptic"
"Gabapentin is an anti-epileptic that exerts its effects by blocking voltage-gated Ca2+ channels"
"What type(s) of seizures (partial, tonic-clonic, or absence) may be treated with gabapentin? Partial"
"Which anti-epileptic may be used to treat peripheral neuropathy and fibromyalgia (chronic pain)? Gabapentin"
"Gabapentin is an anti-epileptic that may be used to treat post-herpetic neuralgia"
"Adverse effects of gabapentin include sedation and ataxia"
"Vigabatrin and tiagabine are narrow spectrum anti-epileptics"
"Vigabatrin is an anti-epileptic that exerts its effects via inhibition of the enzyme GABA transaminase"
"What serious adverse effect may be caused by vigabatrin use? Permanent vision loss (black box warning)"
"Tiagabine is an anti-epileptic that exerts its effects by inhibiting GABA reuptake"
"What type(s) of seizures (partial, tonic-clonic, or absence) may be treated with vigabatrin and tiagabine? Partial"
"Ethosuximide is the first line treatment for absence seizures"
"Ethosuximide exerts its effects by blocking T-type Ca2+::specific channels in the thalamus"
"The side effects of ethosuximide may be remembered with the letters of the alphabet \EFGHIJ\\": E: Ethosuximide F: Fatigue G: GI distress H: Headache I: Itching/urticaria J: Stevens-Johnson syndrome\""
"In addition to ethosuximide, absence seizures may also be treated with valproic acid and lamotrigine"
"A(n) personality disorder is an inflexible, maladaptive, and rigidly pervasive pattern of behavior causing subjective distress and/or impaired functioning"
"Are patients with personality disorders usually aware of their problem? No"
"People with cluster A personality disorders are described as odd or eccentric"
"Which cluster of personality disorders is characterized by an inability to develop meaningful relationships? Cluster A"
"Cluster A personality disorders have a genetic association with schizophrenia"
"Cluster A personality disorders lack psychosis, which is a distinguishing feature from schizophrenia"
"Which personality disorder is characterized by pervasive distrust and suspiciousness of others, with a profoundly cynical view of the world? Paranoid (cluster A)"
"Which personality disorder is characterized by voluntary social withdrawal with limited emotional expression? Schizoid (cluster A)"
"Are patients with schizoid personality disorder content with social isolation? Yes"
"Which personality disorder is characterized by eccentric appearance, interpersonal awkwardness, and odd beliefs/magical thinking? Schizotypal (cluster A)"
"People with cluster B personality disorders are described as dramatic, emotional, or erratic"
"Cluster B personality disorders have a genetic association with mood disorders and substance abuse"
"Which personality disorder is characterized by impulsivity, criminality, and disregard for/violation of rights of others with lack of remorse? Antisocial (cluster B)"
"Antisocial personality disorder is more common in males::gender"
"Antisocial personality disorder can only be diagnosed if the patient is > 18 years old and has a history of conduct disorder before age 15"
"Which personality disorder is characterized by unstable mood and relationships and a sense of emptiness? Borderline (cluster B)"
"Which cluster B personality disorder has a high rate of self-mutilation and suicide? Borderline"
"Borderline personality disorder is more common in females::gender"
"What is the treatment for borderline personality disorder? Dialectical behavioral therapy"
"Which personality disorder is characterized by excessive emotionality/excitability and sexually provocative behavior? Histrionic (cluster B)"
"Patients with histrionic personality disorder are attention seeking, sexually provocative, and overly concerned with appearance"
"Which personality disorder is characterized by grandiosity, sense of entitlement, and lack of empathy? Narcissistic (cluster B)"
"Patients with narcissistic personality disorder often require excessive admiration and react to criticism with rage"
"People with cluster C personality disorders are described as anxious or fearful"
"Cluster C personality disorders have a genetic association with anxiety disorders"
"Which personality disorder is characterized by social withdrawal with hypersensitivity to rejection and feelings of inadequacy? Avoidant (cluster C)"
"Are patients with avoidant personality disorder content with social isolation? No"
"Which personality disorder is characterized by preoccupation with order, perfectionism, and control? Obsessive-compulsive (cluster C)"
"Patients with obsessive compulsive personality disorder are ego-syntonic, which means their behavior is consistent with their own beliefs or attitudes"
"Which personality disorder is characterized by low-self confidence with an excessive need to be taken care of? Dependent (cluster C)"
"Patients with dependent personality disorder are typically submissive and clingy"
"Patients with dependent personality disorder often get stuck in abusive relationships"
"What demographic is associated with eating disorders? Young females"
"Anorexia nervosa is defined as excessive dieting, exercise, or binge eating/purging with BMI < 18.5 kg/m2"
"Anorexia nervosa/strenuous exercise is associated with amenorrhea due to loss of pulsatile GnRH secretion"
"Anorexia nervosa may present with lanugo, which is the presence of soft, fine white hairs along the body"
"Which eating disorder is associated with functional hypothalamic amenorrhea and lanugo? Anorexia nervosa"
"Anorexia nervosa may present with anemia::RBC count and electrolyte disturbances"
"Anorexia nervosa is associated with decreased bone density and metatarsal stress fractures"
"Anorexia nervosa commonly coexists with depression"
"What is the first line therapy for anorexia nervosa? Nutritional rehabilitation and psychotherapy"
"What pharmacotherapy may be used to treat anorexia nervosa? SSRIs or Olanzapine::2"
"Because of the large electrolyte abnormalities in refeeding syndrome, patients can present with arrhythmias::cardiac, rhabdomyolysis, and seizures"
"The massive insulin surge in refeeding syndrome results in hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia"
"Bulimia nervosa is defined as binge eating with recurrent inappropriate compensatory behaviors occurring weekly for at least 3 months::duration"
"Patients with bulimia nervosa often have body weights within normal ranges"
"Bulimia nervosa is associated with parotitis and enamel erosion due to excessive vomiting"
"Which eating disorder is associated with parotitis and enamel erosion and normal weight? Bulimia nervosa"
"Bulimia nervosa is characterized by electrolyte disturbances and metabolic alkalosis"
"Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder that may present with dorsal hand calluses from induced vomiting (Russell sign)"
"Treatment for bulimia nervosa may include psychotherapy, nutritional rehabilitation, and SSRIs (specifically fluoxetine)"
"Binge eating disorder is characterized by regular episodes of excessive, uncontrollable eating without inappropriate compensatory behaviors"
"Binge eating disorder is associated with increased risk for obesity and diabetes mellitus"
"Treatment for binge eating disorder is CBT +/- SSRIs or lisdexamfetamine"
"Gender dysphoria is persistent cross-gender identification that leads to persistent distress with sex assigned at birth"
"Transgenderism is the desire to live as the opposite sex, often through surgery or hormone treatment"
"Transvestism is sexual pleasure from dressing as the opposite sex (cross-dressing)"
"Sexual dysfunction includes sexual desire disorders, such as hypoactive sexual desire and sexual aversion"
"Sexual dysfunction includes sexual arousal disorders, such as erectile dysfunction"
"Sexual dysfunction includes orgasmic disorders, such as anorgasmia and premature ejaculation"
"Sexual dysfunction includes sexual pain disorders, such as dyspareunia and vaginismus"
"Do patients with erectile dysfunction due to psychological etiologies have nocturnal penile tumescence? Yes"
"Do patients with erectile dysfunction due to medical etiologies have nocturnal penile tumescence? No"
"Sleep terror disorder is characterized by inconsolable periods of terror with screaming in the middle of the night (stage N3 sleep)"
"What demographic is associated with sleep terror disorder? Children::age group"
"Do patients with sleep terror disorder have any memory of the arousal episode? No"
"Do patients with nightmares have any memory of the scary dream? Yes"
"The primary symptoms of narcolepsy are excessive daytime sleepiness and sleep attacks"
"Narcolepsy is caused by decreased hypocretin (orexin) production in the lateral hypothalamus"
"Narcolepsy is associated with hallucinations (e.g. hypnagogic and hypnopompic)"
"Narcolepsy is characterized by nocturnal and narcoleptic sleep episodes that start with REM sleep (sleep paralysis)"
"Narcolepsy is associated with cataplexy, which is the loss of all muscle tone following a strong emotional stimulus (e.g. laughter)"
"Does narcolepsy have a strong or weak genetic component? Strong"
"Treatment of narcolepsy involves daytime stimulants (e.g. amphetamines, modafinil)"
"Treatment of narcolepsy involves nighttime sodium oxybate (GHB)"
"Substance use disorder is defined as > 2 of the following signs in 1 year related specifically to substance use: Tolerance Withdrawal Substance taken in larger amounts than desired Persistent desire or unsuccessful attempts to cut down Significant energy spent obtaining, using, or recovering from substance Important social, occupational, or recreational activities reduced Continued use despite knowing it causes problems Craving Recurrent use in physically dangerous situations Failure to fulfill major obligations at work, school, or home Social or interpersonal conflicts"
"Which stage of change is characterized by not yet acknowledging that there is a problem? Precontemplation"
"Which stage of change is characterized by acknowledging there's a problem, BUT not yet ready or willing to make a change? Contemplation"
"Which stage of change is characterized by getting ready to change behavior? Preparation/determination"
"Which stage of change is characterized by changing behaviors? Action/will power"
"Which stage of change is characterized by maintaining the behavioral changes? Maintenance"
"Which stages of change is characterized by returning to old behaviors and abandoning new changes? Relapse (does not always happen)"
"What drug class do haloperidol and pimozide belong to? Typical antipsychotics (1st generation)"
"What drug class do trifluoperazine, fluphenazine, thioridazine, and chlorpromazine belong to? Typical antipsychotics (1st generation)"
"Typical antipsychotics exert their effects by blocking the D2 dopamine receptor"
"Typical antipsychotics result in increased cAMP::second messenger"
"The high potency typical antipsychotics are trifluoperazine, fluphenazine, and haloperidol"
"The low potency typical antipsychotics are chlorpromazine and thioridazine"
"Are typical antipsychotics effective at treating the positive or negative symptoms of schizophrenia? Positive"
"In addition to schizophrenia, typical antipsychotics are used to treat psychosis in many conditions (e.g. bipolar disorder, delirium)"
"Typical and atypical antipsychotics may be used to treat intractable or distressing tics associated with Tourette's syndrome"
"Typical antipsychotics have high lipid solubility and thus long half lives"
"Typical antipsychotics are associated with anti-cholinergic effects, such as dry mouth and constipation"
"Are anti-cholinergic effects more common with high or low potency typical antipsychotics? Low potency"
"Typical antipsychotics are associated with anti-histamine effects, such as sedation"
"Are anti-histamine effects more common with high or low potency typical antipsychotics? Low potency"
"Typical antipsychotics are associated with α1-adrenergic blockade, which may cause orthostatic hypotension"
"Are anti-α1 effects more common with high or low potency typical antipsychotics? Low potency"
"Typical antipsychotics are associated with extrapyramidal symptoms, such as acute dystonia, akathisia, and Parkinsonism"
"Are extrapyramidal symptoms more common with high or low potency typical antipsychotics? High potency"
"Which extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g. due to antipsychotic use) occur within minutes to days? Acute dystonia"
"Which extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g. due to antipsychotic use) occur within days to months? Akathisia (restlessness) and parkinsonism"
"Which extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g. due to antipsychotic use) occur within months to years? Tardive dyskinesia"
"The extrapyramidal symptoms of antipsychotics may be managed with an M1 antagonist such as benztropine"
"Typical antipsychotics may cause symptoms of prolactin excess (e.g. galactorrhea, amenorrhea, gynecomastia)"
"What is the most serious adverse effect associated with antipsychotics? Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS)"
"The symptoms of neuroleptic malignant syndrome may be remembered with the mnemonic \Malignant FEVER\\": M: Myoglobinuria F: Fever E: Encephalopathy (altered mental status) V: unstable Vitals (autonomic instability) E: increased Enzymes (e.g. CK) R: muscle Rigidity\""
"Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is often characterized by a generalized \lead-pipe\\" rigidity\""
"Neuroleptic malignant syndrome may be treated with dantrolene* or a(n) D2 agonist"
"What adverse cardiac effect is associated with both typical and atypical antipsychotics? QT interval prolongation"
"Typical antipsychotics may cause a decreased seizure threshold"
"The typical antipsychotic chlorpromazine is associated with corneal deposits"
"The typical antipsychotic thioridazine is associated with retinal deposits"
"What drug class do asenapine, clozapine, olanzapine, and quetiapine belong to? Atypical antipsychotics (2nd generation)"
"What drug class do iloperidone, paliperidone, and risperidone belong to? Atypical antipsychotics (2nd generation)"
"What drug class do lurasidone and ziprasidone belong to? Atypical antipsychotics (2nd generation)"
"What drug class does aripiprazole belong to? Atypical antipsychotics (2nd generation)"
"Most atypical antipsychotics exert their effects by blocking the D2 dopamine receptor"
"Which serotonin receptor is antagonized by many atypical antipsychotics? 5-HT2A"
"Are atypical antipsychotics effective at treating the positive or negative symptoms of schizophrenia? Both :)"
"In addition to schizophrenia, atypical antipsychotics are used to treat treatment-resistant depression"
"What is the treatment of choice for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder? Clozapine"
"Which atypical antipsychotic is used for suicidality in schizophrenia? Clozapine"
"Compared to typical antipsychotics, atypical antipsychotics cause less::more/less anti-cholinergic side effects"
"Compared to typical antipsychotics, atypical antipsychotics cause less::more/less anti-histamine side effects"
"Compared to typical antipsychotics, atypical antipsychotics cause less::more/less anti-α1 side effects"
"Compared to typical antipsychotics, atypical antipsychotics are more::more/less likely to cause metabolic syndrome"
"Atypical antipsychotics may cause metabolic syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, dyslipidemia, and hyperglycemia"
"Which atypical antipsychotics are most associated with metabolic syndrome? \-pines\\" (esp. clozapine and olanzapine)\""
"Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that may cause agranulocytosis::hematologic complication"
"Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that may cause myocarditis and cardiomyopathy (cardiac complications)"
"Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic associated with a dose dependent risk for seizures::neurologic complication"
"Compared to typical antipsychotics, atypical antipsychotics are less::more/less likely to cause extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS)"
"Compared to typical antipsychotics, atypical antipsychotics are less::more/less likely to cause neuroleptic malignant syndrome"
"Levodopa (L-DOPA) is a precursor of dopamine that does cross the blood-brain-barrier"
"Once in the CNS, L-DOPA may be converted to dopamine via the enzyme DOPA decarboxylase"
"Peripheral conversion of levodopa may cause GI distress"
"Peripheral conversion of levodopa may cause cardiac arrhythmias"
"Peripheral conversion of levodopa may cause orthostatic hypotension::BP"
"Chronic levodopa use can cause a \wearing-off reaction\\""
"Chronic levodopa use can cause an \on-off phenomenon\\""
"Chronic levodopa therapy can cause dyskinesias, such as choreoathetosis of the face and distal extremities"
"Levodopa and other Parkinson's disease therapies are contraindicated in psychotic patients"
"Carbidopa is a peripheral DOPA decarboxylase inhibitor used to increase the bioavailability of levodopa"
"Carbidopa decreases the peripheral side effects of levodopa"
"Carbidopa exacerbates the neuropsychiatric side effects of levodopa"
"Dopamine in the CNS may be degraded to 3-methoxytyramine (3-MT) via the enzyme catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT)"
"Tolcapone is a peripheral and central COMT inhibitor used to increase the bioavailability of levodopa"
"Entacapone is a peripheral COMT inhibitor used to increase the bioavailability of levodopa"
"Tolcapone increases dopamine levels in the CNS"
"Tolcapone can cause hepatic failure as an adverse effect"
"Dopamine in the CNS may be degraded to DOPAC via the enzyme MAO-B"
"Selegiline and rasagiline may exacerbate the adverse effects of levodopa"
"Bromocriptine is an ergot dopamine agonist that is rarely used to treat Parkinson disease"
"Ropinirole is a non-ergot D2 receptor agonist that is used in initial treatment of Parkinson disease"
"Pramipexole is a non-ergot D3 receptor agonist that is used in initial treatment of Parkinson disease"
"What is the first line treatment for restless leg syndrome? Dopamine receptor agonists (ropinirole, pramipexole)"
"Dopamine receptor agonists, such as ropinirole, may increase impulse activities (e.g. gambling, shopping, hypersexuality)"
"Which anti-influenza agent is useful in the management of Parkinson disease? Amantadine"
"Amantadine increases dopamine synthesis and release"
"Amantadine inhibits dopamine reuptake"
"Adverse effects associated with amantadine include ataxia and livedo reticularis"
"Benztropine and trihexyphenidyl are antimuscarinic agents used to treat Parkinsonism, especially tremor and rigidity"
"Trihexyphenidyl and benztropine are useful for treating the tremor and rigidity of Parkinson disease"
"Trihexyphenidyl and benztropine are NOT useful for treating the bradykinesia of Parkinson disease"
"Non-specific symptoms of depressant intoxication (stimulant or depressant) include anxiolysis, disinhibition, respiratory depression, and mood elevation"
"Non-specific symptoms of depressant withdrawal (stimulant or depressant) include anxiety, tremor, insomnia, and seizures"
"Whichdrug intoxication presents as emotional lability, slurred speech, ataxia, and blackouts? Alcohol"
"Serum γ-glutamyltransferase (GGT) is a sensitive indicator of alcohol use"
"What AST to ALT ratio is indicative of alcohol abuse? >2:1 ratio of AST:ALT"
"What symptoms of alcohol withdrawal occur during the 3 - 36 hour time period? Non-specific depressant withdrawal symptoms"
"The non-specific depressant symptoms of alcohol withdrawal usually occur 3 to 36 hours after the last drink"
"What symptoms of alcohol withdrawal occur during the 6 - 48 hour time period? Withdrawal seizures"
"The seizures of alcohol withdrawal usually occur 6 to 48 hours after the last drink"
"What symptoms of alcohol withdrawal occur during the 12 - 48 hour time period? Alcoholic hallucinosis (usually visual)"
"The alcoholic hallucinosis of alcohol withdrawal usually occurs 12 to 48 hours after the last drink"
"What symptoms of alcohol withdrawal may occur during the 48 - 96 hour time period? Delirium tremens (5% of cases)"
"Delirium tremens, secondary to alcohol withdrawal, usually occurs 48 to 96 hours after the last drink"
"Delirium tremens is characterized by autonomic hyper-activity"
"Delirium tremens is characterized by electrolyte disturbances and respiratory alkalosis::acidosis or alkalosis"
"Delirium tremens classically occurs in a(n) hospital setting"
"What is the treatment for alcohol withdrawal? Benzodiazepines"
"What is the treatment for delirium tremens? Benzodiazepines"
"What drug intoxication presents as respiratory and CNS depression, pinpoint pupils and decreased gag reflex? Opioids"
"Opioid intoxication presents with pupillary constriction"
"What drug withdrawal is associated with yawning? Opioid withdrawal"
"What drug withdrawal is associated with nausea, stomach cramps, and diarrhea? Opioid withdrawal"
"What drug withdrawal is associated with piloerection (\cold turkey\\")? Opioid withdrawal\""
"Opioid withdrawal presents with pupillary dilation"
"What drug class is the most common cause of drug overdose death? Opioids (e.g. heroin)"
"What is the treatment for opioid overdose? Naloxone"
"Methadone is a long-acting oral opiate used for opioid detoxification or long-term maintenance therapy"
"What drug combination may be used for maintenance therapy following opioid detoxification? Buprenorphine plus naloxone"
"Naltrexone is a long-acting opioid antagonist used for relapse prevention once detoxified from opiates"
"What drug intoxication carries the highest risk for respiratory depression? Barbiturates"
"Barbiturate withdrawal may present with delirium and life-threatening cardiovascular collapse"
"Non-specific symptoms of stimulant::stimulant or depressant intoxication include psychomotor agitation, tachycardia, arrhythmias and anxiety"
"Non-specific symptoms of stimulant withdrawal (stimulant or depressant) include post-use \crash\\""
"What drug intoxication presents as pupillary dilation, grandiosity, hypertension, and paranoia that lasts for multiple hours? Amphetamines"
"Severe intoxication of amphetamines may cause seizures and cardiac arrest"
"What is the treatment for amphetamine intoxication? Benzodiazepines"
"What drug intoxication presents as pupillary dilation, grandiosity, vasospasm, and paranoia that lasts for less than one hour? Cocaine"
"What is the most lethal complication of cocaine intoxication? Sudden cardiac death"
"What is the treatment for cocaine intoxication? Benzodiazepines, α-blockers"
"Cocaine and amphetamine intoxication cause pupillary dilation"
"Nicotine withdrawal may be treated using nicotine replacement, bupropion, or varenicline"
"What drug intoxication presents as violence, psychomotor agitation, analgesia, and nystagmus? Phencyclidine (PCP)"
"What eye movement is associated with phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication? Nystagmus"
"What is the most common complication of PCP intoxication? Trauma"
"What is the treatment for PCP intoxication? Benzodiazepines, rapid-acting antipsychotics"
"What drug intoxication presents as perceptual distortion (visual, auditory), depersonalization, and possible flashbacks? LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide)"
"What drug intoxication presents as conjunctival injection, tachycardia, increased appetite, paranoid delusions, and dry mouth? Marijuana"
"Marijuana withdrawal may cause irritability, anxiety, depression, insomnia, and decreased appetite"
"What is the pharmaceutical form of marijuana? Dronabinol"
"Dronabinol (medical marijuana) is used clinically as a(n) antiemetic for chemotherapy"
"Dronabinol (medical marijuana) is used clinically as a(n) appetite stimulant for AIDS patients"
"What drug intoxication presents as disinhibition, heightened emotional/tactile sensation, and teeth clenching? MDMA (ecstasy)"
"Life-threatening effects of MDMA (ecstasy) include hyperthermia and hyponatremia::Na+ levels"
"Life-threatening effects of MDMA (ecstasy) include serotonin syndrome"
"Long-term pharmacologic treatment of alcoholism may include disulfiram, which acts a deterrent"
"Long-term pharmacologic treatment of alcoholism may include naltrexone or acamprosate, which reduce cravings"
"What neurologic complication is associated with opioid overdose? Seizures"
"Indirect cholinomimetics exert their effects via inhibition of the enzyme acetylcholinesterase (AChE)"
"Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors lead to increased levels of acetylcholine"
"What drug class do neostigmine, physostigmine, and pyridostigmine belong to? Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors"
"What drug class does edrophonium belong to? Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor"
"Do acetylcholinesterase inhibitors enhance ACh activity at muscarinic or nicotinic receptors? Both :)"
"Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease due to production of antibodies against post-synaptic nicotinic ACh receptors at motor end plates"
"Pyridostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that is used as long-acting treatment for myasthenia gravis"
"Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that is less commonly used to treat myasthenia gravis"
"Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that was historically used to diagnose myasthenia gravis"
"The tensilon test uses edrophonium to help diagnose myasthenia gravis"
"Diagnosis of myasthenia gravis with edrophonium has been replaced by anti-AChR-Ab tests"
"If a patient with myasthenia gravis experiences muscle weakness due to under-treatment, edrophonium will reverse the muscle weakness"
"If a patient with myasthenia gravis experiences muscle weakness due to over-treatment, edrophonium will NOT reverse the muscle weakness"
"Pyridostigmine, neostigmine, and edrophonium are quaternary amines and thus do NOT penetrate the CNS"
"What drug class is used to reverse the effects of neuromuscular junction blockade? Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (e.g. neostigmine)"
"Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors may be used to treat post-operative and neurogenic ileus"
"Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors may be used to treat urinary retention"
"Physostigmine is a(n) tertiary amine and thus DOES penetrate the CNS"
"Physostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that may be used to treat atropine overdose"
"Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor poisoning causes flaccid paralysis due to NMJ nicotinic ACh receptor overactivation"
"Organophosphates are a type of acetylcholinesterase inhibitor found in many insectisides"
"Parathion, malathion, and echothiophate are all examples of organophosphates"
"Do organophosphates (e.g. parathion) reversibly or irreversibly inhibit AChE? Irreversibly (with time)"
"What demographic is associated with organophosphate poisoning? Farmers"
"Organophosphate toxicity may be treated with pralidoxime, which regenerates AChE at muscarinic and nicotinic receptors if given early"
"Does pralidoxime reverse the flaccid paralysis associated with cholinesterase inhibitor poisoning? Yes"
"Organophosphate toxicity may be treated with atropine, which is a competitive inhibitor at muscarinic receptors only"
"Does atropine reverse the flaccid paralysis associated with cholinesterase inhibitor poisoning? No, only effective at muscarinic receptors"
"Which cholinesterase inhibitor poisoning antidote reverses the central muscarinic effects? Atropine"
"Aging of the organophosphate-cholinesterase complex leads to irreversible binding"
"What is a lethal complication of cholinesterase inhibitor poisoning if untreated? Respiratory failure"
"What drug class do galantamine and tacrine belong to? Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors"
"What drug class does rivastigmine belong to? Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor"
"What drug class does donepezil belong to? Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor"
"What is the clinical use for galantamine, rivastigmine, donepezil and tacrine? Alzheimer's disease"
"Memantine is a(n) NMDA receptor antagonist used to treat Alzheimer's disease"
"Memantine helps prevent excitotoxicity (mediated by Ca2+) in Alzheimer's disease"
"Riluzole is a treatment for ALS that increases survival by decreasing glutamate excitotoxicity"
"Huntington disease may be treated with tetrabenazine or reserpine, which inhibit VMAT, decreasing dopamine vesicle packaging and release"
"What D2 receptor antagonist is used to treat Huntington disease? Haloperidol (typical antipsychotic)"
"Neuromuscular blocking drugs are used to induce muscle paralysis for surgery or mechanical ventilation"
"Neuromuscular blocking drugs are selective for NM nicotinic receptors"
"Which neuromuscular blocking drug is characterized as depolarizing? Succinylcholine"
"Succinylcholine is a strong ACh receptor agonist that produces sustained depolarization and prevents muscle contraction"
"Phase I of succinylcholine-induced neuromuscular blockade is characterized as prolonged depolarization"
"Phase II of succinylcholine-induced neuromuscular blockade is characterized as repolarized but blocked"
"What is used to reverse phase I of succinylcholine-induced neuromuscular blockade? No antidote"
"What is used to reverse phase II of succinylcholine-induced neuromuscular blockade? Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors"
"Complications of succinylcholine include hyper-calcemia, hyper-kalemia, and malignant hyperthermia"
"Atracurium and mivacurium are non-depolarizing::depolarizing or non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents"
"Pancuronium, vecuronium, and rocuronium are non-depolarizing::depolarizing or non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents"
"Tubocurarine is a(n) non-depolarizing::depolarizing or non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent"
"The non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents are competitive ACh receptor antagonists"
"What is used to reverse non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockade? Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors plus atropine"
"Baclofen exerts its effects by activation of GABAB receptors at the spinal cord level, causing muscle relaxation"
"Baclofen is used to treat muscle spasms (e.g. acute low back pain) and multiple sclerosis (spasticity)"
"Cyclobenzaprine is a centrally acting skeletal muscle relaxant that is structurally related to TCAs"
"Cyclobenzaprine is used to treat muscle spasms"
"The pain in migraines is due to irritation of CN V, meninges, or blood vessels"
"The pain is migraines is mediated by vasoactive peptides on meningeal vessels, which cause vaso-dilation"
"Acute management of migraine headaches includes NSAIDs, triptans, or dihydroergotamine"
"Triptans (e.g. sumatriptan) are 5-HT1B,D receptor agonists"
"Triptans induce vaso-constriction of cerebral and meningeal vessels"
"Triptans prevent release of vasoactive peptides"
"Triptans inhibit trigeminal nerve activation"
"Triptans may cause coronary vasospasm as an adverse effect"
"Triptans are contraindicated in patients with CAD or Prinzmetal angina"
"Triptans may cause mild paresthesias::neurologic complication"
"What treatment for headaches is associated with serotonin syndrome? Triptans"
"Acute management of cluster headaches includes sumatriptan and 100% O2"
"What drug is used for prophylaxis of cluster headaches? Verapamil"
"What drug is used for chronic pain in tension headaches? Amitriptyline"
"Guillain-Barré syndrome results in inflammation and segmental demyelination of peripheral nerves and motor fibers"
"The tissues/organs that have both aldose reductase and sorbitol dehydrogenase include the liver, ovaries, and seminal vesicles"
"Incidence rate = # of new cases / # of people at risk during a specified time period"
"Prevalence = # of existing cases / total # of people in a population at a point in time"
"What is the relationship between prevalence and incidence? prevalence / (1 - prevalence) = incidence * average duration of disease"
"Prevalence is similar to incidence for short duration disease (e.g. common cold)"
"Prevalence is greater than incidence for chronic diseases (e.g. diabetes)"
"Development of an effective treatment for disease causes no change in incidence and decreased prevalence"
"Development of an effective vaccine for disease causes decreased incidence and decreased prevalence"
"If people with a chronic disease live longer, there is no change in incidence and increased prevalence"
"Prevalence is ~ equal to the pretest probability"
"Increased prevalence results in increased positive predictive value"
"Increased prevalence results in decreased negative predictive value"
"Strep pneumoniae is encapsulated and thus will present a problem in sickle cell/asplenic patients"
"Strep pneumoniae polysaccharide vaccine in adults produces an IgM response"
"Strep pneumoniae conjugate vaccine for children produces an IgG response"
"Strep pneumoniae contains IgA protease, allowing bacteria to adhere and colonize the mucous membranes"
"Strep pneumoniae shares the same virulence factor as H. influenzae type b and Neisseria"
"What gram positive organisms commonly colonize previously damaged heart valves? Streptococcus viridans; Enterococcus spp.; Strep bovis::3"
"What organism is formed on dental plaques? S. viridans (mutans and sanguinis)"
"Vancomycin resistance occurs in Enterococcus spp. (VRE) via amino acid modification of D-Ala-D-Ala to D-Ala-D-Lac"
"VanA gene from vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus to S. aureus is an example of transposition"
"Point prevalence refers to the amount of an existing condition present in a population at a single point in time"
"Period prevalence refers to the amount of an existing condition present in a population during a particular time period"
"Case-control studies are observational studies that compare a group of people with disease to a group without disease"
"Case-control studies are almost always retro-spective"
"Are case-control studies useful for measuring incidence and/or prevalence? Neither :)"
"Case-control studies are useful for measuring odds ratio (OR)"
"Cross-sectional surveys are observational studies that compare a frequency of disease and frequency of risk related factors at one time point"
"Are cross-sectional surveys useful for measuring incidence and/or prevalence? Prevalence"
"Cohort studies are observational studies that compares groups with a given exposure or risk factor to a group without such exposure"
"Which type of observational study can be retro- or prospective? Cohort study"
"Cohort studies are useful for calculating relative risk (RR)"
"Are cohort studies useful for measuring incidence and/or prevalence? Incidence"
"Twin concordance studies are observational studies that compare the frequency with which monozygotic and dizygotic twins develop the same disease"
"Adoption studies are observational studies that compare siblings raised by biological versus adoptive parents"
"Both twin concordance and adoption studies are useful for measuring \nature vs. nurture\\"\""
"Phase I of clinical trials assesses safety, toxicity, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics"
"Phase I of clinical trials uses a small number of healthy volunteers or patients with disease of interest"
"Phase II of clinical trials assesses optimal dosing, treatment efficacy, and adverse effects"
"Phase II of clinical trials uses a small number of patients with a disease of interest"
"Phase III of clinical trials uses a large number of patients randomly assigned either to a treatment under investigation or the best available treatment (or placebo)"
"Phase III of clinical trials assesses efficacy compared to the standard of care, as well as adverse effects"
"Phase IV of clinical trials is the postmarketing surveillance of patients after a treatment is approved"
"Phase IV of clinical trials detects rare or long-term adverse effects"
"Sensitivity is the probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive"
"Sensitivity values approaching 100% is desirable for ruling OUT::in or out disease"
"The false negative rate of a test is equal to 1 - sensitivity"
"A high sensitivity::sensitivity or specificity test is useful for screening in diseases with low prevalence"
"Specificity is the probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative"
"Specificity values approaching 100% is desirable for ruling IN::in or out disease"
"The false positive rate of a test is equal to 1 - specificity"
"A high specificity test is useful for confirmation after a positive screening test"
"Positive predictive value is the probability that when the test is positive, the disease is present"
"Positive predictive value varies directly with pretest probability (prevalence)"
"Negative predictive value is the probability that when the test is negative, the disease is absent"
"Negative predictive value varies inversely with pretest probability (prevalence)"
"When lowering the cutoff point for a disease, the sensitivity and NPV will increase::increase or decrease"
"When lowering the cutoff point for a disease, the specificity and PPV will decrease::increase or decrease"
"When raising the cutoff point for a disease, the sensitivity and NPV will decrease::increase or decrease"
"When raising the cutoff point for a disease, the specificity and PPV will increase::increase or decrease"
"Which type of observational study is best for studying rare diseases? Case-control studies"
"What type of study is at the pinnacle of the hierarchy of medical evidence? Meta analysis"
"Precision (reliability) is the consistency and reproducibility of a test"
"Precision may also be referred to as reliability"
"Precision is decreased by random error in a test"
"Increased precision is associated with decreased standard deviation"
"Increased precision is associated with increased statistical power (1 - β)"
"Accuracy (validity) is the trueness of test measurements"
"Accuracy may also be referred to as validity"
"Accuracy is decreased by systematic error in a test"
"Below is an example of high precision and high accuracy:"
"Below is an example of high precision and low accuracy:"
"Below is an example of low precision and high accuracy:"
"Below is an example of low precision and low accuracy:"
"Likelihood ratios can be multiplied with pretest odds of disease to estimate posttest odds"
"Positive likelihood ratio = sensitivity / (1 - specificity)"
"Positive LR > 10 is an indicator of a very useful diagnostic test"
"Negative LR < 0.1 is an indicator of a very useful diagnostic test"
"Negative likelihood ratio = (1 - sensitivity) / specificity"
"What equation is used to calculate odds ratio using the table below? OR = (A/C) / (B/D) = (A*D) / (B*C)"
"What equation is used to calculate relative risk using the table below? "
"If 21% of smokers develop lung cancer versus only 1% of nonsmokers, the relative risk = 21"
"For rare diseases (low prevalence), odds ratio approximates relative risk"
"If relative risk = 1, there is no association between exposure and disease"
"If relative risk > 1, exposure is associated with increased disease occurrence"
"If relative risk < 1, exposure is associated with decreased disease occurrence"
"Attributable risk is defined as the difference in risk between exposed and unexposed groups"
"If 21% of smokers develop lung cancer versus only 1% of nonsmokers, the attributable risk = 20"
"What equation is used to calculate attributable risk using the table below? "
"Relative risk reduction is the proportion of risk reduction attributable to an intervention compared to a control"
"Relative risk reduction is equal to 1 - relative risk"
"If 2% of patients who receive a flu shot develop the flu, while 8% of unvaccinated patients develop the flu, relative risk reduction is 0.75"
"Absolute risk reduction is the difference in risk attributable to an intervention compared to a control"
"If 2% of patients who receive a flu shot develop the flu, while 8% of unvaccinated patients develop the flu, absolute risk reduction is 6% (.06)"
"What equation is used to calculate absolute risk reduction using the table below? "
"The number needed to treat (NNT) is equal to 1/ARR"
"The number needed to harm (NNH) is equal to 1/AR"
"Jaundice is a yellow discoloration of the skin and/or sclera"
"What is the earliest sign of jaundice? Scleral icterus"
"Jaundice is due to increased serum bilirubin, typically > 2.5 mg/dL"
"Does hemolysis result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia? Unconjugated"
"Hemolysis is associated with dark urine due to increased urine urobilinogen"
"Physiological neonatal jaundice occurs due to transiently low UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity at birth"
"Does physiological neonatal jaundice result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia? Unconjugated"
"In physiological neonatal jaundice, unconjugated bilirubin deposits in the brain, especially in the basal ganglia"
"Kernicterus is the deposition of bilirubin in the brain, especially basal ganglia, causing neurologic deficits and possibly death"
"What is the treatment for physiologic neonatal jaundice? Non-UV phototherapy"
"How does phototherapy treat neonatal jaundice? Isomerize UCB to water-soluble form"
"What is the mode of inheritance of hereditary hyperbilirubinemias (e.g. Gilbert, Crigler-Najjar, Dubin-Johnson)? Autosomal recessive"
"Gilbert syndrome is due to mildly low UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity"
"Gilbert syndrome presents with jaundice during stress, illness, or fasting"
"Does Gilbert syndrome result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia? Unconjugated"
"Crigler-Najjar syndrome is due to absent UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity"
"Does Crigler-Najjar syndrome result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia? Unconjugated"
"Crigler-Najjar syndrome causes jaundice and kernicterus early in life; patients often die within a few years"
"Which form of Crigler-Najjar syndrome is more severe? Type I"
"What are the treatments for Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I? Plasmapheresis and phototherapy::2"
