"Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II is less severe and responds to phenobarbital, which increases liver enzyme synthesis"
"Dubin-Johnson syndrome is due to a deficiency of bilirubin canalicular transport protein"
"Does Dubin-Johnson syndrome result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia? Conjugated"
"Dubin-Johnson syndrome presents with a grossly black liver, but is otherwise not clinically significant"
"Rotor syndrome is similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome, but milder and WITHOUT black liver"
"Does Rotor syndrome result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia? Conjugated"
"What type of jaundice is associated with gallstones, parasites, and liver fluke? Obstructive jaundice"
"What type of jaundice is associated with cholangiocarcinoma and pancreatic carcinoma? Obstructive jaundice"
"Does biliary tract obstruction (obstructive jaundice) result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia? Conjugated"
"Obstructive jaundice is associated with dark urine due to increased urine conjugated bilirubin"
"Obstructive jaundice is associated with decreased urine urobilinogen"
"Obstructive jaundice is associated with pale stools"
"Obstructive jaundice is associated with increased serum bile acids, which may cause pruritus"
"Obstructive jaundice is associated with hypercholesterolemia, which may cause xanthomas::skin finding"
"Obstructive jaundice is associated with steatorrhea::GI symptom, with malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins"
"Does viral hepatitis result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia? Both :)"
"Viral hepatitis is associated with dark urine due to increased urine conjugated bilirubin"
"Viral hepatitis is associated with normal or decreased urine urobilinogen"
"In addition to hepatitis virus, viral hepatitis may also be caused by EBV and CMV"
"Viral hepatitis is characterized by elevated liver enzymes with ALT > AST"
"Acute hepatitis is associated with inflammation that involves the lobules of the liver and portal tracts; characterized by apoptosis of hepatocytes"
"Chronic hepatitis is associated with inflammation that primarily involves the portal tracts"
"Cirrhosis is characterized by disruption of normal hepatic parenchyma by bands of fibrosis and regenerative nodules of hepatocytes"
"The fibrosis seen in cirrhosis is mediated by TGF-β from stellate (ito) cells"
"Alcoholic cirrhosis may be associated with sclerosis around central veins in early disease"
"Cirrhosis is often complicated by portal hypertension"
"Does cirrhosis result in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia? Both :)"
"What is the most common cause of portal hypertension in Western countries? Cirrhosis"
"Portal hypertension may be caused by vascular obstruction, such as portal vein thrombosis and Budd-Chiari syndrome"
"What parasitic infection is associated with portal hypertension? Schistosomiasis"
"Portal hypertension can lead to ascites, which is fluid in the peritoneal cavity"
"Portal hypertension may lead to portosystemic shunts, which can result in esophageal varices, gastric varices, anorectal varices, and caput medusae"
"Portal hypertension may lead to congestive splenomegaly and hypersplenism"
"Hepatorenal syndrome is a complication of portal hypertension characterized by rapidly developing renal failure, secondary to cirrhosis"
"Cirrhosis may present with neuropsychiatric symptoms due to increased serum ammonia (NH3)"
"Neuropsychiatric symptoms of cirrhosis include hepatic encephalopathy and asterixis (\flapping tremor\\")\""
"Is hepatic encephalopathy reversible or irreversible? Reversible"
"Hepatic encephalopathy may be triggered by increased NH3 production or absorption, such as increased dietary protein"
"Hepatic encephalopathy may be triggered by decreased NH3 removal, such as renal failure"
"What antibiotics are used to treat hepatic encephalopathy? rifaximin and neomycin::2"
"What osmotic laxative is used to treat hepatic encephalopathy? Lactulose"
"Dermatologic symptoms of cirrhosis include jaundice, spider angiomas, palmar erythema, and petechiae/purpura"
"How do levels of estrogen change in cirrhosis? Increased"
"Increased estrogen in cirrhosis may lead to spider angiomas and palmar erythema (dermatologic symptoms)"
"Increased estrogen in cirrhosis may lead to gynecomastia, testicular atrophy, and amenorrhea (reproductive symptoms)"
"Cirrhosis may present with peripheral edema, secondary to hypoalbuminemia"
"Cirrhosis may present with coagulopathies due to decreased synthesis of clotting factors"
"Is liver failure followed with PT or PTT? PT"
"What odor may be associated with cirrhosis? Fetor hepaticus"
"What is the most common cause of liver disease in the West? Alcohol consumption"
"Which alcoholic liver disease is characterized by macrovesicular fatty change with a heavy, greasy liver? Hepatic steatosis"
"Hepatic steatosis is characterized by macro-vesicular fatty change"
"Which form of alcoholic liver disease may be reversible with abstinence? Hepatic steatosis"
"Alcoholic hepatitis is characterized by swelling of hepatocytes with necrosis and neutrophilic infiltration"
"Alcoholic hepatitis is characterized histologically by mallory bodies, which are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions of damaged keratin (intermediate) filaments"
"The liver damage in alcoholic hepatitis is mediated by acetaldehyde"
"Alcoholic hepatitis may present with painful::painful or painless hepatomegaly"
"Alcoholic hepatitis is characterized by elevated liver enzymes with ALT < AST"
"Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is associated with obesity and metabolic syndrome"
"Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is characterized by fatty infiltration of hepatocytes with cellular \ballooning\\" and eventual necrosis\""
"Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is characterized by elevated liver enzymes with ALT > AST"
"Hemochromatosis is characterized by organ damage, secondary to excess iron"
"The tissue damage in hemochromatosis is mediated by the generation of free radicals"
"Hemochromatosis may be primary; due to autosomal recessive::inheritance pattern mutations in iron absorption"
"Hemochromatosis typically presents after age 40, when total body iron > 20g"
"Hemochromatosis has a slowed progression in women::gender"
"Why does hemochromatosis have a slowed progression in women? Iron loss through menstruation"
"Hemochromatosis may be secondary; due to chronic transfusions"
"Primary hemochromatosis is due to mutations in the HFE gene on chromosome 6, leading to increased expression of DMT1 and decreased synthesis of Hepcidin"
"Hemochromatosis is associated with HLA-A3"
"What point mutations in the HFE gene are typically seen with primary hemochromatosis? C282Y (more common) and H63D"
"Hemochromatosis classically presents with a triad of cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, and bronze skin"
"Hemochromatosis can cause restrictive cardiomyopathy or dilated cardiomyopathy"
"Hemochromatosis may cause gonadal dysfunction in males due to testicular atrophy"
"Hemochromatosis may cause arthropathy, especially in metacarpophalangeal (MCP)::specific hand joints"
"The arthropathy in hemochromatosis occurs due to calcium pyrophosphate deposition"
"What is a common cause of death in hemochromatosis? Hepatocellular carcinoma"
"Hemochromatosis is characterized by increased ferritin"
"Hemochromatosis is characterized by decreased TIBC"
"Hemochromatosis is characterized by increased serum iron"
"Hemochromatosis is characterized by increased % saturation"
"Liver biopsy of a patient with hemochromatosis reveals accumulation of brown::color pigment in hepatocytes"
"The coarse yellowish-brown pigment in hepatocytes / kupffer cells from hemochromatosis may be distinguished from lipofuscin by staining with Prussian blue"
"Lipofuscin is a yellow-brown \wear and tear\\" pigment associated with normal aging\""
"Which part of the cell does lipofuscin accumulate? Lysosomes"
"Deposits of lipofuscin are commonly found in the liver, heart, colon, kidney, and eye of elderly individuals; and are caused by lipid peroxidation"
"Treatment for hemochromatosis may include repeated phlebotomy"
"What type of drug are deferasirox, deferoxamine, and deferiprone (oral)? Iron chelators"
"What GI disorder may be treated with deferasirox, deferoxamine, and oral deferiprone? Hemochromatosis"
"Wilson disease is caused by a(n) autosomal recessive::inheritance defect in ATP-mediated hepatocyte copper transport"
"Wilson disease is due to mutations in the ATP7B gene on chromosome 13"
"Wilson disease results in lack of copper transport into bile and lack of incorporation into ceruloplasmin"
"Wilson disease is also known as hepatolenticular degeneration"
"Wilson disease is characterized by accumulation of copper, especially in the liver, brain, cornea, and kidneys"
"Wilson disease typically presents before age 40"
"Wilson disease often presents with cirrhosis, due to copper accumulation in the liver"
"Wilson disease often presents with neuropsychiatric manifestations, due to copper deposition and resultant cystic degeneration in the putamen and other adjacent structures"
"Wilson disease presents with Kayser-Fleischer rings due to copper deposits in Descemet's membrane of the cornea"
"Wilson disease may present with renal disease, such as Fanconi syndrome"
"Wilson disease is characterized by decreased serum ceruloplasmin"
"Wilson disease is characterized by increased urinary copper"
"What type of drugs are penicillamine and trientine? Copper chelators"
"Wilson disease may be treated with oral zinc or chelating agents (e.g. penicillamine, trientine)"
"Biliary tract diseases (e.g. PSC, PBC) present with features of obstructive jaundice"
"Does biliary tract disease (e.g. PBC, PSC) result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia? Conjugated"
"Biliary tract diseases (e.g. PBC, PSC) are associated with increased serum cholesterol"
"Primary biliary cholangitis is a(n) autoimmune granulomatous destruction of intra-hepatic bile ducts"
"Does primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) affect intra- or extrahepatic bile ducts? Intrahepatic"
"Histologically, Primary biliary cholangitis is characterized by lymphocytic infiltrate and granulomas"
"What demographic is classically affected by primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)? Middle-aged women (~ 40 y.o)"
"Which biliary tract disease is classically seen in middle-aged women and presents with generalized pruritis and fatigue? Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)"
"Primary biliary cholangitis is associated with other autoimmune diseases"
"Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is associated with anti-mitochondrial antibody"
"Which biliary tract disease is caused by extrahepatic biliary obstruction? Secondary biliary cholangitis"
"Secondary biliary cholangitis occurs in patients with known obstructive lesions (e.g. gallstones, biliary strictures, pancreatic carcinoma)"
"Secondary biliary cholangitis may be complicated by ascending cholangitis"
"Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of both intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts"
"Does primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) affect intra- or extrahepatic bile ducts? Both :)"
"Primary sclerosing cholangitis causes periductal fibrosis with an \onion-skin\\" appearance histologically\""
"Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by a \beading\\" appearance of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts on ERCP and MRCP\""
"What demographic is classically affected by primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)? Middle-aged men (classically with IBD)"
"Primary sclerosing cholangitis is associated with p-ANCA antibody"
"Primary sclerosing cholangitis and primary biliary cholangitis are associated with increased serum IgM"
"Primary sclerosing cholangitis is associated with increased risk for cholangiocarcinoma and gallbladder cancer"
"What is a late complication associated with biliary tract disease (e.g. PBC, PSC)? Cirrhosis"
"Reye syndrome is fulminant liver failure and encephalopathy in children with viral illness who take aspirin"
"Reye syndrome may occur due to decreased β-oxidation secondary to reversible inhibition of mitochondrial enzymes in hepatocytes by aspirin metabolites"
"Reye syndrome presents with micro-vesicular fatty change in the liver, hypoglycemia, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and eventually coma/death"
"What viruses classically cause Reye syndrome when treated with aspirin? Influenza B and VZV"
"Hepatic adenomas are rare, benign tumors associated with OCP and anabolic steroid use; regress upon cessation of drug"
"Hepatic adenomas may rupture, causing intraperitoneal bleeding, especially during pregnancy"
"Hepatic adenomas are subcapsular tumors and grow with exposure to estrogen"
"Hepatic angiosarcoma is a malignant tumor associated with exposure to arsenic and vinyl chloride"
"Cavernous hemangiomas are common, benign tumors involving the deeper tissues of the body (ex. liver, brain) that typically occur from age 30 - 50 years"
"Cavernous hemangiomas should NOT be biopsied due to risk of fatal hemorrhage"
"Hepatocellular carcinoma (hepatoma) is the most common primary malignant liver tumor in adults"
"Risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma include chronic hepatitis (e.g. HBV, HCV)"
"Risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma include causes of cirrhosis (e.g. alcohol, NAFLD, hemochromatosis, Wilson disease, A1AT deficiency)"
"Risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma include aflatoxins derived from Aspergillus"
"Hepatocellular carcinoma increases risk for Budd-Chiari syndrome"
"In addition to HCC, Budd-Chiari syndrome may also be seen with hypercoagulable and post-partum states"
"What myeloproliferative disorder is associated with Budd-Chiari syndrome? Polycythemia vera"
"Budd-Chiari syndrome is liver infarction secondary to hepatic vein obstruction"
"Budd-Chiari syndrome presents with painful::painful or painless hepatomegaly, ascites, varices, and liver failure"
"Budd-Chiari syndrome results in congestion and necrosis of the centrilobular zone of the liver"
"Does Budd-Chiari syndrome present with jugular venous distention (JVD)? No"
"Budd-Chiari syndrome is associated with a characteristic \nutmeg\\" appearance of the liver\""
"How does hepatocellular carcinoma spread? Hematogenously"
"What is the serum tumor marker for hepatocellular carcinoma? Alpha-fetoprotein"
"Which is more common, primary liver tumors or metastasis to the liver? Metastasis"
"Does metastasis to the liver typically present as a single or multiple nodules? Multiple"
"Metastasis to the liver may be detected clinically as hepatomegaly with a(n) nodular free edge of the liver"
"Spontaneous (primary) bacterial peritonitis is a common, potentially fatal bacterial infection in patients with cirrhosis and ascites"
"Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is commonly caused by aerobic, gram negative organisms, especially E. coli and Klebsiella"
"Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is diagnosed by paracentesis with ascitic fluid absolute neutrophil count > 250 cells/mm3"
"AST > ALT in nonalcoholic liver disease suggests progression to advanced fibrosis or cirrhosis"
"Which liver enzyme is increased in cholestasis (e.g. biliary obstruction), infiltrative disorders, and bone disease? Alkaline phosphatase"
"Which liver enzyme is increased in various liver/biliary diseases, but NOT in bone disease? γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)"
"γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) is associated with alcohol use"
"How does prothrombin time (PT) change with advanced liver disease? Increased"
"How do platelet levels change with advanced liver disease? Decreased"
"How do platelet levels change with portal hypertension? Decreased"
"Which embryological structure develops into the GI tract from the lower esophagus to the proximal duodenum? Foregut"
"Which embryological structure develops into the GI tract from the distal duodenum to the proximal 2/3 of the transverse colon? Midgut"
"Which embryological structure develops into the GI tract from the distal 1/3 of the transverse colon to the anal canal above the pectinate line? Hindgut"
"Which embryological structure develops into the liver and gallbladder? Foregut"
"During the 6th week of gestation, the midgut herniates through the umbilical ring"
"During the 10th week of gestation, the midgut returns to the abdominal cavity and rotates 270° counterclockwise around the superior mesenteric artery"
"Congenital umbilical hernia is a failure of umbilical ring to close after physiologic herniation of the intestines"
"The main pancreatic duct drains into the major duodenal papilla"
"The accessory pancreatic duct drains into the minor duodenal papilla"
"The retroperitoneal structures of the GI tract may be remembered with the mnemonic \SAID PUCKER\\": S: Suprarenal (adrenal) glands AI: Aorta and IVC D: Duodenum (2nd through 4th part) P: Pancreas (except tail)::except... U: Ureters C: Colon (ascending and descending) *surgeons consider these intraperitoneal K: Kidney E: Esophagus (thoracic portion) R: Rectum (partially)\""
"Which GI ligament connects the liver to the anterior abdominal wall? Falciform ligament"
"What structure is contained within the falciform ligament? Ligamentum teres hepatis (derivative of fetal umbilical vein)"
"Which GI ligament is a derivative of ventral mesentery? Falciform ligament"
"Which GI ligament connects the liver to the duodenum? Hepatoduodenal ligament"
"What structure is contained within the hepatoduodenal ligament? Portal triad (proper hepatic artery, portal vein, common bile duct)"
"The Pringle maneuver involves compression of the hepatoduodenal ligament to control liver bleeding"
"The hepatoduodenal ligament borders the omental foramen, which connects the greater and lesser sacs"
"Which GI ligament connects the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach? Gastrohepatic ligament"
"What structure is contained within the gastrohepatic ligament? Gastric arteries"
"The gastrohepatic ligament separates the greater and lesser sacs on the right::left or right"
"Which GI ligament may be cut during surgery to access the lesser sac? Gastrohepatic ligament"
"The lesser omentum is formed by the gastrohepatic and hepatoduodenal ligaments"
"Which GI ligament connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the transverse colon? Gastrocolic ligament"
"What structure is contained within the gastrocolic ligament? Gastroepiploic arteries"
"Which GI ligament connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen? Gastrosplenic ligament"
"What structures are contained within the gastrosplenic ligament? Short gastric arteries and left gastroepiploic vessels"
"The gastrosplenic ligament separates the greater and lesser sacs on the left::left or right"
"The greater omentum is formed by the gastrocolic and gastrosplenic ligaments"
"Which GI ligament connects the spleen to the posterior abdominal wall? Splenorenal ligament"
"What structures are contained within the splenorenal ligament? Splenic artery/vein and the tail of the pancreas"
"What type of epithelium lines the esophagus? Non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium"
"The surface of the stomach is marked histologically by closely spaced grooves called gastric pits, into which several gastric glands secrete"
"The gastric glands of the stomach contain the mucous cells, chief cells, and parietal cells"
"The chief::chief or parietal cells of the stomach stain baso-philic"
"The parietal::chief or parietal cells of the stomach stain eosino-philic"
"What type of epithelium lines the small and large intestine? Simple columnar epithelium"
"All three parts of the small intestine contain villi and microvilli, which increase absorptive surface area"
"All three parts of the small intestine contain crypts of Lieberkühn"
"Where are the stem cells of the small intestine located? Crypts of Lieberkühn::specific name"
"The crypts of Lieberkühn contain Paneth cells, which secrete defensins, lysozyme, and TNF"
"What histologic feature distinguishes the duodenum from other parts of the small intestine? Brunner glands (in submucosa)"
"Brunner glands secrete a mucus-rich secretion that contains HCO3-"
"What histologic feature distinguishes the jejunum from other parts of the small intestine? Plicae circulares"
"What histologic feature distinguishes the ileum from other parts of the small intestine? Peyer patches"
"Which part of the small intestine contains the largest number of goblet cells? Ileum"
"Does the large intestine contain crypts of Lieberkühn? Yes"
"Does the large intestine contain villi? No"
"The large intestine is characterized histologically by abundant goblet cells"
"What vertebral level does the celiac artery branch off the aorta? T12/L1"
"What vertebral level does the superior mesenteric artery branch off the aorta? L1"
"What vertebral level does the inferior mesenteric artery branch off the aorta? L3"
"Which artery supplies the regions of the foregut? Celiac trunk"
"Which artery supplies the regions of the midgut? Superior mesenteric artery"
"Which artery supplies the regions of the hindgut? Inferior mesenteric artery"
"What vertebral level does the renal artery branch off the aorta? L1/L2"
"What vertebral level does the gonadal artery branch off the aorta? L1/L2"
"Does the renal artery branch off the aorta superior or inferior to the gonadal artery? Superior"
"What artery branches off the aorta anterior to the IVC? Gonadal artery"
"Which parasympathetics innervate the regions of the foregut and midgut? Vagus nerve"
"Which parasympathetics innervate the regions of the hindgut? Pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4)"
"Which sympathetics innervate the regions of the foregut and midgut? Greater and lesser splanchnics (T5 - T12)::2"
"Which sympathetics innervate the regions of the hindgut? Lumbar splanchnics (L1 - L2)"
"Superior mesenteric artery syndrome occurs due to compression of the 3rd (transverse) part of the duodenum between the SMA and aorta"
"SMA syndrome is characterized by intermittent obstruction symptoms; primarily postprandial pain"
"SMA syndrome typically occurs in conditions associated with diminished mesenteric fat (e.g. low body weight, malnutrition)"
"The foregut develops into structures from the lower esophagus to the proximal duodenum"
"The midgut develops into structures from the distal duodenum to the proximal 2/3 of the transverse colon"
"The hindgut develops into structures from the distal 1/3 of the transverse colon to the anal canal above the pectinate line"
"What vertebral level does the aorta bifurcate into the left and right common iliac arteries? L4"
"The three branches of the celiac trunk are the common hepatic, splenic, and left gastric arteries"
"The left gastric artery gives off esophageal branches"
"The common hepatic artery bifurcates into the proper hepatic and gastroduodenal arteries"
"The proper hepatic artery gives rise to the right gastric artery"
"The gastroduodenal artery gives rise to the right gastroepiploic artery"
"The gastroduodenal artery gives rise to the anterior superior and posterior superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries"
"The splenic artery gives rise to the left gastroepiploic and short gastric arteries"
"ID Artery: Left gastroepiploic"
"ID Artery: Splenic"
"ID Artery: Right gastroepiploic"
"ID Artery: Left gastric"
"ID Artery: Right gastric"
"ID Artery: Common hepatic"
"ID Artery: Gastroduodenal"
"ID Artery: Short gastric arteries"
"Strong anastomoses exist between the left gastroepiploic artery and the right gastroepiploic artery"
"Strong anastomoses exist between the left gastric artery and the right gastric artery"
"The greater curvature of the stomach is supplied by the gastroepiploic arteries"
"The lesser curvature of the stomach is supplied by the gastric arteries"
"The fundus and upper portion of the greater curvature of the stomach are supplied by the short gastric arteries"
"Esophageal varices result from portosystemic shunting between the left gastric (portal) and esophageal branch of the azygos (systemic) veins"
"Caput medusae results from portosystemic shunting between the paraumbilical veins (portal) and small epigastric veins of the abdominal wall (systemic)"
"Anorectal varices result from portosystemic shunting between the superior rectal (portal) and middle/inferior rectal (systemic) veins"
"Portosystemic shunts may be treated with TIPS between the portal and hepatic veins"
"Treatment of portosystemic shunts with TIPS can precipitate hepatic encephalopathy in cirrhotic patients"
"The pectinate (dentate) line is formed where anal endoderm (hindgut) meets ectoderm"
"Which type of hemorrhoids are found above the pectinate line? Internal hemorrhoids"
"Which type of carcinoma forms above the pectinate line? Adenocarcinoma"
"Which artery supplies the rectum above the pectinate line? Superior rectal artery (from the IMA)"
"The superior rectal artery is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery"
"Which lymph nodes drain the rectum above the pectinate line? Internal iliac nodes"
"Internal hemorrhoids receive visceral innervation from pelvic splanchnic nerves"
"Which type of hemorrhoid is NOT painful? Internal hemorrhoids"
"Does the rectum ABOVE the pectinate line drain into the portal or systemic circulation? Portal"
"Which type of hemorrhoids are found below the pectinate line? External hemorrhoids"
"Which type of carcinoma forms below the pectinate line? Squamous cell carcinoma"
"Which artery supplies the rectum below the pectinate line? Inferior rectal artery (from the internal pudendal artery)"
"The inferior rectal artery is a branch of the internal pudendal artery"
"Which lymph nodes drain the rectum below the pectinate line? Superficial inguinal nodes"
"External hemorrhoids receive somatic innervation from the pudendal nerve"
"Which type of hemorrhoid IS painful? External hemorrhoids"
"Does the rectum BELOW the pectinate line drain into the portal or systemic circulation? Systemic"
"Anal fissures are described as tears in the anal mucosa below the pectinate line"
"Anal fissures typically present with pain while pooping and blood on toilet paper"
"Anal fissures are typically located posteromedially::direction, because this area is poorly perfused"
"Anal fissures are associated with constipation and low-fiber diets"
"The portal triad consists of the bile duct, hepatic artery proper, and portal vein"
"Terminal branches of portal veins connect with hepatic sinusoids that converge toward a(n) terminal hepatic (central) vein"
"Blood::blood or bile flows from the portal triad towards the central vein"
"Bile::blood or bile flows from the central vein towards the portal triad"
"What is at the center of each hexagon (liver)? Terminal Hepatic Venule (Central veins)"
"What are the darker areas on the corner of each hexagon (liver)? Portal triads"
"The apical surface of hepatocytes faces bile canaliculi"
"The basolateral surface of hepatocytes faces sinusoids"
"Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages that form the lining of hepatic sinusoids"
"The space of Disse is a narrow space between hepatocytes and the endothelial lining of sinusoids"
"Within the space of Disse are stellate (Ito) cells, which store vitamin A when quiescent"
"Within the space of Disse are stellate (Ito) cells, which produce extracellular matrix when activated"
"Which liver cell is the major mediator of fibrosis in response to tissue damage (e.g. cirrhosis)? Stellate (Ito cells)"
"Zone I of the liver is the periportal zone"
"Zone II of the liver is the intermediate zone"
"Zone III of the liver is the centrilobular (pericentral vein) zone"
"Which liver zone is affected first by viral hepatitis? Zone I (periportal)"
"Which liver zone is affected first by ingested toxins (e.g. cocaine)? Zone I (periportal)"
"Which liver zone is affected by yellow fever? Zone II (intermediate)"
"Which liver zone is affected first by ischemia? Zone III (centrilobular)"
"Which liver zone contains the cytochrome P-450 system? Zone III (centrilobular)"
"Which liver zone is affected first by metabolic toxins (e.g. alcohol, tylenol, ethanol, CCl4, halothane, rifampin)? Zone III (centrilobular)"
"Which liver zone is the site of alcoholic hepatitis? Zone III (centrilobular)"
"The common bile duct is formed by the cystic duct and the common hepatic duct"
"The common bile duct and main pancreatic duct join at the ampulla of Vater"
"What sphincter controls the release of digestive juices from the common bile and pancreatic ducts? Sphincter of Oddi"
"Gallstones that reach the confluence of the common bile and pancreatic ducts at the ampulla of Vater::name of hole can block both ducts (double duct sign) causing cholangitis and pancreatitis"
"Tumors that arise in the head of pancreas can cause obstruction of the common bile duct, leading to an enlarged gallbladder with painless jaundice"
"The organization of the femoral region from lateral to medial is the nerve-artery-vein-lymphatics (NAVeL)"
"What are the contents of the femoral triangle? Femoral nerve, artery, and vein"
"What are the contents of the femoral sheath? Femoral artery, vein, and canal (deep inguinal lymph nodes)"
"The femoral sheath is a fascial tube found 3-4 cm below the inguinal ligament"
"What is the superior border of the femoral triangle? Inguinal ligament"
"What is the lateral border of the femoral triangle? Sartorius muscle"
"What is the medial border of the femoral triangle? Adductor longus muscle"
"The external oblique gives rise to the external spermatic fascia of the spermatic cord"
"The internal oblique muscle gives rise to the cremasteric muscle/fascia of the spermatic cord"
"The transversalis fascia gives rise to the internal spermatic fascia of the spermatic cord"
"A(n) hernia is a protrusion of peritoneum through an opening, usually at a site of weakness"
"Herniated contents may be at risk for incarceration, which is the inability to reduce contents back into the abdomen/pelvis"
"Herniated contents may be at risk for strangulation, which is characterized by ischemia and necrosis"
"Which type of inguinal hernia involves protrusion of the bowel through the internal inguinal ring, external inguinal ring and into the scrotum? Indirect inguinal hernia"
"What is the site of protrusion in an indirect inguinal hernia? Internal (deep) inguinal ring"
"Indirect inguinal hernias herniate lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels"
"Indirect inguinal hernias occur in infants due to failure of the processus vaginalis to close"
"Indirect inguinal hernias are more common in males::gender"
"Which layer(s) of spermatic fascia cover an indirect inguinal hernia? All three :)"
"Which type of inguinal hernia involves protrusion of the bowel through the superficial inguinal ring only? Direct inguinal hernia"
"What is the site of protrusion in a direct inguinal hernia and through what anatomical landmark? Abdominal wall (through Hesselbach triangle)"
"Direct inguinal hernias herniate medial to the inferior epigastric vessels"
"What demographic is more commonly affected by direct inguinal hernias? Older men::age, gender"
"Which layer(s) of spermatic fascia cover a direct inguinal hernia? External spermatic fascia"
"Direct inguinal hernias are usually due to an acquired weakness in the transversalis fascia"
"What is the medial border of the inguinal (Hesselbach) triangle? Lateral border of rectus abdominis"
"What is the lateral border of the inguinal (Hesselbach) triangle? Inferior epigastric vessels"
"What is the inferior border of the inguinal (Hesselbach) triangle? Inguinal (Poupart) ligament"
"Which type of hernia protrudes below the inguinal ligament, lateral to the pubic tubercle? Femoral hernia"
"Which type of hernia is most likely to present with incarceration or strangulation? Femoral hernia"
"Femoral hernias are more common in females::gender"
"Which type of hernia involves protrusion of abdominal structures into the thorax? Diaphragmatic hernia"
"Congenital diaphragmatic hernias occur due a defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane"
"Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is associated with lung hypoplasia and a(n) scaphoid::shape abdomen"
"Diaphragmatic hernias typically occur on the left::left or right side"
"What is the most common type of diaphragmatic hernia? Sliding hiatal hernia"
"What type of diaphragmatic hernia involves upward displacement of the gastroesophageal junction? Sliding hiatal hernia"
"Sliding hiatal hernias are characterized by an \hourglass\\" stomach appearance on imaging\""
"What type of hiatal hernia involves NO displacement of the gastroesophageal junction? Paraesophageal hernia"
"Paraesophageal hiatal hernias occur due to protrusion of the fundus of the stomach into the thorax"
"Paraesophageal hernias are associated with bowel sounds in lung fields"
"What type of hernia is associated with abdominal trauma? Traumatic diaphragmatic hernia"
"In addition to VIP, what other GI regulatory substance causes relaxation of smooth muscle and sphincters? Nitric oxide"
"Nitric oxide causes relaxation of GI smooth muscle and sphincters (including LES)"
"Peyer patches are unencapsulated lymphoid tissue found in the lamina propria and submucosa of the ileum"
"Peyer patches contain specialized M cells that sample and present antigens to immune cells"
"B cells stimulated in germinal centers of Peyer patches differentiate into IgA-secreting plasma cells, which reside in the lamina propria"
"The best way to visualize Kayser-Fleischer rings in Wilson disease is via slit-lamp examination"
"Non-dihydropyridine CCBs may cause excessive AV block when combined with β-adrenergic antagonists"
"Which type of immunity includes T cells and B cells? Adaptive immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Which type of immunity includes circulating antibodies? Adaptive immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Which type of immunity includes macrophages and monocytes? Innate immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Which type of immunity includes neutrophils and dendritic cells? Innate immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Which type of immunity includes NK cells? Innate immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Which type of immunity includes complement? Innate immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Is innate immunity specific or nonspecific? Non-specific"
"Does innate immunity have a memory response? No"
"Which type of immunity occurs rapidly, over minutes to hours? Innate immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Which type of immunity has limited diversity? Innate immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Is adaptive immunity specific or nonspecific? Highly specific"
"Does adaptive immunity have a memory response? Yes"
"Which type of immunity develops over long periods? Adaptive immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Which type of immunity has extensive diversity? Adaptive immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Which type of immunity includes physical barriers, such as skin and mucous membranes? Innate immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Which type of immunity includes physiologic barriers, such as temperature and pH? Innate immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Which type of immunity includes chemical barriers, such as lysozyme and defensins? Innate immunity::innate or adaptive"
"Which immunoglobulin isotypes are expressed by mature, naive B-cells? IgM and IgD"
"The antigen receptors of B lymphocytes have two heavy and light chains (bivalent)"
"The antigen receptors of B lymphocytes have a(n) hinge region, which allows for flexibility"
"The signal transduction region of B lymphocytes includes a heterodimer of Ig-α and Ig-β"
"The idio-type of an antibody is determined by the Fab::Fc or Fab region"
"The iso-type of an antibody is determined by the Fc::Fc or Fab region"
"The heavy chain contributes to the Fab and Fc region of an antibody"
"The light chain only contributes to the Fab region of an antibody"
"The mature, naive T cell expresses a single T-cell receptor on its surface"
"The antigen receptors of T lymphocytes have one α and β chain (monovalent)"
"The signal transduction region of T lymphocytes consists of a multi-chain structure known as CD3"
"Is the T-cell antigen receptor mobile or rigid? Rigid (no hinge region)"
"--- Skipped for now --- :) Lymphoid Cell Function B & T cells - Found in bloodstream, lymph nodes, spleen, submucosa, and epithelia B cells: contain markers CD19, CD20, CD21 - Mature into plasma cells - Function is to produce antibodies TH cells: contain markers CD3 and CD4 - Function is to regulate immune responses Cytotoxic T cells: contain markers CD3 and CD8 - Function is to kill infected cells NK cells - Contain markers CD16 and CD56 - Function is to kill tumor/virus cell targets or antibody-coated target cells - T cells can only bind peptides that have been processed and presented by major histocompatibility complexes (MHCs)"
"Antigen-independent antibody diversity in heavy chains is generated by V(D)J gene recombination"
"V(D)J recombination in heavy chains begins with D-J joining, followed by V-D/J joining"
"Antigen-independent antibody diversity in light chains is generated by VJ gene recombination"
"The enzymes responsible for gene recombination in heavy and light chains are encoded by the genes RAG1 and RAG2"
"Antigen-independent antibody diversity is generated via insertion of random nucleotides during V(D)J recombination by the enzyme terminal deoxyribonucleotidyl transferase (Tdt)"
"Antigen-independent antibody diversity is generated via random combination of heavy and light chains"
"Which primary lymphoid organ is the site for immune cell production? Bone marrow *bonus: whats the survival signal?"
"Which primary lymphoid organ is the site of B-cell maturation? Bone marrow"
"Which primary lymphoid organ is the site of T-cell differentiation and maturation? Thymus"
"The secondary lymphoid organs allow immune cells to react with antigen"
"Antigens are brought into a lymph node via afferent lymphatics"
"The outer cortex of a lymph node contains aggregates of cells called follicles"
"Where in the lymph node do B-cells localize and proliferate? Follicles (outer cortex)"
"In lymph nodes, primary follicles are dense and dormant"
"In lymph nodes, secondary follicles have pale, central germinal centers and are active"
"The paracortex is the region of a lymph node between follicles and medulla"
"Where in the lymph node do T-cells localize and proliferate? Paracortex"
"The lymph node paracortex contains high endothelial venules (HEV), through which T and B cells enter from the blood"
"Which region of the lymph node is not well developed in DiGeorge syndrome? Paracortex"
"Which region of the lymph node enlarges during an extreme cellular immune reponse (e.g. viral infection)? Paracortex"
"The inner layer of lymph nodes is the medulla, which consists of medullary cords and sinuses"
"Medullary sinuses within lymph nodes communicate with the efferent lymphatics"
"The medullary sinuses within lymph nodes contain reticular cells and macrophages"
"The medullary cords within lymph nodes contain closely-packed lymphocytes and plasma cells"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the head and neck? Cervical"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the lungs? Hilar"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the trachea and esophagus? Mediastinal"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the upper limb and breast? Axillary"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the skin above the umbilicus? Axillary"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the stomach, spleen, liver, and pancreas? Celiac"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the upper duodenum? Celiac"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the lower duodenum? Superior mesenteric"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the jejunum and ileum? Superior mesenteric"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the proximal colon up to the splenic flexure? Superior mesenteric"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the colon from splenic flexure to upper rectum? Inferior mesenteric"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the bladder? Internal iliac"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the prostate? Internal iliac"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the cervix? Internal iliac"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the testes and ovaries? Para-aortic"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the kidney? Para-aortic"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the uterus? Para-aortic"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the scrotum and vulva? Superficial inguinal"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the skin below the umbilicus? Superficial inguinal"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the dorsolateral foot? Popliteal"
"Which lymph node cluster drains the posterior calf? Popliteal"
"The right lymphatic duct drains lymph from the right side of the body above the diaphragm"
"The thoracic duct drains most lymph into the junction of the left subclavian and left internal jugular veins"
"The spleen is located in the LUQ of the abdomen, behind the 9th - 11th ribs"
"Within the spleen, central arterioles are surrounded by periarterial lymphatic sheaths (PALS)"
"The PALS and lymphoid follicles of the spleen constitute the white pulp"
"Where in the spleen are T-cells found? Periarterial lymphatic sheath (white pulp)"
"Where in the spleen are B-cells found? Follicles (white pulp)"
"Splenic sinusoids are long, vascular channels with fenestrated basement membranes that constitute the red pulp"
"In between the red and white pulp of the spleen is the marginal zone, which contains macrophages and specialized B cells"
"Where in the spleen do Splenic Macrophages capture blood-borne antigens for recognition by lymphocytes? Marginal zone"
"How do platelet levels change post-splenectomy? Increased (thrombocytosis)"
"How do lymphocyte levels change post-splenectomy? Increased (lymphocytosis)"
"What RBC abnormalities are seen on blood smear post-splenectomy? Howell-Jolly bodies and target cells::2"
"Patients undergoing splenectomy should be vaccinated against encapsulated organisms"
"Which immunoglobulin is decreased with splenic dysfunction? IgM"
"The thymus is an encapsulated lymphoid organ located in the anterosuperior mediastinum"
"What branchial pouch develops into the thymus? Third branchial pouch (ventral wing)"
"What is the embryonic origin of lymphocytes in the thymus? Mesenchymal origin"
"The cortex of the thymus is dense and comprised of immature T cells"
"The medulla of the thymus is pale and comprised of mature T cells and Hassall corpuscles"
"Hassall's corpuscles are eosinophilic areas in the thymus composed of epithelial reticular cells"
"Thymoma is a benign neoplasm of thymus associated with myasthenia gravis::immune, SVC syndrome::lung/vascular, pure red cell aplasia and Good syndrome"
"The progenitor B cell lacks cytoplasmic μ and surface IgM/IgD"
"The precursor B cell is characterized by cytoplasmic μ"
"The immature B cell is characterized by surface IgM, but no surface IgD"
"Plasma cells are mature, differentiated B cells characterized by cytoplasmic Ig"
"Memory B cells are mature, differentiated B cells characterized by surface IgG, IgA, or IgE"
"B-cells with self-reactivity in the bone marrow are destroyed by clonal deletion"
"T-cells that are self-reactive in the periphery are inactivated by clonal anergy"
"Major histocompatibility complexes (MHCs) present antigen fragments to T cells and bind T-cell receptors (TCRs)"
"Major histocompatibility complexes (MHCs) are encoded by HLA genes"
"Which MHC class is associated with the gene products of HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C? MHC I"
"Which MHC class is expressed on all nucleated cells and platelets? MHC I"
"MHC I binds to the T-cell receptor (TCR) and CD-8"
"Which MHC class is formed by 1 long chain and 1 short chain? MHC I"
"Which MHC class has a smaller peptide binding groove (8 - 10 AA)? MHC I"
"What protein is associated with MHC I? β2-microglobulin"
"Which MHC class is associated with the gene products of HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR? MHC II"
"Which MHC class is expressed on antigen presenting cells (APCs), only? MHC II"
"MHC II binds to the T-cell receptor (TCR) and CD-4"
"Which MHC class is formed by 2 equal length chains? MHC II"
"Which MHC class has a larger peptide binding groove (13 - 17 AA)? MHC II"
"What protein is associated with MHC II? Invariant chain"
"How many classes of MHC I are expressed on a single cell? Six"
"Which CD markers (CD4, CD8) does the T-cell precursor express in the bone marrow? None :)"
"Which CD marker(s) (CD4, CD8) does the T-cell express in the thymic cortex? Both CD4 and CD8"
"Which CD marker(s) (CD4, CD8) does the T-cell express in the thymic medulla? Either CD4 or CD8"
"In the thymic medulla, the T cell differentiates into a CD4+ or CD8+ T cell"
"Which type of selection allows survival of T cells expressing TCRs capable of binding self-MHC on cortical epithelial cells? Positive selection"
"Where does positive selection of T cells occur? Thymic cortex"
"Which type of selection causes T cells expressing TCRs with high affinity for self antigens on cortical epithelial cells to either undergo apoptosis or become regulatory T cells Negative selection"
"The tissue-restricted self-antigens expressed in the thymus for negative selection are due to the action of autoimmune regulator (AIRE)"
"Deficiency of autoimmune regulator (AIRE) protein causes autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome-1"
"Where does negative selection of T cells occur? Thymic medulla"
"What non-nucleated cell expresses MHC class I? Platelets"
"MHC I presents endogenously synthesized antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells"
"Antigen loading onto MHC I occurs in the RER after breakdown of endogenous antigen by the proteasome in the cytosol, and delivery to the RER via TAP (transporter associated with antigen processing)"
"MHC II presents exogenously synthesized antigens to CD4+ helper T cells"
"Antigen loading onto MHC II occurs following release of the invariant chain in a(n) acidified endosome"
"The first signal for T-cell activation is binding between the TCR and MHC/peptide complex"
"The second signal for T-cell activation is a costimulatory signal via interaction between B7 (APC) and CD28 (T cell)"
"Differentiation of helper T cells to Th2 is induced by IL-2 and IL-4"
"Differentiation of helper T cells to Th2 is inhibited by IFN-γ"
"What class of helper T cell secretes IL-4, -5, -6, -10, and -13? Th2"
"What class of helper T cell recruits eosinophils for parasite defense? Th2"
"What class of helper T cell promotes IgE production by B cells? Th2"
"What class of helper T cell promotes humoral immunity? Th2"
"Differentiation of helper T cells to Th1 is induced by IFN-γ and IL-12"
"Differentiation of helper T cells to Th1 is inhibited by IL-4 and IL-10 (from Th2 cells)"
"What class of helper T cell secretes IFN-γ and IL-2? Th1"
"Th1 cells secrete IFN-γ and IL-2"
"What class of helper T cell activates macrophages and cytotoxic T cells? Th1"
"What class of helper T cell promotes cell-mediated immunity? Th1"
"Differentiation of helper T cells to Treg is induced by TGF-β and IL-2; inhibited by IL-6"
"What class of helper T cell helps maintain specific immune tolerance by suppressing CD4 and CD8 T-cell effector functions? Regulatory T (TReg) cells"
"Regulatory T cells are identified by expression of CD3, CD4, CD25, and FOXP3"
"Activated regulatory T cells produce IL-10 and TGF-β (anti-inflammatory cytokines)"
"Differentiation of helper T cells to Th17 is induced by IL-1, IL-6 and TGF-β"
"What class of helper T cell are believed to play a role in tissue damage associated with autoimmune disease? Th17 cells"
"Which type of immunity responds to antigens with antibodies from plasma cells? Humoral immunity::humoral or cell-mediated"
"Humoral immunity is used to defend against extra-cellular agents"
"Is humoral immunity primarily mediated by B-cells or T-cells? B-cells"
"B-cell activation begins with presentation of foreign antigen on MHC II, which is recognized by a T-cell receptor"
"B-cell activation requires a costimulatory signal from binding between the CD40 receptor (B cell) and CD40 ligand (Th2 cell)"
"Antigens that lack a(n) peptide component are not recognizable by T cells and thus stimulate B cells directly"
"Do thymus-independent antigens result in immunologic memory? No"
"What is the only immunoglobulin that can be secreted in response to thymus-independent antigens? IgM"
"One example of a thymus-independent antigen is lipopolysaccharides (LPS) from gram negative bacteria"
"Do thymus-dependent antigens result in immunologic memory? Yes"
"Which type of antibody digestion results in 2 monovalent Fab regions and 1 Fc region? Papain cleavage"
"Which type of antibody digestion results in 1 bivalent Fab region and 1 Fc region? Pepsin cleavage"
"Which immunoglobulin isotypes can exist as a monomer? All Ig types"
"IgM exists as a(n) monomer on the surface of B cells"
"IgM exists as a(n) pentamer held by a J chain when secreted"
"How many identical antigens can a single IgM molecule bind? 10"
"Does IgM fix complement? Yes"
"Does IgM cross the placenta? No"
"Which immunoglobulin is produced first in response to an infection? IgM"
"Which immunoglobulin is the main antibody produced during the primary response to antigen? IgM"
"The valence of an antibody refers to the number of sites available to bind epitopes"
"The affinity of an antibody refers to the binding strength for an epitope"
"Which immunoglobulin has the highest avidity? IgM"
"Which immunoglobulin has the highest affinity? IgG"
"Generation of antibody specificity occurs via somatic hypermutation with affinity maturation"
"Where does class switching of IgM take place? Germinal centers of lymph nodes"
"Class switching of IgM is mediated by CD40L and cytokines from Th2::specific cells"
"Class switching to IgA is promoted by IL-5 and TGF-β"
"Class switching to IgE is promoted by IL-4 and IL-13"
"Which immunoglobulin is the main antibody produced during the secondary response to antigen? IgG"
"What is the most abundant immunoglobulin isotype in serum? IgG"
"Does IgG fix complement? Yes"
"Does IgG cross the placenta? Yes"
"Which immunoglobulin(s) fix complement? IgM and IgG"
"Which immunoglobulin(s) cross the placenta? IgG"
"Which immunoglobulin opsonizes bacteria? IgG"
"Which immunoglobulin is the most produced antibody overall? IgA"
"IgA exists as a(n) monomer in circulation"
"IgA exists as a(n) dimer held by a J chain when secreted"
"IgA crosses epithelial cells by transcytosis"
"Which immunoglobulin is produced in the GI tract and protects against gut infections? IgA"
"Which immunoglobulin is released into breast milk (colostrum)? IgA"
"Which immunoglobulin is released into secretions (tears, saliva, mucus)? IgA"
"Does IgA fix complement? No"
"Does IgA cross the placenta? No"
"IgA is transported through the mucosa via binding between the J chain of IgA and the polymeric Ig receptor on epithelial cells"
"When IgA is released into the mucosa, the poly Ig receptor becomes the secretory component, which protects IgA from luminal proteases"
"Which immunoglobulin binds directly to mast cells and basophils? IgE"
"IgE cross-links when exposed to allergen, mediating type I hypersensitivity reactions"
"Which immunoglobulin contributes to immunity to worms by activating eosinophils? IgE"
"What is the least abundant immunoglobulin isotype in serum? IgE"
"Which immunoglobulin(s) can be secreted by plasma cells? IgA, IgG, or IgE (one type per plasma cell)"
"Which type of immunity responds to antigens with activated cytotoxic T-cells? Cell-mediated immunity::humoral or cell-mediated"
"Cell-mediated immunity is used to defend against intra-cellular agents"
"Is cell-mediated immunity primarily mediated by B-cells or T-cells? T-cells"
"Cytotoxic (CD8+) T-cells kill virus infected, neoplastic, and donor graft cells by inducing apoptosis"
"Cytotoxic T cells may induce apoptosis of target cells via release of perforins and granzymes, which leads to activation of caspases"
"Cytotoxic T cells may induce apoptosis of target cells via binding of Fas ligand to Fas, which causes release of TNF"
"Which immune cell is a lymphocyte member of the innate immune system? Natural killer (NK) cells"
"Natural killer cells may induce apoptosis of virally infected cells and tumors cells via release of perforins and granzymes"
"Which interferons enhance activity of natural killer cells? Interferon-α and Interferon-β"
"Which interleukins enhance activity of natural killer cells? IL-2 and IL-12"
"Natural killer cells are induced to kill cells that have an absence of MHC I on their cell surface"
"Natural killer cells may kill cells via binding between CD16 (NK cells) and the Fc region of IgG-bound antigen"
"Which immunoglobulin typically mediates antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)? IgG*"
"Superantigens are antigens that cross-link the β region of T-cell receptors to MHC II on APCs outside the normal peptide-binding groove"
"Superantigens can activate any CD4+ T-cell, resulting in massive release of cytokines"
"Anergy refers to a state in which an immune cell cannot become activated by exposure to its antigen"
"T-cells and B-cells become anergic when exposed to their antigen without a costimulatory signal"
"Which type of immunization is acquired by receiving preformed antibodies? Passive immunization"
"Which type of immunization has a rapid onset? Passive immunization"
"Which type of immunization has a short span of duration? Passive immunization"
"Consumption of IgA in breast milk is an example of passive immunization"
"Maternal IgG crossing the placenta is an example of passive immunization"
"Administration of antitoxin or monoclonal antibody is an example of passive immunization"
"One risk of passive immunotherapy is IgE production and anaphylaxis, especially in patients with selective IgA deficiency"
"Toxins that require passive immunity in exposed, unvaccinated patients may be remembered with the mnemonic \To Be Healed Very Rapidly\\": T: Tetanus toxin B: Botulinum toxin H: HBV V: Varicella R: Rabies virus\""
"Which type of immunization is acquired by exposure to foreign antigens? Active immunization"
"Which type of immunization has a slow onset? Active immunization"
"Which type of immunization has a long-lasting protection (memory)? Active immunization"
"Natural infection is an example of active immunization"
"Administration of toxoid is an example of active immunization"
"Administration of vaccines is an example of active immunization"
"Which type of vaccine induces a strong, often lifelong immunity? Live, attenuated vaccines"
"Which type of vaccine has the potential to revert to a virulent form? Live, attenuated vaccines"
"Live attenuated vaccines are often contraindicated in pregnancy and immunodeficiency"
"MMR and varicella are live vaccines that can be given to HIV patients with CD4 counts > 200/mm3"
"Do live attenuated vaccines induce cellular or humoral responses? Both cellular and humoral :)"
"What type of vaccine is the MMR vaccine? Live attenuated"
"What type of vaccine is the rotavirus vaccine? Live attenuated"
"What type of vaccine is the yellow fever vaccine? Live attenuated"
"What type of vaccine is the varicella vaccine? Live attenuated"
"What type of vaccine is the BCG vaccine? Live attenuated"
"What type of vaccine is the intranasal influenza vaccine? Live attenuated"
"Which polio vaccine is a live attenuated (oral) vaccine? Sabin"
"Which type of vaccine is a pathogen that has been inactivated by heat or chemicals? Inactivated/killed vaccine"
"What is an advantage of inactivated vaccines compared to live attenuated? Inactivated vaccines are safer"
"Which types of vaccine induce a relatively weak immune response? Inactivated/killed vaccines and Subunit vaccine::2"
"Do killed/inactivated vaccines induce cellular or humoral responses? Humoral"
"What part of an antigen should be preserved to elicit an immune response when given as an inactivated/killed vaccine? Epitope"
"What type of vaccine is the rabies vaccine? Inactivated/killed"
"What type of vaccine is the injected influenza vaccine? Inactivated/killed"
"Which polio vaccine is an inactivated/killed vaccine? Salk"
"What type of vaccine is the hepatitis A vaccine? Inactivated/killed"
"What is the first type of immunoglobulin produced in a neonate? IgM"
"By age 1, the total antibody level is approximately 60% of adult levels"
"By age 1, the total IgA level is approximately 20% of adult levels"
"What is the only useful immunoglobulin for diagnosing neonatal infections? IgM"
"Some killed vaccines are conjugated to a(n) protein to elicit a stronger immune response (e.g. immunologic memory)"
"Is primary CNS lymphoma typically a B-cell or T-cell neoplasm? B-cell"
"The pathogenesis of primary CNS lymphoma involves EBV infection"
"--- Do with heme --- Type II Hypersensitivity Disorders - Cytotoxic: Transfusion Reaction - Antibody against ABO blood glycoproteins - IgM isohemagglutinins formed naturally in response to bacterial flora cause opsonization and complement activation - Leads to hemolysis **Hemolytic Disease of the Newborn (Erythroblastosis fetalis) Antibody = Anti-RhD+ IgG - Formed in Rh- mother carrying Rh+ child - First pregnancy sensitizes (doesn't have to be viable pregnancy) - Antibody crosses placenta and injures subsequent fetuses - Prevent with RhoGAM (anti-Rh, binds fetal red cells and prevents mothers immune system from reacting) ABO blood typing and screening for other preformed Abs; always done in case of transplants. Universal donor: type O Universal recipient: type AB (Ex) Type A can donate to type A and type AB. Type A can receive donations from type A and type O. - Anti-B antibodies prevent donation from type B and type AB. HLA Typing - Microcytotoxicity test Tests for MHC class I (HLA-A, HLA-B) Test hundreds of different haplotypes to find a potential match. Cells recognized by antibody will be attacked by complement and thus become leaky and take up dye. HLA Typing - Mixed lymphocyte reaction Tests for MHC class II (HLA-DR) Take donor cells and irradiate them (prevent proliferation). Irradiated cells are mixed with donor cells to see if proliferation occurs. Higher radioactivity (thymidine) signifies lower compatibility."
"Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by cross-linking IgE on presensitized mast cells and basophils? Type I HSR"
"Type I HSR occurs due to cross-linking of IgE on presensitized mast cells and basophils by antigen"
"The immediate response of mast cell and basophil activation is release of preformed histamine granules and tryptase::marker of activation"
"The delayed response of mast cell and basophil activation involves production of chemokines (ex. to attract eosinophils) and cytokines (particularly leukotrienes)"
"Which type of hypersensitivity mediates anaphylaxis (e.g. food, drug, or bee sting allergies)? Type I"
"Which type of hypersensitivity mediates atopic reactions (e.g. asthma, allergic rhinitis)? Type I"
"Skin Pinprick tests or Blood (ELISA) tests for allergen-specific IgE are typically used to diagnose type I hypersensivity reactions"
"Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by binding of antibodies to cell-surface antigens? Type II HSR"
"Type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing cellular destruction by opsonizing the target with antibodies"
"Type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing cellular dysfunction, causing abnormal blockade or activation/inactivation of downstream cellular processes"
"Type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing inflammation by antibodies depositing on cell surfaces, which in turn activates complement"
"Which immunoglobulins mediate type II hypersensivity reactions? IgM and IgG"
"What test is used to diagnose type II hypersensitivity reactions against RBCs? Coombs test"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction are immune thrombocytopenic purpura and autoimmune-hemolytic anemia? Type II HSR (cellular destruction)"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction are hemolytic disease of the newborn and transfusion reactions? Type II HSR (cellular destruction)"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is Goodpasture syndrome? Type II HSR (inflammation)"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is rheumatic fever? Type II HSR (inflammation)"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is hyperacute transplant rejection? Type II HSR (inflammation)"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is Graves disease and Myasthenia Gravis? Type II HSR (cellular dysfunction)"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is Pemphigus Vulgaris? Type II HSR (cellular dysfunction)"
"Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is characterized by circulating immune complexes? Type III HSR"
"In type III HSRs, antigen-antibody complexes activate complement, which attracts neutrophils"
"Serum sickness is an immune complex disease in which antibodies to foreign serum proteins are produced"
"Serum sickness-like reactions are associated with some drugs acting as haptens (ex. penicillin) and infections (ex. HBV)"
"A(n) hapten is a small antigen that may conjugate with larger proteins to elicit an immune response"
"Serum sickness presents with fever, urticaria, arthralgia, proteinuria, and lymphadenopathy 1 - 2 weeks after antigen exposure"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is serum sickness? Type III HSR"
"Arthus reaction is a local subacute antibody-mediated HSR to antigen in intradermal injection"
"Arthus reaction leads to immune complex formation in the skin; characterized by edema, necrosis, and activation of complement"
"What type of hypersensivitity reaction is the Arthus reaction? Type III HSR"
"Which is more common, serum sickness or arthus reaction? Serum sickness"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is polyarteritis nodosa? Type III"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)? Type III"
"Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is T-cell mediated? Type IV"
"Type IV HSRs may occur via direct cell cytotoxicity, which involves CD8+ T cells"
"Type IV HSRs may occur via delayed-type hypersensitivity, which involves CD4+ T-cells"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is type I diabetes mellitus? Type IV HSR (direct cell cytotoxicity)"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is contact dermatitis (e.g. poison ivy, nickel allergy)? Type IV HSR (CD4 & CD8 Mediated)"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is graft-versus-host-disease? Type IV HSR (delayed-type hypersensitivity)"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is tuberculin skin test (PPD)? Type IV HSR (Th1 Mediated*)"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is patch test? Type IV HSR (CD4 Mediated)"
"Which type(s) of hypersensitivity reactions are antibody-mediated? I, II, and III"
"What type of graft is from self? Autograft"
"What type of graft is from an identical twin or clone? Syngeneic graft (isograft)"
"What type of graft is from a non-identical individual of the same species? Allograft"
"What type of graft is from a different species? Xenograft"
"Which type of transplant rejection occurs within minutes? Hyperacute"
"Which type of transplant rejection is due to pre-existing recipient antibodies to donor antigen? Hyperacute"
"Which type of transplant rejection presents with widespread thrombosis of graft vessels, causing ischemia/necrosis? Hyperacute"
"Which type of transplant rejection occurs within weeks to months? Acute"
"Which type of transplant rejection occurs within months to years? Chronic"
"Which type of transplant rejection presents with vasculitis of graft vessels with dense interstitial monocytic / lymphocytic infiltrate? Acute"
"Acute transplant rejection can be prevented/reversed with immunosuppressants"
"Which type of transplant rejection presents with vascular smooth muscle proliferation, parenchymal atrophy, and interstitial fibrosis? Chronic"
"Chronic transplant rejection is dominated by arteriosclerosis"
"Chronic lung transplant rejection typically presents as bronchiolitis obliterans"
"Chronic heart transplant rejection typically presents as accelerated atherosclerosis"
"Chronic kidney transplant rejection typically presents as chronic allograft nephropathy"
"Chronic liver transplant rejection typically presents as vanishing bile duct syndrome"
"Which type of transplant rejection presents as grafted immunocompetent T cells proliferating and rejecting host cells with \foreign\\" proteins? Graft-versus-host-disease (GVHD)\""
"Which type of transplant rejection presents with maculopapular rash, jaundice, diarrhea, and hepatosplenomegaly? Graft-versus-host-disease (GVHD)"
"Which transplants are associated with graft-versus-host disease? Bone marrow and liver::2"
"Graft-versus-host disease is potentially beneficial in bone marrow transplants for patients with leukemia"
"What skin appearance is classically seen in carbon monoxide poisoning? Cherry-red appearance"
"Neisseria gonorrhoeae does not have a polysaccharide capsule"
"There is no N. gonorrhoeae vaccine due to antigenic variation of the pilus proteins"
"What kind of discharge is seen with Gonorrhea? Creamy, white, purulent discharge"
"In addition to Ceftriaxone for Gonorrhea, what other possible co-infection should you treat? Chlamydia"
"Which cellular change is characterized by an increased number of cells? Hyperplasia"
"Which cellular change is characterized by an increased size of cells? Hypertrophy"
"Hypertrophy::(hypertrophy or hyperplasia) involves gene activation, protein synthesis, and production of organelles"
"Hyperplasia::(hypertrophy or hyperplasia) involves the controlled proliferation of stem cells and differentiated cells"
"Do permanent tissues (e.g. cardiac muscle, skeletal muscle, nerve) undergo hypertrophy and/or hyperplasia? Hypertrophy, only"
"Which cellular change is characterized by a decrease in tissue mass due to decrease in size or number of cells? Atrophy"
"Atrophy via decrease in cell number occurs via apoptosis"
"Atrophy via decrease in cell size may occur via ubiquitin-proteasome degradation of cytoskeleton"
"Atrophy via decrease in cell size may occur via autophagy of cellular components"
"Which cellular change is characterized by replacement of one cell type by another? Metaplasia"
"Which cellular change typically occurs after chronic exposure to an irritant, such as gastric acid or smoke? Metaplasia"
"Metaplasia occurs via reprogramming of stem cells, which then produce the new cell type"
"Is metaplasia reversible or irreversible? Reversible"
"Under persistent stress, metaplasia can progress to dysplasia and eventually cancer"
"Which metaplasia carries no increased risk for malignancy? Apocrine metaplasia of breast"
"Vitamin A deficiency can result in metaplasia"
"What vitamin is necessary for differentiation of specialized epithelial surfaces? Vitamin A"
"What musculoskeletal disorder is characterized by metaplasia of skeletal muscle to bone? Myositis ossificans"
"Which cellular change is characterized by disordered, non-neoplastic cellular growth? Dysplasia"
"Dysplasia is a term used only with epithelial cells"
"Dysplasia most often refers to proliferation of pre-cancerous cells"
"Is dysplasia reversible or irreversible? Reversible"
"Which cellular change is characterized by failure of cell production during embryogenesis? Aplasia"
"Which cellular change is characterized by decreased cell production during embryogenesis? Hypoplasia"
"Which mitochondrial membrane contains the electron transport chain? Inner mitochondrial membrane"
"What ultimately leads to cellular injury in hypoxia? Lack of ATP"
"Cellular injury is characterized by decreased activity of the Na+-K+ and Ca2+ pumps"
"What is the hallmark of reversible cellular injury? Swelling"
"Reversible cellular injury is characterized ultrastructurally by membrane blebbing and loss of microvilli"
"Reversible cellular injury is characterized ultrastructurally by ribosomal detachment and polysomal detachment, leading to decreased protein synthesis"
"What is the hallmark of irreversible cellular injury? Membrane damage"
"Leakage of cytosolic enzymes into the serum is a characteristic of irreversible cell injury"
"Plasma membrane damage in irreversible cellular injury results in entry of Ca2+ ions into the cell"
"Mitochondrial vacuolization signifies irreversible cellular injury"
"Lysosome membrane damage in irreversible cell injury results in hydrolytic enzymes leaking into the cytosol"
"What is the end result of irreversible cell injury? Cell death"
"The morphologic hallmark of cell death is loss of the nucleus"
"Which feature of cell death is characterized by nuclear condensation? Pyknosis"
"Which feature of cell death is characterized by nuclear fragmentation? Karyorrhexis"
"Which feature of cell death is characterized by nuclear dissolution? Karyolysis"
"The two MAIN mechanisms of cell death are necrosis and apoptosis"
"Which mechanism of cell death is never physiologic*? Necrosis"
"Which mechanism of cell death is an inflammatory process? Necrosis"
"Which mechanism of cell death involves death of a large group of cells? Necrosis"
"Which type of necrosis is characterized by preserved cell shape and organ structure? Coagulative necrosis"
"Coagulative necrosis is characterized by preserved cell architecture (cell outlines are seen) but the nucleus disappears"
"Coagulative necrosis is characteristic of ischemic infarction of any organ except the brain"
"In coagulative necrosis, injury denatures proteolytic enzymes"
"What type of infarct occurs in tissues with a single arterial blood supply (e.g. heart, kidney, spleen)? Pale (anemic) infarct"
"What type of infarct occurs with venous occlusion, tissues with multiple blood supplies (e.g. liver, lungs, intestine, testes), or reperfusion? Red (hemorrhagic) infarct"
"Which type of necrosis is characterized by enzymatic lysis of cells and protein? Liquefactive necrosis"
"In the late phase of liquefactive necrosis of the brain, cystic spaces and cavitation may be seen"
"What type of necrosis is seen with brain infarcts and abscess? Liquefactive necrosis"
"Which cells release proteolytic enzymes in response to brain infarction, causing liquefactive necrosis? Microglial cells"
"Which cells release proteolytic enzymes in response to brain abscess, causing liquefactive necrosis? Neutrophils"
"In addition to the brain, what other organ may undergo liquefactive necrosis? Pancreas"
"Which type of necrosis resembles mummified tissue? Gangrenous (dry)"
"Gangrenous necrosis is characteristic of chronic ischemia of the lower limb and GI tract"
"Gangrenous necrosis is a form of coagulative necrosis"
"What type of necrosis may be seen with gangrenous necrosis if superinfection occurs? Liquefactive necrosis (\wet gangrene\\")\""
"Which type of necrosis is characterized by soft, friable necrotic tissue with a \cottage cheese-like\\" appearance? Caseous necrosis\""
"Caseous necrosis is a combination of coagulative and liquefactive necrosis"
"Which type of necrosis is characteristic of tuberculous and fungal infections? Caseous necrosis"
"Which type of necrosis is characterized by fragmented cells/debris surrounded by lymphocytes and macrophages? Caseous necrosis"
"Which type of necrosis is characterized by a chalky-white appearance due to deposition of Ca2+? Fat necrosis"
"Fat necrosis is characteristically due to acute pancreatitis or trauma (e.g. breast)"
"In fat necrosis, fatty acids bind to Ca2+ via a process called saponification"
"Saponification of fat appears dark blue::color on H&E stain"
"Which type of calcification occurs in abnormal, necrotic tissues? Dystrophic::dystrophic or metastatic"
"Which type of calcification occurs secondary to injury or necrosis? Dystrophic::dystrophic or metastatic"
"Which type of calcification tends to be localized? Dystrophic::dystrophic or metastatic"
"Are patients with dystrophic calcifications usually normocalcemic? Yes"
"Which type of calcification occurs in normal, non-necrotic tissues? Metastatic::dystrophic or metastatic"
"Which type of calcification occurs secondary to hypercalcemia or hyperphosphatemia? Metastatic::dystrophic or metastatic"
"Which type of calcification tends to be widespread? Metastatic::dystrophic or metastatic"
"Are patients with metastatic calcifications usually normocalcemic? No"
"Metastatic calcification predominantly occurs in the kidney, lung, and gastric mucosa"
"Which type of necrosis is characterized by necrotic damage to blood vessel walls? Fibrinoid necrosis"
"Fibrinoid necrosis is characteristic of malignant hypertension, vasculitis (e.g. PAN), and preeclampsia"
"Fibrinoid necrosis is characterized histologically by thick, bright pink::color staining of vessel walls"
"Which mechanism of cell death is an ATP-dependent programmed cell death? Apoptosis"
"Which mechanism of cell death is NOT followed by inflammation? Apoptosis"
"Which mechanism of cell death involves death of single cells or small groups of cells? Apoptosis"
"Apoptosis is characterized morphologically by cell shrinkage::size, chromatin condensation, and membrane blebbing"
"The cytoplasm of apoptotic cells stains deeply eosino-philic"
"The nucleus of apoptotic cells stains deeply baso-philic"
"Apoptosis results in the formation of apoptotic bodies, which are subsequently phagocytosed by macrophages"
"Apoptosis is mediated by caspases, which activate proteases and endonucleases"
"What class of enzymes breaks down DNA in apoptosis? Endonucleases"
"What class of enzymes breaks down the cytoskeleton in apoptosis? Proteases"
"The mitochondrial (intrinsic) pathway of apoptosis occurs via inactivation of Bcl2"
"Bcl-2 normally keeps the mitochondrial outer membrane impermeable, thus preventing cytochrome c release from the intermembrane space"
"Are the Bcl-2 related proteins BAX and BAK pro- or anti-apoptotic? Pro-apoptotic"
"Are the Bcl-2 related proteins Bcl-2 and Bcl-x pro- or anti-apoptotic? Anti-apoptotic"
"The extrinsic (death receptor) pathway of apoptosis can occur via receptor binding between Fas-L-(receptor: CD95) or TNF-α and their respective receptors"
"The extrinsic pathway of apoptosis can occur via a CD-8+ T-cell pathway"
"Defective Fas-FasL interactions can cause autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome"
"DNA laddering in multiples of 180 BP is a sensitive indicator of apoptosis"
"Free radicals are chemical species with an unpaired electron in their outer orbit"
"If O2 accepts one electron, it forms superoxide (O2-)"
"If O2 accepts two electrons, it forms hydrogen peroxide (H2O2)"
"If O2 accepts three electrons, it forms hydroxyl anion (OH-)"
"Pathologic generation of free radicals arises with ionizing radiation, which hydrolyzes H2O to OH-"
"Which oxygen-derived free radical is the most damaging? OH-"
"Pathologic generation of free radicals arises with metals (e.g. copper and iron) via the Fenton reaction"
"Free radicals cause cellular injury via peroxidation of lipids and oxidation of DNA and proteins"
"Free radicals may be eliminated via antioxidants (e.g. reduced glutathione and vitamins A, C, and E)"
"What mitochondrial enzyme reduces superoxide (O2-) to H2O2? Superoxide dismutase"
"What enzymes reduce hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to O2 and H2O? Catalase and glutathione peroxidase"
"Free radicals may be eliminated via metal carrier proteins, such as transferrin (Fe2+) and ceruloplasmin (Cu2+)"
"What organic solvent used in the dry cleaning industry is converted to free radicals in the liver? Carbon tetrachloride (CCl4)"
"CCl3 free radical damage in the liver results in decreased apolipoprotein synthesis with resultant fatty change and centrilobular::location necrosis"
"What cause of free radical injury occurs following thrombolytic therapy? Reperfusion injury"
"Which layer of the heart wall is most vulnerable to hypoxia/ischemia? Subendocardium (LV)"
"Which regions of the kidney are most vulnerable to hypoxia/ischemia? Proximal straight tubule and thick ascending limb"
"Which regions of the colon are most vulnerable to hypoxia/ischemia? Splenic flexure and rectosigmoid junction"
"Amyloid is a misfolded protein that deposits in the extracellular space, resulting in cellular damage and apoptosis"
"What is the shared structural feature of amyloid? β-pleated sheet"
"Amyloid may be visualized using Congo red staining"
"Amyloid may be visualized as apple-green birefringence under polarized light"
"Primary amyloidosis is characterized by systemic deposition of AL amyloid, which is derived from Ig light chain"
"Secondary amyloidosis is characterized by systemic deposition of AA amyloid, which is derived from serum amyloid-associated protein (SAA)"
"Serum amyloid-associated protein (SAA) is an acute phase reactant that is increased in chronic inflammatory states, malignancy, and Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF)"
"Familial Mediterranean Fever is due to dysfunction of neutrophils::cell type"
"Familial Mediterranean fever is characterized by AA amyloid deposits in tissues during attacks"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Familial Mediterranean fever? Autosomal recessive"
"Which types of amyloidosis deposit systemically? Primary (AL) and secondary (AA)"
"What organ is most commonly affected by systemic amyloidosis? Kidney"
"Diagnosis of amyloidosis requires tissue biopsy; the abdominal fat pad and rectum are easily accessible targets"
"Can amyloid be removed from an organ once it has deposited? No"
"Senile cardiac amyloidosis is characterized by deposition of non-mutated transthyretin (TTR) protein"
"Familial amyloid cardiomyopathy / polyneuropathies are characterized by deposition of mutated transthyretin (TTR) protein in the heart and nerves"
"What type of cardiomyopathy is caused by mutated transthyretin deposits (familial amyloid cardiomyopathy)? Restrictive cardiomyopathy"
"Type II diabetes mellitus is associated with deposition of amylin (islet amyloid polypeptide) in the islets of the pancreas"
"Alzheimer disease is characterized by deposition of Aβ-amyloid in the brain, which forms amyloid plaques"
"Dialysis-associated amyloidosis is characterized by deposition of β2-microglobulin in joints"
"Which amyloidosis may present as carpal tunnel syndrome? Any amyloidosis*"
"Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is characterized by deposition of calcitonin within the tumor"
"Isolated atrial amyloidosis due to atrial natriuretic peptide is common in normal aging and predisposes to atrial fibrillation"
"Acute inflammation is characterized by the presence of edema and neutrophils::cell type in tissue"
"Acute inflammation arises in response to infection, tissue necrosis, trauma and foreign bodies"
"Toll-like receptors (TLRs) on cells of the immune system are activated by pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) that are commonly shared by microbes"
"Are toll-like receptors (TLRs) found on cells of the innate or adaptive immune system? Both :)"
"CD-14 is a co-receptor for TLR4 found on macrophages that recognizes lipopolysaccharide (LPS) on gram-negative bacteria"
"Toll-like receptor (TLR) activation results in upregulation of NF-κB, a nuclear transcription factor that activates immune response genes"
"Arachidonic acid is released from the phospholipid cell membrane by the enzyme phospholipase A2"
"Arachidonic acids are converted to prostaglandins via the enzyme cyclooxygenase"
"Which prostaglandins mediate vasodilation and increased vascular permeability? PGE2, PGD2, and PGI2 (prostacyclin)"
"Which prostaglandin mediates pain and fever? PGE2"
"Prostaglandin I2 (prostacyclin) causes decreased platelet aggregation"
"Arachidonic acids are converted to leukotrienes via the enzyme 5-lipoxygenase"
"Which leukotriene attracts and activates neutrophils? Leukotriene B4"
"Which leukotrienes mediate vasoconstriction, bronchospasm, and increased vascular permeability? Leukotrienes C4, D4, and E4"
"In general, prostaglandins cause vaso-dilation"
"In general, prostaglandins cause increased vascular permeability"
"In general, leukotrienes cause vaso-constriction"
"In general, leukotrienes cause increased vascular permeability"
"Mast cells may be activated by tissue trauma"
"Mast cells may be activated by cross-linking of cell-surface IgE by antigen"
"Which complement proteins can activate mast cells (anaphylatoxins)? C3a, C4a, and C5a"
"What organ synthesizes complement proteins? Liver"
"Complement may be activated via the classic pathway, which is mediated by IgM and IgG"
