"What complement protein does the classical pathway of activation begin with? C1"
"Complement may be activated via the alternative pathway, which occurs spontaneously or when microbial products activate complement"
"What complement protein does the alternative pathway of activation begin with? C3"
"Complement may be activated via the lectin pathway, which is mediated by mannose on microbial surfaces"
"What complement protein does the lectin pathway of activation begin with? C1-like complex"
"All pathways of complement activation result in the production of C3 convertase, which converts C3 to C3a and C3b"
"Which form of C3 convertase is produced via the lectin and classic complement pathways? C4b2b"
"Which form of C3 convertase is produced via the alternative complement pathway? C3bBb"
"All pathways of complement activation result in the production of C5 convertase, which converts C5 to C5a and C5b"
"Which form of C5 convertase is produced via the lectin and classic complement pathways? C4b2b3b"
"Which form of C5 convertase is produced via the alternative complement pathway? C3bBb3b"
"C5b complexes with C6-C9 to form the membrane attack complex (MAC)"
"Which complement proteins are part of the membrane attack complex (MAC)? C5b-C9"
"Which complement protein is a neutrophil chemotactic? C5a"
"Which complement protein is an opsonin for phagocytosis? C3b *bonus: what on the macrophage binds to this?"
"C3b and IgG are the two primary opsonins in bacterial defense, which enhances phagocytosis"
"Which complement protein helps clear immune complexes? C3b"
"Which coagulation factor is a mediator of acute inflammation? Factor XII (Hageman factor)"
"Kallikrein cleaves high-molecular-weight kininogen (HMWK) to bradykinin"
"Bradykinin causes vaso-dilation and increased vascular permeability"
"In addition to vascular effects, bradykinin also mediates pain"
"One cardinal sign of inflammation is rubor, or redness"
"One cardinal sign of inflammation is calor, or warmth"
"The key mediators of redness and warmth in inflammation are histamine, prostaglandins, bradykinin and NO"
"One cardinal sign of inflammation is tumor, or swelling"
"Swelling in inflammation is mediated by endothelial cell disruption (due to tissue damage) and endothelial cell contraction (caused by leukotrienes, histamine, and serotonin)"
"One cardinal sign of inflammation is dolor, or pain"
"The key mediators of pain in inflammation are bradykinin and PGE2, which sensitize nerve endings"
"Fever in inflammation is mediated by release of IL-1, TNF and IL-6 by macrophages in response to pyrogens (e.g. LPS from bacteria)"
"Fever in inflammation is mediated by PGE2, which raises the temperature setpoint"
"Where does leukocyte extravasation predominantly occur? Postcapillary venules"
"What is the first step of leukocyte extravasation? Margination"
"During leukocyte margination, leukocytes marginate from the center::center or periphery of flow to the periphery::center or periphery"
"What step of leukocyte extravasation occurs directly after margination? Rolling"
"During leukocyte rolling, selectin \speed bumps\\" are upregulated on endothelial cells\""
"P-selectin is released from Weibel-Palade bodies"
"Release of P-selectin from Weibel-Palade bodies is mediated by histamine"
"E-selectin expression is induced by IL-1 and TNF"
"Selectins on endothelial cells bind Sialyl-LewisX on leukocytes, resulting in rolling of leukocytes along the vessel wall"
"Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2 is due to a defect in Sialyl-Lewisx"
"What step of leukocyte extravasation occurs directly after rolling? Adhesion"
"ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 are cellular adhesion molecules that are upregulated on endothelium during leukocyte adhesion"
"ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 expression are induced by TNF and IL-1"
"Cellular adhesion molecules (CAMs) on endothelial cells bind integrins on leukocytes, resulting in firm adhesion to the vessel wall"
"Integrin expression is upregulated on leukocytes by C5a and LTB4"
"Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (type 1)::specific type is due to a defect in LFA-1 integrin (CD18)::specific protein on phagocytes"
"What is the mode of inheritance of leukocyte adhesion deficiency? Autosomal recessive"
"Which immunodeficiency presents with delayed separation of the umbilical cord (>30 days)? Leukocyte adhesion deficiency"
"Leukocyte adhesion deficiency is characterized by increased circulating neutrophils"
"Leukocyte adhesion deficiency is characterized by absent neutrophils at infection sites"
"Leukocyte adhesion deficiency is characterized by recurrent bacterial infections (skin and mucosal) with absent pus formation"
"What two steps of leukocyte extravasation occurs directly after adhesion? Transmigration and chemotaxis"
"Neutrophil chemotactants include IL-8, C5a, LTB4, and bacterial products"
"Following leukocyte extravasation, pathogens or necrotic tissue are consumed by phagocytosis"
"During phagocytosis, pseudopods extend from leukocytes to form phagosomes, which are internalized and merged with lysosomes"
"Which immunodeficiency is characterized by impaired phagolysosome formation? Chédiak-Higashi syndrome"
"Chédiak-Higashi syndrome is caused by a defect in the lysosomal trafficking regulator (LYST) gene, resulting in impaired phagolysosome formation"
"What cytoskeletal component is impaired in Chédiak-Higashi syndrome? Microtubules"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Chédiak-Higashi syndrome? Autosomal recessive"
"Which immunodeficiency is associated with albinism? Chédiak-Higashi syndrome"
"Which immunodeficiency is characterized by giant granules in leukocytes and platelets? Chédiak-Higashi syndrome"
"Chédiak-Higashi syndrome is associated with defective primary hemostasis"
"Patients with Chédiak-Higashi syndrome have increased risk for pyogenic infections (e.g. staphylococci and streptococci)"
"Chédiak-Higashi syndrome is characterized by decreased circulating neutrophils"
"Which immunodeficiency is associated with peripheral neuropathy and progressive neurodegeneration? Chédiak-Higashi syndrome"
"Destruction of phagocytosed material occurs through respiratory (oxidative) burst, which utilizes O2 as a substrate"
"What is the end product of oxidative burst that destroys phagocytosed microbes? Hypochlorite (HClO)"
"O2 is converted to superoxide (O2-) by the enzyme NADPH oxidase (oxidative burst)"
"O2- is converted to H2O2 by the enzyme superoxide dismutase (oxidative burst)"
"H2O2 is converted to HClO (hypochlorite) by the enzyme myeloperoxidase (oxidative burst)"
"Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to a defect in NADPH oxidase"
"What is the most common mode of inheritance of chronic granulomatous disease? X-linked recessive"
"Chronic granulomatous disease is characterized by recurrent infection and granuloma formation with catalase-positive organisms"
"How do phagocytes in CGD patients kill catalase-negative organisms? Use H2O2 produced by invading organisms to produce HClO-"
"Which immunodeficiency may be diagnosed with the dihydrorhodamine flow cytometry test or nitrotetrazolium blue test? Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD)"
"Which immunodeficiency may be diagnosed with the nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test? Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD)"
"What color is the nitroblue tetrazolium test in a patient with CGD? Colorless/yellow (negative test)"
"What color is the nitroblue tetrazolium test in a patient without CGD? Blue (positive test)"
"What enzyme is a blue-green heme pigment that gives sputum its color? Myeloperoxidase"
"Which immunodeficiency is characterized by inability to generate HClO (hypochlorite) from H2O2? Myeloperoxidase deficiency"
"Myeloperoxidase deficiency is associated with increased risk for Candida infection, however, most patients are asymptomatic"
"O2-independent killing in phagocytes is less effective than O2-dependent killing"
"Pseudomonas aeruginosa produces pyocyanin, which generates reactive oxygen species (ROS) to kill competing microbes"
"Lactoferrin is a protein found in secretory fluids and neutrophils that inhibits microbial growth via iron chelation"
"How do neutrophil levels decrease following acute inflammation? Neutrophils undergo apoptosis"
"What immune cell predominates after neutrophils (2 - 3 days after inflammation begins)? Macrophages"
"What enzyme in macrophages is primarily used to destroy phagocytosed material? Lysozyme"
"What cytokine is produced by macrophages to recruit neutrophils for persistent acute inflammation? IL-8"
"Acute inflammation may result in abscess formation, which is acute inflammation surrounded by fibrosis"
"Chronic inflammation is characterized by the presence of macrophages, lymphocytes and plasma cells in tissue"
"What is the most common cause of chronic inflammation? Persistent infection"
"Granulomas are collections of epithelioid histiocytes::specific, usually surrounded by giant cells and a rim of lymphocytes"
"Epithelioid histiocytes are macrophages with abundant pink cytoplasm"
"Which type of granuloma lacks central necrosis? Non-caseating granulomas"
"Which type of granuloma is characteristic of autoimmune disease (e.g. Crohn disease, sarcoidosis)? Non-caseating granulomas"
"Which type of granuloma is seen with reaction to foreign material (e.g. berylliosis, retained sutures)? Non-caseating granulomas"
"Which type of granuloma exhibits central necrosis? Caseating granulomas"
"Which type of granuloma is characteristic of tuberculosis and fungal infections? Caseating granulomas"
"Granuloma formation: Macrophages present antigen via MHC II to CD4+ helper T cells"
"Granuloma formation: Interaction between macrophages and Th cells causes macrophages to secrete IL-12, which induces Th1 differentiation"
"Granuloma formation: Th1 cells secrete IFN-γ, which converts macrophages to epithelioid histiocytes and giant cells"
"Granulomatous diseases are associated with hypercalcemia, due to increased 1α-hydroxylase in epithelioid histiocytes"
"What cellular adhesion molecule aids in transmigration during leukocyte extravasation? PECAM-1 (CD31)::... (CD#)"
"DiGeorge syndrome is a developmental failure to develop the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches"
"What chromosomal deletion is associated with DiGeorge syndrome? 22q11 microdeletion"
"The features of a general chromosome 22q11 microdeletion may be remembered with the mnemonic \CATCH 22\\": C: Cleft palate A: Abnormal facies T: Thymic aplasia C: Conotruncal abnormalities (truncus arteriosus"
"DiGeorge syndrome may present with tetany, secondary to hypocalcemia"
"DiGeorge syndrome is characterized by decreased number of T cells"
"DiGeorge syndrome is characterized by decreased serum parathyroid hormone"
"DiGeorge syndrome is characterized by decreased Ca2+"
"DiGeorge syndrome is characterized by an absent thymic shadow on CXR"
"What enzyme deficiency is associated with SCID? (would give you a hint, but this is the only enzyme deficiency assoc /w SCID) Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency"
"Adenosine deaminase deficiency results in buildup of adenosine, which is toxic to lymphocytes; causes SCID"
"What is the mode of inheritance of SCID secondary to ADA deficiency? Autosomal recessive"
"SCID may be caused by a defective IL-2 receptor (most common)"
"What is the mode of inheritance of SCID secondary to a defective IL-2R? X-linked"
"SCID may be caused by MHC class II deficiency"
"Which immunodeficiency presents with recurrent infection, failure to thrive, chronic diarrhea, and thrush? Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)"
"What treatment for SCID is curative? Bone marrow transplant"
"What type of vaccine should be avoided in patients with SCID? Live vaccines"
"Which immunodeficiency is characterized by decreased T-cell receptor excision circles (TRECs)? Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)"
"SCID is characterized by an absent thymic shadow on CXR"
"SCID is characterized by absent germinal centers on lymph node biopsy"
"SCID is characterized by absent T cells on flow cytometry"
"X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia is caused by a defect in the BTK gene"
"What type of gene is the BTK gene? Tyrosine kinase"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Bruton agammaglobulinemia? X-linked recessive"
"Which immunodeficiency is characterized by absent B cells in peripheral blood? X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia"
"What classes of immunoglobulin are decreased in Bruton agammaglobulinemia? All classes"
"Which immunodeficiencies are characterized by absent/scanty lymph nodes and tonsils? X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia and severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)"
"What type of vaccine should be avoided in patients with X-linked agammaglobulinemia? Live vaccines"
"When does X-linked agammaglobulinemia typically present? 6 months after birth"
"Which immunodeficiency is characterized by no B-cell maturation? X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia"
"Which immunodeficiency is characterized by no B-cell differentiation into plasma cells? Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID)"
"When does common variable immunodeficiency typically present? After age 2"
"CVID is associated with low immunoglobulin levels due to decreased plasma cells"
"Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) is associated with increased risk for autoimmune disease and lymphoma"
"What is the most common primary immunodeficiency? Selective IgA deficiency"
"IgA deficiency is characterized by normal levels of IgG and IgM"
"Patients with IgA deficiency may develop anaphylaxis to IgA-containing products (e.g. blood transfusions, gammaglobulins)"
"IgA deficiency may present with increased infections in mucosal sites"
"What parasitic infection are patients with IgA deficiency susceptible to? Giardia"
"Hyper-IgM syndrome is most commonly due to mutated CD40L on Th cells"
"Which immunodeficiency presents with defective class switching? Hyper-IgM syndrome"
"What classes of immunoglobulin are decreased in hyper-IgM syndrome? IgA, IgG, and IgE"
"What is the mode of inheritance of hyper-IgM syndrome? X-linked recessive"
"Hyper-IgM syndrome results in recurrent pyogenic infections, especially at mucosal sites"
"Hyper-IgM syndrome is characterized by absent germinal centers on lymph node biopsy"
"Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is due to a mutation in the WASp gene"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome? X-linked recessive"
"Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is characterized by inability for leukocytes and platelets to reorganize their actin cytoskeleton"
"What classes of immunoglobulin are normal or decreased in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome? IgG and IgM"
"What classes of immunoglobulin are increased in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome? IgA and IgE"
"The symptoms of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome may be remembered with the mnemonic \WATER\\": W: Wiskott A: Aldrich T: Thrombocytopenia (fewer and smaller platelets) E: Eczema R: Recurrent (pyogenic) infections\""
"What is the major cause of death in patients with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome? Bleeding"
"Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is associated with increased risk for autoimmune disease and malignancy"
"Ataxia-Telangiectasia is due to defects in the ATM gene"
"Which immunodeficiency is caused by failure to repair DNA double strand breaks? Ataxia-telangiectasia"
"Ataxia-TelangiectasiA presents with a triad of: - cerebellar defects (Ataxia) but no cognitive defects - spider angiomas (Telangiectasia) - IgA deficiency"
"Which immunodeficiency is associated with increased serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)? Ataxia-telangiectasia"
"What classes of immunoglobulin are decreased in ataxia-telangiectasia? IgA, IgG, and IgE"
"Ataxia-telangiectasia is associated with increased risk of lymphoma and leukemia"
"IL-12 receptor deficiency is characterized by a decreased Th1 response"
"What is the mode of inheritance of IL-12 receptor deficiency? Autosomal recessive"
"IL-12 deficiency presents with decreased levels of IFN-γ::signal"
"Which immunodeficiency may present after administration of the BCG vaccine? IL-12 receptor deficiency"
"Job (hyper-IgE) syndrome is due to a mutation in the STAT3 gene"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Job syndrome? Autosomal dominant"
"What class of helper T cell is deficient in Job syndrome? Th17"
"What class of immunoglobulin is increased in Job syndrome? IgE"
"The symptoms of Job syndrome may be remembered with the mnemonic \FATED\\": F: coarse Facies A: cold (noninflamed) staphylococcal Abscesses T: retained primary Teeth E: increased IgE D: dermatologic problems (eczema)\""
"Which immunodeficiency presents with bone fractures from minor trauma? Job (hyper-IgE) syndrome"
"Job (hyper-IgE) syndrome is characterized by decreased IFN-γ"
"Job (hyper-IgE) syndrome is characterized by increased eosinophils"
"Which immunodeficiency is associated with an absent cutaneous reaction to Candida antigens due to T-cell dysfunction? Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis"
"Which immunodeficiency is associated with an absent in vitro T-cell proliferation in response to Candida antigens due to T-cell dysfunction? Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis"
"Immunodeficiencies with decreased B cells are susceptible to infection by encapsulated bacteria"
"What parasitic infection is more common in patients with decreased B-cells? GI giardiasis (no IgA)"
"Immunodeficiencies with decreased B-cells tend to produce recurrent bacterial, enterovirus, and Giardia infections"
"Immunodeficiences with decreased T-cells tend to produce recurrent viral and fungal infections"
"C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency results in hereditary angioedema"
"Which complement proteins are decreased in C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency? C4 and C2"
"What class of drugs are contraindicated in C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency? ACE inhibitors"
"Terminal Complement (C5-C9) Deficiencies increase susceptibility to recurrent Neisseria bacteremia"
"Which complement deficiencies result in increased risk for Neisseria infection? Terminal Complement (C5-C9) Deficiencies"
"Early Complement Deficiencies (C1-C4) are characterized by increased risk of severe, recurrent pyogenic sinopulmonary::location infections"
"Which complement deficiency results in increased risk for Systemic lupus erythematosus / Glomerulonephritis? Early Complement Deficiencies (C1-C4)"
"Defects in CD-25 on regulatory T cells are associated with multiple sclerosis and type I diabetes mellitus"
"IPEX syndrome is due to a genetic deficiency of FOXP3"
"What is the mode of inheritance of IPEX syndrome? X-linked"
"IPEX syndrome is associated with diabetes in male::gender infants"
"What gender is more commonly affected by autoimmune disease? Females"
"Autoimmune disorders are associated with polymorphisms in the PTPN22 gene"
"What demographic is associated with systemic lupus erytematous (SLE)? Middle-aged females::age, gender"
"What ethnicities are more commonly affected by SLE? African Americans and Hispanics"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is SLE? Type III* HSR (immune complex deposition)"
"Deficiency of early complement proteins are associated with SLE"
"The characteristics of SLE may be remembered with the mnemonic \RASH OR PAIN\\": R: Rash (malar or discoid)::skin A: Arthritis (usually involving > 2 joints) S: Serositis (pleuritis and pericarditis) H: Hematologic disorders (e.g. cytopenias) O: Oral or nasopharyngeal ulcers (usually painless) R: Renal disease P: Photosensitivity A: Antinuclear antibodies I: Immunologic disorder (anti-dsDNA"
"SLE is associated with malar (\butterfly\\") and discoid rashes"
"What is the most common (and severe) form of renal disease in SLE patients? Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN)"
"What type of endocarditis is associated with SLE? Libman-Sacks endocarditis"
"Which antibody is sensitive, but not specific for SLE? Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)"
"Which antibodies are specific, but not sensitive for SLE? anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies::2"
"Which SLE antibody is a useful predictor of disease activity and renal involvement? Anti-dsDNA antibodies"
"SLE is characterized by decreased levels of C3 and C4"
"SLE is characterized by decreased levels of CH50"
"SLE may be associated with antiphospholipid antibodies (e.g. anticardiolipin, lupus anticoagulant)"
"What antibodies are antiphospholipid antibodies? Anti-cardiolipin, lupus anticoagulant, and anti-β2 glycoprotein"
"Anti-cardiolipin is an antiphospholipid antibody that may result in false-positive VDRL and RPR tests"
"Lupus anticoagulant is an antiphospholipid antibody that results in a falsely elevated PTT"
"Is the elevated PTT due to lupus anticoagulant correctable by addition of normal plasma? No"
"Antiphospholipid syndrome can occur as a primary disorder, or as a secondary disorder (e.g. with SLE)"
"Anti-phospholipid syndrome is characterized by a(n) hyper-coagulable state"
"Antiphospholipid syndrome is diagnosed based on clinical criteria including history of thrombosis or spontaneous abortion along with antiphospholipid antibodies"
"What is the treatment for antiphospholipid syndrome? Anticoagulants"
"Which antibody is sensitive for drug-induced lupus? Anti-histone antibodies"
"First-line treatment for SLE includes glucocorticoids for flare ups"
"Common causes of death in SLE patients include renal failure, infection, and cardiovascular disease"
"Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune destruction of lacrimal and salivary glands"
"What demographic is associated with Sjögren's syndrome? Older woman (40-60 years old)::age, gender"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is Sjögren's syndrome? Type IV (lymphocyte-mediated damage)"
"Sjögren's syndrome classically presents with dry eyes, known as keratoconjunctivitis sicca"
"Sjögren's syndrome classically presents with dry mouth, known as xerostomia"
"Sjögren's syndrome may present with recurrent dental caries::oral complication"
"Sjögren's syndrome is characterized by bilateral enlargement of the parotid glands"
"Sjögren's syndrome can be primary (sicca syndrome) or associated with another autoimmune disorder, especially rheumatoid arthritis"
"What non-specific antibodies may be associated with Sjögren's syndrome? Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and rheumatoid factor::2"
"What anti-ribonucleoprotein antibodies are associated with Sjögren's syndrome? Anti-SSA (Ro) and SSB (La) antibodies::full name (short name)"
"The anti-SSA and anti-SSB antibodies in Sjögren's syndrome are against ribonucleoproteins"
"Pregnant women with anti-SSA antibodies are at risk for delivering babies with neonatal lupus and congenital heart block"
"Diagnosis of Sjögren's syndrome is confirmed by presence of focal lymphocytic sialadenitis on labial salivary gland biopsy"
"Sjögren's syndrome is associated with increased risk for MALT lymphoma, which presents as unilateral enlargement of the parotid gland late in the disease course"
"Which autoimmune disease is characterized by sclerosis of skin and visceral organs? Scleroderma (systemic sclerosis)"
"What demographic is associated with scleroderma? Middle-aged females (30-50 years)::age, gender"
"Which autoimmune disease classically presents with puffy, taut skin without wrinkles? Scleroderma"
"Scleroderma may present with fingertip pitting"
"Scleroderma is characterized by fibroblast activation with resultant collagen deposition"
"Limited scleroderma is characterized by limited skin involvement confined to fingers and face"
"Limited scleroderma is also referred to as \CREST syndrome\\": C: Calcinosis cutis (and anti-Centromere Abs) R: Raynaud phenomenon E: Esophageal dysmotility S: Sclerodactyly (thick"
"Which type of scleroderma is associated with the anti-centromere antibody? Limited scleroderma (CREST syndrome)"
"Diffuse scleroderma is characterized by widespread skin involvement with early visceral involvement"
"Diffuse scleroderma is associated with anti-Scl-70 (DNA topoisomerase I) and anti-RNA Polymerase III antibodies"
"What enzyme is targeted by anti-Scl-70 antibodies? DNA topoisomerase I"
"Which type of scleroderma is associated with the anti-Scl-70 antibody? Diffuse scleroderma"
"Sclerosis of what organ is the most common cause of death in scleroderma? Lungs"
"Mixed connective tissue disease has features of SLE, scleroderma, and/or polymyositis"
"Mixed connective tissue disease is characterized by speckled ANA and anti-U1 RNP antibodies"
"Regeneration is the replacement of damaged tissue with native tissue"
"What type of tissue is comprised of stem cells that can continuously cycle to regenerate tissue? Labile"
"What type of tissue is comprised of cells that can re-enter the cell cycle to regenerate tissue when necessary? Stable (quiescent)"
"What type of tissue lacks significant regenerative potential? Permanent"
"Repair is the replacement of damaged tissue with fibrous scar"
"The initial \proliferative\\" phase of wound repair is characterized by deposition of granulation tissue\""
"Granulation tissue consists of type III collagen, capillaries, and myofibroblasts"
"What component of granulation tissue deposits type III collagen? Fibroblasts"
"What component of granulation tissue provides nutrients? Capillaries"
"What component of granulation tissue mediates wound contraction? Myofibroblasts"
"Wound repair eventually results in scar formation, in which type III collagen is replaced with type I collagen (\remodeling\\")\""
"Collagenase is a metalloproteinase enzyme that removes type III collagen"
"Collagenase requires zinc as a cofactor"
"TGF-β is a growth factor that mediates fibrosis and angiogenesis, it inhibits inflammation"
"PDGF is a growth factor that is secreted by activated platelets and macrophages"
"PDGF induces vascular remodeling and smooth muscle cell migration"
"PDGF stimulates fibroblast growth for collagen synthesis"
"What is the primary role of fibroblast growth factor (FGF-2)? Angiogenesis"
"What is the primary role of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)? Angiogenesis / Vasculogenesis"
"Epidermal growth factor stimulates cell growth via tyrosine kinases"
"Cutaneous healing by primary intention is when the wound edges are brought together (e.g. suturing a surgical incision)"
"Cutaneous healing by primary intention leads to minimal scar formation"
"Cutaneous healing by secondary intention is when the wound edges are not approximated"
"Cutaneous healing by secondary intention results in scar formation"
"Delayed wound healing may occur with infection, most commonly due to S. aureus"
"What vitamin deficiency is associated with delayed wound healing? Vitamin C"
"What mineral deficiencies are associated with delayed wound healing? Zinc and copper::2"
"Dehiscence refers to rupture of a wound; most commonly seen after abdominal surgery"
"Scar formation results in 70 - 80% of tensile strength regained by 3 months"
"What type of scar is confined to the borders of the original wound? Hypertrophic scar"
"What type of scar is characterized by parallel collagen organization? Hypertrophic scar"
"Do hypertrophic scars have a genetic predisposition? No"
"Do hypertrophic scars typically recur? No"
"What type of scar extends beyond the borders of the original wound? Keloid scar"
"What type of scar is characterized by disorganized collagen organization? Keloid scar"
"Keloid scars are characterized by very increased type I and III collagen synthesis"
"Do keloid scars have a genetic predisposition? If so, who? Yes (more common in African Americans and Asians)"
"Do keloid scars typically recur? Yes"
"Keloid scars typically affect the earlobes, face, and upper extremities"
"Exudate is characterized by increased LDH compared to serum"
"Exudate is characterized by high levels of protein"
"Transudate is characterized by decreased LDH compared to serum"
"Transudate is characterized by low levels of protein"
"What HLA subtype is associated with hemochromatosis? A3"
"What HLA subtypes are associated with Addison disease? B8, DR3, and DR4"
"What HLA subtypes are associated with Graves disease? B8 and DR3"
"What HLA subtype is associated with seronegative arthropathies? B27"
"What HLA subtypes are associated with celiac disease? DQ2 and DQ8"
"What HLA subtype is associated with multiple sclerosis? DR2"
"What HLA subtype is associated with hay fever? DR2"
"What HLA subtypes are associated with SLE? DR2 and DR3"
"What HLA subtype is associated with Goodpasture syndrome? DR2"
"What HLA subtypes are associated with type I diabetes mellitus? DR3 and DR4"
"What HLA subtype is associated with Rheumatoid arthritis? DR4"
"What HLA subtypes are associated with Hashimoto thyroiditis? DR3 and DR5"
"What HLA subtype is associated with pernicious anemia? DR5"
"Anti-islet cell cytoplasmic autoantibodies are associated with type I diabetes mellitus"
"Anti-synthetase (anti-Jo-1) autoantibodies are associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis"
"Anti-helicase (anti-Mi-2) autoantibodies are associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis"
"Anti-SRP antibodies are associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis"
"What is another name for the p-ANCA antibody? Myeloperoxidase (MPO)-ANCA"
"What is another name for the c-ANCA antibody? Proteinase 3 (PR3)-ANCA"
"Anti-smooth muscle autoantibodies are associated with autoimmune hepatitis type 1"
"Achondroplasia is the most common cause of dwarfism"
"Achondroplasia is due to a(n) activating mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene"
"What is the mode of inheritance of achondroplasia? Autosomal dominant"
"What is the penetrance of achondroplasia? 100%"
"Is achondroplasia typically seen in patients with homozygous or heterozygous mutations? Heterozygous (homozygous is lethal)"
"Over 85% of mutations in the FGFR3 gene occur sporadically and are related to increased paternal age"
"Constitutive activation of FGFR3 inhibits::inhibit/activates chondrocyte proliferation"
"Achondroplasia is characterized by short (rhizomelic) extremities with a relatively large head"
"What type of bone formation is impaired in achondroplasia? Endochondral ossification"
"Achondroplasia is characterized by failure of longitudinal::not endochondral bone growth"
"What MSK pathology is associated with a space between the 3rd and 4th fingers (\trident hands\\")? Achondroplasia\""
"Does achondroplasia affect mental function, life span, and/or fertility? No"
"Osteopetrosis is caused by an inherited defect in bone resorption"
"Osteopetrosis is due to poor osteo-clast function, impairing the ability to remodel bone"
"What MSK pathology is characterized by thick, heavy bone that fractures easily due to failure of bone resorption? Osteopetrosis"
"Osteopetrosis is characterized by diffuse, symmetric skeletal sclerosis on X-ray"
"Osteopetrosis may occur due to mutations in carbonic anhydrase II, which leads to loss of the acidic environment necessary for bone resorption"
"Osteopetrosis is associated with pancytopenia and extramedullary hematopoiesis due to bony replacement of the marrow (myelophthisic process)"
"Osteopetrosis may present with vision and hearing impairment due to cranial nerve impingement"
"Osteopetrosis may present with hydrocephalus due to narrowing of the foramen magnum"
"What is the treatment for osteopetrosis? Bone marrow transplant (osteoclasts are derived from monocytes)"
"Osteomalacia (Rickets) is due to defective mineralization of osteoid"
"What is the most common cause of osteomalacia/rickets? Vitamin D deficiency"
"What MSK pathology is caused by low vitamin D in children? Rickets"
"Rickets may present pectus carinatum (Pigeon-breast deformity)"
"Rickets may present with rachitic rosary due to osteoid deposition at the costochondral junction"
"Rickets may present with frontal bossing and craniotabes (soft skull)"
"Rickets may present with pathologic bow legs (genu varum)"
"What MSK pathology is associated with metaphyseal cupping/fraying? Rickets"
"What MSK pathology is caused by low vitamin D in adults? Osteomalacia"
"What MSK pathology is associated with \Looser zones\\" (pseudofractures) on X-ray? Osteomalacia\""
"Osteomalacia/rickets is characterized by decreased serum Ca2+"
"Osteomalacia/rickets is characterized by decreased serum PO43-"
"Osteomalacia/rickets is characterized by increased serum PTH"
"Osteomalacia/rickets is characterized by increased serum alkaline phosphatase"
"What MSK pathology is characterized by a reduction in trabecular and cortical bone mass and interconnections? Osteoporosis"
"Peak bone mass is achieved by 30 years of age"
"After age 30, slightly less than 1% of bone mass is lost each year"
"Osteoporosis is most commonly due to decreased estrogen levels or increased age"
"Osteoporosis may be secondary to hyper-thyroidism"
"Osteoporosis may be secondary to hyper-parathyroidism"
"Osteoporosis is diagnosed by DXA scan with a T-score of < - 2.5 or a fragility fracture of the hip or vertebrae"
"Prophylaxis for osteoporosis includes regular weight-bearing exercise and adequate Ca2+ / vitamin D intake throughout adulthood"
"What ethnicity is associated with decreased risk for osteoporosis? African Americans"
"Osteoporosis can lead to vertebral compression fractures, which result in loss of height and kyphosis"
"Osteoporosis may present with fracture of the femoral neck or distal radius (Colles fracture)"
"What is test used to measure bone density? DEXA scan"
"Osteoporosis is characterized by normal serum Ca2+"
"Osteoporosis is characterized by normal serum PO43-"
"Osteoporosis is characterized by normal serum PTH"
"Osteoporosis is characterized by normal serum alkaline phosphatase"
"What MSK pathology is characterized by thick, heavy bone that fractures easily due to imbalance of osteoblast and osteoclast function? Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)"
"Is Paget disease of bone a localized or diffuse process? Localized"
"What demographic is associated with Paget disease of bone? Late adulthood (age > 60)::age group"
"What is the first stage of Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)? Osteoclastic (lytic)"
"What is the second stage of Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)? Mixed osteoblastic-osteoclastic"
"What is the third stage of Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)? Osteoblastic (sclerotic)"
"What is the fourth stage of Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)? Quiescent (minimal osteoclast/osteoblast activity)"
"What MSK pathology is characterized histologically by a mosaic pattern of woven and lamellar bone? Paget disease of bone"
"Paget disease of bone may present with bone pain due to microfractures or long bone \chalk stick\\" fractures\""
"What MSK pathology is associated with an increasing hat size due to skull thickening? Paget disease of bone"
"Paget disease of bone often presents with hearing loss due to CN impingement from foramen narrowing"
"Paget disease of bone may present with \lion-like facies\\" due to involvement of craniofacial bones\""
"Paget disease of bone is the most common cause of isolated elevated alkaline phosphatase in patients > 40 years old"
"Paget disease of bone is characterized by normal serum Ca2+"
"Paget disease of bone is characterized by normal serum PO43-"
"Paget disease of bone is characterized by normal serum PTH"
"Paget disease of bone is characterized by elevated serum alkaline phosphatase"
"Treatment for Paget disease of bone includes calcitonin and bisphosphonates"
"One complication of Paget disease of bone is high-output heart failure due to formation of AV shunts in bone"
"What malignancy is associated with Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)? Osteosarcoma"
"Osteomyelitis is an infection of marrow and bone, usually in children"
"What type of microorganism typically causes osteomyelitis? Bacteria"
"Osteomyelitis in children arises with transient bacteremia that seeds the metaphysis"
"Osteomyelitis in adults arises with open-wound bacteremia that seeds the epiphysis"
"What is the most common overall cause of osteomyelitis (90%)? Staphylococcus aureus"
"What cause of osteomyelitis is more common in sexually active young adults? Neisseria gonorrhoeae (rare; septic arthritis more common)"
"What are the top two causes of osteomyelitis in sickle cell disease patients? Salmonella (#1) and S. aureus"
"What cause of osteomyelitis is more common in IV drug users and diabetics? Pseudomonas"
"What cause of osteomyelitis is more common in dog and cat bites? Pasteurella multocida"
"What cause of osteomyelitis is more common in vertebrae? Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Pott disease)"
"What cause of osteomyelitis is more common in prosthetic joint replacement? Staphylococcus epidermidis"
"What mode of imaging is the best for detecting acute osteomyelitis? MRI"
"In addition to MRI, diagnosis of osteomyelitis may be made with blood culture"
"What MSK pathology presents with bone pain and systemic signs of infection (e.g. fever, leukocytosis)? Osteomyelitis"
"Osteomyelitis may be seen on X-ray as a(n) lytic focus (sequestrum) surrounded by sclerosis (involucrum)"
"Osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis) is caused by infarction of bone and marrow"
"What is the most common site for osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis)? Femoral head"
"The causes of osteonecrosis may be remembered with the mnemonic \CAST Bent LEGS\\": C: Corticosteroids A: Alcoholism S: Sickle cell disease::heme T: Trauma (most common) Bent: \\"Bends\\" (Caisson disease) Le: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease G: Gaucher disease S: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE)\""
"Complications of osteomyelitis include osteo-arthritis and fractures"
"Teriparatide is a recombinant form of PTH used to treat osteoporosis"
"Osteoma is a benign tumor of bone::what overall type of structure? that is seen in middle age"
"Osteomas most commonly arise on the surface of facial bones"
"What GI pathology is associated with osteomas? Gardner syndrome"
"Osteoid osteoma is a benign tumor of osteoblasts (which make osteoid), surrounded by a rim of reactive bone"
"What demographic is associated with osteoid osteoma? Males < 25 years old::age, gender"
"Osteoid osteoma typically arises in the cortex of the diaphysis of long bones (e.g. femur)"
"Osteoid osteoma presents with bone pain that is worse at night and DOES resolve with aspirin"
"Imaging of osteoid osteoma reveals a bony mass, < 2 cm, with a radiolucent core (osteoid)"
"Osteoblastoma is benign tumor of osteoblasts, typically > 2 cm"
"Osteoblastoma presents with bone pain, especially at night, that DOES NOT resolve with aspirin"
"Osteoblastoma typically arises in vertebrae::body location"
"Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor with an overlying cartilage cap"
"What is the most common benign tumor of bone? Osteochondroma"
"Osteochondroma arises as a lateral projection of the growth plate (metaphysis)"
"The overlying cartilage in osteochondroma rarely transforms to chondrosarcoma"
"What demographic is associated with osteochondroma? Males < 25 years old::age, gender"
"Osteosarcoma is a malignant proliferation of osteoblasts"
"The peak incidence for primary osteosarcoma is in teenagers (10-20 years old)::specific"
"The peak incidence for secondary osteosarcoma is in the elderly (>65 years old)"
"What MSK pathology predisposes to osteosarcoma? Paget disease of bone"
"Osteosarcoma is associated with radiation exposure"
"What inherited cancers are associated with osteosarcoma? Li-Fraumeni syndrome and familial retinoblastoma::2"
"Osteosarcoma arises in the metaphysis of long bones, often around the knee::body location"
"Osteosarcoma typically presents as a pathologic fracture or bone pain with swelling"
"Imaging of osteosarcoma may reveal a(n) \sunburst\\" pattern on X-ray\""
"Imaging of osteosarcoma may reveal elevation of periosteum, which is known as Codman triangle"
"What bone tumor is characterized by a \sunburst\\" pattern and Codman triangle on X-ray? Osteosarcoma\""
"Biopsy of osteosarcoma reveals pleomorphic cells that produce osteoid"
"What is the treatment for osteosarcoma? En bloc resection and chemotherapy"
"Giant cell tumor is a bone tumor comprised of multinucleated giant cells and stromal cells that express RANKL"
"What demographic is associated with giant cell tumor of bone? Young adults (20 - 40 years old)::age group"
"Giant cell tumor arises in the epiphysis of long bones, often in the knee region"
"Which bone tumor arises in the epiphysis of long bones? Giant cell tumor"
"Giant cell tumor usually arises at the distal femur or proximal tibia"
"Giant cell tumor is associated with a(n) \soap bubble\\" appearance on X-ray\""
"Which bone tumor is associated with a \soap-bubble\\" appearance on X-ray? Giant cell tumor\""
"Giant cell tumor is a locally aggressive benign::benign or malignant tumor"
"Ewing sarcoma is a malignant proliferation of poorly-differentiated cells derived from neuroectoderm"
"Ewing sarcoma arises in the diaphysis of long bones (particularly the femur); other locations include pelvic flat bones, scapula, and ribs"
"What demographic is associated with Ewing sarcoma? Boys < 15 years old::age, gender"
"Ewing sarcoma is associated with a(n) \onion-skin\\" appearance on X-ray\""
"Which bone tumor is characterized by small, round blue cells that resemble lymphocytes? Ewing sarcoma"
"Ewing sarcoma is a bone tumor that is associated with t(11;22) translocation"
"What is the treatment for Ewing sarcoma? Chemotherapy"
"Chondroma is a benign tumor of cartilage"
"Which cartilage tumor arises in the medulla of the small bones in the hands and feet? Chondroma (benign)"
"Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilage-forming tumor"
"Which cartilage tumor arises in the medulla of the pelvis or central skeleton? Chondrosarcoma (malignant)"
"Which is more common, primary bone tumors or metastasis to the bone? Metastasis"
"Metastatic bone tumors usually result in osteolytic (punched-out) lesions"
"Prostatic carcinoma with bone metastasis classically produces osteoblastic lesions"
"The articular surface of adjoining bones is made of hyaline cartilage (type II collagen), surrounded by a joint capsule"
"The synovium lining of joint capsules secrete fluid rich in hyaluronic acid to lubricate the joint and facilitate smooth motion"
"What is the most common type of arthritis? Osteoarthritis (degenerative joint disease)"
"Which joint pathology is caused by a progressive degeneration of articular cartilage, most often due to \wear and tear\\"? Osteoarthritis (degenerative joint disease)\""
"The major risk factor for osteoarthritis is age (> 60); additional risk factors include obesity, joint trauma, and female gender"
"What gender is more commonly affected by osteoarthritis? Females"
"Osteoarthritis classically presents with joint stiffness that improves with rest"
"Osteoarthritis often presents with pain in weight-bearing joints after use (e.g. hip, knees, lower lumbar spine)"
"Osteoarthritis is characterized by fragments of cartilage floating in the joint space, called \joint mice\\"\""
"Osteoarthritis is characterized by eburnation (polishing) of the subchondral bone, due to friction from the opposing bone surface"
"Does osteoarthritis present with symmetric or asymmetric joint involvement? Asymmetric"
"Does osteoarthritis present with systemic symptoms (e.g. fever, fatigue)? No"
"Knee cartilage loss in osteoarthritis begins medially (\bowlegged\\")\""
"Pain management for osteoarthritis includes acetaminophen, NSAIDs, Celecoxib and/or intra-articular glucocorticoids"
"Which joint pathology is caused by a synovitis leading to formation of a pannus (inflamed granulation tissue)? Rheumatoid arthritis"
"Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with synovitis with formation of a(n) pannus, which is proliferative granulation tissue"
"What demographic is associated with rheumatoid arthritis? Women of late childbearing age::age, gender"
"Risk factors for rheumatoid arthritis include HLA-DR4, smoking, and silica exposure"
"Rheumatoid arthritis classically presents with joint stiffness that improves with activity"
"Does rheumatoid arthritis present with symmetric or asymmetric joint involvement? Symmetric"
"Does rheumatoid arthritis present with systemic symptoms (e.g. fever, fatigue)? Yes"
"This image is an example of a \swan neck\\" deformity"
"This image is an example of a \boutonniere\\" deformity"
"Rheumatoid arthritis may present with ulnar finger deviation and radial wrist deviation"
"One complication of long standing rheumatoid arthritis is subluxation of the cervical spine"
"Which arthritis is characterized by joint space narrowing, erosions, and periarticular osteopenia on imaging? Rheumatoid arthritis"
"Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with rheumatoid nodules, which are areas of fibrinoid necrosis with palisading histiocytes in the skin and visceral organs (e.g. lung)"
"Felty syndrome is rheumatoid arthritis with neutropenia and splenomegaly"
"What type of amyloidosis is associated with rheumatoid arthritis? Secondary (AA) amyloidosis"
"Rheumatoid factor is a(n) IgM autoantibody against Fc portion of IgG"
"Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibody is specific for rheumatoid arthritis"
"Which arthritis, osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis, classically involves the PIPs and DIPs? Osteoarthritis (also the 1st CMC)"
"Which arthritis, osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis, is characterized by non-inflammatory synovial fluid (WBC < 2000/mm3)? Osteoarthritis"
"Which arthritis, osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis, improves with rest? Osteoarthritis"
"Which arthritis, osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis, classically involves the PIPs and MCP? Rheumatoid arthritis"
"Which arthritis, osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis, is characterized by inflammatory synovial fluid (WBC > 5000/mm3)? Rheumatoid arthritis"
"Which arthritis, osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis, improves with use? Rheumatoid arthritis"
"Heberden nodes refers to bony swellings in the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints"
"Bouchard nodes refers to bony swellings in the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints"
"Are Heberden and Bouchard nodes seen with osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis? Osteoarthritis"
"Seronegative spondyloarthropathies are a group of joint disorders that lack rheumatoid factor and involve the axial skeleton"
"Seronegative spondyloarthropathies are associated with HLA-B27"
"The seronegative spondyloarthropathies may be remembered with the mnemonic \PAIR\\" P: Psoriatic arthritis A: Ankylosing spondylitis I: Inflammatory bowel disease R: Reactive arthritis\""
"Seronegative spondyloarthropathies may present with inflammatory back pain that improves with exercise"
"What eye pathology is associated with seronegative spondyloathropathies? Uveitis"
"Ankylosing spondylitis involves the spine and sacroiliac joints"
"What demographic is associated with ankylosing spondylitis? Young adult males::age, gender"
"Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by a \bamboo spine\\" appearance on X-ray\""
"Extra-articular manifestations of ankylosing spondylitis include uveitis and aortic regurgitation (due to aortitis)"
"Reactive arthritis is characterized by a triad of conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis, with patients often also having diarrhea::GI"
"Reactive arthritis classically arises in young adults after a(n) GI tract or Chlamydia trachomatis infection"
"Is reactive arthritis characterized by sterile or septic synovial fluid? Sterile"
"What joint pathology is associated with skin psoriasis and nail lesions? Psoriatic arthritis"
"Psoriatic arthritis most commonly involves the DIP joints of the hands and feet"
"Psoriatic arthritis is associated with \sausage\\" fingers and toes\""
"Psoriatic arthritis is associated with a \pencil-in-cup\\" deformity on X-ray\""
"Septic (infectious) arthritis is due to an infectious agent, usually bacterial"
"What is the most common cause of septic arthritis in young adults? Neisseria gonorrhoeae"
"What bacteria typically causes septic arthritis in older children and adults? Staphylococcus aureus"
"Septic arthritis classically presents as a single red, swollen, and painful joint; usually the knee"
"What cause of arthritis presents with purulent synovial fluid (WBC > 50,000/mm3)? Septic (infectious) arthritis"
"Gonococcal arthritis may present with a triad of polyarthralgia, tenosynovitis, and dermatitis"
"Gout is caused by deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals in tissues, especially the joints"
"Is gout more common in males or females? Males"
"Gout is associated with hyper-uricemia"
"Primary gout is caused by an unknown etiology (most common)"
"Gout may occur secondary to leukemia and myeloproliferative disorders due to increased cell turnover"
"Gout may occur secondary to Lesch-Nyhan syndrome due to inability to salvage purines"
"Buildup of lactic acid from von Gierke disease::disorder increases uric acid and leads to secondary gout"
"Gout may occur secondary to renal insufficiency, due to decreased ability to excrete uric acid"
"Does gout present with symmetric or asymmetric joint involvement? Asymmetric"
"Acute gout classically presents as a painful MTP joint of the big toe (podagra)"
"Deposition of MSU crystals (gout) results in activation of neutrophils"
"Acute gout may occur with alcohol consumption due to competition for the same excretion site in the kidney as uric acid"
"Acute gout may occur with red meat or seafood consumption, which are foods rich in purines"
"Chronic gout leads to tophus formation, which are white, chalky aggregates of uric acid crystals"
"Tophi, secondary to gout, often arise on the external ear, olecranon bursa, or Achilles tendon"
"Chronic gout may lead to renal failure due to deposition of urate crystals in kidney tubules (urate nephropathy)"
"Gout is characterized by needle-shaped crystals with negative birefringence under polarized light (seen in synovial fluid)"
"What color are MSU crystals (gout) when under parallel light? Yellow"
"What color are MSU crystals (gout) when under perpendicular light? Blue"
"Pseudogout is caused by deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in tissues, especially the joints"
"Is pseudogout more common in males or females? Both genders affected equally"
"What GI pathology may be associated with pseudogout? Hemochromatosis"
"What endocrine pathology may be associated with pseudogout? Hyperparathyroidism"
"What joint is most commonly affected by pseudogout? Knee"
"Pseudogout may present on X-ray with cartilage calcification (chondrocalcinosis)"
"Pseudogout is characterized by rhomboid-shaped crystals with weakly positive birefringence under polarized light (seen synovial fluid)"
"What color are calcium pyrophosphate crystals (pseudogout) when under parallel light? Blue"
"Dermato-myositis in an inflammatory disorder of the skin and skeletal muscle"
"Dermato-myositis is characterized by peri-mysial inflammation with perifascicular atrophy on biopsy"
"Inflammation in dermato-myositis is mediated by CD-4+ T cells"
"Dermatomyositis may present with a \heliotrope\\" rash"
"Dermatomyositis may present with a(n) malar rash that is similar to SLE"
"Dermatomyositis may present with a \shawl and face\\" rash\""
"Dermatomyositis may present with Gottron papules, which are red papules on the elbows, knuckles, and knees"
"Dermato-myositis is associated with increased risk for occult malignancy"
"Poly-myositis is an inflammatory disorder of skeletal muscle only"
"Poly-myositis is characterized by endo-mysial inflammation with necrotic muscle fibers on biopsy"
"Inflammation in poly-myositis is mediated by CD-8+ T cells"
"Dermatomyositis and polymyositis present with bilateral proximal::proximal or distal muscle weakness"
"What enzyme is elevated in both dermatomyositis and polymyositis? Creatine kinase (CK)"
"Polymyositis and dermatomyositis may have ANA, anti-Jo-1, anti-Mi-2, and/or anti-SRP antibodies"
"What is the treatment for dermatomyositis and polymyositis? Corticosteroids, followed by immunosuppressant therapy"
"Polymyalgia rheumatica is characterized by sudden onset pain and stiffness in the proximal muscles (i.e. shoulders and hips), without::with or without muscular weakness"
"What demographic is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica? Women > 50 years old::age, gender"
"What vasculitis is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica? Giant cell (temporal) arteritis"
"Polymyalgia rheumatica is associated with a(n) normal serum creatine kinase (CK)"
"Polymyalgia rheumatica is associated with a(n) elevated serum CRP and ESR"
"What is the treatment for polymyalgia rheumatica? Low-dose corticosteroids"
"Fibromyalgia presents with chronic, widespread musculoskeletal pain associated with \tender points\\"\""
"Fibromyalgia is associated with a(n) normal serum creatine kinase (CK)"
"Fibromyalgia is associated with a(n) normal serum CRP and ESR"
"Non-pharmacologic treatment for fibromyalgia may include regular exercise"
"Pharmacologic treatment for fibromyalgia may include anti-convulsants or anti-depressants"
"What classes of antidepressant are useful for treating fibromyalgia? TCAs and SNRIs::2"
"X-linked muscular dystrophy is characterized by muscle wasting and replacement of skeletal muscle by adipose tissue"
"What gene is defective in X-linked muscular dystrophy (e.g. Duchenne, Becker)? Dystrophin (DMD) gene"
"Dystrophin normally anchors the muscle cytoskeleton to the extracellular matrix; primarily in skeletal and cardiac muscle"
"Loss of dystrophin (e.g. X-linked muscular dystrophy) results in myo-necrosis"
"Why is the dystrophin (DMD) gene prone to spontaneous mutations? Largest protein-coding human gene"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy? X-linked"
"Duchenne muscular dystrophy is typically due to frameshift or non-sense mutations, resulting in a truncated or absent dystrophin protein"
"Becker muscular dystrophy is typically due to a non-frameshift deletion, resulting in a partially functional dystrophin protein"
"Which is more severe, Duchenne or Becker muscular dystrophy? Duchenne"
"Duchenne muscular dystrophy presents with weakness in the pelvic girdle muscles and progresses superiorly"
"Duchenne muscular dystrophy classically presents with pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles"
"Duchenne muscular dystrophy typically presents before 5 years of age"
"Duchenne muscular dystrophy is associated with increased serum CK and aldolase"
"What is a common cause of death in Duchenne muscular dystrophy? Dilated cardiomyopathy"
"Becker muscular dystrophy typically presents in adolescence or early adulthood"
"Duchenne muscular dystrophy classically presents with the Gower sign, in which a patient uses their upper extremities to help stand up"
"Myotonic dystrophy (type 1) is due to CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the DMPK gene"
"What is the mode of inheritance of myotonic dystrophy? Autosomal dominant"
"Myotonic dystrophy is due to abnormal expression of the enzyme myotonin protein kinase"
"The symptoms of myotonic dystrophy may be remembered with the mnemonic \CTG\\": C: Cataracts T: Toupee (early balding in men) G: Gonadal atrophy Other symptoms include myotonia"
"Myasthenia gravis is caused by autoantibodies to post-synaptic ACh receptors at the NMJ"
"What gender is more commonly affected by myasthenia gravis? Females"
"Myasthenia gravis presents with muscle weakness that worsens with muscle use"
"Myasthenia gravis classically involves the eyes, leading to ptosis and diplopia"
"Do the symptoms of myasthenia gravis improve with administration of an AChE inhibitor (e.g. edrophonium)? Yes"
"What malignancy is associated with myasthenia gravis? Thymoma (also may have thymic hyperplasia)"
"Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is caused by autoantibodies to pre-synaptic Voltage-Dependent Ca2+ Channelss at the NMJ"
"Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome presents with muscle weakness that improves with muscle use"
"What malignancy is associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome? Small cell lung cancer"
"Is the tensilon test (administration of edrophonium) very useful in diagnosis of Lambert-Eaton? No"
"Which is more common, myasthenia gravis or Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome? Myasthenia gravis"
"Raynaud phenomenon is decreased blood flow to the skin due to arteriolar vasospasm in response to cold or stress"
"Raynaud phenomenon is characterized by a skin color change from white (ischemia) to blue (hypoxia) to red (reperfusion)"
"Raynaud phenomenon is called Raynaud syndrome when it is secondary (e.g. mixed connective tissue disease, SLE, CREST)"
"Raynaud phenomenon may result in digital ulceration::not clubbing due to critical ischemia"
"What is the treatment for Raynaud phenomenon? Ca2+ channel blockers"
"Lipoma is a benign tumor of adipose tissue contained within a fibrous capsule"
"What is the most common benign soft tissue tumor in adults? Lipoma"
"Liposarcoma is a malignant tumor of adipose tissue"
"What is the most common malignant soft tissue tumor in adults? Liposarcoma"
"What cell type is characteristic of a liposarcoma? Lipoblast"
"Rhabdomyoma is a benign tumor of striated muscle"
"What is the most common malignant soft tissue tumor in children? Rhabomyosarcoma"
"The layers of the epidermis from surface to base are: 1. Stratum Corneum 2. Stratum Lucidum 3. Stratum Granulosum 4. Stratum Spinosum 5. Stratum Basale"
"Which layer of the epidermis is the regenerative (stem cell) layer? Stratum basalis"
"Which layer of the epidermis is characterized by desmosomes between keratinocytes? Stratum spinosum"
"Which layer of the epidermis is characterized by granules in keratinocytes? Stratum granulosum"
"Which layer of the epidermis is characterized by keratin in anucleate cells? Stratum corneum"
"Which skin layers contain nerve endings, blood vessels, lymphatics, and adnexal structures (e.g. hair follicles, glands)? Dermis and hypodermis::2"
"Which epithelial cell junction prevents paracellular movement of solutes? Tight junctions (zonula occludens)"
"What proteins are tight junctions composed of? Claudins and occludins::2"
"Which epithelial cell junction connects actin cytoskeletons of adjacent cells? Adherens junctions (zonula adherens, belt desmosome)"
"Adherens junctions form a \belt\\" that connects actin cytoskeletons of adjacent cells via cadherins\""
"Which epithelial cell junction connects intermediate filaments of adjacent cells? Desmosomes (macula adherens, spot desmosome)"
"Desmosomes connect intermediate filaments of adjacent cells via cadherins"
"What ion is required by cadherin proteins in epithelial cell junctions? Ca2+"
"Which epithelial cell junction permits electrical/chemical communication between cells? Gap junctions"
"Gap junctions contain channel proteins called connexons, which allow communication between cells"
"Which epithelial cell junction connects keratin in basal cells to underlying basement membrane? Hemidesmosomes"
"What protein in hemidesmosomes binds to fibronectin, laminin, or collagen in the basement membrane? Integrin *bonus-Ca2+ dependent? Y/N"
"What dermatologic lesion is a flat lesion < 1 cm; well-circumscribed color change in skin color? Macule"
"What dermatologic lesion is a macule > 1 cm? Patch"
"What dermatologic lesion is a elevated solid skin lesion < 1 cm? Papule"
"What dermatologic lesion is a papule > 1 cm? Plaque"
"What dermatologic lesion is a small fluid-containing blister < 1 cm? Vesicle"
"What dermatologic lesion is a large fluid-containing blister > 1 cm? Bulla"
"What dermatologic lesion is a vesicle containing pus? Pustule"
"What dermatologic lesion is a transient smooth papule or plaque? Wheal"
"What dermatologic lesion is a flaking off of stratum corneum? Scale"
"What dermatologic lesion is a dry exudate? Crust"
"Hyperkeratosis is defined as increased thickness of the stratum corneum (e.g. psoriasis, calluses)"
"Which skin layer is thickened with callus formation? Stratum corneum"
"Parakeratosis is defined as hyperkeratosis with retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum (e.g. psoriasis)"
"Hypergranulosis is defined as increased thickness of the stratum granulosum (e.g. Lichen planus)"
"Spongiosis is defined as epidermal accumulation of edematous fluid in intercellular spaces (e.g. eczematous dermatitis)"
"Acantholysis is defined as separation of epidermal cells (e.g. Pemphigus vulgaris)"
"Acanthosis is defined as epidermal hyperplasia (increased spinosum)"
"Atopic (eczematous) dermatitis presents with an intensely pruritic, oozing rash with vesicles and edema due to a type I HSR"
"Atopic (eczematous) dermatitis usually appears on the face in infancy"
"Atopic (eczematous) dermatitis often manifests as lichenification on flexor surfaces in children and adults"
"Atopic (eczematous) dermatitis is associated with asthma and allergic rhinitis"
"Atopic (eczematous) dermatitis is associated with increased serum IgE"
"Contact dermatitis presents with a pruritic, oozing rash with vesicles and edema due to a type IV HSR"
"Contact dermatitis arises upon exposure to allergens (e.g. nickel, poison ivy, neomycin)"
"Treatment of contact dermatitis involves removal of the offending agent and topical glucocorticoids if needed"
"Acne vulgaris is due to chronic inflammation of hair follicles and associated sebaceous glands, which secrete its contents through a(n) holocrine mechanism"
"Acne arises due to hormone-related increase in sebum and blockage of hair follicles by excess keratin"
"What bacteria causes acne by producing lipases that break down sebum, releasing proinflammatory fatty acids? Propionibacterium (Cutibacterium) acnes"
"Treatment of acne vulgaris may include benzoyl peroxide and antibiotics, which are anti-microbial"
"Treatment of acne vulgaris may include vitamin A derivatives, which reduces hyperkeratinzation and sebum production"
"Psoriasis is a characterized by well-circumscribed, salmon-colored plaques with silverly scale"
"Psoriasis typically presents on extensor surfaces and the scalp"
"Psoriasis is associated with nail pitting and psoriatic arthritis"
"Psoriasis is due to excessive keratinocyte proliferation"
"What HLA subtype is associated with psoriasis? HLA-C"
"Psoriasis is characterized histologically by acanthosis with parakeratosis"
"Psoriasis may be associated with Munro microabscesses, which are collections of neutrophils in the stratum corneum"
"Psoriasis is associated with Auspitz sign, which is pinpoint bleeding when scale is picked off"
"Psoriasis is associated with increased thickness of the stratum spinosum"
"Psoriasis is associated with decreased thickness of the stratum granulosum"
"Treatment for psoriasis includes corticosteroids, PUVA (psoralen + UV-A light), or immune-modulating thrapy"
"What inflammatory dermatitis presents as pruritic, planar, polygonal, purple papules? Lichen planus"
"Lichen planus often presents on the wrists, elbows, and oral mucosa"
"Lichen planus often presents with reticular white lines on the surface, known as Wickham striae, especially on oral mucosa"
"Lichen planus is characterized histologically by inflammation of the dermal-epidermal junction with a \saw-tooth\\" appearance\""
"Which inflammatory dermatitis has a \saw-tooth\\" appearance histologically? Lichen planus\""
"Lichen planus is an inflammatory dermatitis associated with chronic hepatitis C infection"
"Which inflammatory dermatitis presents with hypergranulosis? Lichen planus"
"Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune inactivation of desmosomes between keratinocytes"
"Pemphigus vulgaris is due to IgG antibodies against desmoglein::specific antigen"
"Which blistering skin disorder presents with thin-walled bullae that rupture easily? Pemphigus vulgaris"
"Which blistering skin disorder is characterized by acantholysis? Pemphigus vulgaris"
"Which blistering skin disorder is characterized histologically by a \tombstone\\" appearance? Pemphigus vulgaris\""
"Which blistering skin disorder, pemphigus vulgaris or bullous pemphigoid, may involve the oral mucosa? Pemphigus vulgaris"
"Is pemphigus vulgaris associated with a positive Nikolsky sign (separation of epidermis with manual stroking of skin)? Yes"
"Which blistering skin disorder is characterized by a \fish net\\" (reticular) pattern on immunofluorescence? Pemphigus vulgaris\""
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid? Type II HSR"
"Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune destruction of hemidesmosomes between basal cells and the underlying basement membrane"
"Bullous pemphigoid is due to IgG antibodies against hemidesmosome components (BP180)"
"Which blistering skin disorder presents with tense blisters with eosinophils that don't rupture easily? Bullous pemphigoid"
"Which blistering skin disorder is characterized histologically by detachment of the basal cell layer from the basement membrane? Bullous pemphigoid"
"Does bullous pemphigoid typically involve the oral mucosa? No"
"Is bullous pemphigoid associated with a positive Nikolsky sign (separation of epidermis with manual stroking of skin)? No"
"Which blistering skin disorder is characterized by a linear pattern on immunofluorescence? Bullous pemphigoid"
"Which blistering skin disorder, pemphigus vulgaris or bullous pemphigoid is more severe? Pemphigus vulgaris (\vulgaris is vulgar\\")\""
"Dermatitis herpetiformis is an autoimmune deposition of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae"
"Which blistering skin disorder presents as pruritic vesicles and bullae that are grouped? Dermatitis herpetiformis"
"What malabsorption syndrome is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis? Celiac disease"
"Dermatitis herpetiformis may be treated with dapsone and a gluten-free diet"
"Which blistering skin disorder is characterized by a targetoid rash and bullae? Erythema multiforme"
"The targetoid appearance of erythema multiforme is due to central epidermal necrosis, surrounded by erythema"
"Erythema multiforme is a blistering skin disorder most commonly associated with HSV infection"
"In addition to HSV, what other infection is associated with erythema multiforme? Mycoplasma pneumoniae"
"Erythema multiforme with lip/oral mucosal involvement and fever is termed Stevens-Johnson syndrome"
"Which blistering skin disorder is characterized by fever and sloughing of skin at the dermal-epidermal junction? Stevens-Johnson syndrome"
"Stevens-Johnson syndrome typically arises as an adverse drug reaction"
"When Stevens-Johnson syndrome involves > 30% of the body surface it is termed toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)"
"Seborrheic keratoses are benign::benign or malignant squamous neoplasms, typically seen on the head, trunk, and extremities in the elderly"
"Which skin disorder can present as a raised, discolored plaque with a waxy, \stuck on\\" appearance? Seborrheic keratosis\""
"Seborrheic keratosis is characterized histologically by keratin pseudocysts (horn cysts)"
"The Leser-Trélat sign is sudden onset of multiple seborrheic keratoses and suggests underlying malignancy (e.g. GI tract)"
"Which skin disorders presents with epidermal hyperplasia and darkening of the skin (\velvet-like\\" skin)? Acanthosis nigricans\""
"Acanthosis nigricans is typically associated with insulin resistance or visceral malignancy (esp. gastric carcinoma)"
"Which skin cancer is the most common cutaneous malignancy? Basal cell carcinoma"
"What is the major risk factor for basal cell carcinoma? UV-B light"
"Which skin cancer typically presents as an elevated nodule with telangiectasias, rolled borders, central crusting, and/or ulcerations? Basal cell carcinoma (nodular type)"
"Which skin cancer presents as a \pink"
"Superficial basal cell carcinoma may present as a scaling plaque"
"The classic location for basal cell carcinoma is the upper lip"
"Basal cell carcinoma is characterized histologically by nodules of basal cells with peripheral palisading"
"Does basal cell carcinoma typically metastasize? No (rare)"
"Squamous cell carcinoma is characterized histologically by formation of keratin pearls"
"Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma include UVB-induced DNA damage"
"Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma of skin include immunosuppressive therapy, arsenic poisoning, and chronic inflammation (e.g. draining sinus tract)"
"What is the most common cancer that develops as a result of immunosuppressive therapy? Squamous cell carcinoma of skin"
"The classic location for squamous cell carcinoma is the lower lip"
"Which skin cancer presents as an ulcerative red lesion with frequent scale? Squamous cell carcinoma"
"Does squamous cell carcinoma typically metastasize? No (rare)"
"Actinic keratosis is a precursor lesion of squamous cell carcinoma"
"Which skin disorder presents as rough, \gritty\\""
"Keratoacanthoma is a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma that develops rapidly and regresses spontaneously"
"Melanocytes are responsible for skin pigmentation and are present in the basal layer of the epidermis"
"What cellular organelle is the site of synthesis/storage of melanin? Melanosomes"
"Melanocytes synthesize melanin using the amino acid tyrosine as a precursor molecule"
"What is the embryonic origin of melanocytes? Neural crest"
"Which skin disorder is characterized by localized loss of skin pigmentation? Vitiligo"
"What skin disorder is caused by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes? Vitiligo"
"Which skin disorder is characterized by congenital lack of pigmentation? Albinism"
"Albinism is usually due to decreased tyrosinase activity or defective tyrosine transport"
"Albinism is associated with increased risk of skin cancer"
"Albinism is associated with a(n) normal melanocyte count with decreased melanin production"
"Freckles (ephelides) are darker than surrouding skin due to increased number of melanosomes"
"Melasma (chloasma) is a mask-like hyperpigmentation of the cheeks associated with pregnancy and OCPs"
"Nevus (mole) is a benign neoplasm of melanocytes"
"Congenital nevi are present at birth and often associated with hair"
"Junctional nevi are flat macules, most commonly seen in children"
"Intradermal nevi are raised papules, most commonly seen in adults"
"Can moles (nevi) transform into melanoma? Yes"
"Melanoma is a malignant neoplasm of melanocytes"
"What is the most common cause of death from skin cancer? Melanoma"
"Melanoma is associated with sunlight exposure and dysplastic nevi"
"Dysplastic nevus syndrome is a(n) autosomal dominant::inheritance disorder characterized by formation of dysplastic nevi"
"The ABCDEs of melanoma are: A: Asymmetry B: Border irregularity C: Color variation D: Diameter > 6 mm::># E: Evolution over time"
"The initial growth phase of melanoma is characterized by radial growth horizontally along the epidermis and superficial dermis"
"Melanoma progresses to vertical growth into the deep dermis"
"Does the radial phase of melanoma growth have a high risk of metastasis? No"
"Does the vertical phase of melanoma growth have a high risk of metastasis? Yes"
"What is the most important prognostic factor in predicting melanoma metastasis? Depth of invasion (Breslow thickness)"
"What is the most common variant of melanoma? Superficial spreading"
"What is the prognosis of the superficial spreading subtype of melanoma? Good (early radial growth)"
"What is the prognosis of the lentigo maligna subtype of melanoma? Good (radial growth, \melanoma in situ\\")\""
"What is the prognosis of the nodular subtype of melanoma? Poor (early vertical growth)"
"Which subtype of melanoma arises on the palms or soles? Acral lentiginous *bonus: cause compared to other types.."
"What area of the body does the acral lentiginous subtype of melanoma typically arise? Palms or soles"
"The highest prevalence of the acral lentiginous subtype of melanoma is more common in which two races? African-Americans and Asians"
"What tumor marker may be used to identify melanoma? S100"
"Melanoma is often driven by activating mutations in B-RAF kinase"
"Metastatic or unresectable melanoma in patients with BRAF V600E::AAs mutations may benefit from vemurafenib, a BRAF kinase inhibitor"
"Which infectious skin disorder is a superficial bacterial skin infection characterized by painful, non-itchy pustules and honey-colored crusting? Impetigo"
"Impetigo is most often due to S. aureus or S. pyogenes infection"
"Bullous impetigo has bullae and is usually caused by S. aureus infection"
"Which infectious skin disorder is an infection involving the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics? Erysipelas"
"Erysipelas is an infectious skin disorder characterized by well-defined border"
"Erysipelas is usually caused by S. pyogenes infection"
"Which infectious skin disorder is an acute, painful infection of the deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissue? Cellulitis"
"Cellulitis is most often due to S. aureus or S. pyogenes infection"
"Which infectious skin disorder is caused by infection with anaerobic \flesh-eating\\" bacteria or S. pyogenes? Necrotizing fasciitis\""
"Necrotizing fasciitis presents with crepitus due to production of methane and CO2"
"Necrotizing fasciitis causes bullae formation, purple::color skin discoloration, and pain out of proportion to exam findings"
"Which infectious skin disorder presents with sloughing of skin with erythematous rash and fever? Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome"
"Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is characterized by epidermolysis of the stratum granulosum"
"Staphycoccal scalded skin syndrome is seen in newborns and children, as well as adults with renal insufficiency"
"Which infectious skin disorder presents as flesh-colored papules with a rough surface? Verruca (wart)"
"What infection is associated with verrucae? HPV"
"Which infectious skin disorder presents as firm, pink, umbilicated papules? Molluscum contagiosum"
"What infection is associated with molluscum contagiosum? Poxvirus"
"Molluscum contagiosum is typically seen in children but can be sexually transmitted in adults"
"Molluscum contagiosum is characterized histologically by cytoplasmic inclusions (molluscum bodies)"
"Rosacea is an inflammatory facial skin disorder characterized by erythematous papules and pustules, but no comedones"
"Which skin disorder is associated with facial flushing in response to external stimuli (e.g. alcohol, heat)? Rosacea"
"Phymatous rosacea can cause rhinophyma, which is a bulbous deformation of the nose"
"Erythema nodosum is a painful, raised inflammatory lesion of subcutaneous fat (panniculitis), usually on the anterior shins"
"Which skin disorder begins as a \Herald patch\\" followed days later by other scaly"
"Which type of UV light is the main cause of sunburn? UV-B"
"Which type of UV light is the main cause of tanning and photoaging? UV-A"
"Which type of UV light increases risk of skin cancer? Both UVA and UVB :)"
"What vascular tumor is a benign, capillary skin papule caused by Bartonella henselae infection in AIDS patients? Bacillary angiomatosis"
"Bacillary angiomatosis has a(n) neutrophilic infiltrate, which distinguishes it from Kaposi sarcoma"
"What vascular tumor is associated with HHV-8 and HIV? Kaposi sarcoma"
"Kaposi sarcoma has a(n) lymphocytic infiltrate, which distinguishes it from bacillary angiomatosis"
"What vascular tumor is a benign capillary hemangioma seen in elderly individuals? Cherry hemangioma"
"Do cherry hemangiomas regress? No"
"What vascular tumor is a benign capillary hemangioma seen in infants? Strawberry hemangioma"
"Strawberry (superficial) hemangiomas appear in the first few weeks of life and grow rapidly, before regressing spontaneously"
"Do strawberry (superficial) hemangiomas regress? Yes"
"What vascular tumor is a cavernous lymphangioma of the neck, associated with Turner syndrome? Cystic hygroma"
"What vascular tumor is a benign, painful, red-blue tumor, formed from AV shunts under fingernails? Glomus tumor"
"Glomus tumors arise from modified smooth muscle cells of the thermoregulatory glomus body"
"What vascular tumor is a polyploid lobulated capillary hemangioma that is associated trauma and pregnancy? Pyogenic granuloma"
"What skin disorder is characterized by painful, pruritic hyperpigmented papules and pustules that occur as a result of shaving? Pseudofolliculitis barbae"
"What demographic is associated with pseudofolliculitis barbae? African-American males"
"Vitamin K is a cofactor for the enzymatic activation of clotting factors"
"Vitamin K promotes γ-carboxylation of factors II, VII, IX, X and protein C/S"
"Vitamin K promotes γ-carboxylation at glutamic acid::amino acid residues"
"What enzyme activates vitamin K? Epoxide reductase"
"What is the mechanism of action of warfarin? Epoxide reductase inhibitor::specific enzyme"
"Warfarin is an anti-coagulant that intereferes with γ-carboxylation of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X)"
"What is the first clotting factor to be reduced when starting warfarin therapy? Factor VII"
"Warfarin's onset of action is 8 - 12 hours (slow)"
"What is the route of administration of warfarin? Oral"
"Warfarin has a(n) long half-life"
"What laboratory assay is used to follow the effects of warfarin? PT/INR"
"The goal INR for warfarin therapy is typically between 2 - 3"
"Which anticoagulant, warfarin or heparin, is used for chronic anticoagulation? Warfarin"
"Does warfarin cross the placenta? Yes (lipid soluble)"
"Warfarin can cause hemorrhage and abnormal bone formation in utero"
"The anti-coagulants protein C and S are reduced early in warfarin therapy, leading to a(n) hyper-coagulable state"
"What warfarin complication presents a few days after beginning treatment due to an early transient hypercoagulable state? Warfarin-induced skin necrosis"
"Coadministration of heparin when starting warfarin therapy prevents the early hypercoagulable state"
"Warfarin anti-coagulation can be reversed with vitamin K (delayed effect)"
"For rapid reversal of warfarin, fresh frozen plasma (FFP) or prothrombin complex concentrates (PCC) should be administered"
"Warfarin is metabolized by cytochrome P450 and thus has many drug interactions"
"Metabolism of warfarin is affected by polymorphisms in the genes for vitamin K epoxide reductase complex (VKORC1) and CYP2C9::specific (p450 enzyme which metabolizes warfarin)"
"Which anticoagulant, warfarin or heparin, has a slow onset of action (days)? Warfarin"
"What is the site of action of warfarin? Liver::organ"
"Unfractionated heparin is the largest indirect thrombin inhibitor"
"Heparin exerts its effects by activating antithrombin III"
"Which clotting factors are inactivated by unfractionated heparin? Thrombin (IIa) and factor Xa"
"What laboratory assay is used to follow heparin activity? aPTT"
"Which anticoagulant, warfarin or heparin, is used for immediate anticoagulation? Heparin"
"Which anticoagulant, warfarin or heparin, may be used in the setting of an acute MI? Heparin"
"What are the routes of administration of heparin? IV::acute or subcutaneous::prophylaxis"
"What is the cause of a hypercoagulable state in a patient on heparin therapy? Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)"
"What effect may heparin have on K+ levels? Increased (hyperkalemia; secondary to hypoaldosteronism)"
"What MSK pathology is associated with heparin use? Osteoporosis"
"What treatment is used for reversal of heparin therapy? Protamine sulfate"
"Unfractionated heparin has a relatively short half-life"
"What drug class do enoxaparin and dalteparin belong to? Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)"
"Which clotting factors are inactivated by the low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)? Mostly Factor Xa, but also Thrombin, Factor XIa, and Factor IXa"
"How is low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) eliminated from the body? Renal excretion"
"Does heparin cross the placenta? No (water soluble)"
"Which anticoagulant, warfarin or heparin, has a fast onset of action (hours)? Heparin"
"What is the site of action of heparin? Blood"
"Fondaparinux is an anticoagulant that acts only on factor Xa"
"Is protamine sulfate effective at reversing the effects of LMWH and fondaparinux? No"
"Compared to heparin, LMWH and fondaparinux have longer half-lives"
"One advantage of LMWH and fondaparinux is that they do not require routine monitoring"
"Compared to unfractionated heparin, LMWH and fondaparinux are less likely to cause HIT"
"What drug class does bivalirudin belong to? Direct thrombin inhibitor"
