"What drug class do argatroban and dabigatran belong to? Direct thrombin inhibitors"
"Which direct thrombin inhibitor is administered orally? Dabigatran"
"Do direct thrombin inhibitors require lab monitoring? No"
"What class of anticoagulants are used to treat heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)? Direct thrombin inhibitors"
"What drug is used to reverse the effects of dabigatran? Idarucizumab"
"What drug class does rivaroxaban and apixaban belong to? Direct Xa inhibitors"
"What is the route of administration of direct factor Xa inhibitors (apixaban, rivaroxaban)? Oral"
"Do direct factor Xa inhibitors (apixaban, rivaroxaban) require lab monitoring? No"
"Direct factor Xa inhibitors may be used for stroke prophylaxis in patients with atrial fibrillation"
"Are the effects of direct factor Xa inhibitors easily reversible? No"
"What adverse effect is common to all anticoagulants (heparin, direct thrombin inhibitors, direct Xa inhibitors, etc.) Bleeding"
"Binding between vWF and platelets occurs via the GPIb receptor"
"ADP is released upon platelet degranulation and binds to P2Y12 receptors on platelets, resulting in platelet aggregation"
"Thromboxane A2 is released upon platelet degranulation and causes platelet aggregation and activation"
"Thromboxane A2 is synthesized within platelets by the enzyme COX-1"
"Cyclooxygenase-2 expression is induced by inflammation"
"What is the precursor molecule of thromboxane A2? Arachidonic acid"
"TXA2 causes vaso-constriction"
"Does aspirin inhibit COX-1 or COX-2? Both :)"
"Is aspirin a reversible or irreversible inhibitor of COX-1 and COX-2? Irreversible"
"Aspirin inhibits cyclooxygenase via irreversible covalent acetylation"
"Aspirin may cause a \pseudo-allergy\\" due to excess leukotriene synthesis\""
"What ADP receptor inhibitor is reversible? Ticagrelor"
"ADP receptor inhibitors (e.g. clopidogrel) prevent expression of GPIIb/IIIa receptors on the platelet surface"
"Do ADP receptor inhibitors reduce risk of future cardiovascular events? Yes"
"Do ADP receptor inhibitors reduce symptoms of claudication in peripheral artery disease? No"
"In the setting of acute MI, aspirin should be administered in a(n) chewable form"
"Dual-platelet therapy with aspirin and ADP receptor inhibitors is used to prevent coronary stent thrombosis"
"What drug class does ticlopidine belong to? ADP receptor inhibitor"
"Ticlopidine is an ADP receptor antagonist associated with granulocytopenia as an adverse effect"
"Platelet aggregation occurs via binding between the GPIIb/IIIa receptor and fibrinogen"
"What drug class does abciximab belong to? GPIIb/IIIa inhibitor"
"Abciximab is a monoclonal IgG antibody against the GPIIb/IIIa receptor"
"What drug class do eptifibatide and tirofiban belong to? GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors"
"What adverse hematologic effect is associated with GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors? Thrombocytopenia"
"What laboratory assay is increased with anti-platelet therapy? Bleeding time"
"What drug class does dipyridamole belong to? Nonspecific PDE inhibitor"
"What drug class does cilostazol belong to? Antiplatelet PDE-3 inhibitor"
"PDE inhibitors (e.g. cilostazol, dipyridamole) increase cAMP, which inhibits platelet aggregation"
"In addition to preventing platelet aggregation, cilostazol and dipyridamole also cause vaso-dilation"
"Can PDE inhibitors reduce symptoms of claudication in peripheral artery disease? Yes (e.g. cilostazol)"
"Cilostazol causes coronary artery vasodilation, which may result in coronary steal syndrome"
"What class of anti-platelet drugs may cause facial flushing and abdominal pain as adverse effects? PDE inhibitors (cilostazol, dipyridamole)"
"What class of anti-platelet drugs may cause TTP as an adverse effect? ADP receptor inhibitors"
"What class of anti-platelet drugs may cause thrombocytopenia as an adverse effect? GPIIb/IIIa inhibitors"
"What drug class do alteplase, reteplase, tenecteplase belong to? Thrombolytics (recombinant tPA)"
"What drug class does streptokinase belong to? Thrombolytics"
"Thrombolytics exert their effects via direct or indirect conversion of plasminogen to plasmin"
"Activated plasmin degrades fibrin clots"
"Thrombolytics result in a(n) elevated PT and elevated PTT"
"What effect do thrombolytics have on platelet count? No effect"
"What type of stroke (hemorrhagic, ischemic) may be treated with thrombolytics, and in what time frame? Ischemic::type? (if within 3 - 4.5 hours::timeframe?)"
"IV thrombolytics can be used for direct thrombolysis of severe PE and DVT"
"What class of drugs may be used for reperfusion therapy for STEMI when PCI is not available? Thrombolytics"
"What is the preferred reperfusion therapy for STEMI? Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)"
"PCI is ideally performed within 2 hours in the setting of acute STEMI"
"What is the main adverse effect of thrombolytics? Bleeding"
"Thrombolytics are contraindicated in patients with recent surgery or head trauma"
"Thrombolytics are contraindicated in patients with any signs of active bleeds"
"Thrombolytics are contraindicated in patients with severe hypertension::BP"
"What adverse effect is rarely associated with streptokinase use? Allergic reaction and anaphylaxis"
"What drugs are used to reverse the effects of thrombolytics? Aminocaproic acid and Tranexamic acid"
"Reversal of thrombolytic therapy may involve platelet transfusions or factor corrections (e.g. FFP, cryoprecipitate, PCC)"
"What is the precursor molecule to prostanoids and leukotrienes? Arachidonic acid"
"Phospholipase A2 hydrolyzes arachidonic acid from the cell membrane"
"COX-1 is constitutively expressed"
"COX-2 is inducible by inflammation"
"COX-1 synthesizes gastric cytoprotective prostaglandins"
"COX-2 is expressed in vascular endothelial cells and smooth muscle cells"
"Prostacyclin (PGI2) is synthesized by COX-2"
"Prostacyclin (PGI2) is a potent vaso-dilator"
"PGI2 inhibits platelet aggregation"
"Which form(s) of cyclooxygenase synthesize prostaglandins that dilate the afferent arteriole? Both COX-1 and COX-2 :)"
"COX-2 synthesizes prostaglandins that increase vascular permeability"
"Which form(s) of cyclooxygenase synthesize prostaglandins that increase pain sensitivity? COX-2"
"Which form(s) of cyclooxygenase synthesize prostaglandins that induce fever? COX-2"
"Do most NSAIDs inhibit COX-1 or COX-2? Both :)"
"Do most NSAIDs reversibly or irreversibly inhibit COX-1 and COX-2? Reversibly (except aspirin)"
"What drug class do diclofenac and ketorolac belong to? NSAIDs"
"What drug class does indomethacin belong to? NSAIDs"
"What drug class do meloxicam and piroxicam belong to? NSAIDs"
"What drug class does naproxen belong to? NSAIDs"
"One adverse effect of NSAIDs is gastric ulcers::GI due to inhibition of COX-1"
"Most NSAIDs increase risk of GI bleeding due to inhibition of TXA2 (platelet aggregator)::not COX"
"Inhibition of COX-1 by NSAIDs leads to increased bleeding time"
"NSAIDs can increase blood pressure"
"NSAIDs can cause acute interstitial nephritis as an adverse effect"
"NSAIDs cause vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole of the kidney, which decreases GFR"
"NSAIDs can cause renal papillary::kidney necrosis as an adverse effect"
"NSAIDs may reduce excretion of lithium, which is commonly used as an antipsychotic drug"
"What type of anemia will rarely be caused by NSAID therapy? Aplastic anemia"
"Which NSAID is most associated with aplastic anemia? Indomethacin"
"What effect may NSAIDs have on K+ levels? Increased (hyperkalemia; secondary to hypoaldosteronism)"
"What is the primary effect of low doses (< 300mg/day) of aspirin? Decreased platelet aggregation"
"What is the primary effect of intermediate doses (300 - 2400mg/day) of aspirin? Antipyretic and analgesic"
"What is the primary effect of high doses (> 2400mg/day) of aspirin? Anti-inflammatory"
"What vasculitis is treated with aspirin? Kawasaki disease"
"What adverse effect may be caused by aspirin administration to a child with a viral infection? Reye's syndrome"
"What acid-base disorder is seen with early phases of aspirin toxicity? Respiratory alkalosis"
"What acid-base disorder is seen with late phases of aspirin toxicity? High anion gap metabolic acidosis"
"Aspirin is an NSAID that is associated with tinnitus::ear as an adverse effect"
"In the setting of acute aspirin toxicity, activated charcoal can be used to absorb aspirin"
"Aspirin toxicity may be treated with alkalinization of serum/urine"
"NSAIDs may be contraindicated for patients with renal insufficiency"
"NSAIDs may be contraindicated during the 3rd trimester of pregnancy due to risk of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus"
"What drug class does celecoxib belong to? Selective COX-2 inhibitor"
"Which NSAID has reduced risk of ulcers and bleeding? Celecoxib"
"What adverse effect is associated with celecoxib use? Increased risk of thrombosis"
"Which NSAID is a sulfa drug? Celecoxib"
"Are NSAIDs useful as antipyretics and analgesics? Yes"
"Are NSAIDs useful as anti-inflammatory agents? Yes"
"Acetaminophen exerts its effects via reversible::reversible or irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase"
"Where does acetaminophen exert its effects? CNS (Inactivated peripherally)"
"Is acetaminophen useful as an antipyretic and analgesic? Yes"
"Is acetaminophen useful as an anti-inflammatory agent? No"
"What toxic intermediate is formed in small amounts by metabolism of acetaminophen? NAPQI"
"Acetaminophen toxicity results in depletion of hepatic glutathione stores by NAPQI"
"Overdose of acetaminophen causes hepatic necrosis"
"In the setting of acute acetaminophen toxicity, activated charcoal can be used to absorb acetaminopen"
"What is the antidote for acetaminophen poisoning? N-acetylcysteine"
"N-acetylcysteine helps restore reduced glutathione stores in the setting of acetaminophen toxicity"
"Two distinct etiologies of oral cancer Tobacco/Alcohol use; HPV (human papilloma virus)"
"What infection is associated with cancer of the tonsil, base of the tongue and oropharynx? HPV"
"Reversible inhibition of growth Bacterio-static"
"Irreversible inhibition of growth Bacterio-cidal"
"What is the lowest concentration of an antibiotic that prevents visible growth of bacteria called? Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC)"
"Penicillins are what class of antibiotics? β-lactams"
"Cephalosporins are what class of antibiotic? β-lactam"
"Carbapenems are what class of antibiotics? β-lactams"
"Monobactams such as Aztreonam are what class of antibiotics? β-lactams"
"What bacterial enzyme hydrolyzes the β-lactam ring of certain penicillins and cephalosporins (β-lactam's), rendering them inactive? β-lactamase"
"All β-lactam antibiotics are bactericidal, as cell walls of bacteria are essential for growth and development"
"β-lactam antibiotics inhibit what family of enzymes involved in cell wall synthesis? Penicillin binding protein transpeptidases"
"What gram staining group have porins in their wall? Gram negative, and thus can downregulate porins in β-lactam resistance"
"Gram-positive bacteria have a cell wall that is easily crossed by β-lactams and does not require presence of porins"
"Penicillinase is a type of β-lactamase that cleaves penicillins"
"Cephalosporinase is a type of β-lactamase that cleaves cephalosporins"
"Which gene of embryogenesis is involved in patterning along the anteroposterior axis and CNS development? Sonic hedgehog gene"
"Which gene of embryogenesis is produced at the base of limbs at the zone of polarizing activity? Sonic hedgehog gene"
"Mutation in the sonic hedgehog gene can cause holoprosencephaly::specific/head"
"Which genes of embryogenesis are produced at the apical ectodermal ridge (thickened ectoderm at distal end of each developing limb)? Wnt-7 and FGF genes::2"
"Which gene of embryogenesis is responsible for proper organization along the dorsal-ventral axis? Wnt-7"
"Which gene of embryogenesis is responsible for lengthening of limbs? FGF (stimulates mitosis of underlying mesoderm)"
"Which gene of embryogenesis is involved in segmental organization of the embryo in a craniocaudal direction? Homeobox (Hox) genes"
"Mutations in hox genes cause appendages to be placed in wrong locations"
"What do homeobox genes code for? Transcription factors"
"Which gene of embryogenesis malfunctioned if a patient develops syndactyly and/or polydactyly? Homeobox (hox) genes"
"Which gene of embryogenesis is affected by vitamin A? Homeobox (hox) genes"
"Within which week of embryogenesis does the bilaminar disc (epiblast, hypoblast) form? Week 2 (2 layers)"
"Within which week of embryogenesis does the trilaminar disc (endoderm, mesoderm, ectoderm) form? Week 3 (3 layers)"
"Within which week of embryogenesis does the neural tube close? Week 4"
"Which weeks of embryogenesis are most susceptible to teratogens? Weeks 3-8 (embryonic period)"
"In which week of embryogenesis does the heart begin to beat? Week 4 (4 weeks = 4 heart chambers)"
"In which week of embryogenesis do the upper/lower limb buds form? Week 4 (4 weeks = 4 limbs)"
"In which week of embryogenesis is fetal cardiac activity detectable by transvaginal ultrasound? Week 6"
"In which week of embryogenesis do fetal movements start? Week 8 (gait at week 8)"
"In which week of embryogenesis do genitalia begin to develop male/female characteristics? Week 10 (\Tenitalia\\")\""
"What is the embryonic origin of the lens of the eye? Surface ectoderm"
"What is the embryonic origin of the sweat and mammary glands? Surface ectoderm"
"What is the embryonic origin of the sensory organs of the ear? Surface ectoderm"
"What is the embryonic origin of the retina? Neural tube (neuroectoderm)"
"What is the embryonic origin of the odontoblasts and bones of the skull? Neural crest"
"What is the embryonic origin of the endocardial cushion and the aorticopulmonary septum? Neural crest"
"What is the embryonic origin of the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus? Neural crest"
"What is the embryonic origin of the muscle, bone, and connective tissue? Mesoderm"
"What is the embryonic origin of the ovaries/testis? Mesoderm"
"What is the embryonic origin of the blood and lymphatics? Mesoderm"
"What is the embryonic origin of the peritoneum (serous lining of cavities)? Mesoderm"
"VACTERL syndrome is due to mesodermal defects"
"What is the embryonic origin of the spleen and kidneys? Mesoderm"
"What is the embryonic origin of the gut tube epithelium and most major organs (e.g. lungs, liver, gallbladder, pancreas)? Endoderm"
"What is the embryonic origin of the parathyroid gland and parafollicular C cells? Endoderm*"
"What is the embryonic origin of the thymus? Endoderm"
"Which error in morphogenesis is characterized by absent organ due to absent primordial tissue? Agenesis"
"Which error in morphogenesis is characterized by absent organ despite the presence of primordial tissue? Aplasia"
"Which error in morphogenesis is characterized by incomplete organ development (primordial tissue present)? Hypoplasia"
"Which error in morphogenesis is characterized by secondary breakdown of previously normal tissue? Disruption (e.g. amniotic band syndrome)"
"Which error in morphogenesis is characterized by extrinsic disruption (after the embryonic period)? Deformation"
"Which error in morphogenesis is characterized by intrinsic disruption (during embryonic period)? Malformation"
"Which recreational drug causes low birth weight, preterm birth, IUGR, and placental abruption? Cocaine"
"What is the leading cause of low birth weight in developed countries? Smoking (nicotine, CO)"
"What compound in swordfish, shark, and king mackarel causes neurotoxicity in the fetus? Methylmercury"
"Vitamin A excess during pregnancy poses an extremely high risk for spontaneous abortion"
"Maternal diabetes may lead to Caudal regression syndrome in infants, which ranges from anal atresia to sirenomelia"
"In addition to caudal regression syndrome, maternal diabetes may result in congenital heart defects, neural tube defects, macrosomia, and neonatal hypoglycemia in newborns"
"What is the leading cause of intellectual disability in the US? Fetal alcohol syndrome"
"What is the mechanism by which fetal alcohol syndrome manifests? Failure of neuronal and glial cell migration"
"What teratogen causes a smooth philtrum and thin upper lip in newborns? Alcohol (fetal alcohol syndrome)"
"In its most severe form, fetal alcohol syndrome may cause heart-lung fistulas and holoprosencephaly"
"The maxillary artery is a derivative of the 1st aortic arch"
"The stapedial artery and hyoid artery are derivatives of the 2nd aortic arch"
"The common carotid artery and proximal part of the internal carotid artery are derivatives of the 3rd aortic arch"
"The true aortic arch::left and proximal part of the right subclavian artery::right are derivatives of the 4th aortic arch"
"The ductus arteriosus and proximal part of pulmonary arteries are derivatives of the 6th aortic arch"
"The branchial clefts/grooves are derivatives of ectoderm"
"The branchial arches are derivatives of mesoderm + neural crest"
"The branchial pouches are derivatives of endoderm"
"The 1st branchial cleft develops into the external auditory meatus"
"The 2nd - 4th branchial clefts form temporary cervical sinuses, which are obliterated"
"A persistent cervical sinus is a branchial cleft cyst within the lateral neck (anterior to SCM muscle)"
"Does a branchial cleft cyst move during swallowing? No (immobile)"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the maxillary process and mandibular process? 1st arch"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the malleus and incus? 1st arch"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the anterior belly of digastric? 1st arch"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the tensor tympani? 1st arch"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the muscles of mastication? 1st arch"
"What cranial nerve(s) are associated with the 1st branchial arch? V3::specific"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the stapes and stapedius m.? 2nd arch"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the posterior belly of digastric? 2nd arch"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the stylohyoid m. and stylohyoid ligament? 2nd arch"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the muscles of facial expression? 2nd arch"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the lesser horn of hyoid? 2nd arch"
"What cranial nerve(s) are associated with the 2nd branchial arch? VII"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the stylopharyngeus muscle? 3rd arch"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the greater horn of hyoid? 3rd arch"
"What cranial nerve(s) are associated with the 3rd branchial arch? IX"
"Which branchial arch/es gives rise to the arytenoid, cricoid, corniculate, cuneiform, and thyroid cartilages? 4th-6th arches"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the cricothyroid m.? 4th arch"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to the levator veli palatini? 4th arch"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to most pharyngeal constrictors? 4th arch"
"Which branchial arch gives rise to all intrinsic muscles of the larynx, except the cricothyroid? 6th arch"

"What cranial nerve(s) are associated with the 6th branchial arch? X (recurrent laryngeal br.)"

"Treacher Collins syndrome is due to neural crest::cell type dysfunction *bonus-failure of migration to which arch?"

"Penicillin V is acid stable, meaning it can be given orally"

"What non-3rd generation group of cephalosporins can be used to treat bacterial meningitis? 4th gen. Cefepime"
"5th generation cephalosporins include Ceftaroline"
"What cephalosporin can bind the altered PBPs of MRSA? Ceftaroline"
"Disulfiram-like reaction is an adverse effect of what β-lactam antibiotics? Cephalosporins"
"Why should tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones be avoided with milk? Divalent cations will chelate the drug, decreasing absorption"
"Linezolid is a protein synthesis inhibitor that can treat nosocomial pneumonia caused by MRSA infections"
"What selection bias occurs when specifically selecting patients from a hospital? Berkson bias"
"What selection bias occurs when specifically selecting healthy people? Healthy worker effect"
"What type of bias is likely to occur when asking patients with disease versus patients without disease about prior risk factors? Recall bias"
"What type of bias occurs when patients change their behavior in response to their awareness of being observed? Hawthorne bias"
"What type of study uses subjects as their own controls? Crossover studies"
"What type of bias is caused by early detection being confused with increased survival? Lead-time bias"
"What type of bias is caused by increased detection of diseases (e.g. cancer) with a more benign course? Length-time bias"
"Which measure of dispersion measures the variability in a set of values? Standard deviation"
"Which measure of dispersion measures the variability of a set of sample means around the true population mean? Standard error"
"As the sample size increases, the standard error decreases"
"What is the equation for standard error? "
"Confidence intervals are a range of values within which the true mean of the population is expected to fall, with a specified probability (usually 95%)"
"How does the width of a 95% confidence interval change with a decreased sample size? Increased width"
"What type of non-normal distribution is suggestive of two different populations (e.g. slow vs. fast acetylators)? Bimodal"
"What type of error is stating that there is an effect when none exists? Type I (false-positive error)"
"What type of error is stating that there is NO effect when one DOES exists? Type II (false-negative error)"
"The probability of making a type 1 error is represented by alpha"
"The probability of making a type 2 error is represented by β"
"The statistical power of a study is calculated by 1 - β"
"The power of a study is increased with increased sample size"
"The power of a study is increased with increased expected effect size"
"The power of a study is increased with increased precision of measurement"
"What statistical test is used to check differences between the means of TWO groups? t-test"
"What statistical test is used to check differences between the means of THREE or more groups? Analysis of variance (ANOVA)"
"What statistical test is used to test the association between two or more categorical variables? Chi-squared"
"Trimethoprim can produce what teratogenic defects? Neural tube defects"
"Fidaxomicin is a macrocyclic antibiotic that works by inhibiting the sigma subunit of RNA polymerase"
"Which urinary antiseptic is used for uncomplicated UTIs in pregnancy? Nitrofurantoin"
"Nitrofurantoin is a urinary antiseptic that can trigger hemolysis in G6PD deficiency patients::disease"
"By what age does the moro reflex normally disappear? 3 months"
"By what age does the rooting reflex normally disappear? 4 months"
"By what age does the palmar reflex normally disappear? 6 months"
"By what age does the Babinski reflex normally disappear? 12 months"
"By what age can an infant lift their head prone? 1 month"
"By what age can an infant roll and sit up? 6 months"
"By what age can an infant stand up? 10 months"
"By what age range can an infant walk? 12 - 18 months"
"By what age can an infant pass objects from hand to hand? 6 months"
"By what age does an infant develop a pincer grasp? 10 months"
"By what age does an infant point to objects? 12 months"
"By what age does an infant develop a social smile? 2 months"
"By what age does an infant develop stranger anxiety? 6 months"
"By what age does an infant develop separation anxiety? 9 months"
"By what age does an infant orient to voice? What about orient to name? 4 months (voice), 9 months (name)"
"By what age does an infant develop object permanence? 9 months"
"By what age can an infant say \mama\\" and \\"dada\\"? 9 months\""
"How many cubes should a toddler be able to stack? Age (year) x 3"
"By what age can a toddler kick a ball? 24 months (2 years)"
"By what age can a toddler climb stairs? 18 months"
"By what age can a toddler feed themselves with fork/spoon? 20 months"
"By what age range does a toddler engage in parallel play? 24 - 36 months"
"By what age does a toddler move away from and return to their mother (rapprochement)? 24 months"
"By what age does a toddler develop an understanding of the concept of gender? 3-4 years"
"How many words can a two year old typically say? 200 (in 2-word sentences)"
"By what age can a preschooler copy lines/circles or draw stick figures? 4 years"
"By what age can a preschooler hop on one foot? 4 years"
"By what age can a preschooler comfortably spend part of the day away from mother? 3 years"
"By what age can a preschooler engage in cooperative play and have imaginary friends? 4 years"
"How many words can a 3 - 4 year old typically say? 1000 (in complete sentences)"
"Children should ride in rear-facing car seats until they are 2 years old"
"Children should ride in car seats with a harness until they are 4 years old"
"Children should use a booster seat until they are 8 years old (or until the seat belt fits properly)"
"Children < 12 years old should not ride in a seat with a front facing airbag"
"Changes in the elderly include increased suicide rate"
"Changes in the elderly include decreased muscle mass and increased fat"
"How does intelligence change in the elderly? No change"
"What type of disease prevention are vaccination and health promotion? Primary"
"What type of disease prevention is screening for disease (individual or community)? Secondary"
"What type of disease prevention is treatment to reduce complications from disease that will have long-term effects? Tertiary"
"What type of disease prevention is identifying patients at risk of unnecessary treatment? Quaternary"
"Clostridium perfringens is a spore-forming gram + bacilli that can be treated by what cell wall synthesis inhibitor? Penicillin What other drug is used in the primary treatment of Clostridium perfringens? Clindamycin"
"Leuprolide, Goserelin, and Buserelin are GnRH analogues"
"Leuprolide, Goserelin, and Buserelin are GnRH analogues with antagonist properties when used in a continuous fashion"
"What cancer may be treated with continuous leuprolide? Prostate Carcinoma"
"Ethinyl estradiol, DES, and mestranol are examples of estrogen analogs"
"Estrogen analogs increase the risk of endometrial cancer when given without progesterone"
"Estrogen analogs induce a(n) hyper-coagulable state"
"Clomiphene is an antagonist at estrogen receptors in the hypothalamus"
"Clomiphene results in increased release of FSH and LH from the pituitary"
"Clomiphene is used to treat infertility due to anovulation (e.g. PCOS)"
"Tamoxifen is an ER antagonist at breast and a(n) agonist at bone and uterus"
"Tamoxifen increases the risk of thromboembolic events and endometrial cancer"
"Tamoxifen is used to treat and prevent recurrence of ER/PR positive breast cancer"
"Raloxifene is an antagonist at breast and uterus and an agonist at bone"
"Does raloxifene increase risk for endometrial cancer? No (estrogen antagonist at uterus)"
"Raloxifene is primarily used to treat post-menopausal osteoporosis"
"What drug class do anastrozole and letrozole belong to? Aromatase inhibitors"
"What drug class does exemestane belong to? Aromatase inhibitor"
"Aromatase inhibitors are used to treat ER positive breast cancer in post-menopausal women"
"What drug class do levonorgestrel, etonogestrel, and megestrol belong to? Progestins"
"The presence of withdrawal bleeding with a(n) progestin challenge excludes anatomic defects (e.g. Asherman syndrome) and chronic anovulation without estrogen"
"What is the mechanism by which progestins, alone, act as a contraceptive? Thicken cervical mucus"
"What drug class do mifepristone and ulipristal belong to? Anti-progestins"
"What is the clinical use of ulipristal? Emergency contraception (anti-progestin)"
"What is the mechanism by which combined contraceptives (progestins + estradiol) act as a contraceptive? Inhibit ovulation"
"Combined contraceptives are contraindicated in patients > 35 years old who smoke"
"Combined contraceptives are contraindicated in patients with increased risk for cardiovascular disease"
"Combined contraceptives are contraindicated in patients who have migraines or breast or endometrial cancer"
"What is the mechanism of action of copper intrauterine devices? Local inflammatory response"
"What is the most effective emergency contraception? Copper intrauterine device"
"Terbutaline and ritodrine are β2-agonists that relax the uterus, thus decreasing contraction frequency during labor"
"Danazol is a synthetic androgen that acts as a(n) partial agonist at androgen receptors"
"Danazol is used to treat endometriosis and hereditary angioedema"
"What neurological side effect is associated with danazol? Pseudotumor cerebri"
"Side effects of danazol include weight gain, edema, acne, hirsutism, and masculinization (androgenic effects)"
"Side effects of danazol include decreased HDL and hepato-toxicity"
"Which sex steroid is used to stimulate anabolism to promote recovery after burn or injury? Testosterone"
"Exogeneous testosterone results in decreased intratesticular testosterone"
"Exogenous testosterone causes increased LDL and decreased HDL"
"Testosterone may promote premature closure of epiphyseal plates"
"What is the mechanism of action of finasteride? 5α-reductase inhibitor"
"Finasteride is used to treat BPH and male-pattern baldness"
"What is the mechanism of action of flutamide? Androgen receptor antagonist (competitive inhibitor)"
"Flutamide is used for prostate carcinoma"
"What steroidogenesis enzymes are inhibited by ketoconazole and spironolactone 17α-hydroxylase and cholesterol desmolase"
"Ketoconazole and spironolactone may be used to reduce androgenic symptoms in PCOS"
"Tamsulosin is a(n) selective α1A/D receptor antagonist used to treat BPH"
"Terazosin is a(n) non-selective α1 receptor antagonist used to treat BPH in patients with hypertension"
"PDE-5 inhibitors result in increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis"
"What is the mechanism of action of minoxidil? Direct arteriolar vasodilator"
"Which calcineurin inhibitor binds to cyclophilin? Cyclosporine"
"Which calcineurin inhibitor binds to FK506 binding protein (FKBP)? Tacrolimus (FK506)"
"Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus are calcineurin inhibitors that block T cell activation by preventing IL-2 transcription"
"Are cyclosporine and tacrolimus nephrotoxic? Yes (highly)"
"Which calcineurin inhibitor is associated with gingival hyperplasia and hirsutism? Cyclosporine"
"In addition to nephrotoxicity, cyclosporine and tacrolimus may also have neuro-toxicity (especially Tacrolimus)"
"Which calcineurin inhibitor is associated with an even greater risk for diabetes vs the other calcineurin inhibitors? Tacrolimus"
"Sirolimus (rapamycin) is an mTOR inhibitor that binds FKBP"
"Sirolimus (rapamycin) is an immunosuppressant that blocks T cell activation via blocking a step in the IL-2 receptor signaling pathway"
"Is sirolimus (rapamycin) nephrotoxic? No"
"What hematologic adverse effect is associated with sirolimus (rapamycin)? Pancytopenia"
"Sirolimus (rapamycin) is an immunosuppressant that can be used in drug-eluting stents"
"Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody that blocks the IL-2 receptor"
"Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant antimetabolite precursor of 6-mercaptopurine, which inhibits the enzyme PRPP amidotransferase"
"6-mercaptopurine (and thus azathioprine) are degraded by the enzyme xanthine oxidase"
"The enzyme PRPP amidotransferase is an important enzyme for de novo purine production, which converts PRPP to an intermediate used in the generation of IMP"
"Because the bone marrow is a rapidly proliferating population, use of 6-mercaptopurine (and thus azathioprine) is associated with Myelosuppression"
"What enzyme is blocked by the immunosuppressant mycophenolate mofetil? IMP dehydrogenase"
"Mycophenolate mofetil is associated with hyperglycemia"
"Aldesleukin is a recombinant form of IL-2 used to treat renal cell carcinoma and metastatic melanoma"
"Epoetin alfa is a recombinant form of erythropoietin used to treat anemias"
"Filgrastim is a recombinant form of G-CSF"
"Sargramostim is a recombinant form of GM-CSF"
"Romiplostim is a(n) thrombopoetin analog used to treat thrombocytopenia"
"Eltrombopag is a(n) thrombopoetin receptor agonist used to treat thrombocytopenia"
"Oprelvekin is a recombinant form of IL-11 used to treat thrombocytopenia"
"Alemtuzumab is primarily used to treat Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia and Multiple Sclerosis"
"Because Bevacizumab impairs sustained angiogenesis, this makes it especially useful for metastatic tumors"
"Cetuximab is a monoclonal antibody against the EGF Receptor most commonly used to treat Stage IV colorectal cancer"
"Adalimumab is a monoclonal antibody against TNF-α"
"Certolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against TNF-α"
"Golimumab is a monoclonal antibody against TNF-α"
"Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody against TNF-α"
"Etanercept is a decoy soluble receptor that binds TNF-a"
"Daclizumab is a monoclonal antibody against CD25 (part of IL-2 receptor) that is used to treat relapsing multiple sclerosis"
"Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against α4-integrin used to treat Multiple Sclerosis and Crohn disease"
"Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-12/IL-23 used to treat psoriasis/psoriatic arthritis"
"Abciximab is a monoclonal antibody against the platelet GpIIb/IIIa cell surface receptor"
"Ranibizumab and Bevacizumab are monoclonal antibodies against Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF) which prevents the growth of blood vessel"
"Which interleukin is primarily responsible for fever and acute inflammation? IL-1"
"Which immune cell(s) secretes IL-1? Macrophages"
"Which interleukin is primarily responsible for acute-phase reactant production? IL-6"
"Which immune cell(s) secretes IL-6? Macrophages"
"Which interleukin is a major chemotactic for neutrophils? IL-8"
"Which immune cell(s) secretes IL-8? Macrophages"
"Which interleukin is responsible for activating NK cells and inducing differentiation of T cells into Th1 cells? IL-12"
"Which immune cell(s) secretes IL-12? Macrophages"
"TNF-α is a cytokine released from macrophages that mediates cachexia and shock"
"Which cytokine is responsible for maintaining granulomas in TB infection? TNF-α (from macrophages)"
"Which interleukin is primarily responsible for stimulating T cells (all) and NK cells? IL-2"
"Which immune cells secrete IL-2? T cells (both Th1 and Th2)"
"Which interleukin is primarily responsible for stimulating growth and differentiation of bone marrow? IL-3 (similar to GM-CSF)"
"Which immune cell(s) secretes IL-3? T cells (both Th1 and Th2)"
"Which cytokine is primarily responsible for stimulating monocytes / macrophages to kill the microbes they ingest (macrophage-lymphocyte interaction)? IFN-γ"
"Which immune cells secretes IFN-γ? NK cells and Th1 cells::2"
"Which cytokine increases MHC expression and antigen presentation on all cells? IFN-γ"
"Which interleukin is primarily responsible for stimulating IgE production? IL-4"
"Which immune cell(s) secretes IL-4? Th2 cells"
"Which interleukin is primarily responsible for stimulating IgA production? IL-5"
"Which immune cell(s) secretes IL-5? Th2 cells"
"Which interleukin is primarily responsible for attenuating the inflammatory response? IL-10"
"Interferon-α and -β are glycoproteins synthesized by virus-infected cells that act locally on uninfected cells, \priming\\" them for viral defense\""
"Which immune cell has the cell surface protein CD28? T cells"
"Which immune cell has the cell surface protein CXCR4? T cells (late HIV infection)"
"Which immune cell has the cell surface protein CD40L? Helper T cells"
"Which immune cell has the cell surface protein CD4 and CD25? Regulatory T cells"
"Which immune cell has the cell surface protein CD19, CD20, and CD21? B cells"
"Which immune cell has the cell surface protein B7 (CD80/86)? APCs (B cells, macrophages, dendritic cells)"
"Which immune cell has the cell surface protein CD16 and CD56? NK cells"
"Which immune cell has the cell surface protein CD34? Hematopoietic stem cells"
"Which immune cell has the cell surface protein CCR5? Macrophages (early HIV infection)"
"Which blood transfusion reaction presents with urticaria, pruritus, hypotension, and shock? Allergic/anaphylactic reaction"
"Which blood transfusion reaction is a reaction against plasma proteins in transfused blood? Allergic/anaphylactic reaction"
"What type of hypersensitivity is allergic transfusion reaction? Type I HSR"
"Which blood transfusion reaction presents with fever, headaches, chills, and flushing? Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction"
"Which blood transfusion reaction can be caused by host antibodies against donor HLA antigens and donor WBCs? Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction"
"A febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction can exhibit what type of hypersensitivity reaction? Type II HSR"
"Which blood transfusion reaction presents with fever, hypotension, tachypnea, hemoglobinuria*, and jaundice? Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction"
"Which blood transfusion reaction is caused by host antibodies against donor ABO blood groups or foreign antigen on donor RBCs? Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction"
"What type of hypersensitivity is acute hemolytic transfusion reaction? Type II HSR"
"Which blood transfusion reaction presents with respiratory distress and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema? Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)"
"Which blood transfusion reaction is caused by donor anti-leukocyte antibodies against recipient neutrophils and pulmonary endothelial cells? Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)"
"What ABO type is the universal recipient of RBCs? Type AB"
"What ABO type is the universal donor of plasma? Type AB"
"What ABO type is the universal donor of RBCs? Type O"
"What ABO type is the universal recipient of plasma? Type O"
"Which Rh type is the universal recipient of RBCs? Rh+"
"Which hemoglobin type migrates the furthest from the negative electrode on electrophoresis? HbA"
"Which hemoglobin type migrates the second furthest from the negative electrode on electrophoresis? HbF"
"Which hemoglobin type migrates the third furthest from the negative electrode on electrophoresis? HbS"
"Which hemoglobin type migrates the least far from the negative electrode on electrophoresis? HbC"
"Which anticoagulant has the greatest efficacy on factor Xa? LMWH"
"Which anticoagulant has the greatest efficacy on factor IIa (thrombin)? Heparin"
"Failure of aggregation with ristocetin assay occurs in von Willebrand disease and Bernard-Soulier syndrome"
"What pathologic RBC is seen in liver disease and abetalipoproteinemia (states of cholesterol dysregulation)? Acanthocytes"
"What pathologic RBC finding is seen in a peripheral smear with lead poisoning, sideroblastic anemia, and myelodysplastic syndrome? Basophilic stippling"
"Basophilic stippling in RBCs is a result of aggregation of residual ribosomes"
"What pathologic RBC is seen with bone marrow infiltration (e.g. myelofibrosis, thalassemias)? Dacrocyte (\tear drop cell\\")::2 names\""
"What pathologic RBC is seen with G6PD deficiency? Degmacyte (\bite cell\\")::2 names\""
"What pathologic RBC is seen with end-stage renal disease, pyruvate kinase deficiency, and liver disease? Echinocyte (\burr cell\\")::2 names\""
"What pathologic RBC is seen with hereditary elliptocytosis? Elliptocytes"
"What pathologic RBC finding is seen in bone marrow with sideroblastic anemia, lead poisoning, and myelodysplastic syndrome? Ringed sideroblasts"
"RBC pathologies associated with target cells may be remembered with the mnemonic \HALT\\": H: HbC disease A: Asplenia L: Liver disease T: Thalassemia\""
"Which non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia presents with rapid-onset anemia within the 1st year of life? Diamond-Blackfan anemia (also known as congenital pure red cell aplasia or congenital hypoplastic anemia)"
"Diamond-Blackfan anemia is characterized by increased % HbF, but decreased total Hb"
"What anemia presents with short stature, craniofacial abnormalities, and triphalangeal thumbs? Diamond-Blackfan anemia"
"What glycolysis enzyme deficiency causes hemolytic anemia in a newborn? Pyruvate kinase deficiency"
"Pyruvate kinase deficiency results in increased levels of 2,3-BPG, which causes decreased Hb affinity for O2"
"How does TIBC change with pregnancy or OCP use? Increased"
"How does % saturation change with pregnancy or OCP use? Decreased"
"How does serum iron/ferritin change with pregnancy or OCP use? No change"
"Lead poisoning presents in children exposed to lead paint with mental detoriation"
"Acute intermittent porphyria is due to deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase"
"What is the mode of inheritance of acute intermittent porphyria? Autosomal dominant"
"The symptoms of acute intermittent porphyria may be remembered with the \5 P's\\": 1. Painful abdomen 2. Port wine-colored urine 3. Polyneuropathy 4. Psychological disturbances 5. Precipitated by drugs (e.g. cytochrome P-450 inducers)"
"Does acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) present with photosensitivity? No"
"Treatment for acute intermittent porphyria include heme and glucose, which inhibit ALA synthesis"
"Porphyria cutanea tarda is due to deficiency of the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase"
"What is the mode of inheritance of porphyria cutanea tarda? Autosomal dominant"
"Which porphyrea presents with blistering cutaneous photosensitivity and hyperpigmentation? Porphyria cutanea tarda"
"What is the most common porphyria? Porphyria cutanea tarda"
"Porphyrea cutanea tarda is exacerbated by alcohol consumption"
"Iron poisoning causes cell death due to peroxidation of membrane lipids"
"Which blood transfusion therapy is used to increase Hb and O2 carrying capacity? Packed RBCs"
"Which blood transfusion therapy is used to increase platelet count? Platelets"
"Which blood transfusion therapy is used to increase coagulation factor levels? Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) or prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC)::2"
"Which blood transfusion therapy contains fibrinogen (factor I), factor VIII and XIII, vWF, and fibronectin? Cryoprecipitate"
"Blood transfusions may result in hypocalcemia due to citrate, which acts as a chelator"
"Blood transfusions may result in hyperkalemia due to RBC lysis in old blood units"
"How does libido change in elderly males? No change"
"Which major medical insurance plan has the cheapest monthly premiums and copays/deductibles? Health maintenance organization"
"Can patients with health maintenance organization (HMO) insurance plans see providers outside their network? No"
"Do patients with health maintenance organization (HMO) insurance plans require PCP referral for specialist visits? Yes"
"Which major medical insurance plan denies payment for any service that does not meet evidence-based guidelines? Health maintenance organization"
"Can patients with point of service (POS) insurance plans see providers outside their network? Yes*"
"Do patients with point of service (POS) insurance plans require PCP referral for specialist visits? Yes"
"Compared to other plans, point of service insurances plans have more expensive::cost monthly premiums"
"Which major medical insurance plan has the most expensive monthly premiums and copays/deductibles? Preferred provider organization"
"Can patients with preferred provider organization (PPO) insurance plans see providers outside their network? Yes"
"Do patients with preferred provider organization (PPO) insurance plans require PCP referral for specialist visits? No"
"Which major medical insurance plan limits patients to a network of doctors, specialists, and hospitals without requirement of referrals? Exclusive provider organization (EPO)"
"Do patients with exclusive provider organization (EPO) insurance plans require PCP referral for specialist visits? No"
"Which healthcare payment model involves physicians receiving a set amount per patient assigned to them per period of time? Capitation"
"Which healthcare payment model involves patients paying for each individual service at a pre-determined, discounted rate? Discounted fee-for-service"
"Which healthcare payment model involves patients paying for all expenses associated with a single incident of care with a single payment? Global payment"
"Medi-care is for: - patients > 65 years - patients with end-stage renal disease - patients with Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis - patients < 65 with certain disabilities"
"Medi-caid is state/federal assistance for people with limited income/resources"
"Which part of medicare provides hospital insurance and home hospice care? Part A"
"Which part of medicare provides basic medical bills (e.g. doctor's fees, diagnostic testing)? Part B"
"Which part of medicare provides basic medical bills and hopistal insurance/home hospice care? Part C (Combo of A + B)"
"Which part of medicare provides insurance for prescription drugs? Part D"
"Hospice care is available for patients whose life expectancy is < 6 months::time"
"What is the focus of end-of-life care (hospice)? Patient comfort and pain relief"
"What is the most common cause of death in infants < 1 years old? Congenital malformation"
"What is the most common cause of death in people 1 - 44 years old? Unintentional injury"
"What is the most common cause of death in people 45 - 64 years old? Cancer"
"What is the most common cause of death in people > 65 years old? Heart disease"
"What is the most common cause of hospital readmission in patients with medicare? CHF"
"What is the most common cause of hospital readmission in patients with medicaid? Mood disorders"
"What is the most common cause of hospital readmission in patients with private insurance? Maintenance of chemo-/radiotherapy"
"What is the most common cause of hospital readmission in patients without insurance? Mood disorders"
"Which type of medical error analysis involves a retrospective approach, applied after failure to prevent recurrence? Root cause analysis"
"Which type of medical error analysis involves a forward-looking approach to prevent failure occurrence? Failure mode and effects analysis"
"What pharmokinetic term describes the theoretical volume occupied by total amount of drug in the body relative to its plasma concentration? Volume of distribution (Vd)"
"What formula is used to estimate volume of distribution (Vd)? "
"What is the relative volume of distribution (Vd) of a large/charged molecule? Low"
"What is the relative volume of distribution (Vd) of a plasma protein-bound molecule? Low"
"What is the relative volume of distribution (Vd) of a small hydrophilic molecule? Medium"
"What is the relative volume of distribution (Vd) of a small lipophilic molecule, especially if it can bind to tissue protein? High"
"What compartment is the majority of a drug with low Vd found in? Intravascular (e.g. plasma)"
"What compartment is the majority of a drug with medium Vd found in? Extracellular fluid"
"What compartment is the majority of a drug with high Vd found in? All tissues including fat"
"What formula is used to calculate clearance? \[CL = \frac{ \text{rate of drug elimination}  }{ \text{plasma drug concentration}  }= V_d \times K_e\]"
"What formula is used to calculate half-life in first-order elimination kinetics? \(t_{1/2} = \frac{  0.693 \times V_d  }{  CL } = \frac{  0.693}{ k_e }\) ::either works"
"In first-order kinetics, a drug infused at a constant rate takes 4 - 5 half-lives to reach steady state"
"What formula is used to calculate loading dose? \(LD = \frac{ C_p \times V_d}{F}\)"
"What formula is used to calculate maintenance dose? \(MD = \frac{  C_p \times CL \times \tau }{ F }\)"
"How should loading dose be adjusted in patients with renal or liver disease? Unchanged"
"How should maintenance dose be adjusted in patients with renal or liver disease? Decreased"
"What type of drug interaction is the effect of substance A and B together is equal to the sum of their individual products? Additive (e.g. aspirin and acetaminophen)"
"What type of drug interaction is the presence of A is required for the full effects of substance B? Permissive (e.g. cortisol on catecholamine responsiveness)"
"What type of drug interaction is the effect of substance A and B together being greater than the sum of their individual products? Synergistic (e.g. clopidogrel with aspirin)"
"What type of drug interaction is an acute decrease in response to a drug after initial/repeated administration? Tachyphylactic (e.g. nitrates, niacin, phenylephrine, LSD, MDMA)"
"What drug elimination is characterized by a constant amount of drug eliminated per unit time? Zero-order elimination"
"What drug elimination is characterized by a constant fraction of drug eliminated per unit time? First-order elimination"
"What drug elimination is characterized by an exponential curve? First-order elimination"
"Examples of drugs eliminated by zero-order elimination include phenytoin, ethanol, and aspirin (high concentrations)"
"Which type of drug, ionized or uncharged, is cleared more quickly? Ionized (trapped in urine)"
"What is the treatment for overdose of drugs that act as weak acids (e.g. phenobarbital, methotrexate, aspirin)? Bicarbonate (alkalinize urine)"
"What is the treatment for overdose of drugs that act as weak bases (e.g. amphetamines, TCAs)? Ammonium chloride (acidify urine)"
"What phase of drug metabolism includes reduction, oxidation, and hydrolysis? Phase I"
"Phase I drug metabolism usually yields slightly polar, water-soluble metabolites (often still active)"
"What phase of drug metabolism includes methylation, glucuronidation, acetylation, and sulfation (i.e. conjugation)? Phase II"
"Phase II drug metabolism usually yields very polar, water-soluble metabolites (inactive)"
"Patients who are slow acetylators::specific metabolization have increased side effects from certain drugs due to decreased rate of metabolism"
"Which phase of drug metabolism is lost first in geriatric patients? Phase I"
"Efficacy is the maximal effect a drug can produce"
"Vmax of a drug is indicative of efficacy::potency or efficacy"
"Compared to full agonists, partial agonists have less efficacy"
"Potency::Potency/Efficacy is the amount of drug needed for a given effect"
"EC50 of a drug is indicative of potency::potency or efficacy"
"What effect does a competitive antagonist have on potency? Decrease (curve shifts right)"
"What effect does a competitive antagonist have on efficacy? No change"
"What effect does a non-competitive antagonist have on potency? No change"
"What effect does a non-competitive antagonist have on efficacy? Decrease (curve shifts down)"
"What effect does a partial agonist have on efficacy? Decrease (curve shifts down)"
"The therapeutic index is calculated by TD50/ED50"
"Safer drugs have a(n) higher therapeutic index value"
"Drugs with a low therapeutic index may be remembered with the mnemonic \Warning! These Drugs are Lethal\\": W: Warfarin T: Theophylline D: Digoxin L: Lithium\""
"What toxin is found in pufferfish? Tetrodotoxin"
"Tetrodotoxin binds fast voltage-gated Na+ channels in cardiac/nerve tissue, preventing depolarization"
"Does tetrodotoxin cause or prevent depolarization? Prevent"
"What toxin is found in reef fish (e.g. Barracuda, snapper, and moray eel)? Ciguatoxin"
"Ciguatoxin opens Na+ channels, causing depolarization"
"Does ciguatoxin cause or prevent depolarization? Causes depolarization"
"What toxin presents with reversal of hot and cold sensations? Ciguatoxin"
"What toxin is found in spoiled dark-meat fish (e.g. tuna, mahi-mahi, mackerel, bonito)? Histamine (scombroid poisoning)"
"Scombroid poisoning mimics anaphylaxis"
"What is the treatment for scombroid poisoning? Antihistamines (also may use albuterol and epinephrine if needed)"
"What are the treatments for arsenic and mercury poisoning? Dimercaprol and succimer (aka DMSA)::2"
"What is the treatment for rapid reversal of rat poison ingestion? Fresh frozen plasma"
"Chronic alcohol use leads to induction of CYP-450"
"Acute alcohol use leads to inhibition of CYP-450"
"Griseofulvin is a(n) inducer of CYP-450"
"Rifampin is a(n) inducer of CYP-450"
"St. John's wort is a(n) inducer of CYP-450"
"Isoniazid is a(n) inhibitor of CYP-450"
"-Azoles (antifungals) are inhibitors of CYP-450"
"Macrolides are inhibitors of CYP-450"
"Sulfonamides are inhibitors of CYP-450"
"Ciprofloxacin is a(n) inhibitor of CYP-450"
"Metronidazole is a(n) inhibitor of CYP-450"
"Valproate is a(n) inhibitor of CYP-450"
"Phenytoin is a(n) inducer of CYP-450"
"Phenobarbital is a(n) inducer of CYP-450"
"Carbamazepine is a(n) inducer of CYP-450"
"Staphylococcus epidermidis is coagulase negative"
"Staph epidermidis is normal flora of the skin and thus can contaminate blood cultures"
"Characteristic petechial rash in meningococcemia indicates thrombocytopenia::platelet levels"
"IgA protease is a virulence factor used by Neisseria that allows bacteria to colonize and adhere to mucous membranes"
"SVC syndrome is commonly caused by malignancy, such as: - #1 mediastinal mass - #2 superior sulcus tumor"
"What is the etiology of laryngeal papillomatosis? HPV 6 and 11"
"Which part of the respiratory tract can HPV infect? Results in what? True vocal cords (producing laryngeal papillomatosis)"
"Which type of genome do papilloma viruses have? Circular::linear or circular"
"Treatment for Cutaneous Warts? Salicylic acid/Liquid Nitrogen"
"Cervical cancer malignancies in HPV are more common with what other disease? HIV/AIDS"
"TRH is released from the hypothalamus to stimulate TSH release from the anterior pituitary"
"Iodide is taken up into the thyroid follicular cell via Na+-iodide symporter"
"Thyroid peroxidase is the enzyme responsible for oxidation and organification of iodide"
"What amino acid plays a role in thyroid hormone synthesis? Tyrosine"
"What amino-acid side chains are located on thyroglobulin? Tyrosine"
"Thyroid Peroxidase is involved in the first part of T4 synthesis, specifically by catalyzing the addition of iodine to tyrosine residues on thyroglobulin"
"Thyroid Peroxidase is involved in the second part of T4 synthesis, generating T3 and T4 bound to thyroglobulin"
"Thyroglobulin is a tyrosine-rich protein precursor to thyroid hormone located in the follicular lumen"
"Thyroid hormones (T3/T4) play a role in development of the CNS"
"Thyroid hormone stimulates upregulation of B1 receptors in the heart"
"Thyroxin-binding globulin (TBG) is a plasma transport protein for T3/T4"
"What form of thyroid hormone is predominately produced by the thyroid gland? 90% T4"
"What thyroid hormone is more potent? T3 (10 x more potent than T4)"
"TSH increases which 2nd messenger? cAMP"
"T3/T4 hormones bind to intracellular::cellular location receptors"
"Hashimoto's Thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder that initially causes a hyperthyroidism that then becomes a hypothyroidism"
"Cretinism is a form of congenital hypothyroidism that presents with developmental delay, protruding umbilicus, pot belly, and protruding tongue"
"What enzyme is involved in the synthesis of T4? Thyroid Peroxidase (Thyroperoxidase)"
"Methimazole is a thioamide that works by inhibiting Thyroid peroxidase ONLY"
"Propylthiouracil is a thioamide that is NOT contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy"
"Propylthiouracil and methimazole are thionamides used to treat hyperthyroidism"
"Propylthiouracil is a thioamide indicated in the treatment of thyroid storm (thyrotoxicosis)"
"Which thioamide is contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy? Methimazole, so need to use PTU"
"Propylthiouracil (PTU) is a thyroid medication that can produce an ANCA-associated vasculitis"
"Which thyroid medications are associated with drug-induced lupus? Propylthiouracil (PTU), methimazole"
"Which thyroid medications are associated with aplastic anemia? Propylthiouracil (PTU) and methimazole"
"Propylthiouracil (PTU) is a thioamide associated with severe hepatotoxicity"
"Jod-Basedow phenomenon is a condition where a patient develops thyrotoxicosis after a period of being administered Iodine"
"Jod-Basedow phenomenon occurs when a patient being given high dose potassium iodide (Lugol's solution) develops thyrotoxicosis as an adverse effect"
"Radioactive (I131) Iodine is a last resort treatment of Hyperthyroidism / Graves' disease that works by ablating the Thyroid"
"Patients who undergo radioactive iodine (I131) treatment can develop hypothyroidism"
"β-Blockers are used to treat Thyrotoxicosis (thyroid storm):: endocrine condition by blocking the hyperadrenergic symptoms"
"Amiodarone is a class III anti-arrhythmic that can produce hyper or hypothyroidism"
"Lithium is a mood stabilizer associated with development of hypothyroidism"
"Staph epidermidis is a coagulase-negative Staph that has the ability to synthesize extracellular polysaccharide matrix (biofilm)"
"What types of HPV encode for the proteins E6 and E7? High Risk (HPV 16, 18, 31, 33)"
"Low serum Ca2+ levels will increase PTH levels in the blood stream"
"The parathyroid glands have Ca2+ sensing (CaSR) receptors that negatively regulate secretion of PTH"
"Chronic PTH exposure stimulates osteoblasts to express as well as secrete RANKL"
"RANKL binds to RANK on Osteoclast precursors / Osteoclast surfaces causing activation of these cells"
"Intermittent PTH stimulates maturation of osteoblasts, thus increasing bone formation"
"PTH increases Ca2+ reabsorption by the kidney"
"PTH increases phosphate excretion by the kidney"
"PTH increases production of Calcitriol activity by stimulating 1-alpha-hydroxylase in the kidney"
"Teriparatide is a(n) PTH analog used to treat osteoporosis, wherein the goal is to increase bone density and formation"
"Teriparatide decreases fractures in patients with osteoporosis"
"Does Teriparatide have the exact same activity as endogenous PTH? Yes"
"Vitamin D3 is also known as cholecalciferol"
"Vitamin D3 is obtained via dairy products and UVB radiation"
"Vitamin D2 is also known as ergocalciferol"
"Vitamin D2 is obtained via plants"
"25-hydroxylase converts Vitamin D3 into 25-hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol)"
"1-alpha-hydroxylase converts 25-hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol) into 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (aka calcitriol)"
"Calcitriol stimulates increased reabsorption of Ca2+ and reabsorption of phosphate by the kidney"
"Calcitriol increases absorption of Ca2+ and absorption of phosphate in the intestine"
"Calcitriol increases Ca2+ and phosphate release into the bloodstream by stimulating osteoblasts to activate osteoclasts"
"Calcitriol inhibits PTH production by the parathyroid gland"
"Calcitriol stimulates maturation of osteoblasts, thereby increasing bone formation"
"Both Calcitriol and Vitamin D can be used to prophylactically treat and mitigate symptoms of osteoporosis"
"Vitamin D deficiency can cause rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults"
"Patients with renal insufficiency can be given Calcitriol to correct their hypocalcemia"
"Vitamin D inhibits proliferation of keratinocytes which can be found in the epidermis"
"Topical Vitamin D can be used as an adjunct therapy for patients with Psoriasis"
"Calcitriol is useful in the long term management of hypocalcemia due to chronic disorders"
"Vitamin D2/D3 are less useful than Calcitriol in the treatment of hypocalcemia due to hypoparathyroidism"
"Patients who have undergone Thyroid surgery can sometimes manifest with symptoms of hypoparathyroidism and hypocalcemia"
"Hypocalcemia can lead to tetany and in severe cases lead to seizures"
"Teriparatide and Vitamin D therapy can cause hypercalcemia::adverse effect"
"Cinacalcet is an allosteric activator of the Ca2+ sensing (CaSR) receptor on the Parathyroid Gland"
"Cinacalcet is used to treat hypercalcemia secondary to hyperparathyroidism"
"Sevelamer is a compound that binds free phosphate in the gastrointestinal tract"
"Sevelamer is used to treat hyperphosphatemia due to chronic kidney disease"
"S. bovis can produce subacute endocarditis"
"What procedure should be performed with S. bovis infection? Colonoscopy (suspect colon cancer)"
"McCune-Albright syndrome is inherited in a(n) non-inherited - somatic mutation fashion"
"Proteasomal inhibitors (-zomibs::suffix) are antineoplastics that inhibit cell cycle progression at the G2-M phase"
"Carfilzomib and Bortezomib are examples of antineoplastics that work by inhibiting the proteasome"
"Ubiquitin-ation of proteins recruits the proteasome to degrade them"
"Proteasomal inhibitors work best in cancers that mark pro-apoptotic proteins to be targeted for degradation too quickly"
"Proteasomal inhibitors are used to treat multiple myeloma and mantle cell lymphoma"
"Pembrolizumab is an immunostimulant that works by targeting the PD-1 receptor"
"The PD1 receptor is normally involved in the maintenance of peripheral immunologic tolerance"
"Tumor cells upregulate PD-L1 to evade anti-tumor T-cells"
"Panobinostat and Vorinostat are antineoplastics that are nonselective Histone Deacetylase [HDAC] Inhibitors"
"In epigenetics, when a histone is acetylated, the histone unwinds the DNA to make it available for transcription"
"In epigenetics, when a histone is deacetylated by an HDAC (an \eraser\\")"
"HDAC inhibitors prevent histones from being deacetylated resulting in genes such as tumor suppressors being transcribed"
"Vorinostat is used to treat cutaneous T cell lymphoma"
"Panobinostat is used to treat multiple myeloma that is refractory to bortezomib + dexamethasone"
"The BCG vaccine is primarily used to prevent tuberculosis, as well as an alternative treatment for superficial bladder cancer"
"The main side effect of the BCG vaccine is that it can cause keloids at the site of the injection"
"The BCG vaccine can cause a false positive to a(n) tuberculin test"
"Because Pembrolizumab targets a peripheral tolerance mechanism, patients taking this drug can develop autoimmune disorders of endocrine organs"
"In the treatment of Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia, all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) prevents differentiation from being halted at the promyelocyte stage"
"All-trans retinoic acid can be used to treat the measles virus"
"Adverse effects of sirolimus (rapamycin) include pancytopenia and insulin resistance"
"Sirolimus is primarily used to treat transplant rejection prophylaxis in patients who have received a(n) kidney transplant"
"Sirolimus works by binding FKBP, which inhibits the mTOR::specific signal signalling complex involved in cell growth"
"mTOR is a(n) protooncogene::protooncogene or tumorsuppressor?"
"Retinoids (like isoretinoin / all-Trans Retinoic Acid) are derivatives of Vitamin A"
"Selection bias is an error introduced in recruiting participants that occurs due to a(n) nonrandom sampling or treatment allocation of subjects"
"Selection bias, most commonly a type of sampling bias, can be reduced via concealment"
"Recall bias is an error introduced while performing the study in which the awareness of the disorder alters recall by the subjects"
"Recall bias can be reduced by decreasing time from exposure to follow-up"
"Measurement bias is an error introduced while performing the study where information is gathered in a(n) systemically distorted manner"
"Measurement bias can be reduced by: - using a(n) placebo group - using objective and standardized methods of data collection"
"Procedure bias is an error introduced in performing the study that results from different groups being treated differently"
"Measurement Bias and Procedure Bias differ in that the former is due to a(n) flawed procedure and the latter is due to a procedure applied in a(n) differential manner"
"Observer-Expectancy Bias is an error introduced performing the study where the researchers belief in the efficacy of a treatment changes the outcome of treatment"
"Procedure bias can be reduced by blinding and minimizing differences in groups (besides variable of intervention)"
"Confounding bias occurs when the exposure-disease relationship is muddled by the effect of an extraneous factor that is associated with both exposure and disease and is NOT on the causal pathway"
"Confounding Bias can be reduced by RANDOMIZATION, but other important interventions include: - Matching / Stratification of exposure groups - crossover studies - restriction of characteristics - multiple / repeated studies"
"Lead-time bias can be reduced by measuring \back-end\\" survival\""
"Publication bias (\the file drawer effect\\") is a systematic error of meta-analysis that results from only using published studies\""
"Assembly Bias occurs when groups of exposed and non-exposed patients::patients assembled for prognostic study differ in ways other than prognostic factors under study"
"Assembly Bias is a type of selection bias instead of a confounding bias because it occurs during the selection process of subjects"
"Migration (attrition) bias is a form of selection bias that occurs when patients drop out of the study prematurely"
"Migration bias can be remedied with the 5 and 20 rule or the Best / Worst Case analysis"
"Generalizability bias is a form of selection bias that is related to the selective referral of patients to tertiary medical centers"
"Why does Generalizability bias matter? Because patients in tertiary centers are usually highly selected"
"Exclusion criteria can result in External Validity being compromised if too strict, maximizing Internal Validity"
"Randomization is critical in preventing confounding bias"
"Randomization can be done in a blocked manner where randomization is done within blocks of 4-8 subjects in order to ensure equal balance in number of treatment and control subjects throughout the study"
"Randomization can be done in a stratified manner where randomization is done within strata in order to ensure equal balance in number of treatment and control subjects throughout the study"
"Are Randomization and Concealment the same? nah bruh"
"Concealment is critical in preventing selection bias"
"Blinding (the cardinal feature of RCTs) is critical in reducing measurement bias"
"Using a placebo allows you to blind the interventions, helping reduce measurement bias"
"Survival Cohort Bias is a special case of assembly bias where as survival cohort (available patients) is used instead of a(n) true inception cohort"
"A survival cohort describes the past history of prevalent cases, and thus introduces bias into the results (this is seen in Retrospective Case Series)"
"The Case Fatality Rate = (# of individuals who die from disease during T0->T+1) / (# of individuals with disease at t0)"
"The CFR is a special type of cumulative incidence rate that measures risk of death among those individuals with the disease"
"Is the CFR the same as the Mortality Rate? No"
"The Mortality Rate = (# of individuals who die from disease during T0->T+1) / (total population time at risk during T0->T1)"
"The Mortality Rate measures the speed of death due to a specific disease in a population at risk"
"Probability is the risk of having an event where P=Odds/1+Odds"
"Where Probability = A/B, A= # of events and B = total # at risk"
"Is probability a proportion or a ratio? Proportion"
"Odds are the ratio of the probability of having an event to the probability of not having"
"How big is the difference between probability and odds when the value of probability is small (<10%)? Minimal Difference"
"Converting Probability (P) to Odds (O), O = (P)/(1-P)"
"In a Ratio of A/B, is A part of B? No"
"In a Proportion of A/B, is A part of B? Yes"
"A rate is a special type of proportion where the numerator is the # of affected individuals in a given time period and the denominator is the population at risk over the same time period"
"With increased prevalence, how are PPV and NPV changed? PPV increases and NPV decreases"
"How are prevalence and pretest probability related? They are similar"
"For a short duration disease, how are prevalence and incidence related? Prevalence ~ Incidence"
"For a chronic disease, how are prevalence and incidence related? Prevalence > Incidence"
"If a treatment for a particular disease is developed the prolongs life but doesn't result in a cure... (options = incidence, prevalence, CFR, Mortality rate) - Incidence is not affected - Prevalence increases, because affected live longer - CFR would depend on the stage of disease, but in general would decrease since less are likely to die during given time period - Mortality Rate in general would decrease since you would likely have less deaths in a given time period"
"How are prevalence and incidence related? Prevalence = Incidence X Duration"
"An incidence rate is a special type of proportion that includes a given time range and a population at risk"
"When do you use a CIR? - when there is a(n) fixed or closed population that is starting at a common point in time - when an outcome can occur only once - and when when disease event rates are relatively stable over time"
"CIR = (# of new cases for a specific time period)/(# of people at risk for same time period) that gives you a measure of average risk"
"CIR has a range from 0-1 and must be accompanied by a(n) specific time period to have any meaningful interpretation"
"An Attack Rate is a special type of CIR that is the (# of people affected)/(# of people at risk at beginning of time period)"
"An incidence density rate (IDR) measures the instanteous rate of speed of the disease in a population at a given point in time"
"IDR = (# of new cases)/(sum of time periods for all disease free individuals at risk)"
"Is IDR a dynamic measure? Yes"
"An IDR of 0 implies that a disease is not occurring in a population whereas an IDR of infinity implies instantaneous, universal effect on population"
"What endogenous protein that binds to RANKL released by Osteoblasts does Denosumab act like? Osteoprotegerin"
"Denosumab prevents osteoclast activation by binding RANKL expressed on osteoblasts"
"As an antineoplastic, Denosumab can be used for Giant Cell Tumor of Bone as well as metastases to bone"
"In the treatment of Giant Cell Tumor Of Bone, Denosumab works by binding RANKL expressed on multinucleated Giant Cells"
"Because RANKL is also expressed on T Helper cells, a side effect of Denosumab treatment is immunosuppression"
"Because denosumab impairs osteoclast activity (like bisphosphonates), these drugs can cause osteonecrosis of the jaw"
"All biologics (ex monoclonal antibodies) carry the risk of eliciting a(n) infusion reaction within the first hour of administration"
"Is the heart failure associated with Trastuzumab reversible with treatment discontinuation? Yes"
"Trastuzumab is an IgG monoclonal antibody against the Her2/Neu receptor"
"Traztusumab works by binding Her2/Neu, preventing it from dimerizing with EGFR"
"Trastuzumab is indicated for Her2-positive cancers, the most important example being breast cancer"
"Busulfan's use as an antineoplastic comes from its ability to be a(n) alkylating agent"
"Busulfan mediated alkylation of DNA leads to cross-linking of strands, which DNA repair mechanisms cannot fix"
"\Busulfan Lung\\" is the term for the fibrotic pattern of lung damage which can be caused by Busulfan\""
"Busulfan chemotherapy is associated with a(n) hyperpigmentation::skin reaction"
"Busulfan is used to treat Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia"
"Prior to a bone marrow transplant, Busulfan can be used as a(n) conditioning agent"
"Nitrosureas are chemotherapeutics which can be recognized by the suffixes -mustine and -zotocin"
"Nitrosureas work by crosslinking DNA"
"Nitrosureas requires bioactivation by cytochrome p450 enzymes to be effective"
"Nitrosureas are able to penetrate the Blood Brain Barrier, making them especially useful for tumors of the Central Nervous System"
"-Phosphamide chemotherapeutics are alkylating agents that work by crosslinking DNA strands"
"Cyclophosphamide must be bioactivated by the liver in order to function"
"Cyclophosphamide is selective for cells that express low / no levels of Aldehyde Dehydrogenase"
"In the process of bioactivating -phosphamides, a highly cytotoxic side product known as Acrolein is released which can cause Hemorrhagic Cystititis"
"To treat the Hemorrhagic Cystitis induced by cyclophosphamide, the compound MESNA can be administered"
"Cyclophosphamide and Ifosfamide are especially suited for neoplasias of immune cells as well as solid malignancies"
"Cyclophosphamide can cause a congenital syndrome (remember with the mnemonic conGEAL) - congenital: - Growth Restriction - Ear and facial abnormalities - Absence of digits - Limb hypoplasia"
"Cyclophosphamide can stimulate ADH secretion, resulting in a euvolemic hyponatremia"
"As a result of Cyclophosphamide metabolites accumulating in the bladder, it is associated with transitional cell carcinoma"
"Ifosfamide can cause a generalized reabsorptive defect in the proximal convoluted tubule"
"Imatinib is the gold standard for patients with Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia that have a(n) Bcr-Abl fusion receptor tyrosine kinase"
"Imatinib can inhibit the receptor tyrosine kinase c-Kit, making it useful for GI Stromal Tumors (GIST)"
"Patients being treated with Imatinib can experience side effects of fluid retention"
"Imatinib specifically inhibits the Bcr-Abl fusion protein by blocking the Abl portion"
"Imatinib is a(n) competitive inhibitor of the Bcr-Abl fusion protein"
"Tyrosine Kinase inhibitors work by targeting downstream signaling pathways involved in growth - the most important being: - PI3K/Akt leads to increased Bcl-2 expression (anti-apoptosis) - JAK/STAT which would've led to increased cell proliferation - Ras/MAPK which would've led to increased cell growth - Src/FAK which would've led to increased cell motility (invasion) and decreased cell adhesion (migration)"
"Ruxolitinib is a(n) JAK1/2 inhibitor"
"Ruxolitinib is used to treat chronic myeloproliferative disorders that have JAK2 mutations including myelofibrosis and polycythemia vera"
"In patients taking ruxolitinib, an important side effect is hepatotoxicity"
"Patients taking Ruxolitinib can experience myelosuppression, which is associated with herpesviridae family reactivation (specific family of viruses)"
"Erlotinib is a(n) EGF-R inhibitor used to treat NSCLC and Pancreatic cancer"
"Because the EGF receptor is expressed at the epidermis, Patients taking Erlotinib are at risk of Stevens-Johnson Syndrome"
"Sorafenib and Sunitinib inhibit the VEGF RTK"
"Sorafenib has the ability to induce autophagy, which helps suppress tumor growth but can also cause drug resistance"
"Because sorafenib targets VEGF, areas that are highly vascularized will be affected such as the skin and the kidney"
"Vemurafenib is an inhibitor of the BRAF oncogene"
"Vemurafenib is used to treat metastatic melanoma that has a BRAF V600E or V600K::2 mutations # mutation"
"Hydroxyurea is an antimetabolite that inhibits pyrimidine synthesis by inhibiting Ribonucleotide Reductase, thus blocking Thymidine synthesis"
"In patients with Sickle Cell Anemia, Hydroxyurea is used prophylactically to reduce veno-occlusive crises"
"Patients taking hydroxyurea can develop a(n) megaloblastic anemia"
"Hydroxyurea is used in the treatment of hematological malignancies, particularly myeloproliferative disorders"
"Besides being indicated for all solid tumors bearing a PD-L1 mutation, Pembrolizumab is indicated for refractory classical Hodgkins Lymphoma"
"Topoisomerase I inhibitors are antineoplastic agents (commonly with the suffix -otecan) that work by preventing cell cycle progression at the S and G2 phases"
"Irinotecan, a(n) Topoisomerase I inhibitor, is used to treat Colon Cancer"
"Topotecan, a Topoisomerase I inhibitor, is used to treat cancers of the female reproductive system and small cell lung cancer"
"Topoisomerase I inhibitors commonly manifest with side effects of gastrointestinal distress and myelosuppression"
"Antineoplastic topoisomerase II inhibitors, with the suffix -posides, prevent cell cycle progression at the S and G2 phases"
"-Posides (aka Topoisomerase II inhibitors) act as antineoplastics by preventing helicase unwinding"
"-Posides (Topoisomerase II inhibitor antineoplastics) are used to treat solid tumors, particularly testicular cancer and small cell lung cancer"
"Side effects of Topoisomerase II inhibitors include alopecia and myelosuppression"
"Platinum based antineoplastics (suffix -platin) work by forming intrastrand adducts"
"Platinum based antineoplastics are indicated for various carcinomas that affect the Genitourinary system, Reproductive system, and Respiratory system"
"Platinum based antineoplastics can cause side effects which might make ya say NOPE - Nephrotoxicity - Ototoxicity - Peripheral Neuropathy - Emesis"
"To prevent cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity, you can administer Amifostine or IV Saline diuresis"
"Vinca Alkaloids are antineoplastics that prevent cell cycle progression at the M phase"
"Vinca Alkaloids bind B-Tubulin, inhibiting the assembly of microtubules"
"Vinca Alkaloids are particularly useful for Lymphomas, in particular vinblastine for Hodgkin lymphoma and vincristine for non-Hodgkin lymphoma"
"As two classes of antineoplastic agents that modulate microtubule structure, the distinction lies in that vinca-alkaloids prevent microtubule assembly whereas taxanes prevent microtubule disassembly"
"Vinca alkaloids can induce a(n) paralytic ileus, resulting in constipation"
"Vincristine can cause a(n) peripheral sensory neuropathy"
"Taxanes (-taxel) are antineoplastics that prevent cell cycle progression at the M-Phase"
"Taxanes work by preventing the disassembly of microtubules"
"Taxanes can cause a peripheral sensory neuropathy as well as induce hypersensitivity reactions"
"Taxanes are used to treat for breast and ovarian carcinomas"
"What is the suffix for small molecule kinase inhibitors? -nib"
"What is the suffix for tyrosine kinase inhibitors? -tinib"
"Patients taking Erlotinib can get a(n) papulopustular acneiform rash"
"Gut mucosa expresses EGFR, resulting in Erlotinib causing diarrhea as a side effect"
"The abbreviation RTK stands for Receptor Tyrosine Kinase"
"VEGF RTK inhibitors can cause hyperkeratosis"
"Because Sorafenib and Sunitinib target the Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor receptor, patients are at increased risk of hemorrhage"
"Vinca Alkaloids affect rapidly dividing cells like those of the hair follicle, resulting in alopecia"
"Taxane can affect rapidly dividing cells like follicular hair cells, resulting in alopecia"
"Platinum based agents, especially carboplatin, can result in myelosuppression"
"A common side effect of all alkylating agents is myelosuppression"
"A general rule of chemotherapeutic side effects is that they will affect all rapidly dividing cells"
"Cyclophosphamide can target germ cells, resulting in infertility and premature menopause"
"Because Her2/Neu is expressed on the Heart, Trastuzumab can cause Heart failure"
"Basiliximab is used prophylactically to reduce transplant rejection in patients who have received kidneys"
"Patients taking Basiliximab can experience side effects of edema, hypertension, and tremor"
"Dupilumab is a monoclonal antibody against the IL4 receptor alpha subunit"
"Dupilumab is indicated for atopic dermatitis"
"The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) extends from the lateral femoral condyle to the anterior tibia"
"The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) extends from the medial femoral condyle to the posterior tibia"
"A knee exam should be performed with the patient in the supine position"
"The anterior drawer test and lachman test are used to test for ACL injury"
"The anterior drawer test is performed with the knee at a(n) 90 degree angle to test for ACL injury"
"A positive anterior drawer sign demonstrates increased anterior gliding of the tibia"
"The Lachman test is similar to the anterior drawer test, but the knee is at a(n) 30 degree angle"
"The posterior drawer test is performed with the knee at a(n) 90 degree angle to test for PCL injury"
"A positive posterior drawer sign shows increased posterior gliding of the tibia"
