"The Valgus test is most commonly used to identify MCL injury"
"The Valgus test is performed with the knee at a(n) 30 degree angle while a(n) lateral (valgus) force is applied"
"An abnormal Valgus test shows increased medial space widening of the tibia"
"The Varus test is used to identify LCL injury"
"The Varus test is performed with the knee at a(n) 30 degree angle while a(n) medial (varus) force is applied"
"An abnormal Varus test shows increased lateral space widening of the tibia"
"The McMurray test is used to identify injury to the meniscus (of the knee)"
"The McMurray test is performed by 1) full flexion of the knee 2) followed by extension of the knee with rotation of the tibia and pressure on the opposite side of the knee you want to test"
"In a positive McMurray test, pain and \popping\\" on external rotation indicates a(n) medial meniscus tear\""
"In a positive McMurray test, pain and \popping\\" on internal rotation indicates a(n) lateral meniscal tear\""
"A positive McMurray test is characterized by pain and \popping\\" on extension (with rotation and side of the knee pressure)\""
"A(n) greenstick fracture is a(n) incomplete fracture through the width of the bone following bending stress"
"Greenstick fractures and torus fractures are both common fractures in pediatric populations"
"A(n) torus fracture occurs when axial force is applied to immature bone, leading to a(n) simple buckle fracture of the cortex"
"Actinomycin D (aka Dactinomycin) is an antineoplastic antibiotic that works by preventing transcription through the process of DNA intercalation"
"Dactinomycin is used to treat for numerous malignancies that affect the pediatric age group"
"Dactinomycin affects all populations of rapidly growing cells, resulting in side effects of myelosuppression (bone marrow) and alopecia (hair follicle cells)"
"Anthracyclines can cause Dilated Cardiomyopathy which can be minimized by preparing the drug in Liposomal form"
"Anthracycline associated Dilated Cardiomyopathy can be prevented with dexrazoxane, a(n) iron chelating agent"
"PEGylation of liposomal Doxorubicin can also result in Hand-Foot Syndrome"
"PEGylated Liposomal Doxorubicin is useful for the treatment of Kaposi Sarcoma"
"Doxorubicin can cause a(n) neutropenic enterocolitis, a life-threatening acute transmural inflammation of the cecum"
"Anthracyclines are used to treat white blood cell neoplasias"
"Bleomycin is an antineoplastic antibiotic indicated for lymphoma as well as cancers of the reproductive system"
"Bleomycin can have severe effects at the lung, which over time can cause pulmonary fibrosis"
"Patients taking Bleomycin can experience hyperpigmentation of the skin"
"Neoplasia is new tissue growth which has three characteristics that distinguish it from hyperplasia and repair: 1 - It is unregulated 2 - It is irreversible 3 - Generally speaking, it is monoclonal*"
"Bleomycin acts as an antineoplastic by inducing single and double strand breaks in DNA"
"Bleomycin and Anthracyclines generate free radicals by generating a pseudoenzyme using bound iron ions to react with oxygen"
"In women, clonality was historically determined by analysis of Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase isoforms"
"Cytarabine and Gemcitabine are examples of pyrimidine nucleoside analogs that block cell cycle progression at S phase"
"The normal ratio of active G6PD isoforms in a sample of any woman's tissue is 1:1"
"While neoplasia is monoclonal, hyperplasia is polyclonal"
"Clonality can be determined by analysis of androgen receptor isoforms"
"Clonality of B lymphocytes can be determined by analysis of the Immunoglobulin Light Chain phenotype"
"Each B cell produces light chains that are either kappa or lambda"
"The normal kappa to lambda light chain ratio in a tissue sample is 3:1"
"In Lymphoma, which is monoclonal, the kappa to lambda light chain ratio increases to > 6:1 or is inverted"
"Which of the following types of tumors remain localized and do not metastasize? Benign"
"Which of the following types of tumors invade locally and have the potential to metastasize? Malignant"
"Tumors of Glandular epithelium are known as adenomas when benign and adenocarcinomas when malignant"
"Pyrimidine nucleoside analogs (ex Cytarabine and Gemcitabine) work by inhibiting DNA polymerase A/B"
"Epithelial tumors that grow exophytically are known as papillomas when benign and papillary carcinoma when malignant"
"Tumors of Fat are known as lipomas when benign and liposarcomas when malignant"
"Lymphomas are malignancies of mature leukocytes, whereas Leukemias are malignancies of immature leukocytes"
"Tumors of Blood Vessels are known as Hemangiomas when benign and Angiosarcomas when malignant"
"Because Cytarabine targets lymphocytes, it is indicated for leukemias as well as non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma"
"All antineoplastic nucleoside analogs (including cladribine, cytarabine, gemcitabine) can cause myelosuppression"
"In the United States, Cancer is the second leading cause of death"
"While cancer begins as a single mutated cell, approximately 30 divisions occur before the average tumor presents with the earliest clinical symptoms"
"Pap smears are used to detect cervical dysplasia (CIN) before it becomes carcinoma"
"One use of Mammography as a screening tool is to detect in situ breast cancer before it invades"
"Levels of Prostate Specific Antigen and Digital Rectal Exam are used as screening tools to detect Prostate Carcinoma before it spreads"
"One use of the Hemoccult test (of the stool) and Colonoscopy as screening tools is to detect colonic adenoma before it becomes colonic adenocarcinoma"
"During carcinogenesis, DNA mutations eventually disrupt key regulatory systems, allowing for tumor promotion and progression"
"Aflatoxins are a carcinogen associated with what type of cancer? Hepatocellular Carcinoma"
"Alkylating agents are a carcinogen associated with what types of cancer? Leukemia / Lymphoma"
"Which carcinogen is associated with the following types of cancer? Ethanol Squamous Cell Carcinoma of Oropharynx and Upper Esophagus Pancreatic Carcinoma Hepatocellular Carcinoma"
"Patients typically get chronically exposed to Alkylating agents when they are being given oncologic chemotherapy"
"Ethanol has many methods of carcinogenic activity including: (1) - metabolites forming DNA adducts (2) - depletion of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) (3) - stimulating the Epithelial-Mesenchymal Transition"
"Which carcinogen is associated with the following types of cancer? Arsenic Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Skin Angiosarcoma of the Liver Lung Cancer"
"Nowadays, patients typically can get chronically exposed to Arsenic in a couple of different situations, including: (1) - cigarette smoke (2) - Herbicides used in vineyards (3) - metal smelting"
"Which carcinogen is associated with the following types of cancer? Asbestos Bronchogenic Carcinoma Mesothelioma"
"Between bronchogenic carcinoma and mesothelioma, patients exposed to asbestos are far more likely to develop bronchogenic carcinoma than mesothelioma"
"Which carcinogen is associated with the following types of cancer? Cigarette Smoke Transitional Cell Carcinoma (Bladder) Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Cervix Squamous Cell Carcinoma / Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus Renal Cell Carcinoma Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Larynx Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Lung Small Cell Lung Cancer Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma"
"Cigarette smoke is the most common carcinogen worldwide"
"Nitrosamines are a carcinogen associated with what type of cancer? Intestinal Gastric Cancer"
"Patients get exposed to Nitrosamines through the consumption of smoked meats"
"Vinyl Chloride is a carcinogen associated with what type of cancer? Angiosarcoma of the Liver"
"Nickel exposure is associated with lung carcinoma"
"Which oncogenic microbe is associated with the following cancers?: EBV Lymphomas (ex. Endemic Burkitt Lymphoma) Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma Primary CNS Lymphoma (in AIDS) Posttransplant Lymphoproliferative Disease"
"Which oncogenic microbe is associated with the following cancers?: HHV-8 Kaposi Sarcoma *common in 3...."
"Which oncogenic microbes are associated with the following cancers?: HBV, HCV, Aspergillus::3 Hepatocellular Carcinoma"
"Which oncogenic microbe is associated with the following cancers?: HTLV-1 Adult T-cell Leukemia / Lymphoma"
"Which form of radiation is associated with the following types of cancer? Ionizing Radiation AML CML Thyroid Papillary Carcinoma"
"Ionizing radiation causes carcinogenesis by generating hydroxyl free radicals::specific"
"Which form of radiation is associated with the following types of cancer? Non-Ionizing Radiation Basal Cell Carcinoma of the Skin Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Skin Melanoma of the Skin"
"Non-ionizing radiation causes carcinogenesis by generating pyrimidine dimers"
"Proto-oncogenes are essential for cell growth and differentiation"
"Categories of proto-oncogenes include: 1) Growth factors 2) Growth factor receptors 3) Signal transducers 4) Nuclear regulators 5) Cell cycle regulators"
"Growth Factors induce cellular growth vs mitogen"
"Signal transducers relay receptor activation to the nucleus (e.g. Ras)"
"The signal transducer Ras is normally associated with Growth Factor Receptors in a(n) inactive GDP-bound state"
"When a Ras-linked Growth Factor receptor is bound, this leads to the Ras bound GDP being replaced with a(n) GTP, resulting in activation of the Ras protein"
"The intrinsic GTPase activity of Ras can be stimulated by GTPase Activating Proteins (GAPs)"
"Activated Ras is regulated by its own intrinsic GTPase activity"
"Mutations of Ras that alter the GAP binding site prolong the activated state of Ras"
"The Cell Cycle is regulated by Cyclins and Cyclin-Dependent Kinases (CDKs) which when complexed allow cells to bypass restriction points (checkpoints)"
"Cyclin-Dependent Kinases are constitutive and are normally inactive"
"The PDGFB proto-oncogene encodes for Platelet-Derived Growth Factor, which upon binding to its receptor stimulates growth This is a(n) growth factor::class found commonly in astrocytoma::pathology"
"The HER2/neu proto-oncogene encodes for the HER2 receptor, which when activated leads to cell proliferation This is a(n) growth factor receptor::class found commonly in breast cancer::pathology"
"The RET proto-oncogene encodes for the RET receptor tyrosine kinase, which is involved in embryological development This is a(n) growth factor receptor::class found commonly in MEN 2A, 2B and medullary carcinoma of thyroid::pathology"
"The KIT proto-oncogene encodes for the Stem Cell Factor receptor, which when bound leads to cell growth This is a(n) growth factor receptor::class found commonly in GI stromal tumor::pathology"
"The RAS family of proto-oncogenes encode for GTP-binding signal transducers that when stimulated leads to cell proliferation This is a(n) signal transducer::class found commonly in carcinomas, lymphoma, and melanoma"
"The ABL proto-oncogene encodes for a cytosolic Tyrosine Kinase that when stimulated leads to cell division"
"The MYCC proto-oncogene encodes for the nuclear regulator c-myc, which stimulates cell cycle progression"
"The MYCN proto-oncogene encodes for the nuclear regulator::class N-myc, which stimulates cell cycle progression"
"The MYCL1 proto-oncogene encodes for the nuclear regulator::class L-myc, which stimulates cell cycle progression"
"The CCND1 proto-oncogene encodes for the cell cycle regulator Cyclin D1, which stimulates cell cycle progression"
"The CDK4 proto-oncogene encodes for the cell cycle regulator Cyclin-Dependent Kinase 4, which stimulates cell cycle progression"
"The G1 restriction point of the cell cycle is regulated by the tumor suppressors p53 and Rb"
"p53 restricts the cell cycle to G1 by allowing the inhibition of CDK4, maintaining the hypophosphorylated state of Rb"
"In response to DNA damage, p53 initially attempts to halt the cell cycle and facilitates the activity of DNA repair enzymes *bonus-what does it induce that inhibits the cell cycle?"
"If DNA repair is not possible, p53 induces apoptosis"
"p53 induces apoptosis by activating BAX and BAK, which dimerize and form a pore in the outer mitochondrial membrane"
"Once the mitochondrial membrane has been made permeable, Cytochrome C can leak out and activate initiator caspases"
"The Knudson two-hit hypothesis states that both copy/copies of a tumor suppressor gene must be knocked out for tumor formation"
"Loss of p53 is seen in >50% of cancers"
"Growth Factors stimulate G1 phase by increasing the levels of the Cyclins"
"Once levels of Cyclins reach an appropriate level, these complex with Cyclin-Dependent Kinases to hyperphosphorylate Rb"
"When in the hypophosphorylated state, Rb sequesters E2F transcription factor, which is necessary for transition to the S phase"
"Once hyperphosphorylated, Rb releases the E2F transcription factor which initates the S phase"
"A mutation in Rb results in constitutively free E2F, leading to uncontrolled cell cycle progression"
"Patients with a sporadic Rb mutation will typically develop a(n) unilateral::laterality Retinoblastoma"
"Patients with a germline Rb mutation will typically develop a(n) bilateral Retinoblastoma, with an increased risk of osteosarcoma"
"The proteins Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL normally stabilize the outer mitochondrial membrane, preventing pro-apoptotic proteins from leaving the intermitochondrial membrane space"
"Tumor suppressor genes regulate cell growth"
"The Bcl-2 proto-oncogene becomes constitutively activated in Follicular Lymphoma and diffuse Large B cell Lymphoma"
"In Follicular lymphoma, there is a failure of apoptosis of faulty B cells during somatic hypermutation"
"Cancers may express telomerase to prevent chromosome shortening and cell death"
"Tumor cells commonly produce angiogenic factors (ex. FGF / VEGF), which are necessary for tumor survival and growth"
"Genetic mutations often result in the cellular production of abnormal proteins, which are expressed on MHC class I molecules"
"Tumor cells can evade apoptosis / immune surveillance by downregulating expression of MHC class I or alternative splicing of the Fas receptor"
"One hallmark of cancer is the ability to be growth signal self-sufficient"
"One hallmark of cancer is the ability to have limitless replicative potential (ex. exceed the hayflick limit)"
"Normal tissue layers have basal to apical polarity"
"Lymphatic spread is characteristic of carcinomas, while Hematogenous spread is characteristic of sarcomas"
"Histologically, benign tumors are usually well differentiated, whereas malignant tumors are classically poorly differentiated"
"Histologically, benign tumors display organized::organized or disorganized? growth, whereas malignant tumors display disorganized::organized or disorganized? growth"
"Histologically, the nuclei of benign tumors are uniform, whereas the nuclei of malignant tumors are pleomorphic and hyperchromatic"
"Histologically, benign tumors have a(n) low nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio, whereas malignant tumors have a(n) high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio"
"Histologically, benign tumors display minimal mitotic activity, whereas malignant tumors display high mitotic activity with atypical mitosis"
"Do benign tumors have metastatic potential? No"
"Immunohistochemistry is used to characterize tumors that are difficult to classify on histology"
"When performing Immunohistochemistry; a(n) Cytokeratin stain can be used to identify Epithelial tumors (ex Squamous Cell Carcinoma)"
"When performing Immunohistochemistry; a(n) Vimentin stain can be used to identify Sarcomas, Endometrial Carcinoma, RCC, Meningioma"
"When performing Immunohistochemistry; a(n) Desmin stain can be used to identify Rhabdomyosarcomas, Leiomyomas, Leiomyosarcomas"
"When performing Immunohistochemistry; a(n) Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein (GFAP) stain can be used to identify Astrocytomas, Glioblastomas, Oligodendrogliomas, Ependymomas"
"When performing Immunohistochemistry; a(n) Neurofilament stain can be used to identify neuroblastomas, medulloblastomas, retinoblastomas"
"When performing Immunohistochemistry; a stain for PSA can be used to identify Prostate Cancer"
"When performing Immunohistochemistry; a stain for ER can be used to identify malignancies of breast epithelium"
"When performing Immunohistochemistry; Thyroglobulin can be used to identify malignancies of the Thyroid"
"When performing Immunohistochemistry; Chromogranin A, Synaptophysin, NCAM (CD56), Neuron Specific Enolase (NSE) can all be used to identify Neuroendocrine and Neuronal tumors"
"When performing Immunohistochemistry; a(n) S-100 stain can be used to identify Melanomas, Schwannomas, Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis"
"Serum tumor markers are proteins released by a tumor into serum (e.g. PSA)"
"Elevated levels of serum tumor markers require tissue biopsy for definitive diagnosis of neoplasia"
"Grading is the microscopic assessment of differentiation in a cancer"
"Well differentiated (low grade) cancers resemble normal parent tissue"
"Poorly differentiated (high grade) cancers do not resemble normal parent tissue"
"Well-differentiated cancers have a better prognosis than poorly-differentiated cancers"
"Staging is the assessment of the size and spread of a cancer"
"Tumor staging is a(n) more important prognostic factor than tumor grading"
"Staging of a cancer is determined after final surgical resection of the tumor"
"Tumor staging utilizes the TNM system: T: Tumor size and/or depth of invasion N: Spread to regional lymph nodes M: Metastasis"
"Spread to regional lymph nodes (N) is the second most important prognostic factor for a cancer"
"Metastasis (M) is the single most important prognostic factor for a cancer"
"The \unhappy triad\\" is a common knee injury in contact sports due to lateral force applied to a(n) planted leg\""
"The \unhappy triad\\" classically consists of damage to the ACL"
"Although the classic presentation for the \unhappy triad\\" involves medial meniscus injury"
"The \unhappy triad\\" presents with acute knee pain and signs of joint injury/instability\""
"Prepatellar bursitis is an inflammation of the prepatellar bursa in front of the kneecap"
"Prepatellar bursitis can be caused by repeated trauma or pressure from excessive kneeling"
"Prepatellar bursitis is also known as \housemaid's knee\\"\""
"A(n) Baker cyst is a collection of synovial fluid in the popliteal fossa in the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus bursa"
"Baker cyst forms in the setting of chronic degenerative or inflammatory joint disease"
"A(n) Baker cyst presents with posterior knee pain/stiffness and detection of a swelling/mass in the popliteal fossa"
"The rotator cuff muscles are innervated primarily by C5-C6::(nerve roots)"
"The rotator cuff muscles are: 1. supraspinatus 2. infraspinatus 3. teres minor 4. subscapularis"
"The supraspinatus and infraspinatus (rotator cuff muscles) are innervated by the suprascapular (C5-C6)::roots nerve"
"The teres minor (rotator cuff muscle) is innervated by the axillary nerve"
"The subscapularis::rotator cuff muscle is innervated by the upper and lower subscapular (C5-C6) nerves"
"The supraspinatus aBducts the arm initially (from 0 to 15°)"
"The supraspinatus is the most commonly injured rotator cuff muscle, due to trauma or degeneration and impingement which leads to tendinopathy or tear"
"Function of the supraspinatus muscle may be assessed using the \empty/full can\\" test\""
"The infraspinatus::rotator cuff muscle and teres minor::rotator cuff muscle laterally (external) rotate::action the arm"
"Injury to the infraspinatus (rotator cuff muscle) is classically seen in baseball pitchers"
"The teres minor (rotator cuff muscle) does the following actions - aDducts the arm - laterally (externally) rotates the arm"
"The subscapularis (rotator cuff muscle) aDducts and medially (internally) rotates the arm (action)"
"The supraspinatus abducts the arm from 0 to 15° and is innervated by the suprascapular nerve"
"The deltoid abducts the arm from 15 to 100° and is innervated by the axillary nerve"
"The trapezius abducts the arm >90° and is innervated by the Spinal Accessory (CNXI) nerve"
"The serratus anterior abducts the arm >100° and is innervated by the long thoracic nerve"
"Medial epicondylitis (aka golfer's elbow) is an elbow injury that may be due to repetitive flexion (forehand shots) that causes tendinosis of the pronator teres and flexor carpi radialis"
"Lateral epicondylitis (aka tennis elbow) is an elbow injury that may be due to repetitive extension (backhand shots) that causes microtrauma of the extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon at its origin"
"The bones of the wrist can be remembered by the mnemonic \So Long To Pinky"
"The scaphoid (bone) (palpable in the anatomic snuff box) is the most commonly fractured carpal bone"
"The scaphoid (bone) is typically injured due to a fall on an outstretched hand"
"Complications of proximal scaphoid fractures include avascular necrosis and nonunion due to retrograde blood supply"
"Dislocation of the lunate (bone) may cause acute carpal tunnel syndrome"
"Carpal tunnel syndrome is due to entrapment of the median nerve between the transverse carpal ligament and the carpal bones"
"Nerve compression in carpal tunnel syndrome presents as paresthesia, pain, and numbness in the distribution of the median nerve"
"Carpal tunnel syndrome leads to atrophy of the thenar eminence, but spares sensation because the palmar cutaneous branch enters the hand external to the carpal tunnel"
"Carpal tunnel syndrome is associated with - Rheumatoid arthritis::inflammatory disorder - Hypothyroidism::thyroid disorder - Acromegaly::pituitary disorder - Pregnancy::reproductive circumstance (due to edema) - Sustained/repeated use (maybe) - Diabetes mellitus::endocrine disorder - Dialysis-related amyloidosis::inflammatory disorder It may also be associated with repetitive use"
"A positive Tinel sign and Phalen maneuver are suggestive of carpal tunnel syndrome"
"A positive Tinel sign is when percussion of the wrist causes tingling"
"A positive Phalen maneuver is when 90 degree flexion of the wrist causes tingling"
"Guyon canal syndrome is due to compression of the ulnar nerve at the wrist or hand"
"Guyon canal syndrome is classically seen in cyclists due to pressure from handlebars"
"Treating an organophosphate poisoning is two fold; Atropine which inhibits all subtypes of muscarinic receptors, and Pralidoxime, which if given early - regenerates AChE"
"Injury to the axillary nerve (C5-C6::(nerve roots)) is commonly due to: - fracture at the surgical neck of the humerus - anterior dislocation of the humerus"
"Injury to the axillary (C5-C6)::roots nerve presents as: 1. flattened deltoid (appearance) 2. loss of arm abduction at shoulder (>15°) (action) 3. loss of sensation over the deltoid muscle and lateral arm (sensation)"
"Injury to the musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7 (nerve roots)) is commonly due to upper trunk compression"
"Injury to the musculocutaneous (C5-7)::roots nerve presents as: 1. loss of forearm flexion and forearm supination (action) 2. loss of sensation over the lateral forearm (sensation)"
"Injury to the radial nerve (C5-T1::(nerve roots)) can be caused by - midshaft fracture of the humerus - compression of the axilla - \nursemaids elbow\\" - \\"finger\\" drop\""
"Compression of the axilla (resulting in radial nerve injury) can occur due to improper use of crutches or sleeping with an arm over a chair (aka Saturday night palsy)"
"Radial nerve injury presents with: 1. wrist drop, including loss of elbow, wrist, and finger extension (action) 2. decreased grip strength (due to loss of wrist extension) (strength) 3. loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand (sensation)"
"Median nerve (C5-T1::nerve roots) injury is commonly due to: - anteromedial supracondylar fracture of the humerus (proximal::proximal or distal? lesion) - carpal tunnel syndrome (distal::proximal or distal? lesion) - wrist laceration (distal::proximal or distal? lesion)"
"Special findings in a(n) median nerve injury include \Median Claw\\" (distal lesion) and \\"Pope's blessing\\" (proximal lesion)\""
"Loss of muscle action in a(n) median nerve injury includes loss of: 1. wrist flexion (weakened-ulnar nerve contributes) 2. flexion of lateral fingers (2nd and 3rd digits) 3. thumb opposition and thumb flexion 4. lateral 2 lumbricals (2nd and 3rd digits)"
"In a(n) median nerve injury, sensation is lost over the: 1. thenar eminence 2. dorsal aspects of lateral 3 1/2 fingers (with proximal lesion) 3. palmar aspects of lateral 3 1/2 fingers (with proximal lesion)"
"Injury to the ulnar nerve (C8-T1 (nerve roots)) commonly occurs due to: - fracture of the medial epicondyle of humerus \funny bone\\" (proximal lesion) - fractured hook of hamate (distal lesion) (from fall on outstretched hand - \\"FOOSH\\")\""
"A special finding in a(n) distal ulnar nerve injury is \ulnar claw\\" on digit extension\""
"The wrist will deviate radially upon flexion in a(n) proximal ulnar nerve lesion"
"Loss of muscle action in a(n) ulnar nerve injury includes loss of: 1. wrist flexion 2. flexion of medial fingers (4th and 5th digits) 3. abduction AND adduction of fingers (interossei) 4. medial 2 lumbricals (4th and 5th digits)"
"In a(n) ulnar nerve injury, sensation is lost over the medial 1 1/2 fingers, including the hypothenar eminence"
"Injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve (C5-T1::nerve roots) is commonly due to superficial laceration of the palm"
"Injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve results in: 1. \ape hand / median claw\\" (appearance) 2. loss of thenar muscles (action) 3. no loss of sensation (sensation)\""
"A lesion to #1 (upper trunk injury) would result in  Erb palsy (\waiter's tip\\")\""
"A lesion to #2 would result in Klumpke palsy (total claw hand)"
"A lesion to the #3 - posterior cord would result in wrist drop, paralysis of the deltoid, and impairment of internal rotation of the humerus"
"A lesion to #4 (long thoracic nerve injury) (C5-C7::root) would result in winged scapula"
"A lesion to #5 (axillary nerve injury) would result in deltoid paralysis"
"A lesion to #6 (radial nerve injury) would result in \Saturday night palsy\\" (wrist drop)\""
"A lesion to #7 (musculocutaneous nerve injury) would result in difficulty flexing elbow::muscular deficit and variable loss of sensation::sensory deficit"
"A proximal lesion to #8 (proximal median nerve injury) presents with \Pope's blessing\\" and a loss of sensation in the median nerve distribution\""
"A(n) distal::Proximal or Distal? lesion to #9 (distal ulnar nerve lesion) would result in loss of intrinsic muscles of the hand and ulnar claw hand"
"Erb palsy::condition is due to traction or tear of the upper trunk (C5-C6 roots)"
"Erb palsy is commonly caused by: - lateral traction on neck during delivery (in infants) - trauma (in adults)"
"Muscles lost in Erb palsy include: 1. deltoid 2. supraspinatus 3. infraspinatus 4. biceps brachii"
"Loss of the deltoid and supraspinatus in Erb palsy result in aDduction of the arm"
"Loss of the infraspinatus (muscle) in Erb palsy results in medial rotation of the arm"
"Loss of the biceps brachii in Erb palsy results in extension and pronation of the forearm"
"Klumpke palsy::condition is due to traction or tear of the lower trunk (C8-T1 roots)"
"Klumpke palsy is commonly caused by upward force on the arm during delivery (in infants) or trauma, such as grabbing a tree branch while falling (in adults)"
"Muscles lost in Klumpke palsy include the intrinsic hand muscles: 1. lumbricals 2. interossei 3. hypothenar 4. thenar"
"Loss of the lumbricals::specific muscle group in Klumpke palsy results in total claw hand"
"Thoracic outlet syndrome::condition is due to compression of the lower trunk (roots C8-T1) and subclavian vessels"
"Thoracic outlet syndrome (condition) is commonly caused by: - presence of a(n) cervical rib - Pancoast tumor - scalene muscular abnormalities / hypertrophy / trauma (ex repetitive overhead arm movements)"
"Muscles lost in thoracic outlet syndrome include the intrinsic hand muscles: 1. lumbricals 2. interossei 3. thenar 4. hypothenar"
"Thoracic outlet syndrome presents with: - atrophy of intrinsic hand muscles (due to loss of lower trunk nourishment) - ischemia and pain (due to artery compression) - edema (due to venous compression) - and Klumpke Palsy (due to lower trunk compression)"
"Winged scapula (condition) is due to a lesion of the long thoracic nerve that supplies the serratus anterior"
"Winged scapula is commonly caused by: - axillary node dissection after mastectomy - stab wounds"
"Winged scapula is due to loss of action of the serratus anterior muscle"
"A long thoracic nerve lesion presents with: #1 - inability to abduct arm above horizontal position #2 - inability to anchor scapula to thoracic cage"
"Clawing of the hand is best seen with distal::proximal or distal lesions of the median or ulnar nerves"
"Clawing of the hand is characterized by extension::flexion/extension at the MCP joint, flexion::flexion/extension at the PIP joint, and flexion::flexion/extension at the DIP joint"
"Claw hand deficits are less::(more/less) pronounced in proximal::(proximal/distal) lesions"
"\Ulnar claw\\" hand (distortion of the hand) is most apparent when extending fingers or at rest"
"\Pope's blessing\\" hand (aka hand of benediction) (distortion of the hand) is most apparent when making a fist"
"\Median claw\\" hand (distortion of the hand) is most apparent when extending fingers or at rest"
"\OK gesture\\" hand is most apparent when making a fist"
"Atrophy of the thenar eminence is seen in median nerve lesions, while atrophy of the hypothenar eminence is seen in ulnar nerve lesions"
"Muscles of the thenar eminence: 1. Opponens pollicis 2. Abductor pollicis brevis 3. Flexor pollicis brevis"
"Muscles of the hypothenar eminence: 1. Opponens digiti minimi 2. Abductor digiti minimi 3. Flexor digiti minimi brevis"
"Muscles of the thenar eminence are innervated by the median nerve"
"Muscles of the hypothenar eminence are innervated by the ulnar nerve"
"The dorsal interossei aBduct the fingers; the palmar interossei aDduct the fingers"
"The lumbricals flex at the MCP joint and extend at the PIP and DIP::2 joints"
"The iliohypogastric nerve (T12-L1::nerve roots) provides: - sensory innervation to the suprapubic region - motor innervation to the transversus abdominis and internal oblique"
"The iliohypogastric nerve is commonly injured due to post abdominal surgery sutures"
"Injury to the iliohypogastric nerve often presents as burning or tingling pain at the surgical incision site radiating to the inguinal and suprapubic region"
"The genitofemoral nerve (L1-L2::(nerve roots)) provides: - sensory innervation to the scrotum/labia majora::genital area and upper anterior thigh::femoral area - motor innervation to the cremaster"
"The genitofemoral nerve is commonly injured due to laparoscopic surgeries for inguinal hernias or by retractor blades used in abdominal surgery"
"Injury to the genitofemoral nerve presents as decreased sensation of upper anterior thigh and an absent cremasteric reflex"
"The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (L2-L3 (nerve roots)) provides sensory innervation to the anterior and lateral thigh and motor innervation to the none"
"The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is commonly injured (meralgia paresthetica) due to tight clothing, obesity or pregnancy"
"Injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve presents as decreased anterior and lateral thigh sensation"
"The Obturator nerve (L2-L4 (nerve roots)) provides: - sensory innervation to the distal medial thigh::very specific - motor innervation to the thigh adductor muscles"
"The obturator nerve is commonly injured due to surgery of the posterior pelvis using a trocar"
"Injury to the obturator nerve presents as decreased medial thigh sensation and adduction"
"The femoral nerve (L2-L4 (nerve roots)) provides: - sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg - motor innervation to the quadriceps, iliopsoas, pectineus, and sartorius"
"The femoral nerve is commonly injured due to pelvic fracture"
"Injury to the femoral nerve presents as decreased thigh flexion and leg extension"
"The sciatic nerve (L4-S3 (nerve roots)) provides: - sensory innervation to the none - motor innervation to the semitendinosus, semimembranosus, biceps femoris, and hamstring portion of the adductor magnus"
"The sciatic nerve is commonly injured due to: - a herniated disc - posterior hip dislocation - piriformis syndrome"
"The sciatic nerve splits into the common peroneal/fibular nerve and the tibial nerve"
"The common peroneal nerve (L4-S2 (nerve roots)) provides: - sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot - motor innervation to the short head of the biceps femoris::proximal, tibialis anterior, and extensor muscles of the digits"
"The common peroneal nerve is commonly injured due to - trauma - compression of the lateral aspect of the leg (ex Cast) - a(n) fibular neck fracture"
"Injury to the common peroneal nerve presents as loss of sensation on the dorsum of the foot and foot drop::motor"
"Foot drop is characterized by a foot that is inverted and plantarflexed at rest"
"Foot drop is characterized by loss of eversion and dorsiflexion (movements) of the foot"
"Foot drop results in a \steppage gait\\"\""
"The tibial nerve (L4-S3::nerve roots) provides: - sensory innervation to the sole of foot - motor innervation to the triceps surae (soleus), plantaris, popliteus, flexor muscles of the foot, and tibialis posterior"
"The tibial nerve is commonly injured due to: - knee trauma - Baker cyst (proximal lesion) - tarsal tunnel syndrome (distal lesion)"
"Distal tibial nerve lesions present with: - sensory loss over the sole of the foot - weakness of intrinsic muscles of the foot"
"The superior gluteal nerve (L4-S1::(nerve roots)) provides: - sensory innervation to the none - motor innervation to the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fascia latae"
"The superior gluteal nerve is commonly injured due to intramuscular injection to the upper medial gluteal region (iatrogenic)"
"Injury to the superior gluteal nerve presents with trendelenburg sign and a gluteus medius lurch"
"Trendelenburg sign is characterized by tilting of the pelvis contralateral to the lesion"
"Intramuscular injections in the buttocks should be given in the anterolateral quadrant (specifically the von Hochstetter triangle) to avoid injury to the superior gluteal nerve"
"The inferior gluteal nerve (L5-S2::(nerve roots)) provides: - sensory innervation to the none - motor innervation to the gluteus maximus"
"The inferior gluteal nerve is commonly injured due to posterior hip dislocation"
"Injury to the inferior gluteal nerve presents as difficulty climbing stairs and rising from a seated position due to loss of hip extension"
"The pudendal nerve (S2-S4 (nerve roots)) provides: - sensory innervation to the perineum - motor innervation to the external urethral and anal sphincters"
"The pudendal nerve can be injured due to: - stretching during childbirth - saddle injury seen in cyclists"
"Injury to the pudendal nerve presents as: - decreased sensation in the perineal and genital area (sensory) - fecal or urinary incontinence (motor)"
"The pudendal nerve can be blocked with local anesthetic during childbirth / minor surgeries of the vagina and perineum using the ischial spine and sacrospinous ligament as landmarks for injection"
"What action do the following muscles allow the hip to do? Hip abduction Gluteus medius Gluteus minimus"
"What action do the following muscles allow the hip to do? Hip adduction Adductor magnus Adductor longus Adductor brevis"
"What action do the following muscles allow the hip to do? Hip extension Gluteus maximus Semitendinosus Semimembranosus Long head of the Biceps femoris"
"What action do the following muscles allow the hip to do? Hip flexion Iliopsoas (Iliacus + Psoas major / minor) Rectus femoris Tensor fascia lata Sartorius Pectineus"
"What kind of rotation do the following muscles allow the hip to do? Internal rotation Gluteus medius Gluteus minimus Tensor fascia lata"
"What kind of rotation do the following muscles allow the hip to do? External rotation Iliopsoas Gluteus maximus Piriformis Obturator"
"In a cervical or lumbar disc herniation, the disc typically herniates into the vertebral canal, affecting the inferior nerve"
"Intervertebral discs generally herniate posterolaterally::direction due to the thin posterior longitudinal ligament and thicker anterior longitudinal ligament"
"An intervertebral disc herniation at the L3-L4 level will result in: - weakness of leg extension and thigh flexion (action) - decreased patellar reflex - decreased sensation of anterior / medial thigh"
"An intervertebral disc herniation at the L4-L5 level will result in: - weakness of dorsiflexion (action) - difficulty in heel-walking"
"An intervertebral disc herniation at the L5-S1 level will result in: - weakness of plantar flexion (action) - difficulty in toe-walking - decreased achilles (ankle jerk) reflex"
"The long thoracic nerve travels with the lateral thoracic artery through the axilla/lateral thorax"
"The axillary nerve travels with the posterior circumflex humeral artery around the surgical neck of the humerus"
"The radial nerve travels with the deep brachial artery around the midshaft of the humerus"
"The median nerve travels with the brachial artery around the distal humerus/cubital fossa"
"The tibial nerve travels with the popliteal artery through the popliteal fossa"
"The tibial nerve travels with the posterior tibial artery posterior to the medial malleolus"
"Nusinersen is an antisense drug used to treat Spinal Muscular Atrophy"
"Treatment with nusinersen increases your risk for scoliosis"
"Eteplirsen is a antisense drug used to treat Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy by allowing the generation of a partially functional dystrophin protein"
"Bevacizumab can be used to treat Wet Age-related Macular Degeneration and Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy"
"Due to its anti-angiogenic effect, Bevacizumab poses an increased risk of bleeding and impairs wound healing"
"Bevacizumab can cause perforation of the GI tract"
"Rituximab targets B cells by binding CD20 surface antigen"
"Rituximab can lead to a depletion of what antibody type? IgG"
"Patients who are being treated with Rituximab should be watched for reactivation of the Hepatitis B or JC::2 Virus"
"Because the skin has abundant EGFR, patients undergoing Cetuximab treatment can experience a(n) Papulopustular acneiform rash"
"Chimeric biologics can be recognized as their names will include the infix -xi-"
"Serum Sickness can be treated with pulsed corticosteroid therapy"
"In physiological homeostasis, purines are excreted by way of metabolism to uric acid"
"In Purine metabolism, purines end up being converted to hypoxanthine, a substrate for xanthine oxidase"
"In Purine metabolism, xanthine oxidase first converts hypoxanthine to xanthine, and then converts xanthine to uric acid"
"Acute gout will commonly manifest in the 1st metatarsal"
"NSAIDs are the 1st line treatment for acute gout"
"Glucocorticoids are an immunosuppresive commonly used to treat acute gout"
"Colchicine is used to treat acute::acute or chronic? gout"
"Treatment for pseudogout consists of - NSAIDs - glucocorticoids - colchicine"
"When Pseudogout crystals are aspirated from the joint for microscopic analysis, these are blue::color and weakly positively::negatively/positively birefringent under parallel polarized light"
"The treatments for prophylactic treatment of chronic gout can be remembered by the mnemonic \Prevent A Painful Flare\\": - Probenecid - Allopurinol - Pegloticase (recombinant uricase) - Febuxostat\""
"Allopurinol and Febuxostat are used to inhibit xanthine oxidase in the management of Chronic Gout"
"After starting cytotoxic chemotherapy, a syndrome that can arise due to the massive amount of Tumor cell death is known as Tumor Lysis Syndrome"
"Tumor Lysis Syndrome is most common with treatment of lymphomas and acute lymphoblastic leukemia"
"The symptoms of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome can be managed with Xanthine Oxidase inhibitors"
"Drugs metabolized by xanthine oxidase (like the immunosuppressant Azathioprine and 6MP) will have serum levels boosted by administration of Allopurinol/Febuxostat"
"Probenecid and high-dose Aspirin decrease renal tubular reabsorption of uric acid"
"Probenecid may increase the risk of forming renal stones due to increased uric acid excretion"
"Patients taking drugs that are excreted via the renal tubular basolateral OAT channels (ex Penicillin, Cephalosporins, Methotrexate) should be monitored carefully while taking Probenecid"
"Uricosurics (like Probenecid) are only for under excretors::over producers / under excretors of uric acid"
"Probenecid is a(n) Sulfa drug and thus in susceptible patients can cause symptoms ranging from Fever to UTI to Stevens Johnson Syndrome"
"Low-dose Aspirin and Diuretics decrease uric acid secretion"
"Pegloticase and Rasburicase are recombinant uricases that works by converting uric acid into water soluble allantoin"
"Pegloticase can cause hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency"
"Pegloticase is a gout drug that can cause anaphylaxis"
"Rasburicase differs from Pegloticase as it is not PEGylated"
"At normal levels, uric acid is excreted by the kidneys"
"The Hawthorne Effect is a type of measurement bias where the participants change their behavior in response to awareness of being observed"
"Cladribine is an antineoplastic purine nucleoside analog that prevents cell cycle progression at the S* phase"
"Cladribine is primarily indicated for Hairy Cell Leukemia"
"Cladribine is activated primarily in lymphocytes, and works by inhibiting the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA)"
"A potentially fatal eosino::cell typephilic delayed hypersensitivity reaction elicited by Allopurinol is DRESS Syndrome"
"Can Allopurinol cause sloughing of skin at the dermal-epidermal junction? Yes"
"Xanthine Oxidase inhibitors can be used for prophylaxis of Uric Acid stones"
"The massive onset of hyperuricemia in Tumor Lysis Syndrome can lead to acute renal failure"
"Azathioprine/6MP are metabolized by the enzyme xanthine oxidase, thus inhibitors of that enzyme can boost serum levels of these drugs"
"6-mercaptopurine is bioactivated into its active metabolites via the enzyme HGPRT"
"Cells generate purines for cell growth through either de novo production or through the salvage pathway"
"The Ubiquitin-Proteasome system is recruited in response to damaged proteins as a result of cellular stress"
"Pembrolizumab is indicated for the treatment of all solid tumors that bear a(n) PD-L1 mutation"
"Because Lymphocytes are a cell population that proliferate rapidly, Azathioprine / 6MP work especially well for the treatment of Lymphocyte mediated inflammatory diseases"
"Azathioprine / 6MP can cause Hepatitis, thus must monitor liver function tests"
"Sulfasalazine is a combination of Mesalamine (anti-inflammatory) and Sulfapyridine (anti-bacterial), and thus is contraindicated in patients with sulfa allergies"
"Sulfasalazine is an anti-inflammatory therapy primarily indicated for Rheumatoid Arthritis"
"Sulfasalazine can cause a hemolytic anemia in patients with G6PD deficiency"
"Mesalamine is typically prescribed to be taken orally / rectally / as an enema for the treatment of IBD"
"Because Mesalamine acts in a similar manner to aspirin, it is contraindicated in patients with kidney disease"
"Sulfasalazine can cause a reversible oligospermia"
"Sulfasalazine is metabolized by colonic bacteria into the active component (mesalamine) which is used to treat the colitis aspects of IBD"
"Mesalamine (5ASA) works by inhibiting the synthesis of proinflammatory eicosanoids and cytokines"
"Mycophenolate Mofetil inhibits the enzyme Inosine Monophosphate Dehydrogenase (IMP dehydrogenase)"
"Mycophenolate mofetil is used prophylactically to reduce transplant rejection"
"Immunosuppressants are frequently used for suppression of cellular immunity to help prevent acute transplant rejection"
"Mycophenolate Mofetil is associated with invasive CMV infections"
"Mycophenolate mofetil can result in the hematological side effect of myelosuppression"
"Mycophenolate mofetil can affect the GI tract, leading to diarrhea"
"Outside of transplant rejection, Mycophenolate mofetil is used to to treat Lupus Nephritis"
"5-Fluorouracil (5FU) is an cytotoxic pyrimidine analog that prevents cell cycle progression at the S phase"
"Upon bioactivation, 5FU (now 5-FdUMP) covalently complexes with thymidylate synthase and folic acid, reducing DNA synthesis"
"When injected intravenously, 5FU can be used to treat colon cancer and pancreatic cancer"
"The effects of 5FU can be potentiated with Leucovorin"
"As a topical cream, 5FU can be used to treat basal cell carcinoma"
"Patients taking 5FU intravenously can experience Hand-Foot::skin syndrome"
"Patients taking 5FU as a topical cream can have complications of hyperpigmentation and photosensitivity"
"Hydroxyurea can also be used to treat malignant melanoma"
"Because the highly proliferative cell population at the bone marrow is very dependent on DNA synthesis, all antimetabolites (ex MTX, 5FU, Hydroxyurea) can cause myelosuppression"
"Methotrexate is a(n) folic acid analogue that blocks pyrimidine synthesis by competitively inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase"
"If taken during pregnancy, Methotrexate can cause neural tube defects, most commonly spina bifida or anencephaly"
"If β-hCG levels are still high after a D&C of a molar pregnancy, the remaining Hydatidiform mole can be treated with methotrexate"
"Methotrexate can cause pulmonary fibrosis, resulting in restrictive lung disease"
"Methotrexate can cause a(n) folate / Vitamin B9::vitamin deficiency"
"Since methotrexate is a(n) weak acid, a methotrexate overdose can be treated with Bicarbonate in order to alkalinize urine"
"Treatment of Polymyositis / Dermatomyositis involves corticosteroids followed by long-term methotrexate therapy"
"Methotrexate can be used as a disease modifying agent in the treatment of Lymphocyte::cell type mediated disorders"
"Choriocarcinomas and Trophoblastic Tumors can be treated with Methotrexate"
"As an antineoplastic, Methotrexate is primarily indicated for cancers of lymphocytes, particularly leukemias and lymphomas"
"During pregnancy, Methotrexate can be used as a(n) abortifacent (with Misoprostol) as well as in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy"
"Because methotrexate affects all rapidly dividing cells, this can affect the oral mucosa resulting in a(n) mucositis"
"Myelosuppression induced by Methotrexate / overdose can be reserved using the drug Leucovorin"
"Etanercept is used primarily for the treatment of Rheumatoid Arthritis"
"Etanercept works by complexing with TNF-a and inducing phagocytosis of the complex"
"Monoclonal antibodies against TNF-a are used primarily to treat Rheumatoid Arthritis and Inflammatory Bowel Disease"
"Cyclosporine can cause arthropathy by causing hyperuricemia"

"Azathioprine/6MP are used to treat chronic inflammatory diseases that are refractory to corticosteroids"

"Recombinant IFN-α can be used to treat malignant melanoma, hairy cell leukemia and renal cell carcinoma"
"IFN-α can be used to treat condyloma accuminatum"
"Recombinant IFN-β can be used to treat Multiple Sclerosis (Type IV HS disease)"

"Rituximab is indicated for immune thrombocytopenic purpura"
"Daclizumab is contraindicated in patients with liver impairment"
"Eculizumab is a monoclonal antibody for the C5 complement protein"
"Eculizumab is indicated for the treatment of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria"

"In the treatment of Crohn's Disease, Natalizumab works by preventing adhesion of autoreactive gut homing Th17 cells"
"Abciximab is an antiplatelet therapy used in patients undergoing PCI in order to prevent ischemic complications"
"Abciximab is indicated for unstable angina"
"Because Abciximab is a monoclonal antibody that binds platelets, patients can develop side effects of bleeding and thrombocytopenia"
"As part of the reversal of digoxin toxicity, anti-digoxin Fab fragments can be given to chelate Digoxin"
"Palivizumab is indicated for RSV prophylaxis in high-risk infants, and works by binding RSV Fusion protein"
"Tocilizumab is an anti-IL-6 receptor monoclonal antibody indicated for Giant Cell Arteritis and Cytokine Release Syndrome"
"In treating patients with RSV, Ribavirin is preferred in adults, whereas palivizumab is perferred in children"
"PCSK9 Inhibitors (alirocumab and evolocumab) work by inactivating LDL-receptor degradation, resulting in a dramatic decrease in LDL"
"An overdose of Dabigatran, a direct thrombin inhibitor, can be reversed by Idarucizumab"
"Tumor Lysis Syndrome results from the fulminant release of tumor cell contents into the plasma, resulting in the following problems - Hyperkalemia - Hyperphosphatemia - Hypocalcemia - hyperuricemia due to increased nucleic acid breakdown"
"Tumor Lysis Syndrome can be prevented / treated with aggressive hydration, xanthine oxidase inhibitors, or rasburicase"
"Recombinant IFN-y can be used to treat Chronic Granulomatous Disease"
"Canakinumab is a biologic that binds and prevents the activity of IL-1B"
"Periodic Fever Syndromes can be treated with Canakinumab"
"Canakinumab can be used to treat patients with Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis"
"Pegademase is a recombinant Adenosine Deaminase used for treatment of the second most common form of SCID"
"Glatiramer is a treatment for Multiple Sclerosis that is an analog of Myelin Basic Protein and works by shifting TH1 cells to a TH2 phenotype"
"Enzyme Replacement Therapy for Fabry Disease requires replacement of alpha-galactosidase A"
"Enzyme Replacement Therapy for Gaucher disease requires replacement of IV Glucocerebrosidase"
"Enzyme Replacement Therapy for Hurler Syndrome requires replacement of alpha-L-iduronidase"
"Enzyme Replacement Therapy for Hunter Syndrome requires replacement of Iduronate Sulfatase"
"Enzyme Replacement Therapy for Pompe disease requires replacement of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (aka acid maltase)"
"The most common side effect of Filgrastim is bone pain"
"Leflunomide is an antimetabolite that reversibly inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase preventing pyrimidine synthesis"
"Leflunomide inhibits T-cell proliferation, which makes it especially useful for its two main indications: Rheumatoid Arthritis and Psoriatic Arthritis"
"Because gut mucosa are a population of rapidly proliferating cells, people taking Leflunomide can experience diarrhea"
"Leflunomide is contraindicated in pregnancy as it is a known teratogen"
"Colchicine works by inhibiting intracellular microtubule polymerization through binding and stabilizing tubulin"
"By interfering with tubulin function, Colchicine disrupts the cytoskeleton::cellular element of neutrophils"
"The pathogenesis of Gout/Pseudogout involves Pattern Recognition Receptors detecting crystalline deposits (uric acid / calcium pyrophosphate) in joints, which in response leads to an inflammatory cascade mediated by IL-1, causing the joint to be invaded by neutrophils"
"Colchicine is primarily used for treatment of diseases that involve dysfunction of neutrophils"
"Colchicine can irritate the GI tract, resulting in diarrhea"
"Patients taking Colchicine can develop agranulocytosis"
"Colchicine can affect the muscle, resulting in a(n) myopathy"
"Colchicine can be used for acute treatment and prophylaxis of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease"
"Phosphoribosyl Pyrophosphate (PRPP) is a precursor to IMP"
"IMP is an intermediate purine nucleotide precursor to AMP and GMP"
"Patients taking Azathioprine / 6MP are predisposed to reactivation of Herpes Zoster or exacerbation of chronic viral Hepatitis"
"Mycophenolate mofetil works by inhibiting the proliferation of lymphocytes"
"Mycophenolate Mofetil can be used to treat Rheumatoid Arthritis"
"Because Cladribine, Cytarabine, Gemcitabine all target immune cells, this can cause patients to be at an increased risk for infection"
"Gemcitabine is active against hematologic malignancies and solid tumors"
"Because the oral mucosa contains rapidly dividing cells, patients taking bleomycin/anthracyclines can experience mucositis and stomatitis"
"The suffix of anthracyclines is -rubicin"
"Intercalation of Anthracyclines into DNA inhibits the progression of Topoisomerase II and induces eviction of histones"
"Rubicins and actinomycin D target rapidly dividing cells, resulting in the hematological side effect of myelosuppression"
"T-tubules are extensions of plasma membrane found in striated muscle"
"T-tubules allow for coordinated contraction of muscles"
"Anthracyclines can target hair follicles, resulting in alopecia"
"A(n) triad is a structure found in skeletal muscle which contains 1 T-tubule with 2 terminal cisternae"
"A(n) dyad is a structure found in cardiac muscle which contains 1 T-tubule with 1 terminal cisterna"
"The first step of muscle contraction occurs when the somatic motor neuron depolarizes, opens Ca2+ channels and ACh is released into the motor end plate"
"An IL-12 Receptor Deficiency may present after administration of the BCG vaccine"
"The BCG vaccine is a(n) live attenuated vaccine"
"In the diagnosis of Tuberculosis, the Interferon-y release assay has fewer false positives from BCG vaccination as opposed to a tuberculin test"
"Chronic PTH stimulates Osteoblasts to upregulate RANKL"
"The second step of muscle contraction occurs after ACh has been released by the motor neuron and binds to nicotinic cholinergic receptors, depolarizing the muscle cell"
"In muscle contraction, after the muscle cell is depolarized, the action potential travels down the T-tubule and to the dihydropyridine receptor::long name"
"Once a(n) conformational change is induced in the dihydropyridine receptor::long name, it opens the ryanodine receptor which releases Ca2+"
"After the ryanodine receptor is opened, the Ca2+ that is released binds to troponin C. This induces a conformational change that moves tropomyosin out of the myosin-binding groove on actin filaments, allowing actin-myosin binding"
"In muscle contraction, the power stroke occurs when myosin binds to actin after releasing Pi"
"During muscle contraction: - the H and I bands, and distance between Z bands, are shortened - the A band remains the same length"
"After the power stroke in muscle contraction, binding of a new ATP molecule causes detachment of the myosin head from the actin filament"
"After myosin binds a new ATP molecule in muscle contraction, hydrolysis of the new ATP molecule to ADP allows the myosin head to adopt a(n) high-energy, \cocked\\" position"
"Type I muscle fibers are also known as slow twitch muscle fibers"
"Slow twitch muscle fibers are red::color due to increased myoglobin concentration"
"Fast twitch muscle fibers are white::color due to decreased myoglobin concentration"
"Slow twitch muscle fibers perform more oxidative phosphorylation due to increased mitochondria"
"Fast twitch muscle fibers perform less oxidative phosphorylation due to decreased mitochondria"
"Type II muscle fibers are also known as fast twitch muscle fibers"
"Type I muscle fibers are increased in proportion after endurance training"
"Type II muscle fibers are increased in proportion after weight/resistance training and sprinting"
"Acetylcholine and bradykinin are stimuli for NO production in endothelial cells"
"Tumor Lysis Syndrome is most commonly seen when patients are treated for Lymphoma and Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia"
"NO is synthesized from L-arginine via NO synthase"
"Ca2+ enters smooth muscle cells via L-type Ca2+ channels and binds to calmodulin, leading to smooth muscle contraction"
"NO is produced in endothelial cells, then diffuses into smooth muscle cells leading to relaxation"
"NO upregulates guanylyl cyclase, which converts GTP to cGMP"
"cGMP stimulates myosin-light-chain phosphatase, which dephosphorylates myosin and relaxes smooth muscle"
"The Ca2+-calmodulin complex upregulates myosin-light-chain kinase, which phosphorylates myosin and contracts smooth muscle"
"Bones of the axial skeleton, appendicular skeleton, and base of the skull are formed via endochondral ossification"
"In endochondral ossification, a(n) hyaline cartilage::specific model is first made by chondrocytes"
"In endochondral ossification, osteoblasts and osteoclasts replace cartilage with a matrix of woven bone and then remodel to lamellar bone"
"In adults, woven bone is seen after fractures and in Paget disease"
"Endochondral ossification is defective in achondroplasia"
"Bones of the calvarium, facial bones, and clavicle are formed via membranous ossification"
"In membranous ossification, woven bone is formed directly, without cartilage::how?. It is then later remodeled to lamellar bone"
"Osteo-blasts build bone by secreting collagen, and catalyze mineralization via secretion of ALP"
"Osteo-blasts differentiate from mesenchymal stem cells in the periosteum"
"Osteoblastic activity is measured by: ALP, osteocalcin, and propeptides of type I procollagen"
"Osteo-clasts dissolve bone by secreting H+ and collagenases"
"Osteo-clasts differentiate from a fusion of monocyte/macrophage lineage precursors"
"At low, intermittent levels, PTH exerts anabolic effects on osteoblasts and osteoclasts"
"When chronically elevated, PTH has catabolic effects on bone, known as osteitis fibrosa cystica"
"Estrogens::hormone inhibit apoptosis in osteoblasts and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts"
"Estrogens (hormone) cause closure of the epiphyseal growth plate (bone structure) during puberty"
"Estrogen deficiency leads to increased cycling of bone remodeling and resorption, increasing risk of osteoporosis"
"Rituximab and Cetuximab are Chimeric monoclonal antibodies"
"Rituximab is indicated for disorders of B lymphocytes"
"Rituximab is associated with a rapidly fatal neuropathology known as Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy due to reactivation of the JC virus"
"Chimeric biologics run the risk of causing Serum Sickness within 7-10 days of administration"
"In patients with cardiovascular disease history, Bevacizumab is contraindicated due to the increased risk of Thrombotic events"
"Alemtuzumab is a monoclonal antibody against the cell surface marker CD52, which is expressed by Lymphocytes"
"Dihydrofolate Reductase converts DHF to THF"
"Thymidylate Synthase is an enzyme that catalyzes the methylation of dUMP to dTMP, utilizing the methyl group from a(n) methylated-THF"
"The main importance of the cofactor THF (Tetrahydrofolate) is that it can be given a(n) methyl group for use in methylation reactions"
"Inhibiting Dihydrofolate Reductase results in increased levels of DHF"
"Besides Thymidine production, THF is also involved in the formation of purine nucleosides, as well as some amino acids"
"Antimetabolites (Methotrexate, 5FU, Hydroxyurea) blocks the progression of S phase"
"As methotrexate affects all rapidly dividing cells, this can affect a patient's scalp and cause alopecia"
"As a result of inhibition of Thymidylate Synthase, there are increased levels of dUMP"
"As a result of 5FU targeting rapidly dividing cells, it can affect the gut mucosa resulting in diarrhea"
"Ribonucleotide reductase is used to convert UDP to dUDP"
"Etanercept is contraindicated in patients with an allergy to sulfa drugs"
"PEGylation of interferons allows what pharmacological property to be extended? Half Life"
"Chronic use of IFN-α is also associated with a profound fatigue and CNS toxicity"
"Chronic use of interferon alpha is associated with patients experiencing flu-like symptoms; as well as depression, neutropenia, and myopathy"
"Patients taking Interferon alpha can experience a drug induced lupus"
"IFN-y is important for activating the respiratory burst in phagocytes"
"When viruses enter cells, they can trigger the host (via capsule / viral products) to produce Type I Interferons by activation of cytosolic pattern recognition receptors"
"IFN-α and IFN-β can cause a(n) flu-like syndrome that can be symptomatically taken care of with ibuprofen"
"Type I interferons (IFN-α/IFN-B) work by presensitizing cells to the products of viral replication"
"Upon cytosolic recognition of viral dsRNA, enzymes upregulated by IFN-α/B presensitization lead to apoptosis of the virus infected cell"
"IFN-α acts to stimulate an anticancer immune environment in three ways - inhibit the proliferation of cancer cells - activating lymphocytes - enhancing expression of MHCI/II"
"Interferon β protects the Blood Brain Barrier by preventing extravasation of lymphocytes"
"IFN-Y is primarily produced by TH1 cells and primarily activates Macrophages and NK cells, along with CD8 CTLs"
"IL-12 stimulates polarization of naive TH0 cells towards a TH1 phenotype and away from a TH2 phenotype"
"IFN-y upregulates production of inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) which is involved in the generation of ONOO- (a powerful free radical)"
"IFN-y activates cytotoxic T cells"
"IFN-y stimulates NK cells and NKT cells"
"Because antimetabolites (methotrexate, 5FU, Hydroxyurea) suppress the immune system, patients taking these are at an increased risk of infection"
"Methotrexate can cause hepatotoxicity, which results in increased ALT and AST levels"
"Anthracyclines act as antineoplastics by producing free radicals and causing DNA intercalation"
"Alprostadil is used to maintain a(n) Patent Ductus Arteriosus in the setting of certain types of congenital heart disease"
"COX-1 and COX-2 are enzymes that produce prostanoids (e.g. prostaglandins)"
"If neonatal ductus arteriosus is not closing properly, this can be treated with Indomethacin"
"Carboprost, a(n) PGF2a analog can be used to increase uterine tone"
"Dinoprostone, a(n) (PGE2) analog, is used to promote uterine contractions for the purpose of inducing labor or abortion"
"Alprostadil and Misoprostol are analogues of PGE1"
"Misoprostol can be used to prevent NSAID-induced peptic ulcers"
"Because PGE1 is involved in physiological responses of the gut mucosa and the uterine smooth muscle, Misoprostol can cause diarrhea as well as uterine contractions"
"Misoprostol can be clinically used to treat gastric ulcers as at high doses it inhibits secretion of gastric acid"
"Sildenafil and tadalafil are examples of PDE-5 inhibitors"
"Latanoprost and Bimatoprost are long acting PGF2a mimics that can be used to treat open angle glaucoma"
"Latanoprost and bimatoprost can produce brown pigmentation in the iris and can cause eyelash growth"
"PDE-5 inhibitors have the suffix -afil"
"PDE-5 inhibitors work by preventing breakdown of cGMP to produce prolonged smooth muscle relaxation"
"Iloprost and Epoprostenol are prostacyclin (PGI2) analogues that can be used to treat Pulmonary Hypertension"
"Bosentan is an agent used to treat pulmonary hypertension that works by blocking the Endothelin-1 (ET-1) receptor"
"Bosentan is associated with fatal hepatotoxicity"
"Because iloprost and epoprostenol are potent vasodilators, these may cause symptoms of cutaneous flushing, headache, and hypotension"
"In adults, Alprostadil can be used for erectile dysfunction or critical limb ischemia due to its ability to cause potent vasodilation"
"Prostacyclin analogues can cause jaw pain as a side effect"
"PDE-5 inhibitors (e.g. sildenafil, tadalafil) are indicated for Erectile Dysfunction by way of increasing blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis"
"What is the route of giardia transmission? Fecal-oral"
"When individuals consume water filled with cysts of Giardia, infection occurs"
"What parasite is commonly associated with individuals who go camping and do not purify their water before consumption? Giardia"
"Giardia is a parasite commonly transmitted through consumption of poorly purified water"
"Giardia (parasite) commonly presents with bloating, flatulence and foul-smelling diarrhea"
"The foul-smelling diarrhea seen in a(n) Giardia::what parasite infection is due to steatorrhea* (fatty diarrhea)"
"The steatorrhea in Giardia is hypothesized to stem from excess mucus production that impairs fat absorption in the intestines"
"What vitamin deficiencies can occur with a Giardia infection? Fat Soluble (ADEK)"
"Weight loss::gain or loss is commonly seen in Giardia infections"
"Giardia is ingested in the cyst form. After ingestion, it differentiates into the trophozoite form"
"Does the trophozoite form of Giardia invade the intestinal wall? No, just attaches"
"Does the trophozoite form of Giardia present with bloody diarrhea? No"
"Trophozoites in stool is diagnostic of Giardia infection"
"What diagnostic tests are run to test for Giardia? Stool O&P (ova and parasites); ELISA stool antigen::2"
"The Giardia trophozoites in stool turn into cysts, thereby allowing them to infect other people"
"What is an ELISA looking for when testing for Giardia? Stool antigens"
"How is Giardiasis treated? Metronidazole"
"Does the trophozoite form of Entamoeba histolytica present with bloody diarrhea? Yes"
"How many life-cycle stages does Entamoeba histolytica have? 2"
"Which form of Entamoeba histolytica is infectious when ingested? Cyst form"
"Which intestinal parasites are ingested via contaminated water in the cyst form? Giardia; Entamoeba histolytica; Cryptosporidium::3"
"What demographic is Entamoeba histolytica associated with? MSMs (men who have sex w/ men)"
"What transmission is Entamoeba histolytica associated with? Anal-oral transmission"
"The cyst form of Entamoeba histolytica resides in the small intestines, while differentiation to the trophozoite form occurs in the colon"
"Differentiation of Entamoeba histolytica to the trophozoite form in the colon allows the parasite to enter the portal circulation and, eventually, the liver"
"Which lobe of the liver is most commonly involved with amoebic liver abscesses? Right lobe"
"Patients with amoebic liver abscesses complain of right upper quadrant pain with hepatomegaly"
"Entamoeba histolytica can cause amoebic liver abscesses, which are described as having \anchovy paste\\" consistency\""
"Entamoeba histolytica::which parasite can cause intestinal amebiasis, with ulcerations along the walls of the colon::where (be specific) and bloody diarrhea"
"What shape do the lesions present as in Entamoeba histolytica? \Flask-shaped\\"\""

"G. lamblia is not susceptible to chlorination but can be killed by boiling the water or with iodine"

"The Cryptococcus capsule is made up of repeating polysaccharide capsular antigens"
"The repeating polysaccharide capsular antigens of the Cryptococci capsule are the main virulence factor of the fungus, making it anti-phagocytic"
"Cryptococcus::which fungus is found mainly in pigeon droppings and soil"
"Cryptococci enter the body via inhalation, therefore the primary infection resides in the lungs"
"Which fungus is urease-positive? Cryptococcus neoformans"
"Cryptococcus is a(n) opportunistic infection, with most symptoms occurring in immuno-compromised patients (e.g. HIV+ patients, those with malignancies, high-dose steroid therapy, etc.)"
"Cryptococcus is the most common cause of fungal meningitis"
"The 3 most common symptoms of Cryptococcal::which fungal infection are Fever Pneumonia (recall lungs are primary site of infection via inhalation) Meningitis"
"Bronchopulmonary washings can be used to diagnose Cryptococcal::which fungal infection"
"The bronchopulmonary washing of tissue samples for diagnosis of Cryptococcus::which fungus utilizes the mucicarmine (red::color) or methenamine (silver::color) stains"
"India ink stains and outlines the heavy capsule that surrounds Cryptococci fungi, giving it a unique \halo\\" appearance\""

"Gross pathology of Cryptococcus infection appears as \soap-bubble\\" lesions in the gray matter of the brain\""
"Treatment of Cryptococcal meningitis consists of a joint therapy of Amphotericin B and Flucytosine followed by maintenance therapy with fluconazole"
