"Cryptococcus neoformans (along with other fungi) can be cultured on Sabouraud agar"
"Mucormycosis is caused primarily by Mucor sp. and Rhizopus"
"Immuno-compromised (e.g. those on glucocorticoids, HIV+/AIDS) and diabetic patients are especially susceptible to Mucormycosis infections"
"Rhizopus is a(n) bread mold, and is one of the major causes of Mucormycosis"
"Transmission of mucormycosis infection occurs via spore inhalation"
"What is the most common predisposing factor to mucormycosis? Diabetic ketoacidosis"
"After inhalation of Mucormycosis, the fungi have a predilection to proliferate in blood vessel walls, especially where there is excess glucose and ketone bodies"
"Mucormycosis::Which fungi's hyphae are non-septated::septated or non-septated with wide-angled (90°) branching"
"Mucormycosis will penetrate the cribriform plate of the skull, entering the brain"
"After penetrating the cribriform plate, mucormycosis continues to proliferate in the blood vessels, causing necrosis of tissues"
"Surgical excision of necrotic tissues is an important step in the treatment of Mucormycosis"
"What is the pharmacological treatment of Mucormycosis? Amphotericin B"
"Deferoxamine, which chelates both iron and aluminum, acts as a(n) siderophore for the species Rhizopus, enhancing its growth and pathogenicity. This leads to an increased risk for Mucormycosis"
"Patients with Mucormycosis::which fungal infection can present with rhinocerebral and frontal lobe abscesses"
"Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a serious complication of Mucormycosis fungal infection"
"Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungus responsible for causing Pneumocystic pneumonia"
"Pneumocystis jirovecii has a(n) respiratory transmission"
"What are the symptoms of Pneumocystis jirovecii in the immunocompetent? Asymptomatic - None :)"
"Pneumocystis pneumonia is a(n) AIDS-defining illness that presents with a CD4+ count < 200"
"When should you start prophylaxis for Pneumocystis jirovecii? CD4+ count < 200"
"Pneumocystis pneumonia is a(n) interstitial (atypical) pneumonia"
"Does Pneumocystis pneumonia have a productive cough? No"
"Does Pneumocystis pneumonia show consolidations on chest xray? No"
"Pneumocystis pneumonia can present with a \ground-glass\\" appearance on chest xray\""
"Pneumocystis pneumonia::which opportunistic infection causes interstitial pneumonia with a ground-glass appearance on chest xray"
"Bronchoalveolar lavage is used to confirm diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia"
"The bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) sample is stained with methenamine silver to identify the fungus Pneumocystis jirovecii in Pneumocystis Pneumonia"
"Pneumocystis pneumonia::infection can be said to have a \ground-glass\\" appearance on chest-xray\""
"Trimethoprim/Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) can be used in prophylaxis and treatment of pneumocystis pneumonia in patients without sulfa drug allergies"
"Pentamidine can be used in prophylaxis and treatment of pneumocystis pneumonia in patients with sulfa drug allergies"
"Pneumocystis jirovecii, formerly Pneumocystis carinii, is an opportunistic fungi that appears as cysts containing dark oval bodies on microscopy"
"Prokaryotes::Prokaryotes or Eukaryotes have no nucleus or membrane bound organelles"
"Eukaryotes::Prokaryotes or Eukaryotes have membrane bound organelles and nuclei"
"Eukaryotes::Prokaryotes or Eukaryotes include plant and animal cells"
"Eukaryotes::Prokaryotes or Eukaryotes include Protozoa and Fungi"
"Prokaryotes::Prokaryotes or Eukaryotes include Bacteria"
"Prokaryotes' nuclear material sits freely within the cytoplasm"
"A bacteria's cell wall can be a target for the immune system and antibiotics"
"purple circles are gram positive::negative or positive"
"Red/pink organisms are gram negative::negative or positive"
"What is the difference between Gram Positive and Gram Negative bacteria? Their cell walls"
"Gram positive bacteria have a much thicker cell wall"
"Lipoteichoic Acids are present in Gram Positive Bacteria's cell walls"
"Gram Negative Bacteria have thinner cell walls with a(n) outer membrane surrounding it"
"Peptidoglycan is a major structural component of bacterial cell walls, consisting of the two sugars N-acetylglucosamine (NAG) and N-acetylmuramic acid (NAM)"
"Peptides attach to N-acetylmuramic acid (NAM)::which sugar of the Peptidoglycan on a Bacterium's cell wall, connecting the sugars together"
"Mycoplasma::which bacteria does not gram stain due to lack of a cell wall. Its cell membrane instead has sterols for stability"
"Mycobacteria::which bacteria cell walls contain mycolic acid, therefore a special Ziehl-Neelsen (acid-fast) stain is used to visualize them"
"Chlamydia::which bacteria lacks muramic acid in its cell wall, resulting in poor gram staining"
"Electron Transport and Oxidative Phosphorylation occur on the Cell membrane of Bacteria"
"What molecule present on the surface of Gram Positive bacteria drives immune response to the organism? Lipoteichoic Acid"
"Gram Negative Bacteria contain a(n) periplasm, which is a space between the cell membrane and outer membrane"
"Gram negative bacteria have enzymes within their periplasm that allow them to resist antibiotic treatment"
"What molecule present on the surface of Gram Negative bacteria drives immune response to the organism? Lipopolysaccharide"
"Lipopolysaccharide is contained on the Outer membrane of Gram Negative Bacteria"
"The three components of Lipopolysaccharide are: 1. Polysaccharide 2. Lipid A 3. O antigen"
"Which part of Lipopolysaccharide is highly toxic and triggers cytokine release? Lipid A"
"Which part of Lipopolysaccharide is a target for antibodies? O antigen"
"Bacteria sometimes secrete a(n) capsule, which is a sticky, gelatinous layer that assists the bacteria in attaching to host cells"
"Capsules of bacteria are typically water and polysaccharide, protecting against phagocytosis"
"Bacillus anthracis has a peptide capsule made of d-glutamate that allows for increased virulence due to unimpeded growth"
"The Quellung Reaction is used to test for bacteria who have a(n) capsule"
"B-cells can secrete capsular antibodies (IgG) against bacteria who secrete a(n) capsule"
"IgG antibodies bind to the bacteria's capsule, resulting in either phagocytosis (Fc receptors) or binding of complement"
"Lack of B-cells, antibodies, or complement can result in recurrent encapsulated bacterial infections"
"Asplenia can result in an increased risk of sepsis from encapsulated bacteria due to loss of splenic phagocytes"
"Bacterial capsular polysaccharides are the basis for many vaccines"
"Bacteria with irregular, fuzz layer have a(n) glycocalyx"
"Bacteria with distinct, firmly attached gelatinous layer have a(n) capsule"
"Some bacteria secrete a(n) glycocalyx::not biofilm, allowing the bacteria to stick to a surface"
"Bacterial pili and fimbria allow bacteria to adhere to surfaces and attach to other bacteria for conjugation (exchange genetic information - sex)"
"The pili/fimbria in E. coli allow for attachment to the urinary tract"
"The pili in Neisseria gonorrhoeae::which bacteria allow for antigenic variation"
"Small DNA within the cells of bacteria that replicate independently are known as plasmids"
"The flagellum of a bacterium is a long protein arm used for motility"
"The two ribosomal subunits in bacteria/prokaryotes are 50S and 30S making 70S"
"The two ribosomal subunits in eukaryotes are 60S and 40S making 80S"
"Which type of antibiotics interfere with synthesis of the 30S ribosomal subunit of bacteria? Aminoglycosides"
"Some bacteria can enter a dormant state called a(n) spore"
"When a bacteria is in a(n) spore form, it can survive long periods in extreme conditions"
"The coat of the bacterial spore is the outermost layer that is made of a(n) keratin-like protein"
"Peptidoglycans make up the middle layer, or cortex, of a bacterial spore"
"The core, or innermost layer of the bacterial spore, contains DNA, ribosomes and glycolytic enzymes"
"Dipicolinic acid is found in abundance within a bacterial spore and is thought to provide heat resistance"
"3 most common bacterial shapes Coccus/Cocci Rods aka Bacilli::... aka ... Spirochetes"
"Pairs of cocci bacteria are known as diplococci"
"Chains of cocci bacteria are known as Streptococci"
"Bunches/Clusters of cocci bacteria are known as Staphylococci"
"Most cocci are gram positive, e.g. streptococcus, staphylococcus"
"Neisseria meningitidis/gonorrhoeae are gram negative diplococci::specific"
"Moraxella catarrhalis are gram negative diplococci"
"Most rods (and coccobacillus) are gram negative"
"Corynebacterium is a gram positive rod"
"Clostridium is a gram positive rod"
"Listeria is a gram positive rod"
"Bacillus (anthrax, cereus) is a gram positive rod"
"Actinomyces and Nocardia are bacteria that have a branching or filamentous shape"
"Treponema (syphilis), Borrelia (Lyme disease), and Leptospira (leptospirosis) are bacteria that have a(n) spirochete shape"
"Vibrio cholerae is a bacterium that has a(n) vibrio shape"
"2 common pleomorphic::shape bacteria are Rickettsia and Chlamydia"
"Purple bacteria of a gram stain are gram positive"
"Red bacteria of a gram stain are gram negative"
"The thick cell wall of peptidoglycan in gram positive bacteria holds the crystal violet of the gram stain in place"
"Intra-cellular bacteria do not gram stain well, including Rickettsia, Chlamydia and Legionella"
"The Giemsa stain enters cells and stains nucleic acids"
"The acid-fast stain is also known as Ziehl-Neelsen stain and contains carbolfuchsin"
"The Ziehl-Neelsen stain is used to stain the bacteria mycobacterium (e.g. TB, leprosy) and Nocardia, as well as the protozoa Cryptosporidium (its oocysts)"
"Silver (methenamine)::... aka ... stain is used to stain the fungi Pneumocystis pneumonia and Coccidioides (coccidioidomycosis), as well as the bacteria Legionella and H. pylori"
"The India Ink stain is mostly used to identify the fungus Cryptococcus neoformans"
"Which bacteria produces Golden/Yellow pigments? Staph Aureus"
"Which bacteria produces Blue-green pigments? Due to? Pseudomonas aeruginosa; Pyocyanin + Pyoverdin"
"Which bacteria produces red pigments? Serratia"
"Which bacteria produces yellow-orange pigments? Actinomyces"
"Actinomyces is a bacteria that cements together, forming \yellow sulfur granules\\"\""
"Selective::Selective/Non-selective media favors the growth of particular microbial organism while inhibiting growth of all other organisms"
"Thayer-Martin Media is a(n) selective media that only grows Neisseria"
"What is the most commonly used non-selective culture media? Blood agar"
"Enriched culture media have special nutrients added so that many bugs will grow"
"Blood agar is a(n) differential culture media because it allows us to identify bacteria based on their hemolytic pattern"
"Indicator (differential) media can also yield color changes due to differences in metabolism of certain organisms"
"Fastidious bacteria do not grow on standard media"
"What are two examples of fastidious bacteria? H. influenzae Legionella"
"Blood agar contains mammalian blood Non-selective (any bacteria can grow)::Selective or Non-selective Enriched (blood)::Enriched or Non-enriched Differential due to hemolysis pattern::Differential or Non-differential"
"The beta hemolysis pattern on blood agar is present with full lysis of RBCs"
"The alpha hemolysis pattern on blood agar is present with partial lysis of RBCs"
"The gamma hemolysis pattern on blood agar is present with lack of lysis of RBCs"
"A = beta hemolytic pattern B = alpha hemolytic pattern C = gamma hemolytic pattern"
"Blood agar is commonly used to differentiate species of streptococcus"
"Pseudomonas::which gram negative rod is β-hemolytic"
"Which gram positive cocci is also β-hemolytic? (besides streptococcus) Staph Aureus"
"What culture media contains RBCs that are lysed via heating? Chocolate Agar"
"Chocolate Agar contains NAD+ (factor V) and hematin (factor X) which are release when the RBCs are lysed"
"Chocolate Agar is used to grow H. influenzae and N. gonorrhoeae"
"H. influenzae is considered a fastidious bacteria because it needs NAD+ (factor V) and hematin (factor X) to grow"
"H. influenzae will grow on blood agar if Staph Aureus is present and causing β-hemolysis"
"Thayer-Martin Media contains vancomycin to kill gram positive organisms"
"Thayer-Martin Media contains Trimethoprim and Colistin (polymixin) to kill gram negative* organisms"
"Thayer-Martin Media contains Nystatin to kill fungi"
"Bordet-Gengou Agar is a potato extract used to grow Bordetella pertussis"
"Regan-Lowe medium is made of charcoal, blood and antibiotic and used to grow Bordetella pertussis"
"Loeffler’s Media/Tellurite Plate is used to identify Corynebacterium diphtheriae"
"Mycoplasma pneumonia requires cholesterol to grow, which is present in Eaton's Agar"
"MacConkey's Agar is a selective media for gram negative bacteria which contains bile salts to inhibit growth of gram positives"
"MacConkey's agar can also be used to differentiate lactose fermenters"
"Eosin-Methylene Blue Agar has a similar function to that of MacConkey agar, as it also inhibits gram positive bacteria growth"
"Eosin-Methylene Blue Agar will have lactose fermenting colonies (e.g. E. coli) appear as a green metallic sheen"
"Sorbitol MacConkey Agar is used to detect the O157 strains of E. coli"
"Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) Agar is used to identify Legionella"
"4 Bacterial Growth Environments Obligate Aerobes - environment w/ O2 Obligate Anaerobes - environment w/o O2 Facultative Anaerobes - either w/ or w/o O2 Intracellular bacteria"
"Superoxide dismutase and Catalase are two enzymes contained in aerobic organisms"
"Oxygen is the final electron acceptor during cellular respiration in obligate aerobes (bacteria type)"
"Obligate Aerobes::Obligate Aerobes or Anaerobes can generate lots of energy through cellular respiration using O2"
"4 common obligate aerobes: Nocardia Pseudomonas Aeruginosa Mycobacterium tuberculosis Bacillus (anthracis and cereus)"
"Obligate Anaerobes::Obligate Aerobes or Anaerobes lack the enzymes Superoxide Dismutase and Catalase"
"Aminoglycosides are antibiotics that require O2 to work, therefore do not work on obligate anaerobic bacteria"
"Obligate Anaerobes::Obligate Aerobes or Anaerobes are common among the normal flora of the gut and mouth"
"Obligate Anaerobes::Obligate Aerobes or Anaerobes use fermentation to generate ATP"
"The byproducts of anaerobic::aerobic or anaerobic fermentation are gases (CO2, H2) and short chain fatty acids (e.g. lactic acid)"
"Actinomyces is a(n) obligate anaerobe::obligate aerobe or anaerobe that is typically found in the gums and causes dental abscesses"
"Bacteroides fragilis is a(n) obligate anaerobe::obligate aerobe or anaerobe that is typically found in the gut and causes abdominal abscesses"
"Clostridium difficile; botulinum; perfringens; tetani are all obligate anaerobes::obligate aerobes or anaerobes"
"Clindamycin is used to treat anaerobic infections above the diaphragm"
"Metronidazole is used to treat anaerobic infections below the diaphragm"
"Bacteroides fragilis is an anaerobe that can enter abdominal abscesses and is resistant to many antibiotics"
"Treatment for abdominal abscesses include Metronidazole (B. fragilis is responsive) and a gram (-) antibiotic"
"Aspiration pneumonia occurs when mouth anaerobic::aerobic or anaerobic bacteria enter the lungs"
"Clindamycin is the drug of choice to treat aspiration pneumonia"
"Facultative Anaerobes::which type of bacteria can live without oxygen but use it if available"
"Do facultative anaerobes perform cellular respiration or fermentation? Both :)"
"Obligate intracellular bacteria cannot synthesize their own ATP, instead depending on the host for supply"
"Rickettsia rickettsi is an obligate intracellular bacteria that causes Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever"
"Chlamydia is an obligate intracellular bacteria that is a common cause of STDs"
"Brucella*, Francisella, and Yersinia pestis are zoonotic facultative intracellular bacteria that can live in macrophages"
"Facultative intracellular bacteria are bacteria that can live in other cells if necessary"
"Neisseria is a facultative intracellular bacterium that can live in urethral (and not intestinal) epithelial cells"
"Salmonella and Shigella are both facultative intracellular bacterium that can live in intestinal cells"
"Bacterial features that allow evasion of host defenses are known as Virulence factors"
"Protein A is a virulence factor part of the peptidoglycan cell wall of Staph Aureus"
"Protein A inhibits the phagocytosis of Staph Aureus by binding to the Fc portion of IgG antibodies"
"IgA is important for mucosal immunity"
"IgA protease::which virulence factor cleaves IgA and allows for colonization of mucosal surfaces"
"IgA protease is a virulence factor common in Streptococcus pneumonia, H. influenzae Type B, Neisseria spp."
"M protein::what surface virulence factor is found on the surface of group A strep (streptococcus pyogenes)"
"M protein::which virulence factor binds factor H and breaks down C3-convertase"
"M protein::which virulence factor shares properties with myosin, which may result in its causing of Rheumatic heart disease"
"M protein is responsible for post-strep throat complications (e.g. glomerulonephritis or Rheumatic heart disease)"
"Endotoxin::Exo or Endotoxin is a component of gram negative bacteria cell walls"
"Endotoxin::Exo or Endotoxin is released when bacteria die"
"Exotoxin::Exo or Endotoxin are proteins secreted by gram positive and negative bacteria"
"Endotoxin::Exo or Endotoxin are composed of a lipopolysaccharide complex (LPS)"
"Lipopolysaccharide Endotoxins::Exo or Endotoxins have a(n) Lipid A core responsible for their toxicity and a(n) O antigen terminal end that varies among bacterial strains"
"Exotoxins::Exo or Endotoxins are a two component \A-B\\" polypeptide\""
"Exotoxins::Exo or Endotoxins have a toxic A component and a(n) B component that binds to cell surfaces"
"Which part of endotoxin is targeted by the immune system? O antigen"
"Endotoxin present on gram negative bacteria can cause fever and shock"
"Endotoxin (part of LPS) triggers the release of which two cytokines? TNF and IL-1"
"Endotoxin is heat stable"
"Endotoxin generates a(n) weak::strength antibody response"
"Gram Negative Bacteria activate macrophages when Lipopolysaccharide (endotoxin) binds to CD14 and TLR4"
"Endotoxin/Lipopolysaccharide binding to CD14 of Macrophages releases IL-1, IL-6, TNF-a, and NO (proinflammatory cytokines)"
"Endotoxin/Lipopolysaccharide of Gram Negative Bacteria can activate the complement system, resulting in release of C3a and C5a"
"Endotoxin/Lipopolysaccharide of Gram Negative Bacteria can activate tissue factor, resulting in coagulation and possible DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation)"
"Some Gram Negative Bacteria have lipooligosaccharide, which lacks a(n) O antigen"
"Lipooligosaccharide (LOS) is an endotoxin found on non-enteric gram negative bacteria, e.g. Neisseria meningitidis"
"Meningococcemia results from an immune reaction to the endotoxin of Neisseria meningitidis"
"Gram negative sepsis can result when a bug like E. coli enters the blood stream from a rupture in the intestinal wall"
"The exotoxin Diphtheria toxin causes ADP-ribosylation (and therefore inhibition) of elongation factor-2 (EF2)"
"Exotoxin A is the exotoxin of Pseudomonas aeruginosa"
"Exotoxin A causes ADP-ribosylation (and therefore inhibition) of Elongation Factor-2"
"The shiga toxin is an exotoxin secreted by Shigella"
"The shiga toxin of Shigella binds the 60S subunit of ribosomes, inhibiting protein synthesis"
"Shigella::Shigella or EHEC invades the GI mucosal cells, resulting in infectious diarrhea"
"Enterohemorrhagic E. Coli (EHEC) produces a \Shiga-like\\" toxin\""
"Enterohemorrhagic E. Coli (EHEC) - classic serotype is O157:H7"
"When the \Shiga-like\\" toxin of Enterohemorrhagic E. Coli (EHEC) enters systemic circulation"
"Shigella and EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E. coli) both produce shiga toxins that result in bloody diarrhea"
"EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E. Coli)::Shigella or EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E. Coli)'s primary MOA is secretion of shiga toxin causing disease"
"The amount of Cl-::what ion secretion by GI mucosal cells determines H2O secretion"
"Fluid secretion in the GI tract occurs when the Gs protein::which G-protein is stimulated, activating adenylyl cyclase::which enzyme, increasing cAMP production and opening the CFTR channel allowing Cl- ion secretion"
"Enterotoxigenic E. Coli (ETEC) is responsible for two exotoxins, Heat labile toxin (LT) and Heat stable toxin (ST)"
"Heat labile toxin::Heat labile or Heat stable toxin activates adenylyl cyclase in the gut, thereby increasing water secretion and causing diarrhea"
"Heat stable toxin::Heat labile or Heat stable toxin activates guanylyl cyclase in the gut, thereby increasing cGMP secretion"
"Heat stable toxin::Heat labile or Heat stable toxin inhibits NaCl absorption and stimulates Cl- secretion, which results in more water in the gut and diarrhea"
"Bacillus Anthracis makes three exotoxic proteins; protective antigen (PA), lethal factor (LF), and edema factor (EF)"
"What exotoxin is secreted by Vibrio Cholerae? Cholera toxin"
"Cholera toxin permanently activates Gs of GI mucosal cells, resulting in Cl- ion secretion and \rice water\\" diarrhea\""
"Bordetella pertussis secretes the exotoxin Pertussis Toxin"
"Pertussis toxin::which exotoxin inhibits a(n) Gi protein within neutrophils, resulting in increased levels of cAMP within the neutrophils"
"Increased cAMP via Pertussis Toxin results in impaired recruitment of neutrophils"
"SNARE proteins are present on neurotransmitter vesicles, allowing the vesicles to dock and release the NT into the synaptic cleft"
"Inhibition of SNARE proteins inhibits docking of neurotransmitter vesicles and ultimately neurotransmitter release"
"Clostridium tetani produces the exotoxin Tetanospasmin"
"The exotoxin Tetanospasmin inhibits inhibitory::excitatory or inhibitory neurons, resulting in lack of GABA and Glycine release"
"Tetanospasmin::which exotoxin works in the Renshaw cells of the spinal cord"
"Clostridium botulinum produces the exotoxin Botulinum toxin"
"Clostridium tetani results in rigid muscles"
"Clostridium botulinum results in floppy muscles"
"Botulinum toxin::which exotoxin inhibits Acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction, resulting in lack of muscle contraction"
"Clostridium perfringens causes \gas gangrene\\" when it enters wounds\""
"Clostridium perfringens produces the exotoxin Alpha toxin, which is a(n) Phospholipase C enzyme"
"Alpha toxin::which exotoxin degrades phosphatidylcholine and sphingomyelin, resulting in myonecrosis of the muscles"
"Along with muscle breakdown, the exotoxin Alpha Toxin also results in decreased muscle blood flow"
"Streptococcus Pyogenes can cause strep throat, rheumatic fever, and glomerulonephritis"
"Streptococcus pyogenes produces the exotoxin Streptolysin O (cytolysin)::... aka ..."
"What antibodies are elevated following a strep infection? Anti-streptolysin O (ASO) antibodies"
"A toxoid is an inactivated bacterial exo::exo/endo-toxin used for vaccination"
"Diphtheria and Tetanus are toxoid vaccines; Pertussis is acellular (therefore partially toxoid)"
"Exo-toxin genes are typically not part of a chromosome, and instead are encoded by plasmids and bacteriophages"
"Superantigens are exotoxins that cause a massive amount of T-cell activation"
"Superantigens fully attach to an antigen present cell's (APC) MHC II::MHC I or II and a T-cell's TCR, stimulating a large T-cell response"
"Superantigens result in a large release of cytokines, leading to massive vasodilation/hypotension and shock"
"Which two bacteria can synthesize superantigens? Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes"
"Staphylococcus aureus synthesizes the superantigen Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin-1 (TSST-1)"
"Streptococcus pyogenes synthesizes the superantigens Pyrogenic exotoxin A or C"
"Superantigens result in toxic shock syndrome"
"Streptococcus pyogenes' pyrogenic exotoxin B is often associated with necrotizing fasciitis"
"Toxic Shock syndrome will present with fever, shock (hypo-tension) and a diffuse red rash"
"Exotoxin generates a(n) strong::strength antibody response"
"Exotoxin is heat labile"
"3 phases of bacterial growth curve: lag phase, growth/log phase, stationary phase"
"During the lag phase of bacterial growth, there is no increase in number of cells since you added them to the culture"
"The growth phase of bacterial growth is dependent on the generation/doubling time"
"The generation/doubling time is the time is takes for the number of bacterial cells to double"
"During the stationary phase of bacterial growth bacteria are continuing to grow but also starting to die"
"What phase of bacterial growth do antibiotics have their greatest effect? Growth"
"Transformation is a way that bacteria uptake DNA from their surrounding environment"
"Addition of DNAase will degrade any naked DNA present in a culture medium, inhibiting any bacterial transformation"
"Conjugation involves bacteria extending a sex pilus, allowing exchange of DNA between two different strains"
"High frequency recombinant (Hfr) strains of bacteria will take plasmids and incorporate them into their cellular DNA"
"When Hfr strains of bacteria undergo conjugation, they transfer their bacterial genome with the plasmid to the recipient"
"In normal conjugation, is there transfer of bacterial chromosomal DNA? No - Normal conjugation involves transfer of plasmids only"
"Transformation::which bacterial genetics phenomenon is used to amplify DNA"
"Conjugation of High Frequency bacterial strains allows us to perform genetic mapping"
"A(n) bacteriophage is a virus that infects bacteria"
"Transduction describes the transfer of DNA from one bacteria to another via a bacteriophage"
"What are the two types of bacterial transduction? Generalized and Specialized"
"Generalized::Generalized or Specialized bacterial DNA transduction occurs when a(n) lytic::lytic or lysogenic phage infects the bacterium"
"Specialized::Generalized or Specialized bacterial DNA transduction occurs when a(n) lysogenic::lytic or lysogenic phage infects the bacterium"
"Generalized::Generalized or Specialized bacterial DNA transduction occurs when bacterial chromosomal DNA is packaged in the phage, resulting in transfer of bacterial DNA with lysis of the bacteria"
"Specialized::Generalized or Specialized bacterial DNA transduction stems from incorporation of viral DNA into bacterial DNA; excision of viral DNA results in excision of bacterial DNA as well"
"The Lytic::Lytic or Lysogenic cycle is when a phage injects nuclear material into preexisting bacterial DNA, multiples and then lyses the cell, releasing the new viruses"
"The Lysogenic::Lytic or Lysogenic cycle is when a phage injects nuclear material into preexisting bacterial DNA and it is incorporated into the host DNA"
"Phages that only replicate via the lytic cycle are known as virulent"
"Phages that replicate via both the lytic and lysogenic cycle are known as temperate"
"Lysogeny allows for non-toxic strains of DNA to obtain bacterial toxins"
"These 5 bacterial toxins depend on lysogeny in order to be secreted by their corresponding bacteria: Group A strep Erythrogenic toxin (causes scarlet fever) Botulinum Toxin Cholera Toxin Diphtheria Toxin Shiga Toxin"
"Which 5 bacterial toxins depend on lysogeny in order to be secreted by their corresponding bacteria? Group A strep Erythrogenic toxin (causes scarlet fever) Botulinum Toxin Cholera Toxin Diphtheria Toxin Shiga Toxin::G, B, C, D, S"
"Transposition describes a(n) transposon of bacterial DNA that can \jump\\" from one location to another (e.g. bacterial DNA or even a plasmid)\""
"In Transposition of bacterial DNA, a(n) transposon can move to a(n) plasmid, allowing transfer to another bacterium via conjugation"
"Transposition of bacterial DNA allows for transfer of bacterial DNA amongst different strains, such as resistance to antibiotics"
"Conjugation of normal bacteria involves transfer of plasmids only"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: First split into Bacilli, Cocci and Branching, Filamentous"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Bacilli and Branching, Filamentous split into aerobic and anaerobic"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Gram Positive Cocci are either anaerobic or facultative anaerobes (O2)"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Cocci split into catalase negative and catalase positive"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Aerobic Bacilli include Listeria, Bacillus, Corynebacterium"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Aerobic Bacilli include Listeria, Bacillus, Corynebacterium"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Anaerobic Bacilli include Clostridium, Propionibacterium"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Anaerobic Bacilli include Clostridium, Propionibacterium"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Aerobic Branching/Filamentous include Nocardia"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Anaerobic Branching/Filamentous include Actinomyces"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Which Branching/Filamentous is weakly acid-fast Nocardia::Actinomyces/Nocardia"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Catalase Positive Cocci - Staphylococcus"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Catalase Negative Cocci - Streptococcus"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: What is used to differentiate between different strains of Staphylococcus? Coagulase test"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: What is used to differentiate between different strains of Streptococcus? Hemolysis pattern"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Staphylococcus Coagulase Positive - Staph Aureus"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Staphylococcus Coagulase Negative is further broken into Novobiocin sensitivity (resistant or sensitive)"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Staphylococcus Coagulase Negative Novobiocin Resistant - Staphylococcus saprophyticus"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Staphylococcus Coagulase Negative Novobiocin Sensitive - Staphylococcus epidermidis"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Streptococcus β-hemolysis is further broken down via Bacitracin sensitivity (resistant/sensitive)"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Streptococcus β-hemolysis Bacitracin Resistant - Streptococcus agalactiae (group B strep)"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Streptococcus β-hemolysis Bacitracin Sensitive - Streptococcus pyogenes (group A strep)"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Streptococcus alpha-hemolysis is further broken down via Optochin sensitivity"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Streptococcus alpha-hemolysis Optochin sensitive - Streptococcus pneumonia"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Streptococcus alpha-hemolysis Optochin resistant - Streptococcus viridans (mutans and mitis)"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Streptococcus gamma-hemolysis are separated via bile and NaCl growth"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Streptococcus gamma-hemolysis, bile and salt::bile and salt/bile only - Enterococcus (Group D strep)"
"Gram Positive Algorithm: Streptococcus gamma-hemolysis, bile only::bile and salt/bile only - Streptococcus bovis"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: First split into Diplococci, Coccobacilli, Bacilli and Comma-shaped rods"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Diplococci are aerobic::aerobic/anaerobic organisms"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Diplococci::shape are further split via whether or not there is maltose utilization"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Diplococci with::with or without maltose metabolism - Neisseria meningitidis"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Diplococci without::with or without maltose metabolism - Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Moraxella"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Coccobacilli includes H. influenzae, Pasteurella, Brucella, Bordetella pertussis, Francisella tularensis"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Coccobacilli includes H. influenzae, Pasteurella, Brucella, Bordetella pertussis, Francisella tularensis"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Bacilli are further split via lactose fermentation"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Bacilli who are::are/are not lactose fermenters are further split into whether they ferment fast or slow"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Bacilli who are not::are/are not lactose fermenters are further split into whether they contain cytochrome oxidase"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Bacilli who are fast lactose fermenters include Klebsiella, E. coli, Enterobacter"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Bacilli who are fast lactose fermenters include Klebsiella, E. coli, Enterobacter"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Bacilli who are slow lactose fermenters include Citrobacter, Serratia"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Bacilli who are slow lactose fermenters include Citrobacter, Serratia"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Bacilli who are not lactose fermenters and are Oxidase Positive - Pseudomonas"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Bacilli who are not lactose fermenters and are Oxidase Negative are further split based on H2S production on TSI agar"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Bacilli who are not lactose fermenters and are Oxidase Negative, H2S production on TSI agar negative - Shigella, Yersinia"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Bacilli who are not lactose fermenters and are Oxidase Negative, H2S production on TSI agar positive - salmonella, proteus"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: All comma-shaped rods are cytochrome oxidase positive::positive or negative"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Comma-shaped rod, grows at 42°C - Campylobacter jejuni"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Comma-shaped rod, grows on alkaline media - Vibrio cholerae"
"Gram Negative Algorithm: Comma-shaped rod, produces urease - Helicobacter pylori"
"The process of decreasing pathogenic organism counts to safe levels is known as disinfection"
"The process of inactivation of self-propagating biological entities is known as sterilization"
"Autoclaves work to sterilize equipment by using pressurized steam"
"Alcohols and Chlorhexidine work by denaturing proteins and disrupting cell membranes"
"Hydrogen peroxide works via a(n) free radical oxidation mechanism"
"Iodine and iodophors work by halogenation of DNA, RNA and proteins"
"What methods of disinfection/sterilization are definitively sporicidal? Hydrogen peroxide and Chlorine"
"What methods of disinfection/sterilization are not sporicidal? Alcohols, Chlorhexidine, Quarternary Amines::3"

"Chlamydia spp. cell walls lack muramic acid"

"2nd stage of Chlamydia spp. life cycle: reticular"

"Which life cycle stage of Chlamydia spp. is intracellular? Reticular Body"
"Which life cycle stage of Chlamydia spp. undergoes replication? Reticular Body"
"Lysis of the cell results in Chlamydia spp. returning back to the elementary body from the reticular body"

"Treponema pallidum is a(n) spirochete::shape and may be described as \spiral-shaped\\"\""
"Darkfield microscopy is needed for direct visualization of Treponema pallidum"
"VDRL is the typical screening test used for diagnosing Primary Treponema pallidum"
"VDRL and RPR are the typical screening tests used for diagnosing Secondary Treponema pallidum"
"A positive screening test for Treponema pallidum (via VDRL or RPR) is confirmed via FTA-ABS (fluorescent treponemal antibody-absorption)"
"Primary syphilis is characterized by a(n) painless::painless/painful genital::location chancre"
"Secondary syphilis is a(n) systemic disease, no longer localized to the genital region"
"Secondary syphilis is characterized by a(n) maculopapular::description,  copper/red::color rash on the palms and soles weeks to months after infection"
"Secondary syphilis presents with condyloma lata, which are raised, infectious gray-white wart-like lesions on mucous membranes (mouth, perineum)"
"Spirochetes of Treponema pallidum can be visualized inside condyloma lata/latum of secondary syphilis via darkfield microscopy"
"Gummas of tertiary syphilis are characterized as soft growths with firm necrotic centers"
"Gummas of tertiary syphilis can occur on the skin, bones or internal organs"
"Tertiary syphilis can present with aortitis, particularly of the ascending thoracic aorta"
"Tertiary syphilis can present with aortitis, with a characteristic \tree-barking\\" appearance\""
"Tertiary syphilis can present with aortitis, complete with aneurysm of the ascending aorta due to endarteritis and resultant aortic valve regurgitation"
"Tertiary syphilis destroys the vasa vasorum, or blood vessels that supply the vessel wall of the aorta"
"Tertiary syphilis can result in Tabes Dorsalis, or demyelination of the dorsal column and roots"
"Tabes Dorsalis is characterized by loss of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs)::clinical finding due to degeneration of the dorsal roots"
"Tabes Dorsalis is characterized by positive romberg sign due to loss of proprioception"
"Tabes Dorsalis is characterized by charcot joints due to loss of proprioception"
"Argyll-Robertson pupil is a complication of Tertiary syphilis where the eye accommodates to near objects but does NOT react to light"
"Congenital syphilis occurs when Treponema pallidum is transmitted trans-placentally from a pregnant woman to her fetus"
"Congenital Syphilis is characterized by \Saber Shins\\""
"Congenital Syphilis is characterized by \saddle-shaped\\" nose\""
"Congenital Syphilis is characterized by Mulberry molars, characterized by enamel outgrowth"
"Congenital Syphilis is characterized by congenital deafness and sensorineural hearing loss due to CN VIII damage"
"What is the treatment for all stages of Syphilis? Benzathine Penicillin G (intramuscular)"
"Administration of Penicillin for Syphilis may lead to the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction"
"The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a response to the release of endotoxin-like factors from the lysis of Treponema pallidum organisms that manifests as fevers, chills, and myalgias"
"A mnemonic used to remember the infectious agents which may cross the placenta and cause congenital infection is ToRCHHeS: Toxoplasmosis Rubella CMV HIV Herpes virus Syphilis (treponema pallidum) VZV Parvovirus"
"Viruses contain either DNA or RNA surrounded by a(n) capsid"
"Do viruses have metabolic activity? No"
"The two most common shapes of viral capsids are icosahedral and helical"
"Viruses can either be \naked\\" or \\"enveloped\\"\""
"All naked viruses have icosahedral capsids"
"Enveloped viruses can have either an icosahedral or helical shape (whereas naked viruses are all icosahedral)"
"The lipid membrane of a host cell can be acquired by the virus and is used as the viral envelope"
"Viral glycoproteins embedded in the surface of the envelope can be used to bind to host cells; are also antigens for the immune system"
"Most RNA virus genomes are single-stranded and linear::circular/linear"
"Most RNA viruses replicate in the cytoplasm"
"RNA viruses can be distinguished via their polarity, either (+) sense or (-) sense"
"Positive sense RNA viruses carry RNA that is structurally similar to mRNA"
"Positive sense RNA can be used immediately by the cell for gene translation and protein synthesis"
"Negative sense RNA viruses must first be converted to positive sense RNA in order to be used by the host cell for protein synthesis"
"Positive sense RNA are oriented in the 5' to 3' direction"
"Negative sense RNA are oriented in the 3' to 5' direction"
"Retroviruses (e.g. HIV) are diploid single-stranded RNA viruses"
"Retroviruses (e.g. HIV) utilize the enzyme reverse transcriptase to convert their diploid linear stranded RNA genome to dsDNA"
"DNA viral genomes can either be circular or linear and are usually double-stranded"
"Parvovirus is the only DNA virus that has a single-stranded genome"
"Which type of viral genome (dsDNA, (+) RNA, (-) RNA) is not infectious by itself? (-) RNA"
"The vaccines for Hepatitis B and HPV 6, 11, 16, 18::which two viruses are recombinant vaccines"
"The vaccine for Hepatitis B Virus uses recombinant HbsAg"
"HIV is a retrovirus, which is a(n) di-ploid single-stranded (+)::(+)/(-) RNA::RNA or DNA virus"
"Does HIV have an envelope? Yes"
"HIV has two strands of RNA in its genome"
"The gag gene of HIV encodes p24 and p17"
"The env gene of HIV encodes gp120 and gp41"
"gp41 is the transmembrane protein of HIV, mediating viral-cell fusion and syncytia formation"
"gp120 is the outer glycoprotein of HIV"
"gp120 of HIV binds CD4, and the co-receptors CXCR4 (primarily on T cells), and CCR5 (primarily on macrophages)"
"The pol gene of HIV encodes the enzymes reverse transcriptase, aspartate protease, and integrase"
"HIV is considered a ToRCHeS infection and can be transmitted through the placenta"
"HIV initially infects what cell type? Macrophages"
"HIV later on infects what cell type? CD4+ Helper T cells"
"The prodrome (onset) of HIV consists of flu or mono-like symptoms with cervical lymphadenopathy and fever"
"The clinical latency period of HIV infection can last 10 years"
"Stage 1 HIV is characterized by wide dissemination to lymphoid organs"
"Stage 2 HIV is characterized by clinical latency. CD4+ count drops to < 500"
"Stage 3 HIV is characterized by recurrent bacterial infections. CD4+ count drops to < 350"
"Stage 4 HIV is also known as AIDS, with a CD4+ count < 200"
"The criteria for AIDS is CD4 count less than 200, or confirmed HIV positivity with AIDS-defining opportunistic infections such as Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) or Candida esophagitis"
"Which AIDS-defining illness is caused directly by HIV? Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma"
"In early::early or late HIV infection, HIV gains entry into macrophages::what cells via binding to CD4 plus the coreceptor CCR5"
"In late::early or late HIV infection, HIV gains entry into Helper T-cells::what cells via binding to CD4 plus the coreceptor CXCR4"
"Individuals with homo-zygous CCR5 allele mutations are resistant to HIV infection"
"Individuals with hetero-zygous CCR5 allele mutations display a slower rate of progression of HIV infection"
"Transmission of HIV occurs via bodily fluids"
"Diagnosis of HIV *previously* was made initially with ELISA; positive results are confirmed with a(n) Western blot"
"ELISA and western blots (no longer used) for the diagnosis of HIV are falsely positive in infants born to HIV+ mothers since anti-gp120 antibodies cross the placenta"
"What tests are used to diagnose HIV in neonates? HIV RNA and HIV DNA nucleic acid amplification tests::2"
"Rev is a regulatory protein of HIV that regulates viral RNA transport of unspliced viral transcripts out of the nucleus"
"Tat is a regulatory protein of HIV that transcriptionally activates other viral genes"
"Which two regulatory proteins of HIV are required for viral replication? Rev and Tat"
"Nef is a cytoplasmic accessory protein of HIV that enhances viral replication through down-regulation of CD4 and MHC-I expression"
"Once HIV is inside a cell, viral reverse transcriptase converts viral RNA to double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) This double-stranded DNA is inserted into the host cell genome by integrase, another viral enzyme"
"The backbone of Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) are NRTIs such as Zidovudine"
"Which NRTI drug has been shown to reduce HIV transmission from pregnant mothers to their fetuses by 2/3? Zidovudine"
"NRTIs::NRTIs or NNRTIs insert themselves into the DNA of the reverse transcriptase, halting further elongation"
"NRTIs and NNRTIs both are reverse transcriptase inhibitors used in the treatment of HIV"
"Protease inhibitors inhibit the enzyme responsible for cleaving proteins during viral replication"
"Maraviroc is a(n) CCR5 inhibitor that inhibits HIV entrance into macrophages early in the disease course"
"Ivabradine is indicated for chronic stable angina in patients who cannot take β-blockers"
"Ivabradine is indicated for chronic Heart Failure with reduced ejection fraction"
"Ivabradine works by inhibiting the funny sodium (If) channels, prolonging phase 4 of the nodal action potential"
"What does Ivabradine do to: Chronotropy = Negative Effect Inotropy = No effect"
"What does Ivabradine do to MvO2? Decrease"
"Ivabradine can manifest visual side effects of luminous phenomena"
"Ivabradine is contraindicated in sick sinus syndrome::rhythm problem"
"Ivabradine can cause cardiac side effects of bradycardia and hypertension"
"p24 is the HIV capsid protein"
"HIV-associated lipodystrophy can be treated by the GHRH analog tesamorelin"

"Most DNA viruses replicate in the nucleus::cytoplasm or nucleus"
"Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) replicates in the nucleus::cytoplasm or nucleus"
"Cowdry bodies are located in the nucleus"
"Cowdry bodies are eosino-philic nuclear inclusions found in cells infected with organisms within the herpesviridae family"
"Vertical transmission is the passage of a pathogen from mother to baby during the period immediately before and after birth"
"Herpes virus can be transmitted via saliva, sex and vertically through the placenta"

"HSV-2 is usually confined to the lower half of the body"

"Erythema multiforme may appear 1-2 weeks after Herpes Simplex Virus infection"
"Erythema multiforme are a result of HSV infection and appear as a \target lesion\\" with a pink-red ring around a pale center\""
"Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy is classically associated with HSV-2"
"HSV-2 remains latent in the sacral ganglion"
"HSV-2 can cause aseptic meningitis in adolescents and adults::what two demographics"

"Pelvic inflammatory disease can result in fallopian tubal scarring, which is a major risk factor for ectopic pregnancies and infertility"

"Mirabegron is a sympathomimetic that stimulates β3 receptors"
"At the bladder, stimulation of β3 receptors results in bladder relaxation"
"In the skeletal muscle, stimulation of β3 receptors results in increased thermogenesis"
"In fat, stimulation of β3 receptors results in increased lipolysis"
"Mirabegron is indicated for urinary urge incontinence"
"Midodrine is a(n) α1 agonist indicated for postural hypotension and autonomic insufficiency"
"Midodrine may exacerbate supine hypertension"

"EDTA is a(n) chelator used for heavy metal poisoning"

"Fomepizole works as an antidote for methanol/ethylene glycol poisoning by inhibiting Alcohol Dehydrogenase"
"Disulfiram is used to discourage alcohol consumption"
"Disulfiram works by inhibiting acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, resulting in a build up of acetaldehyde"

"As a result of inhibition of VDCCs located on the presynaptic membrane of neurons, pregabalin results in decreased neurotransmission"
"The main advantage pregabalin has over gabapentin is that it is more::more/less? bioavailable"

"In the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis, Lumacaftor works by facilitating proper folding of the CFTR protein"
"In the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis, Ivacaftor works by stimulating activity of the CFTR protein"
"Saline is a solution of sodium chloride"
"In the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis, aerosolized hypertonic saline is used to facilitate mucus clearance"
"Cidofovir (a CMV retinitis drug) is administered with probenecid and IV saline to reduce nephrotoxicity"
"In treating β-blocker toxicity, IV saline is given to restore blood pressure"
"In treating SIADH, hypertonic saline is given when treating a patient with severe symptoms, and isotonic saline is given for mild symptoms"
"Isotonic Saline can cause a(n) normal anion gap metabolic acidosis"
"For both :) hypovolemic and distributive::hypovolemic or distributive shock give IV isotonic saline or ringers lactate. For distributive shock only, pressors are indicated"
"Why are hypotonic saline solutions rarely used by themselves? Can cause RBC lysis"

"Group A strep (Streptococcus pyogenes) can cause erysipelas and cellulitis"

"Streptococcus pyogenes results in cellulitis, which is a deep infection of the skin"

"SpeB of Streptococcus pyogenes is associated with necrotizing fasciitis"
"M protein is an anti-phagocytic virulence factor contained on Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS) cell walls"
"M protein of Streptococcus pyogenes is similar in structure to myosin"
"M protein of Streptococcus pyogenes can result in antigenic response to myosin in cardiac muscle"
"Rheumatic fever is caused by cross-reactivity between Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS)::bug antigens (M protein) and self-antigens"
"Rheumatic fever::GAS complication most commonly results in damage and stenosis of the mitral valve"
"Rheumatic fever is generally preceded by group A strep pharyngitis and NOT GAS skin infections (impetigo)"
"Rheumatic fever is a type II hypersensitivity reaction"
"The \JONES\\" criteria is used for Rheumatic Fever: J: Joints - migratory polyarthritis O: ♥ - carditis (endocarditis"
"Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction"
"Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS) can ultimately result in Rheumatic Fever and Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN)"
"Signs of Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis include dark, \cola\\"-colored urine and facial edema\""
"Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis occurs 2 wks::time post GAS infection"
"Circulating immune complex deposition causes glomerular damage and subsequent nephritic syndrome in Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis"
"Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is generally preceded by either group A strep pharyngitis AND/OR GAS skin infections (impetigo)"
"Early diagnosis and treatment of strep throat cannot::can/cannot prevent post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis"
"Early diagnosis and treatment of strep throat can::can/cannot prevent rheumatic fever"
"The drug of choice for treatment of Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS) is penicillin"
"Which virulence factors of Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS) allows for lysis of RBC and WBCs? Streptolysin O and Streptolysin S::2"
"Streptokinase is a virulence factor released from Group A Strep that converts plasminogen to plasmin (a fibrinolytic)"
"DNase-B is a virulence factor released by Group A Strep that de-polymerizes DNA"
"S. pyogenes (GAS) is bacitracin sensitive::sensitive or resistant"
"Elevated titers of Anti-streptolysin O (ASO) or anti-DNase B antibodies are indicative of recent Group A strep (S. pyogenes) infection"
"Anti-M protein antibodies are the cause of Rheumatic Fever"
"Group B Strep is known as Streptococcus agalactiae"
"Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) is hippurate positive::positive or negative"
"Is Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) encapsulated? Yes (polysaccharide capsule)"
"Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) and Listeria monocytogenes are CAMP test positive"
"The CAMP test will show a increasing zone of hemolysis when Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) or Listeria monocytogenes is plated with Staphylococcus aureus"
"Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) is β-hemolytic"
"Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) is bacitracin resistant"
"Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) causes neonatal meningitis, sepsis, and pneumonia"
"Group B strep (Streptococcus agalactiae) is part of the natural flora of the GI tract and vagina"
"Which strain of Streptococcus can be passed to the baby via vaginal delivery? GBS (Streptococcus agalactiae)"
"Culture of the mother's vagina at 35 wks::time of pregnancy is done to ensure Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) has not colonized"
"Pregnant mothers with vaginal colonization of Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) are given intra-partum penicillin prophylaxis"
"What is the treatment for Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS)? Penicillin G::specific"
"Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) is gram-positive"
"Streptococcus agalactiae (GBS) is catalase negative"
"Streptococcus pneumoniae is alpha-hemolytic"
"Streptococcus viridans is alpha-hemolytic"
"In alpha-hemolysis, there is a green hue due to the oxidation of hemoglobin"
"Streptococcus pneumoniae virulence factors are an anti-phagocytic polysaccharide capsule and IgA protease"
"Streptococcus pneumoniae is optochin-sensitive"
"Streptococcus pneumoniae is a(n) lancet-shaped diplo-cocci"
"Streptococcus pneumoniae is bile-soluble"
"What is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia in adults? Streptococcus pneumoniae"
"Lobar pneumonia and \rust\\"-colored sputum are indicative of Streptococcus pneumoniae\""
"Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of C-MOPS: - Conjunctivitis (redness and discharge) - Meningitis (fever, chills, headache, neck stiffness) - Otitis media (ear pain) - Pneumonia (fever, cough, chills) - Sinusitis (nasal discharge, sinus tenderness)"
"Due to Streptococcus pneumoniae having a polysaccharide capsule virulence factor, patients who have sickle cell disease or a-splenic patients are particularly susceptible"
"Treatment of Streptococcus pneumoniae includes azithromycin (macrolides) and ceftriaxone (3rd gen. cephalosporin)"
"The pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) is given to children under 5 years and adults over 65 to prevent Streptococcus pneumoniae infection"
"Is Streptococcus viridans encapsulated? No"
"Streptococcus viridans is optochin-resistant"
"Streptococcus viridans is bile-insoluble"
"Lab results of S. pneumoniae meningitis include low::high or low CSF glucose"
"Lab results of S. pneumoniae meningitis include high::high or low polymorphonuclear cells in CSF"
"Lab results of S. pneumoniae meningitis include high::high or low protein in CSF"
"Which spp. of Streptococcus viridans causes dental caries? Streptococcus mutans"
"Which spp. of Streptococcus viridans causes subacute endocarditis? Streptococcus sanguinis"
"Which spp. of Streptococcus viridans causes endocarditis? (non-subacute) Streptococcus mitis"
"Which heart valve is most commonly affected by subacute and acute endocarditis caused by Streptococcus sanguinis and mitis? Mitral valve"
"Streptococcus sanguinis (viridans family)::specific makes dextrans which bind to fibrin-platelet aggregates on damaged heart valves"
"Enterococci spp. include Enterococcus faecalis and Enterococcus faecium"
"Enterococcus faecalis is more::more/less common and less::more or less likely to be resistant to vancomycin than Enterococcus faecium"
"Enterococcus faecium is less::more/less common and more::more or less likely to be resistant to vancomycin than Enterococcus faecalis"
"Enteroccoci species grows on 6.5% NaCl and 40% bile culture media"
"Enterococcus spp. are bile-insoluble (aka resistant)::soluble or insoluble"
"Enterococcus spp. can result in UTIs, subacute endocarditis, and biliary tree infections"
"Which antibiotics are used to treat VRE? (vancomycin resistant enterococcus - commonly Enterococcus faecium) IV Linezolid; Tigecycline"
"Enterococci spp. are one of the leading causes of nosocomial (hospital) infections in the U.S. due to high antibiotic resistance"
"Enterococci spp. are facultative anaerobes"
"Enterococci spp. are gram-positive"
"Enterococci spp. normally inhabit the lower GI and GU tracts"
"If Streptococcus bovis is present in the blood (bacteremia) what pathology should be suspected? Colon cancer"
"Streptococcus bovis biotype 1 is known as Streptococcus gallolyticus"
"Streptococcus gallolyticus can cause bacteremia and subacute endocarditis; is associated with colon cancer"
"Both Mycobacteria tuberculosis and leprae stain acid-fast, taking up the carbol fuchsin stain"
"Both Mycobacteria tuberculosis and leprae stain acid-fast due to the high concentration of mycolic acids in their cell walls"
"Mycobacteria tuberculosis grows slow::fast or slow, requiring 2-6 wks to grow"
"Mycobacteria tuberculosis grows on the Löwenstein Jensen agar"
"What is the oxygen dependency of Mycobacteria tuberculosis? Obligate aerobe"
"M. tuberculosis is transmitted via inhalation of droplet nuclei (airborne particles)"
"Mycobacteria tuberculosis primarily resides and proliferates in macrophages::cell type"
"Cord factor allows for clumping of Mycobacteria tuberculosis in a \serpentine-like\\" formation\""
"Cord factor of Mycobacteria tuberculosis stimulates granuloma formation via induction of TNF-a"
"Cord factor of Mycobacteria tuberculosis activates macrophages via induction of TNF-a, which then form granulomas"
"Cord factor of Mycobacteria tuberculosis is only present in virulent strains of bacteria"
"Sulfatides (surface glycolipids) of Mycobacterium tuberculosis inhibit phagolysosome fusion"
"Paths of Progression after Primary Mycobacteria tuberculosis infection: healed latent infection (most common)"
"Paths of Progression after Primary Mycobacteria tuberculosis infection: disseminated/systemic infection aka miliary tuberculosis"
"Paths of Progression after Primary Mycobacteria tuberculosis infection: secondary infection, which occurs by reactivated infection due to immunosuppression (HIV, old age, cancer, etc)"
"Primary infection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis commonly affects the middle and lower lobes of the lungs"
"Primary Mycobacteria tuberculosis infection is diagnosed via presence of the Ghon complex"
"The Ghon complex of Primary tuberculosis includes hilar lymphadenopathy with Ghon foci in the middle and lower lobes of the lungs"
"A(n) Ghon focus is a(n) caseating granuloma::specific located near the pleura in the middle or lower lobes of the lung (tuberculosis infection)"
"The granulomas of a Ghon focus are caseating granulomas, meaning they have a central area of necrotic macrophages::specific cell"
"Most cases of primary tuberculosis occur in children::demographic and the immunocompromised"
"Most cases of primary tuberculosis resolve, healing via fibrosis and calcification, transitioning to latent disease"
"Latent tuberculosis infections result in a positive purified protein derivative (PPD+) skin test"
"Exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis::bug name will always* result in a positive PPD test"
"The BCG vaccine can result in a false positive PPD test"
"What is the prognosis for miliary tuberculosis? Poor (100% fatality if not treated)"
"Miliary tuberculosis develops when the infection is disseminated into the blood (bacteremia)"
"Miliary tuberculosis can result in granuloma formation in the spleen, liver, adrenal gland and meninges (causing meningitis)"
"Inhibition of TNF-a::specific molecule (e.g. immunosuppression, drugs) results in lack of granuloma formation and resultant reactivation of tuberculosis"
"Reactivated tuberculosis affects the upper lobes of the lung"
"Cough, night sweats, and hemoptysis are symptoms of reactivated Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection"
"CNS involvement of disseminated Mycobacteria tuberculosis can result in meningitis as well as cavitary lesions known as tuberculomas"
"Active Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection is treated with RIPE therapy"
"Active Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection is treated with RIPE therapy: - Rifampin - Isoniazid - Pyrazinamide - Ethambutol (or streptomycin)"
"Isoniazid is administered with pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) in patients at risk for peripheral neuropathy as well as those who are pregnant, breastfeeding or have epilepsy"
"A(n) Ranke complex is a Ghon complex that has undergone progressive fibrosis and subsequent calcification"
"Diagnosis of active primary tuberculosis is made by chest x-ray (CXR) demonstrating a(n) Ghon complex and pleural effusion"
"What test for tuberculosis does not cross-react with BCG vaccine? Quantiferon Gold assay"
"The Quantiferon Gold assay measures IFN-gamma levels released from Th1-cells exposed to Mycobacterium tuberculosis"
"Kidney infection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis results in RBCs and WBCs in urine WITHOUT bacteria, known as sterile pyuria"
"The two phases of tuberculosis treatment include 4 drugs for 2 months followed by 2 (isoniazid and rifampin) drugs for 4 months"
"Isoniazid (INH) can be used alone as treatment for latent tuberculosis infections"
"Isoniazid (INH) works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid production on Mycobacteria tuberculosis"
"Isoniazid (INH) is a prodrug that is activated by KatG (a catalase-peroxidase), which is produced by Mycobacteria tuberculosis"
"Mutations in Mycobacterium tuberculosis that down-regulate the expression of KatG (a catalase-peroxidase) lead to Isoniazid::drug resistance"
"Peripheral neuropathy, ataxia, and paresthesias are common side-effects of Isoniazid therapy for Mycobacterium tuberculosis"
"Isoniazid is metabolized by the hepatic enzyme N-acetyltransferase"
"Slow-acetylators have an increased risk of side effects from Isoniazid (INH)"
"Isoniazid promotes the excretion of pyridoxine (Vitamin B6), therefore resulting in deficiency and peripheral neuropathy"
"Isoniazid may also cause altered mental status and seizures (CNS toxicity)"
"Hepato-toxicity is associated with Isoniazid use"
"Isoniazid hepatotoxicity results in an asymptomatic rise in aminotransferases (AST, ALT) on LFTs"
"Drug-induced lupus is an immunologic toxicity of Isoniazid use"
"Isoniazid use can result in metabolic acidosis::acidosis or alkalosis"
"The metabolic acidosis associated with Isoniazid use has a(n) elevated::normal or elevated anion gap"
"Isoniazid inhibits::induces or inhibits cytochrome p450"
"Rifampin induces::induces or inhibits cytochrome p450"
"Rifampin::Antibacterial works by binding to bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, inhibiting RNA synthesis"
"Mutations in which bacterial enzyme can result in resistance to Rifampin? DNA-dependent RNA polymerase"
"Rifampin is used as prophylactic mono-therapy in those exposed to H. influenzae and Neisseria meningitidis::what two bugs?"
"Rifampin use is associated with hepato-toxicity"
"Which antibacterial drug may produce a red-orange discoloration of body fluids? Rifampin"
"Ethambutol blocks the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, inhibiting carbohydrate polymerization at the bacterial cell wall"
"Which of the RIPE drugs is bacteriostatic? Ethambutol"
"The most serious adverse effect of ethambutol::TB drug use is optic neuritis, characterized by loss of visual acuity and red-green colorblindness"
"Pyrazinamide is an antibiotic only used to treat Mycobacterium tuberculosis"
"Which RIPE drug can cause uric acid crystal formation and ultimately gout? Pyrazinamide"
"Pyrazinamide is associated with hyper-uricemia"
"Pyrazinamide is hepato-toxic, even leading to liver necrosis"
"Pyrazinamide is a pro-drug that is converted into the active form, pyrazinoic acid, by the enzyme pyrazinamidase"
"Pyrazinamide readily crosses the blood-brain barrier, and is used to treat tuberculous meningitis"
"The B6 depletion with Isoniazid use can lead to decreased protoporphyrin synthesis, leading to a(n) sideroblastic anemia"
"Rifampin can be remembered by the 4 R's DNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibitor Ramps up microsomal CYP450 Red/orange body fluids Rapid Resistance if used alone"
"Mycobacterium leprae thrives in cool temperatures, explaining its predilection for extremities of the body"
"Mycobacteria leprae grows extensively in armadillos::animal, which have a cooler core body temperature"
"Leprosy is caused by Mycobacteria leprae and is also known as Hansen's disease"
"Mycobacteria leprae can cause tuberculoid and lepromatous leprosy"
"Tuberculoid leprosy is associated with a strong Th1-cell response, allowing for cell-mediated immunity"
"Tuberculoid leprosy is able to be contained within macrophages"
"Well-demarcated, hairless, hypoesthetic, hypopigmented skin plaques are common in Tuberculoid leprosy"
"A positive Lepromin skin test demonstrates a good cell-mediated response in Tuberculoid leprosy"
"Lepromatous leprosy is associated with a strong Th2-cell response, allowing for humoral immunity"
"Lepromatous leprosy is unable to be contained within macrophages, allowing for diffuse inflammatory damage"
"Which form of Leprosy (Mycobacteria leprae) is communicable (human to human)? Lepromatous leprosy"
"Lepromatous leprosy presents with a symmetrical glove and stocking neuropathy"
"Poorly-demarcated raised lesions on extensor surfaces of the extremities is characteristic of Lepromatous leprosy"
"\Leonine facies\\" are characteristic of Lepromatous leprosy (Mycobacteria leprae)\""
"Loss of eyebrows is characteristic of Lepromatous leprosy"
"A saddle-nose (thick) with thick cheeks is characteristic of Lepromatous leprosy"
"Infertility due to testicular involvement is characteristic of Lepromatous leprosy"
"Treatment of the Tuberculoid form of Leprosy includes Rifampin and Dapsone for 6 months::time"
"Treatment of the Lepromatous form of Leprosy includes Rifampin, Dapsone and Clofazimine for 24 months to 5 years::time"
"Mycobacterium leprae is an obligate intracellular bacteria"
"Mycobacterium avium complex is a non-TB disease that causes disseminated infection in the late stages of AIDS"
"Mycobacterium avium complex includes Mycobacterium avium and Mycobacterium intracellulare"
"Mycobacterium avium complex is treated with azithromycin/clarithromycin (a macrolide) combined with ethambutol"
"Azithromycin prophylaxis for Mycobacterium avium complex should be started with CD4+ counts < 50"
"Rifabutin may be added as a third agent in the treatment of Mycobacterium avium complex"
"Rifabutin induces::induces or inhibits cytochrome p450"
"Because Rifabutin induces CYP450 less than other drugs in its class (i.e. Rifampin), it is used in the treatment of tuberculosis in HIV patients"
"Side-effects of Dapsone include agranulocytosis and hemolytic anemia in G6PD deficiency"
"What drug used to treat Mycobacteria leprae may present with Heinz bodies and bite cells (degmacytes)? Dapsone"
"Mycobacteria marinum causes a hand-infection in aquarium handlers"
"Mycobacteria scrofulaceum causes cervical lymphadenitis in children"
"What drug can be used instead of Ethambutol to treat Mycobacteria tuberculosis infection? Streptomycin"
"Penicillins are effective against the thick peptidoyglycan cell walls of gram positive bacteria (e.g. Staphylococcus spp. and Streptococcus spp.)"
"What proteins cross-link peptidoglycan on bacterial cell walls? Penicillin binding protein transpeptidases (PBPs)"
"β-lactams (e.g. penicillin, cephalosporins, etc.) work by halting peptidoglycan synthesis via inhibition of penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) transpeptidase activity"
"Penicillin G is administered IV"
"Benzathine salts of penicillin G can be given via intramuscular injection"
"Penicillin V::specific or Aminopenicillins (amoxicillin, ampicillin)::2 (penicillins) treat Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS) pharyngitis (strep throat)"
"Penicillin V or G are treatments for Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS) rheumatic fever::heart"
"Penicillin G treats left-sided endocarditis caused by Strep viridans and Strep bovis"
"The treatment for a pregnant mother's vagina colonized by Strep agalactiae (GBS) is intra-partum penicillin G prophylaxis"
"What is the treatment for Actinomyces israelii? Penicillin"
"What is the treatment for Clostridium perfringens? Penicillin, Clindamycin::2"
"What is the treatment for Pasteurella multocida? Penicillin"
"Which bug commonly infects dog bite wounds? Pasteurella multocida"
"What is the treatment of primary, secondary and latent syphilis (Treponema pallidum)? Benzathine penicillin G (intramuscular)::very specific"
"What gram negative bug that causes meningitis is treated with penicillin G or ceftriaxone? Neisseria meningitidis"
"Resistance of penicillins comes from production of β-lactamases that cleave the β-lactam ring, or changes to penicillin binding proteins (confers methicillin resistance in MRSA)"
"β-lactamases are expressed by plasmid genes"
"Penicillins can result in type I hypersensitivity reactions, mediated by IgE causing anaphylaxis"
"Penicillins can result in autoimmune hemolytic anemia, which results in a positive direct Coombs test due to IgG against penicillin binding to RBCs"
"Which penicillin toxicity involves the kidney? Interstitial nephritis"
"Penicillins inhibit the ability of bacteria to generate a cell wall, which causes death by osmolysis In addition, penicillins allow accumulation of peptidoglycan precursors, which activates bacterial autolysis"
"Penicillin binds to PBP transpeptidases by mimicking the D-ala-D-ala sequence of peptidoglycan"
"β-lactamase enzymes are found in the periplasm of gram negative bacteria"
"Anti-staph penicillins include oxacillin, nafcillin, and dicloxacillin"
"Aminopenicillins include amoxicillin and ampicillin"
"IV::ROA ampicillin::aminopenicillin can be used to treat anaerobic infections (e.g. aspiration pneumonia)"
"Enterococcus spp. can become resistant to ampicillin due to β-lactamase production"
"Are aminopenicillins (amoxicillin, ampicillin) sensitive to β-lactamases? Yes!"
"Which aminopenicillin can be used in asplenic or sickle cell patients to prophylactically treat encapsulated (e.g. Strep pneumoniae or H. influenzae) infection? Amoxicillin"
"Which aminopenicillin can be used in dental procedures to prophylactically treat endocarditis in high-risk patients? Amoxicillin"
"Amoxicillin/clavulanate therapy is one of the most common causes of drug-induced liver injury"
"Aminopenicillins (amoxicillin) causing a maculopapular rash in EBV infection is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction"
"A patient that was given a penicillin drug that has in-creased BUN/creatinine, eosino-phils in urine and sterile pyuria most likely has interstitial nephritis"
"Interstitial nephritis that develops as a result of Penicillin administration is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction"
"Direct Coombs Positive Hemolytic Anemia that develops as a result of Penicillin administration is a type II hypersensitivity reaction"
"What 2 classes of penicillins can penetrate the porins of gram negative bacteria? Aminopenicillins (ampicillin, amoxicillin); Antipseudomonal penicillins (ticarcillin, piperacillin)"
"What type of penicillins have a positively charged R-group? Aminopenicillins (amoxicillin, ampicillin)"
"Clavulanic acid (clavulanate) is a suicide β-lactamase inhibitor that is combined with the aminopenicillin amoxicillin (Augmentin) or the antipseudomonal ticarcillin"
"Sulbactam is an irreversible β-lactamase inhibitor that is combined with ampicillin (an aminopenicillin) (Unasyn)"
"Tazobactam is an irreversible β-lactamase inhibitor that is combined with piperacillin (antipseudomonal penicillin) (Zosyn)"
"Cephalosporins inhibit bacterial penicillin binding protein transpeptidases (PBPs).::enzyme"
"Cephalosporins (and other β-lactam antibiotics) mimic the D-ala-D-ala sequence of peptidoglycans, binding irreversibly::reversibly/irreversibly to penicillin binding protein transpeptidases"
"1st generation cephalosporins include cephalexin and cefazolin"
"1st generation cephalosporins have activity mostly against gram-positive organisms"
"1st generation cephalosporins can be used to treat GAS pharyngitis and cellulitis"
"2nd generation cephalosporins include cefuroxime, cefotetan, cefoxitin and cefaclor"
"2nd generation cephalosporins have the same coverage as 1st generation cephalosporins with extended gram-negative coverage"
"3rd generation cephalosporins include ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, ceftazidime"
"3rd generation cephalosporins are::are/are not able to penetrate the CNS"
"3rd generation cephalosporins can be used to treat community and hospital acquired pneumonia"
"Which 3rd generation cephalosporin can treat Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection? Ceftazidime"
"What generation of cephalosporins has Pseudomonas coverage (besides 3rd gen. ceftazidime)? 4th gen. (cefepime)"
"Do 5th generation cephalosporins have Pseudomonas coverage? No!"
"What generation of cephalosporins have coverage against vancomycin-intermediate staph aureus (VISA)? 5th gen. (ceftaroline)"
"Cephalosporins have similar hypersensitivities to those seen in what drugs? Penicillins"
"What β-lactam antibiotics result in increased nephrotoxicity when combined with aminoglycosides? Cephalosporins"
"Epstein-Barr Virus is part of the herpesviridae family"
"Epstein-Barr Virus is icosahedral::helical or icosahedral"
"Epstein-Barr Virus is enveloped::naked or enveloped"
"Epstein-Barr Virus is linear::circular or linear"
"Epstein-Barr Virus is a(n) dsDNA virus"
"Epstein-Barr Virus causes monospot positive infectious mononucleosis"
"Epstein-Barr Virus is primarily transmitted through saliva or respiratory secretions"
"Epstein-Barr Virus is associated with fever, post-erior cervical lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis, and hepatosplenomegaly"
"Epstein-Barr Virus is associated with Downey type II atypical CD8+ cytotoxic T::very specific cells on blood smear"
"Downey type II T-cells are atypical CD8+ cytotoxic T-cells seen on a blood smear of Epstein-Barr Virus"
"Atypical (Downey type II) T cells are unusually large T cells with baso-philic, vacuolated cytoplasm and lobulated nucleus"
"Epstein-Barr Virus first infects the oropharynx epithelium"
"T-cell proliferation in Epstein-Barr Virus results in (hepato)splenomegaly"
"Epstein-Barr Virus remains latent in B-cells"
"Epstein-Barr virus binds to CD21 (C3d receptor; CR2) on B-cells, causing B-cell proliferation and heterophile antibody production"
"The B-cell CD21 is the receptor for complement protein C3d"
"Because of splenomegaly, patients with mononucleosis (EBV) are advised to avoid contact sports (e.g. football) for danger of splenic rupture"
"Epstein-Barr Virus can result in pharyngitis with tonsillar exudates"
"Which cause of pharyngitis is more commonly seen in children and adolescents? Strep pyogenes (GAS)"
"Which cause of pharyngitis is more commonly seen in late teens and adults? EBV (infectious mononucleosis)"
"If patients with Epstein-Barr Virus are given aminopenicillins (amoxicillin, ampicillin), a maculopapular rash will develop days to weeks after"
"EBV causes heterophile-positive mononucleosis"
"CMV causes heterophile-negative mononucleosis"
"What virus can predispose individuals to oral hairy leukoplakia in the setting of immunosuppression (e.g. HIV)? EBV"
"Epstein-Barr Virus is strongly associated with the mixed cellularity and lymphocyte depleted subtypes of Hodgkin’s lymphoma"
"Which virus is strongly associated with the mixed cellularity and lymphocyte depleted subtype of Hodgkin’s lymphoma? Epstein-Barr Virus"
"Hodgkin's lymphoma consists of malignant \Reed-Sternberg\\" cells surrounded by inflammatory cells\""
"Reed-Sternberg cells of Hodgkin's lymphoma are of B-cell origin"
"Reed-Sternberg cells of Hodgkin's lymphoma are CD15+ and CD30+"
"Reed-Sternberg cells of Hodgkin's lymphoma are bi-nucleate with prominent nucleoi (\owl eyes\\")\""
"Hodgkin's lymphoma mixed cellularity type has the most Reed-Sternberg cells"
"Hodgkin's lymphoma caused by EBV presents as a(n) mediastinal mass or nontender::tender or nontender lymphadenopathy"
"Epstein-Barr Virus is associated with the endemic (African) form of Burkitt’s lymphoma"
"What virus is associated with the endemic (African) form of Burkitt’s lymphoma? Epstein-Barr Virus"
"What complication of Epstein-Barr Virus can present with a large jaw lesion and swelling? Endemic (African) Burkitt lymphoma"
"Which form of Burkitt's lymphoma presents as a mass on the jaw or face? Endemic (African)"
"Which form of Burkitt's lymphoma presents as an abdominal mass? Non-endemic (sporadic form)"

"What demographic is associated with Nasopharyngeal carcinoma that arises from EBV? Asians"
"What virus causes agglutination of sheep or horse RBCs? Epstein-Barr Virus"
"The monospot test for EBV looks for heterophile anti-sheep/horse RBC antibodies"
"Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is part of the herpesviridae family"
"Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is icosahedral::helical or icosahedral"
"Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is enveloped::naked or enveloped"
"Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is linear::circular or linear"
"Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a(n) dsDNA virus"

"Similar to Rubella, CMV can present with a \blueberry muffin\\" rash\""

"What percentage of neonates congenitally infected with CMV are asymptomatic? 80-90%"
"Which trimester is associated with the highest risk of congenital CMV? 1st trimester*"
"CMV can result in hydrops fetalis, which commonly leads to spontaneous abortion"
"What is the most common cause of viral-associated intellectual disability (in the US)? CMV"
"Reactivation of CMV occurs in the immunosuppressed, such as organ transplant and AIDS patients"
"Organ transplant patients are at an increased risk of CMV pneumonia"

"AIDS patients are at risk for CMV infections when their CD4 count is < 50"

"Uric acid is normally freely excreted by the kidney"
"In the liver::organ, nucleic acids are broken down into nucleotide monomers"
"Metabolism of purines ultimately produces uric acid"
"Purines are first converted to hypoxanthine"
"Hypoxanthine is converted to xanthine via xanthine oxidase"
"Xanthine is converted to uric acid by xanthine oxidase"
"NSAIDs (e.g. indomethacin) are first line agents for treatment of acute gout, as they block prostaglandin synthesis at COX"
"Glucocorticoids (e.g. prednisone) are third-line agents for the treatment of acute gout, as they inhibit the immune response to MSU deposition in the joint"

"Clostridium perfringens can result in a crepitus and crackling upon palpation of the infected area of skin"
"Which bacteria produces an alpha toxin that functions as a phospholipase (lecithinase)? Clostridium perfringens"
"Clostridium perfringens produces a(n) alpha toxin that functions as a(n) phospholipase (lecithinase)"
"The alpha toxin of Clostridium perfringens breaks down phospholipids, resulting in myonecrosis (\gas gangrene\\")\""
"Clostridium perfringens breaks down phospholipids, resulting in a(n) double zone of hemolysis on blood agar"
"What food source is associated with Clostridium perfringens food poisoning? Reheated meat dishes"
"Clostridium perfringens is a anaerobic spore former that can produce a double zone of hemolysis"
"What type of diarrhea is caused by Clostridium perfringens? Watery"

"Clostridium perfringens' spores produce heat-labile enterotoxin"

"Which toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae inhibits protein synthesis? Diphtheria toxin"

"Which gram positive rods are catalase positive? Listeria monocytogenes, Nocardia, C. diptheria"
"Which gram positive rod grows well at refrigeration temperatures (4°–10°C; “cold enrichment”)? Listeria monocytogenes"
"Listeria monocytogenes commonly contaminates unpasteurized dairy products (e.g. milk, cheese) and cold deli meats"
"Which gram positive rod commonly contaminates unpasteurized dairy products and cold deli meats? Listeria monocytogenes"

"How does Listeriosis (Listeria monocytogenes) commonly present in healthy individuals? Mild gastroenteritis"

"Nocardia is a gram positive branching filamentous rod"
"What is the oxygen dependency of Nocardia spp.? Obligate aerobe"
"Nocardia spp. is a gram-positive, filamentous bacteria that is normally found in soil"
