"What is the oxygen dependency of Bordetella pertussis? Aerobic"
"Bordetella pertussis is a gram negative coccobacillus"
"What pilus proteins allow Bordetella pertussis to attach to the respiratory epithelium? Filamentous hemagglutinin"
"Which bacteria produces a toxin that ADP-ribosylates and disables Gi receptors? Bordetella pertussis (Pertussis toxin)"
"Pertussis toxin ribosylates Gi, inhibiting::activating or inhibiting the G-protein receptor"
"Inhibition of Gi via the pertussis toxin results in increased levels of cAMP"
"Inhibition of Gi via the pertussis toxin inhibits chemokine receptors on lymphocytes"
"Which bacteria releases a toxin which inhibits chemokine receptors on lymphocytes, ultimately resulting in lymphocytosis? Bordetella pertussis"
"Which toxin of Bordetella pertussis is an ADP-ribosylating toxin? Pertussis toxin"
"Which toxin of Bordetella pertussis mimics the activity of adenylate cyclase? Adenylate cyclase toxin"
"Which toxin of Bordetella pertussis inhibits DNA synthesis in ciliated epithelial cells? Tracheal toxin"
"Tracheal toxin is produced by Bordetella pertussis and functions to damage ciliated epithelial tissue"
"What are the three stages of Bordetella pertussis infection? Catarrhal::1-2wks Paroxysmal::2wks - 2ms Convalescent::3ms"
"Which stage of Bordetella pertussis infection is characterized by non-specific fever and conjunctival injection? Catarrhal"
"Which stage of Bordetella pertussis infection is characterized by whooping cough and post-tussive vomiting? Paroxysmal"
"Which stage of Bordetella pertussis infection is characterized by gradual recovery? Convalescent"
"Whooping cough caused by Bordetella pertussis involves a cough on expiration and a \whoop\\" on inspiration\""
"Bordetella pertussis should be treated early with macrolides (erythromycin)"
"What is the route of transmission of Bordetella pertussis? Respiratory droplets"
"What type of vaccine is used for Bordetella pertussis in infants and children? Acellular (DTaP)"
"Bordetella pertussis can be cultured on Regan-Lowe or Bordet-Gengou (potato) agar"

"Hepatitis B is from the hepadnaviridae family"
"What type of virus is Hepatitis B? DNA::DNA, RNA (sense), etc."
"Does hepatitis B have an envelope? Yes"
"Where does hepatitis B virus replicate? (cytoplasm, nucleus, etc.) Both Nucleus and Cytoplasm :)"
"Hepatitis B virus is partially double-stranded"
"Upon entry into the cell nucleus, HBV DNA-polymerase completes the partially dsDNA"
"Once the dsDNA of HBV is complete, host::host or viral RNA polymerase transcribes mRNA from the dsDNA"
"After mRNA is produced, HBV reverse transcriptase produces progeny dsDNA from mRNA"
"Hepatitis B can be transmitted from mother to baby during delivery"
"When compared to HCV, HBV is less likely to become a chronic infection"
"Newborns infected with HBV have a(n) 90% chance of developing chronic infection"
"Hepatitis B can present like serum sickness: fever, arthralgias, and rash"
"HBV-associated Polyarteritis nodosa affects the vessels of the kidney, resulting in hypertension (HTN) and decreased GFR"
"Hepatitis B virus results in membranous glomerulonephropathy transitioning to membranoproliferative glomerulonephropathy"
"Which demographic will show normal ALT levels in viral hepatitis? Neonates (neonatal hepatitis)"
"What is the first marker that appears in HBV infection? HBsAg"
"What is the second marker that appears in HBV infection? HBeAg"
"What markers are in the blood during early symptomatic HBV infection? HBsAg; HBeAg"
"What is the first detectable antibody in HBV infection? Anti-HBc IgM"
"Which serologic marker is detectable during the window period of HBV infection? Anti-HBc IgM"
"Which serologic markers are detectable during the recovery period of HBV infection? Anti-HBs IgG; Anti-HBc IgG"
"Which serologic marker is detectable due to immunization to HBV? Anti-HBs IgG"
"Chronic::chronic or acute HBV infection can result in cirrhosis"
"HBV is associated with hepatocellular carcinoma"
"Does HBV increase the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma? Yes"
"Hepatitis D virus cannot cause disease without hepatitis B HBsAg"
"What type of virus is Hepatitis D? Negative sense RNA::DNA, RNA (sense), etc."
"Hepatitis D is from the deltaviridae family"
"Does hepatitis D have an envelope? Yes"
"What is the shape of the HBV genome? Circular"
"What is the shape of the HDV genome? Circular"
"What serologic marker must be present for HDV infection? HBsAg"
"Which HDV infection has a worse outcome, co-infection with HBV or superinfection with HBV? Superinfection with HBV"
"What is the treatment for acute cases of HBV? Supportive"

"Does hepatitis C have an envelope? Yes"

"What type of virus is Hepatitis A? Positive sense RNA::DNA, RNA (sense), etc."
"What type of viruses are picornaviruses? Positive sense RNA::DNA, RNA (sense), etc"
"Do picornaviruses have an envelope? No (naked)"
"What is the route of transmission of most picornaviruses? Fecal-oral"
"Positive sense RNA viruses are translated to proteins directly by host cell ribosomes"
"Picornaviruses produce a large polyprotein product (inactive) that is cleaved into smaller subunits (active)"
"Where do Positive sense RNA viruses usually replicate? Cytoplasm"
"What family of viruses do Enteroviruses belong to? Picornaviridae"
"What family of viruses do Rhinoviruses belong to? Picornaviridae"
"Which picornavirus can cause hepatosplenomegaly? HAV"

"Which type of meningitis is caused by a non-bacterial organism? Aseptic meningitis"
"What group of viruses are the most common cause of aseptic meningitis? Enteroviruses (picornaviridae family)"
"CSF glucose in viral meningitis is normal"
"CSF protein in viral meningitis is increased::normal, inc, dec."
"What demographic is most susceptible to viral (aseptic) meningitis caused by enteroviruses? Children"
"What virus is the most common cause of the common cold? Rhinovirus"
"Hepatitis A virus is acid-stable"
"Hepatitis E virus is acid-stable"
"Developed countries purify their water supply, eliminating HAV infection risk (fecal-oral transmission)"
"What is a source of hepatitis A virus in developing countries? Contaminated water"
"What is a source of hepatitis A virus in developed countries? Contaminated shellfish"
"HAV infection is commonly seen in travelers to endemic areas"
"What cutaneous complication arises with HAV infection? Jaundice"
"Which demographic can commonly display anicteric hepatitis A infection? Young children and infants"
"Smokers with hepatitis A virus will develop an aversion to tobacco products"
"Hepatitis A infection symptoms typically last 1 month"
"Which hepatitis virus infection is often self-limiting? HAV"
"Does hepatitis A virus induce a carrier state in infected individuals? No"
"Does Hepatitis A have a vaccine? Yes!"
"What type of vaccine is the HAV vaccine? Inactivated/killed"
"Picornavirus have viral proteases which cleave the large translated polypeptide into functional viral proteins"
"What type of viruses are Flaviviruses? Positive sense RNA::DNA, RNA (sense), etc."
"Do Flaviviruses have an envelope? Yes"
"What family of viruses does HCV belong to? Flaviviridae"
"Are flaviviruses segmented or non-segmented? Non-segmented"
"What family of viruses does Dengue fever belong to? Flaviviridae"
"Which vector transmits Dengue? Mosquito, specifically the Aedes"
"Dengue fever infects the bone marrow"
"What is the most common type of Dengue fever? Type 2"
"How does Dengue fever affect bleeding time? Increased"
"Dengue fever is a type of hemorrhagic fever due to it causing thrombocytopenia"
"Dengue fever can result in renal failure"
"What is the treatment of Dengue fever? Supportive (no treatment at this time)*"
"What family of viruses does Yellow fever belong to? Flaviviridae"
"Which zone of the liver is affected by Yellow Fever? Zone II (intermediate zone)"
"Which vector transmits Yellow Fever? Mosquito, specifically the Aedes"
"What is a cutaneous complication of Yellow Fever? Jaundice"
"Yellow fever classically causes an aching back"
"What changes in stool are seen with Yellow fever? Bloody diarrhea"
"What type of vomiting is seen with Yellow fever? Black (bloody) vomiting"
"What type of vaccine is available for Yellow fever? Live, attenuated"
"What is seen on liver biopsy in Yellow fever? Councilman bodies"
"Which two viruses can present with councilman bodies on liver biopsy? HAV; Yellow Fever"
"What family of viruses does West nile virus belong to? Flaviviridae"
"What is the reservoir of West nile virus? Birds"
"What is the vector of West nile virus? Mosquitos"
"West nile virus can result in meningoencephalitis"
"The meningitis caused by West nile virus can result in a(n) flaccid::spastic or flaccid paralysis"
"The meningoencephalitis caused by West nile virus can result in seizures and coma"
"What is the treatment of West nile virus? Supportive"
"What type of virus is HCV? Positive sense RNA::DNA, RNA (sense), etc."
"Hepatitis C virus is most commonly transmitted through blood"
"Hepatitis C virus can be transmitted through needle sticking or sharing"
"Which hepatitis virus shows antigenic variability of envelope proteins? HCV"
"Hepatitis C virus displays antigenic variability of its envelope proteins"
"What is the mechanism for antigenic variation of envelope proteins in HCV? Lack of 3'-5' exonuclease -> lack of proofreading -> antigenic variation"
"Which hepatitis virus lacks 3'-5' exonuclease activity? HCV"
"Why does HCV have a lack of proofreading ability and thus displays antigenic variation? lack of 3'-5' exonuclease"
"Hepatitis C infections become chronic in 60-80% of cases"
"Hepatitis C virus can result in hepatocellular carcinoma"
"Does HCV increase the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma? Yes"
"Hepatitis C RNA is found in the serum for < 6 months in the acute stage"
"The acute phase of HCV infection is marked by a rise and fall of ALT::liver enzyme in 6 months"
"Hepatitis C RNA is found in the serum for > 6 months in the chronic stage"
"Which hepatitis virus is associated with cryoglobulins? HCV"
"HCV is associated with cryoglobulins, which are IgM immunoglobulins that precipitate out of the blood at cool temperatures"
"Older treatments that can be used for Hep C Virus include IFN-alpha and Ribavirin"
"HCV can be treated with protease::enzyme and polymerase::enzyme inhibitors"
"Acyclovir, famciclovir and valacyclovir are all guanosine analogs"
"Acyclovir, famciclovir, and valacyclovir are used to treat active::active or latent VZV and HSV infections"
"Acyclovir is converted to acyclovir monophosphate by thymidine kinase in virus-infected cells"
"Acyclovir must be phosphorylated three times::specific by intracellular enzymes to reach its activated nucleotide form"
"Acyclovir monophosphate is eventually converted to acyclovir triphosphate by cellular kinases"
"Acyclovir triphosphate incorporates into replicating viral DNA, inhibiting DNA-dependent DNA polymerase"
"What is the rate-limiting step of Acyclovir activation? Thymidine kinase phosphorylation to acyclovir monophosphate"
"Virus-encoded thymidine-kinase phosphorylation is the rate determining activation step of Acyclovir"
"Lack of thymidine kinase to phosphorylate acyclovir explains why the drug is not effective in CMV and EBV"
"Absence of thymidine kinase confers resistance to acyclovir in HSV"
"Which viral DNA-polymerase inhibitors do not require thymidine kinase to become active? Cidofovir, Foscarnet"
"What is the treatment of choice for multiple yearly episodes of HSV recurrence? Once daily oral valacyclovir"
"Which acyclovir prodrug has improved oral bioavailability? Valacyclovir"
"What is the treatment of serious HSV and VZV infections? IV acyclovir"
"What is the treatment of neonatal HSV infection? IV acyclovir"
"What is the treatment of HSV encephalitis? IV acyclovir"
"What two drugs are the preferred treatment of VZV? Famciclovir; Valacyclovir"
"During active Shingles infection (herpes zoster), valacyclovir and famciclovir are most effective if given within 3 days of symptom onset"
"Prophylaxis of HSV with acyclovir is important in immunocompromised patients"
"Pregnant patients with recurrent genital herpes should receive prophylactic acyclovir"
"Acyclovir can cause interstitial nephritis and crystalline nephropathy (renal side effects)"
"Renal complications of acyclovir can be avoided with adequate hydration"
"Uncommon side-effects of acyclovir include delirium, confusion, vertigo, and hallucinations"
"Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir are guanosine analogs"
"Ganciclovir must be phosphorylated three times::specific by intracellular enzymes to reach its activated nucleotide form"
"Ganciclovir is converted to ganciclovir monophosphate by virus-encoded kinases via the UL-97 gene"
"Ganciclovir monophosphate is eventually converted to ganciclovir triphosphate by cellular kinases"
"Valganciclovir is the prodrug form of Ganciclovir that has better oral bioavailability"
"Ganciclovir triphosphate then incorporates into viral DNA, inhibiting viral DNA-dependent DNA polymerase"
"Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir are commonly used to treat CMV"
"Which antiviral is used during solid-organ and bone marrow transplant? Ganciclovir or Valganciclovir"
"Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir are used as prophylaxis of CMV retinitis in immunocompromised patients"
"Leukopenia (neutropenia), anemia and thrombocytopenia are hematological complications of Ganciclovir"
"Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir are associated with bone marrow suppression"
"The myelosuppression of Ganciclovir may be additive in patients receiving Zidovudine::NRTI therapy"
"CMV can gain resistance to ganciclovir via mutations in the UL-97 gene or its DNA polymerase"
"What drugs do not require phosphorylation via CMV viral kinase? Foscarnet; Cidofovir"
"What drug is a pyrophosphate analog that directly inhibits viral DNA polymerase? Foscarnet"
"Foscarnet may induce renal::organ insufficiency"
"Which ion imbalances are associated with Foscarnet administration? Hypo-magnesemia, -kalemia, -calcemia"
"Which antiviral can cause renal insufficiency and decreased serum Ca2+, Mg2+ and K+? Foscarnet"
"Which antiviral can cause seizures due to electrolyte disturbances? Foscarnet"
"Foscarnet can cause seizures due to electrolyte disturbances"
"Which two antiviral drugs directly inhibit DNA polymerase? Foscarnet and Cidofovir"
"Resistance to Cidofovir and Foscarnet occurs with mutations to viral DNA polymerase"
"Cidofovir is an antiviral drug that is nephro-toxic"
"What is administered with Cidofovir to reduce its nephrotoxicity? IV saline; Probenecid::2"
"What drug blocks tubular secretion of Cidofovir? Probenecid"
"Probenecid increases the plasma concentration of drugs (penicillin, methotrexate, NSAIDs, etc.)"
"Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) consists of a minimum of 3 drugs to prevent resistance"
"HAART therapy consists of 2 NRTIs plus 1 of either a(n) NNRTI, protease inhibitor, or integrase inhibitor"
"Which type of HAART drug is abacavir (ABC)? NRTI"
"Which type of HAART drug is didanosine (ddl)? NRTI"
"Which type of HAART drug is emtricitabine (FTC)? NRTI"
"Which type of HAART drug is lamivudine (3TC)? NRTI"
"Which type of HAART drug is stavudine (d4T)? NRTI"
"Which type of HAART drug is tenofovir (TDF)? NRTI"
"Which type of HAART drug is zidovudine (ZDV, formerly AZT)? NRTI"
"Which type of HAART drug is Maraviroc? Fusion inhibitor (inhibitor at attachment)::class (subclass)"
"Which type of HAART drug is Enfuvirtide? Fusion inhibitor (inhibitor at penetration)::class (subclass)"
"Which type of HAART drug is Dolutegravir? Integrase inhibitor"
"Which type of HAART drug is Elvitegravir? Integrase inhibitor"
"Which type of HAART drug is Raltegravir? Integrase inhibitor"
"Which type of HAART drug is Atazanavir? Protease inhibitor"
"Which type of HAART drug is Darunavir? Protease inhibitor"
"Which type of HAART drug is Fosamprenavir? Protease inhibitor"
"Which type of HAART drug is Indinavir? Protease inhibitor"
"Which type of HAART drug is Lopinavir? Protease inhibitor"
"Which type of HAART drug is Ritonavir? Protease inhibitor"
"Which type of HAART drug is Saquinavir? Protease inhibitor"
"Which type of HAART drug is Delavirdine? NNRTI"
"Which type of HAART drug is Efavirenz? NNRTI"
"Which type of HAART drug is Nevirapine? NNRTI"
"What classes of HAART drugs directly inhibit HIV reverse transcriptase? NRTIs; NNRTIs"
"NRTIs are nucleosides or nucleotides that have an absent 3' hydroxyl group"
"NRTIs are incorporated into viral DNA, causing premature chain termination"
"NRTIs inhibit phosphodiester bond formation in a(n) 3' to 5' direction"
"Most NRTIs are nucleosides that must undergo phosphorylation in order to be active"
"NRTI’s lack a 3’ hydroxyl group, causing strand termination when binding to HIV reverse transcriptase"
"Reverse transcriptase inhibitors prevent transcription of ssRNA into dsDNA thereby inhibiting viral replication"
"NRTIs are associated with mitochondrial toxicity and lactic acidosis"
"Which HAART drugs are associated with peripheral neuropathy? NRTIs; specifically lamivudine, stavudine, and didanosine::1 class + 3 examples"
"Which NRTI is a nucleotide and not a nucleoside? Tenofovir"
"Which NRTI does not require phosphorylation to become active? Tenofovir"
"Lamivudine and tenofovir are NRTIs with activity against hepatitis B::liver pathology"
"Which NRTI is used to reduce vertical transmission of HIV? Zidovudine"
"Which NRTI is used during pregnancy and breastfeeding? Zidovudine"
"Which NRTI is associated with myelosuppression? Zidovudine"
"Zidovudine is associated with myelosuppression, which can result in anemia and granulocytopenia"
"Which NRTI is associated with anemia and granulocytopenia? Zidovudine"
"Zidovudine and Stavudine are associated with lipodystrophy::tissue pathology"
"Bone marrow suppression caused by Zidovudine can be reversed with G-CSF and erythropoietin"
"Zidovudine is used to decrease the vertical transmission of HIV"
"Which NRTI is associated with dose-dependent pancreatitis? Didanosine"
"Which allele is Abacavir hypersensitivity associated with? HLA-B 57:01"
"Abacavir and the HLA-B 57:01 allele are associated with a(n) type IV HSR (delayed-type)"
"Which NRTI is associated with a hypersensitivity reaction in patients with the HLA-B 57:01 allele? Abacavir"
"Which NRTI may cause hyperpigmentation of palms and soles? Emtricitabine"
"Do NNRTIs require phosphorylation to be activated? No"
"Which NRTI is associated with Fanconi syndrome? Tenofovir"
"Non-nucleoside RTIs (NNRTIs) directly inhibit HIV reverse transcriptase by binding to a different site from NRTIs"
"What class of HAART drugs compete with nucleotides for binding to HIV reverse transcriptase? NRTIs"
"Do NNRTIs compete with nucleotides for binding to reverse transcriptase? No"
"NNRTIs can cause liver failure, with resulting jaundice cutaneously"
"Which HAART drugs are hepatotoxic? NNRTIs; Maraviroc::2"
"Which NNRTI is associated with vivid dreams and CNS symptoms (psychosis, drowsiness, headache)? Efavirenz"
"Which NNRTIs are teratogenic? Delavirdine; Efavirenz::2"
"NNRTIs have varying effects on CYP450 and thus may have many drug interactions"
"NNRTIs are associated with Stevens-Johnson syndrome, a severe cutaneous pathology associated with the sloughing of skin"
"NNRTIs are associated with rash, that can manifest as a more severe pathology such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome"
"Do protease inhibitors require phosphorylation to be activated? No"
"Do NRTIs require phosphorylation to be activated? Yes"
"Which HAART drugs prevent mature virion formation from large polypeptides? Protease inhibitors"
"Which gene is mutated in HIV protease inhibitor resistance? pol gene"
"Which viral gene in HIV codes for its Aspartate Protease? pol"
"Which viral gene in HIV codes for the surface glycoproteins gp120 and gp41? env"
"Which viral gene in HIV codes for its Integrase? pol"
"Which viral gene in HIV codes for the p24 capsid protein? gag"
"Which viral gene in HIV codes for the p17 matrix protein? gag"
"Which viral gene in HIV codes for its Reverse Transcriptase? pol"
"HIV reverse transcriptase is a(n) RNA-dependent DNA polymerase that synthesizes dsDNA from ssRNA"
"Which HAART drugs can result in hyperglycemia due to insulin resistance? Protease inhibitors"
"Protease inhibitors can result in hyperglycemia due to insulin resistance"
"Which HAART drugs can result in hyperlipidemia? Protease inhibitors"
"What side effect presents with increased central adiposity with skinny legs? Lipodystrophy"
"Which HAART drug class commonly causes lipodystrophy? Protease inhibitors"
"Protease inhibitors can cause hyperlipidemia with lipodystrophy (increased central adiposity)"
"Which HIV protease inhibitor can result in nephrolithiasis? Indinavir"
"Adequate hydration helps prevent nephrolithiasis with Indinavir use (protease inhibitor)"
"HIV protease inhibitors inhibit cytochrome P-450"
"Which HIV protease inhibitor displays the most potent inhibition of CYP450? Ritonavir"
"Rifampin is a CYP450 activator and thus is contraindicated in HIV due to it decreasing HIV protease inhibitor serum concentrations"
"What drug is used instead of Rifampin in patients on HIV protease inhibitors? Rifabutin"
"HIV infects CD4+ helper T-cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells"
"Which envelope protein on HIV functions to allow attachment to host CD4+ T cells? gp120; the docking glycoprotein"
"Which envelope protein on HIV binds the CD4 molecule and a chemokine receptor (CXCR4 or CCR5)? gp120"
"Which HAART drug binds to CCR5? Maraviroc"
"Maraviroc inhibits gp120 of HIV binding to the chemokine receptor CCR5 (macrophages)"
"Which envelope protein on HIV functions to allow HIV fusion and entry into host cells? gp41"
"Which HAART drug binds to gp41? Enfuvirtide"
"Enfuvirtide binds gp41 of HIV inhibiting viral cell fusion with host cells"
"HIV env encoded gp120 and gp41 are first sent to the endoplasmic reticulum of the cell for processing"
"HIV RNA is transcribed to dsDNA by HIV reverse transcriptase"
"What classes of drugs inhibit HIV RNA to dsDNA formation? NRTIs and NNRTIs"
"Which enzyme allows for HIV dsDNA to integrate with host cell DNA? Integrase"
"What class of drugs inhibits HIV DNA integration into host cell genomes? Integrase inhibitors"
"Which enzyme is responsible for mature HIV virion formation from a large polypeptide? Aspartate protease"
"What class of HAART drugs inhibit HIV mRNA formation? Integrase inhibitors"
"Integrase inhibitors will inhibit HIV dsDNA integration into the host cell genome, preventing mRNA production"
"Which HAART drugs can result in rhabdomyolysis? Integrase inhibitors"
"Integrase inhibitors can result in rhabdomyolysis, which will appear with elevated creatine kinase levels"
"Persistent Truncus Arteriosus is due to failure of neural crest cells to drive formation of the aorticopulmonary septum"
"Which congenital cardiovascular defects are associated with 22q11 syndrome? Truncus arteriosus & Tetralogy of Fallot::2"
"What is the preferred initial management for symptomatic patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy? β-blockers (first-line) Non-dihydropyridine Ca+2 channel blockers (second-line)"
"What are the two starting substrates of folate synthesis (prokaryotes)? PABA and pteridine"
"PABA and Pteridine are combined by dihydropteroate synthase to form dihydropteroic acid (prokaryotic folate synthesis)"
"Dihydropteroic acid is converted to dihydrofolic acid (prokaryotic folate synthesis)"
"Dihydrofolate is converted to tetrahydrofolate via dihydrofolate reductase"
"What is the brand-name for TMP-SMX (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole)? Bactrim"
"Sulfamethoxazole (SMX) is a(n) PABA analog, thus inhibiting the enzyme dihydropteroate synthase"
"Which enzyme is inhibited by trimethoprim (TMP)? Dihydrofolate reductase (prokaryotic)"
"Which enzyme is inhibited by sulfamethoxazole (SMX)? Dihydropteroate synthase (prokaryotic)"
"What is the first-line treatment of uncomplicated UTIs? TMP-SMX"
"TMP-SMX can be used to treat acute prostatitis in men"
"TMP-SMX have activity against gram negative GI and urinary tract bacteria"
"Sulfamethoxazole has activity against gram positives, even the highly resistant MRSA"
"Sulfonamides (e.g. sulfamethoxazole) have activity against the gram positive branching, filamentous rod Nocardia"
"Which antibiotics are used for prophylaxis and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia? Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)"
"Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) are used for prophylaxis and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia"
"Pneumocystitis jirovecii prophylaxis in HIV patients should be started at CD4 counts < 200 with TMP-SMX"
"Toxoplasmosis prophylaxis in HIV patients should be started at CD4 counts < 100 with TMP-SMX"
"Toxoplasmosis and Pneumocystitis jirovecii are treated prophylactically in HIV patients with Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)"
"What drugs should be used to treat Toxoplasmosis? Pyrimethamine/sulfadiazine"
"Hematological complications of Trimethoprim (TMP) use include pancytopenia (granulocytopenia, leukopenia) and megaloblastic anemia"
"TMP-SMX are teratogenic and should be avoided due to inhibition of folate metabolism"
"TMP-SMX are contraindicated in the 1st trimester (pregnancy), due to their effects on folate metabolism"
"Hypersensitivity reactions are common with Sulfa drug use; result in fever, hypotension, urticaria and rash"
"Sulfa drugs are contraindicated in G6PD deficiency, as they can can cause hemolytic anemia"
"Sulfa drugs are associated with the rare cutaneous skin complication Stevens-Johnson syndrome"
"What renal acid-base disturbance can be caused by TMP-SMX? Type IV RTA (hyperkalemic)"
"What nephrotoxicity is caused by Sulfonamides? Acute interstitial nephritis"
"TMP-SMX (sulfonamides) can result in photosensitivity, a common cutaneous skin complication"
"How is Warfarin transported in the blood? Bound to albumin"
"What class of antimicrobials displace unconjugated bilirubin from serum albumin in the blood? Sulfonamides"
"Sulfonamides displace unconjugated bilirubin from albumin; can precipitate kernicterus in neonates"
"What class of drugs can displace warfarin (and other drugs) from serum albumin? Sulfonamides"
"Sulfonamides increase the risk of bleeding when taken along with Warfarin"
"Sulfonamides inhibit cytochrome P450"
"What antimicrobial is similar to sulfonamides, inhibiting dihydropteroate synthase? Dapsone"
"What drugs have the suffix -oxacin? Fluoroquinolones"
"Fluoroquinolones are indicated mostly for gram negative infections"
"Which two enzymes are inhibited by fluoroquinolones? DNA topoisomerase II (Prokaryotic DNA gyrase); DNA topoisomerase IV"
"What is the first-line treatment of complicated UTIs? Fluoroquinolones"
"What drugs are used in the empiric treatment of pyelonephritis? Fluoroquinolones"
"Fluoroquinolones can be used to treat acute prostatitis in men"
"Which two drugs are used in the treatment of acute prostatitis in males? TMP-SMX; Fluoroquinolones"
"Fluoroquinolones can be used to treat gram negative gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections"
"What drugs are used to treat Salmonella gastroenteritis? Fluoroquinolones"
"What drugs are used to treat Salmonella osteomyelitis? Fluoroquinolones"
"Sickle cell anemia patients are at an increased risk of Salmonella typhi osteomyelitis"
"What is the first-line treatment of gram-positive Bacillus anthracis? Fluoroquinolones"
"The fluoroquinolones levofloxacin and moxifloxacin can be used to treat Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus spp. (community-acquired pneumonia)"
"The fluoroquinolones levofloxacin and moxifloxacin can be used to treat Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Legionella pneumophila (atypical pneumonia)"
"Fluoroquinolones can prolong the QT interval, predisposing to Torsades de pointes"
"What are the most common adverse effects of Fluoroquinolones? GI upset (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea)"
"Which antibiotics can result in tendonitis, tendon rupture, and cartilage damage? Fluoroquinolones"
"Fluoroquinolone risk of tendon and cartilage damage is increased with concurrent corticosteroid (e.g. prednisone) use"
"Fluoroquinolones are teratogenic due to them causing cartilage damage to the fetus"
"Fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in children < 18* years old due to damage to growing cartilage"
"Fluoroquinolones are nucleic acid synthesis inhibitors"
"Clonality can be determined via G6PD isoforms in females"
"The G6PD isoform genes are located on the X-chromosome"
"X chromosome inactivation (lyonization) can result in differential expression of G6PD isoforms"
"The ratio of G6PD isoforms in hyperplasia is still 1:1"
"The ratio of G6PD isoforms in neoplasia is elevated"
"Is neoplasia reversible? No (irreversible)"
"Each B-cell expresses a light chain that is either a(n) kappa or lambda isoform"
"The typical ratio of kappa to lambda immunoglobulin light chain phenotypes is 3:1"
"An infection with a proliferation of B-cell kappa and lambda light chain phenotypes would cause the 3:1 ratio to stay the same::change or stay the same"
"A lymphoma with a proliferation of B-cell kappa and lambda light chain phenotypes would cause the 3:1 ratio to change::change or stay the same"
"An increase in lymph node size due to infection is known as reactive hyperplasia"
"Neoplasia can either be benign or malignant (malignancy)"
"Benign::Benign or Malignant neoplastic tumors remain localized and do not metastasize"
"Malignant::Benign or Malignant neoplastic tumors invade locally and have potential to metastasize"
"Can you have a benign proliferation of lymphocytes? No (always malignant)"
"Cancer is the 2nd leading cause of death in both adults and children"
"Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the 1st leading cause of death in adults"
"Cerebrovascular disease is the 3rd leading cause of death in adults"
"Accidents are the 1st leading cause of death in children"
"Congenital defects are the 3rd leading cause of death in children"
"Breast/prostate cancer is the 1st most common cancer by incidence"
"Lung cancer is the 2nd most common cancer by incidence"
"Colorectal cancer is the 3rd most common cancer by incidence and mortality"
"Lung cancer is the 1st most common cancer by mortality"
"Breast/prostate cancer is the 2nd most common cancer by mortality"
"What is the best treatment of cancer? Early detection"
"How many cellular divisions occur before the earliest clinical symptoms of cancer arise? About 30"
"Agents that damage DNA are known as carcinogens"
"Alcohol is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx and upper esophagus"
"Arsenic is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the skin"
"Arsenic is associated with angiosarcoma::cancer of the liver"
"Arsenic is commonly found in cigarette smoke, hence its association with lung cancer"
"Cigarette smoke contains the carcinogens arsenic, naphthylamine and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons"
"What is the key risk factor for carcinoma of urothelium (epithelium of bladder, kidney)? Cigarette smoke"
"Which type of stomach carcinoma are nitrosamines related to? Intestinal type of Stomach Carcinoma"
"Transitional cell (urothelial) carcinoma of the bladder can arise from naphthylamine, a derivative of cigarette smoke"
"Chromium exposure is associated with lung carcinoma"
"Beryllium exposure is associated with lung carcinoma"
"Silica exposure is associated with lung carcinoma"
"EBV can result in nasopharyngeal carcinoma, especially in Asian and African males"
"EBV is associated with CNS lymphoma, especially in AIDS patients"
"EBV is associated with Burkitt lymphoma, the endemic/african form"
"Viruses such as EBV, HHV-8, HBV/HCV, etc are said to be oncogenic viruses due to them causing cancer"
"Ionizing radiation is associated with acute myelocytic leukemia"
"Ionizing radiation is associated with chronic myelocytic leukemia"
"Ionizing radiation is associated with papillary carcinoma of the thyroid"
"Ionizing radiation results in the formation of double-stranded breaks in DNA and hydroxyl free radicals which damage DNA"
"Xeroderma pigmentosum results from lack of excision endonuclease activity to remove pyrimidine dimers"
"Carcinoma implies the cancer is of epithelial origin"
"Sarcoma implies the cancer is of mesenchymal origin"
"Upregulation of telomerase prevents chromosomal shortening and cell death in tumors"
"Tumor grading defines the degree of cellular differentiation and mitotic activity"
"Tumor staging defines the degree of localization/spread"
"Low grade tumors are well differentiated"
"High grade tumors are poorly differentiated"
"A(n) hamartoma is an overgrowth of tissues in their native location"
"A(n) choristoma is the presence of normal tissue in a foreign location"
"Blood vessels can give rise to a(n) hemangioma (benign) and angiosarcoma (malignant)"
"Smooth muscle can give rise to a(n) leiomyoma (benign) and leiomyosarcoma (malignant)"
"Striated muscle can give rise to a(n) rhabdomyoma (benign) and rhabdomyosarcoma (malignant)"
"Connective tissue can give rise to a(n) fibroma (benign) and fibrosarcoma (malignant)"
"Bone can give rise to a(n) osteoma (benign) and osteosarcoma (malignant)"
"What is the most common cancer? Skin cancer"
"What is the most common skin cancer? Basal cell carcinoma"
"What is the most common cancer in children? Leukemia"
"What microbe can increase the risk of penile/anal carcinoma? High risk HPV"
"What microbe can increase the risk of gastric adenocarcinoma? H pylori"
"What microbe can increase the risk of gastric MALT lymphoma? H pylori"
"What microbe can increase the risk of cholangiocarcinoma? Liver fluke (Clonorchis sinensis)"
"What microbe can increase the risk of squamous cell bladder cancer? Schistosoma haematobium"
"Growth factor receptors are receptor tyrosine kinases::receptor class"
"What type of oncogene is PDGFB? Platelet derived growth factor"
"What is the mechanism that results in malignancy from the PDGFB oncogene? Overexpression"
"What is the associated tumor that results from overexpression of the PDGFB oncogene? Astrocytoma"
"What type of oncogene is HER2/neu (c-erbB2)? Epidermal growth factor receptor"
"What is the mechanism that results in malignancy from the HER2/neu (c-erbB2) oncogene? Amplification"
"What is the associated tumor that results from amplification of the HER2/neu (c-erbB2) oncogene? Breast carcinoma"
"What type of oncogene is RET? Neural growth factor receptor"
"What is the mechanism that results in malignancy from the RET oncogene? point mutation"
"What are the associated tumors (3) that result from point mutation of the RET oncogene? MEN2A; MEN2B; medullary thyroid carcinoma"
"What type of oncogene is KIT? Stem cell growth factor receptor"
"What is the mechanism that results in malignancy from the KIT oncogene? point mutation"
"What is the associated tumor that results from point mutation of the KIT oncogene? Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)"
"What type of oncogene is RAS? GTP-binding protein (signal transducer)"
"What is the mechanism that results in malignancy from the RAS oncogene? point mutation"
"What type of oncogene is ABL? Tyrosine kinase (signal transducer)"
"What is the mechanism that results in malignancy from the ABL oncogene? t(9;22) with BCR"
"What is the associated tumor that results from 9;22 translocation of the ABL oncogene? CML; some forms of ALL"
"Ras is associated with growth factor receptors in an inactive GDP-bound state"
"Growth factor binding to receptor results in Ras replacing GDP with GTP"
"Activated Ras (Ras-GTP complex) sends signals to the nucleus"
"Ras shuts off its nuclear signalling via GAP cleavage of GTP to GDP"
"A common Ras pathway mutation results in mutations of GAP, resulting in a lack of GTP to GDP inactivation"
"What type of oncogene is c-MYC, N-MYC, L-MYC? Transcription factor (nuclear regulator)"
"What is the mechanism that results in malignancy from the c-MYC oncogene? t(8;14) involving IgH"
"What is the associated tumor that results from translocation 8;14 of the c-MYC oncogene? Burkitt lymphoma"
"The immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) sits on chromosome 14"
"A translocation of c-MYC from chromosome 8 to 14 results in overexpression and ultimately Burkitt lymphoma"
"c-MYC is a transcription factor that sits on chromosome 8"
"What is the mechanism that results in malignancy from the N-MYC oncogene? amplification"
"What is the associated tumor that results from amplification of the N-MYC oncogene? Neuroblastoma"
"What is the mechanism that results in malignancy from the L-MYC oncogene? amplification"
"What is the associated tumor that results from amplification of the L-MYC oncogene? Small cell lung carcinoma"
"What type of oncogene is cyclin D1? Cyclin (cell cycle regulator)"
"What is the mechanism that results in malignancy from the cyclin D1 oncogene? t(11;14) involving IgH"
"What is the associated tumor that results from translocation 11;14 of the cyclin D1 oncogene? mantle cell lymphoma"
"A mantle cell lymphoma is a lymphoma of B-cells"
"Where do mantle cell lymphomas occur? Mantle zone of the lymph node"
"Cyclin D1 sits on chromosome 11"
"A translocation of cyclin D1 from chromosome 11 to 14 results in overexpression and ultimately Mantle cell lymphoma"
"What is the region next to the follicle of the lymph node? Mantle"
"What type of oncogene is CDK4? Cyclin dependent kinase (cell cycle regulator)"
"What is the mechanism that results in malignancy from the CDK4 oncogene? amplification"
"What is the associated tumor that results from amplification of the CDK4 oncogene? melanoma"
"What type of oncogene is ALK? Receptor tyrosine kinase"
"What is the associated tumor that results from gain of function of the ALK oncogene? lung adenocarcinoma"
"What type of oncogene is Bcl-2? Anti-apoptotic molecule"
"What are the associated tumors (2) that result from gain of function of the Bcl-2 oncogene? follicular and diffuse large B-cell lymphomas"
"What type of oncogene is BRAF? Serine/threonine kinase"
"Gain of functions in the BRAF oncogene result in melanoma, non-Hodgkins lymphoma, papillary thyroid carcinoma and hairy cell leukemia"
"What type of oncogene is JAK2? Tyrosine kinase"
"Gain of functions in the JAK2 oncogene result in chronic myeloproliferative disorders"
"A translocation of BCR-ABL from chromosome 9 to 22 results in overexpression and ultimately CML, some forms of ALL"
"Topoisomerase I inhibitors (-otecans) act as antineoplastics by inhibiting DNA unwinding"
"Li-Fraumeni syndrome is characterized by multiple malignancies at a(n) early age"
"Loss of copies of a tumor suppressor gene (knudson two-hit hypothesis) arise from germline (inherited) or somatic (sporadic) mutations"
"A translocation of Bcl2 from chromosome 18 to 14 results in overexpression and ultimately follicular lymphoma"
"A follicular lymphoma due to Bcl-2 overexpression results from a(n) t(14;18) mutation"
"Bcl2 is an anti-apoptotic molecule that sits on chromosome 18"
"Overexpression of Bcl2 in the follicle of a lymph node results in a lack of apoptosis of B-cells during somatic hypermutation"
"Telomerase activity is upregulated in cancer"
"Abnormal proteins produced endogenously by cells are typically expressed on MHC I"
"Tumor cells evade CD8+ T-cell immune surveillance by down-regulating MHC I expression"

"Which tumor suppressor gene is associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and colorectal cancer? APC"

"MEN1 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes Menin, a tumor suppressor protein"
"NF1 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for the protein neurofibromin"
"Neurofibromin (from NF1) is a Ras GTPase activating protein (GAP)"
"NF2 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for the protein merlin (schwannomin)"
"TSC1 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for the protein Hamartin"
"TSC2 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for the protein Tuberin"
"VHL is a tumor suppressor gene whose product inhibits hypoxia inducible factor 1-α (HIF-1α)"
"WT1 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes a transcription factor which regulates urogenital development"

"Downregulation of E-cadherin allows for dissociation and spread of tumor cells"

"Once tumor cells enter the extracellular matrix they will attach themselves to fibronectin"

"What enzyme and cofactor catalyze conversion of dUMP to dTMP? Thymidylate synthase (methylene-THF as cofactor)"
"Conversion of dUMP to dTMP via Thymidylate synthase converts the cofactor methylene THF to DHF"
"What enzyme converts DHF back to THF? Dihydrofolate reductase"

"Which strain(s) of Plasmodium follow a quartan fever cycle? Plasmodium malariae"
"Fever from Plasmodium malariae occurs every 72 hrs"
"Which strain(s) of Plasmodium produce dormant hypnozoites in the liver? Plasmodium vivax; Plasmodium ovale"
"Hypnozoites of Plasmodium vivax and ovale are found in hepatocytes"
"Which strain(s) of Plasmodium follow a tertian fever cycle? Plasmodium vivax and ovale"
"Fevers from Plasmodium vivax and ovale occur every 48 hrs"
"Which strain(s) of Plasmodium follow an irregular fever cycle? Plasmodium falciparum"
"Which strain(s) of Plasmodium forms sticky knobs on RBCs that occlude blood vessels? Plasmodium falciparum"
"The sticky RBCs of Plasmodium falciparum occlude vessels of the brain, lungs, and kidneys"
"The gametocytes of Plasmodium falciparum are banana-like::shape"
"The gametocytes of Plasmodium vivax/ovale are round::shape"
"The gametocytes of Plasmodium malariae are round::shape"
"The trophozoites of Plasmodium malariae are band or rectangular"
"The trophozoites of Plasmodium vivax/ovale are large, irregular rings"
"The trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum are small rings"
"Chloroquine is a drug that works by blocking Plasmodium heme polymerase::enzyme"

"Sickle cell disease protects against which strain(s) of Plasmodium? Plasmodium falciparum"
"Intravenous artesunate and/or quinidine is used for severe malaria infections"
"What drug used for malaria can cause cinchonism? Quinidine"
"Which antiarrhythmic can be used to treat Plasmodium falciparum malaria? Quinidine"
"The anopheles mosquitoes carry sporozoites of Plasmodium spp. in their saliva"
"Sporozoites of Plasmodium from mosquitoes travel to the human liver (hepatocytes), where they replicate and mature to trophozoites"
"Trophozoites of Plasmodium mature into schizonts, which rupture the hepatocytes and release merozoites"
"Merozoites of Plasmodium from the ruptured hepatocytes go on to infect red blood cells"
"Plasmodium merozoite infection of red blood cells can result in gametocyte::sexual form of parasite formation"
"Which strain(s) of Plasmodium is most severe? Plasmodium falciparum"
"Which strain(s) of Plasmodium infects all RBCs? Plasmodium falciparum"
"Which strain(s) of Plasmodium infects mature RBCs only? Plasmodium malariae"
"Which strain(s) of Plasmodium infects reticulocytes only? Plasmodium vivax/ovale"

"Plasmodium vivax/ovale present with multiple, brick-red dots in RBCs, known as Schüffner dots"

"Quinolines block the detoxification of heme into hemozoin by Plasmodium spp."
"Quinolines are drugs that cause a build-up of heme intracellularly, which is toxic to Plasmodium spp."
"Which strain(s) of Plasmodium is primaquine used to treat? Plasmodium vivax/ovale"
"Which antimalarial has activity against Plasmodium hypnozoites? Primaquine"

"Flukes are officially known as trematodes"

"Taenia saginata is a cattle (beef) tapeworm"

"Taenia saginata has no circle of hooklets on its scolex (head)"

"Ingestion of Taenia solium eggs in contaminated water/food can result in neurocysticercosis"
"Neurocysticercosis due to Taenia solium eggs can present with seizures and hydrocephalus"
"Neurocysticercosis due to the helminth Taenia solium has a 'swiss cheese' appearance to the brain on CT/MRI"
"Ingestion of Taenia cysts::cyst/trophozoite in contaminated water/food can result in Taeniasis (intestinal infection)"
"What is the treatment for intestinal Taenia solium infection? Praziquantel"
"What is the treatment for neurocysticercosis Taenia solium infection? Albendazole + corticosteroids"
"What is the presentation of intestinal Taenia solium and saginata infection? Generally asymptomatic"
"What is the treatment for Taenia saginata infection? Praziquantel"
"Diphyllobothrium latum is a fish tapeworm"

"Diphyllobothrium latum is a helminth that can result in megaloblastic anemia due to B12 (cobalamin) deficiency"
"Diphyllobothrium latum infection occurs with consumption of larvae in undercooked freshwater fish::specific"

"Diagnosis of tapeworms occurs with identification of proglottids and eggs in stool"
"Diphyllobothrium latum is treated with praziquantel or niclosamide"
"Echinococcus granulosus is a dog (and sheep) tapeworm"
"Echinococcus granulosus is transmitted via dog feces"
"Echinococcus granulosus is a helminth that can form 'hydatid cysts' in the liver, lungs or brain"
"Imaging of the helminth Echinococcus granulosus reveals hydatid cysts with 'eggshell' calcifications, most commonly in the liver"
"Rupture of Echinococcus granulosus cysts results in anaphylaxis and spread of infection"
"Which hematologic complication arises from Echinococcus granulosus infection? Eosinophilia"
"Entamoeba histolytica::Entamoeba histolytica or Echinococcus presents as a mass in the liver that is treated pharmacologically"
"Echinococcus::Entamoeba histolytica or Echinococcus presents as a mass in the liver that is treated surgically"
"Echinococcus granulosus can be treated with albendazole, but the more common method is surgery"
"Echinococcus granulosus cysts are injected with ethanol during surgery to kill larvae and prevent spread/anaphylaxis"

"Does Enterobacter have a capsule? No"

"Humans are the only reservoir for Salmonella typhi"
"Salmonella paratyphi causes paratyphoid fever"

"Shigella forms green colonies on Hektoen agar"

"Is Shigella motile? No"
"Shigella is acid-stable::stable or labile"
"The required infective dose of Shigella is small::large or small"
"Shigella spp. uses host cell actin filaments to spread from cell to cell"

"Shigella causes bloody::watery or bloody diarrhea"

"Shigella dysenteriae can produce a shiga toxin that leads to hemolytic-uremic syndrome"
"Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) from Shigella dysenteriae results when shiga toxin damages the glomerulus, activating platelets"
"Damage to the glomerulus in Shigella-induced HUS results in platelet aggregation, decreasing the platelet count when microthombi form"
"The microthrombi of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) cause red blood cell lysis"
"What demographic is hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) most common in? Children < 10 y.o.::age"
"Shigella dysenteriae produces Shiga toxin"
"Shiga toxin binds to the 60s subunit of ribosomes, inhibiting protein synthesis"
"Does Shigella produce H2S? No"
"Does Salmonella produce H2S? Yes"
"Shigella secretes effector proteins via a(n) type III secretion system"
"Does E. coli ferment lactose? Yes"
"Does Shigella ferment lactose? No"
"Does Salmonella ferment lactose? No"
"E. coli will stain pink on MacConkey agar"
"Does Shigella have a capsule? no"
"Does E. coli have a capsule? Yes"
"The E. coli K antigen is present on its capsule"
"The E. coli H antigen is present on its flagella"
"The E. coli O antigen is present on its lipopolysaccharide (LPS)"

"What is the 2nd most common cause of neonatal meningitis? E. coli"
"E. coli causes neonatal meningitis only if it is positive for K (capsular) antigen"
"Enteropathogenic E. coli produces no toxin and adheres to intestinal epithelium"
"Enteropathogenic E. coli destroys intestinal microvilli resulting in malabsorption"
"Enteropathogenic E. coli usually presents as diarrhea in children"
"Enterohemorrhagic E. coli is transmitted by eating undercooked beef"
"Which form of E. coli presents with dysentery (bloody, mucousy diarrhea)? Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC)"
"Which form of E. coli does not ferment sorbitol? Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC)"
"Which bacteria produces Shiga-like toxin (verotoxin)? Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC)"
"The shiga-like toxin (SLT) of Enterohemorrhagic E. coli kills enterocytes::cell type"
"Enterohemorrhagic E. coli can result in glomerular damage and thus hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)"
"Enterohemorrhagic E. coli is associated with the O157:H7 serotype"
"Which form of E. coli presents with a watery, 'traveler's diarrhea'? Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)"
"Enterotoxigenic E. coli is transmitted by water sources"
"Enterotoxigenic E. coli is associated with the toxins heat labile toxin (LT) and heat stable toxin (ST)"
"Labile toxin of enterotoxigenic E. coli increases cAMP"
"Stable toxin of enterotoxigenic E. coli increases cGMP"
"Which form of E. coli presents with watery diarrhea? Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)"
"Enteroaggregative E. coli uses aggregative adherence fimbriae (AAF)::specific kind of fimbriae to make a biofilm on the intestinal wall"
"Uropathogenic E. coli adheres via type I fimbriae and P pili and is a major cause of UTIs"
"What is the treatment for E. coli UTI? TMP-SMX"
"Campylobacter jejuni grows best at 42°C::temperature"
"Campylobacter jejuni is microaerophilic, meaning it grows best at lower O2 than atmosphere::aerotolerance"
"The reservoir of Campylobacter jejuni is poultry, cattle, and dogs"
"Campylobacter jejuni is a curved bacteria that presents with inflammatory diarrhea that is initially watery and ill-smelling, proceeding to bloody diarrhea"
"What is the shape and stain of Campylobacter jejuni? Gram negative curved rod"
"Campylobacter jejuni, Vibrio cholerae and Helicobacter pylori are all curved rods that are oxidase positive"
"Which curved gram negative rod is invasive and can thus cause bacteremia? Campylobacter jejuni"
"Campylobacteri jejuni is a curved bacteria that can cause reactive arthritis, a spondyloarthropathy"
"Campylobacter jejuni is a curved bacteria that can precede Guillain-Barré syndrome, characterized by a(n) ascending::ascending or descending paralysis"
"Treatment for Campylobacter jejuni infection includes erythromycin or ciprofloxacin"
"Which comma-shaped bacteria is endemic to developing countries? Vibrio spp."
"What is the stain and shape of Vibrio spp.? Gram negative comma (curved) rod"
"Which gram-negative enteric bacteria causes rice water stools? Vibrio cholerae"
"Vibrio cholerae causes profuse watery diarrhea with visible flakes of mucous and epithelial cells"
"What is the route of transmission of Vibrio cholerae? Fecal-oral"
"Campylobacter jejuni, Vibrio cholerae and Helicobacter pylori are all curved rods that are oxidase positive"
"Vibrio cholerae is a curved bacteria that uses fimbriae to attach to the intestinal mucosa"
"Does Vibrio cholerae invade the intestinal wall? No"
"Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin, which ADP-ribosylates::mechanism and activates Gs resulting in a(n) increase in cAMP in epithelial cells"
"An increase in cAMP from cholera toxin opens the CFTR channel, increasing Cl- ion secretion into the intestinal lumen"
"Increased Cl- secretion from CFTR due to cholera toxin results in decreased Na+ absorption, thus H2O diffuses into the intestinal lumen"
"What is the treatment of Vibrio cholerae? Oral rehydration therapy (with glucose and Na+)"
"Vibrio cholerae grows on alkaline media, as it prefers basic environments"
"Vibrio cholerae is acid-labile::stable or labile"
"Vibrio cholerae is a bacteria that grows flat, yellow colonies on TCBS agar"
"Vibrio cholerae also produces mucinase to digest the protective mucous coat around intestinal cells"
"Vibrio parahaemolyticus and Vibrio vulnificus are associated with consumption of contaminated seafood"
"Vibrio vulnificus is associated with wound infections that contact contaminated seafood or water"
"What is the stain and shape of Helicobacter pylori? Gram negative curved/spiral rod"
"Is Vibrio cholerae motile? Yes"
"Is Helicobacter pylori motile? Yes"
"Which of the curved, negative rods is urease positive? Helicobacter pylori"
"Helicobacter pylori is urease-positive, meaning it splits urea into NH3 and CO2, the basis of the urea breath test"
"Campylobacter jejuni, Vibrio cholerae and Helicobacter pylori are all curved rods that are oxidase positive"
"Helicobacter pylori is a bacteria associated with peptic ulcers of the duodenum and stomach"
"Helicobacter pylori increases the risk of developing gastric adenocarcinoma and MALT lymphoma (malignancies)"
"Helicobacter pylori most commonly colonizes the gastric antrum but does not invade"
"Helicobacter pylori is urease-positive, allowing production of ammonia which creates a(n) alkaline environment"
"Helicobacter pylori triple therapy includes a(n) PPI, amoxicillin/metronidazole, and clarithromycin"
"Helicobacter pylori triple therapy includes a PPI, amoxicillin/metronidazole, and clarithromycin"
"Helicobacter pylori triple therapy includes a PPI, amoxicillin/metronidazole, and clarithromycin"
"Helicobacter pylori quadruple therapy is used when the bacteria is resistant to clarithromycin"
"Helicobacter pylori quadruple therapy is a PPI, bismuth therapy, metronidazole and a(n) tetracycline"
"What can be used in H. pylori triple therapy for those with a penicillin allergy? Metronidazole"
"Individuals with H. pylori who are taking proton-pump inhibitors (PPI) may have a false-negative urease test"
"Serum IgG may be elevated in a Helicobacter pylori infection"
"Helicobacter pylori infection can result in a(n) iron deficiency anemia"
"Helicobacter pylori infection can result in a(n) B12 (cobalamin) deficiency (along with iron)"
"Which bacteria demonstrates 'swarming motility' when plated? Proteus"

"Is Proteus mirabilis urease-positive? Yes"

"Proteus mirabilis commonly causes urinary tract infections"

"Does Klebsiella ferment lactose? Yes"
"Does Enterobacter ferment lactose? Yes"
"Does Serratia ferment lactose? Yes"
"Daptomycin is an antibacterial that works by creating transmembrane channels"
"Daptomycin is a lipopeptide used to treat Multi Drug Resistant Gram-Positive Cocci::gram stain and shape infections"
"Can you use Daptomycin to treat lung infections? No"
"The most significant side effects of Daptomycin manifest due to damage to patients muscles"
"Bacitracin is used as a topical treatment for highly resistant Gram positive infections"
"Bacitracin works by inhibiting Bactoprenol, a peptidoglycan \building block\\" carrier molecule\""
"Polymixin B, Bacitracin, and Neomycin are used as a triple antibiotic combination used to treat superficial skin infections"
"Polymixin B and E (Colistin) are used as salvage therapy for Multi Drug Resistant Gram Negative infections"
"Polymixins work by binding to LPS on bacterial cell membranes"
"Polymixins are severely toxic against the CNS, kidneys, and the lungs"
"Resistance to Colistin (Polymixin E) is encoded via the Mcr-1 gene which alters the structure of Lipid A"
"The suffix -penem is associated with the Carbapenem class of antimicrobials"
"Carbapenems are broad::broad or narrow-spectrum last resort antibiotics useful for bacteria that are resistant against β-lactam drugs"
"To be active, Carbapenems typically need to be administered with an inhibitor of Dehydropeptidase I, an inactivating enzyme located in the Kidney"
"Which Carbapenem is resistant to Renal Dehydropeptidase I? Meropenem"
"Carbapenems are associated with significant side effects, including GI distress, skin rash, and seizures*"
"Most Carbapenems are very useful against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, except Ertapenem which has limited coverage"
"Aztreonam, a β-lactam based monobactam, prevents cross-linking by binding to Penicillin-binding protein 3"
"Does Aztreonam have any cross-allergenicity with penicillins? No"
"Which anti-microbial class is Aztreonam particularly synergistic with? Aminoglycosides"
"Aztreonam is especially useful for patients with renal-insufficiency (and therefore can't tolerate aminoglycosides)"
"Aztreonam is used only for Gram negative Rods::gram stain and shape"
"While Aztreonam is usually nontoxic, patients can experience the occasional GI upset"
"Carbapenems work by by binding bacterial transpeptidases, inhibiting cell wall synthesis"
"Vancomycin is antibacterial that is indicated for multi-drug resistant Gram-positive bugs only"
"Vancomycin inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding the D-ala-D-ala portion of cell wall precursors, thus preventing transpeptidation"
"Resistance to Vancomycin is encoded via modifying the bacteria's D-Ala-D-Ala subunit to D-ala-D-lac"
"Vancomycin Resistant Bacteria typically spread resistance to other bacterium via Transposition"
"Vancomycin is especially suitable for Clostridioides difficile infections when it is prescribed orally::IV or Orally?"
"Vancomycin is only indicated for serious infections caused by Staph Aureus or Staph Epidermidis when they are resistant to Penicillins"
"Vancomycin is given empirically for signs of meningitis in most age groups"
"In regards to side effects, Vancomycin is well tolerated in general but NOT trouble free: - Nephrotoxicity - Ototoxicity - Thrombophlebitis"
"Upon rapid infusion of Vancomycin, if a patient presents like the following image - what is side effect is occurring? Red Man Syndrome"
"Vancomycin causes Red Man Syndrome due to stimulating release of Histamine"
"The following drugs are what class of antimicrobial? β-Lactamase Inhibitors"
"Which group of modified Penicillins does NOT need to be prescribed with β-lactamase (penicillinase) inhibitors? Right::Left or Right?"
"Which group of modified penicillins is especially useful for Pseudomonas and Gram Negative Rods (ex. Bacteroides)? Piperacillin, Ticarcillin"
"Which group of modified penicillins is associated with Hypersensitivity reactions? All :)"
"Which group of modified penicillins is especially associated with Acute Interstitial Nephritis (AIN)? Dicloxacillin, Nafcillin, Oxacillin"
"Which group of modified penicillins is associated with the following rash? Amoxicillin, Ampicillin, Aminopenicillins"
"What infection when mistakenly treated with Amoxicillin / Ampicillin will very frequently manifest a maculopapular / morbilliform rash? Infectious Mononucleosis (EBV infection)"
"Which has greater oral bioavailability? Amoxicillin::Ampicillin OR Amoxicillin?"
"To remember the coverage of Amoxicillin, Ampicillin, and Aminopenicillins, use the mnemonic: Am-cillin HHELPSS kill enterococci Haemophilus influenzae Helicobacter pylori Escherchia coli Listeria monocytogenes Proteus mirabilis Salmonella spp. Shigella spp."
"Penicillin G is given IV and IM, whereas Penicillin V is given Orally"
"The benzathine forms of Pencillin V/G make them long-acting"
"Penicillins and their derivatives are D-ala-D-ala structural analogs which bind and inhibit transpeptidases"
"Does inhibition of transpeptidases directly kill bacteria? No"
"Which Penicillinase-resistant penicillin is commonly used to treat Staph Aureus? Nafcillin"
"Penicillin V/G are mostly used for Gram-Positive organisms"
"Besides Gram + organisms, Penicillin V/G are used to treat Neisseria meningitidis::Gram Negative organism and Treponema pallidum::Spirochete organism"
"Pregnant patients with a positive culture of what microbe receive intrapartum penicillin prophylaxis? Streptococcus agalactiae"
"Patients who have been exposed to what STD should be given prophylactic Benzathine Penicillin G Treponema pallidum"
"Children who have been previously been exposed to what bacterial complication and are now manifesting with oropharyngeal symptoms should be given prophylaxis with Penicillin G or V? Rheumatic Fever"
"If a patient taking penicillin manifests with nausea, hives, or wheezing, and the following rash, they are demonstrating what side effect? Type I Hypersensitivity"
"If a patient taking penicillin manifests with mild fever, myalgia or arthralagias, and the following rash, they are demonstrating what side effect? Hypersensitivity Vasculitis (Cutaneous Small Vessel Vasculitis)"
"Patients taking Penicillin G/V can develop a(n) hemolytic anemia"
"Is the hemolytic anemia caused by penicillin G/V coombs positive or negative? Coombs positive"
"Between patients taking Ampicillin and Amoxicillin, which group has a higher risk of developing a Pseudomembranous Colitis? Ampicillin"
"In patients receiving Triple Therapy for H Pylori that have an amoxicillin allergy, what drug should replace it? Metronidazole"
"In pregnant women and children who have been infected with Borrelia Burgdorferi, they should receive amoxicillin and cefuroxime"
"Penicillins are NOT::are or are not indicated with Mycoplasma pneumoniae"
"Are penicillins bactericidal or bacteriostatic? Bactericidal"
"In patients with streptococcal infections who are allergic to penicillin, they should be given what class of antibiotics instead? Macrolides"
"Patients who are high risk for endocarditis and are undergoing surgical or dental procedures should be given Amoxicillin prophylaxis"
"Can penicillins / derivatives cause sloughing of skin at the dermal-epidermal junction? Yes"
"What gout drug can precipitate the side effects of penicillins? Probenecid"
"What structural feature of Penicillins give them their activity? B-lactam ring"
"Cephalosporins are β-Lactam drugs that inhibit cell wall synthesis but are less susceptible to penicillinases"
"Are Listeria, MRSA, or Enterococcus covered by 1st–4th generation cephalosporins? NO"
"Which generation of Cephalosporins are Cefazolin and Cephalexin? 1st Generation"
"Non-gram + cocci coverage of 1st generation Cephalosporins can be remembered with the Mnemonic PEcK: - Proteus mirabilis - Escherchia coli - Klebsiella pneumoniae"
"To prevent post-surgical wound infections by Staph aureus, what Cephalosporin is indicated? Cefazolin"
"Which generation of Cephalosporins are Cefaclor, Cefoxetin, Cefuroxime? 2nd Generation"
"All generations of Cephalosporins can be used for Gram-positive cocci::stain and shape"
"Non-gram + cocci coverage of 2nd generation Cephalosporins includes 1st generation (PEcK) as well as HENS - Haemophilus influenzae - Enterobacter aerogenes - Neisseria spp. - Serratia marscescens"
"Which generation of Cephalosporins are Ceftriaxone, Cefotaxime, Cefpodoxime, Ceftazidime? 3rd Generation"
"3rd generation Cephalosporins are used for serious Gram-negative infections resistant to other β-lactams"
"3rd generation cephalosporins are used for meningitis vs other generations of cephalosporins due to their ability to cross the Blood Brain Barrier"
"A 3rd generation cephalosporin (Ceftriaxone) indicated for patients who have Lyme disease that is disseminated"
"Which generation of Cephalosporins is Cefepime? 4th Generation"
"Cefepime is primarily used to treat multiple drug resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa"
"Cefepime is indicated as empiric therapy in febrile neutropenia::quite specific"
"Which generation of Cephalosporins is Ceftaroline? 5th Generation"
"Are Listeria, MRSA, or Enterococcus covered by 5th generation cephalosporins (Ceftaroline)? YES"
"Can Cephalosporins cause the same hypersensitivity reactions as Penicillin V/G? Yes"
"Cephalosporins rarely can cause anemia by inducing anti-RBC autoantibodies"
"Cephalosporins are associated with a(n) Disulfiram like reaction"
"Cephalosporins can cause a Vitamin K deficiency"
"Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis does Chloramphenicol inhibit? [C]"
"Which step ([A] - [F]) of Bacterial Genetics does Nitrofurantoin impact? [C]"
"Nitrofurantoin is used to treat patients who have UTIs and are currently pregnant"
"Nitrofurantoin is contraindicated in patients with a deficiency of the enzyme Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase"
"Patients who take Nitrofurantoin are at risk for fibrosis of the lungs"
"Which step ([A] - [F]) of Bacterial Genetics does Metronidazole impact? [C]"
"Metronidazole is used to treat anaerobic infections below the diaphragm"
"The important coverage of Metronidazole can be remembered with the mnemonic: \GET GAP on the Metro with metronidazole\\" - Giardia lamblia - Entamoeba histolytica - Trichomonas vaginalis - Gardnerella vaginalis - Anaerobes - Helicobacter Pylori triple therapy replacement\""
"Patients should not consume alcohol while taking Metronidazole"
"Patients taking Metronidazole can report side effects of headache as well as a(n) metallic taste"

"Which step ([A] - [E]) of the HIV life cycle does Maraviroc target? [A]"
"Which step ([A] - [D]) of the viral life cycle does Oseltamivir and Zanamivir target? [D]"
"Oseltamivir and Zanamivir work by inhibiting Neuraminidase"
"Neuraminidase inhibitors are used to treat and prevent Influenza A and/or B and/or C? A & B"
"Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis do Aminoglycosides inhibit? [B]"
"What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs? Aminoglycosides"
"Are aminoglycosides bactericidal or bacteriostatic? Bactericidal"
"Can aminoglycosides be used for both aerobic and anaerobic infections? No"
"Besides inhibiting the formation of the initiation complex, Aminoglycosides can damage protein synthesis by causing misreading of mRNA"
"Aminoglycosides are primarily indicated for severe Gram-Negative Rod::Stain and Shape? infections"
"Paromomycin is used as a luminal agent against parasites of the GI tract"
"Aminoglycosides are synergistic with β-lactams and Vancomycin since they increase cell wall permeability"
"Are aminoglycosides absorbed effectively from the alimentary / GI tract? No"
"Resistance to Aminoglycosides is encoded by bacterial transferase enzymes"
"Aminoglycosides cause nephrotoxicity by damaging the proximal convoluted tubule"
"Aminoglycosides can impact the neuromuscular junction, blocking post::pre or post? synaptic  Nm receptors"
"Patients taking aminoglycosides can present with vertigo, ataxia, and nausea due to damage to the vestibulocochlear apparatus"
"Patients are at much greater risk of developing ototoxicity while taking Aminoglycosides if they are used with a(n) Loop Diuretic"
"Aminoglycosides act as a teratogen by causing congenital deafness"
"Do bacterial ribosomal inhibitors affect the human ribosome (80S)? No"
"Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis do Tetracyclines inhibit? [E]"
"Are Tetracyclines indicated for patients who are experiencing symptoms of Meningitis? No"
"Doxycycline is safe to use in patients with renal failure as it is fecally eliminated"
"Patients should not consume Milk, Antacids, or Iron-containing preparations with Tetracyclines as they prevent the drugs absorption"
"If a patient presents to you with Lyme disease, your first line drug is Doxycycline"
"Tetracyclines are used to treat what cause of atypical pneumonia? Mycoplasma pneumoniae"
"Doxycycline and Clindamycin can be used as a treatment for what infectious skin condition Acne vulgaris"
"Patients taking Tetracyclines can manifest symptoms of skin sensitivity to light and GI distress"
"Tetracyclines are contraindicated in pregnancy and in children due to their ability to: 1) discolor / deposit in teeth 2) inhibit bone growth"
"Resistance to Tetracyclines occurs in two primary ways 1) Decreasing uptake 2) Increasing efflux"
"Tigecycline is a(n) tetracycline derivative that is resistant to bacterial efflux pumps"
"Tigecycline is useful for infections that have deep tissue penetration"
"Tigecycline is primarily used for bacteria that are multiple-drug resistant"
"Chloramphenicol prevents peptidyl bond formation by inhibiting the enzyme peptidyltransferase"
"Chloramphenicol is hepatically metabolized by UDP-glucuronyltransferase"
"Chloramphenicol is primarily used to treat meningitis and rocky mountain spotted fever"
"Chloramphenicol causes a dose-dependent anemia and a dose-independent aplastic-anemia"
"Chloramphenicol is contraindicated in infants as they havent developed enough UDP-glucuronyltransferase"
"If Chloramphenicol levels build up in infants before liver enzymes have developed, this manifests with Gray-Baby Syndrome"
"Resistance to Chloramphenicol is encoded via a plasmid-encoded acetyltransferase enzyme"
"Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis does Clindamycin inhibit? [D]"
"Clindamycin prevents translocation by binding the 50S ribosome and sterically hindering peptidyl transfer"
"Clindamycin is used to treat anaerobic infections above the diaphragm"
"Clindamycin is effective against invasive Group A Strep and Staph Aureus infection as it is a potent suppressor of the synthesis of their toxins"
"Clindamycin can cause a mild self-limited diarrhea and fever"
"Clindamycin use can unintentionally cause an overgrowth of Clostridioides difficile"
"Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis does Linezolid inhibit? [A]"
"Is Linezolid bacteriostatic or bactericidal? Both :)"
"Linezolid is a drug of last resort used primarily for MRSA and VRE"
"Linezolid can suppress the bone marrow, often manifesting with thrombocytopenia"
"Linezolid can cause a(n) peripheral and optic neuropathy"
"Use of Linezolid is contraindicated in patients taking drugs that increase seroto-nergic transmission"
"Resistance to Linezolid is developed via a point mutation of ribosomal RNA"
"Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis do Macrolides inhibit? [D]"
"Macrolides prevents translocation by binding the 50S ribosome and sterically hindering peptidyl transfer"
"What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs? Macrolides"
"Tetracyclines are very effective against Rickettsia and Chlamydophila because these drugs accumulate intracellularly"
"What macrolide is used for Chlamydia (and thus for Chlamydia-Gonorrhea empirical therapy)? Azithromycin"
"When treating Chlamydia Trachomatis, when would you use Azithromycin over Doxycycline? - Patients who are pregnant - Chlamydia Trachomatis serotypes A-C (eye drop ointment), D-K (STI)"
"Prominent side effects of macrolides can be remembered with the mnemonic MACRO: - Motility issues of the GI tract - Arrhythmia due to prolonged QT - Cholestatic Hepatitis - Rash - eOsinophilia"
"Macrolides cause GI motility issues as they agonize the motilin receptor"
"Macrolides are often used for atypical-pneumonias"
"Macrolides can be used to treat Pertussis as long as it is still in the catarrhal phase"
"Azithromycin can be used as an antiprotozoal in the treatment of Babesiosis"
"Erythromycin eye ointment is indicated as prophylaxis for gonococcal conjunctivitis in the newborn"
"Which of the following macrolides inhibit cytochrome p450 enzymes? Clarithromycin, Erythromycin"
"Resistance to Penicillins and their derivatives occurs in two primary ways: 1) - mutations in Transpeptidases 2) - production of β-lactamases"
"Erythromycin is used off-label for the treatment of gastro-paresis"
"Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis does the Quinupristin-Dalfopristin (Streptogramins) combination inhibit? [C]"
"Quinupristin / Dalfopristin is used to treat vancomycin resistant::sensitive or resistant enterococci"
"Which step ([A] - [F]) of Bacterial Genetics do Fluoroquinolones impact? [E]"
"Which Topoisomerases do Fluoroquinolones inhibit? II and IV"
"Fluoroquinolones that are known as \Respiratory Fluoroquinolones\\" are known as such because they exhibit enhanced activity against Strep pneumoniae\""
"What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs? Fluoroquinolones"
"Fluoroquinolones cannot be taken with antacids as they inhibit the absorption of these drugs"
"Are Fluoroquinolones bactericidal or bacteriostatic? Bactericidal"
"Fluoroquinolones are often used to treat Gram Negative Rods infections of the GI and Urinary tract"
"Fluoroquinolones are indicated for treatment of Otitis Externa"
"Fluoroquinolones can be used for atypical-pneumonias"
"Does Ciprofloxacin alter the blood levels of drugs like Warfarin, Digoxin, Statins? Yes"
"Fluoroquinolone side effects (ex. GI upset) are most likely mediated by mitochondrial toxicity"
"Less commonly, Fluoroquinolones cause myopathy"
"Fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in the following groups due to damage to cartilage - pregnant women - nursing mothers - children < 18 years old"
"Fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in the following groups due to damage to tendons - people > 60 years old - patients taking prednisone"
"Some Fluoroquinolones can prolong the QT interval"
"Resistance to Fluoroquinolones is primarily encoded by chromosome-encoded mutations in DNA Gyrase"
"Which step ([A] - [F]) of Bacterial Genetics do Sulfonamides impact? [A]"
"Sulfonamides are competitive inhibitors of the enzyme Dihydropteroate Synthase"
"Sulfonamides are contraindicated in patients with a deficiency of the enzyme Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase"
"Sulfonamides damage the kidney by causing tubulointerstitial nephritis"
"Sulfonamides cause skin sensitivity to light"
"Infants who are taking sulfonamides are at risk for Kernicterus"
"Drugs that bind to Albumin are displaced by Sulfonamides"
"Resistance to Sulfonamides is primarily developed via a mutation of bacterial dihydropteroate synthase"
"Which step ([A] - [F]) of Bacterial Genetics does Trimethoprim impact? [B]"
"Trimethoprim inhibits the enzyme Dihydrofolate Reductase"
"Can Sulfonamides cause sloughing of skin at the dermal-epidermal junction? Yes"
"Sulfonamides can cause a Type IV Renal Tubular Acidosis"
"Trimethoprim is often combined with Sulfamethoxazole"
"TMP-SMX is the 1st line for UTIs"
"Is TMP-SMX the 1st line for acute prostatitis? No*"
"At less than CD4 count of 200 in AIDS patients, TMP-SMX is indicated for treatment of and prophylaxis for Pneumocystis Jirovecii"
"At less than CD4 count of 100 in AIDS patients, TMP-SMX prophylaxis is indicated to prevent Toxoplasmosis"
"Because Trimethoprim blocks the reduction of DHF Reductase, it is associated with a(n) Megaloblastic anemia and well as increased susceptibility to infections"
"The bone marrow toxicity effects of Trimethoprim treatment may be avoided with coadminstration of folinic acid"
"When taken during early pregnancy, Trimethoprim can cause the baby to develop neural tube defects"

"Rifampin is used for close-contact prophylaxis of the following non-mycobacterial species 1 - Neisseria Meningitidis 2 - Haemophilus Influenzae B"
"Use of Rifamycins can change the color of bodily fluids to Red / Orange"
"Rifamycins can cause minor hepatotoxicity"
"Resistance to Rifamycins is developed when mutations reduce binding to RNA polymerase"

"Chloroquine is associated with pruritis, especially in dark-skinned individuals"
"Long term use / high-doses of Chloroquine can cause an irreversible retinopathy"

"Malathion is an anti-scabies/louse therapy that works by causing flaccid::spastic or flaccid paralysis of scabies/lice"

"Enfuvirtide causes a skin reaction at injection sites"
"What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs? Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NRTI)"
"Which step ([A] - [E]) of the HIV life cycle do NRTI's target? [C]"
"NRTIs are competitive inhibitors of the HIV Reverse Transcriptase"
"NRTI's are mostly nucleoside analogs"
"Do most NRTI's need to be phosphorylated to be active? Yes"
"When incorporated into the nascent DNA chain, NRTI's cause chain termination as they lack a(n) 3' OH group"
"Tenofovir (TDF) and Emtricitabine (FTC) are given as a combination drug for pre-exposure prophylaxis of HIV"
"In treating HIV, Zidovudine (ZDV)::NRTI is used for general prophylaxis as well as decreasing risk of fetal transmission during pregnancy"
"Abacavir (ABC) is contraindicated for HIV treatment if patient has an HLA-B*5701 mutation"
"Patients taking NRTIs suffer from bone marrow suppression"
"Which NRTI's are particularly associated with peripheral neuropathy? Didanosine (ddl), Lamivudine (3TC), Stavudine (d4T)"
"Patients taking nucleoside NRTI's can develop a(n) lactic acidosis"
"Zidovudine (ZDV/AZT) can cause a(n) megaloblastic anemia and agranulocytosis"
"Didanosine (ddl) can cause pancreatitis"
"What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs? Non-Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NNRTI)"
"Which step ([A] - [E]) of the HIV life cycle does NNRTIs target? [C]"
"NNRTIs are non-competitive inhibitors of the HIV Reverse Transcriptase"
"Do NNRTI's need to be phosphorylated to be active? No"
"Rash and hepatotoxicity are common to which NNRTI's? All :)"
"Vivid dreams / Nightmares and CNS symptoms are side effects seen with which NNRTI? Efavirenz"
"Which NNRTI's are contraindicated in pregnancy? Delaviridine, Efavirenz"
"Nevirapine is associated with induction of cytochrome p450 enzymes"
"What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs? HIV Protease Inhibitors"
"Which step ([A] - [E]) of the HIV life cycle do drugs with the suffix -navir target? [E]"
"HIV Protease Inhibitors inhibit the maturation of new viruses"
"HIV Protease Inhibitor's are metabolized by Cytochrome P450"
"Ritonavir is a cytochrome p450 inhibitor"
"Which HIV Protease Inhibitor is especially associated with Nephropathy/Nephrolithiasis, Hematuria, and Thrombocytopenia Indinavir"
"Which HIV Protease Inhibitor is especially associated with GI intolerance (Nausea, Diarrhea) Saquinavir"
"All HIV Protease Inhibitors cause insulin resistance and dyslipidemia"
"Patients taking HIV Protease inhibitors for awhile can resemble patients on chronic Glucocorticoid therapy due to their ability to cause Lipodystrophy"
"Enfuvirtide and Maraviroc are used for treatment-resistant patients with HIV"
"Highly Active Anti-Retroviral Therapy (HAART) is often initiated at the time of HIV Diagnosis"
"A HAART regimen typically consists of 3 drugs to prevent resistance: 2 NRTIs and preferably a(n) Integrase Inhibitor"
"What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs? Integrase Inhibitors"
"Which step ([A] - [E]) of the HIV life cycle do drugs with the infix -tegra- target? [D]"
"Drugs like Dolutegravir, Elvitegravir, and Raltegravir reversibly inhibit HIV integrase"
"If a patient taking Integrase Inhibitors can develops elevated Creatine Kinase levels, what should you suspect is occurring? Rhabdomyolysis"
"Osteitis Fibrosa Cystica is the classic bone disease of primary and secondary hyperparathyroidism"
"Is therapy for Hepatitis Viruses indicated for acute or chronic infection? Chronic"
"All patients with chronic HCV except those with limited life expectancy should be considered for treatment"
"The goal of chronic HCV therapy is to established a sustained virologic response; that HCV RNA is not detected by PCR for 6 months"
"The direct acting antiretroviral HCV drugs work by targeting RNA synthesis"
"HCV therapeutics with the suffix -buvir work by inhibiting the NS5B RNA-dependent polymerase"
"Before beginning treatment for HCV - a clinical history, physical exam, and genotyping are undergone"
"HCV therapeutics with the suffix -asvir work by inhibiting the NS5A protein, which plays an integral role in viral replication"
"HCV therapeutics with the suffix -previr work by inhibiting the NS3/4A protease"
"Which HCV Therapies are generally well tolerated and occasionally present with fatigue, headache and nausea Ledipasvir, Sofosbuvir"
"Which HCV Therapies are generally well tolerated and occasionally present with photosensitivity reactions and rash Simeprevir"

"Patients taking Ribavirin can develop a(n) hemolytic anemia"
"Ribavirin is extremely contraindicated in what patient population? Pregnant patients"
"Ribavirin is used to treat RSV in adults"

"The traditional treatment for HCV was pegylated Interferon alpha / oral ribavirin"
