"In their second step of bioactivation, -cyclovirs are converted to the triphosphate form by specific cellular kinases"
"For Herpes Zoster, which of the following antivirals is indicated? Famciclovir"
"Do any of the following antivirals have activity against CMV? No"
"Acyclovir, Famciclovir, Valacyclovir have weak activity against EBV"
"Are Acyclovir, Famciclovir, Valacyclovir used to treat both HSV-induced mucocutaneous and genital lesions as well as for encephalitis? Yes"
"Do Acyclovir, Famciclovir, Valacyclovir have an effect on latent forms of HSV / VZV? No"
"Acyclovir, Famciclovir, Valacyclovir are used for HSV/VZV prophylaxis in immunocompromised patients"
"Valacyclovir, a prodrug of acyclovir, has better oral bioavailability"
"Patients taking acyclovir, famciclovir, valacyclovir are at risk of obstructive crystalline nephropathy and acute renal failure if not adequately hydrated"
"Resistance to -cyclovir's develops via a mutation of the viral kinase"
"Ganciclovir and Valganciclovir are used to treat CMV, especially in immunocompromised patients"
"Letermovir is an antiviral used for treatment and prophylaxis of CMV infections who have received allogenic hematopoietic stem cell transplants"
"Valganciclovir, a prodrug of ganciclovir, has better oral bioavailability"
"Ganciclovir causes toxicity at the bone marrow and the kidneys"

"Foscarnet and Cidofovir directly inhibit DNA polymerase"
"Foscarnet is a(n) Pyrophosphate analog"
"Foscarnet has been shown to inhibit HIV Reverse Transcriptase::enzyme"
"Do Foscarnet and Cidofovir require any kinase activation? No"
"Foscarnet and Cidofovir are indicated for acyclovir-resistant HSV infections"
"Foscarnet and Cidofovir can cause damage to the kidneys"
"Patients taking Foscarnet can experience various electrolyte abnormalities"
"Resistance to Foscarnet develops via a mutation of DNA Polymerase"
"Cidofovir preferentially inhibits viral DNA polymerase"
"To reduce Cidofovir nephrotoxicity, coadminister with probenecid and IV saline"

"When treating patients with M avium-intracellulare (MAC) infections, you can give Ethambutol + Macrolides*"
"Type III familial dyslipidemia is also known as Dysbetalipoproteinemia"
"Type III familial dyslipidemia is due to a defective Apo E allele"
"What is the mode of inheritance of type III familial dyslipidemia? Autosomal Recessive"
"Type III familial dyslipidemia presents with tuberoeruptive xanthomas and palmar xanthomas"
"Does type III familial dyslipidemia cause an increased risk for atherosclerosis? Yes"
"The serum lipoproteins elevated in type III familial dyslipidemia are Chylomicrons and VLDL"
"Type III familial dyslipidemia is confirmed by genetic analysis that shows absence of E3 and E4 Apo alleles"

"If initiated without NSAIDS / Colchicine, Allopurinol / Febuxostat may precipitate a(n) gout attack"

"Allopurinol can irritate the GI tract"

"Griseofulvin deposits in keratin-containing tissues"
"Griseofulvin is an oral treatment that is most often used to inhibit the growth of dermatophytes"
"Griseofulvin is contraindicated in patients who are pregnant"
"Patients taking Griseofulvin can develop neurotoxicity"
"Patients taking Griseofulvin should not consume alcohol as they can develop Flushing and GI Upset"
"Griseofulvin is a cytochrome p450 inducer"
"The fungal cell membrane is composed of Ergosterol as opposed to cholesterol"

"Antigenic variation of influenza viruses occurs with changes to viral hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA)"
"Influenza viruses are named based on HA and NA types (e.g. H1N1)"
"Antigenic variation can be due to antigenic drift or antigenic shift"
"Antigenic drift occurs when there are point mutations in HA or NA"
"Antigenic drift explains why we need a flu shot each year"
"Antigenic drift is associated with epi-demics"
"Antigenic shift occurs with HA/NA reassortment amongst different species"
"Antigenic drift is associated with epi-demics Antigenic shift is associated with pan-demics"

"Is Adenovirus enveloped? No (naked)"

"Transmission of Adenovirus includes respiratory droplets, fecal-oral route, or direct contact"

"Demographics affected by Adenovirus include children, military recruits, and swimmers in public pools"
"Adenovirus has a(n) linear::linear/circular DNA genome"
"What is a genitourinary complication of Adenovirus? Hemorrhagic cystitis"
"Which linear DNA virus causes hemorrhagic cystitis? Adenovirus"
"Which circular DNA virus causes hemorrhagic cystitis? BK virus"

"Adenovirus will enter and lyse mucosal cells"

"Homologous Recombination occurs after::before/after? S phase of the cell cycle, using a(n) sister chromatid as a template"
"In Homologous Recombination, dsDNA breaks are recognized by the ATM protein and the FA Core Complex, which activate BRCA1/2 to recruit enzymes to repair the break"
"Homologous Recombination is defective in breast/ovarian cancers with BRCA1/2 mutations"
"Is homologous recombination error prone? No"
"Nonhomologous End Joining (NHEJ) occurs before::before/after? S phase of the cell cycle"
"In Nonhomologous End Joining (NHEJ), dsDNA breaks are recognized by ATM, recruiting the MRN complex which then recruits the Artemis protein and various others to help repair the damage"
"Is Nonhomologous End Joining error prone? Yes"
"Nonhomologous End Joining is defective in SCID and Ataxia Telangiectasia"
"Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip can be treated with a Pavlik Harness, which keeps the hips flexed and abducted"
"Manifestations of scarlet fever include fever, sore throat, circumoral pallor, \sandpaper\\" rash"
"EBV is associated with Post-tranplant Lymphoproliferative Disease"
"Post-transplant Lymphoproliferative Disease (PTLD) is the most common malignancy complicating solid organ transplantation*"
"PTLD has a variety of symptoms; ranging from symptoms that resemble mononucleosis to malignancy induced dysfunction of the transplanted organ"
"PTLD most commonly occurs in what age group? Children"
"What movement disorder is associated with Iron Deficiency and Chronic Kidney Disease? Restless Leg Syndrome"
"Symptoms of Restless Legs Syndrome typically worsen or only occur during the night-time"
"Symptoms of Restless Legs Syndrome are partially or totally relieved by movement"
"Restless Leg Syndrome is characterized by unpleasant sensations in the legs, and an uncontrollable urge to move when at rest"
"A leukemoid reaction is a severe elevation in WBC, typically >50,000 cells/mm3"
"A GI infection causing bacteria that can cause a Leukemoid Reaction is Clostridioides difficile"
"The protein S-100 is found in cells of neural crest lineage (ex. schwann cells, melanocytes, langerhans cells)"
"The intermediate filament Cytokeratin is found in Epithelial cells"
"The intermediate filament Vimentin is found in mesenchymal tissue"
"The intermediate filament Desmin is found in muscle cells"
"The intermediate filament Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein (GFAP) is found in neuroglial cells (ex. astrocytes, Schwann cells, oligodendrocytes)"
"The intermediate filament Neurofilament is found in neurons"
"The Peroxisome is a cytosolic membrane involved in the β-oxidation of Very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA)"
"The Peroxisome is unique in that it performs α-oxidation to break down Phytanic Acid"
"Which cellular organelle is responsible for catabolism of branched-chain fatty acids, amino acids, and ethanol? Peroxisome"
"Which cellular organelle is responsible for the synthesis of cholesterol and bile acids? Peroxisome"
"What cellular organelle is responsible for synthesizing Plasmalogens? Peroxisome"
"Zellweger Syndrome is a(n) autosomal recessive::inheritance leukodystrophy caused by defective peroxisome biogenesis"
"Zellweger syndrome is a result of mutations in PEX genes that encode for peroxins, which are required for normal assembly of peroxisomes"
"Patients with Zellweger Syndrome present with a profound hypotonia, seizures, and hepatomegaly"
"Patients with Zellweger Syndrome often have craniofacial::structural abnormalities"
"Patients with Zellweger Syndrome often die at a(n) early age"
"Refsum disease is a(n) autosomal recessive::inheritance metabolic disorder caused by defective α-oxidation"
"Patients with Refsum disease have scaly skin and shortening of the 4th toe"
"Patients with Refsum Disease can have various ophthalmological problems; including cataracts and night blindness"
"Patients with Refsum disease can present with neurological symptoms; such as issues with balance (ataxia), additionally patients nearly universally report a profound loss of smell (anosmia)"
"Patients with Refsum Disease can have skeletal and craniofacial dysmorphism due to epiphyseal dysplasia"
"Patients with Refsum disease do not die early as they can be treated with a(n) phytanic acid restricted diet and plasmapheresis"
"Seborrheic dermatitis is a common, chronic inflammatory disease that presents with a flaky, scaling, rash involving the scalp and eyebrows"
"When Seborrheic Dermatitis is seen in infants, it is known as \Cradle Cap\\"\""
"When seborrheic dermatitis is seen in adults, this most commonly presents as dandruff"

"Are sebaceous glands inflamed in Seborrheic Dermatitis? No"
"Seborrheic Dermatitis is more severe in patients with neurological disease, most notably Parkinsons Disease"

"Leber Hereditary Optic Neuropathy is a mitochondrial disorder caused primarily by a degeneration of retinal ganglion cells of the optic nerve"
"Patients with Leber hereditary optic neuropathy develop a subacute bilateral and progressive loss of central vision"
"Leber Hereditary Optic Neuropathy most often presents when patients are teenagers"
"When performing Immunohistochemistry; TRAP can be used to identify Hairy Cell Leukemia"

"Death from hereditary angioedema is usually due to Airway Swelling"

"Carcinoma implies epithelial origin, whereas Sarcoma denotes mesenchymal origin"
"Is a Hamartoma neoplastic? No"
"A Hamartoma is a disorganized overgrowth of tissues in a(n) native location"
"Is a Choristoma neoplastic? No"
"A Choristoma is normal tissue in a(n) foreign location"

"One use of Mammography as a screening tool is to detect invasive carcinoma before it becomes clinically palpable"
"One use of the Hemoccult test and Colonoscopy as screening tools is to detect colonic carcinoma before it spreads"
"Cancers that are detected late by screening tend to have a(n) poor prognosis"

"Patients get exposed to Aflatoxins produced by Aspergillus by way of eating improperly stored grains and nuts"
"Chronic exposure to Aflatoxins may cause cancer by causing a(n) G:C --> T:A transversion in codon 249 of the TP53 gene"
"Chronic exposure to Arsenic may cause cancer by metabolites (ex. Dimethyl-Arsenic) inhibiting zinc finger motifs in Base-Excision Repair and Nucleotide-Excision Repair enzymes"
"Exposure to carcinogenic Asbestos is most commonly seen in: - construction workers - shipyard workers - plumbers"
"Asbestos acts as a carcinogen by physically destroying cellular chromosomes"

"Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAH) cause carcinogenesis through their metabolites forming DNA adducts"

"What country consumes a large amount of smoked meats in their diet, resulting high rates of intestinal gastric cancer? Japan"
"Patients get chronically exposed to Vinyl Chloride if they manufacture PVC"
"Benzidine is a carcinogenic aromatic amine found in textile dyes associated with Transitional Cell Carcinoma of the Bladder::type of cancer"
"Patients who get chronically exposed to Nickle, Chromium, Beryllium, or Silica are at risk for what cancer? Lung Cancer"
"Chronic exposure to Beryllium can occur with patients who work in the aerospace industry, in electronics manufacturing, or with nuclear reactors"
"Chronic exposure to Nickel can occur with patients who work with stainless-steel arc welding, or in the production of batteries or ceramics"
"Chronic exposure to Chromium can occur with patients who work with metallurgy, dye and pigment manufacturing, wood preservatives"
"Patients typically get exposed to Ionizing radiation via nuclear reactor accidents or radiotherapy"
"Patients typically get exposed to Non-Ionizing radiation via exposure to the sunlight"

"Mutations in which proto-oncogene can lead to Chronic Myeloproliferative Disorders? JAK2"
"A(n) gain of function mutation converts a proto-oncogene to an oncogene"
"A(n) loss of function mutation to a tumor suppressor gene increases the risk of cancer"
"Do both alleles of a protooncogene need to be mutated in order for expression of disease? No"
"Do both alleles of a tumor suppressor gene need to be mutated in order for expression of disease? Yes"
"Mutations in which tumor suppressor gene can lead to FAP associated Colorectal Cancer? APC"
"The APC tumor suppresor regulates the Wnt signalling pathway by destroying B-catenin in the absence of a Wnt receptor-ligand interaction"
"Mutations in which tumor suppressor genes can lead to Breast, Ovarian, and Pancreatic cancers? BRCA1/BRCA2"
"Mutations in which tumor suppressor gene can lead to Melanoma, Pancreatic Cancer, and Dysplastic Nevus Syndrome? CDKN2A::not p53"
"The tumor suppressors encoded by the CDKN2A gene enforce the G1-->S restriction point by: (1) - inhibiting CDK4/6 (2) - relieving inhibition of P53"
"The DCC gene is a(n) tumor suppresor that is frequently mutated in advanced colorectal cancer"
"The DCC tumor suppressor gene is involved in apoptotic regulation of the GI tract epithelium"
"Mutations in which tumor suppressor gene can lead to Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome, Colon Adenocarcinoma, and Pancreatic Cancer? SMAD4"
"Mutations in which tumor suppressor gene can lead to MEN I? MEN1 (Menin)"

"Mutations in which tumor suppressor gene/protein can lead to Neurofibromatosis II? gene-NFII protein-Merlin (Schwannomin)"
"Mutations in which tumor suppressor genes can lead to Tuberous Sclerosis? TSC1 & TSC2"
"BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppresors that are involved in mediating the Homologous Recombination pathway of DNA repair"
"Mutations in which tumor suppressor genes can lead to Wilms Tumors? WT1 and CDKN1C (WT2)"
"Mutations that cause overexpression of the HER2 receptor can precipitate development of certain Breast* and Gastric* Cancers by amplifying the signal transduction"
"Mutations in CCND1 can cause Mantle Cell Lymphoma via a t(11;14) translocation to the Ig Heavy Chain locus"
"Mutations in which tumor suppressor gene can lead to Breast, Prostate, Endometrial Cancer, and Cowden Syndrome? PTEN"
"Mutations in PTEN lead to overactivity of mTOR proto-oncogene"
"Dermatomyositis can present as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with adenocarcinomas"
"Acanthosis Nigricans can present as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with gastric cancer and other visceral malignancies"
"Does Acanthosis Nigricans typically present as a paraneoplastic syndrome? No"
"Which paraneoplastic syndrome presents with progressive proximal muscle weakness, papules on the knuckles, and a rash around the eyes? Dermatomyositis"
"Which paraneoplastic syndrome presents with hyperpigmented velvety plaques in the arm-pit and neck? Acanthosis Nigricans"
"The Sign of Leser-Trélat can present as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma and other visceral malignancies (ex. Lymphoid malignancies)"
"Which paraneoplastic syndrome presents with a sudden onset of multiple seborrheic keratoses? Sign of Leser-Trélat"
"Hypertrophic Osteoarthropathy can present as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Adenocarcinoma of the Lung"
"Hypertrophic Osteoarthropathy is caused by an abnormal proliferation of skin and bone at distal extremities"
"Which paraneoplastic syndrome presents with digital clubbing, arthralgias, joint effusions, and periostosis of tubular bones? Hypertrophic Osteoarthropathy"
"Which paraneoplastic syndrome is associated with Squamous Cell Carcinomas of Lung, Head, and Neck; along with Renal, Bladder, Breast, and Ovarian Carcinoma? Humoral Hypercalcemia of Malignancy"
"The hypercalcemia seen in patients with Humoral Hypercalcemia of Malignancy is mediated by PTHrP"
"The hypercalcemia seen in patients with Lymphoma is mediated by Calcitriol"
"Tumors that cause a(n) paraneoplastic polycythemia can be remembered with the mnemonic: Paraneoplastic rise to high hematocrit levels Pheochromocytoma Renal cell carcinoma Hepatocellular Carcinoma Hemangioblastoma Leiomyoma"
"Cushing Syndrome and SIADH can present as paraneoplastic syndromes associated with Small Cell Lung Cancer"
"Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) and Good syndrome can present as paraneoplastic syndromes associated with Thymoma"
"Good Syndrome refers to the presence of hypogammaglobulinemia that appears near simultaneously as a thymoma"
"Patients with Good Syndrome have deficient levels of what types of lymphocytes? B & T lymphocytes"
"Marantic Endocarditis and Trousseau Syndrome can present as paraneoplastic syndromes associated with visceral Adenocarcinomas"
"Trousseau Syndrome is a(n) migratory superficial thrombophlebitis"
"Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis can present as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Ovarian Teratoma"
"Which paraneoplastic syndrome presents with psychiatric disturbances, memory deficits, seizures, dyskinesias, autonomic instability, and language dysfunction? Anti-NMDA Receptor Encephalitis"
"Paraneoplastic Cerebellar Degeneration is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with antibodies against antigens in purkinje cells"
"Small Cell Lung Cancer can produce anti-Hu antibodies which can cause both Paraneoplastic Cerebellar Degeneration and Paraneoplastic Encephalomyelitis"
"Gynecological and Breast cancers can produce anti-Yo antibodies which can cause Paraneoplastic Cerebellar Degeneration"
"Hodgkin Lymphoma can produce anti-Tr antibodies which can cause Paraneoplastic Cerebellar Degeneration"
"Paraneoplastic Encephalomyelitis is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with antibodies against antigens in Neurons"
"Opsoclonus-Myoclonus Ataxia Syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Small Cell Lung Cancer in adults"
"Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Small Cell Lung Cancer"
"Myasthenia Gravis is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Thymoma"
"Tumor cells that downregulate MHC class I can be detected and destroyed by Natural Killer cells"
"In order to determine a confidence interval of a(n) sample mean at a given alpha value, the standard deviation, and sample size are also necessary"
"Tumors that present with PSaMMoma bodies are: Papillary carcinoma of thyroid Somatostatinoma Meningioma Malignant Mesothelioma Ovarian serous papillary cystadenocarcinoma Milk (prolactinoma)"

"Sacubitril is a(n) neprilysin inhibitor"
"ANP and BNP are endogenously metabolized by the enzyme neprilysin"

"Legal exceptions for parental consent include: (1) - emergency treatment (2) - if the minor is legally emancipated"
"One hallmark of cancer is the ability to be insensitive to anti-growth signals, such as TGF-β"
"Is this histology of this Cervical Epithelium normal, mildly dysplastic, moderately dysplastic, or severe dysplasia / carcinoma in situ? Normal"
"One hallmark of cancer is the Warburg effect, in which cancer cells shift glucose metabolism from mitochondria toward glycolysis"
"In regards to cervical epithelium, if the tissue sample on the left is normal, is the tissue sample on the right: mildly dysplastic, moderately dysplastic, or severely dysplastic / carcinoma in situ? Mildly Dysplastic::Think about nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio, tissue orientation, and pleomorphy VS"
"In regards to cervical epithelium, if the tissue sample on the left is normal, is the tissue sample on the right: mildly dysplastic, moderately dysplastic, or severely dysplastic / carcinoma in situ? Moderately Dysplastic::Think about nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio, tissue orientation, and pleomorphy VS"
"A characteristic of the transformation from normal cells to dysplastic cells is that they become pleomorphic"
"A characteristic of the transformation from normal cells to dysplastic cells is that there is a loss of tissue orientation"
"A characteristic of the transformation from normal cells to dysplastic cells is that there is is an increased nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio"
"In regards to cervical epithelium, if the tissue sample on the left is normal, is the tissue sample on the right: mildly dysplastic, moderately dysplastic, or severely dysplastic / carcinoma in situ? Severely Dysplastic / Carcinoma in Situ::Think about nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio, tissue orientation, and pleomorphy VS"
"How much of the epithelium do cells that are severely dysplastic or have become carcinoma in situ involve? Entire thickness*"
"Do severely dysplastic / carcinoma in situ cells penetrate the intact basement membrane? No"
"Is carcinoma in situ reversible? No"
"Invasive carcinoma invades through the basement membrane using matrix metalloproteinases to access the extracellular matrix"
"In invasive carcinoma, cell-cell contacts are lost by inactivation of E-cadherin"
"Invasive carcinoma cells first bind to basement membrane via laminin"
"Once past the basement membrane, Invasive carcinomas are able to spread locally via attachment to fibronectin"
"Invasive carcinomas become metastatic when they invade the lymphatics or blood"
"In the \seed and soil\\" theory of metastasis: the seed is the tumor embolus\""
"In the \seed and soil\\" theory of metastasis: the \\"soil\\" (target organ) is often the first encountered capillary bed\""
"To remember the most common neoplasias that spread hematogenously (Every Hematogenous Spreading Cancer Reigns Foolishly) Embryonal carcinoma Hepatocellular carcinoma Sarcomas Choriocarcinoma Renal cell carcinoma Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid"
"What percent of brain tumors are from metastases? 50%"
"The primary tumors for brain metastases can be ranked in the following order: Lung > Breast > Melanoma, Colon, Kidney::3 sites"
"After the regional lymph nodes, what are the two most common sites of metastasis? Liver and Lung"
"The primary tumors for liver metastases can be ranked in the following order (patients with liver mets Cant Get Pints): Colon >> Gastric > Pancreas"
"In terms of bone tumors, are bone metastases or 1* bone tumors more common? Metastases, significantly"
"Metastases to the bone have a predilection for the axial skeleton"
"The primary tumors for Bone metastases can be ranked and remembered by the following mnemonic: (Pb (lead) KeTlLe) Prostate > Breast > Kidney, Thyroid, Lung"
"The most common type of metastases to the bone from the breast are mixed::lesion type"
"The most common type of metastases to the bone from Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer are lytic::lesion type"
"The most common type of metastases to the bone from the thyroid are lytic::lesion type"
"The most common type of metastases to the bone from the kidney are lytic::lesion type"
"The most common type of metastases to the bone from the prostate are blastic"
"Lung metastases have a high predilection for the brain due to the proximity of the cerebral vasculature"
"Colon metastases have a high predilection for the liver due to its venous drainage into the portal vein"
"Prostate metastases have a high predilection for the spine due to the prostates venous plexus connection to Batson's venous plexus"
"Metastasis to bone may be bone forming (blastic), bone destructive (lytic), or mixed"
"Lytic bone metastases present with hypercalcemia"
"Blastic bone metastases present with high alkaline phosphatase levels"
"While carcinomas typically spread lymphatically, sarcomas spread hematogenously"
"The initial lymphatic spread of a carcinoma is to regional draining lymph nodes"
"Carcinomas can also directly seed peritoneal structures"
"The most common body cavity seeded by a tumor is the peritoneal cavity"
"In Central cyanosis, there is normal blood flow, and patients will have warm::temperature extremities"
"Central cyanosis typically manifests in the lips, nail beds, and conjunctiva, and other mucosal surfaces"
"In peripheral cyanosis, there is low blood flow, and patients will have cold::temperature extremities"
"Right-to-left shunts typically require urgent surgical treatment and/or maintenance of a(n) PDA"
"The 5 T's of Right-to-Left Shunts: 1. Truncus Arteriosus::1 vessel 2. Transposition::2 switched vessels 3. Tricuspid atresia::3 = Tri 4. Tetralogy of Fallot::4 = Tetra 5. TAPVR::5 letters in the name"
"Ebstein's Anomaly is associated with Wolff-Parkinson-White, which can lead to arrhythmias"
"Pulmonary Atresia is the failure of the pulmonic valve orifice to develop"
"Pulmonary atresia results in no flow from right ventricle to lungs"
"Pulmonary Atresia often co-exists with VSD for outflow of RV"
"Candidemia has an increased prevalence in patients with neutropenia::blood complication"
"Which of the following types of tumors tends to be slow growing, well circumscribed, distinct, and mobile? Benign"
"Which of the following types of tumors tends to be rapid growing, poorly circumscribed, infiltrative, and fixed to surrounding tissues and local structures? Malignant"
"Before a tumor can be classified as benign or malignant with certainty, biopsy or excision must be performed"
"Cachexia is a syndrome of weight loss, muscle atrophy, and fatigue that occurs in chronic diseases"
"Cachexia is mediated by what four cellular factors? TNF, IFN-γ, IL-1, IL-6"
"The P-glycoprotein is a(n) ATP-dependent efflux pump that tumors can produce to generate chemotherapeutic resistance"
"P-glycoprotein is normally found in the intestinal and renal tubular epithelial cells to eliminate foreign compounds from the body"
"P-glycoprotein is found in the capillary endothelium of the blood brain barrier"
"P-glycoprotein is encoded for by the MDR1 gene"
"P-glycoprotein is classically seen in adrenocortical carcinoma but is also expressed in various other cancers"
"Serum tumor markers should only be used for: - monitoring tumor recurrence - monitoring response to therapy"
"Most notably, the serum tumor marker Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP) is elevated in patients with metastases to bone or liver, Paget Disease of Bone, or Seminoma"
"If a patient has moderately elevated serum Alkaline phosphatase levels, you should determine if hepatobiliary or bony origin by checking GGT levels"
"The source of alkaline phosphatase can be determined by an ALP isozyme test, which works by gel electrophoresis"
"α-fetoprotein (AFP) is a serum tumor marker elevated in (mnemonic: HE-MAN is the alpha male) - Hepatocellular carcinoma - Endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumor - Mixed germ cell tumor - Ataxia-telangiectasia - Neural tube defects"
"α-fetoprotein (AFP) is a protein that is normally made by the fetus"
"Elevated α-fetoprotein (AFP) can be associated with abdominal wall defects (ex. Omphalocele)"
"α-fetoprotein (AFP) is transiently elevated in pregnancy"
"Normal levels of α-fetoprotein (AFP) are seen in Trisomy 13 (Patau)"
"Low levels of α-fetoprotein (AFP) are seen in Trisomy 21 (Down's) and decreased levels are seen in Turner Syndrome"
"Most notably, the serum tumor marker β-hCG is elevated in patients with Gestational Trophoblastic Disease (GTD), Testicular Cancer (non-seminomatous), and Mixed Germ Cell tumors"
"Elevated β-hCG is seen in pregnancy, especially when there are multiple gestations"
"Elevated hCG can be a paraneoplastic syndrome, such as in pinealomas::neuro or large cell carcinoma::respiratory"
"Most notably, the serum tumor marker CA 15-3 / CA 27-29 are seen elevated in Breast Cancer"
"Most notably, the serum tumor marker CA 19-9 is seen elevated in Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma"
"Most notably, the serum tumor marker Calcitonin is seen elevated in Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma::malignancy"
"The Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a serum tumor marker that has major associations with colorectal and pancreatic cancers"
"The Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a serum tumor marker that has minor associations with gastric, breast, and medullary thyroid carcinomas"
"How specific is the serum tumor marker CEA? Very nonspecific"
"Patients who are smokers have higher levels of what serum tumor marker? CEA"
"CEA is elevated in gastrointestinal diseases (ex. Crohns, Pancreatitis)"
"Most notably, the serum tumor marker Chromogranin is elevated in patients with neuroendocrine tumors"
"LDH can be used as an indicator of tumor burden"
"Most notably, the serum tumor marker PSA is elevated in Prostate Cancer"
"Because PSA can be also elevated in BPH and prostatitis besides Prostate Cancer, there is a questional risk/benefit for screening"
"PSA can be used as a surveillance marker for recurrent disease after prostatectomy"
"Histologically, in benign tumors there is absence of invasion of basement membrane / local tissue, whereas in malignant tumors there is presence of invasion"
"Do malignant tumors have metastatic potential? Yes"
"When examining a tumor, differentiation refers to the degree to which a tumor resembles its tissue of origin"
"Well differentiated tumors closely resemble their tissue of origin, whereas poorly differentiated tumors look almost nothing like tissue of origin"
"Poorly differentiated tumors are often more aggressive, whereas well differentiated tumors are often less aggressive"
"Anaplasia is the complete lack of differentiation of cells in a malignant neoplasm"
"Tumor grade is the degree of cellular differentiation and mitotic activity on histology"
"Tumor stage is the degree of localization / spread based on site and size of 1* lesion, spread to regional lymph nodes, and presence of metastases"
"Tumors that are low grade are well differentiated"
"Tumors that are high grade are poorly differentiated, undifferentiated, or anaplastic"
"Which has more prognostic value, tumor stage or grade? Tumor Stage"
"Tumor stage is classified by the TNM Staging System, which represents: - Tumor size / invasiveness - Node involvement - Metastases"
"An example of when the tumor staging factor of tumor size / invasiveness is the most important is in Melanoma (Breslow Thickness)"
"Tumor staging is based on clinical::c or pathological::p findings"
"Pityriasis rosea presents with multiple pink plaques with a(n) collarette scale"
"Mini-epidemics of Pityriasis Rosea will often occur among young adults::demographic"
"Burns are injuries to tissue caused by heat, chemicals, and/or radiation"
"The most common cause of burns in children are scald burns"
"The most common cause of burns in adults are flame burns"
"The three zones of burns from outermost to innermost are: - Zone of hyperemia - Zone of stasis (edema) - Zone of ischemia (coagulation)"
"Is damage in the zone of ischemia reversible (and if yes, does it need treatment)? No"
"Is damage in the zone of stasis / edema reversible (and if yes, does it need treatment)? Yes, with treatment"
"In burns, the zone of stasis / edema has decreased perfusion due to microvascular thrombosis"
"Is damage in the zone of hyperemia reversible (and if yes, does it need treatment)? Yes, without treatment"
"Superficial burns are 1st degree burns"
"Superficial burns involve which layers of the skin? Epidermis only"
"Partial thickness burns are 2nd degree burns"
"Superficial partial thickness burns involve which layers of the skin? Epidermis, Superficial Dermis"
"Superficial partial thickness burns cause the skin to blister"
"Superficial burns are blanchable::blanchable / not blanchable? and painful::painful / not painful?"
"Superficial partial thickness burns are blanchable::blanchable / not blanchable? and painful::painful / not painful?"
"Deep partial thickness burns are not blanchable::blanchable / not blanchable? and are painful to pressure only"
"While deep partial thickness burns do not::do/do not? heal without scarring, simple partial thickness burns do::do/do not? heal without scarring"
"Deep partial thickness burns involve which layers of the skin? Epidermis, Superficial Dermis, Deep Dermis"
"Full thickness burns are 3rd degree burns"
"Full thickness burns involve which layers of the skin? Epidermis and whole Dermis"
"Full thickness burns are not blanchable::blanchable / not blanchable? and not painful::painful / not painful?"
"Full thickness burns have a(n) waxy or leathery appearance"
"Do full thickness burns heal without scarring? No"
"Significant / serious burns are treated with surgery, restoration of volume status, infection prophylaxis, and testosterone to promote recovery"
"Burns can cause massive volume loss by alteration of capillary permeability (Kf)"
"Serious burns can lead to hypovolemic shock"
"Massive fluid loss in significant burns can cause acute gastritis::GI problem"
"A 4th degree burn will involve through the epidermis to the hypodermis, and in some cases muscle and bone"
"Clostridium perfringens binds claudins, resulting in watery diarrhea due to destruction of tight junctions"
"Which MEN syndrome can have multiple angiofibromas, collagenomas, meningiomas, and lipomas? MEN1"
"Urinary incontinence > 2 times / week for > 3 months in persons > 5 years old is known as Enuresis"
"The first line treatments for Enuresis are behavioral modification and positive reinforcement"
"For refractory cases of Enuresis, you can use a bedwetting alarm or oral desmopressin"
"UTIs are associated with urgency incontinence"
"Polyuria is associated with overflow incontinence"
"Bladder outlet obstruction is associated with overflow incontinence"
"Neurogenic bladder is associated with overflow incontinence"
"Testicular torsion may lead to infertility and thus is treated with urgent surgery"

"If a patient has a varicocele, consider surgical ligation or catheter embolization if associated with pain or infertility"
"The posterior pituitary gland is derived from neural tube of the ectoderm"
"Urethral injury occurs almost exclusively in men"
"If blood is seen at a patients urethral meatus, you should suspect a urethral injury"
"In a anterior urethral injury, the bulbar (spongy) part of the urethra is damaged"
"In a posterior urethral injury, the membranous part of the urethra is damaged"
"Posterior urethral injuries are typically caused by a(n) pelvic fracture"
"In a posterior urethral injury, urine leaks into the retropubic space"
"Patients with a posterior urethral injury present with blood at urethral meatus and a(n) \high-riding\\" boggy prostate\""
"Anterior urethral injuries are typically caused by a(n) perineal straddle injury"
"In an anterior urethral injury, blood accumulates in the scrotum, and can spread into the perineal space"
"In an anterior urethral injury, if the Buck Fascia is torn, urine can leak into the superficial perineal space"
"Patients with an anterior urethral injury present with blood at urethral meatus and a(n) scrotal hematoma"
"Is placement of a foley (urethral) catheter contraindicated in urethral injury? Relatively contraindicated"
"Spinal Shock describes a change from areflexia --> hyporeflexia --> hyperreflexia in patients with spinal cord injuries"
"Patients with spinal shock may develop autonomic dysreflexia in those with spinal cord injuries typically above T6"
"Critical Limb Ischemia is an advanced stage of peripheral artery disease that is a triad of Ischemic Rest Pain, Arterial Insufficiency Ulcers, and Gangrene"
"Arterial Insufficiency (Peripheral Artery Disease) is due to occlusion of arteries, most commonly due to atherosclerosis or other artery specific inflammatory processes"
"Patients with Peripheral Artery Disease have a higher risk of having a(n) MI than critical limb ischemia"
"Patients with Peripheral Arterial Disease present with claudication, acute rest pain, and numbness distally to occlusion"
"Peripheral Arterial Disease is most commonly caused by occlusion of the popliteal artery"
"Short Bowel Syndrome is a malabsorption disorder caused by a lack of functional small intestine"
"Short bowel syndrome is most commonly seen in patients who have had small intestine resection"
"Patients with short bowel syndrome often develop an increased frequency of calcium oxalate kidney stones"

"The major side effect of Palbociclib is neutropenia"

"Pulsus alternans is most commonly seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction"
"A hyperkinetic pulse can occur with aortic regurgitation and high-output conditions"

"A(n) preventable adverse event is defined as injury to a patient due to failure to follow evidence based best practice guidelines"
"A(n) sentinel event is an unexpected occurrence involving death or serious physical / psychological injury that requires immediate investigation"
"A(n) non preventable adverse event is a complication that cannot be prevented given the current state of medical knowledge"
"A(n) near miss is a medical error that is recognized before any harm is done to the patient"
"What is a legal determination that involves situations in which the treatment provided is below the accepted standard of practice and has resulted in injury or death to the patient? Malpractice"
"Most adverse drug reactions are predictable and are due to the known pharmacologic properties of the drug"
"An exaggerated drug sensitivity refers to adverse actions that occur due to known pharmacologic actions of the drug but at a lower dose than expected"

"Immunologic drug reactions are unpredictable anamnestic responses to medications"

"Conjugation is the transfer of DNA between bacteria using \sex pili\\"\""
"Generalized transduction is the transfer of random DNA between bacteria using bacteriophages"
"Specialized transduction is the transfer of specific DNA between bacteria using bacteriophages"

"Chronic neurohumoral activation induces increased levels of angiotensin II, ADH, aldosterone & norepinephrine results in cardiac remodeling **bonus: how?"

"Propionic acidemia is a defect in the enzyme propionyl-CoA carboxylase"
"What is the mode of inheritance of Propionic acidemia? Autosomal recessive"
"Propionic acidemia results in increased levels of propionyl-CoA and decreased levels of methylmalonic acid"

"Diagnosis of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is confirmed via bone marrow biopsy showing > 10% clonal B cells"

"What is the effect of hyperglycemia on serum sodium levels? Decreased (hyponatremia)"
"Mutation-selection equilibrium is an equilibrium that occurs when the rate of deleterious allele mutations equals the rate at which the deleterious alleles are eliminated by selection"

"In ATN, ischemia damages endothelial cells resulting in decreased NO and increased endothelin"

"The recovery stage of ATN is characterized by tubular re-epithelialization"

"Immunohistochemistry of glomeruli in Goodpasture syndrome shows extensive deposition of complement (C3)"
"Endothelial injury leads to upregulation of leukocyte adhesion molecules, which promote leukocyte adhesion and activation at the site of injury"
"After endothelial injury, LDL, macrophages, smooth muscle cells, and T-cells migrate to the tunica intima"
"After endothelial injury, platelets continue to aggregate and release cytokines and chemokines, which is exacerbated by *foam cells and chronic inflammation"
"Which cell may be altered by cytokines and growth factors to gain the ability to phagocytose LDL and cholesterol? Smooth muscle cells"
"Atherosclerotic plaques contain proliferations of thin-walled blood vessels due to upregulation of growth factors"
"Within atherosclerotic plaques, macrophages::cell and smooth muscle cells::cell produce metalloproteinases to digest extracellular matrix"
"Atherosclerotic plaques thicken the intima and impair perfusion of the tunica media resulting in cystic medial necrosis of smooth muscle cells"
"In peripheral artery disease, buttock pain and erectile dysfunction are due to lesions in the internal iliac artery"
"In peripheral artery disease, calf claudications are caused by lesions in the superficial femoral artery"
"Peripheral Artery Disease causes hair loss in the affected extremity due to deficient blood flow to hair follicles"
"Peripheral Artery Disease causes cool extremities to due reduced blood flow and hair loss"
"Peripheral Artery Disease may present with skin ulcers due to deficient blood flow and scant granulation tissue formation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with pain, pallor, paresthesias, paralysis, poikilothermia and pulselessness in one limb? Acute limb ischemia"
"What is the preferred next step for diagnosis of peripheral arterial disease in symptomatic patients? Ankle-brachial index (ABI) with Doppler (ABI is <0.9 in PAD)"
"Increased age, african american, and family history are non-modifiable risk factors for developing primary hypertension"
"Chronic sympathetic activity is thought to contribute to development of primary hypertension"
"Acute and chronic kidney disease may cause secondary hypertension due to increased renin and/or decreased salt and water excretion"
"Non-illicit drugs such as OCPs, corticosteroids, and NSAIDS may cause secondary hypertension"

"In peripheral artery disease, embolization of thrombus can travel to smaller downstream arteries and cause acute limb ischemia"
"Screening abdominal ultrasound should be performed on what demographic? Men > 65 with history of smoking"
"Large abdominal aortic aneurysms may present with hydronephrosis and postrenal kidney injury"
"Large thoracic aortic aneurysms may present with cough, wheezing, and dyspnea"
"Large thoracic aortic aneurysms may present with dysphagia and hoarseness"
"Thoracic aortic aneurysms may extend proximally and block the coronary artery ostia leading to ischemic heart disease"
"Thoracic aortic aneurysm rupture is associated with increasing vessel diameter (especially > 6cm)"
"A triad of cardiac tamponade, massive hemorrhage, and hypovolemic shock is characteristic of thoracic aortic aneurysm rupture"
"Infection of injured portions of the aorta (atherosclerotic plaque, catheterization injury) can lead to aortic aneurysm formation"
"Septic emboli from endocarditis may seed the aortic wall and lead to development or worsening of aortic aneurysm"
"Inflammatory vasculitides affecting the aorta (e.g. temporal arteritis, Takayasu arteritis) can lead to aortic aneurysm formation"
"Linear calcifications of the aortic arch on chest x-ray is suggestive of syphilitic aortitis"
"True aortic aneurysms involve which layers of the vessel wall? Intima, media, adventitia (all layers) False aortic aneurysms? only the adventitia"
"What iatrogenic risk factor may damage the intimal layer of a vessel wall and cause aortic dissection? Cardiac catheterization"
"What is the preferred diagnostic study for suspected aortic dissection in hemodynamically stable patients with normal renal function? CT angiography"
"Separation of the medial smooth muscle layer by dissecting blood creates a(n) true::true/false (systemic bloodflow) and false::true/false (dissecting bloodflow) lumen"
"How are aortic dissections classified in the DeBakey system? 1. Type 1: Ascending and Descending 2. Type 2: Ascending only 3. Type 3: Descending only"
"Occlusion of the carotid arteries by an expanding thoracic aortic dissection may cause ischemic stroke and/or syncope"
"What intrathoracic pathology may cause a chylous effusion due to obstruction of the thoracic duct? Malignancy (e.g. lymphoma)"
"What is the most common cause of secondary spontaneous pneumothorax? COPD (due to parenchymal destruction)"
"Whole blood leaking into the pleural cavity causes a(n) hemothorax, which may contain blood clots in the fluid collection"
"Hemothorax and chylothorax present with dullness::sound to percussion on the affected side"
"Parenchymal destruction from malignancy can cause secondary spontaneous pneumothorax"
"Pulmonary infections (e.g. pneumonia and lung abscess) may cause seconday spontaneous pneumothorax"
"Infection with M. tuberculosis may cause pleural or bronchial destruction leading to secondary spontaneous pneumothorax"
"Tension pneumothorax may restrict venous return resulting in hypotension and obstructive shock"
"Fibrotic changes in IPF appear as bilateral or diffuse reticular opacities, most prominent in lower::upper/lower lung lobes on CXR/CT"

"Radiation pneumonitis may present with pleural effusions and is treated with oral corticosteroids"
"Patients with history of thoracic radiation may develop pulmonary fibrosis and pneumonitis"
"SLE::Collagen vascular disease can cause pulmonary fibrosis due to recurrent inflammatory damage to type I and II pneumocytes"
"DiGeorge syndrome is associated with increased susceptibility to intracellular infections (e.g. bacterial, viral, fungal)"
"22q11.2 microdeletion can cause velocardiofacial syndrome, which is similar DiGeorge syndrome except the thymus is normal"
"Velocardiofacial syndrome is an immunodeficiency with a normal thymus that presents clinically as abnormal facies, cleft palate, and cyanotic congenital heart disease"

"X-linked agammaglobulinemia increases susceptibility to encapsulated bacteria and viruses, particularly enterovirus::which virus?"

"Dermatomyositis and polymyositis are more common in women::demographic"

"What is the prognosis of Acral Lentiginous melanomas? Poor"

"Mannitol can disrupt the blood-brain barrier which increases the permeability of medications"
"H1 antagonists are used to treat hyperemesis gravidarum"
"The stapedius muscle is responsible for volume modulation"
"The tensor tympani muscle is responsible for dampening of loud noises"
"Alzheimer disease can present histologically with Hirano bodies which are eosinophilic proteinaceous rods in the hippocampus"
"IIH (pseudotumor cerebri) can present with papilledema due to impaired optic nerve axoplasmic flow"
"Sturge-Weber syndrome::Neurocutaneous disorder is derived from neural crest derivatives, manifesting as capillary malformations in the brain, eyes, and skin"
"NF1 is associated with bone lesions such as sphenoid dysplasia"
"Medulloblastomas are soft friable brain tumors with areas of necrosis that may contain MYC amplifications"

"Friedreich ataxia may present with diabetes::endocrine disorder"
"Retinal blood vessel rupture leads to \flame\\" hemorrhages in nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy\""

"Nyctalopia is another name for night blindness, which may be the presenting sign in retinitis pigmentosa"
"Leukocoria (white reflex) may be caused by congenital cataracts and toxocariasis"
"Lamotrigine is an anti-epileptic that has hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis as a black box warning"
"Echothiophate is a(n) indirect cholinomimetic used to treat glaucoma"
"a2-agonists are glaucoma drugs that are associated with ocular hyperemia, foreign body sensation, and ocular pruritis"
"Alcohol, fat-rich diets, caffeine, obesity, pregnancy, smoking, and hiatal hernias may cause GERD::GI pathology"

"Obese individuals have increased levels of leptin"
"Which cytokine(s) utilize receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathways? TGF-β"
"Which cytokine(s) utilize receptor-associated tyrosine kinase signaling pathways? IL-2, IL-6, and IFN::3"
"Patients with acromegaly have an increased risk of colorectal polyp formation and cancer"
"What treatment option for Graves disease may be associated with worsening of ophthalmopathy? Radioactive iodine"
"Papillary thyroid carcinoma is due to PTC mutations"

"Fibrous replacement of the muscularis in the lower esophagus is the cause of esophageal dysmotility in CREST syndrome"

"What effect does H. pylori-mediated chronic gastritis have on serum levels of somatostatin? Decreased *bonus: why?"

"Initial infection with H. pylori may cause acute gastritis"

"Gastroparesis is characterized by delayed gastric emptying without mechanical obstruction"

"Gastroparesis is caused by dysfunction of the vagus nerve, which leads to impaired peristalsis of food through the stomach"

"A positive likelihood ratio > 10 indicates a highly specific test."

"Ménétrier disease is a premalignant stomach enteropathy characterized by massive gastric folds associated with excessive transforming growth factor alpha (TGF-α)"
"Cirrhosis may cause decreased total serum calcium and normal ionized serum calcium"
"Chronic viral hepatitis (HBV, HCV) and autoimmune diseases (PSC, PBC, autoimmune hepatitis) may cause cirrhosis of the liver, which is irreversible scarring/fibrosis"
"Cirrhosis leads to increased intrasinusoidal pressure and shrinkage of hepatocyte endothelial fenestrations"
"Cirrhosis may cause fasting hypoglycemia due to decreased glycogenolysis and decreased gluconeogenesis"
"Cirrhosis may cause vitamin D deficiency due to decreased synthesis of 25-hydroxylase"
"Cirrhosis may cause hypokalemia because the liver is unable to metabolize aldosterone::hormone"
"What effect does cirrhosis have on serum sodium levels? Decreased (hyponatremia) *bonus: why?"
"What creates new hepatocytes in response to cell injury [in cirrhosis]? Liver stem cells"
"Hepatorenal syndrome [2o to cirrhosis] may cause splanchnic arterial dilation due to increased release of NO"
"Cirrhosis may lead to activation of RAAS due to decreased intravascular volume and impaired metabolism of aldosterone"
"Hepatorenal syndrome activates RAAS and increases angiotensin II levels, which leads to pre-renal kidney injury::kidney complication"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back and peripancreatic edema/hemorrhage on CT? Acute necrotizing pancreatitis"
"In gallstone pancreatitis ALT > AST, whereas in alcohol-induced pancreatitis ALT < AST"

"Hereditary elliptocytosis increases protection against malaria"

"In sickle cells, the mutated hemoglobin molecules overlap due to increased hydrophobic/nonpolar interactions between hemoglobin molecules"
"Sickle cell disease may cause Ischemic stroke (large vessel) due to sickling of erythrocytes and thrombus formation in cranial vessels"
"What affect does splenic sequestration crisis have on reticulocyte count? Increased (reticulocytosis)"
"Sickled cells become stiff::characteristic due to irreversible damage from persistent polymerization-depolymerization cycles, which exacerbates polymerization and sickling"
"What affect does splenic sequestration crisis have on serum hemoglobin and hematocrit? Decreased (normocytic anemia)"
"What affect does splenic sequestration crisis have on blood pressure? Decreased (hypotension) *bonus: why?"
"In sickle cell disease, the spleen becomes enlarged and dysfunctional in early childhood (functional asplenia by age 5)::demographic (\splenic fatigue\\")\""
"Sickle cell trait in combination with another β globin defect results in a phenotype similar to sickle cell disease"
"People with sickle cell trait may develop splenic infarction in the setting of physiologic stressors (dehydration, air travel, sepsis)"

"Type I plasminogen deficiency leads to deposition of fibrin on mucous membranes"
"Hypofibrinogenemia is an inherited disorder that is often asymptomatic but may lead to abnormal bleeding"
"Severe intravascular hemolysis can cause acute kidney injury (AKI) due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN)"

"New bleeding on subdural bleeding \acute on chronic\\" will appear as hyperdense areas on non-contrast CT\""

"Headache, altered mental status, syncope, nausea and vomiting are symptoms of intracranial hemorrhage"

"Vitamin B12 deficiency initially presents as lower extremity paresthesias with no other neurologic findings"
"Atrophic glossitis and angular cheilitis are clinical manifestations of iron deficiency anemia"

"Chronic atrophic gastritis and H. pylori gastritis may cause iron deficiency anemia"

"Thrombocytopenia is defined as a platelet count < 150,000 uL"
"Phagocytosis of IgG-coated platelets in the spleen and systemic thrombosis are the two causes of thrombocytopenia in HIT"
"Antibody binding of platelets in HIT induces degranulation (release of cytokines, platelet factor 4, and ADP), which leads to arterial or venous thrombosis::complication"
"Does heparin induced thrombocytopenia often present with constitutional symptoms? Yes"
"What is the next step in diagnosis for a young man that has been acting strange, has signs of renal failure, and thrombocytopenia? Peripheral blood smear"
"Why is there thrombocytopenia in splenic sequestration crisis and portal hypertension? Platelets are trapped in spleen"
"Immune thrombocytopenic purpura in adults::demographic has a chronic course with episodic acute flares"

"Glanzmann Thrombasthenia is a(n) autosomal recessive::inheritance pattern qualitative platelet disorder"
"In Glanzmann Thrombasthenia, the ristocetin test is positive (normal)"
"Trauma may cause qualitative::qualitative/quantitative platelet dysfunction"
"Platelet dysfunction (qualitative) causes \platelet\\" type bleeding in what areas of the body? Skin & mucous membranes\""
"Diabetes mellitus causes qualitative platelet dysfunction that leads to thrombotic::bleeding/thrombotic complications"
"Myocardial infarction and thrombus formation is a complication of diabetes mellitus due to chronic hyperglycemia"
"Newborns are routinely given a(n) vitamin K injection in the hospital, thus a risk factor for hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is home birth"
"DIC causes depletion of pro- & anti::pro/anti-coagulant components of the coagulation cascade"
"What class of drugs can treat acquired hemophilia from anti-factor 8 antibodies? Corticosteroids"
"What drug may cause anti-factor 8 antibodies resulting in acquired hemophilia? Penicillin"
"Pregnancy and postpartum may cause anti-factor 8 antibodies resulting in acquired Hemophilia (A)"
"RA::autoimmmune disease and SLE::autoimmmune disease may cause anti-factor 8 antibodies resulting in acquired hemophilia (A)"
"Severe hemorrhage in vWF disease is treated with IV normal saline and cryoprecipitate (thawed FFP)"

"MERS-CoV is the cause of MERS"
"SARS-CoV-2 is the cause of COVID-19"
"The helical nucleocapsid of coronavirus is a(n) N protein bound to RNA genome"
"Envelope proteins of coronavirus include M, E, and S::3"
"The S glycoprotein of coronavirus is heavily glycosylated"
"Coronavirus binds to angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) on type II alveolar cells in the respiratory tract via the S glycoprotein"
"After viral uncoating, the positive-sense genomic RNA of coronavirus can be translated into 2 long polyproteins"
"After the replication-transcription complex is assembled, the positive-sense genomic RNA of coronavirus can be transcribed into negative-sense RNA"
"Subgenomic RNA of coronavirus can be used to make S, M, E, and N::what 4 proteins"
"Full-length negative-sense RNA is used to make new positive-sense RNA of coronavirus"
"After translation, the S, M, and E proteins of coronavirus are transported to the Golgi apparatus::what organelle?"
"The N protein of coronavirus forms the nucleocapsid in the cytoplasm after associating with newly synthesized genomic RNA"
"After cleavage of the coronavirus long polyprotein by viral protease, these proteins assemble into the replication-transcription complex"
"The key member of the replication-transcription complex of coronavirus is the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RDRP)"
"The newly synthesized coronavirus viral proteins, nucleocapsid, and positive-sense progeny RNA bud from the Golgi apparatus"
"Functional coronavirus virions are transported from the Golgi to the cell membrane and exocytosed"
"Coronavirus is transmitted by airborne or droplet transmission"
"High-pathogenicity strains of coronaviruses can cause potentially fatal pneumonia"
"Coronavirus has a wide range of presentations, from asymptomatic to cough and fever::mild symptoms to pneumonia::moderate disease to ARDS::most severe presentation"
"Patients who develop ARDS may require mechanical ventilation"
"The immune overdrive seen in ARDS in patients with coronavirus may be related to cytokine storm"
"Active coronavirus infection is detected using nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT)"
"Previous coronavirus infections are detected using serologic assays"
"Active coronavirus infection can be diagnosed by detecting antigens (e.g. nucleocapsid proteins)"
