"With Trendelenberg sign, the unaffected::unaffected/affected hip is lowered"
"What are the 3 hamstring muscles? Biceps Femoris, Semitendinosis, Semimembranosus"
"What innervates the hamstring muscles? Tibial Nerve (except short head of biceps)"
"What are the 2 actions of the hamstring muscles? Extension of the hip, Flexion of the knee"
"The femoral sheath is an extension of the transversalis and iliacus fascia"
"What are the 3 components of the femoral sheath (from lateral to medial) Femoral Artery, Femoral Vein, Femoral Canal"
"What are the 3 components of the femoral triangle (from lateral to medial) Femoral Nerve, Femoral Artery, Femoral Vein"
"A femoral hernia passes through the femoral ring into the femoral canal to form a swelling in the upper thigh inferior::direction and lateral::direction to the pubic tubercle"
"A femoral hernia may protrude through the saphenous hiatus into the superficial fascia"
"Femoral hernias are more common in which gender? Females"
"What artery may be damaged in femoral hernia repair? Obturator artery"
"Damage to the Calcaneal (Achilles) tendon disables the triceps surae muscle, inhibiting plantarflexion::action"
"Which muscles comprise the triceps surae? Soleus, Plantaris, 2 heads of gastrocnemius"
"Tibial nerve injury causes weakend plantarflexion and inversion of the foot"
"Fibular neck fracture damages the commmon peroneal nerve"
"Common peroneal nerve injury causes weakness in all muscles of the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg"
"Common peroneal nerve injury causes weakend dorsiflexion and eversion of the foot"
"How does breast cancer cause dimpling of the skin? Malignancy attaches and shortens Cooper's ligaments"
"The lymph from the lateral breast drains to axillary lymph nodes"
"The lymph from the medial breast drains to parasternal lymph nodes, or to the opposite breast"
"During a radial mastectomy, the long thoracic nerve may be lesioned, which presents with a \winged scapula\\"\""
"Besides the long thoracic nerve, the intercostobrachial nerve may be damaged during mastectomy, resulting in numbness of the medial arm"
"Mastitis occurs most frequently during the time of breastfeeding"
"The diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerve (roots C3-C5)"
"Diaphragm hemiparalysis results in the injured side moving superiorly during inspiration instead of inferiorly"
"80-90% of blunt diaphragmatic ruptures result from motor vehicle crashes"
"The majority of blunt diaphragmatic ruptures occur on the left side at the posterolateral aspect"
"Left atrial enlargement is usually secondary to mitral valve failure and may cause hoarseness and dysphagia due to comrpression of the esophagus"
"What forms the right border of the cardiac shadow on CXR? SVC, Right atrium"
"What forms the left border of the cardiac shadow on CXR? Aortic arch, Pulmonary trunk, Left auricle, Left ventricle"
"Which heart valve is ascultated at blue? Pulmonic"
"Which heart valve is ascultated at red? Aortic"
"Which heart valve is ascultated at green? Tricuspid"
"Which heart valve is ascultated at purple? Mitral"
"A heart murmur is heard downstream from the valve"
"The nodal branch of the RCA supplies the SA and AV node::2"
"The marginal branch of the RCA supplies the right ventricle"
"The circumflex branch of the LCA supplies the left atrium and ventricle::2"
"The LAD supplies what 4 regions of the heart?  1) Anterior heart wall 2) Anterior 2/3 of IV septum 3) Bundle of His 4) Apex of heart"
"What coronary artery supplies the AV bundle and moderator band? LCA"
"Aspiration of foreign bodies is most likely to enter the right::left/right primary bronchus and pass into the middle or lower bronchi"
"The right lung has 10 bronchopulmonary segments"
"How many bronchopulmonary segments are in each division of the right lung? Superior lobe: 3 Middle lobe: 2 Inferior lobe: 5"
"How many bronchopulmonary segments are in each division of the left lung? Superior lobe: 4 Inferior lobe: 5"
"The left lung has 9 bronchopulmonary segments"
"CXR of pneumonia produces areas of opacity and enlargement of mediastinal lymph nodes"
"Bronchogenic Carcinoma has early metastasis to thoracic lymph nodes"
"Lung cancer may involve a Pancoast tumor at the apex of the lung, which can cause Horner syndrome and/or thoracic outlet obstruction"
"To listen to breath sounds of the superior lobe of the right lung, place the stethoscope above the 4th rib"
"To listen to breath sounds of the superior lobe of the left lung, place the stethoscope above the 6th rib"
"To listen to breath sounds of the middle lobe of the right lung, place the stethoscope between ribs 4 and 6"
"To listen to breath sounds of the inferior lobes of the left and right lung, the stethoscope is placed on the posterior chest wall"
"In an open pneumothorax, the mediastinum shifts toward the opposite side during inspiration"
"In an open pneumothorax, the mediastinum shifts back to the midline during expiration"
"The parietal pleura receives somatic sensory innervation"
"The visceral pleura receives autonomic sensory innervation"
"What are the divisions of the parietal pleura of the torso? Costal, Mediastinal, Diaphragmatic"
"The coastal parietal pleura receives innervation from intercostal nerves"
"The mediastinal parietal pleura receives innervation from phrenic nerves"
"The diaphragmatic parietal pleura receives innervation from phrenic nerves over the domes"
"The diaphragmatic parietal pleura receives innervation from lower 6 intercostal nerves around the periphery"
"The liver and gallbladder are in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen"
"The stomach and spleen are in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen"
"The descending and sigmoid colon are in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen"
"The cecum and appendix are in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen"
"Pain from the foregut refers to the epigastric region"
"Pain from the midgut refers to the umbilical region"
"Pain from the hindgut refers to the hypogastric region"
"The transveralis fascia is the first structure crossed by any abdominal hernia"
"Indirect inguinal hernias are most common in which gender? Males"
"Direct inguinal hernias are more common in which gender? Males"
"Indirect inguinal hernias are more common in children::adults/children"
"Direct inguinal hernias are more common in older adults::adults/children"
"Indirect inguinal hernias are the most common type of abdominal hernia"
"Indirect inguinal hernias pass through the deep inguinal ring, then the inguinal canal, then exit through the superficial inguinal ring before descinding into the scrotum "
"Indirect inguinal hernias are located lateral::lateral/medial to the inferior epigastric vessels"
"Most indirect inguinal hernias are on what side? Right::Left/Right/Bilateral"
"Why are indirect inguinal hernias more common on the right side? The right processus vaginalis obliterates after the left, so the right testis descend later in life"
"Direct inguinal hernias descend protrude through the inguinal (Hesselbach's) triangle, and then through the superficial inguinal ring"
"Which type of inguinal hernia can descend into the scrotum? Only indirect::Direct/Indirect/Both"
"Most direct inguinal hernias are on what side? Bilateral::Left/Right/Bilateral"
"The hepatogastric and hepatoduodenal ligaments make up the lesser omentum"
"What are the contents in the lesser omentum? Right/Left Gastric vessels, Portal triad"
"What are the components of the portal triad? Bile duct, Portal vein, Proper hepatic artery"
"The borders of the epiploic (winslow's) foramen are: Anterior: hepatoduodenal legament (portal triad) Posterior: IVC Superior: Caudate lobe of liver Inferior: 1st part of duodenum"
"The rectouterine pouch is also known as the pouch of Douglas"
"The pouch of Douglas is located between the rectum and uterus"
"A pelvic abscess usually forms in the rectouterine pouch"
"The vesicouterine pouch is located between the uterus and the bladder"
"Culdocentesis is aspiration of fluid from the rectouterine (Douglas) pouch"
"Culdocentesis is performed by needle puncture through posterior vaginal fornix"
"Because the rectouterine (Douglas) pouch is the lowest::location? portion of the female peritoneal cavity, it can collect inflammatory fluid"
"The foregut spans the esophagus to the proximal duodenum"
"The midgut spans the distal duodenum to the proximal 2/3 of the transverse colon"
"The hindgut spans the distal 1/3 of the transverse colon to the anal canal above the pectinate line"
"The arterial supply of the foregut is from the celiac artery"
"The arterial supply of the midgut is from the superior mesenteric artery"
"The arterial supply of the hindgut is from the inferior mesenteric artery"
"The parasympathetic innervation of the foregut is from the vagus nerve"
"The parasympathetic innervation of the midgut is from the vagus nerve"
"The parasympathetic innervation of the hindgut is from the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4)"
"The sympathetic innervation of the foregut is from the: Preganglionics: greater splanchnic nerves (T5-T9) Postganglionics: celiac ganglion"
"The sympathetic innervation of the midgut is from the: Preganglionics: lesser splanchnic nerves (T10-T11) Postganglionics: superior mesenteric ganglion"
"The sympathetic innervation of the hindgut is from the: Preganglionics: lumbar splanchnic nerves (L1-L2) Postganglionics: inferior mesenteric ganglion"
"The sensory information of the foregut goes to the dorsal root ganglion of spinal levels T5-T9"
"The sensory information of the midgut goes to the dorsal root ganglion of spinal levels T10-T11"
"The sensory information of the hindgut goes to the dorsal root ganglion of spinal levels L1-L2"
"Posterior gastric ulcers may erode into the pancreas, causing referred pain to the back"
"Posterior gastric ulcers may erode into the splenic artery"
"Congenital diaphragmatic hernia results from a posterolateral::where? defect in the diaphragm"
"Congenital diaphragmatic hernia has a high mortality rate due to associated lung hypoplasia"
"A sliding hiatal hernia occurs when the cardia::region of the stomach herniates through the esophageal hiatus::space of the diaphragm"
"A sliding hiatal hernial can damage the vagal trunks, resulting in hyposecretion of gastric juice"
"At what vertebral level is the herniation of a sliding hiatal hernia? T10 (this is the level of the esophageal hiatus) "
"Meckel's diverticulum results from a persistent vitelline duct"
"Meckel's diverticulum is associated with the rule of 2's Occurs in 2% of patients Located 2 feet before the ileocecal junction About 2 inches long"
"What 3 types of tissue can be contained in a Meckel's diverticulum? Gastric, Pancreatic, Endometrial"
"Meckel's diverticulum may cause diverticulitis, which mimicks the symptoms of acute appendicitis"
"What are the 3 structural features of the large intestine? Taeniae coli, Haustra, Omental appendices"
"The taeniae coli of the large intestine meet together at the base of the appendix::organ"
"In appendicitis, pain is first localized where? The umbilicus (T10)"
"In appendicitis, late pain is located where? McBurney's point"
"McBurney point is found 1/3 of the distance between the ASIS and Umbilicus"
"Early::Early/Late pain in appendicitis is vague and diffuse"
"Late::Early/Late pain in appendicitis is sharp and specific"
"Early::Early/Late pain in appendicitis is termed visceral::somatic/visceral pain"
"Late::Early/Late pain in appendicitis is termed somatic::somatic/visceral pain"
"McBurney's point is where the base of the appendix is located"
"Volvulus occurs when the intestine rotates around its mesentery"
"Hirschsprung's Disease results from a failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the colon, causing it to be aganglionic (no postganglionic parasympathetic neurons)"
"Hirschsprung's Disease is commonly found in children with what chromosomal abnormality? Down Syndrome"
"Those with Hirschsprung's Disease are said to have a megacolon"
"The aganglionic colonic sections in Hirschsprung's Disease have inadequate motility, causing failure to pass a meconium stool within 1-2 days after birth"
"What is the treatment of Hirschsprung's Disease? Removal of the aganglionic portion of the colon"
"The celiac trunk branches off the abdominal aorta at what vertebral level? T12"
"The superior mesenteric artery branches off the abdominal aorta at what vertebral level? L1"
"The inferior mesenteric artery branches off the abdominal aorta at what vertebral level? L3"
"The renal arteries branch off the abdominal aorta at what vertebral level? L2"
"The the terminal branches of the abdominal aorta are the common iliac arteries, which branch off at the L4 vertebral level"
"After the celiac trunk branches off the abdominal aorta, it passes over the superior border of the pancreas before dividing into its 3 branches"
"What are the 3 branches of the celiac trunk? 1) Left gastric artery 2) Common hepatic artery 3) Splenic artery"
"The left gastric artery is susceptible to ulcers of the lesser curvature::region? of the stomach"
"The esophageal artery is the first branch off the left gastric artery"
"Gastric branches of the left gastric artery supply the left side of the lesser curvature::region of the stomach and make anastomoses with the right gastric artery"
"Where does the common hepatic artery divide into its 2 branches? The superior surface of the 1st part of the duodenum"
"What are the 2 branches of the common hepatic artery? 1) Proper hepatic artery 2) Gastroduodenal artery"
"The first branch of the proper hepatic artery is the right gastric artery"
"The proper hepatic artery ascends within the hepatoduodenal ligament of the lesser omentum to reach the porta hepatis, where it divides into the right and left hepatic arteries"
"The gallbladder is supplied by the cystic artery, which is a branch off the right hepatic artery"
"The right gastric artery supplies the right side of what region of the stomach? Lesser curvature"
"What artery is susceptible to erosion of a penetrating ulcer in the first part of the duodenum? Gastroduodenal artery"
"What are the 2 branches of the gastroduodenal artery? 1) Right gastroepiploic artery 2) Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery"
"The right gastroepiploic artery supplies what region of the stomach? Right side of the greater curvature"
"The right gastroepiploic artery anastomoses with what other artery? Left gastroepiploic"
"With ligation of the hepatic artery, collateral circulation of the liver can be established through which arteries?  Left and Right gastric arteries Left and Right gastroepiploic arteries"
"The right hepatic artery may be mistakenly ligated during cholecystectomy::procedure because it can be found in the triangle of Calot::region with the cystic artery"
"What may happen if the right hepatic artery is accidentally ligated during cholecystectomy? Right lobe hepatic necrosis"
"The splenic artery courses along the upper border of the pancreas"
"The splenic artery is susceptible to erosion of a penetrating ulcer of the posterior wall of the stomach into the lesser sac"
"The splenic vein runs behind the pancreas"
"The splenic artery::artery/vein runs a more tortuous course along the pancreas"
"The splenic vein::artery/vein runs a more straight course along the pancreas"
"The splenic artery is retroperitoneal until it reaches the tail of the pancreas, where it enters the splenorenal ligament to enter the hilum of the spleen"
"What are the 4 main branches of the splenic artery? 1) Branches to the spleen 2) Branches supplying most of the pancreas (not head) 3) Left gastroepiploic artery 4) Short gastric arteries"
"The fundus::region of the stomach is supplied by short gastric arteries"
"What are the 6 main branches of the superior mesenteric artery? 1) Inferior pancreaticoduodenal 2) Jejunal branches 3) Ileal branches 4) Ileocolic artery 5) Right colic artery 6) Middle colic artery"
"The appendicular artery is a branch of the ileocolic artery"
"What are the 3 main branches of the inferior mesenteric artery? 1) Left colic artery 2) Sigmoid arteries 3) Superior rectal artery"
"Mesenteric ischemia usually involves which region of the GI system? Small intestine"
"Risk for mesenteric ischemia increases if you are a smoker or have a high cholesterol level"
"Atherosclerosis::Pathology slows down blood flow through arteries, and thus is a frequent cause of chronic::acute/chronic mesenteric ischemia"
"AAA (abdominal aortic aneurysm) is a localized dilatation of the aorta"
"AAA typically happens just above the bifurcation of the aorta at the L4 vertebral level (crossed by 3rd::# part of the duodenum)"
"Pulsations of a large AAA can be detected to the left::left/right of the the midline at the umbilical region"
"Rupture of an AAA causes severe pain in the abdomen or back with a 90% mortality rate"
"Surgeons can repair an AAA by opening it and inserting a prosthetic graft"
"Bile is initially secreted by the liver cells and is stored/concentrated in the gallbladder"
"Bile is delivered from the gallbladder ultimately to what location in the GI tract? Duodenum"
"Bile initially leaves the gallbladder through the cystic duct, which joins the common hepatic duct to form the common bile duct"
"The common bile duct descends in the hepatoduodenal ligament, then passes posterior to the 1st part of the duodenum"
"After passing the duodenum, the common bile duct penetrates the head of the pancreas, where it joins the main pancreatic duct and forms the sphincter of Oddi (hepatopancreatic ampulla)"
"The sphincter of Oddi drains into the 2nd part of the duodenum at the major duodenal papilla"
"The distal end of the sphincter of Oddi is the narrowest part of the biliary passage, thus it is a common site for impaction of gallstones"
"Gallstones in most locations of the biliary passage cause yellow::color eyes (sclerel icterus) and jaundice::skin finding"
"Gallstones lodged in the cystic duct do not cause jaundice, and instead cause biliary colic (intense pain in the gallbladder)"
"The fundus of the gallbladder is in contact with the transverse colon, thus gallstones that erode through the posterior wall of the gallbladder may enter the colon"
"Gallstones in the body of the gallbladder may ulcerate through the posterior wall into the duodenum::GI region"
"Gallstones that ulcerate into the duodenum::colon/duodenum are more likely to cause intestinal obstruction due to being held up at the ilocecal valve"
"Sensory innervation of the liver is done by the right phrenic nerve, and pain may radiate to the right shoulder"
"Portal hypertension commonly causes congestive enlargement of the spleen::organ"
"A portacaval shunt is a surgical treatment for portal hypertension"
"A portacaval shunt connects the splenic vein with the renal vein"
"Creating a portacaval shunt requires removal of the spleen::organ, which requires anastomosis of the splenic vein to the left renal vein"
"What are the 3 sites of portocaval anastomoses? 1) Esophageal veins 2) Thoracoepigastric veins 3) Rectal veins"
"Esophageal anastomosis occur between the left gastric vein and the azygous vein"
"In portal hypertension, umbilical anastomosis may enlarge causing caput Medussae"
"Umbilical anastomosis occur between the paraumbilical vein and the superior/inferior epigastric veins"
"Rectal anastomosis occur between the superior rectal vein and the inferior rectal vein veins"
"In portal hypertension, rectal anastomosis may enlarge causing internal hemorrhoids"
"The superior rectal vein drains into the portal vein"
"The inferior rectal vein drains into the IVC system"
"The head of the pancreas includes the uncinate process which is crossed by the superior mesenteric vessels"
"Cancer at the head of the pancreas often compresses the bile duct, causing obstructive jaundice"
"The jaundice caused by cancer of the pancreatic head is associated with neither pain or fever::pain/fever"
"The splenic vein joins with the superior mesenteric vein to form the portal vein at the neck of the pancreas"
"The tail of the pancreas is the only part that is intraperitoneal (the rest is retropreitoneal)"
"The tail of the pancreas may be accidentally removed during splenectomy::procedure, causing diabetes"
"The accessory pancreatic duct drains into the minor duodenal papilla (which is about 2 cm proximal to the major duodenal papilla)"
"Annular pancreas occurs when the ventral and dorsal pancreatic buds form a ring around the duodenum, causing obstruction and polyhydramnios"
"The spleen is deep to ribs 9, 10, 11, thus fracture of these ribs may lacerate the spleen"
"The gastrosplenic ligament connects the spleen and the greater curvature of the stomach"
"The gastrosplenic ligament contains the short gastric vessels and the left gastroepiploic vessels"
"The splenorenal ligament connects the spleen with the left kidney"
"The splenorenal ligament contains the splenic vessels and the tail of the pancreas"
"The kidneys extend from the vertebral levels of T12 to L3"
"The right kidney is about 2-3 cm lower::higher/lower than the left one"
"The ureters lie on the psoas major muscle"
"The renal (Gerota) fascia encloses both the kidney and the adrenal glands, however they are separated by a thin septum"
"The renal fascia must be incised to perform any surgical operation on the kidney"
"The two most common types of kidney stones are calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate"
"If kidney stones grow too large before they are passed, they may obstruct the ureter"
"Staghorn calculi::Type of kidney stone develop in the pelvicaliceal system of the kidney"
"Staghorn calculi are composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate::3 and are formed when the urine pH is high::high/low"
"The right renal vein is much shorter::shorter/longer than the left renal vein"
"The left renal vein is joined by the left adrenal vein and left gonadal vein before empyting in the IVC"
"The left renal vein crosses anterior to the aorta, just inferior of the origin of the SMA"
"Varicoceles are engorgement of the pampiniform plexus"
"Varicoceles are describe as a wormlike scrotal mass"
"Varicocele formation is most commonly on the left::left/right side"
"Varicocele is commonly caused by blockage of the spermatic vein or by kidney cancer"
"The right spermatic vein drains into the IVC, and the left spermatic vein drains into the left renal vein"
"Venous drainage from the rectum above the pectinate line is through the superior rectal vein into the portal system"
"Venous drainage from the rectum below the pectinate line is through the inferior rectal vein into the IVC"
"External hemorrhoids are dilated tributaries of the inferior rectal veins"
"External hemorrhoids are painful"
"Internal hemorrhoids are painless"
"Internal hemorrhoids are dilated tributaries of the superior rectal veins"
"Pregnancy can cause both internal and external (but internal is more common)::internal/external hemorrhoids"
"What are the contents of the deep perineal pouch in males? Sphincter urethrae muscle, Deep transverse perineal muscle, Bulbourethral (Cowper's) glands"
"The deep perineal pouch is formed by the fasciae and muscle of the urogenital diaphragm"
"What muscles are in the superficial perineal pouch? 1) Ischiocavernosus 2) Bulbospongiosus 3) Superficial transverse perineal"
"Cystocele is a herniation of the bladder"
"Cystocele may be caused by increased intrabdominal pressure and damage to the pelvic floor"
"In males, the ureter is crossed superiorly by the ductus deferens near the bladder"
"In females, the ureter is crossed superiorly and anteriorly by the uterine artery at the base of the broad ligament"
"The ureter can be damaged in a hysterectomy::procedure because due to its proximity to the uterine artery"
"Pelvic parasympathetic innervation is done through nerve roots from levels S2-S4"
"Pelvic sympathetic innervation is done through nerve roots from levels T12-L2"
"Pelvic sympathetic::sympathetic/parasympathetic innervation involves the inferior hypogastric plexus"
"Pelvic parasympathetic::sympathetic/parasympathetic innervation involves the intramural plexus"
"Pelvic sensory/pain innervation is carried to dorsal root ganglions at levels S2-S4, and then joins parasympathetic::sympathetic/parasympathetic nerves"
"Parasympathetic and motor nerve fibers facilitate bladder emptying"
"Sympathetic nerve fibers inhibit bladder emptying"
"Parasympathetic nerve fibers effect what 2 bladder muscles?  Stimulates detrusor Relaxes internal uretheral sphincter"
"Sympathetic nerve fibers effect what 2 bladder muscles?  Inhibits detrusor Contracts internal uretheral sphincter"
"Motor nerve fibers effect which bladder muscle? Releaxes external urethral sphincter"
"Relaxation of the external urethral sphincter is voluntary"
"Relaxation of the internal urethral sphincter is involuntary"
"Paracentesis of the bladder is done by inserting where? Just above the pubic symphysis"
"Postate tumors tend to metastasize to the vertebrae and brain because the prostatic venous plexus has numerous connections with the vertebral venous plexus via sacral veins"
"BPH (prostate adenoma) usually involves the median lobe"
"BPH is a common cause of urethral obstruction, leading to nocturia, dysuria, urgency::3 urinary symptoms"
"The prostate is examined for enlargement/tumors by DRE (digital rectal examination)"
"A prostatectomy may be performed through a suprapubic or perineal incision, or transurethrally"
"Prostatectomy may damage nerves in the capsule of the prostate, which may cause impotence and/or urinary incontinence"
"The TURP procedure is the gold standard for prostatectomy"
"The prostatic urethra is the most wide::narrow/wide"
"The membranous urethra is the most narrow::narrow/wide"
"The prostatic urethra has a spindle shape"
"The seminal vesicles and ejaculator duct empty into the prostatic urethra"
"The membranous urethra is the shortest part"
"The membranous urethra is surrounded by the external urethral sphincter"
"The membranous urethra passes through the urogenital diaphragm to enter the bulb of the penis"
"Bulbourethral glands lie posterolateral::direction? to the membranous urethra"
"The spongy urethra is the final part which terminates at the tip of the glans penis"
"The spongy urethra has which two dilations? Bulbar Fossa, Navicular Fossa"
"The bulbar fossa is the more proximal dilation of the spongy urethra"
"The navicular fossa is the more distal dilation of the spongy urethra"
"The internal urethral sphincter is made of smooth muscle"
"The external urethral sphincter is made of skeletal muscle"
"The external urethral sphincter is innervated by the pudendal nerve"
"A hydrocele/hematocele occurs between the parietal and visceral layers of what structure? Tunica vaginalis"
"Will a hydrocele transilluminate? Yes!"
"Will a hematocele transilluminate? No!"
"Will a scrotal tumor transilluminate? No!"
"Will a herniation to the scrotum transilluminate? No!"
"Transillumination of a hydrocele produces a red::color glow"
"Cryptorchidism occurs when the testes fail to descend into the scrotum"
"The testes normally descend into the scrotum within 3 months::time? after birth"
"In cryptorchidism, the undescended testes may be found in the abdominal cavity or in the inguinal canal"
"In cryptorchidism, spermatogenesis::process is arrested leading to infertility if bilateral"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the testes? Lumbar (para-aortic) lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the epididymis? Lumbar (para-aortic) lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the scrotum? superficial inguinal lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the skin of the penis? superficial inguinal lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the glans penis? deep inguinal lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the body/root of the penis? internal iliac lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the prostate gland? internal iliac lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the bladder? internal iliac lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the anal canal ABOVE the pectinate line? internal iliac lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the anal canal BELOW the pectinate line? superficial inguinal lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the ovaries? Lumbar (para-aortic) lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the fallopian (uterine) tubes? Lumbar (para-aortic) lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the uterus (lateral angle)? superficial inguinal lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the uterus (fundus and upper body)? Lumbar (para-aortic) lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the uterus (cervix)? external AND internal iliac lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the vagina (superior to hymen)? external AND internal iliac lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the vagina (inferior to hymen)? superficial inguinal lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of all external femal genitalia (besides glans clitoris)? superficial inguinal lymph nodes"
"What is the lymphatic drainage of the glans clitoris? deep inguinal lymph nodes"
"The uterus is almost exclusively supplied by the uterine arteries"
"The uterine artery is a branch off the internal iliac artery"
"The uterine artery crosses the pelvic floor in the transverse cervical ligament on the base of the broad ligament"
"The uterine artery has branches that have anastomoses with the vaginal and ovarian arteries"
"What are the 4 parts of the fallopian tube? (From medial to lateral) Uterine part, Isthmus, Ampulla, Infundibulum"
"What part of the fallopian tube is the most narrow? Isthmus"
"What part of the fallopian tube is the usual site of implantation? Ampulla"
"What part of the fallopian tube first receives the oocyte at ovulation? Infundibulum"
"The infundibulum part of the fallopian tube is funnel-shaped and fringed with fimbriae"
"Hysterosalpingography is an imaging technique to view the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes"
"Here's all the foramina of the base of the skull, examine if you want, suspend if you want! :)"
"Cranial Nerve I exits the skull through the cribriform plate"
"Cranial Nerve II exits the skull through the optic canal"
"Cranial Nerves III, IV, V1, VI exit the skull through the superior orbital fissue"
"Cranial Nerve V2 exits the skull through the foramen rotundum"
"Cranial Nerve V3 exits the skull through the foramen ovale"
"Cranial Nerves VII and VIII exit the skull through the internal auditory meatus"
"Cranial Nerves IX, X, and XI exit the skull through the jugular foramen"
"Cranial Nerve XII exits the skull through the hypoglossal canal"
"Fracture of the cribiform plate of the ethmoid bone presents with anosmia, periorbital bruising (\raccoon eyes\\")"
"The coronal suture of the skull lies between the frontal bone and the parietal bone"
"The saggital suture of the skull lies between the two parietal bones"
"The squamous suture of the skull lies between the parietal bone and the temporal bone"
"The lambdoid suture of the skull lies between the parietal bone and the occipital bone"
"The bregma of the skull is the intersection of the coronal and saggital sutures"
"Scaphocephaly is premature close of the sagittal suture"
"Oxycephaly is premature close of the coronal suture"
"Plagiocephaly is a condition when there is premature closure of the coronal or lambdoid suture on only one side"
"The anterior frontanelle of the skull closes at the age of 9 to 18 months"
"The posterior frontanelle of the skull closes at the age of 2 months"
"Diminished size of the anterior frontanelle may indicate craniosynostosis or microcephaly"
"Persistence of the posterior frontanelle suggests underlying hydrocephalus or congenital hypothyroidism"
"Epidural hematoma occurs when the skull is fractured near the pterion, tearing the middle meningeal artery"
"Subdural hematoma occurs with damage to what vessel? Bridging veins"
"Epi::Epi/Subdural hematoma has a more rapid progression of symptoms"
"Epidural hematomas form a lens shaped pattern on imaging"
"Subdural hematomas form a crescent shaped pattern on imaging"
"What nerve(s)/vessel(s) are found on the lateral::lateral/medial walls of the cavernous sinus? CN III, IV, V1, V2"
"What nerve(s)/vessel(s) are found medially::laterally/medially in the cavernous sinus? CN VI, Internal carotid artery"
"The superior opthalmic vein communicates with the facial (angular) vein"
"The inferior opthalmic vein communicates with the pterygoid plexus of veins"
"Both the superior and inferior opthalmic veins pass through the superior orbital fissure and drain into the cavernous sinus"
"What layer of the scalp contains nerves and blood vessels? Connective tissue (dense superficial fascia)"
"Sensation of almost all the skin of the face is supplied by what cranial nerve? All the branches of CN V"
"The only skin of the face that doesnt have sensory innervation by CN V is the angle over the mandible, which is supplied by the great auricular nerve (roots C2-C3)"
"CN VII innervates all muscles of facial expression"
"CN VII is embryonically derived from the 2nd::# pharyngeal arch"
"CN VII provides taste sensation in the anterior 2/3 of the tongue through the chorda tympani"
"CN VII innervates what salivary glands? Submandibular, Sublingual"
"CN VII innervates the lacrimal glands"
"Bell's palsy::Condition? is idiopathic unilateral paralysis of CN VII"
"CN VII may be damaged during surgery of the parotid gland"
"The sphenoethmoidal recess receives the opening of the sphenoidal air sinus"
"The superior meatus receives the opening of the posterior ethmoidal air cells"
"The middle meatus receives the opening of the frontal and maxillary sinuses"
"The middle meatus receives the opening of the anterior and middle ethmoidal air cells"
"The inferior meatus receives the opening of the nasolacrimal duct"
"Epistaxis (nosebleed) most often occurs from the anterior nasal septum (Kiesselbach's area)"
"What 4 arteries converge at Kiesselbach's area, and thus contribute to epistaxis? 1) Sphenopalatine 2) Superior labial 3) Anterior ethmoidal 4) Greater palatine"
"Infection can reach the sinuses through their ostia from the nasal cavity or through the floor from the nasopharynx"
"The buccinator is the principal muscle of the cheek"
"All 4 muscles of mastication are innervated by CN V3"
"Which muscle(s) of mastication close the jaw? Temporalis, Masseter, Medial Pterygoid"
"Which muscle(s) of mastication open the jaw? Lateral Pterygoid"
"Which muscle(s) of mastication protrude the jaw? Lateral Pterygoid"
"Lesioning CN XII causes the tongue to deviate toward::away from/toward the side of the lesion due to unopposed action of the contralateral genioglossus muscle"
"What is the afferent limb of the gag reflex? CN IX"
"What is the efferent limb of the gag reflex? CN X"
"Injury to CN IX causes loss of both taste and touch::taste/touch in the posterior 1/3::region of the tongue"
"Palatine tonsillectomy may injury CN IX"
"Palatine tonsillectomy may injure the facial and/or internal carotid artery"
"The palatine tonsils receive their main blood supply from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery"
"The lymphatic drainage of the palatine tonsil is to the jugulodigastric lymph node"
"What is the body's most frequently enlarged lymph node? Jugulodigastric lymph node"
"What is the nerve supply to the palatine tonsils? CN IX and X"
"What parts of the face have lymph drainage to the submental lymph nodes? 1) Central part of upper and lower lips 2) Lower incisor teeth 3) Tip of the tongue Everything else is to the submandibular lymph nodes"
"What part of the tongue has lymph drainage to the submandibular lymph node? Anterior 2/3 (besides the tip)"
"A blow-out fracture of the orbital floor injures the inferior rectus muscle, infraorbital nerve, and infraorbital artery"
"The superior rectus muscle is innervated by CN III"
"The inferior rectus muscle is innervated by CN III"
"The medial rectus muscle is innervated by CN III"
"The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by CN VI"
"The superior oblique muscle is innervated by CN IV"
"The inferior oblique muscle is innervated by CN III"
"What is the action of the superior rectus muscle? Elevates + Adducts pupil"
"What is the action of the inferior rectus muscle? Depresses + Adducts pupil"
"What is the action of the inferior oblique muscle? Elevates + Abducts pupil"
"What is the action of the superior oblique muscle? Depresses + Abducts pupil"
"What is the action of the lateral rectus muscle? Abducts pupil"
"What is the action of the medial rectus muscle? Adducts pupil"
"What is the action of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle? Elevates upper eyelid"
"The levator palpebrae superioris is innervated by CN III"
"How would you clinically test the action of the medial rectus muscle? Ask the patient to look directly medially"
"How would you clinically test the action of the lateral rectus muscle? Ask the patient to look directly laterally"
"How would you clinically test the action of the superior rectus muscle? Ask the patient to look laterally, then superiorly"
"How would you clinically test the action of the inferior rectus muscle? Ask the patient to look laterally, then inferiorly"
"How would you clinically test the action of the superior oblique muscle? Ask the patient to look medially, then inferiorly"
"How would you clinically test the action of the inferior oblique muscle? Ask the patient to look medially, then superiorly"
"What are the 3 common manifestations of Oculomotor Nerve (CN III) palsy? Ptosis (eyelid drooping), Dilated Pupil (\Blown Out\\")"
"The characteristic sign of CN IV palsy is diplopia when looking down (e.g., going down stairs)::direction?"
"CN IV palsy can be compensated for by inclining the head anteriorly and laterally toward the side of the normal eye"
"The affected eye in CN IV palsy is stuck looking superio-laterally::direction?"
"In CN VI palsy, the affected eye is fully adducted due to unopposed action of the medial rectus muscle"
"The afferent limb of the corneal reflex is through CN V1, and the efferent limb of the corneal reflex is through CN VII"
"Which eye blinks in the corneal reflex? Both eyes!"
"The efferent limb of the corneal reflex acts on the orbicularis oculis muscle"
"Horner syndrome is commonly caused by a pancoast tumor or thyroid carcinoma"
"Horner syndrome is the the result of interruping ascending preganglionic sympathetic nerve fibers before they reach the superior cervical ganglion"
"What are 4 common signs of Horner Syndrome? Miosis, Ptosis, Anhydrosis, Vasodilation (causing redness and increased temperature of skin)"
"Otitis media primarily causes diminished hearing::sense"
"Otitis media may alter the sense of taste if the chorda tympani is involved"
"Otitis media may spread to the middle cranial fossa, causing meningitis"
"Otitis media may move through the floor, causing sigmoid sinus thrombosis"
"Because the close proximity of the chorda tympani, tympanic membrane perforation may also cause loss of taste over the anterior 2/3 of the tongue"
"Perforation of the tympanic membrane is a cause of conductive::conductive/sensorineural hearing loss"
"What are the 2 main hormones produced by the thyroid gland? Thyroid hormone, Calcitonin"
"What is the main hormone produced by the parathyroid gland? PTH (parathyroid hormone)"
"Calcitonin acts to reduce blood calcium levels"
"PTH acts to increase blood calcium levels"
"PTH mainly targets what 3 areas of the body? Skeleton, Kidneys, Intestines"
"The common carotid artery is located posterolateral::direction? to the thyroid gland"
"The parathyroid glands are located on the posterior aspect of the thyroid gland"
"Thyroglossal duct (median cervical) cysts usually present as a painless::ful/less midline::location? mass on the anterior aspect of the neck"
"Thyroglossal duct (median cervical) cysts do::do/do not move during swallowing"
"Branchial cleft cysts do not::do/do not move during swallowing"
"A persistent cervical sinus causes a branchial cleft cyst in the lateral aspect of the neck"
"Thyroglossal duct (median cervical) cysts are remnants of the thyroglossal canal"
"In 1-5% of people, a inferior thyroid gland is deep in the superior mediastium within the thymus (due to common embryonic origin)"
"The vestibular folds are also known as false vocal cords"
"The vocal folds are also known as true vocal cords"
"The rima vestibuli is the gap between the vestibular folds"
"The rima glottidis is the gap between the vocal folds (anteriorly) and vocal processes of the arytenoid cartilages (posteriorly)"
"The posterior cricoarytenoid is the only abductor::what does it do? of the vocal folds"
"The superior laryngeal nerve divides into internal and external laryngeal nerves"
"The internal laryngeal nerve supplies much of the larynx above::above/below the vocal folds"
"The external laryngeal nerve supplies the cricothyroid muscle"
"The recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies much of the larynx below::above/below the vocal folds"
"The recurrent laryngeal nerve ascends in the neck in a groove between the trachea and esophagus"
"The right recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks around the right subclavian artery::blood vessel"
"The left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks around the arch of the aorta::blood vessel"
"A cricothyrotomy is an emergeny procedure that relieves an airway obstruction"
"In a cricothyrotomy, a needle inserted just below the thyroid cartilage, through the cricothyroid membrane"
"The retropharyngeal space is located between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia"
"The carotid sheath derives from which embryologic layer? All 3!"
"The carotid sheath encloses what arteries/veins/nerves?  Common and internal carotid arteries Internal jugular vein Vagus nerve"
"The axillary sheath is derived from the prevertebral fascia"
"The axillary sheath encloses the axillary vessels and the brachial plexus"
"The interscalenus space is between the anterior and medial scalene muscles and contains the brachial plexus"
"What arteries/veins/nerves/lymph nodes are contained in the posterior triangle of the neck? Artery: Occipital artery Veins: External jugular and subclavian veins Nerves: CN XI (+ trunks of brachial plexus, branches of cervical plexus, phrenic nerve) Lymph Nodes: Superficial cervical lymph nodes"
"In the posterior triangle of the neck, the superficial cervical lymph nodes are along the external jugular vein"
"esophageal varices caused by anastamosing left gastric and azygous vein in lower part of esophagus"
"anorectal varices formed by anatstaomsis of superior rectal vein and middle/inferior rectal veins"
"Facial nerve implicated in Bell's Palsy when terminal branches accidentally nicked during parotid surgery"
"lesser omentum has hepatogastric and hepatoduodenal ligaments. Also contains portal triad, hepatic plexus, and local lymphatic structures. Collectively, these contents are contained in Gilsson's Capsule"
"Winslow's foramen aka Epiploic foramen connects greater and lesser sacs in the abdomen."
"Any movement (fracture, surgery, etc)) of the femoral head may cause tearing of the medial circumflex femoral artery which leads to avascular necrosis."
"Heberden's nodes are distal Bouchard's nodes are proximal"
"Although foreign objects are more likely to be aspirated into the right main bronchus, the distinction is less clear in children b/c of  kiddos have relatively similar bronchial angles:: give the general reason"
"Piriformis muscle overlies the  Sciatic nerve (so injury to that muscle produces sciatica)"
"Popliteal Fossa borders are the: semimembranosus biceps femoris gastrocnemius medial head gastrocnemius lateral head plantaris."
"Most superficial components of the Popliteal Fossa are the tibial and fibular nerves"
"Swelling in the popliteal fossa should make you think popliteal cyst // baker's cyst or aneurysm. Either way, watch for compression of the tibial nerve, which would cause plantar flexion weakness"
"Injury to the superior gluteal nerve causes contralateral hip side to fall downard (trendelenburg sign, due to weakness of the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles)"
"abdominal aortic aneurysms are most likely to occur above the bifurcation::location, b/c of changes in elasticity and diameter."
"Waiter's Tip involves Axillary, Suprascapular, and Musculocutaneous nerve injuries"
"Most likely place in the peritoneal cavity to have abscesses is rectouterine pouch (AKA Douglas' pouch) since it's the lowest point."
"First structure penetrated by ANY abdominal hernia is the transversalis fascia"
"fibular neck fracture should make you think common peroneal nerve injury. Look for foot drop b/c of anterior and lateral leg muscle weakness"
"Mnemonic for pharyngeal pouches: M S 2 Problems are Vague (1=\M\\""
"The spleen is likely lacerated with a crushing injury to ribs 9 or 10"
"Varicoceles usually form on the left::L/R side b/c venous blood from the left has further to go (thus requiring more pressure to move out)."
"the cavernous sinus receives blood from the facial and superior opthalmic veins. Note: popping pimples in areas supplied by these veins can lead to infection!!"
"The danger zone extends from the base of the skull to the posterior mediastinum. This is posterior to the retropharyngeal space, and can be infected due to local spread from the parapharyngeal/retropharyngeal spaces."
"chorda tympani runs along posterior surface of the tympanic membrane."
"chorda tympani damage results in loss of taste to the tongue (anterior 2/3), as well as dysfunction of submandibular and sublingual glands."
"Most frequently enlarged lymph nodes in the cervical chain are the jugulodigastric, which drain the palatine tonsils."
"chorda timpani damage kills taste to the anterior 2/3 tongue glossopharyngeal nerve damage kills taste to the posterior 1/3 tongue"
"most common ways to damage the ulnar nerve are FOOSH or medial epicondyle injury."
"Hirschprung disease is megacolon b/c of absence of postganglionic parasympathetics. When you hear Hirschprung think Down Syndrome."
"Celiac Artery provides 3 retroperitoneal branches: Left Gastric artery Common Hepatic artery Splenic artery"
"posterior zone of the prostate is comprised of the peripheral and lateral lobes"
"How does valsalve affect blood return to the heart? less blood return"
"A positive inotropic agent drops the right atrial pressure because of inadequate filling time"
"Cryptorchidism decreases fertility because spermatogenesis is impaired due to increased temperature of testis"
"Why do B12 and B9 lead to increased risk for thrombosis? increased serum homocysteine"
"Preterm Premature Rupture of Membranes (PPROM) is a preterm baby with premature rupture of membranes without contractions"
"What is the estimated week of gestation if the measured fundal height is at the navel? 20 weeks"
"What is the likely diagnosis? Cellulitis"
"What is the likely diagnosis? Scabies"
"What is the likely diagnosis? Toxic epidermal necrolysis"
"What is the likely diagnosis? Molluscum contagiosum"
"What birth weight is considered macrosomia? > 4000 to 4500 grams (or 9 to 10 pounds)"
"Before which gestational age should betamethasone (BMZ) always be given to mothers admitted to labour & delivery? Before 36 weeks 6 days"
"What is the most common etiology of spontaneous abortion (SAB)? Fetal chromosomal abnormalities (~60%)"
"How does prior C-section and placenta previa change the risk of placenta accreta? Increase"
"Placenta accreta occurs when placental villi attach directly onto the myometrium"
"What are Braxton Hicks contractions? Uterine contractions w/o cervical changes"
"What is the classic triad of signs of placental separation (during delivery)? Cord lengthening Gushing of vaginal blood Uterine fundal rebound"
"What is the nitrazine test for rupture of membranes (ROM)? pH indication of amniotic fluid; alkaline amniotic fluid turns it blue"
"What are the three tests for rupture of membranes (ROM)? Vaginal pooling via speculum exam Nitrazine on vaginal fluid Ferning test on vaginal fluid"
"What are the \3 P's\\" for the causes of abnormal labor? Power (uterine contractions) Passenger (fetus) Passage (pelvis)\""
"What is the cause of late FHR decelerations? Uteroplacental insufficiency and insufficient fetal blood flow/oxygenation"
"What constitutes a reactive nonstress test (NST)? 2 FHR accelerations in 20 minutes"
"What is the contraindication for Prostaglandin F2alpha (hemabate) in postpartum hemorrhage? Asthma"
"What is the most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB)? Anovulatory cycles"
"What is the most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in postmenopausal women? Atrophic vaginitis"
"What malignancy must be ruled out in all postmenopausal women with uterine bleeding? Endometrial carcinoma"
"What is the treatment for anovulatory bleeding? Medroxyprogesterone acetate (Provera) or OCPs"
"What procedure offers a definitive diagnosis for endometriosis? Diagnostic laparoscopy"
"Which antidiabetic is used to treat infertility in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)? Metformin"
"What class of drugs is known to prevent ovarian cancer? OCPs"
"How is ectopic pregnancy diagnosed? Quantitative β-hCG Ultrasound::Two diagnostic steps"
"What is the medical treatment for ectopic pregnancy? Methotrexate"
"What is the only IUD that can increase bleeding? Paraguard (copper IUD)"
"Which imaging study is most sensitive for pyloric stenosis? Ultrasound"
"What is the diagnosis in an infant with an omega-shaped epiglottis and collapse of the supraglottic structures during inspiration? It is improved by placing the infant in the prone position. Laryngomalacia MCC of chronic stridor in infants"
"Follicular conjunctivitis and pannus (neovascularization) formation in the cornea are seen with trachoma"
"What is the most important first step in management for patients with Somatic Symptom Disorder? Schedule regular monthly visits to establish a single physician as the primary caregiver"
"A young pt presents w/ cough, wheezing, and dyspnea. His PMHx is significant for allergic rhinitis, nasal polyps, and eczema. Physical exam reveals wheezing in the BL upper lobes and a prolonged expiratory phase. What is the most likely Dx? Asthma"
"What is the best diagnostic test for asthma? PFTs"
"Which antipsychotic medication occasionally causes hypothermia by disrupting thermoregulation and the body's shivering mechanism? Fluphenazine"
"What cause of infectious, nonbloody diarrhea (w/o WBC in the stool) is associated with camping/hiking and unfiltered fresh water? Giardia lamblia"
"What is the management for patellofemoral pain syndrome in the recovery phase? PT and strength training with cycling::2"
"The most likely atypical antipsychotic to cause tardive dyskinesia is risperidone, and the least likely is clozapine"
"What is the treatment for viral gastroenteritis? Rehydration (PO preferred, IV if not possible) Loperamide::2"
"ASCUS and HPV (+) -- what is best next step? Colposcopy"
"How many stools should a baby produce over 24 hours? 3-4 Wet diapers? 6"
"What hormone stimulates milk letdown? Oxytocin What is it stimulated by? Suckling"
"What is respiratory depression in pt on MgSO4 a sign of? Mag toxicity What should be done? Stop Mag, start Ca gluconate"
"Does cleavage of SNARE via tetanus toxin prevent release of excitatory or inhibitory neurotransmitters? Inhibitory (thus causing spastic paralysis)"
"Treatment for tetanus includes antitoxin +/- vaccine booster; may also give diazepam for muscle spasms and debride the wound"

"What do you call cheese by itself? Prov-ALONE"
"Why did the can crusher quit his job? It was SODA PRESSING"
"What do you call a fake noodle? An IMPASTA!"
"Good luck studying for your shelf or step 2 or whatever exam it may be! If you score well - congratulations! If your score isn't quite what you had hoped, congratulate yourself on how hard you worked and know that life will find a way to work itself out. Medical student and physician depression/suicide is a major epidemic that isn't talked about enough. If you think someone you know is feeling down, ask how they're doing! If you're feeling down, please don't be afraid to ask for help. I hope you have found these decks useful. May your medical career have many successes. With love, Zanki :')"
"The axillary nerve may be injured by a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus"
"The median nerve may be injured by a supracondylar fracture of the humerus"
"The ulnar nerve may be injured by a fracture of the medial epicondyle of the humerus"
"The ulnar nerve may be injured by a fracture of the hook of hamate from a fall on an outstretched hand"
"Which lower limb nerve provides sensory innervation to the area between the 1st and 2nd toes? Deep peroneal nerve"
"Which lower limb nerve provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot? Superficial peroneal nerve"
"What nerve provides sensory innervation to the anterior and lateral thigh? Lateral femoral cutaneous"
"What nerve provides sensory innervation to the medial thigh? Obturator nerve"
"What nerve provides sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg? Femoral"
"What nerve provides cutaneous innervation to the sole of the foot? Tibial"
"What movements are lost with tibial nerve lesion? inversion and plantar flexion"
"What nerve injury results in difficulty climbing stairs and rising from a seated position (loss of hip extension)? Inferior gluteal nerve injury"
"What is the next step for blunt abdominal trauma in a hemodynamically unstable patient with a positive FAST examination (e.g. free intraperitoneal fluid)? Exploratory laparotomy"
"What imaging modality is useful for hemodynamically stable patients with blunt abdominal trauma and a positive FAST exam? CT scan of the abdomen"
"Is bursitis characterized by pain with active or passive range of motion? Active ROM"
"What bacteria is typically responsible for acute prepatellar bursitis? Staphylococcus aureus"
"If gram stain and culture of bursal fluid in a patient with prepatellar bursitis is negative, what is the next step in management? NSAIDs and activity modification"
"If gram stain and culture of bursal fluid in a patient with prepatellar bursitis is positive, what is the next step in management? Drainage and systemic antibiotics"
"Is septic arthritis characterized by pain with active or passive range of motion? Both active and passive ROM"
"Which type of shock is characterized by decreased central venous pressure (CVP) and cardiac output? Hypovolemic shock"
"Positive pressure mechanical ventilation causes an acute increase::increase/decrease in intrathoracic pressure, which decreases RV preload by compressing the IVC"
"What are the most common peripheral artery aneurysms? popliteal (#1) and femoral (#2)"
"What is next step for blunt abdominal trauma with GI perforation identified on CT? Exploratory laparotomy"
"Blunt abdominal trauma may result in damage to the mesenteric blood supply, leading to subsequent necrosis and eventual GI perforation"
"What is a common complication of glucocorticoid use? Osteonecrosis (avascular necorsis)"
"Patients with scaphoid fractures should have their wrists immobilized and monitored with serial X-rays to rule out osteonecrosis"
"Fracture of which wrist bone is often complicated by osteonecrosis? Scaphoid"
"Fracture of which wrist bone is often complicated by median nerve compression? Lunate"
"The medial border of the \anatomic snuffbox\\" is bounded by the extensor pollicis longus\""
"The lateral border of the \anatomic snuffbox\\" is bounded by the extensor pollicis brevis and the abductor pollicis longus\""
"What is the next step for a ruptured ovarian cyst with hemoperitoneum in a hemodynamically unstable patient? Ex-lap/laparoscopy"
"Physical examination of a ruptured ovarian cyst shows unilateral lower quadrant tenderness +/- hemoperitoneum"
"Succinylcholine works by binding to post-synaptic ACh receptors, triggering an influx of Na+ and efflux of K+ (depolarization)"
"What type of neuromuscular blocking agent should be used in patients with upregulated post-synaptic ACh receptors (e.g. skeletal muscle trauma, burn injury, stroke)? Non-depolarizing agents (e.g. vecuronium, rocuronium)"
"What anesthetic is associated with neurotoxicity in patients with vitamin B12 deficiency? Nitrous oxide"
"What demographic is most commonly associated with umbilical hernia? African-American infants"
"Does gastroschisis typically require surgical intervention? Yes (surgical emergency)"
"Does omphalocele typically require surgical intervention? Yes (surgical emergency)"
"Gastroschisis is characterized by protrusion of bright red intestines to the right side of a normal umbilicus (direction)"
"What abdominal mass presents in newborns as a soft, moist, pink, pedunculated lesion after the umbilical cord has separated? Umbilical granuloma"
"What is the treatment of choice for umbilical granuloma? Silver nitrate"
"Which metatarsal is most commonly injured by stress fractures? 2nd metatarsal"
"Which metatarsal has an increased risk for non-union following a stress fracture, thus requiring more aggressive treatment? 5th metatarsal"
"What major artery must be examined for injury following a clavicular fracture? Subclavian artery"
"What nerve bundle must be examined for injury following a clavicular fracture? Brachial plexus"
"Are fractures of the middle-third of the clavicle typically treated operatively? No"
"Is post-operative ileus characterized by a clear transition point on abdominal X-ray? No"
"Is small-bowel obstruction characterized by a clear transition point on abdominal X-ray? Yes"
"What vital signs (BP, HR) are concerning for hemorrhage following blunt abdominal or thoracic trauma? Hypotension and/or tachycardia"
"What is the most sensitive test for diagnosis of MCL tear? MRI"
"What is the non-operative management for uncomplicated MCL tears? Analgesics and RICE (rest, ice, compression, elevation)"
"MCL tear is characterized by medial knee tenderness and valgus::valgus or varus laxity on physical exam"
"What is the likely cause of gastric outlet obstruction in a patient with a history of acid ingestion? Pyloric stricture"
"Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction produces recurrent, episodic pain in the right upper quadrant or epigastric region with elevations in AST/ALT/ALP"
"What is the gold standard for diagnosis of sphincter of Oddi dysfunction? Sphincter of Oddi manometry"
"What is the treatment of choice for sphincter of Oddi dysfunction? Sphincterotomy"
"What nerve is at risk for injury with supracondylar fracture of the humerus? Median nerve"
"What artery is at risk for injury with supracondylar fracture of the humerus? Brachial artery"
"What is a common early clinical feature of compartment syndrome? Paresthesia (pins/needles)"
"Which organs (2) are most commonly injured with blunt abdominal trauma? liver and spleen"
"What is the most likely diagnosis for a hard, immobile mass on the hard palate of a young individual? Torus palatinus (benign bony growth)"
"What is the best initial step in the management of a hemodynamically stable patient with hemoptysis and a high clinical suspicion for tuberculosis? Respiratory isolation"
"Diaphragmatic rupture is more common on the patient's left side"
"What imaging modality can confirm the diagnosis of diaphragmatic rupture in patients with suggestive X-ray findings? CT scan (chest, abdomen)"
"Reactivation of which virus is associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma? EBV"
"Early spread of nasopharyngeal carcinoma to the cervical lymph nodes is common"
"Which region of the bladder may cause chemical peritonitis if ruptured by blunt trauma? Dome of the bladder"
"Extraperitoneal bladder injury is associated with pelvic fracture and manifests as localized pain and gross hematuria"
"How does PaCO2 change in patients with atelectasis? Decreased"
"Symptoms of atelectasis (e.g. dyspnea, tachypnea) typically manifest on post-operative day 2 and 3"
"Pre-operative smoking cessation should occur at least 8 week(s) prior to surgery"
"What breathing instrument is useful for preventing post-operative atelectasis? Incentive spirometer"
"Epidural hematoma occurs due to sphenoid bone trauma with laceration of the middle meningeal artery::vasculature"
"What is the first step in the management of a necrotizing surgical site infection? Surgical exploration and debridement"
"Necrotizing surgical site infections are usually poly::mono- or poly-microbial"
"What acid-base disturbance typically occurs with acute mesenteric ischemia? Metabolic acidosis (elevated lactate)"
"What is the most likely diagnosis given a patient with swollen, erythematous skin, pain out of proportion to physical exam, systemic signs such as hypotension/fever, and the CT findings below? Necrotizing fasciitis"
"Patients who develop ischemic colitis often have extensive underlying atherosclerotic disease"
"CT findings indicative of ischemic colitis include colonic wall thickening (edema) and fat stranding"
"What hip movement worsens the pain associated with a hip septic arthritis? Hip flexion::flexion or extension"
"What imaging modality is used for diagnosis of a psoas abscess? CT scan of abdomen/pelvis"
"How does preload (RA pressure or PCWP) change in hypovolemic shock? Decreased"
"How does cardiac index change in hypovolemic shock? Decreased"
"How does afterload (SVR) change in hypovolemic shock? Increased"
"How does preload (RA pressure or PCWP) change in cardiogenic shock? Increased"
"How does cardiac index change in cardiogenic shock? Decreased"
"How does afterload (SVR) change in cardiogenic shock? Increased"
"How does afterload (SVR) change in septic shock? Decreased"
"Which type of shock is characterized by increased mixed venous O2 saturation (MvO2)? Septic shock"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with a perforated viscus? Urgent exploratory laparotomy"
"What is the fluid of choice to restore volume quickly in the management of septic shock? IV 0.9% saline (crystalloid)"
"What Staphylococcus species is typically the cause of delayed-onset (3-12 months) prosthetic joint infection? S. epidermidis"
"Which Staphylococcus species is typically the cause of acute-onset (< 3 months) prosthetic joint infection? S. aureus"
"What is the next step in management of a patient with diverticulitis complicated by an abscess < 3 cm? IV antibiotics and observation"
"The differential diagnosis for an anterior mediastinal mass includes the \4 Ts\\": Thyroid neoplasm Thymic neoplasm Teratoma (and other germ cell tumors) Terrible lymphoma\""
"Seminomatous germ cell tumors often present with normal AFP and normal β-HCG levels"
"Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors often present with elevated AFP and elevated β-HCG levels"
"What post-gastrectomy complication presents with GI and vasomotor symptoms? Dumping syndrome"
"What imaging modality should be used to confirm placement of a central venous catheter tip? Chest X-ray"
"What is the ideal placement for a central venous catheter tip? Lower superior vena cava"
"What is the first step in the management of cervical spinal trauma? Spine immobilization"
"What imaging modality is best for confirming a meniscal tear? MRI"
"What is the management for a young patient with persistent symptoms due to a meniscal tear? Surgery (after evaluation by MRI)"
"What is the management for older and/or mildly symptomatic patients with meniscal tears? Rest/activity modification"
"Which tibial pathology presents with a diffuse area of tenderness on palpation? Shin splints (medial tibial stress syndrome)::Shin splints/Stress fracture"
"Which tibial pathology, shin splints or stress fracture, presents with a point tenderness on palpation? Stress fracture"
"Which tibial pathology is more common in underweight individuals? Stress fracture::Shin splints/Stress fracture"
"Immediately after a severe burn, most infections are due to gram-positive organisms"
"After > 5 days following a severe burn, most infections are due to gram-negative organisms or fungi"
"Change in appearance of a burn wound or loss of a viable skin graft is often the earliest sign of wound infection"
"Aortoiliac occlusion (Leriche syndrome) is characterized by a triad of bilateral hip, thigh, and buttock claudication, impotence, and absent/diminished femoral pulses"
"What is the most common cause of primary hypoparathyroidism? Post-surgical"
"What is the most common non-surgical cause of primary hypoparathyroidism? Autoimmune"
"What is the underlying cause of hypocalcemia in a patient with hyperphosphatemia and normal renal function? Hypoparathyroidism"
"What is the initial screening test for blunt aortic trauma? Chest X-ray"
"What is the most sensitive finding indicative of blunt aortic trauma? Mediastinal widening"
"What is the next step in management of a patient with migratory abdominal pain, McBurney point tenderness, nausea/vomiting, fever, and leukocytosis? Laparoscopic appendectomy"
"Varicoceles are due to tortuous dilation of the pampiniform plexus of veins surrounding the spermatic cord and testis"
"Varicoceles increase in size with standing and Valsalva maneuvers"
"Initial hematuria is suggestive of urethral damage"
"Terminal hematuria is suggestive of bladder or prostatic damage"
"Total hematuria is suggestive of kidney or ureter damage"
"What imaging modality is used to confirm a rotator cuff tear? MRI"
"What is the most common location for anal fissures? Posterior midline"
"What three symptoms make up the Cushing's reflex/triad? hypertension, bradycardia, and respiratory depression"
"What nerve provides sensation to the anterior thigh and medial leg? Femoral nerve (saphenous branch)"
"What nerve provides sensation to the dorsum of the foot? Superficial peroneal (fibular) nerve"
"What nerve is responsible for foot eversion and dorsiflexion? Peroneal (fibular) nerve"
"What nerve provides sensation to the area between the 1st and 2nd toes? Deep peroneal (fibular) nerve"
"What nerve provides sensation to the sole of the foot? Tibial nerve"
"What preventive measures are useful for preventing post-operative acute bacterial parotitis? Adequate fluid hydration and oral hygiene"
"Does anterior cord syndrome result in loss of vibration and proprioception? No"
"Does anterior cord syndrome result in loss of pain and temperature? Yes"
"Anterior cord syndrome initially presents with bilateral flaccid::spastic or flaccid paralysis"
"What is the initial step in the management of an uncomplicated small-bowel obstruction? Conservative (bowel rest; nasogastric tube suction; IV fluids)"

"Are penile fractures typically managed medically or surgically? Surgically"
"What is the initial treatment for prerenal acute kidney injury in patients with evidence of hypovolemia? IV fluid bolus"
"What imaging modality is used to determine the need for urgent surgical intervention in patients with ischemic colitis (e.g. extensive bowel damage, perforation)? CT scan"

"What nerve is most commonly damaged during an axillary lymphadenectomy? Long thoracic nerve"

"Management of a duodenal hematoma typically involves gastric decompression (NG tube) +/- parenteral nutrition"

"What is the initial management for a large pneumothorax in a hemodynamically stable patient? Needle decompression"

"What imaging modality is typically used to diagnose acute cholecystitis? Ultrasound"
"When should patients with uncomplicated biliary colic have a cholecystectomy? Electively"

"Platelet counts > 50,000/mm3 provide adequate hemostasis"

"Are most cases of urethral injury treated with immediate or delayed surgical repair? Delayed"

"In addition to antibiotics, risk factors for C. difficile colitis include age > 65 and PPI use"

"The most common causes of acute liver failure are drug toxicity and acute viral hepatitis"

"The diagnosis of carcinoid syndrome can be confirmed by elevated 24-hour urinary 5-HIAA in most patients"
"Carcinoid tumors are typically not symptomatic until they've metastasized to the liver (i.e. carcinoid syndrome)"

"What is the colonoscopy screening recommendation for patients with inflammatory bowel disease? Begin 8 years post-diagnosis; repeat q1-2y"

"Duodenal ulcers are characterized by pain that improves with eating (improves or worsens)"

"What anti-hypertensive medication is associated with dry cough? ACE inhibitors"
"The modified Wells criteria is used to assess pretest probability of acute pulmonary embolism"
"A modified Wells score > 4 suggests that pulmonary embolism is likely"
"What medications should be administered to patients with severe asthma exacerbation? inhaled short-acting β2 agonists, inhaled ipratropium, systemic corticosteroids"
"If a patient with airway obstruction has significant reversal of symptoms with an inhaled bronchodilator, they likely have asthma::asthma or COPD"
"The primary long-term intervention for persistent asthma is daily inhaled corticosteroids"
"The primary long-term intervention for COPD is a daily long-acting anticholinergic inhaler"
"Oxygenation, and thus PaO2, in mechanically ventilated patients may be improved by increasing the FiO2 or PEEP"

"What test/imaging study should be ordered first to evaluate an older patient with a 30 pack-year smoking history and recurrent episodes of pneumonia in the same anatomic location? CT scan of chest"
"Which type of pleural effusion, exudative or transudative, is commonly caused by decreased plasma oncotic pressure or elevated hydrostatic pressure? Transudative"
"Which type of pleural effusion, exudative or transudative, is commonly caused by increased capillary permeability or disruption to lymphatic outflow? Exudative"
"Exudative pleural effusions are characterized by a(n) > 0.5 (high) pleural/serum protein ratio"
"Transudative pleural effusions are characterized by < 0.6 (low) pleural/serum LDH ratio"
"Exudative pleural effusions are characterized by > 0.6 (high) pleural/serum LDH ratio"
"Which type of parapneumonic effusion, uncomplicated or complicated, is characterized by pH > 7.2? Uncomplicated"
"Which type of parapneumonic effusion, uncomplicated or complicated, is characterized by pH < 7.2? Complicated"

"Which type of parapneumonic effusion, uncomplicated or complicated, is characterized by glucose < 60 mg/dL? Complicated"

"What is the general treatment for complicated parapneumonic effusion? Antibiotics and drainage (e.g. chest tube)"
"Which type of parapneumonic effusion is characterized by low pH, low glucose, and positive gram stain & culture? Empyema"
"What asthma severity is characterized by SABA use ≤ 2 days a week with ≤ 2 nighttime awakenings a month? Intermittent"
"What is the recommended treatment regimen for patients with intermittent asthma? Short-acting β2-agonist as needed"
"What asthma severity is characterized by SABA use > 2 days a week (not daily) with 3-4 nighttime awakenings a month? Mild persistent"
"What is the recommended treatment regimen for patients with mild persistent asthma? daily low-dose inhaled corticosteroid and SABA as needed"
"What asthma severity is characterized by SABA use daily with >1 nighttime awakening a week (not nightly)? Moderate persistent"
"What is the recommended treatment regimen for patients with moderate persistent asthma? daily long-acting β2-agonist, daily low-dose ICS, SABA as needed"
"What paraneoplastic syndrome presents with euvolemic hyponatremia? SIADH"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with COPD who develops sudden-onset dyspnea and chest pain with unilaterally decreased breath sounds (no tracheal deviation)? Secondary spontaneous pneumothorax"
"The three most common causes of chronic cough are upper-airway cough syndrome (postnasal drip), asthma, and GERD"
"The diagnosis of upper-airway cough syndrome (postnasal drip) is confirmed by elimination of nasal discharge and cough with the use of first-generation H1 receptor antagonists (e.g. chlorpheniramine)"
"What is the most significant risk factor for tuberculosis in the U.S.? Emigration from an endemic area"
"Patients with COPD who have resting PaO2 < 55 mmHg::units or SaO2 < 88%::units are candidates for long-term home O2 treatment"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with recurrent episodes of bacterial infection, purulent sputum, hemoptysis, and digital clubbing? Bronchiectasis"
"What asthma medication may cause CNS stimulation, cardiac arrhythmia, and GI disturbances as possible side effects? Theophylline"
"The pathogenesis of bronchiectasis involves a(n) infectious insult with impaired bacterial clearance"
"What test/imaging study is the best diagnostic test for bronchiectasis? High-resolution CT (HRCT) scan of the chest"
"What is the underlying etiology for aspiration pneumonia in patients with impaired consciousness and/or advanced dementia? impaired swallowing and cough reflex"
"When using a ventilator, prolonged FiO2 levels > 60% are associated with oxygen toxicity"
"When using a ventilator, the goal is to keep SpO2 between 88 - 95%"
"When using a ventilator, the goal is to keep PaO2 between 55 - 80 mmHg"
"Mechanical ventilation in patients with ARDS should use low tidal volumes and high PEEP (low or high)"
"How does lung compliance change in patients with ARDS? Decreased"
"How does pulmonary arterial pressure change in patients with ARDS? Increased (pulmonary hypertension)"
"What is the likely diagnosis given the flow-volume loop below? Fixed upper airway obstruction (e.g. laryngeal edema)"
"The flow-volume loop shifts to the left in patients with obstructive::obstructive or restrictive lung disease"
"The flow-volume loop shifts to the right in patients with restrictive::obstructive or restrictive lung disease"
"What is the likely underlying etiology of hypoxemia in patient with respiratory acidosis and normal A-a gradient? Hypoventilation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with repeated episodes of fever, dyspnea, and cough after exposure to environmental antigens (e.g. bird droppings, molds)? Hypersensitivity pneumonitis"
"What is the best treatment for hypersensitivity pneumonitis? Avoidance of the responsible antigen"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with PMHx of Hodgkin lymphoma status-post chemotherapy/radiation who presents with cough, dyspnea, and chest pain (imaging below)? Secondary malignancy"
"What bacteria is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia? Streptococcus pneumoniae"
"What imaging modality is typically used to diagnose pneumonia? Chest X-ray"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient on high-doses of β2 agonists (e.g. albuterol, epinephrine) who develops muscle weakness? Hypokalemia"
"An endotracheal tube that is advanced too far will preferentially enter into the right::left or right mainstem bronchus"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a smoker with a chronic productive cough for multiple years without fever, weight loss, or dyspnea? Chronic bronchitis"
"Chronic bronchitis is defined as a chronic productive cough for > 3 months in 2 successive years"
"What is the underlying etiology of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease? aspirin-induced prostaglandin/leukotriene imbalance"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with anosmia, bronchospasm and nasal congestion following aspirin ingestion? Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD)"
"What is the best initial step in management for a stabilized patient with likely PE (modified Wells criteria) who has no absolute contraindications to anticoagulation? Begin anticoagulation (e.g. IV heparin)"
"What is the best initial step in management for a stabilized patient with unlikely PE (modified Wells criteria) who has no absolute contraindications to anticoagulation? Obtain diagnostic test (e.g. D-dimer assay)"
"What is the best initial step in management for a stabilized patient with suspected PE who has absolute contraindications to anticoagulation? Obtain diagnostic test (e.g. CT angiography)"
"What is the next step in management for a smoker with progressive dyspnea, weight loss, and evidence of pleural effusion on CXR? Diagnostic thoracentesis"
"Patients with COPD have an increased work of breathing due to a(n) flattened diaphragm"
"What is the most common adverse effect associated with inhaled corticosteroids? Oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush)"
"What is the first-line therapy for obesity hypoventilation syndrome? Nocturnal positive-pressure ventilation"
"Treatment of invasive aspergillosis often involves IV voriconazole and an echinocandin (e.g. caspofungin)"
"What pneumonia complication is characterized by frank pus or bacteria in the pleural space? Empyema"
"What is the next step in management for a solitary pulmonary nodule discovered on routine CXR in a patient with no previous imaging? CT scan of chest"
"What type of pleural effusion, transudative or exudative, is commonly seen with pulmonary embolism? Exudative (typically a small, bloody effusion)"
"How does the A - a gradient change in patients with pulmonary embolism? Increased (V/Q mismatch)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with previous TB infection who presents with months of weight loss, fatigue, and hemoptysis without night sweats, fever, or chest pain (imaging below)? Chronic pulmonary aspergillosis"
"What is the first-line treatment for patients with exercise-induced bronchoconstriction who exercise a few times per week? Short-acting β-agonists 10-20 minutes before exercise"
"What is the first-line treatment for patients with exercise-induced bronchoconstriction who exercise daily? Inhaled corticosteroids or anti-leukotriene agents 10-20 minutes before exercise"
"Consolidation of the lung results in increased tactile fremitus, and dullness to percussion (e.g. lobar pneumonia)"
"Pneumothorax and emphysema result in decreased breath sounds, decreased tactile fremitus, and hyperresonance to percussion"
"Goodpasture's disease is characterized by antibodies against glomerular and alveolar basement membranes"
"Renal biopsy showing linear IgG antibodies along the glomerular basement membrane is diagnostic for Goodpasture's disease"
"What is the best treatment to minimize the development of life-threatening complications in patients with anaphylaxis (e.g. hypotension, upper airway edema)? Intramuscular epinephrine 1:1000 (1 mg/mL)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient who smokes and has coronary artery disease that presents with shortness of breath, bibasilar crackles, low CO2 and respiratory alkalosis? CHF exacerbation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a plumber with months of progressive dyspnea, bibasilar crackles, and clubbing? Asbestosis"
"What chest imaging finding is virtually pathognomonic for asbestosis? Pleural plaques"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with significant smoking history that presents with shortness of breath, bilateral wheezing, high CO2 and respiratory acidosis? COPD exacerbation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young woman with shortness of breath and the CXR findings below? Sarcoidosis"
"The underlying histopathologic lesion of sarcoidosis is non-caseating granulomas on tissue biopsy"
"What is the likely cause of leukocytosis with neutrophilic predominance in a patient being treated for asthma exacerbation? Glucocorticoid side effect"
"Obstructive lung disease is characterized by an FEV1/FVC ratio < 70% of predicted"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an immigrant with progressive dyspnea, orthopnea, palpitations, and an elevated left main bronchus on CXR? Rheumatic heart disease"
"The initial pathophysiology of a massive PE involves dilation and hypokinesis of the right ventricle with subsequent dysfunction"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young woman with exertional dyspnea and enlargement of the pulmonary arteries and right ventricle on CXR? Primary pulmonary hypertension"
"Features of a high-risk solitary pulmonary nodule include size > 2 cm, age > 60, and smoking cessation within the last 5 years (or current smoker)"
