"Features of an intermediate-risk solitary pulmonary nodule include size 0.8 - 2 cm, age 40 - 60, and smoking cessation within the last 5 - 15 years (or current smoker)"
"Features of a low-risk solitary pulmonary nodule include size < 0.8 cm, age < 40, and smoking cessation for > 15 years (or never smoked)"
"What is the recommended management after chest CT for solitary pulmonary nodules with high malignancy risk? Surgical excision"
"What is the recommended management after chest CT for solitary pulmonary nodules < 8 mm with low to intermediate malignancy risk? Serial CT scan"
"What is the recommended management after chest CT for solitary pulmonary nodules > 8 mm with low to intermediate malignancy risk? FDG-PET showing high metabolic activity or biopsy"
"Bradycardia, hypoventilation, and decreased shivering are associated with moderate::severity hypothermia"
"Tachycardia, tachypnea, and increased shivering are associated with mild::severity hypothermia"
"Coma and cardiovascular collapse are associated with severe::severity hypothermia"
"What warming technique is best for patients with mild hypothermia? Passive external warming"
"What warming technique is best for patients with moderate hypothermia? Active external warming"
"What warming technique is best for patients with severe hypothermia? Active internal warming"
"In addition to rewarming techniques, hypotensive patients with hypothermia should receive warmed IV fluids"
"In mechanically ventilated patients, peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) is equal to the sum of resistive pressure and plateau pressure"
"In mechanically ventilated patients, an increased peak pressure with an unchanged plateau pressure suggests increased airway resistance"
"In mechanically ventilated patients, an increased peak pressure with an increased plateau pressure suggests decreased compliance"
"Ventilation, and thus PaCO2, in mechanically ventilated patients may be altered by changing either respiratory rate or tidal volume"
"In general, tidal volumes in mechanically ventilated patients should be about 6 ml/kg of ideal body weight"
"What ventilator setting change is best to improve respiratory alkalosis in a 70 kg patient with respiratory alkalosis with the following settings: FiO2: 40% PEEP: 5 mmHg VT: 450 mL RR: 18/min Decrease RR"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and dextrocardia? Kartagener syndrome (primary ciliary dyskinesia)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an infant with upper respiratory symptoms, wheezing/crackles, and respiratory distress? Bronchiolitis"
"Infants age < 2 months with bronchiolitis are at high risk of developing apnea and/or respiratory failure"
"An infant with a fever, runny nose, and cough has the X-ray findings below. What does the arrow on the CXR point to? Thymus"
"What is the next step in management for a young patient who is taking PPIs and presents with chronic nocturnal cough without post-nasal drip, fever, dyspnea, weight loss, or response to H1 blockers? Pulmonary function tests"
"Chronic bronchitis-predominant COPD is characterized by a(n) normal DLCO"
"Emphysema-predominant COPD is characterized by a(n) low DLCO"
"The CURB-65 criteria helps guide treatment and treatment location for patients with community-acquired pneumonia: C: Confusion U: Urea > 20 mg/dL R: Respirations > 30/min B: Blood pressure (systolic < 90 or diastolic < 60 mmHg) 65: Age ≥ 65"
"What is the recommended empiric treatment for healthy patients with community-acquired pneumonia in an outpatient setting? macrolide or doxycycline"
"What is the recommended empiric treatment for patients with community-acquired pneumonia in an inpatient setting? Respiratory fluoroquinolone (e.g. moxifloxacin) or β-lactam and macrolide (IV)"
"What type of pleural effusion, transudative or exudative, is characterized by pH 7.40 - 7.55? Transudative"
"What type of pleural effusion, transudative or exudative, is characterized by pH 7.30 - 7.45? Exudative"
"What is the most important risk factor for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome? Prematurity"
"What maternal pathology is associated with increased risk for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome? Maternal diabetes"
"What is the recommended management for amniotic fluid embolism syndrome? Supportive (e.g. respiratory, hemodynamic support)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an unvaccinated child with high fever, drooling, and respiratory distress? Epiglottitis (H. influenza type b)"
"What is the initial treatment for a child with severe respiratory distress and signs of epiglottitis? Endotracheal intubation"
"Patients with hypovolemia often have decreased levels of urine sodium"
"What fungal infection typically occurs in patients exposed to soil contaminated by bird or bat droppings (e.g. caves)? Histoplasma capsulatum"
"How do the following pressures change with pulmonary embolism? RA pressure: increased Pulmonary artery pressure: increased LA wedge pressure: decreased"
"How does the A - a gradient change in patients with a decreased DLCO? Increased"
"Antibiotics should be given to patients with COPD exacerbation if they have an increase in ≥ 2 of the following symptoms: dyspnea, cough, or sputum production (cardinal symptoms)"
"What is the recommended management for solitary pulmonary nodules with stable size and appearance for over 2-3 years on imaging? Reassurance; no further testing required"
"The presence of digital clubbing in patients with COPD should prompt a search for occult malignancy"
"The most common causes of secondary digital clubbing are lung malignancy, cystic fibrosis, and right-to-left cardiac shunts"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an obese patient with daytime somnolence, morning headaches, and normal daytime CO2? Obstructive sleep apnea"
"What is the diagnostic test for obstructive sleep apnea? Nocturnal polysomnography"
"What is the next step in management for a young patient who presents with chronic nocturnal cough with a sensation of liquid dripping into the back of the throat? Oral first-generation H1 blocker"
"What type of V/Q mismatch may occur in patients with pneumonia? Right-to-left intrapulmonary shunt"
"Does hypoxemia secondary to intrapulmonary shunt correct with supplemental O2? No"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a euvolemic patient with low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality? SIADH"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a euvolemic patient with low serum osmolality and low urine osmolality (< 100)? Primary polydipsia"
"What ventilator setting change is best for a 65 kg patient with the following ABG and the ventilator settings: pH: 7.42 PaO2: 105 mmHg PaCO2: 37 mmHg FiO2: 80% PEEP: 7 mmHg VT: 380 mL RR: 14/min Decrease FiO2"
"Normal or high PaCO2 in a patient with an acute asthma exacerbation is suggestive of impending respiratory failure"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with acute COPD exacerbation with continued symptoms despite medical management? Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with acute COPD exacerbation who fails to improve after non-invasive positive pressure ventilation? Tracheal intubation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with pneumonia that presents with continued symptoms despite adequate antibiotic coverage and loculation on CXR? Complicated parapneumonic effusion"
"What physiologic change helps compensate for chronic respiratory acidosis and hypercapnia in patients with COPD, sleep apnea, or obesity hypoventilation syndrome? Increased renal HCO3- retention"
"Which part of the mediastinum are thymomas usually found? Anterior mediastinum::anterior, middle, posterior"
"Which part of the mediastinum are neurogenic tumors usually found? Posterior mediastinum::anterior, middle, posterior"
"What is the most common malignancy diagnosed in patients exposed to asbestos? Bronchogenic carcinoma"
"What risk factor acts synergistically with asbestos to increase risk of lung cancer? Smoking"
"What is the pathophysiologic mechanism underlying worsening hypoxemia when a patient with lobar pneumonia lies on the affected side? Increased intrapulmonary shunting"
"How do RBC levels change in patients with obstructive sleep apnea and obesity hypoventilation syndrome? Increased (secondary erythrocytosis)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient with chronic nasal congestion and dry cough without an identifiable trigger, eye symptoms, itching, or sneezing? Non-allergic rhinitis"
"What is the initial management for patients with non-allergic rhinitis? Intranasal antihistamine or glucocorticoids"
"Which type of lung cancer is associated with Cushing's syndrome (ectopic ACTH) and SIADH? Small cell carcinoma"
"What type of V/Q mismatch is worsened in COPD patients with O2-induced CO2 retention? Dead space"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young male with dyspnea on exertion accompanied by chronic lower back pain that is worse at night and improves with exercise? Ankylosing spondylitis"
"What is the underlying cause of low glucose in complicated parapneumonic effusions? High metabolic activity of leukocytes and/or bacteria"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with lethargy and asterixis with the laboratory findings below? BUN: 78 mg/dL Albumin: 3.8 g/dL AST: 38 U/L ALT: 44 U/L Creatine kinase: 32,000 U/L Uremic encephalopathy"
"Common causes of asterixis include hepatic encephalopathy, uremic encephalopathy, and hypercapnia"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient on RIPE therapy for tuberculosis who presents with painless \red\\" urine? Drug reaction\""
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with anasarca, pulmonary edema, hematuria, and proteinuria (1+)? Acute nephritic syndrome"
"Patients with acute nephritic syndrome develop edema due to glomerular damage, resulting in decreased GFR and increased Na+/H2O retention"
"What is the best test to screen for the initial stages of diabetic nephropathy? Urine test for microalbumin:creatinine ratio"
"What is the initial step in management for a post-operative patient with acute renal failure and oliguria (< 250 mL urine in 12 hours)? Bedside bladder scan to assess for urinary retention"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a middle-aged patient with chronic renal failure, a palpable right flank mass, and an enlarged liver? Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)"
"Drugs with anti-cholinergic properties can cause urinary retention by preventing detrusor muscle contraction and urinary sphincter relaxation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient taking a TCA that develops abdominal pain and suprapubic fullness? Urinary retention"
"What is the long-term treatment for severe hypercalcemia (> 14mg/dL or symptomatic)? bisphosphonates (e.g. zoledronic acid, pamidronate)"
"What formula is used to calculate the anion gap in patients with metabolic acidosis? AG = (Na+) - (HCO3- + Cl-)"
"Common causes of high anion gap (> 12 mEq/L) metabolic acidosis may be remembered with the mnemonic \MUDPILES\\": M: Methanol U: Uremia D: Diabetic ketoacidosis P: Propylene glycol I: Iron tablets or Isoniazid L: Lactic acidosis E: Ethylene glycol (oxalic acid accumulation) S: Salicylates (late; respiratory alkalosis early)\""
"Calcium gluconate or IV insulin with glucose is typically reserved for hyperkalemia in patients with ECG changes, K+ > 6.5 mEq, or rapidly rising K+"
"What classes of anti-hypertensive drugs are associated with hyperkalemia? ACE inhibitors and ARBs"
"What class of autonomic drugs are associated with hyperkalemia? Non-selective β-blockers"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with an elevated serum Ca2+ and low urine Ca2+/Cr clearance ratio (< 0.01)? Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with an elevated serum PTH/Ca2+ and normal urine Ca2+/Cr clearance ratio (> 0.02)? Primary hyperparathyroidism"
"What type of acid-base disturbance occurs with vomiting? hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an afebrile elderly male with BPH who experiences agitation and lower abdominal tenderness 2 days after surgery? Acute urinary retention"
"Diagnosis of acute urinary retention is confirmed by bladder ultrasound demonstrating > 300 mL of urine"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with lower extremity edema, 4+ proteinuria, and a kidney biopsy demonstrating dense deposits within the GBM? Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type II"
"MPGN type II is associated with C3 nephritic factor, an IgG antibody that stabilizes C3 convertase"
"What is the treatment of choice for euvolemic hypernatremia? 5% dextrose (preferred) or 0.45% saline for free water supplementation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with cor pulmonale treated with loop diuretics that develops elevated creatinine and BUN? Prerenal acute kidney injury"
"What BUN:creatinine ratio is suggestive of prerenal acute kidney injury? > 20:1 BUN:creatinine"
"What acid base disturbance is present given the ABG below? pH: 7.53 PaCO2: 30 mmHg HCO3-: 22 mEq/L Respiratory alkalosis"
"What acid base disturbance is present given the ABG below? pH: 7.23 PaCO2: 38 mmHg HCO3-: 12 mEq/L Metabolic acidosis"
"What acid base disturbance is present given the ABG below? pH: 7.53 PaCO2: 40 mmHg HCO3-: 30 mEq/L Metabolic alkalosis"
"What acid base disturbance is present given the ABG below? pH: 7.29 PaCO2: 50 mmHg HCO3-: 24 mEq/L Respiratory acidosis"
"What is the most common form of drug-induced chronic renal failure? Analgesic nephropathy"
"What are the most common renal pathologies seen with analgesic nephropathy? (2) Papillary necrosis Chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis"
"How does urine pH change in patients with respiratory alkalosis? Increase (alkalinized urine)"
"What antibiotic is associated with hyperkalemia and elevated serum creatinine? Trimethoprim"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with tuberculosis who presents with hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypercalcemia, hyperpigmentation, and eosinophilia? Primary adrenal insufficiency"
"What acid-base disturbance is associated with primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease)? Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis"
"What type of cast is characteristic of acute tubular necrosis? Muddy brown granular cast"
"What type of cast is characteristic of glomerulonephritis? RBC cast"
"What type of cast is characteristic of interstitial nephritis and pyelonephritis? WBC cast"
"What type of cast is characteristic of nephrotic syndrome? Fatty cast"
"What type of casts (2) are characteristic of chronic renal failure? broad and waxy casts"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly diabetic with non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and mild renal insufficiency? Type 4 (hyperkalemic) renal tubular acidosis"
"What is the likely cause of acute kidney injury in patients receiving IV acyclovir? Renal tubular obstruction (crystal-induced AKI)"
"Risk of acute kidney injury secondary to IV acyclovir can be reduced by administering concurrent IV fluids"
"Patients age > 35 with gross hematuria should be evaluated for urological neoplasms with CT urogram (diagnostic imaging) and cystoscopy"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young female with hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, normotension, and low urine Cl-? Surreptitious vomiting"
"What is the current recommended screening regimen for bladder cancer? Not recommended, even in patients with significant smoking and family histories"
"Dietary recommendations for patients with renal calculi include increased fluid intake, decreased Na+ intake, and normal Ca2+ intake"
"Saline-responsive metabolic alkalosis is characterized by urine chloride < 20 mEq/L"
"Saline-resistant metabolic alkalosis is characterized by urine chloride > 20 mEq/L"
"What formula is used to calculate the serum osmolality? "
"What formula is used to calculate the osmolal gap? measured serum osmolality - calculated serum osmolality"
"High anion gap metabolic acidosis with a(n) high osmolal gap (> 10) is suggestive of ethylene glycol, methanol, or propylene glycol ingestion"
"High anion gap metabolic acidosis with hyperglycemia is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis"
"High anion gap metabolic acidosis in a patient with hypoperfusion is suggestive of lactic acidosis"
"What imaging modalities are preferred for detecting kidney stones? non-contrast CT scan (preferred) or ultrasound (if pregnant)::2"
"What classes of medications are used for pain management in patients with kidney stones? Narcotics and NSAIDs (preferred with normal renal function)::2"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with QRS widening and peaked T waves on ECG? Hyperkalemia"
"What treatment is used for cardiac membrane stabilization in patients with hyperkalemia? IV calcium infusion (e.g. calcium gluconate or calcium chloride)"
"What treatment provides the most rapid reduction in serum K+ in patients with hyperkalemia? IV insulin and glucose"
"What is the most common extrarenal manifestation of autosomal dominant PKD? Hepatic cysts"
"What neurological complication is associated with autosomal dominant PKD? Berry aneurysms"
"What is the likely underlying cause of refractory hypokalemia in an alcoholic patient? Hypomagnesemia"
"What effect does intracellular magnesium have on renal K+ secretion? Decreased K+ secretion"
"The pathologic hallmark of diabetic nephropathy is nodular glomerulosclerosis (with Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules), but diffuse glomerulosclerosis is more common"
"What class of anti-depressants is commonly associated with SIADH? SSRIs"
"What is the most common reason for higher incidence of UTIs in females than in males? Shorter urethral length in females"
"Winter's formula is use to calculate the expected PaCO2 in a patient with metabolic acidosis via the equation: PaCO2 = (1.5*HCO3-) and 8 +/- 2"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with poorly controlled diabetes that presents with overflow incontinence with a high post-void residual volume (> 50 mL)? Diabetic autonomic neuropathy"
"What is the treatment of choice for mild hypovolemic hypernatremia? 5% dextrose in 0.45% saline"
"What type of anti-histamine has anti-cholinergic activity? 1st generation H1-blockers"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a left-sided varicocele that fails to empty when the patient is lying down, as well as hematuria, fever, and thrombocytosis? Renal cell carcinoma"
"What acid-base disorders are associated with aspirin (salicylate) toxicity? Early: pure respiratory alkalosis Late (> 12 hours): mixed respiratory alkalosis and metabolic acidosis with normal pH"
"What screening procedure is useful for detecting cystinuria? Urinary cyanide nitroprusside test"
"Nephrotic syndrome is defined as proteinuria (> 3.5g / 24 hr) with hypoalbuminemia and edema"
"Which type of nephrotic syndrome is most common in African Americans and Hispanics? Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a recent infection who presents with fever and rash with WBC casts and eosinophiluria on urinalysis? Drug-induced interstitial nephritis"
"What class of antibiotics used to treat severe gram-negative infections is potentially nephrotoxic? Aminoglycosides"
"What complication may result from correcting hyponatremia too quickly? Osmotic demyelination syndrome (central pontine myelinolysis)"
"What complication may result from correcting hypernatremia too quickly? Cerebral edema"
"Correction of serum sodium (both hypo- and hyper-natremia) should not exceed a rate of 0.5 mEq/L/hr"
"What is the underlying cause of hypercoagulability in patients with nephrotic syndrome? Loss of antithrombin III in urine"
"How do lipid levels change in patients with nephrotic syndrome? Increased (hyperlipidemia)"
"Drugs that commonly cause acute interstitial nephritis may be remembered with the \5 P's\\": P: Pee (diuretics) P: Pain-free (NSAIDs) P: Penicillins"
"What is the most common cause of abnormal hemostasis in patients with chronic renal failure? Platelet dysfunction"
"What hematologic laboratory values are consistent with abnormal hemostasis due to chronic renal failure? PT: Normal PTT: Normal Platelet count: Normal Bleeding time: Prolonged"
"What is the likely underlying etiology of kidney disease with arteriosclerotic lesions of renal arterioles? Hypertension"
"What is the likely underlying etiology of kidney disease with GBM thickening, mesangial expansion, and glomerular sclerosis? Diabetic nephropathy"
"What is the earliest renal abnormality seen in diabetic nephropathy? Glomerular hyperfiltration"
"What is the most common cause of glomerulonephritis in adults? IgA nephropathy"
"What drug should be discontinued in an acutely ill patient with sepsis and acute renal failure taking low-dose aspirin, atorvastatin, metformin, and sitagliptin? Metformin"
"First-line treatment options for uncomplicated cystitis include TMP-SMX (3 days), nitrofurantoin (5 days), and fosfomycin (single dose)"
"Should patients with uncomplicated cystitis be treated before a urine culture is obtained? Yes"
"Should patients with complicated cystitis be treated before a urine culture is obtained? No"
"Complicated cystitis in otherwise stable, non-pregnant patients may be managed with oral fluoroquinolones"
"Should patients with pyelonephritis be treated before a urine culture is obtained? No"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young female with orthostatic hypotension, hyponatremia, and hypokalemia with high urine Na+ and K+? Diuretic abuse"
"How do the following laboratory values change in a patient with hypovolemia? ADH: Increase Renin: Increase Aldosterone: Increase"
"What renal pathology is likely present in an asymptomatic patient with the CT below? Simple renal cyst"
"What is the recommended management for an asymptomatic simple renal cyst? Reassurance (no follow-up required)"
"What drug class is useful for the management of recurrent nephrolithiasis secondary to idiopathic hypercalciuria? Thiazide diuretics"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a renal transplant for 3 days who presents with oliguria, elevated creatinine/BUN, lymphocytic infiltration on biopsy, and normal serum cyclosporine levels? Acute transplant rejection"
"What is recommended treatment for an acute rejection of a renal transplant? IV steroids"
"What psychiatric medication is associated with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus? Lithium"
"What is the typical volume state (hypo, eu-, or hyper-volemic) of patients with hypercalcemia? Hypovolemic"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient started on nitroprusside who presents with flushing, confusion, and metabolic acidosis? Cyanide toxicity"
"What is the recommended treatment for a patient with metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia secondary to recurrent vomiting? IV saline and potassium"
"Which type of hematuria, glomerular or non-glomerular, is associated with microscopic hematuria and proteinuria? Glomerular hematuria"
"What is the initial therapy for patients with hypertension and renal artery stenosis? ACE inhibitors or ARBs"
"Which diuretics (2) are commonly administered to cirrhotic patients with volume overload and ascites? furosemide and spironolactone"
"Which type of nephrotic syndrome is associated with Hodgkin lymphoma? Minimal change disease"
"Which type of nephrotic syndrome is most commonly associated with malignancies? Membranous nephropathy"
"Hypokalemia may be caused by increased intracellular entry of K+, which can occur with insulin, β-adrenergic agonists, and hematopoiesis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with intermittent flank pain, low-volume voids, and occasional episodes of high-volume voids? Obstructive uropathy"
"Which type of nephrotic syndrome is most likely in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis? Amyloidosis (AA)"
"What class of autonomic drugs may be useful for treating and facilitating passage of ureteric kidney stones (in addition to IV hydration and analgesics)? alpha1-blockers (e.g. tamsulosin)"
"Some side effects of thiazide diuretics may be remembered with the mnemonic \hyper-GLUC\\": G: hyperGlycemia L: hyperLipidemia U: hyperUricemia C: hyperCalcemia\""
"What is the likely cause of metabolic alkalosis in a young woman with low urine Cl-? Self-induced vomiting"
"What does a positive leukocyte esterase on urine dipstick indicate? Significant pyuria"
"What does positive nitrites on urine dipstick indicate? Gram negative bacteria"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young female with photosensitivity, headaches, thrombocytopenia, hematuria, and proteinuria? SLE"
"What class of drugs are useful for patients with urge incontinence? Anti-muscarinics (e.g. oxybutynin)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a chronic atrial fibrillation patient taking furosemide, metoprolol, digoxin, and warfarin who presents with diarrhea, nausea, decreased appetite, and arrhythmias? Digoxin toxicity"
"The CHA2DS2-VASc score is useful for assessing thromboembolic risk in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation: C: Congestive heart failure H: Hypertension A2: Age > 75* (2 points) D: Diabetes mellitus S2: Stroke/TIA/thromboembolism* (2 points) V: Vascular disease (prior MI, PAD, or aortic plaque) A: Age 65-74 Sc: Sex category (female)"
"What is the initial treatment for chronic venous insufficiency? Conservation measures (e.g. leg elevation, exercise, compression therapy)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a post-MI patient that presents a few weeks later with chest pain that improves while leaning forward and diffuse ST elevation on ECG? Dressler's syndrome (a type of pericarditis)"
"Cold-water immersion relieves symptoms of paraoxysmal supraventricular tachycardia by decreasing AV node conductivity"
"Cor pulmonale is impaired function of the right ventricle due to pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary artery systolic pressure > 25 mmHg)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient with recent uveitis, complete AV heart block, and bilateral midfield lung opacities on CXR? Cardiac sarcoidosis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with peripheral edema, ascites, JVD without inspiratory decline, and pericardial calcifications on CXR? Constrictive pericarditis"
"What is the most common cause of constrictive pericarditis in developing countries? Tuberculosis"
"The combination of atrial tachycardia with AV block is specific for digitalis toxicity"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient with a smoking history that presents with episodic chest pain that resolves spontaneously and is associated with transient ST-segment elevation during the episodes? Vasospastic angina"
"What two drugs/drug classes are used for dual anti-platelet therapy? aspirin and P2y12 receptor blockers (e.g. clopidogrel)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a hypotensive patient requiring IV fluids/pressors to maintain BP that develops cool extremities and the skin findings below? Pressor-induced vasospasm (e.g. norepinephrine)"
"What is the initial management for a patient with suspected acute arterial occlusion leading to an immediately-threatened limb (e.g. sensory loss, weakness)? Anticoagulation (e.g. IV heparin)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient from a developing country that presents with dyspnea, hemoptysis, and occasional palpitations? Mitral stenosis (from rheumatic heart disease)"
"Medications that have been shown to improve long-term survival in patients with LV systolic dysfunction include: 1. β-blockers 2. ACE inhibitors 3. ARBs 4. Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists 5. Hydralazine and nitrates in African American patients"
"What is the likely cause of syncope in a young patient with occasional chest pain, dyspnea, and a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur along the left sternal border without carotid radiation? Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient status-post coronary angiogram that presents with abdominal pain, AKI, eosinophilia, and purple mottling of both feet? Cholesterol embolism"
"What adrenergic receptor is the primary target of dobutamine? β1 receptors (agonist)"
"Dobutamine improves symptoms of decompensated heart failure by increasing myocardial contractility"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a recent URI that presents with syncope, dyspnea, and the ECG findings below? Pericardial effusion"
"What is the primary mechanism by which nitrates improve symptoms of angina? Systemic vasodilation (decreased preload)"
"What is the recommended management for a patient with a smoking/drinking history and atrial premature beats discovered on routine ECG (asymptomatic)? Avoid alcohol and tobacco"
"What valvular defects (2) are associated with Marfan syndrome? aortic regurgitation and mitral valve prolapse"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient with hypertension and palpable bilateral, non-tender, upper abdominal masses on physical exam? Autosomal dominant PKD"
"What is the preferred medication for hypertension associated with autosomal dominant PKD? ACE inhibitors"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with upper extremity hypertension, brachial-femoral pulse delay, and a continuous interscapular murmur? Coarctation of the aorta"
"What is the recommended management for costochondritis? Reassurance and symptomatic pain management"
"What ECG finding is fairly specific for pericardial effusion? Electrical alternans"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an ischemic cardiomyopathy patient on antiarrhythmics that presents with progressive dyspnea, non-productive cough, and bilateral infiltrates on X-ray without JVD or peripheral edema? Amiodarone-induced interstitial pneumonitis"
"How do the following parameters change in LV systolic dysfunction (CHF)? Cardiac output: Decreased Systemic vascular resistance: Increased Left ventricular EDV: Increased"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient status-post lung biopsy that presents with severe shortness of breath and chest pain with a decreased cardiac output and increased PCWP? Cardiogenic shock (secondary to MI)"
"What valvular defect is associated with bacterial endocarditis in IV drug users? Tricuspid regurgitation"
"What is the likely cause of the imaging findings below in an IV drug user with a history of fever, cough, and tricuspid regurgitation? Septic pulmonary emboli"
"What abnormal heart sound is associated with a stiff left ventricle (e.g. LV hypertrophy due to prolonged hypertension)? S4"
"Which type of heart block is characterized by progressive lengthening of the PR interval followed by a dropped QRS complex? 2nd-degree, Mobitz type I (Wenckebach)"
"What level does a 2nd degree, Mobitz type I heart block typically occur? AV node"
"2nd-degree, Mobitz type I heart block has a(n) low risk to develop into complete heart block"
"Which type of heart block is characterized by equal length PR intervals with intermittent dropped QRS complexes? 2nd-degree, Mobitz type II"
"What level does a 2nd degree, Mobitz type II heart block typically occur? Below the AV node (e.g. bundle of His)"
"2nd-degree, Mobitz type II heart block has a(n) high risk to develop into complete heart block"
"What is the most effective non-pharmacologic measure to decrease blood pressure in an overweight, diabetic patient with significant tobacco/alcohol use? Weight loss"
"How do serum levels of digoxin change in patients who begin taking amiodarone? Increase"
"What is the recommended management for a hemodynamically stable Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome patient with atrial fibrillation? Procainamide"
"What is the recommended management for a hemodynamically unstable Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome patient with atrial fibrillation? Electrical cardioversion"
"What is the recommended screening protocol for abdominal aortic aneurysm? One-time abdominal ultrasound for any smokers (past/present) aged 65-75 years"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a male with a history of SLE that presents with epigastric burning provoked by exertion and relieved by rest? Atypical angina"
"What is the recommended diagnostic test for patients with chest pain that have intermediate-risk for CAD? Stress test (ECG, exercise ECG, pharm)"
"What is the primary mitral valve abnormality in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy? Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve"
"What physiologic effect results in increased intensity of a murmur due to hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy? Decreased preload"
"Ascending aortic aneurysms are most often due to cystic medial necrosis (due to aging) and connective tissue disorders"
"Descending aortic aneurysms are usually due to underlying atherosclerosis"
"What is the preferred preventive treatment for vasospastic (Prinzmetal) angina? Calcium channel blockers"
"What is the preferred abortive treatment for episodes of vasospastic angina? Sublingual nitroglycerin"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a chronic renal failure patient that presents with pleuritic chest pain that improves when leaning forward? Uremic pericarditis"
"Patients with CHF often have preferential vasoconstriction of efferent renal arterioles"
"What area of the myocardium is likely involved in an MI with ST elevations in leads V1 - V4? Anterior (typically LAD obstruction)"
"What area of the myocardium is likely involved in an MI with ST elevations in leads II, III, and aVF? Inferior (typically RCA obstruction, or less commonly LCX)"
"What area of the myocardium is likely involved in an MI with ST elevations in leads I and aVL? Lateral (typically LCX obstruction)"
"What artery is likely obstructed given the ECG below? Right coronary artery"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with dizziness, weakness, and the ECG findings below? Complete heart block"
"What is the likely underlying cause of an early decrescendo diastolic murmur in a young patient in the U.S. with a family history of heart disease? Congenital bicuspid aortic valve"
"What physical exam manuever is useful for distinguishing between cardiac- and liver disease-related causes of lower extremity edema? Hepatojugular reflux"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a recent URI that presents with JVD, hypotension, non-palpable PMI, and clear lungs (CXR below)? Pericardial effusion"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient on post-MI day 5 that presents with acute onset chest pain and profound shock without signs of congestive heart failure? Ventricular free wall rupture"
"What is the mode of inheritance of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy? Autosomal dominant"
"What is the recommended lipid-lowering therapy for patients < 75 that have clinically significant atherosclerotic disease? High-intensity statin"
"What is the recommended therapy for patients > 75 that have clinically significant atherosclerotic disease? Moderate-intensity statin"
"Patients with an LDL > 190 mg/dL are recommended to begin high-intensity statin therapy"
"Patients with an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk > 7.5% should be started on a moderate- to high-intensity statin"
"What class of anti-arrhythmic is characterized by prolonged QRS durations at faster heart rates? Class I (especially class IC)"
"What class of anti-arrhythmic is characterized by prolonged PR intervals at faster heart rates? Class IV (CCBs)"
"What anti-hypertensive medication is commonly associated with peripheral edema as an adverse effect? Dihydropyridine Ca2+-channel blockers"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient on post-MI day 3 that presents with pleuritic chest pain that improves when leaning forward with clear lungs on auscultation? Peri-infarction pericarditis"
"What is the treatment of choice for peri-infarction pericarditis? Supportive"
"What is the preferred initial management for symptomatic patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy? β-blockers"
"What is the recommended treatment for a hemodynamically stable patient with a history of panic attacks that presents with chest tightness, lightheadedness, and the ECG below? Adenosine"
"What drug classes are useful for reducing Ca2+ channel blocker-induced peripheral edema? ACE inhibitors and ARBs"
"What is the best initial management for a hemodynamically stable patient with palpitations and the ECG findings below? IV amiodarone"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of recent MI or history of peripheral arterial disease that presents with pain, pallor, paresthesias, and pulselessness in one limb? Acute limb ischemia"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young, non-smoker that presents with difficulty breathing, pulsus paradoxus, and a normal cardiac exam? Asthma"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient 2 months post-MI that presents with CHF and persistent ST elevations/deep Q waves on ECG? Ventricular aneurysm"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young, active patient that suddenly collapses while exercising and presents with a temperature of 106 F, confusion, and respiratory distress? Exertional heat stroke"
"What is the recommended cooling technique for patients with exertional heat strokes? Ice-water immersion"
"What is the recommended cooling technique for patients with non-exertional heat strokes? Evaporative cooling (e.g. spraying lukewarm water while fans blow air on skin)"
"What is the next step in management for an asymptomatic adult with an early diastolic murmur at the left sternal border that is best heard with expiration? Transthoracic echocardiogram"
"What is the most common cause of mitral regurgitation in developed countries? Mitral valve prolpase"
"Features of severe aortic stenosis include a(n) late-peaking systolic murmur and a(n) soft second heart sound"
"What is the likely cause of LAD artery occlusion in a patient with recent stent placement in the LAD artery? Stent thrombosis (likely due to medication non-compliance)"
"What drug classes are used as first-line therapy for chronic stable angina? β-blockers (preferred) and non-dihydropyridine CCBs::2"
"Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is recommended for patients with acute STEMI within 12 hours of symptom onset and within 90 minutes from first medical contact to device time at a PCI-capable facility"
"What is the recommended reperfusion therapy for patients with STEMI that present within 12 hours of symptom onset but cannot undergo PCI? Fibrinolysis"
"What is the likely etiology of NSTEMI in a young patient with chest pain, agitation, and dilated pupils? Cocaine intoxication"
"What is the recommended diagnostic test for patients with chest pain that have high-risk for CAD? Coronary angiography"
"What is the likely cause of bradycardia, AV block, and diffuse wheezing in a CAD patient that has attempted suicide? β-blocker overdose"
"First-line treatment options for β-blocker overdose include IV fluids and atropine"
"Patients with β-blocker overdose that have refractory hypotension (e.g. to atropine, IV fluids) should be started on IV glucagon"
"What is the likely diagnosis & treatment in a systemic sclerosis patient that presents with renal failure and malignant hypertension? Scleroderma renal crisis; treat with ACE Inhibitors"
"What abnormal RBC may be seen in patients with scleroderma renal crisis? Schistocytes"
"Atypical symptoms associated with MI are more common in women, the elderly, and diabetics"
"In addition to history and physical, patients initially diagnosed with hypertension should have the following basic testing: 1. Urinalysis (for occult hematuria and urine protein/creatinine ratio) 2. Chemistry panel 3. Lipid profile 4. Baseline ECG"
"What is the likely underlying etiology of chest pain for > 1 hour, associated with cough/hoarseness but unrelated to activity in a young patient with normal cardiac and pulmonary exam? Esophageal disease (e.g. GERD)"
"What imaging study should be considered in a patient with acute limb ischemia after an MI? Transthoracic echocardiogram"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of a stab wound that develops progressive weakness and exertional dyspnea with widened pulse pressure, tachycardia, and brisk carotid upstroke? High-output heart failure (secondary to AV fistula formation)"
"What is the initial treatment for tachycardia-mediated cardiomyopathy? Rate or rhythm control"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient on post-op day 1 status-post CABG that presents with hypotension, tachycardia, and the findings below: Right atrium: 20 mmHg Right ventricle: 35/20 mmHg PCWP: 20 mmHg Cardiac tamponade"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that experienced a syncopal episode while urinating with normal cardiac exam? Situational syncope"
"What arrhythmia commonly develops in patients with mitral stenosis? Atrial fibrillation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with unexplained CHF accompanied by nephrotic-range proteinuria (> 3.5 g/day) and concentric LV hypertrophy with normal ventricular chamber dimensions? Amyloidosis"
"Diagnosis of amyloidosis is confirmed using tissue biopsy (e.g. abdominal fat pad)"
"The presence of a continuous abdominal bruit has a high specificity for the presence of renovascular hypertension"
"What is the recommended pharmaceutical treatment for acute pulmonary edema secondary to myocardial infarction? IV furosemide (unless patient is hypotensive or hypovolemic)"
"What pharmaceutical treatment should be avoided in patients with MI that present with CHF or bradycardia? β-blockers"
"What abnormal heart sound is associated with volume overload (e.g. CHF with LV dysfunction)? S3"
"What is the recommended treatment for patients with uremic pericarditis? Hemodialysis"
"What thyroid disorder is associated with atrial fibrillation? Hyperthyroidism"
"What electrolyte abnormality parallels the severity of heart failure and is an independent predictor of adverse clinical outcomes? Hyponatremia"
"What is the likely physiologic cause of isolated systolic hypertension in an elderly patient? Increased stiffness of the arterial wall"
"How does baroreceptor sensitivity change with aging? Decreased sensitivity"
"What is preferred treatment to prevent coronary artery disease in a patient with inducible ischemia? Anti-platelet therapy (e.g. aspirin)"
"What intervention is most likely to improve cardiovascular and overall long-term mortality in patients with acute STEMI? Restoration of coronary blood flow (e.g. PCI, fibrinolysis)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an IV drug abuser with fever, an early diastolic murmur (left sternal border), and 2nd-degree AV block? Perivalvular abscess (secondary to aortic valve endocarditis)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient with hypertension, epistaxis, headaches, and ST-segment depression/T-wave inversion in leads V5-V6 on ECG? Coarctation of the aorta"
"What is the mainstay of therapy to improve/normalize heart function in patients with alcoholic cardiomyopathy? Abstinence from alcohol"
"What is the most useful intervention to improve functional capacity and reduce symptomatic claudication in patients with peripheral artery disease? Supervised graded exercise program"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient with fatigue, dizziness, and the ECG findings below? Sinus bradycardia"
"Symptomatic bradycardia is managed with IV atropine::initial treatment"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with extensive alcohol use and hypertension that is not well controlled on two medications? Counsel for reduction in alcohol intake"
"What valvular defect is associated with a hyperdynamic pulse (e.g. bounding or \water hammer\\" pulses)? Aortic regurgitation\""
"What is the recommended management for a patient with first-degree AV block and a normal QRS duration (< 120 msec)? Observation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient with palpitations, tachycardia, and the ECG below (obtained after administration of medication)? Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a hypertensive patient with symptoms of CHF with LV hypertrophy and an ejection fraction of 55% on echocardiography? Diastolic heart failure (HFpEF)"
"What is the likely underlying cause of syncope in a patient with normal EF, prolonged PR interval, prolonged QRS interval, and a normal QTc interval on ECG? AV block or bradyarrhythmia"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient with exertional chest pain, differential blood pressure in upper extremities, a systolic murmur at the first right intercostal space, and a palpable thrill in the suprasternal notch? Supravalvular aortic stenosis"
"What is the recommended management for a 40-year-old male with atrial fibrillation and no history of diabetes, heart disease, or embolic event? Observation (no therapy required)"
"What is the initial management for a patient with pulmonary hypertension that presents with JVD, peripheral edema, bibasilar crackles, and an ejection fraction of 30%? Loop diuretics and ACE inhibitors (or ARBs)"
"How do the following parameters change in an acute MI patient with hypotension, bibasilar crackles, and a systolic murmur (cardiac apex)? Left atrial size: No change LV end-diastolic pressure: Increased"
"Management of acute decompensated heart failure includes supplemental O2, IV loop diuretics, and possibly a vasodilator/vasopressor"
"What is the treatment of choice for agitation in an NSTEMI patient with chest pain, agitation, dilated pupils, and normal cardiac enzymes? IV benzodiazepines"
"Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) should be considered for symptomatic patients (e.g. TIA, stroke) with carotid stenosis between 70 - 99% to reduce future stroke risk"
"What hypertensive complication is defined as severe hypertension (> 180/120 mmHg) with no symptoms or acute end-organ damage? Hypertensive urgency"
"What hypertensive complication presents as severe hypertension (> 180/120 mmHg) with retinal hemorrhages, exudates, or papilledema? Malignant hypertension (type of hypertensive emergency)"
"What hypertensive complication presents as severe hypertension (> 180/120 mmHg) with cerebral edema and non-localized neurologic signs/symptoms (e.g. confusion)? Hypertensive encephalopathy (type of hypertensive emergency)"
"What is the initial treatment for a hemodynamically stable patient with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response? Rate control (e.g. β-blockers or CCBs)"
"What is the most effective non-pharmacologic measure to decrease blood pressure in a patient with significant tobacco/alcohol use and a BMI of 22 kg/m2? Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet"
"What class of drugs should be administered within 24 hours of an MI to limit ventricular remodeling? ACE inhibitors"
"What analgesics are associated with decreased metabolism of warfarin (i.e. increased bleeding risk)? acetaminophen and NSAIDs::2"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with an implantable pacemaker that presents with peripheral edema, JVD, and a holosystolic murmur (left lower sternal border) with clear lungs on auscultation? Tricuspid regurgitation"
"The current indications for operative/endovascular repair of an AAA include rapid rate of expansion, presence of symptoms, and aneurysm size > 5.5 cm"
"Ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia is managed with Immediate defibrillation (aka unsynchronized cardioversion)::next step"
"What is the most important factor for survival in a patient with an out-of-hospital sudden cardiac arrest? Elapsed time to effective resuscitation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young woman with recurrent headaches, significant hypertension, and a subauricular/carotid systolic bruit? Fibromuscular dysplasia"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient being treated with furosemide and nitroprusside for hypertensive emergency that develops confusion, agitation, and seizures? Cyanide toxicity"
"What is the likely underlying etiology of atrial fibrillation in a patient with weight loss, lid lag, and a tremor with outstretched hands? Hyperthyroidism"
"What is the initial therapy for patients with atrial fibrillation due to hyperthyroidism? β-blockers"
"What medication is most likely responsible for weight gain, constipation, dry skin, and elevated LFTs in a patient being treated for hypertension, LV systolic dysfunction, and persistent atrial fibrillation? Amiodarone"
"What is the likely underlying cause of a harsh systolic murmur (right second intercostal space) with radiation to the carotid arteries in a young patient in the U.S.? Bicuspid aortic valve"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an immigrant with a history of megacolon/megaesophagus that presents with pedal edema, JVD, and cardiomegaly? Chagas disease"
"What abnormal heart sound is often heard during the acute phase of myocardial infarction? S4 (atrial gallop)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with ST elevations in leads II, III, and aVF with JVD, hypotension and clear lungs on auscultation? Right ventricular MI"
"What is the initial management for hypotension in a patient with a right ventricular MI that has low-normal JVP? IV saline bolus (nitrates should be avoided)"
"What is the most appropriate initial therapy for a hemodynamically stable patient with chest pain and suspected acute coronary syndrome and low risk for aortic dissection? Aspirin"
"Flushing and pruritus secondary to niacin therapy is caused by prostaglandin-induced peripheral vasodilation"
"Asystole or pulseless electrical activity (no palpable pulse but electrical activity on ECG)? CPR and Epi::next step"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that experiences syncopal episodes provoked by strong emotion with prodromal symptoms (e.g. nausea, diaphoresis)? Vasovagal (neurocardiogenic) syncope"
"Patients with recurrent vasovagal syncope may try physical counterpressure maneuvers during the prodromal phase to abort or delay the syncopal episode"
"What classes of medications should be held for 48 hours prior to cardiac stress testing? β-blockers, calcium channel blockers, and nitrates::3"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young adult with a month history of fever and malaise that develops symptoms of CHF with cardiomegaly on imaging? Viral myocarditis"
"What is the mechanism by which adenosine reveals obstructive CAD during cardiac stress testing? Augmentation of flow in non-obstructed vessels"
"Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed when at least 3 of the 5 following criteria are met: 1. Abdominal obesity (waist circumference > 40 inches in males, > 35 inches in females) 2. Fasting glucose (> 100-110 mg/dL) 3. Blood pressure (> 130/80 mmHg) 4. Triglycerides (> 150 mg/dL) 5. HDL cholesterol (< 40 mg/dL in men, < 50 mg/dL in women)"
"A major pathogenic factor underlying metabolic syndrome is insulin resistance"
"Primary adrenal insufficiency is associated with hypo-natremia and hyper-kalemia"
"Primary adrenal insufficiency is associated with increased levels of ADH"
"What is the most important contributing factor for diabetic foot ulcers? Diabetic neuropathy"
"Monofilament testing is useful for determining the presence of peripheral neuropathy"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a middle-aged woman with hip/shoulder weakness, muscle atrophy, weight loss, and tachycardia? Hyperthyroidism"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient taking risperidone that presents with fatigue and headache with low TSH/LH and mildly elevated prolactin (< 200) on laboratory exam? Non-functioning pituitary adenoma"
"What musculoskeletal pathology is caused by impaired osteoid matrix mineralization? Osteomalacia"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with celiac sprue that develops diffuse bone pain, muscle weakness, and the laboratory results below? Ca2+:low/normal Phosphate: low PTH: high Alkaline phosphatase: high Osteomalacia"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with flushing, watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria? VIPoma"
"The diagnosis of VIPoma is confirmed by a VIP level > 75 pg/mL"
"What is the most serious adverse effect associated with anti-thyroid drugs (e.g. methimazole, PTU)? Agranulocytosis"
"Which anti-thyroid drug, methimazole or PTU, is preferred in most patients? Methimazole (exception: women during the first trimester of pregnancy)"
"Screening for diabetes is recommended in patients with a sustained blood pressure > 135/80 mmHg and may be considered in all patients > 45 years old"
"What musculoskeletal pathology is associated with pseudofractures (Looser zones)? Osteomalacia"
"How do the following laboratory values typically change in patients with osteoporosis? Calcium: normal Phosphate: normal Alkaline phosphatase: normal"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with low urine osmolality that improves to > 600 mOsm/kg after 2-3 hours of water deprivation? Primary polydipsia"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with low urine osmolality that does not improve significantly following water deprivation and administration of desmopressin? Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus"
"What initial laboratory test is best to help determine the underlying etiology of hypercalcemia? PTH levels"
"Primary hyperaldosteronism is characterized by low renin and high aldosterone"
"Secondary hyperaldosteronism is characterized by high plasma renin activity and high plasma aldosterone concentration"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a malignant thyroid nodule, elevated calcitonin, and a family history of thyroid cancer? MEN2 (A or B)"
"What is the initial treatment for a patient with an asymptomatic microprolactinoma (< 10mm)? No treatment"
"What electrolyte abnormality is typically the cause of hypocalcemia in an alcoholic patient? Severe hypomagnesemia"
"What formula is used to calculate the \corrected Ca2+\\" in a patient with low albumin? serum Ca2+ + 0.8(4 - serum albumin)\""
"How do the following laboratory values change in central adrenal insufficiency? Cortisol: decreased ACTH: decreased Aldosterone: normal (no change)"
"How do the following laboratory values change in primary adrenal insufficiency? Cortisol: decreased ACTH: increased Aldosterone: decreased"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a chronic smoker that develops hypertension, hyperglycemia, and weight gain? Cushing's syndrome (likely ectopic production of ACTH from a small cell lung cancer)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with headaches, weight loss, intermittent palpitations, and visual disturbances? Laboratory exam reveals elevated T3/T4 and TSH. TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma"
"What is the next step in diagnosis for a patient with myalgias, proximal muscle weakness, elevated creatine kinase, and delayed reflexes? Measure TSH and T4 (to evaluate for hypothyroid myopathy)"
"What hormone level should be measured as part of the initial diagnostic workup in a patient with confirmed hypocalcemia? Parathyroid hormone"
"What is a common complication of radioactive iodine when treating Graves disease? Permanent hypothyroidism"
"A patient with diabetic sensorimotor polyneuropathy with symptoms of pain, paresthesias, and allodynia likely has injury to the small::large/small nerve fibers"
"A patient with diabetic sensorimotor polyneuropathy with symptoms of loss of proprioception/vibration sense and foot deformities likely has injury to the large::large/small nerve fibers"
"Untreated acromegaly can cause concentric myocardial hypertrophy (concentric or eccentric)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a female that develops proximal muscle weakness (e.g. hair combing, stair climbing) without pain, as well as hirsutism and hypertension? Glucocorticoid-induced myopathy"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient taking HCTZ, levothyroxine, and OTC mineral supplements (for osteoporosis) that develops symptomatic hypercalcemia, metabolic alkalosis, and AKI? Milk-alkali syndrome"
"What is the likely explanation for the abnormal laboratory values in a pregnant woman that experiences fatigue, anxiety, and difficulty sleeping with normal TSH and elevated total T4? Thyroid examination is benign. Increased thyroid-binding globulin (TBG) level"
"Graves ophthalmopathy is caused by T-cell activation and stimulation of orbital fibroblasts by TSH receptor antibodies, leading to expansion of orbital tissues"
"What is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency in developed countries? Autoimmune adrenalitis"
"What should be suspected in a patient taking PTU or methimazole that presents with fever and sore throat? Agranulocytosis"
"What is the next step in management for a patient taking PTU or methimazole that develops fever and sore throat? Discontinuation of the drug, measure WBC count"
"What cardiovascular effect of thyrotoxicosis causes systolic hypertension? Increased myocardial contractility and heart rate"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with an acute MI complicated by cardiogenic shock that develops a low total T3 level despite normal TSH/free T4? Euthyroid sick syndrome (low T3 syndrome)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an asymptomatic patient with a slightly elevated TSH despite normal free T3/T4 levels? Subclinical hypothyroidism"
"How do the following laboratory values change in milk-alkali syndrome? PTH: Decreased Ca2+: Increased Metabolic alkalosis"
"What is the initial management for an elderly patient with heat intolerance, sweating, and palpitations and a low TSH and high free T3/T4 on laboratory exam? β-blocker and anti-thyroid drugs (e.g. methimazole)"
"Anti-thyroid drug therapy alone may be used to treat Graves disease in those with mild disease, pregnant women, or older patients with limited life expectancy"
"What is the appropriate definitive treatment for a patient with severe ophthalmopathy secondary to Graves disease? Thyroidectomy"
"Psychiatric medications that are useful for pain management in diabetic neuropathy patients include TCAs, SNRIs, and anticonvulsants (e.g. gabapentin, pregabalin)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient with nausea/vomiting, weight loss, and polydipsia? Laboratory exam is significant for low HCO3- and high blood glucose/K+ levels. Diabetic ketoacidosis"
"What is the recommended IV fluid regimen for hydration in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis? 0.9% NS initially, add dextrose 5% when serum glucose is < 200 mg/dL"
"What is the recommended insulin regimen in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis? IV insulin initially followed by subcutaneous insulin (see below); overlap SQ & IV insulin by 1-2 hours"
"Potassium should be added to the IV fluids of a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis once serum K+ is < 5.2 mEq/L"
"What formula is used to calculate the \corrected Na+\\" in a patient with severe hyperglycemia? Na+ + 2 mEq/L for every 100 mg/dL glucose is over 100 mg/dL\""
"Tight blood glucose control in patients with diabetes is most likely to decrease risk of micro-vascular complications"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young female with irregular menses, hirsutism, and elevated serum testosterone with no abdominal striae? Polycystic ovary syndrome"
"What medications (4) should be administered to a patient with suspected thyroid storm? 1. Propranolol (β-blocker) 2. Propylthiouracil (PTU) 3. Potassium iodide (unless pregnant) 4. Prednisone (or other glucocorticoid)"
"Which subtype of thyroid cancer is associated with elevated calcitonin? Medullary thyroid carcinoma"
"What is the most common underlying cause of neuropathic ulcers? diabetes mellitus"
"What hypothalamic hormone is directly inhibited by prolactin? GnRH"
"A prolactin level > 200 ng/mL is virtually diagnostic of prolactinoma"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a pituitary mass and the laboratory values below? Prolactin: 45 ng/mL (normal, < 15) LH: low TSH: low Non-functional (gonadotroph) pituitary adenoma"
"What is the preferred imaging modality for evaluation of pituitary tumors? MRI"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an insulin-dependent diabetic patient with anorexia, nausea/vomiting, early satiety, and post-prandial hypoglycemia without heartburn or epigastric pain? Diabetic gastroparesis"
"Diabetic gastroparesis may be managed with small, frequent meals and prokinetic agents such as metoclopramide, erythromycin, and cisapride"
"What are the best markers for indicating resolution of diabetic ketoacidosis? Serum anion gap and β-hydroxybutyrate levels"
"What acid-base disturbance is associated with hyperaldosteronism? Metabolic alkalosis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with weight loss/tachycardia and a diffusely tender thyroid with low TSH and high free T4? Subacute (de Quervain) thyroiditis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an African-American patient that presents with dark urine that stains positive with Prussian blue after being treated for a urinary tract infection? G6PD deficiency"
"What drug class may be used to treat hypercalcemia due to immobilization? Bisphosphonates"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a psychatric patient with increasing polyuria/polydipsia with hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality? Primary polydipsia"
"How does oral estrogen change the required therapeutic dose of levothyroxine in patients with hypothyroidism? Increased dose required"
"How do ionized Ca2+ levels change in a patient with respiratory or metabolic alkalosis? Decreased ionized Ca2+"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly diabetic patient that develops weakness and blurred vision after a viral URI with a markedly elevated serum glucose (> 1000 mg/dL) on laboratory exam? Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state"
"How do total K+ levels typically change in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state? Decreased"
"What thyroid abnormality (hyper- or hypothyroidism) is associated with hyperlipidemia (e.g. hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia)? Hypothyroidism"
"What is the recommended blood pressure goal for patients with diabetes without proteinuria? < 140/90 mmHg"
"A patient's diabetes is considered well controlled if the HbA1c is < 7.0%"
"What additional risk factor(s) warrant initiation of statin therapy in a diabetic patient between age 40 - 75? None. ALL diabetic patients should be started on statin therapy, regardless of other risk factors"
"What is the most important initial step in management of a patient with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state? Fluid replacement with normal saline"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with hypercalcemia, elevated PTH, and high urine Ca2+? Primary hyperparathyroidism"
"What is the likely etiology of hyperthyroidism in a patient with elevated free T3/T4, low TSH, and the radioactive iodine scan below? Toxic adenoma"
"How do total Ca2+ levels change in patients with hypoalbuminemia? Decreased"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a middle-aged female that develops rapid-onset hirsutism and amenorrhea? Androgen-secreting neoplasm (of ovaries or adrenal gland)"
"What is the likely source of an androgen-secreting tumor in a female with elevated testosterone and normal dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) levels? Ovaries (more common)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an obese young woman that presents with male-pattern baldness, excessive acne, and amenorrhea? Polycystic ovarian syndrome"
"What test should be used to screen for diabetes mellitus in patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome? Oral glucose tolerance test"
"Indications for BRCA mutation testing include a 1st or 2nd degree relative with breast & ovarian cancer (any age) or two 1st degree relatives with breast cancer, including 1 at age < 50"
"What is the most beneficial therapy for reducing the progression of diabetic nephropathy? Strict blood pressure control"
"What is the major gluconeogenic amino acid in the liver? Alanine"
"Alanine is converted to pyruvate by alanine aminotransferase during the process of gluconeogenesis"
"What is the likely etiology of hyperthyroidism in a patient with a normal sized thyroid, diffusely decreased radioactive iodine uptake, and low serum thyroglobulin? Exogenous hormone"
"What treatment option for Graves disease may be associated with worsening of ophthalmopathy? Radioactive iodine"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that develops pallor, tachycardia, and severe hypertension without fever after induction of anesthesia? The patient has a history of frequent headaches and hypertension. Pheochromocytoma"
"How do the serum levels of the following change with vitamin D deficiency? Ca2+: Decrease Phosphate: Decrease PTH: Increase"
"What pregnancy complication is associated with Hashimoto thyroiditis? Miscarriage"
"What is the underlying etiology of altered mental status in patients with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state? Hyperosmolality"
"What is the pathophysiology underlying hyperthyroid-induced bone loss? Increased osteoclast activity"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a family history of kidney stones and stomach ulcers that presents with refractory peptic ulcer disease, hypercalcemia, and low serum phosphorus? MEN1"
"What is the recommended treatment for patients that develop heparin-induced thrombocytopenia? discontinue heparin, begin alternative anticoagulant (e.g. direct thrombin inhibitor, fondaparinux)"
"What is the most common cause of megaloblastic anemia in chronic alcoholics? Folate deficiency"
"What is the drug class of choice for stabilizing bony metastatic lesions and preventing hypercalcemia of malignancy? Bisphosphonates"
"What is the likely underlying cause of anemia in a patient with a history of gastrectomy that presents with a shiny tongue, pale palmar creases, and laboratory evidence of hemolysis? Vitamin B12 deficiency (impaired DNA synthesis)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with acute lymphoblastic leukemia that develops premature ventricular beats and acute kidney injury after initiating chemotherapy? Tumor lysis syndrome"
"How do the following laboratory values change with tumor lysis syndrome? Serum Ca2+: Decreased Serum K+: Increased Serum phosphate: Increased Serum uric acid: Increased"
"What is the most common mode of inheritance of hereditary spherocytosis? Autosomal dominant (75%)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a chronic smoker that presents with dyspnea, weight loss, and face/arm swelling that is worst in the morning? SVC syndrome"
"What is the initial imaging modality used for diagnosis of SVC syndrome? Chest X-ray"
"What anticoagulant is associated with decreased levels of proteins C and S? Warfarin"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an asymptomatic Italian male that is found to have microcytic anemia with an abnormally high HbA2 on routine laboratory testing? β-thalassemia minor"
"What is the most common source of symptomatic pulmonary embolism? Proximal deep leg veins (e.g. femoral, popliteal, iliac)"
"What is the recommended treatment for a patient on warfarin that presents with an acute DVT with a subtherapeutic INR due to improper dieting/non-compliance? Oral factor Xa inhibitors (e.g. rivaroxaban)"
"Why do patients with multiple myeloma have an increased risk of infection? Hypogammaglobulinemia"
"What is the recommended treatment for immune thrombocytopenic purpura in adults with platelet counts < 30,000/uL or bleeding? IVIG or corticosteroids"
"What is the underlying pathophysiology leading to sepsis with gram-positive cocci in a patient with a history of \LUQ abdominal surgery\\"? Impaired antibody-mediated phagocytosis\""
"What is the likely underlying etiology of anemia in an elderly patient with fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly? Bone marrow infiltration (e.g. lymphoma, leukemia)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with epistaxis, red blanchable papules on the lips, digital clubbing and isolated polycythemia on laboratory exam? Hereditary telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that develops a fever, chills, and malaise two hours after starting RBC tranfusion? Coombs test is negative. Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction"
"What is the recommended RBC pre-treatment for a patient who will receive a transfusion of pRBCs and has a history of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction? Leukoreduction"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with a year history of fatigue, weakness, and difficulty remembering things? Laboratory examination reveals macrocytic anemia, anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, and basophilic stippling. Measure serum B12 and folate levels"
"The pentad of symptoms seen in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) may be remembered using the mnemonic FAT RN: F: Fever A: Anemia (MAHA) T: Thrombocytopenia R: Renal symptoms N: Neurologic symptoms"
"What is the recommended treatment for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)? Emergent plasma exchange +/- corticosteroids"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an alcoholic vegan patient being treated with thiamine and folate for anemia that develops recurrent falls and increasing forgetfulness? Vitamin B12 deficiency/subacute combined degeneration"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a facial rash that worsens with sun exposure, and a history of DVT, transient ischemic attacks, and 2 miscarriages? Anti-phospholipid syndrome"
"Lupus anticoagulant (anti-phospholipid antibody) is associated with prolonged PTT and a(n) hyper-coagulable state"
"Pica, especially for ice (pagophagia), may be indicative of iron deficiency anemia"
"What is the most common underlying etiology of pancytopenia in patients with SLE? Immune-mediated peripheral destruction"
"Patients with pernicious anemia should be monitored for development of gastric cancer"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that develops fever/chills, flank pain, hemoglobinuria, and DIC within 1 hour after starting RBC tranfusion? Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction"
"What is the usually the underlying etiology behind acute hemolytic transfusion reactions? ABO incompatibility"
"What is the likely underlying cause of vitamin B12 deficiency in a Caucasian male with fatigue, atrophic glossitis, vitiligo, and a vegan diet x5 months? Pernicious anemia"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with brownish skin pigmentation, elevated fasting glucose, and elevated LFTs? Hereditary hemochromatosis"
"Chronic myeloid leukemia is associated with a(n) low leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score"
"Diagnosis of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria may be made with flow cytometry, which can detect the absence of the proteins CD55 and CD59"
"What is the likely underlying cause of microcytic anemia in a patient with chronic kidney disease that recently began erythropoietin therapy? Iron deficiency"
"What vitamins (3) are typically administered to patients with hypercoagulability secondary to increased homocysteine levels? vitamin B6 (pyridoxine), B9 (folate), and B12 (cobalamin)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an alcoholic patient that begins bleeding from an IV site on post-operative day 7 after having an emergency surgery? Laboratory exam reveals anemia with elevated PT/PTT and normal platelet counts. Vitamin K deficiency"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an adult African-American patient that presents with splenomegaly and scleral icterus two weeks after having a URI treated with amoxicillin? Peripheral blood smear reveals spherocytosis. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia"
"What two viruses should be tested for in an asymptomatic patient with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)? HIV and hepatitis C"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young adult with worsening knee pain refractory to NSAID therapy and an expansile lytic area in the epiphysis of the distal femur identified on X-ray? Giant cell tumor of bone (osteoclastoma)"
"What is the pathophysiologic mechanism underlying polycythemia in patients with obstructive sleep apnea? Increased EPO production from kidneys (secondary to hypoxemia)"
"What screening tests would be useful for evaluating an elderly patient with chronic arm pain, anemia, and back pain (X-ray below)? Serum/urine protein electrophoresis (SPEP/UPEP) or serum free light chain analysis"
"Intravascular hemolytic anemias are associated with decreased levels of haptoglobin"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that received a bone marrow transplantation from a sibling that develops a maculopapular rash, bloody diarrhea, and elevated LFTs after two weeks? Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an African-American male that develops dark urine, fatigue, and jaundice after being treated with TMP-SMX? Peripheral smear reveals bite cells, but a G6PD activity assay is normal. G6PD deficiency"
"Leukemoid reaction is associated with a(n) high leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score"
"What is the most important initial screening test in a Mediterranean female receiving preconception counseling due to possible thalassemia? CBC"
"What type of anemia is characterized by the following laboratory values? MCV: low Serum iron: high Ferritin: high Sideroblastic anemia"
"What is the recommended treatment for a patient with suspected sideroblastic anemia after initiating RIPE therapy for tuberculosis? Pyridoxine (vitamin B6)"
"What category of therapy is characterized the following scenario: a patient undergoes radical prostatectomy and has an undetectable PSA post-surgery. Several months later, the patient's PSA is elevated again and he undergoes radiation therapy. Salvage therapy"
"What category of therapy is characterized the following scenario: a patient undergoes radical prostatectomy with concurrent radiation therapy for prostate cancer. Adjuvant therapy"
"What category of therapy is characterized the following scenario: a patient undergoes radiation therapy prior to having a radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer. Neoadjuvant therapy"
"What peripheral blood smear finding is associated with multiple myeloma? Rouleaux formation"
"What is the recommended treatment for polycythemia vera? Phlebotomy +/- hydroxyurea"
"What is the most common side effect associated with recombinant erythropoietin? Worsening of hypertension (30%)"
"What amino acid is likely elevated in a patient with the following peripheral blood smear? Homocysteine"
"What is the diagnostic test of choice for chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)? Flow cytometry"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient that presents with headaches, blurry vision, hepatosplenomegaly? Serum protein electrophoresis reveals a sharp M-spike of IgM. Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia"
"What chromosomal mutation underlies the pathophysiology of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)? t(9;22); BCR-ABL fusion"
"What is the first-line treatment for most patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)? Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g. imatinib)"
"What is the recommended treatment for a patient initiated on phenytoin therapy for seizures that develops anemia? Folic acid"
"What peripheral blood smear finding is associated with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)? Smudge cells"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young male that presents with irritability, aggressive behavior, and gynecomastia with isolated polycythemia on laboratory exam? Androgen abuse"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a signficant smoking history that presents with daytime headaches, dizziness, and nausea? CBC reveals elevated hemoglobin levels. The patient works in a parking garage. Carbon monoxide poisoning"
"What is the recommended pharmacologic treatment for patients with cancer-related anorexia/cachexia syndrome (CACS)? Progesterone analogs (preferred) or corticosteroids"
"What is the recommended pharmacologic treatment for patients with chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting? 5-HT3 (serotonin) receptor antagonists"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that develops wheezing, respiratory distress, and hypotension minutes after reciving a pRBC transfusion? Anaphylactic reaction"
"What condition is associated with increased risk for anaphylactic reaction when receiving blood transfusions? IgA deficiency"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a landscaper with a finger ulceration, draining an odorless, nonpurulent discharge, that spread to include similar nodules along the forearm? There is no lymphadenopathy on physical exam. Sporotrichosis"
"What is the recommended treatment for sporotrichosis? Oral itraconazole (3 - 6 months)"
"What is the next step in management for an asymptomatic patient that has a 12-mm induration two days after a PPD injection? The patient has no TB risk factors. No additional intervention required"
"In the United States, a PPD is considered negative in healthy patients with low likelihood of TB if the induration size is < 15 mm"
"What autoimmune antibody may be elevated in patients with infective endocarditis? Rheumatoid factor"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that recently returned from Mexico and developed abdominal pain and nausea/vomiting, followed by periorbital edema and muscle pain a few days later? Laboratory exam reveals eosinophilia and elevated creatine kinase. Trichinellosis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a recent UTI that presents with fever, back pain, focal tenderness over the L4-L5 vertebrae, and paravertebral muscle spasm? Vertebral osteomyelitis"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with suspected vertebral osteomyelitis that has a significantly elevated ESR with normal spinal X-ray? MRI"
"What is the recommended treatment for patients with cryptococcal meningoencephalitis? amphotericin B plus flucytosine, followed by fluconazole"
"What is the likely underlying infection in a patient with recurrent blisters on sun-exposed areas with fatigue, nausea, and elevated LFTs? Chronic hepatitis C infection"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents in the winter with abrupt onset high-grade fever, headache, and severe myalgias? No lymphadenopathy or abnormal lung sounds are appreciated on physical exam. Influenza"
"What is the recommended treatment for a middle-aged patient that presents with symptoms related to influenza for 4 days? Symptomatic treatment"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with fever, sore throat, drooling, and muffled voice with pooled secretions visible in the oropharynx? There is no visible swelling of the floor of the mouth. Epiglottitis"
"What are the recommendations regarding live attenuated virus vaccination (e.g. MMR, zoster, varicella) in HIV patients? Vaccinate if CD4+ counts > 200/mm3 and titers are low"
"When should a patient visiting a malaria endemic country take chemoprophylactics (e.g. mefloquine)? > 2 weeks prior to travel, during the stay, and 4 weeks after returning"
"In areas with high rates of chloroquine-resistant malaria, chemoprophylaxis typically includes atovaquone-proguanil, doxycycline, or mefloquine"
"What anti-malarial drug is used to prevent dormant hepatic hypnozoites in patients infected with Plasmodium vivax? Primaquine"
"What is the next step for confirming the diagnosis in a patient that developed a non-painful ulcer on the shaft of his penis with negative VDRL and HIV tests? Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS)"
"What is the most common microorganism causing infective endocarditis in IV drug users? Staphylococcus aureus"
"What is the recommended empiric treatment for infective endocarditis in IV drug users with native heart valves? Vancomycin"
"What is the likely causative microorganism in an alcoholic sailor that develops high-grade fever hours after cutting his foot while sailing in the ocean? The cut is surrounded by erythema and dark-colored bullae with streaking erythema extending proximally up the limb. Vibrio vulnificus"
"Infection with Vibrio vulnificus causes severe infection in patients who have liver::organ disease"
"What is the most common source of infection causing Ludwig angina? Infected mandibular molar (dental infection)"
