"What is the likely diagnosis in a HIV patient from Missouri with a CD4+ count of 50/mm3 that presents with cough/dyspnea, mouth ulcers, and diffuse lymphadenopathy? Laboratory exam reveals pancytopenia and elevated LFTs. Disseminated histoplasmosis"
"What is the recommended treatment for patients with disseminated histoplasmosis? IV Amphotericin B (1-2 weeks), followed by oral itraconazole (> 1 year)"
"What are the two most common causes of secondary bacterial pneumonia? Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus aureus"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with recently diagnosed infective endocarditis that now presents with fever and left-sided chest/abdominal pain? CT reveals a left-sided pleural effusion and splenomegaly with a splenic fluid collection. Splenic abscess (secondary to IE)"
"What is the recommended empiric treatment for high-risk patients with febrile neutropenia? broad-spectrum anti-pseudomonal agents (e.g. cefepime, meropenem, piperacillin-tazobactam)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with an intensely pruritic lesion on the foot (picture below)? Cutaneous larva migrans"
"How is cutaneous larva migrans typically acquired (mode of transmission)? Walking barefoot on contaminated sand or soil"
"What is the likely causative organism in a patient who develops infective endocarditis after having a recent cystoscopy for persistent dysuria? Enterococci (e.g. Enterococcus faecalis)"
"Osteomyelitis in diabetic patients is typically preceded by a long-standing foot ulcer that spreads contiguously to bone, causing a(n) poly-microbial infection"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with syphilis that develops fever, headache, myalgia, and a diffuse macular rash on the palms/soles after receiving a dose of IV penicillin G hours ago? Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction"
"What is the likely result of the following serologic tests in a patient vaccinated against hepatitis B? HBsAg: negative HBsAb: positive HBcAb: negative"
"What is the likely result of the following serologic tests in a patient naturally immunized against hepatitis B? HBsAg: negative HBsAb: positive HBcAb: positive"
"What is the likely result of the following serologic tests in a patient with chronic hepatitis B? HBsAg: positive HBsAb: negative HBcAb: positive"
"What antibody is typically positive during the window phase of hepatitis B infection? IgM anti-HBc"
"In healthy adults, acute hepatitis B infection is self-limited in > 90-95% of cases"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an IV drug user with a history of recent incarceration that presents with sub-acute onset of intermittent fevers, weight loss, fatigue, and non-productive cough (CXR below)? Miliary tuberculosis"
"What is the likely causative microorganism in a renal transplant patient that develops fever, progressive dyspnea on exertion, abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and elevated LFTs? Cytomegalovirus"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young adult that presents with two-days of sore throat, enlarged/erythematous tonsils, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly? Many variant forms of lymphocytes are seen on peripheral smear despite a negative heterophile antibody test. Infectious mononucleosis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with poorly controlled HIV that presents with a two day history of severe odynophagia, but no dysphagia? Oral examination is unremarkable (no thrush). Viral esophagitis::Viral/Candidal esophagitis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with flu-like symptoms without a rash after being bitten by a tick two weeks ago? Laboratory exam reveals leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and signs of hemolytic anemia. Babesiosis"
"What type of tick is responsible for spreading babesia? Ixodes scapularis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an HIV patient with a CD4+ count of 175/mm3 that presents with fever, dry cough, and hypoxia? Laboratory exam reveals elevated LDH and CXR reveals diffuse, bilateral infiltrates. Pneumocystis pneumonia"
"What is the likely causative organism in a male that presents with dysuria, urinary frequency, and mucopurulent discharge? Gram stain and urine culture are negative. Chlamydia trachomatis"
"What is the test of choice to confirm the diagnosis of chlamydial urethritis? Nucleic acid amplification test"
"What are the indications for the PPSV23 vaccine, alone, in adults? Age < 65 with other chronic medical conditions (e.g. heart/lung/liver disease, diabetes, smoking)"
"What are the indications for sequential PCV13 vaccine, followed by PPSV23 vaccine 6-12 months later, in adults? Age > 65 or very high risk patients < 65 (e.g. HIV, asplenia, cochlear implants, immunocompromised, CKD)"
"What is the recommended tetanus vaccine schedule for adults with an unknown vaccination history? Tdap once → Td q10y"
"What is the preferred treatment for a patient with infective endocarditis secondary to penicillin-sensitive Streptococcus mutans? IV ceftriaxone (preferred) or IV penicillin G for 4 weeks"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with recent travel in rural areas of South America that presents after having a generalized tonic clonic seizure? Brain MRI reveals several cystic lesions with surrounding edema. Neurocysticercosis"
"What is the treatment of choice for patients with suspected nocardiasis? Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a sex worker that presents with fever/chills, polyarthralgia, and pustules on the chest and extensor surfaces of the forearms? Disseminated gonococcal infection"
"What is the likely causative organism in a patient that presents with fever and mild pharyngeal erythema without lymphadenopathy? A heterophile antibody test is negative. Cytomegalovirus"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with pneumonia symptoms, violaceous/verrucous skin lesions, and bone lesions? The patient works as a construction worker in Wisconsin. Blastomycosis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with poorly controlled HIV that presents with headaches, confusion, fever, and mild neurologic deficits? Brain MRI: several ring-enhancing lesions Toxoplasma encephalitis"
"What is the recommended treatment for patients with toxoplasmosis? sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine"
"Patients with HIV who present with an AIDS defining illness secondary to lack of anti-retroviral therapy should be initiated on HAART two weeks after treatment of the infection"
"Patients who received blood transfusions before 1992 should be screened for hepatitis C"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with poorly controlled diabetes that presents with fever, bloody nasal discharge, and necrosis of the right nasal turbinate/hard palate? Mucormycosis"
"How is the diagnosis of mucormycosis established? sinus endoscopy with biopsy & culture"
"What is the recommended treatment for a patient with suspected Entamoeba histolytica liver abscess? metronidazole and a luminal agent (e.g. paromomycin)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient that presents with two days of fever, altered mental status, seizures, and the lumbar puncture findings below? Opening pressure: normal Protein: normal RBCs: high WBCs: high Lymphocytes: 90% Viral encephalitis (e.g. HSV)"
"What viral testing should be offered to a patient with fever, arthralgias, lymphadenopathy, prolonged diarrhea, and mucosal ulcerations? HIV testing"
"What is the likely causative organism in an HIV patient with a CD4+ count of 30/mm3 that presents with one month of fever, intermittent bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss? Cytomegalovirus (CMV)"
"What type of cancer is associated with Streptococcus gallolyticus infection? Colorectal cancer"
"What is the recommended prophylaxis for an unvaccinated healthcare worker that is exposed to blood from a hepatitis B positive patient? hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B immune globulin"
"Antibiotic prophylaxis in HIV patients with CD4+ count < 50/mm3 should include TMP-SMX::PCP, toxoplasma"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that is bitten by a neighbor's dog? The dog appears healthy but is not vaccinated against rabies. Observe the dog for 10 days for signs of rabies; post-exposure prophylaxis only if dog is symptomatic"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with two days of burning pain on the abdomen, followed by development of the rash below? Herpes zoster (shingles)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young adult with grey mucosal patches in the mouth, widespread (esp. epitrochlear) lymphadenopathy, and a diffuse maculopapular rash? Secondary syphilis"
"What prophylactic medications should be initiated in a patient who is beginning high-dose immunosuppression therapy following a renal transplant? 1. TMP-SMX (for PCP) 2. Ganciclovir or valganclovir (for CMV)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with multiple, large, well-demarcated painful ulcers on the penis with purulent exudate? The patient also has severe inguinal lymphadenopathy. Chancroid (Haemophilus ducreyi infection)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that recently returned from a trip to Kenya and presents with headache, fatigue, and episodic fever? Malaria"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that develops fever, malaise, splinter hemorrhages, and aortic regurgitation following a dental procedure? Obtain blood cultures"
"What is the likely causative organism in a patient that develops osteomyelitis after stepping on a rusty nail? The nail pierced the patient's shoes and pierced the heel. Pseudomonas aeruginosa"
"What systemic mycoses are endemic to the Mississippi and Ohio River basins? Histoplasma and Blastomyces"
"What systemic mycoses are endemic to the Southwestern U.S.? Coccidioides"
"What is the diagnostic test of choice for patients with suspected Pneumocystis pneumonia without an adequate induced sputum sample? Bronchoalveolar lavage"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an Army officer in Arizona that presents with pleuritic chest pain, fever, arthralgias, and erythematous, tender nodules on the bilateral shins? CXR shows a right lower lobe infiltrate. Coccidioides immitis infection"
"What is the recommended meningococcal vaccine schedule for normal risk patients? primary vaccine preferably at age 11-12; booster at age 16-21"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with recent travel out of the country that presents with fever, jaundice, and tender hepatomegaly with very elevated LFTs (AST/ALT > 1,000 U/L)? Acute hepatitis A infection"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with recent travel to the Caribbean that presents with fever, polyarthralgias, and a diffuse maculopapular skin rash? Laboratory exam reveals leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. Chikungunya fever"
"What is the recommended treatment for Legionnaire's disease? macrolides or respiratory fluoroquinolones (e.g. levofloxacin, moxifloxacin)"
"What is the next step in management for a patient being treated with RIPE therapy for TB for the past month that develops mild elevations in AST/ALT? Continue with current treatment; monitor LFTs"
"What is the recommended hepatitis A vaccine schedule for adults who are not immunized (4 groups)? Recommended for men who have sex with men, IV drug users, travelers to endemic areas, and those with chronic liver disease"
"What is the likely causative organism in a patient with poorly controlled HIV that presents with large, reddish pedunculated skin lesions that bleed easily? CT scan of the abdomen reveals hypodense liver lesions that enhance with IV contrast. Bartonella spp."
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with poorly controlled HIV that develops multiple violaceous papules in the groin region? Kaposi sarcoma (HHV-8 infection)"
"What valvular dysfunction is most likely to be detected in a patient with a history of a \heart murmur\\" that develops infective endocarditis? Mitral regurgitation / MVP\""
"What is the next step in management for a patient that notices a tick on the leg with surrounding erythema after spending the past day outside? Remove the tick with tweezers and reassure"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with poorly controlled HIV that presents with subacute-onset fatigue, headache, and fever? Physical exam reveals signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g. bilateral papilledema). Brain MRI is normal. Cryptococcal meningoencephalitis"
"What is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia in HIV patients? Streptococcus pneumoniae"
"What is the recommended treatment for mucormycosis? surgical debridement, liposomal amphotericin B, and elimination of promoting factors"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an adolescent patient that presents with headache, fever, nuchal rigidity, and lower extremity petechiae? CSF: Glucose: low Protein: high Leukocytes: high, neutrophilic predominance Meningococcal meningitis"
"Why is empiric antibiotic therapy avoided in patients with suspected enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) infection? May increase risk of HUS"
"What screening test(s) for STDs should be offered to an asymptomatic 22-year-old male that is not yet sexually active? HIV screening (p24 antigen and HIV antibody tests)"
"A PPD is considered positive in HIV patients if the induration size is > 5 mm"
"What is the next step in management for an HIV patient who has an 8-mm induration at 48 hours following PPD testing and a normal chest X-ray? 9 months of Isoniazid and pyridoxine (B6)"
"What is the likely diagnosis and causative organism in a patient that presents with a 1-day history of fever and a warm, tender, erythematous rash with raised, well-demarcated borders? Erysipelas; Streptococcus pyogenes (group A strep)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an HIV patient with a CD4+ count of 25/mm3 that presents with 3 weeks of fever, night sweats, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss? CXR, CMV serology, and PPD are all negative. Disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with suspected infectious mononucleosis that develops anemia and thrombocytopenia two weeks after the onset of IM symptoms? autoimmune hemolytic anemia"
"What is the most common manifestation of carditis secondary to Lyme disease? AV block"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with pyelonephritis that has clinically resolved after two days of IV ceftriaxone? Urine culture reveals E. coli sensitive to ceftriaxone and TMP-SMX. Switch to oral TMP-SMX"
"What is the recommended tetanus prophylaxis in an adult that stepped on a rusty nail? He received a 3-dose primary tetanus vaccination as a child (> 10 years ago). Tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine"
"What is the diagnostic test of choice for patients with suspected leprosy? Skin biopsy from the edge of a lesion"
"What is the recommended treatment for patients with mild leprosy? Dapsone and rifampin"
"What is the likely causative organism in an HIV patient with a CD4+ count of 85/mm3 that presents with three weeks of copious, watery diarrhea and low-grade fever? Cryptosporidium"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with HIV and a CD4+ count of < 200 that presents with altered mental status and motor deficits? Brain MRI reveals non-enhancing, focal white matter lesions with no edema. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML)"
"What microorganism is associated with acute epididymitis in older men (age > 35)? E. coli"
"What is the likely causative organism in an IV drug user that presents with three days of fever, pleuritic chest pain, and shortness of breath? Chest imaging reveals multiple nodular lesions with small cavities. Staphylococcus aureus"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with HIV and a CD4+ count of 85/mm3 that presents with dysphagia and substernal burning? White plaques that are easily removable are present on the palate. Oral fluconazole"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a slow-growing, painless mass in the mandible? The mass recently began draining a purulent discharge with small yellow granules. The patient's history is significant for a recent tooth extraction. Cervicofacial Actinomyces infection"
"What is the preferred treatment for a patient with cervicofacial actinomyces infection? Pencillin"
"What is the next step in management for a healthcare worker following a needle stick injury while drawing blood from an HIV-positive patient with a high viral load? Draw blood for HIV serology and start anti-retroviral therapy with 3 drugs immediately"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with pruritus and the rash below? A punch biopsy shows linear IgG and C3 deposits at the dermal-epidermal junction. Bullous pemphigoid"
"What is the first-line treatment for patients with bullous pemphigoid? High-potency topical glucocorticoids (e.g. clobetasol)"
"What is the first-line treatment for non-inflammatory comedonal acne vulgaris? Topical retinoids"
"What is the first-line treatment for mild inflammatory acne vulgaris? Benzoyl peroxide and topical retinoids"
"What patient population is likely to have a prolonged course of molluscum contagiosum, with widespread papules? Immunocompromised patients (e.g. HIV)"
"What is the most common skin malignancy in immunocompromised patients and patients with a chronic scar? Squamous cell carcinoma"
"What skin malignancy is most likely in a patient with a significant history of sun exposure and a slow-growing lesion (pictured below)? Basal cell carcinoma"
"What is the likely causative organism in a patient that presents with the rash below? Poxvirus"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient with a history of hepatitis C that presents with painless, pruritic vesicles and erosions on the dorsum of both hands? The patient has a history of \fragile skin\\""
"What is the likely diagnosis in an older patient with a black, raised nodule (pictured below)? It has a rubbery texture and oily surface. It has not changed in appearance over time. Seborrheic keratosis"
"Patients that have sudden onset of multiple seborrheic keratoses should be evaluated for underlying internal malignancy (e.g. GI)"
"What metal most likely caused the contact dermatitis pictured below? Nickel"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a lesion on the foot (pictured below)? The lesion is non-tender, firm, hyperpigmented, and has a central dimple in the center when pinched at the edges. Dermatofibroma"
"A young, obese patient presents with a velvety rash in the axilla and back of the neck (pictured below). What pathologic condition is likely associated with this rash? Insulin resistance"
"What underlying condition is associated with acanthosis nigricans in older individuals? GI malignancy"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a sexually active college student with the rash below? It is painful and associated with low-grade fever. Herpetic whitlow (secondary to HSV infection)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with a 2 x 1 cm pigmented lesion on the abdomen (pictured below)? The lesion has increased in size over the past 6 months. Malignant melanoma"
"Vitiligo is often associated with other autoimmune conditions"
"What is the recommended treatment for a patient that develops rapid-onset pruritus and multiple urticaria after taking amoxicillin for a sore throat? The lungs are clear to auscultation and there is no stridor. Antihistamines and discontinuation of amoxicillin"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with painful mouth ulcerations and scattered, large painful blisters on the trunk and extremities? Light rubbing of uninvolved skin causes easy separation of the epidermis. Punch biopsy shows IgG and C3 deposits in a net-like pattern. Pemphigus vulgaris"
"What is the target of autoimmune antibodies in patients with pemphigus vulgaris? Desmosomes (desmogleins 1 & 3)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that develops numerous pruritic, erythematous papules with scattered vesicles/pustules on the finger webs, palms, and wrist creases (pictured below)? The itching is worse at night, and the patient also has numerous excoriations on the wrist. Scabies"
"What is the recommended treatment for adults with scabies? topical permethrin or oral ivermectin"
"What antibiotic is frequently prescribed for treatment of acne and associated with photosensitivity as an adverse reaction? Doxycycline"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with an intensely pruritic and burning rash (pictured below)? The patient has also experienced ocassional diarrhea and weight loss. Dermatitis herpetiformis"
"What is the recommended treatment for dermatitis herpetiformis? dapsone (acute relief) and a gluten-free diet (long-term relief)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with well-circumscribed and raised erythematous plaques with intense pruritus (pictured below)? The rash occurs episodically, approximately 2 - 3x/day, with each episode lasting about 6 - 8 hours. Urticaria"
"Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignancy of the lower lip"
"Squamous cell carcinoma is characterized histologically by invasive cords of squamous cells with keratin pearls"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that noticed hypopigmented skin lesions on her trunk after returning from a summer vacation in Florida (pictured below)? Tinea versicolor (due to Malassezia infection)"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that presents with basal cell carcinoma on the cheek (pictured below)? Mohs surgery"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with recent steroid use who presents with uniform-appearing, erythematous papules across the back, shoulders, and upper arms? The papules appear to be in same stage of development and do not have associated comedones. Drug-induced acne (e.g. secondary to glucocorticoid use)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a middle-aged patient that presents with the lesions below? Cherry angioma"
"Do cherry hemangiomas typically regress spontaneously? No"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with facial erythema, flushing, and telangiectasias? The flushing is precipitated by alcohol and hot drinks. Rosacea"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with diffusely rough, dry, and scaly skin? The symptoms are worse in the winter, and symptoms of dry skin have been present for most of the patient's life. Ichthyosis vulgaris"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with fever, mucosal lesions, and a desquamating rash on the trunk/thighs (pictured below)? The patient was prescribed TMP-SMX one week ago. Stevens-Johnson syndrome/Toxic epidermal necrolysis"
"What is the next step in management for a teenage male that presents with moderate inflammatory acne refractory to topical retinoids and benzoyl peroxide? Topical antibiotics (e.g. erythromycin, clindamycin)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an adult patient that presents with a pruritic rash for 6 weeks (pictured below)? Tinea corporis (ringworm)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient with multiple ecchymoses on the hands and forearms? The lesions are not itchy nor painful and laboratory studies are within normal limits. Senile purpura"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a middle-aged patient that presents with an itchy, greasy, yellowish, scaly facial rash (pictured below) and increased dandruff? Seborrheic dermatitis"
"Seborrheic dermatitis is associated with HIV and central nervous system disorders, especially Parkinson disease"
"What is the recommended treatment for seborrheic dermatitis in adults? Topical antifungals"
"Which type of skin infection involves the superficial dermis and manifests as raised, sharply demarcated edges? Erysipelas"
"Which type of skin infection involves the deep dermis and manifests as a flat, erythematous rash with indistinct borders? Cellulitis"
"Cellulitis is typically caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (nonpurulent) or Staphylococcus aureus (purulent)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young athlete that presents with sharp, non-radiating pain on the medial side of the tibia just below the knee after falling one week ago? A valgus stress test has no effect on the pain. Pes anserinus pain syndrome (anserine bursitis)"
"What is the recommended initial treatment for a patient that presents with their first episode of uncomplicated gout? NSAIDs (preferred), glucocorticoids, or colchicine"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young woman that presents with fever and migratory joint pain? Synovial fluid analysis reveals 65,000 WBC/mm3 with neutrophilic predominance. Gonococcal septic arthritis"
"Which form of Raynaud's phenomenon, primary or secondary, is characterized by asymmetric attacks with clinical features of tissue ischemia (e.g. numbness, ulcers)? Secondary Raynaud's phenomenon"
"Which form of Raynaud's phenomenon, primary or secondary, is characterized by symmetric attacks without tissue injury (e.g. numbness, ulcers)? Primary Raynaud's phenomenon"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with painful oral ulcers and mildly elevated LFTs? She was recently diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and started on medical therapy. Methotrexate side effect"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young female athlete that presents with sharp, localized pain to palpation along the 2nd metatarsal bone? The patient is an avid runner and her BMI is 18 kg/m2. Stress fracture"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an afebrile patient that presents with acute right ankle pain that becomes \unbearable\\" over a few hours? He recalls having a similar episode 1 year ago that resolved with over-the-counter medication. Gout\""
"What X-ray finding is characteristic of pseudogout (calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal deposition disease)? Chondrocalcinosis (calcification of articular cartilage)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a middle-aged patient with recently diagnosed diabetes mellitus that presents with pseudogout and hepatomegaly? Hereditary hemochromatosis"
"What is the initial test that should be ordered in a patient with suspected SLE? Antinuclear antibody (ANA)"
"Systemic sclerosis is often characterized by decreased peristalsis and decreased tone in the lower esophageal sphincter on manometry"
"What musculoskeletal pathology is significantly more prevalent in patients with rheumatoid arthritis? Osteopenia/osteoporosis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of recurrent pulmonary infections that presents with facial swelling, bilateral lower-extremity edema, hepatomegaly, and palpable kidneys? Urinalysis reveals 4+ proteinuria. Secondary (AA) amyloidosis"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that presents with suspected lumbosacral radiculopathy (sciatica) after lifting a heavy box? Neurological exam is unremarkable. Trial of NSAIDs/acetaminophen"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a one-week history of fatigue and symmetric joint pain/stiffness for 10 - 15 minutes upon awakening? The patient's ESR is normal. She works at a day care center. Parvovirus B19 infection"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a construction worker that complains of his \hard hat being tighter\\"? CT head reveals thickened skull cortices with mixed lytic and osteoblastic lesions. Paget disease of bone\""
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young female that presents with foot pain? The patient experiences pain and a clicking sensation when the 3rd/4th metatarsal heads are squeezed together. Morton neuroma"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a middle-aged woman with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness and mild muscle pain? There are no dermatologic findings and serum creatine kinase is elevated. Polymyositis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a middle-aged woman with fatigue and chronic widespread pain with focal areas of tenderness? Serum creatine kinase, ESR, and CRP are within normal limits. Fibromyalgia"
"What pathology is associated with positive anti-Jo-1 (anti-synthetase) and anti-Mi-2 (anti-helicase) titers? polymyositis/dermatomyositis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with joint pain/stiffness in the hands, especially in the DIP joints (pictured below)? Psoriatic arthritis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a middle-aged patient with a history of SLE* that presents with progressive hip pain for the past six weeks? The pain is worst with abduction and internal rotation. Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis)"
"What is the recommended imaging modality for a patient with back pain secondary to suspected malignancy (e.g. nocturnal pain, weight loss)? X-ray"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an asymptomatic elderly male with isolated elevated alkaline phosphatase? Physical exam, including rectal exam, is insignificant. Paget disease of bone"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with arthralgias, fatigue, and painless, palpable purpura on the bilateral legs? Laboratory examination reveals elevated LFTs, evidence of glomerulonephritis (hematuria & proteinuria), and low serum C4. Mixed cryoglobulinemia syndrome"
"What viral infections are commonly associated with mixed cryoglobulinemia syndrome? HCV and HIV"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with hand swelling/stiffness with skin thickening in the fingers (pictured below)? The patient also experiences Raynaud's phenomenon. Systemic sclerosis (Scleroderma)"
"What pathology is associated with anti-topoisomerase I antibodies? Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an older woman with pain behind the right heel several days after beginning treatment for a UTI? Achilles tendinopathy"

"What is the first-line treatment for reactive arthritis? NSAIDs"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young adult male that presents with diffuse enthesitis and lower back pain? The lower back pain is worse at night and improved with activity. Ankylosing spondylitis"
"What valvular defect is associated with ankylosing spondylitis? Aortic regurgitation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of painful arthritis in the fingers and feet that presents to the clinic with the skin findings below? Tophaceous gout"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an older woman with unilateral headache, jaw pain, and vision loss? Funduscopy shows a swollen pale disc with blurred margins. ESR is elevated. Giant cell (temporal) arteritis"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with suspected giant cell arteritis? High-dose glucocorticoids"
"Spondyloarthropathies associated with HLA-B27 may be remembered with mnemonic \PAIR\\": P: Psoriasis A: Ankylosing spondylitis I: Inflammatory bowel disease R: Reactive arthritis\""
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient with inflammatory bowel disease that has had the leg ulcer below for 1 month? Pyoderma gangrenosum"
"What imaging modality is initially used to diagnose ankylosing spondylitis? X-ray (of sacroiliac joints)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with two months of progressive left shoulder stiffness? The patient has markedly decreased passive and active abduction, flexion, and rotation of the left shoulder. Adhesive capsulitis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an older woman that presents with pain/stiffness in the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints? Osteoarthritis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a postpartum patient with lateral wrist pain that is worst with ulnar deviation while grasping the thumb? De Quervain tenosynovitis"
"Synovial fluid analysis in patients with pseudogout is characterized by rhomboid-shaped crystals made of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate, that are weakly positively-birefringent"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young female with months of progressive achy pain in the anterior right knee? The pain is worsened with running and sitting for an extended period. Patellofemoral pain syndrome"
"What is the initial pharmacologic therapy for treatment of patellofemoral pain syndrome? NSAIDs"
"The initial management for patients with fibromyalgia includes a(n) regular exercise program, patient education, and good sleep hygiene"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an older patient with headache, bone pain, and hearing loss? Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)"
"What is the first-line pharmacologic therapy for patients with fibromyalgia that do not respond to conservative management? Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g. amitriptyline)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient with right-sided neck pain and sensory deficits over the posterior forearm? Physical exam reveals limited neck rotation and lateral bending. Cervical spondylosis"
"What is the most common finding on cervical radiography in patients with cervical spondylosis? Osteophytes"
"Routine monitoring of which organ is necessary for patient's being treated with long-term hydroxychloroquine? Eyes"
"What physical exam test is helpful for diagnosing patellofemoral syndrome? Patellofemoral compression test"
"What is the most sensitive test for the diagnosis of avascular necrosis? MRI"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly male with low-grade fever, arthritis, diarrhea, and generalized lymphadenopathy? Small intestinal biopsy reveals PAS-positive, acid-fast negative macrophages. Whipple's disease"
"What is the recommended treatment for polymyalgia rheumatica? Low-dose glucocorticoids"
"Spondyloarthropathies often result in inflammation at sites of tendon/ligament insertion (enthesitis), leading to gradual onset of low back pain and progressive stiffness"
"What is the recommended treatment for a patient with symptomatic osteoarthritis despite a supervised exercise program and weight loss? NSAIDs/acetaminophen"
"Common causes of lumbar stenosis include vertebral osteoarthritis, degenerative disc disease, and thickening of the ligamentum flavum"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young adult male with one month of shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and fatigue? The patient is hypercalcemic and has bilateral hilar fullness on CXR: Sarcoidosis"
"What is the recommended treatment for patients with symptomatic sarcoidosis? Glucocorticoids"
"What symptom classically arises in patients with Paget disease that affects the temporal bone? Hearing loss"
"What pharmacologic treatment is recommended for patients with symptomatic primary Raynaud's phenomenon? Calcium channel blockers"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with one day of unilateral knee pain/swelling? Laboratory examination reveals significant hypercalcemia. Pseudogout (calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate deposition disease)"
"Felty syndrome classically presents with a triad of rheumatoid arthritis plus splenomegaly and neutropenia"
"What aortic complication is associated with giant cell (temporal) arteritis? Aortic aneurysm"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with back pain after carrying heavy packages? Physical exam reveals paravertebral tenderness. Lumbosacral strain"
"What bladder complications are associated with long-term use of cyclophosphamide? acute hemorrhagic cystitis and bladder carcinoma"
"What is the recommended next step in management for a patient with chronic low back pain despite intermittent use of acetaminophen and NSAIDs? Exercise therapy"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of lung cancer that presents with one month of constant low back pain, especially at night? Physical exam reveals local spinal tenderness at L4-L5. Metastatic bone disease"
"Behçet syndrome is characterized by a triad of recurrent aphthous ulcers, as well as genital ulcers and uveitis"
"What vascular complication is a major cause of morbidity in patients with Behçet syndrome? Thrombosis"
"What is the most common extraskeletal complication of ankylosing spondylitis? Anterior uveitis"
"What sickle cell disease complication commonly presents with progressive hip pain and reduced range of motion without fever? Avascular necrosis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with bilateral proximal muscle weakness? Physical exam reveals erythematous papules involving the dorsum of his fingers. Dermatomyositis"
"Which region of the spine is most commonly affected by rheumatoid arthritis? Cervical spine"
"What skin rash is commonly found in patients with sarcoidosis? Erythema nodosum"
"What is the recommended screening protocol for osteoporosis? One-time dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA scan) for all women > 65"
"Osteoporosis is defined with a DEXA scan T-score < -2.5"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with elbow pain that worsens with resisted wrist extension and wrist passive flexion? Lateral epicondylitis (\tennis elbow\\")\""
"What is the likely diagnosis in a diabetic patient with a severely deformed foot? X-ray shows large osteophytes and several extra-articular bone fragments. Charcot joint (neurogenic arthropathy)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with difficulty rising from a seated position and climbing stairs? The patient also has a violaceous, periorbital rash. Dermatomyositis"
"What is the recommended initial treatment for polymyositis? Oral glucocorticoids"
"How do the following laboratory values change in patients with Paget disease of bone? Serum calcium: No change Serum phosphorus: No change Alkaline phosphatase: Increase Urine hydroxyproline: Increase"
"How do the following laboratory values change in patients with osteoporosis? Serum calcium: No change Serum phosphorus: No change Alkaline phosphatase: No change Urine hydroxyproline: No change"
"What arthritic disorder is associated with hematologic malignancies (e.g. polycythemia vera)? Gout"
"What issue is partially eliminated when using matching during the design of a case-control study? Confounding"
"What bias may arise when the treatment regimen selected for a patient depends on the severity of the patient's condition? Susceptibility bias (a type of selection bias)"
"For a normal distribution, approximately 95% of all values are within 2 standard deviations from the mean"
"Effect modification occurs when an external variable changes the direction or strength of an association between a risk factor and disease"
"What type of bias occurs when the subjects of a study change their behavior because they are aware they are under observation? Hawthorne effect"
"The attributable risk percent can be derived from the relative risk using the formula ARP = (RR - 1)/RR"
"For the results of a study to be statistically significant, the 95% confidence interval must not contain zero or the null value"
"How do the following values change when moving the cutoff point of a screening test from B to A? Sensitivity: increased Specificity: decreased PPV: decreased NPV: increased"
"What type of bias occurs when a new screening test appears to prolong the survival of patients with a poor prognosis disease (e.g. pancreatic cancer)? Lead-time bias"
"What type of study design is characterized by multiple experimental interventions, each with two or more variables that are studied independently? Factorial design"
"What type of bias occurs in prospective studies when there is a large loss to follow-up? Attrition bias (a type of selection bias)"
"At what cut-off value will the number of false negatives be the highest? E"
"What type of study design describes the following study? Researchers identify patients with multidrug-resistant and pansensitive tuberculosis. They then review the patients past records for associated risk factors. Case control"
"What measure of association is typically used in case-control studies? Exposure odds ratio"
"What statistical method is typically used to compare proportions of a categorized outcome? Chi-square"
"The external validity of a study pertains to the applicability of the study results to other populations"
"The most effective interventions to reduce adverse events related to medications at times of transition of care (e.g. between inpatient and outpatient facilities) involve pharmacy personnel and high-risk patients"
"What type of bias/phenomenon occurs when the exposure to a risk factor needs a period of time before a significant outcome is revealed? Latency period"
"In what scenario does the odds ratio of a case-control study closely approximate the relative risk? Low disease incidence and prevalence (\rare disease assumption\\")\""
"What is the approximate sensitivity and specificity (high or low) on the receiver operating characteristic curve below? Sensitivity: high Specificity: low"
"The confidence interval of a study narrows as the sample size increases"
"What study design is best for determining the incidence of disease? Cohort"
"What study design is best for determining the prevalence of disease? Cross-sectional"
"A patient with a high probability of having a disease will have a relatively low negative predictive value"
"What type of study design measures exposure and outcome simultaneously at a particular point in time (\snapshot study\\")? Cross-sectional\""
"What is the next step in management for a patient that complains of foreign body sensation, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation of the right eye? This occurred after the patient was drilling and felt something blow into his eye. Gross examination with a penlight is unrevealing. Fluorescein examination"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with pain, edema, and redness over the medial canthus of the right eye for two days? Slight pressure over the area causes expression of purulent material. Dacryocystitis (infection of the lacrimal sac)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with a red, tender bump on the upper or lower eyelid? Hordeolum (stye)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with sudden onset severe pain in the left eye, accompanied by headache, n/v, blurred vision? The left eye appears red, with a hazy cornea, and mid-dilated, fixed pupil. It is hard to the touch. Acute angle closure glaucoma"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young adult male that presents with pain, watering, and redness of the left eye for two days? Examination reveals vesicles and dendritic ulcers in the cornea of the left eye. He has had similar symptoms in the past. Herpes simplex keratitis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a diabetic patient that presents with sudden-onset loss of vision in the right eye? Ophthalmoscopy reveals loss of fundus details, floating debris, and a dark red glow. Vitreous hemorrhage"
"What is the underlying pathophysiology in a patient that presents with poor vision for close-up objects (presbyopia)? Decreased lens elasticity"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of asthma that presents with sudden onset redness, watery discharge, and itching of both eyes? The conjunctiva has a \bumpy\\" or granular appearance with diffuse injection. Allergic conjunctivitis\""
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of poorly controlled HIV that presents with floaters and blurred vision? Funduscopic examination reveals yellow-white exudates adjacent to the fovea and retinal vessels. CMV retinitis"
"What class of autonomic drugs should be avoided in patients with acute angle closure glaucoma? Anti-muscarinics (e.g. atropine)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that wears contacts and presents with sudden-onset eye pain and discharge? On examination, there is thick, globular yellow discharge. The cornea is hazy and ulcerated. Contact lens-associated keratitis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of poorly controlled HIV that presents with eye pain, conjunctivitis, keratitis, and vision loss? Funduscopy shows widespread, pale, peripheral retinal lesions and central necrosis of the retina. HSV retinitis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a diabetic patient that presents with decreased vision in both eyes? Ophthalmoscopy reveals microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, hard exudates, and macular edema. Diabetic retinopathy"
"What is the suggested treatment to prevent complications of proliferative diabetic retinopathy? Argon laser photocoagulation"
"Primary open angle glaucoma is characterized by gradual loss of peripheral vision and pathologic cupping of the optic disc on ophthalmoscopy"
"Macular degeneration is characterized by gradual loss of central vision"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient that presents with gradual onset blurred vision, glare, and difficulty driving at night for two months? The patient also complains of seeing halos around lights. Cataract"
"What is the initial treatment for external hordeolum (stye)? Warm compresses"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient with progressive vision loss over several months? When the patient is asked to look at a small spot on a grid made of vertical and horizontal lines, he describes the vertical lines as bent and wavy. Macular degeneration"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient with sudden loss of vision in the left eye? Funduscopic examination reveals swelling of the optic disc, retinal hemorrhages, dilated and tortuous veins, and cotton wool spots. Central retinal vein occlusion"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with \floating spots\\" and blurred vision in the right eye? Several weeks ago"
"What is the gold standard tool for diagnosis of acute angle closure glaucoma? gonioscopy or tonometry"
"What is the initial treatment for central retinal artery occlusion? Ocular massage and high-flow O2 administration"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a gritty sensation and watery discharge from the right eye for 3 days? The patient also has rhinorrhea, mild sore throat, and low-grade fever. Eye examination reveals conjunctival injection. Viral conjunctivitis"
"What is the recommended treatment for viral conjunctivitis? Warm or cold compresses + antihistamine/decongestant drops"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that woke up with a \red eye\\" (pictured below)? He does not complain of any symptoms. Observation\""
"What is the likely diagnosis in a 70-year-old man that complains of difficulty hearing and bilateral tinnitus? He has difficulty hearing in noisy, crowded environments. Presbycusis"
"What anti-hypertensive medication is associated with hearing loss? Loop diuretics (e.g. furosemide)"
"Aspirin exacerbated respiratory disease typically presents with a triad of asthma, chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, and bronchospasm after ingestion of aspirin/NSAIDs"
"What type of hearing loss is suggested by the hearing test results below in a patient with left-sided hearing loss? Rinne: bone > air conduction in the left ear; air > bone in the right Weber: lateralizes to the left ear Conductive hearing loss (left)"
"What type of hearing loss occurs with otosclerosis? Conductive hearing loss"
"What type of hearing loss typically occurs with ototoxic antibiotics (e.g. aminoglycosides)? Sensorineural hearing loss"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with right-sided ear pain that increases in severity when chewing food? The patient has nocturnal teeth grinding. Physical examination is normal. Temporomandibular joint dysfunction (TMJ)"
"Sialadenosis is a benign, non-inflammatory enlargement of the salivary glands"
"Sialadenosis is often seen in patients with malnutrition or advanced liver disease"
"What is the recommended initial treatment for patients with allergic rhinitis? Intranasal glucocorticoids"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a three day history of fever and sore throat that develops difficulty swallowing and a muffled voice? Physical exam reveals left-sided cervical lymphadenopathy with rightward deviation of the uvula. Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy)"
"What is the recommended treatment for peritonsillar abscess? incision & drainage and IV antibiotics"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient that presents with worsening severe left-sided ear pain with an edematous auditory canal and purulent discharge and granulation tissue visible on otoscopic exam? Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa"
"What is the recommended treatment for malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa? IV ciprofloxacin"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a significant smoking and drinking history that presents with a granular, non-indurated lesion on the buccal mucosa (pictured below)? The lesion is not removed by scraping with a tongue depressor. Leukoplakia"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a healthcare worker that presents with itchy, dry skin on the hands for the past month? Examination shows dry and irritated skin with erythema at the fingers, finger webs, and dorsum of the hands (pictured below). Irritant contact dermatitis"
"The PPSV23 pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine induces immunization via a(n) T-cell independent B-cell response (mechanism)"
"The PCV13 conjugate polysaccharide vaccine induces immunization via a(n) T-cell dependent B-cell response (mechanism)"
"What immunosuppressive agent has side effects including nephrotoxicity, hyperkalemia, gingival hypertrophy, and hirsuitism? Cyclosporine"
"The major toxicity/side effect associated with mycophenolate is bone marrow suppression"
"The major toxicities/side effects associated with azathioprine are dose-related diarrhea::GI, hepato::organ-toxicity, and leukopenia"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a 50-year-old male that presents with fever, chills, dysuria, and perineal pain? Rectal examination shows a boggy, tender prostate. Urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase. Acute bacterial prostatitis"
"Empiric antibiotic therapy for acute bacterial prostatitis consists of TMP-SMX or a(n) fluoroquinolone for a duration of 4 - 6 weeks"
"What is the next step in management for a male that presents with a painless, hard mass in his testicle and ultrasound imaging consistent with a testicular tumor? Radical orchiectomy"
"PDE-5 inhibitors (e.g. sildenafil) can cause significant hypotension, especially in patients taking alpha blockers or nitrates"
"What is the first-line treatment for most patients with erectile dysfunction? PDE-5 inhibitors (e.g. sildenafil)"
"Which anti-depressant medication is associated with priapism? Trazodone"
"What is the preferred initial treatment for uncomplicated benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)? Alpha-1 blockers (e.g. terazosin, tamsulosin)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a middle-aged man that presents with progressive urinary frequency, urgency and hesitancy for the past several months with chronic pelvic pain and pain with ejaculation? Urine culture is negative. chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CP/CPPS)"
"What is the likely etiology of urinary retention in an elderly male that presents with nocturia and problems initiating micturition for the past few weeks? Straight catheterization of the bladder produces 500 mL of urine. Enlarged prostate (e.g. BPH or prostate carcinoma)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young woman with a history of two miscarriages and the laboratory values below? VDRL: positive FTA-ABS: negative PT: 12s (normal) PTT: 46s (high) Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome"
"Pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome should receive low-dose aspirin and LMWH to avoid pregnancy loss related to arterial and venous thrombosis"
"What is the next step in management for an elderly woman that presents with urinary incontinence for the past week? The patient is delirious. History and physical exam are unremarkable. Urinalysis and culture"
"What is the single most important prognostic consideration in the treatment of patients with breast cancer? Tumor burden (based on TNM staging)"
"Baseline cardiac function should be assessed prior to initiating trastuzumab in patients with HER-2 positive breast cancer"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young woman that presents with bilateral, non-focal breast tenderness and diffuse, cord-like thickening of the breasts with no discharge? Her last menstrual period was three weeks ago. Fibrocystic change"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that develops confusion, agitation, diaphoresis, and tremors three days after being admitted to the hospital following a motor vehicle accident? Physical exam reveals tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypertension. Delirium tremens"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient brought to the ED with severe agitation and combativeness? Urine toxicology is negative. The patient is admitted and remained psychotic for one week before symptoms subsided. Bath salts intoxication"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that experiences sleep difficulties with “normal” bed times resulting in sleep-onset insomnia and daytime sleepiness? Delayed sleep phase disorder"
"What anti-emetic agents may cause extraparkinsonian symptoms (e.g. acute dystonia) as a possible side effect? metoclopramide and prochlorperazine::2"
"What is the likely diagnosis in person with a history of poorly controlled HIV (CD4 < 200) that presents with changes in personality and bizarre behavior? The patient also appears to have impaired attention and calculation. Brain MRI reveals a diffuse increase in intensity in the white matter. HIV-associated neurocognitive dysfunction"
"In addition to statin therapy, what is the recommended management for a patient with known cardiovascular disease and a triglyceride level of 465 mg/dL (high)? Lifestyle modifications (e.g. weight loss, exercise, decreased alcohol intake)"
"How do the following renal findings change in a patient with hypovolemia secondary to gallstone pancreatitis? Renin secretion: Increase Efferent arteriolar resistance: Increase Tubular Na+ reabsorption: Increase"
"What are the recommended screening guidelines for mammogram in patients with average risk of breast cancer? mammogram every 2 years in women age 50-74"
"What are the recommended screening guidelines for pap smear in patients with average risk of cervical cancer? Pap smear every 3 years in women age 21-65"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a military recruit that collapses during training exercises on a hot, humid day? The patient is disoriented and has a fever of 105.8 F, and is bleeding from the nose. Exertional heat stroke"
"Exertional heat stroke occurs in healthy individuals undergoing conditioning in extreme heat/humidity due to thermoregulation failure"
"Antidotes for cyanide poisoning include hydroxycobalamin (preferred) or sodium thiosulfate; alternatively nitrites may be used to induce methemoglobinemia"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that presents with drooling and retrosternal/epigastric pain after ingesting sodium hydroxide (lye)? The patient has been decontaminated and is hemodynamically stable with a normal CXR. Endoscopy"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that presents after ingesting twenty acetaminophen tablets two hours ago? Physical exam and laboratory studies, including LFTs, are normal. administer activated charcoal and measure serum acetaminophen levels"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a group of individuals that present with headache, nausea/vomiting, and confusion after eating at an indoor barbecue? Physical examination of one patient reveals tachycardia, tachypnea, and pinkish-skin hue. Carbon monoxide poisoning"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with confusion and blurry vision after overdosing on an unknown medication? Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes, decreased bowel sounds, and 8 mm pupils bilaterally. Anticholinergic toxicity"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with heavy drooling, dysphagia, and a white tongue after being found next to an empty bottle of an unknown substance? Caustic ingestion"
"What medication is administered to patients with suspected TCA toxicity to improve the effects of cardiac toxicity (e.g. hypotension, prolonged QRS interval, arrhythmia)? Sodium bicarbonate"
"What medication is administered to treat seizures in patients with suspected TCA toxicity? Benzodiazepines"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an automobile mechanic that presents with constipation, increased forgetfulness/fatigue, and peripheral neuropathy? Laboratory studies reveal microcytic anemia and hyperuricemia. Lead poisoning"
"What is the treatment of choice for acute opioid withdrawal? Low-dose methadone and adjunctive medications for symptoms"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with progressive worsening peripheral neuropathy? Physical exam reveals areas of hyper- and hypopigmentation, as well as hyperkeratosis. LFTs are also elevated with pancytopenia. The patient restores antique furniture as a hobby. Arsenic poisoning (chronic)"
"What is the treatment for arsenic toxicity? Chelating agents, such as dimercaprol or DMSA"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a homeless patient that presents with confusion, epigastric pain, and blurred vision? Laboratory studies reveal anion gap metabolic acidosis and eye examination shows a hyperemic optic disc. Methanol poisoning"
"What is the most common cause of death in patients with TCA overdose? Cardiac toxicity (e.g. ventricular arrhythmias)"
"Sodium bicarbonate alleviates the cardiotoxicity associated with TCA overdose by decreasing TCAs ability to bind fast-acting Na+ channels"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a homeless patient that presents with confusion, flank pain, and hematuria? Laboratory studies show anion gap metabolic acidosis and urine microscopy reveals calcium oxalate crystals. Ethylene glycol poisoning"
"What antidote is frequently used to treat methanol and/or ethylene glycol poisoning? Fomepizole"
"What is the recommended initial management of frostbite? Rapid rewarming with warm water"
"What is the recommended treatment for anticholinergic poisoning? Physostigmine (cholinesterase inhibitor)"
"What is the next step in management for an unresponsive patient that presents with respiratory depression and decreased bowel sounds? The patient smells of alcohol. Physical examination reveals 3 mm pupils bilaterally and a respiratory rate of 5/minute. Naloxone"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with a gunshot wound in the right thigh? The right lower extremity is cool to the touch and distal pulses are feeble. Urgent surgical exploration"
"β-blockers are contraindicated in acute cocaine intoxication Treatment? Benzodiazepines (alleviate psychomotor agitation and sympathomimetic effects)"
"Where is the pain in Osgood-Schlatter disease felt? Pain at the tibial tubercle (seen with adolescent athletes)"
"BUN is reabsorbed when the kidneys reabsorb water"
"In acute prerenal failure, BUN::BUN/Creatinine rises relatively more"
"What type of acute renal failure has a large increase in BUN/Cr ratio? Prerenal failure"
"What type of acute renal failure has a normal BUN/Cr ratio? Intrinsic renal failure"
"What are the key features used to diagnose postrenal failure? (2) Anuria Hydronephrosis"
"What are the two most common causes of chronic kidney disease? Hypertensive nephrosclerosis Diabetes nephropathy"
"Osteitis fibrosa cystica occurs due to untreated severe high PTH, causing bone cysts and brown tumors"
"In Osteitis Fibrosa Cystica, there are brown tumors"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient that presents with insomnia, agitation, paranoid delusions, and fluctuating level of consciousness a few days after having surgery? Delirium"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient with a history of ADHD that presents with two weeks of decreased sleep, irritability, distractibility, and excessive involvement in new projects? Bipolar disorder"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly male that presents after months of agitated behavior/moving around in his sleep in the early morning hours? The patient is easily arousable and confused for only a few moments after awakening. He describes a recurrent dream where he feels trapped. REM sleep behavior disorder"
"In older patients, REM sleep behavior disorder may be a sign of neurodegeneration (e.g. Parkinson’s disease)"
"What is the recommended maintenance pharmacotherapy for a patient with bipolar disorder that is not adequately controlled with monotherapy? lithium or valproate and a second-generation antipsychotic (e.g. quetiapine)"
"What laboratory tests are most important to monitor in patients taking second-generation antipsychotics (e.g. olanzapine)? Fasting glucose and lipid levels"
"What is the recommended pharmacotherapy for a patient with a history of alcohol abuse that requests a medication to reduce cravings? He is currently drinking 6-7 beers a day. There is no evidence of hepatitis, cirrhosis, and patient does not take opioids. Naltrexone"
"The DSM-5 criteria for generalized anxiety disorder include: A. Excessive anxiety and worry for at least 6 months::time B. Difficult controlling the worry. C. At least three of the following symptoms: - Restlessness - Fatigue - Difficulty concentrating - Irritability - Muscle tension - Sleep disturbance D. Clinically significant distress or impairment E./F. Not better explained by another medical condition, mental disorder, or substance"
"Blockage of which dopamine pathway is responsible for symptoms of gynecomastia, sexual dysfunction, and infertility in patients taking antipsychotics? Tuberoinfundibular pathway"
"Blockage of which dopamine pathway is responsible for the therapeutic effect of antipsychotics? Mesolimbic pathway"
"Major neurocognitive disorder (dementia) may be distinguished from normal aging by dependence on others for activities of daily living (ADLs)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that experiences two-weeks of insomnia, nightmares, and flashbacks after seeing a traumatic event? Acute stress disorder"
"What is the first-line treatment for patients with acute stress disorder? Trauma-focused CBT"
"What drug withdrawal presents with nausea, muscle/joint aches, diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and pupillary dilation? Heroin (opioid) withdrawal"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young woman that presents with periods of binge eating, followed by guilt, depression, and excessive fasting/exercise? Physical exam is unremarkable. Her BMI is 19.5 kg/m2. Bulimia nervosa"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young woman that presents with periods of binge eating, followed by guilt, depression, and excessive fasting/exercise? Physical exam is unremarkable. Her BMI is 18.0 kg/m2. Anorexia nervosa"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young woman that presents with periods of binge eating with no compensatory behavior? Physical exam is unremarkable. Her BMI is 30 kg/m2. Binge eating disorder"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient with bipolar disorder that develops confusion, tremors, ataxia, vomiting, and seizures two weeks after beginning atenolol and hydrochlorothiazide? Lithium toxicity"
"What class of antihypertensive medication increases risk for lithium toxicity? Thiazide diuretics"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that believes someone has been trying to poison her food for the past 6 months? As a result, the patient refuses to eat any food that is not pre-packaged. The patient is otherwise normal, with no social dysfunction and no other psychotic symptoms. Delusional disorder"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that develops agitation and visual hallucinations 12 hours after hospitalization? Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has a history of cocaine, marijuana, and alcohol abuse. Alcoholic hallucinosis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young male that presents with several months of agitation and irritability? On physical exam, the patient has a receding hair line and palpable tissue underneath the nipples bilaterally. Anabolic steroid abuse"
"What is the like diagnosis in a young woman that presents with irritability, weight loss, and decreased sleep? The patient says she has lots of energy and isn't eating because she's not hungry. Physical exam reveals erythema of the turbinates and nasal septum. BMI is 19.5 kg/m2. Cocaine use disorder"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a long history of schizoaffective disorder that presents with lip smacking, sticking out his tongue, and squirming movements of the torso? Tardive dyskinesia"
"What is the likely underlying pathophysiologic mechanism of tardive dyskinesia? D2 receptor upregulation and supersensitivity"
"What eye exam finding is characteristic of phencyclidine intoxication? Nystagmus"
"Compared to PCP, the effects of methamphetamine generally last longer::shorter or longer"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient being treated in the psychiatric ER that develops confusion, high-grade fever, autonomic instability, and muscle rigidity? Neuroleptic malignant syndrome"
"What muscular symptom is associated with neuroleptic malignant syndrome? Lead-pipe rigidity"
"Diagnosis of a manic episode requires an elevated and/or irritable mood lasting at least 1 week and more than three \DIG FAST\\" criteria: D: Distractibility I: Impulsivity (high-risk behaviors) G: Grandiosity (inflated self-esteem) F: Flight of ideas/racing thoughts A: Agitation/increased Activity S: Sleeplessness T: Talkativeness or pressured speech\""
"The DSM-5 criteria for bipolar I disorder include: A. Criteria have been met for at least one manic episode B. The symptoms cause social/occupational distress or impairment C. Not better explained by another medical condition, mental disorder, or substance"
"The DSM-5 criteria for bipolar II disorder include: A. Criteria have been met for at least one major depressive episode B. Criteria have been met for at least one hypomanic episode C. No history of manic or mixed episodes D. Not better explained by another medical condition, mental disorder, or substance E. The symptoms cause social/occupational distress or impairment"
"Major depressive disorder is characterized by at least four \SIG E CAPS\\" symptoms PLUS a(n) depressed mood or anhedonia for ≥ 2 weeks: S: Sleep changes I: Interest decreases (anhedonia) G: Guilt or feelings of worthlessness E: Energy loss or fatigue C: Concentration deficit A: Appetite/weight changes P: Psychomotor retardation or agitation S: Suicidality\""
"The DSM-5 criteria for major depressive disorder include: A. At least five SIG E CAPS symptoms for > 2 weeks (time); one symptom must be depressed mood or anhedonia B. The symptoms cause social/occupational distress or impairment C/D. Not better explained by another medical condition, mental disorder, or substance E. No history of manic or hypomanic episodes"
"What drug withdrawal presents with acute depression (\crash\\")"
"The DSM-5 criteria for adjustment disorder include: A. Emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable, non-life threatening stressor occurring within 3 months* of the onset of the stressor B. Marked distress out of proportion to the stressor or significant impairment in social or occupational functioning C/D. Symptoms do not meet the criteria for another mental disorder or represent normal bereavement E. Once the stressor ceases, the symptoms do not persist for more than an additional 6 months::time"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that develops seizures, tremulousness, diaphoresis, and autonomic instability one day after having an emergency surgery? Alcohol withdrawal"
"What is the preferred pharmacotherapy for alcohol withdrawal in the hospital setting? IV lorazepam (benzodiazepine)"
"What type of therapy is most useful for a patient that presents with maladaptive thought patterns and behaviors (e.g. negatively interpreting events)? Cognitive behavioral therapy"
"What type of therapy is most useful for a patient that presents with borderline personality disorder? Dialectical behavioral therapy"
"What drug intoxication commonly causes agitation, irritability, psychosis, diaphoresis, and mydriasis without nystagmus for several hours? Amphetamines"
"What are the first-line pharmacotherapy options to reduce cravings during smoking cessation? Nicotine replacement therapy, varenicline, and bupropion"
"What psychiatric disorder is characterized by a preoccupation with a minor or imagined defect in appearance, causing significant emotional distress or impaired functioning? Body dysmorphic disorder"
"Diagnosis of panic disorder requires recurrent & unexpected panic attacks with at least one month::duration of preoccupations with the attack"
"What is the recommended immediate treatment for patients with panic disorder that are acutely symptomatic? Benzodiazepines"
"What is the recommended long-term treatment for patients with panic disorder? CBT and/or SSRIs"
"The primary cause of neuroleptic malignant syndrome is antagonism of dopamine (D2) receptors in the nigrostriatal pathway"
"What is the recommended next step in management in assessing a patient with suspected premenstrual syndrome (PMS)? Menstrual diary"
"What is the recommended first-line treatment for severe premenstrual syndrome and premenstrual dysphoric disorder? SSRIs (after evaluation with menstrual diary)"
"Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) is characterized by > 2 depressive symptoms for ≥ 2 years::duration with no lapses in depressive symptoms for > 2 months::duration at a time"
"What is catalepsy and echolalia, and what syndrome is characterized by both? Catalepsy → limbs remain in fixed posture for long periods of time Echolalia → mimicking speech Catatonia::syndrome?"
"What is the treatment of choice for patients that present with catatonia? First-line is benzodiazepines; 2nd line is ECT"
"Separation anxiety is normal in children age 9 - 18 months and again during times of transition (e.g. beginning preschool)"
"Management of akathisia secondary to antipsychotic medications includes decreasing the dose of the antipsychotic and administration of a(n) β-blocker, a(n) benzodiazepine, or benztropine"
"What is the next step in management for an elderly patient with major depression with psychotic features that has lost a significant amount of weight and is refusing to eat/drink? Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)"
"Indications for involuntary psychiatric hospitalization including being a(n) danger to self or others and/or grave disability (inability to care for self)"
"What is the treatment of choice for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder? Clozapine"
"Patients taking clozapine require regular monitoring of white blood cell and absolute neutrophil counts"
"The DSM-5 criteria for somatic symptom disorder include: A. One or more somatic symptoms that are distressing or result in significant disruption of daily life B. Excessive thoughts or behaviors related to the somatic symptoms C. Duration > 6 months::time"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that presents with severe mania (psychotic features, aggression, harm of self or others)? Administer an antipsychotic +/- a mood stabilizer"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a previously healthy individual that presents with anxiety, irritability, and insomnia, as well as abdominal pain and paresthesias of the right hand? Acute intermittent porphyria"
"Diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria may be aided by the presence of elevated urinary porphobilinogen"
"What is the recommended treatment for bereaved patients who meet criteria for major depressive disorder? Psychotherapy Antidepressants"
"What early childhood disorder is characterized by deficits in social communication & interactions and restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior? Autism spectrum disorder"
"Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by symptoms of schizophrenia lasting > 1 day and < 1 month"
"Schizophreniform disorder is characterized by symptoms of schizophrenia lasting between 1 - 6 months"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with symmetric resting tremor in both hands, muscle stiffness, and slow finger movements? The patient has a history of bipolar disorder controlled with valproate and risperidone. Drug-induced parkinsonism"
"Management of acute dystonia secondary to antipsychotic medications includes administration of a(n) anticholinergic (e.g. benztropine) or a(n) antihistamine (e.g. diphenhydramine)"
"Management of Parkinsonism secondary to antipsychotic medications includes administration of benztropine or amantadine"
"The risk factors for suicide completion may be remembered with the mnemonic \SAD PERSONS\\": S: Sex (male) A: Age (teenage or elderly) D: Depression P: Previous attempt (highest risk factor) E: Ethanol or drug use R: Rational thinking impaired (psychosis) S: Sickness (medical illness) O: Organized plan N: No spouse or other social support S: {{c10::Stated future intent\""
"What is the first-line pharmacotherapy for narcolepsy? Modafinil (non-amphetamine stimulant)"
"Which eating disorder, bulimia or anorexia nervosa, may be effectively treated with SSRIs? Bulimia nervosa"
"What is the first-line treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)? CBT (trauma-focused) and SSRIs/SNRIs"
"Patients < 25 years old have a slightly increased risk of becoming suicidal when initiating antidepressant treatment"
"What is the FENa in patients with prerenal azotemia? < 1%"
"What is the FENa in patients with intrinsic renal failure? > 2%"
"The osmolarity of urine in patients with prerenal azotemia will be high::low/high"
"The osmolarity of urine in patients with intrinsic renal azotemia will be low::low/high"

"What is the treatment of choice for patient's with a specific phobia? CBT with exposure (flooding and desensitization)"

"The DSM-5 criteria for schizoaffective disorder include: A. Presence of a major depressive, manic, or mixed episode concurrent with symptoms of schizophrenia B. Lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations for > 2 weeks::duration in the absence of prominent mood symptoms C. Mood symptoms are present for the majority of the illness D. Not due to substances or another medical condition"
"What is the first-line pharmacotherapy for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)? SSRIs"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child that frequently wakes up screaming in the middle of the night with full alertness? The child is easily consolable and recalls a scary dream. Nightmare disorder"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with agitation, insomnia, paranoid delusions, and tactile hallucinations (bugs under skin)? On physical exam, the patient appears thin and has poor dentition and multiple sores on his face and body. Methamphetamine abuse"
