"In patients with TCA overdose, a QRS duration > 100 msec is associated with increased risk of arrhythmias and/or seizures and is an indication for treatment with sodium bicarbonate"
"What is the treatment of choice to prevent adverse cardiac effects in patients with suspected TCA overdose? Sodium bicarbonate"
"Pediatric depression often presents with symptoms of irritability rather than depressed mood"
"What is the pharmacotherapy of choice in pediatric depression patients? SSRIs, especially fluoxetine"
"What is the treatment of choice for hoarding disorder? Cognitive-behavioral therapy"
"What type of cognitive-behavioral therapy is best for treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)? Exposure with response prevention"
"What is the treatment of choice for adjustment disorder? Psychotherapy/CBT"
"What is the greatest risk factor for committing homicide in adolescents? Access to firearms"
"Prior to beginning lithium therapy, patients should be screened to ensure adequate thyroid and renal function"
"Which mood stabilizer is associated with elevated LFTs, and rarely, hepatic failure? Valproic acid"
"What pharmacologic treatments may be used to treat patients with suicidal intentions/ideations? Clozapine or lithium::2"
"What psychiatric disorder is characterized by an inability to resist the impulse to steal objects, often of low monetary value or not needed for personal use? Kleptomania"
"What neuroimaging finding is most consistently found in patients with schizophrenia? Ventriculomegaly (particularly of the lateral cerebral ventricles) and cortical atrophy"
"Major depressive disorder is associated with increased levels of cortisol."
"What is the first-line treatment for major depressive disorder with psychotic features? Antidepressant and antipsychotic (or ECT)"
"What is the first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with acute psychosis? First or second-generation antipsychotics"
"Which antidepressant is likely to be useful for patients with primary complaints of low energy, impaired concentration, hypersomnia, and weight gain? Bupropion"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that requires antipsychotics, but develops tardive dyskinesia while taking risperidone? Switch to clozapine"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that presents with unstable vital signs and hypokalemia secondary to suspected anorexia nervosa? Hospitalization for nutritional rehabilitation"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with recurrent episodes of psychosis due to medication non-adherence? The patient responds well to oral antipsychotics. Long-acting injectable (depot) antipsychotics"
"What is the likely underlying cause of psychosis in a young female that presents with psychosis and arthralgia? Laboratory findings include thrombocytopenia and hematuria. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)"
"According to the DSM-5, pathological enuresis cannot be diagnosed until the patient is at least 5-years-old (or equivalent developmental level)"
"According to the DSM-5, pathological encopresis cannot be diagnosed until the patient is at least 4-years-old (or equivalent developmental level)"
"What are the two absolute contraindications to non-cardiac surgery? EF < 35% MI within 6 months"
"Goldman Risk Index "
"What three tests should be performed prior to surgery on pt. w/ cardiac complications? ECG Echo Cath"
"The problem with the lungs prior to surgery will be ventilation::ventilation/oxygenation"
"What is the first step in working up a pt. w/ pulmonary disease (e.g. smoker, COPD, fibrotic lung, asthmatic)? PFTs (FEV1/FVC)"
"What is the next step in working up a patient with prexisting pulmonary disease after FEV1/FVC? Blood gases Low O2 or high CO2 is bad"
"When should smoking cessation commence prior to surgery? 8 weeks before surgery (b/c congestion initially worsens)"
"Fever after anesthesia (halothane, succinylcholine) or fever > 104: Malignant hyperthermia::Diagnosis?"
"How do you treat malignant hyperthermia? Administer O2, cooling blankets, dantrolene, and watch for myoglobinuria::4"
"What is a fever on the first day postop? Atelectasis"
"What imaging do you do first if you suspect atelectasis? CXR"
"A fever on the second day, especially if atelectasis wasn't fixed, can turn into pneumonia"
"What is the work up for pneumonia? CXR, ABx"
"What is the prophylaxis for atelectasis/pneumonia? Incentive spirometry/OOB"
"What is postop fever on day 3 dx? UTI"
"What is the tx of UTI postop fever? U/A, Abx"
"What is the dx of fever of postop on day 5? DVT"
"What is the tx of DVT (postop fever day 5)? U/S, heparin"
"What is prophylaxis for DVT (day 5 fever)? Ambulation, heparin"
"What is cause of postop day 7 fever? Wound infection"
"What is tx of wound infection (day 7 fever) U/S, Abx"
"What is prophylaxis for wound infection? Good closure and wound care"
"What is cause of fever > day 10 postop? Wound abscess"
"What is the workup for deep abscess > 10 days postop (imaging, treatment)? CT/Drain/Abx"
"What surgeries are highest risk of DVT's? Orthopedic"
"How do you anticoagulate DVT patients? LMWH bridge to warfarin"
"What tests should be ordered to workup post-op chest pain? (2) ECG, troponin"
"What is the tx of post-op MI? PCI/Heparin"
"How do you definitively dx a PE? CT angiogram"
"What is tx for pulmonary embolism? Heparin for ppx/bridge to Coumadin Greenfield filter if anticoag is CI"
"How do you treat ARDS postop? PEEP on ventilator"
"When do you suspect ARDS postop (imaging, background)? CXR => whiteout, complicated surgical course"
"What do you suspect if elderly pt. has psychosis/AMS postop? sundowning"
"What do you suspect if pt. is having seizures/psychotic/hallucinating 48-72 hrs postop? Delirium tremens"
"How do you treat DT's postop? Benzos"
"How do you treat sundowning in elderly with AMS? Atypical antipsychotics"
"What is tx for postop urinary retention? In and out catheter after 6 hours of not voiding"
"What is dx if pt. has zero output postop? mechanical obstruction"
"What is tx of zero output postop? Unkink catheter and urine will flow"
"What is the differential with low output urine flow postop? Prerenal failure or intrinsic renal failure"
"What is initial test for low output urine postop? 500cc bolus challenge"
"What is presentation of paralytic illeus postop? Distension, obstipated x 1 day, no pain"
"What is seen in KUB with paralytic illeus? Diffuse enlargement of small and large bowel"
"Bowel obstruction appears when paralytic ileus hasn't resolved in 5-7 days"
"How does bowel obstruction present on KUB? Air-fluid levels with decompressed bowel beyond the obstruction"
"What is done following KUB to confirm bowel obstruction? Contrast swallow CT to see if tracer material passes the obstruction"
"Ogilvie syndrome::What disease? is a paralytic ileus of the colon that occurs in elderly pts immobilized post-op"
"What will be seen on KUB of Ogilvie syndrome? Very dilated colon only"
"What is done in pts suspected of Ogilvie syndrome to rule out cancer and decompress the abdomen? Colonoscopy and rectal tube::2"
"Dehiscence::What wound abnormality? occurs when the skin is intact but the fascia has failed"
"How do you treat wound dehiscence? Bind the abdomen and limit mvmt/straining"
"Evisceration occurs when both the skin and fascia fail with increased IA pressure"
"What is the tx for evsiceration? Cover bowel with warm dressings and get back to OR now"
"Fistulas are defined as a connection between 2 epithelialized surfaces"
"What is the tx of fistulas? Remove fistula or divert bowel so fistula can close on its own"
"What causes prehepatic jaundice? (2) Hemolysis Hematomas"
"What causes intrahepatic jaundice? Hepatitis/genetic disease"
"What causes post-hepatic disease? (5) Gallstones, pancreatic cancer, PBC, PSC, stricture"
"What labs are associated with prehepatic jaundice? Increased unconjugated bilirubin"
"What is more elevated in EtOH hepatitis? AST>ALT"
"How does urine/stool appear in obstructive jaundice? Dark urine; pale stool"
"Diagnosis in pt who is jaundiced/pruitus with palpable nontender GB? Cancer"
"What is Murphy's sign dx of? A tender GB"
"What does a thin-walled distended GB free of inflammation on U/S indicate when working up jaundice? Cancer"
"What does a thick-walled rigid (porcelain) GB indicate in US? Chronic inflammation"
"What is the diagnostic method for obstructive jaundice secondary to inflammation from choledocholithiasis/cholangitis? RUQ U/S with MRCP/ERCP"
"How do you tx gallstone? ERCP"
"What is seen on U/S of GB in pt. with choledocholithiasis? Mild duct dilation, gallstones in GB"
"What 3 tumors can present w/ painless jaundice, palpable GB, and weight loss? Pancreatic (adeno from head), cholangiocarcinoma, ampulla of vater"
"First step for diagnosing pancreatic cancer? CT scan"
"Cholangiocarcinoma is dx with ERCP w/ bx"
"What cancer presents with FOBT+ with negative colonoscopy? Ampulla of vater"
"What is tx of pancreatic head cancer? Whipple procedure"
"What is the typical pain of GERD? Burning retrosternal chest pain"
"What is the pathophysiology of GERD? Weakened LES allows reflux of gastric contents"
"What is 1st line tx of GERD? PPI"
"When is an EGD done for GERD? Only when PPIs fail/there are alarm symptoms"
"What is the best diagnostic test for GERD, but is rarely done? 24hr-pH monitoring"
"What is tx if metaplastic changes are seen on EGD? High-dose PPI"
"What is tx if dysplastic changes are seen on EGD? Local ablation methods"
"What is tx of esophageal cancer (adeno)? Resection"
"What is surgical tx of GERD if PPI's are not tolerated or pt. doesnt want them? Nissen fundoplication"
"What is pathophys of achalasia? LES cannot relax"
"What is bird's beak deformity indicative of on barium swallow? Achalasia"
"How is dx of achalasia made? Barium swallow (Bird beak) and manometry"
"What is definitive dx method of achalsia? Manometry (tight LES)"
"What is seen on manometry in achalasia? Failure to relax"
"What is best tx of achalasia? Heller myotomy"
"What is the diagnosis if patient presents with dysphagia progressing from solids to liquids and weight loss? Cancer"
"Where is esophageal adeno found and what is cause? Lower 1/3, GERD"
"Where is esophageal SCC found and what is cause? Upper 1/3, smoking/irritation"
"What is done 1st in workup of esophageal cancer to identify location of lesions/safety of EGD? Barium swallow"
"How do you confirm dx of esophageal cancer following barium swallow? EGD w/ biopsy"
"How is esophageal cancer staged? CT scan"
"What is a superficial mucosal tear of esophagus that occurs after forceful retching, usually at GE junction? Mallory-Weiss tear"
"How does a Mallory-Weiss tear present? Bright red bleeding which resolves spontaneously"
"What is tx for Mallory-Weiss tear? Nothing; treat GI bleed if it is still bleeding"
"What is an esophageal perforation caused by prolonged retching? Boerhaave"
"What is the pathogenesis of Boerhaave syndrome? Esophageal perforation caused by prolonged retching"
"What is pt. presentation in Boerhaave? Fever Leukocytosis Hamman's crunch (air in mediastinum heard with each heartbeat)::3"
"The workup for Boerhaave syndrome includes the following: Initial imaging → CXR Confirmatory imaging → Gastrografin swallow or CT::2 Surgical treatment → exploratory thoracotomy (fix tear)"
"What is tx of Boerhaave syndrome? Surgical repair is definitive"
"What is MCC of esophageal perforation? Iatrogenic"
"What is tx of an esophageal perforation? Surgical repair; tx like boerhaave"
"What are the most common causes of pancreatitis? (2) Gallstones and EtOH"
"What is presentation of pancreatitis? Boring epigastric pain radiating to the back, typically after heavy meal/EtOH"
"What position relieves pancreatitis pain? Leaning forward"
"What enzymes are elevated in pancreatitis? Lipase or amylase"
"What is tx of acute pancreatits? Bowel rest, fluids, and analgesia (IVF+ NPO+morphine)"
"What is the single most prognostic lab for pancreatitis? BUN"
"What do you order if dx of pancreatitis is certain AND enzymes are negative? CT scan"
"What is used to dx complications of pancreatitis but should be reserved until after complications are seen? CT scan"
"What is dx of acute pancreatitis with poor Ranson's criteria or needs pressors? Necrotizing pancreatitis"
"What do you do if pt. presents with severe acute pancreatits with poor Ransons criteria and ? ICU and monitor w/ CT scans"
"What abx do you give if there is FNA-proven infection associated with pancreatitis? Meropenem"
"What is definitive tx for necrotizing pancreatitis? Necrosectomy after fluid has solidified"
"What are 2 ways patients get pancreatic abscesses? 1. Necrotizing pancreatitis who stays ill 2. Typical pancreatitis w/ abscess on day 5(ish) w/ persistent fever/leukocytosis"
"What is tx of pancreatic abscess? Drainage"
"What is a late sequelae cx of pancreatitis? Pancreatic pseudocyst"
"Pancreatitis complication with mass (palpable) sx's (dyspnea, ascites, and early satiety)? Pancreatic pseudocyst"
"How do you dx a pancreatic pseudocyst? CT"
"How do you decide to treat pancreatic pseudocyst? <6cm AND <6 wks old -> watch and wait >6cm OR >6 wks -> drain (risk of hemorrhage is too great)::wks and cm"
"Is surgery recommended for chronic pancreatitis? No; surgery is CI"
"How is chronic pancreatits treated? 1. Treat the pain (very painful) 2. Manage DM, steatorrhea, and malabsorption"
"Right-sided colon cancers bleed while left-sided colon cancers obstruct"
"Suspect colon cancer in a postmenopausal women/any man w/ an iron-def anemia or any aged pt. with change in stool caliber"
"How do you dx colon cancer? Bx via colonoscopy"
"When does colonoscopy screening begin? 50 or 10y before relative who had cancer"
"What is the screening schedule for colon cancer? q10 yrs"
"What is tx of colon cancer? Resection and chemotherapy"
"What is tx if CIS is found on pathology of polyp? More frequent screening"
"What is tx of FAP? Total colectomy"
"When can you treat UC with surgery? Refractory to medical tx or with long-standing disease (>8 yrs = malignant transformation)"
"What type of surgery is performed in Ulcerative Colitis? Proctocolectomy"
"After how many years of UC is surveillance colonoscopy required? Colonoscopy q1 yr needed at yr 8 from dx"
"Is surgery indicated for Crohn's disease? No: surgery is only indicated in severe Crohn's w/ infection/abscess or fistula"
"When is surgery indicated in Crohn's? 1. Infection/abscess requires surgery to drain 2. Fistulas"
"External hemmorhoids hurt and internal hemmorhoids bleed"
"Surgical intervention for hemorrhoids is indicated after conservative therapy (e.g. phenylephrine rectal cream, Sitz baths, stool softeners) fails"
"External hemorrhoids are treated with resection"
"What is surgical tx of internal hemorrhoids? Banding"
"What causes anal fissures? Abnormally tight sphincter → mucosa tears with passage of stools"
"How do anal fissures present? Pain on defectaion that lasts for hours"
"How do you dx anal fissures? Physical exam (DRE, anoscopy)"
"What is initial medical tx for anal fissures? Conservative measures → topical anesthetics/vasodilators"
"What is surgical tx of anal fissures once conservative tx fails? Lateral internal sphincterotomy"
"What causes anal cancer? HPV"
"What can be done for screening of anal cancer in high risk pt's? Anal pap"
"What is tx of anal cancer? Nigro radiochemotherapy or resection"
"What is a pilonidal cyst? Abscessed hair follicle"
"What is the etiology of a pilonidal cyst? Hairy butt that gets infected"
"What is tx of pilondal cyst? Drainage followed by resection"
"What are the two causes of SBO? Adhesions (MCC w/ pior surgeries), hernia (MCC w/out prior surgery)"
"How does SBO initially present? colicky abdominal pain w/ +gas/stool and borborygmi"
"How do you dx SBO? Upright KUB (dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels)"
"What do you do to confirm dx of SBO? CT scan w/oral contrast"
"What is tx for incomplete SBO? Serial exams and conservative measures (fluid, potassium and NG tube compression)"
"What is tx of complete SBO? Ex-lap"
"Direct hernias pass through the inguinal (Hesselbach's) triangle"
"Direct hernias pass directly through abdominal wall through the transversalis muscle"
"Direct hernias are medial to epigastric vessels"
"Indirect inguinal hernia travels the entire length of the inguinal canal following descent path of the testes"
"Indirect inguinal hernia enters internal inguinal ring lateral to inferior epigastric artery and exits external inguinal ring"
"What type of hernia is considered a candidate for elective surgery? Reducible"
"What type of hernia is considered a candidate for urgent surgery? Incarcerated"
"What type of hernia requires emergency surgery requiring ex-lap? Strangulated w/ peritoneal signs"
"What is dx in pt. presenting with anorexia, then vague periumbilical pain that resolves and returneys at Mcburney's pt. w/ focal peritoneal findings? Appendicitis"
"What is tx for obvious appendicitis? Go straight to surgery"
"What type of tumor presents with 5-HIAA in urine plus R valvular fibrosis, flushing, wheezing and diarrhea? Intestinal carcinoid with mets to the liver"
"What are risk factors for gallstones? females, fat, forty, fertile, fnative american"
"What is tx of asymptomatic gallstones? Nothing"
"How do sx gallstones typically present? Colicky RUQ abdominal pain that may radiate to Rt shoulder and occur after fatty meal"
"How is sx gallstones diagnosed? U/S"
"What is tx of sx gallstones? Elective cholecystectomy"
"What are PE findings in a pt. with acute cholecystitis? Constant RUQ abd pain accompanied by mild fever/leukocytosis"
"What causes acute cholecystitis? Gallstone lodged in cystic duct"
"How do you diagnose acute cholecystitis? U/S"
"What test is used to confirm acute cholecystitis? HIDA scan"
"What is tx of acute cholecystitis? Emergent cholecystectomy (percutaneous cholecystostomy if unstable)"
"How does a pt. present with ascending cholangitis? (5) RUQ pain, Murphys sign +, elevated enzymes, T > 104, leukocytosis"
"What is tx of ascending cholangitis? ERCP & start Abx (Cipro and Metro) → urgent cholecystectomy"
"What is the pathophysiology of choledocholithiasis? CBD obstruction proximal to pancreatic duct w/ elevated biliary/liver enzymes"
"How does a pt. present w/ gallstone pancreatitis? RUQ pain, Murphys sign +, elevated AST/ALT, lipase, amylase, mild fever/leukocytosis"
"How is choledocholithiasis dx'd? U/S or MRCP"
"How is choledocholithiasis treated? ERCP to retrieve stone; eventual cholecystectomy"
"How does obstructive abdominal pain present? Colicky (comes and goes) with contraction of lumen/localized near affected organ"
"What is the timing of perforation abdominal pain? Sudden onset"
"Where is perforation pain located? Vague, generalized"
"A pt. with a(n) perforation will lay motionless in fear that any mvmt will slosh fluid around and aggravate pain"
"Perforation pain is constant::constant or colicky?"
"How do you dx perforation? Upright KUB"
"What is tx of perforation? Ex-lap"
"How do you dx small bowel obstruction? Xray (best initial test) CT (more accurate)::2"
"What type of abdominal pain is associated with sudden onset severe pain that is out of proportion to PE? Ischemia"
"What type of abdominal pain is suspected in an old man who is post-MI (shock) or with Afib (emboli)? Ischemia"
"Diarrhea/abd discomfort can occur after cholecystectomy d/t dysregulation of bile/lack of fat digestion"
"What diet changes should occur after cholecystectomy? Smaller meals, healthy fats (easier to digest), increased fiber"
"Postcholecystectomy syndrome is a complex of heterogeneous symptoms, including persistent abdominal pain and dyspepsia, that recur and persist after cholecystectomy"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that presents with bifrontal headaches upon awakening with associated nausea, vomiting, and blurry vision for the past month? MRI of the brain"
"Can a patient with severe, acute pain refractory to NSAIDs and a history of IV drug abuse be given opioids for acute pain management? Yes"
"Diabetic neuropathy strictly affects lower::upper or lower motor neurons"
"In the acute phase of spinal cord injury, patients can develop spinal shock with absent reflexes and flaccid::spastic or flaccid paralysis"
"Initial management of acute spinal cord compression includes emergency MRI and IV glucocorticoids"
"Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration typically affects patients with extensive alcohol abuse and presents with progressive wide-based gait and postural instability"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with painless, proximal muscle weakness of the lower extremities? The patient has a history of giant cell arteritis that is medically managed. ESR and CK levels are normal. Drug-induced myopathy (due to corticosteroids)"
"What is the first-line pharmacotherapy for restless leg syndrome? Dopamine receptor agonists (ropinirole, pramipexole)"
"What hematologic pathology is associated with restless leg syndrome? Iron deficiency anemia"
"Myasthenic crisis is managed with plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulins, usually in combination with corticosteroids"
"Pronator drift is a relatively sensitive and specific sign for UMN or pyramidal tract disease affecting the upper extremities"
"What is the single greatest overall risk factor for both ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke? Hypertension (4x risk of CVA compared to normotensive individuals)"
"What is the initial diagnostic test of choice in a patient with suspected stroke? Non-contrast CT scan of the head"
"What is the most common cause of intraparenchymal hemorrhage in children? AV malformation"
"What is the most common cause of spontaneous lobar (parietal/occipital) hemorrhage in the elderly? Cerebral amyloid angiopathy"
"Wernicke encephalopathy typically manifests as a triad of encephalopathy, oculomotor dysfunction, and gait ataxia"
"What is the major cause of death within the first 24 hours of presentation of a subarachnoid hemorrhage? Rebleeding"
"What is the major cause of delayed morbidity and death after 3 - 10 days of presentation of a subarachnoid hemorrhage? Vasospasm"
"Vasospasm following a subarachnoid hemorrhage can best be prevented with initiation of nimodipine"
"Maneuvers that increase intracranial pressure include leaning forward, Valsalva, and coughing"
"How does a baby with TE fistula present? Gurgling, coughing, bubbling"
"How is TE fistula dx'd? NG tube and X-ray => NG tube coils up in esophagus"
"What is tx of TE fistula? Surgery; Look for VACTERL anomalies"
"How is diagnosis of imperforate anus made? X-ray (upside down)"
"How can low lesions closer to anus causing imperforate anus be corrected? Dilation or minor surgical procedure"
"How are high imperforate anus lesions corrected? Colostomy w/ future correction"
"All pts with imperforate anus need eval for VACTERL"
"If you hear bowel sounds over the lungs and there's a scaphoid abdomen in a dyspneic baby think congenital diaphragmatic hernia"
"What is the biggest complication of having a diaphragmatic hernia for a baby? Hypoplastic lung that requires intubation and ventilation for baby's survival"
"What is tx of congenital diaphragmatic hernia? Surgical repair"
"What does bilious vomiting indicate? Obstruction distal to ampulla of vater"
"What is 1st step in working up bilious vomiting in a neonate? Babygram (X-ray of entire body)"
"What do multiple air fluid levels on babygram during work-up of bilious vomiting indicate? Intestinal atresia"
"What are common causes of intestinal atresia? (2) Vascular accident in utero, mom used coke"
"What does \double-bubble\\" sign on babygram indicate? Duodenal atresia"
"What does a normal gas pattern distal to point of obstruction on babygram indicate? Malrotation"
"What is immediate tx of Gastroschisis/Omphalocele? Cover with wet stuff"
"What do you do to keep bowel decompressed during omphalocele/gastroschisis? NG tube"
"What is tx of gastroschisis/omphalocele if primary closure cannot be achieved? Silo"
"Omphalocele::Gastroschisis or Omphalocele is a midline defect covered with membrane"
"Extrophy of the bladder is a midline defect that is red, shining, and wet with urine"
"What is tx of exstrophy of the bladder? Keep covered with plastic barrier to prevent drying out → surgery"
"What is the assumed diagnosis in a premature baby with bloody diarrhea? Necrotizing enterocolitis"
"How is a diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis confirmed? X-ray/babygram will show pneumatosis intestinalis (air in wall of bowel)"
"What is management of necrotizing enterocolitis in newborn? NPO immediately and start on TPN and IV AB's"
"What is the most common cause of meconium illeus? Cystic Fibrosis"
"What is cause of meconium ileus? Pancreatic insufficiency"
"What is tx of meconium ileus? Water-soluble Gastrografin enema to help breakdown obstruction"
"Hirschsprungs disease is caused by absent ganglion migration to Meissner and Auerbach plexuses in colon"
"What class of autonomic drugs may be used for migraine prophylaxis? β-blockers (e.g. propranolol)"
"What class of antidepressant medication may be used for migraine prophylaxis? Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g. amitriptyline)"
"What will exam show in Hirschsprung's? Increased::↑/↓ rectal tone"
"Which neuromuscular junction pathology is characterized by diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes? Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome::MG or LEMS"
"What will KUB show in Hirschsprung's? dilated colon (normal part) and normal distal colon (abnormal part)"
"What is tx of Hirschsprung's? Surgery (remove aganglionic segment)"
"Intussusception occurs when bowel telescopes into another and blood supply is compromised"
"How does intussusception present? Abrupt onset of colicky abdominal pain in an otherwise healthy baby"
"How does infant with intussusception present? Knee-chest position w/ currant jelly diarrhea and sausage shaped mass in abdomen"
"What is used to dx and treat intussusception? Air enema"
"What is considered if baby has persistent or worsening jaundice after 2 weeks of age? Biliary atresia"
"The initial step in the evaluation of biliary atresia is a(n) abdominal ultrasound"
"What is tx of biliary atresia? Kasai procedure (hepatoportoenterostomy)"
"What is dx in baby who presents with sudden projectile vomiting after feeds, olive-shaped mass, and visible peristaltic waves? Pyloric stenosis"
"What is seen on CMP in baby with pyloric stenosis? (3) Hypochloremic, hypokalemic, metabolic alkalosis"
"Which microorganisms (2) are the most common cause of brain abscess? Viridans streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus"
"Brain abscess is often visualized on CT or MRI as a(n) ring-enhancing lesion with central necrosis"
"What is definitive dx of pyloric stenosis? U/S showing \donut sign\\"\""
"What is tx of pyloric stenosis? Pylormyotomy"
"Choanal atresia is an atretic or anatomically stenosed connection between the nose and mouth"
"How will babies present with choanal atresia? Pink up with crying (he/she uses mouth) and blue at rest (obligate nose-breathers)"
"Thyroid nodules in hyperthyroid::hyperthyroid/hypothyroid patients are almost never cancer"
"What is the initial step in evaluation of a newly discovered thyroid nodule? TSH level and U/S"
"Pts with thyroid nodules that are euthyroid::which thyroid status? are more likely to be cancer"
"What is the recommended initial pain management for a cancer patient with severe pain refractory to NSAIDs? Short-acting opioids (e.g. morphine, hydromorphone)"
"Wernicke encephalopathy may be induced iatrogenically by the administration of glucose without thiamine in an alcoholic or malnourished patient"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that develops rapid, ascending flaccid paralysis and normal sensation with a normal CSF examination after returning from a hiking trip in the Northeast? Tick-borne paralysis"
"The initial treatment of transient ischemic attack involves improving blood pressure control, starting antiplatelet (aspirin → clopidogrel) and statin, and discontinuing smoking"
"If a patient's ptosis is due to myasthenia gravis, application of a(n) ice pack over the eyelids will result in improvement in ptosis"
"What funduscopic finding is likely present in a patient with multiple episodes of transient vision loss associated with changes in head position? Papilledema"
"Cerebral sinus thrombosis typically occurs in patients with hypercoagulable conditions and manifests as headache and signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g. nausea/vomiting, papilledema)"
"What underlying neurological pathology should be suspected in a patient with bilateral trigeminal neuralgia? Multiple sclerosis"
"What is the next step in management for a patient developing respiratory failure due to myasthenic crisis? Intubation"
"Following intubation, myasthenic crisis is managed with plasmapheresis (preferred) or IVIG, as well as corticosteroids"
"The most common subtype of a(n) lacunar stroke is a pure motor stroke, resulting in contralateral hemiparesis of the face, arm, and leg"
"The diagnosis of cerebral sinus thrombosis is confirmed with MRI with venography::imaging modality"
"Which antiplatelet agent is recommended for all patients within 24 hours of ischemic stroke presentation? Aspirin"
"What class of antibiotics is associated with ototoxicity and/or vestibulopathy with an abnormal head thrust test? Aminoglycosides"
"Symptoms of lumbar spinal stenosis are typically relieved while walking up-hill"
"Lacunar infarcts are most commonly associated with chronic hypertension, which results in arteriolar sclerosis"
"A pure motor stroke is typically caused by a lacunar infarct of the posterior limb of the internal capsule"
"The facial/ophthalmic veins are valveless, thus skin infections in this area can easily spread to the cavernous sinus"
"Are patients with pseudodementia typically distressed by their memory impairment? Yes"
"Symptoms of botulism include bilateral cranial neuropathies followed by symmetric, descending::ascending/descending muscle weakness"
"The pathophysiology of foodborne botulism in adults involves inhibition of presynaptic acetylcholine release at the NMJ due to a preformed toxin"
"What is the recommended treatment for foodborne botulism in adults? Horse-derived antitoxin"
"Which lobes are most commonly involved in a spontaneous lobar hemorrhage secondary to cerebral amyloid angiopathy? Parietal and occipital"
"Cerebral amyloid angiopathy is associated with Alzheimer's dementia"
"The pathophysiology of trigeminal neuralgia is related to demyelination along the trigeminal nerve root, often due to localized compression from nearby vascular structures"
"Normal pressure hydrocephalus may develop due to obstructive hydrocephalus or decreased CSF absorption"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with bilateral lower extremity weakness and loss of pain/temperature sensation with preserved proprioception and vibratory sense following a motor vehicle accident? Anterior cord syndrome"
"A \steppage gait\\" secondary to foot drop is often caused by L5 radiculopathy and common peroneal neuropathy\""
"HSV encephalitis mainly affects the temporal lobe of the brain"
"Acute-onset focal neurological findings, fever, and behavioral changes in a young patient are suggestive of HSV encephalitis"
"What is the gold standard for diagnosis of HSV encephalitis? HSV PCR analysis of CSF"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with severe eye pain and a sensation of a foreign body in the eye with a corneal staining defect on fluorescein examination? Corneal abrasion"
"What nerve is responsible for corneal sensation? Ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve (V1)"
"Primary CNS lymphoma is typically characterized by EBV DNA in the CSF and a single ring-enhancing lesion on MRI in an HIV-infected patient"
"CSF analysis in patients with idiopathic intracranial hypertension typically reveals an opening pressure > 250 mm H2O with an otherwise normal CSF analysis"
"What psychiatric comorbidities are associated with absence seizure? ADHD and anxiety"
"What is the first-line pharmacotherapy for absence seizures? Ethosuximide"
"What is the most common sequelae of bacterial meningitis in children, and what is the appropriate management? Hearing loss due to inflammatory damage to CN VIII and the cochlea All children with meningitis should have audiologic screening and developmental follow-up Give dexamethasone for children with HiB meningitis to avoid hearing loss"
" Fragile X is caused by  an expansion of CGG trinucleotide repeats in the  FMR1 gene"
"Which cause of intellectual disability is characterized by prominent jaw, large ears, and macroorchidism? Fragile X"
"What is the next step in management for an infant that presents with intractable vomiting, a bulging anterior fontanelle, and increasing head circumference? Brain imaging"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child that presents with unilateral hemiparesis that self-resolved within four hours following a seizure? Todd paralysis"
"Infant botulism is caused by ingestion of Clostridium botulinum spores, which are found in environmental dust and honey"
"What is the treatment of choice for infant botulism? Human-derived botulism immune globulin"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a previously healthy infant that presents with constipation, bilateral ptosis, and a \floppy\\" head? Infant botulism\""

"Absence seizures are easily provoked by hyperventilation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child that presents with multiple staring episodes accompanied by head tilting and mouth chewing, followed by a transient period of confusion? Focal seizure with impairment of consciousness"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child that presents with hemiparesis and aphasia hours after falling down with an object in their mouth? Internal carotid artery dissection/thrombus formation"
"Treatment of homocystinuria involves vitamin (B6, B9, B12) supplementation and antiplatelets/anticoagulation"
"What is the greatest risk factor for development of cerebral palsy? Prematurity"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child with a history of tetralogy of Fallot and recurrent sinusitis that presents with a two-week history of worsening morning headaches, fever, focal neurological deficits, and a recent first-time seizure? Brain abscess"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an infant that becomes cyanotic and experiences transient loss of consciousness after crying from an upsetting event? Cyanotic breath-holding spell"
"What is the next step in management for an infant that experienced a breath-holding spell? Reassurance"
"Which lysosomal storage diseases are associated with a \cherry-red\\" spot on the macula? Niemann-Pick and Tay-Sachs disease\""
"Niemann-Pick disease may be differentiated from Tay-Sachs disease by the presence of hypo-reflexia and the presence of hepatosplenomegaly"
"Tay-Sachs disease may be differentiated from Niemann-Pick disease by presence of hyperreflexia::hyporeflexia/hyperreflexia and the absence::presence/abscence of hepatosplenomegaly"
"Which lysosomal storage disease is caused by deficiency of sphingomyelinase? Niemann-Pick disease"
"What is the next step in management for a child that presents to the ED after a transient simple febrile seizure? Reassurance"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an adolescent that presents with recurrent episodes of bifrontal or unifrontal headache accompanied by nausea/vomiting, photophobia, phonophobia, and auras? Migraine"
"Generalized seizures may be differentiated from syncopal episodes by the presence of a(n) post-ictal state"
"Intraventricular hemorrhage is most commonly seen in premature and low-birth-weight infants"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a newborn that develops scalp swelling limited to one cranial bone several hours after birth? Cephalohematoma (subperiosteal hemorrhage)"
"Signs of shaken baby syndrome include bilateral retinal hemorrhages and neurological abnormalities (e.g. seizures, AMS)"
"Neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage may be complicated by communicating::communicating or non-communicating hydrocephalus"
"The incidence of neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage may be reduced by preventing preterm labor and administering antenatal maternal corticosteroids"
"Fatigue, polyuria, polydipsia and signs of dehydration/weight loss is suggestive of type 1 diabetes::diagnosis"
"Urinary tract infection typically arises by bacteria ascending into the bladder from the vaginal introitus"
"What microorganism is the most common cause of urinary tract infection (UTI)? Escherichia coli"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an adolescent that presents with features of nephrotic syndrome and hepatitis B infection? Membranous nephropathy"
"What is the most common cause of proteinuria in children? Transient proteinuria"
"What is the next step in management for a child that is found to have isolated proteinuria on urine dipstick? Repeat dipstick testing on two subsequent occasions"
"Renal tubular acidosis in infants commonly presents with failure to thrive in the setting of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis::acid-base abnormality"
"Renal tubular acidosis is caused by a defect in either hydrogen excretion::type 1 or bicarbonate resorption::type 2 in the kidney"
"Which type(s) of renal tubular acidosis are associated with urine pH ≥ 5.5 (alkalotic)? Type 1 (distal)"
"Which type(s) of renal tubular acidosis are associated with urine pH < 5.5? Type 2 (proximal) Type 4"
"Which type(s) of renal tubular acidosis are associated with low or normal serum K+? type 1 (distal) and type 2 (proximal)"
"Which type(s) of renal tubular acidosis are associated with high serum K+? Type 4 (hyperkalemic)"
"What is the fluid of choice for initial resuscitation of severe hypovolemic hypernatremia in an infant? Isotonic solutions (e.g. normal saline, LR)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an African-American patient that presents with painless gross hematuria with numerous intact RBCs on microscopic examination? Renal papillary necrosis (secondary to sickle cell trait)"
"Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a leukocytoclastic vasculitis that occurs secondary to IgA immune complex deposition"
"What is the recommended treatment for Henoch-Schonlein purpura? Supportive (e.g. hydration, NSAIDs); treat with steroids if severe"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young girl that presents with recurrent UTIs since birth with bilateral focal parenchymal scarring and blunted calyces on imaging? Vesicoureteral reflux"
"Chronic constipation in toddlers may be complicated by recurrent UTIs, secondary to urinary stasis"
"Alport syndrome occurs secondary to an inherited defect in type IV collagen"
"What inherited renal pathology is characterized by thinning and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane? Alport syndrome"
"Infants in diapers with suspected UTI should undergo straight catheterization to obtain a sterile specimen for urinalysis and urine culture"
"What is the first-line pharmacotherapy for nocturnal enuresis? Desmopressin"
"Neonatal abstinence syndrome occurs due to exposure to opiate drugs while in the mother's womb"
"Symptoms of neonatal abstinence syndrome include diarrhea, sweating, irritability, and tachypnea::respiratory rate"
"What psychiatric condition is characterized by intentional and repeated fire setting with no obvious motive? Pyromania"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an adolescent with a history of IBD that presents with watery diarrhea, a beefy red tongue, and an erythematous rash in sun exposed areas? Pellagra (B3 deficiency)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young child that presents with dry eyes, dry skin, and difficulty adapting to darkness? Exam may show a gray patch on the conjunctiva. Vitamin A deficiency"
"All exclusively breastfed infants should be started on daily vitamin D supplements within the first month of life"
"What hematologic pathology is more common in preterm infants within the first 4 - 6 months of life? Iron deficiency anemia"
"Preterm infants that are exclusively breastfed should be initiated on iron supplementation in addition to vitamin D"
"According to the AAP, pureed fruits and vegetables may be introduced to infants beginning at age 6 months"
"Exclusive breastfeeding = 6 months::age Pureed/solid foods = 6 months::age Cow's milk = 12 months::age"
"Does physiologic jaundice of the newborn result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia? Unconjugated"
"What is the initial treatment for rapidly rising hyperbilirubinemia in a newborn? Exchange transfusion (for kernicterus prevention)"
"What is the best initial imaging study for a newborn infant that presents with bilious vomiting and no passage of stool? Abdominal X-ray"
"What is the next step in management for an infant with adequate weight gain that spits up formula after each feed? Reassurance"
"What is the next step in management for an infant with failure to thrive that spits up formula after each feed? PPIs and/or thickened feeds (e.g. adding oatmeal)"
"What cause of bilious vomiting is characterized by meconium obstructing the ileum with a microcolon visualized on X-ray? Meconium ileus (usually secondary to cystic fibrosis)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an adolescent with a history of T1DM that presents with weight loss, iron deficiency anemia and a pruritic, vesicular rash on the elbows and knees? Celiac disease"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an otherwise healthy infant that presents with excessive crying for > 3 hours per day (usually evenings), for > 3 days per week, for > 3 weeks? Infantile colic"
"Sandifier syndrome refers to arching of the back (opisthotonic posturing) during or after feeding and is related to pathologic GERD"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an afebrile child that presents with abdominal pain, jaundice, and a palpable RUQ mass with a normal gallbladder on ultrasound? Biliary cyst"
"In addition to dietary changes, constipation in a toddler may be managed initially with oral laxative therapy"
"To decrease risk of constipation, children should drink < 24 oz of cow's milk per day"
"What is the next step in management for a symptomatic child with evidence of a swallowed coin in the esophagus on X-ray? Flexible endoscopy"
"Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) often presents with polyhydramnios on prenatal ultrasound"
"Breast milk jaundice is distinguishable from breastfeeding failure jaundice by the absence of signs of dehydration"
"What is the recommended management for infants with breastfeeding failure jaundice? Increase the frequency and duration of feeds (q2h)"
"Neonates should breastfeed every 2 - 3 hours for > 10 - 20 minutes per breast during the first month of life"
"Reye syndrome is fulminant liver failure and encephalopathy in children with viral illness who take aspirin"
"Intussusception results in compromised blood supply, which causes intermittent::frequency abdominal pain with \currant jelly\\" stool\""
"What is the most common congenital lead point for intussusception in children? Meckel diverticulum"
"Jejunal atresia is characterized by a \triple bubble\\" sign and gasless colon on X-ray\""
"What vitamin deficiency is associated with inflammation of the lips with scaling/fissures at the corners of the mouth (angular cheilitis)? Labs show a normocytic anemia. Vitamin B2 (riboflavin)"
"What vitamin deficiency is associated with a normocytic-normochromic anemia? Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child that presents with self-limiting, recurrent nausea and vomiting at the same time each month with no symptoms in between episodes? Cyclic vomiting syndrome"
"Children with cyclic vomiting syndrome often have a family history of migraine"
"What is the fluid of choice for initial resuscitation of a child with moderate-severe dehydration? IV bolus of isotonic solutions (e.g. normal saline, lactated Ringer's)"
"Midgut volvulus is a surgical emergency that classically presents in a neonate with congenital malrotation, manifesting as bilious vomiting and abdominal distention"
"Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first 6 months of life"
"Breastfeeding is associated with decreased maternal risk of breast and ovarian cancer"
"Breastfeeding is contraindicated in infants with galactosemia::infant metabolic problem"
"Intussusception is occasionally palpable as a \sausage-shaped\\" or cylindrical mass in the right upper quadrant\""
"What is the next step in management for a child that swallowed a battery that is located in the esophagus on X-ray? Immediate endoscopic removal"
"What is the next step in management for a child that swallowed a battery that is located in the stomach on X-ray? Observation for 24 - 48 hours"
"Duodenal atresia is characterized by dilation of the stomach and proximal duodenum with a \double bubble\\" sign on X-ray\""
"Duodenal atresia is associated with Down syndrome in up to a third of cases"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a 1-month-old that presents with one week of jaundice and acholic stool with hepatomegaly and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia on further examination? Biliary atresia"
"What is the recommended management of patients with biliary atresia prior to a liver transplant? Hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure)"
"Meckel diverticuli often contain ectopic acid-secreting gastric mucosa and, less frequently, pancreatic tissue"
"Children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome should be closely monitored for the development of Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) and hepatoblastoma with abdominal ultrasound::imaging and serum AFP"
"Eosinophilic esophagitis is characterized by esophageal rings and linear furrows on endoscopy"
"Eosinophilic esophagitis is characterized by eosinophilic infiltration of the esophagus, often in atopic patients"
"What is the typical prognosis of milk- or soy-protein-induced colitis? Spontaneous resolution by 1 year of age"
"99% of full-term infants stool within 48 hours of birth"
"Congenital umbilical hernia is due to an incomplete closure of the umbilical ring"
"Abdominal wall defects (e.g. gastroschisis) typically result in elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein during pregnancy"
"Which abdominal wall defect, omphalocele or gastroschisis, is associated with other major malformations? Omphalocele"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child that ingested an unknown bottle of pills several hours ago and now presents with abdominal pain, hematemesis, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis? Iron poisoning"
"Patients who survive acute iron toxicity are at risk of developing pyloric stenosis within 2 - 8 weeks after ingestion"
"What acid-base disturbance is associated with acute iron toxicity? Anion gap metabolic acidosis"
"What is the recommended treatment for severely ill patients with iron toxicity? Deferoxamine (an iron chelator)"
"What is the diagnostic test of choice to evaluate the extent of injury following caustic ingestion? Upper GI endoscopy"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child that presents with cyanosis and decreased O2 saturation after using an oral topical anesthetic (e.g. benzocaine)? Methemoglobinemia"
"Methemoglobinemia often presents with cyanosis and chocolate-colored blood"
"Methemoglobinemia is typically treated with methylene blue"
"What is the next step in management for a child that has an elevated lead level on capillary blood testing? Measure venous lead level"
"What is the recommended management for children with mild lead poisoning (5 - 44 mcg/dL on venous blood testing)? Removal from lead-containing environment; repeat level in < 1 month"
"What is the recommended management for children with severe lead poisoning (≥ 70 mcg/dL on venous blood testing)? Dimercaprol plus EDTA"
"Risk factors for lead poisoning include homes built before 1978 under renovation or with peeling paint"
"What hematological complication is associated with nitrates? Methemoglobinemia"
"Atopic dermatitis (eczema) in infants usually manifests as pruritic, scaly, erythematous lesions on the face, chest, and extensor surfaces"
"Atopic dermatitis (eczema) in children/adults usually appears on flexor surfaces"
"What is the first-line treatment for atopic dermatitis (eczema)? Topical emollients"
"What dermatologic condition is more common in patients with a family history of asthma and/or allergic rhinitis? Atopic dermatitis (eczema)"
"Sunscreen with SPF 15 - 30 or higher should be applied 15 - 30 minutes prior to sun exposure to allow time for development of a protective film and be reapplied at least every 2 hours"
"What microorganism is involved in the pathogenesis of tinea versicolor? Malassezia"

"What is the recommended treatment for tinea capitis? Oral griseofulvin or terbinafine"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child that presents with linear streaks of erythematous vesicles a few days after returning from a camping trip? Contact dermatitis"
"What type of hypersensitivity reaction is contact dermatitis (e.g. poison ivy, nickel allergy)? Type IV HSR (delayed-type hypersensitivity)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a healthy-appearing newborn (e.g. baby DOL 2-5) that presents with scattered blanchable erythematous papules that spare the palms/soles? What are they filled with? Erythema toxicum neonatorum; eosinophils"
"What is the next step in management for a newborn with suspected erythema toxicum neonatorum? Reassurance"
"Intentional scald injuries in children are characterized by sharp lines of demarcation and uniform burn depth with sparing of flexor surfaces"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a vaccinated child that presents with intensely pruritic small, erythematous papules and burrows involving the hands? Scabies"
"What is the most common renal manifestation of Henoch-Scholein purpura? Hematuria"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an Asian/African-American infant that presents with flat blue-gray patches on the lower back and buttock? Congenital dermal melanocytosis (\Mongolian spot\\")\""
"Do strawberry hemangiomas typically regress spontaneously? Yes (after an initial period of rapid growth)"
"What is the recommended management for strawberry hemangiomas that are disfiguring, disabling, or life-threatening? β-blockers (e.g. propranolol)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an athlete that presents with a scaly, erythematous, pruritic plaque with a raised border and central clearing on their leg? Tinea corporis (ringworm) caused by dermatophytes"
"What is the first-line treatment for tinea corporis? Topical antifungals (e.g. clotrimazole, terbinafine)"
"What is the recommended management of pityriasis rosea? Reassurance"
"Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is caused by exfoliative toxin-producing strains of S. aureus"
"Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome usually affects children, but may also be seen in adults with immunocompromise or renal insufficiency"

"What is the likely diagnosis in an infant with an erythematous rash in the diaper region that spares skin folds? Irritant (contact) diaper dermatitis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an infant with an erythematous rash in the diaper region with satellite lesions and involvement of skin folds? Candidal diaper dermatitis"

"What is the likely diagnosis in an infant with blanchable, pink patch involving the glabella? Nevus simplex"
"Erythema multiforme is a blistering skin disorder most commonly associated with HSV infection"

"Splenic sequestration is characterized by normocytic anemia with increased reticulocyte count"
"Splenic sequestration is characterized by decreased platelet count"
"Hydroxyurea is useful in the treatment of sickle cell anemia because it increases levels of HbF (typically greater than 15%)"
"At baseline, patients with sickle cell disease have increased levels of HbF"
"What is the most common cause of pediatric stroke? Sickle cell disease"
"How do the following laboratory values change in anemia of chronic disease? Serum iron: decreased TIBC: decreased % Saturation: decreased Ferritin: increased"

"Splenectomy is associated with a long-term risk for sepsis with encapsulated bacteria"

"What is the next step in management for a child with suspected immune thrombocytopenia that presents with scattered petechiae and self-limited epistaxis? Observation"

"Aplastic anemia may be caused by Fanconi anemia, which occurs due to a(n) ds DNA repair defect, resulting in bone marrow failure"
"Pure red cell aplasia is associated with thymoma, lymphocytic leukemias, and parvovirus B19 infection"

"Cytoplasmic aggregates of peroxidase positive granules and/or Auer rods are characteristic of myelo-blasts"
"What demographic (age group) is most commonly associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML)? Older adults (median onset is 65 years old)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an adolescent with a history of hemophilia A that presents with gradually worsening pain and limited motion of his knee? Hemophilic arthropathy"

"What is the likely diagnosis in a child with a history of sickle cell disease that presents with acute, severe anemia in the setting of a low reticulocyte count and no hepatosplenomegaly? Aplastic crisis"

"Aplastic crisis is often seen in patients with sickle cell disease and is characterized by normal platelet count"
"What is the most common trigger of aplastic crisis in patients with sickle cell disease? Parvovirus B19 infection"
"What hematologic pathology is characterized by profound hypocellularity with fatty infiltration on bone marrow biopsy? Aplastic anemia"

"Hemolytic uremic syndrome is classically seen in children with E. coli O157:H7 dysentery, which results from exposure to undercooked beef"
"Medulloblastoma is a posterior fossa tumor of childhood that typically arises from the cerebellar vermis::location"

"Osteosarcoma arises in the metaphysis of long bones, often around the knee"
"What is the most common complication of sickle cell trait? Painless hematuria (microscopic or gross)"
"Thalassemia minor is characterized by normal total RBC count and normal RDW"
"In patients with sickle cell disease, chronic damage and autoinfarction typically causes functional asplenia by age 5"
"Polycythemia in term neonates is defined as a hematocrit > 65%."
"What are two maternal risk factors for neonatal polycythemia other than delayed cord clamping? Maternal HTN Maternal DM"
"What is the recommended treatment for symptomatic neonates with polycythemia (e.g. respiratory distress, hypoglycemia)? Partial exchange transfusion"
"Diamond-Blackfan anemia is associated with congenital anomalies, such as short stature, webbed neck, cleft lip, shield chest, and triphalangeal thumbs"
"What hematologic pathology is characterized by normocytic anemia with a low reticulocyte count in preterm infants? Anemia of prematurity"
"Acute leukemia is defined as a neoplastic proliferation of blasts > 25% on bone marrow biopsy"

"Refeeding syndrome is associated with decreased::increased/decreased serum levels of phosphorus, Mg2+, and K+"

"Patients with von Gierke disease typically have a protuberant abdomen, secondary to hepatomegaly"
"Patients with von Gierke disease often have thin extremities, short stature, and a \doll-like\\" face\""
"Von Gierke disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase"
"von Gierke disease is associated with increased serum lactate, triglycerides, and uric acid"
"In gonadotropin-independent (peripheral) precocious puberty, LH levels are low::high/low at baseline and does not::does/does not increase with a GnRH agonist"
"In gonadotropin-dependent (central) precocious puberty, LH levels are high at baseline"
"The initial evaluation of patients with precocious puberty is to determine the patient's bone age, which helps differentiate true precocious puberty from other benign pubertal variants, such as premature thelarche/adrenarche"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young boy that presents with advanced bone age, coarse pubic hair, and severe cystic acne with low basal LH levels and normal testicular exam? Late-onset (nonclassic) congenital adrenal hyperplasia"
"Precocious puberty is defined as the onset of secondary sexual characteristics in girls < 8 and boys < 9 years of age"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young girl that presents with precocious puberty with an advanced bone age, high FSH/LH levels, and a normal MRI? Idiopathic precocious puberty"
"What is the recommended treatment for idiopathic precocious puberty? Continuous GnRH agonist therapy (e.g. leuprolide)"
"Patients with central precocious puberty require MRI of the brain prior to starting GnRH agonist therapy"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an obese young girl that presents with pubic hair, acne, and normal bone age? Premature adrenarche"
"What cause of precocious puberty is associated with unilateral café-au-lait spots and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia? McCune-Albright syndrome"
"What is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism worldwide? Treatment? Thyroid dysgenesis; levothyroxine"

"How do total body stores of K+ change in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis? Decreased"
"Diabetic ketoacidosis is often precipitated by acute infection due to systemic release of catecholamines and cortisol"

"What is the most common complication among infants of diabetic mothers? Neonatal hypoglycemia"
"What is the next step in management for a healthy adolescent male that presents with tender, subareolar masses on both breasts? Reassurance and follow-up"

"What is the most common cause of vaginal bleeding in the neonatal period? Maternal withdrawal of estrogen"
"In androgen insensitivity syndrome a person is genotypically XY but has female external genitalia with male internal genitalia"
"When should patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome have bilateral gonadectomy? After puberty"
"In 5α-reductase deficiency, a person is genotypically XY but has ambiguous external genitalia with normal male internal genitalia"
"Which sex chromosome disorder is associated with short stature, primary amenorrhea, and absent thelarche/menarche in a female? Turner syndrome"
"Patients with Turner syndrome typically have low levels of estrogen and high levels of FSH/LH"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young girl that presents with breast development and a white, odorless vaginal discharge with an ovarian mass on ultrasound? Granulosa cell tumor"
"What is the next step in management for an adolescent female that presents with nausea/vomiting and RLQ abdominal pain with an unknown last menstrual period? Urine pregnancy testing (e.g. hCG)"
"Do adolescents seeking pregnancy prevention options (e.g. OCPs, emergency contraception) need parental consent? No"
"What is the most effective emergency contraceptive? Copper IUD (inflammatory reaction)"
"What is the next step in management for a young girl that presents with a foul-smelling vaginal discharge with a whitish foreign body inside the vaginal introitus on physical exam? Irrigation with warmed fluid or removal with a swab"
"Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menarche by age 15"
"What is the preferred imaging modality for the initial evaluation of a patient with primary amenorrhea? Pelvic ultrasound"

"Size and tenderness of a fibroadenoma of the breast typically increases prior to menstruation"
"What is the next step in management for an adolescent that presents with a tender breast mass a few days prior to menstruation? Follow-up after menses"
"What is the next step in management for an adolescent girl that presents with primary amenorrhea and absent breast development with a uterus present on ultrasound? Measure serum FSH level"
"What is the next step in management for an adolescent girl with primary amenorrhea with a uterus present on ultrasound and high FSH levels? Karyotyping"
"What is the next step in management for an adolescent girl with primary amenorrhea with a uterus present on ultrasound and low FSH levels? Brain MRI"
"What is the first-line treatment for primary dysmenorrhea? NSAIDs and/or OCPs"

"Fetal macrosomia is associated with increased risk for shoulder dystocia"
"Small for gestational age (SGA) infants have a birth weight that is below the 10th percentile for gestational age"
"What hematologic complication may be seen in a newborn with low birth weight and intrauterine growth restriction? Polycythemia"

"What is the likely diagnosis and next step in a child with a history of neurofibromatosis type 1 that presents with unilateral vision loss, proptosis, and optic disc pallor? Optic pathway glioma; get MRI"

"Gonococcal conjunctivitis can be prevented with prophylactic topical erythromycin ointment soon after birth"
"Strabismus refers to intermittent or constant ocular misalignment."
"Concerning examination findings for children with strabismus include asymmetric corneal light reflections and deviation on cover test"
"What is the next step in management for a 2-month-old infant that presents with intermittent strabismus? Reassurance"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child with a history of asthma that presents with bilateral itchy, red eyes with watery discharge for the past several weeks? Allergic conjunctivitis"
"Is allergic conjunctivitis typically unilateral or bilateral? Always bilateral"
"How often should vision assessment be assessed in children? At every well-child visit"
"Dacryostenosis is caused by obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct and results in crusting of the eye lashes and tearing"
"What is the recommended treatment for dacryostenosis? Nasolacrimal sac massage"
"Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to a defect in NADPH oxidase enzyme"
"Can the rotavirus vaccine be administered to patients with a history of intussusception? No (contraindicated)"
"What is the definitive treatment severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)? Stem cell transplant"
"SCID is characterized by absent T cells and dysfunctional B cells"
"Which immunodeficiency is characterized by no B-cell differentiation and decreased immunoglobulins of all classes? Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID)"
"What is the recommended management for patients with common variable immunodeficiency (CVID)? IV immunoglobulins"
"Leukocyte adhesion deficiency is characterized by recurrent skin and mucosal bacterial infections with absent pus formation"
"Leukocyte adhesion deficiency is characterized by marked leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance"
"In preterm infants, all vaccines should be administered according to chronologic::chronologic/gestational age"
"The first hepatitis B vaccine should be administered when the newborn weighs > 2 kg"
"Contraindications to the DTaP vaccine include history of anaphylaxis to vaccine ingredients, unstable neurologic disorders, and encephalopathy within a week of previous vaccine administration"
"Selective IgA deficiency is associated with anaphylaxis during blood transfusions"
"Conditions causing IgA deficiency predispose patients to chronic giardiasis"

"C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency results in elevated levels of the edema-producing factors C2b and bradykinin"

"Acute epiglottitis may present with a muffled (\hot potato\\") voice and inspiratory stridor\""

"Which type of meningitis presents with normal glucose, protein < 100, and increased lymphocytes in the CSF? Viral meningitis"
"What is the most common cause of viral meningitis? Enteroviruses"

"Hemoglobinopathies, such a sickle cell trait and thalassemia, may confer resistance against malaria"
"Diagnosis of malaria is confirmed by visualization of parasites on thick and thin blood smears"

"What is the mode of transmission of measles virus (rubeola)? Airborne"
"The treatment for measles virus is generally supportive, however vitamin A is recommended for hospitalized patients"

"Cat-scratch disease is caused by the bacteria Bartonella henselae"

"What symptom is characteristic of rubella in adolescents/adults, but not in children? Arthralgias/arthritis"

"After an initial catarrhal phase, pertussis progresses to a paroxysmal phase, which is characterized by a \whooping cough\\""
"Scarlet fever is caused by infection with group A Streptococcus (S. pyogenes)"

"The most important risk factor for vertical transmission of HIV is high maternal viral load"
"Koplik spots are bluish-white lesions on the buccal mucosa and are pathognomonic for measles"

"What is the recommended post-exposure prophylaxis for a pregnant woman exposed to varicella zoster? Administer varicella zoster immunoglobulin"
"What is the recommended post-exposure prophylaxis for an immunized child exposed to varicella zoster? Observation"

"Can acute rheumatic fever be prevented with treatment of Streptococcal pharyngitis (e.g. oral penicillin)? Yes"
"What microorganisms are most commonly associated with non-bullous impetigo? (2) Staphylococcus aureus Streptococcus pyogenes"
"What is the recommended treatment for localized non-bullous impetigo? Topical antibiotics (e.g. mupirocin)"
"Children with meningitis secondary to Haemophilus influenzae type b should receive dexamethasone to reduce the risk of sensorineural hearing loss"
"Congenital toxoplasmosis classically presents with diffuse intracerebral calcifications, hydrocephalus, and ventriculomegaly"
"Maternal toxoplasmosis is typically acquired through ingestion of cat feces or raw/undercooked meat"
"What eye pathology is associated with toxoplasmosis? Chorioretinitis"

"What is the recommended treatment for herpangina? Supportive"
"Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is characterized by sudden vasomotor collapse due to bilateral adrenal hemorrhage"
"Which congenital infection is associated with rhinorrhea and desquamating skin rash? Syphilis"
"Which congenital infection is associated with cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, and patent ductus arteriosus? Rubella"
"Congenital CMV is associated with periventricular calcifications"
"Hydrophobia and aerophobia are pathognomonic features of encephalitic rabies"
"What is the most common source of rabies transmission in the United States? Bats"
"Treatment of neonatal tetanus includes antibiotics and tetanus immune globulin"
"What organism is responsible for recurrent pulmonary infections in a young child with cystic fibrosis? Staphylococcus aureus"
"What is the next step in management for an asymptomatic adolescent that presents with a soft, mobile, non-tender cervical lymph node measuring 1 cm in diameter? Observation"
"What procedure is both diagnostic and therapeutic for septic arthritis? Arthrocentesis (to drain synovial fluid)"
"What is the next step in management for a child that develops a fever and mild rash one week after receiving the MMR vaccine? Reassurance"
"What are the most common causative organisms associated with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis? (2) Streptococcus pneumoniae Nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae"
"What is the diagnosis and recommended treatment for a patient with infectious mononucleosis that presents with difficulty swallowing and labored breathing? Acute airway obstruction; IV corticosteroids"
"Which microorganism is associated with rapid-onset food poisoning with predominant vomiting after eating dairy products? Staphylococcus aureus"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an unvaccinated child that presents with fever and bilateral parotitis? Mumps"
"What neurologic complication is associated with mumps infection? Aseptic meningitis"
"What mumps complication occurs predominantly in post-pubertal males? Orchitis"
"What is the recommended treatment for a newborn of a mother with active hepatitis B? hepatitis B immune globulin followed by HBV vaccine at birth"
"What is the recommended treatment for vaccinated close contacts of patients with pertussis? Prophylactic macrolides"
"Radial head subluxation (nursemaid's elbow) typically occurs in children after being lifted or pulled by the arm"
"Radial head subluxation (nursemaid's elbow) occurs when the radial head slips through part of the annular ligament"
"What maneuvers are both diagnostic and therapeutic for radial head subluxation (nursemaid's elbow)? Forearm hyperpronation or supination plus flexion"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a newborn with bilateral medial deviation of the forefoot that corrects with passive and active foot movement? Metatarsus adductus"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a newborn with rigid medial and upward deviation of the forefoot and hindfoot? Clubfoot (talipes equinovarus)"
"What is the recommended treatment for metatarsus adductus? Reassurance"
"What is the recommended treatment for congenital clubfoot? serial manipulation and casting"
"Why is closed reduction of the hip joint not recommended for slipped capital femoral epiphysis? Can damage tenuous blood supply to femoral head"
"Lyme arthritis presents as an inflammatory monoarticular or asymmetric oligoarticular arthritis, most commonly in the knee"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child that presents with bilateral lower extremity pain, especially at night, with a normal physical exam? Growing pains"
"What is the next step in management for a child with suspected growing pains? Reassurance and supportive treatment"
"Osteoid osteoma typically arises in the cortex of the diaphysis of long bones (typically the proximal femur)"
"Osteoblastoma presents with bone pain, especially at night, that DOES NOT resolve with aspirin/NSAIDs"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an exclusively breastfed infant that presents with craniotabes, widened wrists, Harrison's subcostal groove, rachitic rosary, and genu varum? Rickets (secondary to vitamin D deficiency)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child with Down syndrome that presents with behavioral change, urinary incontinence, and upper motor neuron symptoms (leg spasticity, hyperreflexia, Babinski, clonus)? Atlantoaxial instability"
"Atlantoaxial instability is more common in Down syndrome patients and typically manifests with upper motor neuron symptoms"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child that presents with two months of daily fever, pink macular rash, and knee/hip pain that is worse in the morning? Systemic-onset juvenile idiopathic arthritis (systemic JIA)"
"Osteogenesis imperfecta may present with blue sclerae due to translucent connective tissue over choroidal veins"
"Osteogenesis imperfecta is caused by mutation in the genes coding for type I collagen"
"What is the recommended treatment for transient synovitis? Rest and NSAIDs"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child that presents with three months of symmetric arthritis of wrists, knees, and ankles that is worse in the morning? Polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (aka junvenile RA)"
"What laboratory findings are associated with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA)? RBCs: decreased (anemia) WBCs: increased (leukocytosis) Platelets: increased (thrombocytosis)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child with recent urinary incontinence, several months of back pain worsened by lumbar extension, and a palpable \step-off\\" at the lumbosacral area on physical exam? Spondylolisthesis\""
"Osgood-Schlatter disease presents with focal pain and swelling at the tibial tuberosity, secondary to traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an infant that presents with head tilting toward one side with a neck mass that does not transilluminate on ultrasound? Congenital muscular torticollis"
"Serum sickness typically presents with fever, urticaria, arthralgia, and lymphadenopathy 1 - 2 weeks after antigen exposure (timing)"
"What drug classes are most commonly associated with serum sickness? β-lactams and sulfa drugs"

"Cystic fibrosis may be differentiated from kartagener syndrome by the presence of pancreatic insufficiency"
"The risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome may be reduced by administering maternal antenatal glucocorticoids"

"Approximately how many wet diapers should a 5-day-old newborn make per day? > 5 wet diapers/per day"
"Birth weight should be regained by age 10 - 14 days"
"By age 12 months, an infants weight should triple and height should increase by 50%"
"What gross motor developmental milestone(s) are expected in a 2 month old? Lift head in prone position"

"What gross motor developmental milestone(s) are expected in a 4 month old? begins rolling, sits with trunk support"
"What language developmental milestone(s) are expected in a 4 month old? turns to voice, laughs"

"What fine motor developmental milestone(s) are expected in a 6 month old? transfer objects hand to hand"
"What language developmental milestone(s) are expected in a 6 month old? responds to name, babbles"

"What language developmental milestone(s) are expected in a 9 month old? says \dada\\""

"What language developmental milestone(s) are expected in a 12 month old? says first words aside from \mama\\" and \\"dada\\"\""

"What language developmental milestone(s) are expected in an 18 month old? 10 - 25 word vocabulary, identifies > 1 body parts"

"What social developmental milestone(s) are expected in a 2 year old? begins parallel play, follow 2-step commands"

"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with scoliosis, long fingers and toes, and upwards lens dislocation? Marfan syndrome"

"What chromosomal abnormality presents with clenched hands with overlapping fingers? Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome)"
"Edwards syndrome is associated with intellectual disability, rocker-bottom feet, low-set ears, and a small jaw (micrognathia)"

"What chromosomal abnormality is associated with intellectual disability, prominent epicanthal folds, and a single palmar crease? Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome)"

"In Angelman syndrome, the paternal::maternal or paternal gene is imprinted and the maternal::maternal or paternal gene is mutated/deleted"

"Kallmann syndrome is characterized by a defective migration of GnRH cells and defective formation of the olfactory bulb"
"Kallmann syndrome presents as infertility in males and amenorrhea in females; anosmia may be present in both sexes"
"Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by a(n) 47,XXY karyotype"
"All sexually active women age < 24 should be screened for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae with NAAT::method"
"What is the next step in management for a child with a grade II systolic ejection murmur that decreases with standing? Reassurance"
"The murmurs of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and mitral valve prolapse increase with standing and the Valsalva maneuver"
"How does the murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and mitral valve prolapse change with the Valsalva maneuver? Increase"
"How does the murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and mitral valve prolapse change with standing? Increase"
"How does the murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and mitral valve prolapse change with squatting? Decrease"
"How does the murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy change with handgrip? Decrease"
"How does the murmur of aortic stenosis change with handgrip? Decrease"
"How do regurgitation murmurs change with squatting and handgrip (e.g. AR, MR, VSD)? Increase"
"How do regurgitation murmurs change with standing and the Valsalva maneuver (e.g. AR, MR, VSD)? Decrease"
"What is the next step in management for a newborn with cyanosis that does not improve with 100% O2 and a continuous machine-like murmur on auscultation? Administer prostaglandin E1"

"Coarctation of the aorta may cause a systolic or continuous murmur in the left interscapular area"
"What congenital heart defect results from thickening of the tunica media in the aortic arch? Coarctation of the aorta"

"Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by a(n) boot-shaped heart on CXR"
"ECG changes indicative of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy include a tall R wave in aVL and a deep S wave in V3"

"ECG in a newborn normally shows physiologic right axis deviation"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an infant with Down syndrome that presents with heart failure and 1) Loud S2 2) Systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border 3) Holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border Complete AV septal defect (ASD and VSD)"
"What is the most common heart defect in patients with Down syndrome? Complete AV septal defect"
"What is the recommended treatment for a patient that presents with mitral stenosis secondary to suspected rheumatic fever? Start/continue penicillin prophylaxis"

"What is the likely diagnosis in a child that experiences sudden transient episodes of loss of consciousness with paleness prior to the attack and flushing after? The child is fully alert upon awakening. Adams-Stokes syndrome"

"Rapid Diagnosis (Pediatrics) Rapid breast/teste development, pubic hair, and rapid growth. GnRH stimulation test shows dramatic increase in LH: Central precocious puberty::Diagnosis?"
"What is the main worry in patients with central precocious puberty? Decreased height"
