"What are the indications after birth for positive pressure ventilation? HR <100 or increased respiratory effort (gasping respiratory effort, apnea)"
"Androgen defieciency and excess in Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia Signs of deficiency: XX: Normal genitaliaXY: Female, ambigious Signs of excess:XX: Male external genitalia/virilization (hyperandogenism during embryogenesis), precocious puberty (excess androgens are aromatized to estrogen by aromatase in the granulosa cells of the ovaries)XY: Normal male external genitalia at birth with precocious puberty"
"DiGeorge Syndrome is a defective development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches, which leads to hypoplastic thymus and parathyroids"
"Bronchopulmonary dysplasia is a chronic lung disease found in premature infants exposed to prolonged mechanical ventilation and O2 therapy for respiratory distress syndrome"
"What complications can arise from O2 therapy in premature infants with respiratory distress?  RIBRetinopathy of prematurityIntraventricular hemorrhageBronchopulmonary dysplasia"
"In preterm infants, intraventricular hemorrhage generally originates within the germinal matrix, a highly cellular and richly vascularized layer Diagnostic Imaging? Cranial doppler (up to one-half are clinically silent so routine U.S is performed in premature infants)"
"Rapid Diagnosis Acute onset cough in child, SOB, unilateral wheezing, hyperlucency of lung fields:: Foreign body aspiration; diagnose with bronchoscopy::Diagnosis and Treatment?"
"What is the most appropriate first step for a patient that tests positive for HIV but does not want to tell his/her partner? encourage the patient to tell the partner(s) & notify the local health department"
"Can a pregnant woman with capacity refuse cesarean section if vaginal delivery would put the unborn child at risk? Yes"
"What is the probability of a child having hemophilia A if born to a carrier mother and unaffected father? 25%"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an African-American woman at 20 weeks gestation that presents with new-onset hirsutism and acne? Pelvic ultrasound reveals an intrauterine gestation consistent with dates and bilateral 8-cm solid ovarian masses. Luteoma"
"Symptomatic maternal luteoma puts a female fetus at a high risk of virilization"
"Elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is associated with neural tube defects, abdominal wall defects, and multiple gestation"
"Decreased maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is associated with aneuploidies (e.g. trisomy 18 & 21)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a pregnant woman at 35 weeks gestation that has experienced leakage of fluid over the past two days? The fluid is nitrazine-positive. Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)"
"What is the recommended management for patients with PPROM at < 34 weeks gestation and NO signs of infection/fetal compromise? antibiotics, corticosteroids, and expectant management"
"What is the recommended management for patients with PPROM at > 34 weeks gestation? delivery, antibiotics +/- corticosteroids"
"What is the recommended management for patients with PPROM at < 34 weeks gestation and signs of infection/fetal compromise? corticosteroids, antibiotics, delivery +/- magnesium"
"Maternal complications associated with placental abruption include DIC and hypovolemic shock"
"Indications for prophylactic administration of RhoGAM in Rh(D)- women include women at 28 - 32 weeks gestation or within 72 hours of any procedure in which there is a possibility of feto-maternal blood mixing"
"The presence of amniotic fluid may be detected with the nitrazine and/or fern test"
"Patients in preterm labor at < 32 weeks should receive magnesium sulfate for fetal neuroprotection"
"Healthy patients in preterm labor at < 34 weeks should receive tocolytics to postpone delivery"
"Patients in preterm labor at < 37 weeks should receive corticosteroids to reduce risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome"
"Following suction curettage for a hydatidiform mole, β-hCG levels are measured weekly until undetectable and then monthly for 6 months"
"What is the underlying cause of variable decelerations on fetal heart tracing? Fetal cord compression"
"What is the underlying cause of late decelerations on fetal heart tracing? Placental insufficiency"
"Spontaneous abortion is unprovoked pregnancy loss at < 20 weeks gestation and is a common cause of first trimester bleeding"
"Spontaneous abortions are most commonly the result of fetal chromosomal abnormalities"
"What type of miscarriage is characterized by vaginal bleeding and a dilated cervical os without expulsion of products of conception? Inevitable abortion"
"What type of miscarriage is characterized by vaginal bleeding and a closed cervical os with normal fetal cardiac activity? Threatened abortion"
"What type of miscarriage is characterized by no vaginal bleeding and a closed cervical os with no fetal cardiac activity? Missed abortion"
"Physiologic changes during normal pregnancy include a(n) increased GFR and increased basement membrane permeability"
"How do the following laboratory values change during normal pregnancy? BUN: decrease Creatinine: decrease Renal protein excretion: increase"
"How do the following laboratory values change during normal pregnancy? Plasma volume: 50% increase RBC volume: 30% increase"
"Normal pregnancy is associated with a(n) hyper-coagulable state"
"What is the recommended management for a pregnant woman at 35 weeks gestation that presents in preterm labor with the fetus in breech presentation on ultrasound? Cesarean delivery"
"What is the recommended management for a pregnant woman at 35 weeks gestation that presents in preterm labor with a fetus in vertex presentation on ultrasound? Expectant management"
"Preeclampsia is defined as hypertension with proteinuria or end-organ dysfunction after the 20th week of gestation"
"Maternal hypertensive crisis is defined as a SBP > 160 or DBP > 110 mmHg for > 15 minutes"
"Eclampsia is defined as preeclampsia with new-onset seizures"
"Treatment for eclampsia includes blood pressure control, magnesium sulfate for seizure prevention, and expedient delivery"
"Symmetric fetal growth restriction begins in the first trimester and is typically caused by chromosomal abnormalities"
"Asymmetric fetal growth restriction begins in the second/third trimester and is associated with conditions that cause placental insufficiency (e.g. hypertension, diabetes)"
"Chronic hypertension is a blood pressure > 140/90 mmHg before the 20th week of gestation"
"Universal screening for group B Streptococcus colonization is typically done by vaginal and rectal culture at 35 - 37 weeks gestation"
"What is the prophylactic agent of choice for pregnant women who test positive for group B Streptococcus? Intrapartum penicillin"
"Labor and vaginal delivery are contraindicated after a(n) classical cesarean delivery or extensive myomectomy"
"Evidence of a retained placenta includes an echogenic mass or thickened endometrial stripe on ultrasound"
"Maternal contraindications to breastfeeding include active untreated tuberculosis, varicella infection, HIV and herpetic breast lesions"
"Maternal contraindications to breastfeeding include chemo- or radiation therapy and illicit drug use"
"Examination findings consistent with uterine rupture include the presence of abdominally palpable fetal parts and/or the loss of fetal station"
"Uterine rupture classically occurs in a woman with prior uterine surgery"
"What is the recommended management for a pregnant woman that is rubella-nonimmune? Immediate postpartum vaccination (e.g. MMR)"
"All pregnant women should be screened for gestational diabetes mellitus at 24 - 28 weeks gestation"
"What is the target fasting blood glucose level in patients with gestational diabetes mellitus? < 95 mg/dL"
"What is the recommended treatment for patients with gestational diabetes that continue to have elevated glucose levels despite lifestyle modifications? insulin or oral medications (e.g. metformin)"
"After instructing the laboring patient to breath and not push, management of shoulder dystocia includes flexing the hips toward the abdomen (McRoberts manuever) and application of suprapubic pressure"
"When is a non-stress test is considered reactive (normal)? There are at least 2 fetal heart rate accelerations in 20 minutes"
"Placenta previa is attachment of the placenta to the lower uterine segment over the internal cervical os"
"Second stage arrest of labor is defined as no fetal descent after pushing for > 3 hours (nulliparous) or > 2 hours (multiparous)"
"What is the most common cause of second stage arrest of labor? Cephalopelvic disproportion, secondary to fetal malposition (e.g. occiput transverse)"
"The optimal fetal positioning is occiput anterior"
"The first-trimester combined test analyzes the risk for fetal trisomy 18 & 21 by measuring maternal serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein and β-hCG, as well as nuchal translucency on ultrasound"
"Amniocentesis may be performed between 15 to 22 weeks"
"What is the next step in management for a pregnant woman at 12 weeks gestation with an abnormally elevated β-hCG level and increased nuchal thickness on ultrasound? Chorionic villous sampling (CVS)"
"Complications of inadequate weight gain during pregnancy include fetal growth restriction and preterm delivery"
"What are the current recommendations for influenza vaccination during pregnancy? All pregnant women should receive the inactivated (injectable) influenza vaccine"
"What is the recommended treatment for a pregnant patient with a penicillin allergy that is diagnosed with syphilis? IM penicillin (patients need to be desensitized)"
"What is the next step in management for a pregnant woman at 34 weeks gestation that presents with decreased fetal movement? Non-stress testing reveals a normal FHR but is non-reactive despite vibroacoustic stimulation. biophysical profile or contraction stress test"
"Can a non-reactive non-stress test effectively rule in fetal acidemia? No"
"An abnormal biophysical profile score (0 - 4) is consistent with fetal hypoxia due to placental dysfunction"
"Oligohydramnios is characterized by an amniotic fluid index < 5 cm or a single deepest pocket < 2 cm"
"Symptoms of magnesium toxicity include somnolence, respiratory depression, and hypo-reflexia"
"Symptoms of magnesium toxicity include hypo-calcemia and cardiac arrest"
"What is the first-line treatment for magnesium toxicity? Calcium gluconate"
"Which type(s) of decelerations may be indicative of fetal hypoxia and/or acidosis? late and recurrent variable decelerations"
"What are the infectious complications of atopic dermatitis (eczema)? ::4"
"Cell-free fetal DNA testing can be ordered at > 10 weeks gestation"
"Aspirin should not be given to patients <19, especially those with febrile illnesses, except for which diseases? Kawasaki, Juvenile RA"
"HELLP syndrome is a potential manifestation of severe preeclampsia characterized by a triad of hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets"
"Patients with HELLP syndrome may present with severe RUQ abdominal pain due to liver swelling with distention of the hepatic (Glisson's) capsule"
"Fetal complications of preeclampsia include oligohydramnios and fetal growth restriction due to chronic uteroplacental insufficiency"
"Normal postpartum changes include shivering, lochia, and a(n) contracted uterus (relaxed or contracted)"
"What is the most common risk factor for placental abruption? Hypertension"
"Evaluation of a newborn with fetal growth restriction at delivery includes histopathologic examination of the placenta to assess for infection and/or infarction"
"What is the best screening test for gestational diabetes mellitus? 50g 1-hour glucose challenge"
"What is the recommended treatment for post-stroke depression? SSRIs and/or psychotherapy"
"What is the next step in management for a depressed patient with a partial response to SSRI therapy that complaints of fatigue and weight gain? Add bupropion"
"What psychiatric disorder is more common in patients with oppositional defiant disorder? ADHD"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that experiences panic attacks while driving over bridges for the past year? The patient takes great effort to avoid bridges. Specific phobia"
"In addition to lithium and valproate, first-line maintenance treatments for bipolar disorder include lamotrigine and quetiapine"
"Risk of prescription opioid misuse may be reduced by regular patient follow-up, random urine drug screens, and by reviewing the state's prescription drug-monitoring program data"
"Fluoxetine is an SSRI with a relatively long half-life and thus must be discontinued 5 weeks before initiating an MAOI"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that develops fatigue, insomnia, and myalgias after abruptly discontinuing paroxetine due to undesirable side effects? Restart paroxetine and taper gradually over several weeks"
"What is the treatment of choice for an adult with suspected ADHD and a history of substance use disorder? Atomoxetine"
"What changes detected by maternal quadruple screen are indicative of trisomy 21 (Down syndrome)? AFP: decreased Estriol: decreased β-hCG: increased Inhibin A: increased"
"What changes detected by maternal quadruple screen are indicative of trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome)? AFP: decreased Estriol: decreased β-hCG: decreased Inhibin A: normal"
"Late- and post-term pregnancies are commonly complicated by oligo-hydramnios"
"External cephalic version is relatively contraindicated in patients with decreased amniotic fluid"
"What is the recommended management for a pregnant woman at 28 weeks gestation that presents in labor for a fetus diagnosed with anhydramnios and anencephaly? Allow spontaneous vaginal delivery"
"What is the recommended management for a patient at 28 weeks gestation with the fetus in transverse lie position? The patient desires a vaginal delivery. Expectant management"
"Hyperemesis gravidarum is more common in patients with multiple gestation, hydatidiform mole, or history of GERD"
"What is the next step in management for a pregnant woman with a blood glucose > 140 mg/dL 1 hour after a 50g oral glucose load? 100g 3-hour glucose challenge"
"Gestational diabetes is a result of pancreatic β-cell hyperplasia and increased insulin resistance secondary to elevated levels of human placental lactogen during the third trimester of pregnancy"
"Adequate contractions are defined as generation of > 200 Montevideo units (MVUs) in 10 minutes"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a laboring patient with > 6 cm dilation that experiences abnormally slow cervical dilation? Protraction of active labor"
"What is the recommended management for a patient with protraction of active labor? Oxytocin"
"Maternal adaptations to pregnancy include a(n) increased tidal volume and normal respiratory rate"
"What acid-base disturbance is physiological during normal pregnancy? Chronic respiratory alkalosis"
"What is the recommended management for a pregnant woman at 32 weeks gestation with gestational hypertension and a biophysical profile score of 6 at today's visit? Repeat biophysical profile in 24 hours"
"Ovarian cyst rupture is commonly precipitated by strenuous activity or sexual intercourse"
"What is the next step in management for a 45-year-old woman that presents with insomnia, fatigue, weight gain, amenorrhea, and an enlarged uterus? measure hCG level"
"Polycystic ovarian syndrome often presents in young, obese women with oligo- or amenorrhea and symptoms of androgen excess"
"What is the first-line pharmacologic treatment for menstrual irregularity due to polycystic ovarian syndrome? Oral contraceptives"
"Alcohol consumption is a dose-dependent risk factor for breast cancer"
"What cause of vaginitis is characterized by a thin, white discharge with a fishy odor and no vaginal inflammation? Bacterial vaginosis (Gardnerella vaginalis infection)"
"Which cause(s) of vaginitis are associated with an elevated pH (> 4.5)? Bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis"
"Which cause(s) of vaginitis are associated with a normal pH (3.4 - 4.5)? Candida vaginitis"
"What is the recommended treatment for trichomoniasis (Trichomonas infection)? metronidazole for both the patient and the sexual partner"
"What microscopy finding is characteristic of trichomoniasis (Trichomonas infection)? Motile protozoa"
"What cause of vaginitis is characterized by a thick, white discharge and vaginal inflammation? Candida vaginitis (Candida albicans infection)"
"What is the recommended treatment for Candida vaginitis? Oral fluconazole"

"Oral contraceptives are associated with a(n) hyper-coagulable state"
"Acute mastitis is due to bacterial infection of the breast, most commonly with Staphylococcus aureus"
"What is the recommended treatment for an asymptomatic Bartholin duct cyst? Observation - spontaneous drainage and resolution may occur"
"The \three D's\\" of endometriosis are dysmenorrhea"
"Congenital aromatase deficiency in newborn females is characterized by normal internal genitalia and ambiguous external genitalia"
"Aromatase deficiency is associated with polycystic ovaries on ultrasound due to high concentrations of gonadotropins"
"The diagnosis of a palpable breast mass can only be confirmed with a(n) biopsy"
"What kidney injury is classically associated with sickle cell trait? Renal papillary necrosis"
"Fecal retention (constipation) in infants can cause what urologic complication? Recurrent cystitis (UTIs)"
"BRCA mutations result in significantly increased risk of breast and ovarian cancer"
"BRCA-positive individuals are recommended to have a(n) prophylactic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy to decrease incidence of ovarian cancer"
"What is the most common neurologic sequelae of meningitis? Hearing loss All children with bacterial meningitis should have close developmental f/u and audiologic testing"

"What is the next step in management for a young woman that presents with diffuse periumbilical abdominal pain that then localizes to the right lower quadrant? Her LMP was one month ago. Pregnancy test"
"Rapid Diagnosis Tight anal sphincter with explosive release of stools and air upon removal of finger Hirschsprung Disease (\squirt sign\\")\""
"Potential complications of cervical conization include cervical stenosis, cervical incontinence, and preterm delivery"
"Just prior to ovulation, cervical mucus increases in quantity and becomes more watery and penetrable by sperm"
"Pap testing may be discontinued in patients age ≥ 65 with no history of CIN 2 or higher and 3 consective negative Pap tests or 2 consecutive negative co-testing results"
"If a patient has a history of CIN 2 or higher, Pap testing should continue for another 20 years after detection"
"Pap smears without HPV co-testing are repeated every 3 years beginning at age 21"
"Pap smears with HPV co-testing are repeated every 5 years beginning at age 30"
"Antibiotic therapy for hospitalized patients with pelvic inflammatory disease includes IV cefoxitin or cefotetan plus oral doxycycline"
"Outpatient antibiotic therapy for patients with pelvic inflammatory disease includes IM ceftriaxone plus oral doxycycline"
"Daughters of women exposed to diethylstilbestrol (DES) during pregnancy are at increased risk of developing clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina and cervix"

"Lack of menses is considered normal at age < 15 if development of secondary sex characteristics has been appropriate"
"What is typically the first sign of puberty in girls? Breast development (thelarche)"
"What is the next step in management for a 14-year-old girl that presents with lack of menses? Breast and pubic hair are tanner stage 3. Reassurance and re-evaluation"
"Candida vaginitis is more common in patients with recent corticosteroid or antibiotic use"
"Which genital infection is characterized by tender, large ulcers with a grayish exudate and severe lymphadenopathy? Haemophilus ducreyi (chancroid)"

"What is the likely diagnosis in an afebrile middle-aged woman that presents with unilateral breast warmth, erythema, and swelling refractory to antibiotics? Inflammatory breast carcinoma"
"Menopausal women with vasomotor symptoms and contraindications to HRT are typically managed with non-hormonal therapy, such as SSRIs"

"Infertility in patients age < 35 is defined as the failure to achieve pregnancy after 12 months of regular, unprotected sexual intercourse"
"What is the most accurate way to determine estimated gestational age? ultrasound crown-rump measurement in the first trimester"
"What is the definitive treatment for endometriosis? Hysterectomy and oophorectomy"

"The pathogenesis of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism involves loss of pulsatile GnRH secretion"
"How does bone density change in patients with hypothalamic amenorrhea? Decreased (e.g. osteopenia)"
"Primary genital herpes is associated with high risk for recurrence, with less frequent recurrences over time in immunocompetent individuals"
"What is the most common gynecologic malignancy in the U.S? Endometrial cancer"
"What is the recommended treatment for endometrial carcinoma? Hysterectomy +/- chemo- or radiation therapy"
"The risk of endometrial hyperplasia/cancer is directly related to unopposed estrogen exposure"
"One risk factor for endometrial cancer is obesity due to increased peripheral conversion of androgens into estrone"

"Patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome have increased risk of endometrial carcinoma"

Iron toxicity 2/2 prenatal vitamin ingestion; tx with deferoxamine (iron chelator)Clinical features: Abdominal pain/gastroenteritis, shock, vomiting, metabolic acidosis"

"Pulmonic stenosis is associated with widened splitting of the S2 heart sound, especially during inspiration"
"Inability to lift the skin on the dorsum of the second toe is highly specific for lymphedema"

"Peripheral cyanosis typically involves the distal extremies and is caused by increased O2 extraction due to sluggish blood flow"
"What is the most effective intervention to slow progression of diabetic nephropathy? Tight blood pressure control"

"Does acute myeloid leukemia typically present with lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly? No (rare)"
"No chest rise during administration of PPV to a neonate, next step? Intubation"
"APGAR scores recorded when? Acceptable range of scores? 1 minute, then 5 and 10 minutes → Continued if needed Acceptable between 7-10/10"
"Probable underlying etiology of heart rate < 100 in a neonate? < 60? Treatments for both? Pulse 60-100: Likely respiratory → positive pressure ventilation (PPV) Pulse < 60: Likely cardiac → CPR (3:1 ratio; give epi)"
"Treatment for neonate with acceptable heart rate (>100), but oxygen saturation below goal? Increasd FiO2 (blow-by)"
"CPR ratio in neonates? 3:1 ratio of chest compressions:breaths"
"How is epinephrine administered in neonatal CPR? Catheterization of the umbilical vein"

"What is seen for activity in the APGAR score? 0: No activity 1: Flexion 2: Resist extension"

"Mild cognitive impairment is differentiated from normal aging by modest decline in cognitive function with a MoCA score < 26/30"

"What is the cause of anemia in renal failure? ↓ EPO"

"Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis typically occurs in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis"
"What is the most common etiology of persistent nasal obstruction during early childhood? Adenoid hypertrophy"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a child with recent acute otitis media that presents with fever, otalgia, and displacement of the ear? Mastoiditis"
"What is the next step for a child that presents with symptoms concerning for acute mastoiditis? Empiric IV antibiotic therapy + drainage of purulent material"
"A calcium-phosphorus product > 55 increases the risk of soft tissue calcification"
"Favorable prognostic factors in schizophrenia include acute::acute/gradual onset, identifiable precipitant, older age at onset, and predominantly positive psychotic symptoms"
"Retained placenta is defined as failure of the placenta to deliver within 30 minutes of delivery"
"What chemotherapeutic agent(s) are associated with heart failure with myocardial stunning without necrosis? Trastuzumab"
"Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, especially when severe, is associated with weight loss"
"Pseudoaneurysm is a local vascular complication of cardiac catheterization characterized by a(n) systolic bruit and painful, bulging, pulsatile mass"
"Arteriovenous fistula is a local vascular complication of cardiac catheterization characterized by a(n) continuous bruit and no mass"
"What is the next step in management for a postmenopausal woman that presents with a newly-discovered breast mass? Mammogram 6 months ago was negative. Mammogram"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with a morbilliform rash and eosinophilia 8 weeks after starting allopurinol? DRESS syndrome"
"DRESS syndrome is most commonly precipitated by allopurinol and antiepileptics (e.g. phenytoin, carbamazepine)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly male that presents with abdominal distention and constipation five days after having surgery? His last bowel movement was 3 days ago. Imaging reveals colonic dilation without evidence of anatomic obstruction. Colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie syndrome)"
"What is the greatest risk factor for development of head and neck cancer? Tobacco use"
"Septic arthritis in children most commonly results from hematogenous spread"
"What is the recommended treatment for a patient with symptoms of hyperviscosity secondary to Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia? Urgent plasma exchange"
"Paraphimosis refers to retraction and entrapment of the prepuce in an uncircumcised male"
"What is the first-line treatment for genital warts during pregnancy? Topical trichloroacetic acid"
"The diagnosis of tinea corporis is confirmed with KOH preparation of skin scrapings demonstrating segmented hyphae"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with poorly controlled HIV that presents with mild odynophagia/dysphagia? Empiric fluconazole"
"Which serotonin receptor is antagonized by many atypical antipsychotics? 5-HT2A"
"Patients with borderline personality disorder often have a history of childhood trauma (physical, sexual, emotional abuse)"
"What antibiotic should be started for patients with a first recurrence of C. difficile colitis? Oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin"
"Which congenital infection is associated with seizure and temporal lobe hemorrhage without evidence of intracranial calcifications? Herpes simplex virus"
"What is the recommended treatment for an neonate with suspected HSV infection? Empiric acyclovir"
"What is the recommended treatment for a child with intermittent sleep terrors? Reassurance"
"What is the most reliable sign for vertebral osteomyelitis? Tenderness to percussion over the spinous process of the involved vertebrae"
"What is the preferred diagnostic test for Babesiosis? Peripheral blood smear (\Maltese cross\\")\""
"Intrapartum penicillin is indicated without routine screening in pregnant women with a history of GBS bacteruria or UTI during current pregnancy or those with a prior delivery complicated by neonatal GBS infection"
"Lacunar stroke of the posterolateral thalamus results in sudden-onset contralateral loss involving all sensory modalities (pure sensory stroke)"
"What is the next step in management for a patient found to have positive HCV antibodies? HCV RNA testing"
"Pretest probability of coronary artery disease is high in patients with typical angina > age 40 (men) or 60 (women)"
"Pretest probability of coronary artery disease is intermediate in men with atypical angina (all ages)"
"Pretest probability of coronary artery disease is intermediate in women with atypical angina > age 50 or typical angina age 30 - 50"
"The Parkland formula is an estimate of the total fluid requirement in the first 24 hours for burn victims and is calculated as total fluids = 4 mL * TBSA% x body weight (kg)"
"The most common causes of post-operative fever may be remembered with the \5 W's\\": POD 2-3: Wind (atelectasis) POD 3-5: Water (UTI) POD 5+: Walking (DVT/PE) POD 7: Wound infection POD 8-15: Wonder drugs (drug fever)\""
"What is the most effective nonpharmacological treatment for Tourette's syndrome? Habit reversal training (a form of CBT)"
"What is the recommended treatment for type I renal tubular acidosis? Oral bicarbonate replacement"
"Multiple myeloma is associated with an elevated protein gap (> 4 g/dL)"
"What is the recommended treatment for dissociative identity disorder? Trauma-focused psychotherapy"
"What is the treatment of choice for chronic insomnia? Cognitive behavioral therapy"
"What is the recommended treatment for seasonal affective disorder? Bright light therapy +/- an antidepressant"
"What is the next step in management for that began with SSRI therapy for anxiety that developed worsening anxiety and insomnia? Decrease the SSRI dose"
"Treatment for hoarding disorder? CBT (→ trial of SSRI if CBT fails, off-label use)"
"What is the most likely explanation for a patient who stopped taking his fluoxetine and lorazepam after 2 years and is now anxious and irritable and complains of insomnia, dysphoria, and anxiety? Benzodiazepine withdrawal"
"What is the first-line treatment for anti-psychotic treatment in patients with schizophrenia? Atypical antipsychotics (olanzapine, resperidone, quetiapine)"
"A history of childhood trauma (physical, sexual, emotional abuse) is common in patients with borderline personality disorder"
"What is the treatment of choice in a psychotic patient with previous adverse reactions to haloperidol and a past medical history of diabetes and seasonal allergies? Ziprasidone or Aripiprazole (second-generation with low metabolic risk profile)"
"A patient with a recent hospitalization 1 month ago for a depressive episode with suicidal ideation develops a maculopapular rash over the patient’s left scapula. During that hospitalization, his episode remitted and a new medication regimen was initiated. What medication is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition? Lamotrigine"
"Opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia is a paraneoplastic syndrome seen in neuroblastoma involving rapid and multi-directional eye movements, rhythmic jerks of the limbs, and ataxia"
"Do patients remember their dreams in REM sleep behavior disorder? Yes"
"What is the most likely disorder in an older patient who is constantly moving in his sleep as if acting out his dreams? The patient remembers his dreams and becomes fully alert upon wakening after a transient confusion. REM sleep behavior disorder"
"What anxiety disorder is characterized by anxiety restricted to social and performance situations, fear of scrutiny, and embarrassment? Social anxiety disorder (social phobia)"
"Which anxiety disorder is characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks? Panic disorder"
"Which anxiety disorder is characterized by chronic multiple worries, anxiety, and muscular tension? Generalized anxiety disorder"
"Antidepressants need to be tapered over 6-8 weeks to avoid antidepressant discontinuation syndrome, which may produce flu-like symptoms, headache, nausea, insomnia, and myalgias"
"Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by excessive anxiety and preoccupation with >1 unexplained symptoms"
"Does illness anxiety disorder often have symptoms? No (key differentiating feature from somatic symptom disorder)"
"What is the treatment of choice in an acute mania patient with psychotic symptoms? Antipsychotics (1st and 2nd generation)"
"What is the treatment of choice in a patient with depression and auditory hallucinations, as well as a marked weight loss and refusal to eat? Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)"
"Advanced sleep phase disorder is a circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorder in which the sleep-wake cycle begins and ends earlier than normal Treatment includes phototherapy in the evening"
"What type of defense is seen with someone who is extremely nice to foreigners although the person is xenophobic? Reaction formation"
"Long-acting benzodiazepines such as diazepam and chlordiazepoxide can be used to treat alcohol withdrawal. What is the choice in a patient with hepatic disease (e.g. chronic alcoholic) or in inpatient setting? Lorazepam*"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient who recently lost her husband and reports hearing him call her name? She also reports a loss of interest in activities, guilt over her husbands death, trouble sleeping, and loss of appetite. Major depressive disorder"
"Dialysis is indicated in the treatment of lithium toxicity in patients with levels above >4.0, altered mental status, or life-threatening arrhythmias"
"What is the next best step in management in a patient who has had difficulty sleeping, had weight loss, and trouble concentrating throughout the day? She reports frequent thoughts of suicide. Perform a suicide risk assessment"
"Which antipsychotic extrapyramidal effect is characterized by a subjective restlessness and inability to sit still and what are the treatments available? Akathisia → BB, benzo, or benztropine"
"What is the most likely explanation for hallucinations in a young boy with fever, runny nose, and a cough who appears to be talking to someone in the room and says he can see his old cat? The parents have tried OTC cough and cold medications for the past 36 hours. Labs are significant for fever of 101 F. Medication side effect due to antihistamines"
"What is the next step in management for a patient with suspected anorexia nervosa that presents with stable vital signs, BMI 17.5, and a normal electrolyte panel? Nutritional rehabilitation and psychotherapy (CBT)"
"What is the most likely diagnosis in a patient who has delusions/hallucinations five days after being treated for a severe asthma exacerbation? He remains alert and cognitively intact. Glucocorticoid-induced psychosis"
"What is the treatment in a patient with recurrent major depressive episodes with the onset in the fall and remission in the spring? Antidepressants and bright-light therapy"
"Anorexia Nervosa is associated with osteopenia::musculoskeletal, leading to an increased risk of bone fractures"
"Naltrexone = prevent relapse in opioid use disorder but only in absence of acute withdrawal symptoms Methadone or Suboxone (Buprenorphine & Naloxone) = treat opioid withdrawal Naloxone = treat opioid overdose"
"What is the strongest predisposing risk factor for bipolar disorder? Genetic predisposition"
"There will be decreased::increased/decreased 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) in CSF analysis in patients with major depressive disorder"
"Benzodiazepine overdose leads to CNS depression, causing lethargy, somnolence, and hypo-reflexia"
"What is the treatment of delirium tremens? IV benzodiazepines (Lorazepam)"
"What are the CNS side effects of β-blockers (propranolol)? Drowsiness, fatigue/lethargy, depression::3"
"Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by features of schizophrenia and major mood disorder (depression or bipolar disorder)"
"Rapid Diagnosis A patient has persecutory delusions and hallucinations for the past 3 years. 6 months ago he started having sadness, guilt, insomnia, decreased concentration, and sleep issues. Schizoaffective disorder"
"What is the choice in pharmacotherapy for a patient with specific phobia who refuses CBT or if CBT is not available? Benzodiazepines (i.e. lorazepam)"
"What is the time frame required to diagnose somatic symptom and illness anxiety disorder? 6 months"
"What is the most likely diagnosis in a mother who has trouble sleeping, concentrating, fatigue, guilt about being a bad mother, and a loss of interest in activities? The symptoms began 6 weeks after the birth of her 9-month old child. Major depressive disorder"
"Neonatal herpes simplex virus can cause hemorrhage and edema in the temporal lobe"
"Colicky pain w/o fever and leukocytosis = obstruction::cause of visceral pain"
"Inflammatory pain presents as constant and localized and fever/leukocytosis"
"Sudden onset abdominal pain and patient is motionless = perforation::cause of pain"
"Sudden onset pain with pain out of proportion (POOP) +/- bloody stool = ischemic::cause of pain"
"Generally, pathology of the RUQ is confirmed via ultrasound::imaging modality"
"Free air under the diaphagram on upright chest X-ray indicates perforation of the bowel::cause"

"What test is used to establish the diagnosis of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis? Paracentesis"
"What imaging modalities are preferred for detecting kidney stones? Abdominal CT scan w/o contrast (preferred) Ultrasound::2"
"A child with a history of uncontrolled seizures should not receive which vaccine(s)? Pertussis"
"When should solid foods be initiated in infants? 6 months with continued breast/formula feeding"
"A young patient presents with progressive weakness in the lower limbs. She has a history of scoliosis and high plantar arches. Strength is 2/5 in the lower limbs and 5/5 in the upper limbs. Decreased vibratory and position sense is noted in the lower extremities. MRI shows cervical spinal cord atrophy. What is the best diagnostic test? Genetic testing (frataxin gene)"
"Gunshot wounds below the nipple (T4) = ex lap (surgery)"
"Penetrating trauma to abdomen and peritoneal signs / evisceration / unstable is managed with ex lap::next step Penetrating trauma to abdomen and superficial (non-peritoneal) signs is managed with digital inspection (see if peritoneum penetrated) - NO surgery::next step and CT scan"
"What is used to assess for intraperitoneal hemorrhage in an alert, hemodynamically stable patient with blunt abdominal trauma? Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST)"
"What structure is contained within the hepatoduodenal ligament? What does the Pringle maneuver do? Portal triad (proper hepatic artery, portal vein, common bile duct); clamp ligament to control bleeding"
"Signs of posterior urethral::anterior urethral/posterior urethral injury include blood at the urethral meatus and a high-riding prostate"
"Pelvic fracture, hemodynamically stable and bleed = external::external/internal fixation + no surgery"
"Hip rocking producing crepitus, pain, and mobility = pelvic fracture"
"Rectal injury in pelvic fracture. Next step? Proctoscope"
"What are the ABCs in trauma assessment? Airway, Breathing, Circulation"
"Maintain airway and no facial trauma is managed with endotracheal tube::treatment"
"Maintain airway and significant facial trauma is managed with cricothyrotomy::treatment"
"ABCs: Oxygenation::Oxygenation/Ventilation is influenced by FiO2 and PEEP Ventilation is influenced by TV * RR"
"How is endotracheal tube placement confirmed? End-tidal CO2"
"Shock is defined as systolic BP < 90 or urine output < 0.5 mL/kg/hr"
"Hemorrhagic shock is treated with fluids → blood"
"What blunt chest trauma complication presents with a triad of hypotension, distended neck veins, and distant heart sounds? Cardiac tamponade (\Beck's triad\\")\""
"What is the recommended treatment for a hemodynamically unstable patient with cardiac tamponade? Emergency pericardiocentesis"
"Treatment of cardiogenic shock? Administer inotropes"
"penetrating trauma, distended neck veins, reduced lung sounds, hyperresonance and trachea contralateral deviation is tension pneumothorax::condition"
"Treatment of tension pneumothorax is needle decompression → thoracostomy (chest tube)"
"Neurogenic shock = generalized vasodilation due to spinal trauma and low CO"
"Treatment of neurogenic shock? Fluid and pressors"
"How is septic shock treated? IV fluids (first-line), vasopressors (dopamine) and antibiotics"
"Secondary spontaneous pneumothorax may be due to mechanical ventilation with use of high pressures"
"\Tearing\\" chest pain that radiates to the back and unequal radial pulses is suggestive of aortic dissection::condition\""
"Will hemoglobin change in trauma patients who are bleeding and are hypotensive before giving fluids? No"
"What is the next step in management for a patient that needs emergency fluid resuscitation and peripheral IV access cannot be obtained? Attempt intraosseous access"
"Is there pulmonary edema in cardiac tamponade? No"
"Head trauma = CT::imaging"
"Basilar Skull Fracture::head injury; must check the cervical spine with CT scan"
"Top: Epidural hematoma Middle: Subdural hematoma Bottom: Subarachnoid hemorrhage"
"Which type of cranial hematoma involves a fixed dilated pupil and contralateral hemiparesis? Acute Epidural Hematoma"
"Subdural hematoma occurs due to tearing of bridging veins::vasculature"
"What brain injury typically occurs from traumatic acceleration/deceleration shearing forces? Diffuse axonal injury"
"Loss of consciousness following head injury and retrograde amnesia Concussion::injury, observe for neurologic signs and assess bleeding with CT scan::imaging"
"In addition to CT imaging, acute subdural hematoma should include management of intracranial pressure"
"Mild trauma in elderly and gradual deterioration in mental function = chronic subdural hematoma"
"What is the treatment for acute pericarditis? NSAIDs and Colchicine"
"How do you treat mitral regurgitation? Valve replacement"
"During assessment of neck trauma, if anyone has these signs, what should you do? Surgery"
"Trauma to the spinal cord is assessed via MRI::imaging and treated via high dose steroids"
"Brown-Sequard syndrome"
"What neurological pathology presents with pain/temperature loss and muscle weakness in the upper extremities? Syringomyelia"
"Imaging technique for evaluating neck trauma? CT angiography (evaluate vessels)"
"If there are no soft or hard signs in a penetrating neck injury, what do you do? Observe"
"Treatment of pneumothorax is thoracostomy (chest tube to drain air)"
"Chest tube and surgical exploration (thoracotomy)::treatment is required to treat hemothorax if chest tube produces > 1500 mL of blood on insertion or 200 mL/hr"
"How does the flail chest segment move with inspiration? Moves inward (paradoxical chest wall motion)"
"What trauma pathology occurs when > 3 continuous ribs are fractured in > 2 places? Flail chest"
"What are the most important early steps for managing flail chest? (2) Pain control Supplemental O2"
"What is used to manage respiratory failure secondary to flail chest? Mechanical positive pressure ventilation (PPV)"
"What blunt chest trauma complication is characterized by unilateral decreased breath sounds and patchy, irregular alveolar infiltrate on imaging < 24 hours after the injury? Pulmonary contusion"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a hemodynamically unstable patient that presents following a motor vehicle accident with an elevated PCWP that worsens after administration of IV fluids? Myocardial contusion"
"Widened mediastinum on X-ray after deceleration injury; diagnosis and imaging? Dissection of aorta; CT angio"
"What is the most essential part of management for an uncomplicated rib fracture (e.g. no hypotension, pneumothorax, etc.)? Pain control (nerve block)"
"What is the underlying cause of hemorrhagic shock in a patient with decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation, and dullness to percussion? Hemothorax"
"A(n) sucking::type chest wound involves a flap that sucks air in upon inspiration but closes during expiration"
"Alkaline::Acidic/Alkaline burns are worse"
"Chemical burns of the skin is managed with irrigation::treatment"
"Respiratory burn patients should have their airway assessed for edema/soot with bronchoscope::instrument and intubation::treatment due to risk of airway closure"
"People who have electrical burns are at risk of arrhythmias, posterior shoulder dislocation, and demyelination"
"Electrical burns can cause myoglobinuria, so one should check a serum CK level"
"Circumferential, full-thickness burns can result in eschar formation that restricts venous/lymphatic drainage, leading to acute compartment syndrome"
"1st degree burn = epidermis intact"
"(+) Pain, (+) blister and partial thickness burn = 2nd degree burn"
"(-) Pain and white/charred edges and full thickness burn = 3rd degree burn"

"Each arm (back and front) is 9% surface area Each leg (back and front) is 18% surface area"
"Fomepizole is used as an antidote for methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a homeless patient that presents with confusion, epigastric pain, and blurred vision? Laboratory studies reveal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Methanol poisoning"
"Ethylene glycol damages the kidney::organ, showing calcium oxalate stones with Wood's lamp"
"Acetaminophen toxicity results from overproduction of the toxic metabolite NAPQI, which leads to hepatic necrosis; treated with N-acetylcysteine and activated charcoal"
"What is the likely ingested agent in a patient who overdosed and presents with fever, tinnitus, and tachypnea? Aspirin"
"Early aspirin intoxication = pure respiratory alkalosis Later aspirin intoxication (> 12 hours) = mixed respiratory alkalosis and metabolic acidosis"
"What is the recommended treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning? 100% O2 or hyperbaric O2"
"Antidotes for cyanide poisoning include hydroxycobalamin (preferred) or sodium thiosulfate; alternatively nitrites may be used to induce methemoglobinemia"
"What acid-base disturbance is associated with cyanide poisoning? Metabolic acidosis"
"What is the likely cause of acute renal failure in a patient with high anion, osmolal gap metabolic acidosis, and calcium oxalate crystals on urinalysis? Ethylene glycol poisoning"
"Nitroprusside is associated with cyanide poisoning, which may present as lactic acidosis, altered mental status, and seizures"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a farmer that presents to the hospital with agitation, vomiting, and watery eyes? Physical exam reveals 1 mm pupils bilaterally and increased bowel sounds. Organophosphate (acetylcholinesterase inhibitor) poisoning"
"Treatment: Rabies (wild animal, unprovoked) kill + biopsy, if (+) → administer IgG + vaccine"
"What is the antidote for Black Widow spider bites? IV calcium gluconate"
"Brown Recluse is a type of spider whose bite can cause skin ulceration with a(n) necrotic center and surrounding erythema"
"Human / dog bites are treated with Amoxicillin-Clavulanate (Augmentin)::antibiotic blend"
"A(n) Black Widow spider::insect bite can cause pancreatitis"
"Atrial septal defects are usually asymptomatic, but may present with a(n) fixed split S2 on cardiac ausculation, and rarely pulmonary HTN and Eisenmenger syndrome"
"Large ventricular septal defects may present with a harsh, blowing holosystolic murmur with thrill; and can lead to endocarditis, progressive aortic regurgitation, heart failure, pulmonary HTN, and Eisenmenger syndrome"
"Coarctation of the aorta presents with HTN in upper extremities and hypotension in lower extremities; a(n) midsystolic or continuous murmur heard best over the back (interscapular area); and notching of the ribs on CXR. Treat with surgical decompression"
"Surgical ligation of a patent ductus arteriosus is contraindicated when there is severe pulmonary HTN"
"Tetralogy of fallot is characterized by a(n) pulmonary artery stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and VSD"
"Tetralogy of fallot presents with cyanosis::most common symptom, Tet spells, and a(n) crescendo-decrescendo::nature of the murmur murmur at the left upper sternal border::anatomic location. CXR classically shows upturning of the cardiac apex (\boot-shaped heart\\")"
"Following treatment of septic shock with antibiotics and steroid, patient deteriorates rapidly - cause? Adrenal insufficiency"
"Linear skull fractures that are closed (no overlying wound) are left alone::treatment"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with sudden onset flashes of light and floaters in the left eye? The patient felt like \a curtain came down\\" over her eye. Ophthalmoscopy reveals a grayish-appearing retina. Retinal detachment\""
"Treatment of strabismus includes patching or blurring of the normal::normal/affected eye"
"TIA will resolve within 24 hours"
"Headache, systemic symptoms (fever/leukocytosis), history of sinusitis and cranial nerve symptoms (e.g. diplopia) is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis::syndrome"
"Treatment for facial nerve palsy may include corticosteroids if due to a traumatic etiology (edema)"
"Metronidazole can cause a(n) disulfiram-like reaction with alcohol and leave a metallic taste in the mouth"
"Ménière disease typically presents with a triad of tinnitus, episodic vertigo, and sensorineural hearing loss"
"The symptoms of Ménière disease are due to elevated endolymphatic pressure"
"A patient complaining of dizziness that manifests upon head movement states that the sensation lasts for < 1 min. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver yields rotary nystagmus during physical examination. What type of peripheral vertigo is the likely diagnosis?  Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)"
"A persistent chalazion, as shown above, should be biopsied::next step"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with a hard, painless bump on the eyelid? Chalazion"
"First step if symptomatic spinal cord compression? Dexamethasone (steroids)"
"Patients with spinal shock should get a(n) foley catheter to prevent acute urinary retention"
"What is the long-term treatment for hydrocephalus? Ventriculoperitoneal shunting"
"Treatment for single brain met? Resection Treatment for multiple brain mets? Whole brain radiation therapy"
"Symptomatic spinal epidural hematomas require urgent surgical decompression of the spinal canal and evacuation of the hematoma by laminectomy"
"Ipsilateral headache, neck pain, partial horner syndrome (ptosis/miosis) and absent flow in ICA is suggestive of carotid artery dissection"
"Gradual, severe radicular pain, asymmetrical weakness, saddle anesthesia and bowel/bladder dysfunction Cauda equina syndrome"
"The stapedial branches of the facial nerve branch before::before/after the facial nerve exits the skull"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient with a burning sensation around the left eye and decreased vision for the past 5 days? Physical exam is remarkable for a vesicular rash over the forehead and left eye. Dendriform ulcers are seen on the cornea. Herpes zoster ophthalmicus"
"Epidural blood patch is indicated for post-lumbar puncture headache"
"Nausea/vomiting, headache and focal neuro deficits following otitis media is suggestive of brain abscess::diagnosis"
"Subclavian steal syndrome occurs when the subclavian artery is occluded, leading to retrograde flow from the vertebral artery"
"What is the best choice of treatment in a patient with generalized anxiety disorder with erectile dysfunction? Buspirone"
"Upper vs. Lower GI Bleeding: Rule out Upper GI bleed with EGD Rule out Lower GI bleed with Colonoscopy"
"In addition to lifestyle modifications, refractory constipation in a toddler may be managed initially with oral laxative therapy"
"CXR findings consistent with esophageal perforation include left-sided pleural effusion, subcutaneous emphysema, and widened mediastinum"
"Neonate with \double bubble\\" on CXR is duodenal atresia::condition\""
"What is the likely diagnosis in a middle-aged man with fatigue, pruritus, ulcerative colitis, and elevated alkaline phosphatase? Primary sclerosing cholangitis"

"LLQ pain, change in bowel habits and blood in stool is suggestive of diverticulosis::diagnosis"
"Esophageal atresia with TEF typically presents with excessive secretions at the mouth (drooling, choking), coughing spells/vomiting, and vomiting with the first feeding"
"Diagnosis of C. difficile colitis is made by stool assay for toxins or PCR for genes"
"Pyloric stenosis often presents with a palpable \olive-like\\" mass in the epigastric region of the abdomen\""
"Pyloric stenosis typically presents with nonbilious, projectile vomiting (bilious or nonbilious)"
"What IBD or C. Difficile complication presents with colonic dilation with loss of haustration on X-ray and fever, tachycardia, leukocytosis, and/or anemia? Toxic megacolon"
"Bowel-sparing surgical treatment of Crohn's disease is indicated after conservative medical therapy has failed"
"Diagnostic test for inflammatory bowel disease? Colonoscopy"
"Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune disease characterized by destruction of intra-hepatic bile ducts"
"What antibody is characteristically elevated in primary biliary cholangitis? Anti-mitochondrial antibody"
"What pharmaceutical treatment is helpful for delaying the progression of primary biliary cholangitis? Ursodeoxycholic acid"
"What is the next step in management of a patient with diverticulitis complicated by an abscess > 3 cm? CT-guided percutaneous drainage"
"Open surgical repair for complicated::complicated/uncomplicated hernias Laparascopic surgical repair for uncomplicated::complicated/uncomplicated hernias"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a male patient with HIV that presents with a 3-cm anal ulcer and firm, non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy? Anal cancer"
"What is the surgical management for anal SCC? Nigro chemoradiation protocol and excision of residual tumor::specific"
"Hematocrit::Lab value assesses the severity of pancreatitis and can increase with third spacing"
"Meckel diverticulum is diagnosed using a(n) technetium-99m pertechnetate study for uptake by ectopic gastric mucosa"
"Esophageal ring at GE junction is also known as Schatzki's ring::condition"
"What is the treatment for Schatzki's ring? Mechanical dilatation"
"Barrett's esophagus with dysplasia is managed with endoscopic mucosal resection::treatment"
"What is the most common type of inguinal hernia? Indirect"
"Enterocutaneous fistula may occur as a complication of abdominal surgery, presenting with viscous, dark green \substance\\" draining some time after surgery\""
"What is the likely diagnosis for a solid liver mass in a young woman on oral contraceptives? Hepatic adenoma"
"Are hepatic adenomas typically benign or malignant? Benign"
"Is needle biopsy recommended for a patient with a hepatic adenoma? No (due to risk of bleeding)"
"Treatment of a small perforation of esophagus (Boerhaave) is conservative therapy (antibiotics, NPO))"
"What pharmaceutical therapy is recommended for prophylaxis of non-bleeding esophageal varices? Non-selective β-blockers (e.g. propranolol, nadolol)"
"What is the recommended treatment for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis? Broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g. cefotaxime)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient status-post Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery who presents with abdominal bloating, diarrhea, and macrocytic anemia? Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth"
"Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth may be diagnosed via carbohydrate (lactulose) breath testing or jejunal aspirate/culture"
"GI bleeding and hemodynamic instability =  angiography::next best step to localize and embolize"
"What test/imaging study is used to diagnose esophageal cancer? Endoscopy with biopsy"
"Which form of inflammatory bowel disease is characterized by transmural inflammation and non-caseating granulomas on biopsy? Crohn disease"
"What is the treatment for gallstone ileus? Surgical removal of stone and cholecystectomy"
"Gallstone ileus occurs secondary to cholecystitis with fistula formation between the gallbladder and small bowel"
"What imaging test can confirm the diagnosis of ischemic colitis after a CT scan has been obtained? Colonoscopy"
"Intraabdominal bleeding - imaging? Stable patient = CT scan Unstable patient = FAST"
"What imaging modality is used to confirm a diagnosis of duodenal hematoma? Abdominal CT"
"What is the colonoscopy screening recommendation for patients with Lynch syndrome (HNPCC)? Begin at age 20-25; repeat every 1-2 years"
"First line feeding is oral::route feeding"
"Abdominal compartment syndrome is managed with a(n) temporary cover of abdominal contents"
"Prolonged post-operative ileus is characterized by hypo::hypo/hyper-active bowel sounds"
"Uniform distribution of gas = paralytic ileus::bowel obstruction or ileus"
"Post-abdominal surgery, absent bowel sounds, no passage of gas and distended abdomen and no pain. What is most likely occurring? Paralytic ileus"
"Malrotation with volvulus is managed with detorsion/decompression::surgical treatment"
"Mild ulcerative colitis, <4 stools/day (occasionally bloody): 5-ASA derivatives (mesalamine)::treatment Moderate UC, >4 stools/day: Mesalamine and Steroid::treatment"
"FAP and marked increase in polyps since the last screening or detection of an adenoma with high-grade dysplasia is managed with proctocolectomy::next step"
"Initial management of mild necrotizing enterocolitis includes supportive care and initiation of broad-spectrum IV antibiotics due to risk of septic shock"

"Antibiotic for tetanus = metronidazole"
"All adolescents should get at least one dose of Tdap; then Tdap or Td can be given as a booster q10 years (at least three total lifetime doses)"
"When presented with a wound, consideration for tetanus vaccination begins with determining whether three lifetime doses have been given or not."
"If someone with a wound has had <3 lifetime doses of tetanus vaccine, the next question is whether the wound is clean or dirty"
"3+ lifetime doses, clean wound, 10+ years since booster 3+ lifetime doses, dirty wound, 5+ years since booster TDAP::next step"
"<3 lifetime doses of the tetanus vaccine and dirty wound is managed with TDAP and TIG (tetanus IVIg)::next step"
"3 lifetime tetanus doses and: - clean wound with last booster within 10 years, or - dirty wound with last booster within 5 years No Tdap needed → discharge::next step"

"Gastroschisis::Omphalocele/Gastroschisis is a right of midline defect without a membrane and is more susceptible to twisting and infection"
"Is gastroschisis or omphalocele associated with more health concerns? Which one most commonly? Omphalocele; Beckwith Wiedemann"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an infant that presents with macrosomia, macroglossia, umbilical hernia, hemihyperplasia, and hypoglycemia? Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a newborn that presents with an enlarged tongue, umbilical hernia, and jaundice with high TSH and low free T4? Congenital hypothyroidism"
"Do umbilical hernias typically require surgical intervention? No (most close spontaneously before age 5)"
"Prior to pyloromyotomy, patients with pyloric stenosis should receive IV hydration and electrolytes to decrease the risk of post-operative apnea"
"Double bubble sign, no distal air and Down's syndrome is suggestive of duodenal atresia::annular pancreas/duodenal atresia Double bubble sign, no distal air and NO Down's syndrome is suggestive of annular pancreas::annular pancreas/duodenal atresia"
"Midgut volvulus is a surgical emergency that classically presents in a neonate with congenital malrotation, manifesting as bilious vomiting and abdominal distention."
"What is the next step in management for a newborn with bilious emesis and dilated loops of bowel on X-ray? Contrast enema"
"What cause of bilious vomiting is characterized by meconium obstructing the rectosigmoid colon with a transition zone visualized on X-ray? Hirschsprung disease"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a preterm newborn that presents with feeding intolerance, abdominal distention, bloody stools, lethargy, and the X-ray below? Necrotizing enterocolitis"

"Do patients with cryptorchidism repaired before 1 year of age (e.g. orchiopexy) have an increased risk of testicular cancer? Yes"
"Do you circumcise pts with either hypospadias or epispadias? No"

"17-hydroxyprogesterone::Compound? = elevated in 21-hydroxylase deficiency (the most common CAH)"
"Treatment of congenital adrenal hyperplasia is low dose exogenous corticosteroids (replacement therapy)"
"What is the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction in newborn boys? Posterior urethral valves"
"Why is gestational diabetes a risk factor for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS)? Increased insulin prevents surfactant synthesis and lung maturation by interfering with cortisol"
"Maternal gestational diabetes → ↑ risk of neonatal polycythemia::hematological disorder"
"Baby < 28 days and fever >100.4 = sepsis until proven otherwise"

"Which type of psychotherapy focuses on resolving unconscious conflicts by bringing repressed experiences and feelings into awareness and integrating them into the patient’s conscious experience? Psychoanalysis"
"Psychodynamic psychotherapy focuses on the role of unconscious conflict and gaining insight into how past experience shapes present situations"

"Biofeedback psychotherapy involves using signals from the body (e.g. heart rate, muscle tension, skin temperature, blood pressure) as indicators of emotional distress, which can give patients control over physiological reactions"
"Which type of psychotherapy seeks to correct faulty assumptions and negative feelings that exacerbate psychiatric symptoms? Cognitive therapy"

"What is the likely diagnosis in an obese, multiparous pregnant woman at 34 weeks gestation that presents with intermittent leakage of clear fluid and a negative nitrazine/fern test? Stress urinary incontinence"

"What is the next step in management after IV lines have been placed in a woman with uterine inversion with a retained placenta? Manual replacement of the uterus"
"What is the next step in management after manual replacement of the uterus in a woman with uterine inversion with a retained placenta? Placental removal and uterotonics"
"Postpartum urinary retention is typically related to bladder atony"
"Amphetamine abuse during pregnancy is associated with fetal growth restriction::size"
"Patients in preterm labor at < 37 weeks should receive corticosteroids to reduce risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a pregnant woman at 10 weeks gestation that presents with hyperemesis gravidarum? Pelvic ultrasound reveals an intrauterine gestation enlarged for gestational age and bilateral 10-cm, multilocular ovarian masses. Theca lutein cysts (secondary to a complete hydatidiform mole)"
"Theca-lutein cysts arise due to ovarian hyperstimulation secondary to markedly elevated β-hCG levels"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a sexually active woman that presents with postcoital bleeding and mucopurulent discharge with a friable cervix on pelvic examination? Acute cervicitis"
"What are the most common causes of acute cervicitis? Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection"
"What is the recommended treatment for acute cervicitis? Azithromycin Ceftriaxone"
"Newly detectable β-hCG levels within 6 months following suction curettage for a hydatidiform mole is diagnostic for gestational trophoblastic disease (e.g. choriocarcinoma)"
"During the surveillance period following removal of a hydatidiform mole, patients must take contraceptives for 6 months"
"What is the underlying cause of early decelerations on fetal heart tracing? Fetal head compression"
"Severe fetal anemia typically presents with a(n) sinusoidal fetal heart tracing"
"What are the first-line agents for maternal hypertensive crisis? (3) Nifedipine Hydralazine Labetalol"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a pregnant patient that develops encephalopathy, nystagmus, and gait ataxia after several days of hyperemesis gravidum? Wernicke encephalopathy"
"Antenatally diagnosed placenta accreta is delivered by planned cesarean hysterectomy"
"Fetal growth restriction is an ultrasound-estimated fetal weight < 10th percentile for gestational age"
"Symmetric::Symmetric/Asymmetric fetal growth restriction begins in the first trimester and is typically caused by chromosomal abnormalities or intrauterine infection (TORCH)"
"Chronic hypertension is a blood pressure > 140/90 mmHg before the 20th week of gestation"
"Fetal complications of maternal hypertension include oligohydramnios, preterm delivery, and fetal growth restriction::size"
"What is the recommended treatment for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis? Anticoagulation and broad-spectrum antibiotics"
"Initial treatment of postpartum hemorrhage includes bimanual massage and uterotonics (e.g. oxytocin)"
"The diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy is made by a pregnancy test combined with transvaginal ultrasound"
"What is the most common site of implantation for ectopic pregnancy? Fallopian tube (ampulla)"
"Examination findings consistent with uterine rupture include the presence of abdominally palpable fetal parts and/or the loss of fetal station"
"Which TORCH infection(s) are routinely screened for in pregnant women during their first prenatal visit? Syphilis Rubella"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an afebrile postpartum woman that presents with bilateral, symmetric warmth and tenderness of the breasts 3 days after delivery? Breast engorgement"
"Lochia refers to normal vaginal discharge containing blood and/or mucus in the postpartum period"
"What is the first step in evaluating risk of preterm delivery in a patient with a history of cervical surgery (e.g. cold knife conization)? Transvaginal ultrasound measurement of cervical length in the 2nd trimester"
"What is the recommended management for a pregnant patient with no history of preterm labor and a short cervix (≤ 2 cm) on TVUS? Vaginal progesterone"
"What is the recommended management for a pregnant patient with history of preterm labor and a short cervix (≤ 2.5 cm) on TVUS? IM progesterone and cerclage With serial cervical length measurements until 24 weeks"
"What is the recommended management for a pregnant patient with history of preterm labor and a normal cervix (> 2.5 cm) on TVUS? IM progesterone with serial cervical length measurements until 24 weeks"
"What is the most common cause of a non-reactive non-stress test? Fetal sleep cycle"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a pregnant patient that presents with painless third-trimester bleeding with a normal fetal heart tracing? Placenta previa"
"What is the recommended management for a pregnant woman at 37 weeks gestation that presents with placenta previa? Cesarean delivery"
"Chorionic villus sampling may be performed between 10 to 13 weeks"
"Complications of inadequate weight gain during pregnancy include fetal growth restriction and preterm delivery"
"What is the recommended management for a hemodynamically unstable patient with an inevitable abortion? Suction curettage"
"Can a reactive non-stress test effectively rule out fetal acidemia? Yes"
"Magnesium is solely excreted by the kidneys"
"What is the likely diagnosis in an afebrile patient that recently delivered a macrosomic baby and now presents with sharp lower midline abdominal pain that radiates to the legs and is exacerbated by ambulation? Pubic symphysis diastasis"
"What is the recommended treatment for symptomatic postpartum pubic symphysis diastasis? Supportive (e.g. NSAIDs, physical therapy)"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a pregnant woman at 35 weeks gestation that experiences irregular, mildly painful uterine contractions (~3-5 per hour) with a closed cervix on pelvic examination? False labor"
"What is the recommended management for patients that present in false labor (i.e. Braxton-Hicks)? Expectant management"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a pregnant woman with preeclampsia that develops sudden-onset dyspnea, hypoxia, and crackles? Pulmonary edema"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents one week after an elective abortion with fever, vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge? Pelvic ultrasound reveals a thickened endometrial stripe. Septic abortion"
"Normal postpartum changes include shivering, lochia, and a(n) contracted::relaxed/contracted uterus"
"Late- and post-term pregnancies require antenatal fetal surveillance beginning at 41 weeks with a(n) biophysical profile to screen for fetal hypoxia"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a newborn with thin, loose skin, a thin umbilical cord, and a wide anterior fontanel? Fetal growth restriction"
"Patients with placenta previa should be advised to avoid sexual intercourse"

"Complications of oxytocin include hypo-natremia, hypo-tension, and uterine tachysystole"

"Polyhydramnios is characterized by an amniotic fluid index ≥ 24 cm or a single deepest pocket ≥ 8 cm"
"The major risk factor for shoulder dystocia is fetal macrosomia"
"What is the recommended treatment for a pregnant woman with antiphospholipid syndrome? Aspirin and LMW heparin"
"What is the typical prognosis for newborns with Erb-Duchenne or Klumpke palsy secondary to shoulder dystocia? Spontaneous resolution within 3 months (80%)"
"What is the next step in management for a pregnant woman at 38 weeks gestation with chorioamnionitis after administration of antibiotics? Fetal heart tracing reveals tachycardia but is otherwise reassuring. Induction of labor"
"What screening test is used to determine if an Rh(D)- pregnant woman has already alloimmunized? Antibody screen (indirect Coombs test)"
"Hyperemesis gravidarum is differentiated from typical vomiting of pregnancy by the presence of laboratory abnormalities, changes in volume status, and/or ketones on urinalysis"
"Hyperemesis gravidarum is more common in patients with multiple gestation, hydatidiform mole, or history of GERD"
"What is the initial management for a hemodynamically unstable pregnant patient that presents with abruptio placentae following a motor vehicle accident? IV fluid resuscitation and left lateral decubitus positioning"
"Gestational diabetes is a result of pancreatic β-cell hyperplasia and increased insulin resistance secondary to elevated levels of human placental lactogen during the third trimester of pregnancy"
"What is the underlying pathophysiology of hypotension after administration of epidural anesthesia? Vasodilation and venous pooling"
"Leakage of CSF after epidural placement may result in postural headaches, which are worse with sitting up and better with lying down"

"Maternal adaptations to pregnancy include a(n) increased cardiac output"
"What exercise regimen is recommended for healthy women with uncomplicated pregnancies? 20 - 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise on most or all days of the week"
"Systemic lupus erythematosus flare during pregnancy is distinguished from preeclampsia by the presence of RBC casts on urinalysis and classic symptoms of SLE (e.g. joint pain, malar rash)"
"Hypopituitarism may be caused by Sheehan syndrome, which is a pregnancy-related infarction of the pituitary gland"

"Ultrasound findings consistent with epithelial ovarian carcinoma include a solid mass with thick septations and the presence of ascites"

"Choriocarcinoma is a tumor with early, diffuse hematogenous spread, especially to the lungs"

"The size/tenderness of fibroadenomas and breast cysts increase with exposure to estrogen"

"Osteoporosis with palpable vertebral step-off and pinpoint tenderness = compression fracture::diagnosis?"

"The knee jerk reflex tests spinal nerves L2-L4"

"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with back pain after carrying heavy packages? Physical exam reveals paravertebral tenderness. (most common cause of acute back pain) Lumbosacral strain"

"What differentiates coma from persistent vegetative state? Coma has depressed cerebral function, Whereas persistent vegetative state has absent cerebral function"

"Sudden, stepwise decline in executive function with cardiovascular risk factors (HTN, smoking, diabetes) = vascular dementia"

"Ischemic stroke: An infarction of the central nervous system with resultant neurologic deficit that persists beyond 24 hours or is interrupted by death within 24 hours"
"HEMORRHAGIC STROKE: Central nervous system (CNS) damage secondary to intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage"
"What is the greatest non-modifiable risk factor for both ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke? Age"
"Ischemic strokes are generally classified as being of thrombotic or embolic origin"
"Strokes that affect the small branches (e.g. lenticulostriate) of the main arteries of the brain are termed lacunar infarcts or small-vessel strokes"
"Parkinson disease is characterized by degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the basal ganglia"

"What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in a lateral myocardial infarction? I, aVL::2"

"What is normal blood pressure for an adult? < 120/80 mmHg"
"What is the best initial therapy for hypertension? Lifestyle modifications Weight loss, Na restriction, exercise, dietary changes, smoking cessation"

"Stage 2 hypertension should be treated with two medications"
"In obstructive lung disease, the FEV1/FVC is decreased"

"Emphysema is characterized by the destruction of alveolar air sacs"

"Coronary artery disease is the most common cause of heart failure, which leads to reduced contractility, stroke volume, and therefore cardiac output"

"UMN and LMN::UMN/LMN/Both lesions present with weakness"

"Tabes dorsalis presents with decreased/absent deep tendon reflexes and brief, shooting/burning pain"
"How long do episodes of trigeminal neuralgia (tic douloureux) typically last? seconds up to a minute"
"Hypertensive intraparenchymal hemorrhage typically occurs in the basal ganglia (especially putamen) and the adjacent internal capsule; other common sites include the cerebellum, thalamus, and pons"

"Multiple sclerosis may present with transverse myelitis, which results in motor and sensory loss below the level of the lesion, often with autonomic (bladder and bowel) dysfunction"
"What CSF analysis finding is useful for diagnosis of multiple sclerosis? Oligoclonal bands of IgG"
"Normal pressure hydrocephalus often presents with a characteristic magnetic gait"

"Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is characterized by periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG"
"Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is a malignant, high-grade tumor of astrocytes::cell type"

"What is a worrisome sequelae of pseudotumor cerebri if left untreated? Blindness"
"Which movement disorder presents as a high-frequency tremor with sustained posture (e.g. outstretched arms), often with a family history of tremor? Essential tremor"
"Essential tremor is worsened with movement or when anxious (relieved or worsened)"
"Guillain-Barré syndrome is associated with increased CSF protein, normal CSF WBC, RBC, and glucose count"
"Cauda equina syndrome occurs due to compression of spinal nerve roots from L2 and below"
"Management of cauda equina syndrome involves emergent MRI::imaging and administration of glucocorticoids"
"Central retinal artery occlusion is most commonly caused by an embolized atherosclerotic plaque from the ipsilateral internal carotid artery"
"Wilson disease is characterized by decreased serum ceruloplasmin and increased urinary copper"
"Myasthenia gravis classically manifests as fatigable ocular (e.g. ptosis, diplopia) and bulbar (e.g. dysarthria) muscle weakness"
"What symptom is characteristic of early Alzheimer's disease? Short-term memory loss"
"What is the likely location of hemorrhage in a hypertensive patient that presents with occipital headache, neck stiffness, nausea/vomiting, and ipsilateral hemiataxia without hemiparesis? Cerebellum"
"The initial diagnostic workup of a first-time seizure in an adult should include laboratory tests to evaluate for metabolic and toxic causes"
"Which stroke subtype is characterized by abrupt neurological symptoms that are typically maximal at the start? Embolic ischemic stroke"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that presents with worsening focal back pain, especially at night, and bilateral lower extremity weakness/sensory loss, and gait ataxia for the past week? Spinal cord compression"
"Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration typically affects patients with extensive alcohol abuse and presents with progressive gait instability, truncal ataxia, difficulty with rapid alternating movements, hypotonia, and intention tremor"
"Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration is caused by damage to the Purkinje cells in the anterior cerebellar vermis"
"Manifestations of acute angle-closure glaucoma include unilateral eye pain with conjunctival injection and a(n) dilated::size, non-reactive pupil"
"Acute angle-closure glaucoma is characterized by sudden, painful vision loss with \halos\\" around lights\""
"What neurological pathology typically presents with nerve damage in two or more nerves in separate parts of the body in a patient with vasculitis? Mononeuritis multiplex"
"What is the first-line pharmacotherapy for tabes dorsalis? IV penicillin"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient that develops persistent headache, confusion, difficulty concentrating, and poor sleep for the past month after hitting their head? Post-concussive syndrome"

"(+) stress test and unstable angina is managed with cardiac catheterization::next step"
