"What complications following an acute MI produce a new holosystolic murmur? 1. Papillary muscle rupture (MR murmur at the apex) 2. Interventricular septum rupture (heard at the left sternal border, frequently has an accompanying thrill and step-up in oxygen)"
"One complication that may occur 3 - 14 days post-MI is ventricular free wall rupture, which causes cardiac tamponade"
"Cannon A Waves are caused by contraction of the right atrium against a closed tricuspid valve (AV block, PVC, Vtach) Cannon A Waves are distinguished from large A waves because large A waves occur every heart cycle::every heart cycle or intermittingly"
"Dressler syndrome is a(n) autoimmune phenomenon that results in fibrinous pericarditis following an MI (> 1 month)"
"What is the treatment of choice for Dressler's syndrome? NSAIDs"
"ECG changes associated with acute pericarditis include widespread, diffuse ST segment elevation and/or PR depression"
"Acute pericarditis commonly presents with sharp pain that is aggravated by inspiration and relieved by sitting up and leaning forward"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with sharp, localized chest pain that is worsened with inspiration and tender to palpation? Costochondritis"
"Young smoker with episodic chest pain worse at night + transient ST-segment elevation = Vasospastic (Prinzmetal) angina"
"Prinzmetal angina = nitrates::drug class or CCBs::drug class"
"2nd degree Mobitz type I (Wenckebach)::(aka) AV block is characterized by progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a beat is \dropped\\"\""
"Multiple P wave morphologies, irregular HR and associated with lung disease (e.g. COPD) = multifocal atrial tachycardia::arrhythmia"
"Wide QRS = ventricular::location rhythm Narrow QRS = atrial rhythm"
"> 3 consecutive premature ventricular beats (i.e. widened QRS) at a HR > 120 bpm Ventricular tachycardia::arrhythmia"
"Stable ventricular tachycardia is managed with amiodarone::treatment or lidocaine Unstable ventricular tachycardia is managed with cardioversion Pulseless ventricular tachycardia is managed with defibrillation"
"↓ PR interval and widened/slurred QRS (delta wave) = Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome::arrhythmia"
"Unstable WPW = cardioversion Stable WPW = Procainamide or ibutilide"
"Atrial flutter is most commonly caused by a re-entrant circuit around the tricuspid annulus"
"Atrial flutter is treated similarly to atrial fibrillation::rhythm"
"Stable atrial fibrillation is managed with rate > rhythm control::treatment Unstable atrial fibrillation is managed with cardioversion"
"Torsades::rhythm"
"What is the first-line therapy for conscious and stable patients with torsades de pointes? IV magnesium"
"ECG: regular and narrow complex tachycardia with rate > 150 Clinical: brief episodes of palpitations, dizziness, chest pain, dyspnea, syncope Supraventricular tachycardia::diagnosis"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a young patient with abrupt onset tachycardia and palpitations? Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT)"
"Vagal maneuvers (carotid sinus massage, cold-water immersion, Valsalva) increase parasympathetic tone at the AV node::location, which helps terminate supraventricular tachycardias"
"Low voltage ECG and electrical alternans is suggestive of pericardial effusion (cardiac tamponade)::condition"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with an aortic dissection that develops hypotension, JVD, and pulsus paradoxus? Cardiac tamponade"
"Atrial fibrillation (no p wave) = starts in LA (pulmomary vein)::LA/RA Atrial flutter (sawtooth) = starts in RA (tricuspid valve)::LA/RA"
"Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response in hemodynamically stable patients is managed with rate control"
"Hyperthyroidism may lead to atrial fibrillation::arrhythmia"
"Systolic ejection murmur cresc/decresc, louder w/ squatting, softer w/ valsalva. and parvus et parvus/tardus pulse aortic stenosis::murmur"
"What is the treatment for aortic stenosis? Valve replacement"
"What valvular defect is heard as a holosystolic murmur at the cardiac apex with radiation to the axilla? Mitral regurgitation"
"Continuous machine like murmur PDA::murmur Wide fixed and split S2 ASD"
"A delayed, rumbling late diastolic murmur is indicative of what pathology? Mitral stenosis"
"Patient presents with a blowing diastolic heart murmur with bounding pulses, widened pulse pressure, head bobbing, and eponym parade = aortic regurgitation"
"MCC of aortic regurgitation in: developing countries: rheumatic heart disease developed countries = bicuspid valve"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a wide pulse pressure and \pounding heart\\" sensation"
"What is the recommended anticoagulation for pulmonary embolism in a patient with severe renal insufficiency (GFR < 30 mL/min/1.73m2)? Unfractionated heparin followed by warfarin"
"Non-life-threatening PE is managed with anticoagulation (Xa inhibitor > heparin → warfarin)::treatment Life-threatening PE (e.g. RBBB, hypotension, syncope) is managed with tPA vs. thrombectomy::treatment"
"Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) is diagnosed with echocardiography::best test"
"Suspected pneumonia = X-ray::test"
"What is the treatment plan for acute decompensated heart failure? Lasix (furosemide) - most important intervention Morphine - limited evidence for use Nitrates Oxygen Position"
"What viral pathogens are most commonly associated with viral myocarditis? Coxsackie B Adenovirus"
"Pulmonary HTN is defined as a pulmonary arterial pressure greater than 25 mm Hg at rest"
"Chronic alcohol::substance or cocaine::substance abuse = dilated cardiomyopathy"
"What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with a recent URI that presents with CHF, dilated ventricles with diffuse hypokinesia, and low ejection fraction on echocardiogram? Dilated cardiomyopathy"
"Causes of restrictive cardiomyopathy include amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, post-radiation fibrosis, and hemochromatosis"
"Chronic hypertension = concentric::eccentric/concentric LV hypertrophy = diastolic::systolic/diastolic HF"
"Medications that have been shown to improve long-term survival in patients with LV systolic dysfunction include: 1. β-blockers 2. ACE inhibitors 3. ARBs 4. Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists 5. Hydralazine and nitrates in African American patients"
"Pneumonia::diagnosis"
"COPD::diagnosis"

"Thickened peritracheal stripe and splayed carina bifurcation left atrial enlargement (2/2 mitral stenosis) or cancer (2 diagnoses)"
"Suspected pleural effusion is managed with diagnostic thoracocentesis::next step"
"Most transudative pleural effusions are caused by: CHF::condition::most common cirrhosis::condition nephrotic syndrome::condition"
"Exudative effusion and glucose < 30 mg/dL = rheumatoid or empyema"
"Bloody exudative effusion = malignancy or PE"
"Exudative effusion and lymphocytosis = TB effusion::cause"

"Which type of parapneumonic effusion is characterized by the following values: pH < 7.2 Glucose < 60 mg/dl WBC > 50,000/mm3Gram stain/culture: negative Complicated Parapneumonic Effusion"
"Which type of parapneumonic effusion is characterized by the following values: pH < 7.2 Glucose < 60 mg/dl WBC > 50,000/mm3Gram stain/culture: positive Empyema"
"Exudative pleural effusions must meet one of Light's criteria, which are: Pleural protein/serum protein > 0.5 Pleural LDH/serum LDH > 0.6 or Pleural LDH 2/3 upper limit of normal serum LDH"
"Diagnosis? Pleural effusion"
"S1Q3T3 ECG abnormality = pulmonary emboli"
"Hampton's hump on CXR is suggestive of PE::condition"

"PE prophylaxis for patients with ↑ bleeding risk or recurrent DVTs is managed with IVC filter::treatment"
"Mechanical ventilation in patients with ARDS should use low::low/high tidal volumes and high::low/high PEEP"
"#1 cause of ARDS is sepsis"
"ARDS = ↔::↑↓↔ PCWP"
"FEV1/FVC < 70% = obstructive::obstructive/restrictive lung disease"
"Restrictive lung disease is characterized by an FEV1/FVC ratio > 70% of predicted"
"The diagnosis of asthma can be made in patients with normal or increased DLCO and a >12% increase in FEV1 following bronchodilator administration"
"Obstructive lung disease = ↓::↑↓↔ FVC and ↓↓::↑↓↔ FEV1"
"Restrictive lung disease = ↓::↑/↓/↔ FVC and ↓::↑/↓/↔ FEV1"
"↓ DLCO = emphysema::emphysema/asthma"
"COPD is the coexistence of chronic bronchitis and emphysema"
"Increased vascular markings and ↔ DLCO = chronic bronchitis::chronic bronchitis / emphysema"
"Patients with COPD who have resting PaO2 < 55 mmHg or SaO2 < 88% are candidates for long-term home O2 treatment"
"Patients with COPD and signs of right heart failure or hematocrit > 55% should be started on home oxygen if PaO2 < 59 mmHg or SaO2 < 89%"
"First line therapy in COPD = muscarinic blockers (tiotropium/ipratropium)::drug class"
"Antibiotics should be given to patients with COPD exacerbation if they have an increase in ≥ 2 of the following symptoms: dyspnea, cough, or sputum production (cardinal symptoms)"
"All patients with acute COPD exacerbation should receive inhaled bronchodilators and PO/IV corticosteroids"
"Best prognostic indicator of COPD = FEV1"
"Is smoking cessation associated with a mortality benefit in patients with COPD? Yes"
"Oxygen::Treatment is proven to prolong life in hypoxemic COPD patients (< 88%, 55 mmHg)"

"FEV1 ≤ 80%::% = moderate persistent asthma (+ LABA) FEV1 ≤ 60%::% = severe persistent asthma (+ oral steroid)"

"Francisella tularensis is a zoonotic bacteria that forms caseating granulomas with regional lymphadenopathy"

"What is the treatment of transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN)? Oxygen if needed, occasionally PPV (CPAP)"
"What is the difference in x-rays between transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) vs. respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)? TTN → wet & hyperexpanded lungs RDS → granular & underexpanded lungs"
"What is the clinical presentation of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)? Premature neonate delivered because of perinatal distress with grunting/respiratory distress"
"What is seen on X-ray for respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)? Hypoextended lungs, atelectasis; granular/ground-glass density"
"What is the main complication of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)? Persistent oxygen requirement → bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD)"
"Premature neonate with low lung volumes and granular/ground-glass pattern on chest X-ray? Respiratory distress syndrome::Diagnosis?"
"Premature neonate with perinatal distress; grunting/respiratory distress: Respiratory distress syndrome::Diagnosis?"
"What is the treatment for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS)? (2) Ventilation via CPAP/PEEP ET admin of artificial surfactant If respiratory insuffiencey persits, intubation may be needed"
"What is the pathophysiology of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)? Prematurity → underdeveloped lungs → inadequate surfactant → alveoli fail to open (\derecruitment\\") → poor oxygenation\""
"Inappropriately sized neonate with jitteriness and tremors? Hypoglycemia (<40-45 mg/dL)::Diagnosis?"
"What must be ruled out on follow-up with neontal hypoglycemia? Sepsis"
"What is the treatment of neonatal hypoglycemia? - Asymptomatic → oral feeds - Symptomatic → IV bolus 2 mL/kg of D10W - Persistent → IV infusion of D5 or D10W"
"What is the diagnosis for neontal hypoglycemia? Glucose <40 mg/dL"
"What is the clinical presentation of neontal hypoglycemia? (6) - (may be asymptomatic) - poor feeding- jitteriness - tremors - seizures - lethargy"
"What are the risk factors for neonatal hypoglycemia? (4) LGA SGA IDM IUGR"

"What is asthma? Reactive obstructive airway disease caused by inflammation and bronchoconstriction that results in ↑ resistance to airflow Immunologic pathology? It's allergc disease (Asthma, Allergy, Atopy) and is likewise IgE/Mast cell mediated"
"Rapid Diagnosis: Asthma Presentation: cough, wheezing, dyspnea; may also have tightness during acute attacks Physical exam: prolonged expiratory phase w/ potentially hyperinflated or hyperresonant chest (ominous sign)"
"If someone comes in with an acute onset of wheezing and dyspnea, what is the first step? SKIP the diagnosis and move directly to treatment"
"Best diagnostic modality for outpatient asthmatic patient? PFT Other, ways to diagnose asthma? Expected results? Eosinophilia on CBC or sputum sample Charcot-Leyden Crystals or Curschmann's spirals on sputum Allergen skin test for severe, refractory, or to assess triggers::Three other diagnostic tools"
"What to do for a patient with suspected asthma with a normal FEV1/FVC? Methacholine challenge test to provoke bronchoconstriction"
"Diagnostic (that is also treatment) for an acute asthma? Reverse asthma with bronchodilators (SABA)"
"General treatment concept for asthma as follows: 1. Bronchostriction → SABA/LABA and Leukotrienes + Theophylline 2. Inflammation → Inhaled/PO Corticosteroids 3. Stabilizing → Cromolyn/Nedocromil Of the previous three symptoms, asthma treatment should be focused mainly on which one? Controlling bronchoconstriction and inflammation"
"Asthma classification and treatment: 1. SABA 2. SABA + ICS 3. SABA + ICS + LABA 4. SABA + ↑ICS + LABA 5. SABA + ↑↑ICS + LABA + Oral steroids"
"Examples of the following asthma medications: - SABA: albuterol, xopenex (Levalbuterol) - ICS: fluticasone, budesonide, beclomethasone - ICS/LABA: fluticasone/salmeterol (Advair), budesonide/formoterol (Symbicort) - Leukotriene antagonists: montelukast, zafirlukast - Anticholinergic/SABA: ipratropium/abuterol (DuoNeb) - Anticholinergic/LABA: tiotropium/olodaterol (Stiolto)"
"What to keep in mind before adding new asthma medications? Make sure they're using inhalers properly and w/ proper adherence; use spacers if need be"
"What to prescribe for exercised-induced asthma with known triggers? IgE/Histamine stabilizers (Nedocromil or Cromolyn Sulfate) Can be used immediately before known exposure"
"What is the workup for an acute exacerbation of asthma? (4) Peak expiratory flow rates (PEFR) Physical exam ABG CXR: to r/o other causes of dyspnea; not helpful for asthma"
"ED/inpatient treatment for acute asthma exacerbation: 1. O2 2. Albuterol/Ipratropium nebs 3. Methylprednisolone IV → Prednisone PO (corticosteroids) -If no improvement w/in 3 hours of continuous nebs → ICU -If better (100% improvement & symptom free) → discharge -Anywhere in between, admission → albuterol and ipratropium q4hrs w/ ongoing oral/IV steroids"
"Recommended screening for asymptomatic bacteriuria with a urine culture in pregnant women should be done at what weeks' gestation: 12 to 16 weeks"
"At what age do you start screening for high blood pressure: 18-years-old"
"What is needed to confirm diagnosis of high blood pressure: Measurements outside of the clinical setting::assume you have clinical measurements"
"Primary care providers should screen women who have family members with, breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer; for they might have what potentially harmful mutation(s): BRCA1 or BRCA2"
"Women who are at increased risk for breast cancer and low risk for adverse medication effects should receive: Tamoxifen or raloxifene"
"Recommended screening mammography for women should be done: Every 2 years"
"At what age should women start receiving mammograms: 50-years-old"
"Breastfeeding interventions should be done when: During pregnancy and after birth"
"What hemoglobinopathy is screened as a newborn: Sickle cell disease"
"Patients who are overweight or obese and have additional cardiovascular disease risk factors should be educated on: Healthy diet and exercise"
"Screening for gonorrhea in sexually active women starts at what age or younger? 25-years-old"
"Prophylactic ocular topical medication for all newborns for the prevention of: Gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum"
"Asymptomatic pregnant women should be tested for gestational diabetes mellitus after what week of gestation: 24 weeks"
"When should women take daily supplement of folic acid (range): If they are capable of becoming pregnant, then they need to supplement"
"What type of interventions are recommended to prevent falls in community-dwelling adults 65 years or older who are at increased risk of falling: Exercise/PT"
"At what age range would you screen overweight or obese patients for diabetes: 40- to 70-years-old"
"Patients with abnormal blood glucose levels receive counseling on: Healthy diet and physical activity"
"At what age do you start screening for major depressive disorder (MDD) in adolescents: 12-years-old"
"Should you be screening the general adult population, including pregnant and postpartum women for depression? Yes, please do"
"The USPSTF recommends that primary care clinicians prescribe oral fluoride supplementation starting at age 6 months for children whose water supply is deficient in fluoride"
"Colorectal cancer screenings start at what age: 45-years-old"
"Chlamydia screenings should be done on sexually active women age: 24 years or younger"
"For women aged 21-29, how often should they receive cervical cancer screenings: Every 3 years"
"Women aged 21-29 should receive what type of cervical cancer screening: Cervical cytology only::Cytology only/HPV only/Both"
"How often should women aged 30-65 receive cervical cancer screenings that is cytology only: Every 3 years"
"How often should women aged 30-65 at high risk for HPV receive cervical cancer screenings that is hrHPV testing alone: Every 5 years"
"How often should women aged 30-65 receive cervical cancer screenings that cotest hrHPV testing and cytology: Every 5 years"
"At what age should women start receiving cervical cancer screenings: 21-years-old"
"What does the seborrheic dermatitis look like? Think of this as \super-dandruff\\". Dandruff is flaking of the scalp Etiology? Fungal infection causing inflammatory reaction in areas rich in sebaceous glands Most common locations? Generally hair"
"Treatment for sebborheic dermatitis? Selenium shampoo 2nd line? topical steroids if no decrease in inflammation Low-yield test associations? HIV, cradle cap (infants), and Parkinson's disease"
"Pathophysiology of psoriasis? Autoimmune disease causing proliferation of keratinocytes w/ excessive accumulation of the stratum corneum. D/t dysregulation of T-Helper cells"
"Psoriasis imaging? Symmetric, well-demarcated silvery scales that bleed when picked"
"Where can psoriasis be commonly found? Scalp Gluteal folds Elbows Knees"
"Common complication of psoriasis? Nail pitting and onycholysis (detachment of the nailbed) are common"
"Psoriasis and joint pain is suggestive of psoriatic arthritis::diagnosis?"
"Treatment for psoriasis? 1st line (mild): topical corticosteroids and/or topical Vit D analog (mod to severe): UV light (sunlight or artificial exposure) / narrow-band UVB methotrexate/apremilast/biologic agent/oral retinoid Flares: topical steroids Additional management? MAY have the need to biopsy to r/o lymphoma if the dx is in question (such as if patient has any history of lymphoma)"
"What does the Pityriasis Rosea look like? Begins with flat, oval, salmon-colored macule called the herald patch Progresses to several salmon-colored scaling lesions with a trailing scale (the scale does not reach the border of the salmon-colored lesion)"
"Pityriasis rosea will always spare this body part: Palms and soles"
"Treatment for Pityriasis Rosea? A benign and self-limiting condition that resolves on its own (~6 weeks) Etiology? Unknown what causes it"
"Pityriasis rosea can be the initial presentation of what disease? Syphilis Involvement of this body part will greatly increase its chances? Involvement of the hands and soles"
"What does the lichen planus look like? Symptoms? Intensely pruritic pink or purple flat topped papules w/ a reticulated network of fine white lines Where is it usually found? Wrists, ankles, but may involve the trunk, oral mucosa, or vaginal mucosa Etiology? Inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology"
"Treatment for lichen planus? Topical steroids are the mainstay of therapy (but should be continued long-term) + UV light is used as an adjunct (as opposed to psoriasis where it's more effective)"
"What drugs are associated with the lichenoid drug eruption (drug-induced lichen planus)? ACE-i Thiazides Furosemide β-blockers::4"
"Five P's of lichen planus: Pruritic Planar (flat top) Polyangular Purple papules"
"Common disease in men. Top of the head (the crown) begins to thin - eventually hair loss predominates. Dx? Androgenic Alopecia (male pattern baldness) - largely cosmetic disease Pathology? 5-DHT is implicated"
"Initial therapy for male pattern baldness? Minoxidil topically, and finasteride orally Treatment for women? Women: OCP's (suppress ovarian production of hormones) and spironolactone"
"What is alopecia areata? Autoimmune disorder against hair follicles What does it look like? Creates a well-defined circular bald spot"
"Treatment for alopecia areata? Steroids - topical, intralesional, and systemic depending on severity"
"Circular bald spot with all hairs at equal length: Dx? Tinea capitis - superficial fungal infection caused by Trichophyton tonsurans Etiology? KOH prep must be ordered to visualize the diagnosis Diagnostics? Trichophyton doesn't fluoresce under Wood's Lamp"
"Treatment for tinea capitis? Oral Griseofulvin (note: NOT topical) Complication? Failure to treat will result in permanent hair loss"
"Patient compulsively pulls out hair one stand at a time. Dx? Trichotillomania - psychiatric disease This dx is highly associated with? High association with anxiety disorders (PTSD, OCD, MDD); commonly women"
"How to distinguish trichotillomania w/ other diseases? Pathy alopecia with hair regrowth at different lengths since the pt pulls out hairs at different time frames Diagnostics? Diagnosis is made by shaving a \window\\" at her scalp and assessing equal hair growth within the window; the regrowing hair is too short to be plucked"
"Treatment for trichotillomania? Treat the compulsion; refer to psychiatry"
"Disease mostly arising from extreme braiding? Traction alopecia - permanent scarring resulting in permanent alopecia that's secondary to keeping the hair pulled tightly Treatment? Irreversible once it occurs"
"Terminology when chemo disrupts growth, producing thin fragile hairs that shed with light touch, effectively skipping from anagen to exogen: Anagen-effluvium"
"Thinning the hair as the hair follicles exit growth phase too early: Telogen-effluvium::Diagnosis?"
"Pemphigus Vulgaris Cause: autoimmune on desmoglein (found between the epithelial cells) Sx: Positive (Blisters are thin, tear easily::Positive/Negative Nikolsky Dx +Bx: Tombstone effect on bx; immuno will show Abs on epithelial cells throughout the skin lesion Tx: Systemic steroids followed by myco mofetil or rituximab Epidemiology: ages 30-50"
"Bullous Pemphigoid Causes: Autoimmune, hemidesmosomes that attach the BM cells to the BM Sx: Negative::Positive/Negative Nikolsky Dx and Bx: Intact epithelium on bx with immunoflu showing Abs at the dermal-epidermal junction Tx: Steroids during acute attacks"
"Dermatitis Herpetiformis Causes: IgA Abs on transglutaminase Sx: Extensor surfaces of the body for a pruritic vesicular eruption Dx and Bx: Anti-endomysial Abs or anti-transglutaminase Abs; neutrophil abscess Tx: Remove gluten from the diet"
"Porphyria Cutanea Tarda Causes: OCPs, EtOH, Hep C, and Hemochromatosis → due to deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase Dx: Coral red urine in Wood's lamp; bullae on sun-exposed areas Tx: Avoid the sun"
"Pneumonia::Atelectasis or pneumonia presents with productive cough and pleuritic chest pain"
"What valvular change commonly occurs as a late complication of rheumatic fever? Mitral stenosis"
"Graded exercise therapy decreases mortality in patients with PAD F::T/F"
"Which of the following medications is the most appropriate for management of peripheral arterial disease (PAD)? Clopidogrel::Cilostazol/Clopidogrel"
"What common conditions are associated with primary biliary cholangitis? Autoimmune conditions"
"Cutaneous xanthomas can occur in the setting of primary biliary cholangitis T::T/F"
"In an elderly patient without overt signs of bleeding, occult chronic GI bleeding is the most likely cause of iron deficiency anemia and a diagnostic colonoscopy should be performed"
"Pseudomembranous colitis::Diverticulosis or pseudomembranous colitis presents with fever and foul-smelling, watery diarrhea"
"Brain abscesses smaller than 2.5 cm and those with no signs of ICP are managed with empiric antibiotics for bacterial brain abscess"
"Brain abscesses larger than 2.5 cm or those with signs of increased ICP are managed with biopsy and surgical drainage"
"IFN-α is contraindicated among patients with autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus"
"What is the treatment for pregnancy luteomas? Observation only"
"What is the most appropriate next step in management in a < 60 yo pt who presents w/ dyspepsia w/o sxs of GERD, NSAID use, or alarm sxs of malignancy or PUD? Urea breath test"

"What is the most appropriate recommendation for a teenager w/ appropriately-controlled T1DM who wants to enagage in school sports (physical activity)? Lower insulin dosage on days of exercise"
"Abdominal pain, HTN, generalized fatigue and increase in creatinine within 6 months of renal transplantation = acute rejection of the renal allograft::transplant rejection type?"
"Graft-versus-host disease is mediated via recipient T-cells in the graft F::T/F"
"Which two statins have the lowest risk of statin-associated myopathy? Pravastatin Fluvastatin"

"Dyspareunia and pruritus in a postmenopausal woman with a white vulvar plaque on pelvic examination indicates a diagnosis of lichen sclerosus"
"What are the XR findings in transient synovitis? Normal"

"On ultrasound, pancreatic abscesses are complex cystic fluid collections"
"Is anxiety disorder associated with specific phobias? No"
"Is anxiety disorder associated with MDD? Yes"
"Insufficient mechanical hemostasis due to a slipped suture or tie is one of the main causes of hemorrhage <24 hours following surgery"
"Erosion of blood vessels due to a surgical site infection results in hemorrhage 7–14 days following surgery"
"Which nonselective β-blocker is contraindicated in asthmatics? Propranolol"
"Propranolol::Drug may be given after RAI (radioactive iodine) ablation to control the possible worsening of symptoms due to the release of preformed thyroid hormones into circulation"
"What alternative therapy can be used in rapid symptomatic control of hyperthyroidism in patients with asthma? Oral CCBs"

"What three mechanisms explain hyperestrogenism in the setting of cirrhosis? (3) Increased peripheral conversion of androgens→ estrogens Decreased hepatic breakdown of estrogen Increased amounts of sex-hormone-binding globulin → increased binding (inactivation) of free testosterone"
"A PPD skin test is not routinely recommended as part of prenatal care T::T/F"
"Feminization can occur in the setting of a Leydig cell tumor T::T/F"

"CURB-65 score ≤ 1 is managed with outpatient treatment indicated::interpretation"

"What is the mechanism for decreased bone mineral density in patients with Cushing syndrome? High levels of cortisol inhibits calcitriol synthesis"
"What is the most common cause of Cushing syndrome? Prolonged glucocorticoid therapy"
"Orbital cellulitis is most commonly caused by bacterial spread from ethmoidal or maxillary sinusitis"
"Blepharitis may present with crusting of the eyelashes, thickened eyelid margins, and a history of waking with eyelashes stuck together"

"CURB-65 score ≥ 2 = hospitalization is indicated::interpretation"
"What is the pathophysiology of reactive amyloidosis (secondary amyloidosis)? Chronic inflammatory process → increased production of acute phase reactant SAA → deposition of AA protein in various organs"

"Egg protein allergy is a contraindication when administering the influenza vaccine F::T/F"
"Uncontrolled seizure disorder is a relative contraindication for administering DTaP to a 15-month old boy"
"What is the pathophysiology of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) in setting of obesity? Adipokines released from fat depots decrease insulin sensitivity of peripheral tissue → hyperinsulinemia (peripheral insulin resistance) → triggers lipid uptake and lipogenesis within hepatocytes"
"NASH is a diagnosis of exclusion T::T/F"
"What is the most appropriate and confirmatory diagnostic step for suspected primary adrenal insufficiency? Cosyntropin or ACTH stimulation test"

"What are the four perfusion-related causes of prerenal AKI? Hypovolemia (bleed, cirrhosis, nephrosis) Hypotension (sepsis, CHF) Renovascular (NSAIDs, renal artery stenosis, fibromuscular dysplasia) Large vessel (thrombosis, dissection)"
"Postrenal AKI: Pathology: caused by obstruction to outflow at any level → ureters have to be blocked bilat whether old man w/ BPH or gout (uric acid crystal deposition) Diagnostics: sonogram to look for residual urine & hydroureter/hydronephrosis Treatment: stent obstruction or remove it"
"Postrenal AKI causes: Bladder (BPH, cancer, neurogenic bladder) Urethral/uretral (stone, cancer) Crystals in tubule (oxalate, urate)"
"Pt has muddy brown casts on U/A, high Cr despite normal urine output .Now his Cr continues to rise, but his urine output is next to nothing: Acute tubular necrosis::Diagnosis?"
"Pt has pre-existing renal damage but needs contrast for a study, what are the next best steps? (3) Vigorous fluids Prophylatic N-Acetyl-Cysteine Hold ACE/ARBs & diuretics"
"ATN causes: Prolonged ischemia Toxins (drugs, myoglobin, Ig) Contrast induced"
"AIN causes: Allergic reactions (NSAIDs, Bactrim, Lactams (cephalo's & PCN) → eosinophilia will be present Infxn (pyelo) Infiltrative (sarcoid, amyloid, multiple myeloma)"
"Pt has muddy brown casts on U/A, high Cr despite normal urine output. Now his Cr continues to rise, but his urine output is next to nothing. His U/A shows blood, but no RBC: Myoglobin nephritis::Diagnosis? NaHCO3, IVF::Treatment?"
"Pt w/ RBC casts on U/A: Glomerulonephritis::Diagnosis?"
"A postviral patient who develops RBC casts: IgA nephropathy glomerulonephritis::Diagnosis?"
"Pt who had pharyngitis and impetigo a little bit ago now has RBC casts: Post-Streptococcal glomerulonephritis::Diagnosis?"
"Pt who skin rash on face w/ RBC casts: Lupus glomerulonephritis::Diagnosis?"
"Pt with sinus, lung and kidney issues w/ RBC casts: Wegener's glomerulonephritis::Diagnosis?"
"Patient with hemoptysis and hematuria: Goodpasture's glomerulonephritis::Diagnosis?"
"Pt w/ asthma develops hematuria: Churg-Strauss glomerulonephritis::Diagnosis?"
"Pt who had a cold a little bit ago now has abd pain, palpable purpura and RBC casts: HSP glomerulonephritis::Diagnosis?"
"What is the clinical definition of CKD? Elevated Cr with > 3 months of reduced GFR (< 60mL/hr or Cr~2)"
"Stages of CKD I - Normal/High: GFR > 90 II - Mild: GFR 60-89 III - Moderate: GFR 30-59 IV - Severe: GFR 15-29 V - Kidney failure: GFR < 15"
"Treatment regimens for patients with CKD: - BP control <130/<80 = give ACE-i - BG 80-110: give insulin - HTN & electrolytes: have diet w/ low Na+/K+ - Hgb b/w 11-12: give EPO + Iron - Give  Ca2+ + Vit D to avoid secondary hyperparathyroidism"
"Hypertension and microalbuminuria resistant to ACE inhibitors can be managed with additional calcium channel blockers"
"Suspected acute megacolon and cecal dilation to <12 cm may be treated with NG tube and rectal tube insertion::2"
"Suspected acute megacolon and cecal dilation to >12 cm or signs of ischemia may be treated with laparotomy"
"NSAIDs or acetaminophen::2 are the first-line abortive treatment for children with migraine"
"Can clozapine be prescribed during pregnancy? Yes"
"Tumors located near the esophagogastric junction can be classified according to the Siewart classification"
"Perforated viscus may present with Rigler sign (double-wall sign), in which gas outlines the inner and outer surfaces of the intestine"
"Chronic or severe liver disease can cause respiratory alkalosis::acid/base abnormality"

"What is the first-line treatment for symptomatic supraventricular premature beats (e.g. APBs, junctional) Reduce potential triggers like caffeine, EtOH, smoking"
"What is first-line treatment options for nonpurulent cellulitis w/ systemic signs of infection? (2) Nafcillin or cefazolin"
"Does cellulitis have defined margins? No"
"Pathogen for purulent cellulitis = S. aureus Pathogen for nonpurulent cellulitis = Strep. pyogenes"
"The next best test following a pulmonary nodule found on X-ray with possible growth is Chest CT"
"In ESRD, calciphylaxis is associated with increased levels of phosphate and PTH"
"In Guillain-Barré syndrome, elective intubation is given for patients with: - Decline in FVC >20mL/kg - Respiratory distress - Severe dysautonomia - Widened pulse pressure"
"Cholinergic::Sympathetic or Cholinergic receptors are found on the dome of the bladder, but not known to be present on the ureter"
"What other condition often coexists with polymyalgia rheumatica? Giant cell arteritis"

"Infective endocarditis in prosthetic valves is much harder to treat than in native valves T::T/F"

"Holosystolic murmur that increases on inspiration = tricuspid regurgitation"
"What are the drugs of choice to lower BP in severe preeclampsia (maternal hypertensive crisis > 160/110)? 1. IV Hydralazine 2. IV Labetalol 3. PO Nifedipine"
"Adolescent major depression may present with irritability rather than depressed mood"
"Methemoglobinemia will present with pulse oximetry readings of ~85% regardless of the true oxygen saturation level"
"Methemoglobinemia is a blood pathology that presents with saturation gap and a(n) normal PaO2"
"Patients with left-sided endocarditis are at an increased risk of pulmonary embolism F::T/F"

"MCC of acute bacterial endocarditis? S. aureus"
"S. sanguinis belongs to what bacterial group? Viridans streptococci"
"MCC of subacute endocarditis in damaged native valves? Viridans streptococci"
"What is first-line therapy for HACEK organisms? 3rd or 4th generation IV cephalosporin"
"First-line therapy for HACEK organisms is IV ampicillin F::T/F"
"Bibasilar crackles, S3 gallop, displaced point of maximum impulse and lower extremity edema is suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy::diagnosis?"
"Can obstructive sleep apnea cause hypertension? Yes; hypercapnia causes an increased sympathetic response"
"Is a HbA1c of < 7% an indication of well-controlled diabetes? Yes::Yes/No"
"When is medical therapy for symptomatic atrial premature beats (APBs) considered? After a trial of trigger avoidance (e.g. caffeine, EtOH, stress, smoking)"
"What is the treatment for a patient with asymptomatic atrial premature beats (APBs) at the time of ECG recording? Reassurance"
"Vasospastic angina = transient ST elevation::ECG finding"
"Abdominal bloating, food aversion, weight loss and abdominal pain/nausea following meals is suggestive of intestinal ischemia::diagnosis?"
"What AV Block is depicated in each of the leads? Top: Mobitz type I/Wenckebach Middle: Mobitz type II (2:1 block) Bottom: Mobitz type II (3:1 block)"
"How do you calculate LDL? LDL (mg/dL) = total cholesterol – HDL – (triglycerides/5)"
"What is the most important risk factor for peripheral arterial disease (PAD)? Smoking"
"Stage III peripheral arterial disease (PAD) = ischemic pain at rest"
"Pulmonary embolism is characterized by increased RA pressure, increased pulmonary artery pressure, and normal PCWP"
"Bilateral wheezing can occur in acute PE due to cytokine-induced bronchoconstriction in response to hypoxia and infarction"
"In a pregnant woman at 37 weeks gestation, continuous vaginal leakage of clear fluid for the past 2 days indicates rupture of membranes duration 48 hours"
"What is the most common cause of chronic aortic regurgitation in a young patient? Congenital bicuspid valve"
"In developed countries, myxomatous valve degeneration is the most common cause of mitral valve degeneration and subsequent mitral valve prolapse"

"What is the most common cause of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF)? Chronic uncontrolled hypertension"
"Elevated BNP = S3::S3/S4"
"Assessing hepatojugular reflux can help distinguish cardiac disease from hepatic disease in a patient presenting with bilateral lower extremity edema and ascites"
"Women < 50 years of age with atypical angina have a low pretest probability (< 10 %) of coronary artery disease (CAD) T::T/F"
"Stable angina = usually ST depression::ECG finding"
"Aspirin therapy reduces the frequency of unstable anginal episodes F::T/F"
"Can CCBs reduce anginal episodes in patients with stable ischemic heart disease? Yes!"
"What is first-line therapy for the treatment of stable angina? β-blockers"
"What is the mechanism by which β-blockers are able to relieve anginal pain? Decrease HR and contractility → reduces myocardial oxygen demand"
"Rheumatic fever = late mitral stenosis::mitral stenosis/mitral regurgitation"
"Causes of syncope: VV: Vasovagal O: Orthostatics M: Mechanical cardiac A: Arrhythmia N: Neuro P: PE E: Electrolytes"
"Why isn't antimicrobial prophylaxis, fluid support, or debridement necessary for 1st-degree burns? Keratin barrier remains intact (retaining fluid and barring microbial entry)"
"The presence of proteinuria in the setting of SLE should raise concern for lupus nephritis and requires that a(n) renal biopsy be performed"
"Why is the diagnosis of lupus nephritis important to make in the setting of SLE? Severity of the disease dictates treatment"

"HOCM::HOCM/Long QT syndrome is more common"

"Treatment for allergic conjunctivitis? Cold compress::Warm/Cold compress"
"Symptoms of spontaneous episodic hypoglycemia that resolve with glucose administration or rest should raise concern for the Whipple triad"
"If hypoglycemia is not present at the time of evaluation, a(n) 72-hour fasting test is indicated"
